title: Award Is Upheld Over Pregnancy
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court has upheld a jury's awarding of damages to a woman who gave birth to a daughter after sterilization surgery from her doctor, including the cost of raising the child.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE Defense Language Institute, once considered a pioneer in the teaching of foreign languages, has been reviewed by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, and found deficient in management, priorities and performance. It has, the report said, spent 159 man-years and $4.2 million on efforts to improve the quality of its courses without producing the necessary basic teaching materials. According to testimony taken, ''staffing priorities were so erratic that realistic planning was meaningless.''

title: TWO WHO LED THE PUSH TO BEAT F.T.C. ON CARS
description: Frank E. McCarthy, executive vice president of the National Automobile Dealers Association, and H. Thomas Greene, its director of legislation, had a chance to relax after Congress defeated a proposed Federal Trade Commission rule that would have required dealers to disclose major defects and car warranties.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error in an ar- ticle on the yacht Sea Cloud that ap- peared in the Travel section Sunday, a quotation from ''Two Years Before the Mast'' by Richard Henry Dana was changed slightly and incorpo- rated into the article without attribu- tion.

title: BRITISH TROOPS REPORTED BATTLING ARGENTINES 15 MILES FROM STANLEY
description: Paratroops and Royal Marines have battled to within 15 miles of Stanley, the main Argentine stronghold on the Falkland Islands, the Defense Ministry indicated tonight.

title: THE CATERPILLAR WARS
description: In the spring of 1982, an uneasiness grips New York's suburbs as the populace braces for an onslaught of voracious gypsy moth caterpillars.

title: 270 SENATE AIDES MAKE $50,000
description: Salaries of more than $50,000 a year are paid to 270 Senate staff members, whose jobs essentially are to keep their elected bosses informed, records show.

title: WOLF TRAP TURNS INTO A VERY IMPORTANT CHARITY
description: President Reagan started it when he called Kay Shouse. ''The show must go on,'' said Mr. Reagan the day after an April fire destroyed the performing arts center at Wolf Trap Farm Park in suburban Virginia.

title: BONES OF OLDEST KNOWN PRIMATE FOUND IN WYOMING
description: FOSSIL hunters led by a Johns Hopkins University paleontologist have discovered foot bones of what they report is the oldest known true primate. The fossils, extracted from 50-million-year-old rocks in Wyoming, provide clear evidence of the earliest animal with a grasping big toe, considered by primatologists a definitive feature in the early evolution of modern primates, which include monkeys, apes and humans.

title: Unworthy Pension Grabs
description: Flying in the face of fiscal strains, New York State's Pension Commission urges a reckless 3 percent wage increase for 300,000 state and local workers hired in the past six years. It would excuse them from the pension contributions required since New York City's fiscal crisis in 1976. That would cost governments $168 million immediately, and more with every year.

title: POLL SHOWS COST OF SUCCESS
description: Women who are executives in some of America's largest corporations are well paid and enjoy their affluence, but most feel that to achieve their successes they have had to sacrifice relationships such as marriages and families as well as pleasures like travel, cultural activities and leisure time.

title: Hockey Talks Begin
description: Overshadowed by the spotlight that has accompanied the threat of a strike against professional football, hockey players and representatives of the club owners have gathered in West Palm Beach, Fla., for talks that begin today and that could prove critical to the start of the 1982-83 season. John Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, said yesterday: ''The history of our negotiations with the players indicates that neither side is looking to win when it sits down at the bargaining table.

title: Chinese Export Duties
description: China will introduce export duties of up to 60 percent on certain raw materials beginning Tuesday, the New China News Agency has announced. The new tariffs will affect goods including coal, pig iron, rice, soybeans and sugar.

title: CAREY ENHANCING HOUSING ROLE OF TOP AIDE
description: As Governor Carey enters his last six months in office, he and members of his administration have been taking many steps that are likely to influence the state government for years.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S REMARKS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's Memorial Day address yesterday at Arlington National Cemetery in Arlington, Va., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:

title: PROSPECTS DIMMING FOR COAL PROJECTS
description: When exports of American coal soared three years ago, the huge coal loading facilities of Norfolk, Va., quickly clogged, and ships backed up for miles.

title: Bees That Thrive on DDT
description: A team of Brazilian and American scientists has reported that bees of the species Eufriesia purpurata collect the insecticide DDT but suffer no apparent harm.

title: THEATER ATTENDANCE DOWN, BUT BROADWAY INCOME RISES
description: While ticket sales for the 1981-82 Broadway theater season that ended yesterday reached an all-time high of $222 million, attendance declined for the first time in eight years.

title: The U.N. Today; June 1, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Science and Tech- nology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. DISARMAMENT COMMISSION

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Why Me? By Rose Kushner. 411 pages. Paperback. W.@B. Saunders Company, Philadelphia. $7.95. A Woman's Choice By Mary Spletter. 215 pages. Beacon Press, Boston. $14.50. ''Why Me?'' is a spirited, compelling and extremely informative book by a leading advocate of better treatment for breast cancer patients. It is also the story of how such treatment has changed since 1974, when Rose Kushner, a science writer, discovered a lump in her breast and had to fight to win a say in decisions about her care.

title: Aramco Production
description: The giant Arabian American Oil Company said today its crude oil production in Saudi Arabia last year was unchanged from 1980, at 9.6 million barrels a day.

title: FEW ISSUES SCHEDULED THIS WEEK
description: In this holiday-shortened week, investment bankers have scheduled only about $675 million of new notes and bonds for public sale. Last week $1.5 billion of new issues were offered, according to Moody's Investors Service. Analysts said the reception was generally good for last week's issues, adding that more companies could come to market this week if prices are stable or higher.

title: Market Place; Views Vary On Akzona
description: AKZONA INC. has dipped its fibrous pen in red ink, raising fears that directors may trim or omit the dividend at a meeting tomorrow. Akzona's problems grew with its appearance on a list, published last week by Standard & Poor's, of 39 stocks to avoid. The service, in its Outlook report, spoke of the ''soft market'' for synthetic fibers that has hurt Akzona's American Enka division. Setbacks in the fiber division added to companywide losses in the first quarter.

title: NURSING HOME OPERATOR ON TRIAL FOR KIDNAPPING
description: Lucille Walker, a nursing home operator accused of taking three elderly women from her facility in Miami and abandoning them in a Detroit suburb last summer, is on trial in Oakland County Circuit Court, charged with kidnapping.

title: Lakers Team Up for Success
description: When the Houston Rockets beat the defending champion Los Angeles Lakers in the first round of the National Basketball Association playoffs last spring, it was the most staggering upset of the season, and Norm Nixon and Magic Johnson, the Laker guards, received much of the blame.

title: MRS. LLOYD REACHES SEMIFINAL
description: Though she was never seriously in trouble, Chris Evert Lloyd had to earn a few points for a change in the French Open tennis tournament today. She defeated Lucia Romanov, 6-2, 6-4, and gained the semifinals against Andrea Jaeger, who eliminated Virginia Ruzici, 6-1, 6-0.

title: BUFFLED, BAFFLED, BUFFALOED
description: To the Editor:

title: Transcript of speech, page A14.
description: President Reagan announced today that the United States and the Soviet Union would open negotiations June 29 in Geneva on the ''limitation and reduction'' of strategic nuclear arms.

title: AFRIKANERS ASSAIL PREMIER'S POLICIES
description: Years ago a prime minister from the National Party who ventured into an Afrikaner farming community like this one could take it for granted that he was at the solid base of his support. But when Prime Minister P.W. Botha arrived here tonight to test the climate for a new set of constitutional proposals, he was here on sufferance.

title: TRAVEL AGENTS FEARFUL ON DEREGULATION MOVE
description: Andy J. Spielman, vice president of the Waters Travel Service, which has operated here since the 1930's, has watched the travel agency business grow to become what he describes as ''the best system in the world.''

title: FORMER CHEVRON OFFICER WILL LEAD GEOPHYSICAL
description: N. Allen Riley thought he had left the oil business behind him in late 1980 when he retired from running the Chevron Oil Field Research Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California. Today, however, he finds himself taking charge of a company that he said had ''the competitive edge'' necessary to survive in the depressed oil services industry.

title: CONFESSIONS, AND TIPS, OF A POLITICAL HUMORIST
description: What the world of politics needs now, says Bob Orben, is a better sense of humor. A onetime comedy writer for Red Skelton, Jack Paar, Dick Gregory and Red Buttons, Mr. Orben got involved in politics while serving as a consultant and later chief speechwriter for President Ford. Now a freelance comedy writer here, he advises business executives and politicians on ways to add humor to their speeches.

title: ARGENTINE PAPERS REPORT SHIP RAID
description: A day after reports of the bombardment of the 16,000-ton British aircraft carrier Invincible began to circulate, Argentina's newspapers were reporting the assault as determinedly as the military high command was avoiding either directly confirming or denying it.

title: Wheat Crop Damaged In India's North
description: A combination of drought and an unusual wet spell has severely damaged northern India's wheat crop and a leading economist said today that the Government was considering wheat imports to make up for the losses.

title: SALVADOR KILLING IS SAID TO INCREASE
description: The four bodies lay in the craggy crevice, among the tropical vines, shattered glass and other debris. They had apparently been thrown from a ledge about 100 feet above.

title: CARTER PROMOTES BOOK AND CHARMS THE SELLERS
description: Former President Jimmy Carter charmed an overflow crowd of booksellers here this morning, regaling them with stories about the difficulties involved in writing his memoirs and sharing some of the sadness he felt at the death of Anwar el-Sadat, the Egyptian leader whom he described as ''the greatest man I ever met.'' At a later news conference Mr. Carter revealed that he had ordered increased security for Mr. Sadat at Camp David because he felt he might be ''in danger from the Egyptian delegation.''

title: Robbery Suspects Held Without Bail
description: Three Brooklyn men who the police suspect may have been involved in two Long Island robberies late Friday night and early Saturday - including one at a restaurant in which one customer was raped and two others were shot - were ordered held without bail yesterday after they pleaded not guilty to charges arising from a Brooklyn holdup Friday night.

title: Topics; Conquering the Past; A Pope at Canterbury
description: ''Civilization,'' an English writer said, ''is the thickness of a postage stamp on Cleopatra's Needle.'' So, perhaps, is the passage of time to the world's religions: the 400-year schism between the Roman Catholic Church and the Church of England may have lasted only the length of a few deep breaths.

title: THE STAGE: 'AMADEUS' WITH AMERICAN PRINCIPALS
description: WITH the arrival of Frank Langella and Dennis Boutsikaris in the roles of Antonio Salieri and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, ''Amadeus'' has gained its first American leads since it arrived at the Broadhurst 18 months ago. Is there any reason why Peter Shaffer's metaphysical thriller cannot be performed by our own actors? Of course not. Much as one enjoyed the British stars who have previously graced this production -Ian McKellen and Tim Curry, John Wood and Peter Firth - it's a kick to see what a home team can do.

title: Canada Sees Wider Deficit
description: Canada's Finance Minister, Allan MacEachen, said he expects a larger federal budget deficit in the latest fiscal year, begun in April, because of the recession. Last November, he forecast a $10.5 billion federal deficit for the year.

title: BLUE JAYS TOP YANKS, 5-4
description: Life is like this for Bucky Dent these days: He finally gets into a game after two weeks, has a chance to position the tying run at third base in the ninth inning by bunting one of two pitches fair, and he fails. The fly ball that Roy Smalley follows with for the second out then becomes meaningless, and the Yankees lose to the Toronto Blue Jays, 5-4.

title: HAYES BATS IN 5 AS INDIANS WIN
description: Von Hayes, a rookie, drove in five runs with a three-run homer, a bases-loaded walk and a double tonight to pace the Cleveland Indians' 9-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: UNDERGROUND BEACON

title: Drysdale Mugged
description: Don Drysdale, the 46-year-old former Dodger pitching star who is a broadcaster for the Chicago White Sox, required six stitches in his scalp as a result of a scuffle with two men who robbed him of a gold chain and a watch in a Cleveland hotel Sunday morning. Drysdale, who put the value of the watch at $5,000, was in Cleveland for an Indians-White Sox series. He never made it to Sunday's game.

title: Taste and Vampire Bats
description: The vampire bat apparently does not have much of a sweet tooth, and shows no preference for blood meals that contain added sugar. But given a choice, this highly selective feeder will avoid blood to which salty, sour or bitter-tasting substances have been added.

title: BELMONT MARK SET FOR MILE
description: Conquistador Cielo, a 3-year-old colt with shins so shaky that every race could be his last, ran the fastest mile in the history of Belmont Park yesterday and won the Metropolitan Handicap.

title: 3 EJECTED IN BRAWL
description: A throwing error by Johnny Bench on Manny Trillo's grounder with two out in the 15th inning tonight gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 5-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in a game marred by a bench-clearing brawl that prompted the ejection of three players.

title: WEST SIDE IS GETTING NEW VIEW
description: The West Side Highway, having done enough falling apart on its own, is being torn down, and along its lower Manhattan route sunlight is reaching places it had not touched for 50 years.

title: Smith/Greenland Gets New Bourbon Account
description: Smith/Greenland, for 16 years an agency for Somerset Importers, a subsidiary of Norton Simon, has been named to handle all of the bourbon brands that had been at McDonald & Little, the Atlanta subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide.

title: J.W.T. Official Plans To Join Wells, Rich
description: After a long career at the J. Walter Thompson Company, Ronald K. Sherman, 49-year-old former president of J.W.T./East and now president of its Entertainment Division and a member of its board, will be leaving in July to join Wells, Rich, Greene as president of the division running New York and Detroit.

title: International
description: Western trade with the Soviet bloc is declining, after a decade of explosive growth. President Reagan would like to see the trend furthered and is expected to seek a number of trade limitations aimed at the Eastern bloc at this weekend's summit meeting. (Page A1.)

title: UNESCO GEOGRAPHY
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILADELPHIA SCHOOL FIGHTING ITS LEGACY
description: Girard College, a landmark of judicial as well as architectural history, sits in North Philadelphia like a Greek island that time forgot. It appears untroubled by the years that first sent waves of urban growth lapping around its 10-foot wall and then turned the neighborhood into slums.

title: News Analysis
description: If the war between Iran and Iraq ended today, the wider battle for political and psychological domination of the Persian Gulf would be just beginning.

title: Sports of The Times; Boos for Joe Torre
description: UP above the mist at Shea Stadium yesterday, a gray dome of clouds hid the jetliners that thundered over every few minutes. In the Atlanta Braves' dugout, Joe Torre shuddered at the vibration from one of the jets.

title: A WAY OF LIFE IN HAWAII IS THREATENED BY SQUEEZE IN THE SUGAR INDUSTRY
description: For three generations, members of Tony Cawagas's family have turned the green stands of cane that blanket the hills and valleys around here for as far as anyone can see into sugar for a world beyond the Hawaiian Islands that they never saw.

title: Arab Urges Oil Increase
description: Mani Said al-Otaiba, the United Arab Emirates oil minister, called on Britain and Norway to raise the prices of their North Sea Oil by another $3 a barrel to match price levels set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: LOUIS F. BISHOP 3D
description: Louis Faugeres Bishop 3d, a public relations executive and former chairman of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 48 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''And how they must have wished, in all the ugliness that war brings, that no other generation of young men to follow would have to undergo that same experience.'' - President Reagan, remembering war dead. (A14:6.)

title: P.S.C. OPPOSED ITS RESTRUCTURING
description: It may startle the consumer, but, with inflation taken into account, residential electric prices fell by 2 percent across New York State between 1974 and 1980, according to the chairman of the State Public Service Commission.

title: WILDCATTERS EXPLORING VERMONT FOR OIL AND GAS
description: It is not exactly likely, but there is a chance, just a chance, that tranquil, rural Vermont could become an oil- and gas-producing state.

title: Stocks End Mixed in Toronto
description: Toronto stocks closed mixed in trendless trading today as markets in the United States were closed for the Memorial Day holiday.

title: PUTNAM IS TOLD TO SPEND MORE TO SAVE MORE
description: Which costs more, a bridge that is 21 feet wide or one 44 feet wide? For the taxpayers of Putnam County, the smaller bridge turns out to be more expensive.

title: PERILING ENERGY SECURITY
description: A national tragedy is unfolding. Now invisible, it will become evident all too soon at enormous cost to America. It is the crumbling of our infant alternative-energy industry, which held such promise of freeing the nation from its dangerous dependence on foreign oil.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK SEES REAGAN OVER HER QUARREL WITH HAIG
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, who is admittedly at odds with the Administration's pro-British policy over the Falkland Islands, met for 40 minutes today with President Reagan to discuss her point of view, White House officials said.

title: Motel Gas Leak Kills Guest
description: Carbon monoxide gas seeping from an improperly vented water heater at a west Texas motel killed a woman and sent 13 other persons to a hospital for treatment today. The police identified the victim as Bernice Connery of Midlothian, Tex., 27 years old. Her body was found in a room at the Imperial Motel.

title: Mozambique in Drive Against Guerrillas
description: Thousands of Mozambique Government troops have begun a major offensive against rebels, said to be South African-supported, in an effort to clear the main transport links to Zimbabwe, a rebel spokesman here said today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Randy Cross, the San Francisco 49er offensive guard who was injured during a charity event, will undergo surgery for torn ligaments and a broken bone in his left ankle and won't play for at least three months. Cross, a seven-year pro veteran, has been a mainstay of the Super Bowl champions' offensive line. ... Mats Naslund, the Swedish League's second-highest scorer this year, became the first European player to sign a contract with the Montreal Canadiens. ... John Merritt, football coach at Tennessee State, says that recruiting on the part of the major football schools has a bad effect on young athletes.

title: AIR FORBES WON TRAILS SPANISH DRUMS BY NECK
description: Spanish Drums, responding gamely down the stretch, held off a rally by the favored Air Forbes Won today and captured the $169,100 Pennsylvania Derby by a neck at Keystone.

title: U.S. SIGNS A PACT IN PACIFIC WITH MARSHALL ISLANDS
description: The Marshall Islands, part of the American trust territory in the Pacific since World War II, have signed a provisional agreement with the United States, granting it military rights for 50 years.

title: Giddons Scores Upset In British Amateur Golf
description: Charles Giddons of England upset the defending champion, Philippe Ploujoux of France, 3 and 1, at the start of the British Amateur golf championship today.

title: FOR FALL, LONG AND LEAN FOR WARMTH AND ELEGANCE
description: With the mixture of pragmatism and esthetics that marks the best fashion thinking today, designers have made sure their clothes for next fall and winter are long enough to keep women warm and sufficiently lean to make them feel graceful. In their fall orders, store buyers have emphasized the long, narrower clothes at the expense of shorter, fuller styles.

title: Bomb May Be Linked To Arrests in Canada
description: The case of an attempted bombing of an Air Canada freight terminal in which three Armenians have been detained may have been retaliation for the arrest of Armenians in Canada two weeks ago, the authorities said today.

title: CANADA CUTS LEVY ON ENERGY
description: The Canadian Government tonight announced financial concessions to the depressed oil and gas industry in a bid to revive exploration and development activity. The tax reductions and credits are designed to increase revenue to the industry by $2 billion (Canadian) by 1986.

title: G.M. Adding Shift
description: About 1,900 General Motors Corporation employees will return to work Tuesday as the Fairfax assembly plant resumes full production on a second shift, officials said. The 6 A.M. shift was eliminated in August 1980 because of a slump in bigcar sales. The company then was making large-size Buicks, Oldsmobiles and Pontiacs.

title: Mangurian vs. Buss
description: The Boston Celtics may be out of the playoffs, but their owner, Harry Mangurian, is trading coast-to-coast criticism with the Los Angeles Lakers' owner, Jerry Buss. After the Celtics were eliminated by the Philadelphia 76ers, Mangurian told a Boston paper that he was sorry the Celtics wouldn't meet Los Angeles because, ''I don't like the way he operates and I don't mind saying it.''

title: FRANK K. SINGISER
description: Frank K. Singiser, a radio announcer for 40 years, died Friday at his home in Sudbury, Vt. He was 73 years old.

title: INTERFERON MAKES INROADS AGAINST SOME INFECTIONS, INCLUDING COLDS
description: THE experiments are simple: no injections or complex equipment, just a nasal spray and an ordinary nose-drop dispenser. Yet, over the last year, several hundred such experiments in England have demonstrated a tantalizing fact: that pure interferon, made artificially, can, under certain circumstances, protect humans against a single virus of the common cold.

title: Prince Andrew's Role In Falklands an Issue
description: Tam Dalyell, a Labor member of Parliament from Scotland, urged Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today to consider withdrawing Queen Elizabeth's son, Prince Andrew, from the task force in the Falkland Islands.

title: Sloop Nirvana Takes Block Island Race
description: Nirvana, a new 81-foot sloop from the Stamford (Conn.) Yacht Club, won the annual Block Island Race today.

title: CAN YOU GO TO COLLEGE TO LEARN HOW TO WRITE A MUSICAL COMEDY?  N.Y.U.  IS BETTING YOU CAN
description: THE class in how to write a musical will please come to order. For those marked absent the other morning, here are some notes (better read than sung) taken down in the wings by a nonmatriculating listener.

title: COMPASSIONATE PASTOR OF ENGLISH CATHOLICS
description: As he waited at Gatwick Airport for Pope John Paul II to arrive on a visit he had fought hard to save from the political difficulties that menaced it, Basil Cardinal Hume was asked by a television reporter, ''And how do you feel personally?''

title: Markets Closed
description: All United States stock and commodities markets and most businesses were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day. Some foreign markets were also closed in observance of the Whitsun holiday.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 1, 1982
description: International U.S.-Soviet arms limitation talks will start June 29 in Geneva, President Reagan announced. He also said the United States would not undercut previous arms limitation agreements with Moscow, ''so long as the Soviet Union shows equal restraint.'' Washington and Moscow announced the starting date for the talks simultaneously. The statement said that ''both sides attach great importance to these negotiations.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan will attempt to formally end the huge expansion of East-West trade that took place in the 1970's in a bid to make the West more cautious about trading with the Soviet Union and its satellites. At this weekend's Western economic summit in Versailles, he will press the six other industrial democracies at the meeting to support new curbs on trade with the Eastern Bloc; to withhold cheap export credits; to place a ceiling on future lending to the Soviet Union and its satellites, and to tighten existing NATO restrictions on the sale of strategic goods. Meanwhile, trade with the Soviet bloc is being stifled by the bloc's huge debts, a stagnant world economy and worsening political relations. (A1:5.)

title: LIABILITY IN SETTING STANDARDS
description: For most of the people most of the time, the thousands of pages of engineering and product standards published every year in this country might as well be written with invisible ink. Unless you are an engineer, the Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, for example, which is 18,000 pages long, is probably not on your reading list.

title: Tokyo Dollar Opening
description: The dollar opened at 243.90 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today, up from the previous day's close of 243.70.

title: INTRUDER WOUNDS THE MAYOR IN LA PORTE, IND., AND KILLS WIFE
description: A gunman broke into the home of the Mayor early today and opened fire, killing the Mayor's wife and wounding the Mayor, the authorities said.

title: VOEST-ALPINE PLANS PRODUCT EXPANSION
description: Voest-Alpine, the state-owned steelmaker that is Austria's biggest corporation, has traditionally depended for growth on the country's strong technical base, low inflation rate and labor peace. Methodically, it exploited these central European strengths to haul energy and raw materials from Eastern Europe, and to ship its products and skills around the world.

title: A RAINY RALLY SEEKS TO HELP SOPHIA LOREN
description: It began at noon, when 15-year-old Stacy Albanese and her cousin, wearing almost matching outfits -sailor shirts and blue jeans - stood on a small platform set up on Mulberry Street and started singing show tunes.

title: CBS Note Offering
description: CBS Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $150 million of 10-year notes, to be sold by underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company and Lazard Freres & Company.

title: Court Extends Camera Test
description: A two-year-old experiment allowing cameras in state courtrooms is being extended indefinitely by the Supreme Court of Massachusetts. The action was taken at the request of an advisory committee that plans to make recommendations on cameras in the courtroom this summer.

title: Polish Underground Plans General Strike
description: Fugitive Solidarity leaders announced plans today for a general strike in Warsaw and the Wroclaw and Silesian regions, and called on members of the suspended trade union to abandon previous forms of protest.

title: GEARING UP FOR MILITARY OUTPUT
description: The first ripples of the Reagan Administration's huge military buildup are reaching the nation's factories. At the sprawling Northrop Defense Systems plant in Rolling Meadows, Ill., for example, the company has doubled its manufacturing space in the last two years. It has spent millions of dollars on new equipment, its sales have tripled and its job rolls have grown by 26 percent, to 2,500.

title: SCIENTISTS DISCOUNT VOLCANO TREMORS
description: A huge steam plume clung to the rim of Mount St. Helens today as a flurry of harmonic tremors rumbled beneath it, but scientists said the increased activity was not unusual.

title: 22.7 Million on Food Stamps
description: A total of 22.7 million people received food stamps in March, a 2 percent increase over February, the Agriculture Department says. The March figure was 300,000 fewer than the number that received food stamps a year ago.

title: Heileman Bid for Pabst Held Likely to Succeed
description: The Pabst Brewing Company is likely to accept a $196.8 million cash offer that the G. Heileman Brewing Company made for it on Friday, industry analysts said yesterday.

title: CONSOLIDATED GOLD ADDS U.S. DIRECTORS
description: Consolidated Gold Fields, which was founded by Cecil Rhodes and owns some of South Africa's richest mines, has been steadily expanding in the United States. Last year its American subsidiary, the Amcon Group, obtained 22 percent of the Newmont Mining Corporation. And last week, Amcon added some well-known Americans to its board.

title: SOVIET LETTING A HUNGER STRIKER EMIGRATE
description: One of a group of Soviet citizens on a hunger strike to press for permission to join spouses in the West was advised today that he would be allowed to emigrate.

title: TEACHER TO OFFER TO LEAVE HIS POST
description: A prominent poet said Sunday that he would offer to resign from the faculty of Boston University after an incident in which a student at Harvard University accused him of sexual harassment.

title: Buses to Compete With Conrail
description: A private bus service offered as an alternative to Conrail's Harlem commuter line was to begin operations Tuesday with rush-hour express service from Hartsdale and Scarsdale into Manhattan.

title: Chess: Karpov and Andersson Tie For First in London Event
description: The Phillips & Drew International Tournament in London, one of the strongest ever held in Britain, ended in a tie for first place between the world champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, and Ulf Andersson, a Swedish grandmaster. Each was awarded a prize of 2,850 for his winning score of 8 1/2-4 1/2.

title: BUFFLED, BAFFLED, BUFFALOED
description: To the Editor:

title: Rose Kennedy Is Taken To Palm Beach Hospital
description: Rose Kennedy, the 91-year-old matriarch of the Kennedy family, spent Memorial Day hospitalized in stable condition with family members at her side.

title: Bridge:; Steve Weinstein, at 19, Sets Mark for Age in Goldman
description: For a teen-ager to win a major pair championship is very rare indeed, but Steve Weinstein of Accord, N.Y., seems to be making a habit of it. Last summer, at the age of 18, he captured the National Life Master Pair title, the youngest player to do so in the 53-year history of the event.

title: U.S. HOPES TO END UNION STATION'S PERIOD AS A MESS
description: In the annals of Federal fiascos, there is now perfect bipartisan agreement here, there is no more classical list of Government blunders than those that befell Washington's Union Station.

title: Four States Holding Primary Elections
description: By The Associated Press Democrats in New Mexico are voting to pick a candidate today to oppose Senator Harrison Schmitt, the former astronaut, in November, while Republicans in West Virginia are expected to nominate a strong conservative challenger to Robert C. Byrd, the Senate Minority Leader, who is unopposed in the Democratic primary as he seeks his fifth term.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AFTER THE FALKLANDS, WATCH FOR PERONISM
description: The consequences of the Falklands war for Argentina are of course hard to predict, but one thing is certain: Peronism will re-emerge as a key domestic political force.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Music View column that appeared in Arts and Leisure Section on Sunday gave an incorrect date for the joint concert of the New York Philharmonic and the Israel Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall. The concert will take place on Thursday.

title: Open Door Economic Policy Is Mixed Blessing for Chinese
description: The Shenzhen branch of China's Electronic Import-Export Corporation was doing a flourishing business, but not the sort that the architects of Peking's new open door economic policy had in mind.

title: CONQUERING THE PAST; Rash Decisions
description: New York City has virtually eliminated measles from its public schools, and has made severe inroads on mumps and rubella. The achievement justifies the much debated policy, begun last September, of turning away from school all children without proof of vaccination.

title: COSMOS BOW TO THE STING, 4-3
description: The Chicago Sting captured the third Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup today with a 4-3 victory over the Cosmos before a crowd of 36,904 at Giants Stadium.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE POPE'S REMARKS
description: Following are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's speech on the family at Knavesmire Racecourse near York today, as supplied by the Vatican Press Office:

title: WAR TO THE DEATH
description: ''The first complete defense guidance'' of the Reagan Administration, intended to govern United States military policy for at least the next five years, is a blueprint for turning uneasy Soviet-American relations into an unrelenting war to the death.

title: AUDIT CHALLENGES LOS ANGELES ANTIPOVERTY AGENCY
description: Labor Department auditors have questioned the expenditure of almost $46 million by a federally financed antipoverty agency in East Los Angeles set up to create jobs in the Latin community.

title: TUITION TAX CREDITS WILL BUST NO BUDGET
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR CAIRO'S POOREST, HOME IS WHERE THE SPACE IS
description: Hassanein Farouk Ibrahim, a 26-year-old carpenter, was evicted from a rooftop hovel he had erected on a Cairo building. Despairing of finding other accommodations, he set fire to himself and died.

title: Conviction in Slaying Upheld
description: The 1979 conviction of Alan Canady in the bludgeoning death of his 8-year-old son and a shooting assault on the boy's mother has been upheld in a decision released today by the State Supreme Court. Mr. Canady, who is 29, was sentenced in Waterbury Superior Court in 1980 to 30 years to life in prison.

title: Last Week's War
description: The world's attention span has been reckoned at 90 days, which, unhappily, is probably right. Afghanistan has all but slipped from sight. It is nine times 90 days since the Soviet Union flung its armies at an unaligned and unoffending neighbor. But still the war goes on. The Russians, incredibly, are no nearer victory than at the start, when experts blandly forecast that their modern army would subdue primitive tribesmen in months.

title: WHIRLPOOLS IN THE SKY: A number of atmospheric features have remained unobserved until viewed from the perspectives of space.  The latest such discovery is the formation of a train of vortices in cloud formations downwind of an oceanic island. The phenomenon is reminiscent of whirlpools formed by a rock in a swift-flowing stream.
description: Shown here is a train of such vortices produced south of Guadalupe Island, off Mexico's Baja California, produced by a wind blowing past the island from the north.

title: MRS. WAITZ WINS RACE 4TH TIME
description: Grete Waitz, running in a persistent drizzle in Central Park, won the L'eggs Mini Marathon for the fourth straight year yesterday. Mrs. Waitz, a 28-year-old schoolteacher from Oslo, was clocked in 31 minutes 59 seconds for the 6.2-mile road race, which attracted 4,475 runners. Her time was better than last year's 32:43.1, but short of the meet record of 30:59.8 she set in 1980.

title: WRONG CENSUS FOR AID TO POOR CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: Trevisiol Breaks Mark In 50-Mile Bicycle Race
description: Gary Trevisiol of Sudbury, Ontario, today broke the American record for a 50-mile criterium, a multi-lap bicycle race run over a closed network of city streets.

title: Senate Action to Be Sought On Balanced-Budget Measure
description: The Senate Republican leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., will try to get a Senate vote in June on a constitutional amendment for a balanced budget, his aides say.

title: CONSERVATION WINS IN COLOMBIA
description: Belisario Betancur Cuartas, the Conservative Party candidate, was elected President of Colombia over three opponents Sunday, according to nearly complete results announced today.

title: Nigerian Output
description: Nigeria's oil production, which plummeted earlier this year and brought on an economic crisis in the country, is likely to have recovered to an average of around 1.25 million barrels a day in May, official sources said today. The recovery, from under 900,000 barrels a day in April, was due to a general tightening of the world market, bringing back buyers who had shunned Nigerian oil during a persistent world glut, they said.

title: Summer Job Delusions
description: President Reagan makes no bones about his preference for private sector remedies to social problems. Summer jobs for low-income teenagers offer a case in point. While visiting New York last winter, the President spoke enthusiastically about the New York City Partnership, an admirable coalition of civic-minded corporations. It succeeded in placing almost 10,000 inner-city youths in jobs with private firms last summer. This year it aims to do even better.

title: Twin Cities Talk Show Host, Show Ended, Is Found Dead
description: An unemployed radio talk-show host, Bob Allard, was found dead Sunday in his parents' garage in North Minneapolis. The authorities ruled the death a suicide.

title: Japanese Steel Exports
description: Japan's steel exports to the United States in the July-September quarter are likely to fall below one million metric tons for the first time in about 10 years, trading sources here said. The sources attributed the continuing fall to the slump in United States industries including automobiles, increased competition from Southeast Asia and European countries and a decline in demand for seamless steel pipes.

title: BENZYL ALCOHOL LINKED TO DEATHS OF 16 INFANTS
description: The Food and Drug Administration today urged hospitals and pediatricians to stop using intravenous fluids containing benzyl alcohol as a preservative in their treatment of premature infants.

title: Fitzpatrick, in Porsche, Triumphs at Lime Rock
description: John Fitzpatrick started from the pole position today in a turbocharged Porsche and held the lead for 69 laps to win the one-hour Camel GT at Lime Rock Park.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Lower interest rates would be good news for the American economy, but many economists are resigned to monetary and fiscal policies that point to double-digit rates through the rest of the year.

title: IRANIANS ARE TOLD IRAQ MAY BE INVADED IF NECESSARY
description: In public pronouncements and in sermons in mosques, Iranians have been told that the ''fighters for Islam'' who recaptured Khurramshahr a week ago will carry the battle across the Iraqi border if necessary to punish the enemy and protect Iranian territory.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What causes cluster headaches?

title: STALLONE IN DISPUTE ON 'COTTON CLUB'
description: Less than three weeks ago, it was announced that Sylvester Stallone would star in Robert Evans's saga of Harlem's ''Cotton Club.'' Two weeks later, Mr. Stallone abruptly backed out of his role as the gangster owner of the club, leaving Mr. Evans angry enough to send the actor a blistering letter.

title: MANY END WET HOLIDAY IN LONG STRUGGLE HOME
description: Pushing through patchy fog and drizzle, hundreds of thousands of holiday travelers streamed into and out of the New York metropolitan area late yesterday, ending a sunless and somber Memorial Day weekend at city diversions and shore and country retreats.

title: Mead Plans Note Sale
description: The Mead Corporation, a diversified paper concern, has announced the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $75 million of intermediate-term notes. The underwriting group will be co-managed by Goldman, Sachs & Company and Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: BUFFLED, BAFFLED, BUFFALOED
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerry Falwell's Radio Station Is Knocked Off Air by Vandals
description: The 138-foot-high tower of a radio station operated by the Rev. Jerry Falwell collapsed early today when its support wires were cut, station officials said.

title: JAPANESE GROUP IS REFUSED VISAS FOR RALLY IN CITY
description: The State Department has denied visas to approximately 300 Japanese citizens who were planning to attend the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament next week and a Central Park rally in support of that session, a State Department official said yesterday.

title: News Analysis
description: New York and Boston both have large subway systems that are faced with declining ridership, deteriorating facilities and gaping deficits. Later this month, New York City will hold public hearings on raising its fare from 75 cents, to $1 or more. Last month, Boston lowered its subway fare to 60 cents from 75 cents.

title: Stolen-Guns Verdict Upheld
description: The State Supreme Court has upheld the conviction of a Meriden man on charges that he knowingly bought stolen antique guns, in a ruling announced today. The man, Chester Orsini, had been free on bail after being sentenced to three to six years in prison.

title: GUIDE TO SPECIAL AGENCIES
description: New York State has a broad range of special agencies designed to finance housing and other building projects. They are generally considered ''public benefit corporations,'' and they exist outside the regular structure of state government. Their money usually comes from the sale of bonds, and they are usually governed by boards appointed by the Governor.

title: U.N. Security Council Decides Not to Discuss Iraq-Iran War
description: Security Council members decided today not to open a public debate on the Iraqi-Iranian war as Jordan had requested.

title: Loan for Turkey
description: The World Bank said it had approved a $304.5 million loan to Turkey to assist the country's efforts to improve its serious economic problems. A bank spokesman said the country would require $4 billion to $4.5 billion in assistance during 1982 and 1983 and that loan would cover three percent of the country's exports, and 7.5 percent of its capital needs during the next 12 months. The loan is for 17 years, including three years of grace, with an interest of 11.6 percent per year.

title: DECISION TO SELL RIVER'S WATER ANGERS MISSOURI BASIN STATES
description: South Dakota's agreement to send Missouri River water beyond its borders, for a price, has provoked outrage and court challenges from conservationists, Sioux Indians and several states downstream.

title: BUFFLED, BAFFLED, BUFFALOED
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN'S CAPITAL MARKET HAS U.S.. CRITICS
description: For months, the United States and Western European nations have been putting pressure on Japan relentlessly to open its markets wider to foreign goods. In response, Japan recently announced another package of market-opening measures.

title: Four Youths Arrested In High School Holdup
description: Four teen-agers who invaded a classroom at Brooklyn Technical High School and robbed a teacher and 21 students at gunpoint were arrested yesterday, the police said.

title: REAGAN TO SEEK CURBS ON TRADE WITH EAST BLOC
description: After a decade of rapid growth, trade between the industrial West and the Soviet bloc is being stifled by the Communist world's mountainous debts, a stagnant world economy and worsening political relations.

title: OVERSTATED EFFECTS OF LEAD ON THE MIND
description: To the Editor:

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Susan Bolotin AMERICA IN SEARCH OF ITSELF: The Making of the President 1956-80. By Theodore H. White. 465 pages. A Corne- lia and Michael Bessie Book/Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: 15 WIN FOLK-ART FELLOWSHIPS
description: A Brooklyn balladeer and a Queens harmonica player are among 15 artists who are the first to receive National Heritage Fellowships from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: AID BILL EMERGING FOR THRIFTS
description: After months of intense lobbying, a consensus appears to be forming in Congress that some kind of legislation to rescue faltering savings and loan institutions is urgently needed. But the assistance package now emerging is likely to fall far short of the $10 billion bailout plan the thrift industry has demanded.

title: China Says the Strain in Ties With U.S. Won't Affect Japan
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China assured Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki today that China's solid economic and political ties with Japan will be unaffected by any backsliding of relations with the United States.

title: PACKWOOD THINKS G.O.P. MUST DEBATE ISSUES
description: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, says that he believes he has been the target of punishment by some White House staff members because he opposed President Reagan's wishes, but that he intends to continue pressing his views.

title: BRIEFING
description: Memorial Day Lapse

title: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically
description: When the East 96th Street Block Association called a community meeting on crime the other day, the police of the 23d Precinct expected 30 to 40 people to turn up. Instead, 400 crowded into the auditorium of Hunter College Elementary School, taking nearly every seat. They wanted to know how crime could be wiped out. So they were shocked - gasping and laughing nervously - by a remark of Officer Charles Bonaventura, a community affairs specialist.

title: FIXING THE QUICK FIX
description: First the good news. The state government has worked out a way to meet the temporary need for more prison space at a fraction of what it would have cost if Governor Carey had convinced the voters last fall to approve his $500 million prison bond issue.

title: Flames Drop Coach
description: The Calgary Flames have eased Al MacNeil out of his head-coaching job, apparently the first step toward naming Bob Johnson to the post later this week. Johnson is the highly successful coach at the University of Wisconsin whom the Flames have been coveting for some time, and Cliff Fletcher, the club's president and general manager, said he would meet with Johnson in the next several days to discuss the position.

title: BALLET: KIROV'S 'SWAN'
description: In the end, the true measure of a ballet company is its corps, its body. In this respect, the Kirov Ballet from Leningrad remains unsurpassed, as its ensembles have demonstrated with a highly polished, even spectacular production of ''Swan Lake'' during its current season here at the Palace of Congresses.

title: PULEO AND METS ROUT BRAVES
description: Joe Torre, a victim of the Mets' past, became a victim of their present yesterday when they mauled five of Torre's pitchers with 16 hits and whipped the Atlanta Braves, 10-4.

title: Car Cost Put at 23.8 Cents a Mile
description: An intermediate-size car made in the United States and driven 120,000 miles over a 12-year period will cost its owner $28,640, or 23.8 cents a mile, according to a new Government publication.

title: ATOM BY ATOM, PHYSICISTS CREATE MATTER THAT NATURE HAS NEVER KNOWN BEFORE
description: SCIENTISTS in more than 100 laboratories around the world are rushing to take advantage of a technologically pioneering process that is so fine in its approach to constructing matter that it can be used to build new materials atomic layer by atomic layer.

title: RATES SEEN AS CATALYST FOR STOCKS
description: The stock market has hit the skids again, and some Wall Street professionals think that any price recovery is likely to prove temporary.

title: NIXON PREDICTS THAT REAGAN WILL DEFEAT KENNEDY IN 1984
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon is predicting that the Democrats will nominate Edward M. Kennedy for President in 1984 and that the Massachusetts Senator will be defeated by President Reagan.

title: AMERICAN NEEDS WAGE-NOT PRICE-CURBS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Czech Historian Is Reported Freed
description: The historian Jan Mlynarik, last of a group of Czechoslovak dissidents still detained after being rounded up by the police a year ago, has been freed, emigre sources said here today.

title: P.S.A.L. Title to Tech
description: A scoring error in the 1,600-meter run at the Public Schools Athletic League track and field championships Saturday failed to credit Brooklyn Tech with a fourth-place finish. Officials rectified the mistake yesterday and as a result, Tech was declared the team champion with 98 points. John F. Kennedy of the Bronx, which had been awarded the trophy, lost a point on the rescoring and finished second with 97.

title: CUBA PUSHES ARGENTINE CAUSE
description: Cuba is hoping to generate large third-world support for Argentina over the Falkland crisis at a ministerial conference of countries professing nonalignment that opened here today, according to diplomatic sources.

title: INDY 500 WINNER HAS MIXED EMOTIONS
description: As he stood in his race car at the brick finish line today and held his right hand on the Indianapolis 500 trophy for the endless series of photographs, Gordon Johncock stopped to rub his eyes with his left hand.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: Recession or no, new shops continue to open in New York as if e veryone had nothing to do but spend money on summer clothes. The F inals, for example, a sporting-goods shop at 149 Mercer Street, o ffers reasonable facsimiles of Speedo swimwear at more than r easonable prices. Men's Lycra suits are $9, women's one-piece suits,b eautifully cut with low backs, are $18. There are also knit polo s hirts for $11 that imitate the famous Lacoste shirt. But the newest m en's Speedo suits, navy with white vertical stripes, can be had for $ 18 at All American Boy, 131 Christopher Street.

title: POPE SPEAKS ON THE SANCTITY OF MARRIAGE
description: Pope John Paul II reminded British Catholics today of the sanctity of marriage and condemned divorce, contraception and abortion.

title: Drug Export Shift Weighed
description: 13 WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -The Reagan Administration is moving toward a new trade policy that would let American companies export drugs that are not allowed to be sold in this country because of potential hazards, according to Administration sources.

title: Sootfall on Top of World
description: Although Arctic air is usually considered pristine, far from any sources of pollution, measurements at Barrow, Alaska, the northernmost United States village, have shown it to be remarkably sooty in winter and spring.

title: FACULTY ATTACKS PRESIDENT OF NORTHWESTERN ON BUDGET ISSUES
description: The president of Northwestern University, ordered by the school's trustees to balance the budget, is under attack from faculty members for his handling of university finances.

title: ADVERTISING
description: THE J. Walter Thompson Company, which suspended and then dismissed the head of its TV spot buying earlier this year after the disclosure of $30 million of computer accounting irregularities, has lost the Lever Brothers assignment as its agency of record for all spot buying.

title: MacNamara, Clapp Adds Product by Mem
description: MacNamara, Clapp & Klein of 555 Madison Avenue is one of those agencies that cloaked itself in a low profile until it thought it had a lot to say.

title: The Calendar
description: Tuesday

title: Japan Shipbuilders' Net Up
description: Three leading Japanese shipbuilders have reported major profit growth in the fiscal year ended March 31, despite stiff competition from other countries.

title: MESA BID FOR CITIES SERVICE
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said last night that it had offered to buy the Cities Service Company for $50 a common share in a deal valued at $3.8 billion.

title: Business and the Law; Dismissing Antitrust Suits
description: THERE was a time, not so long ago, when most antitrust experts believed with certainty that the Government had the discretion to dismiss - without interference from the courts - any case that it chose not to pursue.

title: Military Analysis
description: Argentina's bombing offensive against British forces on and around East Falkland Island is slackening in weight and tempo, according to British officials. The officials said that attacks on the aircraft carrier battle group had failed to inflict any serious damage and that the rapid advance of British forces following the northern route to Stanley had been free from air attack.

title: BLACKS INCREASING IN CAPITAL SUBURBS
description: Blacks accounted for nearly 90 percent of the Washington metropolitan area's population growth in the 1970's, according to an analysis of 1980 census data released today.

title: Athens Bans Traffic To Clean Up Air
description: The Government, moving to reduce pollution levels in Athens, imposed a one-month ban today on traffic in the city center.

title: BOMBS HIT U.S. BASES IN WEST GERMANY
description: Bombs exploded at four United States military bases early today, a little more than a week before President Reagan is scheduled to arrive in West Germany for a NATO meeting. An organization calling itself the Revolutionary Cells Terrorist Group tied the bombings to the President's trip.

title: RACIAL VIOLENCE IN BOSTON FORCING BLACKS TO MOVE
description: Grace Egypt Walker was born black in Augusta, Ga., 31 years ago, but it was not until the last six months, she says, that she encountered racial epithets, stone-throwing, hard shoves, drawn knives and a gasoline bomb hurled through her window.

title: Careers; Retailing Offers Job Prospects
description: For new holders of B.A. and M.B.A. degrees, there is a business offering good jobs that might be overlooked - retailing. ''It offers a better opportunity than any other industry I can think of,'' Joseph J. Carideo said. He is a principal of Thorndike Deland Associates, the management recruiting firm that has long taken a special interest in retailing.

title: 2 SUSPECTS ARRESTED
description: A Roman Catholic priest was robbed of nearly $6,000 in weekend church receipts in Brooklyn yesterday. Two suspects were arrested when their motorcycle slammed into a tree after a chase in the Park Slope section, the police said.

title: Fairbanks to Coach N.Y. Football Entry
description: Chuck Fairbanks will be named president and head coach of the New York entry in the newly formed United States Football League today. Fairbanks, who spent six seasons as coach of the New England Patriots before leaving for the University of Colorado three years ago, formally presented his letter of resignation to Eddie Crowder, the Colorado athletic director, yesterday morning. Crowder announced the resignation at a late-afternoon news conference in Boulder.

title: Reagan Vetoes a Bill to Settle Arizona Water Rights Dispute
description: President Reagan today vetoed legislation designed to settle an Arizona water rights dispute involving the Papago Indian tribe, the City of Tucson and other major water users.

title: Hunt Is on for Statue Of Nude Bette Davis
description: Bette Davis, the actress, says that somewhere in a Boston park stands a statue of her in the nude. But the city's parks deparment cannot find it and is looking for clues to its whereabouts.

title: RATES MOVE SHARPLY HIGHER
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday as the need to pay for several recent issues led traders to cut prices in an effort to reduce their holdings.

title: Harvester Unit
description: The International Harvester Company announced that it was selling its Victor Fluid Power subsidiary. The unit, which includes Harvester's Iowa Industrial division, makes hydraulic cylinders and control valves for diversified applications including agricultural, construction, mining and snow removal equipment. The combined units had total sales of more than $32 million last year, and employed about 500 workers.

title: JUSTCES BACK UTILITY ACT IN A STATES' RIGHTS CASE
description: The Supreme Court, sharply divided over issues of state sovereignty, today upheld a Federal energy law that requires state utility regulators to consider pricing policies that are designed to encourage energy conservation.

title: Reds 4, Phillies 1
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Mike Vail drove in a run with a single and added two doubles in support of Greg Harris's five-hit pitching to lead Cincinnati in a game called after a rain delay of 1 hour 34 minutes following completion of the seventh inning.

title: KOCH WARNS CUTS UNLESS STATE ACTS
description: Mayor Koch warned yesterday that the failure of the State Legislature to give New York City the aid and taxing power he requested could lead to reductions in the city's Police and Fire Departments and in services to the elderly and children.

title: Sohio Unit to Buy Sybron's Pfaudler
description: A division of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) has agreed to buy the Sybron Corporation's worldwide Pfaudler process equipment business for $43 million, Sohio said today.

title: KEY LAWYER FOR PROSECTUTION: ROGER MARK ADELMAN
description: Roger M. Adelman, the assistant United States Attorney managing the Government's case against John W. Hinckley Jr., is a man who likes to be in total control. He holds his cards so tightly, in fact, that he will not even disclose the name of his hometown to reporters.

title: Suspect Arrested In L.I. Robbery
description: A Brooklyn woman who the police said was a friend of a suspect in two Long Island robberies last Friday night, including one at a restaurant in which one customer was raped and two others were shot, was arrested yesterday on charges of robbing a different restaurant last week.

title: Accusation on Agents
description: Butch Woolfolk, the Giants' No.1 draft choice, says that while he was at Michigan, agents offered him money and cars as inducements to retain them to represent him in future contract negotiations. ''Agents are smart,'' he said.

title: WABC-TV LEADS NEWS 'SWEEPS'
description: TV, Channel 7, dominated the local Nielsen news ratings during the May ''sweeps,'' winning the three-station race not only at 6 P.M. and at 11 P.M., but also at 5 P.M., with its newest entry, ''Eyewitness News at Five.''

title: Toll for Holiday Traffic Is 341, Lowest Since '49
description: This year's Memorial Day weekend traffic death toll was the lowest since 1949, the National Safety Council said today.

title: A's 3, Red Sox 2
description: Rickey Henderson, who stole his 50th and 51st bases, hit a two-run homer in the fifth inning to give the Oakland the victory.

title: THE POPE REMINDS SCOTS OF ANCESTRY
description: Pope John Paul II told Scottish Roman Catholics today that their spiritual lives should be conducted in such a way as to vindicate their persecuted ancestors' ''valiant struggle for survival.''

title: WIRETAPS ALLOWED IN TEAMSTERS TRIAL
description: Evidence obtained through wiretaps can be admitted in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, a Federal district judge ruled yesterday in Chicago.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HOMILY BY THE POPE IN GLASGOW
description: Following are excerpts from the homily delivered today by Pope John Paul II at an outdoor mass in Bellahouston Park, as provided by Vatican officials:

title: Protest Idles Boston Cabs
description: About half the city's 1,500 taxis were idle today, the police estimated, as a strike by independent cabbies spread in protest over unscheduled limousines cruising for passengers at Logan International Airport. Max Dobor, president of the Independent Taxi Operators Association, said talks were scheduled Wednesday with the Massachusetts Port Authority, which operates the airport.

title: NEGOTIATIONS
description: Following are excerpts from the final report of the Independent Commission on Disarmament and Security Issues, which was made public here today:

title: Bremer Parole Bid Denied
description: The Maryland Parole Commission today denied a full parole hearing to Arthur G. Bremer, who tried to assassinate Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama more than 10 years ago. The seven-member commission said it saw no reason to hold a parole hearing for Mr. Bremer before the mandatory date of August 1985. Mr. Bremer will have served 14 years, or one-quarter of his 53-year sentence, at that time.

title: Bail Is Denied for Man Held in I.B.M. Shootings
description: Edward Thomas Mann, charged with murder and assault in a shooting spree at an I.B.M. building in Bethesda, was ordered held without bail today.

title: U.S. EXPANDS DAIRY GIVEAWAY
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today the Government would distribute 50 million pounds of surplus butter and 120 million more pounds of cheese to states for free distribution to low-income Americans.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Last spring I bought a batch of dried woodruff to make May wine. I still have more than half of it on my spice shelf. Is there any other use for it?

title: 2 METS HURT AS BRAVES WIN, 7-3
description: In one of their costliest evenings of the year, the Mets lost two players to injuries and one game to the Atlanta Braves last night at Shea Stadium.

title: MIDEAST PEACE
description: A wind is rising - a tempest of rhetoric in the United States and abroad proclaiming both the death of the Camp David peace process and a pressing need for a comprehensive approach to replace it. Yet a comprehensive Arab-Israeli settlement, for reasons outside American and Israeli control, is not possible at this time. If Washington fails to base its policy on this reality, it will endanger the partial peace already achieved in pursuit of a panacea that cannot be.

title: ASSEMBLY TO CONSIDER A BILL TO ALLOW TV IN COURTROOM
description: A bill that would allow television cameras into New York State's courtrooms for 18 months on an experimental basis has reached the floor of the Assembly and is expected to be voted on this week.

title: 150 in Protest Against U.S. Aide
description: More than 150 people gathered on West 42d Street yesterday to demand the resignation of J. Peter Grace, the head of a Presidential panel, for having described the Federal food stamp program as ''basically a Puerto Rican program.''

title: Rose Kennedy Is Discharged
description: Rose Kennedy, the 91-year-old matriarch of the Kennedy family, was discharged today from St. Mary's Hospital here after undergoing a series of tests. Ruth Hardy, a spokesman at the hospital, said Mrs. Kennedy was ''feeling fine'' and doctors decided to release her, even though they had not determined the cause of the discomfort that sent her to the hospital Sunday evening.

title: 32,000 Refugees Lose Federal Aid in Florida
description: Federal aid was cut off today for about 32,000 Cuban and Haitian refugees in south Florida.

title: Royals 4, White Sox 3
description: Dan Quisenberry picked up his 13th save and Willie Wilson scored a pair of runs to lead Kansas City. Vida Blue (3-3), making his first start since pulling a leg muscle May 15, struck out nine in five innings. Mike Armstrong pitched the sixth and Quisenberry took over with a runner on and no one out in the seventh.

title: MORE ON NECKING
description: My campaign to build national support for the school necktie amendment is generating an immense outpouring of public enthusiasm. I am particularly grateful to all those who have sent in their $50 checks for the ''Neatness Now'' necktie. To those who haven't gotten around to it yet, I would only say this: Until our nation reclaims its right to foster a neat appearance in the schoolroom we will continue to produce entire generations who throw their empty beer cans on your lawn.

title: Begin Willing to Attend 3-Way Washington Talks
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he would be willing to accept an invitation by President Reagan to an American-Egyptian-Israeli meeting in Washington.

title: Required Reading Brennan: 'Save Me!'
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court at the New York University School of Law, asking rhetorically what can be done about the conservative trend on the Court, April 15, 1982:

title: Alfa Group Cites '81 Loss
description: The troubled Alfa Group, Latin America's largest business conglomerate, lost more than $120 million in 1981 and spent nearly $11 million buying out the jobs of 4,300 workers, Bernardo Garza Sada, president, said here.

title: WINE TALK
description: HEALDSBURG, Calif. THE vine stalks are old and gnarled like the trunks of trees, some of them as thick as a man's thigh, and they date back to the turn of the century. They are brittle with age and sometimes crack when bumped by a picker. Because the vines are so old, the grapes yield only miserly amounts of juice, but it is very concentrated juice, and the wine that results is intensely rich and spicy, the quintessential zinfandel of California.

title: KID CREOLE MAY MAKE BREAKTHROUGH
description: THE new Kid Creole and the Coconuts album is called ''Wise Guy'' in the United States (where Sire/ Warner Bros. is releasing it this week) and ''Tropical Gangsters'' in Europe. Both titles are appropriate.

title: Decision to Bury Dead On Islands Causes Row
description: A dispute has erupted over the Government's decision to bury on the Falkland Islands the bodies of British servicemen killed there.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS BRITISH ACTIONS, SAYING AGGRESSION MUST BE HALTED
description: President Reagan strongly defended Britain's military actions in the Falkland crisis today, asserting that ''armed aggression as originally took place there must not be allowed to succeed.''

title: U.S. AND CHINA DISCUSSING EXPORT OF NUCLEAR TECHNOLOGY
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it had begun talks with China on the possibility of an agreement on nuclear cooperation that would enable American companies to help develop China's nuclear power industry.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: HENRY MORGAN, a keen observer of all major meteorological trends in our city, has been keeping his eye on the weather. Well, not exactly the weather per se, but rather, some of our weather celebrities. Here is Mr. Morgan's report:

title: WHO AND WHAT RAISES POSTAL SERVICE RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Cracow remains quiet under martial law A2 New York Congressman presses El Salvador on nuns A4 Around the World A5 Sudan's leader suggests Arab meeting to try to end gulf war A6 Reagan defends British actions in Falklands A14 Government/Politics House returns to struggle with 1983 budget A21 Senator John C. Stennis wins renomination for seventh term A22 New York Assembly to consider bill to allow TV in courts B4 Koch warns of service cutbacks unless State Legislature acts B4 High Court upholds utility law in states' rights case B6 Washington Talk Government sharply cutting back on its publications A20 Briefing A20 Required Reading A20 Decision File A20 General Space shuttle's glow called an obstacle to some tests A9 Racial violence in Boston forces a black family to move A18 Missouri farmer freed from jail by bankruptcy judge A18 Around the Nation A18 Court blocks rescission of passive restraint rule for new cars A21 The city and the A.S.P.C.A. agree on closing a budget gap B3 Religion Pope exhorts Scots to vindicate their ancestors' struggle A16 News Analysis William Borders examines Britain's options in the Falklands A14 Drew Middleton examines decision facing British military A15 The Living Section Food Raw shellfish: How risky is it? C1

title: Sports of The Times; Pace-Lap Blues Wont't Go Away
description: THE young woman was anything but a barbarian. Her eyes sparkled as she recalled the first time she had read ''The Grand Inquisitor'' chapter of ''The Brothers Karamazov'' back in high school, long before she learned enough Russian to read the original.

title: DOLLAR CLIMBS BROADLY; GOLD HITS A 3-YEAR LOW
description: The dollar rose sharply against other major currencies in foreign exchange trading in the United States and abroad yesterday. The Canadian dollar slumped to its lowest rate ever against the United States dollar.

title: GENERIC DRUGS WIN COURT CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that manufacturers of generic drugs whose products imitate the shape and color of name-brand drugs cannot ordinarily be held liable when pharmacists mislabel and sell their generic product as the higher-priced brandname drug.

title: WILANDER TOPPLES GERULAITIS
description: Mats Wilander made a case for fundamentals over finesse today when he upset Vitas Gerulaitis, 6-3, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4, and reached the semifinals of the French open tennis tournament.

title: Sun Prepayment
description: The Sun Company said it would prepay on June 30 the final $200 million of a floating rate note issued to Seagram Company Ltd. in connection with Sun's 1980 purchase of Seagram's United States oil and gas properties. The original amount of the note was $900 million.

title: Erv Palica, a Former Pitcher For Brooklyn Dodgers, Dies
description: Erv Palica, a former right-handed pitcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Baltimore Orioles, died of a heart attack Saturday while working as a longshoreman. He was 54 years old.

title: AUTHORS AT CONVENTION BEG EDITORS TO BUY MANUSCRIPTS
description: The doors of the Anaheim Convention Center had been open less than two hours when Jackie Farber, editor in chief of Delacorte Press, knew it was going to be a long day. ''I've already had three people thrust their manuscripts at me,'' she said.

title: Southern Biotech To Reorganize
description: Southern Biotech Inc. filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in Federal court here, listing liabilities of $1.4 million.

title: Accounts
description: * Stride-Rite Shoes to Humphrey Browning MacDougall for its Sperry Top-Sider.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 2, 1982; Companies
description: Pabst, itself a takeover target of two other brewers, is seeking 49 percent of Olympia Brewing for $35.56 million. The announcement startled the financial community. It also came as a surprise to Olympia, which said its board would probably discuss the offer today. Pabst is the fifth-largest brewer, and Olympia is No.8. (Page D1.)

title: A Voice in Mideast Is Urged for Moscow
description: Foreign Minister Fuad Butros of Lebanon said today that the United States must accept a role for the Soviet Union in solving his country's crisis, the Iran-Iraq war and the Palestinian problem.

title: 53 South Koreans Are Killed In Crash of a Military Plane
description: A South Korean C-123 military transport plane crashed on takeoff near Seoul today, killing all 53 people aboard, the Defense Ministry said.

title: EX-SCHOOL BOARD HEAD DENIES STEALING
description: The former chairman of Community School Board 3, on Manhattan's Upper West Side, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he stole about $3,000 from the board.

title: PALME'S REPORT
description: It is difficult to expect that any document that is the work of a group of diplomats representing the East, West and the third world will end up other than mealy-mouthed and inconsequential - something less than the sum of its parts. Yet this is not true of the report of Olof Palme's Independent Commission on Disarmament and Security Issues.

title: CORRECTION
description: A music note in Arts and Leisure Sunday gave an incorrect location for the concert performance of the Lat- vian national folk opera ''Banuta'' on Saturday at 2 P.M. It will be at Carne- gie Hall.

title: DEAL ON DEFICIT REACHED BY CITY AND A.S.P.C.A.
description: New York City has conditionally agreed to make up most of the deficit the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals would incur in providing services for the city this year.

title: Economic Scene; A Quiet Crisis For the West
description: LONDON With more than three million people out of work and the jobless rate at 12.6 percent, Britain is experiencing the highest unemployment since the Great Depression. But if Britain, along with the other capitalist democracies of the West, is undergoing a new crisis of the economic system, it is a remarkably quiet one.

title: Cabanas Out Again
description: For nine months, Roberto Cabanas waited for his injured back to heal so that he could return to midfield for the Cosmos.

title: COAST POLICE CHIEF REPRIMANDED FOR REMARK
description: The Board of Police Commissioners today officially reprimanded Police Chief Daryl Gates for his published statement that police chokeholds may affect some blacks differently than they affect "normal people."

title: OUR PARTY-BLIND FOREIGN SERVICE OFFICERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Envoy's Son, 6, Freed After 5 Hours in Safe
description: The 6-year-old son of a member of the Malaysian Mission to the United Nations was rescued by the police last night from a room safe in the mission, about five hours after the boy accidentally locked himself inside. The father was at work in the mission's offices, which are on the 30th floor of 666 Third Avenue, when the boy, Abdullah Azlan, swung the huge safe door shut at about 5 P.M., the police said.

title: Emons Offers Plan on Debt
description: Emons Industries, which rents railroad freight cars, submitted a debt restructuring plan yesterday to its institutional creditors.

title: COURT BARS DROPPING AIR-BAG RULE FOR AUTOS
description: A three-judge Federal appeals panel today temporarily blocked the Reagan Administration's decision to drop a rule requiring air bags or other automatic crash protection on new automobiles.

title: MCI Plans Filing For Cellular Radio
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said today that it planned to file for cellular radio franchises in 12 metropolitan areas, thus becoming the first major company to indicate its strategy for entering the field of improved mobile and portable telephone service.

title: Steel Output Down
description: Steel production fell to 1.365 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 6.8 percent from the previous week's 1.464 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 46.1 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 49.4 percent in the previous week. Production so far this year used 57.3 percent of capacity, compared with 85.1 percent a year earlier.

title: ANDREW J. MCDERMOTT JR.
description: Andrew J. McDermott Jr., a vice president in charge of advertising for the First Boston Corporation, the investment bankers, died Monday night at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 61 years old, and lived in Manhattan.

title: Grand Union Plan
description: The Grand Union Company said today that it planned to spend $700 million during the next six years, including $120 million in the year ending March 1983, to renovate and enlarge existing supermarkets into full-service food markets. The company said a three-year experiment with the fullservice concept had been extremely successful. In the 53-week year ended April 3, Grand Union said it had closed 150 supermarkets at a cost of $8.24 million.

title: Regulation of Agents Backed
description: The travel agency business should not be deregulated, an administrative law judge said today in a recommendation to the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: GAP ON FREE AGENTS
description: After the first day of joint meetings between representatives of the players and the owners in the National Hockey League, the two sides remained far apart on free agency, the key issue in the contract negotiations.

title: Key Evidence Missing In Pornography Trial
description: Several films and magazines ruled ''obscene'' by an Idaho judge, key evidence in a trial involving two adult bookstores, have been stolen, lost or borrowed while under the care of the United States Supreme Court, The Idaho State Journal has reported.

title: Franc Off After Mitterrand Devaluation Comment
description: France's battered franc has come under renewed pressure on foreign-exchange markets following President Francois Mitterrand's surprising acknowledgement that he may be forced to devalue the currency for the second time since taking office a year ago.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ

title: 76er OWNER IS CONSPICUOUS
description: During the seventh game of the recent Philadelphia 76er-Boston Celtic series, Harold Katz, the owner of the 76ers, sat behind his team's bench. His facial expression appeared to change with every basket, rebound and turnover.

title: Warner-Lambert
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said it had sold the vision care and industrial safety business of its American Optical subsidiary to a company controlled by M.J.Cunniffe and R.S. Wood of Greenwich, Conn. It did not disclose the terms. Warner-Lambert said it would retain the use of the American Optical trademark for five years in connection with the marketing of scientific and ophthalmic instruments and fiber optic devices, which are not being divested.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alfa Resources Inc. said it had incorporated a wholly owned subsidiary, Granite Alpha Corp. for the primary purpose of raising drilling funds through the sale of limited partnership interests.

title: A POSTWAR ROLE IN THE FALKLANDS STUDIED AT U.N.
description: Persuaded that a cease-fire is almost impossible, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has begun considering the United Nations' role in the Falkland Islands after the Argentine collapse, the Secretary General's aides said today.

title: Pirates 3, Dodgers 1
