description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - John Candelaria and two relievers combined on a five-hitter, and Bill Madlock hit a two-run homer for Pittsburgh. Madlock's home run, his fifth of the season, came in the first inning off Jerry Reuss (5-5), who lost his fourth game in his last five decisions.

title: Advertising; J.W.T.  After Luisi Episode
description: JUST before he decided to become an ad agency executive, Walter J. O'Brien of Illinois wanted to be a football coach. And now as president and chief operating officer of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., he has figuratively got the team in the locker room after the first half and is telling it: ''We are a good agency. We are leaders. Our aim is to be No.1 in ideas and to increase our share of market in the U.S.A.''

title: BALLET: TETLEY'S 'VOLUNTARIES'
description: GLEN TETLEY'S ''Voluntaries'' is as smooth as butter. In fact, there is such a sameness of choreographic texture to this abstraction to Poulenc's Concerto for Organ, Strings and Percussion that the ballet is more monotonous than it ought to be, given the lush score's everchanging moods.

title: Fazal Elahi Dies at 78; Pakistani Ex-President
description: Fazal Elahi, former President of Pakistan, died today of a heart ailment, his family said. He was 78 years old.

title: WEST IRIAN: WEAK PRECEDENT FOR THE FALKLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Donaldson Dispute
description: Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, the investment bankers, said yesterday that it had made no provision for loss in its financial statements regarding a dispute with Los Angeles County. But the company added that it ''fully expects to collect the $13.5 million balance owed by the county, plus out-of-pocket costs and consequential damages caused by the actions of the county and its agents.''

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The doctor makes rounds every morning just after 8. On a recent morning it is the elephants he sees first, because they have salmonellosis.

title: Lockheed Plans Stock Redemption
description: The Lockheed Corporation has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to call for the redemption of all 623,714 shares of its $11.25 convertible preferred stock.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., has elected Albert J. Costello group vice president, and appointed Darryl D. Fry president of the Agricultural division.

title: JAYS BEAT YANKS ON 4-RUN 8th, 5-2
description: Rich Gossage will not choose the Yankees' game with Toronto tonight as one of the highlights of his season. The Blue Jays erupted for four runs against Shane Rawley and Gossage in the eighth inning and defeated the Yankees for the third straight time, 5-2.

title: Norfolk Southern
description: The consolidation of the Norfolk & Western Railway and the Southern Railway became official today, creating an 18,000-mile system under the name the Norfolk Southern Corporation.

title: A Gift to Help Sick Children
description: A check for $1.4 million was presented to the New York-Cornell Medical Center yesterday by the Warner Communications Company. The donation, the largest gift the hospital has ever received from a corporation, will be used to build a center for children receiving long-term care.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 24-year-old off-duty probationary police officer was shot in the back yesterday when he tried to run away from two holdup men who had apparently followed him from a check-cashing store in East Harlem. The victim, Ronald Simpson, was taken to Metropolitan Hospital for surgery where his condition was listed as satisfactory.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 16.00 16.00 20.00 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 13.72 13.38 19.45 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.02 11.59 15.50 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.05 11.75 14.42 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 14.06 13.86 13.71 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 13.61 13.45 13.10 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 16.01 15.76 14.77 MUNICIPAL BONDS 13.30 13.21 11.24 6-MONTH SAVINGS 12.172 CERTIFICATES** * Split rate, 16.00-16.50 ** Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A 23-Year Wait for Ex-Jockey
description: Mike Kay was explaining why he is so careful and patient with the thoroughbreds he trains. ''They're like wounds,'' he said. ''You just have to wait and wait while they heal up a little every day.'' If Kay can send out Illuminate to win the Belmont Stakes Saturday afternoon, it will be the end of a long, long wait - 23 years, seven months and 29 days.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Wednesday incorrectly identified the liver disorders that a 1973 Food and Drug Administration study linked to the use of Ilosone, an antibiotic marketed by Eli Lilly & Company. The drug's use was linked to increased incidence of inflammatory reaction and jaundice.

title: RAW SHELLFISH: HOW RISKY IS IT?
description: FOR those who love to eat fresh, briny oysters or sweet, succulent clams on the half shell with nothing but a squeeze of lemon juice - and there are many - warnings about the hazards of raw shellfish from experts like Dr. Donald Francis usually go unheeded. Dr. Francis, assistant director of the hepatitis division of the Centers for Disease Control, says, ''In general, one should not eat uncooked animal flesh.'' But even Dr. Francis admits that when scientists from his laboratory go to a city to investigate an outbreak of hepatitis from shellfish, ''They always bring a lot of them back to eat.''

title: CONGRESSMAN WARNS EL SALVADOR
description: Representative Peter A. Peyser said today that economic and military assistance to El Salvador should be withheld until there was a ''satisfactory conclusion'' to that country's investigation into the murders of four American churchwomen there in December 1980.

title: ELECTRIC RICE COOKER
description: RICE is an utterly basic dish, yet it can often be spoiled by being overcooked or served cold. These pitfalls can be avoided if you have an electric steam cooker that not only cooks the rice and turns off once it is done but, and this is a boon for dinner parties, will also keep it warm for several hours without turning it mushy.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt AMERICAN JOURNEY. Traveling With Tocqueville in Search of Democracy in America. By Richard Reeves. 399 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: O'Reilly Testifies
description: Terry O'Reilly of the Boston Bruins, whom the National Hockey League suspended indefinitely after he failed to appear at a disciplinary hearing May 7, did make his appearance yesterday, testifying for 90 minutes in Montreal before Brian O'Neill, the league's executive vice president. O'Neill said afterward that he would make no announcement until today or tomorrow as to what punishment he'll impose on O'Reilly for striking Referee Andy van Hellemond in a playoff game against Quebec a month ago. ... As expected, the Calgary Flames signed Bob Johnson to a three-year contract as head coach.

title: 1. Windowsill Herb Kit
description: What gift for weekend hosts this summer? If they have a windowsill and cook with herbs, they might enjoy a kit that comes in an attractive green and white shopping bag and holds everything needed for growing a quartet of herbs. There are four small pots and saucers, a miniature trowel, seeds for parsley, sage, rosemary and thyme and peat pellets to start them in, as well as recipe cards for herbed dishes, a green ballpoint pen and a pad of shopping lists to hang in the kitchen. The Green Thumbs Kitchen Garden kit is $15 in Saks Fifth Avenue's stationery shop at 10 East 50th Street.

title: MARTIAL LAW TURNS CRACOW INTO HOTBED OF APATHY
description: ''Curfew? There's no curfew here,'' a Cracow intellectual said. ''The general situation here differs from Warsaw. It's more sedate. The authorities on the whole are quieter.''

title: REAGAN MEETS REPUBLICAN CHIEFS
description: The House of Representatives returns Wednesday from a brief holiday to try to salvage the wreckage of the 1983 budget.

title: HAZARDS OF NEW YORK FIN FISH
description: Shellfish from waters in New York State may be safer to eat than the state's freshwater fin fish. The state Department of Health has issued an advisory periodically since 1976 warning people not to eat more than one meal per week of fish taken from the state's fresh waters.

title: NEW BILLS PLANNED
description: Legislative leaders in both houses announced plans today to approve measures that would restore virtually all of the programs Governor Carey vetoed two months ago.

title: SMITH, BOXING PROMOTER, IS GIVEN 10-YEAR SENTENCE IN BANK FRAUD
description: Harold Rossfields Smith, the former boxing promoter, was sentenced today to 10 years in prison for participating in one of the nation's largest bank embezzlement schemes.

title: Greece and Zimbabwe Reach Accord on Aid
description: Greece has agreed to provide Zimbabwe with economic, tourist and trade assistance in agreements signed today under a new framework for cooperation between the two countries.

title: DOW OFF 4.57 IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market declined moderately yesterday in slow trading, with concern over interest rates continuing to inhibit investors. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout the session, fell 4.57 points, to 814.97. Yesterday was the 12th trading day in the last 14 in which the Dow fell.

title: TAX POLICY EXPERT
description: Dan Throop Smith, one of the nation's leading tax experts and the principal architect of the present Internal Revenue Code, died Saturday at Stanford University Medical Center in Stanford, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: THE SYNTAX OF FOOD ADDS SPICE TO LANGUAGE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Anthony Burgess, the British novelist, is author, most recently, of ''Earthly Powers'' (Simon & Schuster). By ANTHONY BURGESS MONTE CARLO, Monaco IT never takes long, when discussing drink or food, to realize the inevitability of drawing on the French language. Many people in Britain or America only properly meet French on menus or in the cookery books of Julia Child, which means that, for them, the language is circumscribed by the kitchen. What they consider to be the elegance or exactitude of French is derived from the memory of palatal events that can be renewed, either in Paris or in the dining room of a neat professorial home in New Hampshire. French dishes, like pieces of music, can be performed with only minor mutations of tempo and dynamic (read, if you wish, seasoning). The Empress Josephine, while still living in the Antilles, offered visitors from France classic Parisian dishes adapted to the climate and the availability of herbs and spices unknown to France: these, so strict is French naming, could not be called what she called them. She might have cooked a chicken in red wine, but it was not really coq au vin.

title: Track Star Is Sentenced To Life Term for Rape
description: A Criminal Court judge imposed a prison term of life and 60 years today on Adrian Ward, a 20-year-old Villanova University track star convicted of the rape of a 40-year-old woman.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON: 'WEAKEST OF THE LOT' POISED FOR RECOVERY
description: Like its major competitors in the depressed global market for farm equipment, Massey-Ferguson Ltd. of Toronto has reeled from one crisis to another in recent years. In a bid to stay solvent in the face of accumulated losses of $834.4 million since 1978, it has slashed its worldwide work force by nearly half, ruthlessly pared away nonperforming assets and gone hat in hand to its lenders and various governments for bailout financing.

title: BRITAIN REPORTS SEIZING KEY HILLS OUTSIDE STANLEY
description: British forces have seized vital high ground about 10 miles west of Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, after only moderate fighting, military sources said tonight.

title: Westchester Takes More in Sales Tax
description: The sales tax rose today in many communities in Westchester County.

title: Tiffany Near End Of Agency Search
description: The new management at Tiffany & Company, headed by Anthony D. Ostron, president, is close to deciding on a new agency after months of searching.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AS a professional chef, I have always been puzzled by one trait of American home cooks. In their own kitchens they tend to look with disdain at the various meats referred to as ''variety meats'' or, less elegantly, as ''innards'' - kidneys and sweetbreads, brains and the like. Yet when visiting a French restaurant, they will eat them with great relish.

title: PUBLICATION CUTBACKS SPUR PROTESTS
description: A mother-to-be found that the Department of Health and Human Services could not give her a free copy of ''Infant Care,'' a book that the agency has distributed without charge for 58 years.

title: Article 178507 -- No Title
description: Wine fanciers and investors spent $604,065 at the annual Heublein rare wine auction here last week, including a record-breaking $13,000 for a jeroboam of 1929 Chateau Mouton-Rothschild. The total sales were the second highest in the 14-year history of the auction, according to its sponsor.

title: E.E.C. Inflation Rate
description: The consumer price index for the 10 countries of the European Economic Community rose 1.2 percent in April, compared with an increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent in March and 1.6 percent in April 1981, the Common Market statistics office said today.

title: 50% FEWER U.S. CATHOLIC PRIESTS SEEN BY 2000
description: The shortage of priests in the Roman Catholic Church, a growing problem worldwide for a decade, will soon reach crisis proportions in the United States, researchers say. Their figures indicate that the Catholic Church in this country will have 50 percent fewer active clergymen by the end of the century than it has today.

title: ELECTRIC CAR IS ACCUSED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused Jet Industries and the Electric Car Company of America, San Antonio-based manufacturers of electric-powered vehicles, of numerous violations of the antifraud and reporting provisions of the Federal securities laws.

title: Stone Retires
description: Steve Stone of the Baltimore Orioles, who has been hampered by arm problems since winning the American League's Cy Young Award in 1980 with a 25-7 record, announced his retirement yesterday. Stone, 34 years old, had been on the disabled list since March 21 with tendinitis in his right elbow and shoulder. He had a 4-7 mark in 1981 and was 107-93 over all.

title: ARGENTINA VERIFIES LOSS OF RIDGES NEAR STANLEY
description: Argentine military officers said British forces captured two hilltops today from Argentine troops in fierce fighting west of Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands.

title: One Easy Point Off Interest Rates
description: Have sky-high interest rates stopped you from buying a home or investing in a business? Join the frustrated crowd. The price of money may be America's hottest political issue, overshadowing even unemployment.

title: India and Pakistan Agree to Revive Talks
description: India and Pakistan agreed today to resume talks on a nonaggression pact. The Pakistan Foreign Ministry said the decision to resume talks that broke down three months ago was made during a visit here by an envoy of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Cominco Sale Set
description: Cominco Ltd. said that its subsidiary, Cominco American Inc., had agreed to sell oil and gas properties for $31 million to an unnamed buyer.

title: President Is Leaving Polygram Corporation
description: Harvey L. Schein is leaving the posts of president and chief executive officer of the Polygram Corporation, the company announced yesterday in Culver City, Calif.

title: HIGH COURT LETS STAND NEW YORK RULING ALLOWING TOPLESS BARS
description: The United States Supreme Court today let stand a ruling by New York State's highest court that a ban on topless entertainment was unconstitutional under the free-speech provisions of the state's Constitution.

title: Mercantile Merger Trail
description: Mercantile House Holdings, the London-based firm that is taking over Wall Street's Oppenheimer & Co., traces its history to 1868, when the son of a chief cashier of the Bank of England founded the partnership of Marshall & Son.

title: LAKERS ROUT 76ers FOR 2-1 LEAD
description: After hitting only three of his 16 shots from the floor in the second game of the National Basketball Association championship series on Sunday, Norm Nixon, the Laker guard, muttered something about the Philadelphia guard Maurice Cheeks hitting him on the elbow while he was shooting.

title: Egypt Raises Crude Price
description: Egypt, reacting to evidence that a worldwide oil glut is disappearing, raised its crude price yesterday by 60 cents a barrel, to $32.60. It thus became the third oil producer to raise prices in the past week.

title: RUSSIANS SKEPTICAL ON ARMS TALKS
description: Senator Larry Pressler said today that he found ''a great deal of skepticism'' about the prospects for a new strategic arms agreement when he met with the Soviet official who will head the Soviet delegation to the talks in Geneva.

title: CAT SCANS SAID TO SHOW SHRUNKEN HINCKLEY BRAIN
description: A defense radiologist showed CAT scan pictures of John W. Hinckley Jr.'s brain to the jury today and testified that they showed his brain to be ''shrunken'' to an unusual degree for a person his age.

title: Judge Won't Free 46 in Hudson Jail
description: A State Supreme Court justice refused to permit the early release today of 46 inmates serving time for disorderly-person offenses at the overcrowded Hudson County Jail, pending a decision by the full court.

title: FILMWAYS NARROWS 4TH-QUARTER LOSS
description: Filmways Inc., a diversified entertainment company, said yesterday that it narrowed its loss to $40 million in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1982 from $46 million in the three months a year earlier.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 2, 1982
description: International Further British advances in the Falklands were reported by military sources in London. They said that Royal Marines and paratroopers had seized vital high ground about 10 miles west of the capital of Stanley after only moderate fighting. The sources disclosed the ouster of Argentine soldiers manning small outposts from the summits of 1,504-foot Mount Kent and adjacent hills, from which Stanley is clearly visible in good weather. (Page A1, Column 6.) Argentina said fighting was heavy during the British seizure of strategic hilltops west of Stanley. (A14:1.)

title: HAITIANS SINGLED OUT FOR HARSH TREATMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: IN ANTARCTICA, FOOD KEEPS OUT THE COLD
description: MCMURDO STATION, Antarctica IT was a typical lazy Sunday afternoon here and the chichi crowd in red down parkas and mukluks was making its way over to the biology laboratory to sample Art DeVries's sashimi.

title: Rights Plan Advocates Assail Insurance Rates
description: he National Organization for women said today that the insurance industry profited from sex discrimination and was one of the chief economic interests fighting ratification of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

title: JAMES A. SPENCER
description: James A. Spencer, chairman of the science department at Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, died Monday after suffering a heart attack in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 47.

title: Market Place; Bearish View On Williams
description: The Williams Companies has suffered serious setbacks as a result of the recession. When hard-hit farmers here and abroad drastically reduced fertilizer purchases Williams was left hanging.

title: Georgia Bank Merger
description: The Trust Company of Georgia said today that it had completed its previously announced acquisition of the First National Bank of Athens, Ga., which had assets of $115 million.

title: Base Car Prices Raised by Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company announced it had increased the base vehicle prices of its Mustang GT and Capri RS by $89, or 1.1 percent, raised the prices for optional equipment on some cars, and raised destination and delivery charges.

title: DURERS GOT FOR $450 RETURNED
description: Two 483-year-old paintings by Albrecht Durer, valued at millions, were taken from a safe-deposit vault here yesterday, and the man who bought them 36 years ago for $450 handed them over to an East German museum.

title: STORMS ON EAST COAST DELAY AIRLINE FLIGHTS
description: Airline flights from New England and the South to the New York metropolitan area were delayed by as much as three hours late yesterday because of several storm systems moving across the region, the Federal Aviation Administration reported last night.

title: Rams' Haden Retires
description: After six years, 52 touchdown passes, a couple of broken fingers and assorted threats to his job from other quarterbacks, Pat Haden of the Los Angeles Rams announced his retirement yesterday at the age of 29. Haden starred at Southern California in the early 70's before going to Oxford on a Rhodes scholarship, then joined the Rams in 1976.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Shifts Management
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation yesterday announced a management reorganization designed to refocus its aluminum operations and expand its businesses in chemicals and refractories.

title: CITIES SERVICE ACREAGE IS MAIN LURE FOR MESA
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company has long enjoyed a reputation for unusual success in the tricky business of exploring for oil and gas. If successful in its bid for the Cities Service Company, it will have a lot more acres on which to carry on the hunt.

title: REAGAN OFF ON EUROPEAN TRIP TODAY
description: With recession, sagging opinion polls and a Congressional budget deadlock at home, President Reagan leaves Wednesday for Europe to seek public support there for his arms and arms-control policies, a tougher Western credit stance toward the Soviet Union and more patience with his economic policies.

title: A New Standard for Mr. Smith
description: In giving back a $50,000 corporate director's fee and renouncing even larger benefits from two tax shelters, Attorney General William French Smith belatedly acknowledged that ethical rules should be tougher for public servants than for private citizens. While defending the legality and propriety of the transactions, he correctly observed last week that ''public service often invites the use of an even stricter standard.''

title: CHINESE POLICE HOLD TEACHER FROM U.S. ON SPYING CHARGES
description: An American teacher has been detained by the Chinese authorities on charges of spying, the United States Embassy said today.

title: THE CITY;
description: A 58-year-old Bolivian who said he was a civil attache for his Government in Mexico was ordered held in $1 million bail in Brooklyn yesterday on Federal cocaine-smuggling charges.

title: ACROSS NEW YORK, RACE HORSES FORM A FAST GROWING INDUSTRY
description: From Long Island to the Finger Lakes, New York is experiencing a boom in the breeding and training of race horses. Twenty years ago a dozen horse farms in the state produced 115 thoroughbred foals of indifferent quality. This year 450 breeders in New York are expected to produce 2,500 foals of far higher potential talent, worth many millions of dollars.

title: Chrysler Starts New Promotion
description: The Chrysler Corporation, in a new $2 million sales promotion, is providing cars made by its competitors to help consumers compare between Chrysler cars and competing models, a spokesman for the auto maker said today.

title: BIG OPPENHEIMER DEAL: ITS SALE
description: Oppenheimer & Co., a Wall Street partnership famous for its bold, deal-making moves, has embarked on perhaps the biggest and most lucrative deal in its 32-year history - its own takeover for approximately $162.5 million, payable mostly in cash.

title: Topics; Competition; Pooh and Peace
description: While many observed the Memorial Day weekend by watching the Indy 500, a small group gathered at a western Connecticut riverbank for a more genteel competition: the annual Pooh-sticks race.

title: THE NURSE PRACTITIONER TO THE RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: Now that the British generally believe themselves to be on the verge of recapturing the Falklands, there is a growing national debate about what to do with the disputed islands afterward.

title: AS RAIDERS LOOK SOUTH, OAKLAND FANS FEEL BETRAYED
description: The Oakland Raiders have left a lot of fans here feeling like a wife whose husband has left her for an ugly but rich rival.

title: 'FRIENDLY' MESA OFFER IS REBUFFED
description: The chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, T. Boone Pickens Jr., said yesterday that his $3.8 billion takeover bid for the Cities Service Company had been rejected by Charles J. Waidelich, chairman of Cities Service.

title: SUDANESE CALLS FOR ARAB MEETING, INCLUDING EGYPT, ON IRAN-IRAQ WAR
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan called today for a conference of moderate Arab countries, including Egypt, to try to end the war between Iraq and Iran.

title: SPENDING BY BUILDING DIPS 0.6%
description: Spending on new construction fell sixtenths of 1 percent in April, partly as a result of a sharp drop in municipal spending for highways and streets, the Government reported today.

title: Paper Tells of Kickbacks To Los Angeles Diocese
description: Since 1979 the Archdiocese of Los Angeles has demanded and received a special payment from the nation's largest Roman Catholic textbook publisher, according to The National Catholic Reporter.

title: ANGLO-AMERICAN'S CHIEF ANNOUNCES RESIGNATION
description: Harry F. Oppenheimer, the most powerful and influential figure in the South African corporate world for the last quarter of a century, announced this evening that he was bowing out as chairman of the mammoth Anglo-American Corporation.

title: Crosby Loses To a Briton, 16
description: Nathaniel Crosby, the United States Amateur golf champion, was beaten in the first round of the British Amateur today by 16-year-old David Gilford of England. Crosby, 20, son of the late Bing Crosby, lost the first three holes on his way to a 4-and-3 loss at the Royal Cinque Ports Club.

title: PABST SETS BID FOR 49% OF OLYMPIA
description: The Pabst Brewing Company, already a takeover tarket of two other brewers, startled the financial community yesterday with the announcement that it would seek 49 percent, or 1.3 million shares, of the Olympia Brewing Company for $35.56 million.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Video Amusement Corp., a unit of Jackpot Enterprises Inc., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a sale of 800,000 common shares, to be sold through Rooney Pace Inc.

title: 'TIME FOR DYING,' VINTAGE '69
description: APPARENTLY because of legal problems arising from the death of its producer, Audie Murphy, shortly after the film's completion, Budd Boetticher's ''A Time for Dying,'' made in 1969, is only now having its New York theatrical premiere.

title: Military Analysis
description: The British command in the Falkland Islands faces its toughest decision of the campaign: to take Stanley and its airfield by assault or to surround the area and settle down to a siege.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ONCE AGAIN, ETIQUETTE IS A POPULAR TOPIC
description: Agers,'' the paperback by Walter Hoving first published 21 years ago, is, according to Tiffany, ''suddenly selling like croissants.'' Or that Ivan Brent, director of catering at the Plaza Hotel notes that partygoers of debutante age are ''no longer brown-bagging liquor bottles on the premises or making a mockery of society the way they did a few years ago, but are, instead, once again bowing, being polite and paying attention to tradition.''

title: The U.N. Today; June 2, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: POLICE OFFICERS ARE TEACHING HIGH SCHOOL COURSE ON THE LAW
description: When the new teacher first came to class, the students could not keep their eyes off the pistol he carried. ''The gun was all they wanted to talk about,'' said the teacher, Robert Richards, a police officer who is running a new kind of civics class at Seward Park High School on the Lower East Side.

title: Reed Sidelined
description: The Philadelphia Phillies learned yesterday that Ron Reed, their 39-year-old relief pitcher, cracked a rib during a bench-clearing brawl with the Cincinnati Reds Monday night and would miss at least two weeks. ... Jay Johnstone, released last week by the Los Angeles Dodgers, has signed with the Chicago Cubs. The 36-year-old pinchhitting specialist, who was batting .077 with one hit with the Dodgers, will be playing for his eighth major league team.

title: Connecticut Opens Top Court to TV
description: For the first time in its history, the Connecticut Supreme Court permitted coverage of its proceedings today by television and still cameras and radio microphones.

title: IN ARGENTINA, ABRUPT END TO OPTIMISM
description: The Argentine Government, press and television appeared today to be preparing the Argentine public for a military defeat in the Falkland Islands.

title: High Court Bars Kleindienst
description: Former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, suspended by the Arizona Supreme Court for lying under oath, was suspended today from practice before the United States Supreme Court. The nation's highest court ordered the Tucson, Ariz., lawyer to show within 40 days ''why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.'' Mr. Kleindienst served as Attorney General under President Nixon.

title: SURVEY FINDS DOCTORS TAKE THEIR OWN ADVICE
description: Many physicians do, indeed, practice what they preach, according to a report published here today by The Harvard Medical School Health Letter.

title: Excerpts from report, page A10.
description: A group of international political figures, urging a ''downward turn in the arms spiral,'' today proposed the removal of battlefield nuclear weapons from Central Europe by the end of 1983 as a major step toward disarmament.

title: SAGE LEXICAL ADVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM RATING SYSTEM UNDER NEW FIRE
description: The voluntary movie-rating system of the Hollywood studios has made news again - in two ways that reflect the tensions inherent in trying to protect children, movie grosses and an uncensored society at the same time.

title: A BILL TO RESTORE DEATH PENALTY VOTED IN ALBANY
description: The State Assembly gave final legislative approval tonight to a bill that would restore the death penalty in New York State. But the 81-to-61 vote for the bill was far short of the twothirds majority that would be necessary to override Governor Carey's certain veto.

title: Indians Win 9th In Row
description: Ron Davis walked Karl Pagel, a pinch-hitter, with the bases loaded in the eighth inning to force home the goahead run, and Andre Thornton belted a three-run homer to spark the Cleveland Indians to a 6-4 victory tonight over the Minnesota Twins.

title: LAWRENCE H. LIPSKIN
description: Lawrence H. Lipskin, former head of advertising and publicity for Columbia Pictures and Columbia International, died Saturday at University Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: CHELSEA PROGRAM OPENS JOYCE THEATER FOR DANCE
description: Somehow the stage curtain got hung, the mirrors went up in the warmup studio and the floor and stage were cleared of debris in time for the opening last night of the Joyce Theater in the Chelsea neighborhood.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When a legitimate search is under way, nice distinctions between closets, drawers and containers, in the case of a home, or between glove compartments, upholstered seats, trunks and wrapped packages, in the case of a vehicle, must give way to the interest in the prompt and efficient completion of the task at hand.'' -Justice John Paul Stevens. (B6:2.)

title: Steel From Japan
description: Four Japanese steelmakers have agreed to export a total of 33,200 tons of specialty steel products to the Soviet Union in the third quarter, industry sources said today. The terms were not disclosed. The companies are the Daido Steel Company, Aichi Steel Works, the Mitsubishi Steel Manufacturing Company and the Sanyo Specialty Steel Company.

title: MISSOURI BEAN FARMER, HERO OF DRIVE FOR A NEW BANKRUPTCY LAW, IS FREED
description: A Missouri farmer who had been in jail here since April 28 was released today when a Federal bankruptcy judge said his confinement would serve no further purpose.

title: Decision File; A Last Gesture From the I.R.S.
description: As a sort of grand finale for the tax season, the Internal Revenue Service has whipped up its ''deterrent publicity effort,'' according to Roderic Young, a spokesman for the agency.

title: Tuition Dodge
description: The issue of tuition tax credits for private schools keeps reappearing.

title: A NORTHERNER'S WAY WITH SOUL FOOD
description: WHEN Laura Sandifer entertains company for dinner, she might prepare a parsleyed rack of lamb or venison stew at a formal dinner in her New York apartment or a whole shell steak on the grill at a more casual meal in her home in Sag Harbor, L.I. Afterward, she is invariably asked, ''Laura, next time, can't we please have soul food?''

title: Dish Wars
description: The satellite wars are escalating. Not among hostile nations, but telecommunications companies.

title: INDUSTRY COOL TO CANADA ENERGY PLAN
description: Canada's oil and gas industry reacted with skepticism today to a $2 billion federal tax relief package designed to revive lagging investment and exploration activity.

title: Gannett Buys 11 Newspapers
description: The Gannett Company said yesterday that it had completed its previously announced acquisition of 11 newspapers in central and southern Mississippi from the Hederman family of Jackson, Miss. The purchase includes daily, weekly and Sunday newspapers.

title: SHUTTLE'S GLOW CALLED OBSTACLE TO SOME TESTS
description: As the space shuttle Columbia passed through the ionosphere on its third mission last March, it caused a variety of surprising lighting and electronic effects.

title: UNLIKELY DEATH KNELL FOR THE MX MISSILE
description: To the Editor:

title: On Disinheriting the P.L.O.
description: Surrogate Marie Lambert, whose Manhattan court administers estates valued at more than $1 billion a year, is making good on her campaign pledge to spice her work with ethnic politics. She vowed in 1977 to keep funds entrusted to her care away from banks that supported the Arab boycott of Israel. It was an injudicious promise, extraneous to any qualifications for her office, but it probably helped her win. Now she is using her court to stage a legal dogfight over a private bequest to the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Trade Tensions Cited by GATT
description: The council that oversees the worldwide observance of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said today that it had examined a record number of charges and countercharges of unfair trade practices in 1981.

title: Talks on DeLorean
description: One of the official receivers for the DeLorean sports car company, Sir Kenneth Cork, held talks with financiers believed to be contemplating taking over the concern, financial sources said today. No details of the discussions were available.

title: THE MEMBERS OF THE PANEL
description: The Independent Commission on Disarmament and Security Issues was established in 1980. It took as its model the Brandt Commission on development problems, a group headed by former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany. That commission had some success last year when 22 leaders of industrialized and developing nations met in Cancun, Mexico.

title: REAGAN'S GRAND TOUR
description: Ronald Reagan is off on the most spectacular Grand Tour of Europe since Woodrow Wilson led the victorious Allies to a disappointing peace conference at Versailles at the end of World War I.

title: Champagne in Cooking
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In her review of my book ''Kitchen Science'' (''A Spate of Books on Cooking Technique,'' May 5), Florence Fabricant wrote that I referred to Champagne as ''a third-rate wine.'' Because I love to drink Champagne and wouldn't want that noble beverage to be slighted, I feel compelled to set the record straight.

title: NASDAQ STARTS ITS NEW QUOTE SYSTEM
description: Last-sale and high-and-low price quotations on 49 actively traded over-the-counter stocks became available to the public yesterday, with the start of a new system established by the National Association of Securities Dealers. Formerly only bid and asked quotations were made public.

title: Layoffs by Kaiser
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said it had laid off 400 more workers at its steel facilities here because of depressed conditions in the industry, bringing the total on layoff to 2,000. Separately in Calgary, Alberta, McIntyre Mines Ltd. said it was laying off 220 employees at its Smoky River coal operations in Alberta because of reduced coal sales and excessive inventory.

title: ELEANOR DANA, 74, PHILANTHROPIST
description: Eleanor Naylor Dana, a philanthropist and New York social leader whose personal wealth amounted to more than $50 million, died Sunday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center after a long illness. She was 74 years old and lived on Park Avenue.

title: Bridge:; Kaplan Team Is Defeated In the Reisinger Knockout
description: A star team was on the sidelines yesterday after the first two rounds of the Reisinger knockout team championship at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: BRIEFING
description: Justice at the Ready

title: THE POP LIFE
description: THERE isn't much agreement these days on what is and isn't folk music, so how does one define folk-rock? In the mid-1960's, things were simpler. Folk-rock was what happened when a musician who had been singing personal or topical or traditional songs in folk clubs traded in his acoustic guitar for an electric model and hired a backup band. That was the route Bob Dylan took to fame and fortune, and the Byrds, the Youngbloods and other bands led by former folk singers followed in his wake.

title: TV: 'THE SHOOTING,' CHILDREN'S SPECIAL
description: THIS afternoon at 4:30, the CBS Afternoon Playhouse, a showcase for children's specials, is offering a somewhat unfocused little drama called ''The Shooting.'' An apparent effort to be mysterious ends up as largely mystifying.

title: WHY A BRITISH PENSION FUND INVESTS IN U.S. PROPERTY
description: Wendy Luscombe is in charge of a $400 million portfolio of American properties for the British Coal Board pension fund, one of the largest pension funds in Europe. She speaks so softly that it is often difficult to hear her, but her message rings clear.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Farmers' Markets Open

title: HIGH COURT WIDENS SEARCH AUTHORITY
description: The Supreme Court today expanded police authority to conduct searches of automobiles without warrants, ruling, 6 to 3, that if the police have ''probable cause'' to search a car without a warrant, they may also search luggage or packages that they find inside.

title: Law Requiring Firearms Challenged by A.C.L.U.
description: A law requiring a firearm in every home in this small Georgia town took effect today and was immediately challenged in Federal District Court by the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AS they travel to ever more far-off and exotic places, more and more Americans are acquiring exotic infections and other unfamiliar ailments along with their out-of-the-way experiences. You certainly don't want to spend days confined to a hotel holding your head or stomach while fellow travelers see the sights. Nor do you want to pick up something abroad that will strike when you get home and back to work.

title: Woolworth Picks Chief For New Clothing Chain
description: The concept is fairly new in retailing: a big company creates a chain of stores to sell brand-name clothing at a price cheaper than at regular retailers.

title: CAMPAIGNING INTENSIFIES IN SENATE RACE IN JERSEY
description: From shopping centers in North Jersey to centers for the elderly in the south, the candidates for the United States Senate nominations in New Jersey campaigned vigorously today. And with just one week remaining before the primary elections, they seemed to have settled on the strategies they hoped would carry them to victory.

title: N.F.L. Calls Lockout Unlikely
description: It appears that there will be training camps and an exhibition season in the National Football League this summer, even if a new collective bargaining agreement is not reached.

title: Israeli-Egyptian Talks Fail to Break Impasse
description: A meeting between Israeli and Egyptian leaders failed today to resolve the two countries' differences over the site of future negotiations on Palestinian autonomy.

title: Namibian Rebel Leader Rejects New Proposals
description: Sam Nujoma, leader of the South-West Africa People's Organization, said today that he had rejected new Western ideas on elections put to him during talks here.

title: Dismissed City Worker Held in Attack on Mayor
description: A former worker at the municipal sewage plant was accused today of invading the home of Mayor A.J. Rumely, shooting and critically wounding him and killing his wife.

title: Techology; Drafting On a Computer
description: pens and pencils, ink, templates, rulers, even the oldfashioned drawing board. Instead, these are being gradually replaced by computer-assisted drafting equipment as the revolution in computer-aided design, or CAD, continues to spread from early applications in aerospace and electronics engineering. The expansion has been accompanied by a steady decline in the price of basic CAD systems and the appearance of new suppliers.

title: Kallestad Labs To Be Acquired
description: Kallestad Laboratories Inc., which makes chemicals, biological substances and other materials used in diagnostic testing, said that it had agreed to be acquired by a subsidiary of a European company in a transaction valued at $75 million.

title: WHAT A TRUE GENTRIFIER IS AND DOES
description: To the Editor:

title: Media General to Buy William B. Tanner Co.
description: Media General of Richmond, owner of newspapers as well as broadcasting and cable TV companies, is planning to acquire for cash the William B. Tanner Company, a 20-year-old Memphis media buying outfit that is widely regarded as the largest barter operator.

title: Carter Hawley Outlook Brightens
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. expects to have a ''strong recovery'' from a weak performance in the first half and is forecasting a ''respectable'' gain in earnings for the full year, Philip M. Hawley, president and chief executive officer, said at the annual meeting in Los Angeles.

title: A DEALER IN PENNY STOCKS VOLUNTARILY CLOSES IN DENVER
description: OTC Net Inc., a major over-the-counter dealer, closed its doors on Tuesday, the ninth firm in Denver's once thriving penny stock market to do so in recent months, and the biggest to date.

title: THE PRIVATE WORLD OF A GREAT GARDENER
description: ''Part of creating is understanding that there is always more to do; nothing is ever completely finished,'' says Rachel Lambert Mellon, whose landscape designs grace such varied places as The White House, Jacqueline Onassis' summer home on Martha's Vineyard and Hubert de Givenchy's Manoir du Jonchet in France.

title: Boycott Continues
description: A court order to end the horsemen's boycott at Arlington Park was dissolved by a judge Tuesday, forcing the cancellation of a second straight racing program today.

title: SALVADOR VOTE INFLATED, STUDY IS SAID TO FIND
description: In a study to be released next week, a team of researchers at the Jesuit-administered Central American University in El Salvador are to charge that fraud was perpetrated in that country's March 28 election for the new Constituent Assembly, with at least the knowledge of the United States Government.

title: Shake-Up at Kenai Laid To 'Policy Differences'
description: The Kenai Corporation, a contract-drilling and oilfield equipment and services company, has been going through a management dispute that has resulted in the resignation of Michael R. Green, its executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: CONNECTICUT'S PRISON SYSTEM HIRES 'RESIDENT' PHILOSOPHER
description: David G. Lovell will begin serving 10 months in Connecticut state prisons next September, enough time to think about many things - empirical and theoretical.

title: Nixon Remark Draws Laugh From Kennedy
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon's remark that Senator Edward M. Kennedy needs to lose 20 pounds if he wants to have a chance to win the 1984 Presidential race got a laugh today from the Massachusetts Democrat.

title: RACIST WHO KILLED 2 INDICTED IN SHOOTING OF VERNON JORDAN
description: Joseph Paul Franklin, an avowed racist convicted of two murders in Salt Lake City, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge of shooting Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the civil rights leader.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Madison Square Garden's Hall of Fame inducted 10 new members yesterday, among them Dick McGuire, a seven-time N.B.A. all-star who is now the Knicks' chief scout. The others inducted were Dave DeBusschere (basketball), George Mikan (basketball), Jean Beliveau (hockey), Harrison Dillard (track), Edward King (horse shows), Frank McGuire (basketball), Beau Jack (boxing), Ed Mosler Jr. (sports philanthropist) and the late Arthur Daley, who had been a sports columnist for The New York Times. ... Franz Beckenbauer, the 36-year-old soccer star who formerly played for the Cosmos, appeared in his final game Tuesday, scoring a goal for Hamburg in a 4-2 loss to the West German national team.

title: Rebel Nest Crushed, Afghanistan Says
description: Afghanistan said today that its troops had wiped out a key rebel stronghold near Kabul, contradicting guerrillas' reports they had scored a major victory in the area.

title: MINORITY BALANCE OF CITY'S TEACHERS IS ASSAILED BY U.S.
description: The Federal Department of Education has found that New York City's Board of Education has failed to comply with an agreement to improve the balance of minority teachers in the city's public schools.

title: The U.N. Today; June 3, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 11 A.M. on the Falklands. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MONEY FUNDS: A NEW PLATEAU
description: In only a decade, money market mutual funds have captured the fancy, and the savings, of millions of Americans. When the latest figures are announced today, the money funds - more than 165 in all - are expected to pass the $200 billion mark in total assets, up from $10 billion at the end of 1978 and $74 billion at the end of 1980.

title: LIBERAL STUDY FINDS REAGAN LACKING
description: Americans for Democratic Action may have less influence than it once did, but at least the liberal organization is consistent.

title: Advertising; Selling the Excitement Of Gaming
description: NEITHER New York State nor Pennsylvania allow casino gambling but they do supply most of the people who go to Atlantic City to enjoy it and the only nearby television stations to advertise it.

title: Douglas Ruhe
description: President of Focus Communications in Nashville, which operates subscription television station in Chicago and has licenses pending in Nashville and Norfolk ... in communications for 13 years ... reporter, in television production, public relations and satellite teleconferences ... 38 years old ... holds master's degree from University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Len R. Small

title: AN OFFICE MAKES ROOM FOR BABY
description: shingled Colonial-style house at 4 Randy Road here to suggest that it is what the futurists call an electronic cottage. Look inside and you will find a roomful of razzle-dazzle office machines and a brave new baby named Lauren.

title: Police in Texas Burglarized
description: Thieves broke into the locker room of the police station here today and stole pistols, ammunition, flak jackets and other equipment, officers reported. Police Chief Robert Heuck refused to discuss the details of the burglary. ''This is just Round 1,'' he said.

title: GLASSBLOWER FORGES DELICATE SEA FORMS
description: In his show at Cowles Gallery a year ago, Dale Chihuly's glass achieved a translucent, gossamer delicacy equal to that of the famous filigree glass of 16th-century Venice. His blown sea forms seemed so fragile that they might collapse at a breath. But his work had made such a positive artistic statement that he could have given up glass entirely and still be remembered for those exquisite pieces.

title: MURDER AND RAPE SUSPECT SEIZED
description: A suspect was seized last night in the murder of one woman and the rape of another in a South Bronx tenement on March 25, the police said.

title: STAGE: 'WITH LOVE AND LAUGHTER,' A COLLAGE
description: ''WITH LOVE AND LAUGHTER,'' at the Harold Clurman Theater, is a collage of poetry, prose and dialogue on the subject of men and women, as delivered by Celeste Holm and Wesley Addy, in real life, wife and husband. As busily directed by Peter Bennett, the selections in the anthology, an uncredited arrrangement, are random and of varying quality. They range from old jokes, demurely delivered by Miss Holm, to a male chauvinist argument from ''Life With Father,'' with Gordon Connell pretending to be the son of the family.

title: Argo Gets Permit
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it had authorized the Argo Communications Corporation to use a Canadian satellite to provide special business telephone links between several American cities.

title: MUSIC: ZUKERMAN LEADS
description: THERE is a carnival air, sometimes approaching the bacchanalian, that pervades Manhattan streets on any warmish day or night, so any planned festivities can easily be swallowed up in the general huggermugger. Nevertheless, it was clear last night that something beyond the ordinary serenading of pedestrians was going on at Carnegie Hall, if only because a brass quintet and a juggler were holding forth in the middle of a milling throng before the main entrance, and contributions were not being solicited.

title: BIRMINGHAM ROTARY VOTES TO END POLICY THAT BARRED BLACKS
description: The Birmingham Rotary Club voted today to end its policy that barred membership to blacks. More than 200 members of the club attended a weekly meeting and decided by a voice vote that was nearly unanimous to ask the board of directors to change the club's 69-year-old constitution. The Birmingham chapter was one of only a few of the 19,600 Rotary clubs in the nation that restricted membership to white men.

title: BALLET: 'INSPECTOR GENERAL'
description: The ever-increasing number of American and British ballet fans who are arriving in Paris to see Leningrad's Kirov Ballet very obviously have gathered to see the famed Russian company's 19th-century classics.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''One life is more important than anything we can say about life.'' -Elie Wiesel, on postponing genocide conference because of reported Turkish threats against Jews. (A1:6.)

title: Budget Cuts Seen Imperiling U.S. Poison Prevention Effort
description: The Reagan Administration is eroding the ''highly effective'' Federal poisoning prevention program with a combination of funding cuts and staff reductions, the program's director said today.

title: Johncock's Mother Dies Not Knowing He Won
description: Frances Johncock died Monday night without having learned that Gordon Johncock, her son, won the Indianapolis 500 the day before.

title: J. Vincent Fagan, 46, Founder Of the Federal Express Corp.
description: J. Vincent Fagan, a founder of the Federal Express Corporation, died Saturday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 46 years old. Mr. Fagan was an executive with the Aerospace Advance Planning Group in 1968 when it was consolidated into the executive management team operating Federal Express. At his death, he was a consultant to the company, having joined the Bass, Fagan, Taylor Group in New York.

title: Sports of the Times; A League's First Fumble
description: UNTIL yesterday, the new United States Football League had appeared to be gaining some yardage. Well before the start of its first season next March 6, it already had a two-year ABC contract, estimated at $20 million, for the televising of a weekly Sunday game and the entire playoffs through its July 10 championship game. It was also negotiating for Chet Simmons, a longtime TV impresario who constructed the ESPN cable sports network, to be its commissioner. And it had 12 clubs whose owners couldn't wait to throw millions to the wind.

title: MOVE BY URUGUAY WORRIES U.S. AIDES
description: The Uruguayan ejection of a senior American diplomat last week led to speculation that the increasingly warm relations between the Reagan Administration and Montevideo's heavily military Government might be cooling.

title: JUDGES WARN CASE BACKLOG IS INCREASING
description: State court officials said today that despite disputed programs to reduce the backlog of court cases in New York City, the backlog of civil and criminal cases was, in fact, increasing. They warned that the number could rise further unless more judgeships were created.

title: Brewers Dismiss Rodgers
description: Bob (Buck) Rodgers was dismissed today as manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, who have fallen to fifth place. Harvey Kuenn was named interim manager.

title: CHAMBER: AMY BEACH'S MASS
description: ''AROUND THE SQUARE'' continued its scrutiny of America's past Sunday afternoon with music by an important 19th-century woman, Mrs. H.H.A. Beach - or Amy Beach, as she is also known.

title: City Pays Honor To 43 Firefighters
description: On what Fire Commissioner Charles J. Hynes called the most important day of the department's calendar, the heroic acts of 43 firefighters were commemorated yesterday in an awards ceremony.

title: Favored Golden Fleece Captures Epsom Derby
description: Golden Fleece rallied through the stretch today to win the $265,000 Epsom Derby by three lengths. Golden Fleece, the 3-1 favorite, entered the final two furlongs of the race in eighth place in the field of 18.

title: Atom-Free Zone Rejected in Bonn
description: Spokesmen for West Germany's governing and opposition parties today rejected a proposal for a Central European nuclear-free zone made by an independent committee of Eastern and Western political leaders.

title: Weep Not for the Americas
description: The United States' open backing of Britain in the Falkland war was bound to go down poorly in Latin America. But the talk about calamitous harm to hemisphere relations is nonsense. It hasn't happened, and needn't happen.

title: Dow Changes Transport List
description: Rio Grande Industries, a railroad holding company, and the Carolina Freight Carriers Corporation, a trucking company, have been added to the list of 20 companies that make up the Dow Jones transportation average, Dow Jones said yesterday.

title: Floods Ebbing in South China
description: Severe floods that have caused more than 400 deaths in China's southern Guangdong Province appeared to be receding today as thousands of peasants strengthened dikes.

title: STRIKES SWEEP ITALY AFTER WAGE PACT IS ENDED
description: Protest strikes were held throughout Italy today after a decision Tuesday by the principal employers' organization to revoke an accord that for seven years has raised wages automatically as the cost of living mounted.

title: REVUE: 3 WOMEN SING THE 'BLUES IN THE NIGHT'
description: IT all looks so easy. First, you get your hands on a catalogue of classic songs. Then you hire big-voiced performers who are willing to knock themselves out for two hours of nonstop singing. Throw in an on-stage jazz band, a few dance steps, a set - and presto! You have a hit revue like ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' or ''One Mo' Time.''

title: Space Shuttle Tank Is Tested For Ability to Resist the Cold
description: More than 500,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxgyen were loaded aboard the space shuttle Columbia today in a successful test to determine if its external tank would hold up to temperatures far colder than those in space.

title: Carter Hawley
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. expects to have a ''strong recovery'' from a weak performance in the first half and is forecasting a ''respectable'' gain in earnings for the full year, Philip M. Hawley, president and chief executive officer, said at the annual meeting in Los Angeles.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO BAR 500 WHO SEEK VISAS TO U.N. DISARMAMENT PARLEY
description: Disarmament advocates said yesterday that the United States had held up visas for about 500 people who want to attend activities in connection with a special session on disarmament in the United Nations General Assembly. The session starts Monday.

title: STERLING SILVER CRAFT OF STUDENTS ON DISPLAY
description: More than 100 works of sterling silver by college and designschool students around the country are now on display in the lobby area of Lever House, on Park Avenue at 54th Street. The show, which runs through June 23, is part of an annual design competition sponsored for the last 24 years by the Sterling Silversmiths Guild of America, a trade association of manufacturers.

title: BALLET THEATER: 'CARMEN'
description: ODDLY enough, for a ballet of so fundamentally unserious and possibly irretrievable a genre, Roland Petit's ''Carmen'' is becoming one of the most interesting and enjoyable of American Ballet Theater's new acquisitions this season at the Metropolitan Opera House. The company's performance last Saturday night of this bit of French music-hall extravaganza was less convincing than the matinee performance, danced to a kind of sizzling, sexy perfection by Alexander Godunov and Susan Jaffe. But Kevin McKenzie, making his debut as Don Jose in the evening, created a character of unforgettable proportions.

title: DOUBLE STANDARDS
description: Even before what promises to be Britain's stunning military victory in the Falklands war, the British have won as difficult and in the long run perhaps more important a battle - for credibility.

title: Bridge: Upsets and a Controversy Mark Reisinger Knockout
description: Two upsets and one controversy marked third-round play in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship at the New York Hilton Hotel Tuesday night.

title: COUNTRY GARDENER
description: Roses

title: 2 Die in Fireworks Explosion
description: Two persons died after the explosion of materials they were apparently using to make fireworks, officials said. The explosion Monday started a fire in a garage, killing Randy Warren Waldron, 28 years old, and Cheryl Ann Peterson, 21.

title: Olympia Sets Board Meeting
description: The Olympia Brewing Company said yesterday that no statement would be issued regarding the takeover proposal made Tuesday by the Pabst Brewing Company until Olympia's board of directors meets to discuss the offer ''within the next few days.''

title: CABARET: DAWN HAMPTON
description: DAWN HAMPTON, the first performer in a new entertainment policy that began Tuesday at Night Wing, a restaurant at Greenwich Avenue and West 13th Street, has such a personal, individual way of doing things that she defies conventional categorizing.

title: KEY CUNNINGHAM WITNESS'S ACCOUNT SHAKEN
description: The Government's key witness in the tax trial of Patrick J. Cunningham told a Federal jury yesterday that his memory was faulty and unreliable. He attributed this to a fall from a horse that he said had damaged his brain, as well as a history of ''alcoholic blackouts.''

title: Planes in Argentina Reported Hit in Raid
description: British commandos on the Argentine mainland destroyed five Super-Etendard jets, which carry Exocet missiles, the Independent Television News said today.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 3, 1982; The Economy
description: Orders for new manufactured goods fell 2.3 percent in April, to a seasonally adjusted $155.3 billion, the Commerce Department reported. The decline is a strong sign that the recession is continuing, both private and Government analysts agreed, with high interest rates stifling economic activity. (Page D1.) Sales of new single-family homes fell 15.3 percent in April, the Government said. (D15.)

title: Rangers 4, Orioles 1
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Dave Hostetler hit a homer and Frank Tanana pitched a four-hitter, ending a personal six-game losing streak, to lead Texas. Hostetler, who hit his homer off Sammy Stewart (5-4) in the fourth inning, has six hits in 14 times at bat since being called up from Denver last Saturday.

title: RECITAL: JEAN GILLEAU, WINNER OF ORGANIST GUILD'S AWARD
description: LISTENING to Jean Guillou play Tuesday at Riverside Church, it was almost impossible to believe that he was giving his recital as recipient of the 1982 International Performer of the Year Award presented by the New York City Chapter of the American Guild of Organists. Neither content nor performance came close to representing musical standards that one would expect the organ profession to encourage.

title: Beirne Lay Jr., 72, the Author Of Film 'Twelve O'Clock High'
description: Beirne Lay Jr., author and screenwriter who specialized in films about the Air Force and who received an Academy Award nomination in 1949 for ''Twelve O'Clock High,'' died of cancer May 26 in Los Angeles. He was 72 years old.

title: Liberty National
description: The Liberty National Insurance Holding Company said it had agreed to buy the CMI Corporation of Troy, Mich., for $20 million in cash and notes and contingency payments based on future performance. CMI is a dealer and lessor of computers and aircraft. Liberty will change its name to the Torchmark Corporation.

title: 14 Seek Synthetic Fuel Funds
description: The United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation said today that it had received 14 new applications for Federal aid for synthetic fuels projects in response to its second round of solicitations, which ended Tuesday.

title: Trans World Offering
description: The Trans World Corporation said yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of about 1.8 million units, each composed of one share of common stock and one dual option warrant. Trans World said that it planned to use the proceeds for partial prepayment of a $161.1 million promissory note owed to its subsidiary, Trans World Airlines.

title: Don't Bottle Up the Bottle Bill
description: New York State's leaders have been playing a beanbag game since January, keeping themselves busy and the public on edge by tossing legislation back and forth between the State Capitol and the Executive suite. Now the matter of clearing bottles and containers from streets, parks and highways has spun absurdly onto the Governor's desk.

title: LOYALTON, POP. 5, VOTES TO DISBAND
description: Fire and a tornado knocked down most of the buildings on Main Street long ago, and drought and the Depression drove folks away, but in the end it was taxes that did in the town of Loyalton, population 5.

title: Justice on Camera
description: New York has a chance to catch up with three-fourths of the states by finally allowing at least an 18-month experiment with cameras in courtrooms. A bill toward that end should pass, recognizing with the Supreme Court that cameras are not inherently harmful to justice.

title: YANKS TOP JAYS ON 6-RUN 13TH, 12-6
description: The team that is supposed to be a pennant contender and the team that is supposed to be a cellar contender tried to give each other the game tonight. The Toronto Blue Jays finally prevailed.

title: Medtronic Offer
description: Medtronic Inc. said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposal to acquire privately held International Medical Corporation through an exchange of stock.

title: HARVESTER CHAIRMAN CAUTIOUS
description: The new chairman of the International Harvester Company, in a cautious assessment of the company's prospects, said today that Harvester's cash position was only strong enough to guarantee its survival for the next 60 to 90 days and possibly through the end of the fiscal year, on Oct. 31.

title: Bail Is Set at $1 Million In Illegal Export Case
description: Bail has been set at $1 million for a Swiss citizen arrested at Los Angeles International Airport carrying two suitcases stuffed with high-technology testing equipment.

title: Nerve Gas Leak at Plant Kills Man in Louisiana
description: Nerve gas leaking at a southwest Louisiana chemical plant killed a Texas man today and forced about 60 other workers to seek medical treatment or go home for the day.

title: U.S. VIETNAMESE RALLY FOR RESISTANCE
description: Vietnamese refugees in California and other parts of the country are holding rallies to raise money and recruit volunteers for guerrilla resistance to the Communist government in Vietnam.

title: Companies Lift Gasoline Price
description: Exxon U.S.A., the nation's third-largest gasoline marketer, raised its wholesale price for gasoline between 1 cent and 1.5 cents a gallon yesterday in parts of the South, the Middle Atlantic States and in Colorado. The move is the latest in a spate of price increases as demand for gasoline by wholesalers has surged.

title: COUNCIL LEADER SUPPORTS HIRING OF MORE POLICE
description: The chairman of the City Council Finance Committee said yesterday that the city could probably afford to hire up to 1,000 new police officers in the next fiscal year.

title: Classic's Store Deal
description: Classic Bookshop, the Canadian-owned bookstore chain, has signed a letter of intent to sell its two New York City stores to Waldenbooks, Brian Melzack, president of Classic, said yesterday.

title: Gavitt to Leave College
description: Dave Gavitt, one of the nation's most prominent college basketball authorities, announced yesterday that he was stepping down as athletic director at Providence College to devote full time to his other job, commissioner of the Big East Conference. Gavitt, who has been serving as part-time commissioner for three years, was the basketball coach of the Providence Friars for a decade beginning in 1969, when he was also named athletic director.

title: AN ENVOY WHO SPECIALIZES IN SENSITIVE MISSIONS
description: Ambassador at Large Vernon A. Walters, the Army private who talked and worked his way up to three stars and then to the top level of the Central Intelligence Agency, is thriving now as the Administration's loner at large. Back in Government from the lucrative world of consulting on oil and arms, he roams the earth as Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s cat's-paw, portraying himself as an old soldier intent on a final run at peace and dismissing criticism that he is a consummate contract artist in pinstripes.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: A shareholder of McCormick & Company, the Maryland-based spice maker that said last week that its earnings from 1977 to 1980 had been exaggerated, filed a class action suit against McCormick, five of its officers and the company's auditor in United States District Court in New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Saturday about the Democratic race in New Jersey for the United States Senate incorrectly described the cir- cumstances of the Princeton Demo- cratic Club's decision to support Bar- bara Boggs Sigmund. The club en- dorsed only Mrs. Sigmund.

title: New Trial Is Ordered In Toxic Shock Case
description: A new trial was ordered Tuesday in a $25 million lawsuit brought against the Procter & Gamble Company, the maker of Rely tampons.

title: AWKWARD LINKAGE OF CHINESE UNIFICATION AND ARMS FOR TAIWAN
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTE ON RIGHTS AMENDMENT DELAYED IN ILLINOIS
description: A Illinois legislator who favors passage of the Federal equal rights amendment said today that he would not vote for it as long as seven women continued a hunger strike here.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MANY houses that have traditional sloping shingled roofs also have attached garages, added rooms, roofed-over patios and other additions with flat roofs. Many urban houses also have flat or shed-type roofs. A flat roof cannot be covered with shingles. It is covered with multiple layers of a heavyweight asphalt roll roofing that may have a layer of gravel embedded on the surface (the gravel helps to lengthen the life of the roofing by reflecting away some of the sun's heat).

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander's Inc. has named Bruce Farkas, executive vice president, to the new position of vice chairman; Roger Barrer executive vice president in charge of management; Walter S. Freedman executive vice president in charge of finance, and Robert Geber and Leon Peck senior vice presidents. Alexander S. Farkas will continue as president of the retail chain and as chief executive officer.

title: U.S. SAYS WOMAN HELD BY CHINA WILL BE FREED TODAY AND EXPELLED
description: An American woman detained in Peking on charges of spying will be released Thursday afternoon and told to leave China within 48 hours, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: NEW FILM SHOWS WORLD OF MUSEUM CURATOR
description: THE museum curator in the late 20th century is a special kind of person. Ideally he should be many things in one - scholar, conservator, collector, exhibition organizer and (in this country) courtier to the wealthy. It is his duty both to look after his museum's holdings and to enrich them. He has to find the art objects, raise the money, make the deal and get it authorized. The great curator is rare.

title: News Analysis
description: Historic moments take place when history has begun to die, when antagonisms have weakened enough for a gesture of reconciliation and old conflicts have lost their pain.

title: HERS
description: TWO women, strangers to each other, sit at the same table in the restaurant with mutual friends. One of the women is beautiful, with feathery gold hair, full lips. She is speaking, at some length, to the other woman's date, leaning forward, her voice as light and pretty as soap bubbles. The man has the same look that he gets after three Scotches: all smiles, dopey, content.

title: SHOULD VIDEO GAMES BE RESTRICTED BY LAW?
description: ALARMED by the seemingly magnetic pull of coin-operated video games, a growing number of parents and school officials across the country are pressing local governments to pass laws restricting young people from playing the games in commercial establishments.

title: Doris Leslie, English Novelist And a Historical Biographer
description: Doris Leslie, the English novelist and historical biographer, died Monday in a Sussex hospital.

title: Venezuelan Curb on Scotch
description: As a protest against Britain's military action in the Falkland Islands, Venezuelan dock workers will no longer unload Scotch whisky, the 20,000-member Federation of Port Workers announced today.

title: '7 Brides for 7 Brothers' Replacing 'Black Shoes'
description: ''Seven Brides for Seven Brothers,'' the musical in which Debby Boone will make her Broadway debut, will open July 8 at the Alvin Theater. The theater became available with the closing last Sunday of ''Do Black Patent Leather Shoes Really Reflect Up?'' after 5 performances and 15 previews.

title: ELIZABETH ARNOLD
description: Elizabeth Arnold, who helped found the Arnold Baking Company with her husband, Paul, 42 years ago in their Greenwich, Conn., home, died yesterday after suffering a heart attack in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: New Test Shows Level For Drugs in Retarded
description: Medical researchers today unveiled a new test to determine if mentally retarded children who act violently are receiving insufficient or excess doses of behavior-modifying drugs.

title: Addenda to Craig Case
description: The Massachusetts state police yesterday applied in an Edgartown court for a disorderly-conduct charge against Jim Craig, the goalie of the victorious 1980 United States Olympic hockey team. The move came a day after Craig had been formally charged with vehicular homicide in Mattapoisett, Mass., as a result of an auto accident last weekend in which one woman died and another was critically injured.

title: ADVERTISERS ASKED TO DROP COMING NBC MOVIE
description: A dozen national advertisers have asked to review a coming NBC-TV film, ''Sister, Sister,'' to determine whether commercials for their products should appear in the program.

title: Market Place; Bear Market In Forecasting
description: SECURITIES analysts, who follow the fortunes of publicly owned companies and predict their profit prospects, have taken refuge in a creed of economists: ''Forecast often.'' The strategy is designed to protect one's flanks in an error-prone business.

title: American Air to Raise Fares
description: American Airlines, responding to the bankruptcy of rival Braniff International, said today that it would raise its fares beginning June 18.

title: FLORIDA WORRIES ABOUT CRIME WAVE AS FEDERAL FUNDS FOR REFUGEES ENDS
description: Alberto Morales pulled up his pants and waded through the rain-soaked high grass to busy Flagler Street, then patiently dangled a freshly caught red snapper at the passing automobiles.

title: Antinuclear Group From West Meets With Officials in Soviet
description: Members of the Greenpeace environmentalist group, led by Daniel Ellsberg, told Soviet officials today that they wanted the Soviet Union to end its nuclear testing program.

title: THE NOMADIC LIFE OF THE SUBTENANT
description: WHEN Elizabeth Harper arrived in New York from Toronto last September, she had already arranged to share a seven-room sublet apartment on Riverside Drive with a friend. But three weeks later, after learning that a legal battle was taking place over the apartment, Miss Harper was forced to began what she calls the ''life of a gypsy,'' moving in and out of five sublets during the next eight months.

title: CBI to Cut Back
description: CBI Industries said its Chicago Bridge and Iron Company subsidiary would phase out the manufacturing portion of its operation in Greenville, Pa., this year. About 320 of the 400 employees at Greenville will be affected.

title: MOVEMENT
description: A mass demonstration planned here June 10, timed to President Reagan's visit for a meeting of the Atlantic alliance, has become the focal point of activities this year of the groups in Western Europe that call themselves the peace movement.

title: News Analysis
description: For more than half a century, New York State's budgets have been crafted by Governors. The Legislature has generally confined itself to some minor alterations.

title: Publisher Announced At Business Week
description: James R. Pierce, 49 years old, yesterday was named publisher of Business Week magazine, and vice president of the McGraw-Hill Publications Company. He replaces R. Bernard Alexander, 64, six years publisher, who until he retires later this year will ''assume responsibility for special projects on the publications company's executive staff.''

title: CITIES ASSAIL CUT IN PROGRAM TO HIRE YOUTHS FOR SUMMER
description: As the Summer Youth Employment program begins what the Reagan Administration believes will be its final year, many cities are already complaining that its $685 million allocation will not be nearly enough to meet their needs.

title: CALENDAR: INFLUENCE OF CITY DEVELOPERS
description: New York's Hidden Designers: The Developers, Japan Society auditori- um, 333 East 47th Street, 753-1722.

title: Beatrice Adding Coke Bottlers
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said it is spending $125 million to buy Coca-Cola bottling companies in California and to start bottling operations in Venezuela. The company said that the new businesses were expected to increase the company's beverage sales 70 percent this year from $705 million in the year ended Feb. 28.

title: NEW YORK CITY GIRDS FOR JUNE 12 ANTINUCLEAR RALLY
description: Anticipating one of the largest rallies in New York City's history, the Koch administration announced yesterday that more than 6,000 municipal employees, mostly police officers, would be mobilized for the nuclear disarmament demonstration on June 12.

title: MOTOR VEHICLES AIDE SUSPENDED IN JERSEY
description: An 11-year employee of the State Division of Motor Vehicles was suspended today on charges that she had illegally restored a suspended driver's license.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard PIECES AND PONTIFICATIONS. By Nor- man Mailer. 400 pages. Little, Brown. $20.

title: No Headline
description: Chuck Shelton, the football coach at Drake, will be interviewed Thursday as a candidate to succeed Chuck Fairbanks as coach at Colorado.

title: Gerulaitis Fines Cut
description: During a third-round match at the French Open last week, Vitas Gerulaitis, upset over a few close line calls, made some seemingly obscene gestures. The officials there responded by fining him $2,250, but the effect of the penalty appeared certain to be more costly still.

title: Financial Federation
description: The California Department of Savings and Loan yesterday barred Severyn Ashkenazy, a Los Angeles hotel owner, and one of his associates from acting as directors of Financial Federation Inc., pending a hearing July 6.

title: FEDERAL JOB TRAINING NEEDS THE PRIVATE SECTOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Thatcher's remarks, page A14.
description: After further advances, British forces are within sight of Stanley and now hold all the important high ground around the low-lying capital of the Falkland Islands, military sources here and correspondents on the scene said today.

title: CITIES SERVICE SUES MESA ON STOCK BID
description: The Cities Service Company yesterday accused the Mesa Petroleum Company and its chairman, T. Boone Pickens Jr., of issuing statements ''calculated to mislead the investing public into believing that Mesa is committed to launching a formal tender offer for Cities Service stock.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Guilty Plea in Abduction
description: A man charged in the 1980 abduction of Denise Kay Gravely has pleaded guilty to a Federal charge of kidnapping.

title: TRACK OPENS DOORS FOR MERLENE OTTEY
description: From 1978 to 1980, Merlene Ottey went from running barefoot to winning an Olympic bronze medal. In the two years since, she has become one of the world's leading female sprinters.

title: REAGAN, IN PARIS, WILL STRESS ECONOMIC TIES
description: President Reagan arrived here in a drizzle tonight for the start of a nine-day visit to Europe after pledging this morning in Washington to seek a greater convergence of economic policies among the industrial democracies of the West.

title: THE PART OF ALBANIA THAT BELONGS TO GREECE
description: To the Editor:

title: TOUR OF PARK REJUVENATES TREE DEBATE
