description: The save-the-trees people and the pester-the-parks people strolled through the sun-dappled paths of Central Park yesterday to chat about their differences and found, to no one's surprise, that they did not always speak the same language.

title: WESTHEAD THE FORGOTTEN MAN
description: Paul Westhead recalled that he was running frantically, struggling to complete a recent 10-kilometer race here. His goal was to complete the course in what would have been a personal best of 40 minutes. Yet, he rounded the final turn that day, exhausted, with little hope of attaining the goal.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Canada is floating a $750 million five-year note issue at par bearing 14.375 interest through a Eurobond syndicate led by a Deutsche Bank syndicate.

title: Corporate Title Given G.E. Scientist
description: The General Electric Company has underscored its commitment to research and development by electing its top scientist, Roland W. Schmitt, to a corporate position.

title: STATE LEGISLATOR FROM BROOKLYN IN BID FOR SENATE
description: Describing herself as the only candidate with a chance of getting three lines on the ballot, Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan said yesterday that she would run for United States Senator from New York.

title: 2 DES MOINES PAPERS TO MERGE
description: The Des Moines Tribune, beset by the readership loss that has affected many other afternoon newspapers, will be merged with its larger sister paper into one morning newspaper, officials said today.

title: GRANITEWARE OF ALL HUES
description: order houses. Today the late 19th- and early 20thcentury pieces are available from a 100-piece collection, including mugs, platters, bowls, milk pails, wash basins, baking pans and coffeepots, from $20 to $175 apiece. There are pieces in blue, red, yellow and green as well as ''rarer hues like purple that are particularly desirable to collectors,'' Miss Greenstein said. Thomas K. Woodard, 835 Madison Avenue (70th Street), is open Monday through Saturday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: HABIB WILL RETURN TO MIDEAST
description: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy on the Middle East, will go there next week for talks on Lebanon, the State Department said today.

title: Y Plans Summer Concerts
description: Summer Music at the Y, a six-concert series from June 29 to July 8 at the 92d Street Y, is to include works by five American composers. On the programs will be works by Charles Ives, George Gershwin, Elliott Carter, Aaron Copland and Irving Fine. Information: 427-4410.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an erroneous caption from The Associated Press, and because a later, corrected version was misplaced, an incorrect picture was used yesterday alongside the Man in the News article about Roger M. Adelman, prosecutor in the Hinckley trial. The picture showed another assistant United States attorney, Richard Chapman.

title: Hinault Regains Lead
description: Bernard Hinault of France won the 18th stage of the Italian bicycling tour today, regaining the overall lead.

title: CITY GARDENER
description: Transplant help

title: AILING CANADIAN DOLLAR TOUCHES A RECORD LOW
description: For the second consecutive day, the Canadian dollar fell to an all-time low against its United States counterpart before support measures by the Bank of Canada brought a modest recovery.

title: Strike Threat in Detroit
description: Workers at downtown parking garages are threatening a strike that could disrupt the city's first Formula One auto race. About 100 members of Teamsters Local 283, who are unhappy with a contract offer, say they may walk off the job Thursday, a day before the beginning of trials for the race, which is scheduled for Sunday in the downtown area.

title: HIGUERAS TOPPLES CONNERS IN 3 SETS
description: Jose Higueras, a 29-year-old Spaniard whose bout with hepatitis two years ago made him concerned about his future in tennis, left little doubt about his recovery today as he posted a 6-2, 6-2, 6-2 victory over top-seeded Jimmy Connors in the French Open.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
SQUEEGEES AND SUCH
description: THERE are some new cleaning tools available that have very specific functions. While they may seem a bit esoteric, they are designed to do particular jobs and are useful as such.

title: WHO ARE THE REALISTS?
description: Those who work at the business of arms control - who look for ways to limit the menace of modern weapons - are often dismissed as visionaries. The realists are those who press for more weapons and plan their use.

title: Tacoma Sex Offender Is Facing Sterilization
description: A 30-year-old Tacoma man who pleaded guilty to sexually abusing his stepdaughter for seven years has been ordered sterilized, a sentence allowed under a 1909 state law.

title: FEDERAL JOB TRAINING NEEDS THE PRIVATE SECTOR
description: To the Editor:

title: ABUSE OF DISABILITY AID FOUND
description: Fraudulent benefit claims still plague a disability aid program for Federal employees that is managed by the Labor Department, the agency's inspector general said in a report made public Tuesday.

title: UNITED PRESS INTERNATIONAL: REPUTATION OF ALWAYS BEING A VERY LIVELY NO. 2
description: The news service that was to become United Press International began life as an underdog and an upstart in 1907, and in many ways continued to be characterized in such a manner.

title: Lepage Purchase
description: A.E. Lepage Ltd. said it had bought the Fuller Commercial Brokerage Company of Chicago for an undisclosed price. Fuller, which is privately held, had revenues of $20 million (United States) in 1981.

title: Grain Trader Sues in Hiring
description: Conticommodity Services said today that it had sued Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in Federal District Court here in connection with the recent hiring away of 10 of its employees.Conticommodity is the Chicago-based grain trading arm of the Continental Grain Company, which posted $15 billion in sales last year.

title: NLT's American General Bid
description: The NLT Corporation, a Nashville insurance company that also owns that city's Grand Ole Opry, said yesterday that it had been tendered 32.4 percent of the American General Corporation's common and 32.7 percent of its preferred shares.

title: DANCE: SPOLETO FESTIVAL, NIJINSKA'S 'LES NOCES'
description: CHARLESTON, S.C. ALTHOUGH this year's Spoleto Festival U.S.A. was rich in dance, the choreographic attraction that made it truly memorable was the first production by any American company of one of the greatest but most infrequently staged works of our century, Bronislava Nijinska's ''Les Noces.''

title: Sun Life Assurance
description: The Sun Life Assurance Company of Canda said today that it had completed the purchase of Massachusetts Financial Services Company.

title: Highway Worker Killed in Crash
description: A member of the city's pothole patrol was killed yesterday when a tractor-trailer rammed into the rear of his truck on the Staten Island Expressway and trapped him in the cab, the police said.

title: NEW-HOME SALES RATE FALLS 15.3%
description: Sales of new single-family houses plunged 15.3 percent in April from March, to the lowest level since the Government began keeping such figures 19 years ago, two Federal agencies said today.

title: Met Museum to Show 3 Series of Films
description: In its first film venture, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will present three series of feature motion pictures from July 6 through July 28. A total of 16 movies produced between 1934 and 1981 will be shown at 8 P.M. - four written or directed by Garson Kanin, seven directed by Louis Malle and five co-starring Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers.

title: Why Start Fair Trade in New York?
description: Looking to dramatize the issue at the Versailles summit meeting, the Reagan Administration is suddenly talking tough on trade. It says Canada's subsidy of the sale of subway cars to New York violates the trade laws. Yet the Metropolitan Transportation Authority felt a duty to pass up a domestic bid to take the best deal available. Both have a point, but this is a strange place to begin enforcing fair trade principles.

title: GROWING RIFT OVER EXPORT SUBSIDIES
description: An emergent conflict with Canada over the sale of subway cars to New York City is but the latest expression of an increasingly bitter dispute between the United States and its major trading partners over officially subsidized export credits.

title: END OF THE LINE DRAWING NEAR FOR JERSEY'S SOMERSET BUS CO.
description: The maroon and gold of the Somerset Bus Company will disappear from the routes running from Union, Essex, Middlesex and Somerset Counties in New Jersey to New York City when the family-owned line goes out of business at the end of this month.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ADM. DAVID L. WHELCHEL
description: Rear Adm. David Lee Whelchel, U.S.N., retired, died of cancer Saturday at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center.

title: 'HONEYBEES' MAKE DEBUT
description: ''I guess everybody has to be an insect around here to function,'' said Representative George Hansen, Republican of Idaho, as he arrived at a news conference to announce still another entomological subspecies of Congressmen, ''the honeybees.''

title: CONSUMER BODY ASSAILS CITY TAX ABATEMENTS
description: New York City's programs for residential tax abatements and exemptions benefit a small number of Manhattan real-estate developers who build luxury housing and do not need the tax breaks, the New York Public Interest Research Group charged yesterday.

title: VICTIMS RECALL HORROR OF A-BOMBINGS
description: Thirty survivors of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki related their experiences at two gatherings held in New York yesterday in advance of the special United Nations session on disarmament opening next week.

title: 'Took My Hide Off,' Baker Says of Chinese
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. reported today that Chinese leaders ''took my hide off'' over the issue of United States arms sales to Taiwan.

title: Merrick Print Business To David Enright Co.
description: David Merrick, the Broadway producer, has given the assignment for all of his print advertising needs, which currently means just the hit musical ''42nd Street,'' to the David Enright Company, a new agency established by J. David Enright 4th.

title: BELMONT DRAWS RECORD-SETTER
description: The 113th Belmont Stakes on Saturday gained an unexpected starter, a probable favorite and some added drama yesterday when the trainer Woody Stephens announced he was ''leaning strongly'' toward running Conquistador Cielo in the race.

title: PRINCETON PLAGIARISM PENALTY UPHELD
description: A Superior Court judge today upheld Princeton University's right to withhold a degree from a senior accused of plagiarism, despite, he said, his personal feeling that the university should have been more compassionate in imposing the penalty.

title: CAREY SIGNS BILL ON SECURITIES FRAUD
description: Governor Carey signed legislation today that would stiffen the penalty for persons who intentionally engage in fraudulent activities in the sale, exchange or purchase of securities or commodities.

title: FORD TO TEST LIFETIME GUARANTEED JOBS
description: Until recently Mike Kokotovich, a 45-yearold gear inspector for the Ford Motor Company, was deeply worried about losing his job.

title: VW to Lay Off 400 From Staff in U.S.
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. announced today that it would lay off 400 salaried workers and speed up the transfer of its Englewood Cliffs, N.J., offices to Detroit-area facilities to cut costs.

title: ENTERTAINMENT NETWORK OFFERING AN 'ALTERNATIVE'
description: Television has long served the extremes of entertainment tastes. While the commercial networks generally aim at the lowest common denominator, public television has emphasized the performing arts. But is there a middle ground?

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abitibi-Price Inc. said it will close its newsprint mill at Grand Falls, Newfoundland, for two weeks starting June 21.

title: GUATEMALA EXILES ASSAIL JUNTA
description: A Guatemalan opposition group urged the Reagan Administration today to halt aid to the new military junta in Guatemala because of what it termed the ''terror and violence'' against Indians and peasants.

title: DOW UP 1.91
description: The stock market yesterday broke its five-session losing streak by registering a small advance in accelerated trading. Analysts noted that bargain-hunting in some of the recently depressed issues was mostly responsible for the slight upswing in prices.

title: GROUP OF BLACK EXECUTIVES FORMS NEW CHARITY FOR THEIR COMMUNITY
description: A group of black executives of human-service agencies in New York City announced yesterday that it had formed a charity to help alleviate problems in the black community.

title: POSTAL SERVICE IN ACCORD ON REHIRING 86 WORKERS DISMISSED ON STRIKE
description: Eighty-six former postal workers who, like the air traffic controllers, were discharged for taking part in an illegal strike will be allowed to reapply for new jobs in the United States Postal Service under terms of a court-approved settlement made public yesterday.

title: EXPERT ON LABOR LED CONSULTING CONCERN
description: Earl Palay, president of the Martin E. Segal Company, a leading national concern of consultants and actuaries, died of cardiac arrest on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 50 years old.

title: SOME RIGHTS GAINS SEEN IN GUATEMALA
description: Since a coup gave power in March to a three-man military junta headed by Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, there appears to have been a marked improvement in the human-rights situation for Guatemala's urban middle class, according to diplomats and Guatemalans.

title: Rising Truck Output
description: Truck production by the nation's major auto makers will reach an estimated 588,000 vehicles this quarter, up 16.7 percent from 504,000 in the same period a year ago, according to an industry trade journal.

title: GREEK TRAGEDY: A JAPANESE 'BACCHAE'
description: TADASHI SUZUKI'S Japanese versions of Greek tragedy -''The Trojan Women,'' presented recently at Japan House, and ''The Bacchae,'' currently at La Mama Annex - are interpretive rearrangements rather than adaptations. Filtering classics through his very contemporary vision, he presents rituals in performance.

title: 'Son of Sam' Bill on Royalties Is Signed Into Law by O'Neill
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill has signed into law a bill aimed at preventing criminals from profiting from their crimes by writing books or selling movie rights about them.

title: SOMETHING ABOUT A WALTZ PUT BIRD IN MATERNAL MOOD
description: The years George Archibald spent dancing in front of a five-foot female whooping crane who loves him have finally paid off. The International Crane Foundation in Baraboo, Wis., announced yesterday that its rare female whooping crane named Tex gave birth Tuesday to her first chick after six steady weeks of performing a ritual mating dance with Dr. Archibald, her human ''spouse.'' The mother had been named by handlers in doubt about her sex.

title: FAIRBANKS OUTLINES U.S. LEAGUE POLICY ON PLAYERS
description: The new United States Football League will not attempt to sign players who still are in college, but the league will compete with the National Football League for athletes who have completed their college eligibility. That policy and some others were defined yesterday by Chuck Fairbanks, the coach and president of the New York entry in the 12-team league at his first news conference.

title: Robbery Suspect Hangs Himself
description: A 35-year-old robbery suspect using strips from his jacket hanged himself early yesterday from the bars of a cell in a police station in Harlem, the police said.

title: Municipal Art Society Giving Awards Today
description: The Municipal Art Society of New York will present its annual awards today 3 P.M. in the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, to organizations, individuals, public events and buildings that have contributed to the quality of life in New York City.

title: CHORAL: NINE GROUPS PERFORM IN AMERICAN JEWISH FESTIVAL
description: THE Hebrew Arts School and its director, Tzipora Jochsberger, think singing can bring Jewish people together, so Sunday evening they brought together nine Jewish choruses from New York, New Haven, Long Island, Boston and Washington, assembled them at the Abraham Goodman House and let them perform for a sold-out auditorium of people. The music featured Jewish folk and popular influences, serious composers such as Rossi, Mendelssohn and Robert Starer, and a whole stylistic area between the two.

title: BRIFING
description: Radio Station's Appeal

title: Chock Full o'Nuts Dissidents Gain
description: Jerry Finkelstein, the dissident shareholder of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, disclosed that two other shareholders had sided with him, effectively raising the group's stake to 10.4 percent from 6.1 percent.

title: HANOI BY BIKE: DORIS DAY SONGS AND AN OLD MIG
description: An old man was asked the population of his native city, ''One million people and two million bicycles, '' he said.

title: MURDER SUSPECT MISTAKENLY FREED FOR 3 DAYS
description: A coincidence in a computer system designed to catch suspects for their old crimes, combined with an administrative courtroom error, allowed a youth charged with a triple murder to go free last Friday, law enforcement officials said last night.

title: National Bank Gets An American Chief
description: When the National Bank of North America was taken over three years ago, its acquirer, the National Westminster Bank of Britain, vowed that it would continue to be ''an American bank run by Americans.''

title: U.P.I. SOLD TO NEW COMPANY
description: The E.W. Scripps Company said yesterday that it had sold United Press International, the news service, to the Media News Corporation, a new privately owned company.

title: Oil Data Delayed
description: The American Petroleum Institute said yesterday that the Memorial Day holiday had delayed the release of its weekly energy data. The data will appear in tomorrow's editions.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 3, 1982
description: International British forces advanced farther, seizing the last key high ground around the low-lying capital of the Falklands, and British artillery began pounding Argentine positions in Stanley, according to correspondents at the scene. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said that further hostilities could be avoided if Argentine forces were withdrawn, but there was a growing sense in London that a British assault on Stanley was inevitable and imminent. (Page A1, Column 6.) Argentine officers expressed pessimism about how long their troops in the Falklands could hold out against the British forces. About 7,000 Argentines making a last stand at Stanley were surrounded by British forces closing in with artillery fire. (A14:1.)

title: Hitless 7 Innings, Mets Fall, 3-1
description: As if they did not have enough trouble, the Mets failed to get a hit off 43-year-old Phil Niekro until the eighth inning last night, then got only four hits after that and lost, 3-1, to the Atlanta Braves in Shea Stadium.

title: ARGENTINES GRIM AS BRITISH CLOSE IN
description: Argentine military officers expressed pessimism today about how long their troops in the Falkland Islands could hold out against advancing British forces. The Argentine delegation at the United Nations called for an immediate cease-fire.

title: Admitted Killer of 12 Gets Two Life Terms
description: Robert Dale Henderson, a drifter who told the police he had killed 12 people in a multistate crime spree, pleaded guilty today to two charges of first-degree murder.

title: A FREEZE CAN BE VERIFIED
description: Among the most frequently expressed objections to the proposed nuclear freeze is the argument that a freeze on production of nuclear weapons could not be verified. This arbitrary conclusion rests on several assumptions: first, the Soviet Union cannot be trusted to comply with a freeze; second, the United States does not have the ability to verify compliance; third, the Soviet Union will not agree to adequate verification procedures.

title: SENATOR JACKSON RUNNING FERVOR OF BEGINNER
description: Even with 42 years in Congress behind him, Henry M. Jackson is campaigning for his sixth term as a Senator with the fervor of a beginner.

title: FACTORY ORDERS DOWN 2.3%
description: Orders for new manufactured goods fell 2.3 percent in April from March, the Government reported today, in what private and Government analysts saw as a clear reflection of the continuing recession.

title: PERSONALITIES HEAT CAMPAIGN IN JERSEY
description: Joseph P. Merlino recently did something he had never done before in a 23-year career in New Jersey politics. He went to a bank and borrowed $20,000 to help pay for a campaign.

title: I.R.S. QUESTIONS GIFTS OF ART IN COAST INQUIRY
description: The Internal Revenue Service has filed affidavits in Federal Court here indicating that officials of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the University of California at Santa Barbara had falsified documents for art donations that would have permitted several thousand dollars in illegal income-tax deductions.

title: Padres 3, Cubs 1
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Juan Eichelberger (5-6) allowed just one hit, a soft single by Scot Thompson in the second. He faced 31 batters in his fifth complete game of the season, dealing the Cubs their fourth straight loss.

title: Q & A
description: Q. We have mildew on our bathroom walls and ceilings. On the tile we have no problem; we wash it off with a bleach solution as described in your column. But we can't use bleach on the wallpaper. Under the paper is paint, and under this, plaster. What should we do? - B.G., Great Neck, L.I.

title: Newspaper Ad Bureau Has New President
description: Jack Kauffman, president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau since 1966, will turn over his office next Tuesday to Craig C. Standen, 39, a packaged goods marketing pro who has been executive vice president of the bureau since joining two years ago.

title: Judge Commits Suicide
description: A judge shot himself to death while alone in the municipal courtroom where he presided, the authorities said Tuesday. Judge J. Patrick Denis, 50 years old, was found dead about 8:30 P.M. Monday with a gunshot wound to the head, said Jack Patterson, director of public safety in this affluent Detroit suburb. A .38-caliber revolver was under the body, which was slumped on the floor behind the court bench.

title: A FINE HARBOR WON STANLEY ITS PLACE AS ISLANDS' CAPITAL
description: Stanley, the remote South Atlantic settlement that has become the final prize in the battle for the Falkland Islands, seems an unlikely site for a colonial capital.

title: Braniff, Pan Am Plan Discussions
description: Executives from the Braniff International Corporation plan to meet with executives from Pan American World Airways soon to discuss a plan presented by Pan Am to operate some of Braniff's former routes.

title: HOME SAVINGS TRADES 620 MILLION IN MORTGAGES
description: Home Savings of America, the largest savings and loan association in the country, announced yesterday that it had exchanged $620 million of home mortgages for an equal amount of mortgage participation certificates issued by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the largest single exchange of mortgages for certificates ever arranged.

title: ISRAELIS SAID TO OPPOSE PARLEY AFTER THREAT TO TURKISH JEWS
description: The Israeli Government is trying to induce the organizers of an international conference on genocide to cancel it. The only reason the Israelis give publicly is that the conference, scheduled to open in Tel Aviv on June 17, would threaten ''the humanitarian interest of Jews.''

title: SEOUL PRESSING SHAKE-UP AFTER SCANDAL
description: In the wake of a financial scandal last month, two key South Korean Government posts changed hands today with the appointment of Lee Bum Suk, a former diplomat, as Foreign Minister, replacing Lho Shin Yong, who was named to be director of the country's intelligence agency.

title: GROUND-FLOOR LIVING: A CITY AT THE DOOR
description: MANY city residents, either because of economic advantages or by preference, live in ground-floor apartments or maisonettes. They inhabit that urban netherworld of passing kneecaps and peeping passers-by, intrusive headlights and inquisitive dogs. Their outlook, or at least part of it, is framed by iron bars. If a manhole blows, if a taxi honks, if the garbage truck whines, they are the first to know. Despite all this, many would not trade for the fanciest penthouse.

title: RATES SHOW LITTLE CHANGE
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday, with short-term rates rising and long-term rates falling. Dealers said growing uncertainty about the future direction of rates was keeping many investors on the sidelines, even though yields are higher than last month.

title: 2 WITNESSES SAY HINCKLEY APPEARED NORMAL AFTER SHOOTINGS
description: Two prosecution witnesses testified today that John W. Hinckley Jr. appeared normal, alert and lucid in the hours immediately after his arrest for shooting President Reagan.

title: U.N. CHIEF ACKNOWLEDGES FAILURE IN ATTEMPT TO WIN FALKLAND TRUCE
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar acknowledged to the Security Council today that he had again failed to win a cease-fire between Argentina and Britain in the Falkland war.

title: SPOTTING SIGNS OF TROUBLE IN FLEA-MARKET 'BARGAINS'
description: THEY'RE known as ''runners'' in America and ''totters'' in England - those professionals who scour flea markets and auctions for bargains -but there are many more of us who are merely addicted to yard sales, flea markets and secondhand shops, looking for furniture finds. For those with a little know-how and ability and a willingness to put in time, effort and a small outlay, good buys are still available.

title: SWITCH HELPS STIEB'S CAREER
description: When Tommy John began pitching in the major leagues in 1963, Dave Stieb had not pitched a game in his life. That was understandable because Stieb was only 6 years old. But when Stieb was 20 years old, he still hadn't pitched a game.

title: Oxoco Acquisition
description: Oxoco Inc., an oil and gas exploration company based in Houston, said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the privately held Hawthorn Oil and Gas Company for about $32 million.

title: SLUDGE DUMPING HELD NO PERIL
description: Federal and city analyses yesterday agreed that no fire or health hazard had been posed by composted sewage sludge that was trucked from a city-owned lot in the Bronx last month and dumped in the Sanitation Department's Fountain Avenue landfill in Brooklyn. The landfill is across from the Starrett City housing complex.

title: Ladies' Home Journal Plans a Bus Campaign
description: In addition to a comparative advertising campaign in The New York Times and The Chicago Tribune, The Ladies' Home Journal will shoot for the ego of Madison Avenue with a three-month campaign using the posters on the sides of 100 buses that run on affluent avenues.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE CLOUD

title: U.S. URGING ARGENTINES TO WITHDRAW PROMPTLY
description: The United States, in an attempt to persuade Argentina to agree immediately to withdraw its troops from the Falkland Islands, said today that there was no reason for Britain to accept a cease-fire until that condition was met.

title: PRESIDENT REJECTS BIPARTISAN BUDGET
description: The White House has rejected Democratic suggestions for a bipartisan budget plan, and both parties have agreed to give House members a clear choice in a showdown between rival proposals.

title: FIVE YOUNG INMATES CHARGED
description: A 17-year-old boy, who died after being tortured and beaten in a county jail, had been placed there by his parents to face the consequences of failure to pay $60 in traffic fines, his mother said today.

title: CRISIS
description: Following are excerpts from interviews with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher tonight by correspondents of the BBC and Britain's commercial television service:

title: WOMEN VS. MONEY ADVISERS
description: Some wealthy women have long felt that they were being patronized - or worse - by the financial institutions that handle their money. Despite the women's movement and the equal-credit laws and women's banks that resulted, many women of means feel that they get secondclass treatment from their money managers. And some of them have begun to fight back, either in court or through less formal grievance mechanisms.

title: Indians Win 10th in Row
description: CLEVELAND (AP) - Andre Thornton homered for the fourth straight game as Cleveland beat Minnesota, 4-2, and sent the Twins to their 14th loss in a row.

title: REPORT ON AGING CONFERENCE SAYS THE ELDERLY ARE WELL OFF
description: The Reagan Administration issued the final report of last year's White House Conference on Aging today, concluding that the problems of the nation's elderly were overemphasized and that the Social Security system should be strengthened. The document did not suggest how to do that.

title: CUBA ASSAILS U.S. ROLE IN CRISIS OVER FALKLANDS
description: Cuba denounced the United States today for supporting Britain over the Falkland Islands. It offered to join other Latin American countries in providing ''all necessary help'' to Argentina in the conflict.

title: POPE ENDS VISIT AS HE BEGAN IT, CALLING FOR PEACE
description: Pope John Paul II ended a historic six-day visit to Britain that began with a fervent appeal for peace in the Falkland Islands and ended tonight with a gentle serenade from one of the choirs for which this principality is famous.

title: M.A.C. to Offer New Security
description: Directors of the Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday approved the sale of up to $100 million of commercial paper - a type of short-term security that will complement the corporation's sale of bonds.

title: Now, Scientific American in Russian
description: Scientific American, one of America's oldest magazines, will get its first Russian-language edition in the Soviet Union beginning January.

title: GENOCIDE PARLEY WITH ARMENIANS TO PROCEED
description: A conference on genocide will convene as planned despite reported Turkish threats of reprisal and pressure from Israeli authorities to cancel it, the conference organizer said today.

title: Dean Martin Accused
description: Dean Martin was accused Wednesday of carrying a loaded .38-caliber pistol in his car, the District Attorney's office said. The singer, who is 65 years old, will be arraigned June 18 on one count of carrying a concealed weapon in his car and one of carrying a loaded weapon.

title: STAGE: 'ARCATA PROMISE,' STUDY OF A PSYCHOPATHIC ACTOR
description: A psychopathic English actor is mercilessly dissected in David Mercer's ''The Arcata Promise.'' Originally written for television and shown in the United States on WNET-TV, the play has been adapted for the theater and is running at the No Smoking Playhouse. Brian Murray gives a harrowing performance on stage, as did Anthony Hopkins in the same role on television.

title: FRANCE WILL DAZZLE ITS VISITORS WITH THE RESTORED SPLENDOR OF THE SUN KING
description: When journalists were shown around the Palace of Versailles last month to inspect the work in progress for the economic summit conference, one room was barred to them. It was the Salle du Sacre, where the presidents and prime ministers will meet. A photographer who tried to peek had his film confiscated.

title: MOSCOW REBUTS AMERICAN PLAN FOR ARMS CUTS
description: In a detailed rejection of President Reagan's proposals for strategic arms reduction, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said in an editorial tonight that he was seeking to ''inflict considerable damage on the defense capacity'' of the Soviet Union.

title: Mets Start Trip A Player Short
description: The Mets, losers of four of their last six games, flew to Cincinnati last night for a weekend series against the Reds without a replacement for the injured Tom Veryzer.

title: Railroad Is Told To Resume Service
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Oklahoma, Kansas & Texas Railroad Company to resume freight service over 630 miles of line owned by the bankrupt Rock Island line between Salina, Kan., and Dallas.

title: MANY U.S. BRIDGES TERMED DEFICIENT
description: Nearly half of all the bridges in the United States are officially classified as deficient or obsolete, and the number is rising, according to a nationwide study by the Department of Transportation.

title: 3 Kitchens: Tibet, France, Hungary.
description: REMEMBERING some of the interesting Russian and Central Asian specialties sampled several years ago at Firuz, we set out for that tiny restaurant on Third Avenue near 31st Street recently and found in its place the two-month-old Tibetan Kitchen. Our disappointment at not being able to get borscht, luli kebob, pilimini and Tadzhik bread was assuaged by the availability of thang, momo, gyathuk ngopa and shapta. If gastronomic esoterica is the prize, it can still be found here at what is said to be the first and only Tibetan restaurant in the country.

title: FRAUD IS REPORTED IN SALVADOR VOTE
description: The President of El Salvador's Central Elections Council said today that the vote total in the March elections might have been inflated.

title: Index; International
description: A black union runs up against South Africa's railway A2 China frees American accused of spying and orders her out A3 Two leaders of Spanish coup at- tempt get 30-year terms A3 Ex-Turkish Premier ordered freed from prison A4 Soviet tows shipborne antinu- clear group out of harbor A6 U.N. Council postpones vote on Falkland truce resolution A8 Argentine officials belittle the battle for Stanley A8 Argentina appeals to third world for support on Falklands A9 Weinberger acknowledges strat- egy on prolong nuclear war A10 Parley in Israel to go ahead de- spite reported Turkish threats A10 Around the World A11 France to dazzle visitors with Sun King's splendor A12 Reporter's Notebook: A sartorial surprise in Paris A12 Government/Politics Nearly half the nation's bridges termed deficient or obsolete A14 New York enforcing new law on child safety seats in cars B2 Washington Talk Briefing A18 A look at consumer product ex- perts as consumers A18 General Around the Nation A14 Detroit gets ready for its first Grand Prix race A14 California officials irked at South Dakota crime policy A14 Expert describes Hinckley's brain as normal A21 Monsanto announces research agreement with university A21 Synanon suit against TV station settled out of court A21 Conference plans emergency food programs for the hungry B3 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Great Irish Fair set for Brooklyn waterfront C1 Guide to street fairs around town C14 Theater: Broadway C2

title: Beverly Hills Amends Suit
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association says that it has filed an amended complaint to its lawsuit against a group of dissident shareholders battling to place one of their members on the board of directors.

title: POITIER'S 'HANKY PANKY'
description: SIDNEY POITIER'S ''Hanky Panky,'' which opens today at the Embassy 1 and other theaters, is an out-of-breath suspense-comedy that is apt to leave you far less exhilarated than exhausted, but that comment is made with a certain amount of hesitancy. I felt much the same way about his last comedy, ''Stir Crazy,'' with Gene Wilder and Richard Pryor, and that movie went on to become one of the biggest moneymaking films of all time.

title: Japan Vehicle Sales
description: Domestic sales of passenger cars, trucks and buses in Japan rose 5 percent in May from a year earlier, to 286,899 units, the automobile dealers association said today.

title: THE 750-MILE DREAM COURSE
description: One amateur became airsick going from the second green to the third tee. An experienced touring pro lost his 9 iron between the South Shore of Long Island and New Jersey's Bergen County. And the foursome took 13 hours 10 minutes to play an 18-hole round of golf, without once incurring a two-stroke penalty for slow play.

title: 2 Youths Indicted
description: Two white youths were indicted in Brooklyn yesterday on charges stemming from the assault of a black student on his way to take a Civil Service examination at James Madison High School in the Flatbush section on May 22, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office announced.

title: DR. GUSTAVO CUDKOWICZ
description: Dr. Gustavo Cudkowicz, professor of pathology at the State University of New York School of Medicine in Buffalo, died May 25 at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City after a brief illness. Dr. Cudkowicz, a resident of Buffalo, was 54 years old.

title: BROKERS GROUP TO SUE ON PLAN FOR THRIFT UNITS
description: A new confrontation between the brokerage and thrift industries emerged here today over a decision taken by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board last month to permit savings and loan associations to offer their customers investment and brokerage services.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp. said it had been awarded an $85 million contract for the modernization of the turbines at the Aswan High Dam in Egypt.

title: CONCERT: ISRAELIS JOIN NEW YORKERS AT BENEFIT
description: IT was by any standard a big night at Avery Fisher Hall. Big sounds came from the combined forces of the Israel Philharmonic and the New York Philharmonic in Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique.'' Big money, amounting to more than $500,000, flowed in from a benefit audience, half of the amount going to each orchestra's endowment fund. That it was also a big disappointment, musically, was perhaps inevitable. This was one of those musical events in which the event is bound to overshadow the music.

title: LEAD, 3-1, IN FINAL SERIES
description: It was evident early tonight that this was not to be Julius Erving's or the Philadelphia 76ers' night. The 76ers lost to the Los Angeles Lakers, 111-101, before a sellout crowd of 17,505 at the Forum. They now trail the indefatigable Lakers, three games to one, in the National Basketball Association's championship series.

title: Article 185013 -- No Title
description: The Democratic National Committee announced today that it had paid off the last of the $9.3 million in 1968 Presidential campaign debts run up by Robert F. Kennedy and Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: Benefit Appraisal Set
description: The value of pieces of artwork, jewelry, glass and other items can be assessed on Sunday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. at a benefit appraisal sponsored by Christie's at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue at 92d Street.

title: MESA SEEN IN BID SOON TO HOLDERS
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company, rejected by management of the Cities Service Company in its $1.8 billion bid for a controlling interest, will soon take an offer directly to the stockholders, Wall Street sources reported yesterday.

title: Perkins Given A Longer Pact
description: Ray Perkins's contract as head coach of the Giants has been extended again.

title: Rangers Shifting Farms
description: The New York Rangers plan to switch their chief minor league affiliation for the second time in a year and are reported to be considering both Birmingham, Ala., and Tulsa, Okla. The Rangers' farm club had been New Haven of the American Hockey League until last season, when the affiliation was switched to Springfield, Mass., under a one-year agreement. Yesterday, the Springfield club, also of the A.H.L., signed a two-year agreement with the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: A BLACK UNION TAKES ON SOUTH AFRICA'S RAILROAD
description: Doctor Ngotsha, who received the honorific of a medical practitioner as his Christian name, is a stubby black dockworker with a shaved head, fringe beard and an emphatic manner of expressing himself. Sitting in an underfurnished labor union office near the docks here, he recalled how he expressed himself when he was summoned by the Railway Police to explain why he had joined an ''outside union.''

title: 2 Brazilian Jets Escort British Vulcan to Rio
description: Two Brazilian Air Force F5-E fighterbombers intercepted a British Vulcan bomber today 185 miles south of this city.

title: Dan River Moving
description: Dan River Inc., one of the nation's 10 largest textile companies, will move its headquarters to Danville, Va., ending a 14-year corporate residence here, officials said.

title: Pintor Retains Title On Knockout in 11th
description: Lupe Pintor of Mexico survived a fifthround knockdown tonight and went on to stop Seung Hoon Lee of Korea at 46 seconds of the 11th round to retain his World Boxing Council bantamweight title.

title: BRITAIN SAID TO ORDER TROOPS TO BEGIN ATTACK WHEN READY
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has ordered British commanders in the Falkland Islands to begin their final assault on the Argentine garrison at Stanley as soon as they are ready, Government officials said today.

title: HURRICANE AIMS FOR FLORIDA COAST
description: The first hurricane of the 1982 season threw gales and tornadoes at the Florida Keys tonight and forecasters said it then headed for a landfall at daybreak on the southwestern coast of Florida.

title: WHY A DEVELOPER IN CITY USES QUALITY ZONING RULE
description: Five years ago New York City enacted what it called a housing quality zoning ordinance. Its purpose was to give builders of multifamily housing an alternative to by-the-book, or as-of-right, zoning to encourage them to achieve certain quality standards.

title: LONG-TERM BOND PRICES FALL
description: Long-term bond prices were stable early yesterday, but turned lower in the afternoon when dealers said that a significant amount of Treasury issues were sold.

title: SCHWEIKER'S GIFT TO NURSING HOME OPERATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW FUELS' PROMISE IN THE WAR ON ACID RAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Guatemalan Army Reports Rebel Raid
description: About 30 guerrillas attacked a village in Quiche state, killing four civil guards and wounding four others, the army said today.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A SARTORIAL SURPRISE IN PARIS
description: What was probably one of the most prestigious parties of the year here was held tonight at the residence of the American Embassy, on the Avenue Gabriel. It was the opening social event of President and Mrs. Reagan's trip to Europe, a dinner given for President Francois Mitterrand and his wife, Daniele, and some 120 French and American guests. Despite the fact that it was informal - the men in business suits and the women in colorful cocktail dresses - there was something of a fashion bombshell.

title: HOUSE WILL VOTE ON REAGAN BUDGET
description: The House Budget Committee gave President Reagan his wish today and voted to send to the House floor his original budget proposal for the fiscal year 1983. That budget, which includes a deficit of about $122 billion, has virtually no support in Congress.

title: JEWISH WOMEN ASSESS A DECADE OF RELIGIOUS GAINS
description: Ten years ago this month, Sally Priesand became the first woman to be ordained a rabbi in the United States. It was a major religious breakthrough for Jewish women, and to mark the anniversary, a symposium was held the other day to measure their progress within their religion since 1972.

title: REAGAN MAY OFFER SOME COMPROMISES
description: President Reagan intends to offer modest American concessions on economic policy to win European agreement to ''limit the volume and raise the price'' of Western financial credits to the Soviet Union, an authoritative American source disclosed today.

title: Economic Scene; The Ghosts Of Versailles
description: VERSAILLES, France THESE hallowed halls and walks evoke memories not only of heads of state from Louis XIV to Woodrow Wilson but also of economists from Jacques Necker to John Maynard Keynes.

title: U.N. COUNCIL DEFERS VOTE ON CEASE-FIRE RESOLUTION
description: The Security Council postponed a vote today on a compromise resolution on a cease-fire in the Falkland Islands.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph accompanying the Kitchen Equipment column in The Living Section on May 19 was incor- rectly identified. It showed a Braun electric coffee grinder.

title: Brunswick Files Suit Over Patents
description: The Brunswick Corporation, a diversified manufacturer of technical and recreational products, said it had filed a patent infringement suit against the Suzuki Motor Company of Japan in Federal District Court in Milwaukee.

title: POLICE ENFORCE NEW RULE ON CAR SEATS FOR INFANTS
description: New York motorists making trips around the state with young children this summer have an added responsibility under a two-monthold law that requires children under 4 years old to ride in a safety seat.

title: ARGENTINE OFFICIALS ARE BELITTLING THE BATTLE FOR STANLEY
description: The military high command said tonight that fighting in the Falkland Islands today was limited to artillery shelling between the British forces surrounding Stanley and the Argentine troops holding the capital.

title: REAGAN, IN PARIS, ASSERTS RECOVERY IS ON HORIZON
description: President Reagan, opening his nine-day visit to Europe with a mixture of ceremony and business, met today with President Francois Mitterrand of France. The two leaders discussed the Falkland Islands situation and France's objections to United States policies in Central America.

title: PUBLISHING: HARPER'S AND GARCIA MARQUEZ PART
description: THE lead book displayed in next fall's Harper & Row catalogue is ''Chronicle of a Death Foretold'' by Gabriel Garcia Marquez, a new novella by the author of ''One Hundred Years of Solitude.'' Harper's even commissioned a translation from the Spanish by Gregory Rabassa. Yet Harper's is not going to publish the book. A spokesman for Random House said that Ballantine Books, Random's mass market paperback division, is negotiating for the right to publish it in this country, with the likelihood that Alfred A. Knopf, a Random House subsidiary, would become the hard-cover publisher.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Banker of Last Resort; But Could an R.F.C. Be Insulated Against Patronage?
description: The Reconstruction Finance Corporation: how one responds to the words gives a good idea of where one fits on the political spectrum. For liberals, it is a symbol of benevolent Government intervention during the Depression -just the sort that could now breathe life into aging cities and industries that President Reagan ignores. For conservatives, R.F.C. represents Big Government as Big Bumbler, ad hoc activism at its worst.

title: CLAROSTAT'S CHAIRMAN WINS PROXY CHALLENGE
description: Glen E. Swanson, the chairman of the Clarostat Manufacturing Company, a $20 million-a-year electronics parts producer based in Dover, N.H., does not live in Dover. In fact, the 75-year-old chairman, who owns nearly 30 percent of the company's stock, does not even live in New Hampshire. Mr. Swanson lives in Los Angeles.

title: BELL AND MRS. FENWICK OUTLINE POSITIONS ON ISSUES
description: Jeffrey Bell and Millicent Fenwick, the two candidates in the June 8 primary for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, have waged a vigorous and expensive campaign that has attracted national attention.

title: EDITORIAL ON CNN STIRS DISPUTE
description: A dispute has arisen over an editorial presented on the Cable News Network by Ted Turner, chairman of the Turner Broadcasting Company, which owns the 24-hour news service. Daniel Schorr, a correspondent for CNN, also appeared on the network to criticize Mr. Turner's position and later objected when his commentary was not repeated as is usually the case. Both Mr. Turner's editorial and the subsequent treatment of Mr. Schorr's commentary have provoked criticism from journalists within the organization.

title: TONYS, BELMONT STAKES
description: TWO live events are most prominent on the weekend television schedule, one involving the Broadway stage, the other a horse race. Any resemblance between the two is purely coincidental.

title: EUROPEANS SEEK AGREEMENT BY U.S. TO STABILIZE DOLLAR
description: On the eve of the annual economic summit conference, European leaders are striving to reach a consensus with President Reagan on stabilizing the value of the dollar and curbing trade with the Soviet bloc.

title: Wickes Talks To Creditors
description: The Wickes Companies, the diversified retailer that owed almost $2 billion when it filed for Chapter 11 status on April 24, told its creditors today that it had enough cash to stock its shelves while it shapes a reorganization plan.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 4, 1982
description: International President Reagan was conciliatory in his comments to Francois Mitterrand about the French President's Socialist Government. But by the end of Mr. Reagan's first day of his Europe visit, several issues remained dividing the two Presidents, among them France's objections to American policies in Central America, and differing views on the Falkland Islands war. The two leaders also discussed the war between Iran and Iraq. (Page A1, Col.6.) The Soviets are aiding Argentina by working to help link Argentine radar sytems into a nationwide net to guard against possible British air attacks, according to Argentine official and industry sources and foreign diplomats. They reported that more than 20 technicians were involved in the project under a secret accord between the two nations. Their presence was said to be the first evidence of a Soviet military role in the Falkland conflict. (A1:3-5.)

title: IRKED BY ATOM TEST PROTESTORS, SOVIET HAULS THEM OUT TO SEA
description: A group of shipborne protesters who included Daniel Ellsberg, the antiwar campaigner, was towed out Leningrad harbor on Wednesday after releasing 2,000 balloons carrying messages demanding an end to Soviet nuclear testing, according to an account reaching here.

title: A 'KING' OF NIGHT LOOKS NORTH
description: A lot of people in Rio de Janeiro devote themselves to lives of leisure, but none of them pursue the pastime so earnestly or make so much money at it as Ricardo Amaral.

title: Davis Wins; Thumb Hurt
description: Howard Davis Jr., the only United States gold medalist from the 1976 Montreal Olympics who has not won a world boxing title, scored a unanimous 10-round lightweight decision over Julio (Diablito) Valdez at the Sands Hotel tonight.

title: Kuwaiti Diplomat Is Reported Slain in New Delhi Shooting
description: A gunman firing from a car killed a Kuwaiti diplomat here today, a Kuwaiti official said.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 RISE 10.5%
description: The Big Three auto manufacturers reported today that sales rose 10.5 percent in the final 10 days of May, mostly as a result of a strong showing by General Motors.

title: SENATE PASSES FAMILY COURT REVISION
description: The State Senate approved a bill today that would make the first major revision in 20 years in the way the state treats juvenile delinquents.

title: LEARNING ETHNIC DANCES AT A FESTIVAL IN QUEENS
description: Ethnic music and dancing from eight regions of Central Europe, Armenia and the Balkan and Italian peninsulas can be sampled tomorrow in their most exuberant form at the seventh annual Ethnic Music Festival in Astoria, Queens, sponsored by the Ethnic Folk Arts Center.

title: CHINA DEPORTS U.S. WOMAN IT ACCUSED OF SPYING
description: An American woman who was detained for seven days after being accused of spying against China was deported today.

title: CHRYSLER SEES PROFIT IN QUARTER AND 1982
description: The Chrysler Corporation will earn an operating profit in the second quarter and for all of 1982, Lee A. Iacocca, the company's chairman, predicted today. The profit in 1982 will be recorded, he said, without the benefit of the $335 million the company received from the sale of its tank-making subsidiary in March.

title: VOLUNTARY UNITS CONFER ON PLANS TO FEED HUNGRY
description: They came from the Bronx, Brooklyn, Suffolk County and Bergen County. And each of the 50 participants had one thing in mind - how to set up emergency food programs for the poor.

title: CANADA LIFTS KEY BANK RATE
description: The Bank of Canada today raised its benchmark bank rate by almost half a point in a further effort to shore up the country's badly deteriorating dollar.

title: Eva Le Gallienne to return in 'Alice in Wonderland.'
description: EVA LE GALLIENNE will return to Broadway in ''Alice in Wonderland'' - the ''Alice in Wonderland,'' the one her Civic Repertory Theater did in 1932, the one that was revived uptown in 1947, the one in which Miss Le Gallienne plays the White Queen. This ''Alice'' will be a new production, of course; the 1932 set, for example, was a cyclorama by Irene Sharaff that unrolled across the stage. But esthetics and technology march on, and it is unlikely that John Lee Beatty, who will design the new set, will use a cyclorama. Still, the new production will be faithful to the old, which, in turn, was faithful to Lewis Carroll and the original John Tenniel drawings. Miss Le Gallienne, who will co-direct with John Strasberg, Lee Strasberg's son, will see to that. She and Florida Friebus adapted ''Alice'' for the stage.

title: SPOTLIGHT ON ART FROM AROUND THE WORLD
description: GREAT painting comes about when people just cannot get on without it. And it gets to be rediscovered and reappraised in much the same circumstances. For proof of both these propositions, we need look no further than the exhibition of ''France in the Golden Age: 17th-Century French Paintings in American Collections'' that opens tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and that can be seen there through Aug. 22.

title: Miss Jaeger Gains Final
description: Andrea Jaeger, who turns 17 Friday, defeated Chris Evert Lloyd on clay today for the second time this year and reached the final of the French Open, the world's premier clay-court tennis tournament.

title: AN EAST WEST SUMMIT
description: President Reagan's announcement that the United States and the Soviet Union will begin strategic arms negotiations at the end of the month confirms that, despite significant differences, both world powers are at last prepared to enter into a comprehensive dialogue about security and arms control. Many of us in Europe now hope that this progress in the military sphere can be followed by steps to re-establish political trust. These efforts toward improved relations are of course of great significance for the Atlantic alliance as its leading representatives gather for next week's summit meeting in Bonn.

title: Guard for Brothers
description: When the Whittington brothers -Dale, Don and Bill - made racing history by qualifying for the Indianapolis 500 they were being guarded all the time at Indianapolis by six undercover police officers of the Indiana State Police. The guard was assembled after a man who had been shot and left for dead in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., reported that he had heard his assailants say they were after the Whittingtons.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Billy Martin, the manager of the Oakland A's, has been appointed manager of the 1982 American League All-Star team. ... One of Larry Holmes's sparring partners, Jody Ballard, suffered a partly detached retina in his left eye and is now recovering after surgery in a Los Angeles hospital. ... Ron Reed, the Philadelphia Phillies relief pitcher, was fined $350 for taking part in a brawl in a game with the Cincinnati Reds Monday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt ETERNAL CURSE ON THE READER OF THESE PAGES. By Manuel Puig. 232 pages. Random House. $13.50.

title: BAKKE GRADUATING AS DEBATE OVER CASE GOES ON
description: Allan M. Bakke will graduate Friday from the medical school of the University of California here, to which he won admission through a decision by the Supreme Court four years ago this month.

title: TRY CAMP VIRGIL FOR BASIC TRAINING
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAN'S RECOVERED PORT CITY: LIFELESS WASTELAND
description: This once-bustling port city, which Iranian forces recaptured from the Iraqis 10 days ago, is a wasteland of rubble, minefields and abandoned trenches. Virtually no building has escaped destruction. There is no life in the ruins.

title: THE EXPERTS ON PRODUCT SAFETY: WHAT THEY SAY AND WHAT THEY DO
description: The five members of the Consumer Product Safety Commission do not always practice what they preach. Some of their offices have defective chrome chairs in which visitors' feet become entangled. None of their bathrooms or kitchens has an electrocution-preventing ''ground fault interceptor,'' a device that, as commissioners, they officially recommend for home wiring. And two of them will not give up defective coffee pots that were recalled two years ago.

title: Ex-Southern Chief Seen As Next Amtrak Head
description: W. Graham Claytor Jr., a highly regarded former chairman of the Southern Railway, is the leading candidate to replace Alan S. Boyd as president of Amtrak, according to sources in the Administration. Mr. Boyd has resigned effective in July.

title: POP JAZZ
description: NEW YORK is a city of contrasts. And one of the city's most striking contrasts is provided by Summerpier, a series of admissionfree jazz concerts that begins tonight at the South Street Seaport Museum's Pier 16, Fulton Street and the East River.

title: HINCKLEY'S BRAIN IS TERMED NORMAL
description: A prosecution neuroradiologist, contradicting expert defense testimony, told the jury today that ''there is no evidence of any significant abnormality whatsoever'' in CAT scans of John W. Hinckley Jr.'s brain.

title: 11 ENTERED IN BELMONT STAKES
description: Eleven 3-year-old colts were entered yesterday for the 114th running of the Belmont Stakes tomorrow, and the morning-line favorite is a horse that was not even being considered for the race only five day ago.

title: 50 IN PEACE GROUP TO GET VISAS FOR SESSION AT U.N.
description: Fifty members of the World Peace Council who were denied visas to attend United Nations disarmament sessions starting here Monday have now been approved for restricted entry, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said yesterday.

title: Nine Days to Learn
description: Richard Nixon raced to Europe after four weeks in office, Jimmy Carter after four months. Ronald Reagan waited l6 months, a delay that symbolizes the problems he confronts there.

title: JUSTICE O'CONNOR FINDS A THEME IN STATES' RIGHTS
description: As she nears the end of her first Supreme Court term, Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor has emerged as one of the Court's most ardent champions of states' rights, a development with important implications for a Court in the midst of re-examining the balance of power between the states and the Federal Government.

title: Trend Toward Rookies
description: According to the agent for the National Basketball Association's scoring leader, George Gervin, many teams in the league will trim their hefty payrolls by bringing in more rookies next season. Pat Healy said in Seattle that, after discussions with front-office officials around the league, he felt that lower-priced rookies will take over the lower spots on rosters that had previously been occupied by highly paid veterans. At the end of the playoffs, 68 players will become free agents and Healy predicted that ''only about 25 percent'' would be playing in the N.B.A. next season.

title: The Ace of Aces
description: Mancil Davis, 28, has broken the world record for aces by a professional golfer.

title: Two Bills on Rape Signed by O'Neill
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill announced today that he had signed a bill to make it harder for defendants in rape cases to raise the victim's prior sexual history as evidence. Mr. O'Neill also signed a $25,000 appropriation for counseling of rape victims, and a bill to allow the police to fingerprint 14- and 15-year-olds who are charged with felonies.

title: Meanwhile Back at The Ranch
description: President Reagan is off to Europe to attend the Western economic summit conference, which is a new rite of the Presidency - but his trip also fits in nicely with one of the oldest rules of the office: when in trouble, travel abroad.

title: Abitibi Lifts Prices
description: Abitibi-Price Inc. raised newsprint prices 5 percent to $525 (United States funds) a metric ton, effective last Tuesday. A company official said that the price was expected to be maintained, but Frederick S. Burbidge, chairman of Canadian Pacific Ltd., which owns CIP Inc., another major newsprint producer, said it would not. ''There is some discounting going on,'' he said.

title: QUEENS DAY LEADS A WEEKEND FULL OF FAIRS
description: IN addition to the Great Irish Fair in Brooklyn, streets and parks all over town will be alive this weekend with music, dance and other amusements.

title: THEODORE FRENCH
description: Theodore French, a lawyer who retired from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in 1979 after 34 years of Government service, died May 25 at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. Mr. French, a resident of Rockville, Md., was 65 years old.

title: AFTER VERSAILLES, THE DELUGE?
description: The most pressing question for Western leaders as they meet at the summit conference in Versailles today must be: What should be done to bring back prosperity and work to our countries?

title: DELBELLO SEEKING DEADLINE FOR NUCLEAR ACCIDENT PLAN
description: The Westchester County Executive said today that he and other county officials doubted that residents could be safely evacuated from the Indian Point area in the event of a nuclear accident.

title: Women Rally for Rights In the Illinois Capitol
description: Seventeen women chained themselves together and blocked the doors of the Illinois Senate today, asking lawmakers to ''break our chains'' by ratifying the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

title: DANCE: FELD BALLET BACK
description: THE Feld Ballet, which last performed in New York City in 1978, opened a four-week season at the new Joyce Theater Wednesday. The dancers are still strong, alert and full of sophisticated personal charm. And Eliot Feld is as provocative a choreographer as ever.

title: B.P. Down Sharply In Quarter
description: The British Petroleum Company, the world's sixth-largest oil company, said its net income for the first quarter, ended March 31, plummeted to the equivalent of $162 million, or 36 cents per American Depository Receipt, from $703 million, or $1.73 per A.D.R., a year earlier.

title: ARGENTINA APPEALS FOR THIRD WORLD SUPPORT
description: Argentina appealed ''with true passion'' today for third world support in the Falkland crisis. It accused Britain and the United States of planning to convert the islands into a military base as part of a new South Atlantic alliance.

title: 5 INDICTED FOR PLAINVIEW ASSAULTS
description: A Nassau County grand jury indicted five Brooklyn men today for an attack on a Plainview family and their guests last Saturday morning.

title: Florida Bank Sets Purchase
description: Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., which is the focus of a takeover fight involving several banks, said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy nine First Marine Bank offices from Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. for $19 million in cash.

title: The U.N. Today; June 4, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. SECURITY COUNCIL

title: SYNANON SUIT AGAINST TV STATION SETTLED OUT OF COURT IN CALIFORNIA
description: A $21 million slander suit filed by the Synanon Foundation against KGO-TV, a television station owned and operated by ABC, was settled out of court Wednesday after the jury heard five months of evidence.

title: BRIEFING
description: Now, the Gender Gap

title: CITY TEACHER TRANSFERS IN MINORITY PLAN FOUGHT
description: Officials of the New York City Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers yesterday denounced a threat by the Federal Government to require the transfer of teachers to improve the racial balance of teachers in the city's public schools.

title: Arlington Boycott Ends As Governor Intervenes
description: Horsemen at Arlington Park ended their boycott of the track today and planned to resume racing Friday. The boycott had caused the cancellation of cards the last three days.

title: 2 SPANISH COUP LEADERS GIVEN 30 YEARS
description: A military court today sentenced the two leaders of last year's attempted coup to 30 years' imprisonment and imposed a six-year sentence on a general who had once been King Juan Carlos's tutor and aide.

title: Raider Ruling Delayed
description: Federal Judge Harry Pregerson said Wednesday that he would not decide on motions for an injunction that could move the Oakland Raiders to Los Angeles until after final motions were made June 14. A six-woman jury in the United States District Court on May 7 found the National Football League guilty of antitrust violations in refusing to permit the move.

title: ERIN GO BROOKLYN! IT'S THE 2-DAY IRISH FAIR
description: LAST June a million New Yorkers assembled on some grassy turf on the Brooklyn side of the East River to attend the first Great Irish Fair. They had such a grand time that this weekend they'll do it all over again.

title: Israeli Police Question Maimed Arab Mayor
description: Bassam al-Shaka, the deposed mayor of Nablus in the occupied West Bank, was detained for questioning by the Israeli police in Nablus today after his Israeli bodyguards complained that he had cursed them and spat at them in the town's central square.

title: Competitor Acts On Transit Deal
description: The Budd Company of Michigan filed a countervailing duty petition here today that seeks protection from the Federal Government against the offer made by the Canadian manufacturer, Bombardier Inc., to build subway cars for the Metropolitan Transit Authority.

title: WHAT IT'S LIKE TO DANCE IN THE ELIOT FELD TROUPE
description: It has been four years since the Eliot Feld Ballet performed in New York, but it isn't likely that two Feld dancers named Edmund LaFosse and Megan Murphy could have been forgotten in the interval. Lyrical, with a long, easy body line and a thoughtful approach to all they dance, the dreamy-seeming Mr. LaFosse and the piquant Miss Murphy have unmistakable looks of their own. And this weekend they will be seen in a wide-ranging selection of new and old ballets by Feld at the Joyce Theater, the company's new home in Chelsea.

title: For Latin enthusiasts.
description: Paintings and sculpture of interest to Latin American collectors and Pre-Columbian enthusiasts will be offered in three sales next week. The roster of Latin American artists represented in two of these sales reads like a who's who of the field.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 16.00 16.00 20.00 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 13.45 13.05 20.05 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.06 12.06 15.67 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.07 12.06 14.65 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 14.02 13.99 13.67 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 13.64 13.59 13.01 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 15.93 15.95 14.81 MUNICIPAL BONDS 13.32 13.32 11.27 6-MONTH SAVINGS 12.172 CERTIFICATES** %* Split rate, 16.00-16.50 ** Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Savings Unit Branches
description: The Justice Department today urged the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to lift restrictions on interstate branching by federally chartered savings and loan associations.

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 4, 1982; The Economy
description: Auto sales by the Big Three auto makers rose 10.5 percent in the final 10 days of May, completing the first full month of increasing sales since September. In the May 21-30 period, G.M.'s sales were up 15.2 percent, while Chrysler's rose 5.7 percent and Ford's, 0.5 percent. Analysts, while welcoming the gains, noted that sales are still running far short of the industry's goals for 1982. (Page D1.)

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Billboard, a trade publication. Singles and albums are determined by national sales and radio air play reports. An asterisk indicates an especially fast-selling record. Albums ThisLast WeekWeek 11Tug of War* Paul McCartney 22Success Hasn't Spoiled Rick Springfield 33Asia* Asia 44Diver Down* Van Halen 55Original Musiquarium I* Stevie Wonder 66Chariots of Fire Vangelis 77Dare* Human League 88Aldo Nova Aldo Nova 99Always on My Mind Willie Nelson 1010Blackout Scorpion Singles ThisLast WeekWeek 11Ebony & Ivory* McCartney & Wonder 22Don't Talk to Strangers* Rick Springfield 33I've Never Been to Me Charlene 44867-5309/Jenny Tommy Tutone 55The Other Woman* Ray Parker Jr. 67Don't You Want Me* Human League 78Always on My Mind Willie Nelson 811Heat of the Moment* Asia 96'65 Love Affair Paul Davis 1016Rosanna* Toto Copyright c 1982 by Billboard Publications Inc.

title: SOUTH DAKOTA EXPORTING SUSPECTS
description: Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota says he has carried out a threat to export criminal defendants to California.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DETROIT PREPARES FOR GRAND PRIX RACE
description: The scream of high-powered racing cars will shatter the decorum of Detroit's downtown business district this weekend when the Motor City opens its first international Grand Prix automobile race, and any resemblance to the more famous event in the European principality of Monaco will be purely intentional.

title: 3 Navy Crews Qualify For 80th I.R.A. Regatta
description: The United States Naval Academy qualified its freshman, junior varsity and varsity heavyweight eight-oared crews in the opening heats of the 80th Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta today.

title: PROTESTERS OLD AND NEW FORGE ALLIANCE FOR ANTINUCLEAR RALLY
description: The nuclear disarmament rally that is expected to draw hundreds of thousands of people into Manhattan on June 12 has been conceived and organized by groups with a history of protest reaching back to anti-Vietnam War days and by a new set of protesters.

title: Jockey Sent to Jail
description: Ronnie Franklin, the 22-year-old jockey who in 1979 won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness with Spectacular Bid, yesterday pleaded guilty to a charge of possession of cocaine and was jailed pending the outcome of a pre-sentencing investigation.

title: Debt Extended At Wienerwald
description: The worldwide Wienerwald restaurant group said today that it had succeeded in averting bankruptcy because a group of Swiss and West German creditor banks had agreed to extend repayments of the company's debt.

title: NEW 'STAR TREK' FULL OF GADGETS AND FUN
description: NOW this is more like it: after the colossal, big-budget bore that was ''Star Trek: The Motion Picture,'' here comes a sequel that's worth its salt. The second Star Trek movie is swift, droll and adventurous, not to mention appealingly gadget-happy. It's everything the first one should have been and wasn't.

title: WEINBERGER CONFIRMS NEW STRATEGY ON ATOM WAR
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger acknowledged today that the Reagan Administration had adopted a strategy for fighting a protracted nuclear war and defended it as necessary to deter an attack from the Soviet Union.

title: RANGE FOR WORD BUFFS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE A.M.A. POSITION ON CURBING THE F.T.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: Fidelity Case Reversal
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Federal Government illegally seized the financially troubled Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of Oakland and he ordered the thrift institution's forced receivership lifted.

title: YANKEES LOSE, 3-1 ON 4 HITS
description: If American League teams have been wondering how to make certain that they beat Tommy John, the Toronto Blue Jays have the answer: Pitch Luis Leal against him.

title: LEVENSON AND MORGAN TIED FOR LEAD WITH 68's
description: Gavin Levenson, a 28-year-old South African who needed three hours to find his way here from Washington, came out of the dusk and rain this evening to tie Gil Morgan for the lead in the opening round of the Kemper Open.

title: Advertising; Superman Product To B.& B.
description: BENTON & BOWLES has become the first New York agency for the the Kane-Miller Corporation. Your eyes betray nonrecognition of Kane-Miller. They own Sunnyland Refining. Still that look. Sunnyland makes Superman Peanut Butter. You say ''Superman what?'' Well, that's a one out of four recognition factor. Not bad for starters. The blankness is understandable. Kane-Miller is a food processor specializing in the private label area, a real behind-the-scenes operator. And its Sunnyland Refining has a three-and-a-half-year-old peanut butter factory, which like most factories of its kind these days has excess capacity.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We in the West have big problems, and we must not pretend that we can solve them overnight.

title: GROUP WILL STUDY THE ENVIRONMENT
description: The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation announced today that it would provide $15 million over the next five years to create and operate an institute devoted to research and policy planning on global environmental issues.

title: News Analysis
description: ''Some things are worse than not having a budget,'' Representative Trent Lott remarked today. ''It would be worse to have a budget that taxes the American people to a degree that we couldn't stand, that undermines military strength, that greatly increases Federal spending or cuts Federal spending too much.''

title: Long Solar Flare Registered
description: The largest solar flare in 18 months was registered early today by forecasters at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The flare began at 5:43 A.M. local time and lasted for 30 minutes in the southeast area of the sun.

title: ISRAELI AMBASSADOR WOUNDED IN LONDON SHOOTING
description: The Israeli Ambassador to Britain was shot and critically wounded Thursday night as he left a party at a luxury hotel.

title: Blurred Choice in New Jersey
description: New Jersey Republicans have the advantage in Tuesday's primary election for U.S. Senator. They must choose between only two candidates. For Democrats, the choice is blurred by a pack of nine.

title: Israel Says Palestinians Dig Tunnels to Protect Artillery
description: Maj. Gen. Yehoshua Saguy, chief of Israeli military intelligence, said today that Palestinian guerrillas were digging tunnels into Lebanese mountainsides to shelter their artillery and rocket lauchers.

title: FILM: 'CHAN IS MISSING' AT CINEMA STUDIO
description: ''Chan Is Missing'' was shown as part of the 1982 New Directors/New Films Series at the Festival Theater. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times on April 24, 1982. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio, Broadway and West 66th Street.

title: TURKEY FREEING EX-PREMIER, BUT HE IS STILL FACING CHARGES
description: A Turkish military court ordered former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit freed from prison today, but he still faces two separate charges and possible jail sentences.

title: 2 Bonanno Brothers in Plea
description: Two sons of the reputed Mafia chieftain Joseph Bonanno and two other men pleaded not guilty Wednesday to charges of fraud, interstate transportation of stolen property and conspiracy.

title: WYOMING'S COAL BOOM SLOWS
description: The great concrete silos stand out sharply against the distant horizon, a line of 200-feet-tall, windowless towers that parallel State Highway 59 as it rolls north and south from here, through the desolate hills of Wyoming's Campbell County.

title: MONSANTO RESEARCH PACT AIMS TO CUT ACADEMIC CONTROVERSY
description: Washington University and the Monsanto Company, both based in St. Louis, Mo., announced yesterday that they had signed a $23.5 million, five-year agreement to collaborate in biomedical research.

title: FRANCE AND AMERICA
description: On the eve of Ronald Reagan's visit to France and Europe, a diplomatic counselor at the Elysee Palace affirmed that ''everything'' separated France from the United States. Everything except one thing: the fact that both countries are part of the same community and that they have, after all, the same moral values and the same material interests at stake.

title: Friday; NUCLEAR TALE AT THE PUBLIC
description: ''Dead End Kids,'' a multimedia history of nuclear power from the alchemists to the cold war, drew praise from the critics and sold-out audiences when the Mabou Mines company presented it at the Public Theater in 1980. The production, conceived and directed by JoAnne Akalaitis, combined melodrama, mystery, comedy, dance and film. It has now returned to the Public, 425 Lafayette Street, for three weeks. Performances at 8 P.M. with Sunday matinees at 3. Tickets are $8 (with last-minute tickets available for $4). Information: 598-7150. DANCE GRADS SHOW THEIR STUFF

title: 'COMEBACK TRAIL,' A '74 COMEDY, OPENS AT THE THALIA
description: THE best thing in ''The Comeback Trail'' is the swimming star Buster Crabbe, who looks trim, dives gracefully and speaks in a mellifluous voice not unlike President Reagan's. He's not on screen for long, through, and the rest of the movie is all wet.

title: Boston Bank Sets 16% Prime
description: The First National Bank of Boston lowered its prime interest rate yesterday to 16 percent from 16 1/2 percent, the second major bank to do so in the last 10 days.

title: REPRISE ON McCARRAN ACT; News Analysis
description: Thirty years ago, in the middle of the McCarthy era, Senator Pat McCarran told the United States Senate of the urgent need for drastic changes in America's immigration policies.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: DIONNE SLATER stood off to one side of the penguin preserve within t he grounds of the aquarium Wednesday evening, looking at a covey of t he small South African birds, which are black except for their whitec hests. ''I wonder,'' she said softly, ''if anyone will show up in e vening clothes.''

title: Francis Stays on Bench
description: Emile Francis, president and general manager of the St. Louis Blues, took over as coach for the final month of the National Hockey League season after dismissing Red Berenson on March 9. Yesterday, the former Ranger coach and general manager announced that he would remain as coach next season.

title: Owner of Karen E Cited as Negligent
description: Richard Lublin, the owner of the yacht Karen E - which collided with a barge and sank, killing his wife, daughter and three neighbors - was charged by the Coast Guard yesterday with negligently operating the craft.

title: MUSIC: NAUMBERG SYMPHONY
description: THE whole evening was low key, except for what sounded like howitzers going off now and then. The weather was mild, and there were no long speeches.

title: FREEZE ON HIRING ORDERED BY KOCH PENDING STATE AID
description: Mayor Koch, citing uncertainty whether the State Legislature would approve his request for $519 million in aid and taxes, yesterday ordered a freeze on hiring, promotions and merit raises in all municipal agencies.

title: Gene Wilder's plans include Gilda Radner.
description: GILDA RADNER and Gene Wilder are lunching in the dining room of a hotel where even the waiters are French, never mind the menu.
