And Miss Radner is asking for her usual, a can of tuna fish. She has also brought along her own coleslaw. It worries her that she's hurting the hotel's feelings -somehow the hotel has become a person to her - but not enough so she'll mess around with any of that fancy food.

title: Clarostat Buys Dissident Stake
description: A proxy fight for control of the Clarostat Manufacturing Company, a New Hampshire producer of electrical supplies, has been resolved with the company's repurchase of the stock holdings of four dissident shareholders, Clarostat announced.

title: ART: NEW CAST OF RODIN'S 'GATES OF HELL' ON VIEW
description: AS of this morning, visitors to the Charles Engelhard Court at the Metropolitan Museum can see the bronze cast of Auguste Rodin's ''The Gates of Hell'' that was commissioned by the California financier B. Gerald Cantor. The cast was first seen at the retrospective exhibition called ''Rodin Reconsidered'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington from June 1981 to last month. It will go to the Minneapolis Institute of Arts and several other museums before finding its permanent home at the Stanford University Museum of Art, to which Mr. Cantor has already given more than 150 works by Rodin.

title: SONG: JANE BRYDEN, SOPRANO
description: INTELLIGENCE isn't always quite enough. But sometimes one can recognize a deficiency of technique or sheer talent in a performer and still be pleased by the results, as was the case with Jane Bryden's well-attended recital Tuesday night at the Abraham Goodman House.

title: PARK AVE. FLORIST IS SEIZED IN HEORIN CASE AND LINKED TO BOMBINGS
description: The owner of a Park Avenue flower shop was charged yesterday by Federal authorities with heading a heroin-trafficking operation. The authorities said the florist had also told an undercover narcotics agent that he had twice ordered a competitor's shop to be bombed.

title: NEW ROCKET WILL CARRY SHUTTLE'S SATELLITES INTO HIGHER ORBITS
description: A new propulsion system for launching satellites from the space shuttle into higher orbits, a solid-fuel rocket known as the inertial upper stage, was unveiled yesterday after a four-year development program marked by technical problems, schedule delays and excess costs.

title: MUSIC: PRO ARTE CHORALE DOES MENDELSSOHN
description: ATE DEUM composed by Mendelssohn that seems never to have been performed previously in this country was sung at Abraham Goodman House Wednesday night by the Pro Arte Chorale of New Jersey under the direction of Roger Nierenberg.

title: 2 in Candor Corp.  Accused of Fraud
description: A Federal grand jury handed up a 42-count indictment yesterday against the head of a bankrupt diamond company and his wife.

title: BALDRIGE REPORTED IN STEEL TALKS
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige is conducting secret negotiations with the European Economic Community and the American steel industry that could lead to new limitations on steel imports here, industry sources reported today.

title: Ayer in New Moves With A.T.& T., G.M.
description: Two events of note at N.W. Ayer yesterday. One concerned outgoing traffic on the Long Lines division of American Telephone and Telegraph and the other, incoming traffic from General Motors.

title: Rumania to Be Warned On Jewish Emigration
description: President Reagan and members of Congress intend to warn Rumania's Government that it could lose preferential trade status if it does not expand Jewish emigration to Israel.

title: Flood in Sumatra Leaves 176 Dead
description: Heavy flooding swept through the farmland of Indonesia's Sumatra island today, killing 176 people and leaving 2,500 homeless in the worst floods to hit the province this century, officials said.

title: Bridge: 4 Star Teams Begin Battle In the Reisinger Semifinals
description: Four star teams last night began the first of two semifinal sessions in one of the world's oldest annual bridge events - the 52-year-old Reisinger Knockout Team Championship. The semifinal pairings in the event, held at the Beverly East Club, Lexington Avenue and 50th Street, were, as listed by captain: John Lowenthal vs. John Solodar and Barry Goren vs. Alan Greenberg. The captains are all New Yorkers.

title: Stake in Blue Bell
description: Bass Brothers Enterprises said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had raised its stake in Blue Bell Inc. to 812,000 shares, or 6.4 percent. It said it purchased the shares on the New York Stock Exchange between April 6 and May 21 for $24.06 to $25.08 a share. Sid R. Bass also reported ownership of 170,570 shares acquired for investment, and Bass Brothers said it intended to acquire more than 10 percent of Blue Bell, ''assuming appropriate market conditions exist.''

title: Refugees in Florida Get Emergency Federal Aid
description: Emergency aid, described by one state official as a ''drop in the bucket,'' was being put in place today for about 18,000 Cuban and Haitian refugees cut off from Federal welfare funds by the Reagan Administration.

title: Beethoven Finale
description: The final concert of the season by the Beethoven Society's Composer String Quartet will be given on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall, Broadway and 65th Street.

title: CONCERT: LEINSDORF HELPS OUT
description: KLAUS TENNSTEDT is the cult conductor of the moment, and so his cancellation of this week's Tuesday and Wednesday New York Philharmonic concerts in Avery Fisher Hall came as a particular disappointment. Mr. Tennstedt suffered a minor injury in a fall but is expected to recover in time for his Philharmonic date next Tuesday.

title: 21 CHARGED IN SWEATSHOP CASES
description: Two men were arrested yesterday in the Bronx and criminal charges were filed against 19 other persons in what State Attorney General Robert Abrams described as ''the state's most significant crackdown on sweatshops.''

title: Inventor Sues On Machines
description: Jerome Lemelson, a Metuchen, N.J., inventor, has filed an antitrust suit against the Bendix Corporation and the Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company. He charges that the two companies conspired to boycott his patents relating to automatic measuring machines used in inspecting parts.

title: A.M.C. To Add Renault Models
description: The American Motors Corporation said that its recently enacted $150 million employee investment plan would enable it to build additional Renault models at its Kenosha, Wis., plant starting next summer.

title: Brown's President Adds Chief's Post
description: Brown Group Inc., one of the nation's largest shoe manufacturers, announced yesterday that B.A. Bridgewater Jr., president and chief operating officer, had been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer.

title: Two Summit Reagans
description: Two Ronald Reagans represent this nation at the Western economic summit meeting: one is eager to be liked, the other is anxious to be respected.

title: Funds' Assets At $201 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose $1.06 billion during the week ended Wednesday, to another record high of $201 billion, the Investment Company Institute, the industry trade organization, said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Trust Co. has appointed W. Douglas Cadogan, Brian J. Farmer, Richard N. Geib, Neil Harding, Thomas W. Hardy and Steven A. Kol-tai vice presidents.

title: Gulf Canada Well
description: Gulf Canada Ltd. said its East Tarsuit N-44 well in Canada's Beaufort Sea has an estimated sustained production capability of 3,500 barrels of oil a day. It said it had completed testing of the well and would drill further to assess the size of the oil reservoir. Partners in the well are Gulf Canada's Gulf Canada Resources Inc., Dome Petroleum Ltd., Norcen Energy Resources Ltd., the Mobil Corporation's Mobil Oil Canada Ltd. and the Canada Development Corporation's Canterra Energy Ltd.

title: Bank Merger Complete
description: The previously announced merger of the Erie Savings Bank and the First Savings and Loan Association of Poughkeepsie has been completed, officials said today. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board gave its approval Monday. Erie Savings said it was now the nation's largest federally chartered savings institution.

title: CAMERON'S GOAL IS 400 RECORD
description: Bertland (Bert) Cameron has never met Lee Evans and has never seen him run, but Evans has something Cameron wants before Cameron leaves town Sunday.

title: 3 UNIONS REJECT NONWAGE OFFER DETAILED BY CITY
description: New York City's negotiators presented contract proposals yesterday to leaders of the Uniformed Forces Coalition but held back on any wage offer because of budget uncertainties.

title: 'Chief' Is Target
description: Lawyers for the Cleveland Indians and a group that objects to the team's symbol, a grinning Indian named Chief Wahoo, say they are near agreement on a settlement of the dispute that began in 1972.

title: Sports of The Times; A Jockey's Life In the Fast Lane
description: JACK KAENEL, all of 16 years old, pulled into Belmont on Wednesday morning in a rented white 1982 Cadillac. The vehicle replaced the custom Cadillac he wrecked last month, just before he and Aloma's Ruler won the Preakness.

title: Wages at Hecla
description: The Hecla Mining Company said that it was temporarily rolling back wages and freezing salary adjustments, effective Sunday. It said salaries and wages would be reduced 10 percent for a majority of employees. The directors, president and vice president have accepted a 15 percent reduction.

title: 'POLTERGEIST' FROM SPIELBERG
description: MORE than any other Hollywood film maker of his generation, Steven Spielberg has preserved the wonderment of childhood while growing up to make the sort of movies he always loved as a child, but bigger and better and far more imaginative. He's a brilliant technican who still has doubts about the dark.

title: Chevron Cutbacks
description: A seven-month construction delay in Utah is forcing staff cutbacks and work slowdowns at the Chevron Oil Company's Clear Creek shale oil project near De Beque, Colo., the company said. It also said it would reorganize its Denver and Grand Junction offices and eliminate some of the 48 workers in them. Clear Creek is planned as a 100,000-barrel-a-day operation, with both underground and surface mines.

title: AT LICENSING SHOW, 'CUTENESS' IS A MUST
description: ''I'm looking specifically at cats,'' Dan Frantz said. There were numerous cats, not to mention pandas, raccoons and other unendangered species at the second annual Licensing and Merchandising Show, which concluded a two-day run yesterday at the New York Hilton.

title: MANY OF DICK HYMAN'S MANY TALENTS ON DISPLAY
description: THE musical activities of Dick Hyman have been so multitudinous over the last 25 years that there has been speculation that he may have been successfully cloned. His guises have included pianist, organist, whistler, singer, arranger, conductor and composer for films, television and musical theater in pop, jazz and classical veins.

title: Third Victim Is Found In Explosion at Plant
description: A third victim was found today in the smoldering rubble of a plastics factory by a team of engineers trying to contain and neutralize a spilled mixture of hazardous chemicals.

title: Lloyd Rejoins Giants After Cancer Battle
description: Wellington Mara, the president of the Giants, was standing at the edge of the field today as his players came out for the first practice of a three-day minicamp. When Dan Lloyd walked by carrying his helmet, Mara said, ''Dan, I hope you remember which is the front and which is the back.''

title: AID TO EL SALVADOR: UNDILUTED CONDITIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET AID IN LINKING ARGENTINE RADAR IS REPORTED
description: Soviet technicians have been working to help link Argentine radar systems into a nationwide net to guard against possible British air attacks, according to Argentine official and industry sources and foreign diplomats.

title: Dow Drops as Trading Slows
description: The stock market declined slightly yesterday in slower trading, with issues responding to corporate developments showing the biggest price moves.

title: Red Wings Are Bought By Pizza Chain Owner
description: The Detroit Red Wings, the last-place finishers in the Norris Division for four seasons, have been sold to Mike Ilitch, the 53-year-old owner of a pizza store chain.

title: HOUSE ADOPTS NEW BILL TO PROTECT IDENTITIES OF AGENTS
description: The House approved a compromise bill today that would impose penalties of up to 10 years in prison and fines of up to $50,000 on those convicted of making public the identities of covert United States intelligence agents, informers and sources.

title: Market Place; Pac-Man And Beyond
description: Investor fears that the video game market could be approaching saturation have hurt Warner Communications shares. But fans are rallying around this maker of Pac-Man video games, the dominant factor in that marketplace.

title: UNFORGOTTEN LAWYER
description: To the Editor:

title: Fatal Plane Crash Studied by U.S.
description: Federal inspectors studied the wreckage of a twin-engine airplane today as they tried to determine why it rolled over after takeoff from Tompkins County Airport and crashed. The pilot and all four passengers were killed in the accident Thursday afternoon.

title: Canada Seeks Cutback
description: Canada renewed its demand today that Japan reduce its car exports to Canada to 146,000 units in the year ending next March, the Kyodo News Service reported. Japan exported 174,000 cars to Canada the previous year.

title: STATE DEPT. SAYS A 'SOVIET FRONT' WON'T GET VISAS
description: The State Department said today that except in ''special circumstances,'' visas for ''members of Soviet-front groups'' wanting to attend the United Nations disarmament sessions would not be granted by the United States. The sessions start in New York on Monday.

title: Stroh Brewery Mortgages Unit
description: The Stroh Brewery Company helped pay for its $494.7 million acquisition of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company by mortgaging its Detroit brewing facilities, according to a national mortgage insurer.

title: Iran Demands Payment Of $150 Billion by Iraq
description: Iran today demanded $150 billion from Iraq and the trial of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, as its two main conditions for ending the 20-month-old Persian Gulf war, the Iranian press agency reported.

title: Player Pleads Guilty
description: Quintin Dailey, an all-America basketball guard for the University of San Francisco, pleaded guilty today to assaulting a nursing student in her dormitory room. In return for the guilty plea on a nonsexual charge, prosecutors agreed to drop three other charges, two of which were sexually related. George Walker, Dailey's attorney, said that the player would be sentenced June 25 to three years' probation on the felony assault charge.

title: PARTY CHIEFS PLAN BUDGET STRATEGIES
description: House Democratic and Republican leaders worked separately today on new budget proposals and strategies to take to the House floor on Wednesday.

title: VIGNETTES AT VERSAILLES: GUARDS AND GRANDEUR
description: If this particular American tourist did not exist, French television would have invented him. Around 10 o'clock this morning, complete with plaid shirt and camera, he was shown at the locked front gate of the Palace of Versailles. ''What summit?'' he asked the guard.

title: QUEENS ELDERLY GATHER TO HEAR THEIR DEFENDER
description: They all came because of the same concern - to many of them it is a matter of survival - and because they revered the same leader. And when Representative Claude Pepper, the 81-year-old chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging, arrived yesterday at a town meeting in Far Rockaway, Queens, he did not disappoint the more than 350 elderly residents who crowded into the Gustave Hartman Y.M./Y.W.H.A. to hear him.

title: 11.52 DROP PUTS DOW AT 804.98
description: The stock market fell yesterday to its lowest level in more than two months as investors reacted to the steady declines in the market over the last two weeks and became fearful of an even sharper selloff ahead.

title: ARGENTINA AND CUBA SIGN TRADE PACT
description: Argentina's Foreign Minister signed a $100 million trade agreement with Cuba Thursday night to underline the new friendship that has sprung up as a result of the Falkland crisis.

title: YOUNG SEEN FACING DIM PROSPECT ON SUMMER JOBS
description: Hundreds of thousands of young people will soon flood the job market in their quest for summer work. Most will be disappointed. The students will find that the recession and high rates of adult unemployment, cutbacks in Federal programs for youth and a failure of private enterprise to fill the gap have drained away the jobs. Experts who deal with the subject say they expect that only 40 percent of students seeking summer jobs to find them, and some authorities, including the United States Conference of Mayors, are worried about violence among idle young people.

title: WASHINGTON'S BAD NEWS FOR SPECIES
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBATES AND TV ADVERTISING CAP JERSEY SENATE CONTESTS
description: The nine candidates for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New Jersey will turn their attention over the final weekend of the campaign to getting their supporters to the polls.

title: FREED AMERICAN FLIES HOME FROM CHINA
description: A young American teacher accused of stealing state secrets left China today after being detained and interrogated for nearly a week before being expelled.

title: Walton in Settlement
description: An out-of-court settlement has been reached in Bill Walton's $5.6 million suit against the team physician of the Portland Trail Blazers. The settlement was announced today, more than two years after the suit was filed and five years after Walton led the Trail Blazers to the National Basketball Association title.

title: Main Issues At Versailles
description: The principal issues at this year's economic summit meeting are the following: INTEREST RATES. America's allies argue that high United States interest rates are depressing their currencies, slowing business investments in other nations and impeding growth.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Flight Transportation Corp. is offering 25,000 units, representing a total of $25 million of 11 1/4 percent sinking fund debentures, due in 1995, with warrants to purchase 1.4 million shares of common stock. Each unit, consisting of $1,000 principal amount of debentures and 57 warrants, is priced at $750.

title: ANTI-NUCLEAR GROUPS ARE USING PROFESSIONS AS RALLYING POINTS
description: Organizing within the professions, new nuclear disarmament groups have spread throughout the metropolitan area in the last two months. There are Dancers for Disarmament and Nurses for a Non-Nuclear Future, Social Workers for Nuclear Disarmament and Architects for Social Responsibility. There are new organizations of magazine editors and life insurance salesmen, psychotherapists and cancer researchers. And they have all been moved to action by what they see as the threat of a nuclear holocaust.

title: INSTRUCTION DOLLARS THAT FURTHER NO INSTRUCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Mitsubishi Stock Deal
description: The Mitsubishi Aluminum Company said today that it would buy back the 8.8 percent stake, or 1,830,000 shares, that the Reynolds Metals Company holds. It did not disclose the cost.

title: MAPLE UNABLE TO RIDE IN BELMONT
description: Eddie Maple suffered at least one cracked rib in a spill at Belmont Park yesterday and will be unable to ride Conquistador Cielo, the morning-line favorite for the 114th Belmont Stakes today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style Page on May 16 incorrectly identified the nation's oldest college humor magazine. It is the sporadic Yale Record, started in 1872, four years before The Harvard Lampoon, which is published five times a year.

title: Trouble on the Colts
description: Roger Carr, a leading receiver for the Baltimore Colts, is not looking forward to the regime of Frank Kush, the new coach.

title: LAWRENCE H. CAMP
description: Lawrence H. Camp, immediate past president and chief executive officer of the Chesapeake Corporation of Virginia, which manufactures kraft paper, died Wednesday after he was stricken by a heart attack.

title: NORTH CAROLINA SENATE BARS VOTE ON EQUAL RIGHTS PLAN
description: The North Carolina Senate voted today, 27 to 23, to put aside the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, apparently killing the measure in this state.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Thursday about Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, in- correctly identified Lieut. Richard C. Moody, who was named Lieutenant Governor of the Falklands in 1841. He was an army officer.

title: Radio Station Sale
description: The owners of WAVZ-AM and WKCI-FM have agreed in principle to sell the radio stations to the Eastern Broadcasting Corporation for $6 million in cash, a spokesman said today. The sale of the stations, now owned by Kops Monahan Communications Inc. of New Haven, is subject to final agreement and the approval of the Federal Communications Commission, according to the president of Kops, Daniel W. Kops, and Eastern's president, Roger A. Neuhoff.

title: F.T.C.'S EXXON CASE IS FIZZLING OUT
description: The Federal Trade Commission is expected to act soon on a staff recommendation to drop its three-year-old antitrust suit against the Exxon Corporation for its acquisition of the Reliance Electric Company.

title: 'STAUNCH' SUPPORT OF U.S. AND FRANCE IS CITED BY BRITAIN
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain conferred separately today with President Reagan and President Francois Mitterrand of France and received what British officials said was staunch support for British military actions and plans in the Falkland Islands.

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO SUPPORT A BYRD OPPONENT IN VIRGINIA
description: Entering the political minefield that is this year's race for the United States Senate in Virginia, President Reagan is sending a discouraging word to Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 5, 1982; The Summit
description: The economic summit meeting formally opened in Versailles, France, with the heads of the seven leading industrial nations at odds over how to ease the world recession. (Page 1.) A plan to defuse the Europeans' worry over volatile currency rates and high interest rates may emerge. (30.) An array of electronics devices at Versailles underlined President Mitterrand's stress on technology. (31.)

title: Kuwaiti Diplomat Slain At Home in New Delhi
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has ordered an investigation into the murder of a senior Kuwaiti diplomat who was shot and killed at his home here today by an unidentified gunman.

title: Miami Beats Maine, 7-2,
description: Phil Lane's three-run homer in the second inning sparked Miami to a 7-2 baseball victory over Maine in the first round of the College World Series tonight. Miami (50-18-1) added a run in the third inning and three in the fourth, helped by Javier Velazquez's two-run double. Maine is 32-13.

title: Kinney to Sell Car Parking Unit
description: The National Kinney Corporation agreed in principle to sell its car parking businesses to the chairman of Kinney System Inc., its leading car parking subsidiary, for an amount that would net it $50 million after expenses.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. Spain. 1955. West Germany. 2. That nuclear conflict with the Soviet Union could last ''over a protracted period.'' 3.

title: Three on the Albany Seesaw
description: The New York State Budget has been balanced well enough to persuade bankers to lend the state a new $3 billion. But in the eyes of anyone who understands the need for more state aid to localities and Governor Carey's view of probable revenues, the balance is no steadier than a seesaw's. While Mr. Carey and the Senate Majority Leader, Warren Anderson, disagree about how to stop the teetering, the Assembly Speaker, Stanley Fink, has had the daring to do something about it. But that should be the Governor's job.

title: OUTCAST VIETNAM CHILDREN STILL HOPE
description: Scores of children and adolescents of mixed American and Vietnamese parentage were camped outside the Cuu Long Hotel today to sell peanuts to a party of visiting Vietnam War veterans from the United States and some American reporters.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE UP SLIGHTLY IN MAY, TO 9.5%
description: The unemployment rate rose one-tenth of a percentage point in May, to 9.5 percent of the labor force, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Chrysler Plans Price Increases
description: The Chrysler Corporation said that it would increase the manufacturer's suggested retail price on select car models, with the base price for the Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon Miser four-door hatchback rising by $200, to $5,699, effective June 14.

title: Canada
description: Pierre Elliott Trudeau. ... 62. ... Prime Minister of Canada. ... Re-elected in 1980, nine months after being turned out of office. ... Had been Prime Minister since 1968. ... leader of the Liberal Party. ... Says United States is Canada's best friend. ... With Canadian unemployment the highest in 40 years and the Canadian dollar weak, sees lower interest rates as vital for recovery. ... Will continue strong advocacy of aid to poorer countries. ... Intellectual, a maverick, often cool. Britain

title: 2 Suspended In Police Inquiry
description: Two New York City police officers were suspended without pay yesterday on charges that they failed to investigate properly a report on Thursday morning that a woman in a Bronx apartment needed help. Eight hours after the report came in, the woman, Denise Batista, 22 years old, was found dead of a gunshot wound. Her husband, Raul, 18, was arrested in the slaying.

title: Copper Group Loses on Penny
description: The copper industry lost another round today in its effort to keep the Treasury Department from drastically reducing the amount of copper in a penny.

title: Wilander Topples Clerc, Gains Final
description: Jose-Luis Clerc's forehand was called long by the linesman today, and the fans at Roland Garros Stadium began to cheer Mats Wilander's third upset in the French Open tennis tournament. But the semifinal match was not over yet.

title: Index Setback For Dow Jones
description: Dow Jones & Company suffered another judicial setback today in its attempt to halt the Chicago Board of Trade from trading a stock index futures contract pegged to various Dow Jones stock market averages.

title: Japan and U.S. Sign Air Pact
description: Friction between Japan and the United States over airline service between the two countries eased somewhat yesterday when President Reagan and Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki formally agreed to a threeyear, interim pact granting one another significant new rights.

title: Practice Delayed Again For Detroit Grand Prix
description: Qualifying for Sunday's inaugural Detroit Grand Prix was postponed for the second straight day today while officials finished work on the course a day late.

title:
PATENTS;
Code System Patented 20 Years After Filing
description: A teletypewriter encryption system was patented this week for American Standard Inc. of New York City, 20 years after the application was filed.

title: Your Money; 3-Month C.D.'s: A Slow Start
description: MONTH bank certificates of deposit, which have been available for about a month, have drawn a sluggish response from the public. The new instruments, formally known as 91-day time deposits, have been sold since May 1 and have a new ceiling each week tied to the three-month discount rate for Treasury bills at savings banks and savings and loan associations.

title:
PATENTS;
Vaccine Protects Cats Against Leukemia
description: For the protection of cats, a new feline leukemia vaccine has been invented. Richard G. Olson was granted patent 4,332,793 this week, assigning it to the Ohio State University Research Foundation in Columbus.

title: Bomb Blast at Paris School
description: An anarchist group claimed today that it was behind the bombing of the American School near here and a bomb threat at an American Legion post, saying both actions were to protest President Reagan's visit.

title: THE TWO ISMO'S
description: American city life is now torn by two violently opposed doctrines of social conduct. One is machismo. Its adherents pride themselves on being ''machos.'' The opposing dogma is quichismo (pronounced ''key shizmo''), and its practitioners call themselves quiche-o's (pronounced ''key shows'').

title: J.E. WEBB, FOUNDER OF ONE OF FLORIDA'S MERCANTILE EMPIRES
description: James Earl Webb, who parlayed a drugstore operation and a flair for showmanship into a multimillion-dollar business, died Thursday at St. Anthony's Hospital here. He was 85 years old.

title: Dennis Rosati Marries Mary Patricia Gerne
description: Lieut. Mary Patricia Gerne and Lieut. Dennis Rosati, who are stationed with the Navy Medical Corps at the Naval Regional Medical Center in Charleston, S.C., were married yesterday in Ringwood, N.J. Msgr.

title: British Oil Output
description: Britain's North Sea oil output exceeded 2 million barrels a day in April, according to figures released today, placing Britain among the world's top seven oil producers. It is surpassed by the Soviet Union, the United States, Saudi Arabia and Mexico, while China and Iran may produce about the same as Britain.

title: FOG DELAYS BRITISH ASSAULT, REPORTS FROM FALKLANDS SAY
description: A thick fog has delayed the British assault on Stanley, capital of the Falkland Islands, and could hold it up for several more days, dispatches from correspondents in the combat zone said tonight.

title: S.E.C. Settles Insider Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged a former consultant with the Advent Corporation, a manufacturer of electronic components, with using insider information in trading in the company's stock.

title: 3d Victim Dies in Shootings At Maryland I.B.M. Building
description: A security guard shot in the neck last week in a shooting incident at an office of International Business Machines Corporation died today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am told that it is impossible for a Government to change a vote once it is cast. But I have been instructed by my Government to report the fact that were it possible to change our vote, we should like to change it from a veto, a 'No' that is, to an abstention.'' - Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, on U.N. resolution calling for Falkland ceasefire. (4:5.)

title: Sophia Loren Is Freed After 17 Days in Jail
description: Sophia Loren left the women's prison here early today, freed under a court order after serving 17 days of a 30-day jail sentence for tax evasion.

title: TEXACO PAYS UTILITY IN GAS SETTLEMENT
description: Texaco Inc. paid $587 million in cash yesterday to the Louisiana Power and Light Company as part of a $1.1 billion settlement that cut its obligations for delivery of natural gas to the utility by 50 percent, or 400 billion cubic feet.

title: Bridge: In the Reisinger, Disputes About Eligibility Dominate
description: In the closing stages of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship here, arguments about bids and plays were overshadowed by disputes about eligibility. One player, Peter Weichsel, had been disqualified earlier in the week, and the status of three others, Monroe Ingberman of White Plains, N.Y., and Alan Greenberg and Roger Bates of New York, was in doubt. These three players, for varying reasons, had failed to compete to the extent required by the conditions of the event.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 5, 1982
description: International Britain was given ''staunch'' support by the United States and France for its military actions and plans in the Falkland Islands in Prime Margaret Thatcher's separate meetings with President Reagan and President Francois Mitterrand in Paris, the British Foreign Secretary, Francis Pym, said. Mr. Pym said Mrs. Thatcher ''felt even more reassured than she was before.'' He said that both Mr. Reagan and Mr. Mitterrand agreed that it was up to Argentina to forestall a potentially bloody assault on Stanley, the capital, by agreeing to remove its forces from the islands. (Page 1, Column 6.) High American interest rates and their damaging economic effects abroad came under immediate criticism from the Canadian delegation and others at the opening meeting of the leaders of seven industrial nations in Versailles. (1:5.)

title: ISRAELI JETS BOMB GUERRILLA TARGETS IN REPRISAL STRIKE
description: Waves of Israeli jets struck at Palestinian guerrilla camps here and in southern Lebanon today in what the Israeli command described as retaliation for the shooting of the Israeli Ambassador to Britain.

title: GEOTHERMAL PLAN SHAKES HAWAII HAMLET
description: In Hawaiian mythology, Pele was the goddess of volcanoes who wandered from island to island randomly creating firebreathing mountains. Here in Volcano these days, it sometimes seems that Pele has come out of her resting place in a local crater and has set the town on fire oratorically.

title: LEADERS OF N.A.A.C.P. WORRIED ABOUT MICROFILMING OF RECORDS
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is considering an effort to restrict public access to some of the papers it has donated to the Library of Congress.

title: Canada Reaches Oil Agreements
description: The Canadian federal Government concluded oil exploration agreements worth $263 million (in Canadian currency) under which Shell Canada Resources Ltd. would drill six deep-water wells along the Scotian Shelf, Energy Minister Marc Lalonde announced.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48. 1. What country has become the 16th member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization? When was the last time there was a new member? What country was it?

title: KEAN THREATENS TO CUT 5,000 WORKERS
description: Governor Kean said today that he would have to send out layoff notices to thousands of state employees because of cuts made in his proposed 1982-83 budget by the Democrat-controlled Joint Appropriations Committee.

title: ECONOMIC ISSUES DIVIDE LEADERS AS TALKS OPEN
description: In the grand setting of former French royalty, the leaders of seven industrial nations formally opened their economic summit conference tonight, still at odds over measures to ease the world recession and stabilize the value of their currencies.

title: CURRENCY INTERVENTION
description: The New York Federal Reserve Bank said yesterday that foreign central banks spent about $25 billion to intervene in foreign exchange markets from February through April, up from $18.5 billion in the previous three months.

title: THE ENDURING VALUES OF THE MARSHALL PLAN
description: Thirty-five years ago today, George C. Marshall, the first general to serve as Secretary of State, unveiled in a graduation day speech at Harvard one of the undeniable triumphs of United States foreign policy.

title: CITY RETAIL SALES UP 4.2% IN MAY
description: New York City's major retail stores reported yesterday that May sales advanced only 4.2 percent from a year earlier, continuing a five-month trend in which the year-to-year increase has failed to match the approximate 7 percent price inflation for typical department store goods.

title: LIVING AND DYING BY HORSES
description: EVER since Al died, about a year ago, Annie hasn't gone to the race track quite as much as she once did. This year, she won't be going to the Belmont Stakes - she attended regularly -but she'll be involved. Annie's got a gig.

title: Centronics Offer
description: The Centronics Data Computer Corporation said it had signed agreements to sell 4.9 million of its common shares, or 45 percent, to the Control Data Corporation, the NCR Corporation and International Computers Ltd. for $25 million. Control Data would acquire a 35 percent interest in Centronics, with the other two concerns each taking 4.7 percent. Centronics said it would also trade additional stock for the printer business of Computer Peripherals Inc. which is jointly owned by the three other companies and has a book value of $28 million.

title: THEATER: MORE OFFERINGS IN 'MARATHON' ONE-ACT
description: The offerings in Series C of the Ensemble Studio Theater's one-act play ''Marathon'' are not fully accomplished works, but in its own rough-hewn way the evening is a modest success. In two of the three plays, we encounter writers with striking young voices, and that's just what should be happening at the E.S.T.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a new law requiring vehicle safety seats for small children included some incorrect information.

title: Military Analysis
description: The British ground, sea and air forces around Stanley, the last Argentine stronghold on East Falkland, have subjected the garrison to prolonged bombardment by field artillery, naval guns and bombers.

title: 4 WITH ARAB PASSPORTS HELD IN LONDON ATTACK
description: Four men traveling on passports from Arab countries were held by the police today in connection with the shooting Thursday night of the Israeli Ambassador to Britain. The envoy, Shlomo Argov, was still in critical condition.

title: VW Will Help With Resumes
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. will offer the 400 salaried workers that it plans to lay off next Friday help in preparing resumes and conduct job counseling seminars, a company spokesman said today.

title: Cupecoy's Joy Wins the Mother Goose
description: Cupecoy's Joy stretched her blazing early speed over a mile and an eighth yesterday to hold on to win by three-quarters of a length from Christmas Past in the $115,200 Mother Goose Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: Trial Set in Ring Death
description: A judge in Bologna, Italy, has ordered three men to stand trial for manslaughter in the death in 1978 of the Italian middleweight Angelo Jacopucci. Magistrate Marco Boniventi said that Rocco Agostino, Jacopucci's manager; Raymond Boldeyrou, the French referee, and Dr. Ezio Pimpinelli, the ring physician, could have prevented the fighter's death by stopping the bout stopped earlier. Jacopucci died of a cerebral hemorrhage three days after having been knocked out by Britain's Alan Minter, who was the European champion then.

title: HINCKLEY DESCRIBED AS SANE WHEN HE SHOT REAGAN
description: The leadoff prosecution psychiatrist testified this afternoon that John W. Hinckley Jr. did not have schizophrenia or any other serious mental illness and was sane when he shot President Reagan.

title: JAMES BOND MAKING 'WILD' COMEBACK
description: Eighteen years after his creator died, James Bond, the sophisticated spy who was named for an ornithologist, is staging an impressive comeback in the nation's bookstores. ''For Special Services'' (Coward, McCann & Geoghegan), the recently published Bond adventure, is No. 12 on The New York Times fiction best-seller list while ''License Renewed'' (Berkley), a hardcover best-seller that sold more than 110,000 copies last year, is No. 5 on the mass-market paperback list.

title: HONORING A MODERN CIVIL RIGHTS PIONEER
description: She seemed rather shy, a bit overwhelmed by the constant flow of admirers offering praise or asking to be in a photograph with her. But she never lost her quiet dignity or her sweet smile. It was difficult to believe that this was the woman who, that day in Montgomery, Ala., nearly three decades ago, had refused to budge from her seat on the bus.

title: AS HOBOKEN GENTRIFIES, FIRES KILL
description: Hoboken, 10 minutes by PATH train from Manhattan, is an old town, only one square mile in size. But Hoboken has caught its neighbor's spreading disease, gentrification - the upgrading of neighborhoods - and is beginning to show not only the benefits of urban renewal but also several frightening symptoms. The most insidious is suspected arson.

title: A SUPERLOBBY IN ACTION
description: From his ninth-floor command post at 1801 K Street N.W., Raymond Garcia scans a list of 52 House and Senate Budget Committee members, then buzzes his assistant, Alexis Piper. ''Prepare the Action Alert,'' he orders.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ALL'S FAIR

title: DAVIS LOSES TITLE DESPITE 7-7 1 4 JUMP
description: The high-jumping competition upstaged the runners and throwers today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 61st annual outdoor track and field championships.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: IT began, Hazard Reeves recalls, for want of an electronic timing d evice. A little more than two years ago, Mr. Reeves, a 75-year-old b usinessman who lives in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., spent an entire day goingf rom store to store in search of a timer necessary for the i nstallation of a sound system in his local church. He remembered h aving seen just such an item in a mail-order catalogue, but he had f orgotten what catalogue it had been.

title: Prague Rail Crash Kills One
description: One passenger was killed and 42 were injured when a passenger train ran into the last car of an empty train waiting between two stations in Prague today, the official C.T.K. press agency said.

title: CALL MADE FOR U.S. TO END SCHOOL AID
description: The Rev. Alfred Sharpton, president of the National Youth Movement, and State Senator Vander L. Beatty, called yesterday for a cutoff of Federal funds to the New York City public schools until the school system complied with an agreement to improve the racial balance of the teaching staff.

title: GODUNOV LEAVING TROUPE
description: Alexander Godunov, the Russian ballet dancer who defected to the United States three years ago, will not dance with American Ballet Theater next season, according to his spokesman.

title: U.N. ENVOY SURVIVES IN A FEUD WITH HAIG
description: If an ordinary ambassador runs afoul of the Secretary of State, especially one with a temper like that of Alexander M. Haig Jr., the ambassador runs the risk of a quick return to private life.

title: 'Templetown' Opened
description: Garry Templeton, the shortstop who was traded from the St. Louis Cardinals to the San Diego Padres in the offseason, has opened ''Templetown'' in the stands at Jack Murphy Stadium. He bought a block of 50 seats to be available for groups for the underprivileged in the San Diego area. Tickets will be distributed free for all home games. ... Mark Fidrych, who is attempting a comeback after arm injuries, was beaten Thursday on a homer in the ninth that gave the Syracuse Chiefs a 4-3 victory over the Pawtucket Red Sox.

title: BUYERS VOW TO COVER U.P.I. LOSSES
description: The new owners of United Press International said yesterday that all of the news agency's financial ties to its previous owner had been severed and that they alone would be responsible for paying any of U.P.I.'s operating losses or any closing costs if they could not turn the operation around.

title: U.S. SAYS MUBARAK HAS REJECTED REQUEST TO MEET REAGAN AND BEGIN
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt has turned down an informal American suggestion that he meet later this month in Washington with President Reagan and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, Administration officials said today. The purpose of the meeting, they said, would have been to give new impetus to the stalemated negotiations on Palestinian self-rule.

title: VERSAILLES: COMPUTERS AMID GILT
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France has fitted out the gilded chambers of Versailles with some incongruous gadgetry - a proud display of the fruits of France's newly nationalized electronics industry and a ploy to draw attention to technology, which he sees as the hope of industrialized economies.

title: The Murder of a City
description: The ancient city of Hama, the fifth largest in Syria, has been laid waste. Acres of buildings have been flattened; others stand in ruins.

title: DRIVING WHILE DRUNK, DEADLY AT ANY AGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ON A SOHO STREET, A FEAST FOR BODY AND SOUL
description: As sure as the sun will come up in the morning and the three-card monte men will play on Broadway in the afternoon, so there will be crowds on Sullivan Street this week. That is because the Feast of St. Anthony of Padua has begun, and even if it rains - God forbid, as they say on the street - there will be sausage, and zeppole, and ragtag games of chance with stuffed-animal prizes that look something like dogs, something like cats, something like nothing at all.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Coming of Age By ANATOLE BROYARD CUBAN PASSAGE. By Norman Lewis. 250 pages. Pantheon. $13.50. BAD GUY. By Rosalyn Drexler. 180 pages. Dutton. $11.95.

title: Quentron's Position
description: Quentron Inc. said today that it opposed any takeover by Andrew Evans, chairman of Evans, Llewellyn Securities Inc. Mr. Evans, in proxy solicitations, has called the Quentron management unqualified.

title: Coast Professor, Suspended Over His Sex Course, Resigns
description: A professor who gave course credit for homosexual and extramarital sex and admitted being ''romantically involved'' with students has resigned without explanation, a university spokesman says.

title: MRS. REAGAN VISITS BLIND YOUTHS IN PARIS
description: Nancy Reagan visited the National Institute for Blind Youth today and, as usual when on public display, she looked happier and considerably more relaxed with the children than she does with adults.

title: Steelmakers And Japanese
description: Japanese steelmakers are considering investing in the beleaguered American steel industry. One company, Kobe Steel Ltd., is studying an equity investment in the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation and a $140 million joint venture to make seamless pipe for use in oil and gas exploration, according to Kobe's president, Koukichi Takahashi.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP A BIT
description: Corporations stashed away $3.9 billion in bank savings accounts in the week ended May 26, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday. Economists said the rise in corporate time accounts indicated that financial pressures on many companies might have eased somewhat.

title:
PATENTS;
Handling Contact Lenses
description: Soft contact lenses are sold to professionals in small glass vials, from which they are removed by tweezers that may contaminate the lenses.

title: GENERAL
description: The Department of Justice is conducting a preliminary investigation to see whether a special prosecutor should look into the acceptance of a $50,000 severance payment by Attorney General William French Smith, according to a Justice Department official familiar with the case.

title: A LEADER OF SALVADORAN PEASANTS ASSERTS 25 ARE EVICTED EVERY DAY
description: The leader of one of the country's largest peasant agricultural organizations said today that 25 to 30 peasants were being evicted from their land daily. But he said the rate of evictions had declined since the country's provisional President and the Minster of Defense pledged to help the peasants.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS FEAR A PROLONGED WAR
description: Senior Defense Department officials say they have become concerned that the fighting between Britain and Argentina will continue even after the battle of the Falklands and cause more damage to United States interests in Latin America.

title: 4th Man Arrested In L.I. Crime Spree
description: A fourth suspect in a crime spree that included an attack on a Plainview, L.I., family and their guests last Saturday was arrested yesterday after he returned voluntarily from Georgia and surrendered by arrangement at La Guardia Airport.

title: PANEL WARNS AGAINST HIGH-ABSORBENCY TAMPONS
description: A panel of leading medical scientists today urged women, especially adolescents, to avoid using high-absorbency tampons because the tampons have been linked to a greater risk of toxic shock syndrome.

title: Ellen Koblitz Married To Michael Kingman
description: Ellen Laura Koblitz, a senior trial lawyer with the New Jersey Public Defender's office in Bergen County, was married yesterday to Michael L. Kingman, a senior associate with the Hackensack (N.J.) law firm of Hogan & Palace. New Jersey Superior Court Judge James F. Madden performed the ceremony in his chambers in Hackensack.

title: U.S. Steel Settles Suit Filed by Black Workers
description: The United States Steel Corporation has agreed to pay $2.1 million to settle a discrimination lawsuit filed by 500 workers and former workers who were passed over for promotions, two groups representing the employees said today.

title: The Editorial Notebook Cheapskate Commerce
description: Once upon a time there were Rummage Sales, whose proceeds went to the high school band (new uniforms), the volunteer fire department (new engine) or the church (new furnace). Today they are Garage/Yard/Tag/ Barn/Stoop sales, whose proceeds go straight into the seller's pocket. It's sugar-bowl money usually, a collection of crumpled dollar bills, but to overhear a yard sale's participants crowing over the day's take is to assume they've pulled off a bank heist.

title: JOBLESSNESS DOWN IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Unemployment in New York City in May declined to 8.8 percent, dropping below 9 percent for the first time in six months, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, announced yesterday.

title: WHEN CHANGE MAY NOT BE FORTHE BETTER
description: ''New and improved'' is a phrase meant to induce a sense of promise and optimism, but to me it has become an ominous warning, especially when it appears on the wrapper of a favorite food product. ''New'' is, of course, an adjective not to be argued with, but ''improved'' is something else again, a value judgment strictly in the mind of the beholder or taster.

title: 'ORATORICAL MISTAKES'
description: Racial and ethnic gaffes by public figures are the periodic embarrassments by which we are reminded that there are flaws in our system of equally created persons.

title:
PATENTS;
Computers Operate With Other Computers
description: A multiple computer system, basically intended for aerospace applications and for industrial operation of robots and machine tools, is being developed by the Bendix Corporation, based in Southfield, Mich. A patent was granted this week for the method of communication between computers on tasks they are performing.

title: The Value of J-51 Tax Breaks
description: A state law that allows New York City to subsidize the reconstruction of old buildings will soon expire. Some Democrats who oppose extension charge that reducing taxes to push housing improvement often enriches a few at the expense of many and also has depressing side effects. While some of this surely occurs, the city has learned to apply correctives. The program should continue.

title: YANKS LOSE, 4-3
description: Hours after Joe Pepitone was named the new Yankee batting coach, Paul Splittorff and Dan Quisenberry combined to hold his new pupils to five hits in a 4-3 victory by the Kansas City Royals.

title: Lendl Passing On Wimbledon
description: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia will not compete in the All-England Championships at Wimbledon later this month, his agent said today.

title: KOCH'S HIRING BAN HAS INITIAL EFFECT
description: Part of each of New York City's seven beaches will be closed this weekend because the city cannot afford to hire 200 lifeguards and maintenance workers, Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis said yesterday.

title: Pesticides' Dangers Cited
description: A consumer protection body that links 125 groups in 50 countries announced a public awareness campaign today aimed at halting the unrestricted sale and misuse of hazardous pesticides. Anwar Fazal, president of the International Organization of Consumers Unions, quoted United Nations statistics showing that 1.5 million people are poisoned worldwide by pesticides every year, most of them in developing countries.

title: ARGENTINA REPORTS BOMBING BRITISH CAMPS NEAR STANLEY
description: The Argentine high command said tonight that it had repelled a British air attack on Stanley and had gone on to conduct an ''intense bombardment'' of British positions west of the Falkland capital.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anacomp Inc. said its wholly owned subsidiary, Anacomp Micrographics Inc., had extended to June 10 its tender offer for all outstanding shares of common stock of D.S.I. Corp. at $6.25 a share net in cash.

title: NO BLEACHERS ON BEDFORD
description: To the Editor:

title: EMERGENCY PLAN FOR 4 COUNTIES FAULTED BY U.S.
description: A Federal agency overseeing emergency plans for nuclear accidents said today that a test exercise involving four counties around the Indian Point nuclear power plants March 3 showed that the county responses did not meet Federal standards.

title: SOUTH KOREA BETTING ON SHIPS
description: The huge shipyard of Hyundai Heavy Industries here swarms with activity six days a week. In the 2,000-acre yard, 10,500 workers are building ships in three dry docks, so large that they resemble open-pit mines.

title: MIDLAND CAUSES FLURRY IN GOVERNMENTS MARKET
description: The Government securities market got another scare yesterday when the Marine Midland Bank temporarily suspended its activity as clearing agent for Comark, a small California-based Government securities firm.

title: 11 RUSSIANS OPEN ANTINUCLEAR DRIVE
description: The Soviet Union, a strong backer of peace campaigns in Western countries, found itself today with an embryonic peace movement of its own that aims to be as independent of Government control as groups in the United States and Western Europe.

title: F.B.I. REPORTEDLY KNEW OF RACE-FIXING
description: Federal agents knew at the time that harness horses were being illegally drugged in a suspected fixing scheme involving at least six races at Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways four years ago, according to Federal law enforcement sources.

title: BRIEFING
description: Campaign Against Baker

title: U.N. RESOLUTION ON FALKLAND WAR
description: Following is the text of a resolution on the Falkland conflict that was introduced in the Security Council by Panama and Spain and vetoed by Britain and the United States:

title: FROM S.R.O.'S TO M.D.U.'S: AID-ELIGIBLE MINI DWELLING UNITS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 PARTIES WEIGHING 'LOYALTY OATHS' FOR CANDIDATES
description: Some form of loyalty oath - a promise by candidates to support their party's nominees in the general election -will be pressed at the Democratic and Republican state conventions, leaders of both parties said yesterday.

title: NEW SCOPE FOR BRIDAL REGISTRIES
description: Once in the world of bridal registries, there were three gifts: china, silver and crystal. Today, however, couples can register for woks and cappuccino machines as wedding presents, for candles and smoke alarms, for reproductions of first century B.C. Greek artwork or bottles of California cabernet sauvignon 1974. In fact, the bridal registry business is expanding, not only in the scope of gifts being registered, but also in the number of stores that have added registries to help couples select wedding presents in advance.

title: Harvester Sets Cummins Accord
description: The International Harvester Company announced that it had entered into a ''multimillion-dollar'' agreement to provide diesel engine castings for the Cummins Engine Company.

title: DANCE: FELD BALLET PRESENTS FIRST PREMIERE IN NEW HOME
description: Thursday night the Feld Ballet presented the first world premiere in its new home, the Joyce Theater. So far, the company has been offering revivals and works that, though new to New York, have been seen on tour. But Eliot Feld's ''Over the Pavement'' is brand new and slightly unusual as well.

title: Twins' Ordeal Finally Ends
description: The Minnesota Twins capitalized on the combined six-hit pitching of Brad Havens and Terry Felton, and on homers by Ron Washington and Gary Ward to snap a 14-game losing streak with a 6-0 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

title: MANNIE L. WILSON, PASTOR IN HARLEM
description: The Rev. Mannie Lee Wilson, the pastor of the Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem and a former president of the Council of Churches of the City of New York, died Tuesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 76 years old.

title: Bumble Bee Announces Nationwide Tuna Recall
description: Bumble Bee Seafoods is recalling 1.5 million cases of canned tuna because some cans have a small hole that might admit bacteria that can cause illness, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: News Analysis
description: The United States is trying hard, at this eighth summit conference, to convey the message that it will go a long way to meet European criticism of its foreign-exchange and domestic economics.

title: John F. Nims Awarded Poets Academy Prize
description: John Frederick Nims has been named winner of the $10,000 fellowship of the American Academy of Poets.

title: NLT Amends Payment Offer
description: The NLT Corporation, in its bid for the American General Corporation, amended a provision of its bid that had offered early payment to American General shareholders for up to 600,000 shares of American General's 1980 convertible junior preferred stock.

title: NICKLAUS, ON 65-137, LEADS BY 2
description: Jack Nicklaus shot seven birdies in a stretch of eight holes today on his way to a 65 and a two-stroke lead in the second round of the Kemper Open.

title: Three Solar Flares Reported
description: Three major solar flares were reported today by forecasters with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Joe Hirman, the agency's chief forecaster, said the flares would probably disrupt some short-wave communications and magnetic equipment.

title: An Argentine Prisoner To Reach Britain Today
description: Lieut. Comdr. Alfredo Astiz, the captured commander of the Argentine garrison on South Georgia Island, who is accused of having headed a torture squad in Argentina, will arrive in Britain by sea Saturday, the Defense Ministry announced tonight.

title: ISRAEL CALLS RAIDS A RETALIATORY ACT
description: The military command said today that the air strikes by Israeli planes in Lebanon were in retaliation for the shooting Thursday night of Israel's Ambassador in London.

title: CITY'S LOBBYIST BATTLES IN ALBANY
description: Margaret L. W. Boepple, Mayor Koch's chief lobbyist here, is warm, soft-spoken and diplomatic - until something happens that she thinks will hurt her boss or New York City. Then she becomes positively icy.

title: WARNING ISSUED ON GIVING ASPIRIN TO CHILDREN
description: The Government announced plans today to advise doctors and parents against using aspirin to treat children's chicken pox or flu-like symptoms because studies have linked aspirin to Reye's Syndrome, a rare but often fatal children's disease.

title: GENOCIDE
description: The Turkish Government categorically denied today that any threat had been made to Jews here in retaliation for Armenian participation in a scheduled international conference in Tel Aviv on genocide.

title:
PATENTS;
Bacteria Transformed To Produce Proteins
description: Methods of inserting genes into bacteria so they will produce desired proteins or other materials were patented this week for Harvard University. Richard N. Goldstein obtained patent 4,332,901 for a cloning vector, which is explained as a plasmid used in biological research and engineering to insert a selected fraction of a gene.

title: HAROLD VON SCHMIDT, PAINTER AND ILLUSTRATOR, IS DEAD AT 86
description: Harold von Schmidt, a painter whose magazine illustrations helped spur a renewed interest in Western art, died on Thursday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 86 years old.

title: REPORTS OF SOVIET AID ARE DENIED
description: A spokesman for the Argentine military was quoted by an Argentine news service today as denying that Soviet technicians had been working to help the Argentine military upgrade its radar system in the southern part of the country.

title: U.S. AND THE BRITISH VETO RESOLUTION ON FALKLANDS
description: The United States joined Britain in vetoing a Security Council resolution calling for an immediate ceasefire in the Falkland Islands but the American delegate, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, said the United States would rather have abstained.

title: Bombs Spilled in Canada
description: A commercial truck rolled off a remote stretch of the Alaska Highway in Canada, dropping a load of unarmed, conventional United States Air Force bombs. The road was closed for 25 hours while the bombs were loaded on another truck. The driver cut his arm in the accident. The bombs were being shipped from Elmendorf Air Force Base in Anchorage to Sunny Point, S.C.

title: Alaskans to Receive $1,000 Cash Payments
description: Each person who has lived in Alaska for six months could receive $1,000 in cash this summer under a new state plan aimed at sharing Alaska's oil wealth with its citizens.

title: RICHMOND'S BID TO SEAL LETTERS BEING CONTESTED
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Representative Frederick W. Richmond would have to swear that certain correspondence of his was personal and thus not subject to grand jury scrutiny or the judge would review the material and decide the matter.

title: DON'T TAMPER WITH SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: John McEnroe scored a 6-3, 7-6 victory over John Alexander of Australia in a semifinal match of the Greater Manchester grass court tournament today. McEnroe will play Russell Simpson of New Zealand in the final on Saturday. Simpson defeated John Sadri of the United States, 6-4, 1-6, 6-3, in the other semifinal.

title: Capt. Sydney Trew, 81, Dies; Managed S.I. Sailors' Home
description: Capt. Sydney H. Trew, a former superintendent of Sailors' Snug Harbor, the home for retired seamen on Staten Island, died Monday at the Paul Kimball Hospital in Lakewood, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Lakewood.

title: O'Neill Signs Bill on 'Lemons'
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill signed the nation's first ''lemon bill'' today, giving Connecticut residents with chronic new-car problems some recourse against manufacturers.

title: BOMBS KILL THREE IN SOUTH AFRICA AND SWAZILAND
description: Two bombings nearly 1,000 miles apart today appeared to be part of a new round of violence in the shadowy conflict between South Africa's white Government and the underground movements that oppose it.

title: Katherine F. Ihle Married to Harold J. Sweeney Jr.
description: Katherine Frances Ihle, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur William Ihle of Delray Beach, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to Harold Joseph Sweeney Jr., son of Mrs. Sweeney of Sea Girt, N.J., and the late Mr. Sweeney. The Rev. John F. Corr performed the ceremony in St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church.

title: Davis Breaks Thumb
description: Howard Davis Jr. said he broke his right thumb during his unanimous 10-round lightweight victory over Julio Valdez Thursday night in Atlantic City.

title: Frank Corrigan, Senior Editor Of Newsday Business Pages
description: Frank Corrigan, senior business editor of the Long Island newspaper Newsday, died of a heart attack last Wednesday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital.

title: BULLING HER OTHER ISLANDS
description: Margaret Thatcher has Britain hurtling down a dead-end track. She also appears intent on taking the United States along on the ride. We have done the right thing in supporting Britain in its war with Argentina, but we better be very careful about how and whether we continue that support in the troubled peace that will soon ensue.

title: O'Reilly's Costly Slap
description: Terry O'Reilly of the Boston Bruins, who slapped an official in a playoff game April 25, was suspended yesterday without pay for 10 games, beginning next season, and fined $500. He slapped Andy van Hellemond, the referee, in the face while being restrained from going after a Quebec Nordique player.

title: United Cuts Fares
description: In a move to match competition from Trans World Airlines, United Airlines said it had cut fares on its Chicago-New York flights for the month of June.

title: Summary of the Economic Meetings Held by the Seven Nations Since '75
description: The economic summit conference has been an annual event since 1975. Following are summaries of the seven previous meetings. Rambouillet, France, 1975 - The conferees rejected a return to fixed exchange rates among their currencies, while agreeing on the need for monetary stability and for international economic cooperation. But currency upheavals and international economic sparring matches ensued.

title: Bakeries Charged With Conspiracy
description: A Federal grand jury in New York indicted six bakeries and their executives today for conspiring to fix pastry prices since the mid-1960's.

title: DANCE: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER AND CONTEMPORARY TROUPE
description: By shuttling between theaters Wednesday, balletomanes could see both the American Ballet Theater, New York's oldest ballet company, at the Metropolitan Opera House and the Contemporary Ballet Company, one of our newest companies, at the Space at City Center.

title: John Carr Duff, Ex-Chairman Of Adult Education at N.Y.U.
description: Dr. John Carr Duff, chairman of New York University's department of adult education from 1949 to 1958, died Tuesday at Nassau Hospital. He was 80 years old and a resident of Garden City, L.I.

title: HOW TO EAT GRAPEFRUIT
description: MISS MANNERS' GUIDE TO EXCRUCIATINGLY CORRECT BEHAVIOR By Judith Martin. Illustrated by Gloria Kamen. 745 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: Woman Dies on Pisa Tower
description: A 32-year-old Italian woman plunged to her death from the top of the Leaning Tower of Pisa. The police said today that Umberta Giorgia Carli Piglia of Turin was killed instantly Friday after she apparently jumped from the top of the 180-foot tower.

title: WORKS IN PROGRESS
description: The Book Review asked a number of authors to report on the books they were writing. The variation in specificity is quite remarkable (see Salman Rushdie, for instance, for detail and E.L. Doctorow for what might be called the metaphysics of a work in progress). A few of the authors did not respond, which we hope was due to overwork rather than writer's block. The replies of those who did respond appear below.

title: James Reid Weds Pamela Tomkinson
description: Pamela Joan Tomkinson, daughter of Joan Tomkinson of New York and New Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to James M. Reid Jr., son of Mr. Reid of Kent, Conn., and the late Helen Grace Reid. The Rev. Thomas Pike performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square.

title: LAWYERS EXPAND ROLES IN GOVERNMENT
description: LESS than 10 years ago, assistants in the Suffolk County Attorney's office, many of them political appointees, worked out of their private law offices, with the county paying half their rent and half the salary of a secretary. Now, confronted with a growing caseload, the County Attorney's office has taken on the trappings of professionalism, with all the assistants in county buildings, although most of the 43 attorneys are still political appointees.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: OFFICIALS of the Town of Huntington and Suffolk County have learned a lesson in how the destructive flow of tidal waters is undaunted by legislative intent or jurisprudence.

title: 4-1 CONQUISTADOR CIELO TAKES BELMONT IN MUD
description: Until yesterday, only three horses in this century had won the Belmont Stakes by more than 10 lengths: Secretariat, Count Fleet and Man o' War. Now there is a fourth, and if he keeps running the way he did yesterday, he may someday be mentioned in the same breath as those three thoroughbred idols.

title: A SAMPLER OF THE CALLS THAT RALLY THE MOVEMENT FOR NUCLEAR DISARMAMENT
description: Fueling the growing public concern over nuclear disarmament have been the views of present and former government officials and independent activists. Following are excerpts from speeches, books and articles that have been cited by some participants as philosophical underpinnings of the disarmament movement and are likely to be cited again as events unfold in New York this week in anticipation of a rally Saturday in Central Park. 'Reduction By 50 Percent'

title: The World in Summary; A Mixed Message For Coup Plotters
description: Spain officially joined NATO last week, a membership Spanish democrats hope will give their armed forces something to do besides fret at the constraints of civilian government. Supporters of democracy had also hoped that the court martial of officers charged in an attempted coup last year would be a deterrent to further plots.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: Bruehl. (Yale University Press, $25.) A biography of the German-born philosopher and social critic.

title: Egypt
description: To the Editor: If I could add one book to William E. Farrell's recommended guides to Egypt included in the roundup of ''Baedeker and His Heirs'' (Travel, April 25), it would be Newsweek's ''Treasures of the Egyptian Museum.'' This is a large paperback with beautiful color plates showing the finest examples from the museum's incredible collection.

title: SUBURBS OFFERING CHEAP OFFICE SPACE
description: A NEW YORK CITY company looking for cheaper space for back-office o perations in the metropolitan region will find it in abundance, at r ents far below those charged in prime Manhattan areas.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JUNE 6, 1982
description: International A limit on cheap export credits in world trade appeared to near agreement by the leaders of the major industrial democracies at their meeting in Versailles. However, it would not include the sharp restrictions on credits to the Soviet Union that President Reagan has wanted. A spokesman for the French Government said that Mr. Reagan raised the issue ''with great intensity,'' at a luncheon meeting, but quickly found himself ''isolated'' from the six other leaders at the table. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Katherine Atkins Becomes a Bride
description: Katherine Wrisley Atkins, a research assistant at the Management Analysis Center, a consulting company in Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Stephen Ayers Barrand, a research assistant at the Harvard School of Public Health. The Rev. Everett Bodge performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: ENERGY AGENCY FIGHTS FOR LIFE
description: TRENTON WHILE a panel of legislators voted last week to give the state's Department of Energy more power, the executive branch was considering abolishing the agency altogether.

title: Around the Nation; Florida Using U.S. Funds To Assist Refugees
description: Florida has begun spending a $5 million Federal emergency grant for services for 32,000 Cuban and Haitian refugees whose assistance checks ended this week.

title: FOOD
description: Dishing Out A Good Ribbing

title: Sarah Lee Friedrichs Is the Bride of Robert Collins
description: Sarah Lee Friedrichs, director of education at the Animal Rescue League of Boston, was married yesterday to Robert Collins, a senior underwriter with the America Corporation, marine insurers in Boston. The Rev. Carl Scovel performed the Unitarian ceremony at the King's Chapel in Boston.

title: By Theodore W. Libbey Jr.; Svanber, Andersen And Petersen, on Horns
description: Three Danes playing horns took over Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday and Friday evenings for an unusual pair of New York debut recitals. In one, the repertory was well off the beaten track; in the other, it was the instrument playing the repertory that made for novelty.

title: Captured Officer in Britain
description: A captured Argentine naval officer, Alfredo Astiz, wanted by Sweden and France for questioning about the presumed deaths of three women, arrived in Britain today, the Defense Ministry said. He is being held at military barracks at Chichester in southern England. Captain Astiz has been in British custody since surrendering to marines who retook the Falklands' dependency of South Georgia from Argentina in April.

title: The Old Aerobic Standbys
description: Despite numerous claims that weight training can be aerobic, the research evidence shows that weight training at any speed or intensity is at best only mildly aerobic (Health and Beauty Section, May 9). Our research, and that of other respected laboratories, has looked at both high-intensity and high-speed weight training.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title:
COMMENT;
THE GAME IN NAMES
description: THERE are several hundred books and pamphlets that show-and-tell h ow to start and maintain a successful small business. These p ublications usually cover bank credit, cash flow, budgets, traffic l ocations, stock arrangements, personnel training, sales promotion, s ecurity, display techniques and appropriate profit patterns.

title: CUNNINGHAM BEGINS HIS DEFENSE TOMORROW
description: The defense opens tomorrow in the Federal trial of Patrick J. Cunningham, the former state Democratic chairman who is accused of failing to report $23,000 in income and then covering up the attempt.

title: Bankruptcy Liabilities Balloon
description: The number of business failures continued to rise in April, as more than 2,000 companies went under. While most of the failing businesses were small, the inclusion of the Wickes Companies in the monthly total pushed the estimated size of total liabilities for bankrupt companies up drastically, to $3 billion. Of that total, the Wickes failure amounted to about $2.5 billion.

title: DELEGATION AGREES ON MANY BUDGET ISSUES
description: WHILE Connecticut's six United States Representatives are busy shuttling between Washington and their districts, watching the political developments at home and preparing a record in office on which they can seek re-election, they are facing a difficult, confusing and overdue piece of business that will probably reach the top of the agenda later this week: the 1983 budget.

title: BERMUDA NOTEBOOK
description: RICHARD HALLORAN is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

title: TEACHER CALLS CONFINEMENT IN CHINA A 'NIGHTMARE'
description: An American teacher who was expelled from China after being accused of spying said today she had undergone a ''nightmare'' experience. She arrived home Friday night to a greeting of tears, flags and flowers.

title: THE CASE FOR FEWER BUT LESS VULNERABLE AMERICAN ICBM'S
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA AND MONET HOME FILL MRS. REAGAN'S DAY
description: While her husband attended the opening sessions of the economic conference today, Nancy Reagan spent a relaxing day in the sun, touring the home and gardens where Claude Monet, the Impressionist painter, did much of his most famous work.

title: KEEP EAST-WEST LINKAGE FROM BECOMING BONDAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: WHOOPS; Gulliver's Tale
description: The author relates several particulars of some Yahoos in the Country of Academe. Having told me about learning in the land of the Houyhnhnms, my master asked me if all Yahoos were welcome in all colleges.

title: MUSICAL: JEWISH GROUP WITH 'VAGABOND STARS'
description: It's impossible not to be charmed by ''Vagabond Stars,'' the Jewish Repertory Theater's bright new musical, so why even try? ''Vagabond Stars'' is an evocation, entirely in English, of the Yiddish stage, circa 1900, and, more than that, a mirror of what was on the minds of the Jewish emigres from Eastern Europe who were pouring into America at that time. As we learned, some were uprooted in the sea passage, never could make the adjustment quite right, and others were merely transplanted proper Yankees as soon as they bought a straw hat or derby.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; The State of Hinckley's Brain
description: Lawyers for John W. Hinckley Jr., who had already presented their case that Mr. Hinkley is schizophrenic and was insane when he shot President Reagan and three others last year, got an unexpected encore last week when a Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker reversed himself, deciding that excluding the results of a brain scan would ''deprive the jury of the complete picture'' of Mr. Hinckley's mental condition.

title: BARBARA TUCHMAN ON ARMS CONTROL
description: Stating correctly that there is no military solution to the contemporary crisis, Barbara Tuchman recommends that the dangerous position of the Russian and American Governments should be deactivated by public rejection. It is clear how to reject the American position: ''The working instrument is votes.''

title: Around the World; Rebels Blame Pretoria For Car-Bomb Deaths
description: The banned African National Congress blamed the South African Government today for the deaths of a senior member of the organization and his wife in an car bombing Friday in the black kingdom of Swaziland.

title: THE SUBTLE POWER OF THE POLISH CHURCH
description: Nina Darnton, who has been living in Poland for the last three years, is a freelance writer. At a recent meeting of the Communist Party organization of the Polish radio and television network, a military commissar warned his comrades to beware of the Roman Catholic Church and its Primate in Poland, 52-year-old Archbishop Jozef Glemp. ''I think that the church is a time bomb,'' the commissar said, little suspecting that a tape recording of the session would be widely circulated and eventually published in Paris's Le Monde.

title: MALPRACTICE APPROACHES THE PULPIT
description: IN 1979, as part of his routine pastoral duties at the Grace C ommunity Church in Los Angeles, the Rev. John MacArthur was giving g uidance to Kenneth Nalley, a troubled teenager. In the midst of the c ounseling, the young man committed suicide.

title: Television Week
description: Globe-Trotting ''Walter's been on the bottom of the Pacific Ocean in a tiny submarine the size of a phone booth,'' said Jonathan Ward, in reference to Walter Cronkite, the CBS News special correspondent. ''He's been high over the North Pole in a jet, he's been in Africa, he spent New Year's Eve in the Brazilian rain forest and he's visited Windsor Castle and Prince Philip.

title: The Region in Summary; The Bottom Line On Topless Bars
description: After five years of sporadic litigation in the highest state and Federal courts, a law banning topless entertainment in New York bars has been struck down for good. Last week the United States Supreme Court let stand a ruling that the law violated free-speech provisions in the State Constitution.

title: by Barbara Delatiner; SALUTE TO YOUTH
description: Although some cynics believe that youth is wasted on the young, Nassau County's Office of Cultural Development doesn't think so.
