The county's first multi-arts festival of the season today is devoted to a ''Salute to Youth,'' and from 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. the Center for the Fine Arts in Roslyn Harbor will be alive with the sound of youngsters having fun: participating in a ''children's art happening,'' watching Poho the Clown, catching a performance of ''Little Red Riding Hood'' by Opera Options at 1 P.M. or attending a concert by the Training Orchestra at 3 P.M.

title: UNION CITY ARTICLE CALLED A DISTORTION
description: As the current Postmaster of Union City, I am offering this in rebuttal to Mr. Weiss. The allegation that Mr. Musto controlled the Post Office is entirely false.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 'SECRET' CHARMS OF PERTH AMBOY
description: Despite Perth Amboy's attractive waterfront along the Raritan Bay a nd the Arthur Kill, and its array of still-affordable V ictorianstyle homes along wide, tree-lined streets, it is generally k nown for its industry, manufacturing facilities and tank farms. Its c harm as a residential community, said an urban consultant, is ''New J ersey's best-kept secret.''

title: PRINT CENTER MELDS OLD, NEW
description: PURCHASE THE Center for Edition Works at the State University of New York's campus here brings together a diverse combination of resources: old and new printing presses, rare wood typefaces, a small library of fine arts editions and a faculty of artists and printmakers dedicated to producing the highest quality of works.

title: Correction
description: The Week in Business column last week incorrectly stated General Motors' 1980 results and the date of Roger B. Smith's appointment as chairman. The company had a 1980 loss of $762 million and Mr. Smith assumed his post in January 1981.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: CLASSICAL MUSICVocalists are a resourceful lot, yet it seems that many of them would rather ignore 20th-century music, or think of new reasons not to perform it, than study it, learn it and put it on their programs. Not Bethany Beardslee, who has long been involved with the music of this century and has developed, in the process, an extraordinary technique and interpretive fluency that distinguish her as one of the leading exponents of the repertory.

title: Steven Tucker Weds Jennifer L.Bingham
description: Jennifer Lynn Bingham, an assistant in the paintings department of Christie's East auction gallery, was married yesterday to Steven E. Tucker, a freelance photographer. Criminal Court Judge Jay Gold performed the ceremony in the couple's Manhattan home.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MULTI-USE COLONIAL FURNITURE
description: TABLES that could be used for a variety of purposes, chairs that could turn into tables or storage boxes as needed, beds that disappeared from sight or folded against the wall when not in use were all well-known space and energy savers in colonial New England homes.

title: Blues Singer: Sippie Wallace
description: Sippie Wallace, the legendary blues singer and song writer who appeared at The Bottom Line on Friday, was one of the classic stylists of the 1920's. Now she is enjoying a unique second career thanks largely to Bonnie Raitt, whom she met 10 years ago and with whom she has since performed on an irregular basis.

title: TOURING THE TULAROSA BASIN
description: NORMAN ZOLLINGER, a novelist who lives in Albuquerque, is the author of ''Corey Lane'' and ''Riders to Cibola.''

title: ARTS GROUP OF WESTPORT-WESTON ENJOYS ITS SUCCESS
description: WESTPORT DESPITE Washington's recent budget tightening and the resulting cutbacks in aid to the arts on a Federal, state and local level, there is one arts organization in Connecticut that is not only surviving the adverse financial times, but is also flourishing.

title: THE EGLEVSKY TURNS TO TEACHING ON L.I.
description: HAVING recently concluded a successul 1982 season, the Eglevsky Ballet is gearing up for its first summer residency on the Island, at the C.W. Post Center in Brookville. This four-week, preprofessional course, running from July 5 through Aug. 1, will bring together 80 dancers from around the country with Eglevsky Ballet members and an illustrious roster of guest faculty members including Allegra Kent, Patricia Wilde, Lee Theodore, Melissa Hayden, Kay Mazzo and Norman Walker.

title: IN PRAISE OF MYSELF
description: WE'VE all been through the ordeal. From the day we applied for our first job to the last time we sought promotion, it's puff, puff, puff! We inflate our credentials to make ourselves look a bit more attractive to those who can advance us.

title: REFLECTIONS ON MASS TRANSIT, VENETIAN STYLE
description: PETER LAURITZEN is a lecturer and historian who lives in Venice. His recent books include ''Islands and Lagoons of Venice.''

title: The World in Summary; London Attack Triggers Raids Against P.L.O.
description: Israel has always retaliated against terrorism by hitting back many times harder than it has been hit. So it did again last week after an Arab gunman shot the Israeli Ambassador to London. As the diplomat, Shlomo Argov, lay in critical condition following brain surgery, Israeli fighter-bombers swept over Palestinian enclaves in Lebanon Friday and yesterday, killing scores of people.

title: A TIME FOR FESTIVALS
description: MASSACHUSETTS may have its Tanglewood, but Connecticut has two major centers of culture nestled in the Berkshire foothills: Music Mountain, which takes understandable pride in its status as the oldest continuous summer chamber music festival in North America, and the Yale Chamber Music Festival in Norfolk, launching its 42d year tomorrow.

title: CACHE FOR CASH
description: For several months it has been taking shape behind whitewashed windows at 1191 Third Avenue, looking to passersby like yet another boutique aborning in a neighborhood of boutiques. But now the windows have been washed clean, a uniformed guard is at the door and everyone can see what the first new private safe-deposit vault in New York City in 20 years looks like.

title: LOSS IS 4TH STRAIGHT
description: The ink stain on the front of George Bamberger's shirt, right under where it says Mets, was a sign that he had been doodling during the game tonight. The 6-2 loss to the Reds was the fourth straight defeat for the Mets, tied their longest losing streak of the year, and was evidence that some changes were in order.

title: Sunday Observer; Play It Again
description: I envy Hoagy Carmichael. Hoagy chose the right line of work. While seated one day at the piano he wrote a song called ''Stardust,'' after which he never had to work again unless he wanted to.

title:
CRAFTS;
IKEBANA BASKETS OF TWO CENTURIES
description: THE centuries-old art of Japanese flower arranging known as ikebana was an outgrowth of the respected, formal tea ceremony. Traditionally, in the special rooms where tea ceremonies were convened, a work of art, a small hanging scroll or ink drawing and an abbreviated floral arrangement were displayed.

title: U.S. PLANS WEAPON AGAINST SATELLITES
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has directed the Air Force to deploy antisatellite weapons within five years as part of President Reagan's comprehensive program to strengthen the nation's nuclear deterrent, according to a new military plan.

title: PIANO RECITAL: JULIE HOLTZMAN
description: Julie Holtzman, a Canadian pianist with training in many diverse, related areas of music beyond sheer pianism, including a stint in New York at the Juilliard School and elsewhere, returned here Thursday night for a generally pleasing recital in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: The Nation in Summary; Smith's Finances Under Scrutiny
description: Last December, Attorney General William French Smith said he would not seek changes in the much debated special prosecutor law - a campaign for the repeal of which he had led -while Administration officials were under investigation. Last week, his position, and that of the Administration, became even more awkward.

title: THEODORE WHITE SUMS UP
description: Theodore White has written a marvel of political perspective in his ''Summing Up.''

title: REAGAN ECONOMIC PLAN FACES TEST IN OHIO'S CONGRESSIONAL PRIMARY
description: The country's first popular test of President Reagan's economic policies will take place here Tuesday in a bitter Congressional primary contest between two Democrats.

title: DOCTOR HELD LIABLE AFTER FAILED STERILIZATION
description: A physician who performed an unsuccessful sterilization on a woman who later gave birth is liable for child support payments, Connecticut's highest court has ruled.

title: 48 Ignore Rain in 100-Mile Run
description: The rain was steady, the temperature was 59 degrees and the clock at Shea Stadium read 6:16 when the fifth annual New York Road Runners Club 100-mile invitation run got off yesterday evening to the clang of a bell. But few of the 48 runners, three of them women, had spirits as damp as the weather.

title: A HUMAN RESOURCE AT ALLIED CORP.
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J. WHEN Charles Bischoff Jr. was asked recently how a personnel manager spent his time years ago, a broad smile crinkled his face. ''Making sure everybody got a birthday card on their birthday and a turkey on Thanksgiving,'' he replied, only half facetiously. The personnel department, he added, was ''quite clearly the dumping ground for people who couldn't hack it in operations.''

title: DEMAND RISES HERE FOR ENGINEERS
description: WITH the growth of high-technology industry on the Island, and the Federal Government's increased spending for defense, there has been a recent resurgence of demand for engineers here. Four of the Island's largest employers of engineers - Grumman, Sperry, Fairchild Republic and Eaton - are actively recruiting graduates from the Island's three engineering schools, as well as conducting national searches for more highly skilled engineers, mainly in the fields of electronics and computer sciences.

title: DIPLOMAT'S CHARGES FOCUS OF INQUIRIES
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH the State Department and a member of the Congressional Black Caucus are pressing for full disclosure, some New Jersey officials say that the results of a State Police investigation of charges made by a Nigerian diplomat may never be fully known.

title: Mailer Talking
description: ''There was that law of life,'' Norman Mailer wrote in ''The Deer Park,'' ''so cruel and so just which demanded that one must grow or else pay more for remaining the same.'' Clearly it is a sentiment taken to heart by the author himself. Now 59, Mr. Mailer has fashioned a career in which he has continually reinvented a style and a self, using his own personality as a kind of index to discover how the world has changed. The polite young Brooklyn-born, Harvardeducated author of ''The Naked and the Dead'' evolved, through the 50's and hectic 60's, into the blustering protagonist of ''The Armies of the Night'' - ''warrior, presumptive general, champion of obscenity, embattled aging enfant terrible of the literary world'' - and surfaced again in the less flamboyant 70's as a ''modest and half-invisible Aquarius.'' Indeed, the self-portrait that emerges in Mr. Mailer's new collection of short work and interviews from the 60's and 70's, ''Pieces and Pontifications,'' is that of a writer who has traded his egocentric concerns of the past for a new objectivity, his prodigality of emotion and rhetoric for more modest satisfactions.

title: The Summer of '82
description: This is a most anxious time in the world of paperback publishing. Traditionally, the 13 weeks from now until Labor Day are the industry's highest season, the time when sales records are set as millions of Americans grab books out of the racks to help pass the time at the beach or beside the pool. The publishers hope that, despite the recession, high unemployment and prices of $3.95 or more for many paperbacks, readers will find their offerings irresistible. Herewith a rundown on some of the titles on which they're pinning their hopes.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; John Paul Makes His Way In Britain
description: By the time Pope John Paul II left Britain last week, the sound of cheers, prayers and skeletons rolling in their graves had somehow brought ecumenism to a new high. At times it was impossible to tell historical symbolism from Realpolitik, but few in the crowds seemed to mind.

title: PIANO: BRADSHAW-BUONO DUO
description: David Bradshaw and Cosmo Buono played music for two pianos at the 92d Street Y Thursday night. The program was an interesting combination of the slightly old and the relatively new, with Casella's ''Pupazzetti'' and Bax's ''The Poisoned Fountain'' from the early 20th century and the Grieg ''Variations on an Old Norwegian Romance'' and Liszt's Fantasy and Fugue on ''Ad Nos, Ad Salutarem Undam'' from the 19th.

title: BARBARA TUCHMAN ON ARMS CONTROL
description: Once again, Barbara Tuchman displays a clarity of expression and soundness of reasoning which is synonymous with scholarship.

title: The World in Summary; China Trade in Nuclear Power?
description: China's priority on security from external threats led it to develop nuclear weapons in the 1960's, but not reactors for the peaceful use of atomic power. Its priority now on internal economic development has obliged it to turn to outsiders for reactor technology.

title: Prudence Regan And a Physician Wed in New York
description: Prudence Rindell Regan and Dr. Peter Seth Hallarman were married yesterday at the Tillman Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations in New York, where the Rev. Robert J. Robbins, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg officiated.

title: Urling Iselin And Student Are Married
description: Urling Sibley Iselin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Iselin of New York, was married yesterday to E.T. Bedford Davie Jr., son of Mrs. Charles Addams of New York and Watermill, L.I., and Mr. Davie of Palm Beach, Fla., and Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: AN EERIE LAND NAMED JOSHUA
description: R. V. DENENBERG is a frequent contributor to Travel. BY R.V.DENENBERG

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
IT ONLY HAPPENS TO OTHERS, UNTIL...
description: ''THE bells,'' he announced one day, ''are gone.'' And with that, he left. ''Are you two talking?'' the lawyer asked, when I finally made the appointment.

title: ALPS
description: To the Editor:

title: CRIME'S LINGERING ALLURE
description: AMID hard times, crime is doing handsomely. The television networks p lan a bumper crop of crime dramas for the fall. Major b ookpublishing houses are reissuing squads of classic detective n ovels from decades past. Bookstores specializing in crime stories s ay business is better than ever.

title: KOWTOWING AND THE ELDERLY
description: To The Business Editor: Mr. Penner's fine article illustrates two major flaws in the Social Security debate. Most scholars and politicians alike discuss Social Security retirement benefits while ignoring the rate of return that recipients earn.

title: The Nation in Summary; ELiminating 'Fine Distinctions' In Auto Searches
description: In a move intended to clarify and expand search and seizure laws governing automobiles, the United States Supreme Court last week ruled 6 to 3 that police officers with ''probable cause'' to search a car without a warrant may search all luggage and packages found inside as well.

title: BY DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL
description: DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL is a writer who lives in New York.

title:
DINING OUT;
A CHOICE OF ITALIAN AND OR FRENCH
description: SCANIO'S is a pleasantly casual Italian restaurant in the Bergen County community of Oakland. For the last 12 years, Ted Giandinia has been both owner and chef of the restaurant, which is open for dinner only and at which reservations are not accepted.

title: HUDSON PINNING DREAMS OF GLORY ON THE PRIMARY
description: TRENTON ONE of the big stories in Tuesday's Democratic primary election will be the performance, or lack of it, of the Hudson County Democratic organization.

title: TWO POP SINGERS IN JAZZ LAND
description: One of the great unresolved questions in jazz is: What is a jazz singer? What are the hallmarks by which one identifies a jazz singer? Is a blues singer, ipso facto, a jazz singer? Is scat singing - nonverbalized sounds - what is meant by jazz singing? Is a jazz singer someone who sings in the company of jazz musicians? Or does a singer become a jazz singer simply because of that singer's selfdescription?

title: HAMMOCK MAKING AND OTHER CRAFTS
description: JOAN COOK is a reporter for The Times. By JOAN COOK

title: by Eleanor Charles; MORRIS DANCERS COMING
description: The origin of the term ''Morris'' dancing seems to have faded into the distant past, according to John Dexter. ''It may be an anglicized version of Moorish, since similar dances exist in Spain, France, the Basque country and Rumania,'' he said.

title: MRS. GHANDI MAKING THE MOST OF FOREIGN POLICY OPENINGS
description: Halfway through her latest term as Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi is embarked on an effort to win new foreign friends and reassure old enemies. Gone are the strident tone and loud insistence on India's regional dominance that have often characterized her Government's foreign policy statements.

title: KOWTOWING AND THE ELDERLY
description: To the Business Editor: Mr. Penner prescribes aspirin for the Social Security disease, when radical surgery is required. Social Security, like any socialist program becomes bankrupt, because again, again and again there is no free lunch.

title: 39 YEARS LATER, OHIOAN FINDS CITY STILL CLOUDY
description: In 1943, Irving Bickford was in New York for one day on his way home to Ohio from an I.B.M. seminar. He decided to take a look at the city from the 69th-floor observation deck of the RCA Building. But it was cloudy and - as is still the policy when visibility is less than two miles - he was given a pass to try again another day.

title: Hassan Beats Cameron in 400
description: The matchup in the men's 400-meter final was a natural - Kasheef Hassan of Oregon State and the Sudan, the 1979 champion, against Bert Cameron of Texas-El Paso and Jamaica, the 1980 and 1981 champion. At 4,500-foot altitude, a world record seemed possible.

title: Catherine Stratemeyer Wed
description: Catherine Louise Stratemeyer, daughter of Eileen Vokes Stratemeyer and Dr. Winslow Plato Stratemeyer, both of El Paso, Tex., was married yesterday to Dr. Steven Herman, son of Joseph Herman of Lakewood, N.J., and the late Rebecca Herman. The ceremony was performed at the Tavern on the Green in New York by Rabbi Ronald Sobel of Temple Emanuel-El. The bride is an account supervisor of Ketchum Public Relations, in New York. Dr. Herman, a plastic and cosmetic surgeon in New York, is a member of the faculty of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: THEODORE WHITE SUMS UP
description: In ''Summing Up,'' the growth and loss of control of the Federal Government is clearly described.

title: BUS RIDERS POCKET THE BIGGEST SAVINGS
description: Some of the most extensive, least restricted and most durable transportation bargains in the United States this year are to be found not on highly competitive air routes but in travel by bus.

title: MORE COOPERATION IN SOUTH IS URGED
description: Gov. Bob Graham of Florida, the new chairman of the Southern Growth Policies Board, today called for the formation of a ''Southern Common Market'' to enable the region to expand and properly develop an economic growth that has slowed in recent years.

Last week's story on summer activities for county children and their parents incorrectly identified the name of an opera to be performed July 10 at the Center for the Arts on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York. The opera is ''Noah's Flood'' by Benjamin Britten.

title: NEW CONCERT SERIES OFFERS FREE SOUNDS
description: IF the increasing cost of concert going is on your worry list, meet the Center for Music in Westchester, which is embarking on a major series of free public concerts. ''We don't know if we're doing the right thing,'' concedes Alan Bramson, director of the center, ''but we've been impressed by the way the Pleasantville Chamber Music Society has been getting big turnouts for its free concerts at the library and supporting them by asking people who can afford to do so to become contributing members. Anyway, we've decided to try that system, to open up our concerts to everybody, so we can attract people who can't pay, or maybe who would come if they didn't have to worry about buying tickets for their children. Our hope is to develop a resident nucleus of superb musicians for the programs, and build grass-roots support from local residents in a kind of community project.''

title: BEAUTY
description: The Subtle Scents of Chypre The ancient appeal of a group of fragrances that are based on oakmoss is being rediscovered by a growing number of men and women. With fragrances, as with many things in life, subtlety provides its own attraction. One source of such an attraction, and an increasingly popular one, according to those who sell and manufacture scents, is a family of subtle fragrances called Chypre.

title: SONG-DANCE: ANN REINKING
description: The act that Ann Reinking presented at Les Mouches, 11th Avenue at 26th Street, through last night, is a fireworks display of energetic dancing and singing. It leaves Miss Reinking obviously breathless at times, a circumstance that gives her a brief opportunity to come out from behind the stylized surface she presents throughout most of the performance.

title: INDIA'S BELATED CLAIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Written in a Blaze

title: FINANCE CHIEFS AGREE TO TRY TO ALIGN NATIONAL POLICIES
description: Finance ministers from the seven major Western industrial democracies announced today that they would try to align their national economic policies more closely in the future and would also study ways of making the dollar more stable on international currency markets.

title: CATHOLICS IN BRITAIN ARE QUITE BRITISH INDEED
description: The public embrace of the heads of the Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches last weekend exorcised the pain of a great religious schism, if not the schism itself. Less obvious, perhaps, as Pope John Paul II and Archbishop Robert Runcie knelt side-by-side in prayer in Canterbury Cathedral, was the exorcism of what might be called an embarrassment. It was symbolized by a chair.

title: STATE POWER AUTHORITY PLANS TO BUILD 180-MILE-LONG ELECTRIC LINE
description: The State Power Authority is planning to build a 180-mile-long, $550 million power line through southeastern New York State to bring inexpensive hydroelectric power to metropolitan New York.

title: 2 MISSING AND 1,300 FORCED FROM HOMES IN CONNECTICUT FLOODS
description: At least two persons were missing and feared drowned and more than 1,300 others were forced from their homes across Connecticut Saturday as heavy rains caused rivers to rise. State officials alerted the National Guard and activated disaster crews.

title: RE-CREATING THE DAWN OF MANNED SPACE FLIGHT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Audie Bock's most recent publication is a translation of the Japanese film director Akira Kurosawa's memoirs, ''Something Like an Autobiography'' (Alfred A. Knopf, May 1982). By AUDIE BOCK HAMILTON AIR FORCE BASE, CALIF. An imposing multiple gateway yawns open, guardless. The driveway, lined with squat, thick-crowned old palm trees, curves lazily past large blocks of buildings painted a creamy military hue. Surrounding them are overlush lawns, the recent floodgauge Northern California rains pushing their seedy tips into a waist-deep jungle. A filling station sign sports the elongated lettering that immediately recalls late 1950's graphic design. No one walks the street, and the classic Chevy Bel Aires and Studebakers one would almost expect to roll by fail to materialize.

title: CHOOSING A COLLEGE, SORT OF
description: SHOPPING is not my favorite pastime - not for clothing, not for food, but particularly not for services. When our children were little, we shopped for nursery schools, for cello teachers, for orthodontists, for dermatologists, even for baby sitters. But now we're coming into the home stretch of some really heavy stuff - shopping for colleges for the youngest of our offspring.

title: Theodore White Sums Up
description: Theodore H. White's article, ''Summing Up'' (April 25), is a selection of peculiar anecdotes and shallow analysis that may account for Mr. White's disillusionment, but that does little justice to the last 20 years of American history. Summing up the civil-rights movement with tales of bloodshed and incoherent agitators, Mr. White leaves out the genuine and often eloquent indignation felt by Americans who saw injustice and poverty where the American dream was supposed to be.

title: BARBARA TUCHMAN ON ARMS CONTROL
description: In ''The Alternative to Arms Control'' (April 18), Barbara Tuchman hits the nail on the head, saying, ''Control of nuclear war is too serious a matter to be left any longer to governments. They are not going to get it for us; in fact, they are the obstacle.''

title: Peggy Isham Wed To C.W. Hughes
description: Margaret Dorothy Isham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Trumbull Isham of Newport, R.I., was married there yesterday to Christian Weston Hughes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Scudder Hughes of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The Rev. Bradley Davis and the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: ALL THE FACTS (SOME TRUE) ABOUT GONDOLAS
description: MacDONALD HARRIS lives in Southern California. His next novel, ''Screenplay,'' will be published by Atheneum in the fall.

title: Oxbridge
description: To the Editor:

title: 'THE NEIGHBORHOOD'S COMING ALIVE AGAIN'
description: WHEN my family moved into our blue shuttered house in Northport, we were part of a young, transitional wave. For me it was a homecoming, of sorts. After living in the West and South for 10 years, I was coming back to the place of my birth, my childhood.

title: THE MAYAN RUINS OF PALENQUE
description: KATHERINE BOUTON is a New York author who writes frequently on archeology.

title:
Numismatics;
A.N.A. COMPLETES ITS HEADQUARTERS BUILDING
description: There are many ways to measure the tremendous burst of interest that the coin collecting hobby has enjoyed in recent years. One, of course, is the surge in market activity and the resultant climb in prices, which are far higher now than they were in earlier decades despite the prolonged slump of the last two years.

title: Joseph Leininger, 59, a Dean At Stanford U. School of Law
description: Joseph E. Leininger, a former agent for the Central Intelligence Agency who went on to become the associate dean of the Stanford Law School, died Thursday of heart disease. He was 59 years old.

title: ABOUT RECORDS: A CLASSIC COMMITMENT
description: The pop record business is not booming these days, but the classics, if not booming, at least seem promising enough for new labels to keep popping up and for entrepreneurs to gamble that the public will continue to support serious music on established labels as well.

title: U.S. SUGAR REFINERS LOSE MOVE IN COURT FOR ENDING QUOTAS
description: The United States Court of International Trade yesterday rejected a bid by a group of domestic sugar refiners to block sugar import quotas imposed last month by President Reagan.

title: BY ANN B. SILVERMAN
description: "Only about 4 percent of the elderly reside in nursing homes, so just to keep pace with the increasing number of older people we have to look at alternatives" - that is, to more care of the elderly in thier homes, Sister Miriam Therese Peppin, director of the New Rochelle Office for the Aging, said recently.

title: A MAGIC CARPET RIDE THROUGH AMERICA
description: THE trailer rests in hibernation now, in a clump of trees behind the garage. The third in a proud line of Lyons Family trailers, it should be rolling down the highway, sleek and gleaming, instead of sitting there in storage with its wheels up on blocks. Once our trailer bounced over the hard dirt of a ranch in south Texas, past cattle grazing under gnarled mesquite trees. It navigated the rocky Mendocino coast of California, climbed the steady rise between Los Angeles and Las Vegas and maneuvered the back roads of the Ozarks in search of a fiddle maker.

title: Mailbox; Sacred Outfield
description: To the Sports Editor: I read recently that Lawrence Ritter, author of ''The Glory of Their Times,'' recalled a time in the 1930's when and he and his father walked across the Yankee Stadium outfield after a game, remembering ''the place just seemed so enormous to me, and I kept wondering how any player in the whole wide world could possibly throw or hit a ball such a huge distance.''

title: FITTING IN WITH THE NEIGHBORS
description: Unlike the recent generation of high-rise towers that stand back f rom the street wall and tower over older structures, a recently c onstructed apartment building on Manhattan's Upper West Side has m ade an effort to fit in more amicably with its surroundings.

title: SAFETY BOARD SAYS JET ENGINE FAILED
description: The National Transportation Safety Board has handed down its verdict in the second of two incidents of aircraft engine failure that, under different circumstances, could have ended in fatal crashes and turned last Sept. 22 into one of aviation's blackest days.

title: BOSTON'S SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENT ASKS THAT CITY SCRAP DESEGREGATION PLAN
description: After eight years of what was possibly the closest supervision by a Federal District Court of any school system in the country, the desegregation of the Boston public schools is not working out, according to the Superintendent of Schools, who said the plan should be scrapped in favor of a new approach.

title: CITY SAID TO TRAIL IN U.S. TRANSIT AID
description: New York City's transit system gets less Federal assistance as a proportion of operating budget than the six other major city transit systems in the United States, according to studies by a leading consultant concern.

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'One, Two, Three' There have been few faster comedies than ''One, Two, Three'' (1961), a crackling, funny satire of both American and Soviet bureaucracy set in post-war Berlin. And there are two reasons: Billy Wilder, the coscenarist and director, and his starring mouthpiece, James Cagney, who plays a far-from-home Coca Cola executive who emits his dialogue like a machine gun.

title: WHEN BROADWAY CELEBRATES ITSELF
description: The luncheon conversation in the normally sedate theater corner of Sardi's has been unusually heated in recent weeks. Between bites of their executive salads or eggs Benedict, movers and shakers of the Broadway theater have been debating the great issues of the day: Does ''Nine'' have a chance of beating out ''Dreamgirls'' as best musical of the season? Can '' 'Master Harold'...and the Boys'' score an upset over ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' by being named best play?

title: CHAMBER: ST. PAUL ORCHESTRA
description: The most vital part of the Friday evening Serenades concert at Carnegie Hall came just after the intermission, with the first movement of Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 1. Joseph Kalichstein, the soloist, played the movement with a gruff strength and a nice, fullbodied tone, and contributed a cadenza of his own that blustered on with a sweet Busonian exuberance.

title: Dr. S.H. Swersky to Wed Lillian Marie DeGaetano
description: Jeanette Clasen of Roslyn, L.I., and Philip DeGaetano of Brooklyn, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lillian Marie DeGaetano, to Dr. Steven H. Swersky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Swersky of Roslyn, L.I.

title: BRITISH SAY NEW ARMS FOR ARGENTINA WOULD MEAN LONG, HIT-AND-RUN WAR
description: British views on the duration and nature of the conflict with Argentina will change drastically if it proves true, as reported here, that Buenos Aires is receiving Gabriel missiles and additional Mirage and Dagger fighter-bombers and Exocet air-tosurface missiles.

title: THE ALPS
description: To the Editor:

title: Nova Scotia
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Although Barbara Tuchman tells us many things about the prevention of nuclear war, her chief argument against arms control seems to be her belief that ''nations don't distrust each other because they are armed, they are armed because they distrust each other.'' But then, Barbara Tuchman contradicts this principle by asking us to demand of our Government ''a ban on all nuclear testing and, above all, ... a firm renunciation of first strike by act of Congress.'' Would not the logic of her argument lead to our negotiating with Russia to reduce ''distrust'' before we agree to give up nuclear weapons? LAWRENCE W. HYMAN, Ridgewood, N.J.

title: PATRICIA CANNING ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Canning of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Georgette Canning, to Steven Walter Chryston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Chrystone of Greenburgh, N.Y.

title: THE CASE OF THE MISSING OIL
description: REPRESENTATIVE Peter A. Peyser's action last week on behalf of the Maryknoll Sisters and others seeking action in the investigation of four church women killed in El Salvador 18 months ago seemed to have domestic political overtones - specifically, the contest for the new 22d Congressional District.

title: Paw Paw Blues
description: With a yearly budget of $25,000 and a $25-a-month Mayor, Paw Paw, W.Va., faced a shaky prospect two months ago: how to pay $16,000 in costs stemming from a lawsuit and still stay solvent.

title: DUMPING GARBAGE: A COSTLY ERROR
description: NEW JERSEY taxpayers are getting dumped on, literally and figuratively. The totals for 1981 are not in yet, but for 1980 - depending on what set of statistics one uses - 10 million tons of municipally generated garbage was dumped in landfills around the state.

title: Hawaii Beach Remains Shut
description: Hanauma Bay, one of Hawaii's most popular tourist attractions, will remain closed indefinitely after tests found unacceptable levels of bacteria in the drinking water there, city officials said Thursday.

title: STAPLETON
description: Even on a clear day, you can't see forever from the open back porch o f the McAndrew house on a tiny street called Smith Terrace in the S taten Island community of Stapleton. But when the leaves fall from t he trees, you can see as far as the World Trade Center, 10 miles offa cross the bay.

title: Ban on Pistols
description: When the nation's only law banning the sale or possession of handguns went into effect in Morton Grove, Ill., last Feb. 1, three residents surrendered a total of five weapons. The police said they expected few others.

title: Suites with Sweets
description: White Plains, whose ''Platinum Mile'' has become a prestige location for Fortune 500 corporations, now has another amenity befitting its image as a corporate center - a luxury, all-suite hotel whose pristine white concrete terraces slant up the northern slope of the city's core.

title: HAS DESIGN BYPASSED SAFETY?
description: PEOPLE often ask me if the technology of auto racing has surpassed the drivers' ability to control their machines. I've had some thoughts about this recently.

title: A Professional Role In Support Groups
description: I read with great interest the recent article ''Support Groups: Help and Debate.'' As a professional social worker, I have been involved as a sponsor for Parents Anonymous, a self-help group, for the last five years.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page April 25 included a quotation incorrectly de- scribing the relationship between the Boston-based Ritz-Carlton group and the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Chicago. John Coleman, the hotel entrepre- neur, has amended his comment and says the two organizations have a licensing agreement under which the Chicago hotel is entitled to call itself the Ritz-Carlton.

title: 25 SCHOOLS IN CITY WILL OFFER FREE HEALTH CARE
description: Thousands of New York City schoolchildren have become eligible for free health care, including physical examinations and treatment of minor illnesses, under a new demonstration program financed by the state.

title: BOYSTOWN: UNBROKEN SILENCE
description: KEARNY SOME people say that when Msgr. Robert P. Egan left New Jersey Boystown here, after being its director for 26 years, an era ended. The popular priest, they say, was Boystown.

title: Lauren Hamilton Will Be Married
description: Margaret H. Hamilton and James Cox Hamilton, both of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Hamilton, to James Cox Chambers, son of Anne Cox Chambers and Robert W. Chambers, both of Atlanta.

title:
Photography View;
GLAMOUR-A NEW KIND OF PUBLIC ART
description: Two or three hundred years ago public art consisted of paintings and sculptures on the walls and ceilings of churches and palaces. This was the only kind of public art there was, and it was well liked by the people who paid for it, who were, for the most part, kings and clergymen.

title: Cornell's Eight Captures I.R.A. Title
description: Cornell, rulers of Cayuga's waters, spread its dominance to Lake Onondaga today and won the varsity eight race in the 80th Intercollegiate Rowing Association championships.

title: Firebombs Hurled in Rome
description: Terrorists threw firebombs at two Americanowned companies here today, causing minor damage but no injuries.

title: 'A DISTANT CRY FROM SPRING,' JAPANESE
description: In ''A Distant Cry From Spring,'' a Japanese film at the Film Forum, a mysterious stranger appears at the door of a farmhouse on a stormy night and asks for shelter. The young widow who owns the farm puts him up in the barn. At dawn, he helps to deliver a calf and, just as mysteriously and distantly, disappears down the road. In the spring, he returns to stay as a farmhand, gains the respect of the widow and the devotion of her young son, and begins to end their feelings of loneliness.

title: Patton's Pistols
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Diplomat in Soviet Asks The Netherlands for Asylum
description: The Second Secretary of the Iranian Embassy in Moscow has requested political asylum in the Netherlands, and the request is being studied, a spokesman for the Dutch Foreign Ministry said today.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: TWO groups that have walked coast to coast to support the second United Nations special session on disarmament have been marching through New Jersey recently. About 200 ''southern route'' walkers started out from Los Angeles last October, combining in Washington on May 11 with a group that began from New Orleans on New Year's Day. Approximately 75 of that number - including Buddhist priests, Canadians, Japanese, native Americans and Americans of varying backgrounds - arrived in Gibbstown, in Gloucester County, on May 28 and in Camden the next day. There, they were put up in Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church, where they attended a peace mass the next morning.

title: Vicki M. Knebel Becomes a Bride
description: Vicki Marie Knebel and Timothy McLellan Davis, New York lawyers, were married yesterday in Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. Victor Hummert, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church.

title: DISPUTES PREDICTED ON OFFSHORE OIL AND GAS
description: THE quest for oil and natural gas off New Jersey, which has gone slowly since the first leases were sold in 1976, may become controversial by next month and even more so over the next year or two, according to authorities.

title: Sports People; Malone Given Offer
description: Ray Patterson, general manager of the Houston Rockets, confirmed yesterday that the team had made a contract offer to Moses Malone, its star center who becomes a free agent at the end of the National Basketball Association playoffs. ''I sent it in a letter to his attorney, Lee Fentress of Washington, D.C., in the middle of the week,'' Patterson said.

title: Janet Lynn Johnson Will Be Married To Elbridge T. Gerry 3d Next Aug. 28
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Filmore C. Johnson of West Hartford, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Janet Lynn Johnson, to Elbridge T. Gerry 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerry Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: AN ANNIVERSARY FOR THE WEAKFISH
description: THIS year we can celebrate the 10th anniversary of the return of the weakfish. In 1972, after an absence of several decades, schools of this delictably delicate, finely textured fish reappeared in our offshore waters, to the delight of fishermen with waiting nets and fish lovers with waiting forks. There is a good chance that you have tasted weakfish in restaurants or purchased some to cook at home without knowing it, because this time around, the fish has been widely marketed under the rather more appealing name of sea trout.

title: VIGNETTES: WAR HARD TO IGNORE
description: While they discuss world issues this weekend, the seven heads of government meeting here are also trying to keep track of whatever is going on back in their home capitals.

title: Sound; AN AUDIO SUBSPECIES ARISES: DECK RECEIVERS
description: The button, when invented in Germany circa 1250, was considered a foppish ornament unfit for respectable wearers of proper cassocks. Only after it had been widely observed that buttoning up helps to keep warm, did buttons and their matching holes attain a popularity lasting to this day.

title: Stage View; A LESSON IN HOW ACTORS COPE WTH TEDIUM
description: I am afraid that ''Beyond Therapy'' is beyond redemption, though a couple of good people are currently giving it a shot. I always find myself interested in the techniques actors adopt in an effort to cope with material that flatly isn't working and probably never will. They must attempt something, of course, since their Equity contracts do not permit them the civilized luxury of simply throwing up their hands and getting out of there. And the various devices that they try on for size are often quite appropriate devices, intelligently chosen - even if they can't and don't save the day or the play.

title: THE INS AND OUTS OF PIANO DUETS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Leslie Kandell is a freelance writer and a player of piano duets. BY LESLIE KANDELL

title: Q&A
description: Question:We plan a vacation in Rio de Janeiro for December of this year and would like a small apartment or a place with some kitchen facilities near Copacabana. How do we find out about such accommodations? - B.C., Denver, Colo. Answer:''While we do not handle real estate inquiries,'' said a spokesman for the Brazilian Tourism Authority in New York, ''we would suggest that you contact the United States Consulate in Rio and ask them to forward a list of real estate agents who do. The address of the consulate is Avenida Presidente Wilson 147, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.''

title: THEATER: RETURN OF HENRY ALDRICH
description: For adolescents growing up in the 1940's, Henry Aldrich was a scapegrace. An impossible incompetent, he was always getting in trouble - at home and at school - yet he managed to come through relatively unscathed. Perhaps the secret was that he had a latent sense of decorum. When his mother shouted, as she did at least once on every radio show, ''Henry ... Henry Aldrich,'' he knew enough to answer immediately, ''Coming, Mother.''

title: SOCCER'S BIGGEST EVENT: A LOOK AT THE WORLD CUP
description: The blood pressures of fans in more than 140 countries where soccer is the most popular sport will begin to rise next Sunday and remain elevated for 28 days. Their emotions will be charged by the World Cup tournament, which will be played in Spain at 16 stadiums in 14 cities, starting with a game in Barcelona between Argentina and Belgium, and ending July 11 with the final in Madrid.

title: Robin L. Clayton Is Engaged to William M. Roach
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William L. Clayton of Short Hills, N.J., and Quechee, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter, Robin Lynn Clayton, to Willian Michael Roach, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Roach of Braintree, Mass.

title: ABOUT LONG ISALND
description: THIS is about women drivers, but before you sit down and write a steamy letter, let me explain right off that it's not one of those pieces about women drivers and their expertise behind the wheel. It is one that is rooted more in the nature of the car and its role in the family, and it might also have something to say about life in the suburbs.

title: BRITAIN CHARTING A COURSE FOR FUTURE OF FALKLANDS AS ITS TROOPS REMAIN POISED TO RETAKE THE CAPITAL
description: The British Government has begun to map long-term development plans for the Falkland Islands that would maintain British sovereignty over the islands for the indefinite future, according to officials here.

title: Raul Sunico, Pianist From the Philippines
description: Raul Sunico, a young pianist from the Philippines, played a taxing program of Chopin, Brahms, Ravel and Rachmaninoff at Alice Tully Hall Friday night. Mr. Sunico may not have seen very deeply into either the Polonaise-Fantaisie by Chopin or the three Mazurkas that followed, but he created warm, clear sound from his instrument, and both his instincts and his ear responded in basically musical ways.

title: SANTA CLAUS 'DOUBLE' RENAMED SANTA CLAUS
description: Winfred Eugene Holley, a 63-year-old man who has been playing Santa Claus for years in behalf of charitable organizations, has been legally renamed Santa Claus.

title: Jail Overcrowding: Other Solutions
description: Why focus on construction of more cells as the only way to reduce overcrowding in the Nassau and Suffolk jails? The recent article ''Why Jail Crowding Is So Hard to Cure'' points out that inmate overcrowding is a function of both the number of individuals incarcerated and the length of time they spend in the jail. Since over half of the prisoners in both jails are pretrial detainees and approximately 60 percent of them will be out in 10 days or less, why aren't both counties improving the efficiency of the courts so that detainees are released faster?

title: THE CLARIDGE ISSUE: 'NEW' VS. THE 'OLD'
description: LAWRENCEVILLE AT ISSUE in what may be a long gambling-license hearing for the Claridge Hotel-Casino in Atlantic City is whether the managing general partner is ''the old Del Webb'' or ''the new Del Webb.''

title: McEnroe Wins Final on Grass
description: John McEnroe, in a struggle lasting 2 hours 10 minutes, outlasted Russell Simpson of New Zealand, 6-3, 6-7, 10-8, today to win the $18,000 Greater Manchester grasscourt tennis tournament.

title: STUDY FINDS RACIAL BIAS IN UNION MOVEMENT
description: A new study has found that a clear, pervasive pattern of racial discrimination has marked the American union movement since the merger of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations in 1955 and, in many cases, that it continues today.

title: ORNAMENTAL GRASSES ADD SPLENDOR
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Eric Rosenthal is a freelance writer. By ERIC ROSENTHAL

title: WHERE TO SIT, TO SEE AND TO BE SEEN
description: PATRICIA WELLS is a writer who lives in Paris. By PATRICIA WELLS

title:
GARDENING;
THE GROWING AND HARVESTING OF HERBS
description: IT would seem logical that the ideal location for an herb garden would be just outside the kitchen door. The cook would merely have to step outside to gather a leaf or two of this and that and a sprig of something else for preparing a meal. Indeed, many a Colonial household did have such a garden.

title: LEGISLATORS FEAR DELAY IN NEW YORK STATE PRIMARY
description: Possible delays in Justice Department approval of New York's new political boundaries could force postponement of the state's primary election, now scheduled for Sept. 14, according to key legislators.

title: POLITICS? WHY NOT?
description: THE Town of Hempstead's recycling plant controversy has taken on a new twist in recent months. The battle has heated up as the town's advisory committee has recommended the reopening of the plant for testing.

title: 2 SIDES FIRE ACROSS LEBANESE LINE; REAGAN ADVISERS MEET URGENTLY IN VERSAILLES ON THE MIDEAST CRISIS
description: President Reagan's advisers met early today to discuss the Middle East as apprehension grew that Israeli forces were mobilizing for a possible invasion of southern Lebanon.

title: THE ONE-MAN FOURTH ESTATE
description: WILLIAM COBBETT The Poor Man's Friend. By George Spater. Two-Volume Set. Illustrated. 653 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $49.50.

title: One-Day Cruise To Freeport; BY GLENN R. SINGER
description: GLENN R. SINGER is a writer for The Post in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title:
GARDENING;
THE GROWING AND HARVESTING OF HERBS
description: It would seem logical that the ideal location for an herb garden would be just outside the kitchen door. The cook would merely have to step outside to gather a leaf or two of this and that and a sprig of something else for preparing a meal. Indeed, many a Colonial household did have such a garden.

title: FIVE PAPERS FIGHT IN ALBANY SUBURB
description: This affluent suburb in the upper Hudson Valley is the center of what is increasingly becoming a rarity in American journalism - a newspaper circulation war.

title: Robert C. Reiser Marries Bernadette Mary Hughes
description: Bernadette Mary Hughes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Hughes of Somers, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Christopher Reiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Reiser of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Gunman Kills Salesclerk, 22, In Upper West Side Boutique
description: A 22-year-old salesclerk was killed ''for no apparent reason'' last night by a gunman attempting to rob the boutique where she worked on Manhattan's Upper West Side, the police said.

title: CUTS THREATEN BOCES CLASSES
description: CUTS in the Federal budget allocation for education along with the loss of certain state aid are expected to have a serious effect on some of the more unusual programs offered by the Board of Cooperative Educational Services on Long Island.

title: Dr. John Penek Weds Miss Bridy
description: Barbara Bridy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Bridy of Lincoln Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. John Penek of Morristown, N.J., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Penek of Warren, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Pringle in Our Lady of the Mount Roman Catholic Church in Warren. He was assisted by the Rev. Michael German, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. William Strain, pastor of Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit, N.J.

title: Around the World; Sweden Seals Off Bay After Sub Is Sighted
description: The Swedish Navy and Air Force sealed off the Gulf of Bothnia in the northern Baltic Sea today to prevent the escape of an unidentified submarine believed trapped there, a naval spokesman said.

title: STUDY URGES NEW USES FOR HISTORIC SITES IN RYE
description: A300-acre strip of land in Rye, with three historic houses, a nature preserve, an old cemetery and a possible prehistoric Indian encampment, has passed the first hurdle toward becoming a historic site. It has been approved by the State Preservation Office and sent to the National Landmarks Commission in Washington.

title: FOR THESE BODYGUARDS, ROSES AND REVOLVERS
description: LOS ANGELES Young, handsome and intoxicated, the gentleman noticed two businesswomen enter his favorite Beverly Hills restaurant and assumed that they would appreciate his overtures. He missed the hint when they ignored him and later complained to the manager. But he got the message when one of the women discreetly revealed the .357-magnum revolver holstered beneath her blazer.

title: Film View; QUESTIONS GROWN IN THE DARK
description: Question: Is it absolutely necessary to pay up to $11 million for a Broadway show or several million dollars for a best-selling book to make a hit film? The answer: an unequivocal no. Among the other merits of the current season is the large number of good and/or successful films based on original screenplays, many of which were written - entirely or in part - by their directors.

title: Conservation
description: Neighborhoods are complex amalgams of housing, commerce, architecture and amenities, but most of all they are amalgams of people interested in making them work and survive. To help people who want to help their neighborhoods, the National Trust for Historic Preservation is offering a free ''Conserve Neighborhoods Organizing Kit.''

title: NO ONE ASKED ME TO WRITE A NOVEL
description: From time to time The Book Review has invited both new and established writers to comment on various aspects of their craft: their imaginative and autobiographical sources, their practices of composition, the origin of their sense of vocation. These essays are intended to provide a forum for writers to consider the rewards and perils of their craft.

title: FAMILIES ARE HOSTS TO INMATES' CHILDREN
description: JUDY BASSETT, a South Salem mother of two young boys, got a call from her minister's wife early last summer asking her for a favor. The minister's wife said she had agreed to take two children into her home for a week but a conflict had arisen and she wondered if Mrs. Bassett would take them instead. The children, she said, belonged to a woman who was a prisoner at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, a state prison for women.

title: DIPLOMATS HAVING TO SCRATCH FOR APARTMENTS
description: AFTER a long search for a place to live in New York, Olara Otunnu found a suitable cooperative apartment to s ublet and made all the arrangements without a hitch. But the day he w as to sign the lease, the president of the co-op board suddenly a nnounced that he could not have the apartment after all.

title: ONE ISOLATED WORLD WITHIN ANOTHER
description: FELICE By Angela Davis-Gardner. 302 pp. New York: Random House. $13.50.

title: World Cup On Home TV
description: For the first time in the history of the World Cup, the entire tournament will be available on home television in the United States. The Spanish International Network, Channel 41 in New York, will show 41 of the 52 games live, including the opening game between Argentina and Belgium and the final game.

title: MONEY AND MISSILES
description: As usual, pressures for a good report card to take home are working on the seven summit leaders here. No doubt they will agree. The question is whether fine phrases merely blur flatly contradictory contentions, or whether lack of substantive new decisions hides real movement for which domestic politics aren't yet prepared.

title: PEPITONE IS GRATEFUL TO REJOIN YANKEES
description: A year and a half ago, when Stephanie Pepitone showed her husband the letter she had written to George Steinbrenner, he was sure her effort to end his seven-year absence from major league baseball was futile.

title: COLLEGE'S PERIPATETIC STUDENTS MEET, AT GRADUATION
description: Ann Gardner spent her four years as an undergraduate in a Bedouin camp in the Sinai Desert, studying women in the tribe and why they preserve the traditional social order by wearing a veil in public.

title: TIME'S UP FOR THE PENNY METER
description: IN Greenport a penny has some value. It will buy 12 minutes of time at one of the municipal parking meters. But like the wooden boats that used to crowd this harbor village before the age of fiberglass, the penny parking meter will soon be a thing of the past.

title: AN AMBITIOUS FRENCH RESTAURANT
description: CALLING the place Le Restaurant almost sounds no-frills or generic, but don't be misled. The establishment that has taken the place of Villa Pierre in Glen Cove is anything but.

title: Around the World; Costa Rica to Tighten Immigration Policy
description: Warning that Costa Rica had entered ''the eye of the storm of Central America,'' Costa Rica's Vice President has announced that his Government will seek to tighten its immigration policy to preserve national security.

title: Headliners Princeton Flunks Leniency
description: Being under stress didn't give Gabrielle Napolitano the right to bend the rules, a New Jersey Superior Court judge said last week.

title: A LIFE MEASURED IN BASEBALL
description: EARLY last spring, with the snow of April on the ground and the bite of a dying winter still in the air, I was plagued by thoughts of last summer. It was a ruptured summer, shorn of baseball for two months, and I remembered those days passing slowly, without direction, as if the flow of time had been bent from its axis.

title: A PROFESSIONAL ROLE IN SUPPORT GROUPS
description: The timely piece on support groups deserves commendation for its clear exposition of the self-help movement and its relation to the professionally led therapies. There is an important omission and an addition.

title: LIFE BEFORE DEATH
description: Good books should be revisited, just as we revisit places or paintings or listen again to a piece of music. I've usually found that a second reading of a good book is even better than the first, because this time you're prepared for it, like someone who stretches and limbers up before exercising. Though the pleasure is just as great, it's more of a conscious pleasure than a blind surrender. You're more alert to what is happening.

title: THEATER: 'THE DUBLINERS' FOR JOYCE'S CENTENNIAL
description: In celebration of the centennial of James Joyce's birth, the Acting Company is presenting a Story Theater version of stories from ''The Dubliners'' at the Actors and Directors Theater on Theater Row. Several weeks ago there was a poetry-night play reading at the Public Theater of Joseph Carroll's ''Mr. Bloom and the Cyclops,'' a grand new adaptation of ''Ulysses.'' In tandem, the evenings remind one of Joyce's immense theatricality, how naturally his language resides on stage.

title: TRACKING SQUIRRELS BY RADIO
description: OBSERVING tiny gray-brown animals that spend much of their time hiding in deserted woodpecker holes 20 feet above the ground and that come out only at night is no easy matter.

title: Karen Beth Sussman Is Wed to Doctor
description: Karen Beth Sussman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Sussman of Clifton, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Allan Gibofsky, son of Mrs. Louis Gibofsky of New York, and the late Mr. Gibofsky. Rabbis Haskel Lookstein and Eugene Markovitz performed the ceremony in the Plaza Hotel.

title: James A. Hofman Marries Mary Lizbeth Hanavan
description: Mary Lizbeth Hanavan and James Augustine Hofman were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph on the Brandywine, Greenville, Del. The bride's cousin, the Rev. Francis J. Evans of Howard Beach, Queens, performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; United Press Finds a Taker
description: United Press International, the perennial second fiddle of the news wire business, was sold last week after years of being financially out of tune. Four newspaper and television executives from the South and Middle West made the purchase from E.W. Scripps Company, which started the service in 1907.

title: U.P.I. CLIENTS PLEASED ABOUT NEW OWNERSHIP
description: Officials of newspapers and broadcasting stations that use the services of United Press International say they are pleased the news agency has new owners but also express uncertainty about what the owners intend to do to improve the news-gathering operations.

title: PINK SLIPS TOUGH ON EVERYONE
description: It is every employee's nightmare. The boss beckons him to his office and, with averted eyes, tells him that he is being ''dismissed'' or ''let go'' or ''separated.'' Things just have not worked out.

title: College Bargain
description: At a time of rising tuition, Lake Erie College, a liberal arts school for women in Painesville, Ohio, offered a bargain last October: two-for-the-price-of-one enrollment for twins.

title: DOWN THE SINKHOLE
description: THE American people are rebelling. They are rejecting an ethos that sacrifices the nation's working poor and disadvantaged to the everwidening Pentagon sinkhole, which targets huge chunks of the Federal domestic budget and swallows them whole. They are protesting a mentality that reduces them to pawns in the East-West nuclear chess game.

title: FOR ROY DECARAVA, 62, IT'S TIME FOR OPTIMISM
description: At the age of 62, Roy DeCarava, who has been making photographs all of his adult life, believes that finally ''people are getting a chance to see what I have done.''

title: MELCHER FACES DIFFICULT TEST IN MONTANA'S SENATE PRIMARY
description: Senator John Melcher, seeking a second term, faces strong opposition in the Democratic primary Tuesday from Michael Bond, a housing contractor who has made the opposition to nuclear war the major issue in his campaign.

title: Television Week
description: Rehearsal on View ''Stages: Houseman Directs Lear'' is a documentary that lifts the curtain on the rarely-viewed theatrical rehearsal process in order to show, in the words of the John Houseman, ''how a play, in the course of four weeks, gets built up to performance tension.'' The film, introduced by Jason Robards, will be broadcast Wednesday on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. The rehearsal is for ''King Lear'' with David Schramm, Frances Conroy, Mary Lou Rosato, Dennis Bacigalupi, Brooks Baldwin and Patricia Hodges, all members of the Acting Company which Mr. Houseman founded.

title: FOR THE ELITE, BRASSERIE LIPP
description: FRANK J. PRIAL, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times, recently completed an assignment in the Paris bureau. By FRANK J. PRIAL

title: ZOO THAT CARES FOR ANIMAL REJECTS
description: FORKED RIVER HERE at the edge of the Pine Barrens is a zoo with a difference. It is for the rejects of the animal world. Popcorn Park Zoo is a fouracre haven for, among others, a peacock that was deserted when its owners divorced and sold their estate, raccoons and deer wounded by hunters or trappers and hundreds of Easter bunnies that outlived their welcomes.

title: CARL LEWIS, THE MAN WHO WOULD BE KING
description: HOUSTON TOMORROW night, at the Sheraton Poste Inn in Cherry Hill, N.J., Carl Lewis will be roasted at a $30-a-plate fund-raising dinner. And that is unusual. Bob Hopes and Henny Youngmans are roasted. Governors and football coaches and baseball club owners are roasted. But a 20-year-old college student who hardly has to shave?

title: Music View; STRIKING A POLITICAL NOTE
description: Classical music is conventionally encountered in cloistered halls, cloaked in the musty rituals of concert life. But sometimes music reaches out to engage the larger issues of the day, reminding us of the links between esthetic pleasure and political concern. Just now, several otherwise unrelated events have pointed up the curiously ambivalent relationship between art-music and politics.

title: The Other Side
description: To the Editor:

title: FEW GOOD OMENS VISIBLE FOR THE 76ERS
description: Billy Cunningham's birthday was celebrated belatedly Friday when he returned from Los Angeles. Sondra, his wife, and Stephanie and Heather, his daughters, had prepared a birthday cake and invited several of the neighborhood youngsters to the party.

title: Michael Savage Marries Martha Kane
description: Martha Lucille Kane and Michael Leonard Savage were married yesterday at the United Church of Christ (Congregational) in Summit, N.J. The Rev. Allen Tinker performed the ceremony.

title: ROCK STARS ARE MOVING TO MADISON AVENUE
description: For years, rock musicians spurned Madison Avenue and vice versa. But now, with a version of the Beach Boys' ''Good Vibrations'' serving as a Sunkist advertisement, a licensed Orleans hit providing the theme for ABC-TV, the Marshall Tucker Band plugging Ronrico rum, and Dave Mason promoting Miller beer, the mutual hostility has given way to a lucrative love affair. In fact, rock 'n roll's message of protest has faded into a new message of promotion.

title: THE POLITICS OF DEATH STILL THRIVE
description: It was hardly surprising that the New York State Legislature approved the death penalty last week. After all, it had done so for the last five years, only to have its efforts undone by a veto from Governor Carey. But what was notable was the passion the subject still engendered.

title: CAREY SIGNS BILL EASING LICENSING RULES FOR ALIENS
description: Various state statutes that have barred foreign citizens from getting licenses in certain professions have been repealed by legislation signed by Governor Carey.

title: Katharine Armstrong a Bride
description: The marriage of Katharine Armant Armstrong to Warren Bruce Idsal of New York took place in Armstrong, Tex., yesterday. The Rev. James Alcorn of Epiphany Episcopal Church in Kingsville, Tex., performed the ceremony in the garden of the Armstrong Ranch, home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Tobin Armstrong.

title: ARGENTINA CLOSES TWO PRESS ORGANS
description: An Argentine news agency and a newspaper published in the southern city of Comodoro Rivadavia were temporarily shut down by the military junta today for having violated official guidelines for reporting on the war in the South Atlantic.

title: Miss Clifford, W.B. Danner Are Married
description: Jennifer Leggett Clifford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Burnett Clifford of New York and Duxbury, Mass., was married yesterday to William Brewster Danner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Danner of Duxbury. The Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: ART While live animals disport at the Central Park Zoo, a group of painted ones by two New York artists can be found this month at the nearby Arsenal Gallery, run by the city's Department of Parks and Recreation in Central Park's Arsenal Building, 64th Street and Fifth Avenue. ''More Animals in the Arsenal'' is the second such show presented by this gallery, and it boasts the work of Rica Charmoz and Kenneth Smith, winner this year of a Creative Artists Public Service award.

title: KOWTOWING AND THE ELDERLY
description: To the Business Editor I wish it were possible for Mr. Penner, Resident Scholar at the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research, to be forced to come down from his ivory tower of contempt for the poor and struggling, and join the ranks of those who have toiled all their lives, without respite, with little savings, with little hope, with great fear, with aching bodies and weary minds.

title: DANCE: FELD'S 'THEATER' IS REVIVED
description: All the world was a stage and the stage was the world and, finally, one could no longer say what was the stage world and what was the real world in Eliot Feld's ''Theater,'' which was revived by the Feld Ballet on Friday night at the new Joyce Theater.

title: The Nation in Summary; Ample Waves of Grain
description: For a good many American farmers, Wayne Cryts is a folk hero. Mr. Cryts left jail last week after serving more than a month for contempt for refusing to identify farmers who helped him remove 31,000 bushels of soybeans from a grain elevator in Bernie, Mo. last year. Farmers say the case underlines the need for new bankruptcy laws that more closely protect their fragile economy.

title: 3 HOMERS IN A ROW HELP BREWERS WINN
description: Robin Yount, Cecil Cooper and Ben Oglivie hit consecutive bases-empty home runs in the seventh inning as the Milwaukee Brewers made 17 hits and beat the Oakland A's, 11-3, today.

title: THE MAKE OR BREAK SALES FOR BOEING
description: If the orders do fall away, Boeing's borrowing could easily exceed a staggering $2 billion in the next 18 months, analysts predict. Yet few analysts foresee a replay of the punishing cutbacks that wracked Boeing between 1969 and 1971, when the company slashed its payroll to 37,500 from 101,000, and profits shriveled to a trickle.

title: WISHFUL THINKING ON THE SPOT MARKET
description: MR. BROWN suggests that the United States Government should investigate the pricing of Saudi A rabian crude. Unfortunately, he has so little understanding of the S audi Arabian crude supply arrangements that his remarks border on t he ludicrous.

title: IN CO-OPS, FIRST GET CLEARANCE
description: A long-time renter has just bought his first cooperative apartment a nd plans to redo it to his taste, with through-the-wall a irconditioners, picture windows, an enlarged living room, a kitchen e quipped to turn out banquets and a bathroom-spa with whirlpool bath a nd sauna. Then he learns he must win approval of his plans from the c o-op's board - and reality sets in.

title: Wendy Abrams Married To Lawrence Alan Bassell
description: Wendy Abrams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Abrams of West Hartford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Lawrence Alan Bassell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Bassel of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Harold S. Silver performed the ceremony in Congregation Beth Israel.

title: EAST END MUSEUMS EYE NEW DIRECTIONS
description: THE past may be present at Guild Hall and the Parrish Art Museum, but these days the future counts, too. For both East End landmarks have new directors - Annabelle Hebert and Trudy Kramer, respectively - who were hired to continue the transformation of the venerable institutions from summer playthings of the rich into viable, professional regional arts centers, and this, the two women agree, means looking ahead.

AS Philadelphia celebrates its 300th anniversary this year, its s tock exchange is marking year 192, making it the nation's oldest s tock exchange. Despite such longevity - or perhaps because of it - t he Philadelphia Stock Exchange has made a name as the most i nnovative of the six regional stock exchanges. It is now eagerly a waiting a go-ahead from the Securities and Exchange Commission for i ts latest innovation, trading in foreign currency options, which c ould go on stream as early as September.

title: AS THE NATION IS REARMING, IT CAN'T HURT TO BE DISARMING
description: WASHINGTON ON his first major overseas trip as President, Ronald Reagan is trying to convince Europeans that he has developed a solid grasp on the crucial issues of war and peace and a vision for the future that they can accept. In particular, the leader of the Western alliance must persuade skeptics that his recent statements on arms control represent a long-term policy, not an expedient to take the steam out of the disarmament and nuclear freeze movements that have been expanding around the world.

title: CITIZEN UTILITY BOARDS HUNT INDUSTRY WHITE ELEPHANTS
description: ''Are you mad as *!* about your utility bills? Join the Citizens Utility Board,'' states a flyer tucked, rather surprisingly, inside telephone bills sent to residents of Wisconsin during the past year. This solicitation, and similar ones in all other utility bills, was authorized by the State Legislature to give consumers a stronger voice at hearings on rate increases and legislative proposals.

title: Mailbox Sports Capitalism
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THEODORE WHITE SUMS UP
description: Theodore White picked up an error made by some journalists who reported on President Carter's Camp David discussions with intellectuals. I was invited but did not attend. DAVID RIESMAN Department of Sociology Harvard University Cambridge, Mass.

title: JERSEYANS TO VOTE TUESDAY IN SENATE PRIMARIES
description: A resurgent New Jersey Republican Party will decide a hard-fought two-way contest for the party's United States Senate nomination, and Democrats will be looking for someone to salvage the Senate seat that was held for 24 years by Harrison A. Williams Jr. as voters cast ballots in party primaries on Tuesday.

title: THE WORDS OF REASSURANCE NEVER CAME FOR PAT HADEN
description: LOS ANGELES PAT HADEN stood on the dais before all the TV cameras and the notepads and the flashing bulbs and he said, ''To paraphrase another well-known Southern Californian, you're not going to have me around to boo anymore.'' And then he went on, ''Actually, I've come here to announce my real height. I'm 5-4.''

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: 3 CHARGED IN ATTACK
description: Israel's Ambassador to Britain, who was shot Thursday night, will probably be at least partly paralyzed if he lives, the surgeon who operated on him said Saturday.

title: THE PARTICULAR PLEASURES OF A HOME MUSIC LIBRARY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Tim Page is host of a daily music program on WNYC. By TIM PAGE

title: 400 SOCIAL SCIENTISTS SEEK END TO ARMS RACE
description: Focusing on the perils of the nuclear age and who should bear the responsibility, more than 400 social scientists gathered in New York this weekend to discuss how they could help end the arms race.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BY MICHAEL STRAUSS
description: DENVILLE AGUEST competing in the recent $60,000 Dodge Open golf tournament at the Rockaway River Country Club seemed to pale when, after driving off the first tee for the first time, he was told he had hooked his ball into a cemetery.

title: WHEN AUTUMN FALLS IN JUNE
description: As summer starts, many stores as usual are full of fall clothes. There are reasons why this will continue. But there are also changes afoot to accommodate a broader range of customers.

title: Alice Colburn and Richard Neff Married
description: Alice Armitage Colburn and Richard Evan Neff, Washington lawyers, were married yesterday in Leesburg, Va. The Rev. Richard A. DeMott of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Sterling, Va., performed the ceremony at Oatlands, a former plantation that is the property of the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

title: Presidential Panel Sworn In
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis swore in 30 members of a Presidential commission on drunken driving Friday.

title: Bay Bazaar
description: The 100,000 sq. ft. and 2,000 parking spaces that until last year were a bustling Korvettes in the Bay Parkway Shopping Center overlooking Gravesend Bay reopened yesterday as Ceasars Bay Bazaar. It is a weekends-only center of discount booths for merchants and manufacturers of everything from clothing to gold items.

title: by Martin Gansberg
description: WITH all the talk about the problems of drug abuse and alcoholism in high schools, officials of Weston High School completed a survey of students and parents last month that showed most felt alcohol was the primary concern. The results indicated that 70 percent of the students and 90 percent of the parents agreed with this conclusion.

title: SOME VOICES ON HOLMES-COONEY
description: The fight between Larry Holmes and Gerry Cooney on Friday night has stirred the sports world. Can Holmes retain his title and his stature as one of the most active and longest-reigning heavyweight champions? Has Cooney recuperated from the shoulder injury that postponed the fight last March? Will he be rusty after not fighting since May 1981? The New York Times sought opinions about the fight from many people. Following are some of the responses:

title: Businessman Killed in Spain
description: Youths suspected of being Basque guerrillas shot and killed a local businessman in his office today, the police said. Rafael Vega, 50 years old, was in his wholesale warehouse in Santurce, near Bilbao, when several youths stormed in, shot him six times and fled. The police later found the abandoned car used by the gunmen.

title: Ann S. Pavey Wed To Alan C. Silbergh
description: Ann Stuart Pavey, a buyer and manager of the men's furnishings departments at Burton Ltd. in New York, was married yesterday to Alan Charles Mark Silbergh, policy and systems coordinator of Brooks Brothers in New York. The Rev. Dr. David H.C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Headliners; A Suspect Again
description: Joseph Paul Franklin preached racial hatred and, judging from his record, practiced what he preached. An avowed racist who once belonged to the Ku Klux Klan and the American Nazi Party, Mr. Franklin is serving a pair of life sentences for killing two black joggers in Salt Lake City, faces prosecution for racially motivated slayings in Indianapolis and Oklahoma City and is under investigation for similar crimes in Johnstown, Pa. and Cincinnati. Last week a Federal grand jury in South Bend, Ind., added another case to the list, indicting Mr. Franklin in the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., former president of the National Urban League, at a Fort Wayne, Ind., motel two years ago.

title: Television Week
description: 'Awfully Tough' Maya Angelou's film, ''Sister, Sister,'' starring Diahann Carroll, Rosalind Cash, Irene Cara, Paul Winfield, Robert Hooks and Dick Anthony Williams, will be broadcast Monday night on NBC, from 9 to 11. The drama centers on three sisters with clashing values.

title: JERSEY RACE IS A DOUBLE TOSS-UP
description: New Jersey's Republican voters have a clear choice in Tuesday's Senate primary between two candidates with distinctly opposing views, but Democrats who step up to exercise their freedom of choice will have their work cut out for them. With nine candidates, their party's race has become a free-for-all with few clear issues and no clear leader.

title: The Region in Summary; Seeking Sense in Juvenile Justice
description: When it comes to juveniles, many believe, the quality of justice in New York State could hardly be more strained. But a bill the State Senate approved last week may at least improve the quantity that is dispensed.

title: LONDON The American Academy Awards collected by British films in Hollywood this year have infused the British film business with a promising vigor. But it is uncertain whether the industry will burst into renewed productivity and success, reminiscent of its heyday in the 1940's, or collapse altogether from lack of funding. The mood here is optimistic, but very cautious.
description: Much depends on the outcome of several movies nearing release. Perhaps the most critical test of the industry's future will be Richard Attenborough's $22 million epic, ''Gandhi,'' scheduled for release on three continents this November. Also crucial will be ''Local Hero,'' produced by the Oscar-winner David Puttnam, and directed by William Forsyth, the Scot who recently won a British Academy of Film and Television Award for ''Gregory's Girl.'' Alan Parker's ''The Wall,'' a rock movie coming out in July, is yet another British hopeful.

title: CITY BALLET MARKS STRAVINSKY'S CENTENNIAL WITH 11 NEW WORKS
description: Arguably, Igor Stravinsky was this century's greatest composer. Demonstrably, George Balanchine is its greatest choreographer.
