Therefore, the New York York City Ballet will now offer the Stravinsky Centennial Celebration, largely dedicated to the fruits of their collaboration. It starts on Thursday at the New York State Theater, and ends on June 18, 100 years to the day after Stravinsky was born in Oranienbaum, Russia, in 1882. Most authorities give his birthdate as June 17; Balanchine, however, knows better.

title: CARLOS FUENTES TURNS TO THEATER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Arthur Holmberg, who teaches literature and theater at Harvard, writes frequently about the arts. By ARTHUR HOLMBERG CAMBRIDGE, MASS. ''When I was a young man,'' Carlos Fuentes confesses, ''I wrote to live. Now, at 54, I write not to die. Like Scheherazade in the 'Arabian Nights,' I'll live as long as I have another story to tell.'' ''The Death of Artemio Cruz'' and ''Terra Nostra'' established Mr. Fuentes's reputation as one of the world's leading novelists. Now ''Orchids in the Moonlight,'' his first play to be produced in America, will have its world premiere at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., on Wednesday.

title: TO BE TUTORED OR NOT TO BE TUTORED-A QUESTION OF NEEDS
description: ACONFERENCE is being held in the principal's office in a school somewhere in the county. Present are the principal, a parent, a guidance counselor and 15-year-old Mary Jane, a ninth-grade student. She has missed three and a half weeks of school because of surgery. While able to keep up with her work in most subjects through assignments provided by her teachers and coordinated by the counselor, she has fallen behind in French. Several extra help sessions have been arranged by her teacher on her return, and she has doubled the amount of time spent at home on her French, but the loss has been too great and she is falling further and further behind.

title: by Lynne Ames
description: SCARSDALE MOST of them were past retirement age, but that didn't impede the discussion. Sixteen people in their 60's, 70's and 80's were talking about work, about what it meant to them and to the fictional character they were reading about.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ROCKINGHAM WARE IN BOONTON
description: POMPTON PLAINS ACCORDING to Barry Block, ''most people call Rockingham ware Bennington ware.'' And that, he said, ''is incorrect,'' since Bennington, Vt., was only one of the places in America where this pottery was made.

title: WHOOPS; Normalcy
description: Demonstrators may be denouncing President Reagan this week in Europe. Demonstrators in New York may be preparing for their big nuclear freeze rally next week.

title: WISHFUL THINKINNG ON THE SPOT MARKET
description: WILLIAM M. BROWN'S ''Our Taxes Help Pay the Saudi 'Ransom' '' (May 23), leaves your readers with a distorted view of t he operating conditions in the international petroleum market, i gnores important realities in the international energy economy and e mploys faulty economic reasoning.

title: JUNTA IS USING SLICK ADS TO BOLSTER WAR MORALE
description: Not far from where Argentina's military leaders are plotting the country's war strategy for the Falklands, another group is plotting its advertising strategy.

title: Sports of the Times; THE CAKE FOR WOODY
description: WOODY STEPHENS kept saying, ''This puts the icing on the cake,'' butt he icing made a tinkling sound as it sloshed around with the amber l iquid in the plastic cup.

title: 'GIMPEL' IN MONTCLAIR
description: Isaac Bashevis Singer and the Bakery Theater Cooperative will present an adaptaton of ''Gimpel the Fool,'' the Nobel laureate's short story, at the First Congregational Church in Montclair next Sunday evening.

title: DRINKING: WHAT AGE THE 'LAST CARRIAGE'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dangers of Turkey Hunting
description: IN New York State, pursuing wild turkeys is the most dangerous form of hunting. It's not that hunters imitating the cry of a lovelorn female are attacked by impassioned gobblers, or that an inordinate number of heart attacks are induced by the pre-dawn hikes that are an essential part of spring turkey hunting. Rather, it's that the sport, which should be quite safe, has apparently attracted more than its share of irrational and sometimes law-defying devotees.

title:
GARDENING;
THE GROWING AND HARVESTING OF HERBS
description: IT would seem logical that the ideal location for an herb garden would be just outside the kitchen door. The cook would merely have to step outside to gather a leaf or two of this and that and a sprig of something else for preparing a meal. Indeed, many a Colonial household did have such a garden.

title: Around the Nation; Idaho Opens Inquiry Into Torture of Youth
description: The state Attorney General's office has begun an investigation into the death by torture of 17-year-old Christopher Peterman in a county jail.

title: Union City Article Called a Distortion
description: I read with shock and dismay the May 16 Opinion article by Alan Jay Weiss. As a lifelong resident of Union City and (without contradiction) the only outspoken, open, political opponent of William V. Musto for the last 20 years, I must protest the distortions presented by Mr. Weiss.

title: MITTERRAND URGES COOPERATIVE EFFORT ON RESEARCH
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France opened the formal working sessions of the conference of the seven leading industrialized nations with an appeal for formal planning and cooperation in managing the revolution brought on by technology.

title: LAWYERS EXPAND ROLES IN GOVERNMENT
description: THE increase in the size of town legal departments on Long Island over the last decade has made this once obscure branch of town government costly as well as controversial.

title: A DIGITAL FIRST: BEETHOVEN'S NINE
description: The name of Kurt Sanderling is not well known in this country, but anyone who is familiar with his stereo cycle of the Brahms symphonies with the Staatskappelle Dresden - which appeared in this country around 1973 on European RCA - or who has run across his earlier mono recordings with the Leningrad Philharmonic, must have looked forward to the release by EMI earlier this year of his integral recording of Beethoven's nine symphonies with the Philharmonia Orchestra of London.

title:
GARDENING;
THE GROWING AND HARVESTING OF HERBS
description: IT would seem logical that the ideal location for an herb garden would be just outside the kitchen door. The cook would merely have to step outside to gather a leaf or two of this and that and a sprig of something else for preparing a meal. Indeed, many a Colonial household did have such a garden.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't do interviews at lunch time.'' - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher responding to question about the U.N. Falkland vote. (17:1.)

title: CONDOMINIUMS HAVE SPECIAL INSURANCE NEEDS
description: IT was the night before Christmas. Outside the temperature had dipped below freezing, with icy winds reaching speeds of up to 40 miles an hour. While most of the 150 condominium owners at Harbor Village, a town-house complex on the waterfront in Branford, lay snug in their beds, flames from a defective fireplace in building 17 were rapidly consuming that structure.

title: RIVAL PAPERS IN DETROIT BAR NO HOLDS IN FIGHT THAT ONLY ONE MAY SURVIVE
description: When the racial disturbances of 1967 erupted here, an editor at The Detroit Free Press borrowed an armored car from the Chrysler Corporation's defense subsidiary so that his reporters could cover the rioting in safety.

title: Sports People; Jones Eyes New League
description: Ed (Too Tall) Jones of the Dallas Cowboys has become the first prominent National Football League player to express interest in the new United States Football League.

title: Opera in Central Park
description: The New York Grand Opera will present its ninth summer of free, fully-staged opera in Central Park with three Thursday evenings of Verdi next month. These 8:30 P.M. performances conducted by Vincent La Selva will be at the Band Shell in the Mall and will consist of ''La Traviata'' on July 1, ''Rigoletto'' on July 8 and ''Aida'' on July 15. The Mall can be reached from the East or West Side entrances to the park at 72d Street.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Charlie Scott, an N.B.A. guard who retired in 1980, is charging that the Denver Nuggets have fallen $9,000 behind in deferred payments to him.

title: LOBSTERMAN FINDS PROFIT IN THE SOUND
description: BRIDGEPORT ''I'D enjoy being like the old man and the sea someday,'' said Bruce Williams, a 33-year-old lobsterman, ''because then I'll be around for a long time.''

title: Bridge; A COUP FOR PAUL CHEMLA
description: In 1980 a brilliant young French team surprised the cognoscenti by defeating a strong United States squad in the final of the World Team Olympiad in Valkenberg, the Netherlands. One of the French players was Paul Chemla, a rotund, ebullient, chatty character who used to be a classical scholar. He was for a short time a professor, but decided to dedicate himself to bridge when he found this allowed him to get up late in the morning.

title:
Camera;
GOOD COMPOSITION IS ESSENTIAL FOR GOOD PHOTOS
Funt Psychology
description: As the creator, producer, director and editor of television's ''Candid Camera,'' Allen Funt has been described as a part humorist, psychologist and con artist who lifted aggravation to a fine art. His program, which used a hidden camera to catch the reactions of people to frustrating situations, was popular from its inception in 1949.

title: Voting in Papua New Guinea Starts and Will Last 3 Weeks
description: Voing began today in Papua New Guinea in one of the world's longest election processes.

title: U.S. ENDS MOST EXPLORATION OF SPACE WITH RUSSIA
description: Almost all official cooperation between the United States and the Soviet Union regarding space exploration has come to a quiet end as a result of the two nations' widening political differences.

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'The Suspect' It has been said, perhaps with some justice, that the Charles Laughton vehicle, Robert Siodmak's ''The Suspect'' (1945), is too genteel as a derivation of the infamous Dr. Crippen murder case in England. Perhaps.

title: TOWN HAILS MANDATORY GUNS
description: Residents of this tiny rural community of 300 people in southeastern Pennsylvania do not worry much about crime, and they want to keep it that way. To that end, the borough council is mandating gun ownership and is making no secret about it.

title: Recent Sales
description: Atlantic Highlands $63,000 124 Memorial Parkway *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old Cape Cod; *2*hardwood floors, new roof; taxes $1,849. Freehold $98,000 995 Waterworks Road *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath. 4-year-oldcolonial; *2*full basement, central airconditioning; taxes $2029. Holmdel $185,000 7 Grandview Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; *2*60-foot deck, fireplace; taxes $3,092. Elberon $68,000 296 Lockwood Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; *2*in-ground pool, aluminum siding; taxes $1,688. Middletown $95,000 30 Herb Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; in-ground *2*pool, central air-conditions; taxes $2,063. Colts Neck $133,000 1 Horse Shoe Court *2*5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 13-year-old *2*colonial; new appliances, redwood deck; taxes $2,757 OTHER AREAS Patchogue, L.I. $55,000 245 North Ocean Avenue *2*7-bedroom, 3-bath, 100-year-old colonial; wraparound porch, *2*six fireplaces, formal dining room, basement; taxes $3,200. Ardsley, N.Y. $105,000 11 Chestnut Street *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in *2*kitchen, terrace, semifinished basement; taxes $2,247. Fairfield, Conn. $169,000 87 Northwood Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 50-year-old custom- *2*built colonial; oversized rooms, remodeled *2*kitchen with new appliances; taxes, $1,952.

title: Carolyn Rueckert, C. J. Stouffer 3d, Teacher, Married
description: Carolyn Rueckert, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic Rueckert of Hanover, N.H., was married there yesterday to C.J. Stouffer 3d, son of Mrs. Roger Saylor of Enola, Pa., and the late Brigadier General Stouffer Jr., U.S.A. The Rev. Park Dickerson, assisted by the Rev. Burton A. MacLean, performed the Congregational ceremony in the Church of Christ at Dartmouth College.

title: Stadler Takes 3-Stroke Lead
description: Craig Stadler hits a golf ball so far that he reminds Jack Nicklaus of how Nicklaus played ''when I was in my 20's.'' By Nicklaus's appraisal, Stadler did everything right today as he shot his second straight 67 to take the lead from Nicklaus in the rain-delayed third round of the Kemper Open.

title: Jackie Stewart Stays on Scene
description: Just about the only person who walked down pit row of the parking lot that became part of a Grand Prix racecourse here without a big pass on display this week was a pocket-size man with a pronounced Scottish burr.

title: PEAK TO PEAK
description: BONN CHANCELLOR Helmut Schmidt, according to key aides, regards the NATO summit this week as more important than the economic discussions in Versailles this weekend - and not just because the NATO talks happen to be taking place in Bonn.

title: ALASKA VOTES TO BAR TOWNS FROM REGULATING GUNS
description: The Legislature in Alaska, where it is legal to walk down the steet carrying a gun, has voted to bar its cities from regulating firearms.

title: KOWTOWING AND THE ELDERLY
description: To the Business Editor: We must protest Rudolph G. Penner's portrayal of us elderly as fat cats living off the sweat of those now employed, and intimidating Congress to increase our benefits under Social Security - ''Kowtowing to the Elderly'' (May 23).

title: YALE CREW SEEN OVER HARVARD
description: NEW LONDON PERHAPS it was coincidence. No one seems certain. But the first crew race between Yale and Harvard was held in New Hampshire in 1852. Franklin Pierce was the 14th President. His home state? New Hampshire. His alma mater, however, was Maine's Bowdoin College.

title: ROLE OF GOVERNMENT IN NEW TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT MAY SPLIT CONFEREES
description: The call by President Francois Mitterrand of France yesterday for more direct involvement in the development of new technologies seems bound to divide the participants at the economic meeting in Versailles.

title: The World in Summary; Billion-Dollar Housecleaning
description: Last month's $988 million financial scandal cast a wide smirch in South Korea, and President Chun Doo Hwan's political purification drive has proved to be no overnight job. Mr. Chun last week continued his effort ''to refresh the social atmosphere,'' as Seoul newspapers put it, by adding a 12th new face to the 22-man Cabinet (11 members were dismissed last month).

title: WILANDER RESISTS COMPARISON TO BORG
description: Mats Wilander may be Swedish but he is not really one of those ''clones of Bjorn Borg'' that Vitas Gerulaitis warned about the other day. For one thing, Wilander is even more low key than Borg. For another, he is more natural with the volley.

title: HOW TO FIND AND WORK WITH A BROKER
description: In these days of high interest rates and low housing sales, the role of the real-estate broker or salesman is becoming increasingly important to both buyers and sellers.

title: COLLEGES FACING UNIONISM ISSUE
description: ARE professors employees, managers or both? This seemingly academic question has aroused controversy between faculties and administrations at Long Island private universities and colleges.

title: Miss Vietor Is Affianced
description: Mrs. Alexander Orr Vietor of New York and Edgartown, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Martha Knox Vietor, to John Bristol Glass Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Glass of Whiteville, N.C.

title: Yes, There Is a Better Income Tax
description: As many Americans keep saying, it's a poison in the body politic. Who can respect an income tax system that allows many wealthy citizens to pay little or no tax yet claims close to half the marginal earnings of the middle class? Who can defend a tax code so complicated that even the most educated family needs a professional to decide how much it owes?

title: VOTE DUE TOMORROW IN PHILIPPINE REBEL AREA
description: Legislative elections, postponed twice this year, are to be held on Monday in the Moslem-dominated southern part of the Philippines, and opposition politicians are charging that the balloting will not be fair.

title: A Quango for Democracy?
description: The British have minted a word - quango -which America could now put to good use. Quango stands for quasi-autonomous nongovernmental organ, an example being the British Council. Funded by the Government but directed by private citizens, the Council does what bureaucrats are poorly situated to do: decide how much money to give to which groups for overseas cultural tours and talks. It has literally given Shakespeare the great Globe as a stage.

title: Miss Beck Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest W. Beck of Lake Forest, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melinda Noel Beck, to Peter Curtis Neger, son of Mrs. Stanley Stahl and Edward B. Neger, both of New York.

title: Milan Honors Bernstein
description: Leonard Bernstein, the conductor and composer, has been awarded the City of Milan's Gold Medal. Mr. Bernstein made his Milan debut in 1953 and was the first American to conduct at the Teatro alla Scala. La Scala has commissioned a new opera from Mr. Bernstein for performance early in 1984. Previous winners of the Gold Medal include Arturo Toscanini, Claudio Abbado and Luchino Visconti.

title: MEDICARE: A GUIDE FOR USERS
description: THE widespread confusion and misinformation about Medicare led a Wilton writer, Geri Harrington, to an intensive two-year research effort that culminated in ''The Medicare Answer Book,'' just published by Harper & Row in hard-cover ($17.95) and paperback ($5.95) editions.

title: THE OTHER SUMMIT
description: By an odd coincidence in recent days, there have been two summit meetings in Europe - one temporal among the political leaders of the industrial world, and the other spiritual, between the Pope of Rome and the Protestant leaders of Britain - both at the climax of the wars between Britain and Argentina and between Iran and Iraq.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
LET THE F.T.C. BE A CHECK ON THE DOCTORS
description: WE are all aware of the beneficial effects of professional licensingb oards and medical associations that protect consumers from quackery a nd charlatans. But we are not so aware that these same associations a re actually being used to establish cartels for their members. And s uch cartels are convenient vehicles for setting higher fees on many k inds of health and other professional services.

title: LEVEL OF FIGHTING IN MIDEAST GROWS
description: Fighting between Israeli forces and Palestinian guerrillas intensified today, with artillery and rocket attacks on northern Israeli towns and Israeli air strikes on Palestinian bases in southern Lebanon.

title: Sports People; Good News for Davis
description: Howard Davis Jr. believed until yesterday morning that he had broken his right thumb while winning a unanimous 10-round decision over Julio Valdes Thursday night in Atlantic City. But an examination by Dr. Noah Finkel, an orthopedic surgeon from Huntington, L.I., disclosed that the lightweight boxer had only a small bone chip.

title: IT'S TIME TO PICK YOUR OWN
description: SWEET scarlet strawberries ripening in the fields signal the start of another season of ''pick your own.'' At many of the farms, especially the smaller ones, picking your own begins and ends with the strawberries and rarely lasts beyond the Fourth of July. But a number of farms make other fruit and vegetable crops available on a ''pick your own'' basis as the season progresses.

title: STATE A LEADER IN RIDE-SHARING
description: THE clock on the dashboard reads exactly 7:40 A.M. each working day when a 15-passenger van begins its trip from Westport to Stamford. Hermione Sakolsky, one of the organizers of the two-yearold van pool, learned during her two-month stint as the van's driver that, ''If you are like a railroad - which we are - you're going to leave on time whether everyone is there or not.''

title: by Jeanne Clare Ferron; Cool Summer Bargains At Mall Dress Shop
description: South of the Border, at The Galleria in White Plains, has summer prom gowns of all lengths from $30 to $185 for the laciest of white traditional styles. Many are Jessica's Gunnies of San Francisco, or Gunne Sax, in sheers, pastels and florals with many-tiered skirts and Victorian detailing, often marked down from the original prices. The greatest number are priced at about $60 now.

title: by Eleanor Charles; 50TH ANNUAL DOG SHOW
description: The Greenwich Kennel Club holds its 50th yearly Dog Show on Saturday on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York. Thirty-four judges will begin their deliberations at 9 A.M., and the show will be on all day. Elsworth S. Howell of Darien, Conn., will judge best in show. Last year's winner, Ch. St. Aubrey Dragonora of Elsdon, was a Pekingese who also won the Westminster Show at Madison Square Garden in New York City last February.

title:
ART;
PRINCETON: THE ART OF INDIA IN ALL ITS GLORY
description: PRINCETON AN EXTRAORDINARILY beautiful exhibition, ''Indian Paintings from the Polsky Collections,'' opened recently at the Princeton Art Museum and will be on view through June 18.

title: SAUDI DONATION TO HARVARD STIRS FACULTY CONCERN
description: Harvard University has accepted a gift of $1 million from an anonymous Saudi Arabian businessman to create a professorial chair in Arab studies.

title: JACK N. BARTFIELD, 73, IS DEAD
description: Jack N. Bartfield, a rare-book dealer and art collector and authority on the work of John James Audubon, the naturalist and painter, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73 years old.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RISES SLIGHTLY TO 9.5%
description: With 10.5 million people out of work, unemployment rose in May to 9.5 percent, a post-World War II high, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. The Reagan Administration said the slight rise, from 9.4 percent in April, proved that the recession was bottoming out. Budget Director David A. Stockman said the economy would stage a recovery in the second half.

title: VERSATILE TORONTO TO TEST COSMOS TODAY
description: The Cosmos disapproved of the way the Blizzard played when the two teams met in Toronto a month ago, griping that the Canadian team tried only to stifle them and did not attack.

title: HAVE THE NETWORKS RESPONDED TO CABLE?
description: When ABC perfunctorily dropped the acclaimed comedy series ''Taxi'' from its fall schedule last month, not even its fiercest supporters held out much hope that the show could be raised, like Lazarus, from the dead. Yet within a week, both NBC and Home Box Office were engaged in a bidding war to buy the show. HBO's bid provided the best evidence yet that at least one cable television service is now in a position to compete head-to-head with the three commercial networks for the best available programming.

title: Hebrew Academy Describes Expansion
description: The recent article about a new rival Hebrew school contains several erroneous statements relating to the Hebrew Academy of Suffolk County.

title: POP: LOIS SAGE BACKED BY A SAX
description: One of the things that distinguishes Lois Sage's singing at Caroline's, Eighth Avenue between 26th and 27th Streets, where she appeared through last night, is her accompaniment. Instead of the piano-bass or piano-guitar combination that is the customary form of duo backing for a pop singer, Miss Sage uses a pianist, Charles Lindberg, and a saxophonist who also plays flute, Don Haviland.

title: Frankie Andrews Wed In Greenwich to Doctor
description: The marriage of Frankie Ann Andrews to Dr. Dickerman Hollister Jr. took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hollister, in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Eloise E. Lester of St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Atlanta performed the ceremony.

title: TRANSIT POLICE IN NIGHTTIME SWEEP ARREST 117 IN BROOKLYN'S SUBWAYS
description: A force of more than 300 Transit Authority police officers spread through the Brooklyn subway system Friday night, making 117 arrests and issuing 530 summonses in an eight-hour period.

title: The Nation in Summary; THe Familiarity of Victory
description: Like the river that borders his state, that old man John C. Stennis of Mississippi keeps rolling along. Mr. Stennis, who first went to the Senate in 1947 to fill a vacancy and has since been elected to five terms, last week won the Democratic nomination for another as Mississippi, West Virginia, New Mexico and South Dakota held primary elections.

title: Future Events In and Out of Town
description: Tickets for the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Rite of Spring June 10 - The New York City Ballet's annual spring gala benefit and supper ball at the New York State Theater opens the company's weeklong salute to Igor Stravinsky on the 100th anniversary of his birth. The proceedings start with a cocktail party outdoors on the Promenade Terrace at 6:30 P.M., followed at 8 P.M. by the performance with premieres of works choreographed by George Balanchine and Peter Martins. A black-tie supper ball on the Theater Promenade until 1 A.M. winds up the festivities. Vera Stravinsky, the composer's widow, is the honorary chairman for the gala, the proceeds from which will go to the company's production fund. Tickets, $1,000, $500 and $250 for the entire evening, depending on the seating arrangements, $100 for cocktails and the performance only.

title: BALLET THEATER: LA FOSSE IN 'GISELLE'
description: American Ballet Theater presented a ''Giselle'' on Friday at the Metropolitan Opera House that was, surprisingly enough, one of the joys of its season. Robert La Fosse, a new Albrecht, is a young dancer who has been pushed hard and into occasionally unsuitableseeming roles such as this demanding one. Cynthia Harvey, new as Giselle, has sometimes been off her stride after a recent injury. And who needs another ''Giselle,'' anyway?

title: Helen Mary Watson Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Helen Mary Watson, to Mark Wentworth Blodgett, son of Lee Billings Blodgett of Fitzwilliam, N.H., and Lawrence W. Blodgett of Killingworth, Conn.

title: BOOKS ABOUT JERSEY: CHAPTER TWO
description: IT'S TRAVEL time - time to locate hidden gold, recall forgotten sites and country trails, pay homage to artistic treasures and fulfill long-ago promises of self enrichment. A variety of books about New Jersey can lead the way.

title: Accountant, Miss Curran Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Curran of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Sea Girt, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Louise Curran, to James Clayton Kingsbery, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walton W. Kingsbery Jr. of Rolling Hills, Calif.

title: Chess; SOME PLAYERS PUT ALL ASIDE IN PURSUIT OF A PAWN
description: Wilhelm Steinitz, world champion from 1866 to 1894, was a man for whom no danger was too great as long as it netted him a pawn. The occasional crushing he suffered in the service of such a noble ideal never did anything to diminish his appetite.

title: Teaching the Autistic: Another View
description: That anonymous special-education teacher whose article ''This Is the Way She Is'' (Opinion Page) launched an avalanche of high indignation and self-serving solemnity has my full support. While some people at the C.W. Post Center may denounce her for ''being in direct opposition to current special-education theory and practice'' (shades of mini-totalitarianism!), I find her observations refreshingly perceptive and forthright.

title: A GLOOMY VIEW FROM VERSAILLES
description: ONE goes to a summit for the view. But the view from this year's economic summit at the palace of the Sun King is not particularly inspiring. In fact, it seems somewhat depressing.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error in an article on the yacht Sea Cloud that appeared last Sunday, a quotation from ''Two Years Before the Mast'' by Richard Henry Dana was changed slightly and incorporated into the article without attribution.

title: ARGENTINA BUYING NEW ARMS
description: Argentina has been buying planes, missiles and other arms in a worldwide shopping effort to replace losses in the Falkland Islands war, according to Argentine and foreign sources.

title: GIVING THE DISABLED A SHOT AT TENNIS
description: ''PHYSICALLY handicapped children have the intellect of other normal children,'' said Suzanne Lippe of Hewlett. ''They just have a physical difference. They can think and reason very well, and there is no reason why they should not be physically active.''

title: FOR HONEYMOONERS AND THRILL SEEKERS; Discounts for Those Who Tie the Knot
description: On the informal calendar, June may be the month of weddings, but so far as Air France and the Marriott Corporation are concerned, newly minted marriages know a less restricted season.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. AND COURTS EXPAND REDISTRICTING ROLE
description: The Justice Department and the Federal courts appear to be playing a larger role than ever in determining the boundaries of Congressional and state legislative districts.

title: New York Times Magazine June 6, 1982
description: William Safire 16 On Language My Fellow Americanians Russell Baker 20 Sunday Observer Play It Again Nina Darnton 22 The Subtle Power of the Polish Church The Roman Catholic Church has grown stronger since the crackdown in Poland, but Archbishop Jozef Glemp must exercise his power cautiously, balancing the needs of the people and the nation to assure that both survive. John Lombardi 26 Lumet: The City Is His Sound Stage The veteran director Sidney Lumet has achieved a hard-won reputation as an artist and gained wide fame as the quintessential New York movie maker.

title: BEDFORD GARDEN CLUB READIES ITS ANNUAL FLOWER SHOW
description: WITH a little luck - and much hammering, painting, scrambling and hustling - when the sun sets on the salmon-colored pavilion at the Venetian Theater at Caramoor in Katonah on Wednesday, every niche, pedestal and trellis for the Bedford Garden Club's Third Annual Flower Show will be in place.

title: Janet Mary Carafa Bride Of Timothy Mather Lee
description: Janet Mary Carafa, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Carafa of Wallingford, Conn., was married yesterday to Timothy Mather Lee, son of Mrs. Burton James Lee Jr., of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and the late Mr. Lee. The Rev. Daniel Johnson performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Hamden, Conn.

title: PRECISION CHUTISTS: THE SKY'S THE LIMIT
description: WRIGHTSTOWN LIKE a startled snake, the yellow streamer darted out from the tail of the sleek twin-engine aircraft and disappeared into the afternoon haze, telling the crowd at McGuire Air Force Base below that the Golden Knights, the Army's precision parachute team, were ready to jump.

title: 2 SIDES FIRE ACROSS LEBANESE LINE; U.N. SPOKESMAN SAYS GUNS AND TANKS PUSH NORTH ACROSS BORDER
description: Israeli jets and gunboats bombed and strafed Palestinian guerrilla strongholds along the coastal highway between Beirut and southern Lebanon today as Palestinian and Israeli gunners exchanged heavy artillery fire across the Israeli-Lebanese border.

title: RX - A TAXING SYSTEM THAT FITS COUNTRY'S NEEDS
description: HOW sensitive a political issue Social Security is was demonstrated again last month when Congress backed away from considering a proposal, endorsed by the White House, to save $40 billion in the system. Yet unless Congress acts in the next 12 months, the monthly checks that now go to 36 million Americans may not get sent out. The Week in Review asked three specialists - Colin D. Campbell, professor of economics at Dartmouth College, Alicia H. Munnell, vice president and economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, and Stanford G. Ross, a Washingon lawyer who was commissioner of the Social Security Administration for President Carter - to talk about Social Security's near- and far-term problems and how to fix them. Excerpts of their discussion with Edward Cowan, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times, and Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, follow.

title: THE ASSEMBLY-LINE NEWS CONFERENCE
description: HARTFORD LAST Tuesday morning, United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. was holding forth at a news conference in the caucus room that Republican State Senators normally use on the third floor of the State Capitol.

title: FOREIGN AID UNDER FIRE
description: Ann Crittenden reports on international economic affairs for The New York Times.

title: CANADIANS BICKER OVER NEW EMBASSY IN U.S.
description: Canada is going to build a new embassy in Washington, but the project has become enmeshed in acrimony. The choice of Arthur Erickson of Vancouver as the architect of what is officially described as ''the Canadian Government's prime architectural showpiece abroad'' has created an uproar in architectural and political circles. The reason is that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau ignored the recommendations of a special panel that spent months examining some 300 applications.

title: M.I.T. Chairman to Retire
description: Howard W. Johnson says he plans to retire after 12 years as chairman of the corporation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on June 30, 1983. The 96-member corporation governs the institute. Mr. Johnson, 59 years old, who was M.I.T. president for five years before before becoming corportion chairman, made his announcement Tuesday.

title: A BARN RISES, AUTHENTICALLY, IN TARRYTOWN
description: TARRYTOWN FOLLOWING in the footsteps of his father, a master craftsman descended from some of the earliest settlers of the Hudson Valley, and of the great-grandfather for whom he was named, 18-year-old Clayton Babcock threw the weight of his muscular frame behind the handle of a 250-year-old wooden capstan. Known also as a ''bull wheel,'' the tool has been used for hoisting since the days of ancient Greece. After several turns, a huge wooden beam weighing more than 1,000 pounds began to rise from the ground.

title: Hurdler Wins 2 Events
description: Dean McFarlane had little trouble with the rain today at the New York State Boys and Girls Intersectional Track and Field Championships as he won two hurdles events and helped win a relay.

title: SALVADORAN LEADER DENIES VOTE FRAUD
description: El Salvador's provisional president, Alvaro Magana, said today that he ''definitely'' did not accept charges being made by researchers at the country's largest university that there was fraud in the number of votes reported in the March elections here.

title: Alison Mary Gottlieb Wed
description: Alison Mary Gottlieb and Dr. Jeffrey I. Haber were married yesterday at the Bayside Jewish Center by Rabbi William Orentlicher. The bride is a daughter of Bertram H. Gottlieb of White Plains and the late Helen Broadwin Gottlieb. Dr. Haber, who expects to begin a residency in obstetrics at Jersey City Medical Center in July, is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Haber of Jericho, L.I.

title: 12-1 Time Charter Wins Oaks Stakes at Epsom
description: Billy Newnes rode Time Charter to victory today in the 204th Oaks Stakes for 3-year-old fillies, run over 1 1/2 miles on the turf at Epsom Race Course.

title: Television Week
description: Casting Account When B. Gerald Cantor - an investment banker, art patron and owner of the world's most comprehensive collection of Rodin sculpture - commissioned the casting in bronze of Rodin's ''The Gates of Hell,'' Iris Cantor, his wife, suggested that it ought to be documented. She said, in an interview, that ''he agreed and let me do just that.''

title: Quarantine Against Fruit Fly Lifted in 3 California Counties
description: Satisfied with the success of its campaign against the Mediterranean fruit fly, California has lifted quarantines on fruits and vegetables in three counties.

title: SCHOOL IS THE WRONG PLACE FOR PRAYER
description: CONSIDERABLE discussion is bound to take place in the months ahead regarding President Reagan's proposed Constitutional amendment that would restrict the state and Federal Governments' ability to prohibit prayer in the public schools. My objections to the proposed amendment are threefold: (a) religious (b) instructional and (c) legal.

title: Charles Mitchell Weds Laura Grossen
description: Laura Ann Grossen, an assistant director of finance with the entertainment division of CBS Inc., was married yesterday to Charles MacNeil Mitchell, a litigation partner in the New York Law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan. The Rev. Dr. David H.C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: On Language
description: My Fellow Americanians

title: IF NOTHING ELSE, ARGENTINES HOPE TO WIN LASTING UNITY
description: A bumper sticker recently spotted here proclaimed ''I Love Argentina'' - in letters modest enough to permit space for an accompanying advertisement for a brand of home heater. ''That's the way patriotism always was before,'' said a Buenos Aires businessman. ''It was individualistic with no common identity. Now, with the Malvinas, there is something more than just the self.''

title: Dr. Brian Robert Thomas Weds Nancy Rita Derleth
description: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Nancy Rita Derleth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Derleth of Riverside, Conn., was married to Dr. Brian Robert Thomas, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Thomas of Westwood, Mass. The Rev. Leo J. Gorman performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about a controversy over a conservative publication at Dartmouth College incorrectly characterized the position of Representative Jack F. Kemp. Mr. Kemp, who resigned from the publication's advisory board, later wrote to a member of its staff saying that his resignation did not affect his plan to sponsor the member for a job. E. William Cattan Jr., the editor in chief, says he misunderstood the letter to be a statement of support for the publication.

title: MOMENTUM GAINS ON NUCLEAR-LIMIT RALLY
description: THEY call themselves the World Peace Marchers, and 200 strong they will leave the county this morning on Route 1 through New Rochelle for a rally in Manhattan. But they are only the first to go. By Saturday, an estimated 5,000 people from this county will have joined what some predict will be a half million others in front of the United Nations, calling for an end to the arms race.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Rates Stay Sticky

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ Red Garland has been one of the major names in jazz since he spent two years as the pianist in Miles Davis's quintet from 1956 to 1958, a quintet of literal all-star quality that included John Coltrane on tenor saxophone, Paul Chamberson on bass and Philly Joe Jones on drums. But he has also been one of the most elusive names in jazz because, for 15 years in the 60's and 70's, he stayed at home in Dallas with his family and limited his playing to the Dallas area.

title:
Stamps;
THE 'ROYAL FAMILY' OF THE THEATER
description: Ethel, John and Lionel Barrymore, the ''Royal Family'' of the American theater, are appearing together on a new commemorative being issued by the United States.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE No one has ever accused Merce Cunningham of making dances like anybody else's. This week Mr. Cunningham goes a step further to present dance in an idiosyncratic way. He and his company will perform ''events,'' full-evening pieces made up of excerpts from the repertory sewn seamlessly together and danced to new scores. The composer of choice for performances Tuesday through Thursday will be Ron Kuivila; Richard Lerman takes over Friday through June 13. The ''events'' will be danced at Mr. Cunningham's Westbeth studio, beyond whose windows lies a beautiful nightscape against which dances have sometimes started out in bold, exceptional relief.

title: The Region in Summary; Showdown at The N.J. Budget
description: Budget brinkmanship in Trenton moved a step closer to the edge last week as the Democrat-dominated Assembly refused to pass a gasoline surtax Governor Kean said was needed to keep the state out of the hole. Mr. Kean said that without the gas tax revenue, which has been estimated at $185 million, 5,000 state employees would have to be laid off to balance the 1982-83 budget.

title: Seaver Sheds 'Awful' Month
description: It did not seem appropriate for a New York Mets coach to telephone the Cincinnati Reds clubhouse to congratulate the winning pitcher immediately after the game. So Bud Harrelson, the first-base coach, discreetly waited until nearly everyone was gone, walked through the tunnel beneath Riverfront Stadium to the home team's side and extended his hand to his former roommate.

title: FOLK-POP: JOHN DENVER
description: In the last decade, John Denver has developed from a cheerful folk-pop entertainer into an inspirational public figure whose appeal has almost as much to do with his ministerial presence as with his music. And at his second annual appearance at the Brendan Byrne Arena on Wednesday, Mr. Denver put on a smooth two-hour show that emphasized the contemplative, wistful side of his sensibility.

title: WOMEN'S BAR ASSOCIATION GROWING
description: ''HELLO, Sweetie.'' ''Young lady.'' ''Honey.'' These appellations addressed to lawyers who happen to be women are becoming less frequent these days, in part because of the temper of the times in the 1980's but also because of the efforts of the Westchester Women's Bar Association.

title: DEMANDS ON ANIMAL SHELTERS
description: YONKERS IN April, the Central Westchester Humane Society, which operates animal shelters in the Dunwoodie section of this city and also in Elmsford, sent out a call for help. Both establishments were overcrowded with dogs and cats.

title: ACCORD ON TRADE SEEMS TO BE NEAR AT FRENCH PARLEY
description: The leaders of the major industrial democracies headed today toward an agreement to limit the use of cheap export credits in world trade, but without the sharp restrictions on credits to the Soviet Union that President Reagan has been seeking.

title: U.S. BACKED AT WEST GERMAN RALLIES
description: Tens of thousands of West Germans demonstrated today in favor of close friendship with the United States and peace through the unity of the Western alliance.

title: SOLIDARITY AND MARTIAL LAW BRING CHURCH AND POLAND'S INTELLECTUALS INTO AN ALLIANCE
description: In these days of martial law, when Poles find little to give them cheer, one positive development has been the emergence of an alliance between the Roman Catholic Church and the intelligentsia, according to intellectuals.

title: Letters; Tenant Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Beth Anne Glover Wed To Lt. Kevin Shannon
description: Beth Anne Glover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bryce Glover of Portland, Me., was married there yesterday to Lieut. Kevin M. Shannon, Medical Corps, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew A. Shannon of Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Gerald E. Burt performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: RUBIK'S RIVAL
description: dimensional puzzle.

title: POP-ROCK: A CAJUN FLAVOR
description: Micheal Smotherman and Kasim Sulton, who shared the bill at the Bottom Line Thursday, are raw young pop talents whose music eludes instant categorization. Mr. Smotherman, the more charismatic of the two, comes from Oklahoma, and his lilting style of pop-rock is a captivating mixture of Cajun influences, jug-band music and rockabilly.

title: LOTTERY OF DEATH IS NO ANSWER
description: IF GOVERNOR KEAN keeps his campaign promises, New Jersey again will have capital punishment, this time attended by all sorts of ''safeguards'' to insure that the ultimate penalty is meted out under only the most egregious circumstances.

title: BUDGET-STALLED POLITICIANS FEAR THE VOTERS' WRATH
description: ''As of last Friday, it's Tip's recession,'' said Representative Guy Vander Jagt, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. Not to be outdone for an elemental partisan interpretation of the House's failure to pass a budget resolution, Representative Jim Wright, the majority leader, said, ''The

title: JOY KEEPS FAMILY IN FRESH AIR FUND
description: Welcoming Fresh Air Fund children into their homes had become a family tradition. Her grandparents, Axel and Tyyne Tuomi, had done so. Her aunt Irene Kamila had done so. And so a year after she married, Betsy Hannula and her husband, Edward, did so.

title: EXPLORING THE ENORMOUS OUTPUT OF TELEMANN
description: Has history given Georg Philipp Telemann a fair shake? For most of his 86 years, Telemann maintained a high profile wherever he worked, keeping a hand in everything from sacred music to opera, from ceremonial works to coffee house entertainment. Even the abbreviated works list in the ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'' notes thousands of extant scores, as well as many that were destroyed during World War II. Yet, Telemann's industriousness may have created one of the problems posterity has had with his music - namely, the feeling that anyone who composed so much music must have churned out his works mechanically and without much thought.

title: Paula Short Wed To Dr. Ira J. Fink
description: Paula Short, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roderic Malcolm Short of Anchorage, was married yesterday to Dr. Ira J. Fink, son of Alice Lefton Fink of New York and the late Dr. Seymour Albert Fink. The Rev. Dr. Edwin Lane of the First Unitarian Church in Cambridge, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church of Harvard University in Cambridge.

title: U.S. AIDE SAYS ALLIES CRITICIZE BLACKS IN ARMY
description: Some of the United States' European allies have been quietly putting pressure on the Pentagon to reduce the percentage of blacks in the armed forces and to limit the number of blacks assigned to European bases of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, a top Defense Department official said Friday.

title: KOWTOWING AND THE ELDERLY
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding Mr. Penner's article, Social Security is not a system for redistribution of wealth. It is a pension plan to which working people have been compelled to contribute, comforted only by the promise that, when they grow old, this money - their own money - will be given back to them.

title: AMID CHAOS OF CONSTRUCTION, PITTSBURGH'S FESTIVAL GOES ON
description: Despite a thicket of subway and building construction here, Pittsburgh went ahead with plans for a summer of cultural events that could bring thousands of people into the center city.

title: CRAFTS
description: YOU can learn to weave a melon basket in a day, but it will take six weeks to explore the intricacies of metal castings. Those are among the dozens of craft courses and workshops being offered around the state this summer.

title: PREJUDICES OF A NOVELIST
description: In the small hours of the morning, wooing sleep, I like to imagine impossible marriages of novelists. Louis Auchincloss and Jacqueline Susann.

title: WITHERSPOON DEFEATS SNIPES
description: Two young heavyweight contenders, one who had cut Gerry Cooney in sparring and the other who had knocked down Larry Holmes in a title fight, fought a controversial 10-rounder today. When it was over, the only thing they agreed on was that Holmes should beat Cooney next Friday.

title: BOOKS FOR VACATION READING
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of December 1981. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review. Autobiography & Biography

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: down tales he hears the faith and scientific knowledge that was lost. This short, swiftly paced tale, told in a strange version of English, juxtaposes - in the words of our reviewer Benjamin DeMott - ''preliterate fable and Beckett-ian wit, Boschian monstrosities and a hero with Huck Finn's heart and charm. Haunting, fiercely imagined and intensely ponderable.''

title: The Region in Summary; Slashed Budget Heals Rapidly In Legislature
description: Only a few weeks ago, the New York State Legislature failed to stop Governor Carey from cutting the budget. Last week, Mr. Carey seemed powerless to prevent the Legislature from adding to it again.

title: PREARRAIGNMENT SYSTEM TO BE USED BY MORGENTHAU
description: After resisting the plan for several years, the Manhattan District Attorney has decided to use a procedure designed to reduce the time police officers must spend in Criminal Court waiting for suspects to be arraigned.

title: Headliners; Chinese Heave-ho
description: If her curiosity prompted Lisa Wischer to visit China, it also prompted the Chinese to expell her last week.

title: The Nation in Summary; No Jokes About Dropping In
description: That the United States is in a period of moral decay is a matter of opinion. That its physical plant is decaying is a matter of fact.

title: Cary Tait Collins Wed
description: Cary Tait Collins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Collins of Bethany, Conn., was married yesterday to Wade Peter Gradia, son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Gradia of Bethel, Conn. Justice of the Peace Dorey Sarkady of Bethany performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Collins, in Southbury, Conn.

title: A Correction
description: The president of Harrow's pool stores is Bob Ellentuck, not Donald Fusco, as was stated in last week's story on swimming pool sales on Long Island. Mr. Fusco is president of Care-Free Swimming Pools.

title: THE END OF AN ERA
description: After a quarter century as South Africa's most powerful corporate figure, Harry F. Oppenheimer (right), said he was stepping down, at age 73, as chairman of the Anglo American Corporation, the huge producer of gold, diamonds and other minerals. But he said hard times require his staying on as chairman of DeBeers Consolidated Mines, which runs the cartel controlling 80 percent of the world's diamonds. In 1957, he succeeded his father, Sir Ernest Oppenheimer, founder of the mining empire; now his son, Nicholas, 36, will become one of two deputy chairmen. Mr. Oppenheimer recommended that Gavin Relly, 56, a key aide and once a Rhodes Scholar, become chairman.

title: IT COMES DOWN TO OLD-FASHIONED SLOGGING
description: The Falkland Islands campaign opened with a display of esoteric missiles that might almost have been borrowed from ''Star Wars.'' But last week, the emphasis shifted to marching infantry and field guns, an atmosphere more familiar to readers of Stephen Crane's American civil war novel, ''The Red Badge of Courage.''

title: DRUG TREATMENT UNIT OFFSETS CUTS ON ITS OWN
description: Many agencies financed by New York State are facing an 8 percent budget cut July 1 and are not able to cover the deficit. One New York City drug rehabilitation center, however, has decided to take the offensive.

title: Kissinger and Gibbon
description: In Russell Baker's article ''Getting on With It'' (Sunday Observer, May 2), he notes that Edward Gibbon required 1,170 pages for his ''Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire,'' whereas Henry Kissinger required 1,283 pages for one volume of his memoirs which covered 0.15 percent of the period of time Gibbon covered. But, of course! Henry Kissinger was writing about Henry Kissinger. JAMES B. KELLY, San Diego

title: COLLAPSE OF OUR INDUSTRIAL HEARTLAND
description: William Serrin is a reporter for The New York Times. Richard Palmer was piloting the Jay D., a ferry that shuttles back and forth across the quarter-mile-wide Ohio River between Dilles Bottom, Ohio, and Moundsville, W. Va. In many ways, it is a lovely, restful spot, one of the world's great waterfowl flyways; in the spring and fall great, beating flocks of ducks and geese go by. It is also the route of choice for hundreds of barges loaded down with coal and steel and chemicals. ''Almost anything people make,'' Palmer said, ''it comes by here.''

title: Dodging Around On Ebbets Field
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Program Presents Environmental Awards
description: The United Nations Environmental Program has presented medals to a group of American citizens and institutions in recognition of their leadership over the past decade in efforts to clean up the environment.

title: Censorship by Israelis On Fighting Tightens
description: Israeli military censorship was extended today to accounts issued by the United Nations on the fighting in southern Lebanon.

title: Dawn Radley Wed to Richard Dana Jr.
description: Dawn Elizabeth Radley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Otis Radley of Cape Vincent, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Richard Henry Dana Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dana of New York and Washington, Conn. The Rev. Paul Whitmore performed the ceremony in St. Vincent de Paul Roman Catholic Church.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: OFFICIALS of the state's Department of Environmental Protection and local health departments are investigating the source of a dumping incident near Lindenwold, in Camden County, that killed fish and led to the closing of Laurel Lake to swimming and fishing for the summer.

title: Elizabeth D. Root Is Bride of Hugh G. Moulton Jr.
description: Elizabeth Downey Root, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Prince Root of New Canaan, Conn., and North Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday to Hugh Geoffrey Moulton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moulton of Fort Washington, Pa., and Chatham, Mass.

title:
ART;
HENRY MOORE: SCULPTURE
description: GREENWICH A BEAUTIFUL and very interesting exhibition called ''Henry Moore: Perspectives on Form'' will be on view at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through July 3.

title: ANTINUCLEAR RALLY UNITES L.I. GROUPS
description: THE statistics spilled out of Saul Friedberg as easily as the ABC's tumble out of a child. ''We will be spending $258 billion on defense in fiscal 1983. That is $1,100 for every person in the United States, including the infant that was born a minute ago.

title: MAILER WRITING
description: PIECES AND PONTIFICATIONS By Norman Mailer. 448 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $20.

title: POPULAR VIRGINIA DEMOCRAT NOMINATED FOR SENATE
description: Virginia Democrats today nominated the party's front-runner in last year's gubernatorial election as their candidate for the United States Senate seat now held by Harry F. Byrd Jr.

title: STYLISH DARIEN SPOT REVISITED
description: DARIEN CONFLICTING reports from readers over the last months prompted a series of return visits to Hienkel's, the stylish restaurant on the Post Road in Darien. Hienkel's is obviously prospering. A new, small dining room has been added beyond the long, handsome bar (with live jazz most evenings). A semi-round room, with heavily textured, coir wall covering and fine wood trim, it shows the same taste and use of high-quality materials as the main dining room, though the style of the new room is more intimate and less formal.

title: Helping Nature Take Its Course Design/Gardening By Ken Druse
description: A new style of landscape design advocates equality in the garden. Many homeowners are discovering that in partnership with nature they can create handsome plantings that rely on the environment for maintenance and support.

title: LIBERALS STUCK IN AN ANTI-DEFICIT TRAP
description: To the Editor:

title: SCRAP METAL LAMENT
description: As reports on sales of single family homes and new orders attest, the recession was still very much around in April. And recent trends in scrap metal prices, used by some analysts as a harbinger of economic activity, suggest the downturn was continuing in May and early June.

title: HIGH COURT VERSION OF THE NEW FEDERALISM?
description: While Congress debates new limits on Federal court jurisdiction, the United States Supreme Court this term is taking its own approach toward circumscribing the power of the lower Federal courts. The Court's focus has been not jurisdiction, but access: Who may bring a Federal case in the first place.

title: LIMITS DISCUSSED ON BILLS AND DEBATE
description: DURING one lengthy debate in the State Senate in April, Richard F. Schneller, Democrat of Essex and the Senate majority leader, rose to denounce an amendment some Senators wanted attached to a bill. ''More and more in this chamber,'' he said, ''we are attempting to legislate by amendment. The trend is very pronounced this year and it disturbs me.''

title: Guggenheim Awards To American and Italian
description: The first annual Peggy Guggenheim Award will be presented Wednesday in Venice to the composers Mario Davidovsky of the United States and Ruggero Lagana of Italy.

title: BALLET: PHULLIS LAMHUT
description: Every so often a dance comes along that seems a matter of life and death, so strongly and inevitably is it chiseled from bodies and open space. Phyllis Lamhut's ''Passing'' is such a dance. And its revival by Miss Lamhut's company Thursday at the Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, where it will be performed through today, testified that none of its power had dimmed in the two years since it was made.

title: BAD TIMES ARE WORSE IN POMFRET
description: The stoic Yankees of this little town are accustomed to adversity. Their moods have grown coarse over the decades contending with nasty winters, rocky soil and the Boston Red Sox, their self-destructive heroes. So what surprised the 2,775 residents was not so much that Washington had put Pomfret on its list of ''severe unemployment areas,'' but that a problem they had long ago accepted as chronic should suddenly be singled out.

title: Craig Wolfe Branigan Marries Nancy Smith
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in San Francisco yesterday, Nancy Ewing Smith, daughter of Elisabeth Becker Smith of Wellesley Hills, Mass., and the late Dickson Smith, was married to Craig Wolfe Branigan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Duane A. Branigan of Champaign, Ill. The Rev. Richard Fowler performed the ceremony.

title: 3 DEMOCRATS SEEK SURROGATE'S POST
description: At least three candidates - two who were judged ''highly qualified'' by a Democratic party panel and one the panel rejected - plan to run for Surrogate of Manhattan.

title: Around the Nation; Federal Judge Excuses Himself in Shooting Case
description: Because of a possible conflict of interest, a Federal judge has refused to try Joseph Paul Franklin on charges that he shot and injured Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the civilrights leader.

title: 'INTERVENTION' AND ALCOHOLISM
description: MANY in our society have the misconception that alcoholics have to recognize their illness and ask for help - generally when they ''hit bottom'' - before they can be treated. Nothing could be further from the truth. Historically, as with other fatal diseases before the advancement of modern medicine, there was no ''treatment''; and even long after Alcoholics Anonymous was founded and treatment centers were established, the problem of convincing alcoholics to accept the help available remained. Today, there is a highly successful method for overcoming this problem of getting through to alcoholics. This method is called intervention and is being adopted by many employers and concerned people.

title: Linda F. Comenitz To Be Wed Aug. 1
description: Linda Faye Comenitz, a psychiatric social worker at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, and Dr. Steven Edward Gelda, a psychiatric resident at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, plan to be married Aug. 1.

title: LUMET: THE CITY IS HIS SOUND STAGE
description: John Lombardi is a freelance writer. You don't say ''film'' on a Sidney Lumet set - you say ''movie.'' And in his sparse 56th Street work loft, behind Carnegie Hall, you don't say ''auteur,'' ''vision'' or ''ambient'' either. There is nothing highbrow about the dean of New York directors, as is shown in his best-known work: ''Prince of the City,'' ''Dog Day Afternoon,'' ''Network'' and ''Serpico.'' As Lumet doesn't mind explaining: ''I'm constantly being asked, 'What's the overall theme in your work?' - that kind of stuff. I'm not an intellectual, and if there is a theme, I don't want to know about it. To me, the death of a great many awfully good creative people has been pretension. They start believing what the 'serious' critics say about them. It's as if when the flag of protest - which is what a lot of us start with - is ripped out of their hands, they're afraid to delve further into themselves. So they take someone else's definition and start trying to fit into that.''

title: NEW VETERINARY HOSPITAL NEAR BOSTON FILLING A VOID IN TEACHING AND ANIMAL CARE
description: The patients are brought in through the sterile induction room, where they are given an anesthetic and scrubbed clean. Then they are placed gently in a sling attached to an overhead monorail, carried into the operating room and placed on the operating table, already asleep.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA WINS FRENCH TITLE
description: Martina Navratilova, who had been considered vulnerable on clay, won the biggest clay-court title in tennis for the first time by defeating Andrea Jaeger today in the final of the French Open, 7-6, 6-1.

title: David H. Cowin Weds Stephanie Jill Landau
description: The marriage of Stephanie Jill Landau to Lieut. David Hale Cowin, Dental Corps, U.S.N., took place yesterday at the Tappan Hill, a restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y. Town Court Judge Lawrence D. Lenihan of New Castle, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: FLAW FOUND IN SUBWAY PARTS BROUGHT TO FIX ORIGINAL DEFECT
description: Minor flaws have been discovered in hundreds of undercarriages built to replace defective parts of a problem-plagued fleet of city subway cars, but the effect on service will not be known until experts study the defects this week, Transit Authority officials said yesterday.

title: Texas Tops Okla. State On a Five-Hitter, 9-1
description: Tracy Dophied drove in three runs and Roger Clemens pitched a five-hitter as No.1-ranked Texas stopped Oklahoma State, 9-1, in a College World Series first-round baseball game today.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Toehold Found in Primate History
description: A handful of scientists believe the grasping toe may be mightier than the grinding tooth in explaining why primates such as monkeys, apes and humans developed as they did. The problem is that teeth are more durable than toe bones, so there has been little fossil evidence of the big toe's evolutionary importance.

title: ON FOOD AND LIFE AND HERSELF
description: In a properly run culture, Mary Frances Kennedy Fisher would be recognized as one of the great writers this country has produced in this century. A few acute readers have understood this. Nearly 20 years ago, W.H. Auden said: ''I do not know of anyone in the United States today who writes better prose.'' Perhaps ''As They Were,'' her new anthology, consisting of well-chosen work spanning the past five decades, will take the gastronomic curse off Mrs. Fisher and convince a world quite ready to acclaim her as the doyenne of food writers that she deserves much higher literary status. ''As They Were'' certainly provides the proper occasion to look again at all her books and to think about M.F.K. Fisher's peculiar eminence.

title: ALL IN THE FAMILY ON THE RENTAL FRONT
description: LOOKING for a good tax shelter? Consider buying a small condominium a s living quarters for your college sophomore instead of sinking m oney into housing fees or off-campus rent. Or, look into purchasing a bungalow in a Florida retirement community for your elderly p arents.

title: ABOVE THE DIN, A FLUTE SOUNDS
description: WHEN I was young, I wanted to be a college professor. I wanted to write esoteric books illuminating passages from the Greek classics and I wanted to argue passionately about the influences on Euripides.

title: When Tenants Divorce
description: Question: Can my landlord refuse to accept my check, force me to sign a new lease and increase the rent because I just got divorced and the lease was under my ex-husband's name only? I have been paying the rent with my personal checks since we separated a year ago and the landlord has been accepting them. However, he has just learned of my divorce and has refused to accept my rent check. ... I.M., Manhattan Answer: The New York City Conciliation and Appeals Board says most leases explicitly state - and where they do not, there is an implicit, legally recognized assumption - that an apartment, whether rent-controlled or rent-stabilized, can be occupied by the person named in the lease and his immediate family. The board has ruled in several cases that a divorced, separated, or surviving spouse of the named tenant has the right to remain and to be offered renewal leases.

title: Lucy Ogden Lee Married to William Orin LaCasse
description: Lucy Ogden Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Carroll Lee Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., and Prouts Neck, Me., was married at the Spurwink Meeting House in Cape Elizabeth, Me., yesterday to William Orin LaCasse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph LaCasse of Skowhegan, Me. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stephen W. Foote of the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in Falmouth, Me., assisted by the Rev. Bert Poussard, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Antiques View; 19TH-CENTURY REVIVAL FINDS NEW FAVOR
description: The 19th-century revival styles - rococo, Louis XV and Louis XVI, Renaissance, Gothic, Egyptian and Elizabethan - have been increasingly in the spotlight in recent seasons. Museum and gallery exhibitions have enlarged our understanding of these Victorian reinterpretations of earlier periods, and the amount of scholarship in books and catalogues is astounding. Two shows of 19th-century revivals held simultaneously from March through May of last year at Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, certainly bolstered both the understanding and the popularity of these styles.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Brick Sidewalk Stolen And Sold, Police Say
description: Residents of the Bergen-Lanning neighborhood here thought that the workmen ripping up the brick sidewalks in front of their homes were doing them a favor.

title: THEATER TO THE NINES
description: IN the contemporary musical theater, the director is the star. Jerome Robbins established the tradition, the late Gower Champion followed, and Harold Prince, Bob Fosse and Michael Bennett have perpetuated it. Their shows bear the identifiable imprint of innovation. They have changed the shape of musicals.

title: TWENTY SIDEWALK FAVORITES
description: If you know how to nurse a beer or coffee for hours, cafe-sitting can be one of the city's best buys. No matter how crowded a cafe may be, waiters will respect your graceful loafing and won't insist that you order another round just to hold the table.

title: G.L. Phillips Weds Alice Golembiewski
description: Alice Hughes Golembiewski, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Robert T. Golembiewski of Athens, Ga., was married there yesterday to Greer Laurence Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil F. Phillips of Montreal and Montpelier Station, Va. The ceremony was performed at the University of Georgia Catholic Center Chapel by the Rev. Jonathan Haschka and the Rev. Joseph Hollohan.

title: CRIME AND PUNISHMENT?
description: THE KILLING OF BONNIE GARLAND A Question of Justice. By Willard Gaylin, M.D. Illustrated. 366 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.50. THE YALE MURDER By Peter Meyer. 302 pp. New York: Empire Books. $12.95.

title: ANSWERS TO QUERIES ON TIDAL PROPERTY
description: TRENTON WHEN the Tidelands Resource Council and the state's Department of Environmental Protection announced last month that New Jersey was laying claim to privately held coastal property from the New York line to Cape May, they notified the press but not the property holders.

title: FASTEST CRAFT AFLOAT MADE MORE STABLE
description: The conditions were perfect. The lagoon was as smooth as a sheet of glass and there wasn't a whisper of wind. In the third heat of the world championships last fall, Bill Muncey, driving the thunderbolt Atlas Van Lines, shot into the lead. But while accelerating down the backstretch, his boat rose into the air, flipped and landed upside down, killing the man who had dominated the sport for 20 years.

title: Faculty Pay Rise Reported
description: The average college faculty member was paid $24,843 for the current academic year, a 9.2 percent rise over last year, the Government reported Thursday. The National Center for Education Statistics also found that the pay disparity between male and female educators has persisted. ''Women were paid 18.5 percent less than men - $21,337 on the average compared to $26,172,'' said a report by the agency, a part of the Department of Education.

title: IRAQI AIR RAID KILLS 40 IN PROVINCIAL CAPITAL, IRAN SAYS
description: Iraqi planes today attacked the city of Ilam, the capital of the province of the same name in western Iran, killing at least 40 people and wounding about 200 more, the Iranian Government announced.

title: Barbara Ann Fagan Married
description: Barbara Ann Fagan, daughter of Dr. Edward Thomas Fagan of Hempstead, L.I., and the late Barbara Gilman Fagan, was married yesterday to Roman Michael Brygider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roman Brygider of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. William F. Costello performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The bride's father is professor of law and former associate dean of St. John's University School of Law.

title: Gallery View; IMAGERY FROM THE JEWISH CONSCIOUSNESS
description: Who'd have thought that the small, Minimal-looking floor pieces of forged iron by Alain Kirili, already familiar to us from several exhibitions around town, are really derived from decorative mountings for the Torah, the sacred scroll of Jewish ritual? Or that Alain Gavin's loving renditions of rumpled but sumptuous fabrics relate to instructions given by the Lord to Moses? And that Ernest Shaw's series of abstract, free-standing steel plates with torn edges were inspired by the Biblical epic of the walls of Jericho?

title: Around the World; 95 Killed as a Storm Strikes Coast of India
description: A severe storm that hit the southeast coastal state of Orissa two days ago killed 95 people and wrecked thousands of mud homes, reports said today.

title: MAGAZINE'S GRASP OF GOVERNMENT GIVES IT CLOUT
description: WASHINGTON LAST October the editors of the National Journal, the weekly gazeteer of Government terrain, made a small adjustment in the magazine's printing schedule. They moved the deadline forward by two hours, got the publication on the street by Friday morning and engaged an ancient technology, the human foot, to insure that 2,000 copies reached Washington offices on Friday rather than on Monday.

title: STOCK MARKET DOLDRUMS
description: Equity investors had little reason to cheer last quarter, as tumbling corporate profits and the continuing impasse over the budget kept stock prices down. With only one or two exceptions, however, things were even worse on stock exchanges elsewhere in the world.

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'Count of Monte Cristo' Once or twice a year, with little fanfare and an obscure schedule slot, ''The Count of Monte Cristo'' (1934) sails into view on the home screen. Here it is again, at family viewing time - Sunday at 1 P.M. on NBC - and hallelujah! They simply don't bother making them like this anymore: a sweeping, full-rigged adventure with a fine cast, a lavish production, a tingling, old-fashioned plot, via Alexander Dumas, with a beginning, middle and end.

title: VIRGINIA SLADE FLINT
description: Virginia Slade Flint, a longtime teacher of English and Spanish at the Academy of Languages in Manhattan and a retired teacher of fashion and merchandising at Macy's Herald Square, died Friday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J., after suffering a stroke at her home. She was 79 years old and lived in Bloomfield, N.J.

title: STEVIE WONDER TAKES A LONG LOOK BACK
description: Stevie Wonder is a pop star of the brightest magnitude. His singing style has been so influential for the past decade or so that several artists, among them the jazz guitarist and pop crooner George Benson, have achieved spectacular commercial breakthroughs by copying it blatantly, while many others have altered their phrasing or timbre so that it reflects a bit of Mr. Wonder's special glow. Several of his harmonically sophisticated, jazz-influenced pop ballads, ''Ma Cherie Amour'' and ''You Are the Sunshine of my Life'' for example, have become instant standards, performed by pop singers of almost every conceivable stripe, but he has also written rock songs, dance floor funk, angrily explicit protest songs, and many other songs that are more difficult to categorize.

title: Art View; IS EAKINS OUR GREATEST PAINTER?
description: PHILADELPHIA There never was an American painter like Thomas Eakins, who was born in 1844, died in 1916, and is the subject of a great exhibition that has just opened at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. It is not simply that in his hands painting became an exact science, so that if he paints two men rowing on a river we can tell the month, the day and the hour that they passed under a certain bridge. We admire Eakins for that, but we prize him above all for the new dimension of moral awareness that he brought to American painting.

title: ON THE EVE OF U.N. SESSION, SOME ANTINUCLEAR INITIATIVES
description: BEFORE the upcoming United Nations special session on disarmament bogs down in a propaganda contest between East and West and North and South, a group of statesmen representing all camps last week issued its own ideas for reducing the threat of nuclear war. The key proposal of the Independent Commission on Disarmament and Security Issues was to eliminate so-called tactical nuclear weapons from Central Europe by the end of 1983.

title: Sports People; Iarusci's Solo
description: Bob Iarusci of the Cosmos has played in three championship games in the North American Soccer League, and he has been a defensive mainstay of the Canadian national team for six years. But he says that when he steps onto the turf at Giants Stadium today, before the Cosmos play the Toronto Blizzard, he's going to feel more nervous than he did for any Soccer Bowl.

title: Beautification Starts For Holland Tunnel
description: Scores of blue and green banners were installed yesterday on light poles along approaches to the Holland Tunnel in New Jersey, marking the first phase of a multimillion-dollar project by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey aimed at turning tunnel portals into park-like settings.

title: PINCAY ALMOST LEFT HIS BIG OPPORTUNITY AT THE GATE
description: From his bed in Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I., Eddie Maple looked into the television camera and delivered a message to the jockey who had replaced him aboard Conquistador Cielo in yesterday's Belmont Stakes:

title: GIVING IS NO PICNIC IN GUATEMALA
description: The new military Government of Guatemala is causing an unusual kind of headache for Washington. The United States Agency for International Development and other American agencies ''are scrambling to find money for them,'' an official said, ''but these guys are saying they don't want it.'' The Reagan Administration wants to send helicopters, $2.5 million in military equipment, $300,000 for military training and at least $50 million to assist Guatemala's crippled economy.

title: MAILER TALKING
description: ''There was that law of life,'' Norman Mailer wrote in ''The Deer Park,'' ''so cruel and so just which demanded that one must grow or else pay more for remaining the same.'' Clearly it is a sentiment taken to heart by the author himself. Now 59, Mr. Mailer has fashioned a career in which he has continually reinvented a style and a self, using his own personality as a kind of index to discover how the world has changed. The polite young Brooklyn-born, Harvardeducated author of ''The Naked and the Dead'' evolved, through the 50's and hectic 60's, into the blustering protagonist of ''The Armies of the Night'' - ''warrior, presumptive general, champion of obscenity, embattled aging enfant terrible of the literary world'' - and surfaced again in the less flamboyant 70's as a ''modest and half-invisible Aquarius.'' Indeed, the self-portrait that emerges in Mr. Mailer's new collection of short work and interviews from the 60's and 70's, ''Pieces and Pontifications,'' is that of a writer who has traded his egocentric concerns of the past for a new objectivity, his prodigality of emotion and rhetoric for more modest satisfactions.

title:
ART;
34 PRINTS THAT ADD UP TO A REFRESHING, INTERESTING SHOW
description: RIVERHEAD THE first annual juried exhibition of prints, now on view at the East End Arts Center, is refreshing in its inclusion of work by quite a few young and less well known printmakers. Although the selection is small - only 34 works - it features a broad spectrum of media and some interesting examples of technical experimentation.

title: HAIG'S PALESTINE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s first major pronouncement on the Palestine problem, on May 27 before the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations, came as a heavy blow to moderate observers of the Middle East scene. No one can quarrel with the ''just, comprehensive, durable'' peace that Mr. Haig says he seeks, but neither his route nor tactics will take us to his destination. And the glimpses one catches between his lines do not point to his declared objective.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; New Findings On Toxic Shock
description: The National Academy of Sciences released last week the first comprehensive report on toxic shock syndrome, a rare disease usually associated with the use of tampons. Researchers remain unsure about what causes the sometimes fatal affliction, but were able to list several risk factors and recommendations: Women age 15 to 24 are more susceptible than older women; women who are postpartum should not use tampons at all; most women should especially not use high-absorbency brands.

title: ALLIES' DISSENSION OVER U.N. VOTE DISMAYS BRITAIN
description: A diplomatic uproar developed today over the decision of the United States, Japan and France to break with Britain over a proposed United Nations resolution that would have called for a cease-fire in the Falkland Islands. The situation left Britain dismayed by the breach, but trying to play down any long-term effect.

title:
DINING OUT;
VARIETY OF CUISINES IN PLEASANTVILLE
description: NO secret to the crowd of diners who on weekends vie for one of the 12 tables in its dining room, The Saute Cafe is an emporium of cuisines, a small jewel of a restaurant with most of the sparkle where it should be, in the kitchen. Charles Yacovelli, the ambitious chef (Beverly Kaplan, the co-owner, manages), has over the last twoand-a-half years patiently refined his craft to a level of a skilled and creative technician working with as many bloomingly fresh ingredients as the day's market can provide.
