In lesser restaurants, salt seasons all; here fresh herbs prevail.

title: IN MOROCCO A BERBER FACE HIDES BENEATH AN ARAB MASK
description: Arabs came to North Africa in the seventh century. But since the dawn of history, there have been Berbers in this part of the world that the Arabs call the Maghreb. When the Arabs invaded, the mountain fastnesses of Morocco inhibited intermingling of the two peoples, and although the Berbers were eventually converted to Islam, their ethnic and linguistic purity has been preserved until today.

title: Crime Update; PSYCHIATRIST STUDIES NOTE SENT BY KILLER
description: A parcel containing a cookbook arrived in the mail at the home of Howard and Joan Kipp in Brooklyn's Bay Ridge section on May 7. The parcel was addressed to Mrs. Kipp, and when she opened it that afternoon an elaborate device hidden in the hollowed-out book fired two .22-caliber bullets into her chest. A third slug, apparently intended to strike Mrs. Kipp if she opened the parcel the opposite way, hit a kitchen wall.

title: Eric Edmondson, Miss Lively Wed
description: Jennifer Elizabeth Lively, daughter of Michael Lively of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. James King of Munich, West Germany, was married yesterday to Eric Winston Edmondson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Edmondson of La Canada, Calif. The interdenominational ceremony was performed in the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich by the Rev. Dr. Richard Thornburg, assisted by the Rev. John Olofson.

title: Margot Bramble Is Married to Dr. T.S. Dermody
description: Margot Elizabeth Bramble, manager of sales at the Drake Swissotel in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Terence Shawn Dermody, a resident in internal medicine at the Presbyterian Hospital in New York. The Rev. David Mura of Rochester performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Sage Chapel of Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: HUGHES OPPOSING POSTAL TRANSFER
description: WASHINGTON THE decision of the United States Postal Service to sort Atlantic City's mail in Bellmawr, starting July 10, is ''firm and we're not going to change it at this point,'' Thomas Comick, legislative liaison for the Postal Service, said last week.

title: Index; International
description: Salvador's provisional president discounts vote-fraud charges 3 Philippines to hold elections tomorrow in rebel region 4 Around the World 5 U.N. asks prompt Mideast cease- fire 7 Argentina temporarily closes a news agency and newspaper 14 Britain mapping long-term plans for development of Falklands 14 Mitterrand urges planning for changes caused by technology 16 Finance Ministers plan to try to align national policies 16 Tens of thousands of West Ger- mans rally in support of U.S. 18 Government/Politics Attorney General Morgenthau to try prearraignment procedure 32 State Power Authority plans to build 180-mile-long power line 32 General Around the Nation 22 Study says union movement is ra- cially discriminatory 28 The Port Authority begins beauti- fication program 32 Health/Science U.S.-Soviet cooperation in space is virtually ended 19 City begins free health-care pro- gram in public schools 38 Education/Welfare Saudi donation to Harvard stirs academic controversy 29 Arts/Entertainment ''A Distant Cry From Spring,'' Japanese film, shown 58 Roy DeCarava discusses his life as a photographer 60 John Denver continues his pop musical ministry 61 David Bradshaw and Cosmo Buono in piano recital 61 Style Spending 50 years with preschool- ers 64 A cape caper 64 Obituaries Jack N. Bartfield, rare-book dealer and art collector 36 News Analysis Drew Middleton on reports of new weapons for Argentina 12

title: LIBERALS' LEADERS SUPPORTING CUOMO
description: The Liberal Party policy committee - the party's leaders - yesterday endorsed Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for Governor and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan for re-election, virtually assuring both of a position on the ballot in November regardless of any Democratic primary contest.

title: IS THE UNITED STATES FALLING INTO SCIENTIFIC ILLITERACY?
description: MOST of you know of my strong feelings for a greater buildup in our national defense capability to meet the ever increasing Soviet global military threat.

title: CHIEF URGING TRIBE TO RETURN TO LAND
description: KENT A NAGGING fear that the mountain above it would some day topple over prompted William Coggswell to ask, many years ago, that he not be interred in the slight, grassy incline that is the Schaghticoke Indian burial grounds in Kent. His granddaughter, Trudie Ray Lamb, is less superstitious. She plans to build a home on that mountainside this summer.

title: ElizaBeth Cronk Married
description: ElizaBeth Ann Cronk and Richard Carl Pepperman were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Thomas D. Bowers. The bride, a registered representative of Merrill Lynch Inc., is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Frederick Cronk of Bel Air, Md. Mr. Pepperman, director of ''The Edge of Night,'' the long-running ABC-TV show, is a son of Dorothea M. Pepperman of Greenville, Del., and the late Maurice Leon Pepperman. The bride was previously married and divorced, as was her husband.

title: By Theodore W. Libbey Jr.; Music: Debuts in Review; Marilyn Engle, Pianist, Stresses Central Europe
description: Central European goulash, made from assorted cuts of the Austro-Germanic repertory, simmered over low heat and seasoned before and after in the Hungarian manner with pianistic curios by Bartok and Liszt, was the fare Tuesday night at Marilyn Engle's New York debut recital in Alice Tully Hall. The first half of the program, which went down rather drily, linked Bartok's Three Burlesques (Op. 8c) to Busoni's piano transcriptions of Bach's chorale preludes ''Wachet auf, ruft uns die Stimme'' and ''Komm, Gott, Schopfer'' and Beethoven's Sonata in E-flat (Op. 7).

title: TV View; BENEATH THE TIRED SURFACE RUNS A THREAD OF REALITY
description: Contrary to widespread impressions in this country, British television is not, pound for pound, vastly superior to the American product. The British highs, such as a ''Brideshead Revisited,'' are indeed splendid and seemingly beyond the artistic or economic grasp of United States producers, but the average British situation comedy or game show is no slouch when it comes to familiar idiocies. Beginning tonight at 10, for instance, WNET/13 will be offering still another British import in the form of 20 weekly episodes of a BBC situation comedy called ''Butterflies.''

title: DIGGING FOR BOUNTY IN ROSLYN
description: ROSLYN MOTORISTS on Roslyn Road here have been causing minor traffic jams at the intersection of East Broadway. They moved slowly when the signal turned green, as they continued to observe a group of young people working on the grounds of a small house nestled at the foot of the hill at the south end of the historic area of old Roslyn Village. ''What are you doing?'' they have called out to the blue-jeaned, sweatband-wearing crew.

title: HAVANA MEETING ASSAILS BRITAIN ON FALKLANDS
description: A conference of third world nations today deplored British efforts to recover control over the Falkland Islands and demanded an immediate end to United States military support for Britain.

title: U.N. COUNCIL CALLS FOR CEASE-FIRE IN LEBANON
description: The United Nations Security Council, meeting in an urgent bid to halt the fighting in Lebanon, held an emergency meeting today and unanimously called for a cease-fire.

title: FICTION
description: 1 4 4 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) During a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past. 2 1 12 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 3 2 6 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 4 3 18 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 5 5 7 CELEBRITY, by Thomas Thompson. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A crime committed in their boyhood comes back to haunt three young men. 6 7 8 TWICE SHY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Greed at work in the world of horse racing and computer programming. 7 6 8 THY BROTHER'S WIFE, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Geis, $14.95.) Two brothers, a priest and a senator, each in his own way, love the same woman.

title: Lisa Brooks Myers Is Bride
description: Lisa Brooks Myers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Myers of Madison, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Gregory Smets, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Smets of Hillsdale, N.J. The Rev. Fayette Severence of the United Methodist Church performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Annisquam (Mass.) Village Church.

title: A NATION OF READERS?
description: If we can become a nation of readers, we will find refuge from the narrowing biases of our time. First, the bias of presentism. Modern communications, from the telegraph and telephone to television, have increased the emphasis of our daily experience on the recent and present - on news scoops and newsbreaks, on the latest words and images. Most of what we learn from day to day is certified by its immediacy. We learn more and more before it can be put into print, and even before anyone has reflected on whether it is worth knowing. By the time it reaches print, it is often obsolete or obviously false.

title: Federal Funds And Summer Jobs
description: In the recent article ''Summer Jobs Lag as U.S. Cuts Funds,'' nowhere is there an explanation of why each summer job that may pay the holder $1,200 to $1,500 takes between $3,000 and $4,000 of Federal money. Into whose pockets does the difference go? JAMES M. JENKS Garden City

title: MUSTO REFLECTS ON HIS CAREER
description: UNION CITY THE door to the Mayor's office stands open, the way it always has, and visitors poke their heads in to say hello. Some walk right in to greet or plant a kiss on the cheek of the man at the desk.

title: Topics Whoops Love on the Wing
description: Thisbe, Marie Antoinette's spaniel, committed suicide after her death. Caesar, his terrier, marched in Edward VII's funeral procession. But there is little in life or literature that tells of the love of man and bird.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BRASILIA
description: WARREN HOGE is the Rio de Janeiro bureau chief of The Times. BY WARREN HOGE

title: 44 MILLION FOR MEDICAL CAREERS
description: To help students from minority groups qualify for medical careers, the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation has begun a $4 million program to provide education for hundreds of promising teen-agers in New York City and rural areas of Alabama. About 1,000 students will be enrolled in the next four years.

title: MORE SPLENDOR THAN COMFORT
description: AS they gathered for their eighth annual economic meeting this weekend, the leaders of the major industrial democracies could perhaps be forgiven if the sumptuousness of the setting - Louis XIV's Palace of Versailles - made them momentarily forget that the world was facing its most serious economic crisis since the Depression. President Francois Mitterrand, proving that socialism, at least the French variety, need not be drab, welcomed the leaders of the United States, Britain, West Germany, Canada, Japan and Italy as they arrived by limousine at the rose-pink columned Grand Trianon Palace.

title: The Region in Summary; City's Pain Increases
description: Though New York City could gain about $100 million as a result of the actions in Albany, another $419 million in state aid and tax revenue remained uncertain last week, prompting Mayor Koch to impose a hiring freeze. Mr. Koch also asked aides to prepare a list of service cuts ''and other sacrifices'' that might be needed to balance his $15.5 billion budget for the 1982-83 fiscal year.

title: THE HENLEY ROYAL: REALLY TOP-DRAWER
description: CHRISTOPHER DODD is the author of ''Henley Royal Regatta,'' published by Stanley Paul, London, and available from the United States Rowing Association, Philadelphia, in July.

title: REPAIR CLAPBOARD SPLITS QUICKLY AND CORRECTLY
description: WHEN a length of exterior clapboard siding splits or cracks - either because one of the boards has badly warped or because it has been damaged in an accident - it is best to repair the crack as soon as possible. Otherwise the opening will allow water (and possibly insects) to enter. This in turn can lead to peeling of the outside paint (when the wood behind the paint gets soaked) as well as possible rotting of the siding and other structural members inside the wall.

title: COSMOS TOP BLIZZARD, 2-1, ON HUNT'S GOAL
description: It was a game of close calls today at Giants Stadium, and the Cosmos benefitted from most of them, pulling out a 2-1 victory over the Toronto Blizzard in a cold, driving rainstorm.

title: BANQUET, MASQUE, FIREWORKS
description: President and Mrs. Reagan dined in the fabled Hall of Mirrors at the Palace of Versailles tonight, watched a 45-minute musical masque in the 210-year-old palace opera house and witnessed a fireworks display in the gardens of the Grand Trianon, the Louis XIV chateau now used as an official residence for visiting heads of government.

title: DR. HARRINGTON IS RETIRING AS PASTOR
description: For the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington, the apostle of liberalism in both politics and religion, it was ''a goodbye of sorts but also a rebirth of sorts.'' After 46 years of ministry, 38 of them as senior pastor of the Community Church of New York, he was turning the pulpit over to his successor, the Rev. Bruce Southworth.

title: Georgette Bennett Bride of Rabbi Marc Tanenbaum
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue yesterday Dr. Georgette Francesca Bennett, a senior research associate at the Center for Policy Research and principal of Bennett Associates, consultants to the insurance industry, was married to Rabbi Marc Herman Tanenbaum, national interreligious director of the American Jewish committee. Rabbi Judah Nadich, assisted by Rabbis Israel Mowshowitz and James Rudin, performed the ceremony.

title: SALVADOR LAND REDISTRIBUTION PLANS HAVE BEEN SHELVED, DUARTE ASSERTS
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte, the former Salvadoran junta President who was replaced after the March elections, has sharply criticized the new Government's handling of the country's land redistribution program.

title: HOUSES FLOODED, CARS TOSSED ABOUT
description: ''It was like an extension of the river,'' said Peter Pepe Jr., as he stood on his front porch in the Westville section this afternoon, looking at West Rock Avenue, which borders the West River.

title: DISPUTE MARS BOSTON RACE TRADITION
description: The Boston Marathon, long one of the purest spectacles in sport, has become the center of a bitter controversy. Allegations that the road race has been turned over to a ''mysterious'' promoter have been met with countercharges by the promoter that the city's dominant newspaper is conducting a vendetta against him.

title: Mary Morrissey Becomes a Bride
description: In St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday Mary Patricia Morrissey and Stefan Richard Underhill, graduates of the University of Virginia, were married by the Rev. George B. Wilson.

title: 2 AMERICANS HELD HOSTAGE BY SEOUL WORKERS 9 HOURS
description: Two American businessmen were held hostage for nine hours by about 100 Korean workers at a United States-owned computer parts plant in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday. The incident, which ended with the safe release of the executives, is regarded as the most serious labor clash since President Chun Doo Hwan took power in 1980.

title: JAZZ: HERBIE MANN AND TRIO
description: HERBIE MANN, whose forceful flute has been turning on exuberant audiences in New York's larger clubs for years with the backing of some intensely rhythmic groups, has moved to a very different venue and a different musical situation. He is leading a trio in the staid Saratoga Room of the American Stanhope Hotel, across Fifth Avenue from the Metropolitan Museum of Art at 81st Street.

title: RASH U.S. DECISION TO SUPPORT BRITAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Economy Slow, France Reports
description: French business activity weakened in the first three months of 1982, according to recently released figures, dealing a blow to President Francois Mitterrand's plans to revitalize the economy.

title: JUDGE APPROVES USE OF CURRENCY FOR ILLUSTRATIONS
description: A Federal judge has found unconstitutional two counterfeiting laws that limit news publications from using United States currency for illustrative purposes.

title: LEVEE PLAN SPLITS 2 LOUISIANA TOWNS
description: Southern Louisiana is literally losing ground, sinking, scientists say, one foot every 50 years. There is river flooding, and the salty Gulf of Mexico is inching inland as the barrier of marshland breaks up. Dry land is losing and water is winning.

title: IN ENEMY'S CAPITAL, BRITISH PRESS MEETS CORDIALITY
description: The question and the accent were entirely British. Did the Argentines believe, asked Neil Wallis of the conservative Daily Star of London, that the British Vulcan bomber forced down in Brazil was on its way to Port Stanley on the Falkland Islands?

title: Miss Rothenberg Wed To Dr. David Makover
description: Reena Ann Rothenberg, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Tobias Rothenberg of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. David Makover, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Makover of Brooklyn. The bride's father performed the ceremony at the Huntington Jewish Center, of which he is spiritual leader.

title: C.F.A. AIMS AT COACHES
description: The College Football Association voted today to recommend to the National College Athletic Association that a coach found guilty of serious violations of N.C.A.A. rules be suspended for at least one year without pay. It also urged that an athlete who knowingly accepted illegal inducements lose all further eligibility.

title: 26 Reported Slain in Mexico
description: Cattlemen and hired gunmen killed 26 peasants outside an east Mexican town in a dispute over land, the official Notimex press agency said today. It quoted the mayor of Mecapalapa, 180 miles east of here, as saying the cattlemen had ordered the killings to end a five-day occupation by the peasants of grazing land near the village.

title: DETROIT GRAND PRIX TO WATSON
description: Driving his McLaren smoothly and aggressively, John Watson of Britain charged from 17th place in the starting grid to win the first Grand Prix race ever run through the streets of the Motor City.

title: Top-Secret Cargo Placed Into Bay of Space Shuttle
description: Top-secret Defense Department cargo was loaded into the bay of the Columbia as the space shuttle sat on the launching pad awaiting its fourth venture into orbit, officials said.

title: 8 BELIEVED DEAD
description: Torrential weekend rains and overflowing rivers swamped wide areas of Connecticut yesterday with the state's worst floods in decades. The state police said that eight persons were dead or missing in the storm. More than 1,300 others were removed from their homes as floodwaters invaded residential areas, washed out roads and earthen dams and disrupted electric and telephone service and public transportation for tens of thousands of residents.

title: Betty Ann Pinck Becomes Bride of Dr. Alan Sperber
description: Betty Ann Pinck, daughter of Mrs. Bernard D. Pinck of Passaic, N.J., and the late Dr. Pinck, was married at the Harmonie Club yesterday to Dr. Alan B. Sperber, son of Mrs. Fred Sperber of New York and the late Mr. Sperber.

title: U.N. COUNCIL ASKS ISRAELI PULLBACK
description: The Security Council unanimously demanded tonight that Israel pull its invading forces out of Lebanon. There was, however, no indication that Israel would pay any more attention to this order than to the unanimous Council demand Saturday night for a cease-fire.

title: COUSTEAU BEGINS 11-MONTH STUDY OF AMAZON
description: The French oceanographer Jacques Cousteau left Belem this week on an 11-month expedition to study Amazon animal and plant life.

title: Grand Banquet: The Menu
description: Following is the menu for the grand banquet that was served tonight at the economic conference here.

title: WEAKNESS IN TREASURY ISSUES
description: The collapse of Drysdale Government Securities in mid-May has led to a contraction in the market for Treasury securities as securities firms, banks and other lenders reassess the creditworthiness of their customers.

title: A NEW FAD INVADES: MARTIAN ANTENNAE
description: No one seems certain of their name - the street vendors hawking them all over town call them everything from ''Martian antennas'' to ''heart hats'' - but one thing is sure: Those glittery stars, hearts and balls bobbing around are a presummer fad.

title: JOHN JAY'S CLASS HEARS ADDRESS BY WIESENTHAL
description: For the graduating class of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, assembled yesterday in Carnegie Hall at the school's 17th commencement, the message was clear, but not simple.

title: By Theodore W. Libbey Jr.; Noel E. Velasco Offers Art Songs and Opera
description: Noel E. Velasco, the Philippine tenor, divided his Saturday afternoon program at Alice Tully Hall between art song and opera, meeting with some success in the art songs, little in the opera. His account of Beethoven's ''An die ferne Geliebte'' (Op. 98) was reasonably sensitive, though undercharacterized, and he sang with authority in ''Mga Awit ng Pag-asa't Pag-ibig'' (''Songs of Hope and Love''), a cycle for tenor, flute and guitar by the Philippine composer Michael Dadap that received its world premiere in the performance.

title: ECONOMY SLUMPED IN MAY
description: The rate of decline in the economy increased sharply in May, casting further doubts on a recovery until later in the year at the earliest, according to a monthly survey of purchasing managers in the nation's leading industrial companies.

title: SUMMIT CHIEFS SHOCKED BY INVASION OF LEBANON
description: Leaders of the seven major industrial democracies, interrupting their discussions of economic issues, declared today that they were shocked by Israel's invasion of Lebanon and warned of the ''disastrous consequences'' of continued violence in the Middle East.

title: Gerald Gelbloom, 56, Violinist With 2 Boston Orchestras
description: Gerald Gelbloom, a first violinist with the Boston Symphony and Boston Pops Orchestras and a member of the faculties of Boston University and the Longy School of Music, died last Wednesday. He was 56 years old and lived in Newton Centre, a Boston suburb.

title: Advertising; Atlantic Takes the High Road
description: FOR 30 years two of America's best-known magazines, Harper's and The Atlantic - like Siamese twins joined at the waist - had a common national advertising sales force. Judging from the financial health of the two publications in the years just before the sales company closed last September, it was not a roaring success.

title: The U.N. Today; June 7, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Second Special Session of the Gen- eral Assembly Devoted to Disarma- ment - 3 P.M.

title: SYRIA TELLS OF ISRAELI CONTACTS
description: The Israeli forces that invaded Lebanon today have come into contact with Syrian troops in three places, a Syrian military spokesman said. However, it was not clear from his statement whether the Syrians were actually fighting the Israelis or whether they were just holding their ground.

title: STADELR'S 69 FOR 275 TAKES KEMPER BY 7
description: It was no contest, and by Craig Stadler's estimate it was all over after the first two holes, which took about 25 minutes to play.

title: CLASSIC BOOKSHOP SALE SHOWS STAMP OF LEADER
description: When Brian Melzack, president of the Toronto-based Classic Bookshop chain, signed a letter of intent recently to sell his two Manhattan stores to Waldenbooks, his competitors in the Canadian bookstore industry were startled. ''That's surprising,'' said John Taylor, manager of the University of Toronto Bookstore and former president of the Canadian Booksellers Association. ''I thought he was making a pile of money off those stores.''

title: Quality-Control Engineer
description: Add another phrase to the terminology of pro football. Late last month, the Oakland Raiders hired 37-year-old Larry Kennan, the head coach at Lamar University in Beaumont, Tex., and said he would be an assistant coach ''in charge of quality control.''

title: Hinault Is Victor Of Italian Cycling
description: Bernard Hinault of France won the final leg of the Giro of Italy bicycle race today and also captured the overall title.

title: GYPSY LEADER SAYS PERSECUTION IS CONTINUING
description: For the last several years, an English-born man popularly known as the ''king of the gypsies'' has organized campaigns on behalf of his people from a home in the slum quarters of this northern Greek city.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1982
description: International Israel invaded southern Lebanon by land, sea and air in an attack aimed at destroying the main bases of the Palestine Liberation Organization. More than 250 tanks and armored personnel carriers backed up by thousands of infantrymen rolled past observation posts of the United Nations peacekeeping troops and spread out over the frontier, according to a United Nations spokesman in Beirut. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Israeli Army was ordered to push Palestinian forces northward to a distance of 25 miles from Israel's border so that the P.L.O. artillery would be removed beyond the range of Israeli territory, Prime Minister Menachem Begin said in a letter to President Reagan. (A1:5-6.)

title: MRS. REAGAN VISITS U.S. CEMETRY IN NORMANDY ON D-DAY ANNIVERSARY
description: SUR-MER, France, June 6 - It was raining as Nancy Reagan arrived at the American cemetery in Normandy today, and it seemed somehow fitting. The gentle patter on this, the 38th anniversary of the Allied invasion of Europe, could have been the nation's tears of remembrance as the First Lady placed a wreath to commemorate the 9,386 Americans buried here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our computers are down, our telephones are out and there are four to five inches of water on the floor.'' -Warren Silverzahn of the National Weather Service in Bloomfield, Conn. (B4:2.)

title: WILANDER, 17, WINS FRENCH TITLE
description: With cracks of thunder accenting the most dramatic moments, Mats Wilander completed a memorable performance in the French Open tennis championships today by emerging as the youngest player ever to win the men's title.

title: WEST SIDE MURDER MOTIVE SOUGHT
description: A 22-year-old clerk who was slain during an attempted holdup at an Upper West Side dress boutique Saturday night was shot for no apparent reason, the police said yesterday.

title: Commodities; Boards Vie For Lead In Indexes
description: THE quiet but furious struggle to dominate the four-month-old stock index futures market is expected to quicken now that the Chicago Board of Trade prepares to open a market in futures based on the popular Dow Jones averages. Until now, lawsuits by Dow Jones & Company had held up these plans for more than a month, while rival markets gathered strength.

title: REVAMPED METS WIN BY 6-3
description: The idea was conceived Saturday night, but it was not until this morning that Mike Jorgensen wrote the new name on a piece of tape and fixed it to the top of the Met lineup card. "Bambi's Bandits," Jorgensen wrote. It was not clear whether the group's goal was to steal victories, jobs, or both.

title: REAGAN ARRIVES IN LONDON TODAY UNDER A BIT OF A U.N. CLOUD
description: President Reagan arrives in Britain Monday for a 40-hour stay that appears likely to be dominated by pomp, circumstance and further discussion of Washington's handling of a United Nations vote Saturday on the Falkland crisis.

title: BLOCK MOVES TO DEFEAT FARM AID BILL
description: The Reagan Administration marshalled its forces last week to beat back election year efforts by Congress to provide new and more expensive rescue programs for farmers.

title: Dr. S.E. Hindman weds Barbara Galton
description: Barbara Robin Galton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene B. Galton of Newton, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Steven Elliot Hindman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Hindman of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Samuel Chiel performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Newton.

title: Anastasio Is First
description: Bob Anastasio, a former Cornell University standout, defended his Manufacturers-Hanover five-borough five-mile championship yesterday morning, winning in 24 minutes 3.1 seconds in light rain at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: EX-U.S. ATTORNEY IS FAVORED IN IOWA PRIMARY
description: Arlene Murphy sat in the Riverside Bowling Alley here eating pancakes one Sunday morning last month and watched Roxanne Conlin work the crowd in search of votes.

title: OUTDOORS: TAKING CODFISH OFF LONG ISLAND
description: IF you have a yen to take in great draughts of salt air while enjoying good fishing, you might visit either the northern or the southern tips of Long Island.

title: ISRAELI SAYS MOVE IS TO FORM BUFFER
description: Moshe Arens, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, said today that the sole objective of Israel's invasion of Lebanon was to push Palestine Liberation Organization forces out of artillery and rocket range of northern Israeli settlements.

title: SCHMIDT'S PARTY IS DEALT A SEVERE DEFEAT IN HAMBURG STATE ELECTION
description: The opposition Christian Democratic Party administered a stunning defeat to the Social Democratic Party tonight, outpolling it for the first time in elections for the Hamburg State parliament that may affect the future of the federal coalition Government in Bonn.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: A 'Union' Team
description: Beasley Reece, player representative, said the Giants are ''definitely a union team,'' but he refused to disclose the outcome of a strike authorization vote taken Saturday.

title: Zimbabwe Premier's Airliner Is Forced to Land in France
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, his wife, four Government ministers and 161 other passengers slid down emergency chutes from an airliner Saturday night after a bomb scare forced it to land in Paris, officials said today.

title: Revere Aluminum Cuts
description: Revere Aluminum Southeast, a division of Revere Copper and Brass Inc., has announced that it will suspend operations at its Scottsboro, Ala., aluminum reduction plant for an indefinite period. About 600 jobs will be lost.

title: ABDUL JABBAR HELD TO A MERE 6 POINTS
description: With Caldwell Jones harassing him from either side and Darryl Dawkins muscling him from front and rear, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored only 6 points this afternoon - the fewest the 7-foot-2-inch center has scored in a game since 1977.

title: Eileen Robin Sandler Bride Of Lawrence Stephen Reich
description: Eileen Robin Sandler, daughter of Mrs. Sol Rukskin of New York and the late Jack Sandler, was married yesterday to Lawrence Stephen Reich, son of Mrs. Jack Letteris of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Jerome D. Reich.

title: C.F.T.C. IS COMING UNDER FIRE
description: A move is under way in Congress to curtail sharply or even eliminate the Commodity Futures Trading Commission's authority to approve stock index futures, an action that commodities industry officials fear could be the first step in removing the agency's responsibility for regulating financial futures.

title: Bridge: Barry Goren's Team Wins Reisinger Knockout Title
description: A player bearing a famous bridge name led his team to an upset victory in the final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, which ended Saturday at the New York Hilton.

title: Richard Boeth, 49, a Writer For National Magazines, Dies
description: Richard Boeth, a writer whose work appeared in a number of national magazines, died Saturday at his home after a long illness. He was 49 years old.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Seals of Approval
description: An abandoned New York tenement with broken windows is like a corpse with open eyes. The city government ultimately comes and closes the lids by nailing gray sheets of galvanized steel to the exterior frames. It hopes to discourage vandals from breaking in. But they come, starting fires, and terrifying neighbors until they move.

title: AT THE DOOR TO JAPAN'S CAPITAL MARKETS
description: To the Editor:

title: BEGIN ORDERS ISRAELIS TO PUSH PALESTINIANS 25 MILES TO NORTH
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said Sunday that the Israeli Army had been ordered to push the Palestinian forces northward to a distance of 25 miles from the Israeli border, to place their artillery beyond the range of Israeli territory.

title: LIMITED SUMMIT AGREEMENT SET ON TRADE AND CURRENCY
description: The eighth summit conference of the industrialized nations reached limited agreement today on two contentious subjects - East-West trade and the handling of currency fluctuations - and produced something of a breakthrough on North-South relations.

title: Egypt Frees 37 Youths Facing Conspiracy Trial
description: The state security prosecutor ruled today that 40 youths must stand trial on charges of conspiring to overthrow the Government by armed force, but released 37 others for lack of evidence.

title: Maine Eliminates Fullerton, 6-0, in College Series
description: Joe Johnson pitched a four-hitter today as-Maine eliminated California State-Fullerton, 6-0, in the College World Series. Kevin Bernier had three singles and scored three runs.

title: HAVANA EXPLOITS FALKLAND DISPUTE
description: Heartened by evidence that the Falkland conflict has already damaged Washington's relations with Latin America, Cuba is now trying to use the crisis to end its political isolation from much of the region.

title: A FORMER GOVERNOR TO HEAD COMMITTEE ON U.S.-CHINA TIES
description: Raymond Philip Shafer, a former Governor of Pennsylvania, has been named chairman of the National Committee on United States-China Relations.

title: PRINCETON REUNIONS DRAW WET, SPIRITED THOUSANDS
description: There was revelry and hoopla as thousands of Princeton alumni returned this weekend to Old Nassau for reunions, the annual rite that transforms the town and campus into a gallery of orange and black costumes.

title: WHY ISRAELIS INVADED NOW
description: Israel's invasion of Lebanon came today as the culmination of months of military and political calculation in which Prime Minister Menachem Begin repeatedly allowed the troops to be massed and the saber to be rattled, only to pull back at what seemed like the last moment. Until today the crucial factors favoring a major assault never quite lined up, and the risks seemed greater than the potential benefits.

title: Way Over Her Head
description: Cindy John Holmes remembers watching on television in 1978 when 5-foot-8-inch Franklin Jacobs high-jumped 7 feet 7 1/4 inches, at the time a world indoor best. More important to her, the Fairleigh Dickinson sophomore had jumped 23 1/4 inches over his head, still the farthest over one's height by any man.

title: Fight-Night Sellout
description: It will be seen at Radio City Music Hall, at a drive-in movie theater on Long Island, in Pocatello, Idaho, at Wenatchee, Wash., and at about 300 other locations across the United States.

title: GLOBAL CONFLICT: A 90-DEGREE SHIFT
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIEST REFLECTS ON DECADES OF AMERICAN UNIONISM
description: To talk with Msgr. Charles Owen Rice as he reflects on five decades of involvement with American unions is to gain an understanding of the tumultuous fights between Communists and anti-Communists, the repercussions of which are still felt today.

title: U.S. Examining Safety At M.I.T. Nuclear Facility
description: Federal officials have begun an investigation of safety standards in a laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where a machinist said he was forced to work with radioactive material, The Boston Sunday Globe reported.

title: GOVERNOR AND A MAYOR SAID TO LEAD IN CALIFORNIA RACE
description: California will hold its 1982 primary election Tuesday, and opinion polls indicate that Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., a Democrat, and Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego, a Republican, are leading the races for their parties' nominations for the United States Senate.

title: First Aid, By Dawkins
description: HALF a dozen fans were wearing hospital gowns and surgical masks and carrying signs that said: ''The Doctor Is In.'' A man waved a sign that said he had come all the way from Germany ''To See Dr. Operate.''

title: Paul Schackman Marries Carolyn Hope Sherman
description: The marriage of Carolyn Hope Sherman and Paul Michael Schackman, former members of the faculty of the Horace Mann-Barnard Elementary School, took place at the Travelers Rest in Millwood, N.Y., yesterday. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony.

title: Record Is Set
description: Mary Decker Tabb's world-record performance in the women's 5,000-meter run highlighted the Prefontaine Classic track and field meet Saturday night.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Mary Cantwell THE DIARY OF VIRGINIA WOOLF, Vol- ume IV, 1931-1935. Edited by Anne Oli- vier Bell, assisted by Andrew McNeil- lie. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. 402 pages. $19.95.

title: 17 Killed in Canton Explosion
description: An explosion in a fireworks factory that had been ordered to shut down for unsafe practices killed 17 workers and injured 24 others, a Canton newspaper reported today. The explosion was touched off by a worker's careless handling of materials and destroyed the plant's warehouse, the Yangcheng Evening News reported.

title: U.N. RESOLUTION ON MIDDLE EAST
description: Following is the text of the resolution adopted unanimously by the Security Council tonight on the fighting in Lebanon:

title: RASH U.S. DECISION TO SUPPORT BRITAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: PCA International Goes To Rosenfeld, Sirowitz
description: PCA International, in Matthews, N.C., which operates permanent and temporary photographic portrait studios in department stores in the United States, Canada and four other countries, is going to Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson for $14 million worth of broadcast, print and point-of-sale advertising.

title: YOUTH: A CHANGE IN VALUES
description: IT has been a spontaneous occurrence at more than a few graduation c eremonies this year: the spectacle of students rising in cap and g own to applaud their parents in the audience. It is a sight that w ould have been inconceivable little more than a decade ago, when thew ar between the generations erupted in the cancellation of graduationc eremonies throughout the nation. What does this new behavior say a bout the mores of a new generation of students? And is it the emblemo f a sea change in the relationship between parents and children?

title: FOREST SERVICE CAUGHT IN LOBBYING CROSSFIRE
description: Mention the Forest Service and most people envision Smokey Bear and fire wardens in campaign hats in their towers deep in a National Forest. Or forest rangers on guard to prevent the lumber barons from overcutting the people's trees and the ranchers from overgrazing National Forest grasslands with cattle and sheep.

title: DEFOLIANT LINKED TO CANCER RATE
description: A defoliant that the Army stopped using in the Vietnam War because of potential ecological damage is suspected of causing an increase in cancer deaths in western North Carolina, The Baltimore Sunday Sun has reported.

title: Rangers 5, White Sox 4
description: Jim Sundberg drove in the winning run with a two-out double to left field in the eighth inning. Mark Wagner singled off Jerry Koosman (1-3) with two outs and moved to third on George Wright's single before Sundberg's hit.

title: Offer for Malone Is Called a Record
description: Gavin Maloof, owner of the Houston Rockets, said today that his team has offered Moses Malone, ''the largest contract ever offered to a professional athlete in the history of sports.''

title: Richard Brower
description: Joan Throckmorton, president of Throckmorton Associates (formerly Throckmorton/Zolfo), well known in direct marketing circles, has arranged for Richard Brower Inc., the graphics design firm, to replace Victor F. Zolfo, her creative director, who resigned.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American International Group Inc. has appointed E.A.G. Manton and Ernest E. Stempel to the newly created positions of senior advisers; George A. Abouzeid executive vice president-life insurance; Edward E. Matthews executive vice president-finance; Robert B. Sanborn executive vice president-agency operations; Wayland M. Mead senior vice president and general counsel; Joseph P. DeAlessandro vice president-domestic general (brokerage), and Marion E. Fajen vice president and secretary.

title: FALLING DIESEL CAR SALES TIED TO GAS PRICE DROP
description: When William Miles bought his new Cadillac El Dorado in August 1980, he chose a diesel-powered engine. Gasoline prices were on the rise and 1978's shortage scare was fresh in his mind.

title: Washington Watch; Tokyo's Fresh View on Trade
description: WASHINGTON WHAT Washington policy makers liked most about Japan's newest trade liberalization action was Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki's call on the Japanese people to ''extend a welcoming hand to foreign products.''

title: Pope Bids the Faithful Pray For Him on His Argentine Trip
description: Pope John Paul II today asked the faithful to pray for him on his trip to Argentina this week and thanked all those who made possible his trip to Britain last week.

title: ISRAELIS APPARENTLY SEEK TO CRUSH THE GUERRILLAS
description: As columns of Israeli troops and armor poured into Lebanon from three directions and Israeli planes and ships bombarded the coastal highway yesterday, the prospect was one of yet more bloodshed and destruction for the war-ravaged country.

title: NYAMBUI EYEING 5,000 RECORD
description: Suleiman Nyambui is content. In the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 61st annual outdoor track and field championships, which ended here Saturday, he won the 10,000-meter run for the fourth straight year and the 5,000 for the third straight. He raised his career total to 15 N.C.A.A. individual titles -seven indoors, seven outdoors and one in crosscountry. He led Texas-El Paso to its fourth straight outdoor team title.

title: Cast Vote, Win Prize, Californians Are Told
description: Californians who cast their ballots on Tuesday could win airline tickets, a trip to Hawaii, a date with a television actress or a lifetime supply of french fries.

title: FOCUS OF GUN-CONTROL FIGHT SHIFTS
description: The nation's chronic debate over gun controls, already burnished by cycles of time, tragedy and rhetoric into a Capitol Hill specialty, is waxing once again.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 7, 1982; The Summit
description: The summit conference ended with limited agreements on East-West trade and the handling of currency fluctuations and also opened wider the subject of North-South relations. But many analysts hold that even the limited gains were produced by papering over fundamental differences. (Page A1.) What gains there were turned out to be more modest than Washington had hoped for. (D6.) There was considerable feeling that the seven leaders did not really come to grips with the worldwide recession. (D6.)

title: Esther C. Kisk Goddard Dies; Widow of Pioneer in Rockets
description: Esther C. Kisk Goddard, who was a photographer in early rocket experiments by her husband, Robert Hutchings Goddard, died Friday at her home in Worcester, Mass. She was 81 years old.

title: RENT RISES UP TO 30% URGED FOR STABILIZED UNITS IN CITY
description: Landlords of rent-stabilized apartments in New York City proposed yesterday that monthly rent increases ranging from 12 to 30 percent be imposed for leases starting Oct. 1.

title: Filipino Troops on Alert For Voting in South
description: Troops in the southern Philippines went on alert today in preparation for the first real electoral test of President Ferdinand Marcos's Government in more than 10 years.

title: Fox to Offer Video Games
description: The 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation entered the video game industry today, forming a new division to market software for the games.

title: Handle Largest
description: The New York Racing Association's simulcast program for the Belmont Stakes resulted in the largest handle in the state's thoroughbred racing history, it was announced yesterday. A total of $7,454,975 was wagered on the Belmont, with $2,398,489 of it coming from 17 simulcast outlets. The previous record was $4,016,551, set in 1980.

title: Insurance on Floods Is Offered by the U.S.
description: Flood insurance, which is not normally available on the commercial market, is provided by the Federal Government to those who live in communities that have taken steps to reduce the risks of flood damage.

title: Roberta White Is Wed To Daniel Owen Smith
description: Roberta Jane White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar White of Pearl River, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Owen Smith, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick G. Smith of Macedon, N.Y. Village Justice Elizabeth Brown performed the ceremony at the Corinthian Yacht Club in Marblehead, Mass.

title: MRS. THATCHER SAYS 'HIT LIST' INCLUDED NAME OF P.L.O. AIDE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said tonight that a ''hit list'' that included the name of the Palestine Liberation Organization representative in London had been found on the suspects arrested after the shooting of the Israeli Ambassador to Britain.

title: What's Plain in Spain
description: A Spanish military court has sent a salutary message to any coupminded officers by giving 30-year sentences to the two principal plotters of last year's brazen seizure of the parliament. The toughness of those sentences should offset the conspicuously lighter punishment for lesser conspirators.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH FOR EQUAL RIGHTS
description: Thousands of demonstrators descended on the State Capitol today to demand that legislators ratify the proposed Federal equal rights amendment before the June 30 deadline.

title: REMEMBER NATIONAL CURRICULUM PRIORITIES?
description: To the Editor:

title: STATEMENT ON LEBANON BATTLE
description: Following is the text of a statement on the Middle East fighting issued here today by the leaders of the United States, France, Britain, Italy, Canada, West Germany and Japan:

title: Palestinians' Shelling Of Galilee Is Sporadic
description: The Palestinian guerrilla bombardment of Galilee let up today as Israeli armor advanced toward the gun positions in southern Lebanon. No casualties were reported.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: In a soccer game, a player from the offensive Team A and one from the defensive Team B pursue the ball as it nears the sideline deep in Team B's territory. The defensive player kicks the ball and it goes up and strikes his hand. The referee rules it a hand ball and calls a penalty shot. Was that proper?

title: LAW PANEL SEES ATOM ARMS AS ILLEGAL
description: A committee of lawyers and law professors from the United States, Europe and Japan has declared that the manufacture and use of nuclear weapons violates long-accepted principles of international law. They expressed the hope that their declaration, issued over the weekend, would strengthen the nuclear disarmament movement.

title: Ellen Cohen Is Married
description: Ellen Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Cohen of Huntington, L.I., was married there yesterday to Dr. David Grossman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Grossman of Glen Rock, N.J. Rabbi Barton Shallat performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El. The bride is director of special services at April-Marcus Inc., advertising and merchandise consultants. Dr. Grossman was graduated last month from the Rutgers University Medical school.

title: Market Place; Weakening A.T.& T. Stock
description: ON Jan. 11 of this year, the common stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company jumped 1 5/8 points, closing at 60 1/2, on a turnover of 2.6 million shares. It marked the initial response of investors and traders to an agreement whereby the Justice Department, a few days earlier, had dropped its seven-year-old antitrust case against A.T.& T.

title: NEW PRESIDENT NAMED AT VAIL ASSOCIATES
description: For the past 10 years, Harry H. Frampton 3d has worked to turn 5,500 acres of raw Virginia land into Brandermill, a lakeside residential community with 2,300 suburban homes.

title: WESLEYAN GRADUATES HEAR CRITICISM OF U.S.
description: The Mexican writer-diplomat Carlos Fuentes told graduating seniors at Wesleyan University today that the Falkland Islands crisis had resulted in ''an immense loss of faith'' in the United States on the part of Latin America.

title: Prison Guard Is Held Hostage For Brief Time in Connecticut
description: An inmate at the Somers state prison who briefly held a guard hostage has been placed in administrative segregation at the maximum-security facility, officials said today.

title: DISSAREAGAN
description: At one of the first economic summits, a British Prime Minister was photographed frolicking in the surf when his constituents back home in London were freezing. Reminded of this predecessor's gaffe last week by Newsday reporter Pat Sloyan, Prime Minister Thatcher mock-seriously proposed a maxim for summiteers: ''Never disrobe at a summit.''

title: STATE ECONOMY IS MAIN ISSUE IN THE PRIMARY RACES IN OHIO
description: Voters in Ohio will choose the main contenders for Governor and other statewide offices Tuesday after a primary campaign that has been dominated by the state's economic problems.

title: GIANTS DUEL LOOMS: BRUNNER VS. SIMMS
description: For the first time since Y.A. Tittle challenged Charlie Conerly for the job 21 years ago, the Giants have a bona fide competition for quarterback. The contestants are Phil Simms, who is the frontrunner by edict of the coach, Ray Perkins, and Scott Brunner, who played well late last season after Simms had suffered a shoulder separation.

title: REARDON OF EXPOS POSTS 6th IN A ROW
description: After their formation in 1969, it took the Montreal Expos 13 seasons to qualify for postseason competition. Last season, when the players' strike split the season, Montreal won the National League Eastern Division second-half race by a half-game over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: ARGENTINES EXPECT ASSAULT BY THE BRITISH AT ANY TIME
description: Argentina said today that its planes and artillery bombarded British positions surrounding the besieged Falkland Islands' garrison at Stanley.

title: Taking the Measure of Crime
description: For the police, robbery is a bellwether crime, and New York's police supervisors have waged a sophisticated campaign to speed up robbery investigations and to improve coordination with prosecutors. Their efforts appear to be paying off.

title: Leaders Skip Services
description: None of the seven leaders at the Western economic summit conference made use of the chance to attend a religious service this morning, organizers said. The French hosts at the conference in the Chateau of Versailles had told the leaders of the United States, Japan, Britain, Canada, Italy and West Germany that services in their denominations would be available. The leaders had not taken up the offer, organizers said.

title: MAKE NO AID OFFER
description: A sharply divided Arab world has so far failed to offer any assistance to the Lebanese and the Palestinians in the face of Israel's invasion today of southern Lebanon.

title: BUSY WEEK SET FOR NEW OFFERINGS
description: Besides a full schedule of corporate debt offerings this week that totals more than $1.1 billion, the United States Treasury is scheduled to sell $10 billion of three- and six-month bills today and $5.5 billion of one-year bills Thursday.

title: Tiffany in O.& M. Move; Frances Denney Shifts
description: Tiffany & Company, the world-famous jewelry and silverware shop, and breakfast location, has selected Ogilvy & Mather Partners as its new agency. The previous agency was Lord, Geller, Federico, which served the account for 14 years.

title: FLURRY OF DETAILS KEEPS TONY ORGANIZERS HOPPING
description: Broadway embraced itself last night, publicly, at length and in a blaze of last minute-tribulations. The occasion was the televised presentation of the Tony awards at the Imperial Theater; the tribulations, meanwhile, were of the usual kind.

title: U.S. IS FASHIONING NEW MILITARY STRATEGY FOR ASIA
description: The Reagan Administration has fashioned a new military strategy for Asia that emphasizes a shift in planning and forces from Northeast Asia to Southeast Asia and the Indian Ocean, according to Administration officials.

title: HANOI TRIP: GAINS SEEN BY EX-G.I.'S
description: A group of American veterans of the Vietnam War has left this country after a six-day visit, taking with them what seemed a heightened awareness of the possibilities - and pitfalls - of unofficial diplomacy.

title: Thompson Takes British Amateur
description: Martin Thompson of Britain became the third-youngest winner Saturday in the 97-year history of the British Amateur golf championship when he beat his countryman, Andy Stubbs, 4 and 3.

title: VIGNETTES: PAYING THE BILL, QUIETLY
description: With all the limousines, the helicopters, the closed-circuit television, the food and drink and mountains of glossy documents, the economic conference that ended here tonight was obviously a costly affair for the French Government. But the authorities declined to say just how costly.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: 'SINGULAR'S' MANY LIVES

title: JOANNE CARNER TRIUMPHS
description: JoAnne Carner shot a five-under-par 67 today to complete a six-shot victory in the Ladies Professional Golf Association McDonald's Classic.

title: Chenoweth Wins Hydroplane Race
description: Dean Chenoweth steered Miss Budweiser to an easy victory today in the $75,000 Champion Spark Plug unlimited hydroplane race at Miami Marine Stadium.

title: DISARMAMENT PARLEY OPENS TODAY AT THE U.N.
description: President Reagan, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and Prime Ministers Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Zenko Suzuki of Japan are among 14 world leaders scheduled to address a five-week conference on disarmament that begins here Monday.

title: NEW OWNERS HELP RICHMOND'S RETAILERS
description: The old clock has been repaired and the information desk has been reopened on the main floor of the 97-year-old Miller & Rhoads department store here to recapture an image of service. At Thalhimer Brothers, founded in 1842 and the largest-volume department store here, most large home furnishings, drugs, sporting goods and toys have been dropped to concentrate on more profitable departments.

title: Allison Wins Pocono 500
description: Bobby Allison easily won the raininterrupted $250,525 Pocono 500 stock car race today. Allison waged a close battle with the seven-time Nascar Grand National champion Richard Petty for most of the first 154 laps.

title: Orioles 7, Twins 5
description: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) - A two-run home run by Eddie Murray with one out in the 11th inning dealt Minnesota its 16th loss in 17 games. Jim Dwyer led off the 11th against Ron Davis (1-7) with a pinchhit single.

title: U.S. TO WARN 500,000 MEN ON DRAFT REGISTRATION
description: The Selective Service System, having registered 7.5 million young men, will start a final effort Monday to persuade the 500,000 who have not signed up to do so before they face prosecution, according to officials of the system.

title: Little Impact on Economic Outlook Seen; Economic Analysis
description: What did the Versailles conference do to end the worst slump of the postwar period? And how did it change the outlook for a decade of stagnation that so many business executives, economists and unemployed workers fear, with high unemployment, high interest rates and sluggish growth?

title: SOUNDS OF REUNION, AND SCIENCE, FROM THE CLASS OF '50
description: The Versailles Terrace of the Sheraton Centre hotel rang with the sounds of reunion - squeals of surprise and joy, derisive hoots at old nicknames and prom pictures. There were rueful glances at gray and thinning hair and envious stares at trim figures. The room was plastered with poster-size blowups of yearbook photos, and a man in a green-and-gold school cap boasted that his had more buttons and autographs than anyone else's.

title: GERMANS HOSTILITY TO THE U.S.
description: Ronald Reagan's visit to West Germany, like past Presidential visits, is intended to demonstrate the United States' commitment to that country's security. But many Germans - perhaps for the first time since 1948, when the Federal Republic was founded - are profoundly ambivalent about an American President.

title: OPERA: WARD'S 'MIDNIGHT' OPENS MIAMI FESTIVAL
description: A newly invented arts festival that begins with a contemporary opera about an impending cosmic bomb would seem to be daring the fates. The symbolism, at any rate, turned out to be cruelly apt. Robert Ward's ''Minutes Till Midnight,'' the work chosen to launch the New World Festival of the Arts in this culturally diffuse metropolis, bombed decisively, if not quite cosmically, in its premiere.

title: HEART OF RACING SEASON AHEAD
description: Conquistador Cielo's breathtaking 14 1/2-length victory in the Belmont Stakes Saturday was the final chapter of the 1982 Triple Crown. But it added some intriguing possibilities to the remainder of the thoroughbred racing season, which is only just beginning.

title: Vanderbilt Picks Chancellor
description: A vice president of Harvard University has been named chancellor, or chief executive officer, of Vanderbilt University here. The Vanderbilt board, upon recommendation by a search committee, appointed Joe B. Wyatt, 47 years old, vice president for administration at Harvard since 1976, to succeed Alexander Heard, who is retiring.

title: Australia Deal
description: The National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd., an Australian life insurance company in Melbourne, has announced that it purchased 20.4 million shares, or 13.3 percent, of Santos Ltd., an Adelaide-based oil exploration company involved in drilling projects in the Cooper Basin in central Australia, for $143.4 million. The shares were purchased from the Bond Corporation, a diversified energy company based in Perth. Bond still holds 2.1 million shares, or 1.4 percent, of Santos.

title: Washington Rows To A.I.A.W. Title
description: The University of Washington successfully defended its varsity eight-oared title today at the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women national rowing championships on Lake Waramaug.

title: CITY COLLEGE'S NEW PRESIDENT URGES GRADUATES TO FULFILL 'DUTY'
description: Addressing his first commencement audience since being named president of City College, Dr. Bernard W. Harleston yesterday told more than 1,700 graduates that they had ''made it,'' but now must make their education count.

title: 4 Composers Featured On St. Luke's Program
description: The St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble played music by Prokofiev, Mozart, Spohr and Johann Strauss at the Abraham Goodman House on Saturday night. The concert was to have offered the American premiere of Corrado Pasquotti's ''Forma Magistra Ludi,'' now deferred until the fall.

title: Spaniards March to U.S. Base And Assail NATO Membership
description: As many as 10,000 protesters marched today from Madrid to the site of a United States air base nine miles away, and another 2,000 gathered in downtown Barcelona to protest Spain's entry into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: INDIANS' WINNING STREAK ENDS
description: When the Cleveland Indians took the field at Exhibition Stadium in Toronto yesterday, they had an 11-game winning streak. With a doubleheader scheduled against the Blue Jays, they were near the club record of 13 consecutive victories, set in 1942 and matched in 1951.

title: Apathy of Voters Marks Runoff Election in Texas
description: Representative Jim Mattox, who based his campaign on a promise to be the ''people's lawyer,'' has defeated a former Federal prosecutor, John Hannah, in a runoff election for the Democratic nomination for Texas Attorney General.

title: Bribery Alleged at University
description: An Oregon man was arrested on a bribery charge Thursday in connection with an alleged scheme to obtain false diplomas for members of the royal family of the Arab emirate of Qatar in return for nearly $1 million, officials said. Robert Tufts, the registrar at Portland State University, told the authorities that he was offered from $5,000 to $125,000 each for 20 bogus degrees and transcripts from the university.

title: PRENUPTIAL AGREEMENTS THE 2D TIME AROUND
description: They sat on opposite sides of the negotiating table, he with his lawyer, she with hers. They talked of property, bank accounts and stocks and bonds, of her interior decorating business, his dental practice. Voices were raised, charges traded.

title: THE ELEMENTS TUG AT LARRY HOLMES
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. HIS mood varies. Sometimes it is rage, sometimes it is pique and sometimes it is whimsy. The road has been difficult, and now as Larry Holmes approaches what he hopes will be a $10 million victory lap, the scars from the hard knocks along the way burn on occasion.

title: Aquarius Theater Sold To Tahse Productions
description: The Aquarius Theater, owned by the Center Theater Group, has been sold for around $3 million to Martin Tahse Productions. Mr. Tahse, who produced the first national tours of more than a dozen Broadway shows including ''Funny Girl'' and ''The Miracle Worker,'' has been the prime supplier of the American Broadcasting Companies' ''Afterschool Specials'' television programs for the last 10 years.

title: Diana G. Liskin Wed to Lawyer
description: Diana G. Liskin, an associate in the New York law firm of Rosenman, Colin, Freund, Lewis & Cohen was married yesterday to Gordon Chapman, an associate with the Newark law firm of McCarter & English. Mayor Michael A. Ackerman of Mendham, N.J., performed the ceremony at the home of bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. Chapman of Short Hills, N.J..

title: Cycling to Aussie
description: Shane Sutton of Australia won the United States professional cycling championship today. The 24-year-old Sutton covered the 100-kilometer distance around a 1.5-mile course at Baltimore's Inner Harbor in 2 hours 28 minutes 31 seconds.

title: Traces of Neil Young At Tom Verlaine Show
description: Tom Verlaine has matured into one of rock music's very finest guitarists by steering a course that is only distantly related to the virtuosic blues-oriented tradition of the rock mainstream. Mr. Verlaine's surreal dream songs, with their hypnotic, repetitive phrases usually set in minor keys, are essentially rock tone poems, in which the implications of his stark surreal lyrics are elaborated in majestic, exquisitely colored guitar solos.

title: BALLET: FELD'S 'CONSORT'
description: A REVEALING group of ballets covering a 13-year span in Eliot Feld's choreographic career was presented Saturday by the Feld Ballet at the Joyce Theater. Performed in the afternoon, ''The Consort,'' a 1970 work set to music of Elizabethan composers, is Mr. Feld at his earthiest. The suite of dances begins decorously as four couples move through formal partnering and display, the men preening, each woman unfolding a leg that rises like the sail of a ship under her long skirt. The pace quickens almost imperceptibly. On their own, the men break out into swaggering lunges. A lone woman appears - the lovely Cheryl Jones -for a lyrical, little solitary moment.

title: 100,000 Jam Rose Bowl For a Disarmament Rally
description: About 100,000 people jammed the Rose Bowl today for an afternoon of music, speeches and prayer in support of nuclear disarmament.

title: TV: 'SISTER, SISTER' FILM AND 'COUPLES' SERIES
description: ''SISTER, SISTER,'' a movie on NBC-TV tonight at 9 o'clock, carries a list of imposing credits. It was written by Maya Angelou. The strong cast includes Diahann Carroll, Rosalind Cash, Irene Cara, Dick Anthony Williams, Paul Winfield and Robert Hooks. It was coproduced, with Miss Angelou, by John Berry, who also directed. It was clearly put together with care and love. But ''Sister, Sister'' steadfastly refuses to come to convincing life.

title: Ginny E. Schwartzman, Michael Abrams Wed
description: Ginny Elise Schwartzman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen L. Schwartzman of Sands Point, L.I., was married in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel yesterday to Michael David Abrams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Abrams of Washingon. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz.

title: NEW RAIL GIANT SET TO ROLL
description: Robert B. Claytor, the recently elected chairman and chief executive of the newly merged Norfolk & Western Railway and the Southern Railway, emerged from a meeting with senior executives of both railroads the last week of May and said: ''The one thing we don't want to do is mess it up.''

title: Reagan Visit Draws Fire
description: The news magazine Der Spiegel, in a strongly worded cover article titled ''The Unpleasant Guest,'' said today that President Reagan would get the most unfriendly welcome ever given a visitor to West Germany.

title: REVAMPED METS WIN BY 6-3
description: The Kansas City Royals took batting practice against four pitchers yesterday and got 22 hits for a 14-1 victory over the Yankees that Manager Gene Michael said was ''embarrassing'' and an indication that his players were once again thinking like losers.

title: Ever Greater Israel
description: The scene of battle changes, but the nature of the Israeli-Arab conflict does not. So long as it is denied secure boundaries, Israel will pursue a chimeric security in an ever wider arc of territory, buying time and breathing space by means that inflict new wounds of Arab grievance. Israel can be condemned, and perhaps restrained, but that will only nourish its anguish, and defiance.

title: Military Analysis
description: Israel's main risk in the invasion of southern Lebanon is not resistance by the Palestine Liberation Organization, but the possibility that the operation will provoke a strong military response from Syria.

title: THE JOB OF REVIVING AM INTERNATIONAL
description: Joe B. Freeman Jr. describes himself as ''energetic, loose and starving for a challenge.'' He has found perhaps one of the major challenges of his life in the job of trying to resuscitate AM International Inc., which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act six weeks ago as one of the major casualties in the current recession.

title: Chad's Rebel Forces Report Encircling Capital
description: Rebel forces loyal to Chad's former Prime Minister, Hissen Habre have destroyed the last Government defenses and surround the capital city, Ndjamena, Mr. Habre's representative in Europe said today.

title: Home Loan Rates Drop
description: Average effective interest rates on new home loans declined slightly in May for the second consecutive month, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: BRIEFING
description: Protest on Energy Panel

title: Chile's Villablanca Dethrones Serrano
description: Benedicto Villablanca of Chile dethroned the World Boxing Association's junior lightweight champion, Sammy Serrano of Puerto Rico, when a doctor ruled in the 11th round today that Serrano could not continue because of a cut over his eye. Villablanca became the first Chilean to win a world title.

title: OPERATION PEACE
description: In launching its large-scale invasion of Lebanon, Israel rejected urgent pleas from among others its principal supporter, the United States. Prime Minister Begin and his colleagues did so because they believed the move into Lebanon offered compelling opportunities.

title: CONNECTICUT LISTS SERVICE PROSPECTS
description: Connecticut officials said the weekend flooding would interfere with a number of services today. Highways: Expected to be in ''reasonable'' condition.

title: 8 Escape From Colorado Jail
description: Eight inmates escaped from a county jail today, the authorities said. One was recaptured. Still being sought was Ross Thomas, 37 years old, who faces charges in the shooting death of a liquor store clerk in Aurora, Colo.

title: 'NINE' AND 'NICKLEBY' TAKE TOP TONYS
description: ''Nine,'' based on Federico Fellini's autobiographical film ''8 1/2,'' the story of a troubled Italian film director, won the Antoinette Perry (Tony) Award last night as best musical of the year. ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' the Royal Shakespeare Company's ambitious stage adaptation of the Dickens classic, was named best play.

title: A New Growl
description: The engraved invitation has a classy look, with a large purple ''N'' at the top and a tasteful purple border. The president and national campaign chairman are pleased to invite the addressee to the ''kickoff'' of an athletics facilities campaign on June 8, the invitation reads.

title: MESA'S FOUNDER TAKES ON BIG FOE
description: Mention the name T. Boone Pickens Jr. to a stock market analyst, and the response is a long, pleasurable chuckle. The founder and chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company has created almost a cult among the generally skeptical investment community.

title: Red Sox 5, Angels 1
description: A single by Rick Miller broke a 1-1 tie in the seventh inning and Gary Allenson hit a two-run homer in the ninth inning that helped to stretch the California losing streak to seven games.

title: SHARP FIGHTING WITH GUERRILLAS REPORTED
description: The Israeli Army invaded southern Lebanon by land, sea and air Sunday in an attack aimed at destroying the main military bases of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Brewers 7, A's 2
description: Gorman Thomas hit a two-run double and Ted Simmons hit a two-run homer in the first inning to lead a 14-hit attack. The Brewers swept the three-game series with 29 runs and 43 hits. They have won five in a row and four under Harvey Kuenn, their interim manager.

title: MITTLEMAN IS FIRST IN 100 -MILER
description: Stu Mittleman, who says he does best on hot and dry days, yesterday won his third consecutive New York Road Runners Club 100-mile invitation run and bettered his American record in rainy, chilly weather at Shea Stadium.

title: Sports World Specials; Into the Stretch
description: Why did almost 800 people at the annual Manhattan College alumni dinner on Saturday night stand up in unison and stretch their arms as widely as possible? Because they were commemorating the 100th anniversary of baseball's seventh-inning stretch.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New York Day by Day will appear Monday through Saturday in Metropolitan Report. Antinuclear Week Begins With Clouds

title: Big Steelmakers Ask Union to Renegotiate
description: The nation's seven largest steel companies, citing the depressed condition of the industry and bleak prospects, have asked the United Steelworkers union to renegotiate their basic labor agreement, which is scheduled to expire Aug.1, 1983.

title: MESA'S BID IS TAKEN TO HOLDERS
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company, pressing its takeover bid for the Cities Service Company in spite of an outright rejection by the company's top management, disclosed last night that it was taking its offer directly to stockholders of Cities Service.

title: Swiss Voters Approve Antiriot Measures
description: Swiss voters ratified amendments to the penal code today that would crack down on rioting demonstrators and on terrorists. The amendments had previously been approved by Parliament.

title: FOR RICHARD, THE ROAD BACK IS PAVED IN TESTS OF PATIENCE
description: SARASOTA, Fla. THE windy aftermath of Hurricane Alberto buffeted the Ed Smith Sports Complex, home of the Sarasota Rookie League. It was an hour before the Friday afternoon practice, and J.R. Richard, once the dominating pitcher in baseball, sat in the rickety bleachers behind home plate.

title: Cairo Cabinet Protests 'Aggression' by Israelis
description: The Egyptian Cabinet today denounced Israel's attacks in Lebanon and ordered the Egyptian Ambassador to Israel to lodge a formal protest with the Israeli Foreign Ministry.

title: 76ers ROUT LAKERS, 135-102, AND TRAIL BY 3-2 IN SERIES
description: The Philadelphia 76ers threw everything at the Los Angeles Lakers today, including a zone trap, a blistering second-half running game and Darryl Dawkins.

title: BRITAIN CONFIRMS THE LANDING OF 3,000 SOLDIERS FROM QE2
description: British troops besieging the Argentine garrison at Stanley in the Falkland Islands have been reinforced by 3,000 fresh infantrymen from the liner Queen Elizabeth 2, the Defense Ministry announced tonight.

title: LET'S KEEP WASHINGTON OUT OF LOCAL SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXT OF COMMUNIQUE ISSUED AFTER THE VERSAILLES CONFERENCE
description: Following is the official English-language text of the joint communique issued today by the seven major industrial nations at the conclusion of the economic conference here:

title: Tigers 10, Mariners 2
description: DETROIT (AP) - Detroit chased Gaylord Perry with a six-run first inning, scoring three runs on Lance Parrish's double, and Dan Petry pitched a three-hitter for his sixth victory in nine decisions.

title: Synthetic Fuel Plans
description: The United States Synthetic Fuel Corporation has announced that it received 37 proposals for synthetic fuel projects in its second solicitation. The organization provides Federal loan or price guarantees, or both, for projects it considers worthwhile.

title: Korea President Names Aide
description: Hahm Pyong Choon, who served as South Korean Ambassador to the United States from 1973 to 1977, was named chief secretary to President Chun Doo Hwan today, the presidential office said. The 50-year-old Mr. Hahm, a law professor and aide to the late President Park Chung Hee, succeeds Lee Bum Suk, who was named Foreign Minister last week in a series of Cabinet changes that followed a loan market scandal.

title: BALLET: A SHY 'GISELLE'
description: THE American Ballet Theater offered a fine ''Giselle'' on Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House with Magali Messac in the title role and Patrick Bissell as Count Albrecht.

title: N.F.L. TALKS ON
description: A percentage of the gross, the key issue in the labor negotiations between the National Football League owners and the players' union, wil be the main topic Monday as representatives of both sides resume contract talks here.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK LAUGHS OFF HAIG'S 'COMMANDER' REMARK
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States representative at the United Nations, indicated today that she did not resent being dubbed a ''company commander'' by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: BRITONS DIE TRYING AN UNCLIMBED WAY UP EVEREST
description: Two of Britain's foremost mountain climbers have vanished high on the Tibetan side of Mount Everest and are presumed dead.

title: WHOSE SOVIET THREAT?
description: Despite President Reagan's dramatic proposal to limit American and Soviet ballistic missiles, he still tells us that the Soviet Union is superior to the United States in strategic nuclear weapons. This assertion, which effectively blocks significant efforts at arms control, strikingly resembles several postwar exaggerations of the Soviet military threat that served to promote an American buildup.

title: Gain for U.S. Goals Below Expectations; News Analysis
description: President Reagan traded a last-minute concession on global economic negotiations with the third world for a modest, face-saving gain in his campaign to curb credits to the Soviet

title: Death Toll Rises to 200 As Storm Lashes India
description: Government helicopters dropped food today over isolated regions of southeast India's Orissa State, where officials said the death toll had climbed to 200 and more than 200,000 people remained homeless after a hurricane that ravaged the state's coastal areas.

title: LANDOWNERS ON JERSEY COAST WONDER IF THEY REALLY ARE
description: Thousands of homeowners up and down New Jersey's coast are alarmed, angry or simply confused over claims to their property filed by the state on the contention that the land once was flowed by tidal water and therefore belongs to the public.

title: JULIUS ASHKIN, 61, PHYSICIST, DIES
description: Dr. Julius Ashkin, professor of physics at Carnegie-Mellon University since 1958 and chairman of the department from 1961 to 1972, died Friday at Montefiore Hospital here. He was 61 years old.

title: DR. PEARL B. HOLLY, PSYCHIATRIST
description: Dr. Pearl Bronz Holly, a former chairman of the hematology department at George Washington University Medical School, who, at the age of 56, changed her specialty to psychiatry, died Wednesday at her home in Sante Fe, N.M. She was 73 years old.

title: TENANT GROUPS AND POLITICIANS ASSAIL RENT PLAN
description: Speaking before the city's Rent Guidelines Board, a parade of politicians and tenant advocates sharply condemned yesterday requests by owners of rent-stabilized apartments for monthly rent increases of 12 to 30 percent for leases during the year starting Oct. 1.

title: Rolls-Royce Begins New Ad Campaign
description: To help potential customers make the decision to part with the $111,000 to $162,000 needed to get behind the wheel of one of its products, Britain's Rolls-Royce Ltd. began a new ad campaign last Friday that is the biggest it has ever unleashed in this colony. Warren Pfaff Inc. is the agency.

title: Levi Strauss Names Head of U.S. Group
description: Levi Strauss & Company announced the appointment yesterday of Peter Thigpen to be president of Levi Strauss USA, the company's top domestic operating position.

title: DiMuro, Umpire, Dies After Being Hit by Car
description: Lou DiMuro, an American League umpire the last 19 years, was struck by a car while crossing a city street and died early today.

title: Less Than Meets the Eye
description: ''In times of economic stress,'' said President Reagan, ''it is always tempting to seek simple solutions at the expense of others. At Versailles, we resisted the temptation.'' At earlier summit meetings, such an agreement to disagree would not have been viewed as much of an achievement. This time, though, the divisions of ideology and perceived interest were fundamental. No amount of good food, good wine or good will could bridge them.

title: BRIEFING
description: Navy Plans an Arch

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Sunday about a primary contest for the House of Representa- tives in Ohio incorrectlydescribed the status of Representative Dennis E. Eckart, Democrat of Ohio. He is a candidate for re-election this year in a district adjacent to the one he has rep- resented.

title: 76ERS NOT AT HOME IN FORUM
description: The Forum in Inglewood, Calif., the site tonight of the sixth game in the National Basketball Association championship series, is not the Philadelphia 76ers' favorite arena.

title: BELL'S FEES TO EXPERTS CITED BY RIVALS
