description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its affiliated local companies last year paid nearly $3.5 million in fees to professors and other consultants for academic services and, in some cases, for providing testimony favorable to Bell before Congressional panels and Federal courts, according to an industry study published today.

title: News Analysis
description: South American leaders are already taking steps and anxiously pondering others to adjust to the conditions they believe will face the continent in the aftermath of the Falkland Island crisis.

title: G.M. Layoffs
description: General Motors of Canada Ltd., a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said it had indefinitely extended a layoff of 1,750 workers, or half the staff at its Sainte Therese, Quebec, car plant, which makes Oldsmobiles. The company said it had planned to recall the workers, who were laid off at the start of the year, by early summer. A spokesman said the layoffs had been extended because demand has not increased.

title: COUNTING ALL MISSILES AIMED AT U.S.S.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: LICENSES SOUGHT FOR CELLULAR RADIO
description: Dozens of companies submitted applications today to the Federal Communications Commission seeking permission to construct a new type of mobile telephone system in the nation's 30 largest cities.

title: Clark Equipment
description: The Clark Equipment Company, a Michigan manufacturer of heavy-duty trucks and construction equipment, said it would cut its salaried staff by 700 employees, including 500 workers over age 55 who will be given early retirement. Clark employs a total of 5,200 workers, mostly in Michigan, and said the early retirement program, which will begin in July and run for two months, is voluntary. The company said the cuts were made necessary by earnings declines caused by the recession in the construction industry.

title: Hockey Trade
description: The Minnesota North Stars traded Steve Christoff, right wing and former Olympian, Bill Nyrop, defenseman, and a second-round draft choice, to the Calgary Flames for Willi Plett, right wing, and a fourth-round draft choice.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brown Group Inc., St. Louis, has elected B.A. Bridgewater, Jr., chief executive officer, succeeding W.L. Hadley Griffin, who will continue as chairman of the board and chairman of the executive committee.

title: 'GYPSY MOTHS' IN THE BUDGETARY LIMELIGHT IN CONGRESS
description: As Congressional leaders search for a budget package that can be passed by the House of Representatives this week, Democrats and Republicans have been focusing much of their attention on a group of two dozen moderate Republicans, known around Capitol Hill as the ''gypsy moths.''

title: Pipe Bomb Rips Store in Bronx
description: At least one pipe bomb exploded in a small discount store in the Bronx yesterday, starting a fire that was quickly put out, the police said. There were no injuries, but the store was damaged extensively.

title: Kupchak's Bad News
description: The early prognosis was good: The injured knee of Mitch Kupchak would heal quickly and the big forward would be back with the Los Angeles Lakers before the end of the season.

title: Arbitrager and a Hunt Fight for Hotel Bel-Air
description: Both Ivan F. Boesky, who is the New York arbitrager, and Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf, who is a daughter of the late Texas billionaire, H.L. Hunt, are having a hotel problem. The problem, as it happens, is with the same hotel - the plush 66-room Hotel Bel-Air, nestled in a tree-shaded canyon away from the Hollywood throngs -and the nature of it is that they both want to own it.

title: WHEN A LAST WILL MUST NOT BE CARRIED OUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Illinois Police Cut Chains Of Rights Protesters
description: State police with chain-cutters arrived at the Illinois Senate at 4 A.M. today and surprised 15 women who had chained themselves to a rail to dramatize their support of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

title: Bank Lifts Prime Rate
description: The Continental Bank of Philadelphia raised its prime interest rate to 16 1/2 percent yesterday, two weeks after it had followed Citibank down to the 16 percent level. Economists said the move reflected a lack of conviction in banking circles that interest rates in general will decline in the coming months.

title: ACID RAIN ISSUE CREATES STRESS BETWEEN ADMINISTRATION AND SCIENCE ACADEMY
description: The Reagan Administration has cut off funds to the National Academy of Sciences for research into the controversial question of acid rain. As a result, the Administration is being accused of allowing its politics to interfere with important scientific inquiry.

title: PRIVATE WEALTH AND PUBLIC SERVICE
description: The Reagan Administration, more so than any other in recent memory, is dominated by wealthy businessmen and millionaires.

title: RIVAL STOCK FALLS AFTER MESA'S BID
description: Wall Street apparently took a dim view yesterday of the Mesa Petroleum Company's hostile takeover bid for the Cities Service Company. Shares of Cities Service fell 1 3/4, to 36 1/4, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of Mesa, which is facing a competing takeover bid from Cities Service, edged up 1/8, to 18 3/4, also in heavy trading.

title: CAREY WARNS CITY HE MAY OVERTURN ITS FINANCIAL PLANS
description: Governor Carey warned today that he would not approve New York City's financial plan if it was based on a local aid program passed last week by the Legislature.

title: RATES CHANGE ONLY SLIGHTLY
description: The Federal Reserve has been more generous in providing credit, or reserves, to the banking system but many analysts expressed doubt yesterday that the extra credit would reduce interest rates much below current levels.

title: SUPREME COURT LIMITS APPLICATION OF DOUBLE JEOPARDY CLAUSE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution permits the Government to retry a defendant after an appellate court has overturned a guilty verdict as ''against the weight of the evidence.''

title: PARTY CONTROL OF VACANT OFFICE IS UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a state may permit a political party automatically to retain control of a legislative seat that becomes vacant between elections.

title: All Livestock Futures Fall by Daily Limits
description: All actively traded livestock futures fell their daily permissible limits yesterday in what many brokers said may have signaled the end of an extraordinary five-month advance in cattle, hog and pork bellies prices.

title: Florida Architect Suspended
description: The Florida Board of Architecture has suspended for 10 years the license of William Juhn, the Cocoa Beach architect who helped design a condominium that collapsed last year, killing 11 construction workers and injuring 23. Mr. Juhn, who is 57 years old, was the last of five professionals charged with negligence in the case by the Department of Professional Regulation. He was also fined $1,000.

title: FORMALITY RETURNS TO CITY CLOTHES
description: City dressing for many summers has not looked that much different from dressing for the country. In other years, on a fashionable corner, such as 57th Street and Fifth Avenue, many women could have been heading toward a cabana on the beach rather than to their jobs or a shopping binge in nearby stores.

title: Military Analysis
description: British and foreign military sources say that, while they do not discount British military achievements in the Falklands, they believe Argentine commanders have made a series of errors that have placed their forces in a steadily deteriorating position.

title: TOWN BACKS WORKERS IN PLAN TO BUY STEEL MILL
description: What is happening in Weirton seems part of a peculiarly American myth - a movie like Frank Capra's ''It's a Wonderful Life'' springs to mind - in which a town is threatened with calamity and the citizens band together to save it.

title: Garvey Plays in 1,000th in Row
description: Steve Garvey tonight became the fifth major leaguer to play in 1,000 consecutive games. But Garvey went hitless in four times at bat as he and the Dodgers were upstaged by Dale Murphy, who hit a three-run homer as the Atlanta Braves won, 4-3.

title: Soviet Cites Delays on Gas
description: Delays in drilling and in laying pipe are complicating the development of the world's biggest natural gas field, at Urengoi, in the northern part of the Soviet Union, Pravda said today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt CHURCHILL. Young Man in a Hurry 1874- 1915. By Ted Morgan. 607 pages. Illus- trated. Simon & Schuster. $22.50.

title: Gen. Norma Brown Retiring
description: Maj. Gen. Norma E. Brown, the highest ranking woman in the Air Force and commander of Chanute Air Force Base, will retire July 31, the Air Force announced today. General Brown, 56 years old, will end more than 30 years of active duty.

title: CAPITAL OF CHAD REPORTED TO FALL
description: The capital of Chad fell today to rebel forces commanded by Hissen Habre, a former Defense Minister, the French Embassy there reported.

title: Advertising; Switch at Newspaper Ad Bureau
description: CRAIG STANDEN was on a very fast track in the world of packagedgoods marketing two years ago when he decided to join Jack Kauffman at the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. Mr. Kauffman, after 23 years of promoting newspapers as an advertising medium, was preparing to retire.

title: RCA TV Tube
description: The RCA Corporation said that it was completing development of a new color television picture tube system designed to lower the manufacturing cost of sets and to improve performance and reliability. The company said the system has a new color tube design that can be used in all tube sizes from 13 inch to 25 inch.

title: EXCERPTS FROM STATEMENTS BY POPE AND PRESIDENT
description: Following are excerpts from the official text of Pope John Paul II's comments to President Reagan today and remarks by Mr. Reagan:

title: HOUSE G.O.P. REVISES ITS BUDGET PLAN
description: House Republican leaders tentatively agreed today on a new budget plan that would provide more funds for Medicare and less for welfare programs and military spending than their original proposal.

title: U.S. INSURANCE: CRITICS GROW
description: Whether you are the victim of a burglary in Brooklyn, a flood in Florida, an insurrection in Indonesia or a credit union collapse in California there is a good chance you will be looking to Washington for reimbursement.

title: WARNING ISSUED ON 2 BIG BANKS
description: Two of New York's biggest savings banks, the Bowery and the Emigrant, are in danger of failing by January if they do not receive Government assistance, Alan R. Cohen, Acting Superintendent of New York State Banks, told Congress yesterday.

title: Shift to Los Angeles By Clippers Sought
description: The Los Angeles Coliseum Commission announced today it has signed an agreement with the San Diego Clippers under which the club would move to the Los Angeles Sports Arena. But officials of the commission, which operates the Sports Arena, acknowledged they had not discussed the plan with the National Basketball Association.

title: AN EPIDEMIOLOGIST AND RESEARCHER
description: Dr. Wolf Szmuness, a Polish-born epidemiologist who spent 10 years in a Siberian labor camp and who later designed the New York Blood Center studies that documented the efficacy of the first vaccine against hepatitis B, died Sunday at his home in Flushing, Queens, after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

title: THE BALD EAGLE: FLIGHT FROM EXTINCTION
description: THE massive bird with the great hooked beak was perched on top of a pole about 200 feet away. The angle of the sun and the bird's fluffed-out plumage made it difficult at first to spot its snow-white head and tail and its brownish-black body. But after a few seconds the telltale markings could be seen clearly in the binoculars: It was, indeed, a bald eagle.

title: Massey to Trim Some Paychecks
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the troubled maker of tractors, has announced that the company's 3,000 nonunion workers in Canada and the United States would take a temporary 20 percent pay cut.

title: BALLET: THE KIROV TOUCH FOR 2 ROMANTIC CLASSICS
description: ''La Sylphide'' and ''Giselle,'' the two signature ballets of the 19th-century Romantic era, have completed the range of programs given here by the Kirov Ballet.

title: DAMASCUS REPORTS SYRIA-ISRAEL FIGHT
description: Syria said tonight that fighting began today between Syrian and Israeli ground forces in southern Lebanon. A communique issued by the army high command said that Syrian forces confronted Israeli tanks that were advancing on Syrian positions south of Jezzin and destroyed some of them by artillery and antitank rocket fire. No number was mentioned.

title: 2 Injured Japanese Climbers Rescued From Mt. McKinley
description: United States Army helicopters today rescued two unconscious Japanese climbers who were critically injured in a fall on Mount McKinley.

title: DISARMAMENT SESSION OPENS AT THE U.N.
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar called today for an end ''to the madness and immorality of the arms race'' as the General Assembly began a five week special session on disarmament.

title: Tosco Directors
description: The Tosco Corporation has announced that the five managementnominated candidates for the company's board received 60 percent of the 17.8 million votes cast at the oil refining concern's shareholders meeting on May 11. Tosco shareholders last week also approved a management-sponsored proposal for an employee incentive stock option plan. A proposal to double the number of Tosco's authorized common shares did not pass, however, the Los Angeles-based company said.

title: USE OF MEMORIZATION IN SCHOOLS FADING
description: Listen, my children, and you shall hear, Of the midnight ride of Paul Revere, On the eighteenth of April, in Seventy-five; Hardly a man is now alive Who remembers that famous day and year. By GENE I. MAEROFF

title: Area Is Closed to All, Even (Oops) Premier
description: When Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini arrived at his Rome office a few minutes ahead of President Reagan today, a United States Secret Service agent tried to stop him from leaving his car.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 8, 1982
description: International A string of P.L.O. bases was captured by Israeli forces advancing from southern Lebanon northward into Palestinian-controlled towns and villages just south of Beirut. Israeli and Syrian jets fought over the southern suburbs of Beirut. Syria reportedly lost a plane. A spokesman for the Syrian Army said that the Israelis came into direct conflict with units of the 30,000-man Syrian peacekeeping force in Lebanon. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Syrian and Israeli ground forces began fighting in southern Lebanon, a communique from the army high command in Damascus said. It said that Syrian forces confronted Israeli tanks advancing on Syrian positions south of Jezzin and that an undisclosed number of them had been destroyed. (A14:1-5.)

title: COONEY CAMP CONCERNED ABOUT OFFICIALS
description: The Gerry Cooney camp says it is worried about the selection of officials, especially the referee, for the undefeated challenger's World Boxing Council heavyweight title fight with Larry Holmes here Friday night.

title: Name of the Game
description: The name of the sport may be football, says Billy Kilmer, but the name of the game is gambling. For that reason, according to the former Redskin quarterback and retired commissioner of an obscure, poverty-stricken league, the projected United States Football League will be successful.

title: New Computer From Zenith
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation today introduced a new series of desktop computers designed for the business, professional and original-equipment manufacturers' market.

title: COUNTIES VOICE FEAR OF COST ON ALIEN LEGALIZATION
description: Local officials from New York, Florida, California and other states warned today that Federal legislation granting legal status to illegal aliens would substantially increase health and welfare costs for local governments.

title: Georgia Head Testifies For College TV Control
description: Fred Davison, the president of Georgia, testified today that the National Collegiate Athletic Association's control of television rights to college football games deprived his school of a chance to earn maximum revenues.

title: Byrd Out of Race in Virginia
description: Harry F. Byrd Jr. of Virginia, who stirred a free-for-all by announcing plans last fall to retire in January at the end of his third term as the Senate's only independent, but then changed his mind, made it official tonight: He is out of the 1982 race, at least formally.

title: U.S. Copter Reported Attacked by Nicaragua
description: An unarmed Navy helicopter was attacked by machine-gun fire from a Nicaraguan patrol boat today in international waters, the State Department reported.

title: A BUSY DAY FOR PRIMARIES: PARTY CONTESTS IN 10 STATES
description: The busiest primary day of the spring will feature contests in 10 states Tuesday, with party nominations for six governorships and four Senate seats at stake.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A divided Lebanon must not be the outcome of this present violence.

title: KDT Auditors' Report
description: KDT Industries, a Massachusetts-based department store chain that had trouble meeting payments on some of its bank loans earlier this year, ''may be unable to continue as a going concern'' until it restores credit with some of its suppliers, the company's independent auditors, Peat Marwick Mitchell & Co., reported yesterday. KDT, which operates 190 stores, lost $52.1 million last year.

title: Alcohol and the Young
description: Even before they start drinking, many adolescents have notions about the pleasurable effects of alcohol and its ability to reduce tension, increase power, relieve worry, magically transform experiences and smooth interactions with others. The expectations about alcohol's effects are apparently acquired from family, peers, the media and by observing individuals who drink.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on May 25 about litigation over formaldehyde exposure misstated the amount of formaldehyde produced in the United States annually. It is more than eight billion pounds.

title: THE SOVIET SOLDIER
description: The Pentagon normally reduces comparisons of Soviet and American military power to ''bean counts,'' to use its own term. In the standard news magazine chart, this boils down to a row of Soviet tanks and a shorter row of American tanks. This chart usually includes a row of Soviet soldiers in sihouette and a shorter row of American soldiers in sihouette.

title: REPAIRING J-51 DAMAGE
description: The city's tax-giveaway development policy, which has operated for years without sensible controls, is finally facing a long-overdue scrutiny of its excesses and haphazardness.

title: Sperry in Japan
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation and the Sperry Corporation have signed an agreement to cooperate in the manufacture and marketing of computers, Mitsubishi said. Mitsubishi said it would supply Sperry with semiconductors and computer peripherals, and it would act as the marketer in Japan for Sperry Univac, Sperry's computer division. Sperry is based in New York.

title: Birmingham Rotary Directors Seek Change in Racial Policy
description: Directors of the Birmingham Rotary Club voted today to ask members to replace the club's current constitution, which stipulates an all-white policy, with a standard Rotary constitution making no mention of race.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In Percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 16.00 16.00 20.00 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 13.47 13.55 18.73 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.07 12.11 15.18 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.12 12.10 14.09 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 14.04 14.02 13.60 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 13.66 13.69 12.87 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 15.99 15.99 14.71 MUNICIPAL BONDS 13.46 13.37 11.28 6-MONTH SAVINGS 12.172 CERTIFICATES** * Split rate, 16.00-16.50 ** Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TRIAL TO OPEN IN MURDER OF POLICEMAN IN QUEENS
description: Opening arguments are expected this week in State Supreme Court in Queens in the trial of two men accused of killing one police officer and wounding another when the officers stopped their van on a Queens street in April 1981.

title: 6 NEW JUDGES ARE SWORN IN
description: Six new judges were sworn in yesterday in ceremonies at City Hall. Ira Beal, 50 years old, of Manhattan, and Robert G.M. Keating, 40, of Brooklyn, were sworn in as Criminal Court judges. Sworn in as Family Court judges were Judith Blum Sheindlin, 39, of the Bronx; George Jurow, 39, of Manhattan; Stanley Nason, 63, of Manhattan, and Clair Pearce, 49, of Brooklyn.

title: Moroccan Aide Visits Egypt
description: Morocco's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Boucetta, arrived here today on the first visit to Egypt by a senior Arab official since most Arab countries severed relations with Egypt in 1979 for making peace with Israel. Mr. Boucetta told reporters at the airport he was carrying a message from King Hassan II to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.

title: LIFE RESUMES IN NORTHERN ISRAEL AFTER 2 NIGHTS UNDER GROUND
description: As Israeli forces continued their attacks on Palestinian strongholds in Lebanon today, the rain of shells and rockets that had plagued Israeli towns and kibbutzim dwindled and ended, and residents of northern Israel came out of their shelters into a mixed mood of relief and concern.

title: OPERA: LATVIAN 'BANUTA'
description: Every East European ethnic enclave harbors at least one opera to serve as its banner of national pride. For Latvians, it is Alfreds Kalnins's ''Banuta.'' The New York Latvian Concert Choir, the Bronx Arts Ensemble and seven soloists presented ''Banuta'' at Carnegie Hall Saturday afternoon in what may be the first performance in North America.

title: High Court Rejects a Gas-Pricing Appeal
description: The Supreme Court today refused to halt Federal regulation of prices for natural gas that never leaves the producing state.

title: COALITION IN BONN PUT UNDER STRAIN
description: The Social Democratic Party acknowledged the deep psychological effect today of its defeat in the Hamburg state elections Sunday and said that the results created strong new pressures on the federal coalition in Bonn.

title: ABOVE ALL ELSE, HE IS 'THE PRESIDENT'S LAWYER'
description: On the fifth floor at the Justice Department, beyond the street noise that testifies to Government as a growth industry, the sounds in the Attorney General's office are muted, the walls paneled, the lamp cloisonne, the tennis trophy small. On the back of the tiger, as some have described this place, there is a calm not found in schools or prisons or refugee camps, although this office profoundly affects them all.

title: 2 Koreas Exchange Gunfire
description: North Korea and South Korea exchanged gunfire today for the third time this year across the demilitarized zone dividing the Korean peninsula, the Defense Ministry in Seoul said.

title: Bombings by Basque Rebels
description: Basque separatist guerrillas today claimed responsibility for bomb attacks on two banks and two power plants in the Basque province of Guipuzcoa Sunday. One person was injured in the attacks.

title: CRUSADERS BUILT THE CASTLE
description: Beaufort Castle, the Palestinian stronghold captured yesterday by the Israelis, has been a prized fortress since it was built by the Crusaders in the 12th century.

title: KOCH IS ASSAILED AS BADEN CASE OPENS
description: Mayor Koch was accused yesterday of dismissing Dr. Michael M. Baden as the city's Chief Medical Examiner three years ago knowing ''that some of the charges against him were untrue.''

title: ISRAEL AND THE P.L.O.: 7 YEARS OF STRIFE
description: 1970. Palestine Liberation Organization forces are ejected from Jordan and move into Lebanon. 1975. Lebanese civil war envelopes various factions of Moslems, Christians and Palestinians. There are frequent clashes between Israeli and Palestinian forces across the border.

title: Kobe Steel, Wheeling Tie
description: Kobe Steel Ltd., Japan's fifth-largest steelmaker, is considering an equity investment in the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation and a $140 million joint venture in making seamless pipe, according to Koukichi Takahashi, the company's president.

title: STAGE: '110 IN THE SHADE' 1963 MUSICAL, REVIVED
description: When ''110 in the Shade'' first reached Broadway in October 1963, the musical theater had just been through a disastrous season and seemed on its way to another equally unhappy one. ''110 in the Shade,'' the first Broadway score by Harvey Schmidt and Tom Jones, who had come to attention Off Broadway three years earlier with ''The Fantasticks,'' seemed to be a ray of hope. But before it could really build an audience, it was overwhelmed by the arrival of two blockbusters - ''Hello, Dolly!'' and Barbra Streisand in ''Funny Girl.''

title: BATTLER OF WIND AND RAIN
description: Early Saturday, Frank Mancuso drove his car to a service station for an oil change. As he walked the one mile home in a drizzle, he felt sure it would end in time for an afternoon of gardening. The light rain, he recalled, was rather pleasant.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: WITHIN 10 days of exposure to the bacterium that causes whooping cough, or pertussis, the child comes down with sneezing, red eyes and a mild cough that lasts about a week. It is like a cold that will not go away. Then, he develops paroxysms of violent coughing that usually come at night. As the child exhales, he gives several short coughs, and, as he inhales, there is a high-pitched crowing sound, or whoop. As the child gasps for breath and vital oxygen, the face can turn blue.

title: Bossy Outpolls Gretzky
description: There was no surprise in the announcement that the two top scorers in the National Hockey League, Wayne Gretzky and Mike Bossy, were named to the 1981-82 all-star team. But Gretzky, the most prolific scorer on the ice, was outscored by Bossy in the balloting of the Hockey Writers' Association.

title: BANK BRANCHING BILL IS PASSED BY ASSEMBLY
description: After years of turning down similar measures, the Assembly passed a bill today that would allow out-of-state banks to open branches or acquire banks in New York provided that New Yorkbased banks were permitted to do the same in their states.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS LEADERS PLAN NEW TENT CITY NEAR WHITE HOUSE
description: Black leaders announced plans today for a new tent city in Washington and called on President Reagan to throw more weight behind extension of the Voting Rights Act and to create a million new jobs this summer.

title: FLYING POCKET WINS YOUTHFUL
description: Flying Pocket, a New York bred, won the $54,900 Youthful Stakes for 2-year-olds by a length yesterday on a muddy track at Belmont Park. It was his third straight triumph.

title: Stock Index Futures Assailed in Congress
description: The proliferation of stock index futures and options could stymie corporate efforts to raise money and undermine the economy, Representative John D. Dingell, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MUSEUM MILE

title: WELFARE BENEFITS TIED TO TAX FORM
description: The Reagan Administration, trying to cut what it estimates is $140 million in waste, will require four million welfare recipients to let the Government see Federal tax information about their outside income, a top Administration official said today.

title: RUHRGAS SAYS SOVIET IS SURE ON GAS LINE DESPITE U.S. CURB
description: Ruhrgas A.G., the West German gas company, has disclosed that it received assurances from the Soviet Union that deliveries of Siberian natural gas to Western Europe through a controversial gas pipeline would begin on schedule in late 1984 despite United States sanctions hindering delivery of essential pipeline equipment.

title: New Zealand Fuel Project
description: Two Japanese banks and seven banks of other countries plan to lend $1.7 billion to help finance construction of a synthetic gasoline plant in New Zealand, banking sources said today. The agreement may be signed in two months, they added.

title: Keep Shielding the Public Tube
description: The House should sustain the Senate's wise approval of $24.4 million more for public broadcasting. That would bring the year's Federal contribution to $130 million, a comparative driblet in the budgetary barrel.

title: Maple Leaves Hospital
description: Eddie Maple went home yesterday with his fractured rib, bruised kidney and memories of the Belmont Stakes, which he watched on television Saturday from his bed in Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I. Because he took a spill Friday, he was forced to miss his regular turn on Conquistador Cielo. For a moment when the colt was at the head of the stretch, he said in a telephone interview, he imagined that he was riding instead of Laffit Pincay Jr.

title: Prices Steady On Spot Oil
description: Spot oil prices barely moved yesterday despite the outbreak of fighting in Lebanon. But oil futures prices on the New York Marcantile Exchange moved up sharply in heavy trading.

title: TEXT OF STATE DEPT. STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of a statement issued today by the State Department on the fighting in Lebanon: Special to the New York Times

title: 'STAR TREK II' SETS MARK FOR SALES AT OPENING
description: ''Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan,'' which opened Friday in 1,621 theaters, earned $14,347,221, the largest opening weekend in movie history. Paramount's ''Star Trek II'' outgrossed the previous champion, last summer's ''Superman II,'' by $250,000. Paramount thus recaptured the opening-week championship held by the original ''Star Trek'' before it was won by ''Superman II.''

title: Rolling Stone Owner Ousts New Publisher
description: Peter Bonanni, publisher for three months of the Rolling Stone magazine, was discharged last week by Jann Wenner, the owner.

title: Accounts
description: * Renfield Importers to Brainreserve, for Piper Heidsieck Champagne.

title: Japan Escapes Rise in Jobless
description: Unemployment crept up last winter not only in the United States but also in its main industrial rivals, except for Japan, according to figures made available today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: BROOKLYN'S DUNSTON NO. 1 DRAFT CHOICE
description: Shawon Dunston, a 19-year-old infielder from Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, yesterday became the first player from the New York area to be the No.1 selection in baseball's summer free agent draft.

title: Wrapped Up, in a Car
description: Don't accuse the Supreme Court of sticking rigidly to precedent. Its decision last week to give the police more power in automobile searches overruled one handed down all of 11 months ago. Justice Potter Stewart delivered the Court's original judgment, but he retired the next day. His replacement, Justice Sandra O'Connor, lined up with a new majority, some other Justices had earlier doubts confirmed and, presto, new law.

title: The U.N. Today; June 8, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL

title: DOW OFF 0.95, CLOSING AT 804.03
description: The stock market retreated yesterday as several negative factors continued to keep investors on the sidelines, including high interest rates, the gloomy economic outlook, a Federal budget impasse and the intensifying Middle East crisis.

title: CHAMBER: ZUKERMAN LEADS A THREE-COMPOSER PROGRAM
description: The new, bigger, more orchestral, steely stringed St. Paul Chamber Orchestra continued its serenading Saturday with a Haydn-Stravinsky-Beethoven program in Carnegie Hall, playing under the baton of its music director, Pinchas Zukerman. In spite of the fact that the evening was designed to showcase the talents of two soloists -the violinist Cho-liang Lin in Haydn's Concerto No. 1 in C, and the pianist Jean-Bernard Pommier in Beethoven's Concerto No. 4 in G - the program proved a substantial and intriguing one, even though hamstrung by the orchestra's less-than-admirable ensemble and Mr. Zukerman's less-than-compelling conducting.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. DENIES 315 VISAS FOR U.N. DISARMAMENT SESSION
description: The Justice Department said today that it had denied visas to 315 people who wanted to attend the special United Nations disarmament session and related activities that began today.

title: EAST BLOC ENERGY: PRECEDENT OF WESTERN CAUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. WOULD RELAX RULE ON CHILD HEALTH EXAMS
description: The Department of Health and Human Services has drafted regulations that would permit states to curtail or eliminate many benefits provided under a preventive health program for children.

title: Clevepak-Torin Merger
description: The Torin Corporation of Torrington, Conn., said yesterday that it had accepted a tender offer of $25 a share from the Clevepak Corporation of White Plains. Based on the number of shares outstanding at Dec. 31, the offer values Torin at $25.7 million.

title: SCIENTISTS AT BELL LABS NEEDN'T WORRY
description: To the Editor:

title: ANOMALIES MARK PRIMARY CAMPAIGN FOR GOVERNOR IN ARKANSAS
description: Joe Purcell, a taciturn politician with a halting manner of public speaking, has imperiled the comeback of former Gov. Bill Clinton, the former Rhodes Scholar who was defeated in the Republican sweep of 1980.

title: Eagleton and Kennedy Urge Donovan Hearing
description: Democratic Senators Thomas Eagleton of Missouri and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts have asked for Senate hearings on whether the Federal Bureau of Investigation withheld information during confirmation hearings for Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: Tempest
description: Henry Hill, the Arizona physicist who is boldly challenging Einstein's theory of general relativity, recently walked into a lions' den of Einsteinian physicists at the New York Academy of Sciences. Surprisingly, he was not eaten, and the talk turned peaceably to cups of tea.

title: Lawsuit Asks Court to Void Veto Power Over F.T.C. Rules
description: Two consumer groups have asked the Federal District Court here to declare unconstitutional the 1980 law by which Congress gave itself authority to veto rules of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Bridge: Defenders Must Make Use Of Opponents' Difficulties
description: It often happens that the declarer has communication problems. He can see the danger that one hand or the other will lack sufficient entries, or lack any entry at all.

title: 2 PORTS ARE KEY P.L.O. CENTERS
description: Sidon and Tyre, the two Mediterreanean port cities that appear to be prime objectives of the Israeli push into Lebanon, have long been regarded as key centers of activity for the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Market Place; Analysts Differ On Teledyne
description: ALTHOUGH Teledyne Inc., the Los Angeles-based conglomerate, has never paid a cash dividend, its shareholders had little reason to complain. In 1974, the issue traded as low as 3 1/8, adjusted for numerous stock dividends, and by mid-1981 it climbed to a record price of 174 3/4.

title: Metromedia Inc.  Plans Acquisition
description: Metromedia Inc., the nation's fourth-largest broadcast operator, announced that it had agreed in principle to acquire three commmon carriers, Zip-Call Inc. of Boston, the Radio Broadcasting Company of Philadelphia and the Rogers Radio Communication Services Inc. of Chicago, for a total of $86.5 million.

title: SYRIAN JETS AND GUNS JOIN LEBANON BATTLE
description: Israeli tanks and infantry captured Beaufort Castle and several other Palestinian guerrilla strongholds in southern Lebanon Monday and began sweeping northward toward Palestinian-controlled towns and villages just south of Beirut.

title: RALLIES IN NEW JERSEY WIND UP RACES FOR U.S. SENATE
description: The Republican and Democratic races in New Jersey for the United States Senate drew to a close today with a round of rallies and last-minute campaign appearances. Two Republicans and nine Democrats are seeking their parties' nominations in the primary election Tuesday.

title: LARGEST SOLAR FLARE SINCE '78 ERUPTS
description: A huge solar flare shot from the sun's surface Sunday, releasing more energy than the earth uses in a year, scientists said today.

title: SCHOLS AUDIT FINDS WASTE IN PURCHASING AND FACULTY RECORDS
description: The Board of Education wastes at least $1 million a year buying unneeded textbooks because no proper records are kept, according to the New York City Comptroller. The official, Harrison J. Goldin, also said $10.4 million worth of the schools' audio-visual equipment was either missing or not catalogued.

title: DON R. BERLIN, 83, A DESIGNER OF AIRCRAFT FOR WORLD WAR II
description: Don R. Berlin, a retired aeronautical industry executive and a leading designer of military aircraft, died May 17 at Riddle Hospital in Middletown, Pa., after a long illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Glen Mills, Pa.

title: 3 Prison Officials Resign In F.B.I. Investigation
description: An investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, purportedly into a $300,000 shakedown of inmates at the Terminal Island Federal prison, has prompted the resignations of three prison officials.

title: Tentative Pact Ends Strike at P.S.E. & G.
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company reached a tentative agreement today with more than 4,000 striking electrical workers, ending a 38-day strike, company officials said.

title: A TOLL FREE NUMBER FOR FLOOD INSURANCE
description: Connecticut residents seeking general information about the National Flood Insurance Program - which covers homes, businesses and their contents -can call, without charge, (800) 638-6620, from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M., Monday through Friday.

title: SENATE APPROVES LOFT-CONVERSION BILL
description: The State Senate today passed a bill that would legalize the status of tens of thousands of tenants who live in converted industrial lofts in New York City.

title: Bendix Chief Marries Ex-Official Who Quit
description: William M. Agee, the chairman of the Bendix Corporation, and Mary Cunningham, the former Bendix executive who quit her post after a burst of publicity about her relationship with Mr. Agee, have been married, the company announced today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: While some said that Nancy Reagan committed high-fashion heresy last week by wearing black s atin knickers with a chiffon overskirt at the American Embassy d inner in Paris last Thursday night, others weren't so sure. But it w as clearly a sign of her growing political astuteness that the j ewelry she wore - described as rubies and diamonds - was neither c arbon nor corundum. It was pure glass, a bit of upscale sleight of h and from the New York costume jewelry designer Kenneth Jay Lane.

title: CELEBRATION IN ART AND RITUAL
description: On her wedding day in 1928, Constance Emily Millard of Elizabeth, N.J., saved everything: a pair of shoes with the imprint of a silver sixpence that had been fastened on them, bouquet fragments, a garter, stockings, a formal portrait and newspaper clippings that she filed in her wedding book.

title: Unimation Has Loss for Period
description: Unimation, the maker of robots, reported yesterday that it suffered a net loss of $257,000 for its third quarter ended April 30, in contrast with a profit of $234,000, or 6 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year.

title: People
description: * Gary Roberts promoted to executive vice president, Wells, Rich, Greene/ New York.

title: Phelps Dodge Officer To Take College Post
description: ''This will be about my fourth career,'' said L. William Seidman, 61, who has announced plans to become dean of the College of Business Administration at Arizona State University effective Sept. 1. The college is one of the largest business schools, with some 11,000 undergraduate and graduate students.

title: THE BRAVES' GENTLE GIANT
description: The revival of the Atlanta Braves may be one of the mysteries of the baseball season to some people, but not to Claudell Washington. ''All of us ride on the wings of Murphy,'' he says. Dale Bryan Murphy, that is. At age 26 and at 6 feet 5 inches, Murphy is one of the youngest power hitters and tallest center fielders. And he probably is the ranking candidate to lead the majors this year in home runs and smiles.

title: ABC MOVES UP NEW EARLY NEWSCAST
description: TV's new early-morning newscast, originally scheduled to begin next September, will start July 5 instead. The reason, sources within ABC said, is to blunt the debut on that day of ''Early Today,'' an extension of NBC-TV's ''Today'' program, beginning at 6:30 A.M. ''It's very straightforward,'' said one ABC news producer. ''One doesn't let the competitor have that much of a head start.''

title: FEAR DRIVES TO SUBURBS
description: ''Things like this just don't happen out here,'' said Gloria McDonald, holding the hand of her 3-year-old daughter at the Morton Village Plaza shopping center. ''They do now,'' Lisa Caputo responded.

title: EATING LESS MAY BE THE KEY TO LIVING BEYOND 100 YEARS
description: IN searching for ways to extend the human life span and to ward off the diseases of old age, some scientists find themselves focusing not on enhancing diet but rather on limiting it.

title: Shelf Registration
description: The Justice Department urged the Securities and Exchange Commission today to make permanent its temporary ''shelf registration'' rule. This lets issuers sell securities over a two-year period rather than right after they are registered, the traditional method. Waiting for a favorable market reduces the cost of raising capital.

title: THE 'INFERNAL MACHINES' ADULTS PLAY WITH
description: To the Editor:

title: Claireve Grandjouan, 52, Dies; Taught Archeology at Hunter
description: Claireve Grandjouan, professor of archeology and former chairman of classical and Oriental studies at Hunter College, died last Tuesday at her home in Manhattan after an illness of several months. She was 52 years old.

title: BUDDHIST-LED RALLY IS HELD AT THE U.N.
description: Hundreds of marchers who had walked across the United States in support of the United Nations session on disarmament converged in New York yesterday beating drums and chanting a Japanese prayer for peace.

title: Savings Yields Rising Today
description: Increasing interest rates on Treasury securities auctioned yesterday raised the yields that banks and savings institutions may pay on various kinds of savings certificates.

title: U.S. AVOIDS CRITICISM OF ISRAELI ASSAULT
description: The State Department said today that Israel ''will have to withdraw its forces from Lebanon,'' but it refrained from criticizing the assault against military bases of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: OPERA: 10 BLACK MALE SINGERS
description: In this paper's Sunday Magazine not long ago, Harold C. Schonberg rejoiced in the riches of opera's black soprano voices and lamented that so few male black singers matched them in caliber. Sunday night in Alice Tully Hall, 10 black tenors and baritones from Independent Black Opera Singers Inc. sought to prove Mr. Schonberg wrong. The program covered a lot of history and many styles - including arias and ensemble pieces ranging from Purcell and Handel through Mozart and Rossini and on to the heavier drama of Verdi, Puccini and Strauss.

title: A Mozambique Official Defects to South Africa
description: Mozambique's national security director defected to South Africa today and said on South African television that the Soviet Union was trying to dominate his country to gain access to the riches of southern Africa.

title: Warner-Lambert to Acquire IMED at Cost of $465 Million
description: The Warner-Lambert Company, a major pharmaceutical concern, said yesterday that it would acquire all the shares of the IMED Corporation, a San Diego-based maker of medical electronic equipment, for $465 million, or $163 a share.

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 8, 1982; Companies
description: The Bowery and the Emigrant savings banks are in danger of failing by January if they do not get Government aid, Congress was told by Alan R. Cohen, acting state banking superintendent. Testifying in favor of Federal aid to the thrift industry, Mr. Cohen listed the 20 most troubled savings banks in New York State. (Page D1.)

title: FLOOD CLEANUP TASK STARTS IN CONNECTICUT
description: Connecticut is bailing out after a weekend of flooding that left at least 12 persons dead or missing and caused millions of dollars in damage. Dams broke, bridges and roadways were washed out and homes and automobiles floated away as the storm left up to 11 inches of rain in some areas.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: South St. Museum Keeps Watch on South Atlantic

title: CONNECTICUT BEGINS STRUGGLE TO RECUPERATE FROM FLOODS
description: Connecticut began bailing out today as state and local officials struggled to put a price tag on what they said was ''astronomical'' damage left from a weekend of torrential rain.

title: BIG SEOUL BANK GIVES DETAILS OF A NEW FINANCIAL SCANDAL
description: In a further twist to a billion-dollar financial scandal involving relatives of President Chun Doo Hwan, a South Korean bank has announced details of a $12 million swindle by a bank manager who committed suicide, Seoul newspapers reported.

title: POLAND SAID TO THREATEN DEFAULT IF AID IS DENIED
description: The Polish authorities have warned Western banks that Poland will not be able to pay any of the $2.1 billion in interest due this year on its $14 billion in foreign bank debt unless the West lends Warsaw more money, banking sources reported today.

title: YANKEES NEED LIFT OF SPIRITS
description: Butch Wynegar poked his head out of the training room at Yankee Stadium after Sunday's 14-1 loss to the Royals, saw a crush of reporters heading for his locker and retreated back into the crowded room, an off-limits area of the clubhouse.

title: PIRATES TO METS, 4-3, IN 12
description: A pitcher-batter confrontation between two of the more significant players in the National League, Neil Allen of the Mets and Bill Madlock of the Pittsburgh Pirates, wound up in favor of the batter in the 12th inning last night at Shea Stadium.

title: 8 U.N. Personnel Killed
description: The United Nations said today that seven trainee teachers with a United Nations program in Lebanon and their instructor were killed when their bus was hit by a rocket near Beirut on Saturday. The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees said the trainees, all women, were from the agency's training center in Siblin.

title: Bloc to Meet in Budapest
description: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov of the Soviet Union flew to Budapest today for a meeting of the Soviet-led Council for Mutual Economic Cooperation, the press agency Tass said.

title: BAD START FOR START
description: Huge land-based missiles carry 70 percent of Soviet warheads, according to a Pravda editorial that rejected President Reagan's arms reduction proposals. But only 20 percent of American warheads are land-based.

title: Chess: Netherlands' Jan Timman Awarded a Brilliancy Prize
description: You never know what you'll get when an early winner and a slow starter meet - it could even be a brilliancy prize game. Lajos Portisch, Hungary's top grandmaster, had ripped off 6 points in the first seven rounds of the Phillips & Drew International Tournament in London. In that same span, Jan Timman, the Netherlands' top grandmaster, had scored a lowly three.

title: CRIME SEEN ON THE RISE IN ZAMBIA
description: Lusaka's international school is the place where most foreigners living in the Zambian capital send their children, and at lunchtime each day a traffic jam forms as parents wait for their offspring.

title: Leaves, Fig and Tea; Enlightenment
description: ''Would you like to sin with Elinor Glyn on a tiger skin?'' asked a ditty prevalent in the time of Lord Curzon, whose friend she was. ''Or would you prefer to err with her on some other fur?'' We have erred not with Mrs. Glyn but with two other enlightened women of the time.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ON April 27, Rebecca Taylor, acting principal of Intermediate School 44 on Manhattan's Upper West Side, was notified that she had been denied tenure.

title: Polaroid Product
description: The Polaroid Corporation said that it had developed a prototype 8-by-10-inch color film recorder that transforms video signals into full-color instant photographs. The device, which can be used in computer-related displays, is expected to be available this fall at a suggested price of $6,000.

title: BRITISH SAID TO TAKE RIDGE CLOSE TO STANLEY AIRFIELD
description: Royal Marine commandos have captured a ridge only five miles north of the center of Stanley, the main Argentine garrison in the Falkland Islands, and overlooking its vital airstrip, a correspondent at the battlefront reported tonight.

title: CATHOLIC POPULATION SAID TO HAVE REACHED 51,207,579 IN 1981
description: The number of Roman Catholic parishes in the United States increased by 19 last year to a record total of 18,903, according to The Official Catholic Directory, which is scheduled for publication Thursday.

title: Comark Is Under Study
description: The California Department of Corporations is examining the financial condition and record-keeping methods of Comark, a Government securities firm that is late in filing its 1981 financial statement, Steven Gourley, deputy commissioner, said today.

title: ARGENTINA REPORTS RETREAT BY BRITISH IN CLASH
description: Argentina sought to keep an optimistic tone today as it awaited a British assault against Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands.

title: 3D 'DUKES OF HAZZARD' STAR BALKS AT RETURN TO JOB
description: At least three stars of CBS-TV's ''The Dukes of Hazzard'' have indicated that they will not report back to work this month, casting into doubt the future of one of television's most popular and profitable series.

title: Talking Business with Frank Barnako Jr. of video group; Video Cassette Developments
description: The video cassette retail industry seemed to spring up overnight. In the last few years more than 6,000 stores opened to sell and rent prerecorded tapes of movies. But now the business faces an uncertain future.

title: Reform Group Backs Lehrer for Surrogate
description: Civil Court Judge Edward H. Lehner Jr. won the support of the Democratic Party's reform faction last night in the race for Surrogate of Manhattan.

title: No. 4 in Long Play Runs, 'Deathtrap' Will Close
description: ''Deathtrap'' will close June 27 after 1,809 performances, one of the most successful runs in Broadway history. The comedy-thriller by Ira Levin, which opened at the Music Box Theater on Feb. 26, 1978, to respectable, but not unanimous, reviews, and is now at the Biltmore, is Broadway's fourth-longest-running straight play.

title: NLT WINS ROUND IN BID TO ACQUIRE AMERICAN GENERAL
description: A Federal judge in Houston cleared the way yesterday for the NLT Corporation to press its bid for the American General Corporation. The move frees the Nashville-based insurance company to pursue its innovative takeover strategy - offering early payment for a limited number of shares.

title: CAPTURED CASTLE IS VISITED BY BEGIN
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin flew to Beaufort Castle in southern Lebanon on Monday to meet with Defense Minister Ariel Sharon shortly after the castle was captured by Israeli forces.

title: FATHER FIGURE TO BEST POETS
description: Kenneth Rexroth, poet, author, critic and translator of Chinese, Japanese and classic Greek poetry, died Sunday at his home in Montecito, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: 'Yogi' Troubled at the Plate
description: ONE day recently Bill Madlock, the Pittsburgh Pirate third baseman, came into the clubhouse from the field after checking the weather at Three Rivers Stadium. It had been raining.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Financial Corp., which is seeking representation on the board of the Penn Central Corp., said it had increased its stake in Penn Central to the equivalent of 24.2 percent of common stock.

title: Turkish Envoy in Lisbon Is Killed by Gunman
description: A gunman killed a Turkish diplomat and seriously wounded the envoy's wife near his home outside Lisbon today. A group calling itself Justice Commandos Against Armenian Genocide claimed responsibility.

title: SHOOTINGS BY HINCKLEY TERMED A COOL DECISION
description: A prosecution psychiatrist testified today that John W. Hinckley Jr. made a cool, rational decision to shoot President Reagan because of his ''long-standing interest in becoming famous without working'' and his desire to gain the attention of Jodie Foster, a film actress.

title: CITY BALLET: 'DIVERTISSEMENTS' BY DENMARK'S BOURNONVILLE
description: COPENHAGEN is a whole ocean away, yet seeing the New York City Ballet dance ''Bournonville Divertissements'' on a damp gloomy night suggested one reason why the Danes treasure August Bournonville, their great 19th-century choreographer. Bournonville's ballets are so sunny that they can brighten the longest, wettest and darkest of Scandinavian nights.

title: IN ROYAL STYLE, THE REAGANS SETTLE IN
description: President and Mrs. Reagan were guests tonight of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip at a private dinner in the Crimson Room, the small state dining room in the private apartment of Windsor Castle, the official residence of British sovereigns for more than 800 years.

title: Report on Miami Riots Cites Isolation of Blacks
description: The United States Civil Rights Commission today attributed the 1980 race riots in Miami to the failure of the public and private sectors to meet the needs of Dade County blacks.

title: Memorial for Susan Bloch
description: A memorial service for Susan Bloch, former public relations director of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center, will be held at the Roundabout Theater, Stage One, 333 West 23d Street, next Monday at 11 A.M. Miss Bloch, who died May 10, operated her own agency and represented the Roundabout Theater, the Phoenix Theater and the Chelsea Theater Center.

title: Flights to Scandinavia
description: Air Florida will begin service between Miami and Scandinavia on Oct. 1, the airline announced today. It plans a weekly nonstop flight to Stockholm and a weekly flight to Copenhagen via Oslo.

title: TERRORISM CHEST
description: To the Editor:

title: A VISIT TO WINDSOR CAPS MONTHS OF PREPARATION
description: During his brief visit to Britain, President Reagan will be spending most of his time - as well as his two nights - at Windsor Castle, a rambling stone fortress that was begun more than 900 years ago.

title: SALVADOR LAND PROGRAM DISPUTED
description: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador, Deane R. Hinton, said here today that assertions that El Salvador had stopped its land redistribution program constituted ''a bum rap.''

title: POPE, ITALIANS AND BRITISH QUEEN MEET REAGANS IN DAY OF PAGEANTRY
description: President Reagan flew to Rome today for a six-hour visit that included meetings with Italian leaders and Pope John Paul II. Late in the day Queen Elizabeth welcomed him to Britain with a gleaming guard of honor on parade at Windsor Castle.

title: AEG-Telefunken To Lay Off 1,000
description: Telefunken, West Germany's largest electrical products company, has announced that it is closing a washing machine manufacturing plant in Tubingen that employs 1,000 workers. AEG said other units of its money-losing consumer goods manufacturing division would probably also be closed but did not specify.

title: 9 Youngsters Facing Trial by Guatemala
description: Nine youngsters accused of belonging to a guerrilla organization will be tried on charges of participating in leftist subversive activities, the President, Gen. Efrain Rios Montt said.

title: ANGLO AMERICAN'S NEXT CHIEF
description: To smooth the way for his successor at the helm of the Anglo American Corporation, Harry F. Oppenheimer made a point last week of announcing he would be vacating not only the chairman's post at year-end but also the seat on the board of directors he has held for 48 years.

title: Winners of Tonys
description: Winners of Tony Awards for the 1981-82 Broadway season are: PLAY: ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' by David Edgar, based on Charles Dickens's novel. MUSICAL: ''Nine.''

title: STRING RECITAL: BEETHOVEN
description: THE Beethoven Society brought the Composers String Quartet to Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon. The music was for three, four and five string players and included the Trio in C minor (Op. 9, No. 3) and the C Major Quintet (Op.29) - both showing a young Beethoven still operating within the bounds of good behavior -and then the F-major Quartet from Opus 59, with its abrupt disregard for stylistic niceties.

title: Playboy to Sell Book Division
description: Playboy Enterprises announced that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its book publishing operations to the Berkley/ Jove and Putnam publishing groups for an undisclosed sum.

title: N.F.L. PAY AVERAGE OF $150,000 IS PROPOSED
description: The average player salary in the National Football League would nearly double this season, to $150,000, under a central demand outlined formally for the first time today in negotiations between the league and the N.F.L. Players Association.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What causes hair to be thick or thin?

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Good Carryout Salads

title: TO DEMEAN A WITNESS DEMEANS JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: SYRIANS VOWING TO HOLD TROOPS IN PRESENT LINES
description: Syria said again today that it intended to maintin its military forces in their positions in Lebanon despite growing Israeli military and political pressure for them to withdraw.

title: British Cut Rates
description: Leading British banks today cut their key lending rates to 12 1/2 percent from 13 percent, giving a lift to recession-hit industry and the stock market. The reduction in the rates, equivalent to United States prime rates, was announced first by National Westminster Bank, followed by the other major banks. Share prices rose on the London Stock Exchange, with The Financial Times index of 30 leading stocks rising 2.5 points, to 595.1, near its record high of 597.3 set a year ago.

title: LET THE PUNISHMENT ANTICIPATE THE CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: RACIAL HYPE FOR A TITLE FIGHT
description: Once, Eddie Davis stood in the middle of the Madison Square Garden ring and looked down, and there was Gerry Cooney lying at his feet, knocked out. Eight years later, Davis looks up at Cooney, now his stablemate, and sees Cooney's biggest fight turning into somewhat of a color war.

title: Stravinsky Celebration To Help Public Library
description: A Stravinsky Centennial Celebration will take place June 18, marking the 100th anniversary of the birth of Igor Stravinsky, to benefit the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library.

title: IRAN'S FOREIGN MINISTER URGES MOSLEMS TO ACT
description: The Foreign Minister of Iran called yesterday for a united Islamic front to oppose Israel's incursion into Lebanon but he stopped short of saying his country would go to war against Israel.

title: 'Amateurs,' on Parade
description: In her outspoken way, Jeane Kirkpatrick has put it exactly right. Americans do behave like ''a bunch of amateurs'' at the United Nations, where she is chief U.S. delegate. And not just this last time, when Secretary Haig, apparently out of pique, failed to inform Mrs. Kirkpatrick in time that she was supposed to abstain on a Falkland resolution.

title: NATIONAL RURAL WATER STUDY CAUTIONS ON CONTAMINANTS
description: Sixty-three percent of rural Americans, nearly 39 million people, drink water that could be unsafe, according to a Congressionally mandated study released yesterday.

title: BUDD SEEKS TO BLOCK PURCHASE BY M.T.A. OF CARS IN MONTREAL
description: The Budd Company sought an injunction in Federal District Court yesterday to stop the Metropolitan Transportation Authority from buying 825 IRT subway cars from a Canadian manufacturer.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard THE FROG WHO DARED TO CROAK. By Richard Sennett. 182 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95.

title: HARVARD DEAN SEEKS SHIFT IN MEDICAL STUDIES
description: The dean of Harvard Medical School, responding to recent criticisms of medical and premedical education, has proposed radical changes in the way students are trained to become doctors.

title: SAFETY AGENCY TO FOCUS ON HAZARDOUS WORK
description: The Occupational Health and Safety Administration is moving slowly over a broad front to reduce safety reporting requirements and expand its new system of directing its limited inspection staff to industries most likely to have accidents.

title: THE PHONEY WAR
description: Annals of Telephoning: Chapter XLVII - A Crisis of Etiquette: 1. Upon learning of Argentina's plan to invade the Falkland Islands, President Reagan dialed President Galtieri and urged him to be a good fellow and reconsider. President Galtieri urged President Reagan to go jump in the lake. The exchange raised acute questions of telephone etiquette that were to have profound and lasting effects.

title: VOLCKER IS HONORED AS 1,024 GRADUATE AT PRINCETON
description: Princeton University awarded 1,024 bachelor's degrees today to the class of 1982 in a 90-minute ceremony on the lawn outside Nassau Hall, where the university has bade its students farewell since before the Revolutionary War.

title: 2 SEIZED IN $100,000 EXTORTION
description: Two men were arrested yesterday and accused of stealing $10,000 and then extorting $100,000 as a kidnapping ransom last January from the owner of a Chinese restaurant, according to Queens District Attorney John J. Santucci. An accomplice, a woman, fled the country, he said.

title: Archbishop Says Pope's Visit To Argentina Is Nonpolitical
description: Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, Pope John Paul's chief tour organizer, arrived here today and said the Pope's forthcoming visit to Argentina would be strictly pastoral.

title: DOCUMENTARY ON ANTINUCLEAR ACTIVIST
description: LIKE all good documentaries, Mary Benjamin's ''Eight Minutes to Midnight'' is defined by its subject, in this case the intense, profoundly worried personality of Dr. Helen Caldicott, the president of Physicians for Social Responsibility and one of the most effectively outspoken antinuclear activists in this country.

title: IDAHO SHERIFF SAYS JAIL HAD MONITOR
description: The cell where a teen-ager was beaten to death on Memorial Day was equipped with an audio system for monitoring by jail guards, the sheriff of Ada County said today, but the device was broken.

title: NEW JOHNSON LIBRARY EXHIBIT FOCUSES ON IMAGES OF VIETNAM
description: In the center of the new exhibit at the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library, its first to cover Vietnam in depth, there is a yellow corduroy armchair that presumably evokes the habitat of the typical American television viewer.

title: Economic Scene; France Under Mitterrand
description: PARIS ASWING through West Germany, Britain and France, followed by three days in the rarefied atmosphere of the Versailles summit conference, leaves one convinced that anybody not confused about the state of the Western economies simply does not recognize the scope of the problem.

title: Griffith Opens Purse
description: Calvin Griffith, the owner of the Minnesota Twins, who has been criticized for dealing away his high-priced players in favor of lower-paid rookies, has given Kent Hrbek, Tom Brunansky and Randy Johnson pay raises of almost $8,500 each.

title: TEXT OF U.N. RESOLUTION
description: Following is the text of the Security Council resolution on Lebanon that was vetoed tonight by the United States:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''On distant islands in the South Atlantic young men are fighting for Britain.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE MODESTLY
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday as weak investor demand for notes and bonds led traders to reduce prices. In the money markets, meanwhile, rates rose about a tenth of a percentage point or less for securities due in less than a year.

title: U.S. Insurance Office To Deal With Claims
description: The National Flood Insurance Program has opened an office at the Ramada Inn, 201 North Washington Street, North Haven, to handle claims resulting from the weekend flooding in Connecticut.

title: McEnroe and Connors Win London Matches
description: Top-seeded John McEnroe and second-seeded Jimmy Connors scored straight-set victories in first-round play today in a $175,000 grass-court tournament at Queen's Club.

title: POLICE AND ATOM RALLY'S SPONSORS COOPERATE
description: Like two families planning a wedding, the New York City Police and the sponsors of Saturday's disarmament demonstration have been meeting day after day to check -and sometimes tactfully negotiate - the final arrangements.

title: MAYOR WILSON WINS G.O.P. SENATE RACE ON COAST
description: Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego was the victor tonight in a hotly contested race for the Republican nomination to the United States Senate. On the Democratic side, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. won the nomination, as had been expected.

title: Harriet T. Righter, 104; Led Scrabble Company
description: Harriet T. Righter, the former president of the Selchow & Righter Company, manufacturers of Scrabble and Parcheesi, died yesterday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 104 years old and was a lifelong resident of Brooklyn.

title: Brewers Spike Punch
description: The Milwaukee Brewer players are calling themselves ''Harvey's Wallbangers,'' and the catch-phrase has proved so popular that club officials plan to seek a trademark on it. The nickname is a reference to Harvey Kuenn, the Brewers' batting instructor, who was named the team's interim manager to succeed Bob Rodgers, dismissed last Wednesday. ''Just like the drink, Harvey Wallbangers,'' said Cecil Cooper, the Brewers' first baseman, who first used the expression, ''we keep banging 'em off the walls.''

title: ASSESSING SEASON'S JUST ARRIVED FRUIT
description: IT'S been a rough ride for many of them, but the first fruits of the season - apricots, peaches, cherries, blueberries, raspberries and strawberries - are starting to arrive in local stores. A hard winter and recent rains may mean smaller crops this year. Freezing weather in North Carolina and Georgia earlier this spring, for instance, could cut the blueberry and peach crops by a third.

title: N.F.L. Talks Draw Blank
description: An eight-hour bargaining session between National Football League players and management ended tonight with neither side speaking to the other in the last hour.

title: Rockwell Opens Plant
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it had opened a plant near Glasgow, Scotland, to produce valves for the oil, petrochemical and power generation industries.

title: HAIG SUGGESTS EXPANDED U.N. FORCE AND SMALLER SYRIAN ROLE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that an expanded United Nations peacekeeping force and ''some lessening'' of Syria's 25,000-man military force in Lebanon should be part of a ''comprehensive solution'' in Lebanon after a ceasefire.

title: KROL ASSESSES POSITION IN DISARMAMENT MOVEMENT
description: To some leaders, he seems to symbolize broad support for the nuclear disarmament movement: John Cardinal Krol, a prince of the Roman Catholic Church and an associate of Presidents, long regarded here as a conservative and autocratic prelate.

title: FOOD MARKET GETS NEW LEASE ON LIFE
description: A farmer's market in the heart of Philadelphia has been converted from a moribund institution into a bustling bazaar by an eclectic mix of immigrant storekeepers, young entrepreneurs and managers of generations-old businesses.

title: Hibernia Oil Find Cited
description: The Hibernia oilfield, off Canada's east coast, may harbor more than 1.5 billion barrels of recoverable petroleum, according to a study by the government of the province of Newfoundland and petroleum consultants.

title: U.P.I. SALE SET UP BY BANKERS TRUST
description: The sale of United Press International, the country's second largest news agency, to a newly formed and little-known group of entrepreneurs was arranged by the Bankers Trust Company of New York, a vice president of the bank said yesterday.

title: BRITAIN REPORTS A FRIGATE DAMAGED IN RAID BY JETS
description: Argentine warplanes bombed and damaged the British frigate Plymouth and two landing ships tonight, causing at least five casualties, the Defense Ministry announced.

title: 59 Children of Theater Will Graduate Today
description: When the 59 graduates of the class of '82 of the Professional Children's School receive their diplomas today, there will be at least one family event in the proceedings. Martin Charnin, lyricistdirector of ''Annie,'' who will hand out the diplomas, will give one to his daughter, Sasha, a member of the graduating class.

title: TV: HOUSEMAN AS HE DIRECTS 'LEAR'
description: ''STAGES: HOUSEMAN DIRECTS LEAR,'' on WNET-TV at 9 o'clock this evening, is a behind-the-scenes portrait of actors and acting. Houseman is John Houseman, the veteran actor perhaps best known for his performances in ''The Paper Chase'' and American Express commercials. Using members of the Acting Company, an organization that he founded in 1972, Mr. Houseman is seen in action as he mounts a production of ''King Lear.''

title: Howe About That
description: Gordie Howe, who spent 25 of his 32 seasons in professional hockey with the Detroit Red Wings, told The Detroit Free Press that he might rejoin the organization under its new ownership. Mike Ilitch, a close friend of Howe, recently purchased the Red Wings from the Norris family.

title: BARRYMORE STAMP NOTES ACTORS' FUND CENTENARY
description: Commemorating the centenary of the Actors Fund of America, the United States Postal Service issued a stamp yesterday honoring the Barrymores, one of the theater's most distinguished families.

title: TANKER ATTACKED IN SOUTH ATLANTIC
description: A 100,000-ton supertanker, bound from St. Croix in the Virgin Islands to Alaska, reported that it was bombed and hit by aircraft rocket fire 480 miles northeast of the Falkland Islands yesterday.

title: Real Estate
description: Hotel Talks Examine The Slump AFEW years ago, Stephen Brener, at the time executive vice p resident of Helmsley-Spear Hospitality Services Inc. raised the q uestion in a talk with colleagues at New York University's Real E state Institute of why local professionals did not hold regular l odging industry conferences.

title: ASSAD VS. THE P.L.O.
description: It may appear that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria is in a no-win situation. He is damned if he launches a counterattack to defend Palestinian forces in Lebanon and ends up losing in a costly war to Israel's superior might, but equally damned if Syria offers only token resistance and he is discredited in his Arab ''rejectionist'' role as the Palestine Liberation Organization's main supporter. But, for the P.L.O., the bitter truth is that Mr. Assad may find extermination of its militia the most palatable outcome of all.

title: REAGAN AT WESTMINSTER: RED CARPET ALL THE WAY
description: After the 500 Members of Parliament had taken their seats in the Palace of Westminster this morning - and just before President Reagan arrived to address them - Lottie Pearson, a charlady there, got out her vacuum cleaner and ran it one more time over the red carpet that leads up to the grand marble staircase.

title: 2 Policemen Killed in Rome, Reportedly by Red Brigades
description: Two policemen were shot and killed in central Rome early today, and the Red Brigades guerrilla organization claimed responsibility, the police said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AM International, a Chicago-based supplier of engineering graphics equipment and imaging systems, has appointed Dieter E.A. Tannenberg president of its Multigraphics division, Jerry O. Williams president of its Bruning division and William C. Zeeb senior vice president, planning.

title: G.E., A TAX LOBBY MAVERICK
description: Once again, the General Electric Company is going it alone in lobbying Congress on taxes. It opposes the Administration and most of big business on tax leasing. It opposes the Administration's proposal to strengthen the corporate minimum tax, although it has not joined a coalition of 20 companies also opposed. In a move that set tongues wagging in Washington tax circles, G.E. recently retained a high-powered lobbyist and political fund-raiser, J.D. Williams.

title: BIG FLEXI-VAN INVESTOR IS ELECTED CHAIRMAN
description: David H. Murdock, one of the nation's wealthiest and most active investors, was elected chairman of the Flexi-Van Corporation yesterday. The move prompted conjecture that he might be taking a stronger hand in day-to-day management of the container company. Mr. Murdock said that was not the case, however.

title: Israelis Are Censoring Accounts of Invasion
description: All dispatches filed by correspondents from Israel on the Israeli invasion of southern Lebanon are subject to censorship by the military authorities. Last Sunday, the Israelis extended military censorship to accounts issued by the United Nations on the fighting.

title: WHITE HOUSE PLAYING DOWN KIRKPATRICK REMARKS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and other senior aides to President Reagan dismissed as inconsequential today the comment by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick Monday that the United States has behaved ''like a bunch of amateurs'' at the United Nations.

title: The 100-Year Diet
description: How have we dieted? Let us count the ways. 1. We have snubbed sugar, pounced on protein and gulped a halfgallon of water daily. 2.

title: 3 Colorado Fugitives Caught
description: The police recaptured two murder suspects this morning and a third jailbreak fugitive was arrested this afternoon. Ross David Thomas, 38 years old, and Gilbert Norman Fritz, 39, offered no resistance when they were captured this morning. Larry Lamar Smith, 23, was arrested about 2 P.M. Two of eight inmates who escaped Sunday from the Arapahoe County Jail are still at large.

title: Israeli Shelling Is Said to Hit Red Cross Center in Lebanon
description: A center of the International Committee of the Red Cross has been destroyed by Israeli shelling of the Lebanese port of Sidon, a Red Cross official said today.

title: THEY REPORT SHOOTING; DOWN 6 SYRIAN JETS
description: Israeli tank columns and infantry units pushed as far as 32 miles into Lebanon today, driving toward Beirut from two directions in an apparent attempt to trap as many Palestinian guerrillas as possible.

title: ARMY BEGINS TESTING ONE-MAN JET FLYING MACHINE
description: The Army began tests this week on a one-man flying device powered by a turbofan jet engine essentially the same as those in cruise missiles, its developers said.

title: U.S. LIFE INSURERS UNOPPOSED TO E.R.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Century Trust of Jacksonville, Fla., said it had agreed to acquire for $15 million the Commerce Savings Association, a Texas savings and loan with 12 branches in the greater Houston and Dallas areas.

title: RECALL OF TUNA PROCEEDS SLOWLY
description: AT 5 P.M. last Friday the Food and Drug Administration announced a recall of 40 million cans of tuna packed by Bumble Bee and sold under that brand name and several others. Unlike the recall of canned salmon earlier this year, which was triggered by the death of a Belgian from eating salmon contaminated with botulism, this recall was initiated because of complaints from consumers about spoiled tuna. There have been no reports of illness from eating the tuna.

title: COURTER IS WINNER OF HOUSE RACE IN JERSEY PRIMARY
description: Representative James A. Courter, the only primary candidate in the country who received an endorsement from President Reagan, scored an easy victory yesterday over Rodney Frelinghuysen, a Morris County Freeholder, in New Jersey's 12th Congressional District.

title: Torture Charged in Istanbul
description: The military prosecutor's office of Istanbul has begun an investigation into charges of hundreds of cases of torture, legal sources said today, as a hunger strike by 2,300 prisoners reportedly went into its 22d day.

title: YANKS BOW TO RED SOX IN 10th
description: Two hours before the Yankees played the Boston Red Sox tonight for the first time this season, Manager Gene Michael held a team meeting to try to shake his men out of their doldrums.

title: WILLIAM W. PEVEAR
description: William W. Pevear, a former senior vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died yesterday at the Stamford (Conn.) Hospital.

title: LYRICIST: LEO ROBIN, 87, SINGS 'JUNE IN JANUARY
description: THE first half of ''An Evening With Leo Robin,'' the final program in this season's ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series at the 92d Street Y on Sunday and Monday evenings, seemed to be avoiding the subject. Customarily, the subject of these programs is introduced immediately and he talks about his career and his songs and, with the help of others, sings them. But Mr. Robin remained in the wings while Julius La Rosa, Marlene Verplanck, Margaret Whiting, Jonathan Schwartz and his father, Arthur Schwartz, one of Mr. Robin's collaborators, sang songs that would identify Mr. Robin to the audience, including ''My Ideal,'' written with Miss Whiting's father, Richard Whiting, for Maurice Chevalier; ''A Gal in Calico,'' written with Mr. Schwartz, and ''Beyond the Blue Horizon'' and ''Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend,'' sung in flim clips by, respectively, Jeanette MacDonald and Marilyn Monroe.

title: Pan Am to Lease
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. said it is leasing 11 twin-engine Boeing 737 jetliners for use in its internal German service network linking Berlin with London, Zurich and five West German cities. The airline said four of the jets are already in service, another two will be in operation by mid-June and the other five are due to be flying between July and September. Six of the 737's are being leased from Air Florida and the rest from other sources.

title: Careers; Strategic Corporate Planners
description: IS this the age of the strategic planner in corporate management? J. Ray Watson, assistant dean of Duke University's Fuqua School of Business, believes it is.

title: SAM JAFFE, 91, LOOKING FOR MORE ROLES
description: HOLLYWOOD WHEN he was 46 years old, Sam Jaffe played the 200-year-old High Lama in ''Lost Horizon.'' That was in 1937. Now that he is 91, he says wryly that if he had a chance at the role again, ''I wouldn't act old - I'd just be myself.''

title: GRAHAM DANCE GALA TODAY
description: Gala benefits today, next Tuesday and Wednesday will highlight the Martha Graham Dance Company's three-week season at City Center, from today through June 27. Proceeds of the benefit next Tuesday will go to the Graham school.

title: Kaiser Expects Record Losses
