description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation, which lost $20 million on steel operations in the first quarter of the year, expects record losses to pile up through the end of the year unless the economy improves, its chairman, Stephen A. Girard, said.

title: SWEDISH NAVY REPORTS CHASING OFF A SUBMARINE WITH DEPTH CHARGES
description: Navy helicopters dropped depth charges today to chase an unidentified submarine out of Swedish waters. The authorities said another foreign sub violating Swedish coastal limits probably also fled.

title: Steps to Prevent Riots Urged By Federal Civil Rights Panel
description: The United States Civil Rights Commission, stopping short of forecasting new riots, today called for public and private initiatives to improve the kind of urban conditions that contributed to disturbances in Miami in 1980.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: BECAUSE of the texture and flavor of swordfish, I have always had a tremendous liking for it, particularly in the form of steaks simply broiled or grilled out of doors over charcoal.

title: Judge Orders Farmer To Pay for Soybeans
description: A Missouri farmer, his wife, his father and two friends have been ordered to pay $287,708.73 to cover losses suffered by fellow farmers when their soybeans were removed from a bankrupt elevator.

title: China Calls Goldwater A 'Blind Die-Hard'
description: China accused Senator Barry Goldwater today of being a ''blind die-hard'' who tried to sabotage United States-Chinese relations in his visit to Taiwan last week.

title: AN INSIDE LOOK AT WINE COMPETITIONS
description: FULLERTON, Calif. IN a cluster of rooms fronting on a courtyard beneath the palm trees at Griswold's Inn here, 40 expert palates were sequestered for three days in May, tasting some 1,400 California wines in a ritual with implications for consumers and producers alike. The tasters were judges in the annual Orange County Fair wine competition, and they were deciding which wines should be awarded gold, silver or bronze medals.

title: INTERIOR DEPARTMENT ADDS ROYALTY COLLECTOR
description: The Mineral Management Service may sound like just another Government agency, but the Interior Department, which formed it in January, says it is second only to the Internal Revenue Service in terms of revenues taken in. The first head of the new unit is Harold E. Doley Jr., 35, founder and owner of a New Orleans securities firm.

title: ARMS CURBS URGED ON 2 SUPERPOWERS
description: Several industrial and third world nations that are often at odds on major issues joined today in calling for the two superpowers to take the lead in in bringing about world peace and disarmament.

title: Soviet Sub Intrudes
description: The French Navy said today that a Soviet submarine passed through a zone in which French, Dutch and British naval forces were engaged in war exercises.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In a recent story you stated that strands of packaged pasta such as spaghetti should not be broken before adding them to the kettle of boiling water. If you wait until the pasta softens enough to be pushed down into the water, however, is it not true that the two ends of the strands will have different cooking times?

title: PARTIES OFFER NEW, SLIGHTLY CHANGED BUDGET PLANS
description: House Democratic and Republican leaders today unveiled new budget plans that were only slightly different from those rejected by the House last month.

title: EXTENSION VOTED FOR WILDLIFE LAW
description: The House of Representatives today approved a three-year extension of the widely debated Endangered Species Act and added several amendments sought by environmentalists. The measure was passed on a voice vote.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 9, 1982
description: International Israeli forces moved toward Beirut, converging on Lebanon's capital from two directions in an apparent attempt to trap as many Palestinian guerrillas as possible. As Israeli units progressed northward along the Shouf mountain range running through central Lebanon they ran into large concentrations of Syrian peacekeeping troops. A Syrian military spokesman said Syrian tanks, helicopter gunships and artillery attacked the Israelis at several points. (Page A1, Column 6.) The U.S. vetoed a resolution voted by all 14 other members of the Security Council of the United Nations that threatened Israel with sanctions for refusing to halt its invasion of Lebanon. (A1:6.)

title: RICHMOND LOSES ROUND IN BATTLE OVER HIS LETTERS
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that correspondence from Representative Frederick W. Richmond must be turned over to a grand jury investigating the Brooklyn Democrat.

title: Premier Z.A. Pataridze Of Soviet Georgia Dies
description: The Premier of the Soviet republic of Georgia was killed in a car accident Saturday, it was reported today by Tass, the official press agency.

title: Moroccan Visits Egypt To Talk of Reconciliation
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met with Foreign Minister Mohammed Boucetta of Morocco today in what Mr. Boucetta called the initial step of Egypt's reconciliation with the Arab world.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES

title: SOME GOLD MEDAL WINNERS
description: FULLERTON, Calif. A total of 1,389 wines competed in the Orange County Fair this year, and 91 of these were awarded gold medals.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Father will have his day June 20, so it's time to think about a present he might enjoy. Here are some ideas that might match up with a father's hobbies or tastes. 1. If He'd Rather Sail For a Dad whose relaxation is sailing, there is a necktie of navy blue rep that's decorated with white anchors and the phrase ''Don't give up the ship'' repeated over and over again. It is $14 at Jenny B. Goode, 1194 Lexington Avenue (82d Street). A pleasant outing for a sailor father could be a trip on the South Street Seaport's schooner Pioneer. The seaport has gift certificates: They're $15 for a twohour lunchtime sail or $20 for a three-hour afternoon sail. (You might outfit Dad with a navy T-shirt printed with a drawing of the Pioneer on the front. It's $7 in the seaport gift shop.)

title: ISRAEL ASKS SYRIA TO KEEP TROOPS OUT OF FIGHTING
description: Israeli and Syrian planes and troops clashed today, but Israeli officials said the Syrians had not entered the battle in force. Prime Minister Menachem Begin called publicly on President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to refrain from engaging the Israelis.

title: FALLEN FACADE REVIVES THEATER RAZING DISPUTE
description: The Helen Hayes Theater was the center of yet another dispute yesterday as much of its facade, a third of which was supposed to have been preserved because of its architectural importance, collapsed during demolition work on the remainder of the theater.

title: New Braniff Filing
description: The Braniff International Corporation will file a reorganization plan for a subsidiary, the Braniff Realty Company, by Friday, according to Sam Coats, vice president of the airline. Braniff quit flying May 12 and got court protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Texas Defeats Stanford In College World Series
description: Tracy Dophied and Randy Richard drove in runs in the top of the 12th inning tonight as top-ranked Texas defeated Stanford 8-6 in a winners' bracket semifinal in the College World Series.

title: F.B.I.'s Data Is at Issue In Inquiry on Donovan
description: The chairman of the Senate Labor Committee said yesterday that the committee would investigate whether the Federal Bureau of Investigation had withheld pertinent information about Raymond J. Donovan at the time of the committee's hearings last year on Mr. Donovan's appointment as the Secretary of Labor.

title: Priest Kidnapped and Freed
description: A Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. David Dzermejko of Perrysville, Pa., was abducted at gunpoint and locked in the trunk of his automobile, then released early today along a highway after a 225-mile ride, officials said.

title: ASPIRIN LINK TO DISEASE CHALLENGED
description: The aspirin industry has vowed to fight a Government-proposed warning label on aspirin packages, saying studies that link aspirin to the sometimes-fatal childhood disease Reye's Syndrome are inconclusive.

title: G.M. Lifts Prices
description: The General Motors Corporation has joined the other Big Three car makers in raising prices of optional equipment and destination charges. G.M. announced that effective June 14, a price increase on optional equipment would increase the list price of an average-equipped car by $36. Destination charges on cars and trucks will increase by an average of $15, the auto maker said. Last week, the Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company announced increases on some car models, optional equipment and destination charges.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: NOW that summer is here, simple broiled dishes have a special appeal. Recently I received an excellent piece of equipment for broiling that works wonderfully, not only for broiling, but also for a variety of other things. It is called a WaterBroiler pan and rack.

title: CELERYHOOD: THE ART OF BEING FULLY GROWN (An Inspirational Self-Help Guide)
description: Green is good. One stalk alone is nothing, together you are a bunch. In the crunch of the marketplace, you are the crispest. You bring texture to the smoothly bland, you alleviate the wait for the main course, in the depths of the cold refrigerated night, you relieve the hungry dieter's gnawing desire. You have a heart.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: On a rainy Monday afternoon, shortly before the evening rush was to begin in the Bowling Green IRT subway station in lower Manhattan, the body of a newborn boy was discovered enclosed in two bags - one clear plastic, the other brown paper - in a trash can on the mezzanine level.

title: Mariners 2, Rangers 1
description: Todd Cruz doubled to drive in Al Cowens with the winning run in the 14th inning for Seattle.

title: Hunt Trust Wins Hotel
description: Directors of the Hotel Bel-Air will be allowed to sell the luxury hotel to the Caroline Hunt Trust Estate of Dallas for $18 million, a Los Angeles probate court judge decided today. The Beverly Hills Hotel Corporation, which is controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, a New York arbitrager, and his family, had opposed the sale and had offered $20 million for the 66-room hotel.

title: C.I.A. ON USING JOURNALISTS
description: Six years after the Central Intelligence Agency restricted the use of journalists as intelligence agents, the C.I.A. has reluctantly disclosed that journalists were used before the restriction in a variety of roles, ranging from couriers to case officers who secretly supervised other agents.

title: U.S. Judge Takes Court Oath And Attacks Article in Paper
description: A Federal district judge whose integrity was questioned in an article published by The Grand Rapids Press swore a witness's oath in a special courtroom session Monday and accused the newspaper of waging a vendetta against black public officials.

title: ARGENTINES TELL OF SINKING FRIGATE
description: Argentina announced tonight that its planes attacked British forces making an amphibious landing on the Falkland Islands today, sinking a frigate and killing many of the British troops.

title: Tenneco Sales
description: Tenneco Inc, which announced the sale of certain Canadian oil and natural gas properties, said it would receive more than $100 million from the transaction. Tenneco said the properties were sold to Harvard Developments Ltd., a subsidiary of McCallum Hill Ltd., and the Oceanic Exploration Company, which will take a minority interest. It said the sale did not include its 49 percent stake in the Athabasca tar sands project and its investment in an Arctic Islands project.

title: Ronald Reagan's Flower Power
description: Truly, as President Reagan said so well in Parliament yesterday, Americans want only one kind of global conflict. A ''crusade'' for the open society, he called it, employing the only tolerable weapons: the powerful ideas and economies of democracy. His crusade would aim not to destroy other societies but to help them recognize the inhumanity and inefficiency of totalitarianism. What a tonic the President's faith and optimism could become for the pugnacity so often heard from his Administration.

title: 137 Said to Die in Crash Of Brazilian Airliner
description: A Brazilian airliner crashed into a mountaintop in heavy rain outside this northeastern coastal city early today, killing all 137 people on board, air force rescue teams reported.

title: TRACES OF 'ENEMY' ABOUND IN ARGENTINA
description: They have taken the Queen's picture off the wall at the Hurlingham Club and renamed Plaza Britania after the Argentine Air Force, but Buenos Aires still bears many traces of the people identified in daily communiques from the military high command as the ''enemy.''

title: Advertising; Touting The Allure Of Radio
description: IT was funny hearing Jerry Della Femina talking about Blue Nun wine at a radio advertising meeting once again, since Della Femina, Travisano & Partners has not had the account in about five years and since most of its advertising is going into television these days.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BLUES IN THE NIGHT

title: Market Place; Chase Stock: Brokers' View
description: ON Monday, May 17, shares of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the holding company that owns the Chase Manhattan Bank, closed at 52, down 3/4, in routine trading. But the next day Chase tumbled 3 1/2 points in response to news that jarred not only its shares but also the stock market in general.

title: PANEL DECLARES TREATMENT PLANT CITY LANDMARK
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission voted in executive session yesterday to designate a Bronx sewage treatment plant at 158 Bruckner Boulevard a New York City landmark.

title: Text of Reagan's address, page A16.
description: President Reagan urged Britain and the world today to join the United States in a crusade for freedom by encouraging the spread of democracy, even in Communist countries.

title: MOST EXPERTS CALL SOCIAL SECURITY BASICALLY SOUNG
description: Robert J. Myers, the staff director of the National Commission for Social Security Reform, is a ''double dipper.'' A former chief actuary of the Social Security Administration, he worked for the Federal Government for 36 years and was a college professor for 10 more years, until 1981, when he rejoined the Government at the age of 69.

title: CHAD'S PRESIDENT SAID TO FLEE COUNTRY
description: Chad's President, Goukouni Oueddei, was reported today to have fled his capital for neighboring Cameroon after the capital's fall Monday to forces loyal to a rebellious former Defense Minister, Hissen Habre.

title: TWO SIDES; News Analysis
description: Israel's policy makers have not yet formulated their specific conditions for withdrawing the invasion force from Lebanon, but it appears likely that the demands will include some restructuring of the political and military alignments in that country.

title: GRANT KEEHN, ONCE EQUITABLE LIFE HEAD AND FORMER BANKER
description: Grant Keehn, the former president and retired vice chairman of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, died Sunday at the Virginia Mason Hospital in Seattle. He was 81 years old and lived in Bellevue, Wash.

title: SATCHEL PAGE, BLACK PITCHING STAR, IS DEAD AT 75
description: Leroy (Satchel) Paige, one of the folk heroes of baseball's old Negro leagues who became a rookie pitcher in the major leagues at the age of 42, died yesterday at his home in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Pay for College Athletes Proposed by Educators
description: The American Council on Education has drafted a report suggesting that one way out of the ''crisis'' facing big-time college athletics would be for the major schools to pay athletes openly and not require them to be students.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Hayes, an outstanding receiver for 10 seasons with the Dallas Cowboys and currently on parole for a cocaine-possession conviction, is scheduled to appear today before a county judge in Dallas to enter his plea in a drunken driving case. Hayes was arrested Monday after police officers noticed his car weaving in and out of traffic.

title: Arabs Condemn Israel; Urge a Moslem Rebuff
description: Arab leaders today condemned the invasion of Lebanon and called for Moslem nations to unite to confront Israel.

title: BID RAISED FOR MESA IF IT APPROVES
description: The Cities Service Company yesterday rejected two takeover bids from the Mesa Petroleum Company and offered to sweeten its own offer for Mesa.

title: Kuwait Acquires 18% of Hoechst
description: Officials of Hoechst A.G., Europe's biggest chemical company, confirmed privately reports that Kuwait has acquired a major share of the company's equity.

title: FOS SUMMER, COLD MARINATED DISHES WITH SEAFOOD AND FOWL
description: IF the summer hath his joys, to borrow a phrase from the poet Thomas Campion, it also hath its dishes. Not the least of these is a category of foods, basically related to one another, that includes the escabeches of Spain and Latin America, the soused dishes of England and certain marinated or vinaigrette dishes of France and Italy.

title: LEADERS SEEKING DAMAGE TOTALS FOR CONNECTICUT
description: As Connecticut's flooding emergencies began to ease today, state and Federal officials intensified their efforts to get Federal aid to help repair the still uncalculated damage caused by the weekend deluge.

title: Gretzky by Acclamation
description: Wayne Gretzky yesterday became the first player in National Hockey League history to be named the most valuable player by a unanimous vote. That vote gave him the Hart Trophy, which goes to the m.v.p., for the third straight year.

title: Loan Package At Holly Sugar
description: The chairman of the Holly Sugar Corporation, Michael S. Buchsbaum, said that the General Electric Credit Corporation had offered his investor group a $100 million loan package that would provide the cash for the group to carry out its plan to buy Holly for $65 a share.

title: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically
description: When the man walked in to her specialty food shop on Lexington Avenue near 93d Street the other day, Linda Deme was hunched over a counter, drafting a petition to Capt. John J. Murphy, the commander of the 23d Precinct. Mrs. Deme, like 165 other store owners and residents who eventually signed the petition, was disturbed that the only foot patrolman who walked a beat in the neighborhood had been transferred to another trouble spot in the Upper East Side-East Harlem precinct.

title: FOR BUSINESS GROUP, ART IS A MOVING PROBLEM
description: A quiet drama has been taking place at the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry that provides further evidence how difficult and complex disposing of an art collection in a responsible way can be.

title: Neinas Assails N.C.A.A.  On Football TV Policy
description: The chief executive of a group of 61 major football powers testified today that the National Collegiate Athletic Association's control of television rights to college football games prevents schools from selling those rights to the highest bidder.

title: Dow Off 1.80 Amid Rate Fears
description: Stock prices finished mostly lower yesterday amid new investor concern over fighting in the Middle East and continuing worries about high interest rates and the economic outlook.

title: The U.N. Today; June 9, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL

title: Reserve Mining
description: The Reserve Mining Company will extend its planned four-week summer shutdown to five and a half months beginning June 19, the company announced today. The shutdown will idle most of Reserve's 2,700 employees until Dec. 5. The fourweek shutdown was to have started July 4.

title: LOU DiMURO, UMPIRE
description: LOU DIMURO had a reputation for bad luck. His fellow umpire Larry Barnett recalls with a catch in his voice that ''I used to tell Lou, 'If you didn't have bad luck, you wouldn't have any luck at all.' ''

title: IN JAPAN, EDUCATION CAME FIRST
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT GETS MASTER'S DISTRICTING PLAN
description: A plan by a Federal court master to revise New York's political boundaries - scrambling districts and pitting incumbents against each other - was made public yesterday.

title: 2 EX-AIDES CONVICTED IN JAPAN IN '72 LOCKHEED BRIBERY CASE
description: Two former Government officials were convicted today, after a five-year trial, of having taken bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. The defendants, the first politicians to be found guilty in the scandal, were sentenced to suspended prison terms of two and a half years and two years, and both appealed.

title: Stargell Charity Told To Stop Raising Funds
description: State officials said today that a charitable foundation headed by Willie Stargell, the Pittsburgh Pirates' star, had not filed a required audit and had been told to stop raising funds.

title: LAKERS BEAT 76ers, 114-104, AND GAIN TITLE IN 6 GAMES
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, who started the season by dismissing their coach, ended it tonight ''relieved'' and as the best team in the National Basketball Association.

title: Quota for European Steel Weighed
description: The European Economic Community would receive a steel import quota of between 4 and 5 percent of total domestic consumption under proposals being laid before the domestic industry by Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, industry and Government sources reported today.

title: LESSON ON FARMS FROM THE DAKOTAS
description: Every time Representative Thomas A. Daschle goes home to South Dakota, the young Democrat hears the same story. The world of the family farmer is crumbling under high interest rates and low market prices.

title: AFGHAN REBELS OUSTED FROM KEY VALLEY
description: A large ground force of Afghan soldiers, supported by Soviet helicopters and troops, has seized control of the strategic Panjshir Valley, long a stronghold of anti-Soviet rebels, Western diplomats reported today.

title: CHANGING THE GUARD
description: Around the halfway mark in most four-year Presidential terms, there is a natural tendency to make changes in the Cabinet and the White House staff. Ronald Reagan is now reaching this point, a little earlier than usual.

title: Utility Law Repeal Asked
description: The Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission today urged repeal of Depression-era legislation aimed at preventing abuses by public utility holding companies.

title: A.T.&T. IN PACT ON CELLULAR UNITS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it had reached joint agreements with 19 other telephone companies to develop cellular radio systems.

title: NEW CLUE IN MURDER OF A FRAUD WITNESS
description: A new clue was found yesterday in the murders last April of a witness in a fraud investigation and three CBS employees who came to her aid at a West Side pier garage in Manhattan.

title: PHARMACISTS NEED A FINANCIAL SPUR TO DISPENSE GENERIC DRUGS
description: To the Editor:

title: SLUMPING SALES CLOUD ELECTRONIC SHOW
description: The Consumer Electronics Show this year is a subdued affair, despite record attendance of nearly 70,000 people and a dazzling display of video games. The mood reflects the state of the industry. Sales of many products are below 1981 levels. The threat of new restrictions on audio and video taping hangs in the air. And even in areas of increasing sales volume, prices and profits are plummeting.

title: Financial Futures Drop In a Cautious Session
description: Traders in financial futures continued to move to the sidelines yesterday while prices fell and the general caution resulting from the Drysdale default still pervaded the market. After some carry-over buying from Monday's feeble rally, prices resumed their declines early in the day. Brokers said the financial futures closely reflected the pattern in the cash market.

title: Youth, 14, Convicted Of Killing Best Friend
description: A 14-year-old boy, reported to be the youngest person in Nassau County history to be prosecuted as an adult for second-degree murder, was convicted by a jury today of the lesser charge of manslaughter for killing his best friend. The County Court jury decided that the boy, Michael Baccari, had not intended to kill his friend, Erwin Michelitsch Jr., 13, who was fatally stabbed on a New Hyde Park street last year after an argument.

title: Western Air Gets Delay on Debt
description: Western Air Lines Inc. said its creditors had agreed to a two-month extension of waivers on $153 million in longterm debt on which the airline has been in technical default since December.

title: Affairs of State In Motor City
description: The big talk lately in non-automotive-related Detroit advertising had to do with the future of the Michigan Department of Commerce account. First as the Michigan Tourist Council and then as the Michigan Travel Commission, the account had been served for 21 years by W.B. Doner there.

title: TEXT OF REAGAN'S ADDRESS TO PARLIAMENT ON PROMOTING DEMOCRACY
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's speech today to the British Parliament, as made public by White House officials:

title: INVENTION: MOTHER OF THE CULINARY ART
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert Farrar Capon is an Episcopal priest, author and food writer whose latest book is ''Between Noon and Three'' (Harper & Row). By ROBERT F. CAPON

title: DOUBTS EXPRESSED ON A TV EXCHANGE
description: A decade ago, at the peak of detente between the Soviet Union and the United States, President Nixon delivered an address on Soviet radio and television.

title: Spot Oil Prices Climb Slightly
description: Crude oil prices on the European spot market rose slightly yesterday in light trading, a development that traders attributed as much to reduced supplies for sale as to concern about the fighting in Lebanon.

title: Miriam H. Morris, 90, Collector of Americana
description: Miriam H. Morris, owner of ''The Lindens,'' the oldest house in the capital, and a well-known collector of 17th- and 18th-century American furniture and decorative arts, died here last Thursday of cancer. She was 90 years old.

title: Cosmos Win on Hunt's Goal
description: A goal by Steve Hunt in the 34th minute gave the Cosmos a 1-0 victory over A.C. Milan of Italy in an international soccer match tonight before a crowd of 17,896 at Giants Stadium.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Evening Hours column on the Style page May 28 gave an incorrect site for the Longwood Gardens. They are in Pennsylvania.

title: INSTALLMENT DEBT GREW IN APRIL
description: In a sign that Americans are buying more, consumer installment debt rose a seasonally adjusted $1.18 billion in April, the biggest increase in seven months, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: AT WINDSOR CASTLE DINNER, POMP, CIRCUMSTANCE AND CEREMONY FOR REAGANS
description: It was not called a state banquet, but it is doubtful if Windsor Castle could offer anything more in the way of pomp, circumstance and ceremony than was afforded President and Mrs. Reagan tonight at the only dinner ever given in the castle for an American President.

title: Therapy for Dancers
description: The Performing Arts Center for Health, a nonprofit organization engaged in a survey of health problems of dancers, has published the results of its first questionnaire. As a result of that survey, the center is offering low-cost psychotherapy to professional dancers and is gathering material for a dancers' resource directory of physicians throughout the country. Information on the therapy project, which is being undertaken with the cooperation of New York University-Bellevue Hospital, 561-4860 mornings.

title: Mitterrand News Parley
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France, in his second news conference as head of state, will tell the nation tomorrow to prepare for more rigorous Government economic management. He will also announce moves to restrict the 1983 budget deficit, Government officials said. However, they added, he will not change his basic policy aimed at higher spending to end the recession and reduce unemployment.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Box Step on Second Ave.

title: Misfit Hands May Cause A Communications Break
description: Misfit hands often end up in three no-trump, presenting problems in play for both partnerships. The declarer may find himself with severed communications, as happened last week on the diagramed deal from the the Flight B Reisinger Knockout final.

title: KOCH CONSIDERS $200 MILLION CUT, INCLUDING LAYOFFS, IN 1983 BUDGET
description: The Koch administration is considering cutting its proposed budget for fiscal 1983 by up to $200 million by eliminating or reducing some social programs for children and the elderly and by laying off some employees.

title: Murder Charges Are Dropped In Killing of Vietnamese Man
description: Murder charges were dismissed Monday against Dat V. Nguyen, a Vietnamese man accused of fatally shooting a Vietnamese leftist here last summer.

title: 300 in Florida Respond To Hoax Ad for Jobs
description: About 300 unemployed laborers seeking jobs were victims of what one of them called ''a cruel hoax'' when they applied for advertised construction jobs that did not exist.

title: Volcker Urged To Resign
description: Representative Jim Wright, the House majority leader, a strong critic of current monetary policy, called today for the resignation of Paul A. Volcker as the Federal Reserve Board's chairman.

title: TRAINER AMONG FOUR INDICTED FOR FIXING OF HARNESS RACES
description: Four men, including a trainer of harness horses, were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of conspiring to fix six races at Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways in 1978.

title: Cyclops to Buy Colt Steel Unit
description: Cyclops Inc. agreed in principle to buy Colt Industries' Crucible Steel division, the two companies said in a joint announcement. The price of the deal was not disclosed, although Colt will incur a substantial write-off on the sale.

title: ARTS ENDOWMENT WILL AID REGIONAL ARTISTS
description: The National Endowment for the Arts and the American Film Institute announced today the establishment of a program designed to promote film and video artists throughout the country and to help curb the flow of those artists to New York City. The program will in effect reduce the percentage of endowment grants to New York-based artists but apparently will not reduce the dollar amount.

title: MUSIC: 'HISTORIE DU SOLDAT' IN 'SERENADES' SERIES
description: ''L'HISTOIRE DU SOLDAT'' or, if you will, ''The Soldier's Tale,'' is a work that asks to be fiddled with, and not only because the solo violinist carries so much of the musical burden. Stravinsky's little morality play with music, set in no particular place and no particular period, invites every new producer to dress it out in fresh, pertinent concepts.

title: IDEAL TOY GAINS 30.2%
description: Gulf and Western Industries announced yesterday that net income in the third fiscal quarter declined 53 percent from the same period last year. The diversified company attributed the drop to the recession and high interest rates, as well as depressed sugar prices and bad weather in Florida.

title: VIETNAM'S AMERASIANS DRIFT IN SEA OF INDIFFERENCE
description: There was a time not long ago when some Vietnamese cities offered up children who resembled the thousands of children of mixed American and Vietnamese background who now haunt this city.

title: Hagler-Hearns Called Off
description: The Marvelous Marvin Hagler-Thomas Hearns middleweight title bout, scheduled for July 15, has been called off, and both boxers were looking for new opponents yesterday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Beverly Enterprises' $70 million issue of 15 percent subordinated debentures due in 2002 was offered at 85.023 plus any accrued interest from June 15, through a group headed by a Merrill Lynch unit.

title: FORMER ARKANSAS GOVERNOR WINS CHANCE TO RUN AGAIN
description: Former Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas won the Democratic gubernatorial runoff primary yesterday in a tight race as Democratic and Republican voters chose nominees for key contests of the 1982 elections in 10 states from Maine to California.

title: KEEPING NIGHT DARK AT WRIGLEY FIELD
description: Christina Cressey's house sits outside a major league ballpark, so close that a home run ball once struck her front stoop. What makes its location different from that of houses near outdoor ballparks in 22 other cities is that on summer evenings, her street is dark. The predominant sound is not the roar of fullthroated throngs, but the gentle flapping of pennants rippling in the breeze.

title: PEOPLE-WATCHING: SOME FAVORITE SPOTS
description: WHERE are the best places for people-watching in New York City? Madison Avenue at lunchtime? Orchard Street on Sunday? The subway any time? And what about the parks, the piers and, of course, the Plaza Hotel, where, its advertisements boast, ''nothing unimportant ever happens''? Every New Yorker, it seems, is an avid people-watcher, and each has a favorite spot for practicing the sport.

title: CUNNINGHAM IS QUESTIONED ON 2 CONVICTED FRIENDS
description: The prosecution in the tax-evasion trial of Patrick J. Cunningham, the former state Democratic chairman, questioned him yesterday about his version of the events that led to the indictment and conviction of two of his closest friends and associates.

title: PROTECTING THE SKIN FROM THE ELEMENTS
description: SUMMER may do wonders for your spirits, but it's likely to be very hard on your skin. From assaults by searing sun, drying wind, excessive bathing and penetrating chlorine to irritations triggered by heat, sweat and common chemicals, your skin is under constant attack from typical summertime activities.

title: John S. Williams, 80, Is Dead; Founder of a Shaker Museum
description: John S. Williams, a New York investment broker and founder of the Shaker Museum in Old Chatham, N.Y., died last Thursday at a nursing home in Valatie, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Old Chatham.

title: CLARINETIST: ETHAN SLOANE
description: ETHAN SLOANE, a clarinetist now teaching at the University of West Virginia, joined Dan Saunders, piano, and the Manhattan String Quartet in a lovely evening of music at the Abraham Goodman House Monday night. There were Weber's Grand Duo Concertant (Op. 48), Busoni's ''Elegie,'' the Poulenc Sonata for Clarinet and Piano and Mozart's Quintet for Clarinet and Strings.

title: U.S. AT U.N., VETOES CURBS ON ISRAELIS
description: The United States vetoed a Security Council resolution tonight that threatened Israel with sanctions for refusing to halt its invasion of Lebanon.

title: BOTH ARAB AND ISRAELI ENVOYS MAKE THEIR CASES TO REAGAN
description: Representatives from Arab nations urged the Reagan Administration today to press Israel to withdraw immediately from Lebanon, and they expressed concern about rising tensions in the Middle East.

title: E.E.C.'s Steel Cut Extended
description: Economic ministers of the European Economic Community agreed to a one-year extension of mandatory production cuts on Common Market steelmakers, Otto Lambsdorff, West Germany's Minister of Economic Affairs, said today.

title: REP. BROWN AND CELESTE WIN OHIO NOMINATIONS
description: United States Representative Clarence J. Brown easily won the Ohio Republican gubernatorial primary tonight, while former Lieut. Gov. Richard Celeste defeated Attorney General William J. Brown in a close race for the Democratic nomination.

title: What Will Grudging Teachers Teach?
description: Stung by criticism that it is soft on civil rights, the Reagan Administration has struck back in a disturbing way. It insists that the faculty of each New York public school reflect the ethnic proportions of the teaching corps at large, even if that means mandatory reassignments.

title: P.L.O.'S MAIN LEBANON BASES FALL TO FAST-MOVING ISRAELIS
description: Israeli troops have now captured nearly all the major Palestinian strongholds in southern Lebanon and have also heavily damaged the guerrillas' headquarters complex, in a crowded Palestinian quarter at the southern edge of Beirut.

title: CLORE STOCK TAKES OVER AT GULF
description: Alan E. Clore, the leader of a dissident stockholder group that won control of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Company, was appointed chairman yesterday at the first meeting of the company's new board of directors. He replaces Robert H. Allen, who was dismissed.

title: Tribes Given Control Of Liquor on Reservation
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that Indian tribes have exclusive jurisdiction to license and distribute liquor on their reservations.

title: HOW REAGAN CAN END THE BUDGET IMPASSE
description: A strange feature of the debate on the Federal budget is that anyone (read: any Democrat) who wants to tackle the root causes of the gigantic deficits we face - President Reagan's huge tax cuts and defense buildup - automatically qualifies as a ''demagogue'' in the Reagan lexicon.

title: Buyer Cuts Price of Gas
description: Citing price competition from propane and fuel oil, the Michigan Wisconsin Pipe Line Company announced yesterday that it was reducing by 29 percent the price it pays for certain unregulated natural gas.

title: HINCKLEY'S STUDY OF MURDERS CITED
description: Contradicting the diagnoses of four defense witnesses, a prosecution psychiatrist testified today that John W. Hinckley Jr. ''was remarkably aware of the wrongfulness of his conduct'' when he shot President Reagan.

title: Phoenix Plans Acquisition
description: The Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company, which is based in Hartford, said that it had reached preliminary agreement to buy 51 percent of Burgess & Leith, a Boston-based investment banking concern.

title: PLAN FOR FARE RISE FAILS TO ROUSE STATEN ISLANDERS
description: The last nickel clunked into the Staten Island ferry turnstiles nearly seven years ago, giving way to the quarter - a sign of the city's fiscal woes, inflation and the waning of the way things were. Now, if City Hall has its way, the quarter will yield to a brass token embossed with a ferryboat. It will sell for 50 cents.

title: BE HUMBLE, KIBBEE TELLS BROOKLYN'S CLASS OF 1982
description: In his final commencement address before his retirement June 30 as chancellor of the City University of New York, Robert J. Kibbee counseled the graduating class at Brooklyn College yesterday to be humble and compassionate and to ''temper your judgments to the limits of your knowledge.''

title: PRESIDENT LEAVING MISSOURI PACIFIC
description: Thomas H. O'Leary, president of the Missouri Pacific Corporation of St. Louis, said yesterday that he would resign July 31 to become a vice chairman and a director of Burlington Northern Inc.

title: BRIEFING
description: . . .Or Your Money Back

title: COMPLETE OVERHAUL SET FOR AILING TELEFUNKEN
description: AEG Telefunken, West Germany's ailing electrical products giant, is ready to embark on another far-reaching restructuring plan, this time with the prospect of substantial Government help.

title: OFFICIALS ASSAIL EFFORT TO LINK WELFARE TO TAX DATA
description: A Congressman, a prominent tax lawyer and a civil liberties advocate expressed concern today about the Social Security Administration's plans to require more than four million welfare recipients to disclose tax return information as a condition of receiving benefits.

title: JERSEY RACES WON BY REP. FENWICK AND LAUTENBERG
description: Representative Millicent Fenwick, a four-term Republican Congresswoman, and Frank R. Lautenberg, a Democratic business executive making his first bid for public office, today won nominations for the United States Senate seat from New Jersey that was held for 24 years by Harrison A. Williams Jr.

title: PIRATES DEFEAT METS, 6-2
description: The Mets lost again to the Pirates last night at Shea Stadium, 6-2, and apart from a mild rally in the eighth inning, the New York team lacked offense once more.

title: SURVEY FINDS LITTLE RESPONSE TO REAGAN RADIO TALK SERIES
description: Some broadcasters who did not air President Reagan's series of Saturday radio talks said the programs were too long and that the talks were political and not newsworthy.

title: 4 Quit to Back Suit by Nuns
description: Four staff members resigned from Sacred Heart School here Monday to protest the dismissal of four teaching nuns in late January. The dismissed nuns said they had never been told why they were dismissed and have appealed their case to the State Supreme Court. Church historians say it is the first time that nuns have filed suit against their Bishop.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 9, 1982; Companies
description: Cities Service offered to sweeten its bid for a 51 percent controlling interest in Mesa Petroleum by $4, to $21 a share, rejecting two bids by Mesa. The company, conditioning the bid on Mesa's support, proposed a stock swap for the rest, offering 0.45 share, equal to about $16, for each remaining Mesa share. Mesa's chairman disdained the new bid but said he would submit it to his board. (Page D1.)

title: FERDINAND WALDO DEMARA, 60, AN IMPOSTOR IN VARIED FIELDS
description: Ferdinand Waldo Demara Jr., the inspiration for the movie ''The Great Impostor,'' who spent much of his life pretending to be somebody else, is dead at the age of 60 years.

title: WOMEN LOSE A ROUND
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: AFTER MODERNISM
description: Four years' worth of dance performances at the Kitchen Center for Video and Music were the subject of a recent festival at that avantgarde studio in SoHo. Twenty-seven choreographers participated, but such has been the nature of the Kitchen's dance presentations that any one night yielded an interestingly varied crop of leading postmodernists. Take Monday, for example, when the program was shared by Senta Driver, Molissa Fenley, Elizabeth Streb and Nancy Topf.

title: Dance Critics to Hold Conference June 17-20
description: The Dance Critics Association will hold a conference on reviving dance from June 17 to 20 at the Milford Plaza Hotel.

title: U.S. NUCLEAR ARMS MAKERS SOUR ON PROGRAM
description: In the 1940's, the United States Government called on private industry to help build the atom bomb. In a flurry of patriotic zeal, Du Pont, Union Carbide, Monsanto and others built nuclear weapons plants, staffed them and supervised the building of atomic warheads.

title: Tar Heel, a Leading Sire Of Pacers, Is Dead at 34
description: Tar Heel, who won the Little Brown Jug in 1951 and went on to become a leading sire of harness horses, died today at Hanover Shoe Farms in Hanover, Pa., the United States Trotting Association announced.

title: THE VIDEO GAME SALES WAR
description: Everyone, it seems, is trying to enter the home video game business, bringing forth a profusion of new game-playing machines and games.

title: BIG EAST SIGNS A TV PACKAGE
description: The Big East Conference has signed a $2 million basketball television package for the 1982-83 season providing for coverage by two major networks and four cable systems, Commissioner Dave Gavitt announced today.

title: Ford Warranties
description: The Ford Motor Company announced it would continue the rebate and free-maintenance and warranty program on its subcompacts and the extended warranty on luxury cars through July 31. The sales promotion started Jan. 13 on the Escort and Lynx subcompacts and March 11 on the luxury Continental, Lincoln and Mark VI models and was extended until last Sunday. The move leaves the General Motors Corporation as the only domestic car maker without a sales promotion.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: British post-punk rock bands such as the Gang of Four and the Cure tend to take themselves very seriously. These bands are keen, critical observers of the racial and class conflicts and generational tensions that led last summer to widespread rioting, but they are not detached observers. They are involved, often passionately, in trying to make sense out of what they see going on around them, and the things they see are serious things.

title: 2 Civil Guards Are Wounded In Terrorist Attack in Spain
description: Terrorists bombed and machine-gunned a civil guard explosives truck today, wounding two guardsmen near the site where the England national soccer team will play in next week's World Cup, the authorities said. Police sources blamed E.T.A., a Basque separatist group.

title: France Raids Centers Of Sun Myung Moon
description: The French police raided centers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church today in Paris and six other cities.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Scores With Effies and Clios
description: Ogilvy & Mather had an outstanding day yesterday on the advertising awards circuit. It was the big winner at the Effies, with four gold statuettes, and tied for first with Needham, Harper & Steers with three Clios in the print competition.

title: Penn Mutual To Buy Janney
description: The Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company said that it had reached agreement in principle to buy Janney, Montgomery Scott Inc., a Philadelphia-based regional retail brokerage.

title: THEATER: LAST IN SERIES OF SHORT PLAYS
description: PLAYING a 13-year-old, Elizabeth Ward is standing outside her parents' luxurious apartment waiting for her heart to be broken. With an amusing sequence of cosmetic flourishes and frills, she prepares herself to encounter the love of her young life. Enter Ben Siegler, as Barney the Clown, big on the rich kids' birthday circuit. With all the nearsighted innocence of her age, the young girl looks longingly in his eyes and says, ''You don't remember me, do you?'' Years ago, he had entertained at one of her birthday parties and had casually sworn an oath of fealty. Now she has come to collect on his promissory note.

title: METS SCORE 2 RUNS IN 9TH-INNING RALLY TO TOP PIRATES, 3-2
description: Rusty Tillman, an outfielder who had been a Met for only five days following elevation from the Tidewater farm club, scored the winning run for the New York team with one out in the bottom of the ninth inning last night at Shea Stadium. He slid into home plate below and ahead of a throw to the Pittsburgh catcher, Tony Pena, from Dale Berra, the shortstop.

title: Michigan Debt Under Study
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation, a major rating agency, warned yesterday that it may reduce its ratings on the debt of some and possibly all Michigan utilities because of a legislative initiative in that state.

title: Housing Officer Wounds Youth, 17
description: A Housing Authority police officer shot a teen-ager in the head yesterday during a scuffle on a dark stairway in a Staten Island housing project, the police said.

title: KREMLIN STILL BACKING POLISH LEADERSHIP
description: A visitor from Warsaw finds that the Soviet Union remains concerned about the continuing resistance in Poland to martial law, but is still squarely backing Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, in his efforts to enforce Communist rule.

title: LITTLE PEACE, LITTLE WARS
description: Three full-scale wars are raging now: in the Falkslands, Lebanon and Iran, and Chad has just completed another phase in its generation-long civil war. None were caused by the United States or the Soviet Union, though both must be keenly interested in the outcomes.

title: Boston's School Committee Votes to Lay Off 595 Teachers
description: To the sounds of catcalls and jeers from angry teachers, the Boston School Committee voted Tuesday, 4 to 1, to lay off 595 of the city's 4,000 teachers because of budget problems in the second year of a drastic voter-approved cut in property taxes.

title: EX-CHAIRMAN OF XEROX CORP.
description: John B. Hartnett, retired chairman of the Xerox Corporation and a principal force behind the mass marketing of Xerox copiers, died of a heart attack last Thursday at his home in Pittsford, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: CBS, FOX MAY SCRAP CABLE PLAN
description: A planned joint venture linking CBS Inc. and the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation in an ambitious cable television programming enterprise might be called off, industry sources said today.

title: ARGENTINA TELLS OF 2 NEW ATTACKS
description: The Argentine military command reported tonight that it had repelled dual attacks by British troops near the Falkland Islands capital of Stanley Tuesday - one from ground troops at Mount Kent, west of the town, and another from troops trying to land at Enriqueta Bay, just to its south.

title: TIFFANY EXHIBITION OPENING IN CHICAGO
description: The largest exhibition of works by Louis Comfort Tiffany ever assembled opens here Thursday near the site of the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition, where he first gained international acclaim.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ROSES AND IKEBANA
description: Caramoor Flower Show, Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road, Katonah, N.Y., 914-234-7254.

title: Syntex-Key Talks
description: The Syntex Corporation, a Palo Alto, Calif., pharmaceuticals and health products company, said it was involved in discussions with Key Pharmaceuticals Inc., a Miami-based drug manufacturer, regarding the purchase of 6.5 percent of Key's common stock for $30 million. The company also said that licensing agreements were being discussed with Key.

title: Mexico Orders Inquiry In Killing of 25 Peasants
description: Federal authorities have ordered state governments of Veracruz and Puebla to conduct an investigation into the killing of 25 peasants by hired gunmen in a land dispute, the official newspaper El Nacional said today.

title: IN LEBANON
description: Israel said tonight that its air force destroyed the Syrian surface-to-air missile system in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon ''in a concentrated strike'' this afternoon. Twenty-two Syrian MIG's were reported shot down in the air battle that accompanied the raid, and seven more were said to have been hit.

title: VOLUME UP
description: The Dow Jones industrial average sank to 795.57 yesterday, piercing the 800-point mark widely regarded as a key support level. The selling pressure reflected the combined pressures of the intensifying Middle East crisis, high interest rates, the weakening economy and the continued inability of Congress to reach a compromise on the budget deficit.

title: Carlton Fans 16 Cub Batters
description: Steve Carlton struck out 16 batters tonight, a major league high for the season, and Bo Diaz and Mike Schmidt homered as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Chicago Cubs, 3-2.

title: JITTERY BEIRUT, ISRAELI JETS OVERHEAD, IS TAKEN OVER BY RIVAL MILITIA
description: GROUPS By WILLIAM E. FARRELL

title: LIBYAN OIL CONCESSIONS RELINQUISHED BY MOBILE
description: The Mobil Corporation announced yesterday that it would end its oil exploration and production operations in Libya by July 13. Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil company, did not explain why it was withdrawing from Libya beyond saying in a prepared statement that the decision was based solely on economics. Industry analysts said that Mobil might have been under pressure from Saudi Arabia to withdraw from Libya, because the two Arab nations are at odds.

title: Mozambique Envoy In Lisbon Defects
description: Mozambique's ambassador to Portugal, Joao Ataide, has become the latest Mozambican official to defect from the country, official sources said today.

title: Poll Finds Most Favor Reagan Prayer Proposal
description: Most Americans who know about the proposal for a constitutional amendment permitting officially sponsored prayer in public schools favor the practice, according to the results of a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: ARGENTINE STRIKE: NO TIME FOR BRITISH TO REACT
description: The following dispatch, which was cleared by British military censors, is by Michael Nicholson of Independent Television News:

title: San Francisco Ballet Building Arts Center
description: Construction has begun on a four-level, $10 million Performing Arts Center on Franklin and Fulton Streets in San Francisco that will be the headquarters for the San Francisco Ballet.

title: SHIRER, AT 78, IS THINKING ABOUT BOOK-AFTER-NEXT
description: WILLIAM L. SHIRER, a vigorous 78 years old, concedes lightly that he is ''getting on'' and he hedges his bets slightly in talking about his plans for the future. But he aims to finish the second volume of his autobiographical ''Twentieth Century Journey'' by the end of the summer. And ''if I live long enough,'' he said in a recent interview, ''and the publishers will publish it, I'm going to do a third one

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Dip; New Supply Called Factor
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds declined modestly yesterday on news of upcoming Treasury offerings. Securities dealers said that the supply of Treasury issues was growing at the same time that investors such as insurance companies and pension funds were showing little buying interest. As a result, they said, prices were being reduced until a level was found where demand from investors and speculators will increase.

title: Kenyan Parliament Approves Measure for One-Party State
description: Kenya officially became a oneparty state today under the ruling Kenya African National Union after Parliament unanimously approved a bill to amend the Constitution to this end.

title: 15 People Are Contaminated After West Virginia Accident
description: A truck carrying toxic chemicals overturned in southern West Virginia and contaminated at least 15 people, two Raleigh County hospitals and four water systems in two counties, state health officials said today.

title: HOUSE VOTES PLAN TO REPEAL ITS $75-A-DAY TAX DEDUCTION
description: The House voted today to go along with the Senate and repeal an automatic $75-a-day tax deduction for members of Congress. The vote was 356 to 43.

title: New A.M.C. Car
description: The American Motors Corporation will begin production of the new Alliance, a fuel-efficient, front-wheel-drive car, next week at a plant in Kenosha, Wis., a company spokesman said today. The car, designed by A.M.C.'s French partner, Renault, is patterned after Renault's R9, which is selling well in Europe. The Alliance, which will have its debut this fall, is the first joint production project in the United States for Renault and A.M.C.

title: REPAIRING FABRICS WITH REWEAVING
description: With warm weather here to stay for a while, there are no more excuses for putting off the packing away of cold-weather clothes. But before clothes are stored out of sight, they should be checked for spots, stains or damage. If action is taken now, the chances of stains wearing into the fabric or of holes getting bigger are minimized.

title: Auto Executive Named
description: The American Motors Corporation said today that it had named Richard A. Calmes, 49 years old, to the new post of vice president, personnel and industrial relations.

title: FLORIDA SUSPECT, 37, TIED TO 100 MURDERS BY CONTRACT KILLERS
description: A man who the police say may head a hit squad possibly responsible for at least 100 contract killings around the nation has been arrested, the police announced today.

title: Quebec Separatist Arrested After His Return From Exile
description: Yves Langlois, the last of five Quebec separatist guerrillas wanted for the kidnapping of a British diplomat in Montreal 12 years ago, returned home today from exile in France and was arrested.

title: Western Union Launches Satellite
description: The Western Union Corporation's fifth communications satellite was launched successfully into space Tuesday night by a Delta rocket.

title: U.S. JUDGES IMPOSE MISSISSIPPI REDISTRICTING PLAN
description: A three-judge Federal panel in Oxford ordered state officials today to carry out a Congressional redistricting plan that creates the first district in the state with a black majority since the 1960's.

title: Sports of the Times; Looking Back at Satchel
description: SATCHEL PAIGE can look back now. Nothing is gaining on him anymore. Everybody in baseball also can look back now that Satchel Paige has died at age 75, give or take a year or two. Or a laugh or two. And everybody in baseball should look back. Especially those black players, such as Reggie Jackson, Dave Winfield and George Foster, who are making so much more money in one season, if not in a month or two, than Satchel Paige ever made in his lifetime. Or dreamed of making.

title: 17 Die in India Bomb Blast
description: A bomb exploded in a crowded bazaar tonight in the northwestern city of Gauhati, killing 17 people and wounding 28, the United News of India said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Seating Co., Grand Rapids, Mich., has elected three officials of Fuqua Industries to its board of directors. They are J.B. Fuqua, Fuqua Industries' chairman; Lawrence P. Klamon, president, and Carl E. Sanders, a Fuqua Industries director.

title: SOTHEBY'S TO SHUT 2 GALLERIES IN U.S.
description: In its latest move to reduce operations because of declining profits, Sotheby Parke Bernet announced yesterday that it would close its auction galleries on Madison Avenue and East 76th Street and sell its Los Angeles facilities.

title: Mrs. Korchnoi and Son To Get Soviet Exit Visas
description: Officials in Leningrad have told Bella Korchnoi that she and her son, Igor, can leave the Soviet Union to join her husband, the chess grandmaster Viktor, thus apparently ending an emigration battle that began when Mr. Korchnoi defected to the West nearly six years ago.

title: Spot Oil Prices Gain
description: Oil prices on the European spot market advanced yesterday for the third consecutive day as traders cited increasing fears that the fighting in Lebanon would widen and that Arab oil-producing countries would become involved in the conflict.

title: AUTHOR OF GULF'S SUCCESS WRITTEN OUT OF THE PART
description: Twenty-five years ago, Robert H. Allen joined a $2 million-a-year sulfur company and, over the years, turned it into a major energy and natural resources company with annual revenues of $400 million. On Tuesday, his duties there were ended.

title: THE 5-YEAR PLAN-A LOSER 2 WAYS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger clearly shows misguided thinking in the curiously flawed study ''Fiscal Year 1984-1988 Defense Guidance,'' which the Pentagon calls the Administration's first ''complete defense guidance.''

title: WHAT KILLED LONG TERM U.S. BUSINESS PLANNING
description: To the Editor:

title: Stockbroker Is Enjoined
description: A stockbroker, Meyer Blinder, and his firm, Blinder, Robinson & Company, have been permanently enjoined from selling common stock and warrants connected with construction of a gambling casino and hotel in Atlantic City.

title: 3 IN RACE FOR GOVERNOR DIFFER ON TAXES
description: In their first debate, three candidates for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York disagreed yesterday on whether state taxes could be drastically cut.

title: MISS HOLTZMAN AND JUDGE DISPUTE
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney and a Brooklyn judge clashed yesterday over the release of a robbery suspect who is now also a suspect in a murder that took place the day after he was freed from jail.

title: ANTICRIME MEASURE PASSES, CAUSING CONFUSION ON COAST
description: California's justice system was thrust into a state of confusion today by the passage Tuesday of a far-reaching ballot proposition that drastically changed the rules for prosecuting criminal defendants.

title: John S. Williams, 80, Is Dead; Founder of a Shaker Museum
description: John S. Williams, a New York investment broker and founder of the Shaker Museum in Old Chatham, N.Y., died last Thursday at a nursing home in Valatie, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Old Chatham.

title: WITH THE BOSS AWAY...
description: A fly buzzes inside the Oval Office. A Secret Service officer yawns as he strolls a West Wing corridor. In the press office, Jeannie Winnick, an assistant, toys with a new camera at her desk. All 12 telephone lines are silent. With the chief in Europe, the atmosphere inside the White House is genuinely relaxed these days. ''Come on in,'' says Anson Franklin, an assistant press secretary, beckoning visitors into his office. ''It's real busy though,'' he adds, chuckling, ''we might not have time to talk.''

title: NEW JERSEY TRADES RAMAGE AND CHOOSES A TROTTIER IN DRAFT
description: Billy MacMillan, general manager of the new New Jersey hockey team, yesterday managed to snare the high first-round draft choice he coveted. But the move cost his team, formerly the Colorado Rockies, one of its best players, Rob Ramage, a defenseman.

title: N.F.L. Contract Talks Are Reported at a Standstill
description: The latest round of contract talks between the National Football League's management and player union ended today after three days, with neither side changing its position on the players' major demand.

title: HOME BEAT
description: AS their Vienna gallery already dealt in designs from that era, it made sense for Hede and Wolfgang Karolinsky to start manufacturing about 40 lamps from the Wiener Werkstatte period. The WOKA collection, as it is called, includes designs by Josef Hoffmann, Adolf Loos, Koloman Moser and Otto Wagner and all pieces are made using the original tools.

title: AT EVERS, THE CLASS OF '82 HOLDS OWN GRADUATION
description: Graduating seniors at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn held their own commencement last night after the college president canceled it. The ceremony combined elements of black culture and Western academic tradition.

title: THE 5-YEAR PLAN-A LOSER 2 WAYS
description: The Soviet Union has always been blessed with fiveyear plans. Thanks to the Defense Department, we are to have our own in the ''Defense Guidance'' that is to form the basis for Pentagon budget requests for the next five fiscal years. This comprehensive plan, which envisions a possibly ''protracted'' nuclear war, global conventional war and ''space-based'' fighting with anti-satellite weapons, must be examined with great care. It comes close to a declaration of war on the Soviet Union and contradicts and may destroy President Reagan's initiatives toward nuclear arms control.

title: JOHN PAUL WILL FIND A CHANGING ARGENTINE CHURCH
description: When Pope John Paul II arrives here Friday, he will be find a conservative and powerful Argentine Roman Catholic Church in the midst of change.

title: GUS DAVID KUHN
description: Gus David Kuhn, retired president of Kuhn's-Big K Stores Corporation, a general merchandising discount chain, died Tuesday.

title: Make the Poor Pay, and Pay Again
description: Two weeks ago House Republicans devised a splendid way to trim the deficit in their proposed Federal budget: bleed the poor. They lost, but they're back, and today the House will vote on a Republican proposal that improves on the original idea. It would bleed the poor twice as much. The Democrats, too, are putting up a new budget proposal. It may or may not be politically impractical, but the new Republican proposal is morally indefensible.

title: Refunds on Water Given in Jersey
description: More than 18,000 customers of the Hackensack Water Company in Bergen and Hudson Counties who were fined nearly $2 million for excess water use during last year's drought will receive refund checks.

title: TAX TREATY ABUSES ARE CITED
description: Tens of thousands of Americans apparently are illegally avoiding taxes on dividends, interest and other sources of income by having the funds sent to foreign addresses. The practice is costing the Government hundreds of millions of dollars in uncollected taxes, Internal Revenue Service audit documents indicate.

title: SAY THEY DOWNED 19 JETS, LOST 16
description: Israeli and Syrian jets fought two large battles this afternoon over Syrian antiaircraft missile sites in eastern Lebanon, according to communiques made public here.

title: SOVIET SAYS CRUSADE BY REAGAN MAY RISK GLOBAL CATASTROPHE
description: The Soviet Government press agency Tass responded today to President Reagan's call for an ideological crusade against Communism by saying that such a struggle ''may end only in catastrophe.''

title: REGAN SEE NO PLUNGE IN INTEREST RATES FOR '82
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, who has predicted sharp declines in interest rates in the past, cautioned today against expecting any dramatic decline in interest rates this year, even if Congress approves a budget resolution and then a budget.

title: SENATORS DEBATE VOTING RIGHT ACT
description: The Senate began debate today on a revised version of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, and Senator Jesse Helms vowed to filibuster against it ''until the cows come home.''

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: LIGHTING in the garden is important both for esthetics and safety. It is particularly important around entrances and terraces when warm weather arrives and you are apt to be outdoors after dark.

title: TRADE CENTER POWER FAILURE BLACKS OUT FIVE TV STATIONS
description: A power failure blacked out most of the south side of the 110-story office tower at 1 World Trade Center just after 2 P.M. yesterday. It stalled eight elevators carrying passengers for varying periods and interrupted five television stations' programs for about half an hour. One interruption was in Channel 13's telecast of Shakespeare's ''All's Well That Ends Well.''

title: News Analysis
description: ''We're down to the wire here now,'' Representative Trent Lott, the Republican whip, said on the eve of a new House effort to adopt a budget plan for next year. ''This is it. The alternatives are horrendous: a year of confrontation, and collapse of the budget process. People will say, 'a pox on both parties.' ''

title: NEWSWEEK GETS FIFTH NEW EDITOR IN LAST 10 YEARS
description: Newsweek, the nation's second largest weekly news magazine, got a new editor yesterday, its fifth in the last 10 years. The new editor is William D. Broyles Jr., a 37-year-old writer and educator who helped to lift Texas Monthly magazine into a recognized journalistic force in Texas and who has been trying to do the same thing for California magazine, based in Los Angeles.

title: THEATER: 'FRONT PAGE' IN NEW HAVEN
description: NEW HAVEN FOR all their outward contempt for the press, Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur wrote ''The Front Page'' as a tribute to the bad old days of earthy journalism. Any good production of ''The Front Page'' - and Harris Yulin's revival at the Long Wharf Theater is, on all counts, vibrant - must capture both aspects: the cynicism that coats the play like sawdust on a barroom floor and the love for the romantic ephemera of the profession.

title: O'NEILL VETOES COMMUTER TAX IN CONNECTICUT
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, saying he was concerned about ''border wars'' with New York State, vetoed legislation today that would have imposed a commuter tax on New Yorkers working in Connecticut.

title: Military Analysis
description: The momentum of war that so often governs the tactics of an advancing army has carried Israeli tanks and armored infantry to positions from which, with one extra effort, they can block the main escape route to Syria for Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas and their Syrian allies.

title: HERS
description: IGLIMPSED her on the street some months ago. For a moment, I was surprised to see her looking so well, walking around. Part of me still thinks that I nearly killed her. We had been friends, and competitors, years ago. At the time, as I recall, I felt she had some kind of leg up on me - she seemed to get waylaid less than I, had a firmer sense of purpose, a bouncier step, a more cheerful disposition. I must have possessed some qualities that she envied as well, for the rivalry worked both ways: we competed - daintily, tiptoeing around the subject - in our work, our friendships. At one point we quarreled, over something silly, and afterward she informed me that I had looked at her during the quarrel as if I had wanted to kill her.

title: GUATEMALA JUNTA'S CHIEF SAYS GOD GUIDES HIM
description: Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, who took power here after a coup in March, believes that his authority to rule comes from God. On the evening of the coup, the general, dressed in his jungle camouflage uniform, delivered a fiery 13-minute oration to the Guatemalan people that was laced with references to his beliefs. General Rios Montt is a born-again Christian who belongs to the Christian Church of the Word, a fundamentalist group based in California.

title: E.E.C. SAID TO GET STEEL PLAN
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and leaders of the domestic steel industry have proposed to the European Economic Community that its steelmakers restrict their exports to the United States to 4.3 percent of the American market, Government and industry sources said today.

title: CITY SAYS NO TO 'CRISIS RELOCATION'
description: Despite public antipathy and professional skepticism, the Reagan Administration is pressing its ambitious civil defense program. Page B20. By LESLIE BENNETTS

title: DESPITE FOES AND SKEPTICS ADMINISTRATION PRESSES AHEAD ON CIVIL DEFENSE
description: Despite considerable public antipathy and professional skepticism, the Reagan Administration is pressing ahead with an ambitious civil defense program that it believes will make a nuclear war less likely and will minimize American casualties should such a war occur.

title: Volvo Plans Stake In Hamilton Group
description: Volvo announced plans today to purchase part of the Hamilton Brothers group of oil companies based in Denver.

title: IRAQ VOWS TO QUIT IRAN, FIGHT ISRAEL
description: Iraq offered today to withdraw its troops from Iranian territory and to use its military forces against Israel.

title: OHIO GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATES SHIFTING VIEWS TOWARD CENTER
description: Voters in Tuesday's Ohio gubernatorial primaries picked a liberal Democrat and a conservative Republican, each of whom shows signs of shading his views toward the center.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bill McCartney, a former Missouri linebacker who has been serving as defensive coordinator at Michigan, has been named head football coach at the University of Colorado. He succeeds Chuck Fairbanks, who resigned last week to go to the United States Football League.... The New England Patriots signed Kenneth Sims, a University of Texas defensive lineman who was their No.1 draft choice, to a four-year contract.

title: SuperSonics Rule Out Gambling-Firm Merger
description: The Seattle SuperSonics' owners will not merge with a company whose primary business is in gambling.

title: The U.N. Today; June 10, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL

title: Copper Futures Prices Plunge to a 4-Year Low
description: Copper futures prices plunged again yesterday, closing at levels not seen on New York's Commodity Exchange since mid-1978. Neither the heightened Middle East conflict nor the new mine closings announced by producers stanched the selling, which fed on itself during the day as chart resistance points were broken and prices fell to life-of-contract lows.

title: M.T.A. Postpones Subway Purchase
description: At a hearing in Federal District Court yesterday, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority agreed to postpone for three days final action on its controversial plan to purchase 825 subway cars from a Canadian manufacturer. The agreement came after the Budd Company of Michigan sought an injunction against the deal.

title: LAWYER IS TOLD HE MUST YIELD RICHMOND FILE
description: A lawyer for Representative Frederick W. Richmond was held in contempt of court yesterday for refusing to turn over a batch of letters to a Federal grand jury investigating the Brooklyn Democrat.

title: MITTERRAND AFFIRMS FRENCH ECONOMIC POLICY
description: President Francois Mitterrand indicated today that he would press ahead with his policy of economic expansion despite the pressures on the franc and a general expectation that he would have to impose a policy of austerity akin to that of his neighbors.

title: Leans Toward Football
description: Stanley Floyd, the National Collegiate 100-meter champion, has been wondering whether he should channel his talents toward professional football or baseball after his graduation from the University of Houston. Though only 5 feet 10 inches tall and 168 pounds, he is leaning toward football because he believes that Renaldo Nehemiah ''has made the right decision and I am really thinking about doing the same thing.''

title: PENNSYLVANIA KEEPING ITS OLD BUT NOT ITS YOUNG
description: Joseph Koizen stopped for a downtown traffic light. He pointed ahead to several gray-haired Scrantonians crossing the street. ''There,'' said Mr. Koizen, a sociologist who is the deputy director of the Lackawanna County Area Agency for the Aging, ''that says it all. The young move away and the elderly stay behind.''

title: A FEDERAL PROPOSAL TO HURT CHARITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: IN VIETNAM, AN EX-AIDE SPEAKS OUT
description: Dr. Quong Quynh Hoa, who says she is Vietnam's only Communist-era Cabinet Minister to resign, runs a research center at Ho Chi Minh City's Pediatric Hospital 2.

title: Perskie Planning To Leave Senate
description: The State Senate's majority leader, Steven P. Perskie, is telling colleagues he plans to resign and accept a nomination to be a judge of the Superior Court, according to two top state Democrats.

title: Service for Fetuses Blocked
description: A judge has temporarily blocked the release of 17,000 fetuses to people who want to hold a religious burial service. The injunction, issued Tuesday by Judge Dickran M. Tevrizian of the Superior Court, had been sought by the Feminist Women's Health Center in Hollywood in a complaint filed by the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: FOLK ART MUSEUM TO LEND ARTIFACTS
description: The Museum of American Folk Art has prepared a kit to be lent to students and community groups unable to travel to the museum. When a shipping charge is paid, a small part of the museum's collection will be available for a week or two beginning this fall. Accompanying literature encourages teachers to use the kit as a springboard for class lessons in American history, science and sociology.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The tiled shower in my bathroom has separate handles for the hot and cold water. When the hot water is turned on, water leaks out of the cold-water handle. The holding nut for each handle is recessed so deep inside the tile that I cannot grasp it with a pipe wrench if the washers have to be changed. Can this condition be corrected without removing any of the tiles? - L.R., Brooklyn

title: BALLET: 'DANZON CUBANO'
description: THE vibes are excellent over at the new Joyce Theater, conceived and realized by Eliot Feld. Tuesday night the Feld Ballet presented the season's first performance of his ''Danzon Cubano'' and ''La Vida.'' They have never looked better.

title: Goesta Andreasson, Teacher And Busch Quartet Violinist
description: Goesta Andreasson, second violinist in the Busch Quartet from 1919 until 1943, died Tuesday night at a nursing home in Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 87 years od.

title: BALLET: NATALIA MAKAROVA MAKES DEBUT AS CARMEN
description: IN the long run, the only thing that can really rescue weak choreography is an infusion of stronger choreography. Yet, thanks to force of personality, fine dancers occasionally make flawed ballets at least tolerable to watch, and two works were so invigorated by the American Ballet Theater on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on May 20 incorrectly stated the ratio of surplus to loss in the first quarter for United Mutual Savings Bank and the net operating income for Manhattan Savings Bank. The ratio for United Mutual was 3.3. Manhattan Savings lost $8.4 million in the first quarter.

title: DONOVAN INQUIRY WAS DISCOURAGED, WEBSTER SAYS
description: William H. Webster, F.B.I. Director, said today that a top aide to President Reagan had discouraged the bureau from asking Raymond J. Donovan, now the Secretary of Labor, about his possible ties to organized crime figures.

title: Chessie Port Plans
description: The Chessie System plans to spend more than $58 million and create 145 new jobs to modernize and add to its rail and coal loading facilities here, a Chessie spokesman said. The railroad has asked the Peninsula Ports Authority of Virginia for permission to sell tax-free industrial revenue bonds to finance the project.

title: 1,000 PROTESTING STUDENTS IN SEOUL BATTLE OF RIOT POLICEMEN
description: More than 1,000 anti-Government students at a South Korean university battled hundreds of riot policemen for more than an hour Tuesday, according to university officials.

title: Strike at Airline Continues
description: Bolstered by a membership vote refusing a company offer by a 5-to-1 margin, leaders of the striking machinists union pushed today for renewed negotiations with Northwest Airlines. There was no reply from the airline, but a spokesman had said Tuesday that negotiators had gone ''as far as we can go.''

title: FROM STRATEGY TO CHITCHAT
description: Everything from strategizing to chitchat can be heard over the Air Force One lines, as taped by Mr. Stogel. An example of the former is this talk on Oct. 15, 1981, between President Reagan, flying to a speaking engagement, and James A. Baker 3d, his chief of staff.

title: THE RESCUE OF DELTA DATA SYSTEMS
description: For the small companies that come and go at the feet of the industry's giants, computer terminal manufacturing can be a business of sudden extremes.

title: Nugget Loses Glitter
description: David Thompson, considered the nation's highest paid athlete in 1976-77 after he signed his second contract with the Nuggets, worth $800,000 per season, lost his starting role with Denver when he injured a knee just before the 1981 exhibition schedule began.

title: 25,000 Sing for Arms Freeze
description: More than 25,000 antinuclear demonstrators lighted candles and joined John Denver in singing ''America the Beautiful'' Tuesday night to show their support for a halt to the nuclear arms race. Mr. Denver, who sponsored the huge gathering along with the Colorado Council of Churches, said the organizers hoped to reach a broad spectrum of people ''looking for constructive ways to peace.''

title: Trudeau Warns of the Danger Of a Wider War in the Mideast
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada warned Israel today that the invasion of Lebanon could lead to a wider Middle East war.

title: U.S. Flotilla in Position If Evacuation Is Needed
