description: The United States Navy has moved a flotilla of warships, including the aircraft carrier Kennedy, off the coast of Lebanon to evacuate American citizens who might be caught in the fighting there, according to the Defense Department.

title: Harriet T. Righter, 104; Led Scrabble Company
description: Harriet T. Righter, the former president of the Selchow & Righter Company, manufacturers of Scrabble and Parcheesi, died Tuesday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 104 years old and was a lifelong resident of Brooklyn.

title: Novo Starts to Sell Synthetic Insulin
description: Novo Industri of Denmark said that it would begin today to sell to British and Irish diabetes victims the first synthetic insulin chemically identical to that produced in the human pancreas.

title: WITNESS SAYS HINCKLEY PLAGIARIZED IDEAS FROM PSYCHIATRISTS
description: A prosecution psychiatrist testified today that experts hired by the defense to examine John W. Hinckley Jr. had unwittingly planted ideas in the defendant's head that he used to embellish his fantasies and lie about his mental state.

title: New Albums Celebrate Sinatra-Dorsey Team
description: Frank Sinatra has had many heydays, but his first was certainly in the days when he was the ''boy singer'' with the Tommy Dorsey band in the 1940's.

title: Product Introductions
description: May showed a decline in new product introductions from May last year and its poor showing pulled the total for the first five months of the year down below 1981's results. May's was 142 compared with 149, while the year-to-date slipped to 532 from 536. That is the report from the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News.

title: Jersey Court Bars Release of Inmates
description: The State Supreme Court refused today to permit the immediate release of 46 minor offenders serving time in the seriously overcrowded Hudson County Jail.

title: 4 Agencies Lead Field In Awards for Radio
description: More lunch and Clios were served up at the Sheraton Centre yesterday, this time for radio advertising, not print like Tuesday.

title: BRIEFING
description: Wired for Cable

title: BELL-G.T.E. CELLULAR RADIO PLAN ASSAILED
description: The chairman of the MCI Communications Corporation charged today that the nation's two largest phone companies, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, had conspired to capture 29 of the top 30 markets for a new type of mobile phone service.

title: REAGANS DINE IN CASTLE WITH NATO LEADERS
description: The flags of the 16 North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations lined both sides of the red-carpeted cobblestone driveway leading to Schloss Augustusburg 20 miles north of Bonn tonight as Karl Carstens, the President of West Germany, entertained 260 guests at a state dinner.

title: ISRAELIS IN SIGHT OF CITY OF BEIRUT
description: Israel's ground forces drove to within sight of Beirut today as its fighter-bombers struck heavily at Syrian surface-to-air missile batteries east of here.

title: GUATEMALAN ASSUMES SOLE POWER, OUSTING OTHER MEMBERS OF JUNTA
description: Gen. Efrain Rios Montt deposed his two fellow junta members today and named himself President. The move broke a pledge that General Rios Montt made shortly after the junta took power in a bloodless coup on March 23. He had promised to be only a caretaker ruler and not seek the presidency.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Monday in Metropoli- tan Report about a law panel that views atomic arms as illegal incor- rectly identified John H. E. Fried. He is a former consultant to the United Nations on international law and a re- tired City University professor of political science.

title: STOCK DIP FOR MESA AND CITIES SERVICE
description: Stocks of both the Cities Service Company and the Mesa Petroleum Company declined yesterday as doubt grew that their takeover duel would result in an acquisition.

title: FLOOD LOSSES IN CONNECTICUT
description: Businesses and factories across southern Connecticut are reporting millions of dollars in flood damage and lost sales after the heavy rains last weekend, a spot-check yesterday showed.

title: GENERAL ASSEMBLY MEETING IS SOUGHT BY SOME DELEGATES
description: As fighting continued in Lebanon, delegates here continued discussions today on whether to call an emergency session of the General Assembly,

title: REGAN SUGGEST DELAYING PENSION LIMIT CHANGES
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan suggested today that any revision of inflation adjustments for tax-deductible pension fund contributions by employers should be delayed until a bipartisan commission makes recommendations for changing the formula for annual cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security.

title: Bank on Coast In British Deal
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, a bank holding company based in Los Angeles, is negotiating to acquire a 29.9 percent equity interest in Hoare Govett Ltd., a British brokerage firm, the two said in a joint statement today.

title: SOME U.S. MONEY PROPOSED FOR PROGRAMS GIVEN TO STATES
description: The Federal Government may continue to provide some money for the 40 programs the Reagan Administration wants to hand over to the states, an Administration official said this week.

title: VOTE IN CALIFORNIA INDICATES POSSIBLE TROUBLE FOR BROWN
description: After a primary election that produced danger signals for the continued political success of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., lineups were in place today for a general election campaign that could produce major changes in California's political scene.

title: CONFIDENT NEWCOMER FOR DEMOCRATS
description: When Frank Raleigh Lautenberg was growing up in Paterson, he did not have to apologize for his family's wealth. There was none.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 10, 1982; Markets
description: Stock prices declined sharply, piercing the 800-mark widely considered a key support level, to close near its two-year low. The Dow Jones industrial average, which has tumbled 74 points in the last four weeks, fell 6.66 points, to 795.57. Analysts said that the decline, fueled by panic selling, could send prices down to the 780 level on the Dow average in the next few days. (Page D1.)

title: Linde Gets Soviet Job
description: Linde A.G. said today that it had won an engineering contract (amount undisclosed) from the Russians for a petrochemical complex to be built at Kalush in the Ukraine. The plant, to cost a total of $125 million, will produce ethylene and other feedstocks.

title: Queens Man Guilty In 1981 Slaying
description: A Queens man was convicted yesterday of the slaying of an auto mechanic who had resisted the attempted theft of his portable radio. A jury returned the verdict in State Supreme Court in Queens against Louis Bradley, 21 years old, of 115-45 146th Street, Jamaica. Mr. Bradley was convicted of second-degree murder and attempted robbery.

title: HUNTER GRADUATES TOLD OF NEED TO REBUILD THE CITY
description: Eleanor Holmes Norton, speaking at Hunter College's 150th commencement yesterday, said New York City needed rebuilding and there were ''too few healing and unifying voices, especially among its leadership.''

title: Rains and High Winds Lash the Middle West
description: By The Associated Press Storms whipped through the Middle West with 100-mile-per-hour winds yesterday, creating a rash of tornadoes and torrents of rain that sent rivers over their banks into towns and cities.

title: MURIEL SIEBERT: BANK 'PIONEER'
description: When Muriel Siebert took over as New York State Superintendent of Banks five years ago, she knew she would have a lot to learn. Despite a successful career in the securities industry, she had little direct experience in banking.

title: Saudis and Aden in a Thaw
description: Pro-Western Saudi Arabia and Soviet-aligned Southern Yemen will move soon to improve their tense relations, the Saudi Interior Minister, Prince Nayef ibn Abdel-Aziz said today as he ended a visit here. ''A lot will be done in the near future to create strong relaations between the two sister countries and achieve a joint effort to serve Arab causes,'' he said.

title: Salvadoran Colonel Says Army Killed 135 in Sweep
description: The commander of a United Statestrained battalion that has just ended a sweep through northern El Salvador said today that 135 guerrillas and 3 Government soldiers had died in the eight days of fighting.

title: PRETORIA CLERICS ATTACK APARTHEID
description: One hundred and twenty three white ministers of the Dutch Reformed Church declared today that the nation's official racial segregation policy ''cannot be defended scripturally'' and called for racial equality.

title: HENNING MIKKELSEN
description: Henning Dahl Mikkelsen, the Danishborn cartoonist who created the popular comic strip ''Ferd'nand,'' died Friday of a heart attack at 67 years of age.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In this transcendental moment for Guatemala, I assume the weight of governing only on my shoulders.'' -Gen. Efrain Rios Montt. (A8:3.)

title: TEXT OF PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS IN WEST GERMANY ON ARMS AND DISARMAMANT
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's address to the West German Parliament today, as made public by White House officials:

title: An Israeli General Says There Must Be Talks
description: Gen. Benjamin Ben-Eliezer of Israel said today that his country's army would not leave Lebanon until there was an ''agreement guaranteeing the security of Israel from the P.L.O.''

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: CONTROL films, transparent tinted plastic sheets that have a reflective facing on one side to reflect the sun's heat during the summer, have been widely used for years on the windows of commercial buildings to cut the cost of air-conditioning. In recent years, similar types of window film have also become popular for use in homes to save on energy costs in winter and summer and to help keep the house cooler in summer.

title: U.S. IS WARNED ON A TROOP PULLOUT IN EUROPE
description: A withdrawal of American forces from Europe might prompt the weaker nations of the Continent to make individual accommodations with the Soviet Union and encourage large parts of Western Europe to fall under Soviet influence, former Under Secretary of State George W. Ball said today.

title: SENATE PANEL REJECTS NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee rejected a resolution today that called for a freeze in Soviet and American nuclear arsenals and instead endorsed a measure acceptable to the Reagan Administration.

title: Illinois House Rejects Bid to Spur Rights Plan
description: The Illinois House of Representatives today blocked a proposed legislative rules change that proponents of the Federal equal rights amendment consider crucial to the proposed amendment's chances of passage in Illinois.

title: EX-EDITOR REPORTS ON HIS ADDICTION
description: Michael Balfe Howard, an heir to the Scripps-Howard fortune, testified Tuesday that that he had taken advantage of the narcotics agent he hired as a bodyguard.

title: PERILOUS 'DECAPITATION' STRATEGY
description: To the Editor:

title: REFUGEES IN LEBANON NEED FOOD CRITICALLY
description: United Nations observers said today that thousands of Lebanese civilians, uprooted from their homes by the Israeli advance, were in critical need of food and water.

title: ISLE OFF AFRICA ABOUT TO UNDERGO PLACID UPHEAVAL
description: The American image-makers hired to save the job of the venerable Prime Minister who has been in office for the last 22 of his 82 years have hurriedly decamped from this Indian Ocean island, apparently to avoid charges that they were ''foreign mercenaries'' recruited by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: ALL-AMERICAN VICTIMS OF THE DRYSDALE FIASCO
description: To the Editor:

title: M IS FOR THE MANY THINGS...
description: A woman stopped by to see Fritz Schmid one recent Saturday, but then women always visit Mr. Schmid at the King Kullen supermarket. This one, however, was different. She didn't want lamb chops or hamburger.

title: DANCERS' BRAINS: ONLY IN THEIR FEET?
description: VIRGIL THOMSON once complained that dancers have ''no conversation.'' And that's essentially a variant of the old familiar charge, ''Dancers are dumb.''

title: T. F. Childs, 73, Ex-President Of Lenox Hill Hospital, Dead
description: Theodore F. Childs, retired president of Lenox Hill Hospital and former president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, died Sunday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. He was 73 years old and had lived in Yarmouth Port, Mass., since 1971.

title: C.I.A. Deputy Confirmed
description: The Senate today unanimously approved the nomination of John N. McMahon as deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Mr. McMahon, 52 years old, a career intelligence officer, replaces Adm. Bobby R. Inman, who resigned April 21 after a 30-year military and intelligence career to enter private business.

title: DO TWO RESEARCH CHIMPS WANT TO RETIRE? ASK THEM, SOME PEOPLE SAY
description: Two chimpanzees who were taught to ''talk'' with sign language are heading for an easy retirement instead of spending their future in laboratory cages.

title: TURKEY'S JEWS ARE UNDER NO THREAT
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. and Toyota In Further Talks
description: Officials of the General Motors Corporation and Toyota Motor Company have concluded a round of talks on joint production of a small car in the United States.

title: Deutsch to Introduce Two Investment Funds
description: David Deutsch Associates will be the agency for the introduction of two new investment funds from the National Securities and Research Corporation. They are National Cash Reserves and National Government Reserves, which will primarily be distributed through investment brokers and dealers and managed by National Securities and Research.

title: A CHANGING FOCUS IN DESIGN BUSINESS
description: FIVE years ago, the New York interior designer Angelo Donghia and his eight-person staff spent about 80 percent of their time on residential work and the rest on contract jobs - offices, hotels, restaurants and other commercial spaces. Mr. Donghia's company dealt primarily with the cosmetic element of design. Architects handled structural considerations.

title: Great Plains Water Bill Gets Conditional Federal Backing
description: The Reagan Administration has voiced support for legislation to begin rebuilding the dwindling underground water supplies of the Great Plains, but with a provision that it have the final say on whether the project should go forward.

title: Oral Roberts's Son, 37, Found Shot Dead in Car
description: Ronald Roberts, the 37-year-old son of the evangelist Oral Roberts, was found shot dead in his car early today, investigators said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Niagara Mohawk Power Co.'s $75 million of 10-year, 15 3/4 percent coupon bonds due in 1992 were priced at 99.25 to yield 15.90 percent by underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Squibb Sees Sales Of Capoten Rising
description: The Squibb Corporatation said that a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee recommendation regarding captopril, a hypertension treatment marketed by the company under the name Capoten, could potentially double the drug's market. Last year, domestic sales of Capoten, now used only in the treatment of severe hypertension, were between $10 million and $20 million.

title: DATA SHOWS 2 RINGS CIRCLING NEPTUNE
description: American astronomers reported yesterday the discovery of what appear to be two faint rings circling the planet Neptune. The finding, if confirmed, would mean that all four of the giant outer planets have ring systems.

title: Armenian to Get New Trial
description: A jury was selected today to hear the re-trial of an Armenian charged with firebombing the house of a Turkish diplomat, who was assassinated two years later. A mistrial was declared May 5 in the first trial of Harout Sassounian, 21 years old, after several jurors said they had heard news reports about the assassination of another Turkish diplomat in New England. Federal District Judge Terry Hatter warned the jury not to listen to or read any accounts of the new proceedings.

title: Bell Scientist Objects to Bill
description: Pending telecommunications legislation could weaken Bell Laboratories, possibly threatening a vital part of the national program for pure scientific research, a Bell Labs vice president told the House Committee on Science and Technology today.

title: Bridge: Hungarians Adding Talent To New York Community
description: The decision of George Bernard Shaw to make the egregious Zoltan Karpathy what Alan Jay Lerner later described as ''a hairy hound from Budapest'' undoubtedly did some harm to the image of the Hungarian people.

title: Miriam H. Morris, 90, Collector of Americana
description: Miriam H. Morris, owner of ''The Lindens,'' the oldest house in the capital, and a well-known collector of 17th-@ and 18th-century American furniture and decorative arts, died here last Thursday of cancer. She was 90 years old.

title: CHALLENGER APPEARS SLUGGISH
description: Gerry Cooney had boxed his last round, No. 244, in preparation for Larry Holmes and, as he removed the tape from his hands, he apologized Tuesday to his training-session audience for looking so bad.

title: BRITONS STAGE NEW LANDING BUT THE COST IS CALLED HIGH
description: British troops have staged a major new landing in the Falkland Islands but have suffered heavily in the process, correspondents' reports and military sources said tonight.

title: CON ED GRANTED RISE OF 8.7% IN GAS RATES
description: The Public Service Commission today granted Consolidated Edison an increase in its natural-gas rates that will raise revenue by $52.4 million.

title: Market Place; How Options Can Be Used
description: ADECADE ago, selling stocks short was virtually the only game in t own for nervy speculators out to make money in a declining market. But with the growth in options trading, there are other strategies t o use in trying to capitalize on falling stock prices. These range f rom buying put options and selling ''naked'' call options to a rranging ''bear spreads.''

title: AEG-Telefunken
description: AEG-Telefunken workers rebuffed the ailing electrical company's plan for making AEG a holding company and selling shares to outside parties and instead urged the Government to take a direct shareholders' position. The workers objected in particular to plans for General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain to buy a 40 percent stake in a new subsidiary, AEG-Technik, that would embrace the profitable information technology, communications and turbines businesses.

title: French Steel Expansion
description: The French Cabinet adopted a plan today to modernize the French steel industry.

title: Satchel
description: Leroy (Satchel) Paige, the fabled black pitcher who died this week at 75 or thereabouts, was one of those wondrously endowed and worldly athletes who looms larger than any sports arena.

title: GARDENING
description: SHRUBBERY is galloping ahead with new growth spurred on by recent rainfall. This is good news for gardeners who may want to polish their green thumbs and try some plant cloning. This new soft growth is especially easy to root. Each new plant will grow up to be exactly like the parent. Unlike sowing seeds, which may not breed true or germinate, this type of propagation is a sure way to produce lookalikes.

title: Required Reading Conflicting Aims
description: From the Republican Party platform, as adopted in July, 1980: ''Republicans commit themselves to an immediate increase in defense spending to be applied judiciously to critically needed programs. We will build toward a sustained defense expenditure sufficient to close the gap with the Soviets, and ultimately reach the position of military superiority that the American people demand.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: To Save a Life

title: Student Appeals In Plagiarism Case
description: A Princeton University student from Stamford, Conn., unmoved by a judge's refusal to overrule a school decision to withhold her diploma because of plagiarism, has appealed to a higher court.

title: THE KREMLIN RACE: IS ANDROPOV OUT?
description: To the Editor:

title: AGENT HIRED TO FIGHT TO PREVENT ABORTION OF 11-YEAR-OLD GIRL
description: An antiabortion group hired a private detective to track down a mother who wants her pregnant 11-year-old daughter to have an abortion but failed to change the woman's mind.

title: RED SOX SET BACK YANKEES
description: After three bottles soared over Fenway Park's high center-field wall in the eighth inning tonight and landed near Ken Griffey of the Yankees, the public address announcer cautioned the fans that if they didn't refrain from throwing debris onto the field, the Red Sox could forfeit the game.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PARK YOUR TROUBLES

title: STATE PASSES A TAKEOVER OF SOME LOCAL MEDICAID
description: The Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill that would have the state take over a portion of local health-care costs for one year.

title: An Appraisal
description: conserving Home of the Future.

title: Rotarians Vote to Bar Racial Restrictions
description: Delegates to Rotary International's annual convention voted overwhelmingly today to prohibit racial restrictions on membership. The move was in reaction to votes by Rotary's chapter at Birmingham, Ala., to retain an all-white membership policy.

title: U.S. Stockpile Plan Reported
description: The Reagan Administration has sent to Congress a secret plan proposing purchases of critical materials for the national defense stockpile for the next five years, a Government official said today.

title: Technology; Longer-Lived Batteries
description: IN the quarter-century that has produced pocket calculators, smoke detectors for the bedroom ceiling, headphone-equipped stereos for joggers and an array of other battery-powered devices, one rule has remained largely unchallenged: The batteries wear out.

title: BACKING FOR ISRAEL CALLED DIMINISHED
description: The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Clement J. Zablocki, said today that Congressional support for Israel had ''somewhat diminished'' in the aftermath of Israel's attacks on Palestinian strongholds in Lebanon.

title: LEBANON'S CHRISTIANS AND MOSLEMS ASK UNITY
description: Lebanese Christian and Moslem leaders urged all Lebanese today to close ranks and rally around President Elias Sarkis and his Government to confront the grave situation arising from Israel's invasion of their country.

title: REAGAN IN EUROPE AVOIDS THE PUBLIC
description: In a program about President Reagan's arrival in West Germany, a television station here showed film this afternoon of past visits by Mr. Reagan's predecessors. Presidents Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon and Carter were all seen speaking outdoors, waving from open motorcades and working the crowds.

title: LANSING GOVERNOR ORDERS STATE WORKERS LAID OFF
description: Unable to win wage concessions from Michigan's largest union of state employees, Gov. William G. Milliken is ordering a combination of temporary and indefinite layoffs for 16,000 workers.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: IF world's fairs exist in part to provide a sense of fantasy, they do so on every possible level -from the total escape of rides and imaginary environments to the much more plausible fantasies of hinting at a different kind of everyday life.

title: U.S. ARTS GRANTS TO ORCHESTRAS CUT $500,000
description: The National Endowment for the Arts today announced 154 grants to American concert orchestras with the value of the awards cut $500,000 from last year's total in a reflection of reduced Federal spending for the arts.

title: Early Hints Of the Slump
description: President Reagan's chief economist conceded today that the White House privately projected in February 1981 that a recession was on its way. Yet, in its public forecasts, the Administration was saying just the opposite - and it was October before Mr. Reagan acknowledged the downturn.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 10, 1982
description: International Israel said it had destroyed the Syrian ground-to-air missile system in the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon. Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, in a broadcast interview, described the strikes as ''one of the most brilliant, complicated and intricate operations'' ever carried out by Israel and said they represented ''a turning point'' in the fighting. (Page A1, Column 6.) Thousands of Lebanese civilians, uprooted from their homes by the Israeli advance, are in critical need of food and water, United Nations observers said. The Israeli Army and the United Nations have delivered some supplies, but the situation is still serious, United Nations officials said. (A1:6.)

title: Advertising; Recovery Is in Sight At Esquire
description: FOR Esquire magazine, next year will bring not only a 12 percent ad rate increase but also a 50th anniversary, and the young entrepreneurs who are now running it are trying think up a proper way to celebrate, the 50 years, that is.

title: Swimmers Cautioned On Connecticut Rivers
description: Connecticut residents should not swim in rivers which were contaminated with sewage by the floods of last weekend, the Commissioner of Health Services, Dr. Douglas S. Lloyd, said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50 ** Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Bally Interest in Namco
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, leading manufacturer and distributor of coin-operated electronic amusement games, announced today that it had purchased for an undisclosed sum a small equity interest in Namco Ltd. of Japan, which designs and makes video games.

title: COMBING THE WRECKAGE
description: As Israel's forces cut through Lebanon, we are told by Israeli and some American voices that the invasion actually presents a great opportunity for peace. Arab radicals are on the run, they say, and moderates may now come to the negotiating table. American leadership must seize the diplomatic moment.

title: TOUGH DAYS AT THE OFFICE OVER FOR CITIBANK AIDE
description: The day Henry Mueller took over as chairman of Citibank's key credit policy committee, the Herstatt Bank failure in West Germany shook the banking world.

title: DANCE: 'ACTS OF LIGHT' OPENS FOR GRAHAM TROUPE
description: THE Martha Graham Dance Company opened last night at the City Center, and it is safe to say there will be nothing like this company or its works on view anywhere else this season. The sign posted outside the door should simply say ''Genius at Work.''

title: Alza Share Switch With Ciba-Geigy
description: The Alza Corporation, a Palo Alto, Calif., pharmaceutical research conern, said that its shareholders had approved a plan proposed at the company's annual meeting to exchange 100,000 nonvoting preferred shares and 2.9 million nonvoting convertible class B common shares for the 8.7 million voting convertible preferred shares currently owned by Ciba-Geigy of Basel, Switzerland, and Ciba-Geigy of Ardsley, N.Y.

title: AUTHOR FINDS THE HARLEM OF LEGEND IS NO MORE
description: IN a sense, it is all over for black Harlem. The curtain has come down on the Harlem of legend. Harlem blossomed between two world wars, nurtured creative artists, harbored black people's ideas and helped forge world leaders such as Ghana's Nkrumah and Nigeria's Azikiwe. If the Statue of Liberty beckoned some future Americans, Harlem summoned others.

title: News Analysis
description: The busiest primary day of the spring appears to have turned out better for political parties than for any particular brand of political ideology and to have rewarded the often tedious political necessities of organization and money.

title: EDMOND S. BAUER
description: Edmond S. Bauer, chairman of the board and president of Fisher Controls International, died Tuesday at St. John's Mercy Medical Center in St. Louis after injuring himself in an accidental fall.

title: RADIO BUFFS TUNE IN ON AIR FORCE ONE
description: When Air Force One wheels back across the Atlantic from the European summit meetings this week, Stewart Stogel will be all ears up at his home in Mt. Vernon, N.Y., with his $8 antenna, $150 ham receiver and $15 manual of not-so-secret Government radio frequencies. He fully expects to tune in on President Reagan's aircraft communication lines and to eavesdrop on most unscrambled calls between the President and White House aides.

title: ARMY PRESSES A WIDE EFFORT TO FIGHT SEXUAL HARASSMENT
description: Two Army women were preparing recently for a scene in an Army film on sexual harassment when a group of men nearby made animalistic noises in their direction. It was a good, and unrehearsed, example of what the Army is trying to combat.

title: HAIG SEES A SHIFT IN AIMS OF ISRAEL
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., saying that the fighting in Lebanon had grown ''somewhat more ominous'' in the last 24 hours, suggested today that Israel might be shifting its originally announced objective in Lebanon and was now seeking to take on Syrian forces in combat.

title: INDEPENDENT REPUBLICAN NOMINEE
description: It may have been a ''wonderful'' victory, but she hardly paused long enough to let it take hold. Barely 12 hours after Jeffrey Bell, her opponent in New Jersey's Republican primary for the United States Senate, conceded defeat, Representative Millicent Fenwick was on her way back to

title: THE CORPORATE-REFORM FUROR
description: Corporate executives do not like lawyers telling them what to do - especially when they think the lawyers' approach will lead to more lawsuits, less risk-taking and fewer candidates willing to serve on boards of directors.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt FAMILY TRADE. By James Carroll. 417 pages. Little, Brown. $14.95.

title: TARZAN WAS THE STAR ONCE, AND NOT BO DEREK
description: GOLDWYN-MAY-ER'S victory last week in a court case set Sam Marx to reminiscing. The Edgar Rice Burroughs estate had sued M-G-M over the studio's 1981 ''Tarzan, the Ape Man,'' a movie in which the emphasis was very definitely placed on a nude Bo Derek as Jane. Tarzan was essentially a grunting straight man both to Miss Derek's plucky Jane and to a randy orangutan. A year ago, the estate charged copyright infringement and sought unsuccessfully to block the release of the movie. There was a definite implication that the estate saw nothing funny in a movie that did not treat Mr. Burroughs's ape man with proper reverence.

title: JAPAN, AT U.N., EXPLAINS PLAN TO REARM
description: The Japanese government said today that it is building up its military forces as a first step toward eventually reducing the level of armaments in the world.

title: Entertainer's Wife Drowns
description: Jaren Tate Lewis, estranged wife of the entertainer Jerry Lee Lewis, drowned today in a friend's swimming pool, the police said. Mr. Lewis said through a spokesman that he was ''shocked and saddened'' by the death. The body of Mrs. Lewis, 39, was taken to the Shelby County Medical Examiner for a ruling on the cause of death, said Chief Dennie Joyner of the Collierville Police.

title: U.S. EASES POSITION ON RACIAL BALANCE OF CITY'S TEACHERS
description: The Federal Department of Education backed away today from its finding that the New York City Board of Education had failed to comply with an agreement to improve the racial balance of teachers in the city's public schools.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aloha Airlines Inc. of Honolulu said it had received authorization from its board to exercise an option acquired in 1979 to purchase 282,443, or 13.3 percent, of its common stock outstanding at $10 a share from International Air Services Co. of Burlingame, Calif.

title: Weaver Takes Swing
description: Most baseball managers are content to vent their hostilities by kicking dirt at umpires and flinging their caps to the ground. Not Earl Weaver.

title: Would There Were No Salvador News
description: There was a sour Salvadoran chord in President Reagan's call for a democratic crusade the other day. The President spoke as if the conflict there were only between Cuban-backed guerrillas and 1.4 million people who chose freedom by voting last March. ''Strange,'' he complained, ''but there has been little if any news coverage of that war since the election.''

title: TRYING THE LOFT LIFE AFTERYEARS UPTOWN
description: KATE and John Lloyd lived for 32 years in a town house on the Upper East Side. Then, like many couples whose children have gone off to live their own lives, the Lloyds decided they no longer needed a four-story house.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Clips and Talks to Mark Barrymore Anniversary
description: To mark the 100th anniversary of his birth, John Barrymore will be honored July 6 at 8 P.M. with ''The Great Profile,'' a commemorative program at the recently restored Beacon Theater, Broadway and West 74th Street.

title: Cunningham Rests Federal Tax Case
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the former state Democratic chairman, rested his tax case in Federal District Court yesterday after calling on Robert S. Strauss, the former Democratic national chairman; former Mayor Abraham D. Beame, and Justice Burton B. Roberts of State Supreme Court to testify on his behalf.

title: WILLIAM W. PEVEAR
description: William W. Pevear, a former senior vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died Tuesday at the Stamford (Conn.) Hospital.

title: Britain Puts Two Men on Trial On Charge of Spying for Cuba
description: A prosecutor said today that two men picked up at Gatwick Airport with an assortment of ''cloak and dagger stuff'' had been sent to Britain by Cuba.

title: PLAYER TELLS OF WIDE DRUG USE IN N.F.L.
description: Don Reese, a pro football player who in 1977 was sentenced to a year in prison for selling cocaine, has charged that the drug ''now controls and corrupts the game because so many players are on it.''

title: Braniff Fights Airport
description: The Braniff International Corporation, in court papers filed Tuesday, challenges the right of the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport Authority to evict the airline. Judge John Flowers set a June 22 hearing. Braniff owes more than $1.8 million in back rent on the airport facilities it used until it quit flying May 12 and got Chapter 11 status under the bankruptcy laws.

title: Boise Sees Loss
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation, a leading forest and paper products concern, said it expected to report a loss for the second quarter because of the continuing impact of the depressed home building market and the rapidly weakening pulp and paper markets. Unless operating results showed continued improvement, the company added, there might also be a first-half deficit. It earned $5.56 million in the first quarter.

title: THOSE NAMED 'TRAKTOR' STILL WINCE
description: It is hard to imagine a Russia without Ivans or Borises. But there was a time when the blond child frolicking in a Moscow courtyard was as likely to respond to names like Traktor or Elektrifikatsiya.

title: Edward Rutledge Hawn, 73, Leader of Godfrey Orchestra
description: Edward Rutledge Hawn, a musician, died Monday in Cedars Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles.

title: BRITONS REASSURED BY REAGAN'S VISIT
description: President Reagan ended a 41-hour visit to Britain today that succeeded in strengthening relations between the two traditional allies, despite a lack of agreement on the long-term future of the Falkland Islands.

title: General Cinema Net Up
description: The General Cinema Corporation, the nation's largest soft drink bottler and motion-picture exhibitor, said yesterday that net income in its second fiscal quarter increased 64.5 percent, to $12.5 million, or $1.19 a share, from $7.6 million, or 69 cents, in the similar period last year. Revenues rose 14.7 percent, to $206.9 million, from $180.4 million.

title: REAGAN SUGGESTS LIMIT ON TROOPS FOR 2 ALLIANCES
description: President Reagan, expressing sympathy with the goal of the European antinuclear movement but differing with its tactics, urged today that East and West agree to a ceiling of 700,000 ground troops for each alliance as ''a major step toward a safer Europe.''

title: VERSATILE LAKERS HAILED
description: Pat Riley, the coach of the Lakers, was a playing member of the 1972 Los Angeles team that set a record by winning 33 straight games. As a coach, Riley led a team that was 8-0 against two playoff opponents, Phoenix and San Antonio, also a record. But until Tuesday night, when the Lakers ended the four-ofseven-game National Basketball Association championship series against the Philadelphia 76ers in the sixth game, 114-104, he had refused to say which Laker team was better.

title: EX-CANNON CHIEF IS JOINING LAW FIRM
description: Otto G. Stolz, who was forced out in April as chairman and chief executive officer of the Cannon Mills Company, the sheet and towel manufacturer, has been named a partner in the New York Law firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie & Alexander and will head the firm's Washington office.

title: CHINTZ FLOWERS IN GRAND REVIVAL
description: CHINTZ. Just the word conjures up a number of decorating worlds: gracious rooms by such legendary designers as Elsie de Wolfe and Sybil Colefax, cozy morning rooms in English country houses and the currently popular amalgam of these two styles, as evidenced in the work of several prominent New York designers, including Mario Buatta, Thomas Fleming and his partner, Keith Irvine, and Mark Hampton. In these modern adaptations, as well as their predecessors, the overall image is fresh and flowery - rooms festooned with flounced draperies, skirted tables, pillow-laden canopied beds and flounced slipper chairs.

title: News Analysis
description: A little song has been cropping up on West German television the past few weeks. It is sung by Prof. Joseph Beuys, a 61-year-old former Stuka dive bomber pilot and a sculptor of international reputation.

title: Big Small Talk
description: News is news. Newspapers keep expiring but national circulation has held steady for a decade, and TV news, meanwhile, is positively booming. The day-and-night Cable News Network, only two years old, already has a little brother, CNN 2. ABC and Group W are about to launch one and then two rivals. Local stations around the country have been adding afternoon news. All three networks are rushing to add more news time in the late-night and early-morning hours.

title: Jail Order Stayed In Richmond Case
description: An attorney for Representative Frederick W. Richmond yesterday won a stay of a contempt order that could have sent the lawyer to jail for refusing to turn 10 letters over to a Federal grand jury.

title: VOTES IN ALBANY GIVE CITY POWER TO ENACT SURTAX
description: The State Legislature tonight approved a bill that would allow New York City to impose a surcharge on the city income taxes paid by its residents.

title: Assets Rise Again at Funds
description: The assets of the nation's money market funds rose $1.68 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to a record $202.68 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Tamara M. Schuchalter Married to Steven Wagner
description: Tamara Minna Schuchalter, daughter of Mrs. Mayer Moskowitz of Brooklyn and Ralph Schuchalter of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Steven Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Wagner of Far Rockaway, Queens. Rabbi Israel Chait performed the ceremony at the Shaare Zion Synagogue in Brooklyn.

title: HENRY VIII BYPASSED
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE theme party could be making a comeback. Last week's ''Free S ophia Loren!'' parties were swiftly followed this week by ''Sophia I s Free!'' parties. And, rather less flamboyantly, Dorothy H ammerstein gave herself an Australian birthday party in her Park A venue apartment the other evening.

title: HARVARD COMMENCEMENT NOTES NUCLEAR WAR PREIL
description: Harvard University replayed one of America's oldest secular ceremonies for the 331st time today, conferring graduate and undergraduate degrees on 4,706 men and women. Twelve persons received honorary degrees, including Mother Teresa of Calcutta, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979 for work among the poor in India.

title: SPAIN'S COMMUNIST CHIEF QUITS, SHAKING PARTY
description: The Communist Party's longtime secretary general, Santiago Carrillo, resigned suddenly Wednesday night, throwing the party into its most severe leadership crisis since the death of Francisco Franco in 1975.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Seminar Center With Rabbits, Riv Vu

title: Franklin to Jail
description: Ronnie Franklin, who rode Spectacular Bid to victories in 1979 in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, was sentenced yesterday to serve 60 days of a six-month sentence in jail for a misdemeanor charge of attempting to use cocaine. He was also fined $500. Gerald Delp, the son of Buddy Delp, the trainer, received a similar sentence and fine, and Stephen Badie, who was with them when they were arrested on April 13 at Keeneland, a Lexington, Ky., track, was ordered to serve 30 days of a four-month term and pay a $250 fine.

title: 6 BANKS HELP MESA AND CITIES AS WELL
description: Six of the 10 banks helping the Mesa Petroleum Company in its takeover battle for the Cities Service Company are also helping Cities Service in its bid for Mesa, documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commerce showed yesterday.

title: MEXICO, VENEZUELA AND PEACE
description: As the dominant power in Central America, the United States has generally assumed that countries in that region are subordinate, useful only when their policies complement our own. Today, however, Washington's singlehanded diplomacy in Central America may be a serious mistake, because the two most important regional powers, Mexico and Venezuela, have developed strategies of their own for bringing peace to the region - strategies that are showing a surprising tendency to converge. The long-term goal of Mexican foreign policy is to supplant Cuban patronage of revolution throughout Central America - an approach that would tend to moderate revolutionary change.

title: People
description: * Richard Huebner has joined AC& R Advertising as senior vice president and associate creative director.

title: COURT ATTRIBUTES BLACKOUT OF '77 TO 'NEGLIGENCE'
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Consolidated Edison's ''gross negligence'' was responsible for the 1977 blackout in New York City and that a trial must be held to determine what damages may be owed to the city.

title: Taiwan's Premier Sees Chance of Peking Accord
description: Prime Minister Sun Yun-suan of Taiwan said today that reunification with China could become possible as differences between the two sides narrow.

title: ALFRED W. JONES
description: Alfred W. Jones, a major developer of Georgia's coastline and islands, died Wednesday at his home in Sea Island, Ga. He would have been 80 years old today.

title: ARGENTINES TELL OF 2 NEW RAIDS ON BRITISH
description: An Argentine military spokesman said tonight that air force planes had inflicted ''heavy casualties'' in two attacks on British positions in the Falkland Islands.

title: 'Test Tube' Baby Born On Coast, 3d in U.S.
description: The nation's third ''test tube'' baby, a healthy seven-pound girl, was born by Caesarian section Wednesday at the County-University of Southern California Medical Center.

title: SCREEN: 'WILLFUL MURDER' FROM JAPAN
description: ''Willful Murder'' is a Japanese political thriller, combining some of the Western aspects of that genre with a more contemplative, Japanese mood. The story is based on a real incident, a political assassination that occurred in 1949.

title: REPORT CONCLUDES HINCKLEY MADE CONSCIOUS CHOICE IN THE SHOOTINGS
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. made a conscious choice when he shot President Reagan and did not have ''any compelling drive'' to do so, a team of prosecution psychiatrists concluded in a report cited in testimony today.

title: RCA Expands Videodisk Line
description: The RCA Corporation announced an expansion of its videodisk player line from one to four models, including its first player with stereo sound, despite unimpressive sales of the Selectavision videodisk system last year.

title: IN BRONX, GIRAFFES STAND TALL AGAIN
description: Beginning today, giraffes will be on view at the Bronx Zoo for the first time in a year as the zoo formally opens its $2.5 million Carter Giraffe Building.

title: Reese May Face Return to Prison
description: Officials in Florida said yesterday that the former defensive lineman Don Reese might be sent back to prison for parole violation, one outgrowth of his charge that cocaine use is now so extensive among players that it ''controls and corrupts'' professional football.

title: MILITANT MORALITY; In the Lord's Name
description: Guatemala's Efrain Rios Montt is hardly the first Latin American general to say, ''Thank you, God, for giving me the opportunity to govern.'' He may, however, be the first to really mean it as a a born-again adherent of the Christian Church of the Word, a fundamentalist sect based in California.

title: POLISH PRELATE URGING POPE TO MAKE PLANNED VISIT
description: The Roman Catholic Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, said today that Poles wanted Pope John Paul II to come for a visit this summer and that it might help to stabilize the political situation.

title: WILSON'S SUCCESS IN CALIFORNIA G.O.P. PRIMARY REWRITES A POLITICAL OBITUARY
description: Four years ago, after Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego spent $1 million and 18 months campaigning yet finished fourth in a five-man race for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, a political columnist for The San Diego Union wrote an article concluding that it was doubtful Mr. Wilson ''has a bright future as a statewide candidate.''

title: Suspect Arrested
description: The F.B.I. said today it had arrested a 24-year-old Spring Valley man who had been sought for more than 18 months in the murders of a Rockland County couple in December 1980.

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 11, 1982; The Economy
description: The House adopted a conservative budget plan, breaking a lengthy stalemate. The plan would provide the largest peacetime increase in military spending ever, at the expense of social programs. The vote, a triumph for President Reagan, came after he intervened by phone from Bonn. (Page A1.) Soon after the vote, prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates fell. (D5.)

title: Psychotherapist Weds Julie Leff
description: Julie Rachel Leff, daughter of Mrs. Ted Ashley of Beverly Hills, Calif., and New York, and Joseph Leff of New York and Southport, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Jeffrey Satinover, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Satinover of Los Angeles. Rabbi Robert Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: POLISH ANTI-MINORITY PROVOCATION IN ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ SEPTET: DJANGO'S MUSIC
description: For more than four years, Mike Peters, a jazz guitarist, has been working with the music of Django Reinhardt, the Belgian gypsy guitarist who was the star of the all-string Quintet of the Hot Club of France in the 30's. In 1977, Mr. Peters formed, with Charles Wizen, a violinist, a group called Jazz A Cordes, an instrumental duplication of the Hot Club Quintet. When that ensemble broke up after three years, Mr. Peters put together String Fever, with a cello replacing the violin and a repertory that extended beyond material associated with Mr. Reinhardt.

title: RAINER WERNER FASSBINDER, 36, FILM MAKER, DEAD
description: Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the controversial and furiously prolific film maker most responsible for the resurgence of German cinema in the 1970's, was found dead yesterday at his home in Munich, West Germany. He was 36 years old, and had made 41 feature-length films - the best known was ''The Marriage of Maria Braun'' - in an erratic, iconoclastic screen career lasting only 13 years. The cause of death was unknown, and an autopsy will be performed today. ''We do not know if he killed himself or if he took too many pills or too much whisky or something similar,'' a police spokesman said. ''The only thing we are ruling out is murder.''

title: 'E.T. the Extra-Terrestial'
description: THE camera pans across a starry sky so clear that it has the effect of putting you in touch with the galaxies. When you lie on your back and stare into such a night sky, you feel as if you were tumbling upward through space. The camera slowly descends to earth to come to rest on a spaceship, its lights ablaze, comfortably settled in a clearing in a California forest. Small, Munchkin-sized creatures, whose abdomens glow on and off like those of fireflies, attend to their tasks of gathering specimens of earth rocks and plant life.

title: Les Brown Band Plays
description: Les Brown and His Band of Renown will appear tonight at 8:30 at the John Harms Englewood Plaza Theater, 30 North Van Brunt Street, Englewood, N.J. Featured members of the band are the comic and musician Butch Stone, the trombonist Stumpy Brown, the singer Jo Anne Greer and the drummer Jack Sperling. Tickets are $13.50, $14.50 and $15.50. Information: (201) 825-8793.

title: Horse Trainer, 3 Others Plead Not Guilty in Fix
description: A trainer of harness horses and three other men pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court today of conspiring to fix six races at Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways in 1978.

title: SHATTERED, TENSE BEIRUT A CITY OF MURDERED SLEEP
description: On the fifth day of Israel's invasion of Lebanon, residents of this sad and weary city hid behind shutters, camped out on stairwells and took refuge in shelters and basements as they awaited an Israeli attack.

title: COUNTY ORGANIZATION BACKS KOCH
description: Mayor Koch gained endorsement of the Manhattan Democratic organization last night in his bid for the party's gubernatorial nomination.

title: Dow Advances 3.14, to 798.71
description: Lending encouragement to investors, the Dow Jones industrial average edged up yesterday, thanks to a burst of short-covering activity in the final minutes.

title: WHEN 18 SAXAPHONISTS GET TOGETHER
description: IT used to be that youngsters turned to the saxophone - the ungainly issue of an unlikely marriage between a clarinet and a cornet - when they failed as a clarinetist in the high school band. Next to the accordion, it was the least prestigious instrument you could claim to be taking lessons on, generally more fit for noisemaking and vulgar displays in front of pals than serious practice or, perish the thought, concerts and recitals.

title: SOVIET AGAIN ASSAILS ISRAELIS BUT SHOWS CAUTION ON CRISIS
description: Pravda condemned Israel again today for its invasion of Lebanon but a commentary in the Soviet Communist Party newspaper offered no indication that the Kremlin was preparing to abandon the cautious diplomatic stand it has observed since the fighting began.

title: ABRAMS AFFIRMS RE-ELECTION BID, CHASTISES P.S.C.
description: Announcing his candidacy for a second term, Attorney General Robert Abrams said yesterday that if he was re-elected he would concentrate on organized crime, felony indictments of industrial polluters and efforts to reorganize the Public Service Commission.

title: HUNGER STRIKER SAYS FATHER NOW FAVORS HER LEAVING SOVIET
description: The daughter of a general said today that her father had visited her in the apartment where she is in the 32d day of a hunger strike and said he had interceded with officials in support of her bid to emigrate.

title: LOW SOVIET CROP IN FORECAST
description: The Agriculture Department today sharply reduced its earlier estimate of this year's Soviet grain crop, forecasting that the Russians would harvest only 185 million metric tons because of poor growing conditions this spring in the major crop areas.

title: 'RACIST ONSLAUGHT' AGAINST A TV FILM
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Courts
description: Muhammad Ali is suing Don King, the promoter, for $1.26 million, claiming he was shortchanged for his title fight against Larry Holmes. According to an Ali spokesman, the suit, filed in United States District Court in Chicago late Wednesday, said that Ali received $6.83 million instead of the $8 million he was supposed to get for the October 1980 bout that the former champion lost ... Nike Inc. has almost 20,000 posters depicting Darryl Dawkins wearing Nike shoes.

title: TEXT OF LEAFLETS SENT TO BEIRUT
description: Following is a translation by The Associated Press of leaflets printed in Arabic and dropped by Israeli planes over Beirut this morning. The message was addressed to the commander of the Syrian forces in Beirut and was signed by the commander of Israel's northern front.

title: BILL TO PENALIZE UNCOVERING OF AGENTS PASSED BY SENATE
description: The Senate today approved and sent to President Reagan a bill making it a crime to disclose the names of covert United States intelligence agents. The vote was 81 to 4.

title: NEW TYPE OF BACTERIA LINKED TO DISEASE IMPARTED BY TICKS
description: A newly discovered type of bacteria may be the cause of a mysterious illness called Lyme disease, according to a report in the latest issue of Science.

title: NEW YORKERS PROVIDING LODGING FOR RALLYGOERS
description: Thousands of people have already begun to arrive in New York for tomorrow's nuclear disarmament rally, confronting the crowded city with the challenge of where to put them.

title: Losing Is No Fun
description: Johnny Bench, who has played for six National League champions and in four World Series during the last 14 seasons with the Cincinnati Reds, is finding it difficult being on a Reds team that is in last place in the National League West.

title: Beth Daniel Shares L.P.G.A. Lead on 69
description: Therese Hession took such a powerful overswing on a practice tee on April 28 that she tore cartilage on the right side of her rib cage.

title: MAJOR VATICAN SHOW PLANNED AT MUSEUM
description: The first major show of art from the Vatican ever to travel outside Rome will open at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Feb. 26, 1983. The Vatican has never before agreed to lend out more than a handful of works in its vast and invaluable collection that runs from Egypt through Matisse and includes sculptures, paintings, tapestries and all other pre-20th-century mediums.

title: Counterattack By Sprinkel
description: Beryl W. Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, charged today that those calling on the Federal Reserve Board to relax its grip on the money supply and thus pos@sibly lower interest rates were compounding the problem and undermining the prospects for economic recovery.

title: Mattel Profit $17.1 Million
description: Mattel Inc., a leading manufacturer of toys, games and video games, yesterday announced earnings of $17.1 million, or 76 cents a share, in its first quarter, ended May 1, compared with a net loss of $4.2 million in the similar period last year.

title: SALVADORAN PRESIDENT TAKES 'CAUTIOUS' APPROACH TO RIGHTISTS
description: El Salvador's provisional President, Alvaro Magana, says he is taking a ''cautious'' approach to his country's problems and especially to efforts by rightist politicians in the Constituent Assembly to alter the economic restructuring begun by the previous Government.

title: Senate Votes Measure On Endangered Species
description: The Senate has approved a three-year extension of the Endangered Species Act, which is designed to protect animals and plants from extinction.

title: Son of Justice Stevens Held
description: John Stevens, the 33-year-old son of Associate Justice John Paul Stevens of the United States Supreme Court, has been charged with selling cocaine to undercover lawenforcement agents, the police say. Mr. Stevens, who lives in Chicago, was arrested Tuesday and charged with delivering an ounce of cocaine to undercover agents for $2,200. He appeared in court Wednesday and was freed on $10,000 bond pending a court appearance set for June 19.

title: BALLET: SERIES OF PREMIERES AT STRATVINSKY OPENING
description: The feast, presumably, is yet to come. The opening of the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Centennial Celebration last night at the New York State Theater, however, was made up mainly of hors d'oeuvres.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Roy Emerson of Australia, who has won more Grand-Slam events than any man in tennis, was selected for the the International Tennis Hall of Fame by a panel of writers. Others selected for July 11 induction in Newport, R.I., were William McChesney Martin, an avid tennis promoter; Lance Tingay, who retired from The London Daily Telegraph, and the late Tom Pettitt, a former star ... The Green Bay Packers yesterday traded Bruce Clark, a defensive lineman and their top 1980 draft choice, to the New Orleans Saints for a 1983 No. 1 pick ... The Yankees have signed Dan Pasqua, a left-handed hitting outfielder.

title: TWINS STOP ROYALS, 8-7, ON HRBEK'S GRAND SLAM
description: Kent Hrbek hit his first major league grand slam to power Minnesota to an 8-7 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight, snapping the Twins' five-game losing streak. The game also ended an eight-game Royal victory streak.

title: JAMES McNALLY WAS A JUSTICE IN STATE'S APPELATE DIVISION
description: James B.M. McNally, a former associate justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court and a United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, died yesterday at Cabrini Medical Center. Justice McNally, a resident of Manhattan, was 86 years old.

title: Texas Dismisses Robinson
description: Eddie Chiles, owner of the Texas Rangers, today dismissed the team's executive vice president, Eddie Robinson.

title: Friday; ASIA IN FLUSHING MEADOW
description: A stage comedy, shadow puppets, dance and music are the fare of the Second Asian Summer Gala this weekend at Queens Theater in the Park in Flushing Meadow. The Pan Asian Repertory Theater will present Edward Sakamoto's comedy ''Yellow Is My Favorite Color'' today at 3 P.M. (free) and tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 3 and 8 ($7; $5 for students and the elderly). Chen Hsueh-Tung & Dancers will perform modern works on Sunday at 3. ($5; $4 for students and the elderly.) And on Sunday at 7, the Yueh Lung Shadow Theater will present a traditional drama with translucent figures manipulated behind a back-lit screen. The figures as well as Chinese musical instruments will be demonstrated. ($5; $4 for students and the elderly). Reservations: 592-5700. In addition, the Yueh Lung company will perform and demonstrate at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 914 Richmond Terrace on Staten Island Saturday at 1:30 and 4 P.M. ($1.50; $1 for children and the elderly). Reservations: 448-2500.

title: PANEL AGREES ON HOME LOAN AID
description: House-Senate negotiators agreed today on a three-year, $3 billion program of subsidies for home mortgages as a way of stimulating housing construction, but the measure is likely to be vetoed by President Reagan.

title: Pension Deduction Curb Backed
description: The Reagan Administration endorsed in principle today a Democratic proposal to reduce the limits on taxdeductible employer contributions to profit-sharing and pension plans.

title: Fueling of Spacecraft Goes Into Second Phase
description: Launching teams for the space shuttle today began the second phase of a four-day operation to pump highly combustible propellants into the Columbia's supplementary fuel tanks.

title: Sports of The Times; Get It Over With
description: THE grubbiest thing about boxing is that people are licensed to hurt each other. The second grubbiest thing is the money that other people make on pain and permanent injury. The third grubbiest thing about boxing is the hype, of which we have seen more than enough in the interminable wait for the Holmes-Cooney fight.

title: TEHERAN BARS TRUCE
description: Iraq said today that it halted all its military activities in Iran at dawn and began to observe a ceasefire in its war with Iran, which began 21 months ago.

title: I.T.T. Seeking Agency For Long Distance
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation is searching for a new agency for its long-distance telephone service, it confirmed yesterday.

title: Floyd and Lye Lead on 67's
description: Ray Floyd and Mark Lye shot five-under-par 67's today to share the first-round lead in the $400,000 Danny Thomas-Memphis Classic.

title: Mozambicans in Lisbon Deny Ambassador Has Defected
description: The Mozambique Embassy in Lisbon has denied reports that its Ambassador to Portugal, Joao da Silva Ataide, has defected.

title: Lawyers Cite Evidence Of Chemical War in Asia
description: A group of lawyers and jurists from Asia, Australia and New Zealand said today that they had found circumstances indicating that chemical warfare had been selectively applied in Laos and Cambodia.

title: Racist Pleads Not Guilty In Jordan Shooting
description: Joseph Paul Franklin, an avowed racist, pleaded not guilty today in Federal District Court to the sniper shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr. two years ago in Fort Wayne.

title: A CRITIC'S GUIDE TO THE OUTDOOR SCULPTURE SHOWS
description: So long as there's outdoors, there'll be outdoor art.'' That was the confident prediction of an environmental artist the other day, and this city certainly bears him out. Not content with confinement to museums and galleries, artists have always been moved to challenge - or embellish - both nature and architecture, and there's nothing like the opportunity offered by New York, particularly its spectacular environment.

title: Military Analysis
description: The British high command apparently has decided that the successful Argentine bombing of troops and landing ships at Bluff Cove on Tuesday cannot be allowed to delay the assault on Stanley. On the contrary, military sources here believe that the operation will be stepped up after the setbacks are overcome.

title: NEW LONDON GIRDS FOR THE YALE-HARVARD REGATTA
description: In celebration of the 117th Yale-Harvard Regatta, one of Connecticut's most festive weekends gets under way tonight and continues through Sunday in the historic port city of New London. The weekend theme is ''The Good Ol' Days,'' and the 324-year-old town will pulsate with classical ensembles and ragtime bands. Visitors can board horse-drawn trolleys and view an antique and classic car show and arts and crafts demonstrations. They can also sail on a moonlight cruise and be serenaded by violinists on New London Transit buses.

title: THE LIBERATION OF LEBANON
description: The biggest mistake King Hussein of Jordan ever made was to launch an attack against Israel in 1967; it cost his country the West Bank. This week, Syrians occupying most of Lebanon made their great mistake by sending planes and troops to aid the P.L.O., despite repeated assurances from Israel that no wider war was wanted; it will cost Syria its long-sought annexation of Lebanon.

title: BENCHMARK BANK RATE RAISED AGAIN IN CANADA
description: The Bank of Canada today raised its benchmark discount rate for the second time in two weeks in a thus-far unsuccessful effort to halt the slide in the value of the Canadian dollar.

title: An Irish Celebration
description: The Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island will be the site of an outdoor festival of Irish music, dance and theater tomorrow from 2 to 10 P.M. Music groups from Ireland and the United States will perform at the event, sponsored by the Irish Arts Center in celebration of its 10th anniversary.

title: EX-C.I.A. AIDE GLOOMY ABOUT CURB ON WRITING
description: ''Sometimes,'' said Frank Snepp, ''I think I'm living out a Kafka story. Or maybe it's '1984.' '' Two years have passed since the Central Intelligence Agency obtained a court order forbidding Mr. Snepp, a former employee of the agency in Vietnam, to publish information about the agency without prior approval from its officials. As the months have dragged by, life under the landmark order has become harder and harder.

title: WOMEN'S VIEWS ON DIVORCE ARE CHANGING IN JAPAN
description: Last fall, Mieko Enomoto became the most talkedabout divorced woman in Japan. In the long-running trial of former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, accused of receiving bribes from the Lockheed Corporation, Mrs. Enomoto disclosed that her former husband, Toshio Enomoto, admitted that he had accepted $1.8 million on the Prime Minister's behalf.

title: Wallace Neff, Architect, 87; Pioneer of the California Style
description: Wallace Neff, an architect active in the development of southern California's early architectural style with buildings such as the Pickfair mansion in Beverly Hills, has died at the age of 87.

title: Sled of 'Citizen Kane' Brings $60,500; Sled in 'Citizen Kane' Is Sold for $60,500
description: Rosebud, the sled made for Orson Welles's classic 1941 film ''Citizen Kane,'' was bought Wednesday afternoon by Steven Spielberg, the director-producer, for $55,000 at Sotheby Park Bernet.

title: The U.N. Today; June 11, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Hearing Scheduled In I.B.M. Review
description: A hearing on whether to halt a judge's review of the Federal Government's decision to dismiss the I.B.M. antitrust case has been scheduled for next Thursday before the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York.

title: BIZARRE TRIP WITH HERZOG AND DISARMAMENT RALLY
description: The weekend schedule is unusually heavy with special or offbeat presentations, beginning with a ''Non Fiction Television'' documentary called ''Burden of Dreams.'' Produced by Les Blank, this hourlong film offers a startling close-up of Werner Herzog, the German film director, at work in the Peruvian Amazon jungle.

title: Israel's Goal, and America's
description: Israeli troops and American weapons have created another ''new fact'' in the Middle East and there is no point wailing about what might have been. Arrogantly, perhaps foolishly, the Israelis believe they can by force create the stable environment that history has denied them. Every battle creates imperatives for more battle, but the Israelis pursue a tough logic. Like it or not, their policy can be deterred only with better policy. In Lebanon, the world has left them to their own devices.

title: IRREGULARITIES FOUND IN SUICIDE VICTIMS' BRAINS
description: A team of scientists studying the human brain in efforts to learn why people commit suicide has found chemical and physiological conditions in the frontal cortexes of suicide victims that differ from those in the cortexes of people who died of other causes, such as homicide, heart attack and auto accident.

title: News Analysis
description: As a result of its military performance in the last five days, Israel suddenly finds itself facing some tempting new opportunities in Lebanon, options that could carry the invasion far beyond its original concept.

title: 4 Investors Sue Brokers
description: Four investors have filed suit against Shearson/American Express and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in Federal court in Manhattan, contending that misleading investment advice from the firms caused them to lose $495,000 in trading of Nucorp Energy Inc. stock.

title: SPAIN SAYS BRITISH MOVE COULD DIVIDE THE WEST
description: Spain, the newest member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, warned its allies today that British efforts to retake the Falkland Islands by force risked seriously dividing the Western world.

title: Issue and Debate
description: MENTAL HEALTH EXPERTS AS WITNESSES WHERE A DEFENDANT PLEADS INSANITY By MAYA PINES

title: Hempstead Greek Fair
description: Three days of ethnic food, music and entertainment are planned at the ninth Grecian Festival of St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church, 110 Cathedral Avenue, Hempstead, L.I. The action takes place in two large tents.

title: Brown Laboratory Cited For Safety Violations
description: Health officials have cited Brown University for safety violations after two laboratory workers ate food laced with a radioactive substance.

title: Three to Join the Cast Of 'Pirates of Penzance'
description: Pam Dawber, Peter Noone and James Belushi will join ''The Pirates of Penzance'' as, respectively, Mabel, Frederic and the Pirate King. Miss Dawber, however, will fill in for only three weeks; Mr. Noone and Mr. Belushi will become permanent members of the cast.

title: JOHN PAUL TO VISIT ARGENTINA TODAY
description: Pope John Paul II will arrive here Friday morning for a two-day visit that is focused on peace but that will be overshadowed by war and politics.

title: Mary Bacon Hurt
description: Mary Bacon, one of the nation's leading women jockeys, suffered severe head injuries after she was involved in a spill Wednesday night at Golden Gate Fields in Albany, Calif. She was reported in critical condition yesterday in Herrick Memorial Hospital, Mrs. Bacon, 34 years old, was unconscious and bleeding from the head when she was taken to the hospital. Dr. Edward O'Reagan, the track doctor, said, ''My preliminary examination indicated a serious head injury.'' The spill occurred in the backstretch of a six-furlong event.

title: 26 Are Seized As Illegal Aliens
description: Federal agents raided an apartment house in downtown Brooklyn yesterday and arrested 26 illegal aliens from Nigeria, including four who had fraudulently obtained up to $100,000 in Government-backed student loans, officials said.

title: UNIVERSITY TEAM LURES AMERICANS TO SCOTLAND
description: American students are becoming prize catches at British universities, and the effort to recruit them seems most energetic at the University of St. Andrews, 50 miles north of Edinburgh.

title: Ashe Names Cup Squad
description: Arthur Ashe, the captain of the United States' Davis Cup team, today named the four men who will compete against Sweden in the quarterfinals next month. They are John McEnroe, Peter Fleming, Brian Gottfried and Eliot Teltscher, the same squad that beat India in the first round of this year's competition.

title: Seagram Net Down by 10.3%
description: The Seagram Company, the world's largest producer of distilled spirits and wines, reported yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter ended April 30 fell 10.3 percent, to $53.7 million, from $59.9 million in the same period last year.

title: Market Place; Factory-Built Homes' Trend
description: BACK in 1972, Wall Street analysts hailed factory-built homes as one of the premier growth industries of the decade. Before 1973 ended, however, their market had collapsed.

title: WHEN AN OIL BOOM FADES
description: A year ago, there wasn't an idle drilling rig to be found in the rugged high country of southwestern Wyoming and northeastern Utah. Among the oil companies working the region, the great search was on to unlock the vast reserves of petroleum and natural gas that are trapped inside the crumpled rock formations that geologists call the Overthurst Belt.

title: BRIEFING
description: Journey From Kootznoowoo

title: McEnroe Defeats Sadri; Connors Also Advances
description: Top-seeded John McEnroe produced his best form of the tournament today and beat John Sadri, 6-3, 6-2, to advance to the quarterfinals of a $175,000 tennis championship at the Queen's Club.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: No Mention of Yankees
description: Despite a reference to members of the Yankees in a wiretapped conversation between two defendants, no one on the team will be mentioned by name during a trial of five persons who have been charged with selling cocaine.

title: FRANCE UNDER SOCIALISTS EDGING CLOSER TO NATO
description: President Francois Mitterrand's attendance at Wednesday's dinner of Atlantic alliance leaders and his decision to have Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy attend the meeting today appear to be signs that France is edging closer to the alliance, in the view of Western officials.

title: Census Data Show Migration of 'Snowbirds'
description: Almost half the more than 500,000 people who live away from home are in Florida, and more temporary residents are from New York than any other state, a report based on the 1980 census shows.

title: REAGAN SENDS BEGIN A 'FIRM' CALL TO STOP FIGHTING AND START PULLOUT
description: President Reagan has sent Prime Minister Menachem Begin a ''firm'' message calling for Israeli forces to stop fighting in Lebanon and prepare to withdraw, senior Reagan Administration officials disclosed today. They indicated that there was rising American concern about the spreading conflict.

title: SURVEY FINDS SEMINARY PROFESSORS MORE MORALLY CONSERVATIVE THAN PUBLIC
description: Roman Catholic and Protestant seminary professors are more conservative on religious and moral concerns than the general public, but more liberal on certain political issues, according to a recent survey conducted by the Roper Center at the University of Connecticut.

title: AT NIGHT, VARIETY IN THE FASHION PARADE
description: Even if New Yorkers are more concerned about the weekend weather report than what to wear at night, still the city this week was filled with nighttime functions that required some thought about clothing.

title: CITIES SERVICE RALLIES ITS FACTS
description: Charles J. Waidelich, chairman of the Cities Service Company, has had a rough month. First, T. Boone Pickens Jr., chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, wanted to walk away with his company, and then Mr. Pickens almost turned the merger battle between the two companies into a personality contest.

title: PARK RALLY TOMORROW IS EXPECTED TO CAUSE EXTENSIVE TIE-UPS
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire warned yesterday that there could be ''massive congestion'' in New York City tomorrow, when thousands of demonstrators are expected to stream into Manhattan for a series of marches and a rally to protest the nuclear arms race.

title: TURKISH TEA GROWERS BEWAIL TIGHT QUALITY RULES
description: They're not burning tea leaves or throwing them into the sea here anymore. In fact, they are not sure they can produce enough this year to meet the demands of this tea-consuming nation of 45 million people.

title: 'WILLFUL MURDER' FROM JAPAN
description: ''Willful Murder'' is a Japanese political thriller, combining some of the Western aspects of that genre with a more contemplative, Japanese mood. The story is based on a real incident, a political assassination that occurred in 1949.

title: Mrs. Kissinger Wins Acquittal on Assault
description: A judge acquitted Nancy Kissinger of a charge of simple assault today, declaring that the wife of the former Secretary of State had displayed a ''somewhat human reaction to an offensive question'' when she scuffled with a woman at Newark International Airport.

title: 'BABY BELL' CLEARS LAST HURDLE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company was authorized today to proceed with its plan to create a new subsidiary for offering unregulated computer and phone answering services to the public, its first foray into the unregulated telecommunications field.

title: Boston Bank's Prime at 16 1/2%
description: The First National Bank of Boston raised its prime interest rate yesterday to 16 1/2 percent from 16 percent. The bank, which lowered its prime rate to 16 percent on June 3, said in a statement that market conditions prevented other banks from matching the 16 percent and that, as a result, it was returning to the higher level.

title: Ford Appoints Leader For International Unit
description: While the Ford Motor Company may be suffering with the rest of the automobile industry at home, it is profitable overseas. Yesterday, Ford directors named a new head of the company's international operations.

title: Prices Raised For Gasoline
description: The Mobil Corporation, Texaco Inc. and Sunoco Inc. raised their wholesale gasoline prices in some regions yesterday by between a half cent and 2 cents a gallon.

title: SEEK ATOMIC BAN, YESHIVA U. IS URGED
description: Senator Bob Packwood told graduates of Yeshiva University yesterday that the biggest challenge they faced was that of helping to stop the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Chad's Rebel Chief Asks O.A.U. Forces to Stay
description: Hissen Habre, the rebel leader whose forces seized the capital of Chad three days ago, said today that the Organization of African Unity should allow its peacekeeping forces to stay in the country.

title: MORE GREASE
description: THE sap is rising - again - at Rydell High School. The kids are back from summer vacation, ready to wriggle and bop their way through ''Grease 2,'' which is less a sequel than a retread. There are as many crazy pranks and cute costumes here as there were in the original ''Grease,'' it's true. And everyone here remains relentlessly youthful - even those as old as Eve Arden, who plays one of the story's few alleged adults. But ''Grease 2'' is dizzy and slight, with an even more negligible plot than its predecessor had. This time the story can't even masquerade as an excuse for stringing the songs together.

title: THE CRIME ISSUE REVIVED
description: Voters in the California primary have revived law and order as a political issue, just in case anyone thought it was dead. That may have set up one of the nation's sharpest tests of Reaganomics in the 1982 general elections. Here's how:

title: A Chinatown find, old-style French.
description: Finding excellent, interesting and inexpensive food served by a pleasant, efficient staff in a festive, sparklingly clean restaurant may sound like a dream of paradise. Yet it is a dream that seems to come true at Say Eng Look on East Broadway in Chinatown.

title: Economic Scene; That Seminar At Versailles
description: PARIS DOES a rise in inflation cause a rise in unemployment or does a rise in one mean a drop in the other? That was one of the juicier topics debated by the heads of government of the seven major industrial democracies at the Versailles summit conference - surely the most elegant and probably the most expensive economic seminar in the history of the world.

title: THE REGION
description: A state commission has rejected the plan submitted by the Long Island Lighting Company for the handling of emergencies at the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 11, 1982
description: International Outskirts of Beirut were attacked by Israeli planes and gunboats. Israel dropped leaflets over the capital, warning that it would capture the city soon. The leaflets offered Syrian forces two safe routes from the capital, and asserted that resistance would be ''tantamount to suicide.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel reported more heavy combat on the ground and in the air with Syrian forces in Lebanon. But for the first time since the Israelis' invasion Sunday, they expressed a willingness to accept a cease-fire. (A12:1-2.)

title: Eastern College Group Is Named Atlantic Ten
description: The Eastern Athletic Association changed its name today and adopted structural and rules changes that will take effect in basketball next season.

title: LACK OF BLACK N.F.L. COACHES CITED
