description: Several current and former pro players accused the National Football League today of ''institutional discrimination'' and asked Congress to put pressure on Commissioner Pete Rozelle and other N.F.L. executives so that more blacks would be considered for top-level management and coaching positions.

title: THEATER ROW HAVING A BIRTHDAY FESTIVAL AND FAIR
description: THE coming of age of Theater Row was probably complete on a recent crisp June evening. It was a gala benefit night for all participating companies in this thriving theater district on West 42d Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues. Before the curtains rose, hundreds of theatergoers -some formally attired - were gathered on the sidewalk under the bright banners that act as marquees for the theaters. They sipped champagne and toasted an experiment in urban reclamation.

title: CITY BALLET OPENS 8-DAY CELEBRATION OF STRAVINSKY
description: The New York City Ballet had done it again. Its Stravinsky Centennial Celebration opened last night at the New York State Theater without a hitch. It didn't rain, so guests could eat and drink on the theater terrace before the performance.

title: U.S. ACCEPTS COUNCIL LINES AIDING MINORITIES
description: The Justice Department approved a redistricting plan for the New York City Council today, saying that the Council had drawn lines that increased the voting strength of minority groups.

title: Philadelphia Waiter Held In Mob Leader's Death
description: The police arrested a 21-year-old waiter today in the bombing death last year of a reputed mob leader, Philip Testa.

title: The Situation in the Middle East
description: FIGHTING

title: Blast Kills Munitions Worker
description: One worker was killed and at least 10 others were injured in a nitroglycerine explosion today at the Radford Army Ammunition Plant, a plant spokesman said. The dead man was identified as Rufus W. Marshall, 41 years old, of Hiwassee, the operator of a nitroglycerine storehouse where the blast occurred at 11 A.M. The explosion was felt in Blacksburg, 15 miles to the northeast. There was no estimate of damages.

title: HIROSHIMA AND 60'S RECALLED AT PROTEST
description: Shunji Tsuboi will never forget Aug. 6, 1945, the day the first atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima. He lived there.

title: G.M.A.C. Note Offering
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financing arm of the General Motors Corporation, yesterday registered $1.25 billion of notes, due in nine months to five years, with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In April, the company had registered simliar notes with the S.E.C. Since then, however, the total available for sale had been reduced to $304 million, prompting a new registration. Notes currently carry yields ranging from 13.75 percent for maturities of 9 months to 18 months, to 14.75 percent for maturities of between two years and five years. G.M.A.C. sells the notes directly to investors as a means of financing the sale of G.M. products.

title: Billie Jean King Wins And Gains Quarterfinals
description: Billie Jean King, the six-time Wimbledon singles champion, reached the quarterfinals of the Edgbaston Cup tennis tournament today with a 7-6, 6-1 victory over Marjorie Blackwood of Canada.

title: Nor'easter Named Maine Hits Omaha
description: Early this week, John Winkin, the University of Maine baseball coach, realized that there was something that his players needed to be told as they reached the College World Series for the second consecutive year. For the first time, Winkin announced to his players that they could win a national championship.

title: The Talk of Haddam
description: Haddam this week is a town of wide-open cellar windows and rugs set on sunny lawns to dry, a town where hoses at the gutter gush water pumped from basements.

title: Bill Opposes Subway-Car Deal
description: United States Senator Donald Riegle, Democrat of Michigan, said yesterday in Detroit that he had introduced legislation designed to cut off Federal mass transit financing to New York City if it goes through with the purchase of subway cars from a Canadian company.

title: ART DEALERS DISMAYED AT SOTHEBY'S CLOSING
description: New York art dealers expressed surprise and dismay yesterday over Sotheby Parke Bernet's announcement Wednesday that the auction house would close its Madison Avenue galleries at East 76th Street next September. The concern will consolidate its American corporate and auction operations at its York Avenue galleries at East 72d Street. The Los Angeles galleries will also be sold and auctions of West Coast material will be moved to New York.

title: NAMING COVERT AGENTS
description: From the waning days of the Eisenhower Administration through the Presidency of John F. Kennedy, the Central Intelligence Agency and leaders of the Mafia plotted the murder of Fidel Castro. The C.I.A. prepared botulinum toxin pills in its laboratories, successfully tested the pills on monkeys and then furnished them to Mafia leaders. They, in turn, planned the mechanics of the murder, including who in Cuba would administer the pills to Mr. Castro. It was the stuff of a grade-B movie plot. It was all true. And it was all unreported at the time that it occurred, since neither the press nor the public knew of it.

title: Holmes in Six
description: LAS VEGAS, NEV. LARRY HOLMES is a proven champion. Gerry Cooney is an unproven challenger. In analyzing tonight's World Boxing Council heavyweight title bout at Caesars Palace, those are the basic truths. As a puncher with a left hook that has demolished tired old fighters and cautious young fighters, Gerry Cooney has a chance; a puncher always does. But with his experience and with his left jab, Larry Holmes should dominate the tempo, he should bloody the challenger, and he should stop Gerry Cooney in, say, the sixth round.

title: SYRIAN AIDE ASSERTS TROOPS IN LEBANON WILL BATTLE ON
description: Syria's Information Minister declared today that Syrian troops would keep fighting in Lebanon ''for our Palestinian and Lebanese brothers and for our basic national security.''

title: HIGH AIDE OUSTED IN EDUCATION DEPT.
description: Edward A. Curran, the director of the National Institute of Education, was dismissed today by Secretary of Education T.H. Bell in the latest in a series of Department of Education shakeups.

title: Heavy Rains Kill 5 in Haiti
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 10 (UPI) - At least five people died and scores were injured during heavy rains Tuesday night that caused severe flooding and left Port-au-Prince filled with mounds of mud and debris, the authorities said today. Ambulances and firemen spent Wednesday searching for victims, radio reports said.

title: 72 Arrested at Protest At Arms Manufacturer
description: Seventy-two protesters were arrested today in a demonstration here at Rockwell International, which has contracts for the B-1 bomber and the MX missile.

title: 7,000 AT N.Y.U. HEAR BRADEMAS TALK ON DEFENSE
description: With flags fluttering in the breeze from the top of Washington Square Arch, water spewing from the usually dry fountain and trees serving as camouflage for loudspeakers, more than 7,000 students received degrees in Washington Square Park yesterday at New York University's 150th commencement.

title: OUTSKIRTS OF BEIRUT BOMBED AS ISRAEL WARNS THE SYRIANS TO LEAVE BEFORE CITY FALLS
description: Israeli warplanes and gunboats struck on the southern outskirts of Beirut today, and Israeli leaflets were dropped over the capital saying, ''In a short time, we will capture the city.''

title: YANKS HALT SKID, TOP RED SOX, 5-3
description: Dave Righetti, an inconsistent pitcher in his second major league season, did not allow the Boston Red Sox a hit until the seventh inning tonight. The Yankees, on the other hand, had seven hits before the seventh.

title: IRISH PREMIER, AT THE WALDORF WARNS, VIOLENCE DELAYS UNITY
description: Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey of Ireland told Irish-American leaders last night that violence would only delay the unity of all Ireland, which he called ''the first political priority of the Irish Government.''

title: BRITISH TOLL OF 50 FEARED IN ARGENTINE ATTACK
description: As many as 50 soldiers and sailors may have been killed in Argentine air attacks on British landing craft Tuesday, unofficial military sources said tonight. They described the episode as the most serious setback suffered by Britain in the war in the Falkland Islands.

title: Chief Administrator Named at N.W. Ayer
description: David H. Means, an executive vice president with N.W. Ayer, has been promoted to chief administrative officer. The 54-year-old executive, who has been with Ayer for 29 years, was formerly executive account director. He will be responsible for all finance and administration for four domestic offices and 11 abroad.

title: HOLMES VS. COONEY: THE RICHEST FIGHT
description: In a ring on a parking lot at Caesars Palace, two undefeated fighters from different backgrounds will compete in 120-degree temperature for sport's richest prize in boxing's richest event Friday night.

title: RATES SLIP AFTER BUDGET VOTE
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates fell yesterday immediately after traders learned that the House of Representatives had approved Republican budget proposals calling for an estimated deficit of $99.3 billion in the 1983 fiscal year, which begins Oct.1. The market reaction was subdued because most traders had left work, but late trading in a few active issues clearly showed rising prices.

title: Advertising; American Heritage to Accept Ads
description: SOON after American Heritage magazine went to soft cover in 1978 after 25 years as a hard-cover publication, there appeared within its covers an ad for subscriptions along with a bound-in card. It was the first ad the magazine had ever carried. Some time later, the six-a-year publication began to carry ads for American Heritage catalogue products.

title: Shell Chemical To Close Plant
description: The Shell Chemical Company has decided to close its plant on land leased at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal northeast of here, where it has manufactured pesticides and other toxic chemicals for about 30 years.

title: ISRAELIS AND SYRIANS LOCKED IN COMBAT IN BEKAA VALLEY
description: Israel reported continuing heavy combat in the air and on the ground with Syrian forces in Lebanon today but, for the first time since the invasion on Sunday, spoke of a readiness to accept a cease-fire.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Hanoi on May 30 transposed the names of two American servicemen whose identification cards were given to a group of Vietnam veterans by the Vietnamese Government. The correct names are Roosevelt Hestle Jr. and Woodrow Frederick Knapp.

title: Craig Escapes Charge
description: Thomas A. Teller, the clerk-magistrate of Edgartown District Court, in Massachusetts, yesterday declined to charge Jim Craig, the goalie of the 1980 United States gold-medal winning hockey team, with rowdyism on Cuttyhunk Island off the Massachusetts coast on May 7. Mr. Teller, however, charged five of Craig's companions with disorderly conduct. The five included Craig's brothers, Kevin and Daniel. Assistant District Attorney Charlie Morano said that the rowdyism took place while Craig was in a telephone booth and the others were outside.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Topics; Militant Morality; Hounding a Child
description: ''She was almost hysterical - we couldn't reason with her.'' So said Joseph Scheidler, an officer of Chicago's Pro-Life Abortion League, about a woman who had scheduled an abortion for her pregnant 11-year-old. Mr. Scheidler and his group had hired a private detective to track them down.

title: THE BULLETS DESPERATE CRIMINALS LIKE TO BUY
description: To the Editor:

title: Depressing Choice in Newark
description: With the two candidates for mayor under indictment, Newark voters face a depressing choice in Tuesday's nonpartisan runoff. The incumbent, Kenneth Gibson, and City Council President Earl Harris, both charged with giving a former City Councilman a no-show job, are also parties to stagnant and ineffective leadership. Mr. Gibson at least offers 12 years of experience as Mayor.

title: Exploring Art Deco
description: A tour of 15 midtown buildings, each with elements of Art Deco styling from the 1920's and 30's, will be conducted by the Art Deco Society tomorrow at 2:30, beginning at The Daily News Building, Second Avenue and 42d Street.

title: BETTER TIES TO HOLDERS PROPOSED
description: A Securities and Exchange Commission advisory panel today proposed a series of steps to enable corporations to improve their ability to communicate with millions of shareholders whose identities they do not now know.

title: G.O.P. BUDGET WINS APPROVAL IN HOUSE BY VOTE OF 219-206
description: In a victory for President Reagan, the House today adopted a conservative budget that would provide the largest peacetime increase in military spending at the expense of social programs.

title: Falconbridge
description: Falconbridge Nickel Mines Ltd. of Toronto announced production cutbacks at its Sudbury, Ontario, mining operations. It also plans to reduce its work force by 25 percent, to 3,000 persons, in the face of the recession and depressed metal markets. The company, the second-largest nickel producer after Inco Ltd., lost $13 million (Canadian) in the first quarter of 1982.

title: RETAIL SALES ROSE 1.5% IN MAY
description: Retail sales rose a strong 1.5 percent in May, the Government reported today. It was the second consecutive monthly gain and an indication that consumer purchases might finally be on the increase.

title: Bell Copter Layoff
description: Bell Helicopter Textron Inc., Fort Worth, said it would immediately lay off 160 unionized workers because of a decline in helicopter orders.

title: PUBLISHING: PUTTING A SPOTLIGHT ON THE FIRST NOVEL
description: On Wednesday, the Louisiana State University Press will publish ''Masseni,'' a novel about tribal life in the Ivory Coast by Tidiane Dem. That evening, Ntozake Shange, the playwright and novelist, will read from ''Masseni'' at the Public Theater. If this first novel by a relatively unknown African author would seem to have attracted an unusual amount of attention, it is because ''Masseni'' is the winner of the 1981 Pegasus Prize for Literature, an award established by Mobil Corporation five years ago to provide international recognition to authors of merit writing in languages other than English.,

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * ARA Services expects a tax-free gain of $5 million from an agreement with Goldman, Sachs to swap 250,000 common shares for $12 million of its outstanding 4 5/8 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 1996.

title: Bank Branch Bill Advances
description: The Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill that would allow an out-of-state bank to open branches in New York State or acquire a New York bank, if New York-based banks were permitted reciprocal privileges in the other state. The bill now goes to Governor Carey.

title: RECITAL: BETHANY BEARDSLEE, RICHARD GOODE
description: Songs and piano music composed between 1885 and 1911 by Schoenberg, Berg and Debussy were the subject of the joint recital given by Bethany Beardslee, soprano, and Richard Goode, pianist, at the Abraham Goodman House on Tuesday. In Vienna -where Schoenberg and Berg lived and worked - this turn-of-the-century period was a time of rather decadent lushness in music.

title: BONN
description: Following are excerpts from the text of the declaration issued today by the 16 heads of state and government participating in the North Atlantic Treaty Alliance conference here.

title: LEGISLATOR SAYS VOTE WAS SOLD
description: Representative Dan Glickman said today that a House colleague turned to him in the debate on whether to defeat a consumer-oriented regulation on used cars and virtually admitted selling his vote for $10,000.

title: ARABS MEET BUSH ON ISRAEL INVASION
description: Arab ambassadors met with Vice President George Bush today and expressed anger over United States ''silence'' on Israel's invasion of Lebanon.

title: Bridge: Saul Bronstein Does a Lot But Gets LIttle Credit For It
description: Many of those who contribute a great deal of time and effort to organized bridge do so unobtrusively, without fanfare and with little thanks. They might be called conspicuously inconspicuous. One such in New York City is Saul Bronstein, who for the past three years has been Secretary of the Greater New York Bridge Association. He goes well beyond his secretarial duties in several directions: In particular, he organizes a variety of activities for newcomers - that is, players with fewer than 20 master points.

title: ISRAEL ORDERS U.N. TO END FOOD AID
description: The Israeli military authorities have ordered the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon to stop donating and delivering food to Lebanese civilians caught in the fighting.

title: CONDOMINIUM RISES ALONG HUDSON IN EDGEWATER, N.J.
description: For years this small municipality (population: 4,600; size: three and a half miles by a quarter mile) seemed destined to be bypassed by the slow but steady march of high-rise office and residential development along the west bank of the Hudson River from West New York to Fort Lee. The main reason was that its riverfront, which lies directly across from Lincoln Center and Upper West Side neighborhoods, was largely occupied by industrial plants and warehouses.

title: A Hamilton Brother To Sell Company Stake
description: The Hamilton brothers, founders of the Denver petroleum company of that name, are going their own business ways after 34 years. The company announced yesterday that the part of the company it plans to sell to Volvo of Sweden represents the interests of Ferris F. Hamilton Jr., 56, and that he is withdrawing from the company.

title: Drinking Age of 21 Gains in Jersey
description: The State Senate, in a 27-to-8 vote, approved a bill today that would raise New Jersey's drinking age from 19 to 21 next Jan. 1.

title: ETHIOPIA BONES CALLED OLDEST ANCESTOR OF MAN
description: Fossil bones discovered in Ethiopia were reported yesterday to be from the oldest ancestor of man yet known, an ape-man who walked on two feet, had a small brain and lived four million years ago. The bones were 400,000 years older than the famous ''Lucy'' skeleton found in 1974, which had been considered the oldest ancestor.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has named Ronald K. Glover executive vice president of marketing for consumer financial services.

title: IMPORT TAX ON STEEL EXPECTED
description: The Commerce Department has decided to impose duties on a wide range of European steel imports because of a finding that they are being sold in this country at unfairly low prices, a Commerce Department official said late tonight.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard WOLFNIGHT. By Nicolas Freeling. 200 pages. Pantheon. $12.50. CAT CHASER. By Elmore Leonard. 283 pages. Arbor House. $13.50. THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG. By Ken Follett. 323 pages. Morrow. $14.50.

title: CAPITAL MOVE IS SCHEDULED BY AUDUBON
description: The National Audubon Society, the bird lovers' organization that has been a resident of New York City throughout its 80-year history, is planning to fly the coop for Washington.

title: Faberge Holds Talks on Sale
description: Faberge Inc., a major beauty products company, said that it had entered into preliminary discussions with an unnamed company interested in acquiring it. After a short halt in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, the company's shares rose $7.50, closing at $21.625.

title: BUSINESSMEN CUT SPENDING PLANS
description: American corporate leaders are continuing to scale back their plans for spending on expansion and modernization, the Government reported today. The businessmen estimate a 2.4 percent decline this year from their 1981 outlays, after allowing for inflation.

title: ART: MARLBOROUGH OFFERS A SAMPLER OF 17 PAINTERS
description: This is the moment of summer migrations for the international art world - the moment at which to stay home is to stagnate and to pack one's bags is a mark of potency. People pretend that they don't want to go, but the truth is that for curators, collectors, dealers and critics the combination of the Basel Art Fair, the Venice Biennale and the seventh Documenta exhibition in Kassel, Germany, is hard to resist. Who wants to be tagged as an ignoramus?

title: GALA DALI, IMPELLED HER ARTIST HUSBAND TO FAME AND WEALTH
description: Gala Dali, the wife and muse of the surrealist painter Salvador Dali for more than 50 years, died today in her 12thcentury castle in northeastern Catalonia. She was believed to be 89 years old.

title: Hicks Jazz Sessions
description: A 13-piece jazz ensemble, led by the pianist John Hicks, will perform this weekend at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: CRITICS CIRCLE SELECTS 'NICKELBY' AS BEST PLAY
description: ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' as adapted from the Dickens novel by David Edgar, was named best new play of the 1981-82 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle at a meeting yesterday in the Century Club. The critics also selected Charles Fuller's ''A Soldier's Play'' as the best new American play and voted not to give an award for best musical.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Buenos Aires on May 25 about the fighting on the Falk- land Islands included an incorrect date for the establishment of the Inter-American Defense Board. The board was formed on March 30, 1942, although Argentina did not become a member until 1945.

title: Syrup Processors Agree to Limits
description: A group of corn syrup processors has agreed to an injunction prohibiting price fixing or exchanging of price data for 10 years, the Federal Trade Commission said.

title: OLYMPIA ACCEPTS PABST OFFER
description: The Olympia Brewing Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by the Pabst Brewing Company for $69.9 million in cash and securities. The combination, if it is approved by the Justice Department and Olympia's shareholders, would create the nation's fourth-largest brewing company.

title: GOVERNMENT'S PARTY IS RETURNED TO POWER IN BAHAMAS ELECTION
description: Bahamians extended the 15-year rule of Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling in general elections today. By 10:30 P.M., returns showed Mr. Pindling's Progressive Liberal Party, which led the Bahamas to independence, winning in 22 of 43 districts.

title: RUSSIANS, TOO, JOKE SADLY ON ATOM-WAR SURVIVAL
description: Russians have a way of poking fun at much in their lives that is tedious, so it's no surprise that humorists have their stock of macabre jokes about the Kremlin's elaborate civil defense program.

title: BASELESS CHARGES OF MASSIVE SALVADORAN ELECTION FRAUD
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST LADY, ON RHINE VISIT, SEES DRUG CENTER
description: Nancy Reagan went cruising along the Rhine this afternoon, serenaded by a choir singing folk songs and such classics as ''My Grandfather's Clock,'' and escorted by streamlined blue-and-white police boats fore and aft.

title: SURVIVORS IN JAZZ ROCK DISCLAIM IT
description: ROCK: it seemed like a good idea at the time. The time was the end of the 1960's, a decade that had seen rock music win an immense youth audience and become the cultural focus of an entire generation.

title: Step by Genentech
description: Genentech Inc. said it had engineered micro-organisms capable of producing an enzyme that dissolves blood clots in humans. The enzyme, urokinase, is used to break down blood clots following surgery, but treatment is uncommon and costly because urokinase must normally be extracted from human urine and kidney cells. Dr. Herbert Heyneker, Genentech's senior scientist, made the announcement at a genetics conference in Japan. The genetic engineering company, based in South San Francisco, earned $503,000 on revenue of $21.3 million in 1981.

title: SOUNDS OF BATTLE DROWN OUT DEBATE
description: As battle casualties continued to mount in Lebanon, the Falklands, Afghanistan and other trouble spots around the world, a parade of statesmen and diplomats mounted the podium in the spacious General Assembly hall to urge steps toward arms reduction and even complete disarmament.

title: Fantasy From Spielberg
description: The camera pans across a starry sky so clear that it has the effect of putting you in touch with the galaxies. When you lie on your back and stare into such a night sky, you feel as if you were tumbling upward through space. The camera slowly descends to earth to come to rest on a spaceship, its lights ablaze, comfortably settled in a clearing in a California forest. Small, Munchkin-sized creatures, whose abdomens glow on and off like those of fireflies, attend to their tasks of gathering specimens of earth rocks and plant life.

title: 'E.T.,' FANTASY FROM SPIELBERG
description: THE camera pans across a starry sky so clear that it has the effect of putting you in touch with the galaxies. When you lie on your back and stare into such a night sky, you feel as if you were tumbling upward through space. The camera slowly descends to earth to come to rest on a spaceship, its lights ablaze, comfortably settled in a clearing in a California forest. Small, Munchkin-sized creatures, whose abdomens glow on and off like those of fireflies, attend to their tasks of gathering specimens of earth rocks and plant life.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN EDITORS FIGHT MOVE TO LEGISLATE CONDUCT OF THE PRESS
description: South African newspaper editors held emergency talks today about a bill that would force newspapers to submit themselves to a disciplinary body. The editors fear that the Government will rush the measure through Parliament before Friday night's recess.

title: STRAVINSKY DANCE SCHEDULE
description: At press time, tickets are available for all performances of the Stravinsky Centennial Celebration at the New York State Theater, although some sections have been sold out. Casting is subject to change. Ticket availability and casting for the programs of Tuesday through next Friday are not yet available. Information: 870-5570.

title: Excerpts from declaration, page A18.
description: Leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ended a one-day meeting here today with commitments to strengthen all military defenses and seek broad negotiations with the Soviet Union to reduce conventional and nuclear arms.

title: CRANSTON, EX-TRACK STAR, PONDERS A RUN IN 1984
description: In the hidden chambers of the Capitol, where public civilities are discarded and harsh judgments are made, Senator Alan Cranston, the Californian who is the Democratic whip, is regarded with great respect. He is only the fifth Democratic whip to win the position three times. He is considered intelligent, seriousminded and hard-working. He is trusted, even by his colleagues across the aisle.

title: New Amtrak Chairman
description: W. Graham Claytor Jr., the retired chairman of the Southern Railway, as expected, was named chairman and president today of Amtrak, the National Passenger Railroad Corporation. He succeeds Alan S. Boyd, who has resigned effective July 2.

title: Snead, Palmer Tied at 68
description: Sam Snead, who turned 70 two weeks ago, bettered his age by two shots today to tie Arnold Palmer for the first round lead of the $150,000 Marlboro Classic seniors tournament.

title: Toll in India Bombing Now Reported at 19
description: The death toll in a bomb explosion in the northeastern city of Gauhati on Wednesday night has risen to 19, officials reported today.

title: Alien Ideas Need No Quarantine
description: What has the United States to fear from 315 foreign disarmament demonstrators, mostly from Japan, who want to attend the United Nations disarmament conference?

title: WHEN NUCLEAR PEACE HINGES ON COMPUTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicaragua Reports 26 Slain
description: Twenty-one ''counterrevolutionaries'' and five soldiers were killed in battles near the Honduran border in recent days, Nicaraguan officials say. Most of the rightist groups near the border are made up of former national guard soldiers who fled to Honduras in 1979 when President Anastasio Somoza Debayle was overthrown.

title: Lower East Side of 1910 is the root of 'Rags' next winter.
description: ''RAGS,'' a musical about the immigrant experience, is supposed to arrive on Broadway next winter. The book is by Joseph Stein, and the music is by Charles Strouse. The lyrics are by Stephen Schwartz, who will also be the director. They are all big names, with many Broadway credits, although the most pertinent credit -the book for ''Fiddler on the Roof'' - belongs to Mr. Stein. ''Rags'' takes place around 1910; the place is the Lower East Side. Tevye and his family are not around, although the characters will be people very much like the ones who must have traveled with them on the boat.

title: Lakers Are on Display In Los Angeles Parade
description: Los Angeles celebrated its second world championship in less than a year today as thousands of people lined Broadway and greeted the Lakers, the National Basketball Association champions, with cheers and confetti.

title: 200,000 ARE DRAWN TO A BONN PROTEST
description: Crowds of young people, tens of thousands of them, gathered in grassy fields at the edge of the Rhine today to hear speakers call for peace and denounce the Atlantic alliance's plans to deploy new atomic weapons in Western Europe.

title: Shift at Dayco Is Seen Ended
description: The outside director investigating Dayco Corporation orders that may have been false said yesterday that he did not foresee additional management changes following those made on Wednesday.

title: THE ROUTES OF MARCH PROTESTERS WILL TAKE
description: Those taking part in the antinuclear weapons demonstration will begin gathering tomorrow morning in the area from 47th Street to 56th Street between First and Third Avenues, according to organizers.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Paintings by Old Master artists to satisfy virtually every taste will be up for bidding in two sales scheduled next week in New York's auction houses. Both auctions have works by major and minor English, Italian, Dutch and French artists that the galleries expect to sell for up to six figures.

title: Biomedical Merger
description: A definitive merger agreement between Hoffman-La Roche Inc. and Biomedical Reference Laboratories Inc. was approved by shareholders of Biomedical, the companies announced.

title: BEGIN'S ZIONISM GRINDS ON
description: Israel's invasion of Lebanon makes a self-fulfilling prophecy of Menachem Begin's interpretation of Zionism, which reduces Palestinians either to the pacified inhabitants of ''Judea and Samaria'' or to terrorists.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Israelis have imposed this savage war on us and we have no choice but to fight for our Palestinian and Lebanese brothers and for our basic national security, which is threatened by the Israeli invasion.'' - Ahmed Iskander Ahmed, Syrian Information Minister. (A14:1.)

title: 2 Events Rescheduled
description: As a result of the postponement because of last weekend's rain, two events will be held on Sunday.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: Dawn Hampton, who will sing tonight and tomorrow at midnight at Night Wing, the new club at Greenwich Avenue and 13th Street, is a performer who believes in projecting emotions. This, she finds, disturbs some people in her audiences.

title: Claim in Iran Settled
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said today that it had received $178,604.87 from an international tribunal handling claims against Iran that arose from the hostage crisis. The rubber company has a second claim pending, for $2.7 million.

title: U.S. STEEL TO SELL ASSETS TO CUT DEBT
description: The United States Steel Corporation, in a major program to reduce its debt, said it plans to raise $500 million to $750 million this year and a similar amount in 1983 through the sale of inventory, commercial real estate, timberland and other assets.

title: An Appreciation
description: Much in the way he made his films, in a rush, impatient to get to the next project, Rainer Werner Fassbinder has dashed off a life and moved on abruptly to his death, at age 36. He was still a wonder child, though he had completed a body of work to match that of any major director twice his age.

title: EUROPE TRIP'S PACE TIRES REAGAN PARTY
description: Moving themselves from city to city in Europe, President Reagan and his staff have been hampered this last week by logistical headaches, communications breakdowns and an overly crowded schedule for the President, White House aides said today.

title: REGIONAL ROLL-CALL ON SPENDING PLAN
description: Following is the roll-call of votes by representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the Republican-backed budget resolution for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. A ''yes'' vote represents a vote for the resolution, and a ''no'' represents a vote against it; ''xxx'' means not voting.

title: Lelouch film runs 3 hours; 6 if you'd like.
description: CLAUDE LELOUCH, who is best known to most Americans for his 1966 movie, ''A Man and a Woman,'' has come to New York from Paris to talk about ''Bolero,'' which opens here next Wednesday. Ambitious may be too mild a word for ''Bolero.'' It follows the lives of a Russian couple, a French couple, a German couple and an American couple (and their children and grandchildren in some cases) through more than 30 years and a couple of wars. It is also three hours long.

title: Coopers & Lybrand Chooses Chairman
description: Coopers & Lybrand, which calls itself the largest international accounting and consulting firm, has elected Peter R. Scanlon, currently vice chairman of domestic operations, to be its chairman.

title: New Analysis
description: The presence of Israeli troops on the outskirts of Beirut has put the Palestine Liberation Organization into the tightest predicament in its 16-year history.

title: Dutton Plans Sale
description: The Dutton Lumber Company, once among the nation's top 10 lumber products concerns, has tentatively agreed to sell all its operating assets to the Phil-Mar Corporation of Brooklyn for $1.4 million. The ailing lumber wholesaler had been trying to restructure its finances in Federal Bankruptcy Court. Two years ago it had annual sales of $100 million, but by the end of 1981 its sales had declined to $66 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Hoist and Derrick Co. said that it would extend its regular two-week summer shutdown to five weeks, beginning June 19, at its St. Paul mobile crane plant.

title: Miami Tops Texas, 2-1, And Gains Spot in Final
description: Sam Sorce and Dan Smith combined for a fivehitter as Miami downed Texas, 2-1, tonight to earn a spot in the College World Series finals.

title: Esther Ofarim to Make Singing Debut Saturday
description: Esther Ofarim, an Israeli singer whose repertory ranges from folk songs and ballads to pop tunes, will make her American concert debut next Saturday and June 20 at 8:30 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: 'HUMONGOUS'
description: If you've ever seen a single horror movie, it was probably better than ''Humongous,'' which opened yesterday at Loew's State and other theaters. If you've never seen one, don't start here.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * CBS Inc.'s $150 million issue of notes due in 1992 was priced today at 99 3/8 with 14 1/2 percent coupons to yield 14.62 percent by underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: CALL FOR ARMS HALT REJECTED, BUT TOWN REMAINS DIVIDED
description: Voters here have reversed their earlier adoption of a resolution calling for a freeze on the production of nuclear weapons.

title: IN CHRISTIAN AREA, CALM
description: Just before a tenuous cease-fire went into effect at noon today, residents of east Beirut stood on their balconies and watched the Israelis shell Palestinian targets in predominantly Moslem west Beirut.

title: TRUCES IN MIDEAST SAID TO BE FRAGILE
description: Western diplomats said tonight that the cease-fire in effect between Syrian and Israeli forces was an ''extremely fragile'' arrangement.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Layman's Guide To Counting Crowds

title: Turks Send Protest to Israel; Say 11 Died in Lebanese Fight
description: Turkey delivered a protest to Israel today for the deaths of 11 Turkish nationals caught in the fighting in Lebanon, the Foreign Ministry announced.

title: DOCTOR TELLS OF HINCKLEY REACTION TO SEEING VICTIM
description: In the frenzied moment right after he had emptied his gun, John W. Hinckley Jr. ''looked out of the corner of his eye and saw someone lying on the ground bleeding, recognized him not to be the President and said to himself, 'Oh, hell!' '' a psychiatrist testified today.

title: JONES IS ROUTED
description: Randy Jones, the Mets' most consistent starter in the early part of the season, failed for the third time in a row last night. He gave up five runs in two and one-third innings as the Mets lost, 7-3, to the first-place St. Louis Cardinals at Shea Stadium and dropped five and a half games from the top in National League East.

title: URGES END TO FALKLAND WAR
description: Pope John Paul II arrived in this proud but war weary nation today praying for peace in the Falkland Islands and asking that the British and Argentine Governments pursue it.

title: Joffrey Benefit Monday
description: Aretha Franklin will head the cast of ''No Dancing Allowed,'' a single-performance musical theater performance to benefit the Joffrey Ballet, Monday at 8 o'clock in Carnegie Hall.

title: CITICORP'S BID TO BUY THRIFT UNIT ON COAST
description: For years, Citicorp has been trying to find a way to compete for consumer deposit business in the nation's most populous state, and for years it has been frustrated by the California banking lobby.

title: APPEALS COURT UPHOLDS THE DECERTIFICATION OF AIR CONTROLLERS' UNION
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld the Government ruling that stripped the Professional Air Traffic Controllers' Organization of its status as a union.

title: CHILDREN'S HOT COLD WAR
description: Fearing the horror of nuclear holocaust, Americans are planning for it today as they have at no time since the 1950's and early 1960's. For me, their doomsday plans bring back jarring memories of a childhood made less secure by the cold war.

title: Europe's Struggle Against the Veto
description: At least one consequence of the Falkland war may be lasting and favorable: a stronger European Community. The community's sanctions, supporting Britain against Argentina, were the toughest it has ever adopted and helped produce a welcome truce in the Common Market's annual catfight over farm prices and budget dues. And that may lead it to more effective decision making.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 12, 1982; The Economy
description: The U.S. announced a plan for stiff penalties on steel imports from nine nations, including seven in the Common Market. The Europeans reacted angrily, saying much of their steel will be priced out of the American market. (Page 1.) The Common Market plans to retaliate by placing countervailing duties on imports from the U.S. It will also challenge the legality of the American move. (45.)

title: Trudeau Visiting Yugoslavia
description: Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau of Canada, who arrived yesterday, and Prime Minister Milka Planinc met today and discussed the Falklands and Middle East crises, officials said.

title: HOW DISABILITY CLAIMANTS ARE SHORTCHANGED
description: To the Editor:

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.5 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve late yesterday announced a $1.5 billion rise in the nation's basic money supply, a larger-than-expected increase that left the closely watched measure of money circulating in the economy higher than the Federal Reserve's short- and long-run targets.

title: ENVOY SAYS SALVADORAN PLAN IS INTACT
description: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador, Deane R. Hinton, said today that the Central American nation's land redistribution efforts were in jeopardy, but he denied that the program had been canceled.

title: 5-RUN FIRST HELPS ORIOLES BEAT YANKS
description: It apparently will take some time for the Yankees' latest pitching-coach change to create improvement in their injured and stumbling staff.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday misstated the number of disposable batteries expected to be sold in the United States this year. The number is 2.5 billion.

title: THOUSANDS OF ANTI-REAGAN PROTESTERS CLASH WITH THE POLICE IN WEST BERLIN
description: Demonstrators clashed with policemen throughout this city today during President Reagan's three-hour visit to West Berlin. City officials described the violence as the worst in recent years.

title: JETS RAZE P.L.O.'S COMMAND SITE
description: Israeli forces and Palestinian guerrillas fought throughout today on the approaches to Beirut and elsewhere in Lebanon as spokesmen for both said the newly proclaimed cease-fires of Israel and Syria did not apply to them.

title: Going Out Guide
description: LEG STRETCHERS

title: New German Link For Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with West Germany to begin teletex service, a form of high-speed, computerized message transmission, between the United States and Germany in the fall.

title: Kings Retaining Link With New Haven Farm
description: The Los Angeles Kings of the National Hockey League and the New Haven Nighthawks have renewed their affiliate agreement for another year and the Kings have signed four players who led New Haven into the American Hockey League playoffs last season.

title: Leadership on the Lawn
description: The first lesson in leadership is for the multitudes that will stretch out across the Great Lawn this afternoon: Look how far you have led Ronald Reagan already.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's as ugly as the idea behind it.'' - President Reagan at the Berlin wall. (8:5.)

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JUNE 12, 1982
description: International Israel announced a cease-fire with Syria after fighting a successful series of tank, artillery and air battles in Lebanon that drove Syrian forces northward. Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said that the truce would not halt combat with Palestinian guerrillas and that the Israeli forces would secure a zone extending 25 miles into southern Lebanon. Israel, he said, has achieved all major military objectives. (Page 1, Column 6.) Fighting continued between Israeli forces and Palestinian guerrillas outside Beirut and elsewhere in Lebanon. Israeli bombers scored a direct hit on a building occupied by the military command of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The group's leaders were said to be unharmed. (1:3-4.)

title: U.N.'S MODERATE MOSLEMS SAY P.L.O. WILL SURVIVE
description: Moderate Moslem diplomats here say that while the Palestine Liberation Organization is suffering a military defeat, it will survive as a political force.

title: YOUNG WRITERS AND ARTISTS HONORED
description: John Guare stole the show, but Ann Lofquist wasn't far behind. The afternoon was devoted to a single theme, ''How I Became an Artist.'' Young artists and writers, all winners of scholarships in the 55th annual national Scholastic Art Awards, sat down with older artists and writers who have had some success to talk with one another about their individual moments of realization.

title: Prosecutions Ordered Over Registry for Draft
description: The Government has sent the names of nearly 200 youths who failed to register for the military draft to United States attorneys with instructions that they be prosecuted, the Justice Department said today.

title: Mexico Delays Nuclear Plant
description: The Mexican Government has advised competing American and European companies that it has postponed construction of the first plant of an ambitious nuclear energy development program because of Mexico's current economic crisis.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration has apparently decided to make the best of Israel's military moves in Lebanon by trying to translate them into a long-term political solution for Lebanon.

title: Around the Nation; Pennsylvania Governor Signs Antiabortion Law
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh today signed into law a measure that prohibits abortions except when a physician determines a mother's well-being is endangered.

title: National Science Chief To Leave Federal Post
description: After less than two years as the director of the National Science Foundation, Dr. John B. Slaughter has decided to leave to become chancellor of the University of Maryland at College Park this summer.

title: Milers Meet
description: Today is a big day for milers in track meets on both coasts. At the University of Southern California's Kinney Invitation, John Walker, who ran a 3:51 mile last Wednesday in New Zealand, the best in the world this year, will be in a group that includes Ray Flynn of Ireland and Steve Scott, the United States record holder.

title: PRODUCER PRICE INDEX UNCHANGED
description: The Producer Price Index, slowed by a decline in energy prices, was unchanged in May, the Labor Department reported today. The May report continued the positive trend on prices that has brought the rate of inflation down to a level not seen in six years.

title: Choreography Seminars
description: Teachers of choreography, music and dance technique will participate in two ''Craft of Choreography'' conferences sponsored by the National Association for Regional Ballet, from July 3 to 16 and July 19-Aug. 1 at Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y. Information: 757-8460.

title: New York; THE KILLER-IDEA MENACE
description: Is our brain fiber so eroded by Perrier water and our spine so softened by beanbag chairs that we can no longer do battle with ideas from an alien galaxy? Can we rise anymore to a challenge? Is this the Big Apple - or only a rotten nectarine?

title: Yankees Again Replace Williams With King
description: One week after dismissing their hitting coach, the Yankees yesterday dismissed their pitching coach, Stan Williams, replacing him with Clyde King.

title: NEW PATHWAYS IN HIKING GEAR
description: Hikers, campers and backpackers in the market for clothing and gear this season will find many new options open to them. And they may decide against such tried and true standbys as leather boots, woolen sweaters and down sleeping bags. The overall trend is toward lightness.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE POPE'S REMARKS
description: Following are excerpts from remarks in Spanish by Pope John Paul II as he arrived here today, as translated by the Vatican: Special to the New York Times

title: Around the Nation; Boston Hit by 30 Fires Throughout the Night
description: Thirty fires, including four suspicious major blazes, raged throughout Boston early today, straining the city's firefighting force to a ''dangerous'' breaking point, officials said.

title: HOW PRESIDENT'S TRIP PLAYED ON TV
description: President Reagan had barely left Bonn for home yesterday before the capital's politicians, polltakers and assorted political operatives began assessing his nine days abroad, not in terms of diplomatic successes or economic quarrels but as a television special and domestic political event.

title: FLORIDA GETS FEDERAL REFUGEE AID
description: The Federal Government gave Florida $31 million today to help resettle Cuban and Haitian refugees. The grant defuses, at least until next year, a lawsuit Gov. Bob Graham filed against the Reagan Administration.

title: NOBEL LAUREATES' PROMISING PROGENY
description: To the Editor:

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 36.

title: SECURITY FIRM IS CALLED A GUN-LICENSING 'FRONT'
description: A company licensed as a private security concern has been operating ''solely as a front'' to help New Yorkers get pistol permits, the chairman of the State Investigation Commission said yesterday.

title: U.S. PLANS PENALTY ON STEEL IMPORTS
description: The Commerce Department announced today that it would levy stiff penalties on steel imports from nine countries, including seven in the European Common Market - an action that seemed certain to bring retaliation against American goods exported to Europe.

title: METROPOLITAN TRANSIT NEEDS A COMMUTER PASS
description: To the Editor:

title: In Austria, a Bomb Explodes At the Home of Nazi Hunter
description: A bomb exploded tonight near the front entrance of the home of Simon Wiesenthal, the hunter of fugitive Nazi war criminals, causing heavy damage but no injuries, the police reported.

title: CHAD REBELS INHERIT CITY FULL OF GUNS AND MEASLES
description: The capital of Chad began to return today to its own distinctive normalcy. There were armed men on the streets, although they were from the rebel forces that took the city last Monday rather than the forces that held sway a week ago. The few foreign embassies and international organizations that evacuated their offices in the dusty city last weekend began returning by canoe and raft across the Shari River from Cameroon.

title: Civilians Can't Enter Israeli-Held Lebanon
description: The Israeli Army tonight forbade all civilians, including journalists, to enter Israeli-occupied southern Lebanon.

title: Around the Nation; G.M. Agrees to Award Of $16.5 Million in Crash
description: A couple have been awarded $16.5 million by the General Motors Corportion and the defendants' insurance companies in the largest out-of-court settlement ever recorded involving vehicular death and injury.

title: ROCK: THREE NUCLEAR VOICES
description: The Concert for Nuclear Disarmament, which brought together Jackson Browne, Linda Ronstadt, James Taylor, and their respective stellar bands on stage at the Nassau Coliseum Wednesday, found three of the most significant voices of 1970's rock at the peak of their powers. Perhaps because the event was a benefit and not a record companycoordinated tour, a joyful, relaxed atmosphere permeated the stage and animated performances of even the most familiar material with a special excitement.

title: O.A.U. CHIEF ORDERS PULLOUT DESPITE APPEAL OF CHAD RULER
description: The commander of the Organization of African Unity peace force in Chad said today that he had ordered the withdrawal of his troops despite an appeal for them to stay on by the country's new ruler, Hissen Habre.

title: E.E.C. OFFICIAL OUTLINES POSSIBLE RETALIATION
description: The European Common Market today outlined its strategy of retaliation against the United States plan to levy countervailing duties on steel imports from seven of the community's members. The new import tax will follow the United States finding, announced today, that the seven countries had unfairly subsidized exports to the United States.

title: REAGAN, BACK HOME, CHEERED BY THOUSANDS
description: President Reagan, arriving here at 6:30 P.M. from his nine-day tour of Europe, declared that the trip had reminded him anew of America's mission to keep peace in the world.

title: Around the World; Solidarity Aide Sent To Mental Institution
description: A senior official of the suspended Solidarity union movement has been sent to a mental hospital after a court acquitted him on charges of organizing an illegal strike, a Justice Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Bond Denied Man Suspected In 100 Underworld Slayings
description: A judge today denied bond for Bernard Hunwick, a 37-year-old man who is charged with attempted murder but who the authorities say may be responsible for 100 contract slayings.

title: Memorial for Paige
description: Kansas City officials have announced a $250,000 fund-raising drive to modernize the weed-covered O'Hara Field, which last Saturday was renamed ''Leroy Satchel Paige Stadium.'' Satchel Paige, the legendary pitcher and a member of the Hall of Fame, attended the ceremonies, his last public appearance before his death three days later.

title: Mrs. King in Semifinals
description: Billie Jean King, the six-time Wimbledon champion who is pursuing her first singles title since September 1980, reached the semifinals of the Edgbaston Cup today by beating Leslie Allen, another American, 6-3, 7-6.

title: A WORLD'S ILLS TO HEAL
description: Seven years ago, four Stanford University graduate students were abducted from a forested wildlife station in Tanzania by African guerrillas. Held for weeks, they were released after delicate negotiations conducted by Dr. David A. Hamburg, a Stanford behavioral scientist.

title: SALES OFF 0.9% FOR APRIL
description: Cramped by poor sales, American businesses saw their inventories rise two-tenths of 1 percent in April, the first increase since November, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: THEATER: JOHN WILKES AND THE OTHER BOOTHS
description: The Booths are back in town in Robert A. Morse's new play, ''Booth,'' which opened Thursday night at the South Street Theater. The evening begins with a version of a scene from theatrical life. The acting brothers -Edwin, Junius and John Wilkes - are rehearsing a fractious production of ''Julius Caesar.'' At this point, John Wilkes, the youngest, is more of a madcap than a madman, darting from Antony to Brutus, and finally demolishing the entire rehearsal.

title: TRAGEDY STRIKES DOWN A TIMES FAMILY IN BEIRUT
description: For more than 20 years, Mohammed Kasrawi has served The New York Times as assistant to the correspondent in Beirut, Lebanon. In recent years, as that unhappy land descended into chaos and violence, his task and his obsession more and more became the protection of a succession of correspondents.

title: Tultex Acquisition
description: The Tultex Corporation agreed to acquire the Washington Mills Company, a subsidiary of the Washington Group, for $13.5 million in cash and notes, the companies said.

title: Around the Nation; 6 Die in Missouri Crash Of Air Force Helicopter
description: An Air Force helicopter escorting a military convoy crashed and burned in a muddy farm field today, killing all six persons aboard, the authorities said.

title: Around the World; 'Irregularities' Cited In Bahamas Election
description: A spokesman for the opposition Free National Movement said today that his party would examine ''irregularities'' in several more assembly races, but otherwise considered this week's general election results ''a moral victory.''

title: CROWDS TAKE TO RIVER IN INNER TUBES
description: The temperature is nearly 100 degrees, and the flat desert sky reflects the sun like the mirrors of a solar cooker. But on the narrow roads that roll east through the cactus and bare rock, the traffic this Sunday morning is bumper to bumper, a steaming convoy of cars and pickup trucks and dune buggies, piled high with big black inner tubes and beer coolers and bound for the cold, shallow waters of the Salt River.

title: BUDGET PACT CITED
description: The stock market rallied in heavy trading yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 11.03 points, partly in response to the long-awaited Federal budget compromise approved by the House.

title: Kansas City Is Urged To Disband Orchestra
description: The Kansas City Philharmonic has money problems that cannot be solved, and its directors should dissolve the orchestra, cancel its 50th season next fall and try to start from scratch on a smaller scale, an advisory panel said.

title: Reuss Retires 27 After 1 Hit
description: Jerry Reuss, pitching his second onehitter of the season, retired the last 27 batters he faced after giving up a leadoff double as the Los Angeles Dodgers pounded out 13-hits and beat the Cincinnati Reds, 11-1, tonight.

title: Around the World; Mauritians Go to Polls To Decide Leadership
description: Mauritians braved rain today to vote on whether to continue the 22-year rule of Prime Minister Seewoosagur Ramgoolam or replace his pro-West minority Labor Party Government with a left-leaning coalition.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL YANKEES (AL) - Reinstalled Clyde King as pitching coach, replacing Stan Williams, who replaced King last year.  Williams will be offered King's present post of advance scout.
description: METS (NL) - Signed three draft c hoices and announced their assignments: D wight Gooden, right-handed pitcher, f irst round, for Class A team in Kingsport, T enn.; Roger McDowell, right-handed p itcher, third round, Class A team in S helby, N.C.; and Gerald Young, short- s top, fifth round, Kingsport CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Jim Bou- d reau, left-handed pitcher and son of Lou B oudreau, Hall of Fame shortstop and n ow a broadcaster for the Cubs. Jim Bou- d reau was 19th-round draft choice out of A rizona State. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed 10 free- a gent draft choices: Sammy Khalifa, T ony Bagwell, Andy Watson and John K enny, shortstops; James Taylor, third b aseman; Brian DeValk and David F rederick, outfielders; Bernard Stan- t ongs, pitcher; James Mims, catcher, and T homas Graziano, first baseman-outfield- e r. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed 12 players f rom free-agent draft: Tim Wallace, c atcher from Wofford College, second r ound; Brad Blunt, pitcher, Vince Cole- m an, outfielder, and Vince Russomagno, o utfielder-first baseman, all assigned to J ohnson City, Tenn. farm; signed to Erie, P a. farm were John Young and Bill Dona- t han, pitchers, Dave Clemens and Pedro L atorre, infielders, Gary Gill, first base- m an from Livingston, N.J., and Tom R ossi, pitcher. Signed to St. Petersburg, F la., was Dennis Seiple, pitcher.

title: SOVIET YIELDS ON VISA FOR GENERAL'S DAUGHTER
description: Tatyana Lozansky, a Soviet general's daughter who, with several other Russians, went on a hunger strike more than a month ago to press demands for exit visas to join their spouses, said today that the authorities had agreed to let her leave.

title: Consumer Saturday; HAIR-DRYER SAFETY IS AT ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON IN Elyria, Ohio, JoAnne Cayton ran a few inches of water in the bathtub for her 3-year-old son, Scott. When he was splashing happiliy, she left him briefly to check on her 19-month-old baby. By the time she returned, Scott had electrocuted himself by pulling a blow-dryer that was plugged in into the water.

title: HOLMES STOPS COONEY IN 13TH AND RETAINS TITLE
description: In one of the finest performances of a 10-year undefeated professional career, Larry Holmes retained the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship tonight by stopping Gerry Cooney at 2:52 of the 13th round.

title: Observer; THE BIG SCENE STEAL
description: The idea was to change the subject with a little Presidential theater. Other Presidents had tried it before Mr. Reagan and more often than not it hadn't worked. But then, none of those other Presidents had been an actor in his salad days. With Mr. Reagan there was more reason for hope than there usually is when Presidents go in for theater.

title: WEST BANK ANIMOSITIES GROW WIDER, ARABS SAY
description: Occupied West Bank, June 11 - Prominent Palestinians said today that the Israeli invasion of Lebanon had widened the gulf between the Israeli authorities and Arabs in Jerusalem and the West Bank.

title: COONEY COUNTRY CHEERS
description: Suddenly it was quiet in Cooney Country a few minutes before midnight. Gerry Cooney had just lost to Larry Holmes at 2 minutes 52 seconds of the 13th round in Las Vegas, Nev., and his hometown friends and fans fell silent at Cooney's East End supper club here.

title: JAN STEPHENSON LEADS BY SHOT
description: Jan Stephenson, who has been one of the most consistent players in the 28th annual Ladies Professional Golfers Association championship, today shot her second straight three-under-par 69 to take the halfway lead at six-under 138. That put her one shot in front of the inconsistent but strong Beth Daniel.

title: CORRECTION
description: A correction yesterday, referring to a dispatch from Hanoi published on May 30 about missing American serv- icemen, incorrectly gave one name. It is Fredric Woodrow Knapp.

title: Lincoln Center Society Gets Emerson Quartet
description: The Emerson String Quartet will join the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center starting with the 1982-83 season as the society's first resident string quartet.

title: Kenty Returns to Ring, Knocks Out Fernandez
description: Hilmer Kenty of Detroit, the former World Boxing Association lightweight champion, began a comeback tonight with a fourth-round knockout of Chris Fernandez of New York.

title: Jockey Injured
description: Kathy Moore suffered a ruptured spleen yesterday when she was kicked by a horse after dismounting at Churchill Downs, and will miss about six weeks of racing.

title: WOMAN, 41, AND FOUR CHILDREN ARE SLAIN IN BRONX
description: Four young children and a 41-year-old woman were found stabbed and bludgeoned to death yesterday afternoon in an apartment on University Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Mary Bruce Starbuds To Dance Tomorrow
description: The Mary Bruce Starbuds, pupils of Mary Bruce, who has been teaching dance in Harlem for more than 40 years, will present their annual concert tomorrow at 2 P.M. in Town Hall. Miss Bruce's pupils have traditionally been called ''Starbuds,'' a name given them by Michael Todd, the late promoter, when Miss Bruce worked with him at the New York World's Fair in 1939.

title: Mud Wrestling Match Turns to Brawl on Bet
description: A women's mud wrestling match turned into a brawl involving 500 patrons after a spectator tossed the emcee into the ring on a $50 bet, the authorities said today.

title: U.S. Enters Torture Slaying
description: The United States Justice Department will investigate the torture death of a juvenile inmate at the Ada County Jail to see if a civil rights inquiry is justified, says an agency spokesman. The spokesman confirmed Thursday in Washington that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been asked by the Justice Department to compile data on the Memorial Day murder of Christopher Peterman, 17 years old.

title: Justice Minton's Widow Dies
description: Gertrude Gurtz Minton, widow of Associate Justice Sherman Minton of the Supreme Court, died June 4, a Court spokesman said today.

title: ROBERT ROTH
description: Robert Roth, a former Washington bureau chief and columnist for The Philadelphia Bulletin for nearly 30 years, died yesterday in the National Institutes of Health of complications after heart surgery.

title: Marguerite S. Clark, 90, Dies; Former Editor for Newsweek
description: Marguerite Sheridan Clark, medical editor of Newsweek magazine from 1941 to 1961 and the author of several books on medicine, died Thursday at her home in Manhattan.

title: TULLY IS LEAVING TAX POST TO RUN FOR COMPTROLLER
description: James H. Tully Jr., submitted his resignation today as the State Tax Commissioner and formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for State Comptroller.

title: CHINA OFFERS TO JOIN DISARMAMENT MOVE
description: China, one of the world's five acknowledged nuclear powers, offered today to join in steps to reduce and ultimately eliminate all nuclear weapons.

title: 10,000 AT INTERFAITH SERVICE PRAY FOR END TO ARMS RACE
description: Prayers of many religions, spoken and sung in several languages, echoed through the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday as more than 10,000 people sought spiritual strength to aid them in their struggle against the nuclear arms race.

title: News Analysis
description: The end of the first phase of the budget battle Thursday in the House of Representatives marked the beginning of the November election campaign.

title: WASHINGTON VS. THRIFT
description: To the Editor:

title: LEBANON'S HISTORY MARRED BY STRIFE
description: Civil war, religious strife, foreign invasions, a crippled economy, a disintegration of governmental authority, a scarred and bloody landscape - these are the tragic elements of Lebanon's tortured modern history, elements more appropriate to a battleground than to a nation.

title: BUENOS AIRES REPORTS THAT BRITISH ATTACKED A HOSPITAL SHIP DURING RAIDS ON STANLEY
description: The Argentine Government reported today that the British had carried out repeated attacks on the Falkland capital of Stanley and charged that one of them was aimed at its hospital ship, the Bahia Paraiso.

title: MARCH PAST U.N. TO OPEN ANTINUCLEAR RALLY TODAY
description: Today's disarmament protest - which is expected to draw thousands of people into the city - begins officially at 9 A.M. when entertainers and speakers mount a temporary stage on 47th Street at First Avenue where the protesters are expected to mass for their first march.

title: MAYOR STILL WARY ON BUDGET, DESPITE HELP FROM ALBANY
description: Mayor Koch warned yesterday that the city's budget was far from resolved and held open the possibility that services would still have to be reduced.

title: PHILHARMONIC: STRAVINSKY
description: Zubin Mehta came to the rescue of his own orchestra in Avery Fisher Hall Tuesday night, appearing with the New York Philharmonic as a last-minute stand-in for Klaus Tennstedt, the evening's scheduled guest conductor. Mr. Tennstedt, who suffered a slight concussion in a fall May 30, has been ordered off the podium for a couple of weeks by his doctor. The program, the fifth in the Philharmonic's Mozart-Stravinsky Spring Series, sustained a single change: it opened with Stravinsky's Symphony in Three Movements instead of his ballet ''Jeu de Cartes.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Bridge: Westchester Believed Best In Grand National Playoffs
description: Teams representing New York City, Westchester County and New England clash today and tomorrow at the New York Hilton Hotel in zonal Grand National playoffs. The winners will advance to the national quarterfinals, with international honors beckoning on the horizon: The national winners will be involved in playoffs to represent the United States in the 1984 world championships.

title: Berbick Beats Page, Ending 18-0 Streak
description: Trevor Berbick, who got his chance to fight by impressing Larry Holmes in the ring a year ago, ended Greg Page's undefeated streak at 18 tonight with a unanimous 10-round decision in the major preliminary to the Holmes-Gerry Cooney title fight at Caesars Palace.

title: Floyd Takes 3-Shot Lead
description: Ray Floyd shot a 68 today and took a three-stroke lead with a total of 135, nine under par, after the second round of the Memphis Classic on the 7,249-yard Colonial Country Club course.

title: ISRAEL'S STATEMENT ON THE CEASE-FIRE
description: Following is the text of the Israeli Government statement today announcing a cease-fire in Lebanon, as translated from the Hebrew by United Press International:

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times A Scrabbling in the Soul By ANATOLE BROYARD MICKELSSON'S GHOSTS. By John Gard- ner. Illustrated with photographs by Joel Gardner. 590 pages. Knopf. $16.95.

title: CITY BALLET: STRAVINSKY PREMIERES
description: The feast, presumably, is yet to come. The opening of the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Centennial Celebration Thursday night at the New York State Theater, however, was made up mainly of hors d'oeuvres.

title: SURVEY WARNS OF ANT INVASION IN TEXAS HOSPITALS
description: Tiny red pharaoh ants have invaded operating rooms, intensive care units and nurseries in some Texas hospitals, posing a ''significant risk'' to patients by feeding in open wounds, university researchers say.

title: AUTO THEFT RING TIED TO MURDERS
description: Federal and New York City investigators looking into a major stolen-car operation believe that members of the ring may also be responsible for a dozen or more gangland murders in the metropolitan area over the last 10 years, law-enforcement sources said yesterday.

title: UNEASY MOOD EMERGING IN EGYPT OVER THE RELATIONSHIP WITH ISRAEL
description: The announcement today of at least a partial cease-fire in Lebanon has done little to ease the pains of Egypt's leaders and people, who in the last week have been almost as humiliated in their peace with Israel as they had been in war.

title: PROSECUTOR ACCUSES CUNNINGHAM OF 'WEB OF LIES' IN U.S. TAX CASE
description: The Government yesterday summed up its case against Patrick J. Cunningham, asserting that the former state Democratic chairman engaged in a prolonged conspiracy to cover up his evasion of of $14,000 in taxes in 1974 and 1975.

title: LEBANON AND PALESTINE: A TIME OF OPPORTUNITY
description: Historians and philosophers will long argue about the particular causes and justice of the Lebanon war, but statesmen must ask right away to mold a more hopeful future out of the conditions created by the war. American leaders bear a particular responsibility in this respect.

title: SOL KITTAY, APPAREL EXECUTIVE AND PHILANTHROPIST, DIES AT 71
description: Sol Kittay, former chairman and president of the B.V.D. Company and a philanthropist, died Thursday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: De Gustibus; FROZEN CHOCOLATE: SUMMER MADNESS
description: If summer ever arrives this year, thoughts of eaters will undoubtedly turn to cold food and drink. Among such, an idiosyncratic preference I intend to indulge is a passion for chocolate that is very cold or, better yet, frozen. A treat even in winter, frozen chocolate takes on special meaning in summer when tiny, crackling cold bits of thin crisp bittersweet chocolate are allowed to melt slowly on the tongue, cooling the mouth while gradually releasing that rich and miraculous essence and, finally, an incomparable surge of energy.

title: Your Money; Tax Shelter Data Refined
description: INVESTORS in many limited partnerships -those oil and gas and real estate programs widely referred to as tax shelters - will be getting less information about these offerings because of a new easing of the Federal Government's financial disclosure rules.

title: Young Armenian Is Convicted Of Bombing House of Envoy
description: A young Armenian whose brother is charged with the ambush murder of a Turkish diplomat earlier this year was convicted today of charges that he firebombed the envoy's Bel-Air home in 1980.

title: CHICAGO POLICEMEN ARRESTED
description: Fourteen police officers and the wives of two of them were arrested today and charged with drug violations, including peddling heroin, cocaine and marijuana, sometimes from squad cars.

title: Carbide Business Bought by Arco
description: The Union Carbide Corporation announced that it had agreed in principle to sell its urethane polyols manufacturing and distribution business to a subsidiary of the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: Norcen Blocked In Bid for Hanna
description: A Federal Judge in Cleveland issued a preliminary injunction blocking a $45-a-share bid made last April by Toronto-based Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. for control of the Hanna Mining Company.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Hedged Vengeance
description: The death penalty is the modern politician's easy answer to crime, yet actually executing people isn't easy at all. In the 37 states where it is legal, the death penalty is hardly an incisive expression of official outrage. What it can offer in the way of vengeance is heavily hedged and inhibited.

title: CATALOGUE SHOWROOMS PLANNING TO MERGE
description: The Best Products Company and Modern Merchandising Inc., two of the country's largest operators of catalogue showroom chains, announced yesterday that Best would acquire Modern, taking over its 71 showrooms and large catalogue printing business in an exchange of stock valued at about $111 million.

title: 'WELL DONE,' A GRATEFUL BRITAIN SAYS AS QE2 BRINGS HOME FALKLAND SURVIVORS
description: Her decks lined with nearly 700 survivors of the fight for the Falkland Islands, the Queen Elizabeth 2 steamed home from war today and a grateful nation responded with a tumultuous welcome.

title: Broncos' Testing for Drug Use Angers N.F.L. Players Union
description: Dan Reeves, the head coach of the Denver Broncos, says that the team tested all its players for drug use in training camp last summer and plans to do the same this year. The National Football League Players Association, having learned yesterday of the tests, promptly protested to the league office, saying that the practice constituted an invasion of privacy.

title: ISRAELIS AND SYRIANS DECLARE CEASE-FIRES, BUT DEAL IS SHAKY AS P.L.O. COMBAT GOES ON
description: Israel and Syria announced cease-fires in Lebanon today after a series of fierce tank, artillery and air battles.

title:
Patents;
Stock Data Computer Programs
description: WASHINGTON ASYSTEM of computer programs patented this week is already in nationwide use for retrieving data and producing reports on stocks and bonds. Investors have thousands of portfolios checked every week.

title: CITY UNITS MAKEUP TERMED UNLAWFUL
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union charged in court yesterday that the voting structure of the city's Board of Estimate was unconstitutional, and said a possible solution could lie in nearly tripling the board's membership.

title:
PATENTS;
Cancer Detection Test Measures Sugar Rise
description: Galactose is sugar that indicates the existence of tissue cancer when an increased quantity is discovered in the bladder cells.

title: POLL FINDS MOST AMERICANS REJECTING FACT THAT INFLATION RATE HAS SLOWED
description: Jackvelin Ventour of Detroit thinks that prices are rising faster this year than last, even though Government statistics show that just the opposite is true.

title: CITIES SERVICE RAISES BID
description: The Cities Service Company reported yesterday that its $17-a-share offer for 51 percent of the Mesa Petroleum Company had brought in some 30 million shares, about 41 percent, by the Thursday deadline for assuring payment.

title: 12 Light Operas Bought For Showings on PBS
description: The Mobil Corporation has acquired the rights to 12 Gilbert and Sullivan light operas for presentation on PBS in 1984. The performers will include Vincent Price and Keith Michel in ''Ruddigore,'' Joel Grey in ''Yeomen of the Guard,'' Clive Revill in ''The Sorcerer'' and Tony Randall in ''Trial by Jury.''

title: Briefing
description: Udall's Election Debt

title: THE NEW YORK BOTTLE BILL IS AN EXPENSIVE HOAX
description: To the Editor:

title: NOT A JERSEY MONOPOLY
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Medium Devised to Aid Growing of Mushrooms
description: A mushroom-growing medium has been invented at the Department of Agriculture's Western Regional Research Laboratory in Berkeley, Calif.

title: THE PROFESSOR AS PAID EXPERT
description: Franklin Fisher, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, earned as much as $125,000 a year by providing testimony for the International Business Machines Corporation during its 13-year antitrust case with the Federal Government.

title: MORGADO IS RESIGNING AS CHIEF AIDE TO CAREY
description: Robert J. Morgado, who rose from a lower-level state budget analyst to become one of the most powerful unelected officials in New York State, today announced his resignation as secretary to Governor Carey.

title: Pabst-Olympia Merger Accord
description: A definitive merger agreement between the Pabst Brewing Company and the Olympia Brewing Company of Olympia, Wash., was signed yesterday, Pabst said, after Olympia's directors met and unanimously approved Pabst's takeover bid.

title: COURT APPROVES REVISED PLAN TO PICK ACTING STATE JUSTICES
description: The New York State Court of Appeals approved yesterday a revised plan by Chief Judge Lawrence H. Cooke for assigning lower-court judges to work as acting justices in State Supreme Court in New York City.

title: Jury Levies $14 Million Fine For Hazardous Waste Dump
description: A Superior Court jury has levied more than $14 million in fines against three persons and two businesses associated with one of the nation's worst hazardous waste dumps. The award is to compensate the Federal Government and the state for the cost of cleaning up the Gilson Road dump in Nashua.

title: DISPUTE WITH LAWYER LEADS TO GUNPLAY, FIRE AND DEATH
description: A man opened fire with a sawed-off shotgun in his lawyer's office today after he was refused an insurance check, As the shooting continued, a fire-bomb was set off in a nearby office. The police said a woman was killed, four people suffered gunshot wounds and 34 more were injured in the fire, which burned for about an hour.

title: CHURCH, BREAKING WITH COLONIAL TRADITION, OFFERS TO SELL ITS SILVER CUPS
description: In a break with the tradition of church and culture here, a part of the heritage of New England goes on the auction block at Christie's in New York on Saturday afternoon.

title: WHEN U.P. HAD NO I.
description: Newspapermen, as journalists used to be called, have long been charged with the sin of cynicism. It is a characterization that many of us encourage, to deflect attention from our far more widespread flaw, incorrigible sentimentalism. This truth was borne home to me by the news that United Press International had been sold by the E. W. Scripps Company to a new set of owners.

title: CHAMPION PROVES A POINT TO HIMSELF
description: For several months now, the heavyweight champion Larry Holmes has been watching the world over which he reigned. With those thin, almost piercing eyes, he took it all in and waited.

title: A KISS AND A HUG FOR GERRY COONEY
description: yearold challenger's head in his hands and kissed him on the right cheek. And nearly an hour later Victor Valle had Gerry Cooney's head in his hands again, hugging him this time, leading him back to his corner, bloody and bowed and beaten. And wobbling on his weary legs.

title: SUBWAY TURNSTILES ALTERED TO ACCEPT DIFFERENT TOKEN
description: The Transit Authority, which says that it might have to raise subway and bus fares to $1 or more next month, has begun altering subway turnstiles to accept a token different from the one now in use, the authority's president said yesterday.
To the Editor:

title: LOW SPIRITS HINTED AMONG ARGENTINES
description: British intelligence has intercepted a pessimistic message from the commander of the beleaguered Argentine garrison at Stanley in the Falkland Islands.

title: Optimism on Seaver
description: Tom Seaver, the 37-year-old Cincinnati Reds right-hander, has won his last two games after losing six of his first seven decisions. That has prompted Bill Fischer, the pitching coach, to predict continued success for the three-time Cy Young Award winner, who has 262 major league victories.

title: THEATER: 'HENRY IV' IN LONDON
description: Before a single line was spoken, the audience broke into warm applause at Wednesday's all-day press premiere of the Royal Shakespeare Company's new ''Henry IV,'' Parts I and II. Some of the applause, no doubt, was for the theater itself. With this production, the company officially occupies its new London home at the Barbican Center, and a splendid home it is.
