Tasteful, comfortable and blessed with ideal sightlines, the Barbican Theater seems a model of how to design a substantial (1,160 seats) yet intimate modern playhouse. It's so cozy that one can almost forget about the oppressive complex that contains it - a grim concrete jungle that makes Los Angeles's Century City or Washington's Kennedy Center look like Versailles by comparison.

title: HAIG, WELCOMING THE CEASE-FIRE, SEES NO SIGN OF EARLY WITHDRAWAL
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today welcomed the Israeli cease-fire in Lebanon and Syria's acceptance of it, calling it ''a very positive step'' but asserting that there was ''no indication at all'' of an early Israeli withdrawal.

title: CURBS ON REPORTERS KEEP SOME FACTS ON 3 WARS FROM PUBLIC
description: Governments' restrictions on reporters, including the denial of access to battle areas and censorship of dispatches and pictures, has kept the public from getting full and objective reports about the fighting in Lebanon, in the Falkland Islands and along the Iran-Iraq border.

title: Around the World; Iraqis Say Iranians Are Still Attacking
description: Iran has ignored Iraq's declaration of what amounts to a unilateral cease-fire and is still attacking Iraqi positions, Iraq's supreme command said today.

title: Knowing Where the Children Are
description: Almost every parent has a story about a child who decides to run away, packs a toy and clean pair of socks and gets only as far as the front steps before changing his mind. But the parents of the nearly two million American children who do disappear from home every year have a grimmer tale to tell.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Smith, a receiver for the Pittsburgh Steelers who starred at the University of Michigan, is scheduled to appear in United States District Court in Ann Arbor, Mich., June 29 to answer charges of felonious assault and carrying a concealed weapon after a May 26 confrontation with three men from Ypsilanti. ... Orval Tessier has confirmed he has completed negotiations to become the coach of the Chicago Black Hawks next season. Keith Magnuson started last season as the Black Hawks' coach, but when the team faltered early in the second half of the season, Bob Pulford, the general manager, replaced him. The Hawks made the playoffs and were eliminated by the Vancouver Canucks in the Clarence Campbell Conference final.

title: 11 Names Are on Ballot For Jersey Hockey Club
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority today unveiled 11 names that will appear in its statewide newspaper contest to determine the name for New Jersey's new National Hockey League team, formerly the Colorado Rockies.

title: ARELLANO HEARINGS CONCLUDE
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday concluded four days of hearings at which the jockey Jaime Arellano had been ordered to show cause why his riding license should not be suspended or revoked.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 19. 1. ''Rawhide'' is White House communications lingo for President Reagan. Using a $15 manual of not-so-secret Government radio frequencies, Mr. Stogel has been able to eavesdrop on most unscrambled conversations from Air Force One.

title: REAGAN, IN BERLIN, BIDS SOVIET WORK FOR A SAFE EUROPE
description: President Reagan, bringing his arduous European trip to a dramatic close with a visit to the Berlin wall, challenged the Soviet Union today to move beyond ''the dashed hopes of the 1970's'' to ''a safer and freer Europe'' in the years ahead.

title: 2,600 Face Layoff At 2 Amax Mines
description: Amax Inc. said it would lay off slightly more than 2,600 workers at its Climax and Henderson molybdenum mines in west-central Colorado for five weeks beginning June 28. The company laid off 1,500 workers earlier this year at the two mines and its state headquarters in Golden.

title: QUEENS SATELLITE TV SERVICE BANNED
description: A Queens telecommunications company passed over by the city for a cable franchise announced plans yesterday to set up a television system of its own that would provide satellite programming to subscribers in Queens as early as next fall.

title: RADAR AIRCRAFT BUILT IN U.S. PLAY ROLE IN ISRAEL'S SUCCESS
description: An American-built aircraft equipped with radar capable of tracking 250 planes at once and a computer that can instantaneously compute l5 interception solutions was a major factor in Israel's almost total domination of the sky in the Middle East fighting this week, according to military and aerospace experts.

title: WAGE LAW CHANGE PROTESTED
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. took legal steps today to thwart a Reagan Administration plan that it says ''would repeal by administrative fiat'' a law protecting wage standards for workers on Government construction projects.

title: Florida Bank Suit
description: A lawsuit against Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. was filed yesterday by one of its major shareholders, C.A. Cavendes Sociedad Financiera of Venezuela, charging that its merger in May with the Alliance Corporation was illegal because no shareholder vote was held. The suit charges that Florida National issued 55,000 more shares in connection with the merger than permitted, under Florida law, without shareholder approval. ''We are seeking a binding shareholder vote,'' Gerald B. Cope Jr., a Miami lawyer whose firm represents the Venezuelan investment group, said.

title: MCCALLUM WINNER IN GARDEN
description: When Mike McCallum and Kevin Perry stepped into the ring in the main event in Madison Square Garden last night, the two junior middleweights had 21 knockouts between them in 22 fights. When they left after 10 rounds, they had the same number of knockouts, but McCallum had his 15th straight victory without a defeat.

title: Weisweiler Picks Brazil
description: Hennes Weisweiler, the former Cosmos coach, is a native of West Germany, but he has picked Brazil to win the World Cup, which begins tomorrow in Spain. ''Brazil, without a doubt,'' said Weisweiler, who is covering the event for German television.

title: E.E.C. MEETS TODAY ON FRENCH FRANC
description: France has bowed to mounting pressure against the franc and has asked for a significant devaluation of the currency against the West German mark, sources at the European Economic Community said here early today.

title: AFTER VICTORY, G.O.P. LEADERS LOOK AHEAD TO BUDGET OBSTACLES
description: House Republican leaders said today that, despite their budget victory Thursday, the spending measure still faced major obstacles in Congress.

title: Acquisition by Coldwell
description: Coldwell, Banker & Company, the nation's largest full-service real estate company, announced today that it had acquired the Realtek R.E. Company, a residential real estate brokerage concern based in Jupiter, Fla, for an undisclosed amount. Realtek employs 740 full-time and part-time sales associates and has eight offices in Palm Beach, Martin and St. Lucie counties in Florida. Coldwell, which is based in Los Angeles and is owned by Sears, Roebuck & Company, operates 542 offices across the nation and employs a staff of more than 11,700.

title: Mary Jackson Is Married To Robert W. Outtrim Jr.
description: Mary Shirley Billings Jackson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Clarke Billings of Old Saybrook, Conn., was married yesterday in Trinity Chapel on the Green in New Haven to Robert Winthrop Outtrim Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Outtrim of West Hartford, Conn.

title: YANKS LOSE, 5-3
description: Just after the dramatic two-run eighth-inning home run that would give the Yankees their seventh loss in eight games, the man in the third-base coach's box quietly shook the rookie's hand as he jogged through the noise. When the crowd at Memorial Stadium demanded a curtain call from the rookie, the coach did not turn around to look.

title: Wendy C. Mohr Becomes Bride of Cooper Morris
description: Wendy Carlyle Mohr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Day Mohr of Unionville, Pa., was married yesterday to Cooper Jowell Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Morris of Pughtown, Pa. The Rev. Cameron Yorkston performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: S.I. MOVING INTO THE SPACE AGE
description: CONSTRUCTION is scheduled to begin soon in northwestern Staten I sland on a telecommunications facility called Teleport, designed to r eceive and transmit global satellite signals for as many as a h undred companies.

title: INTRUDES
description: News of the British attack on Stanley reached here on a sparkling fall morning with Argentines in the streets of their capital celebrating the presence of Pope John Paul II.

title: A PROTEGE'S STORY
description: DREAMS DIE HARD By David Harris. 341 pp. New York: St. Martin's/Marek. $14.95.

title: Gloria Miller Wed To Kevin Daigh
description: Gloria Chalmers Miller, daughter of the late Gloria Reisinger Stowell of Palm Beach and New York, and the late Philip Francis Miller Jr. of Boca Grande, Fla., was married yesterday to Kevin Daigh, son of Pamela Byrne Daigh of Richmond and the late Michael Daigh. The Rev. Frederick Thayer performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club at Centre Island, L.I.

title: CONTROL DATA'S DRIVE TO STAY IN FRONT
description: the ''number-crunchers'' used for such tasks as nuclear weapons research, weather forecasting and oil exploration - the 25-year-old Control Data now shares that field with an offspring, Cray Research Inc., formed a decade ago by Seymour R. Cray, who helped found Control Data.

title: 2 Events Rescheduled
description: As a result of the postponement because of last weekend's rain, two events will be held today.

title: DISPUTES OVER THE HAYES AND ABERNATHY GOSPEL
description: To the Business Editor: It is surprising that it took so long for Hayes and Abernathy to find ''Management Gospel Gone Wrong.'' But we remain deep in the woods because America's senior managers, who do understand the problem, must respond to a headless, mindless entity - the American shareholder - who demands immediate sacrifices of future productivity in favor of short-term earnings.

title: HE WHO WIELDS THE PEN DRAWS SMILES
description: HARTFORD A BEAMING Representative Thomas D. Ritter watched over Governor O'Neill's shoulder the other day as the Governor signed into law legislation enabling the police to photograph and fingerprint 14-and 15-year-olds arrested for felonies.

title: MIRO'S IMPACT IN AMERICA
description: HOUSTON

title: Battle Begins Near Stanley
description: Britain last week suffered its worst casualties of the Falklands war, but the losses only seemed to increase Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's determination to push for military victory. Striking before dawn yesterday, British forces surprised Argentine positions near Stanley amid indications that the final assault against the 7,000-man Argentine garrison was under way.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN CAPE COD
description: SUSAN DAAR is editor of the leisure and entertainment supplement of the Cape Cod Times. By SUSAN DAAR

title: DUO: COPPOCK-HODGKINSON
description: In a singularly loud recital at the Abraham Goodman House's Merkin Concert Hall Thursday evening, Bruce Coppock, cellist, and Randall Hodgkinson, pianist, joined forces for a program that featured sonatas by Beethoven, Brahms and Debussy. At times, the combination of a strong pianist who insisted on being heard and a strong but sometimes shaky cellist whose playing occasionally lacked sophistication, restraint and sensitivity, if not fervor, proved uniquely oppressive.

title: MRS. THATCHER DRAWING MORE FIRE ON THE HOME FRONT
description: LONDON "The strong wind fanned the flames, enormous flames, and as the fuel tanks exploded the ship was half enveloped in thick, black smoke, but the Royal Navy helicopter pilots and their crews ignored it. They ignored the explosions and ignored the ammunition erupting around them, and they flew their machines in to lift the queues of men waiting calmly below. The casualties and survivors, many suffering from shock and burns, were picked up from the beach by soldiers who had run from their trenches. Some carried men on their shoulders, struggling in the waves, then went back for more.''

title: POP SINGER: HUMPERDINCK
description: Engelbert Humperdinck, the English crooner who has achieved fame and fortune in Las Vegas, opened a three-day engagement at Carnegie Hall on Friday with a performance that was so exaggerated it might almost have been a Lily Tomlin parody.

title:
Economic Affairs;
ALL TIED UP BY THE BUSINESS CYCLES
description: ARE the gods against us, or have we not brought the increasing e conomic chaos upon ourselves? Is the outcome of the supply-side t ragedy - sealed by last week's actions in the House - that we will h ave to live with high unemployment and volatile financial markets? T o answer these questions, let's go back to basics.

title: About Cars; PUTTING BRAKES TO A SEVERE TEST
description: the kind of emergency where you don't care if that car ever moves again, as long as it stops right now - when you have that kind of thing, then you really have to stomp on those brakes.''

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC Jamaican reggae has been a pervasive influence in American and British popular music for more than a decade now. But there are many varieties of Jamaican reggae, and Jamaicans living in Britain have fashioned a British reggae style that is unlike any of the Jamaican styles.

title: Business Conditions; RESEARCH BUDGETS GROW
description: The recent announcement that companies plan to reduce plant and equipment expenditures by 2.4 percent was not surprising, given their plight: They are besieged by high interest rates, tumbling profits and a persistent recession. The amount they plan to spend for research and development, however, seems to be rising.

title: City Landlords Ask for More
description: The cost of living may be leveling off but, if landlords in New York City have their way, the cost of living in many rent-stabilized apartments isn't about to. Last week, building owners asked the city's Rent Guidelines Board for one of the largest increases in the 14 years of rent stabilization.

title: CAREY VETOES BILL ON JOINT CUSTODY IN DIVORCES
description: Governor Carey has vetoed legislation that would have required judges to consider joint custody of children in divorce proceedings if one or both parents requested it.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: MEDIATOR FOR THE ENVIRONMENT
description: ''I FEEL I'm returning to my first love,'' Dorothy S. McCluskey said of her decision to leave political office and continue her interests in environmental concerns in the private sector.

title: ARGENTINES REPORT BRITISH BREACHED STANLEY DEFENSES
description: British and Argentine troops were pitted in a major battle today for control of Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, the Argentine high command announced.

title: Around the Nation; Strikers Burn Truck After Guards Fire Shots
description: Strikers at a phonograph recording company overturned and burned a security truck today after guards fired shots at a car driven by a union member, officials said.

title: SON HELD IN MURDER OF HIS MOTHER AND FOUR CHILDREN IN BRONX HOME
description: A 20-year-old Bronx man was arrested early yesterday and charged with murdering his mother, his young brother, his niece and two other children on Friday, the police said.

title: A Look at China's Grass Roots
description: It was interesting to read about life in China from the perspective of a foreigner (''How the Chinese Police Themselves,'' by Fox Butterfield, April 18). Many Chinese, like myself, do not always realize how strange our way of life must seem to others.

title: 'I AN MOT INTERESTED IN OPERA, OF COURSE'
description: Perhaps I had read just one too many interviews with a modish theater director who had been offered the chance to stage an opera in his own image. Or possibly it was that midnight snack of shredded beef, Hunan-style. In any event, I found myself in my dreams interviewing the latest rage of the stage, Ben Trovato. In what follows, I will hide behind the persona of Q while Mr. Trovato masquerades as A.

title: Lawrence Walsh Weds Gael Doar
description: Mary Gael Doar, daughter of John Doar of New York and Anne Leffingwell Doar of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Lawrence Raymond Walsh, son of Margaret I. Walsh of Colorado Springs and the late Joseph R. Walsh. Msgr. Charles E. Diviney performed the ceremony in St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: JAN STEPHENSON LEADS L.P.G.A. BY TWO
description: Jan Stephenson, despite a bogey on the final hole, shot a two-under-par 70 today to take a two-stroke lead after three rounds of the $200,000 L.P.G.A. Championship.

title: Rogene Elkins Married to Jan Austelle
description: Rogene Elkins and Jan Van Etten Austell, members of the faculty at the Kent (Conn.) School were married there yesterday in St. Joseph's Chapel.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME PROBLEMS OF THE SEASON IN REVIEW
description: NOW that spring is almost over, it would seem to be appropriate that we evaluate the season to date. While there was a deficiency of rainfall in early spring, and it became necessary to water lawns in areas of sandy soil, recent rainfall would seem to have more than offset the immediate moisture needs. Small ponds that were low on water a few weeks ago now seem to be bank full.

title:
ANTIQUES;
COMMON ITEMS TELL TALE OF TWO TOWNS
description: HARTFORD BASED on the belief that clues to the New England past can be found by studying and comparing everyday objects from different communities, a major new exhibit, ''Two Towns,'' will be on view next month at the Connecticut Historical Society, 1 Elizabeth Street.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: On Middle Initials

title: TURN THE BLACKBOARD INTO A VIDEO GAME
description: To the Editor:

title: RIGHT STRINGS CAN STILL PULL A BUDGET VOTE
description: It was Thursday, shortly before the House was to try once again to adopt a spending plan for fiscal 1983. President Reagan was on the telephone from Bonn, asking Representative Jack Hightower, a Texas Democrat, to vote for the Republican budget.

title: U.S. SEEKS REFORMS FOR MILITARY DATA
description: The Reagan Administration has begun a wideranging program to correct serious deficiencies in gathering, assessing and disseminating military intelligence, according to senior Defense Department officials.

title: HELEN PALTIS SILVER
description: Helen Paltis Silver, a former reporter for U.S. News & World Report who also wrote for The New York Times and various newspapers in New Jersey, died Friday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: China Attacks Reagan For Comments in Bonn
description: China's official press agency said today in a commentary that the Reagan Administration compromised on arms control and disarmament during the NATO summit meeting in Bonn partly to make a show of unity and partly because of American economic problems.

title: GEORGE BAMBERGER'S BEST DECISION: HIS OPEN-HEART SURGERY
description: The decision was as clear-cut as removing a tired pitcher from a game. The doctors had given me two choices: A - Don't have the operation and be 75 percent; or B - Have surgery and be 100 percent.

title: FIGHTING MALE INFERTILITY
description: He that is wounded in the stones ... shall not enter into the congregation of the Lord. - DEUTERONOMY 23:1.

title: A TALK WITH ANDRE BRINK
description: Unlike a musician or a painter, a writer needs a language. Obvious, and not very interesting, until the question, which language? Our century is littered with examples of writers who have had to make a choice, to stick with or to abandon their mother tongue. Conrad and Nabokov learned to write in English. Almost more poignant than these is the case of a writer whose language is under threat all around him and who at the same time is driven away from his language by political rather than personal considerations. The writer is Andre Brink; the language is Afrikaans, the only European language to have taken root outside Europe and to have developed radically. It is a simplified but enriched descendant of Dutch, spoken by the children of the Dutch, French and German settlers who came to the Cape of Good Hope in the 17th and 18th centuries.

title: DON'T DISCOUNT THE BLACK VOTE
description: According to the 1980 census, there were 104,815 black residents among the county's 866,599 total population. Of course, this does not mean there are not a few more black people among us, what with the demonstrated propensity of the United States Census Bureau for failing to count everyone - especially minorities.

title: U.N. LOWERS ESTIMATES OF POPULATION IN 2000
description: Because of population-control programs, the world's population in the year 2000 will be 20 percent less than the 7.5 billion that major international agencies had predicted, according to a report by the United Nations Fund for Population Activities.

title: IN SURVEY, 72% FAVOR FREEZE
description: The idea of freezing the nuclear arsenals of the United States and the Soviet Union at their present levels has the support of 72 percent of the American public, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted last month. Only 30 percent of the respondents, however, would support a freeze if it would allow the Soviet Union an advantage in nuclear strength.

title: HATCH DISOWNS GROUP'S ADS ATTACKING MAYOR OF SALT LAKE
description: A national political action committee based in Virginia has committed $80,000 to an advertising campaign against Mayor Ted Wilson of Salt Lake City, a Democrat, who is seeking the Senate seat held by Senator Orrin G. Hatch. Mr. Hatch, a conservative Republican, has resisted that committee's support.

title: MRS. GANDHI GROOMS ANOTHER SON
description: When dawn broke in India on June 23, 1980, Rajiv Gandhi, who was vacationing in Europe with his Italian wife, Sonia, was an unassuming pilot for India Airlines. He was looking forward to the day when he would qualify and move up to Boeing jets from the twin-propeller craft he had been flying between relatively small Indian cities. True, he was the older son of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, but unlike his flamboyant, assertive and politically ambitious brother, Sanjay, he had energetically shunned public life, living almost anonymously through the turbulent 1970's, when his mother fell from power - and into prison - then returned to it.

title: CAN SCIENCE AND POLITICS SAFELY MIX
description: Remember Allen V. Astin? He became the Eisenhower Administration's first big bombshell back in 1953. As director of the National Bureau of Standards, Dr. Astin ran afoul of the political leadership because his agency -which jealously guarded its reputation as a scientific bastion impregnable to political and commercial pressures - had declared a chemical called AD-X2, then sold as a rejuvenator of tired car batteries, useless.

title: TURNING BACK THE CLOCK IN WATCH HILL
description: BETSY WADE is an editor on the national desk of The Times. BY BETSY WADE

title: Around the World; Detroit Man Arraigned In Fatal Shooting Spree
description: A Detroit man was arraigned today on charges of murder, assault and arson in a shooting spree and firebombing at a downtown office building that left a young woman dead and 38 persons injured.

title: AMATEURS MAKE WINE FOR THE FUN OF IT
description: MANCHESTER AMID an amiable hubbub, it was a time for bottles to gurgle and for glass after glass to be filled and refilled. The occasion was a sampling of both the winning and losing wines in the second annual Amateur Wine Making Contest, run by the Connecticut Grape Growers Association.

title: Greek Cruise
description: To the Editor: Certain major shipping lines in Greece are perpetuating a monstrous fraud on the tourist who books an Aegean cruise. The brochures advertise a stop at Crete where an optional excursion is available to the ancient ruins of the Palace of Knossos and also to the Museum of Heraklion with its Minoan treasures.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Just Nostalgia R.L. Delderfield's English country novel ''A Horseman Riding By'' begins in 1902 and tells of a young man who is discharged from the army after the Boer War, returns home to an inheritance, buys an estate, marries, becomes a squire and, with that, his adventures begin.

title: L.I. COLLEGES AIMING TO LIMIT INCREASES IN TUITION
description: MANY Long Island colleges, recognizing the plight of students affected by cutbacks in Federal aid and concerned that enrollment may drop as a result, are generally limiting tuition increases to about 8 percent, the annual rate of inflation.

title: Juan N. Calero Jr. Weds Helen Hughes
description: Helen Sullivan Hughes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Hughes of Princeton, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Juan Nery Calero Jr., son of Mrs. Elida Calero and the late Mr. Calero of Isabela, P.R. The Rev. Joseph R. Hughes, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Princeton.

title: Japanese Ryokans
description: To the Editor: Harold C. Schonberg's article ''In Kyoto, the Definitive Japanese Inn'' (Travel, May 23) evoked happy memories. Having been married to a nisei for 25 years when we made a similar journey to Japan (to return the ashes of my husband's parents to the ancestral tomb), I had perhaps a more compelling need to know the rationale behind the rituals. v. hile the Hiiragiya ryokan may be for celebrities, the truth of the matter is that any ryokan is not that easily accessible to the public, especially not to tourists. The Japanese are sensitive about their singular culture. They share it with foreigners reluctantly, unwilling to risk ridicule or misunderstanding.

title: A NUCLEAR FREEZE FAVORS THE RUSSIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: FEMINISTS PUBLISH A COOKBOOK
description: SINCE the Bloodroot Collective opened its waterfront restaurant and bookstore at 85 Ferris Street in the Black Rock section of Bridgeport five years ago, its patrons have been asking for recipes of dishes they particularly favor.

title: GENETICS LED THE WAY TO A NEW KIND OF SQUASH
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Louise Saul is the associate editor of the Sentinel Newspapers in East Brunswick, N.J. By LOUISE SAUL

title: AN ORIGINAL ACTION PAINTER
description: FREDERIC REMINGTON A Biography. By Peggy and Harold Samuels. Illustrated. 537 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $24.95.

title: Gillian Barth Is Married
description: Gillian Margaret Barth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce A. Barth of Greenwich, Conn., was married in Ottawa yesterday to Hugh Grenville Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas William McConnell Davis of Ottawa. The Very Rev. T.E. Downey performed the ceremony at Christ Church Anglican Cathedral.

title: Republicans Win A Suspect Victory on Budget
description: Republicans continued to hold sway in the nominally Democraticcontrolled House last week.

title: Hidden Treasures; Prop Art
description: The auctioning of a tiny sled named Rosebud for $60,500 suggests that prop art could be the newest form of gold in the hills of Hollywood. ''Rosebud,'' was the word the dying Citizen Kane gasped out, referring to a cheap sled taken from him when he was a child.

title: West Bank Arab Dies Of Wounds in Protest
description: An Arab man died today of a bullet wound inflicted Friday by an Israeli soldier patrolling Nablus, an army spokesman reported.

title: NOMINEE ON COAST IS RIGHT OF CENTER
description: In Attorney General George Deukmejian, their nominee for Governor of California, Republicans have selected a man whose views are conservative enough to satisfy all but the ideological extremists, a survey of his record shows.

title: Milking Milk
description: By law on Aug. 12, 1981, milk became the official beverage of New York State. Mindful of a strong wine constituency upstate, Governor Carey said in signing the bill, ''It is important to note, however, that such an action does not denigrate any worthy item not so mentioned.''

title: IN THE HOME STRETCH
description: After nine rounds of the Phillips & Drew International Tournament in London, Yasser Seirawan, a 22-year-old Seattle grandmaster, trailed eight players and seemed headed for an undistinguished result in a very impressive field. But he was only warming up for what lay ahead.

title: THE HOMOSEXUAL MARKET
description: Yes, there is a gay market; there is also a lesbian market despite the fact that the word ''lesbian'' did not appear in your article. However, we are not ''recession proof.''

title: GIVING A LIFT TO LOS ANGELES ROCK
description: ''Revenge Will Come,'' (Geffen GHS 2010), the debut album by the West Coast singer/songwriter Greg Copeland, introduces a feisty, original voice into the mainstream of Los Angeles rock. Though there are many echoes vocally and lyrically in Mr. Copeland of Bob Dylan, Neil Young, and Warren Zevon, with whom he shares an ironic, edgy aggressiveness, Mr. Copeland's disturbing mixture of leftist rhetoric, Christian imagery, and personal sexual politics is something new in pop. And his songs - alternately enraged, selflacerating, and meditative - are strong enough to infuse a low-keyed musical genre with a surge of energy.

title: INVENTIVE 'NEW AMERICAN' FARE
description: WITH several years of painstaking restoration completed and the paint barely dry, the Bull's Head Inn in Bridgehampton finally opened for business in the middle of last summer. By the time the season was winding down, the Bull's Head Inn was maintaining a commendable kitchen, matching it with pleasantly competent dining room service.

title: Getting It Right On Redistricting
description: The New York City Council finally has a redistricting plan that toes the line. So ruled the Justice Department last week, ending months of legal and political wrangling and clearing the way for the once-postponed Council elections to be held in the fall.

title: ITALIAN-AMERICAN WOMEN LINK UP
description: In July 1980 a small group of Italian-American professional women met in a West Side apartment to talk about forming what some of them at the time believed was a ''pipedream'' - a women's organization in which they could share their experiences, further their careers and become role models for younger women.

title: MARTHA EGGERTH TO PRESIDE AT VIENNA GALA
description: She was a Hungarian soprano, he was a Polish tenor, but as the husband-and-wife team of Marta Eggerth and Jan Kiepura they achieved fame as interpreters of some of the most memorable Viennese music ever heard on the stages and screens of Europe and America, particularly in more than 2,000 performances of Franz Lehar's operetta ''The Merry Widow'' on Broadway and on tour from 1943 to 1957.

title: Perspectives: Tax Incentives; THE J-51 TAX INCENTIVES: A PROGRAM UNDER FIRE
description: NO city program has done as much to further housing improvement in N ew York City over the last 20 years as the tax-incentive system k nown as J-51. But as the housing market has strengthened, especiallyi n Manhattan, critics have grown more vocal. Now a number of l egislators are fighting the renewal of J-51 authorization in Albany.

title: Sarah Bucknell Becomes Bride Of James Treco
description: Sarah Harlan Bucknell, daughter of Mrs. Edward C. Carter 2d of Wayne, Pa., was married there yesterday to James Dempsey Treco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Treco Jr. of Gates Mills, Ohio. The Rev. Richard Hess performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. David's Episcopal Church.

title: Raise Barred for Governor
description: The Delaware House of Representatives has rejected a proposed pay increase for the Governor, keeping him among the lowest-paid Governors in the nation. The House defeated a bill Thursday that would have doubled the Governor's annual salary from $35,000 to $70,000.

title: Aliens Found Challenging U.S.
description: Immigration in the next few years will pose a challenge to American society similar to that when Europeans flocked here at the turn of the century, according to a private study.

title: Galway to Conduct
description: James Galway, the flutist, will conduct and perform as soloist with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra in a concert to be televised on PBS's ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series tomorrow from 8 to 10 P.M. The concert will originate from Avery Fisher Hall and will include music by Handel, Mozart and Vivaldi.

title: Mark Ruggiero, Salesman, Weds Kathleen Mary Shea
description: Kathleen Mary Shea, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul V. Shea of Ossining, N.Y., and Mark Ruggiero, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ruggiero of Dedham, Mass., were married yesterday in St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Church in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Waldron performed the ceremony.

title: Henry J. Gumpel Dies at 73; International Law Specialist
description: Henry J. Gumpel, a partner in the New York law firm of Walter, Conston, Schurtman & Gumpel, died Tuesday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. Mr. Gumpel was 73 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: HEARING SET ON SALE OF A SPACE SHUTTLE
description: A HOUSE subcommittee will hold a hearing Tuesday on a proposal by a Princeton company that seeks to buy a space shuttle in exchange for a franchise to sell its cargo space.

title: OXBRIDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: PSYCHIATRIST SAYS HINCKLEY HAD A SENSE OF REALITY
description: A prison psychiatrist testified today that John W. Hinckley Jr. shot President Reagan in March 1981 partly to ''make his mark in the world'' and partly to ''get back at all those people who let him down,'' including his family.

title: Postings; What a Trip!
description: Some developers go a long way to put the right face on a building. The Durst Organization had planned a facade of black reflective glass for the 40-story office tower it is putting up at 1155 Avenue of the Americas, at 44th Street.

title: South Shore, Holy Cross Capture Baseball Titles
description: Wayne Rosenthal pitched a two-hitter and Vin Martino a four-hitter in leading their teams to shutout victories in high school baseball championships at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

title: Karen Hohner Bride of Randall Keith
description: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday Karen Hohner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hohner of Centre Island, L.I., was married to Randall Guy Keith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Keith of Pebble Beach, Calif. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony.

title: BAPTISTS PREPARE FOR STORMY MEETNG
description: As 18,000 Southern Baptists arrive in New Orleans this weekend for the annual meeting of the nation's largest Protestant denomination, conflict between two cherished Baptist principles threatens to plunge the denomination even deeper into into doctrinal turmoil.

title: Lindsey Mary Stansfield Wed
description: In St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church yesterday Lindsey Mary Stansfield, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John B. Stansfield of New York, was married to Samuel Frazier Pryor 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pryor 3d of Bedford Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Walsh performed the ceremony.

title: A WAY TO HALT THE ARMS RACE
description: There is an easily structured, effective way to stop the escalating arms race. President Reagan should declare an open-ended unilateral moratorium, always subject to reversal, on the production, testing and deployment of new nuclear weapons and delivery systems. He should invite the Russians to respond with a parallel declaration of purpose. If they did, it would result in a non-negotiated freeze. Only the President has the power and prestige to put this into effect; only he might have the courage to break such new ground and help reduce worldwide fear.

title: Camera Safari
description: To the Editor:

title: Heading for a Reaganomics Referendum?
description: President Reagan isn't running for anything in New Jersey this year, but his economic policies are. As the winners in last week's senatorial primaries move toward their November confrontation, the issue of Reaganomics just might overshadow the public image Republican Representative Millicent Fenwick has built and the one Democrat Frank R. Lautenberg is buying.

title: ECONOMICALLY, VIETNAM IS LOSING THE PEACE
description: The Vietnamese economy is in a shambles and Communists and Western economists, in varying degrees, cite war and the huge military establishment as primary causes. But even Vietnamese leaders are beginning to concede that part of the blame must be placed upon government mismanagement, rigid policies, lack of popular support, official corruption and general weariness.

title: Mailbox; Yanks in the Rain
description: To the Sports Editor: A Mailbox letter from Charles R. Sager (''When a Rainout Should Be Called,'' The New York Times, May 30), bemoaned the fact that the Yankees played a game in the rain on Sunday, May 23.

title: Beyond Anxiety
description: Several hundred thousand demonstrators in New York's Central Park can't be wrong. For peace, against war, for disarmament, against nukes -whatever their anxieties and ambitions, people in such numbers represent strong and widely shared emotions. They are a force that did not exist in America's first three atomic decades.

title: Maree Takes Mile in 3:52.86
description: During his 46 years as Villanova's track coach, James (Jumbo) Elliott coached 14 sub-four-minute milers. The last was Sydney Maree of South Africa, who may turn out to be the greatest of all.

title: CHECKS OF SPANS, ROADS CONTINUE
description: IN the wake of the collapse of six dams and the breaching of 14 others during last weekend's severe rainstorm, about 150 of the approximately 3,200 dams in the state will be examined by environmental officials.

title: STAR FROM RYE HEADING FOR TENNIS TOUR
description: MAMARONECK ''Like to hit a few, Billy?'' The voice on the other end of the phone not only posed a question but also again caused Bill Stanley to wonder if the invitation wasn't just too good to be true.

title: CLARIDGE DECISION IMMINENT
description: TRENTON THE state's Casino Control Commission is expected to rule by next week whether to license the Del E. Webb Corporation to operate the Claridge Hotel-Casino in Atlantic City.

title: Robert England Grant Jr.  Marries Patricia Ann Hill
description: Patricia Ann Hill, daughter of Mrs. Donald P. Hill of Ridgewood, N.J., and the late Mr. Hill, was married there yesterday to Robert England Grant Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Grant of Barrington, R.I. The Rev. Bernard C. Fischer performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church.

title: Boston Church Gets $86,650 In Auction of Historic Silver
description: The auction of four 18th-century American silver cups and two 19th-century English silverplated flagons brought $86,650 to help a Boston church purchase a parsonage for its pastor, the Rev. William Boylan, and his family. The silverware, which had been on loan for decades to the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, had not been used in a church service since the mid-1950's, Mr. Boylan said last week.

title: 3-1 PRINCELET WINS AT BELMONT
description: Princelet, who had lost 10 straight races since winning the Meadowlands Cup last fall, finally found a field he could handle yesterday at Belmont Park and scored a 1 1/4-length victory in the $55,800 Nassau County Handicap.

title: OPERA: FROM O. HENRY
description: New York University's Opera Studio remembered a former Greenwich Village neighbor Friday night with its ''American Trilogy'' - three one-act operas by different composers all based on stories by O. Henry. The subject matter ranged from broad humor to melodrama and the quality of musical workmanship from drab to very appealing. The performances were at the N.Y.U. University Theater.

title: Where Is Truth In Rent Dispute?
description: The raging controversy between tenants' aggrievements and landlords' coercions continues to blaze with mounting fury and discord. The Opinion Page contained an apologia by Kenneth J. Gould, counsel to the Apartment Owners Advisory Council (May 23), asserting that ''tenants are now afforded significant and adequate protections and no additional tinkering with the 'balance of power' is necessary.''

title: WINE
description: '47 WAS DOUBLY BLESSED he splashing of the fountain in the central courtyard of the Saint Louis Hotel vies with the soft pelting of the rain as a spring shower cleanses the French Quarter of New Orleans. Wrought-iron gas lanterns flicker, illuminating red tiles and stucco walls. The air is soft and heavy with the scent of magnolia blossoms.

title: Renter vs. Buyer
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION
description: 1 2 13 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 1 5 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) During a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past. 3 3 7 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 4 5 8 CELEBRITY, by Thomas Thompson. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A crime committed in their boyhood comes back to haunt three young men. 5 1 EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romance and political upheaval on a Caribbean island. 6 15 2 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 7 7 9 THY BROTHER'S WIFE, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Geis, $14.95.) Two brothers, a priest and a senator, each in his own way, love the same woman.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER Bill Irwin is both an original clown and a throwback to the great silent comedians. His show, ''The Regard of Flight,'' at the American Place Theater, gives free reign to his unpredictable, unequivocal talent.

title: Free Guide
description: To the Editor: In the Q & A column (Travel, May 23), you list several European guides for the Jewish traveler. You will be glad to know that a new, and free, 15-page guide entitled ''France for the Jewish Traveler'' is offered to those who send a stamped, self-addressed business envelope to the following address: ''France for the Jewish Traveler,'' Air France, P.O. Box 10-747, Long Island City, N.Y. 11101. PETER E. STEWARD National press manager Air France New York

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Dobbs Ferry Boutique Offers Up to 50% Off
description: Two Dobbs Ferry shops combined resources recently to produce a fashion show and dinner dance that ended with the distribution of 25 prizes from local merchants and restaurants. Novita and Francine's Boutique were the main sponsors, and each shop offers weekly or seasonal specials.

title: Personal Finance; WARM WELCOME FOR INCENTIVE OPTIONS
description: WHEN Congress created the incentive stock option last summer, there w ere high hopes that it would become a popular means of rewarding v alued executives. But while incentive options do offer executives c onsiderable tax advantages, they are also more costly for businessest han the usual ''nonqualified'' options, and some management s pecialists felt this would dampen the companies' enthusiasm.

title: ORPHANED CHILDREN OF L.I. POLICE OFFICER ASK FOR FULL PENSION
description: Three children of a Nassau County police officer who was killed in a traffic accident five years ago are asking the Legislature to restore to them their father's full pension benefits.

title: MARTHA'S VINEYARD: GREEN AND SOLID
description: HENRY BEETLE HOUGH has been an editor and writer for the Vineyard Gazette for 62 years. By HENRY BEETLE HOUGH

title: MOSCOW: ARMS BUILDUP IS ECONOMIC WARFARE
description: To a Westerner with a normal degree of skepticism about Soviet intentions there is much that is manifestly specious about the Kremlin's position on arms issues. There is, for example, the Soviet official who nurses a scotch at a diplomatic reception and argues that the nature of communism and capitalism make Soviet nuclear missiles inherently defensive and their American counterparts just as certainly offensive. In the face of such arguments, one can lose sight of the fact that the Russians have real problems in coping with the improving arsenals arrayed against them by potential adversaries.

title: Area Receipts Top $2 Million
description: Telecasts of the Larry Holmes-Gerry Cooney bout from Las Vegas, Nev., generated more than $1 million in gate receipts at both Madison Square Garden and the Meadowlands Friday night.

title: Chemical Clue To Suicide
description: The theory that mental and emotional illnesses may result from chemical disorders in the brain is familiar, though proof has been elusive. Now, scientists at Wayne State University in Detroit and the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md., have independently adduced evidence that suicidal tendencies are influenced by a brain chemical abnormality.

title: COULD HOLMES HAVE LOST DECISION?
description: Larry Holmes, in a self-controlled and intelligent performance, had thoroughly beaten a courageous but outclassed Gerry Cooney for 12 rounds. In the 13th, Holmes turned on the power and, with Cooney about to slump to the canvas for the second time in the World Boxing Council heavyweight title fight, his trainer, Victor Valle, entered the ring at the Caesars Palace parking lot and the referee ended the fight. There were eight seconds left in the round.

title: ALEXIS DE TOCQUEVILLE WAS HERE
description: AMERICAN JOURNEY Traveling With Tocqueville in Search of ''Democracy in America.'' By Richard Reeves. Illustrated. 399 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: GOOD ANGELS, BAD ANGELS AND PROLONGING SMOKING
description: I made it - a cigarette-free day. For a two-pack-a-day man that's an achievement, and to keep me from backsliding I'm relying on that sense of achievement, coupled with memories of agonizing and rationalizing I endured.

title: HOLES IN NEW YORK'S FISCAL SAFETY NET
description: The New York City budget battle, an annual rite of spring between City Hall and Albany, has been rough and tumble ever since the city's fiscal crisis in the mid-70's required everybody to pay closer attention to the numbers and installed several layers of monitors. But the 1982 version has set even veteran heads to spinning.

title: REAGAN AND THE NEO-CONSERVATIVES
description: One would imagine that a serious intellectual, conservative or otherwise, would wish to point out to the policy makers that the major historical forces behind our age seem to aim in a different direction from the United States-Russia confrontation. A growing body of scholarly opinion feels that we are passing through as cataclysmic a period of historic change as the fall of Rome, marked by the emergence of the third world, which stands ready to replace traditional Western hegemony.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IN a unanimous decision, the Connecticut Supreme Court has ruled that the use of grand jury transcripts by defendants can be restricted and, in some circumstances, presiding judges should even reject requests.

title: Sports of the Times; GERRY COONEY'S NEXT FIGHT
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. FOR all the rhetoric of the past weeks, reality did not strike home until the boxers surged into the makeshift arena Friday night: Gerry Cooney was more popular than Larry Holmes.

title: Aids to Navigation Are Targets of Cuts
description: Because of the Reagan Administration's efforts to reduce the Federal budget, the Coast Guard could be forced to remove thousands of navigation aids from the nation's waterways.

title: Joan R. Dearborn Becomes a Bride
description: Joan Ruth Dearborn, an assistant in the print and silver department of Phillips Son & Neale Inc., the New York auction house, was married yesterday to A. Michael Choremi Jr., of Glen Head, L.I., an assistant traffic manager with the Southern Star Shipping Company in New York. The Rev. George W. Wyer performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Ivy, Va.

title: HUSBANDS AND WIVES
description: Whether husbands and wives should play bridge together is a question that has been often posed but never satisfactorily answered. Does the marital relationship lead to poor bridge results? And does a bridge partnership place a strain on a marriage?

title: Sports People; A Year-Old Memory
description: At first Doug DeCinces didn't want to talk about it. Then he decided he would. Yesterday was the first anniversary of the start of the 50-day baseball strike.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME PROBLEMS OF THE SEASON IN REVIEW
description: Now that spring is almost over, it would seem to be appropriate that we evaluate the season to date. While there was a deficiency of rainfall in early spring, and it became necessary to water lawns in areas of sandy soil, recent rainfall would seem to have more than offset the immediate moisture needs. Small ponds that were low on water a few weeks ago now seem to be bank full.

title: REAGAN AND THE NEO-CONSERVATIVES
description: As a former liberal Democrat now a Reagan supporter, as a former physics professor now a venture capitalist, let me suggest to Norman Podhoretz another, better method to stimulate ''entrepreneurial venturesomeness.''

title: GENE RESEARCH GIVES NEW HOPE ON CANCER CAUSES
description: New evidence now suggests that the causes of cancer, which have long seemed mysterious and almost infinite in variety, can be narrowed to the improper actions of a relatively few genes present in all human cells.

title: IDENTIFY TEEN DRINKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: JEWISH CENTER AIDS LEARNING DISABLED
description: In a six-year-old program in Brooklyn that combines the traditional curriculum of a yeshiva with the latest techniques of special education, 100 boys with learning disabilities study English and Hebrew in an environment designed to help them and their families cope with their special needs.

title: DAVID LETTERMAN-A TOUGH ACT TO PACKAGE
description: The continuing saga could be titled ''The Packaging of David Letterman.'' The comedian first came to national prominence as a guest on NBC's ''The Johnny Carson Show.'' He later moved up to be the occasional host during Mr. Carson's frequent sabbaticals. Then there was a good deal of trade talk that he was being groomed as Mr. Carson's eventual successor. NBC gave him a daytime show that, after weeks of sagging spirits and ratings, was finally deemed a setback to his neatly soaring career. But then, last Feb. 1, a determined NBC brought Mr. Letterman back to TV land, this time as a replacement for Tom Snyder, who followed Johnny Carson on the weeknight schedule. The new ''Late Night'' series can be seen Monday through Thursday at 12:30 A.M.

title: Comment; CRYING WOLF OVER WORD PROCESSORS
description: TO the Business Editor: Barbara R. Bergmann's article, ''A Threat Ahead From Word P rocessing'' (May 30) was quite destructive because it was full of m isinformation and gave a large number of readers a big false i mpression.

title: AMBIVALENTLY, TURKEY BUILDS ROAD TO SOVIET
description: Heavy earth-moving machines are busy leveling the new coastal road to the Soviet border, just nine miles away. And the people in this Black Sea port hope that the completion of the road next year will mean the opening of the Turkish-Soviet border to trade and travelers.

title: ENd of the Road At Ndjamena
description: Civil war comes naturally to artificial states like Chad, which was carved out of the desert in colonial times and has been in various stages of unrest since independence from France 22 years ago. Last week, rebel forces led by former Defense Minister Hissen Habre easily took the capital, Ndjamena, and crushed the regime of President Goukouni Oueddei. Mr. Goukouni fled to neighboring Cameroon, along with a quarter of Ndjamena's other residents.

title: AIR FORCE BUSES CARRIED SOME TO CHEER PRESIDENT
description: The Air Force provided 6 to 12 buses to take Congressional aides to and from the Friday evening welcoming ceremonies for President Reagan at Andrews Air Force Base, a Defense Department spokesman said today.

title: SCHOOL ADVERTISES FOR NEW TRUSTEES
description: The cost of becoming a trustee at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University is $1 million. That is the price tag put on an offer for trusteeships at the Florida school in an advertisement in The Wall Street Journal. The school says it needs the money for loans to students who pay more than $20,000 in tuition for a four-year course of study.

title: Albany Highflying
description: Aircraft owned by New York State and intended for the exclusive use of state employees on official business were being used by friends and relatives of Governor Carey and other officials, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan reported in an audit last March. He recommended that nonofficial use ''be clearly delineated'' and that the state reduce its air fleet.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC For all its brashly contemporary bustle, Washington Square symbolizes better than anything else the historical flavor of old Greenwich Village. This week, two free musical events will concentrate on the square and, directly or by implication, its history.

title: CRABS TESTED FOR TOXIC LEVELS
description: Preliminary tests by the state's Department of Environmental Protection show high levels of cadmium, a potentially toxic substance, in some blue crabs taken in the last year between New York Harbor and Delaware Bay.

title: Israel Overruns The P.L.O. - and Much of Lebanon
description: Israel proved its prowess anew last week, sending its forces smashing into Lebanon and transforming the Mideast political map for months and perhaps years to come.

title: TWO CITIES IN NEW SEARCH FOR BUSINESS
description: Yonkers and Mount Vernon moved in different directions last week, but with the same objective - to attract businesses to economically beleaguered cities that may become the county's most active sites of development this decade.

title: SEAGOING STEREO BECKONS SAILORS
description: When the King of England wanted some Water Music for his outing on the Thames, George Frederic Handel readily obliged and rowed alongside the royal barge with a boatful of musicians.

title: PETE SEEGER AND THE HUDSON RIVER
description: ON-HOUSE

title: RALLY SPEAKERS DECRY COST OF NUCLEAR ARMS RACE
description: Asserting that the nuclear arms race, while threatening mankind with extinction, already damages life on the earth, scores of speakers at yesterday's disarmament rally sought to show how their individual constituencies were suffering.

title: JOBLESS RATE AND POACHING RISE IN TIMBER COUNTRY
description: An increase in poaching and an emergency run to Idaho for potatoes are graphic signs that times are harder than usual in this timber-producing region.

title: CONCOURSE CO-OP IS A SYMBOL OF COOPERATION
description: The entrance to 800 Grand Concourse, a 250-apartment red-brick building diagonally across the broad boulevard from the Bronx County Courthouse, bespeaks an archetypal New York cooperative.

title: SENATE WEIGHS VOTING RIGHTS AND PAST WRONGS
description: In California last week, Hispanic candidates won the Democratic nomination in two Congressional districts that were drawn to favor their election. In Mississippi, a three-judge Federal panel imposed a redistricting plan that creates a Congressional seat with a black majority. In New York City, the Justice Department approved a district map for the City Council that could boost minority districts from nine seats to 12.

title: EGYPT'S LEADERS GROPE FOR LEBANON SOLUTION
description: As criticism increased here of what is considered a dilatory and pro-Israeli response by the United States, President Hosni Mubarak spent the morning with his top aides discussing how they might best press for a rapid and total Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: Page's Thumb Broken in 2d
description: Greg Page broke his right thumb in the second round of his 10-round fight against Trevor Berbick Friday night on the Larry Holmes-Gerry Cooney undercard.

title: A Shot Hits Police Car; Officer Is Hurt by Glass
description: A man suspected of robbery and homicide fired at least two shots at a police car in Brooklyn last night, the police said. An officer inside was cut on the hand by flying glass when a window shattered.

title: No Headline
description: June 6: Israeli Army invades southern Lebanon by land, sea and air, besieging Tyre, Beaufort Castle, Nabatiye and Kawkaba. Jets and gunboats bombard Sidon. June 7: Israeli tanks and infantry capture Beaufort Castle and overrun guerrilla outposts in Nabatiye and Hasbeya. Israelis begin sweep northward toward Palestinian-controlled towns and villages just south of Beirut, and their jets clash with Syrian planes over suburbs of Beirut, shooting down one. Ground fighting breaks out between Syrian troops and Israeli armored units around town of Jezzin. Israeli forces enter Sidon, establish beachhead at Zahrani and clash with Palestinian guerrillas at Tyre. June 8: Israeli tank columns and infantry units push as far as 32 miles into Lebanon, driving toward Beirut in two directions. One column reaches Baruk, another advances toward Saadiyat and Damur. Israeli forces also clash with Palestinians at Sidon and Tyre. Israel says its planes downed 6 Syrian MIG's. Israeli jets bomb a former Beirut sports complex used by the P.L.O. as training ground and arms depot as well as Damur, Saadiyat and Khalde. June 9: Israel says its jets destroyed 19 Syrian surface-to-air missile systems in the Bekaa Valley and downed 22 Syrian MIG's during air battle that accompanied raid. Syria claims to have shot down 19 Israeli jets. Israeli forces seize control of Damur and Sidon. Israeli and Syrian ground forces clash in mountains southeast of Beirut and in the lower Bekaa Valley. Israeli amphibious forces establish a bridgehead at Khalde, 4 miles south of Beirut.

title: ETHICAL-ISSUES CLASSES IN PERIL
description: FOUR years ago, a course called ''Ethical Issues in Decision Making'' was taught to a group of 30 students at Mamaroneck High School. Since then, 12 teachers from the county have received training in the ethical-issues curriculum at summer institutes at Harvard University's Center for Moral Education, and more than 700 students have taken ethical-issues classes at five high schools in the county.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Protecting ElephantsBy the time ''The Last Roundup of the Elephants'' is broadcast Wednesday at 8 P.M. on CBS, Dieter Plage, the cinematographer, armed with his silent, 16-millimeter Arriflex camera and an assortment of zoom lenses, and accompanied by his wife, a still photographer, and an assistant, will be in Indonesia. He explained last week in an interview from London that he will be off in that part of the world ''looking for the Java rhino, the world's rarest mammal - there are only between 35 and 50 left.''

title: Iran Rejects Iraq's Call For Cease-fire
description: Iraq, apparently near defeat in its war with Iran and faced with Iranian demands for massive reparations and punishment of the ''aggressors,'' volunteered to stop shooting last week if its neighbor would join it in supporting Syria against Israel. Iran found it an offer easy to refuse, even before the shaky cease-fire between Syria and Israel.

title: HIGHS AND LOWS OF THE STRAW HAT TRAIL
description: The Tonys have been awarded, the end-of season curtain has been rung down on Broadway and, as evidenced by the diverse listing elsewhere in this section, theatrical activity is shifting to the many stages that make up the summer circuit. Except for Katharine Cornell and the Lunts, virtually every major American stage star has appeared at some time in summer stock. Even Katharine Hepburn apprenticed there. Why do top stars subject themselves to the rigors of the road? Sometimes, though less frequently these days, there is the opportunity to try out a new play. Or, a summer stock production may hold out the lure of a long-cherished but elusive role. In addition, performers who have found a durable vehicle know that summer theater audiences tend to welcome the tried and true.

title: EVOLUTION OF THE NEW WOMAN IN THE SUBURBS
description: RHYTHMS. Years ago, you could feel them on the suburban streets, divine the hours of the day without consulting a clock from the sounds heard in the cool, leafy neighborhoods.

title: WOMEN AND SCIENCE FICTION
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Grace Dermody writes as if abortion did not exist before the equal rights amendment. Time magazine reported in the 30's that illegal abortions were estimated to number at least one million a year; an accurate figure could not be obtained because of its illegality. It is not feminists who are preoccupied with abortion. Abortion isn't even mentioned in the amendment and, contrary to what Mrs. Dermody said, defeat of the amendment would not put a stop to abortion.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: Bruehl. (Yale University Press, $25.) A biography of the German-born philosopher and social critic.

title: Around the World; Poland Lifts Curfew In a Northern Port City
description: Polish authorities have lifted the overnight curfew in the northern port of Szczecin, imposed after street clashes between security forces and supporters of the suspended Solidarity labor union May 3, the state radio said today. An overnight curfew is still in force in Warsaw.

title: Tanaka's Turn Is Coming Up
description: The law drew a slightly tighter circle around former Japanese Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka last week with the conviction of two former government officials in the Lockheed payoff scandal.

title: FARE AND DECOR, CALIFORNIA STYLE
description: WESTPORT WESTPORT has been called ''Beverly Hills East,'' and now, with the opening of a new restaurant, Tanglewoods, it seems the California style is here in full force.

title: BRITISH SAY BATTLE FOR STANLEY IS ON
description: British forces launched an assault Friday night against Argentine troops at Stanley, their last major stronghold in the Falkland Islands, and advanced five miles before dawn today, Defense Secretary John Nott announced.

title: Feroline Perkins Burrage, Researcher, Is Wed to T.L. Higginson Jr., Lawyer
description: Feroline Perkins Burrage, a picture researcher with Time-Life Books Inc., in Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Thomas Lee Higginson Jr., an associate in the New York law firm of White & Case in Washington. The Rev. Prentice Kinser 3d performed the ceremony at the St. James Protestant Episcopal Church in Warrenton, Va.

title: A WINNING LOOK AT LOSERS IN 'GIN GAME'
description: EAST FARMINGDALE ''THE GIN GAME,'' the 1977 Pulitzer Prize-winning play, is winding up a much delayed, oft-postponed Long Island premiere engagement today. A couple of local theaters had it on their schedules last season. One realized it didn't have the rights; the other didn't have the right cast.

title: AVANT GARDE: JOHNSON
description: One hears a good deal about post-Minimalism these days, but Tom Johnson is one composer who has stayed loyal to the austerity of Minimalism yet managed to keep it fresh; fresher than ever, in fact, to judge from the program of mostly new material that he presented Thursday evening at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation.

title: Postings; JERSEY BANK SINKING ITS ROOTS
description: Like a family that is constantly outgrowing its quarters, United Jersey Banks has moved around a lot since it started in 1970 in the United Bank Building in Hackensack. It moved first to Princeton, then to rented space in Princeton Junction, then to leased space in the Princeton-Forrestal Center on Route 1.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Rejects Quotas For New Orleans Police
description: A Federal district judge has rejected a quota system for promotions in the city's Police Department, but he said he would approve other portions of a settlement in a racial discrimination case.

title: William Ketcham Weds Renee Amory
description: Renee Elisabeth Amory, bookings editor of Vogue magazine in New York, was married yesterday to William Parker Ketcham, a senior product manager of Pepsico Inc., in Purchase, N.Y. The Rev. Edwin H. Cromey performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title: CHUCK FAIRBANKS: MAN ON THE MOVE
description: CHUCK FAIRBANKS is the president, part owner and head coach of the N ew York team in the new United States Football League. He may be, asc ritics say, interested in football success at the expense of f inancial responsibility, academics, loyalty and much more. Or he mayb e, as he says, a victim of his success and the misunderstandings of o thers.

title: SEnate Approves Agent Protection
description: The Government's intelligence-gathering agencies have long maintained that something had to be done about those who set out to deliberately blow an undercover operative's cover. Last week, the agencies were but a single signature away from getting the protection they say they need.

title: Crises Crowd The Agenda
description: President Reagan's advisers planned his European trip partly as a respite from domestic unpleasantness in the economy and Congress. But in nine crowded days abroad, the international scene turned out to be taxing, too, and Mr. Reagan's return to Washington last week was brightened by word that the House had finally approved a Republican budget. He conferred with Western leaders on economic and alliance concerns and explained to Europeans, via television, his policies on bolstering defense while pursuing arms control negotiations with the Russians.

title: BILLS SEEK TO MARK CAR PARTS AS A MEANS TO REDUCE THEFTS
description: The House Subcommittee on Consumer Protection has endorsed legislation intended to dampen the thriving automobile theft industry by curtailing traffic in stolen parts.

title: NOTES: ROCK COMES TO THE AID OF ART
description: This Thursday at 10 P.M. there will be benefit concert for PASS, which is an acronym for the Public Access Synthesizer Studio, a worthy organization that since 1977 has provided equipment and technical assistance to composers interested in working in electronic music but who lack the requisite funds or expertise.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Ann Mackay, Soprano, Sings German, English
description: Ann Mackay, who made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night, is an English soprano - a very, very English soprano. In other words, she fulfills stereotypes both positive and negative about present-day British art-song and opera singers.

title: Prospects
description: The Budget Impasse (II)

title: Gorky Works in Newark
description: Two murals painted by Ashile Gorky on the walls of Newark Airport in the 1930's and 40's and now part of the permanent collection at the Newark Museum are on view at the museum through Sept. 27. The murals were part of a series of 10 completed by Gorky under the Works Project Administration; the other panels were lost during later construction work.

title: DEXTER TROT TO MYSTIC PARK
description: Six trotters with Swedish connections made a mighty effort to capture the Dexter Cup at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, but it was an American with a ''secret weapon'' who jogged Mystic Park into the winner's circle.

title: BERKELEY ATTEMPTS TO DETOUR COMMERCIALISM
description: Berkeley voters have approved of a commercial rent control measure that would protect shopkeepers in one of the city's oldest neighborhoods from increases that have been as high as 600 percent a year.

title: SHE ISN'T THE SAME WOMAN NOW
description: RHYTHMS. Years ago, you could feel them on the suburban streets, divine the hours of the day without consulting a clock from the sounds heard in the cool, leafy neighborhoods.

title: IN DEFENSE OF THE MALIGNED CROW
description: Like Rodney Dangerfield, crows just don't get no respect. Yet, despite their nasty habits, they deserve at least some. Unfortunately for them, their name is often used in a derogatory sense. For example:

title: Miami Wins Title, 9-3, With Six Runs in Fifth
description: Phil Lane hit his third home run of the College World Series tonight as Miami defeated Wichita State, 9-3, and won the division 1 baseball championship.

title: CORRECTION
description: A vote tally last Sunday incorrectly reported the date on which the House of Representatives passed a confer- ence report that would impose penal- ties for making public the identities of American spies. The measure passed June 3.

title: WASHINGTON: IT'S TIME FOR REALLY HARD BARGAINING
description: President Reagan has now put three sweeping and dramatic arms control proposals to the Soviet Union - on long-range nuclear missiles, on medium range missiles in Europe and on conventional forces in Central Europe. The birthing of each was long and painful. A number of senior officials in the Reagan Administration still feel very uncomfortable about such negotiations with Moscow.

title: No Headline
description: The problems of the United States are tremendous. We deal poorly with violence and crime, shortages of housing and energy, illegal immigration and the demands of special groups whose wishes are often an outrage to society: Guns, tobacco, gambling, drugs, chemicals and a plethora of various religious moral positions.

title: ON LITERARY CELEBRITY
description: D.M. Thomas is an English poet and novelist. By D.M. Thomas

title: GERRY TSAI BUILDS HIS DREAMHOUSE
description: IN the go-go years of the 1960's, the days of soaring stocks and rampant market fever, there was no bigger name on Wall Street than Gerald Tsai, the Shanghai-born stock picker who dazzled investors by doubling their money in one year's time. All good things come to an end, however, and they did for Mr. Tsai in 1968, when the five mutual funds he managed - the most noted was the Manhattan Fund - entered a bear market. Their values plunged and so, correspondingly, did Mr. Tsai's reputation for financial wizardry.

title: POP-SOUL: SMOKEY ROBINSON
description: Although Smokey Robinson, the great pop-soul tenor, is in his 40's, the matinee idol's reception at the Radio City Music Hall Thursday had an adolescent fervor to it. And this enthusiasm was more than justified by a remarkable performance in which Mr. Robinson took requests from the audience and delivered a seemingly impromptu retrospective of his greatest hits from the last 20 years.

title: FOR ISRAEL, VICTORY IS ONLY THE FIRST STEP
description: JERUSALEM Israel is a country of short wars. Its smallness, its intimacy, its ''people's army'' of musicians, teachers, farmers and auto mechanics, cannot withstand the gradual erosion of a prolonged conflict. The economy slows and dies; morale withers. For when the call comes, as it did last week, men leave their fields and desks, their construction sites, classrooms, stores and families.

title: DO SQUIRRELS OFFER SOCIAL INSIGHT?
description: ''Would you like to meet my pet flying squirrel, Rocky?'' asked Prof. Jacalyn Giacalone Willis. Rocky, however, (named after the character in the popular children's show ''Rocky and Bullwinkle'') was not the least interested in meeting anyone. A nocturnal animal, he was fast asleep at 4 P.M., nestled inside a pair of cut-off jeans fastened to his cage. (''He likes to think they're tree trunks,'' Dr. Willis explained.)

title: Future Events Dance Is the Ploy
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. One of Their Own June 16 - Leading maritime executives, their wives and guests will gather in the ballroom at Windows on the World to honor Charles I. Hiltzheimer, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Sea-Land Industries Investments Inc., the maritime division of R.J. Reynolds Industries. Sixth annual benefit dinner sponsored by the Maritime Friends of the Seamen's Church Institute will be followed by a cabaret and dancing. Proceeds will go to the 147-year-old institute's services to merchant seafarers of all nations. Tickets, $150.

title: FROM A BUSINESS VIEW, MARCH HAD BIG IMPACT
description: It was hardly business as usual for businesses yesterday in midtown Manhattan, which was choked with demonstrators seeking an end to the nuclear arms race.

title: Susan Brown Married To John H. Colehower
description: Susan Jane Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Brown of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to John Harris Colehower, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Harris Colehower of Merion, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: DISABLED TO SHOW ART WORK
description: PETER SCHNEIDER composed an original piece for the piano and named it ''Down by the Beach'' because the melody reminded him of being near water. Sandra Harris, his music teacher at the Rosemary Kennedy Center in Wantagh, videotaped him playing the piece and has entered it in the art exhibition that will be held at the school this week.

title: 300-ACRE TRACT MADE NATURE PRESERVE
description: THERE is a place at East Haddam where eagles nest, bob-cats hunt and northern pike spawn. It has a 90-acre freshwater pond connected by two small channels to the Connecticut River, which flows 12 miles downstream to join Long Island Sound.

title: JAPAN STRUGGLING WITH ITSELF
description: THE term ''the Japanese challenge'' has become a modern incantation, a phrase that instantly elicits admiration and fear in the West. Its mention summons images of devastation and layoffs in such American industries as autos and steel, and the looming Japanese threat to the high-technology industries of the future, such as computers, semiconductors and bioengineering.

title: MOSCOW SAYS PRESIDENT ESPOUSED 'BRISTLING ANTI-COMMUNISM'
description: The Soviet Union today assailed President Reagan's tour of Western Europe as an exercise in ''bristling anti-Communism'' and an attempt to draw Europeans into a campaign for American military superiority.

title: New Cathedral School Head
description: The Cathedral School of St. John the Divine in Manhattan has named a new headmaster, Richard K. Ackerly. Mr. Ackerly, 37 years old, was formerly headmaster of Notre Dame de Sion School in Kansas City, Mo. He graduated from Williams College, has a master's degree in education from Harvard University and recently completed a year of study at the Graduate Theological Union in Berkeley. The Cathedral School is a private, coeducational day school for students of all faiths.

title: Andrea Henk and David Randolph Corbin Married
description: Andrea Henk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund F. Henk of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to David Randolph Corbin, son of Natalie Corbin of Westport, Conn., and Howard J. Corbin of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. William A. Eddy Jr. of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., performed the ceremony at St. Bede's Chapel at the Daycroft School in Greenwich, Conn.

title: EXPLORING INNER AND OUTER SPACE WITH STEVEN SPIELBERG
description: ''Children's literature in America,'' says ''The Oxford Companion to American Literature,'' ''first consisted of aids to piety, seemingly addressed to miniature adults.'' Among the earliest such works, the companion cites John Cotton's ''Milk for Babes, Drawn out of the Breasts of Both Testaments,'' published in 1633.

title: THE WAY IT USED TO BE
description: My uncle who worked used to support his wife, two daughters, his brother, his sister and her two growing children on $30 a week. This was in 1934 when the dollar was stronger, but the memory comes back every time I go to dinner in a medium-swell New York restaurant where the going price for a feed this season is $30 a plate. When four of us dined out the other night and the waiter presented the bill for $120 my first impulse was to call the cops.

title: YALE'S ARCHITECTURE: A WALKING TOUR
description: PAUL GOLDBERGER, the architecture critic of The Times, graduated from Yale. By PAUL GOLDBERGER

title: THE SCANDAL IS FADING BUT WON'T BE FORGOTTEN
description: Ten years ago this Thursday, a guard making his rounds in the Watergate office building in Washington, D.C., discovered a door lock that had been taped open. Burglars were apprehended in the offices of the Democratic National Committee and, before the ensuing investigation had run its course, an extraordinary maze of other political crimes and conspiracies was uncovered, President Nixon was forced to resign and many of his closest aides went to prison.

title: France Ousts Italian Suspect
description: France today expelled Francesco Piperno, who is suspected of belonging to the Italian Red Brigades guerrilla organization, sending him back to Montreal only hours after his arrival in Paris, the airport police said. Canadian courts recently turned down an Italian extradition request for Mr. Piperno.

title: ROBERT VICKERY: SKIRTING THE EDGE
description: AT the Museum of Art, Science and Industry in Bridgeport through June 27 is a retrospective exhibition of the work of Robert Vickrey. The show is sponsored by the Fairfield Chamber of Commerce, which in the past has shown the work of artists such as Robert Motherwell and Willem de Kooning.

title: FOR REAGAN, NO SUCH THING AS OTHER PEOPLE'S WARS
description: BONN For weeks, Reagan Administration Middle East experts had been bracing for an Israeli invasion of Lebanon aimed at crippling the Palestine Liberation Organization and driving it out of the zone just north of the Israeli border. But the actual strike could hardly have come at a more inopportune moment for President Reagan. Israel's lightning military advances overshadowed his grand tour of Europe, serving as a reminder that the superpowers may busy themselves with arming for big wars and negotiating to make them less likely, only to learn once again that it is the small wars that ensnarl them and jeopardize their interests.

title: MCENROE, CONNORS REACH GRASS FINAL
description: John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors gained the final of the Stella Artois grass tennis tournament at the Queen's Club today, the big tuneup for Wimbledon.

title: A BATTLE AHEAD FOR BROWN
description: Though they went mostly according to script, some of last week's state primary elections for six governerships and four Senate seats raised key questions about the finale in November.

title: ALTERNATIVE PATHS TO ADOPTION
description: Richard, 30 years old, and Margie, 28, a Manhattan couple who have been married for six years, are unable to have a child. They have even tried fertility drugs, but to no avail.

title: Jazz and Tap Session
description: An afternoon of jazz music and tap dancing is scheduled today at 2:30 at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

title: On Bensonhurst
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO TRANSLATE THE HYPE IN REAL ESTATE ADS
