description: "EVERY hair in place,'' read the newspaper ad, describing a house for sale on Long Island. This tonsorial allusion and other effusions elsewhere show that people will say just about anything when they are trying to unload a bit of real estate.

title: U.S. ASKS COURT TO TELL TOWN TO AID LOW-INCOME HOUSING
description: The Justice Department recommended today that a Federal court expand its order requiring the affluent Detroit suburb of Birmingham, Mich., to aid potential developers of lowincome housing.

title: GENEROUS LOVE
description: It seems to me that there are two kinds of love in contemporary fiction. One is generous in its impulse; the lovers reach out and embrace the world too. The other kind turns in jealously on itself, almost as if love were an antisocial act, a seceding from the environment. Because the second kind is more common, I'd rather examine the first - especially since I've just read a brilliant example of it in Shirley Hazzard's ''The Evening of the Holiday,'' a short novel published in 1965 and recently issued in paperback.

title: HOW TO REPAIR OR REPLACE A TORN WINDOW SCREEN
description: A WINDOW screen with a hole or tear in it is almost as bad as having no screen at all. Every time you open the window to let a breeze in, a horde of uninvited mosquitoes and flies come in with it.

title: DESIGN
description: STREETWISE AND SPARSELY FURNISHED On the edge of a less-than-elegant Los Angeles neighborhood, an architect has hidden a new house behind a dilapidated, graffitistrewn facade. From the street (left) the only clue to the house's existence is a discreet, gated door, but from the courtyard (above) the structure is evidently brand new. Both inside and out, the decorative focal point is a concrete fireplace surrounded by frosted glass (above and right) and its mantel topped with a slab of unpolished onyx.

title: SOME RIVERS POLLUTED
description: EVEN in towns with relatively minor damage from last weekend's flooding, many rivers and streams were left dangerously polluted, according to Dr. Douglas S. Lloyd, State Commissioner of Health Services, who advised not swimming in them.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT CONTROL FAULTED
description: An official of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission says that a license to operate will not be issued to the Zimmer nuclear power plant in southwestern Ohio until the commission is sure the plant can operate properly. The plant has been plagued by continuing reports of shoddy construction work.

title: NOW'S ITS TIME TO ENJOY GARDEN-FRESH PEAS AND BEANS
description: PEAS and green beans are at their best in early summer. These days they are good enough to eat on their own as well as being an accompaniment to meat, chicken or fish. And they are in the markets in abundance - not only string beans and fresh peas but also sugar snap peas, brilliant snow peas, exotic yellow or purple string beans, fresh fava beans nestling in furry linings in oversized pods and even skinny haricots verts, imported from France and sold at an exhorbitant price.

title: A SPECTRUM OF HUMANITY REPRESENTED AT THE RALLY
description: It was a kaleidoscope of humanity - young people and old, rich and poor, the famous, the forgotten and countless thousands in between. They spoke in Western twangs and Southern drawls, in the accents of Appalachia, New England, New York and the Middle West, as well as in the tongues of Asia, Europe and Latin America.

title: HOW TO ENJOY CANOEING NEW JERSEY'S WATERS
description: From the shallow, sluggish rivers of the Pine Barrens to the exciting white waters of the Delaware, New Jersey offers a rich variety of opportunities for canoeists.

title: WOMEN AND SCIENCE FICTION
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAQ SAYS IT IS KEEPING CEASE-FIRE WITH IRAN
description: Iraq said today that it was maintaining its unilateral cease-fire with Iran despite daily artillery fire from Iranian forces.

title: 'THE BEGGAR'S OPERA': LIVELY AT THE AGE OF 250
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Traubner writes frequently on operetta and musical comedy. BY RICHARD TRAUBNER

title: AN ISLAND GUIDE
description: Getting to Martha's Vineyard takes at least 45 minutes by boat, and to some people that's a major inconvenience. But lovers of the island will tell you the trip wouldn't be worthwhile if it were easy. The centuries-old maxim still applies: Martha's Vineyard is nice to go to because it's hard to get to. Otherwise it might have been spoiled long ago.

title: A 3-HITTER FOR ANGELS' FORSCH
description: Ken Forsch pitched a three-hitter to lead the California Angels to a 3-0 victory over the Chicago White Sox today. Doug DeCinces hit a two-run single with the bases loaded in the sixth.

title: B'nai B'rith Names New Chief For Anti-Defamation League
description: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith has chosen Kenneth J. Bialkin as its new national chairman. Mr. Bialkin, 52 years old, is a a senior partner in the law firm of Willke, Farr & Gallagher. He is also a member of the board of directors of New York State's Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: FRESH AIR FUND LETS CITY CHILD SAMPLE RURAL LIFE
description: One day last summer Kellie Nickolas, then 8 years old, became homesick for her family in Harlem. She was spending two weeks with a family in a small town in Pennsylvania on her first trip away from home.

title: Bloustein Analysis Is Called Lacking
description: The article about Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, president of Rutgers, the State University, on May 30 highlights a flaw in a current approach to an important problem in education.

title: WHEN A VAGABOND ARTIST BREAKS THE AMERICAN MOLD
description: Some writers and artists are remembered for their personalities or the movements they joined as much as for their works. Looking, say, at America's Nobel laureates in literature, Pearl Buck and William Faulkner were, while Saul Bellow, Isaac Bashevis Singer and Czeslaw Milosz are, comparatively private figures. Sinclair Lewis, Eugene O'Neill, John Steinbeck and Ernest Hemingway were more public presences.

title: BRAVES WIN 5TH STRAIGHT
description: Glenn Hubbard drove in four runs today to help the Atlanta Braves beat the San Francisco Giants, 10-5, for their fifth straight victory.

title: SUCCESS, FAILURE
description: CHURCHILL Young Man in a Hurry 1874-1915. By Ted Morgan. Illustrated. 607 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.50.

title: BARANELLO 'NEUTRAL' FOR KOCH
description: ADEMOCRATIC county chairman who is expected to lead his followers and a state chairman who is expected to be neutral in intraparty contests, Dominic J. Baranello has resolved this dilemma by quietly working with Mayor Koch's camp while publicly maintaining his neutrality.

title: ZOE CALDWELL SEES GOOD, BAD ON TONYS
description: With her third Tony Award in tow, Zoe Caldwell took off for her home in Pound Ridge last Sunday night saying that she felt, by turns, ''tickled'' because she had won the season's outstanding actress accolade and enraged by what she called the ''depersonalized and inhuman'' nature of the awards presentations. Miss Caldwell won a Tony Award for her performance as ''Medea.''

title: FEW DISRUPTIONS AS 5,000 POLICE MONITOR PROTEST
description: Circling in their helicopters, watching the city's vital signs from special command posts and lining the avenues that were filled with demonstrators, 5,000 New York City police officers -the largest such contingent ever assembled to patrol a single event - presided over a rally yesterday that was as smooth as it was large.

title: Spanish Party Chief Resigns
description: Spain's waning Communist Party is split and one faction wants to restore the firm grasp of Moscow discipline. Last week, Santiago Carrillo, a leading exponent of Eurocommunist independence that has included open criticism of Soviet interference in Poland, Afghanistan and elsewhere, resigned as secretary general.

title: PIANO: HYMAN AND KELLWAY
description: A year ago, Dick Hyman and Roger Kellaway were brought together by Gil Wiest, the owner of Michael's Pub, to play there as a piano duo, setting a precedent for several two-piano teams that has followed them at the West 55th Street restaurant since then. None of the others matched the suave, inventive skill with which Mr. Hyman and Mr. Kellaway worked together, and now that original team is back until next Saturday, performing, if anything, with even more interresponsive imagination than before.

title: AVOIDING THE BIG BANG
description: ''Death Before Dishonor'' was the motto of several military f ormations during the Civil War - on both sides. It may be the motto o f the 82d Airborne Division right now. A motto like that made a c ertain amount of sense, I suppose, when military death was what h appened to the soldier on the right or the left of you - or in fronto f you - or in back of you. But military death now can easily mean t he death of everything, including the blue-footed boobies of the G alapagos Islands.

title: R. S. Bookman to Wed Meira Rosenberg July 4
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Rosenberg of Easton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Meira Rosenberg, to Robert Stuart Bookman son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bookman of Brooklyn. A July 4 wedding is planned.

title: Moira McNamara Becomes Bride Of Lance F. James
description: Moira Patricia McNamara, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. McNamara Jr., of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Lance Fitzgerald James, son of Richard E. James of San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, and Marion Fitzgerald James of Tucson, Ariz. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Darien by the Rev. William C. McInnes, former president of Fairfield University.

title: Jump Riders Thrive Near City
description: Where do Grand Prix show jumping riders come from? With its venerable equestrian traditions and opportunities, Virginia and Pennsylvania foxhunting country would seem the most likely place. The New York metropolitan area would not.

title: INNOVATIVE BUILDINGS WIN AWARDS
description: FIVE modernistic and very diversified buildings on Long Island have been recognized for their design excellence by the Long Island chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

title: BALLET: BALANCHINE RESTAGES STRAVINSKY'S 'FLOOD'
description: George Balanchine's new production of Igor Stravinsky's musical allegory, ''The Flood'' will be repeated this afternoon and this evening as part of the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Centennial Celebration and it is a serio-delight.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART As of Thursday there can be seen at the Museum of Modern Art an exhibition of prints and illustrated books in celebration of the 25th anniversary of Universal Limited Art Editions, the print workshop on Long Island that was founded by Tatyana Grosman and is still directed by her.

title: ARABS LEAVE P.L.O. TO FIGHT ALONE FOR SURVIVAL
description: When the invasion came, it was all that Lebanon expected - and more. Since mid-December, the Lebanese and the dwindling cluster of foreign journalists and diplomats in Beirut, along with the Palestinian guerrillas strung out in bases to the south, had been living in a permanent state of jitters, expecting an Israeli strike any day. Any move would be massive, the feeling went, a blow to crush the slowly mounting military power of the guerrillas.

title: THE WEEK THAT WAS
description: This was supposed to be the week when the leaders of the industrial world would meet in the palaces and castles of Europe to proclaim the virtues of reconciliation and peace, but we couldn't hear them because of the bombs.

title: Betsey Carpenter a Bride
description: Betsey Anne Carpenter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Elliott Carpenter of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Gary Robert Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn B. Morris of New Wilmington, Pa. The ceremony was performed at the Wilton Congregational Church by the Rev. Zdenek F. Bednar, assisted by the Rev. Harold E. Burns, a retired Methodist minister and the bridegroom's grandfather.

title: TIPS FOR VISITORS
description: DICK MACKAY is the author of ''Nantucket! Nantucket! Nantucket! An Insider's Guide'' (Sankaty Head Press). By DICK MACKAY

title: TWO SUSPECTS SEIZED IN CHASE
description: A Rutherford, N.J., police officer was shot and slightly wounded yesterday during an automobile chase from Allendale to North Bergen that ended with the arrest of two youths, the police said.

title: Military Analysis
description: The British forces outside Stanley followed the military textbooks in launching their first but probably not their only attack on the Argentine garrison.

title:
MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
Marc Silberger Plays Mozart Violin Sonata
description: Town Hall's ''Dollar Debut'' program, a weekly matinee series that began in April, presented a recital Tuesday by Marc Silberger, a Baltimore-born violinist, as its final offering of the season. The program, which marked Mr. Silberger's New York recital debut, consisted of sonatas by Mozart and Beethoven on its first half, and Stravinsky's ''Suite Italienne'' and Sarasate's ''Zigeunerweisen'' on its second.

title: WORLD CUP: PRESSURES OF PLAYING FOR YOUR COUNTRY
description: The World Cup tournament begins today in Barcelona, Spain. The interest of an estimated 1.5 billion people will be focused upon the 24 teams competing in Spain from now through July 11.

title: 'FAMILY' HONORS HOME-BIRTH DOCTOR
description: BASS RIVER TOWNSHIP ''SHE never does anything nice for herself,'' one woman said, and so Dr. Mary Slifer's patients organized a picnic for her last weekend at Lake Absegami in Bass River State Forest. From Elana Cox, who was one week old, to 13-year-old Lynn Comis, with scores in between, the children came with their parents to honor the Tuckerton physician on her 58th birthday.

title: Ray Thomas Munger, Ann Lansing Silk Wed
description: Ann Lansing Silk, daughter of Mrs. Lawrence Frederick Bentley of Chatham, Mass., and C. Hugh P. Silk of Englewood, Colo., was married yesterday to Ray Thomas Munger, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Pattee Munger of Far Hills, N.J. The Rev. George A. Kyle of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J., performed the ceremony in the garden of the Munger home in Far Hills.

title: The Korchnois' Move
description: When Soviet chess grandmaster Viktor Korchnoi made a surprise move to Switzerland six years ago, his wife remained back on square one in Russia.

title: A ROLLS IS A ROLLS IS...
description: You need not be rich to belong the Rolls-Royce Owners Club, according to Edgar Eaton, the chairman of the Atlantic region of the international organization. ''It's a hobby - it can be cheaper than owning a boat,'' he said. ''Many middle-income people buy them in poor condition for a few thousand dollars and restore them.''

title: HIDDEN TREASURES; Action, Not Abortion
description: A Topic last Friday referred to the Chicago-based Pro-Life Abortion League. Our apologies: it's the Pro-Life Action League.

title: TOURING THE MOHAWK TRAIL
description: ELLEN PERLEY FRANK is a writer living in Greenfield, Mass. BY ELLEN PERLEY FRANK

title:
CAMERA;
PICTURE-TAKING POINTERS FOR WEDDING GUESTS
description: Fred W. Rosen and George Schaub are freelance writers and photographers.

title: Denise O'Toole Is a Bride
description: Denise Marie O'Toole, daughter of Mrs. John J. O'Toole of Elizabeth, N.J., and the late Mr. O'Toole, was married yesterday in the Reformed Church of Bronxville, N.Y., to James J. Mulhearn. The Rev. George W. Easton performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James J. Mulhearn of Brooklyn.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I will be traveling to Japan this fall with a seven-monthold baby. Can you tell me what this country offers - or does not offer - in the way of food and supplies for children of that age? Also, what emergency medical facilities are there for visitors? - S.E.C., New York. Answer:A spokesman for the Japan National Tourist Organization suggests that you bring as much of the baby's supplies as you can handle since you should expect to pay perhaps three times as much in Japan as in the United States for familiar brands of formula, food and disposable diapers.

title: The Talk of Miami
description: A man killed a boy in a quarrel over a hedge this week. The police said it was hot, and these things happen when it's hot. A sergeant in homicide said people weren't sleeping well, and a shift commander said the heat made people excited and agitated. Anyway, the cuttings fell on the wrong side of the hedge, and the neighbor shot the boy. Miami, a city gone begging for a kind word, is most unpleasant this time of year. It's sticky, thick with mosquitoes, and its citizenry is sore -and no wonder. If tempers were short here before the temperature rose, they have no length at all now. An accounting of the reasons would have to start with the Federal Government.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
FLAG DAY
description: Flag Day is tomorrow, and to celebrate, the Nassau Center for the Fine Arts in Roslyn Harbor is staging a Flag Day Festival today. Part of its June Arts Jubilee, the festivities get under way at 1 P.M. with an appearance by Joe Sugar's Big Bad Band, which specializes in jazz and pop. They will continue with an interpretive nature hike at 1:30 P.M. and a multimedia nature slide show at 3:30 P.M. and conclude with performances by the Great Neck Symphony at 2:30 P.M. and the Minnewaska Chamber Music Society at 4 P.M. Everything is free. The center is off Northern Boulevard.WHALE WATCHES

title: Jodi Lou Levy Married
description: Jodi Lou Levy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Levy of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Robert Edward Collins, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Collins of New Hyde Park, L.I., were married yesterday by Rabbi Albert Sturmer in the Mansion at Stouffer's Inn in Harrison, N.Y. The bride is an account executive with the Murjani Corporation in New York. Mr. Collins, professionally known as Bobby Collins, is a television and stage comedian.

title: LEARNING HOW TO LOOK AT ART
description: ''WHAT does an art museum have in common with Yankee Stadium?'' asked Margret-Ellen Fein of the fourth graders she was visiting on behalf of the Yale Center for British Art.

title: Kissinger Case Closed
description: Confronted with a sticky situation four months ago, Nancy Kissinger choked - but apparently not very hard.

title: Postings; For Sale: A Heritage
description: On May 21, 1983, 50 years after Walter Ladd's death, Natirar, the 494-acre country estate in New Jersey where he and his wife made their home in 1912, will be ready for its third incarnation. On that day, the Kate Macy Ladd Convalescent Home, which was named for his wife and established in their home after her death, will cease to be, pursuant to the philanthropist's will.

title: Around the World; Nazi Hunter Says Bomb Was Left by Neo-Nazis
description: Simon Wiesenthal, the hunter of fugitive Nazi war criminals, said today that he believed the bomb that exploded outside his home Friday night was left by neo-Nazis.

title: A NEW CHAPTER FOR HOCKNEY
description: David Hockney, the British (and sometime California) artist known primarily for his paintings, has made photographs since 1964, but to my knowledge no one has yet suggested that he abandon the canvas for the darkroom. Early on, he made fuzzy instant pictures that he used as guides for acrylic figure studies and portraits; by the second half of the 70's his skill and confidence had perked up to the point that he produced an edition of small, colorful photographic prints depicting swimming pools, swimming-pool furniture and the like. On one hand these pictures were as unassuming and intimate as common snapshots; on the other they were restatements of Hockney's major work in other mediums. In either case, they seemed of peripheral importance to Hockney's career, in which representation has been a primary issue, not a given.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're thinking of our babies. There are no Communist babies; there are no capitalist babies.

title: Central Park Gala
description: When Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel held their free reunion concert in Central Park last Sept. 19, the promoters said the affair would benefit New York City's parks. They expected to raise $50,000 for this purpose through the sale of T-shirts and posters.

title: Martha Ross Is Bride Of James Thomas 4th
description: Martha Ross and James Talbert Thomas 4th, who are lawyers, were married yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Episopal Church. The Rev. Thomas Bowers performed the ceremony.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A STROLL THROUGH THE CLINTON OF OLD
description: CLINTON There will be a tour of some fine old homes and historic sites here next Sunday. Billed as ''An Old-Fashioned Walk,'' the tour includes:

title: Perrault Heads the Field In Hollywood Gold Cup
description: Perrault, the highweight at 127 pounds, and Erins Isle, winner of the Californian, provide the trainer Charlie Whittingham with two of the favorites among eight scheduled to go to the post Sunday in the $500,000 Hollywood Gold Cup.

title: Helene Hare Has Nuptials
description: Helene Louise Hare, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A.D. Hare of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Barry Morton Rose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Rose Jr., of Pinehurst, N.C. The Rev. Ross Baxter performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon A.T. Heath, friends of the bride's family.

title: WESTERN GOVERNORS JOIN BATTLE OVER EXTRADITIONS
description: In a modern-day version of get-out-oftown-before-sundown frontier justice, a verbal battle has erupted between South Dakota and California over the extradition of suspected criminals.

title: House Finally Passes Budget Plan
description: The House passed a budget for the year beginning Oct. 1 that calls for big increases in military spending at the expense of social programs. The plan, which now goes to a House-Senate conference committee, calls for a deficit of $99.3 million. The vote, breaking a long stalement, was a victory for President Reagan.

title: 2 Bodies Found in Car Trunks
description: The bodies of two men have been found in the trunks of cars abandoned at two locations in Manhattan, the police said yesterday.

title: Doberman Named Best
description: A sleek, compactly built Doberman Pinscher today was named best of 1,838 dogs at the 50th show of the Greenwich Kennel Club on the grounds of the State University of New York campus here. She was Tiffany's Gwynlln of Amulet and it was her first top award. She is owned by Carol and Bill Nock and Diane Downey.

title: TELEVISION
description: Video's Future Nam June Paik, known as the father of video art, does things with television sets that Sony never thought of. And Channel 13, in a seven-week tribute, presents Mr. Paik's ''Guadalcanal Requiem Revised,'' with Charlotte Moorman, the avant-garde cellist and a regular fixture in Mr. Paik's works.

title: Suzanne M. Hand To Become Bride
description: Mrs. Robert Fulton Kurtz of Prides Crossing, Mass., and John Hand of Manchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Morrow Hand, to David Dalton Collins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Francis Collins of West Dennis, Mass.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Gentleman in the Arts This past November at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C., 16 opera stars gathered in recital to pay tribute to George London. The two-hour film of that event, ''An Opera Gala: A Salute to George London,'' will be broadcast on Channel 13 on Wednesday at 8 P.M. The program includes biographical documentary and performance footage of Mr. London as well.

title: HAROLD S. LEVY
description: Harold S. Levy, vice president and general counsel of the New York Telephone Company, died Thursday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Mr. Levy, who was a resident of Livingston, N.J., was 49 years old.

title: THE STORM STILL LINGERS OVER CONNECTICUT'S DAMS
description: It was raining hard, but Louis Nosal, the Chief Clerk at the United States Post Office in Higganum, felt prepared. ''We had moved everything about three feet above the floor late Saturday night,'' he said. By the next day, however, six feet of water had come and gone, firemen had rescued many residents by boat and workers were drying out first-class mail between layers of newspapers and paper towels.

title: RIGHTS CASE OF YOUTH COUNSELOR TAKES 5 YEARS
description: Arnold Jeffreys has been waiting more than five years for a ruling from New York City's Commission on Human Rights on his complaint that the city discriminated against him when it transferred him from one municipal job to another in 1977.

title: SHOW HAILS ARTISTS OF THE ROSES
description: A lifelong passion for plants inspired Pierre-Joseph Redoute, the foremost botanical illustrator of the late 18th and early 19th centuries in France.

title: FEAR WON'T DRIVE DISARMAMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: FORAYS INTO SOUND AND VIDEOTAPE
description: An art show that can be played on a turntable: that's the catchphrase for ''Revolutions Per Minute,'' a two-record album of 21 ''original sound works'' by artists who exhibit at Ronald Feldman Fine Arts, Inc., 31 Mercer Street. Though the punny title has a political ring, not to worry. The most revolutionary aspect of the disks is - well, that they spin. But the artists themselves, released from visual imperatives, give us quite an earful: they talk, chant, sing, act, ruminate, tell stories, play roles and coax sounds from offbeat instruments, each in a separate segment.

title: THINKING ABOUT NUCLEAR MORALITY
description: Herman Kahn is the director of the Hudson Institute and author of ''The Coming Boom: Economic, Political, Social,'' soon to be published. This article was written with the assistance of Carol Kahn, a consultant to the Hudson Institute. The two writers are not related. By Herman Kahn A new debate has begun over whether the United States should publicly pledge never to be the first to use nuclear weapons in an international confrontation. Opponents of this ''no-first-use'' position argue that it is foolish to give our adversaries such military or strategic assurances. They point to the fact that both the Soviet Union and China endorsed no-first-use a long time ago, and caution that American strategic planners cannot and should not necessarily accept that pledge as sincere. Were the United States to endorse no-first-use - and mean it - we would then clearly be at a disadvantage.

title: Headliners Citizen Spielberg's Purchase
description: Film director Stephen Spielberg, who has created many a plot peg, went and bought one last week.

title: Missouri Bond Issue Passes
description: Missouri voters have passed a $600 million construction bond issue that Gov. Christopher S. Bond views as a mandate to spur economic development and create jobs. Less than 17 percent of the state's 2.7 million registered voters went to the polls Tuesday as heavy thunderstorms rolled across the state. With all but one of the state's 3,329 precincts unofficially reporting, the measure was approved, 226,569 to 216,506.

title: FOUR FORMS OF LIGHT EXPLORED IN A DELIGHTFUL SHOW
description: EAST ISLIP HOW often do we consider the fact that light is an essential ingredient in the visual arts? Light acting upon pigment creates the colors that we see in all paintings, and sculpture is accented and modeled by the action of light and shadow on its surfaces.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: YONKERS THE topic was block watching, and James Bubbico, a lieutenant with the Yonkers Police Department whose colorful clothing and assured manner give him the air of a Las Vegas entertainer, was addressing the audience:

title: 'I WANTED TO WORK IN CONSTRUCTION'
description: ''THE initial reaction,'' said Susan Chipouras of East Williston, ''is that I'm either the foreman's girl-friend or that I'm somebody's secretary.''

title: Dr. Cuomo Plans To Be Married
description: Announcement has been made by Lieut. Gov. and Mrs. Mario M. Cuomo of Holliswood, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Margaret Cuomo, to Peter Robert Perpignano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Perpignano of Bayside, Queens.

title: Yale Eight Beats Harvard by 4 Lengths
description: Yale's varsity crew trounced Harvard by four lengths in their annual race over a four-mile course on the Thames River today. The eight oarsmen did the work, but special accolades went to John Scheffield, the coxswain, who managed to keep the Yale boat on course in darkness over the final mile.

title: Karen L. Ramsay, Brooks Clark Wed
description: Karen Lee Ramsay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Stirling Ramsay of Vienna, Va., was married yesterday to Nathaniel Brooks Clark, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Bayard Stockton Clark of Washington and Harwich Port, Mass. The ceremony in the Bethlehem Chapel of the Washington Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS.

title: THE VIRTUE OF BEING CHEESY
description: Two of our favorite lines about cheese come from Robert Louis Stevenson, who wrote in ''Treasure Island,'' ''Many's the long night I've dreamed of cheese - toasted mostly,'' and from Clifton Fadiman, who observed in an essay that cheese is ''milk's leap toward immortality.''

title: COOKING, STEAM AND THE GLORIOUS FOURTH; Setting Sail In Connecticut
description: Evoking New England's seafaring heritage, the ports of call are places like Block Island, Nantucket, Martha's Vineyard and Newport. The ports of embarkation are Haddam and Mystic. And the ships? Everything from the motor vessels Independence and America to the packet schooner Voyager, built in the style of the 19th century, and the Mystic Whaler, a replica of the schooners that once sailed the world's whaling waters.

title: MORATORIUM PLAN ON THE EAST END GAINS SUPPORT
description: PROPOSED moratoriums to halt new housing subdivisions on watershed land are under discussion in two East End towns, while in East Hampton the Town Board has unanimously approved a 90-day moratorium on subdivision plans for 10,000 watershed acres.

title: Gas Station Attendant Is Slain In Queens, and 4 Are Arrested
description: A gasoline station attendant was stabbed to death with a butcher knife during an attempted robbery early yesterday in Queens, the police said. They said four suspects were arrested in the case.

title: POP:HOLLY NEAR'S SONGS
description: Holly Near, one of the leaders of the women's music movement, has a captivating personality and a warm sense of humor. And Thursday at the Bottom Line, where she appeared for two sold-out shows, Miss Near and her devoted cult sustained a uniquely intimate rapport.

title: MONDANOCK TOUR
description: HANK NICHOLS has worked for three New Hampshire newspapers BY HANK NICHOLS

title: 11 Food Outlets in New York Fail Health Dept. Inspection
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday released the names of 11 food establishments found in violation of the city's health code. The department also listed three restaurants that had reopened after correcting violations and two that were closed for failure to do so.

title: Index; International
description: Chad's new rulers try to censor reports by foreign journalists 3 U.N. agency lowers world population estimates for year 2000 4 Around the World 5 Western European finance ministers meet to realign currencies 6 Egypt, vexed by Lebanon invasion, sends two aides to U.S. 8 Iraq says it is keeping cease-fire despite Iranian shelling 10 Turkey and the Soviet Union may open their border 11 U.S. worked behind the scenes for the Israeli-P.L.O. cease-fire 12 Soviet harshly criticizes Reagan's tour of Europe 18 Excerpts from Pope's final comments in Argentina 28 Government/Politics F.T.C. is urged to scrap rules on food ads 23 California G.O.P. nominee Governor has conservative record 35 It was difficult to muster votes for taxes in Albany 46 Western governors join battle over extraditions 68 General American group takes new approach to Mt. Everest 7 James Earl Ray struggles for freedom 20 Opposition growing to proposed rule changes on nursing homes 22 Around the Nation 30 The talk of Miami: Summer brings hot tempers, hot issues 30 The unemployed walk California in search of work 30 A call for public television to resist lure of advertising 31 Psychiatrist says Hinckley had a sense of reality 32 A spectrum of humanity represented at disarmament rally 42 Rally speakers emphasize cost of nuclear arms race 43 Son held in murder of his mother and four children in Bronx 46 Industry/Labor Union leaders resisting tide of concessions granted by labor 29 Religion Methodists seek to save a church 17 Baptists prepare for stormy convention in New Orleans 62 Arts/Entertainment Tom Johnson offers experimental composition ''Counting'' 69 Main library show celebrates ''The Rembrandt of Roses'' 70 Engelbert Humperdinck, crooner, at Carnegie Hall 70 Leinsdorf and Ax join Philhar- monic's series 70 Dick Hyman and Roger Kellaway back at Michael's Pub 70 Bill T. Jones dance company offers ''Social Intercourse' 70 The debuts of young musicians are reviewed 72 Smokey Robinson, pop-soul tenor, gives a recital 72 Style Italian-American women link up 73 A new bear fact 73 Features/Notes Man in the News: Ariel Sharon, new laurels for Israeli warrior 12 About New York 43

title: SAVORING LOBSTER ON MAINE'S COAST
description: SHERRY MARKER is a writer who lives in Northampton, Mass. BY SHERRY MARKER

title: USES FOUND FOR TEACHER DATA
description: Every year, the Division of Research, Planning and Evaluation of the state's Department of Education offers an insight into teachers and teaching by way of survey responses to questions covering age, sex, race, degrees, experience and turnover.

title: METHODISTS SEEK TO SAVE A CHURCH
description: Each of the nation's 9.6 million Methodists is being asked to donate $1 to save a dilapidated but elegant church that is the cradle of the faith in the United States.

title: NURSING HOME PLAN DRAWS OPPOSITION
description: The Reagan Administration's effort to change the rules for inspections of nursing homes is facing growing opposition.

title: EXCERPTS FROM POPE'S HOMILY AND HIS FAREWELL
description: Following are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's homily at an open air mass here today, and his farewell remarks at the airport, as translated by the Argentine Roman Catholic Church from the Spanish: From the Homily

title: 14 Die in Philippine Battle
description: Twelve Communist rebels and two Government soldiers were killed in a two-hour battle in the mountainous northern Philippines, the military said today. A spokesman said the battle took place Thursday in Mountain Province, about 175 miles north of Manila, when an army patrol spotted about 50 people believed to be members of the Communist New People's Army.

title: Victims' Kin Traps Suspect
description: A man whose teen-age nieces had been raped saw a suspect near the French Quarter, offered him a lift and drove him directly to jail, the police said. Joseph Henry Nelson, 37 years old, was charged with aggravated rape and aggravated burglary. The name of the uncle was withheld by the police because it would identify the girls, ages 15 and 17, who were raped at gunpoint in their home June 5.

title: SYRIANS FELT WAR WAS TOO PERILOUS, ENVOYS SAY
description: The most compelling reason behind Syria's decision on Friday to observe a cease-fire in Lebanon, according to Western diplomats, was President Hafez al-Assad's unwillingness to risk an Israeli attack on his country.

title: POPE TAKES PRAYERS FOR PEACE TO ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES POPE John Paul II brought his prayers for peace in the Falkland Islands to Argentina last week, on a mission that was described as pastoral but could not help being largely political.

title: DID FRANZ LISZT COMPOSE THIS CONCERT?
description: ''What? ...A ballet? ...Balanchine!'' Cyprien Katsaris exclaimed, drawing back from the table with a gesture of helplessness. A pained look spread across the face of this French-born pianist of Greek-Cypriot descent.

title: CONVICTED KILLER OF DR. KING WANTS A HEARING
description: James Earl Ray, pale and slightly paunchy, nourishes his hope of getting out of prison and of going to a small town where no one knows him. He wants to live out his life in peace and anonymity.

title: MADE BY HAND IN VERMONT
description: RUTH ROBINSON is a reporter for the Style section of The Times. BY RUTH ROBINSON

title: Linda June Levine Fiancee of Mark Morgenstern
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Levine of Valley Stream, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Linda June Levine, to Mark Jay Morgenstern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour D. Morgenstern of San Diego. An August wedding is planned.

title: JULIA CHILD'S BOSTON CHOICES
description: T rue to the spirit of New England, Julia Child casts her gastronomic favor on the bounty of the sea. When it comes to dining out, Mrs. Child, the cook, food writer and television personality, who has made her home in Cambridge, Mass., since 1960, enjoys fresh seafood, simply prepared. And when it comes to seafood, she need not travel far to satisfy her taste.

title: AT PEBBLE BEACH, FINESSE AND POSITION TAKE OVER
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. THE United States Open returns this week to the Pebble Beach Golf Links, the picturesque seaside course that is both an American golfing tradition and the only public course ever to be host to an Open.

title: JAZZ PIANO: RED GARLAND
description: Since Red Garland, the Texas pianist who rose to fame 25 years ago in the Miles Davis Quintet, started making occasional visits to New York from his home in Dallas three years ago, he has usually come by himself. However, for a weeklong engagement at Lush Life, Thompson and Bleecker Streets, that ended last night, he brought with him for the first time Marshall Ivery, a tenor saxophonist with whom he usually works in Dallas.

title: PROPOSED HAWAII ROAD CALLED PERIL TO DRIVERS
description: In the latest skirmish in a long battle to prevent the construction of a superhighway through the mountains of the island of Hawaii, foes of the project have asserted that the road could be lethal for motorists.

title: NANTUCKET: SUFFICIENT UNTO ITSELF
description: RUSSELL BAKER is a columnist for The New York Times. BY RUSSELL BAKER

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: IN CHAD, MOVES TO CURB FOREIGN PRESS
description: The new authorities in Chad today introduced regulations designed to let them censor reports by foreign journalists.

title: RUTHERFORD
description: MATT AND TOM SHANNON were sitting in a fast-food outlet on Meadow R oad talking with their uncle about growing up in Rutherford. ''There's a lot of sports,'' Matt said, ''but to tell you the t ruth, if it weren't for athletics, there wouldn't be much for kids t o do.''

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: The county's criticisms of the response plans for radiation emergencies at Indian Point center largely on transportation problems during an evacuation. County Executive Alfred B. DelBello made the critiques public when he asked the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission to establish a 120-day ''regulatory clock,'' requiring utilities to make the plan workable or face the closing of the Indian Point nuclear plants.

title: No Headline
description: The headline ''How Militant Feminists Are Killing the E.R.A.'' was not pertinent to the content of the article, which devoted itself to the evils of abortion and did not deal accurately and factually with the amendment. Rather, the author sneakily spilled a few smudgy sentences about the amendment before launching into her real theme. If I understood her murky prose, if the amendment passes, there will be no more live births; everyone - men and women - will run right out and stand in line to be aborted.

title: Women and Science Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: HERE COME THE DANES, BEARING BOURNONVILLE
description: ''Not all Danes are melancholy,'' the newspaper headline proclaimed hopefully over photographs of leaping Danish dancers. It was 1956 and a week before the first visit to the United States of the full Royal Danish Ballet, which had just begun to be recognized as a major world ballet company after over 200 years of existence. A sleeping princess of a rare and delicate beauty had been kissed awake by the attention of international audiences in 1950. Would she be vapid with age or prattle on, a little ill-temperedly, in some dialect unfamiliar to Americans?

title: THE NEW WOMAN OF THE SUBURBS
description: RHYTHMS. Years ago, you could feel them on the suburban streets, divine the hours of the day without consulting a clock from the sounds heard in the cool, leafy neighborhoods.

title: U.S. Seeks to Deport an Alien Accused of Nazi Unit Service
description: The Justice Department has filed a request for deportation of a man who is accused of concealing his service in a German SS unit in Nazi concentration camps in World War II.

title: For Snail Darters And the Like, 3 Years of Peace
description: With its reauthorization up for Congressional review and industry pushing to restrict its scope, the Endangered Species Act has itself seemed endangered. No longer.

title: ISRAEL AND P.L.O. AGREE TO START CEASE-FIRE AFTER DAY OF EXTENSIVE BOMBING IN BEIRUT
description: A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said tonight that as of 9 P.M. Israeli forces in Lebanon would cease firing at the Palestinians in the Beirut area. The announcement came after a day of bombing and shelling in the city and clashes with the guerrillas.

title: Ann Broadus Is a Bride
description: Anne Elizabeth Broadus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Carlisle Broadus of New York, was married yesterday to Hunter Holding Jr., son of Mrs. Holding of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Holding. The Rev. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Planning for Protest Was a Group Effort
description: The rally and march yesterday were planned by a steering committee of 13 organizations, ranging from such religious groups as the Ministerial Interfaith Association and the Riverside Church Disarmament Program to newly formed coalitions of minority groups. Established groups of peace activists such as Mobilization for Survival and SANE were also on the steering committee.

title: FIRST AMONG FIRST LADIES
description: LOVE, ELEANOR Eleanor Roosevelt and Her Friends. By Joseph P. Lash. Foreword by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. Illustrated. 534 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $19.95. MOTHER & DAUGHTER The Letters of Eleanor and Anna Roosevelt. Edited by Bernard Asbell. 366 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $17.95.

title: No Headline
description: The article ''Tapping the Homosexual Market'' by Karen Stabiner (May 2) overstated the figure for the over-18 population of the United States, and thus in turn overstated the estimate of this country's homosexual population. The correct 1980 census figure for those over 18 is 162,751,000. The correct estimate of the homosexual population is 8 to 10 million.

title: Hsueh-wei Wang Is Married to Corey S. Whitman
description: Hsueh-wei Wang and Corey S. Whitman were married yesterday in the Harvard University Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Paul S. Koumrian, an Episcopal priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: The Worst Possible Novel

title: A SELLER'S GUIDE TO LURING HOME BUYERS
description: THERE are some house-hunters who can overlook layers of grime and z ebra-stripe wall paper and see the charm and warmth of a home u nderneath. But most people confronted with such cosmetic flaws will g et out of a house as quickly as they can without insulting the o wner.

title: Business Conditions; OFFICE DEMAND SAGS
description: New, nonresidential construction has declined for some time, but the weakening demand for the office space gained during the latest up cycle has been slow to show itself. That is beginning to change.

title: PSYCHOLOGICAL TIME BOMBS
description: In Cherokee County, N.C., residents learned this month that their rising cancer rates may be related to exposure to Agent White, a herbicide that had been sprayed in the region years earlier. Their fears were similar to those of Vietnam veterans who in the 1960's were exposed to Agent Orange - a defoliant associated with cancer, genetic damage and other serious health problems.

title: San Francisco
description: To the Editor: As a fourth-generation San Franciscan, I was happy to read the articles on ''The Small Worlds of San Francisco'' (Travel, May 23). And while I realize that everything about the city cannot be incorporated in any one article, I was dismayed that no mention was made of the Palace Hotel's lavish dining room.

title: Trouble at the Tap
description: Speaking of threatened species, Americans who use small-scale water systems don't have much to cheer about, according to a five-year study by Cornell University researchers released last week. From a statistical sample of 2,645 households, the researchers calculated that 63 percent of rural Americans, nearly 39 million people, drink water that could be unsafe.

title: AID FOR PARENTS OF DISABLED
description: For every 1,000 babies born in the county, about 10 have a serious mental or physical handicap. Until recently, there was little organized support for the parents of these newborns, but a new county-financed program has been established to help them with emotional concerns, to refer them to parent-support groups and to provide information about agencies that offer services they need.

title: SPREAD OF WILDFLOWER SAID TO PERIL PLANTS IN THE NORTHEAST'S WETLANDS
description: One of the most beautiful flowers of the summer, purple loosestrife, is spreading so fast that it is endangering the flora and fauna of wetlands in upstate New York and other parts of the Northeast, according to a Cornell University botanist.

title: The White House vs. Children's Health
description: About two million poor children whose parents cannot afford medical checkups for them benefit from a Federal adjunct of Medicaid known as the Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis and Treatment Program. Last year, apparently believing such a service is better left to states, the Administration tried to eliminate it legislatively. Rebuffed by Congress, the White House is now trying a flank attack by deregulators.

title:
In New Jersey;
CONDOS PUTTING CHIPS ON ATLANTIC CITY
description: HAVING experienced for the last four years the joys - and, at t imes, distress - brought about by the advent of gambling, Atlantic C ity is now undergoing its second wave of development with an e mphasis on housing.

title: U.S. ARMS NEGOTIATOR SAYS HE EXPECTS PACT
description: The chief American arms negotiator, Edward L. Rowny, says optimistically that agreement on deep cuts in both American and Soviet nuclear weapons are ''eminently achievable,'' if not guaranteed, by the end of President Reagan's current term.

title: THE NEW PITCH
description: The series of speeches President Reagan made during his European trip and the documents he endorsed at two summits have given a new pitch to American foreign policy.

title: SPINKS STOPS CELESTINE IN 8TH
description: Michael Spinks, after a workmanlike but unspectacular seven rounds, knocked out Jerry Celestine with a right uppercut today and retained the World Boxing Association's lightheavyweight championship.

title: F.T.C. URGED TO DROP PROPOSED RULES ON FOOD ADS
description: Senior staff members of the Federal Trade Commission appointed by the Reagan Administration said today that they would soon advise the agency to reverse a 1980 decision to set standards on the kinds of food that could be advertised as ''natural.''

title: NOW'S THE TIME TO ENJOY GARDEN-FRESH PEAS AND BEANS
description: PEAS and green beans are at their best in early summer. These days they are good enough to eat on their own as well as being an accompaniment to meat, chicken or fish. And they are in the markets in abundance - not only string beans and fresh peas but also sugar snap peas, brilliant snow peas, exotic yellow or purple string beans, fresh fava beans nestling in furry linings in oversized pods and even skinny haricots verts, imported from France and sold at an exhorbitant price.

title: ACTION IN DISASTERS CAN MAKE OR BREAK POLITICAL FORTUNES
description: HARTFORD FOR some reason, natural disasters always seem to have political implications in Connecticut, and the deluge that flooded the state last weekend was no exception.

title: Sports People; Ownership Switch?
description: B.J. (Red) McCombs, of San Antonio, who owns 20 percent of the San Antonio Spurs, has offered to sell his stock in that National Basketball Association franchise and purchase 100 percent of the stock in the Denver Nuggets for $10 million.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JUNE 13, 1982
description: International A new cease-fire, in the Beirut area, was announced by Israel yesterday after Israeli forces had continued earlier in the day to clash with Palestinians. The announcement of the Beirut cease-fire with the Palestinians followed a cease-fire that took effect Friday between Israeli and Syrian forces elsewhere in Lebanon. Israel said it would continue fighting in the Beirut area if fired upon by the Palestinians. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Jan Alison Nadrich Bride
description: Jan Alison Nadrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Nadrich of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married yesterday to Howard Joseph Sprung, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Sprung of New York. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik, assisted by Cantor Jodi Sufrin, performed the ceremony in the Plaza Hotel. The bride is a consultant for the Clairol Corporation. Mr. Sprung is a buyer with the Abraham & Straus department stores.

title: CRIME VICTIMS EXPLORE ATTITUDES WITH INMATES
description: William Santanna, an inmate at the Westchester County Penitentiary, was trying to be helpful. ''If I see anything coming out of this,'' he said at a discussion in the jail with crime victims, ''it's to prevent more victims - lots of us have insight on how to do that.''

title: Victoria S. Lloyd-Rees Is Wed to Stephen K. Smith
description: The marriage of Victoria S. Lloyd-Rees, a sales representative with the Reynolds Metals Company in New York, to Stephen Kenneth Smith, an associate with Booz, Allen & Hamilton, the management consultants, took place yesterday in Falmouth Foreside, Me. The Rev. Stephen W. Foote performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin.

title: THRONGS FILL MANHATTAN TO PROTEST NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: Hundreds of thousands of peaceful demonstrators opposed to nuclear arms overwhelmed Central Park and midtown Manhattan yesterday, filling the streets and groves with echoing songs and hopeful slogans.

title: END OF NEWS SHOW ON CHANNEL 21 STIRS STRONG REACTION
description: THE latest news from WLIW-TV, Channel 21, is that there may be no news - or at least not the way it is currently gathered and reported. The television station, which serves Long Island viewers, is dropping its nightly news show, citing economic reasons.

title: POETRY IS WISE AND DANGEROUS, LISTEN TO IT.
description: YOU and I are considered to be generations apart not only in years but in wisdom and experience as well. Like others before me, I have the honor to finally send you out into that world with some words of advice, encouragement and warning.

title: REAGAN TRIP REPAIRED RIFTS AND SEEMED TO SOFTEN IMAGE
description: First reactions to President Reagan's hectic 10-day tour of Europe indicate that he repaired some of the rifts between his Administration and Western Europe.

title: FIVE NEW CENTERS FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS ARE OPENING IN SEPTEMBER
description: Within two weeks in September, five major structures dedicated to the performing arts will hold inaugural concerts in the United States and Canada. In the shaky state of the economy these five ambitious projects might be considered some kind of defiant cultural statement. But the sponsors unanimously say that the openings are coincidental, and that the planning was started as much as 12 years ago, when the economy was in much better condition. They also say that they would think twice about starting such a project today.

title: World Cup Opens
description: The 12th World Cup tournament will start in Spain today with one game - Argentina facing Belgium in Barcelona. The game will be televised live in the United States by the Entertainment Sports Programming Network (ESPN), and the Spanish International Network (Channel 41 in New York).

title: CASINO PANEL OPENS INQUIRY ON HOTEL UNION
description: The Casino Control Commission has broken new ground in regulation of the casino industry by opening a hearing on whether to register a casino hotel union.

title: SOMETIMES WASHINGTON CLAIMS TO KNOW BEST
description: Ronald Reagan ran for the Presidency promising to get Government off the backs of the people and, in many ways, he has been true to his word. He has tried to reduce the burden of Federal regulations and the role of Federal agencies in private industry and in private lives.

title: HIDDEN TREASURES; Noble Grit
description: If the Bronx Grit Chamber had been built recently, it probably would have looked like a building in which sewage is screened - which is to say plain. But it was built 45 years ago, and the architectural firm of McKim, Mead and White made it fancy, with a monu-mental arch and eight colossal pilasters.

title: A Filibuster? On Voting? In 1982?
description: Senator Jesse Helms promises to filibuster ''until the cows come home'' to prevent a vote on the Voting Rights Act. But the debate is over and the cows are coming home. Though he is taking days to say it, the North Carolina obstructionist has nothing new to say. Underneath it all there is an old message.

title: Oxbridge
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Little to Report
description: In a bargaining progress report from Chicago, Ed Garvey, executive director of the National Football League Players Association, and Gene Upshaw, president of the union, said that negotiators for team owners remained opposed to a players' proposal calling for 55 percent of gross revenues to go to the players. With the approach of the July 15 deadline for the end of the current collective bargaining agreement, the only positive move has been formation of a joint committee on safety, they said. The committee will study recommendations of the association for establishing qualifications of team doctors, disclosure of team doctors' findings to the players and development of a standard physical examination.

title: Kelly E. Costigan, T. E. Smith Wed
description: Kelly Ellen Costigan, daughter of Sarah Anne Friend of La Jolla, Calif., was married yesterday to Timothy E. Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elwin Earl Smith of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Luchia Ballantine performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: NEW BEAR FACT
description: Once upon a time there was a phenomenally successful series that reigned high in television land for many, many weeks. It was called ''Brideshead Revisited,'' and among the things that endeared it to so many people was Aloysius, the teddy bear who was the almost-constant companion of Sebastian Flyte, a charming but quirky young aristocrat.

title: ELDERLY TAKING ACTIVIST STANCE
description: AMONG the Island's latest activists are a group whose numbers are steadily increasing merely with the passage of time. They are the elderly, those who must cope with the problems of old age in suburban communities that were created primarily to accommodate young families.

title: Youth Dies in Avignon Brawl
description: A violent brawl between two youth gangs in the heart of this southern tourist city left a teenager stabbed to death and 15 other people seriously injured Friday night, the police said today.

title: French Ships Off to Lebanon
description: Three naval transport ships have left for Lebanon in case French nationals there need to be evacuated, the Defense Ministry said today. A ministry spokesman said the ships left the Mediterranean naval port of Toulon Friday morning.

title: T.A. Readies a Token Change
description: Subway riders who hope to save the 75-cent fare temporarily by saving 75-cent tokens are in a no-win proposition, Transit Authority president John Simpson said last week. With the prospect of fares going up to $1 or more next month, the authority began altering turnstiles to accept different tokens last week.

title: Problems With Drugs Conceded by Browns
description: The Cleveland Browns have had some problems with drug use over the years and may still, according to the team's owner and coach.

title: CRAFTS
description: KINGSTON A craft show at the Full House here embraces a bountiful assortment of ceramics, baskets, jewelry, handwoven wearables and pillows, blown-glass objects and wood boxes by 40 artisans from New Jersey and neighboring states.

title: Julie Nassau the Bride Of James Alan Brady
description: Julie Pamela Nassau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul David Nassau of New York and Stockbridge, Mass., was married in Washington yesterday to James Alan Brady, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry William Brady of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and Lavallette, N.J. The Rev. Hubert S. Beckwith, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony in the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University.

title: GREAT LAKES STATES SEEK TO KEEP THEIR WATER
description: Surrounded by water, the governments of four Middle Western states, New York and the provinces of Ontario and Quebec have worked out a series of resolutions here designed to protect their most plentiful, most valuable and possibly most endangered natural resource: fresh water.

title: SWAMP YIELDS A NEW ANTIBIOTIC
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP A small patch of swampy soil in the Pine Barrens has yielded a molecule that some researchers believe may become the basis for an entire new generation of antibiotics.

title: Daphne A. Riker, K.F. Hagan Wed
description: Daphne Ann Riker, a teacher at St. David's School in New York, was married yesterday to Kevin Frederick Hagan, an associate with the New York law firm of Burke & Burke. The Rev. John Catoir performed the ceremony in St. Peter's of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington, L.I. He was assisted by the Rev. Bruce Rodgers.

title: PURCELL'S STAGE MUSIC ON DISKS
description: The incidental music that Henry Purcell wrote for the 17th-century English stage constitutes one of the most significant areas of his work, yet for many years it never fared very well on phonograph records. Perhaps its absence resulted from a lack of satisfactory performing editions, or because the idioms in which Purcell composed are so far removed from those of our own time. Whatever the reasons, recordings - where they existed - have at best been sporadic and uneven in quality.

title: NOTEBOOK: INTEREST HIGH IN SENATE RACE
description: WASHINGTON CONNECTICUT politics is a popular topic in Washington these days. ''Everywhere you go, people ask, 'How's Toby doing?' '' said United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, Democrat of Hartford, who has a partisan interest in the candidacy of her fellow Democratic Representative, Toby Moffett, for the Senate seat now held by Lowell P. Weicker Jr. Many others are asking how Prescott Bush, the Vice President's brother, is doing in his campaign to deny Mr. Weicker the Republican nomination.

title: THE FALMOUTH TO PROVINCETOWN CANVAS
description: ALEXANDER THEROUX spends part of each year on Cape Cod; his most recent novel is ''Darconville's Cat.'' By ALEXANDER THEROUX

title: COSMOS DEFEAT ROWDIES, 2-0
description: Hubert Birkenmeier turned in a superb performance for a 10-minute stretch in the second half, and the Cosmos followed it with two goals in the last eight minutes for a 2-0 victory over the Rowdies tonight at Tampa Stadium.

title: IT'S BOB AND RAY TIME-AGAIN
description: ''Now we've come up to music time here on the old Bob and Ray Show. So, for your afternoon listening pleasure, let's swing out to the Polygon Ballroom in Larchmont for the haunting melodies of Herbie Waitkus and his orchestra ....''

title: Trudeau Visiting Macedonia
description: Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau of Canada, who is on a three-day official visit to Yugoslavia, left today on a sightseeing visit to the Lake Ochrida area in the southern republic of Macedonia.

title: Talking Co-op Arrears; DEALING WITH THE DELINQUENT
description: SOMETIMES a tenant shareholder leaves for Europe and paying the m aintenance slips his mind. Or perhaps the shareholder loses his job o r has severe family illnesses. Occasionally, a person will die and t he apartment will be tied up in an estate that will not have cash f or months. There are families that are simply juggling too many b ills, or cannot afford an assessment that a new group of affluent o wners has voted in.

title: Iranian Official Killed
description: A senior Iranian Navy official, Hojatolislam Mohammad Ali Amininejad, was shot dead Friday on a Teheran street, the national news agency Irna reported today. Hojatolislam Amininejad, head of the navy's political-ideological office, was killed by three gunmen in a car who were believed to be members of the People's Mujahedeen opposed to the clergy's rule in Iran.

title: Spill at Jersey Nuclear Plant
description: Radioactive water spilled today on a patch of ground outside the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station, officials said. Mark Budaj, speaking for the plant, said the spill was reported to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. No plant personnel were contaminated, and there were no detectable radioactive releases beyond the boundaries of the plant site, he said.

title: HIGHLIGHT OF THE SUMMER SEASON IS OFFERED AT CARAMOOR
description: Once again, summer in the county will be aglow with music of every description. But in terms of elegant ambience and programming variety, Caramoor in Katonah still remains the jewel of our festival season. Opening night is June 26 (if you can't wait that long, the yearly fund-raising dinner and concert gala is this Saturday, starting at 6:30 P.M.), with the superb young American violinist Dylana Jenson playing the Mendelssohn Concerto and Stanislaw Skrowaczewski conducting Mozart and Beethoven symphonies. The Saturday evening series in the Venetian Theater continues through July, with Michael Feldman, Julius Rudel, James Conlon and Alexander Schneider taking turns on the podium and welcoming such distinguished soloists as the soprano Elly Ameling and the pianist Rudolf Firkusny.

title: DECLINING SUPPLIES EXPECTED TO BRING HIGHER MEAT PRICES
description: With the outdoor cooking season at hand and the demand for meat rising, supplies of beef, pork and poultry have still been declining, a welcome development for livestock farmers but a harbinger of higher consumer prices for the next two months.

title: BRINGING 'TURNKEY' RADIO INTO EVERYBODY'S BACKYARD
description: WASHINGTON DICK Purtan is a celebrity in Detroit. A morning disk jockey at CKLW-AM radio, his voice is heard each week by half a million Michigan listeners. But local fame is not enough for Mr. Purtan anymore. He wants to be a national radio star -a cross-country disk jockey. And Superadio, one of a new, ambitious family of radio networks, will give Mr. Purtan his chance.

title: U.S. WORKED FOR CEASE-FIRE BETWEEN ISRAELIS AND P.L.O.
description: The United States worked intensively behind the scenes today to bring about a cease-fire between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization in Beirut, the State Department said.

title: A NEW LOOK FOR THE KIROV
description: The other day in the Paris subway, I saw two young men in blue jeans struggling over a Rubik cube. As it happened, they were members of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet en route to the same performance I was about to see during the famed Russian company's two-month season at the Palais des Congres, which concludes today.

title: Jeanne Budde Malyniak Wed to D. L. Simmons
description: Jeanne Budde Malyniak, manager of marketing communications for the fibers division of American Cyanamid Company in Wayne, N.J., was married yesterday to Desmond Leverock Simmons, vice president of construction for the Prudential Insurance Company of America in Newark. The Rev. David Hodgson performed the Methodist ceremony in the Smoke Rise Community Interdenominational Church in Kinnelon, N.J.

title: PRIMARY LEAVES SOME BIG 'IFS' FOR DEMOCRATS
description: TRENTON THERE are always ''what ifs'' in the wake of an election, and the ''what ifs'' in last Tuesday's Democratic primary for United States Senator center on Barbara Boggs Sigmund of Princeton and Andrew Maguire of Ridgewood.

title: American Population Center Officially Placed in Missouri
description: With each United States census, the population center of the United States has been moving gradually westward.

title: Q and A; Vacancy Rent Rises
description: Question:When a rent-controlled apartment becomes vacant and passes into rent stabilization, is there a fixed percentage by which the landlord is allowed to increase the rent? ... J.S., Bronx Answer: The Conciliation and Appeals Board says the owner may charge whatever he thinks is a fair market rent. However, he must notify the tenant by certified mail within 30 days of his taking occupancy of his 90-day right to petition the board to reduce the rent. If the tenant chooses not to, that rent becomes the legal starting rent for that apartment under rent stabilization.

title: FASHION
description: WHEN THE PRICE IS RIGHT The creative shopper can often find more than she bargains for. Even in this day of constantly rising costs, it is still possible to put together outfits that are both attractive and inexpensive.

title: WHEN MANAGEMENT TAKES CARE OF ITSELF
description: IN these precarious economic times, many chief executive officers a re trying to figure out whether the bottle is half-full or h alfempty. Others have already decided the issue.

title: BEIRUT IS QUIET AFTER A DAY OF HEAVY FIGHTING
description: This city and its suburbs were subjected today to a relentless series of bombings and artillery and gunfire exchanges as Israelis and Palestinian guerrillas continued to do battle.

title: FREE RUGBY TICKETS
description: As many as 500 boys and girls between the ages of 8 and 18 may be eligible for free tickets to the British-American rugby matches Saturday in Hartford, if they participate in a free rugby clinic at 11 A.M. in Colt Park. The professional games will begin at 1 P.M. across the street in Dillon Stadium.

title: SUPERCOMPUTERS CAN'T ADD QUALITY TO LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
CONTROVERSY CONTINUES OVER OLYMPIC COINS
description: Despite months of controversy it seems almost certain that United States commemorative coins will be issued and sold to help finance the 1984 Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles. Both houses of Congress have now approved bills authorizing coins for the Olympics. While the bills differ dramatically -reflecting the deep divisions over how many coins should be made and how they should be sold - some type of program seems assured. At the same time the long dispute has raised some troubling questions that are likely to linger after the Games are over.

title: SALVADOR DEPLOYS U.S.-TRAINED UNIT
description: The Salvadoran soldiers who recently completed training in the United States have taken part in their first combat operation. They conducted a search-and-destroy operation in the rugged mountainous regions of Chalatenango Province in which the army says 135 rebels were killed.

title: ADOPTION: SHOULD RECORDS BE OPENED?
description: Adoption is at least as old as the Bible. Moses, the world's most famous adoptee, was placed by his mother in a spot where Pharoah's daughter would be sure to find and take him in.

title: HE'S STILL A HERO IN HOMETOWN
description: Gerry Cooney may have lost the heavyweight title fight in Las Vegas Friday night, but for many Long Islanders here he retained the title of hometown hero.

title: LAURELS FOR ISRAELI WARRIOR
description: However divided Israeli opinion is about the politics of the Defense Minister - and no one except Prime Minister Menachem Begin splits opinon here so sharply -Ariel Sharon commands armies of admirers of his prowess as a military planner and battlefield leader.

title: THE FLOOD OF '82: WHY DID IT HAPPEN?
description: BLOOMFIELD WHILE hundreds of flood victims around the state were cleaning up after last weekend's heavy rain, the six hydrologists who man the Northeast River Forecast Center in this suburb of Hartford were busy analyzing what had happened, how it had happened and what could be done in the future to help individuals and communities better prepare for such a calamity.

title:
DINING OUT;
CHANGES AT AN INDIAN RESTAURANT
description: WE always look forward to sampling Indian cuisine, exciting with its teasingly complex flavors and mellow heat. It offers seemingly endless combinations of agreeable aromatics such as bright coriander leaves, sweet nim, sunny turmeric, cumin, sesame, cardamom, black salt, kalonji, to name a few among at least several dozen more familiar items - onions, honey, mint, garlic, nuts, citrus fruit and pickles. The intriguing names promise exotic, uncharted territories.

title: Draft Sign-Up Campaign Is On
description: Callers to Selective Service headquarters in Washington last week were informed by recorded message that, while 7.8 million eligible young men had registered for the draft, many of Uncle Sam's nephews remained unaccounted for and could face Federal prosecution.

title: WHEN THE MONEY TALKS TOO MUCH
description: IF you are like me, Marvin Miller, George Steinbrenner and David Stockman, from time to time you worry about money. Getting and spending. Provender. The price of tuition, shock absorbers, alimony and meat loaf.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME PROBLEMS OF THE SEASON IN REVIEW
description: NOW that spring is almost over, it would seem to be appropriate that we evaluate the season to date. While there was a deficiency of rainfall in early spring, and it became necessary to water lawns in areas of sandy soil, recent rainfall would seem to have more than offset the immediate moisture needs. Small ponds that were low on water a few weeks ago now seem to be bank full.

title: CHAMBER: AN EVENING OF BAROQUE
description: The only thing ''Gothic'' about the Gothic Concert by Frederick Renz, harpsichordist, and several associates on Friday night was its location: the vaulted confines of St. James Chapel in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The fare itself - chamber music for obbligato keyboard by C.P.E. Bach - was pure Enlightenment, a word that, in adjectival form, might easily have described the performers and the way they played.

title: GETTING HELP FOR A NEW ENGLAND TRIP
description: Abundant in natural beauty and American history, New England also has a wealth of information about tourism and travel. The problem is, how to single out what is best for your needs and tastes.

title: Around the World; 7 Somali Aides Arrested In a Conspiracy Plot
description: Seven high-ranking Somali officials, including a Vice President, have been arrested and charged with conspiracy in a plot involving an unspecified ''enemy country,'' the official Somali press agency reported today.

title: THE OHIO PRIMARY PROVIDES LITTLE TO CLING TO
description: Last week's Ohio primary provided few of the hoped-for clues to how the Administration is faring in middle America, but it did reinforce some basic political tenets. For example, that it still pays to campaign hard and not rely totally on television; and that, regardless of issues, many voters remain creatures of habit who will flock to a familiar face.

title: SOVIET TO BE BARRED FROM DEEP-SEA DRILLING PROJECT
description: The Soviet Union, reportedly on directions from the White House, is not being invited to continue to participate in a highly successful international deep-sea drilling project.

title: JAPANESE RITUALS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DANCE:BILL T. JONES
description: ''This looks even weirder than what's going on upstairs,'' a woman said Wednesday night as she peered into the basement Space at City Center. The Martha Graham Dance Company was performing upstairs, Bill T. Jones & Company below. And whatever Miss Graham was up to, Mr. Jones's ''Social Intercourse: Pilgrims' Progress'' was very strange.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: PLAID BEAR AND THE RUDE RABBIT GANG Written and Illustrated by P.K. Roche. Unpaged. New York: Dial. $9.95. (Ages 4 to 7) BEACH PARTY By Joanne Ryder. Illustrated by Diane Stanley. Unpaged. New York: Frederick Warne. $9.95. (Ages 4 to 7) By KATHLEEN LEVERICH

title: PUBLIC TV CHIEF CALLS FOR RESISTANCE TO ADVERTISING
description: Edward J. Pfister, president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, has urged the nation's public television stations to ''resist the lure of broadcast advertising.''

title: AMERICANS GIVE MT. EVEREST THE ONCE-AROUND
description: While mountaineers keep vying to find new ways to climb Mount Everest, a small team of Americans has pulled off an imaginative variation by becoming the first people to trek completely around the world's highest mountain.

title: The Price of Hospitality
description: With their cities already in economic straits, officials from around the country complained last week that proposed legislation granting legal status to 2.7 million illegal aliens would increase health and welfare costs and incite a taxpayers' backlash.

title: 3 DIFFERING VIEWS OF ADOPTION
description: THE view from each side of the adoption triangle - that of the adoptee, the birth parent and the adoptive parent - can be different. Barbara Cohen of Watchung, whose daughter Julie died at the age of 4 eight years ago, feels that knowing her own medical history might have saved her child. She knew nothing about it because she was an adopted child.

title: Karen Ann Greer Married To Edward Eugene Eyler
description: Karen Ann Greer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Waters Greer of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to Edward Eugene Eyler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Bartholomew Eyler of Akron, Ohio. The Rev. Constance Chandler Ward, the chaplain of Wellesley College, performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Houghton Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College.

title: LOWERING BUMPER STANDARD RAISES THE DANGER
description: To the Editor:

title: DISPUTES OVER THE HAYES AND ABERNATHY GOSPEL
description: To the Business Editor: In my opinion, capital investment is discouraged, not by business management gone wrong, not by ''discounted cash flow,'' but by the environment of chronic inflation and the high interest rates demanded by investors to protect their dollars.

title: AT THE AGE OF 2, THEY'RE STARTING TO MAKE MUSIC
description: EAST SETAUKET AT 3 P.M. today, her tiny arms barely reaching around a viola precariously poised on the stage floor, 4-year-old Asiya Tschannerl will make her debut at the Fine Arts Center of the State University at Stony Brook. Not as a soloist - she has been playing only since October. Rather, Asiya is one of 125 children from the ages of 2 to 14 who as students of the North Shore Suzuki School will perform in the school's spring concert.

title: MISS FRETWELL BECOMES BRIDE OF ROBERT SAUL
description: At the Myers Park Presbyterian Church in Charlotte, N.C., yesterday Katharine Louise Fretwell and Robert Southey Saul, 1981 graduates of Amherst College, were married by the Rev. Margaret Peery.

title: FOR JOBLESS, A NEW 'GRAPES OF WRATH'
description: On the dusty road next to the railway tracks, a dozen men and women were walking the mile from the Union Gospel Mission to the Salvation Army for a free meal. Some were walking stooped over, stirring up the dust; others were pushing supermarket carts containing all their possessions.

title: Inmate Found Hanged in Cell
description: A convicted killer whose home for the past 32 years had been the Green Haven Correctional Facility apparently hanged himself from the bars of his cell with a leather belt, the authorities said today. The body of the killer, William Jones, 51 years old, formerly of Brooklyn, was discovered at about 3:30 P.M. Friday by another inmate, Fishkill State Police said.

title: Bacon Is Improved
description: Mary Bacon, the jockey, today showed ''slow signs of recovery'' but remained semiconscious, according to a spokesman for Herrick Hospital in Berkeley. Miss Bacon received head and face injuries but had no broken bones when she tumbled from her mount during a race Wednesday.

title: About New York; EARNESTNESS AND WHIMSY IN A COLORFUL PANORAMA
description: Any public demonstration is a leap of faith, evidence of an optimistic belief that the sound of one hand clapping, given sufficient hands, will be applause, that a single human being, if there are enough of them, can make a difference.

title: FOLK FESTIVAL: A REVERENCE FOR TRADITION
description: THIS weekend, Connecticut celebrates an ethnic legacy as new as the 126 persons who were naturalized as American citizens on Friday. The mass ceremony began the 27th annual folk festival sponsored by the International Institute of Connecticut. The festival, held at Sacred Heart University on Park Avenue in Bridgeport, concludes between noon and 8 P.M. today.

title: THE ASTORS BATTLE A TV IMAGE
description: ''If you were my husband,'' Nancy Viscountess Astor once told Winston Churchill, ''I'd poison your coffee.'' ''If you were my wife,'' replied Churchill, ''I'd drink it.''

title: Social Security Gains In Its Recovery of Debts
description: The Social Security Administration, owed $2 billion by people who were overpaid, is more than 28 percent ahead of last year in debt recovery, according to agency officials, who said they also planned to try private collection agencies.

title: DISPUTES OVER THE HAYES AND ABERNATHY GOSPEL
description: To the Business Editor: While I enjoyed reading ''Management Gospel Gone Wrong'' (May 30), which attempted to deal with the subtle reasons for Japan's current industrial productivity, unfortunately it doesn't tell us anything that is not obvious. If this is the essence of revolutionary spirit at the Harvard Business School, then we really are in trouble.

title: Alicia Dickman Married
description: The marriage of Alicia Loris Dickman to Raymond Ernest Joslin took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Williams in Stockton, Calif. The Rev. James Booth, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Dickman, also of Stockman. Mr. Joslin, son of Mrs. William Landry of Providence, R.I., is a vice president of the Hearst Cable Communications Division of the Hearst Corporation and is co-chairman of the board of directors of Hearst/ABC Video Services, both in New York.

title: Teresa Galuska Married
description: Teresa Jane Galuska, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Vincent Galuska of South Plainfield, N.J., was married there yesterday to Wayne Theowald Meichner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theowald Meichner of Lindenhurst, L.I. The Rev. Matthew Sheary performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart.
