The bride is a merchandise administrator in the retail-outlet division of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation in New York. Her husband is a buyer of cosmetics with Saks Fifth Avenue in New York.

title: Gabrielle Massab Is Wed
description: Gabrielle Beder Massab, a partner of Massab Bros. Inc., importers of antiques in New York, was married yesterday to Vincent Leon Vallarino, a partner in Callaway Vallarino Editions, art-book publishers in New York. The Rev. Andrew Zbeebs of St. George's Antiochian Orthodox Christian Church in Lowell, Mass., performed the ceremony at Stonehurst Manor in North Conway, N.H. The bride is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Lian Massab of New York. Mr. Vallarino is a son of Mrs. Edith Vallarino of Conway, N.J., and the late Robert Vallarino of Austin, Tex.

title: HANGING OUT-FROM 'MARTY' TO 'DINER'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Avery Corman is the author of the novels ''Oh, God!,'' ''Kramer vs. Kramer'' and ''The Old Neighborhood.'' By AVERY CORMAN

title: Sports of the Times; A PIGMENT OF THEIR IMAGINATION
description: managers, Dennis Rappaport, began to whine that ''we want officials who are both competent and honest in our opinion'' for Friday night's World Boxing Council heavyweight championship fight with Larry Holmes.

title: PROMOTING AMERICAN MUSIC
description: SERIOUS music, many people may think, falls into the realm of the classical and is invariably derived from the Western European tradition. However, if one major Connecticut insurance corporation and a West Coast foundation have their ways, this view may soon shift -in opinion as well as in reality.

title: Business Conditions; THE RECESSION'S COST
description: As last quarter's earnings reports grimly illustrate, corporations are bearing the brunt of the current recession. As a percentage of national income, after-tax corporate profits declined to a seasonally adjusted 5 percent, a full percentage point below levels at the end of last year.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: OVER the years I had seen Jim McDonald root out his crabgrass and plant clover in Hicksville; I had seen him plant gardens in Baldwin, scrape and repaint in Freeport; he was always doing something to make his impressive variety of homes more livable for his wife, Pat, and their seven children. And all on those postage-stamp lots that are the stamp of living on the Island.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Buck Belue, quarterback of Georgia's national football champions for the 1980 season and the Southeastern Conference batting champion this season with a .447 average, has decided on a baseball career. An outfielder, he was selected by the Montreal Expos last week and signed yesterday.

title: Miss Prout, Russell Selby Are Married
description: Frances Wall Prout, an investment analyst with the Equitable Life Assurance Society in New York, was married yesterday to Russell MacLeod Selby, a first-year student at the Brooklyn Law School. The Rev. Francis J. Hamill performed the ceremony in the St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: Suits on Hyatt Regency Won't Be Class Action
description: A Federal appeals court has vacated a judge's order that suits resulting from the collapse of two skywalks at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Kansas City be combined to represent all plaintiffs as a class.

title: BILL IRWIN-A BUSY AND BUOYANT YOUNG CLOWN
description: You've simply got to leave good clowns to their own devices. There's no use making rules. Oh, you can always try to tell a clown what he should or shouldn't do. You can, if you wish, tell a nimble fool not to smile while he is being funny, because if he smiles first, the audience may not smile at all. That's why you don't see Marcel Marceau smiling very often, and why you probably never saw Buster Keaton smile at any time. And you can tell a zany wearing a dunce cap on his head and a great white ruff around his neck never, never to use his speaking voice for fear of destroying our conviction that he is really a pen-and-ink drawing on leave from a comic strip. Many a mime has played it mum from beginning to end. You can see the sort of brilliant advice you can dispense out of sheer generosity.

title: WIDESPREAD EFFECTS ARE FELT FROM POST-WATERGATE REFORM
description: The proliferation of reform laws and regulations enacted in response to the abuses of government authority exposed in the Watergate era have had a profound effect on the course of government and politics in the United States.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: POTATO growers on the East End suffered a second setback of the season when torrential rains flooded the fields last weekend. William Sanok, Suffolk County Cooperative Extension agent, said that the drenching rain and accompanying temperatures in the 60's provided ideal conditions for the spread of late blight, a fungus that could have devastating consequences for the crop. Late blight, he said, was the cause of the Irish potato famine in 1845. The fungus rots potato foliage and tubers.

title: WEIGHING ART AND RELIGION AT ST. BART'S
description: To the Editor:$

title: Bishops' Assembly to Begin
description: About 200 Roman Catholic bishops will attend a 10-day assembly starting Sunday at St. John's University in Collegeville, Minn., church officials said Friday. Bishop James W. Malone, vice president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops and the United States Catholic Conference, said the purpose was to bring the bishops together ''in prayerful and reflective atmosphere, and to consider various implications for pastoral ministry through the 1980's in the light of the Second Vatican Council.''

title: Miss Van Hanswyk to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Van Hanswyk of Camillus, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Claire Van Hanswyk, to Robert J. Hoffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Hoffman of East Williston, L.I. The prospective bride is a personnel interviewer at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. Mr. Hoffman is a postal inspector in the Washington area. His father, executive vice president of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center, is a former first deputy police commissioner of the New York Police Department.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME PROBLEMS OF THE SEASON IN REVIEW
description: NOW that spring is almost over, it would seem to be appropriate that we evaluate the season to date. While there was a deficiency of rainfall in early spring, and it became necessary to water lawns in areas of sandy soil, recent rainfall would seem to have more than offset the immediate moisture needs. Small ponds that were low on water a few weeks ago now seem to be bank full.

title: E.R.A.-Abortion Article Draws Readers' Fire
description: Grace Dermody, in her Opinion Page article of May 16, certainly mixed many issues together. I would like to clarify all, but will only discuss a few.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: MOST of the debris left by winter has been removed from New Jersey's 127 miles of ocean beaches. But where do all those charred timbers come from?

title: FURNITURE CLASSICS
description: Tubular steel furniture, synonymous with the most sophisticated European modern designs of the 1920's and 1930's, when the Bauhaus in Germany and other workshops elsewhere dominated avant-garde design thinking, has been reproduced in volume for decades. But what happened to the originals? Do some still exist and are they as desirable as the glittering reproductions which since the 1960's have become status symbols in homes and offices around the world? And are the original versions now regarded as - and collected as - antiques?

title: SEVEN YEARS AND NINE STRAWBERRIES
description: SEVEN lean years ago, I decided I wanted a strawberry patch at my East Hampton summer home. I love strawberries, dislike lawns and landscaping and enjoy growing things I can eat.

title: Controlling Deer
description: The California Department of Fish and Game and the San Francisco Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals locked horns in March 1981 on an environmental issue: how to control the growth of a wild deer herd that was sheltered from predators.

title: ROCK SONG:MARIANNE FAITHFULL
description: What a story Marianne Faithfull makes! And although it isn't over yet, one would have to say that as of her performance late Thursday night at the Ritz, the first of three evenings there, the story had, improbably enough, a happy ending. This was one of the most exciting rock performances in New York in recent years; if Miss Faithfull feels like it, she could become this generation's Lotte Lenya.

title: Mary Theresa Keepnews Is Bride of Eric S. Luskin
description: Mary Theresa Keepnews, daughter of Mrs. Lawrence William Keepnews of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late Mr. Keepnews, was married yesterday to Eric Stephen Luskin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Luskin of Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: New York NEW YORK CITY; The Light Opera of Manhattan Summer Festival Of Musical Theater Eastside Playhouse 334 E. 74th Street
description: Today, The Mikado. Wed.-June 27, Aug. 25-Sept. 5, H.M.S. Pinafore. June 30-July 11, The Merry Widow. July 14-25, The Pirates of Penzance. July 28-Aug. 8, Ruddigore. Aug. 11-22, A Night in Venice. Sept. 8-26, The Red Mill. The New York Shakespeare Festival Delacorte Theater Central Park Fri.-July 17, Don Juan. July 30-Aug. 28, A Midsummer Night's Dream. July 7-18, Ain't Misbehavin'. July 28-Aug. 8, Carousel. Aug. 18-29, Beatlemania.

title: Albany Notes; VOTE ON CITY TAX RISE WAS TEST FOR LOBBYISTS
description: A legislative leader trying to round up votes for taxes is often akin to a Marine sergeant attempting to find volunteers for a dangerous, unpleasant mission. Sometimes, volunteers must be compelled.

title: Pamela D. Pearce Is Married
description: Pamela Durkin Pearce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Thompson Pearce of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Donald Collins Carey, son of Governor Carey of New York and the late Helen Owen Carey. Msgr. Harold Murray performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church.

title: POPE, ENDING HIS TRIP, CAUTIONS AGAINST BLOCS
description: Pope John Paul II, acknowledging Latin American unity on the Falkland Islands, appealed to bishops from throughout the hemisphere today to prevent the world from dividing into blocs.

title: DISPUTES OVER THE HAYES AND ABERNATHY GOSPEL
description: To the Business Editor: At last Professors Hayes and Abernathy seem to get management to listen to simple wisdom that has long been clear to millions of their lower-level staff - the use of short-term profitability, separately for each operating division, as a performance criterion is short-sighted foolishness.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THROUGH THE PINELANDS BY BIKE AND BACKPACK
description: IT WAS not until I was 33 years old - three years ago - that I became interested in bicycling. But I've made up for lost time since then, taking to my bike for day trips and using it to commute to my job as a teacher. So far, I've put well over 2,000 miles on the odometer.

title: EXISTENTIAL SAINT
description: DOROTHY DAY A Biography. By William D. Miller. Illustrated. 527 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: Memorable Weekend
description: If you'd taken a stroll along Publishers Row during the past 10 days, you'd have seen a number of residents wearing a California tan and an unusual expression of puzzled delight. They were just back from the 82d Annual Convention of the American Booksellers Association, held in Anaheim, Calif., over Memorial Day weekend, and were still trying to understand what they'd experienced. The Grim Expectations

title: OXBRIDGE
description: To the Editor: The building at Cambridge shown in the Travel Section is not any part of Pembroke. It is the Pepys Library, in the Second Court of Magdalene College.

title: DESK SALE MARKS A SCHOOL'S DEMISE
description: DUSTED schoolday memories were on sale in Westport much of last week, many of them bargain-priced at only $1. Burr Farms School, one of the five remaining elementary schools in the town, was closed last year because of declining enrollment and was about to be demolished. And residents had been invited to go back into the building, where years ago they might have learned their times tables or even how to tie their shoelaces, and select certain items as keepsakes.

title: Postings; The City Auction
description: For those of pioneering spirit, patience and perseverance, there may be some good buys on Tuesday at the auction of 88 vacant cityowned brownstones in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island.

title: GORKY'S AIRPORT MURALS AT THE NEWARK MUSEUM
description: NEWARK One cannot help but think that the military officials who were probably responsible for the destruction or disappearance of Arshile Gorky's murals at Newark Airport during World War II would be surprised to learn that he is viewed today as one of the leading masters of modernism.

title: Outlanders Are Off the Hook
description: Their longstanding reluctance to tax the income of Connecticut residents didn't stop lawmakers in Hartford from approving a tax on commuters from New York State earlier this year. But Gov. William A. O'Neill's aversion to an income tax apparently knows no borders and last week he vetoed it.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Mary Orr and George Saterson Married
description: Mary Catherine Orr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Frank Orr of New York and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to George Michael Saterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Saterson of Ridgewood, N.J., and Irving, Tex. The Rev. Robert Collins performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE LAWYER OF LAST RESORT
description: THE BEST DEFENSE By Alan M. Dershowitz. Illustrated. 425 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95. By TOM GOLDSTEIN

title: Elizabeth Flood Married to Michael J. McNamara
description: Elizabeth Susan Flood, a graduate student in business administration at Wake Forest University, was married yesterday to Michael James McNamara, a student at Wake Forest's Bowman Gray School of Medicine. Msgr. William Capik performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at St. Colman's Roman Catholic Church in Ardmore, Pa.

title: WEST EUROPE PACE REALIGNING MONEY
description: Seven Western European finance ministers announced today that they had agreed on a realignment in the value of their currencies, including a 10 percent devaluation of the French franc against the West German mark, which is being revalued upward.

title:
Investing:;
BANKRUPT SECURITIES AS GROWTH ISSUES
description: "Bankruptcy" and "liquidation" are grisly words that produce frissons of terror in most investors. But not in 30-year-old Michael F. Price.

title: Some New Bones Of Contention
description: Africa continues to give up the remains of mankind's earliest ancestors, though arguments they cause among anthropologists may prove more durable than the bones themselves. Professors J. Desmond Clark and Tim D. White of the University of California at Berkeley announced last week the discovery in Ethiopia of skull and thigh fragments that push back the existence of bipedal ape-men to four million years ago.

title: Guilty Plea in Sex-Photo Case
description: A Levittown man admitted to photographing a 6-year-old girl in nude poses while acting as her baby sitter.

title: DRUM-BUGLE CORPS SEEKS AID
description: BAYONNE It had rained most of the day, and by 7 P.M. only a handful of spectators, wearing rain gear and clutching umbrellas, dotted the grandstands overlooking the muddy field at Veterans Memorial Stadium here.

title: Comment; CRYING WOLF OVER WORD PROCESSORS
description: O the Business Editor: Professor Bergmann has struck out with her article. She used erroneous information, and inadequate research methods to, naturally, arrive at a mistaken conclusion.

title: The Homosexual Market
description: Karen Stabiner's article ''Tapping the Homosexual Market'' (May 2) focuses on the more affluent segment of the gay market. But this segment of the market is not necessarily congruent with the out-of-thecloset gays, and certainly not with those who have fought and struggled for the application of the American Constitution to the gay community.

title: Young-Hwa Im, Bass, Offers Schumann Cycle
description: Young-Hwa Im, a bass born and educated in Korea who has also studied singing in New York, made his debut in Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday night. His program offered Schumann's ''Dichterliebe'' and arias by Mozart and Verdi.

title: CURTAIN IS RISING ON ANOTHER SEASON
description: For the state's theatrical managers, summer is when fall schedules must be solidified, casts chosen and promotional material sent to regular and prospective subscribers. It is also a time for renewed theatergoing.

title: OXBRIDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Accord on Sales Tax Is Signed By New York and Connecticut
description: Tax officials from New York State and Connecticut today signed an agreement to help both states crack down on businesses that sell goods to out-of-state residents without collecting the sales tax.

title: AT 15, SHE WILL DEFEND HER EASTERN TITLE
description: RYE ''Nice motion,'' said an assistant pro at the Rye Racquet Club as he watched Terry Phelps practice serves. ''But she should snap her wrist a little more.''

title: The 'Good' Wars And the 'Bad'
description: To the Editor:

title: Equal Rights: One Last Try
description: After last weekend's public displays in support of an equal rights amendment, including marches 10,000 strong in the capitals of Illinois, Oklahoma, North Carolina and Florida, came the political infighting last week.

title:
STAMPS;
COMMEMORATIVE FOR CIVIL WAR SURGEON
description: Mary Walker, a pioneer crusader for women's rights who served as a surgeon in the Union Army in the Civil War and was awarded a Congressional Medal Of Honor, appears on a new 20-centcommemorative from the United States. It has just been issued in Oswego, N.Y., her birthplace, and marks the 150th anniversary of her birth.

title: PLAN NOW ON WATER NEEDS
description: EXCEPT for a drought in the mid-60's, Connecticut has, in the past, been fortunate to have an abundant supply of water. But with gradual growth in population and industry, the demand for water has begun to exceed the supply, a situation which is highlighted during periods of less than average precipitation.

title: DISPUTES OVER THE HAYES AND ABERNATHY GOSPEL
description: To the Business Editor: In reference to ''Management Gospel Gone Wrong,'' I have but three words - ''It's about time.'' CHARLES MORGO

title: Schmidt Takes A Loss On His Own Turf
description: While West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt had his sights set on the Versailles summit last week, his political base cracked beneath him. Voters in his home town of Hamburg dealt the Chancellor and the Social Democrats their worst defeat there since World War II.

title: MAYORS GATHER TO TALK OF TAXES AND TROUBLES
description: Ronald Canestrari and Mario Villa were among the more sought-after men at the four-day meeting of state mayors and municipal officials, which ended here today.

title: SHAPIRO PLANNING A FALL RETURN
description: NEWARK A jubilant Peter Shapiro, fresh from an overwhelming victory over two rivals for the Democratic nomination for Essex County Executive, is planning a door-to-door campaign like the one that brought him victory in last Tuesday's primary.

title: PHILHARMONIC: LEINSDORF CONDUCTS
description: Thursday's edition of the New York Philharmonic's Mozart-Stravinsky series featured Erich Leinsdorf conducting the Stravinsky Symphony in C and two works by Mozart - the G minor Symphony, No. 40, and the D minor Piano Concerto (K.466).

title: Pakistani Chief in Hospital
description: Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, has been cured of a kidney ailment but advised to take a few days rest at the hospital to which he was admitted Thursday, an official spokesman said today. General Zia, 58 years old, went to the hospital a day after returning from Saudi Arabia, where he attended meetings of an Islamic committee trying to mediate in the Iran-Iraq war.

title: NORTH TARRYTOWN MAYOR IN THE LIMELIGHT
description: year-old son, Phillip, and 1-year-old son, Robert, sat off in the corner of the dining room at Grossingers Hotel, seemingly outside the events that swirled around the more than 500 people attending the yearly meeting of the New York Conference of Mayors and other municipal officials. But the tableau of aloofness was misleading, because Mr. Zegarelli had been thrust into the middle of the organization and its activities last week when he was elected second vice president.

title: Virginia
description: To the Editor: As a transplanted Virginian, I am compelled to take issue with your correspondent Maurice Carroll with regard to his reference to the Virginian pronunciation of the word house (''hoose'') in the article ''Bed and Breakfast in Jefferson Country,'' (Travel, May 23).

title: RELUCTANT HISTORY
description: THE CHARIOT OF ISRAEL Britain, America and the State of Israel. By Harold Wilson. Illustrated. 406 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $24.95.

title: SOCIALIST ALLIANCE SWEPT INTO OFFICE IN MAURITIUS VOTE
description: The party that has ruled this Indian Ocean island democracy since independence 14 years ago was routed so completely in elections today that it was left with not a single seat in Parliament.

title: Casualties Are Hard to Determine
description: A combination of chaos and military censorship has made it difficult to obtain precise information on the casualties in the Lebanese fighting.

title: Other Business; RULES OF THUMB FOR BUDGET FORECASTING
description: WASHINGTON Last year, the Administration predicted a balanced Federal budget by 1984. There was even to be a small surplus. Now, however, the Administration's projection for 1984 has changed radically. Instead of a slight surplus, there is to be a deficit of $216 billion.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: class house in a small Vermont town, Sally Sweetsir ends yet another argument with her abusive second husband by accidentally yet fatally stabbing him with a carving knife. The trial that follows and the events in Sally's life that led up to it are the burden of a novel that - in the words of Rosellen Brown - ''does a rare and difficult thing, lets us hear a real anguished voice in the act of self-discovery.''

title: TO THE DICKENS AND OTHER AUTHORS BY WAY OF CASSETTE
description: Paul Kresh is a contributing editor of Stereo Review and is writing a book about the spoken word on records for Prentice-Hall. By PAUL KRESH

title: Sports People; Honoring Satchel
description: With Monte Irvin representing Commisssioner Bowie Kuhn's office, baseball dignataries gathered in Kansas City yesterday for the funeral of Leroy (Satchel) Paige, the legendary pitching star of the Negro leagues and a member of the Hall of Fame, who died last Tuesday. One of those in town was Rene Lachemann, one of Paige's last major league teammates when Paige was brought back to the Kansas City A's by Charles O. Finley, at the age of 59 in 1965.

title: MANY TOURS BEGIN IN WESTPORT
description: TWO entrepreneurs in the travel field, Lars Eric Lindblad and Arthur Tauck Jr., share the northwest corner of the Post Road and Wilton Road in Westport. Their office buildings are at right angles and sometimes they look out of their office windows and wave. Mr. Lindblad time-shares Mr. Tauck's computer reservation services. Once they even had lunch together.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Late last month, Robert Melly of Wayne got himself into the record books, but it cost him $225. The 38-year-old Mr. Melly, an unemployed carpenter, jumped from the top of the Great Falls in Paterson and lived to tell about it, thus making him the first person to do so since ''Leaping Sam'' Patch took the plunge in 1828.

title: LABOR IS RESISTING MORE CONCESSIONS
description: An effort is under way to create a national movement to resist the concessions on wages, benefits and work rules that are being widely made by American labor unions.

title: FIVE THEATERS ADDED TO 42D ST. REVIVAL PLAN
description: Five once-famous legitimate theaters, the only holdouts in the proposed $1 billion redevelopment of 42d Street announced in April, have now been included in the plan.

title:
ART;
A LOOK AT THE CAREER OF PAUL CADMUS
description: YONKERS Through July 11, the Hudson River Museum will be showing the first major retrospective exhibition devoted to the work of Paul Cadmus. At one time extremely well known, the artist has been little regarded of late, and this traveling exhibition affords the first chance ever to see his career as a whole.

title: Enrique Hernandez Jr.  Weds Megan McLeod
description: Megan Beth McLeod, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. McLeod of Huntington, Conn., was married there yesterday to Enrique Hernandez Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hernandez of San Marino, Calif. The Rev. Joseph M. Fitzgerald performed the ceremony in St. Lawrence Roman Catholic Church.

title:
Other Business;
FROM CHICAGO, SOUL ON ICE
description: CHICAGO They laughed at Charles Birdseye when he thought of freezing foods and they laughed at William K. Kellogg when he tried to market a ready-to-eat cereal made of rolled and flaked corn kernels. Now they're snickering at Kenneth Hennings and Fletcher Smith, who have put hog maws, chitterlings, greens and pot-likker gravy into the freezers of hundreds of Middle Western supermarkets.

title: Around the World; 6 Untouchables in India Die as Huts Are Burned
description: A mob of upper-caste Hindus set fire to 100 huts in a community of untouchables in southern Tamil Nadu state, burning six villagers to death before the authorities quelled the violence, the police said today.

title: RUSSIAN SAYS U.S. FASCINATES K.G.B.'S CHIEF
description: A former Soviet diplomat who defected to the United States in 1971 says that Yuri V. Andropov, who is regarded as a possible successor to Leonid I. Brezhnev, has long been fascinated by the United States and has more than a casual understanding of its culture and its political realities.

title: Reagan and the Neo-Conservatives
description: Norman Podhoretz's neo-conservative anguish seems to amount to this: He wants the United States to recover its economic strength but appears bored by the details of planning for that goal (''The Neo-Conservative Anguish Over Reagan's Foreign Policy,'' May 2).

title: MRS. REAGAN'S EUROPEAN TRIP: FLAWLESS PRECISION WITHOUT VISIBLE THAWING
description: It was, with few exceptions, a low-key Nancy Reagan who traveled with the President on his just-completed 10-day European trip. She went through a carefully planned program with flawless precision but no visible thawing of her innate reserve. There was throughout a demonstration of rote good manners and a lack of spontaneity other than in West Berlin, where she made an impulsive dash to hug the Secret Service agent who saved the President's life last year during the assassination attempt, and at a Paris reception, where she reached for and held the hand of the widow of Col. Charles Ray, who was slain by terrorists in January.

title: NEW HOUSING STIRS HOPE AND ANXIETY
description: JERSEY CITY In the shadow of City Hall on Montgomery Street, in the heart of Jersey City, the signs of large-scale construction are everywhere. Legions of planners, architects, carpenters and other buildingtrades employees have spent the last three years transforming four blocks of a blighted urban neighborhood into a highly desirable mixed housing complex known as the Montgomery Gateway Renewal Project.

title: SAXOPHONE: 2 GROUPS SHOW THE HORN'S RANGE
description: New York has seen something of a saxophone onslaught this week, or more properly an onslaught of Adolphe Sax's mellow hybrids turned to classical usages. Sax himself conceived his instrument for classical and band contexts, and had no way of envisaging the extent to which jazz would co-opt his creation. But all along the sax has survived as a concert and band instrument, mostly in colleges away from the coasts, and in saxophone quartets modeled after the Paris Saxophone Quartet, which did so much to inspire composers' interest in the instrument between the world wars.

title: SOME SOUTH FLORIDA DOCTORS THREATEN STRIKE
description: The surgical staffs of at least five hospitals in southern Florida have voted to stop performing all nonemergency surgery beginning Tuesday as a protest against high premiums for medical malpractice insurance.

title: SIMPLE COUNTRY PLEASURES
description: JOYCE MAYNARD's latest novel is ''Baby Love,'' to be issued in paperback in August. By JOYCE MAYNARD

title: SLAVES WHO SAID NO
description: A CHAIN OF VOICES By Andre Brink. 525 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.50.

title: JEWISH ARTS FESTIVAL
description: Molly Picon, a legend of the Yiddish theater, will be a headliner next Sunday at the 10th annual Jewish Festival of the Arts at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel.

title:
DINING OUT;
NOW, IF ATMOSPHERE'S YOUR DISH...
description: Sipping an aperitif on the terrace and watching a family of ducks waddle along the grassy banks of the Delaware River, all seems right with the world. Tables are set out under the trees on the terrace and in the glass-enclosed garden room, and a more sylvan setting would be hard to find.

title: WHAT'S BEHIND THE PUBLIC FIGHT ON THE BUDGET?
description: When the legislative branch of the state government enters the home stretch of the budget-making process, it is often difficult to step back and understand the significance of the actions being taken in Trenton.

title: LITERACY TAUGHT TO ADULTS
description: ''CAN you imagine doing something as routine as grocery shopping if you couldn't read the labels?'' Kit Weiss, president of the Literacy Volunteers' Valley Shore affiliate, put that question recently to a group whose support she sought.

title: Outdoors; 2 BOOKS ON TROUT ARE GOOD CATCHES
description: IN recent years I have recoiled from new books on flyfishing for trout; the reason being that while I enjoy the sport immensely and I'm fairly competent at it, I am unwilling or unable to absorb its seemingly endless refinements.

title: BOLD PAGE IN BEST PRODUCTS' BOOK
description: foot-high Claes Oldenburg typewriter eraser poised in the lobby of the Best Products Company's Parham Road headquarters here might be more than whimsy. The company's position as the nation's most profitable and most successful catalogue showroom retailer may signify management awareness that the means of correcting mistakes should always be at hand.

title: BRING THE CHAIRS-THEY'LL BRING THE SUMMER MUSIC
description: IF variety is the spice of life, then the Island's summer music scene should be spicy, indeed. This year the menu is as varied as any musical potpourri could possibly get: from opera, with both the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera appearing, along with local companies; to classical concerts, with the New York Philharmonic making its annual al fresco pilgrimages and Bach and Beethoven festivals scheduled; to jazz, with Benny Goodman highlighting one festival and Jones Beach entering the scene with a one-week jam session.

title: AT SUMMERSTAGE, SUMMER IS TUESDAY
description: TO my mind, the ideal summer-theater experience should involve a good show in a comfortable theater, with a picnic supper beforehand in an attractive setting of trees and lush green lawns. I know of one such summer theater that offers it all. If you don't, you probably have never been to Summerstage, which is about to open its sixth season on the campus of Trinity College in Hartford.

title: ISRAEL REPORTED TO IMPERIL LAST P.L.O. EXIT
description: Israeli troops with tanks and armored personnel carriers reportedly moved into a village just five miles southeast of central Beirut tonight. If the troops consolidate their position, it could lead to the virtual encirclement of the capital and the Palestinian guerrilla forces there.

title: FRANCE FREEZES PAY AND PRICES AFTER DEVALUATION
description: France announced today that it would freeze wages and prices for four months as a first step in an austerity program aimed at preventing a further weakening of the franc and the continued erosion of France's foreign-exchange reserves.

title: Oil Awards Off Ireland
description: Ireland has awarded 24 offshore blocks in the Celtic Sea and the Porcupine and Kish basins to 37 oil companies that participated in the second round of bidding for oil exploration licenses, the Irish Energy Department said Friday.

title: Mercantile House Has Energetic Head
description: John Barkshire, the 46-year-old chairman of Mercantile House Holdings P.L.C. of London, which recently made a surprise agreement to buy Wall Street's Oppenheimer Holdings, has always handled his business operations with a certain panache. Ten years ago, as managing director of the discount house Cater Ryder, Mr. Barkshire rustled up 1 million with a dozen colleagues to buy out the company's international money-brokering operation.

title: Pope Returns to the Vatican; Urges Swift Aid for Lebanese
description: Pope John Paul II pleaded today, less than three hours after returning to the Vatican from Argentina, for emergency aid to Lebanon.

title: OPEN CALL IS WINNER IN BOWLING GREEN
description: Horses who like to run from behind face the risk of getting stuck in traffic when they finally make their move. Open Call, who has won major grass stakes here and in Canada with a big late run, had been blocked, stopped and steadied under Jorge Velasquez in his two previous races this year, both times falling short of catching Highland Blade.

title: Newsweek Lineup
description: Charles Kennedy, publisher of Newsweek, fresh from a bit of study at Harvard, has found himself the center of rumors that have him out of the job. Of course, the editorship has just been changed, from Lester Bernstein to William D. Broyles Jr., but Mr. Kennedy's job is secure, judging from a statement by F.H. (Steve) Price, recently arrived executive vice president and general manager. ''Any rumors that Chuck Kennedy is no longer publisher of Newsweek are absolutely unfounded,'' he said.

title: INVENTORY AND THE ECONOMY
description: Typically, when a recession ends, businesses are caught with empty shelves and scramble to raise raw material inventories and production. This provides momentum to the entire economy.

title: SENATORS CONFRONT TAX RISES
description: Senate Republicans and the Reagan Administration buckle down this week to solving one of the great riddles of democratic politics: How to raise taxes in an election year without suffering on Election Day.

title: LAWERNCE AND ELINOR MARKS DIE
description: Dr. Lawrence Marks, former chief executive of E.R. Squibb & Sons Inc., died Friday after heart surgery at New York University Medical Center. He was 55 years old and lived in Summit, N.J.

title: Russell Blau, Lawyer, Marries Linda Wallace
description: Linda Wallace, daughter of Mrs. Philip J. Hansen of Winchester, Mass., and Ralph Wallace of Stoneham, Mass., was married yesterday to Russell M. Blau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Blau of White Plains.

title: Fighting in El Salvador Heavy As Troops Battle Guerrillas
description: Leftist rebels battled government soldiers in heavy fighting across northern Morazan Province and in sporadic raids throughout the eastern end of the country today, military officials said.

title: PALETTI KILLED IN CANADA GRAND PRIX CRASH
description: Riccardo Paletti of Italy died tonight from injuries suffered when his Denim Osella race car crashed into the back of the Ferrari driven by Didier Pironi and burst into flames at the start of today's Canadian Grand Prix.

title: ENDS AND MEANS
description: The casualties cannot yet be reckoned. Israel has barred the press from areas taken by its forces in Lebanon, wanting to limit reports of the devastation inflicted and hold down adverse international reaction. But we are beginning to get an idea of what the operation cost in human terms, and it is sickening.

title: Washington Watch; Efforts to Sell Federal Lands
description: WASHINGTON ALTHOUGH the national debt has passed $1,000 billion, there are untold billions of dollars on the asset side of the ledger, including one-third of all the land in the country and more than 400,000 federally owned buildings. The real property is carried on the books at $104.9 billion, representing the official cost, but that vastly understates the actual market value.

title: Fotomat Moves To Foote, Cone
description: As last week was running down and most of the agency had departed for weekend fun spots, Foote, Cone & Belding in New York got the word that it was to be the new agency for the Fotomat Corporation. Fotomat operates about 3,800 outlets that sell film, photofinishing and other photography-related products.

title: Ensemble Studio Picked In New Plays Program
description: The Ensemble Studio Theater is one of five theaters chosen to participate in a program set up by the Foundation of the Dramatists Guild and financed by CBS Inc. The four others designated are the Empty Space in Seattle; Portland (Me.) Stage Company; South Coast Repertory in Costa Mesa, Calif., and Wisdom Bridge Theater in Chicago.

title: Bridge:; Youth Will Have Its Day, And It's Earlier and Earlier
description: Bridge players, like swimmers, gymnasts and tennis players, seem to get younger all the time. Spearheading the winning team recently in a match between two prominent private schools in New York City was the world's only 12-year-old life master, Douglas Hsieh.

title: Cut Disability With Care
description: A commendable effort to eliminate cheating and waste from the Federal disability program has been pursued with cruel - and avoidable - zeal. Congress needs encouragement to slow down the pace and make it more humane.

title: U.S. AIDES PLEASED BY BONN MEETING
description: President Reagan's military planners won a small victory at last week's Bonn meeting of the leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Administration officials asserted over the weekend.

title: Yankees Stay Home
description: Mayor Koch was at a news conference at City Hall last week, helping to promote an eminently noncontroversial subject. Who could find fault with a corporation putting half a million dollars into summer athletic programs for city youth? That's what the Mobil Big Apple Games program is all about, and one of its most enticing aspects, for the youngsters, is one-day clinics with famous athletes from the metropolitan area.

title: ARVA JOHNSON EVERITT
description: Arva Graham Johnson Everitt, writer of ''Gangbusters'' and ''Mr. District Attorney,'' radio shows popular in the 1940's, died Friday after a long illness.

title: THE GAME OF THE WEEK? CONGRESSIONAL HARDBALL
description: Representative Ronald M. Mottl is 4 and 3 on the baseball mound against the Republicans and, as of last week, a dispirited 0 and 1 in the all-important loss column of his own Democratic party primary.

title: Representative Richmond's Contempt
description: Representative Frederick Richmond of Brooklyn has managed to display simultaneous contempt for the courts and for Congress. In Federal court, his attorney has been cited for contempt for refusing to turn over official correspondence about the Congressman's help in putting an escaped convict on the House payroll last year.

title: Kuhn's Power May Be Cut
description: The 26 major league club owners convene Monday and Tuesday for meetings that could result in a restructuring that would shift the balance of power in baseball's hierarchy.

title: The Last Crop For Weaver?
description: RALPH HOUK could tell Earl Weaver a little about retirement. Houk tried it for two years until he discovered there were just so many fish he could catch in Florida. In 1981 Houk promptly returned to his true calling, managing a baseball team, which he will do tonight in Yankee Stadium when the Boston Red Sox open a crucial week for the troubled Yankees.

title: Accounts
description: * The Greater Albany Area Chevrolet Dealers Association to Berger, Stone & Ratner.

title: The U.N. Today; June 14, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special session on disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Stock Index Trade Delay
description: The Chicago Board of Trade's hopes to begin trading stock index futures contracts soon based on various Dow Jones & Company market averages have been dashed by the appellate court of Illinois, which ordered that a stay granted by a trial judge last week ''remain in full force and effect'' until it made a further ruling.

title: Savings Units' Ratings Lower
description: Moody's Investors Service has reduced ratings on mortgage-backed bonds issued by three savings and loan associations.

title: Giving a Helping Hand; To Struggling Trees
description: I t's a hard-knock life for the city's 600,000 street trees. They must be hardy types, such as gingkos or willow oaks or London planes. ''A good street tree is a good swamp tree,'' said Randi Glickberg. ''Swamp trees like stagnant air. Also, you want small leaves, so they don't clog the sewers.''

title: BRITISH RADIO TOLD FOE OF THE QE2'S ARRIVAL
description: Tha Argentine garrison on the Falkland Islands heard about the arrival of the reinforcements aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2 four days before it was announced here, over the British Ministry of Defense's own radio station.

title: HAIG ASSERTS U.S. IS SEEKING A LASTING LEBANON SOLUTION
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States would seek the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon as part of a long-term solution in which Syrian and all other foreign troops would also be pulled out.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Thursday incorrectly described the role of Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, at a meeting in Washington on racial in- tegration of the teachers in New York City's schools. Mr. Shanker was in- vited to the meeting and participated in the discussion.

title: L.P.G.A. TITLE WON BY JAN STEPHENSON
description: Jan Stephenson of Australia became only the third foreign player to win the Ladies Professional Golf Association title in the 28 years of the tournament when she shot a one-under-par 71 today for a 279.

title: Policeman Reports Shooting Assailant
description: An off-duty policeman who was assaulted by a group of men yesterday shot one assailant, the police said. According to a department spokesman, Officer Roscoe Small was jumped by five or six men about 3 A.M. at 130th Street and Atlantic Avenue in Queens.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday incorrectly listed the program for tonight at Avery Fisher Hall. The program will be a dance and instrumental benefit by the National and Greater New York Conferences on Soviet Jewry working for the emigration of the pianist Vladimir Feltsman.

title: Brookhaven Lab Tours
description: Visitors can play tic-tac-toe with a computer, learn about holograms and see their shadows frozen by strobe lights in exhibits at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I. Free guided tours of the 800-acre exhibition run every Sunday through September. The two-hour tours, covering indoor and outdoor exhibits, are given from 10 A.M . to 3 P.M.; the laboratory is open until 5 P.M. To reach the laboratory, take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 68, which is the entrance to the William Floyd Parkway, and continue on the Parkway for about one mile. Information: (516) 282-2345.

title: Article 207833 -- No Title
description: Investment bankers have scheduled more than $900 million of new corporate note and bond issues for sale this week, although some analysts expect the volume to be less.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Player A in a tennis match is at the net when Player B returns a ball that strikes the top of the net and begins to roll along the netcord, half on Player B's side and half on Player A's side. Player A taps the ball gently with his racquet, without touching the net. The ball drops back on the side of Player B, who cannot return it. Whose point is it?

title: MUSIC: USTAD SABRI KHAN PLAYS SARANGI
description: USTAD SABRI KHAN played the sarangi for a rapt and appreciative audience at the Alternative Museum on Saturday night. The ragas for this evening drew from the classical music of northern India.

title: ONLY HAIG IS NO. 1
description: Before you blame Jeane J. Kirkpatrick or Alexander M. Haig Jr. for their unseemly spectacle, it's well to remember that friction between our representatives to the United Nations and Secretaries of State has become virtually institutionalized and that without corrective action by a President willing to change a bad tradition, it will recur.

title: Peoples Temple Receiver Settles Major Claims
description: A Superior Court judge approved a settlement of nearly $2 million Friday to help satisfy claims in the 1978 mass murders and suicides at the Peoples Temple outpost in Guyana.

title: MARIE RAMBERT, 94, A LEADER IN BALLET
description: Dame Marie Rambert, one of the pioneering figures of British ballet, died of a stroke Saturday. She was 94 years old. Dame Marie influenced some of the 20th century's most famous choreographers. She was an adviser to Vaslav Nijinsky when he created ''The Rite of Spring.'' She was a teacher of the young Agnes de Mille and of Frederick Ashton, who created his first ballets for her. She produced the earliest and some of the greatest works of Antony Tudor, including ''Jardin aux Lilas'' and ''Dark Elegies.''

title: RAPID CITY RECALLS DEVASTATING FLOOD OF 1972
description: Few physical signs remain today of one of the worst natural disasters in United States history, the flash flood that descended on the Black Hills community of Rapid City 10 years ago, killing 238 people. But emotional scars remain.

title: FINAL TO MRS. KING
description: Billie Jean King won her first singles tournament in nearly two years today, taking a $100,000 grass tune-up for Wimbledon.

title: Julie Brosterman Married On L.I. to Marc Schector
description: Julie Brosterman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley S. Brosterman of Great Neck, L.I., and West Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Marc N. Schector, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin B. Schector of Clifton, N.J. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Golf and Country Club.

title: STUDY SAYS TECHNOLOGY COULD TRANSFORM SOCIETY
description: A report commissioned by the National Science Foundation and made public today speculates that by the end of this century electronic information technology will have transformed American home, business, manufacturing, school, family and political life.

title: WILLIAM SAROYAN'S LONG JOURNEY FROM FRESNO TO HIS ANCESTRAL LAND
description: When William Saroyan decreed that half his ashes be buried in his native California and the other half in Armenia, the land of his forebears, he could scarcely have guessed at the panoply with which Armenia's Communist hierarchy would execute his will.

title: NEW DOUBT CAST ON SALVADORAN VOTE
description: A study by a research center at El Salvador's largest university asserts that the number of voters in the March elections was at least 270,000 fewer than the Government has reported.

title: Perrault Captures Hollywood Cup
description: Heavily favored Perrault held off the closing charge of Erins Isle and It's the One to win the $500,000 Hollywood Gold Cup by one length at Hollywood Park today.

title: Military Analysis
description: Where and how to launch what British military planners hope will be the final attack on the Argentine garrison in Stanley is now the main tactical question facing the British command in the Falklands. The expectation among military analysts is that the assault will begin soon unless the Argentines capitulate.

title: BRIEFING
description: Senate Workers' Appeal

title: MaryLou Burke Is Bride
description: In St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L.I., yesterday MaryLou Cordia Burke, daughter of Robert Joseph Burke of Cliffside Park, N.J., and Elizabeth Anne Burke of Garden City, was married to Michael Thomas Kenny, son of Geraldine Kenny of Perth Amboy, N.J., and the late James Kenny. Msgr. Emil A. Wcela performed the ceremony. The bride is an executive secretary with Philip Morris Inc., where her husband is a financial analyst. Her father is president of the Union Dry Dock & Repair Company in Weehawken, N.J.

title: 12 Chosen as Fellows By Nieman Foundation
description: The Nieman Foundation has chosen 12 American journalists to attend Harvard University next fall in the 45th class of Nieman Fellows.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DEBUT

title: STATEMENTS ON THE TRUCE
description: Following is the text of the Israeli Foreign Ministry's announcement Saturday night of the cease-fire between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization. It is followed by the P.L.O. statement of acceptance, issued in Beirut and translated from the Arabic by The Associated Press:

title: RED CROSS GROUP SEEKS SAFE ZONE IN STANLEY
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross, disclosing that it had sent a team into the Falkland capital of Stanley last Thursday, urgently appealed today for the establishment of a neutral zone there for the protection of the civilian population.

title: SLOOP SCARAMOUCHE FIRST IN ASTOR RACE
description: Scaramouche, a 45-foot sloop skippered by John H. Batts of Zeeland, Mich., captured first place on corrected time today in the 175-mile overnight Astor Trophy race. It was the opener of the five-race international team competition known as Onion Patch.

title: EX-SECURITY ADVISER DISPUTED ON ACCOUNT OF JAPANESE GIFT
description: A Japanese writer has disputed Richard V. Allen's account of his receipt of a $1,000 charity donation, an event that led to his resignation as national security adviser to President Reagan last year.

title: Globetrotters
description: Artis Gilmore of the Chicago Bulls, wearing a yarmulka, has prayed at the Wailing Wall in Jerusalem. In Tangiers, Wes Unseld rode a camel. In Monaco, Walt Bellamy, while being photographed with Princess Grace, was asked to put his arm around her. He refused, saying, ''That would not be protocol.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: A MAN'S LIFE. An Autobiography. By Roger Wilkins. Illustrated. 384 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: LEBANESE IN AN OCCUPIED TOWN EXPRESS RELIEF
description: For the time being, the people of this quiet mountain town near the borders of Syria and Israel are keeping whatever complaints they may have about the Israeli occupation to themselves.

title: Howard Beats Cooper in Bout
description: After scoring three knockdowns, Kevin Howard defeated Johnny Cooper in a battle of Philadelphia welterweights today at the Sands Hotel and Casino. Howard, 21 years old and rated ninth in the world by Ring magazine, floored Cooper with straight rights in the seventh, ninth and 10th rounds of their scheduled 10-round bout. Referee Tony Perez stopped the bout at 1 minute 32 seconds of the 10th after a right by Howard staggered Cooper.

title: Market Place; Holder's Stake In Takeovers
description: FOR more than a decade, targets of takeover efforts have debated a novel strategy of defense, namely, offense - the direct counterattack.

title: Asian Non-Communists Meeting in Singapore
description: The foreign ministers of five non-C@ommunist Southeast Asian countries are scheduled to meet here Monday to seek a way to break an impasse in their diplomatic efforts to get Vietnamese forces out of Cambodia.

title: Government by Nudge and Wink
description: On the morning of last Dec. 11, three attorneys and a Senate aide visited Anne Gorsuch, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. What ensued in the 40-minute meeting is known with unusual accuracy because all the participants have signed sworn statements. Their testimony portrays a style of government breathtakingly different from that of civics textbooks.

title: Dr. Mark A. Glassner Weds Lisa J. Schwartz
description: Lisa Julie Schwartz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Fred Schwartz of Pomona, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Colonial Terrace in Peekskill, N.Y., to Dr. Mark Alan Glassner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Glassner of Spring Valley, N.Y. Rabbi Stanley Urbis performed the ceremony.

title: EFFECTS OF INCENTIVES ARE TROUBLING CUBA
description: The middle-aged man carrying a carton had hardly arrived at the market when he was surrounded by women eager to buy his handmade shoes. A teen-age girl grabbed a pair, tried them on and then happily handed over the equivalent of $70.

title: Reggie Who?
description: Pitching for the Mets, Reggie Jackson. Reggie Jackson? No, the slugger now playing for the California Angels, is not considering a new career. But the 22-year-old son of Al Jackson, the Mets' left-handed pitcher of the 1960's, recently signed a contract with the Mets and is playing for the Shelby, N.C., team of the Carolina League.

title: ISRAEL IS RAISING TAXES TO COVER COSTS OF WAR
description: Israel, faced with huge costs and economic dislocation from its invasion of Lebanon, announced sweeping new revenue-producing measures today.

title: SCOTT TAKES MILE AND OLSON WINS VAULT
description: Steve Scott, the American mile record-holder, won his duel with John Walker of New Zealand, but Billy Olson lost his bid for a pole-vault record to the wind Saturday at an international track and field meet held at Edwards Field.

title: BOARD SAYS FEES FOR SCHOOL CASE PASS $250,000
description: A 1979 Federal court judgment instructing the Board of Education to improve its programs for handicapped students has already cost New York City more than $250,000 in legal fees, and those costs could reach $1 million if the case continues to grow, according to board officials.

title: MARVIN GRIFFIN, 74, FORMER GOVERNOR
description: Marvin Griffin, the former Governor of Georgia who was elected on a pledge to preserve segregated schools ''come hell or high water,'' died of cancer yesterday at Memorial Hospital in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 74 years old.

title: PRO-ABORTION GROUP SETS A MAJOR POLITICAL DRIVE
description: After years of watching their opponents cast terror into the hearts of politicians, the advocates of legal abortion are planning their own all-out political drive this year.

title: 2 Shoot at Police
description: Two men, both of whom were wearing bulletproof vests and one of whom was carrying a submachine gun, exchanged shots yesterday afternoon with police officers called to the scene of a robbery near Central Park West at 109th Street, the police said.

title: Laurie Adlman Becomes The Bride of Kevin Frank
description: Laurie Adlman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe Adlman of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kevin Frank, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lou Frank of Dunwoody, Ga.

title: Against Pension Gimmicks, Slowly
description: Ever wonder why so many physicians, lawyers and accountants have sprouted a ''P.C.'' after their names? The initials stand for ''professional corporation,'' a legal status that permits highincome professionals to shelter an enormous proportion of their incomes from taxation. Representative Charles Rangel proposes a law to reduce these tax breaks and thus raise Federal revenues by about $1 billion annually.

title: Tanker Attacked in Atlantic Sails to Rio's Port for Repairs
description: A Liberian-registered supertanker, the Hercules, which was damaged by unidentified aircraft in the South Atlantic, sailed into Rio de Janeiro Bay today for repairs, a port official said.

title: RALLY'S CLEANUP IS DONE QUICKER THAN EXPECTED
description: Central Park and the thoroughfares that led hundreds of thousands of singing, chanting demonstrators to Saturday's antinuclear protest were quiet and bare yesterday, with cleanup efforts completed more quickly and less expensively than had been expected.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 14, 1982
description: International A new Israeli advance was under way five miles from central Beirut soon after a cease-fire between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization collapsed in bitter fighting. Israeli troops with tanks and armored personnel carriers reportedly moved into a Lebanese Army-controlled mountain village. If the troops consolidate their position, it could lead to the virtual encirclement of the capital and Palestinian guerrilla forces there. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel blamed the Palestinians for initially breaking the brief cease-fire, and the two sides fought through the day. But the Israeli truce with Syrian forces appeared to be holding. (A1:3.)

title: Dance Critics' Seminar
description: Esthetics, historical dance and criticism are among the topics to be covered in ''Refining a Critical Eye,'' a seminar Aug. 2-7 at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn. The participants will include Charles (Honi) Coles, the tap-dancer; Anna Kisselgoff, chief dance critic for The New York Times, and scholars of music, philosophy, dance and theater history. Information is available from the Graduate Liberal Studies Program, Wesleyan University, Middletown, Conn. 06457, or (203) 344-7930.

title: Last Suspect Is Seized In Shooting of Officer
description: The last of three youths wanted in the shooting Saturday of a Rutherford, N.J., policeman was arrested early yesterday, the police in North Bergen said.

title: KING KHALID'S DEATH MAY PUSH OIL PRICES HIGHER
description: In the context of widening turbulence in the Middle East, the death yesterday of King Khalid could heighten Saudi Arabia's conservatism and result in upward pressure on oil prices, according to some energy analysts.

title: Israelis Volunteer Help In Rebuilding Lebanon
description: A grass-roots Israeli volunteer movement to help repair the war ravages in neighboring Lebanon started today. Dozens of people telephoned the state radio station in Jerusalem to say that they wanted to cross the border to rebuild wrecked homes.

title: MURPHY HITS 19th AS BRAVES, GIANTS SPLIT
description: Dale Murphy hit his 19th homer of the season, a two-run shot in the first inning, to spark the Atlanta Braves to a 5-1 victory in the second game today and a split of their doubleheader with the San Francisco Giants.

title: Sanders Captures Half-Marathon
description: Odis Sanders of the Millrose Athletic Association, a 22-year-old recreation worker from Freeport, L.I., easily captured the Wendy's half-marathon this morning in 1 hour 3 minutes 39 seconds.

title: MONETARY EASING BY U.S. URGED
description: The Bank for International Settlements, warning that the world economy is now ''in a highly unstable situation,'' is urging the United States to relax its tight monetary policy in order to lower interest rates and stop the ''near stagnation of the industrial economies'' from turning into ''a real slump.''

title: THE SAKHALIN DEAL DOESN'T BIND JAPAN TO RUSSIA
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE HOUSE HAS E.P.A. ON POLITICAL 'WATCH LIST'
description: The White House has begun keeping a close watch over the Environmental Protection Agency and its head, Anne M. Gorsuch, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: BREWERS TROUNCE TIGERS, 13-5
description: Since the Milwaukee Brewers dismissed Manager Buck Rodgers almost two weeks ago and replaced him with Harvey Kuenn, the batting coach, they've nicknamed themselves, ''Harvey's Wallbangers,'' which Cecil Cooper, the first baseman, says is ''just like the drink. We keep banging them off the wall.''

title: Its Fast-Talking Ad Wins for Ally, Gargano
description: The marketing partnership of Federal Express and its agency, Ally & Gargano, produced still another landslide victory for Ally Friday night at the annual Clio television advertising awards ceremony at the Sheraton Centre. The agency won eight statuettes, five of them for its Federal Express work, specifically ''Fast-Paced World,'' the spot featuring the fast-talking executive played by John Moshitta.

title: AIRPORT HOTELS SHEDDING STOPOVER IMAGE
description: In 1931, Henry Ford opened the Dearborn Inn next door to his company airport. ''In those days, Dearborn was pretty much out in the boonies, and Mr. Ford figured as long as we had the airport, he might as well build a hotel so people wouldn't have to go downtown,'' said David Crippen, a Ford archivist.

title: OUTDOORS: FASHIONING LURES FOR SALTWATER FISHING
description: THOSE who spend a considerable amount of their spare time fishing would do well to consider making their own lures. This is particularly true of saltwater anglers who cast for such species as striped bass and bluefish from shore or boat because the price of the plugs used to catch those fish has soared in recent years to $5 or $6 or more.

title: ARGENTINA ASSERTS IT HELD OFF DRIVE
description: Argentina said tonight that its planes and ground forces repulsed a renewed British assault today west of the Falkland Islands' capital of Stanley in heavy fighting.

title: 'DERELICT' IN MIAMI TURNS OUT TO BE DIPLOMAT'S DAUGHTER
description: A frightened ''shopping bag lady'' who wandered city streets shoeless and hungry for more than three years has been reunited with a long-sought brother after convincing officials that she was the daughter of a British diplomat.

title: FAHD SUCCEEDS IN SAUDI ARABIA
description: King Khalid of Saudi Arabia, ruler of the desert oil nation since 1975, died today of a heart attack in the mountain resort of Taif. The King, 69 years old, was succeeded by Crown Prince Fahd, 59, a half-brother.

title: TV: THE SECOND MONTEVERDI OPERA
description: WHILE the various constituents of Lincoln Center occupy themselves with such special performance packages as a Stravinsky Celebration or a Mozart Festival, public television has been clever enough to acquire from Europe's Unitel organization ''A Monteverdi Cycle.'' Popular demand may not be overwhelming these days for the three extant operas of Claudio Monteverdi, who died in 1643 at the age of 76, but this ''Great Performances'' series is invaluable - and fascinating - for anybody claiming an interest in serious music.

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: IT is estimated that one out of eight Americans snores. Some of them will not admit that they snore while others cannot quite believe it. Ask their mates.

title: The Economy
description: The recession seems to be ending, according to an increasing number of economists and bankers. Though segments of the economy are still slumping, the Commerce Department's next ''flash'' estimate of the gross national product, due next Monday, is expected to indicate the improvement. (Page D1.)

title: FALKLAND ADVANCE ASSURES VICTORY, BRITAIN DECLARES
description: Britain's Defense Secretary, John Nott, said tonight that his country's success in ousting Argentine troops from the Falkland Islands had been assured by fighting this weekend.

title: STEELWORKERS, SHRUNK TO A MILLION, AT CRUCIAL POINT
description: With the steel industry in disarray and union membership plummeting, the United Steelworkers of America finds itself confronted with industry proposals for early contract negotiations.

title: Sunshine Mine Closing
description: The Sunshine Mining Company, operator of the largest silver mine in the United States, announced today that it was suspending production at its mine in Kellogg, Idaho.

title: DEATH SENTENCE FOR PENNSYLVANIA BOY REFLECTS COUNTRY'S MOOD, JUDGE SAYS
description: Joseph Aulisio could have expected to grow up to be an automobile mechanic. He loved to tinker with cars and, despite mental and emotional problems, he seemed to have a quick grasp of how motors worked and how to fix them.

title: A FALKLAND CRISIS LOOMS AGAIN IN 1990
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATIC PARTY BATTLE SEEN FOR TICKET's 2d SPOT
description: With New York State's Democrats certain to choose their candidate for Governor in a primary, a struggle over the designation of a nominee for Lieutenant Governor is likely to dominate the party's state committee meeting.

title: For Distinguished Service
description: Abel Kiviat, the oldest living American track and field Olympian, won hundreds of prizes during his career. But the prize he cherishes most is a seven-jewel gold pocket watch he received for his victory over Oscar Hedlund in a one-mile match race in Somerville, Mass., June 19, 1911.

title: R.L. Gelfond Marries Linda R. Rothenberg
description: The marriage of Linda Rose Rothenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Rothenberg Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Chicago, to Richard Lewis Gelfond, took place yesterday at Temple Israel in New Rochelle. Rabbi Amiel Wohl performed the ceremony.

title: American Sign Installs Outsider as President
description: The American Sign and Indicator Corporation began life 30 years ago as the Williams Brothers Neon Sign Company, a Spokane enterprise started by Luke G. Williams and Charles M. Williams.

title: Gulf Leaving Taiwan
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation says that it has withdrawn from its 11-year-old joint venture with the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corporation of Taiwan to search for oil off the north coast of the island. The move, announced Friday, was described as part of the company's plan to pull out of all oil and chemical activities in East Asia.

title: World Cup Opens and Belgium Upsets Argentina, 1-0
description: The most ambitious World Cup soccer championships in the history of the sport opened here tonight, and Belgium upset the defending titleholder, Argentina, with a single goal in the second half.

title: Anna Hayes Married
description: The marriage of Anna Wheeler Hayes to Seth William Levin took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Arthur Levin in New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Hayes Jr. of Portland, Ore., is an associate with the New York law firm of Battle Fowler Jaffin Pierce & Kheel. Mr. Levin is a lawyer with the firm of Davis Polk Wardwell.

title: BATTLE SHAPING UP OVER PUBLIC EMPLOYEE PENSIONS
description: A battle involving governments, unions and business groups is taking shape over the future of hundreds of millions of dollars in pensions for 300,000 public employees in New York.

title: Spinks Challenges Braxton to Fight
description: Michael Spinks had hardly finished defending his World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title when the word went out to Dwight Braxton.

title: HAPPY WATERGATE TO YOU
description: The 10th anniversary of the Watergate break-in is the occasion for partying by that balding bunch of prosecutors who fondly recall their days of Jill Wine and roses.

title: Susana Duncan and Peter Mezan Wed
description: Susana Grace Duncan and Peter Mezan were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation. The Rev. Robert Zerbe and Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony.

title: DEAF, BLIND, AND NOW Ph.D.
description: Shut off from the seeing and hearing world by blindness and deafness, Adeline Becht has proved herself in the classroom and is ready to take on the clinic.

title: Hearing Is Listed In Raiders Case
description: United States District Judge Harry Pregerson was to hold a hearing Monday on several routine post-trial motions to overturn a jury verdict that would clear the way for the Oakland Raiders to move to Los Angeles.

title: DANCE: MARTHA GRAHAM COMPANY IN 3 REVIVALS
description: THE choreographer who reaches beyond the dimension of the spoken word, past even rational understanding, is a rare and great one. Martha Graham is such a choreographer.

title: EGYPT'S PRESIDENT FLIES TO JOIN OTHER ARAB LEADERS IN SAUDI ARABIA
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt flew to Saudi Arabia tonight to present his condolences to the royal family and greet the new sovereign, King Fahd. Most of the other Arab leaders left their capitals for similar missions.

title: HOW COGENERATION HURTS THE 'LITTLE GUY'
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Energy Reserves Group, Wichita, Kan., has elected Clinton C. Engstrand chairman and Clark R. Mandigo executive vice president, administration, and a director.

title: Five Men at L.I. Boating Party Injured When Vessel Crashes
description: Five Freeport men were injured, two critically, when a boat in which they were having a bachelor party crashed into an ice-breaking pole and a concrete bridge pillar in the State Boat Channel, the police said.

title: ANOTHER VIEW OF THE COMMUNIST POOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Gerry Cooney's Road to a Rematch
description: SITTING on the edge of the training ring that had been stripped down to accommodate their Saturday news conference, Larry Holmes nodded toward Gerry Cooney.

title: Berlin Leftists' Offices Are Wrecked in Fire
description: The headquarters of the radical party in West Berlin that organized a protest during President Reagan's visit to the city Friday was destroyed by fire early today, according to police officials.

title: SPANISH COMMUNIST PARTY LEADER AGREES TO WITHDRAW RESIGNATION
description: Santiago Carrillo, Secretary General of the Communist Party, agreed today to withdraw his resignation after a week of internal debates that opened new fissures in the organization's leadership.

title: Recession End Seen By Many; But Analysts Forecast Weak 1982 Recovery
description: Slowly and unevenly, but with increasing certainty, the recession that began with little warning last July seems finally to be coming to an end. It is quite possible, in fact, that as measured by total output of goods and services, the broadest gauge of economic activity, it is already over.

title: ITT World Appoints Manager
description: The Western Union Telegraph Company held a monopoly position in domestic telex and data-communications systems for almost 40 years. But that changed last year when the Federal Communications Commission decided to allow the major international carriers to offer similar services in the United States.

title: COSMOS HAIL GOALIE AS KEY TO VICTORY
description: As a goalkeeper, Hubert Birkenmeier of the Cosmos gets better with age. In the history of soccer, the greatest goalkeepers have reached their peak at around 35 years of age. Birkenmeier, 33 and progressing at a steady pace, is apparently following that pattern.

title: BALLET: ELIOT FELD'S 'SCENES,' VIGNETTES OF THE DEPRESSION
description: ELIOT FELD'S ''Scenes,'' which received its New York premiere Saturday afternoon at the Joyce Theater, is a convincing argument for the fitness of the Feld Ballet's new home. In an earlier performance, ''Scenes for the Theater,'' as it was called when it was first performed in 1980, seemed to exist in some historical limbo. On the more intimate Joyce stage, the ballet now has some of the intense, gathered focus, though none of the grittiness, of one of John Sloan's city scenes.

title: Bomb Defused in Ulster
description: Bomb-disposal experts defused a bomb containing 350 pounds of explosives thought to have been set as a trap for a British military border patrol, the police said today. The explosives were found Saturday in a wall near the border with the Irish Republic at Crossmaglen, County Armagh, a police spokesman said.

title: HOW DISPUTED J-51 TAX AID FOR DEVELOPERS WORKS
description: New York City's most important tax abatement program for developers has expired because members of the State Legislature have been unable to agree on whether it should be extended and for how long.

title: U.N. Members Consult
description: The Security Council held private consultations tonight at Lebanon's request. The consultations on the week-old Israeli invasion of Lebanon began at 11:15 P.M. and ended 15 minutes later with no action taken. There was no announcement that the 15-nation Council planned to hold another public debate on the fighting.

title: KHALID, QUIET KING AND DESERT HUNTER
description: King Khalid ibn Abdel Aziz Al Saud, who died in Taif, Saudi Arabia, yesterday, was described as almost reluctant when chosen Crown Prince by his half-brother King Faisal. He became Saudi Arabia's fourth king when King Faisal was murdered on March 25, 1975.

title: NEEDED: A PACIFIC VERSAILLES
description: With Versailles behind us, Washington should talk soon with Tokyo and other Asian capitals about a much-needed Pacific conference.

title: A RELAXED STADLER IS AT THE TOP
description: minute drive through some of the most gorgeous snow-capped scenery in America. Here, even in June, the snow comes down to the roadside. In this place Stadler is far from the big cities he dislikes and, at 6,500 feet above sea level, contentedly breathing air that is pure and invigorating. There is little traffic in ''downtown'' Lake Tahoe, and even the dust raised by a work crew laying down blacktop seems an instrusion.

title: News Analysis
description: The Israeli invasion of Lebanon has recast the balance of power in this corner of the world and created a whole new set of relationships involving Israel, Syria,

title: DEMOCRATS TO ADDRESS ATOM ARMS FREEZE AT PARLEY
description: The Democratic Party is being asked to support a nuclear weapons freeze and promise a detailed anticrime program at its party conference later this month.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think we are going to want and work to achieve adjustments in the withdrawal of all foreign elements from Lebanon.

title: FLOYD WINNER BY 6, PASSES $2 MILLION
description: Ray Floyd became the sixth golfer to accumulate $2 million in career earnings today when he won the $400,000 Memphis Classic by six shots.

title: U.S. Will Not Prosecute Reporter in Aliens Case
description: A newspaper reporter who posed as an illegal alien and was arrested will not be prosecuted for transporting real illegal aliens in Texas, a Federal official said Friday.

title: FUSION BAND: WEATHER REPORT
description: fusion bands of the 1970's, recently underwent personnel changes with the loss of the bassist Jaco Pastorius and the drummer Peter Erskine to Mr. Pastorius's big band. At the Palladium Saturday, the latest version of the quintet, featuring the drummer Omar Hakim, the bassist Victor Bailey and the percussionist Jose Raffi, in addition to the longtime leaders, Joe Zawinul and Wayne Shorter, touched half a dozen stylistic bases.

title: CONNORS BEATS MCENROE IN GRASS FINAL
description: Jimmy Connors defeated John McEnroe today, 7-5, 6-3, in the final of the Stella Artois grass tennis tournament, the major tune-up for Wimbledon.

title: Malcolm Schweiker, 87, Dies; Father of Cabinet Secretary
description: Malcolm A. Schweiker, a former ceramics company executive and father of Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services, died Saturday after a long illness. He was 87 years old,

title: HOLMES MAY RETIRE AFTER A 'CLUB' FIGHT
description: If Gerry Cooney could be portrayed as a real-life Rocky, Larry Holmes wants to play Apollo Creed in his next fight and meet a real club fighter in what may well be his finale.

title: INVASION VICTIMS SWAMP THE HOSPITALS OF LEBANON
description: The driveway was lined with stretchers. Every so often today ambulances, some of them caked with mud and camouflaged with twigs and greenery, pulled into the driveway, their sirens wailing.

title: WHITE HOUSE HAS LITTLE TO SAY ON ATOM PROTEST
description: Official Washington, preoccupied with wars elsewhere, had a subdued reaction today to Saturday's nuclear disarmament rally in New York.

title: THE CITY
description: The police said they were searching yesterday for a suspect in several robberies and a homicide who fired two shots at officers trying to capture him in Brooklyn Saturday night. One officer was slightly injured by flying glass from a bullet-pierced patrol car windshield.

title: FOLK MUSIC: CONCERT WITH THEME OF PEACE
description: THOUGH it did not appear to be connected with the disarmament rally in Central Park Saturday, the concert staged by the International Symphony for World Peace Inc. at Alice Tully Hall that evening stressed a similar theme. Copies of an ''International Anthem for World Peace,'' festooned with the flags of 142 nations, were handed out to those who attended the $25-a-seat benefit, and Nina Deutsch, the organization's executive vice president, spoke hopefully of its assuming the role of a ''musical Red Cross'' and of her belief in ''the magic of music.''

title: Commodities; Choosing Best Stock Index
description: HOW'S the market? No matter how big or small stock investors may be, that is the first question they invariably ask of their brokers before making an investment decision. The question is important because picking the right stock in a wrong market often can be as costly as the other way round.

title: UNDERCOVER OPERATIONS UNDER STUDY
description: James F. Neal, the former Watergate prosecutor, threaded his way from the House hearing room through the Capitol subways to his new Senate offices, talking almost as quickly as he was moving.

title: BUSH LAUDS CHRISTIANS' ROLE
description: Vice President Bush said tonight that he did not believe that the religious right ''has a serious intention to impose its own moral activity on American society.''

title: CAR-PARTS SUPPLIER IS BUOYED BY JAPAN
description: When Detroit is in a slump, the smaller companies that supply parts to the auto makers typically suffer the most, as orders dry up in the early stages of the industry's production cutbacks.

title: Beckenbauer Is Back
description: Steve Ross usually gets his man, and this time it is Franz Beckenbauer. Mr. Ross, the chairman of the board of Warner Communications, which owns the Cosmos, has signed the West German star to a five-year contract to represent the company.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: NEWARK TO PICK MAYOR IN A RUNOFF TOMMORROW
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, seeking an unprecedented fourth term as chief executive of the state's largest city, and City Council President Earl Harris will face each other on Tuesday in a runoff election.

title: Advertising; Marketing Portraits Of Kids
description: FOR PCA International of Matthews, N.C., the age of marketing has come to the kiddie portrait-photo business. In the 15 years of PCA's existence, in-house advertising has brought its growth to $175 million in annual sales with an ad budget of some $14 million.

title: SHUTDOWN OF INIDAN POINT 3 EXTENDED BY TUBE CORROSION
description: Corrosion of steam-generator tubes at the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant will force the plant, closed since a generator accident in March, to remain shut at least until the fall, according to the Power Authority of the State of New York.

title: THE COURT MADE A MISTAKE ON WESTWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Increase Prices of Gasoline
