description: The Exxon Company USA, Chevron USA Inc. and the Amoco Oil Company have raised their wholesale gasoline prices in several regions of the country by 1 to 2 cents a gallon.

title: Richmondtown Project Offers Weekend Tours
description: Every Saturday and Sunday through November, buses will take visitors from the St. George Terminal of the Staten Island Ferry to the Richmondtown Restoration, a village of recreated 17th-century buildings with people in period costume playing the part of villagers. The buses, chartered by the restoration, leave from the terminal at noon, 1:30 and 3 P.M.; return-trip buses leave from the restoration at 12:45, 2:15, 3:45 and 4:45 P.M.

title: 60 Wounded British Soldiers Are Evacuated From Uruguay
description: Sixty British troops wounded in fighting in the Falkland Islands left Montevideo for home today on board a Royal Air Force ambulance plane after arriving a few hours earlier on a hospital ship.

title: Irish Premier Calls His U.S. Visit a Success
description: Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey said today that he was succeeding in swinging American public opinion toward supporting the goal of a unified Ireland.

title: CHILD SUPPORT: A GROWING PROBLEM OF NONPAYMENT
description: Exasperated by the difficulties they say they have encountered collecting delinquent child support payments, hundreds of divorced mothers in several states have begun forming protest groups.

title: Battered Yanks Glad for Rain
description: The Yankees left for home this afternoon after a trip in which they had gone against two of the top three teams in the East. They could consider today successful because it rained.

title: Drug Use Called A Private Matter
description: The president of the National Football League Players' Association says that drug problems among players are ''a private matter.''

title: CHANGE IN TARGETS FOR MONEY URGED
description: The persistence of high interest rates that first pushed the economy into a recession and now threatens to stymie a recovery has led some economists to contend that the time is ripe for the Federal Reserve to bring rates down and help the economy by raising its money supply growth targets.

title: SOVIET POLICE BAR DISARMAMENT MEETING
description: The Soviet police moved in today to seal off the apartment where a fledgling independent disarmament group was planning to meet. The action came after the police had warned the group's members that their movement was provocative, antisocial and illegal.

title: Court Orders Phone Study
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has reversed a ruling and ordered the Federal Communications Commission to reconsider a decision in 1980 that ordinary long-distance service and WATS are ''like'' services.

title: CHINA SOWING THE SEEDS FOR A SHIFT IN RURAL POLICY
description: A row of straw-hatted peasants, stooping in calfdeep water, deftly thrust the slender green stalks of young rice into the dark mud. Ignoring the relentless drizzle, another farmer in patched denims cajoled his stubborn water buffalo into dragging a wooden sledge around the adjacent paddy to level the soggy earth for the afternoon's transplanting.

title: THE AFGHAN BURDEN
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Asahi Optical Co. has agreed with the Benson Co., of Mountain View, Calif., to distribute the full line of Benson printers and pen plotters in Japan.

title: NORTHERNERS WHO FOLLOW DREAM OF JOB IN TEXAS FIND WORK SCARCE AND WELFARE SKIMPY IN REALITY
description: Deluged by a swarm of penniless job hunters from the North and mounting home-grown unemployment, labor leaders in Texas are warning the jobless to stay home.

title: Barbara Citronberg is Bride of Dr. Samuel Singer
description: At Congregation B'nai Israel in Bridgeport, Conn., yesterday Barbara Citronberg, a senior staff nurse at the Children's Hospital Medical Center in Boston, was married to Dr. Samuel Singer, who graduated Thursday from the Harvard Medical School. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Arnold Sher, assisted by Cantor Ramon Gilbert.

title: MAX L. RAFFERTY, 65, CONSERVATIVE WHO RAN CALIFORNIA SCHOOLS, DIES
description: Max L. Rafferty, the conservative educator who was State Superintendent of Public Instruction in California from 1963 to 1971, died yesterday when his car plunged off an earthen dam into a pond in Alabama. He was 65 years old.

title: Mesa Lines Up 1-Billion Credit
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company has signed a $1.05 billion credit agreement with nine banks to finance its tender offer for 12.1 million shares in the Cities Service Company, Mesa announced yesterday.

title: Dr. Edward J. Trapido Marries Nancy Carroll
description: Nancy Ellen Carroll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Carroll of Malden, Mass., was married at the King's Grant Inn in Danvers, Mass., yesterday to Dr. Edward Jay Trapido, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Trapido of Kew Gardens, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh and the Rev. Michael Guarino, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: E. J. Beinecke Jr., Chairman Of Sperry & Hutchinson Co.
description: Edwin J. Beinecke Jr., chairman of the Sperry & Hutchinson Company, died yesterday at his home in Remsenburg, L.I. He was 68 years old. He joined the trading-stamp concern in 1950 as a director.

title: PARENTS ESTABLISH ACTION GROUPS
description: ''It's humiliating to be on assistance,'' said 44-year-old Yvonne Prestwich, founder of a protest group, Pecos, Parents for the Enforcement of Court Ordered Support, of 25 divorced mothers formed a month ago in Enfield, Conn. Mrs. Prestwich said she had to turn to the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program in 1979 when she was unable to collect support from her former husband for their three children.

title: A DAY IN THE LIVES OF BIG-LEAGUERS WAS A CAREER
description: THEIR nicknames were Dazzy and Dizzy - like the Hall of Fame members Dazzy Vance and Dizzy Dean - and they were major league pitchers with something very special in common.

title: STRAVINSKY'S DIVERSE MUSICAL INFLUENCES
description: FOUR works on the New York City Ballet's Saturday night Stravinsky Festival program at the New York State Theater attested to Igor Stravinsky's ability to absorb diverse musical influences.

title: FOR MODEL YACHTSMEN, A SOGGY RACE IN PARK
description: The rain soaked their shoes, their boats and in some cases their radio transmitters, but 12 ''skippers'' stood by the edge of Conservatory Pond in Central Park yesterday guiding their model yachts through seven heats on the second day of the Eastern Divisional Championships.

title: MIAMI WINS SERIES
description: The Miami Hurricanes have won their first college baseball title, thanks to the pitching of Mike Kasprzak and Dan Smith, who checked Wichita State's Shockers twice in the same week.

title: Delta Sets Braniff Credit
description: Delta Air Lines has announced that it will accept credits from Braniff Airways' ''travel bonus bonanza'' program in its own ''frequent flier'' program. A Delta spokesman, Jim Ewing, said Friday that the step had been taken because the members of Braniff's plan were ''just left out in the cold'' when the Texasbased airline filed for protection under bankruptcy laws. It also means more business for Delta, he added.

title: STUDY CITES LACK OF PROGRAMS FOR RETARDED INMATES IN U.S.
description: Thousands of mentally and physically handicapped people are in the nation's prisons, but apparently no one knows exactly how many and few resources exist to meet their needs, according to a federally financed survey.

title: 14 Injured at I.B.M. Plant
description: Fourteen people were injured today when a container of scrap aluminum exploded at an International Business Machines plant, sending a plume of black smoke into the air and rattling nearby houses, officials said. Most of the injured were treated at hospitals for smoke inhalation or minor injuries and released, according to hospital officials and Dick O'Connell, an I.B.M. spokesman. One man, Robert Pagaduan, 33 years old, of San Jose, was admitted to Santa Teresa Community Hospital here with second-degree burns, said Carol Voss, a hospital spokesman.

title: METS' SWAN REVELS IN SUCCESS
description: After each performance in this so far rosy season, Craig Swan is pressed to come up with new words to describe the feelings that accompany his comeback from a 1980 rotator-cuff injury.

title: Presbyterian Group Acts To Merge With Another
description: The Northern-oriented Reformed Presbyterian Church-Evangelical Synod voted Saturday, by a ratio of more than 3 to 1, to merge with the Southern-rooted Presbyterian Church in America, a church spokesman said.

title: Sunshine Mining Closes Idaho Silver Operation
description: The Sunshine Mining Company announced Saturday that it was closing its 98-year-old silver mine here indefinitely and laying off 450 employees.

title: HINCKLEY TRIAL: $2 MILLION SO FAR IN CASE WHERE EXPERTS PLUS TIME EQUAL MONEY
description: The Government and the parents of John W. Hinckley Jr. have been billed at least $350,000 to $450,000 by the opposing teams of private psychiatrists and other experts who have spent much of the past year probing his mind.

title: U.S. Accuses Vietnam Over Exit Permits
description: The State Department accused the Vietnamese Government today of foot-dragging on the expatriation of thousands of inmates at labor detention camps, many of whom are eligible to come to the United States.

title: Required Reading 'The Secret Is Out'
description: Eugene V. Rostow, Director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, in remarks before the annual meeting of the American Institute of Astronautics and Aeronautics, Baltimore, May 25, 1982:

title: Election Judge Indicted in Jersey
description: A Union City building inspector who served as an election judge in a Board of Education election last year has been indicted on eight counts of the fraudulent use of the mails to aid candidates supported by Mayor William V. Musto.

title: OUR AIMS AND ISRAEL'S
description: In the past few weeks, the United States has been confronted with two wars, one in the Falklands and one in Lebanon, and in both instances our initial response has been uncertainty over the position we ought to be taking. With regard to the Falklands, where our interest in backing an ally collided with considerations of regional security, this uncertainty was understandable. In the end, however, we rightly resolved it in favor of England - rightly, because just as we should favor authoritarianism over totalitarianism where those are the only alternatives, so in any conflict between a democratic and a nondemocratic country, our proper place is with the democracy.

title: MET MUSEUM DECLARES 17 EGYPTIAN ITEMS FAKE
description: Preparing for a reinstallation of its Egyptian galleries, the Metropolitan Museum has discovered that 17 gold vessels that were part of an important holding known as the Treasure of the Three Princesses are fakes.

title: GASTINEAU & CO. CASH IN
description: M ark Gastineau's mother cried when she learned that the New York Jets had chosen her son in the 1979 college football draft. Mrs. Gastineau, an Oklahoman named Lou, said that she imagined her boy would be ruined in the city's ominous canyons and teeming streets.

title: A NIGHT WITH ISAAC B. SINGER AND HIS DEMONS
description: The Grand Imp settled himself in front of a piece of apple pie and a cup of coffee. A long night of mischief lay ahead and he needed to fortify himself. Between bites, an anxious bystander slipped in quietly next to him. ''Have the demons and dybbuks arrived?'' he was asked. The Imp smiled. His bright blue eyes narrowed. ''For the time being,'' he said, ''I see only people, but most probably the others will show up.''

title: MOSCOW TEXT ON INVASION
description: Following is the text of a Soviet Government statement, as distributed by the English-language service of Tass, the Government press agency:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bank of Nova Scotia said it was proposing a public offering of $150 million 12-year, floating rate subordinated debentures in the Eurobond market.

title: Herfindahl Index a Gauge
description: The most dramatic change in the new merger guidelines is probably the adoption of the Herfindahl index, a mathematical standard for determining when an industry is so concentrated that mergers will be anticompetitive.

title: New Teller Machine Link
description: An agreement announced yesterday by 10 regional banks would give the banks' 10 million customers access to a network of automatic teller machines in 35 states. The network, Cirrus System, would link 3,500 machines and is expected to become operational early next year.

title: 'E.T.' GROSSES $13 MILLION FOR OPENING WEEKEND
description: For the third weekend in a row, the men who run Hollywood's movie studios are grinning from ear to ear. After record-breaking weekends by ''Rocky III'' and ''Star Trek II,'' Steven Spielberg's ''E.T. - the Extra-Terrestrial'' has earned what Universal Pictures projects as nearly $13 million during the three days since it opened Friday.

title: Texas Rule Stands
description: The Supreme Court has left intact a Texas rule forbidding high school athletes from participating in varsity sports if they have attended special training programs such as summer basketball camps. Del Harris, head coach of the Houston Rockets, brought a suit challenging the rule, contending that it was unconstitutional because, in barring his two sons from attending a basketball camp and competing in varsity sports, it interfered with ''a fundamental right of family privacy.'' The court, without comment, turned away the arguments.

title: JAMES P. STERBA
description: A frog's feast is invariably movable. Being extremely fussy eaters, both frogs and toads eschew insects and other small creatures that are unwilling to demonstrate their freshness by crawling, buzzing or flying.

title: BATTLING THE 'BIG BOYS'
description: There's an old saying in this state that ''the water won't clear up till you get the hogs out of the creek.'' That's what Jim Hightower claims anyway, which suggests one reason the supposedly conservative Democrats of Texas have just nominated him - a self-proclaimed Progressive who's delighted if you call him a Populist - for Agriculture Commissioner.

title: PAUL APPERSON REID
description: Dr. Paul Apperson Reid, president of Western Carolina University for 18 years, has died after a long illness.

title: Boycott Hits Yonkers
description: Some members of the Standardbred Owners Association began their boycott as promised yesterday, refusing to enter their horses for Yonkers Raceway's opening card Thursday night.

title: Year Without Pay For L.I. Teacher
description: A Long Island English teacher accused of placing a tarantula on the desk of his department chairman was suspended without pay for a year by the State Education Commissioner today.

title: General Motors Recalls 13,000 Trucks and Buses
description: The General Motors Corporation is recalling about 13,000 Chevrolet and GMC trucks and buses because of a possible problem with steering shafts that could cause loss of steering, the corporation said today. The heavy- and medium-duty trucks and school buses are from the 1981-82 model years.

title: TRANSIT OFFICIAL DEFENDS TAKING BENEFITS ILLEGALLY
description: An official of the New York City Transit Authority charged with illegally taking benefits from companies doing business with the authority said yesterday he ''thought there was nothing wrong with it'' because other officials were doing the same.

title: ADOPTION: FATHERS GIVE VIEWS
description: John Festa described the scene that takes place every day when he returns to his Staten Island home: ''At 4:45 my wife opens the front door and when I pull up, I see Kimberly Ann standing there, going nuts for her Dada. There is absolutely nothing else like it. I miss her even now.'' Kimberly Ann has been in the Festa home since she was 5 days old; her adoption was made final in March.

title: BUDGET OFFICE HINTS REAGAN VETO OF SPENDING MEASURE
description: The Reagan Administration reaffirmed its opposition today to a supplemental spending bill that would add $8.9 billion to the current Federal budget, including $3 billion for a program to aid the slumping housing industry and $1.3 billion for student loans.

title: FROM A PHILIPPINE 'APOCALYPSE' TO A 42d ST. STAGE, JONATHAN REYNOLD'S LARGER-THAN-LIFE WORLD
description: THE movie is 28 days behind schedule, and the director and his company have spent ''three months in the worst country in the world, 200 miles from the worst city in the world.'' The entire Philippine Air Force and thousands of extras have been mobilized, gallons of phony blood have been spilled and the film designer's carefully constructed huts have been blown to smithereens - all this, and still there is not one usable foot of film because the world-famous director of this war epic has been unable to get his helicopters to fly into camera range.

title: Stuart Johnson, Former Aide In a House Antitrust Inquiry
description: Stuart H. Johnson Jr., a Washington lawyer who served as chief counsel of the House Antitrust Subcommittee, died Saturday of injuries suffered in a horseback riding accident. He was 58 years old.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: DOES everything, finally, come back? The same fashions recycled, t he same events and politics recast? That's what Joyce Ravid, a p hotographer, wanted to know at the opening of Amy Arbus's first showo f photographs at the Mudd Club, 77 White Street.

title: Taking Sides; Bankrupt Chic
description: Lawyers are eyeing a potentially lucrative new field: bankruptcy law. Traditionally, negotiating deals with creditors for strapped corporations and individuals has hardly seemed a path to riches.

title: KARL C. LEEBRICK
description: Karl C. Leebrick, president emeritus of Kent State University, died Sunday at the age of 96. Mr. Leebrick was born in Burlington, Iowa, and served as president of Kent State in Ohio from 1939 to 1943.

title: Reagan Adviser Asserts Courts Need to Change
description: Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to President Reagan, told conferees on judicial reform today that ''it's time for a change'' in matters of criminal law and activism in the nation's courts. But he said getting Congress to go along with such changes would take time, a process that he likened to ''Chinese water torture.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * AVX Corp. of Great Neck, L.I., said it had formed three new operating divisions within its multilayer ceramic capacitor operations.

title: KNOXVILLE LURING RUNAWAYS IN SEARCH OF JOBS
description: Dozens of runaway children have come here in search of meager jobs at the World's Fair, a Knoxville youth shelter official said today.

title: Supreme Court to Rule On Home Video Dispute
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the use of home video recorders to tape television broadcasts violates Federal copyright law.

title: 11 Beaten to Death in India
description: Eleven people were beaten to death by a mob in West Bengal, the state police reported today. The police said the victims had been killed by angry villagers who suspected them of smuggling. The police also said contraband goods had been recovered.

title: Libya Official Visiting Syria
description: Foreign Relations Secretary Abdel-Aati al-Ubeidi of Libya arrived today from Tripoli for talks with Syrian leaders on the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, the official Syrian press agency said.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES PLAN LINKING FOOD STAMPS TO MANDATORY WORK
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee today voted to require millions of food stamp recipients either to find jobs by next year or face the loss of their benefits.

title: THE COSTLIEST FEDERAL BUILDING EVER
description: The new Hart Senate Office Building will include a gymnasium after all, and at the bargain price of $736,000 instead of the $906,000 that, senators reluctantly decided earlier, was just too expensive.

title: Faberge Talks Off
description: Faberge Inc. said it had broken off talks with an undisclosed suitor after Faberge's board had ''unanimously decided'' to end acquisition discussions that began last week.

title: Phones Restored At Grand Central
description: Telephone service was partially restored yesterday to thousands of customers in the Grand Central Terminal area after it was disrupted by a weekend fire on a railroad track, the New York Telephone Company reported.

title: TURKEY'S JEWS SEE LEBANON HAZARDS
description: Leaders of the small Jewish population in Turkey hope that Israel's invasion of Lebanon will not have adverse effects for Jews in this Moslem country.

title: A Smash Hit For Mrs. King
description: M atch point. Billie Jean King, 38 years old, watched the ball arch into a high lob over the court in Birmingham, England, and waited for it to come down. One smash, and she would move within one match of winning her first tournament in two years.

title: Market Place; Plasma Process And Cobe Labs
description: COBE LABORATORIES, faced with a maturing market for its hemodialysis equipment, is moving into related markets in hopes of renewed growth.

title: U.S. TO BAR HEILEMAN'S PABST BID
description: The Justice Department announced today that it would move to block the G. Heileman Brewing Company's proposed acquisition of the Pabst Brewing Company, charging that the merger would increase market concentration for the new company beyond limits acceptable under antitrust law.

title: SOLIDARITY'S POSITION ON NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa Angers Zulus
description: South Africa announced today that it would hand over a remote inhabited piece of the Zulus' coastal land to Swaziland in a move that would reduce South Africa's border with Marxist-led Mozambique. The action, which would also give the land-locked Swazi kingdom access to the sea, brought immediate and noisy protest from the country's five million Zulus.

title: Quebec Takeovers
description: The government of Quebec is exploring the possible purchase of 40 percent of Gulf Canada Ltd.'s assets in the province, Premier Rene Levesque said. Mr. Levesque said the province is also involved in similar talks with Ultramar Canada Inc. and B.P. Canada Ltd. Finance Minister Jacques Parizeau said talks are at an early stage and could last several years.

title: General Cinema
description: Herbert Paige, a former senior vice president of the General Cinema Corporation who was charged with misappropriating $5.1 million in funds intended for General Cinema last September, settled charges made against him by the Securities and Exchange Commission by agreeing to put his $880,000 net worth into an escrow account. As part of the settlement, Mr. Paige neither admitted nor denied the charges. In establishing the escrow account, Mr. Paige would be complying with a Federal court ruling, handed down yesterday, that would allow him to direct those funds to General Cinema. Mr. Paige could not be reached for comment by telephone at his home in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Boycott Fines Are Paid by 8
description: The Commerce Department said today that a total of $42,000 in fines had been paid by eight companies for reportedly complying with the Arab boycott against Israel in violation of antiboycott laws.

title: General Dynamics To Sell 3 Divisions
description: The United Technologies Corporation will purchase three telecommunications divisions of the General Dynamics Corporation for about $100 million in cash, the two companies annnounced yesterday.

title: Suits Seek End to Crowding In Jails of Essex and Camden
description: The Public Defender's office filed separate lawsuits against Essex and Camden Counties today, asking a Federal judge to declare conditions in those overcrowded county jails unconstitutional.

title: ISLAND WAR: 10 WEEKS OF OFTEN BRUTAL COMBAT
description: April 2. Argentina invades the Falklands. After a 3 1/2-hour battle, most of the defending British marines surrender. April 3. Argentina seizes South Georgia Island and the South Sandwich Islands. April 7. Two British aircraft carriers, the vanguard of a 65-ship task force, leave naval headquarters at Portsmouth, bound for the South Atlantic. April 12. Britain imposes a blockade of Argentine sea traffic within 200 miles of the Falklands. April 25. British commandos invade South Georgia at dawn. Argentine submarine is hit and beached and 140 defenders surrender. May 2. Argentina's only cruiser, the General Belgrano, is sunk by a British submarine. More than 321 are reported dead or missing. May 3. British helicopters reportedly sink one Argentine patrol vessel and damage a second. May 4. The British destroyer Sheffield is set ablaze by a missile from an Argentine fighter plane and abandoned with 20 reported killed. A British Harrier jet is shot down and the pilot is lost. May 9.

title: ISRAELIS CUT OFF WEST BEIRUT, TRAPPING P.L.O. LEADERS
description: Israeli tank columns completely cut off Moslem western Beirut today, trapping the military and political leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: A New Commissioner
description: Chet Simmons, the president of the all-sports cable television network ESPN, was named commissioner of the new United States Football League yesterday. Simmons, 53 years old, was president of NBC Sports from 1977 to 1979.

title: JUDGE ASKED TO SAVE BENEFITS
description: A legal aid group today asked a Federal district judge to block the Social Security Administration from cutting off welfare benefits to elderly or disabled people who refuse to let the agency see their tax records.

title: Child Killed in Fall From Train
description: An 18-month-old child was killed when she fell from a train at Walt Disney World. A spokesman for the amusement park said that Cassandra Lusinski, the daughter of a Muscatine, Iowa, couple, fell out of the seven-car tram as it made a turn while moving through a parking lot Saturday.

title: CITY BALLET: BALLANCHINE RETURNS TO STRAVINSKY'S 'ELEGIE' SCORE
description: Up to this point, the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Centennial Celebration has been carried by the inclusion of older ballets already in the repertory. Yet if most of the initial premieres have been disappointing, the celebration itself has embodied the kind of event that only the City Ballet would be capable of conceiving.

title: NURSING HOME OPERATOR CONVICTED OF KIDNAPPING 3 ELDERLY WOMEN
description: A nursing home operator and two codefendants were convicted today on charges they kidnapped three elderly women from a home in Florida, the county authorities said.

title: Floyd to Protest Fine
description: Raymond Floyd, who won the Memphis Classic golf tournament and its $72,000 first prize on Sunday, says he will protest a fine of $200 assessed by Professional Golfers' Association officials for slow play during the third round on Saturday. Floyd, in a threesome with Jim Nelford and Mark Lye, blamed his partners, who were also fined $200, for the pace. It took more than five hours for them to complete 18 holes.

title: William Stephens, 75, Former Steel Executive
description: William J. Stephens, former board chairman of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, died Sunday at his home in Hilton Head, S.C. He was 75 years old.

title: Relative's Questions Led To Baby-Selling Charge
description: The suspicions of a grandmother led to the arrest of her daughter and son-in-law on charges of selling their infant sons for $300 each to help pay the rent, the police said today.

title: Zellerbach Executive Shift
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation of San Francisco, which has been battered harder than others in the sagging forest-products industry, announced yesterday what it termed a major realignment of senior management responsibilities.

title: California Finds Flies; Cuts Off Mexican Fruit
description: California officials have stopped imports of Mexican fruit after finding fruit-fly larvae in crates of oranges bound for Santa Clara and San Mateo counties, it was announced today.

title: Business and the Law; Manufacturers And Recalls
description: While consumers have to deal with the relatively simple question of whether to return the 40 million cans of tuna packed by Bumble Bee Seafoods that were recalled this month, manufacturers involved in recalls face a host of more complicated legal questions.

title: POLISH LOAN CLAIMS UP $52 MILLION
description: The Agriculture Department has received claims from American banks for an additional $52 million of reimbursement for federally guaranteed farm commodity loans to Poland now overdue, a Commodity Credit Corporation offical said today.

title: ISRAELI GENERAL SAYS MISSION IS TO SMASH P.L.O. IN BEIRUT
description: Israel's Chief of Staff said today that Israeli troops had trapped guerrilla forces in West Beirut and had as their mission the smashing of the Palestine Liberation Organization's political and military nerve center there.

title: Taking Sides; Publish? Perish?
description: Since 1891, the ''manufacturing clause'' of the Copyright Act has forbidden importation and distribution of books by American authors that have been printed abroad. Writers who flout this economic protectionism lose the protection of their copyright.

title: Fish Harvested by Sound
description: Owls can hear a mouse far away on the forest floor. Dogs hear a range of sound frequencies far wider than those heard by humans. But what about fish that live in a semisolid environment?

title: YANKS AND METS MAKING A PITCH FOR HELP
description: The Yankees and the Mets were looking to acquire another starting pitcher before the trading deadline of 8 o'clock tonight, but neither club was optimistic that a deal would be made.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS HOPEFUL ON NAMIBIA TALKS
description: Reagan Administration officials believe that the delicate and complex negotiations to bring the South Africancontrolled territory of South-West Africa to independence as the new state of Namibia could reach a successful conclusion by the end of the year.

title: Another Round for the Homeless
description: John Klosterman and Earl Ruth, both former mental patients, may be living in New York City doorways and subway stations, but they have an excellent lawyer, Robert Hayes. While working for the prestigious firm of Sullivan and Cromwell, Mr. Hayes brought a suit that led to a consent decree requiring the city to provide emergency shelter for anyone requesting it. Now Mr. Hayes aims at a bigger target.

title: Tentative Pact Reached At Northwest Airlines
description: Northwest Airlines reached tentative agreement tonight on a new contract with mechanics and baggage handlers who have been on strike since May 21, a company official said.

title: Sunshine Mining Chief Is Seeking Alternatives
description: With silver currently trading at below $6 an ounce, mining for the metal is not the most profitable of endeavors these days. No one knows that better than G. Michael Boswell, chairman of the Sunshine Mining Company, one of the nation's largest silver mining operations. Mr. Boswell has just decided to close Sunshine's mine in Kellogg, Idaho, to wait for better prices. And he has also decided to get Sunshine into other businesses: oil, for one.

title: WEINBERGER CALLS HIS 'BASIC OUTLOOK' UNCHANGED
description: The word around Washington in recent weeks has been that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger is beginning to tone down his hard-line military views.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Condominium Sales Increase
description: Condominium purchases have doubled in the past two years as increasing numbers of older homeowners and retirees are shifting to smaller and generally less costly housing, according to a new housing study.

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 15, 1982; The Economy
description: The Government issued a new set of antitrust guidelines in an effort to reduce uncertainty over what kinds of corporate mergers it will allow. Though the new policy was described as more lenient, the Justice Department and the F.T.C. said they doubted that any significant increase in mergers would result. (Page A1.)

title: Dow Loses 7.89 on Rate Fears
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday after Friday's sharp advance because of investors' renewed apprehension about persistent high interest rates.

title: Citibank Raises Prime to 16 1/2%
description: Citibank, rejoining the rest of the banking industry, raised its prime rate yesterday back to 16 1/2 percent from 16 percent. The nation's second-largest commercial bank had lowered its prime on May 25, citing the lower cost of funds.

title: Playboy Club Plans to Move
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. announced that it would relocate its New York Playboy Club, and sell the existing site, at 5 East 59th Street, to the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation for more than $10 million.

title: Gibson and Harris Down to the Wire
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and City Council President Earl Harris campaigned vigorously today in the waning hours before their runoff election for Mayor Tuesday.

title: ELAINE MANDLE STRAUSS
description: Elaine Mandle Strauss, a polio victim who wrote ''In My Heart I'm Still Dancing,'' which is widely circulated at rehabilitation centers for polio patients, died last Saturday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. She was 66 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: E.E.C. Offers Credit Plan
description: Finance ministers of the European Economic Community today proposed an international export credit arrangement with minimum interest rates below those that some officials here feel are likely to be acceptable to the United States, heightening fears of an ''export credit war.''

title: Advertising; Campaign For Chain Of Saloons
description: A television commercial full of big-beat music, flashing lights and b eautiful people that promotes a gin mill named Brannigan's as a fun p lace for young people to drink and eat began running yesterday in n ine major markets. ''Come on, get happy,'' is the important and t imely message.

title: DATA ON PROTESTANT CHURCHES SHOW LOSSES MAY BE ENDING
description: Membership in United States churches is not keeping pace with population growth, but the decline that hit mainstream Protestant bodies in the 1960's appears to be ending, the National Council of Churches reported today.

title: SOUTHERN BAPTISTS' LEADER ASSAILS MODERATES
description: The outgoing president of the Southern Baptist Convention says there is no room in the denomination for humanists or those who do not accept the absolute inerrancy of the Bible.

title: THREAT TO U.S. LEADERSHIP IN SPACE PROJECT IS SEEN
description: A lack of consistent long-range goals and financial support, coupled with rising foreign competition, is seriously threatening United States leadership in nonmilitary space technology, according to a report released yesterday by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.

title: MOVE TO DESIGNATE THEATERS AS LANDMARKS IS DISCUSSED
description: Colleen Dewhurst, describing the recent demolition of the Helen Hayes and Morosco Theaters as ''calamities,'' appealed yesterday to the Landmarks Preservation Commission to grant landmark status to 45 Broadway theaters in order to protect them.

title: EGYPT SUSPENDS TALKS ON SELF-RULE FOR PALESTINIANS
description: Egypt told the United States today that it was suspending talks with Israel on Palestinian self-rule because of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Susan Bolotin THE SEVENTH GAME. By Roger Kahn. NAL Books/New American Library. 321 pages. $13.95.

title: Gasoline Prices Up
description: The average nationwide price of gasoline rose 6.4 cents a gallon in the last three weeks, even though dealers have cut their profit margin, according to Dan Lundberg, oil industry analyst. Mr. Lundberg said that his nationwide survey of 17,000 gas stations indicated that retailers have reduced their average per-gallon markup from 9.93 cents on April 16 to 8.81 cents as of last Saturday.

title: G.M. in Tunisia
description: The General Motors Corporation was to sign contracts today in Tunisia with four local investors to make cars and trucks there at a new plant in Kairouan starting in 1984, company sources said.

title: RAIDERS AGAIN BEAT N.F.L. IN THE COURTS
description: A judge in Federal District Court issued an injunction today that would allow the Oakland Raiders to move to the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum.

title: In the Spirit of an Evert
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, the tennis player, has been a symbol of consistency over the years. Now it appears that Chris Evert, the filly, is doing the same for thoroughbred racing.

title: Caterpillar Outlays
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company has further reduced its capital spending plans for 1982 to about $600 million from a recently projected $650 million, E.J. Schlegel, executive vice president, said yesterday in remarks prepared for security analysts. Caterpillar had originally projected spending of about $750 million. The company spent $836 million in 1981.

title: Steinbrenner's Sales Pitch
description: Would you buy a brand of beer if you saw George Steinbrenner endorsing it in a television commercial? Peter Kelley says the Yankees' boss has charisma and as much credibility as some established athletes.

title: ITT Virginia Plant Struck
description: Unionized workers struck the Roanoke County plant of International Telephone and Telegraph today in a dispute over renewal of a three-year contract. About 300 employees are affected by the first strike for Local 162, International Union of Electrical Workers, since it won representation at the plant 16 years ago. The contract expired Thursday.

title: TEEN-AGE HAPPY HOUR
description: ''To me it's strange,'' said Robert Frank, a middle-aged patron at a local bar, ''seeing a kid in here having a drink after a hard day at high school.''

title: Opinion Issued On Mesa Suit
description: The Cities Service Company said a Delaware court issued an opinion yesterday that the Mesa Petroleum Company should be enjoined from prosecuting the claims it brought against Cities Service in a suit filed in Beaumont, Tex., earlier this month.

title: Mego in Chapter 11
description: Mego International Inc., the toy maker and distributor, said that it and its Mego Corporation subsidiary have filed for court protection from creditors while it reorganizes under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: AMERICA'S MODEST WAGE INCREASES
description: To the Editor:

title: Abortion Activists Protest Pennsylvania Act
description: Abortion rights activists protested today outside the official residence of Gov. Dick Thornburgh because of an anti-abortion law he signed into law last week.

title: ISRAELI SOLDIERS ARE GIVEN FLOWERS AND COLD SODA
description: The Israeli tanks were poised here today on terraced hilltops overlooking the entire city of Beirut and the Mediterranean Sea.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Red Sox. Game 2 of the first visit by the Red Sox to Yankee Stadium this season again matches the pitchers of last Wednesday's 3-2 Yankee loss at Boston. Tommy John (4-6) of the Yankees will start against Bruce Hurst (2-1). John, who is 10-12 lifetime against Boston, gave up a home run to Tony Perez that was the difference. John went seven innings, gave up seven hits, walked two batters and struck out three. (Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates. The major league trading deadline is at 8 P.M. Eastern daylight time, and the Mets are in Pittsburgh on the anniversary of one of their more significant deals. In that one, in 1969, they got Donn Clendenon from the Montreal Expos for Kevin Collins, Steve Renko, Jay Carten and Dave Colon. They were in second place at the time and went on to win the World Series. Charley Puleo, acquired in another deal last season with the Toronto Blue Jays, starts for the Mets against Rick Rhoden (2-6). Puleo (5-3) has been the most consistent Mets starter lately. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570, and WBNX, 1380; 7:30 P.M.) Houston Astros vs. Atlanta Braves. (Television - Manhattan Cable, 8:30 P.M.) Basketball New York Professional Summer League. For those not sated by the National Basketball Association season that ended last week with the Lakers-76ers final, there are former, present and prospective N.B.A. players taking part in doubleheaders at 6:30 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays.

title: Concession by Mecom
description: Although he denied the assertion by Don Reese that half the members of the 1980 New Orleans team used cocaine, John Mecom, the Saints' owner, acknowledged that ''maybe 10 percent'' of the players used the drug that season, when the Saints' record was 1-15.

title: HINCKLEY INTERVIEWS DEBATED AT TRIAL
description: A 29-year-old prison psychiatrist today disputed a defense attorney's suggestion that John W. Hinckley Jr. had concealed his most bizarre thoughts from her because he wanted her to like him, and to have ''an idealized friendship relationship.''

title: Key's New Drug
description: Key Pharmaceuticals Inc., a Miami-based drug manufacturer, said it had signed an agreement in principle to acquire exclusive United States and Canadian distribution rights for Sobrerol, a bronchitis treatment made by Camillo Corvi S.p.A. of Italy.

title: Low-Cholesterol Eggs
description: Last year the nation's flock of roughly 286.5 million laying hens produced 69.6 billion eggs, 81 million fewer eggs than the year before. Nutritionists attribute the drop in production to consumers' fears about the health effects of the relatively high levels of cholesterol in egg yolks.

title: Raven's Wingspread Blacks Out Anchorage
description: A large raven has been blamed for an interruption in electric power that blacked out more than half the population of Alaska.

title: PALESTINIAN REFUGEES WILL NOT GO AWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: TREASURY ISSUES OFF SHARPLY
description: Responding to an array of negative developments, prices of Government securities fell sharply yesterday, sending some yields to their highest levels since late February.

title: Norcen Appeals Hanna Ruling
description: Norcen Energy Resources Ltd., a Toronto-based oil company, said it had appealed last Friday's Federal court ruling that blocked Norcen from buying a controlling share of the Hanna Mining Company, based in Cleveland.

title: POLICY ON BIDDING UNDERCUTS DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Lefty' Meteorites TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: In his article ''Meteorite Found to Be 'Left-Handed' '' (May 4), Walter Sullivan commits an error made by many chemists. It is true that all asymmetrical amino acids involved in living processes on this planet may be considered to be ''left-handed.''

title: U.S. IS EASING '68 ANTITRUST GUIDELINES ON MERGERS
description: The Government, seeking to reduce uncertainty about the types of corporate mergers that it will allow, today published a new set of enforcement guidelines ''more lenient'' than previous antitrust policy.

title: Challenged Claims: 8 Ads Stand, 5 Do Not
description: In May, the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus resolved 13 challenges to national advertising claims.

title: FALCONE AND ALLEN COMBINE ON 6-HITTER
description: A two-run homer by Ellis Valentine and some flashy defense by the Mets' young middle infielders gave Pete Falcone a 2-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

title: Air Florida Loss
description: Air Florida System Inc., citing reduced air traffic and the depressed economy, said that its second-quarter loss would be larger than previously expected. The airline also said that it had revised its earlier projection of a 1982 profit to a loss.

title: Bombs Explode in Spain And Sniper Kills Guard
description: Four bombs exploded in Madrid today and a sniper killed a civil guard in the Basque region.

title: GUIDRY WINS 8th, STRIKING OUT 7; COLLINS HOMERS
description: The Yankees needed more than a third of the season, but last night they finally displayed the speed and aggressiveness they had promised before the season began.

title: '62, '72 AND NOW '82 FOR NICKLAUS AT 42?
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. B ehind the 18th green, near the rocky shore where sea otters seem to laugh at golfers truding by, the big white leader board for the 82d United States Open has no names or numbers on it yet. But when Jack Nicklaus tees off early Thursday, his name will be up there as he tries to win a record fifth Open championship. If he succeeds, he will be one up on Ben Hogan, Bobby Jones and Willie Anderson.

title: Rehnquist Again in Hospital
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist has been admitted to George Washington University Hospital for ''minor surgery,'' the Supreme Court spokesman, Barrett McGurn, said today. The 57-year-old justice was treated in December for treatment of a chronic back problem and adverse drug reaction.

title: DEFENSE DELIVERS SUMMATION AT CUNNINGHAM TRIAL
description: The defense summed up yesterday in the Patrick J. Cunningham tax trial and accused John S. Martin Jr., the United States Attorney, of ''prosecutorial arrogance'' and of creating a case based on ''smear and innuendo.''

title: Connecticut Given Disaster Status
description: President Reagan declared all of Connecticut a major disaster area today, members of Congress reported. The White House press office refused to confirm the decision, but said an announcement would be made today.

title: CORRECTION
description: The book review yesterday of ''A Man's Life,'' by Roger Wilkins, incor- rectly described a 1973 Pulitzer Prize that resulted from the Watergate case. The award, for meritorious pub- lic service, went to The Washington Post.

title: Iran-Japan Oil Sales
description: Several Japanese trading houses and oil companies have agreed to long-term contracts with the National Iranian Oil Company to import Iranian crude, industry sources said today. In total, contracts that have been or are close to completion will involve the import of between 90,000 and 100,000 barrels daily, one source estimated.

title: U.N. ENVOYS WARY ON ARMS OUTLOOK
description: Now that the demonstrators who flooded New York over the weekend have returned home, the delegates left at the General Assembly's special session on disarmament are facing an unpleasant truth: whatever they do here, they say, is almost certain to be a big letdown to those eager for major steps toward nuclear disarmament.

title: THE 'DIRTY TRADE' THAT HANDICAPS U.S. ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRE AND SMOKE BLOCK 5 UNDERGROUND LINES
description: Service on three northbound West Side subway lines and two PATH lines was disrupted yesterday evening. A track fire forced the Transit Authority to shut off power on uptown tracks at 5:50 P.M. Service on the No. 1 line was cut from South Ferry to 96th Street.

title: Saudi Burial Practices Alike for Rich or Poor
description: After King Khalid of Saudi Arabia died Sunday, his body was wrapped in a light brown cloth and buried without ceremony in an unmarked grave. Grounded both in Islamic law and custom, Saudi burial practice, according to Dr. Eqbal Ahmad, an authority on Islam, is the same for king and pauper alike.

title: 8 Workers Injured In Water Tunnel
description: Eight workers in a water tunnel under construction were injured yesterday, two of them seriously, by two runaway rail cars. The incident occurred at 12:30 P.M. in the area beneath 242d Street and Katonah Avenue in the Bronx, according to John Cunningham, a spokesman for the city's Environmental Protection Agency.

title: News Analysis
description: The reported surrender of Argentine forces in the Falkland Islands has forced Argentina, a nation that has never lived up to its own expectations, to ponder why and what next.

title: Slump in Tin Prices
description: Tin slumped to 17-month lows on continued selling as there were fears for the future of the international tin agreement that aims to stabilize world prices, dealers said.

title: RCA Telex Plan
description: RCA Global Communications said it had filed with the Federal Communications Commission to provide telex service between the United States and Canada, a $30 million market that it said was now served only by the Western Union Telegraph Company. The RCA Corporation unit said that it had agreed to offer the service with CNCP Telecommunications of Canada, although an agreement has yet to be signed. Alan Garratt, a spokesman for RCA Global, said that the service would be in place by the end of the summer, pending F.C.C. approval.

title: U.S. MOVES TO STABILIZE CURRENCY
description: The Reagan Administration, for only the second time, intervened today in the international currency markets in an attempt to smooth out what it called ''disorderly markets,'' according to Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan.

title: IN LEBANON, WHITE FLAGS FLY AMID THE MISERY AND RUBBLE
description: Along the battered Lebanese coast, in the wake of the invasion, white flags still fly. They flutter from the antennas of cars without windows or windshields. They hang from bamboo poles stuck into the shell-pocked roofs and verandas of concrete houses. Even some pedestrians carried torn strips of white cloth to signify their neutrality, their surrender to the storm of war.

title: Wieboldt Fills Post
description: David C. Keller, 61, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Wieboldt Stores Inc., a financially troubled departmentstore chain. Mr. Keller, who will continue to serve as treasurer, will be the Chicago-based retailer's first chief executive officer in the company's 97-year history. Arthur K. Muenze abruptly resigned as president in December.

title: HIGH CALIFORNIA INTEREST RATES LURED INVESTORS TO BIG LOSSES
description: The great California land rush of the 1970's has soured into disaster for thousands of investors in California and other states, according to regulators. Those lured by promises of interest rates of 25 percent or more invested billions of dollars in home mortgages and now stand to lose more than $250 million, the officials say.

title: Dodgers 4, Padres 3
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Dusty Baker homered with two outs in the 11th inning to lift Los Angeles over San Diego before a crowd of 49,973, the second largest in the history of the Padres.

title: U.S. Official Has Manila Talks
description: Deputy Secretary of State Walter J. Stoessel Jr. arrived in Manila today for two days of talks with Philippine leaders on the world situation, regional issues and United States-Philippine relations. He is scheduled to leave Wednesday for Singapore to meet with foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which groups the Philippines, Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand.

title: CALIFORNIA SUPREME COURT ASKED TO DECIDE ON CRIME BILL'S LEGALITY
description: Attorney General George Deukmejian, the Republican nominee for governor, today asked the California Supreme Court to decide whether an anticrime measure passed by the voters was constitutional and enforceable.

title: Nicaraguan Exile in Plea To Socialist International
description: Eden Pastora, a former Nicaraguan revolutionary leader, appealed to the Socialist International today to reconsider its support for the present Nicaraguan Government.

title: A Merciful Falkland Finish
description: That ''de facto cease-fire'' in the Falklands is, de facto, an Argentine surrender. Britain's strangulation of Port Stanley was the moral and honorable substitute for a final bloodbath. For their courage in acknowledging defeat, the departing Argentines will deserve an old-fashioned battlefield salute. Then let the bloody posturing finally end.

title: Imprecise Language TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: In your article ''Birth Control: 4-Day Pill Is Promising in Early Test'' (April 20), you repeatedly misuse the term ''contraception.''

title: Indians Sweep Tigers
description: CLEVELAND (UPI) - The Indians snapped a five-game losing streak by taking a doubleheader from the Tigers, who are in second place in the American League East.

title: COURT BARS ALASKA FROM CASH PAYOUT
description: The Supreme Court today invalidated Alaska's plan to distribute its oil revenue windfall among its citizens on the basis of length of residence in the state.

title: Suspect Pleads Not Guilty
description: A former city employee today pleaded not guilty to charges stemming from the Memorial Day attack in which Mayor A.J. Rumely was critically wounded and his wife, Frances, killed. Harold W. Lang, 31, was ordered held without bail at Laporte County Jail on charges of murder, attempted murder and burglary. Judge Robert Gettinger of the LaPorte Circuit Court set an Aug. 17 trial date. Mr. Rumely, 71, was in critical but stable condition in the intensive care unit at St. Joseph's Medical Center at South Bend.

title: WATT ANNOUNCES PLAN TO SELL 5% OF U.S. LANDS
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt said today that the Federal Government planned to sell up to 5 percent of its real estate over the next several years, but promised that National Parks and areas with ''unique characteristics and national values'' would not be put on the market.

title: Utah Judge Steps Out of Trial He Said Was Open and Shut
description: A state district judge today waived a jury trial for Marc Francis Schreuder, who is accused with his mother of murdering his grandfather, who was a millionaire. The judge, Jay E. Banks, then disqualified himself from the case.

title: U.S. Aid Halt On Shale Oil
description: The directors of the United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation authorized termination today of $1.1 billion in Federal loan guarantees for the halted Exxon-Tosco Colony Shale Oil Project in Colorado, clearing the way for the Tosco Corporation to sell its 40 percent share in the project to Exxon.

title: BRIEFING
description: No to Public Relations

title: ROLE OF F.B.I. ON NOMINEES IS STUDIED
description: The case of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan has raised the question of precisely what role the Federal Bureau of Investigation is supposed to play in checking into the background of Presidential nominees.

title: Economic Analysis
description: There is hardly a sector of the economy now that has not been stymied by high interest rates. But there is no agreement on how to bring them down. Congress wants more money growth, in exchange for lower deficits, while the ''monetarists'' contend that such growth would just push interest rates up by reigniting fears of inflation. At the center of the dispute, as always, stands the Federal Reserve Board, and the Fed, faced with a continuing sharp recession, is in the tightest corner it has been since its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, set his anti-inflation course in October 1979.

title: Ambassador to Venezuela
description: President Reagan today nominated George W. Landau, a career foreign service officer, as ambassador to Venezuela. Mr. Landau, 62 years old, most recently served as executive director of the Presidential Commission on Broadcasting to Cuba. He had held two ambassadorial posts, in Chile from 1977 to 1982, and in Paraguay from 1972 to 1977.

title: 'Baby' Dubbed American Bell
description: ''Baby Bell'' is finally being christened. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, ending months of industry speculation, has decided on a name for the fully separated subsidiary that will enter deregulated telecommunications markets.

title: No Headline
description: Because of typographical errors in Robert Manning's article Saturday, ''When U.P. Had No I.,'' the reporter Merriman Smith's first name was misspelled.

title: CALIFANO CITES 50% INCREASE IN HEROIN ADDICTION IN CITY
description: The number of heroin addicts in New York City has increased by 50 percent since 1978, a new report to Governor Carey said yesterday. The report estimated that there were 163,000 to 177,500 addicts in the city, or one addict for every 40 to 43 residents. It said the total in New York State was 234,000, or one of every 75 residents. The report said there were 450,000 to 600,000 heroin addicts in the United States, or one of every 375 to 500 Americans.

title: G.O.P. GATHERS FOR 'WIDE OPEN' STATE CONVENTION
description: With private maneuvers to reduce the four-candidate field for Governor, and balloons, buttons and a splash of wall posters, Republicans converged on the city yesterday for what their chairman called ''the most wide-open convention in Republican history in New York State.''

title: Plows and Erosion TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: I would not have expected to find the moldboard plow a feature story in The New York Times. However, I am delighted to have my provincial notions corrected with the publication of ''Erosion-Wary Farmers Are Spurning the Traditional Plow'' (May 11).

title: Fireman's Fund
description: The Fireman's Fund Insurance Companies, a subsidiary of the American Express Company, said it had reached agreement with the Sime Darby Group of Malaysia calling for the companies to acquire equity interests in each other's insurance operations and to exchange technical and marketing resources in five South-east Asian nations and Hong Kong. Sime Darby is the largest publicly owned nonbank corporation in the five Asian nations and Fireman's Fund is the 10th-largest property-liability insurer in the United States. Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Text of Soviet statement, page A20.
description: The Soviet Government warned Israel today not to forget that the Middle East was close to the Soviet Union's southern borders and that developments in that area ''cannot help affecting the interests of the U.S.S.R.''

title: Williams Of Nets Is Top Rookie
description: AYEAR after he decided to leave the University of Maryland after hisj unior season to enter the National Basketball Association draft, B uck Williams, the New Jersey Nets' forward, will be honored as the l eague's rookie of the year.

title: THEATER: WONDERLAND CHARACTERS IN 'LOOKING-GLASS'
description: ''LOOKING-GLASS,'' which opened at the Entermedia last night, is an actors' delight. Characters metamorphose; they are transmogrified. A student, sitting on a sofa, becomes the Mad Hatter. A chaplain, trotting about Oxford, becomes the White Rabbit. It is not magic; metamorphosis and transmogrification are patented acting techniques, and they make up much of the charm of ''Looking-Glass.'' The rest of the charm, a considerable amount, is supplied by John Vickery, who plays Charles Dodgson. He metamorphoses, in a way, into Lewis Carroll.

title: UNIONS MAY BAN OUTSIDE CAMPAIGN CONTRIBUTIONS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a labor union is legally free to prohibit candidates for union office from accepting campaign contributions from sources outside the union.

title: To Err May Also Be Costly
description: To err may be human, but when the International Business Machines Corporation makes a mistake, it is costly to correct. Because of a technical error in the proxy solicitation sent out last spring, I.B.M. had to void a vote of the stockholders at the annual meeting on April 26.

title: AMERICA'S MODEST WAGE INCREASES
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Taking 'No' for 'Maybe'

title: Q&A
description: Q. Do horses have to be destroyed when they break their legs? Why can't their legs be set instead?

title: 'DEATHTRAP,' 'THERAPY' CLOSE
description: ''DEATHTRAP,'' Ira Levin's thriller, ended its long Broadway run Sunday at the Biltmore, and ''Beyond Therapy,'' Christopher Durang's new comedy, also closed that day. As a result, the number of shows playing on Broadway is down to 24, compared to 31 at this time last year.

title: TAX BENEFIT SALE CALLED COSTLY
description: Congressional tax experts reported today that the sale of tax benefits through leasing, as authorized by Congress in 1981, appears to be more wasteful than was estimated by the Treasury.

title: SLAIN MAN IS LINKED TO INQUIRY
description: A former Teamster whose body was found in the trunk of a car in Manhattan last Friday had been interviewed in connection with the Federal investigation of Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan, authorities said early this morning.

title: TWO FASHION TEAMS THAT STARTED SMALL
description: Jill Kollmar and Marianne Smith met at boarding school when they were 15 years old. They now design and manufacture sweaters under the name Smith Kollmar.

title: CHASE LOWERS DRYSDALE WRITE-OFF
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it would take a $117 million after-tax write-off in its second fiscal quarter as a result of its dealings with Drysdale Government Securities, an improvement over the $135 million write-off the bank said it anticipated last month.

title: NEW THERAPY APPEARS CAPABLE OF STOPPING HEART ATTACK'S PROGRESS
description: EACH day, more than 4,000 Americans suffer heart attacks. They result from destruction of a large number of heart muscle cells because of a stoppage of the flow of blood - usually from a clot - through a coronary artery. Precisely how long it takes for completion of a heart attack is not known. But it happens relatively quickly, within a few hours.

title: NOW IT'S CABLE PASTIME
description: L ike the winds that often play tricks with fly balls in the outfield, a shift in the television policies of major league baseball teams has had an unsettling effect on the sport.

title: SOCIAL ACTIVISM SPROUTS AS INDIA'S POLITICS DECAY
description: In all but a handful of the 350 administrative districts of India, there are groups of volunteers administering social programs and rural development plans intended to better the lives and raise the hopes of the downtrodden.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 15, 1982
description: International Argentines have begun surrendering in the Falkland Islands capital of Stanley, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced. Mrs. Thatcher disclosed that the deputy commander of British land forces was negotiating surrender terms with the commander of the 6,500 Argentine defenders of the town. Government officials said they expected surrender documents to be signed today. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israeli tanks circled western Beirut, trapping the military and political leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The Beirut siege came as the Lebanese Government of President Elias Sarkis announced the formation of a six-member national salvation board to deal with the repercussions of the invasion. (A1:1.)

title: PLAYERS
description: C arl Yastrzemski was knocked down by a fastball recently. He got up and promptly lined a single. ''You can't knock Yaz down,'' said Ralph Houk, the Red Sox manager, ''because it makes him 20 years younger.''

title: WEBSTER MCDONALD, NEGRO LEAGUE PITCHER
description: Webster McDonald, a pitching star in the Negro baseball leagues from 1919 through 1939, died in Philadelphia last Saturday at the age of 82. He had been ailing since being attacked by muggers several months ago.

title: COUNCIL SEEKS $83 MILLION IN CHANGES IN KOCH BUDGET
description: Leaders of the City Council said yesterday that they hoped to make $83.5 million worth of changes and additions in Mayor Koch's budget for 1,000 more police officers and for public schools, libraries, fire marshals and pruning of trees.

title: U.S. to Supply Britain With Trident Missiles
description: The Defense Department said today that it had notified Congress of the intent to sell Britain the Trident D-5 submarine-launched strategic nuclear missile system for about $3.9 billion.

title: U.S. ANNOUNCES NEW POLICY FOR PAROLE OF SOME HAITIANS
description: The Justice Department announced today that it was issuing guidelines for the release of some Haitians from Federal detention facilities. The Haitians would be paroled to sponsors while they awaited hearings on whether they would be deported.

title: Downeast Orchestra To Play in White House
description: The Downeast Chamber Orchestra, composed of youths from New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, has been invited by Nancy Reagan to give a concert at the White House tomorrow. Members of the five-year-old ensemble, which won the National Youth Orchestra Competition in 1979, are 14 to 22 years of age and spend summers in Castine, Me., to attend music school and perform in weekly concerts.

title: BRITAIN ANNOUNCES ARGENTINE SURRENDER TO END THE 10-WEEK WAR IN THE FALKLANDS
description: Argentine forces in the Falkland Islands have surrendered, halting the war in the South Atlantic, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's office announced early this morning.

title: REARMING ARGENTINA
description: After Stanley falls, Argentina certainly will aggressively seek more weapons. This would present a tough policy dilemma for Washington, caught between a desire to restore relations with Argentina and not damage those with Britain.

title: SPACE AGENCY SWITCHES TIME OF SHUTTLE LANDING ON JULY 4
description: The space agency said today it has decided to delay the space shuttle's Fourth of July landing in California by one orbit, and an aerospace magazine said the move was designed to give President Reagan an extra hour of sleep.

title: WHAT PARTY COMMITTEES DO, AND WHY
description: In an intensive 10 days of political activity, the Democratic, Republican, Conservative, Right to Life and Liberal Party state committees will designate candidates for Governor, Lieutenant Governor, State Comptroller, Attorney General and United States Senator.

title: Union Oil and U.S.  In Consent Order
description: The Energy Department said it had reached a $25 million proposed consent order with the Union Oil Company of California to settle charges of violations of Federal oilprice controls from 1973 to 1981.

title: Sailor Trying to Cross Atlantic in Small Boat
description: After a sendoff under grey skies, Bill Dunlop spent his first day at sea today in a nine-foot sailboat, heading across the Atlantic.

title: France Demands That Israel Stop All Attacks in Lebanon
description: President Francois Mitterrand demanded today that Israel stop all attacks in Lebanon in an appeal directed to Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who arrived hours earlier to explain his nation's invasion.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: POLITICOS

title: Convicted Killer Charged
description: Robert Dale Henderson, a convicted murderer who has confessed to killing 12 people in five states, was charged Saturday with three more slayings in Florida. Mr. Henderson, 37 years old, who already was serving life sentences for two Florida slayings, was charged with killing three Mississippi hitchhikers in February.

title: American Bakeries Names Top Officer
description: The American Bakeries Company announced the appointment yesterday of E. Garrett Bewkes Jr. as chairman, president and chief executive officer.

title: The U.N. Today; June 15, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the Cyprus peacekeeping force at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 3 Arrows Are Fined
description: Two New York Arrows' forwards and Coach Don Popovic, along with a St. Louis Steamers' player, have been fined and suspended for pushing, kicking and grabbing during the fourth game of the Major Indoor Soccer League championship series last month.

title: Orioles 9, Brewers 4
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Dan Ford capped a five-run seventh inning with a pinch-hit, grand-slam homer to lead Baltimore past Milwaukee.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report May 28 on a Rockland County physician who believes he is the boy in a World War II Holocaust picture incorrectly identified the liberators of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. They were the British Eighth Army.

title: MUBARAK CONSULTS SAUDIS' NEW KING
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt flew here today for the first meeting of Saudi and Egyptian leaders since Saudi Arabia and most other Arab countries broke ties with Cairo in 1979 to protest its peace treaty with Israel.

title: SILENT EXPLOSION OF A SINGLE PROTON COULD FORTELL FATE OF THE UNIVERSE
description: SOUDAN, Minn. MEN used to descend into the depths of the earth here in search of matter so visible and tactile that there could be no missing it. Its heft almost broke their backs. It was so seemingly everlasting that out of it nations built their places in the cosmos. The matter the men dug out of the depths here was ore containing a richness of iron.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: Scholastic aptitude tests encourage sloth and frivolity, while achievement tests reward diligence and serious study. These are the conclusions of Christopher Jencks, a sociologist, and James Crouse, a professor of educational studies. They propose that aptitude tests, which in theory measure a student's potential ability to do college work, be abolished and replaced with achievement tests, which measure what students have learned in a specific course of study.

title: Suspended Officer Accused of Bribery
description: The indictment of Serge Gervais, a suspended city police officer, on charges of accepting a bribe and grand larceny was announced yesterday.

title: CAREY SCOLDS REAGAN, FINDS BUDGET ADVICE LACKING IN PRUDENCE
description: Governor Carey has charged that some statements by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan exhibit ''a severe lack of professional standards and an abdication of the principles of prudent bugeting.''

title: Latvian Emigre Says Soviet Is Expanding a Naval Harbor
description: The Soviet Navy is enlarging its base at Liepaja in Latvia as part of a program to strengthen its Baltic fleet, according to a Latvian emigre here.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., has named Frank V. AtLee president of its Europe/Mideast/Africa division.

title: An All-Ad Catalogue Of the Catalogues
description: American Theatre Press, publishers of Playbill, is moving into a quite different type of publication in a joint venture with the Print Project.

title: RICHEST IN HISTORY
description: The figures are not all in yet, but the Larry Holmes-Gerry Cooney title fight easily broke boxing's gross-receipts record. Mike Cohen of Momentum Enterprises, which handled the closed-circuit television arrangements for last Friday night's fight from Las Vegas, Nev., said the gross could be nearly $50 million. But Dan Duva, who promoted the Sugar Ray Leonard-Thomas Hearns welterweight title fight last Sept.16, in which the previous mark of nearly $38 million was set, said the heavyweight clash would gross $42 million to $45 million.

title: OWNERS BACK MOVE TO ALTER KUHN ROLE
description: The owners of major league baseball teams unanimously endorsed a program today to change the role of the commissioner and to have all 26 clubs vote in concert on proposed changes, rather than by leagues.

title: RIOT POLICE IN POLAND USE TEAR GAS TO CRUSH PROTEST OVER ARMY RULE
description: Polish riot policemen used tear gas and water cannon in two cities over the weekend to disperse demonstrators protesting six months of martial law, the press agency P.A.P. said today.

title: ISRAELI ENVOY HAS NEW OPERATION
description: Ambassador Shlomo Argov of Israel, who was critically wounded 11 days ago in an assassination attempt, underwent surgery today to assist his breathing and repair his wounds, the National Hospital for Nervous Diseases said.

title: Bea Traub, Consultant On Fashion to Notables
description: Bea Traub, a retired fashion consultant to many of the nation's best-dressed women and the mother of Marvin S. Traub, chairman of Bloomingdale's, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 81 years old.

title: Profits Off for Producers
description: After-tax profits of the nation's manufacturers dropped to an average of 3.8 cents per dollar of sales in the year's first quarter, the Federal Trade Commission reported today. The figure, one of the lowest in recent years, was down fivetenths of a cent from the previous quarter and nine-tenths of a cent from the first quarter of 1981.

title: Baker Pledges He'll Act On Voting Rights Bill
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, said today that he would meet with Republican and Democratic leaders in an attempt to speed action on extending the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: POPE MAKING 12-HOUR TRIP TODAY TO RED CROSS AND I.L.O. IN GENEVA
description: Pope John Paul II will take his message of peace and social justice to Geneva Tuesday in his third foreign trip in less than three weeks.

title: New York Enters Its Bid For '84 Marathon Trials
description: The success of the New York City Marathon, Fifth Avenue Mile, L'eggs Mini-Marathon and other distance races has established New York as a road-racing capital. Now the New York Road Runners Club has filed a bid to stage the 1984 United States Olympic men's and women's marathon trials in Manhattan.

title: Iran Dissidents Offer to Send 100,000 to Fight in Lebanon
description: Guerrillas opposed to the Iranian Islamic regime offered today to send 100,000 volunteers to fight Israeli forces in Lebanon and asked Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, to release 40,000 others from jails to join them.

title: Japan Economy Weaker in '81
description: The Japanese economy, depressed by sagging exports, grew at the lackluster rate of 2.7 percent in the fiscal year 1981 ended March 31, the Government has reported. The growth rate was the lowest since 1974, when the Arab oil embargo caused the economy to contract by two-tenths of 1 percent.

title: SALVADORAN TROOPS AND GUERRILLAS REPORT HEAVIEST FIGHTING OF WAR
description: Salvadoran Government troops and guerrillas are engaged in what a military spokesman says is perhaps the fiercest combat of the two-and-a-half-year-old war here.

title: BUSH'S AID ON E.R.A. IS ASKED
description: Seven women ending the fourth week of a fast for the proposed equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution asked Vice President Bush today for a meeting they say is imperative for the amendment's survival.

title: INVENTORIES: A NEW PHILOSOPHY
description: In Louisville, Ky., the Ford Motor Company produces heavy trucks. As interest rates soared in the late 1970's, and Ford became increasingly conscious of the burdensome cost of carrying inventories, that plant, along with other Ford plants, was subjected to a major inventory reduction campaign. In tires alone, the truck plant reduced its stockpiles by $1.8 million, while its inventory of drive shafts was reduced by $2 million.

title: Taking Sides; Cheerleaders
description: People who went to the giant disarmament demonstration in Central Park Saturday reported later that the mood was overwhelmingly genial. People who watched on Channel 13 couldn't tell that for sure from reporting that at times was strident and loaded.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 52-year-old woman was arrested and charged with drowning her 3-year-old foster son, whose body was found by the police shortly after 5:30 P.M. in the bathtub of the woman's apartment at 3609 Broadway in uppper Manhattan. The police identified the woman as Rosemarie Lewis and the boy as Gerard Jones.... A Brooklyn teen-ager was shot by two police officers at 5 P.M. in the Brownsville section after he turned on them with a gun, the police said.

title: 1,600 ARE ARRESTED IN NUCLEAR PROTESTS AT 5 U.N. MISSIONS
description: Offering daisies to policemen or chanting prayers for peace, more than 1,600 nonviolent demonstrators for disarmament were arrested in midtown Manhattan yesterday as they tried to block the entrances of the United Nations missions of five countries that have atomic weapons.

title: 16 Go on Trial in Korea In Burning of U.S. Center
description: Sixteen people, including a man accused of plotting to overthrow President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea, went on trial today on charges of burning down a United States cultural center.

title: VIETNAMESE BLAME CHINESE FOR WOES
description: ''Do you know that 85 percent of the people in Bangkok are Chinese?'' asked a low-ranking Vietnamese official. ''This is a fact,'' he said.

title: McEnroe Put at No. 1
description: Americans got the first four seeded places today in both men's and women's singles for the Wimbledon tennis championships.

title: Art From 3 Continents Planned for City Tour
description: Twenty-eight works of art from three continents and many cultures and now in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum's Michael Rockefeller Wing will tour the city during the next nine months, after an exhibition in the lobby of Avery Fisher Hall, in Lincoln Center.

title: Flood Damage In Connecticut
description: Businesses and factories across southern Connecticut suffered $107 million in flood damage as a result of the heavy rains two weeks ago, the state's Department of Economic Development said.

title: ARGENTINE REPORTS A TRUCE BUT IS SILENT ON A SURRENDER
description: Argentine officials had no comment early today on the British announcement that Argentine forces had surrendered in a two-and-a-half month effort to seize control of the Falkland Islands.

title: SOVIET HUNGER STRIKER OBTAINS HIS U.S. VISA
description: Andrei Frolov, a member of a group of Soviet citizens seeking to join family members abroad, today obtained the United States visa he needs to join his wife in Chicago.

title: Telefunken, Banks Reach Agreement
description: AEG-Telefunken said it and its banks had agreed in principle on a plan to restructure the troubled electrical products maker.

title: Fasting for Feminism
description: Sixty-nine years ago this month a British suffragist named Emily Wilding Davison threw herself in front of the King's horse on the Derby racetrack and was killed. She had long believed that a woman's sacrificing her life in the name of female suffrage might help bring it about.

title: SCHMIDT BIDS WORLD CHIEFS HEED ANTINUCLEAR PROTESTS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany warned his fellow politicians today that they were ignoring the growing popular demand for halting the nuclear arms race at their own peril.

title: THE VOICES OF CHILDREN
description: After a demonstration for living such as the extraordinary gathering that enveloped New York City on Saturday, there is an urge - probably born of adult vanity and pomposity -to say something momentous. Honesty tells us to keep it simple. And the simplest thoughts this time are those of our children.

title: BUS-ONLY LANES TO BE INCREASED TO SPEED TRAVEL
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday the creation of a system of 10 ''red zone'' lanes for buses in Manhattan to help relieve traffic congestion, increase bus speeds and reduce what has long been the bane of bus travelers - bus bunching.

title: ITALY IN TIE
description: Brazil rallied from a 1-0 halftime deficit with two goals in the final 15 minutes today to score a 2-1 victory over the Soviet Union in their opening match of the World Cup soccer championships.

title: Quotation of the Day
