description: ''The present-day Israeli policy makers should not forget that the Middle East is an area lying in close proximity to the southern borders of the Soviet Union and that developments there cannot help affecting the interests of the U.S.S.R. We warn Israel about this.'' - Soviet Government statement. (A20:1.)

title: CUBS HALT SKID AT 13
description: The Cubs snapped a 13-game losing streak today with a 12-11 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. Bump Wills had four hits, including a three-run homer, to highlight a 19-hit Chicago attack against five pitchers.

title: EDUCATION
description: Some blame the community school district. Others cite the school's former principal. Still others blame a chain of events that began the day the school opened.

title: SYRIANS REPORT SKIRMISHES WITH ISRAELI UNITS
description: Syrian troops joined Palestinian forces last night and today in fighting at Khalde, south of Beirut, near the Beirut international airport and in the hills southeast of the Lebanese capital, informed Syrians reported tonight.

title: Beth Heiden's New Turn
description: The Heiden name may be back in the Olympic spotlight again. Beth Heiden has already been a world champion in speed skating and cycling, but apparently those challenges did not satisfy her competitive curiosity.

title: A Place for the Palestinians
description: Do Israel's ends in Lebanon, now also those of America, justify the horrendous means? Only if the Palestinian roots of the problem are properly addressed at last.

title: REAGAN WELCOMES HALT IN FIGHTING
description: President Reagan welcomed the end of fighting in the Falkland Islands today and pledged the United States to assist ''in any way it can'' to produce a lasting political settlement.

title: Allied Gives Retail Outlook
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, one of the country's largest department-and specialty-store operators, has found that sales trends have improved since the end of the first quarter, ''but we doubt that there will be any meaningful improvement in the climate for retailing until the second half of the year,'' said Thomas M. Macioce, president and chief executive officer. He spoke at the annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: THE JUBILANT BRITONS ACCLAIM THEIR PRIME MINISTER
description: Coming back to 10 Downing Street Monday night, after making her victorious statement in Parliament, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher found a crowd of jubilant supporters standing behind police barricades singing ''Rule, Britannia'' and ''For She's a Jolly Good Fellow.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Asian Development Bank said it planned to offer $400 million of zero coupon notes due in 1992 through an underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: Soviet Accuses British Of Jingoism in Victory
description: Soviet reports today on the British victory in the Falkland Islands said a ''new flare-up of jingoism'' in Britain obscured the fact that the problem was far from solved.

title: New Gould Model
description: Gould Inc. introduced a new super-minicomputer that it said was five times faster in certain applications than its existing model and competitors' machines. The Concept 32/8780 will have a base price of $330,000 and is being made by the former Systems Engineering Laboratories, a company Gould acquired in December 1980.

title: A.T.& T. MOVES INTO DATA FIELD
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company officially announced its entry into the data processing business yesterday, outlining plans for a new subsidiary and a new data communications service.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Vectors Associates, an airplane service company at Stewart Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Addendum
description: * Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Publications to acquire American Automatic Merchandiser magazine from the co-founders/publishers, Mike Michaels and Ben Ginsberg.

title: Kroger Divestiture
description: The Kroger Company said it had reached tentative agreements to divest itself of most of its California-based Market Basket stores, which it has owned since 1963.

title: FUNDS CUT, WNET-TV TO LAY OFF 40
description: As a result of reductions in Federal funds and other national economic factors, WNET-TV is planning to cut its budget by $9.5 million, lay off 40 of its staff members and freeze management salaries.

title: PIANIST: MUSSORGSKY
description: ANN ZALKIND'S performance of Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall lacked the technical assurance and coloristic subtlety that we demand in exhibitions of these images, but the playing was never careless. Chordal voicings were precisely balanced; melodic lines were vocally shaped.

title: Virginia Corrections Official Found Shot Dead in His Office
description: A top state corrections official was found fatally shot Monday morning in the hallway of his office. The police said they were not ruling out the possibility that the official shot himself.

title: ARGENTINE SANCTIONS CONTINUE
description: Despite the British recapture of the Falkland Islands, London's European allies will maintain their ban on Argentine imports for the immediate future, an official of the European Economic Community said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Behind Them: Waiting, Ahead: More Waiting

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: There is a kind of predictability about life in New York. Lines for takeout coffee will be long at 9 A.M. On rainy days there will be no cabs, or at least none without passengers. Only one side of the door to the express train will open at rush hour. The ideal apartment will be taken by the time you arrive to look at it.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL TO CUT TOP SALARIES
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, projecting a loss for the first half of 1982, said yesterday that it would cut salaries of about 250 of its executives as of July 1. They also may forfeit their year-end bonuses, the company said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ART BEFORE ANYTHING

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SINCE coming to this country more than 40 years ago, I have naturally been exposed to a good deal of American cooking, and I have an abundant liking for much of it, whether it be a Philadelphia pepper pot that is made with tripe, a creole gumbo, Brunswick stew or pumpkin pie.

title: CONSERVATIVE TEXAN IS ELECTED PRESIDENT OF SOUTHERN BAPTISTS
description: The Southern Baptist Convention today elected the Rev. Dr. James T. Draper as president of the 13-millionmember congregation. Dr. Draper, a staunch conservative who is pastor of the First Baptist Church in Euless, Tex., was elected on the second ballot cast at the denomination's annual meeting here.

title: TROUBLED TIMES FOR JAN STEPHENSON
description: I t may be some months before Jan Stephenson is allowed to spend or invest any or all of the $30,000 purse she earned Sunday, when she won the 28th annual Ladies Professional Golf Association championship. She may not even be able to give her father the Mazda sports car that went along with the victory as she wants to.

title: WELFARE CUTOFFS BLOCKED AFTER PLEA OF TAX PRIVACY
description: A Federal district judge issued an order today temporarily barring the Department of Health and Human Services from ending welfare payments to people who refuse to waive the privacy of their tax records.

title: MOVIE: 4 COUPLES DANCE THE 'BOLERO' IN HISTORY
description: CLAUDE LELOUCH has a particular gift for making small, charming, throwaway comedies, especially about ineffective hoods with dreams of glory that will never be realized. I remember with special fondness the one in which two such misfits plan to kidnap the Pope and hold him for ransom -one cent each from every Catholic in the world. Mr. Lelouch is also generous with time and money in helping other film makers. He's not the sort of person you like to see crash, but that's what he does in his latest, heavier-than-air vehicle.

title: JUSTICES RULE STATES MUST PAY TO EDUCATE ILLEGAL ALIEN PUPILS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that children who are illegal aliens have a constitutional right to a free public education.

title: WHITE HOUSE 'FAIRY TALE' FOR THE ELDERLY
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Panel Dropping Controversial TV Ads
description: The House Republican Campaign Committee has withdrawn from television a commercial that featured look-alikes for former President Carter and the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.. It has also dismissed the agency that created them, a White House political aide said today.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: THE Rolling Stones' American tour last year was the most profitable and widely publicized series of performances in the history of rock-and-roll. Profiteers furtively resold tickets at unheard-of prices, and some of the nation's largest outdoor arenas - the 90,000-seat John F. Kennedy Stadium in Philadelphia, for example - sold out so quickly that second shows had to be added. Daily newspapers in a number of cities gave the arrival of the Stones front-page coverage.

title: REQUIRED LABELING OF SODIUM FAVORED
description: The Reagan Administration proposed today that many food manufacturers be required to label their products' content of sodium, which is linked to high blood pressure, a health problem for millions of Americans.

title: ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS WILL 'SKIM THE CREAM'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BRITISH MILLINER WHO WINS AT ASCOT
description: LONDON THE feminist and author Germaine Greer is not known for her fashion-consciousness, but on a recent television talk show here her first question to a guest was, ''That's a David Shilling, isn't it?''

title: The U.N. Today; June 16, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BRITISH PLANNING A LARGE GARRISON
description: The establishment of a powerful military force to defend the Falklands should the Argentines carry on the war after the surrender of their troops on the islands is a prime objective of the British Government, according to senior military officials.

title: Layoff by Pemex
description: The state oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, known as Pemex, laid off 4,000 workers in northeastern Mexico, citing decreased oil drilling and construction stoppages as a result of federal budget cuts and lower oil revenues.

title: U.S. EQUAL OPPORTUNITY PANEL ACCUSED OF LAX BOOKKEEPING
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which oversees compliance with Federal antidiscrimination laws, is in financial chaos and is failing to dispose of thousands of discrimination cases brought before it, an offical of the General Accounting Office asserted today.

title: POPE BIDS I.L.O. BUILD SOCIAL SOLIDARITY
description: Pope John Paul II called here today for a ''new solidarity without frontiers'' based on the ''primacy of human work over the means of production.''

title: DRYSDALE SECURITIES OUT OF BUSINESS
description: The Drysdale Securities Corporation, a 92-year-old stock and bond trading firm, announced yesterday that it was liquidating its business.

title: TOY SELECTION UNDID MEGO
description: A combination of the wrong products and a fickle toy market were the leading factors in the bankruptcy proceedings of Mego International Inc., company officials and industry analysts said.

title: Bill Doubles Aid To Protect Envoys
description: A bill to double the amount of money the Federal Government gives New York City to protect foreign diplomats at the United Nations was passed today by the House of Representatives.

title: A Law to Cope With Strays
description: If the State Legislature has indeed completed work on New York City's budgetary needs, the time has come to take care of the animals - stray and unwanted animals. Only the state can resolve a crisis facing the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, to which the city delegates responsibility for keeping unwanted animals from endangering public health.

title: C. RAYMOND HULSART, 69, HEADED THE NEW YORK TIMES FOUNDATION
description: C. Raymond Hulsart, retired president of the New York Times Foundation and former secretary of The New York Times Company, died yesterday at the Candlewood Valley Care Center in New Milford, Conn., after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived in South Kent, Conn.

title: MAKE THE STATE PAY FOR BUDGET ADOPTION DELAYS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PLEASURES OF A LONG COUNTRY LUNCH
description: IT has rained on the last four weekends, but that has not stopped a lot of people who are fortunate enough to have out-of-town retreats from going to the country. Whether one is roasting potatoes indoors over a log fire - June or no June - or pouring cream on strawberries rescued from a waterlogged garden patch, what better way to pass an afternoon in the country than over a long lunch?

title: Gas Station Chain Shift
description: In a cost-cutting move, the Kayo Oil Company said today that it was assuming operation of the Minneapolis-based Western Stores service station chain, effective Aug. 1. Kayo is a subsidiary of Conoco, and Western Stores is a division of the marketing operation of Conoco, an oil company. Franz B. Ehrhardt, Kayo president, said that the absorption of the Western Stores operation into Kayo was designed to streamline Conoco's marketing operations and would not affect Western's marketing.

title: JAILED AGENT'S FAMILY LEARNS TO COPE
description: John Henry Barnett is 8 years old. He wrote his father a letter asking: ''Why did you do it? Why did you go to the Russians? Why don't we live in a big house anymore?''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Ugly but Delicious

title: Comings and Goings
description: The New York Jets have signed four college draft choices to oneyear contracts. They are George Floyd, safety man and kickoff returner from Eastern Kentucky; Lonell Phea, a wide receiver and kickoff returner from Houston; Lawrence Txada, a running back from Henderson State, and Perry Parmelee, a wide receiver from Santa Clara. ... The Las Vegas police have booked Michael Dokes, the heavweight boxer, in an incident in which, according to authorities, he hit an officer who was trying to frisk him while investigating a report of a disturbance. Dokes was released in $3,250 bail.

title: HINCKLEY STIRRED TO AN OUTBURST
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. audibly exclaimed ''You're wrong'' from his seat at the defense table today when a prison psychiatrist told the jury that she did not believe his motive for shooting President Reagan had been to win Jodie Foster's love.

title: BATTLE SCENE: QUITE SUDDENLY, RESISTANCE CEASED
description: Following are excerpts from dispatches by Brian Hanrahan of the British Broadcasting Corporation, who watched the battle for Stanley, and Max Hastings of The London Standard, the first British journalist to enter the town after the fighting: Battle of Lights and Sound By BRIAN HANRAHAN

title: CITICORP APPOINTS 3 VICE CHAIRMEN
description: Hans H. Angemueller, John S. Reed and Thomas C. Theobald - the front contenders to succeed Walter B. Wriston as chairman and chief executive officer of Citicorp - were named vice chairmen yesterday, Mr. Wriston announced.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture that accompanied a dispatch from Mauritius last Thursday was published in error. It showed Harish Boodhoo, the head of the Hindu Organization of the Mauritian Socialist Party. The person mentioned in the caption - Paul Berenger, leader of the opposition - was correctly pictured Sunday on page 3.

title: NASA RAISES RATES FOR SHUTTLE'S CUSTOMERS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday an approximately 85 percent increase in the launching fees for commercial and foreign customers of the space shuttle, effective after the 1985 expiration of the low ''introductory'' rates.

title: Woman's Day Goes to Nadler
description: Woman's Day magazine, after 15 years as a client of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, is switching to Nadler & Larimer.

title: ART PEPPER, 56, SAXOPHONIST WITH KENTON ORCHESTRA, DIES
description: Art Pepper, a star saxophonist with Stan Kenton's orchestra 30 years ago who had been successfully rebuilding his career in the last five years after losing two decades to drugs and consequent prison terms, died yesterday in the Kaiser Panorama Medical Center, Los Angeles. He had suffered a stroke last Wednesday and never regained consciousness. He was 56 years old.

title: NJ Transit Adopts A Capital Budget
description: The NJ Transit Corporation's board of directors today approved a $399 million capital budget for the year starting July 1, earmarking $226 million to buy new buses and support equipment and $163 million for rail improvements.

title: BREZHNEV'S STATEMENT AND EXCERPTS FROM GROMYKO'S SPEECH
description: Following are a transcript of a statement from Leonid I. Brezhnev, delivered to the United Nations Second Special Session on Disarmament yesterday by Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, and excerpts from Mr. Gromyko's speech to the session, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Speak to My Lawyer(s)

title: BIG 3 CAR SALES UP 0.8% IN EARLY JUNE
description: The nation's Big Three auto makers said today that new car sales in the first 10 days of June rose eight-tenths of 1 percent from the 1981 period, to 169,470 units. The slight improvement, the fourth consecutive 10-day period in which results have been higher, came despite a 6.6 percent decline in sales by the General Motors Corporation.

title: An Advanced Method To Track Consumers
description: At least six marketing research companies are currently availing themselves of the wondrous potential for tracking consumers' activities inherant in the Universal Product Code.

title: 17 Americans in the Falklands Are Believed to Be Uninjured
description: The 17 United States citizens still on the Falkland Islands are believed to have come through the final British assault on Stanley without injuries, a United States Embassy spokesman here said today.

title: THEY REFUSE, AND THE FORCES REDEPLOY
description: An Israeli commander called today for the withdrawal of all Syrian forces stationed in the Beirut area as Israeli armored units tightened their grip on the city. Syria rejected the demand.

title: A TIME FOR REFLECTION
description: In this pause in the Middle East and South Atlantic wars, the political leaders of the world have gathered here on the East River to proclaim their various formulas for peace.

title: Real Estate; Commercial Co-Op in Brooklyn
description: TWO years ago when word got around Brooklyn Heights that the medical office building at 142 Joralemon Street would be converted into a cooperative with its commercial space to be sold, not rented, many in the real estate community there thought the idea laughable, the new owners say.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Going Out Guide yesterday about the comedy team of Bob and Ray incorrectly described their careers. They are still working in radio.

title: EMERY DECIDES TO STAY IN RACE TO BE GOVERNOR
description: Hours after suggesting that he might be willing to run for lieutenant governor, James L. Emery said last night that he would remain a candidate for the Republican nomination for governor.

title: REUSS PITCHES ANOTHER SHUTOUT
description: Jerry Reuss pitched a five-hitter and recorded his second straight shutout as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored a 3-0 victory tonight over the San Diego Padres.

title: WALTER G. ANDERSON
description: Walter G. Anderson, founder of The Editor's Newsletter at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old and also maintained a residence in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Khomeini Son Away From Car When Bullets Hit It in Attack
description: The car of Hojatolislam Ahmad Khomeini, the oldest son of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, was hit by bullets in a grenade and machine-gun attack today, but he was not in the car and its driver was unhurt, a spokesman for the Ayatollah's office said by telephone.

title: Walton and Cowens Considering Comebacks
description: Bill Walton and Dave Cowens, once dominant centers and most valuable players in the National Basketball Association, are considering playing professionally again.

title: Bush, in Saudi Arabia, Meets With New King
description: Vice President Bush flew here Tuesday evening and met late into the night with Saudi Arabia's new ruler, King Fahd, amid signs of Saudi displeasure at the United States' role in the Lebanese conflict.

title: Senior Golf Off
description: Organizational difficulties and lagging ticket sales have forced promoters to cancel next month's P.G.A. Seniors Golf Tournament at the Nashville Golf and Athletic Club.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I often make my own tomato sauce for spaghetti and lasagna and sometimes it is much too acid for my taste. I do not like to cook with sugar. Could you recommend some ingredient, like sweet fennel, that would do away with the tartness?

title: BIG WIG GATE
description: I brought the family to Washington for the great celebration of the 10th anniversary of Watergate. It doesn't bother me that all 500,000 tickets to the reenactment of the famous Watergate break-in were sold out before we arrived. I go out of my way to avoid reenactments. In recent years I have fled to Nebraska to avoid the reenactment of the Battle of Antietam, to Michigan to avoid the reenactment of the Battle of Yorktown and to Maine to avoid the reenactment of Lee's surrender at Appomattox.

title: V.I.P.'S MUST LEARN THE ETIQUETTE OF WINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts from speech, page A20.
description: The Soviet Union pledged today that it would not use a nuclear weapon first in any war. The promise came in a statement from Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, that was delivered by his Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, to the General Assembly's special session on disarmament.

title: Military Analysis
description: Careful coordination of infantry, armor and artillery plus a high degree of professionalism were the basic ingredients in the British victory over the Argentine troops defending Stanley.

title: MONEY RISE ABOVE FED GOAL HINTED
description: The Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said today that the central bank's monetary policy should not be restricted by rigid adherence to its monetary targets, his strongest indication to date that the practice would jeopardize the recovery.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES UP AGAIN
description: Short-term interest rates continued to climb yesterday, pushed up in part by a big volume of large certificates of deposit issued by New York City banks.

title: Rolling Stones Attract 140,000 to Paris Shows
description: The Rolling Stones attracted a total of 140,000 fans to two Paris concerts marking the rock group's first appearance in France since 1976.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON HIRING POLICE
description: The City Council and the Board of Estimate agreed yesterday to add funds for 1,000 new police officers to Mayor Koch's proposed budget, but were unable to agree on how much money should be given to the public school system.

title: WHISTLE BLOWER ON EXCESS PENTAGON COSTS WINS PROMOTION
description: A. Ernest Fitzgerald, a civilian budget analyst for the Air Force who was dismissed for telling Congress about billions of dollars in excess costs, today won a promotion and $200,000 in legal fees in a settlement of his suit against the Federal Government.

title: HUNGARY, SCOTLAND VICTORS
description: Cameroon stunned the soccer world today by gaining a tie in the World Cup and Hungary and Scotland surprised no one by winning.

title: HOW THE U.S. CAN PREVENT FUTURE FALKLAND WARS
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS BID DONOVAN 'STEP ASIDE' FOR INQUIRY
description: Senate Democrats demanded today that Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan ''step aside'' until an investigation was completed into his activities, including disclosures that President Reagan's transition team knew at the time of his Senate confirmation hearings of charges he had ties to organized crime figures.

title: ISRAELI SELF-DEFENSE? NO. SELF-DEFEAT.
description: In the wake of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, a large number of Panglosses are gloating about the opportunities for peace opened up by Israel's military success, as well as justifying the invasion as an act of self-defense. Reality is starkly different.

title: Pabst to Press Bid for Olympia
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said that the Justice Department's decision on Monday not to allow a merger between Pabst and the G. Heileman Brewing Company did not come as a surprise and that it would pursue its merger with the Olympia Brewing Company.

title: Hay Dancers Back
description: The Deborah Hay Dance Company will return to New York tomorrow with performances through Sunday in Public School 122, First Avenue and Ninth Street.

title: Southeast's Bank Option
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation, which is seeking to acquire Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., paid $11.5 million for an option on the 1,873,938 shares of Florida National's common stock held by C.A. Cavendes Sociedad Financiera, the company announced yesterday.

title: 2 SEATTLE PAPERS GIVEN CONSENT FOR JOINT OPERATION
description: Attorney General William French Smith gave final governmental approval yesterday for a merger of the business and production facilities of the two daily newspapers in Seattle.

title: NEW 'TEST TUBE' BABY BORN
description: Lesley Brown, who gave birth to the world's first ''test tube'' baby in 1978, has become the mother of another child conceived by the same method, her attorney reported today.

title: HAIG ON EUROPEAN TRIP: 'I HAVE COME A LONG WAY
description: When the seven Western foreign ministers were gathering for their banquet recently in the elegance of the Versailles palace, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. fondled a glass of French Sauternes and mused about life.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Big Bag, Big Headache

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 16, 1982; The Economy
description: Industrial production dropped just 0.2 percent in May, the Federal Reserve Board said. The small decline, though it was the ninth in 10 months, raised hopes that the recession may be easing. It also meant factory utilization fell, probably under 71 percent of capacity for the first time in the recession, analysts said. (Page D1.)

title: U.S. IS COOL TO DECLARATION BY SOVIET ON USE OF A-BOMB
description: The United States responded coolly today to a Soviet pledge not to be the first to use nuclear weapons, but American proponents of the concept praised the Soviet announcement.

title: 2 Customs Offices to Close
description: The United States Customs Service announced plans Monday to shut down regional offices in Baltimore and San Francisco Sept. 30 to save money. The duties of the offices will be transferred to Boston and Los Angeles. The other regional offices are in New York, Miami, New Orleans, Houston and Chicago.

title: GRIFFEY CLOUT BEATS CLEAR
description: The same people who provided the Yankees with one of their most exciting victories of the season Monday night produced one of their most scintillating victories of the season last night.

title: Beef Producers' Suit Has Setback
description: A Federal judge has dropped two dozen grocery store chains from a seven-year-old antitrust suit brought by beef producers who accused the chains of fixing beef prices.

title: Advertising; Computer Billings Up At Ally
description: COMMODORE BUSINESS MACHINES, a leader in microcomputers, has assigned its Vic 20 computer to Ally & Gargano. Billings will soon grow to the $20 million level.

title: CAREY APPROVES $56 MILLION IN SPENDING HE HAD VETOED
description: Governor Carey tonight signed $56 million in appropriations he vetoed earlier this year, including funds for a program aimed at violent criminals and repeat offenders.

title: Dow Off 0.58 After Late Rally
description: The stock market continued to decline yesterday, although a late rally enabled the Dow Jones industrial average to close slightly above the 800-point mark widely regarded as a key support level.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NUGGETS, ROCKETS ARE SOLD
description: The Denver Nuggets and the Houston Rockets announced yesterday that they would be sold, but would remain in their cities. B.J. (Red) McCombs, a San Antonio businessman and a part owner of the San Antonio Spurs, told a news conference in Denver that he had signed a letter of intent to purchase 100 percent of the financiallytroubled Nuggets. Details of the reported $10 million sale were not immediately available, but part of the offer from McCombs was to pick up all the Nuggets' debts.

title: A SOILDER IS RESCUED
description: The Israeli Army spokesman reported today that Syrian and Israeli troops had exchanged artillery fire east of the Beirut international airport.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Mighty Dollar, The Wilting Traveler

title: Contemplating Suit
description: Doyle Alexander, who expects to return to the Yankees within a week to 10 days, said he was ''99.9 percent certain'' he would file a grievance over the $12,500 fine the Yankees assessed him for breaking a finger when he punched the dugout wall in Seattle May 6. The pitcher has until the end of this month to file.

title: 6 OFFICES TO AID VICTIMS OF FLOOD IN CONNECTICUT
description: Federal and state officials said today that they would open six disaster assistance centers in Connecticut on Friday to aid flood victims following President Reagan's declaration of a major disaster in the southern half of the state.

title: WINE TALK
description: SAN JOSE, Calif. IT is unusual to discover a wine of exquisite quality from one of the giants of the American wine industry. They are accustomed to dealing in huge volume, and their paramount considerations are consistency and value, which often seem to mean blandness. But such a wine has been produced here by Almaden Vineyards, and the achievement is all the more extraordinary because it was accomplished in spite of the broad trends in consumer demand rather than because of them.

title: Officer Shifts Set For Campbell-Ewald
description: Under the umbrella of the Interpublic Group of Companies, Richard D. O'Connor, 50 years old, vice chairman and chief executive of Campbell-Ewald, Detroit, is coming to New York to take on the same titles at Marschalk Campbell-Ewald Worldwide, one of Interpublic's three globe-girdling ad-agency systems.

title: RETAIN FIRST USE
description: Nuclear weapons are full of horrible paradoxes. They are constantly being improved so that they may be rendered useless. For the sake of deterrence, we threaten to destroy the world in order to save it. The West has regularly ''resolved'' these paradoxes by repressing them, by banishing the unthinkable to the innermost recesses of our minds and military bureaucracies.

title: ALIENS
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today in Plyler v. Doe, in which the Court held that children who are illegal aliens have a constitutional right to a free public education. The majority opinion by Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. was joined by Associate Justice John Paul Stevens and by three Associate Justices who also wrote separate concurring opinions, Lewis F. Powell, Thurgood Marshall, and Harry A. Blackmun. The dissenting opinion by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger was joined by Associate Justices Byron R. White, William H. Rehnquist, and Sandra Day O'Connor.

title: Jartran Debt Pact
description: Jartran Inc., the truck leasing company that has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since January, said that it had reached a tentative oral agreement to reschedule its debt of about $230 million with its three major secured creditors, and that it was close to settling with its unsecured creditors. As a result, Kevin Murphy, president, said he believed the company, based in Coral Gables, Fla., could emerge from bankruptcy by late summer.

title: CARL J. LALUMIA
description: Carl J. Lalumia, an executive aide to two Connecticut Governors, died yesterday at Longwood Memorial Hospital in Orlando, Fla.

title: Teaching Alien Children Is a Duty
description: By ordering the state of Texas to educate illegal alien children, the Supreme Court has struck a blow for minimal decency. The 5-to-4 vote was too close and the legal rule too narrow to make the case one of liberty's landmarks, yet any other result would have been a national disgrace. It was intolerable that a state so wealthy and so willing to wink at undocumented workers should evade the duty - and ignore the need - to educate all its children.

title: Schlitz's Chairman Resigns Post
description: Daniel F. McKeithan Jr. turned down an offer to stay on as chairman of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, which is being taken over by the Stroh Brewing Company of Detroit, and resigned effective Monday to pursue other interests, Schlitz said yesterday.

title: TV: HIS OPERATIC PEERS SALUTE GEORGE LONDON
description: ''AN OPERA GALA: A Salute to George London,'' being broadcast from 8 to 10 o'clock this evening on WNET-TV, Channel 13, is a tribute to the acclaimed bass-baritone whose singing career was cut short by a paralyzed vocal cord in 1967. Mr. London then became active in helping young performers through such organizations as the National Opera Institute. In 1977 he was felled by a heart attack. This tribute, which Mr. London was unable to attend, was recorded a couple of months ago at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, in Washington. It features 16 of Mr. London's opera colleagues, singing for him and recalling his special qualities as a performer and a man.

title: Yonkers' Boycott Ended by Owners
description: Yonkers Raceway reached an agreement on purses with the Standardbred Owners Association yesterday, putting an end to a boycott by some of the association's members.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Airlines announced that R.J. Masiello had been named to head its operations organization and William P. Hannon to head its maintenance and engineering department.

title: LIFE BEGINS AT 65
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Is Shot In Face by Mugger
description: A 51-year-old Manhattan business executive was shot in the face by one of two youths in an attempted robbery as he and his wife walked on 64th Street near Park Avenue shortly after 11 o'clock Monday night, the police said.

title: GOLFER ATTAINS GOAL
description: For the first time in 10 attempts, Bobby Heins, a 31-year-old extrovert who is an assistant pro at Winged Foot Golf Club in Westchester, has qualified for a United States Open.

title: STUDY SEES PERILS FOR ROAD SYSTEM
description: The national highway program is plunging deeply into the red, requiring an urgent and complete overhaul in the next year, the Congressional Budget Office reported today in a 94-page study.

title: L.I.R.R. Absolved In Fatal Van Crash
description: The Federal Railroad Administration has cleared the Long Island Rail Road of responsibility for the March 14 crash of an eastbound train and a van in Mineola. Nine teen-agers in the van, including the 19-year-old driver, Joseph Grammas of New Hyde Park, L.I., were killed.

title: Connecticut Utility Tie
description: The merger of the Connecticut Light and Power Company and the Hartford Electric Power Company, both subsidiaries of Northeast Utilities, has been approved by their preferred shareholders, Northeast said yesterday. The vote followed state and Federal approval. Connecticut Light will gain 307,000 electric customers in 37 towns and will also assume Hartford Electric's undisclosed obligations to pay various bonds and notes.

title: Drug Hearings Set
description: Representative Leo C. Zeferetti announced plans yesterday for Congressional hearings to investigate drug abuse in professional football.

title: 1. Pretty Pinafores
description: A couple of years ago, when Jan Dutton went to live in Hong Kong, where her husband is a doll manufacturer, she wanted a business of her own. Since the crown colony and the nearby Chinese mainland had excellent cotton and workers skilled at embroidery and lace making, Mrs. Dutton chose to produce pinafores and aprons that are almost too pretty to wear in a kitchen (six of her pinafores were worn by a wedding party recently). The designer calls her company Paper White and she commutes from Hong Kong to her wholesale office in San Anselmo, Calif. One of her designs, a beautifully embroidered and lace-edged pinafore in ankle length, is $46 in Bendel's third floor lingerie department.

title: BOSTON IS BECOMING THE HUB OF ARSON
description: For a time last weekend, it appeared that Boston deserved the term one often hears on the streets of this old and combustible city: ''the arson capital of the world.''

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 16, 1982
description: International Over 13,000 Argentines surrendered to British forces in the Falklands during the night, bringing the total number of prisoners to 15,000 in the three-week war, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced. The final capitulation came after heavily outnumbered British troops fought to within rifleshot of the defenders of Stanley, the last major Argentine stronghold in the islands. (Page A1, Column 6.) Peace will not be possible if Britain restores ''colonial rule'' in the Falklands, President Leopoldo F. Galtieri asserted in an angry televised speech to Argentines. A senior official said that Argentina would continue to fight in the air and at sea. (A22:1-2.)

title: INTERNATIONAL ATOMIC AGENCY SAYS IT HAD INSPECTION PROBLEMS IN '81
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency has acknowledged that it could not adequately verify last year whether nuclear material in two countries was being diverted for military purposes.

title: Alcan Smelter Cut
description: Citing slackened demand for aluminum and uncertain economic conditions, the Aluminum Company of Canada said it had canceled plans for a $500 million (Canadian) smelter north of Winnipeg. The subsidiary of Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said it would not renew an option to buy the proposed land site.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE PAST HAUNTS VIETNAM
description: A pedicab pusher, noticing two curious young men walking alongside his small vehicle, tells his passenger, ''Watch.'' He means the wristwatch: keep it out of sight.

title: SYRIA REJECTS ISRAELI DEMAND FOR WITHDRAWL FROM BEIRUT
description: Syria today formally rejected an Israeli ''ultimatum'' requesting the withdrawal of its troops from Beirut and its vicinity, the Damascus radio announced tonight.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: NEW YORK was the scene of a pitched battle last week, a strategic retreat in a long and costly war. ''Establish the defense perimeter,'' shouted the rebel commander to his troops, ''we've got 'em on the run.'' Soon, amid the smoking wreckage of the rebel base, a brigadier yelled: ''Fighters - stick close to your transports.''

title: VALUE OF AN EARLY START IN ESTABLISHING GOOD EATING HABITS
description: BABIES are born liking sweet things; it is not an acquired taste. What is acquired is the taste for overly sweetened foods. The desire for salt, on the other hand, is learned.

title: LURED OUT OF LIBYA, ARRESTED AT KENNEDY
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a fugitive former American intelligence agent, was arrested by Federal agents in New York City yesterday after being snared in an international trap set by the Justice Department.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: Quake Shakes California
description: An earthquake measuring 4.8 on the Richter scale shook a five-county area of southern California about 5 P.M. today, the authorities said. There were no injuries or major damage. The quake was centered near this small community 90 miles southeast of Los Angeles.

title: GETTING CHILDREN TO EAT RIGHT
description: THERE is nothing more frustrating to most parents than to watch what their children eat - and don't eat. Many parents complain that their control over their children's diets ends with weaning. With each passing year, the menu seems to get worse. This is especially true now when most children are growing up in households where both parents work or where there is only one parent - one who works. The problem is compounded by seductive television advertising, vending machines, fast-food establishments and street vendors hawking foods of questionable nutritional value. When visions of sugarplums are dancing in young heads, apples and carrot sticks are less likely to start mouths watering.

title: KAREN ROGERS INJURED IN SPILL
description: Karen Rogers suffered a hairline fracture of the right leg today in a spill after the fourth race at Monmouth Park.

title: Economic Scene; Expansionism And Rigidity
description: FOLLOWING the Versailles summit conference, there has been a burst of action on the international monetary front. The United States has intervened in foreign-exchange markets to counter ''disorderly'' market conditions for the first time since March 30, 1981, following the attempt on President Reagan's life

title: Mrs. King Upset By South African
description: Rosalyn Fairbank, a 21-year-old South African, upset Billie Jean King today, 6-1, 1-6, 6-3, in the second round of the BMW tennis tournament.

title: U.S. HINTS PRESIDENT MAY NOT MEET BEGIN IF BEIRUT IS CAPTURED
description: Administration officials suggested today that President Reagan might not meet with Prime Minister Menachem Begin on Monday, as originally scheduled, if Israeli troops take over Beirut.

title: Of Vanity Presses
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I certainly wish I had read your excellent article, ''More Authors Turn to Vanity Presses'' (May 26), a year ago. If I had, there might have been time to convince an elderly friend to stipulate the publication of her poetry in a will.

title: CITY LIABLE FOR INJURIES CAUSED BY ITS WORKERS
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday in Albany that New York City and other municipalities are liable for injuries to their workers caused by the negligence of fellow employees, even though the cities themselves bear no responsibility for the mishaps,

title: People
description: * Dennis Ritzel, director of advertising and corporate identity for the Eaton Corporation, has been elected president of the Business/Professional Advertising Association.

title: POLITICAL TRIAL UNDER WAY IN KOREA
description: One of the most important political trials in South Korea since Chun Doo Hwan took power in 1980 opened in Pusan this week with 16 people accused of involvement in burning the United States cultural center there.

title: Arab Banking Branch
description: The Arab Banking Corporation said that it had formally opened a branch in New York yesterday to cover its North American operations.

title: Direct Marketing On the Increase
description: At a press conference held in connection with its 17th Spring Conference and Exhibition at the New York Hilton yesterday the Direct Mail Marketing Association announced the results of a survey of top financial institutions and retailers that disclosed that, as suspected, there has been a sizable increase in the use of direct marketing in those areas.

title: VOTING RIGHTS BILL PASSES A KEY TEST
description: Supporters of a bill to extend enforcement sections of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 decisively won a test vote in the Senate today, but opponents of the measure continued stalling tactics that threatened to block legislative action on urgent economic matters in the weeks ahead.

title: Export-Credit Talks Continue
description: The United States has granted a 10-day extension on a deadline set to expire today to work out a new exportcredit arrangement with the European Economic Community, Canada and Japan, Treasury officials said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: Salutes for Addabbo

title: A Beauty Queen Loses Her Title
description: A 22-year-old beauty queen lost her title because she refused to sing at a truck stop and said today that she was going to fight for her crown.

title: Careers; Following New Jobs To Exurbia
description: IN his book ''The Year 2000,'' Herman Kahn of the Hudson Institute visualizes the growth of a single dense urban concentration extending all the way from Boston to Washington and, to a lesser degree, along similar corridors between other major metropolitan areas. The forecast in the book, which was published 15 years ago, still appears well founded.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Yankees are expecting 35,000 for the finale of the three-game series. When Dave Righetti, the starter tonight, faced the Red Sox at Fenway Park last week, he had a nohitter for six and one-third innings in a game the Yanks won, 5-3. Righetti is 4-4. John Tudor (5-4) will pitch for Boston. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. Randy Jones (6-5) the Mets' starter, has said his arm needs to be tired for him to pitch effectively, which means he needs to last more than a couple of innings, as he has done in his last three games. John Candelaria, the Pittsburgh starter, is struggling at 2-3 and is eligible for free agency as the end of the season, of which he will probably take advantage. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 7:30 P.M.) Minnesota vs. Kansas City, at Kansas City. Remember Frank Viola, the St. John's all-America left-hander who won an 11-inning duel with Yale's Ron Darling in last year's National Collegiate Eastern Regional tournament, even though Darling hurled 11 no-hit innings? The Minnesota Twins remembered him. They drafted Viola on the second round last year and called him up from their Class AAA farm in Toledo on June 4. Although he has no decisions, he is making his third start tonight, against Vida Blue (4-3).

title: WOMAN DEAD AND 16 PEOPLE HURT
description: The Amtrak passenger train the San Francisco Zephyr derailed today near here when it hit a spot where the tracks had been washed away by flood waters.

title: STUDENTS IN CITY TOP U.S. LEVELS FOR SCHOOL TESTS
description: For the first time in at least a decade, students in the New York City public schools exceeded the national averages in both reading and mathematics scores, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the city's Board of Education.

title: I.B.M. Advance
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had developed a computer-aided design system that can cut the cost of designing computer logic chips by as much as 90 percent. I.B.M. said the system is capable of providing high performance and high density using an automated, instead of a custom, design. It said the system can automatically design chips with over 7,000 circuits.

title: Florida Doctors Curb Surgery In Protest of Insurance Rates
description: South Florida doctors protesting rising malpractice insurance rates stopped scheduling elective surgery today, but a leader of the protest said emergency cases would not be turned down.

title: RAVITCH AND KEY LEGISLATORS STILL AT ODDS OVER FARE RISE
description: The State Assembly's Democratic leaders and the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority remained at odds today over whether increases in bus, subway and commuter rail fares were needed.

title: President Is Named At Firestone Tire
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, Ohio, has elected Leon R. Brodeur, 54 years old, president and chief operating officer. Those titles had been held by John J. Nevin, 55, who will remain as chairman and chief executive. Mr. Nevin left the Zenith Radio Corporation in 1980 to head Firestone, which was losing money and reeling from the recall of its Firestone 500 radial tires.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Michiko Kakutani FORSAKING ALL OTHERS. By Jimmy Breslin. 431 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: The City Council approved a 9 percent pay increase for uniformed police officers tonight, thus averting a threatened strike and possible disruptions at the World's Fair here.

title: THOUSANDS IN BUENOS AIRES ASSAIL JUNTA FOR SURRENDERING TO BRITAIN
description: Policemen firing tear gas tonight dispersed thousands of angry Argentines who had massed in front of the presidential palace to condemn the Government for surrendering to the British on the Falkland Islands.

title: BRITONS ARE TAKING DELIGHT IN THEIR VICTORY IN THE FALKLANDS
description: A wave of pride and elation cascaded over Britain today as joyous citizens delighted in the news of victory over Argentina on the Falkland Islands.

title: Bank of America Gives Top Title to Economist
description: John O. Wilson sees short-term interest rates climbing to 15 or 16 percent by early fall, but easing after the November elections. He gave the forecast in his new position as chief economist for the Bank of America.

title: FACTORY OUTPUT OFF 0.2% IN MAY
description: The output of the nation's factories and mines dropped in May for the ninth time in 10 months, the Government reported today. But the size of the decline - just two-tenths of 1 percent from the April level - raised new hopes the recession may be easing.

title: ON THE RED SOX SYNDROME
description: I f I had gone to the Bronx on Monday night, the Yankees would have beaten the Red Sox because the Yankees almost always beat the Red Sox when I go to the Bronx. On the other hand, I almost always go to the Bronx with my son, and the Red Sox specialize in losing in front of my son, and he is off somewhere studying Chinese, and so if I went to the Bronx without my son, the Sox would probably win just to make my son hate me for not having taken him to the Bronx on the night the Sox finally beat the Yankees.

title: Bridge:; Fast Thinker and Talker Meets Match in a Partner
description: Whether quick wits tend to go with speedy speech is an interesting question for psychologists to consider. The great Oswald Jacoby of Dallas, approaching 80, has long been considered one of the fastest thinkers at the table and one of the fastest talkers away from it.

title: Wallach Gambles And Hits to Right
description: Now that the 13-game losing streak is over, the Chicago Cubs have a nomination: The worst moment of their two-week collapse may have been the opposite-field home run hit by Tim Wallach of the Montreal Expos with two out in the 10th inning on Sunday.

title: Pennzoil Cards
description: The Pennzoil Company said it would discontinue its company credit card program as of Aug. 15.

title: HOW THE U.S. CAN PREVENT FURTURE FALKLAND WARS
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of Sol Kittay on Satur- day incorrectly identified the benefici- ary of the Kittay Scientific Founda- tion. It financed research in psychia- try in general, not just in one hospital.

title: HOW THE LAW ON 5 DEPOSIT SHOULD WORK
description: Following are the major provisions of the bottle deposit law, which takes effect on July 1, 1983, and an explanation of how the sponsors say it will work:

title: Thatcher Visit Is Postponed
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher tonight postponed for a week her planned visit to New York to address the United Nations' Special Session on Disarmament. She will now speak there next Wednesday.

title: Doctors Dispute Status of Unruh
description: A psychiatrist testified today that Howard Unruh, who killed 13 of the 16 people he shot in a rampage here in 1949, no longer poses any danger to others.

title: Market Place; How to Rate Credit Risks
description: IN these difficult times for state and local governments, investors in tax-exempt securities might consider examining underlying assumptions used by rating agencies in determining investment risks.

title: INDIAN MUSEUM ARTIFACTS MISSING
description: A collection of five wooden Indian masks and ceremonial headdress ornaments said to be worth $1.3 million has been reported missing from the Museum of the American Indian, the police said.

title: NAPA CHARDONNAY CHOSEN IN TASTING
description: A Napa Valley chardonnay produced by Acacia Vineyards took first place in an unusual blind tasting of 16 American chardonnays in New York last week. Most of the wines are well-known to sophisticated consumers, but are sometimes difficult to find in the East.

title: Borg Looks Ahead
description: It won't be easy, Bjorn Borg acknowledges, but at the age of 26 he is planning a campaign to become the best tennis player in the world again. His regimen, he explained in an interview by a West German magazine, calls for exhibitions and tournaments starting in the United States next month, followed by ''a lot of matches in the last three months of this year so that I can really get back in business in January 1983.''

title: Jersey Localities Press for State Aid
description: Most local governments in New Jersey are clamoring for state relief as they lay off employees, trim services and delay projects because of a $660 million cut in Federal aid, a special Eagleton Poll said today.

title: WILSON USED OLD 'COVERS' AFTER LEAVING C.I.A.
description: Edwin P. Wilson, who was captured today in a trap by the Justice Department, made a career of covert operations, often for the United States Government.

title: Mixed Blessing
description: Jim Craig, the goaltender hero of the United States hockey triumph over the Soviet Union in the 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, was among those honored at the White House that February. He heard President Carter say that the triumph was ''one of the most breathtaking upsets, not only in Olympic history, but in the entire history of sports.''

title: REAGAN DENOUNCES ECONOMIC CRITICS
description: President Reagan returned to the Oval Office today for the first time since the start of his European trip two weeks ago but then flew here this afternoon for a rousing defense of his economic policies and some partisan blasts at his critics.

title: Mitterrand in Austria Today
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France arrives here Wednesday for two days of talks with Austrian leaders and the first official visit to Vienna by a French head of state since Napoleon rode in victoriously in 1809.

title: TEXAS GOVERNOR SAYS COMPLIANCE WITH COURT RULING IS NO PROBLEM
description: Gov. William Clements said today that Texas could easily provide court-mandated education of illegal aliens in its public schools, but he predicted that doing so would make illegal immigration more attractive, particularly from Mexico.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF MRS. THATCHER'S REMARKS ON VICTORY
description: Following is a transcript of a statement to the House of Commons today by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I do not intend to negotiate on the sovereignty of the islands in any way except with the people who live there.

title: THOMPSON SHOWS HIS POWER
description: The Pirates battered Charlie Puleo, Pat Zachry and Tom Hausman for 13 runs and 17 hits tonight en route to a 13-3 victory over the Mets at Three Rivers Stadium.

title: Library Center
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Andree Brooks's article ''Where Mothers Can Gather for Camaraderie and Support'' (May 12) was interesting and informative. However, she did not include the New York Public Library's Early Childhood Resource and Information Center at 66 Leroy Street.

title: SAUDIS' KING: ALLY OF WEST: FAHD
description: An Arabic proverb - ''Good health may result from illnesses'' - was recalled once by the new Saudi King, Fahd ibn Abdel Aziz Al Saud, after a time of trouble - the November 1979 seizure of the Grand Mosque in Mecca by Moslem militants.

title: IMPROVED POTS AND PANS
description: FOR people starting a kitchen the most important items are sharp knives and good pans. When you look at the choice of pots and pans available it is no wonder that people so often end up with expensive mistakes: pans that burn and buckle and warp until they are thrown out in exasperation.

title: RAILROAD'S FREIGHT COMEBACK
description: Before the deregulation of the railroad industry, said David M. Boyd, the manager of Conrail's piggyback yard here, the railroad could change rates only with approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: CITIES SERVICE SUES BANK ON MESA FUND
description: The takeover duel between the Cities Service Company and the Mesa Petroleum Company moved into the courts yesterday.Cities Service sued the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in Chicago on charges that the big Chicago bank had violated Federal margin lending rules in helping Mesa raise $600 million to make a takeover bid for Cities Service.

title: CAREY SIGNS LAW REQUIRING 5 BOTTLE DEPOSIT
description: Governor Carey today signed legislation requiring a 5-cent deposit on soda and beer containers sold in New York State. Mr. Carey called his action ''in the best interest of the state, and of its people and its natural resources, for today and for future generations.''

title: MARKETS UP IN BRITAIN ON VICTORY
description: Britain's financial markets responded favorably at first to news of the Argentine surrender on the Falkland Islands, but by the close of trading today, the gains had evaporated as the initial euphoria gave way to other worries.

title: GALTIERI BARS PEACE IF BRITAIN RESTORES ITS 'COLONIAL RULE'
description: President Leopoldo Galtieri said tonight that ''there would be no security or definitive peace'' if Britain ''proceeds to restore colonial rule'' in the Falkland Islands.

title: Letter: On the Smatv System
description: If Co-op City Had Its Own Dish To the Editor: Co-op City's struggle to overcome official objections to having its own satellite master antenna television system (Editorial Notebook article by Hugh Price on May 10) indicates just how beneficial Smatv, or ''Smatz'' as you have so well labeled it, can be as a stimulating competitor to cable television.

title: BALLET: THE DANES ARRIVE WITH COMIC 'KERMESSE AT BRUGES'
description: THERE hasn't been a more festive ballet opening in years than last night's first program of the Royal Danish Ballet's two-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: THEATER: 'NOISES OFF' AND OTHER LONDON COMEDIES
description: LONDON= - The two London hits that reached Broadway last season, ''Nicholas Nickleby'' and ''The Dresser,'' both made wild comic hay out of the misadventures of fleabag British theatrical troupes touring Shakespeare in the provinces. Now the West End has a new hit farce, Michael Frayn's ''Noises Off,'' that takes the same basic premise to its ludicrous apotheosis and just possibly to its most dizzying comic heights yet.

title: OFFICIALS FROM AFAR FIND NEW YORK A WONDER
description: Since proclaiming itself a civic watchdog half a century ago, the Citizens Budget Commission has made a municipal tradition of nipping at the Mayor's heels whenever it saw fit, which has been often.

title: A TROUBLED BRIDGE OVER THE POTOMAC
description: Of the more than 43,000 miles of interstate highway across the United States, only 5,897 feet are owned by the Federal Government, those making up the the Woodrow Wilson Memorial Bridge.

title: McEnroe Draws Winitsky as Foe
description: John McEnroe, the defending champion and top-seeded at Wimbledon, drew Van Winitsky today as his opponent in the first round next Monday.

title: Papal Envoy in Warsaw To Discuss Pope's Visit
description: Msgr. Luigi Poggi, a Vatican envoy, met Poland's Roman Catholic primate, Archbishop Josef Glemp, and other church officials in the first round of talks on a planned visit by Pope John Paul II, Catholic sources said today.

title: BAR ARGENTINE ROLE; JUNTA BALKS AT TERMS; Mrs. Thatcher's statement, page A24.
description: More than 13,000 bedraggled Argentine troops in the Falkland Islands surrendered during the night, bringing the total to 15,000 in the fierce infantry campaign that lasted only three weeks, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today.

title: Talks on Pay TV
description: Major league baseball owners concluded their two-day meeting today after hearing several proposals from their revenue-sharing committee on new formulas for distributing income to reflect the impact of pay television. A six-man committee, headed by Eddie Chiles, owner of the Texas Rangers, presented several formulas for revenue-sharing among the clubs.

title: E.E.C. Studies Sanction Halt
description: Britain's Common Market partners appeared willing, following the end of the fighting in the Falkland Islands, to end their ban on trade with Argentina, West German officials said today.

title: Zimbabwe to Enlist Ex-Rebels to Keep Order
description: The Zimbabwe Government announced today that it was calling up former guerrillas to combat mounting violence in the country.

title: Namibian Insurgents Agree to West's Plan
description: The South-West Africa People's Organization and its allies have agreed to a Western proposal to put aside political issues temporarily during talks on a cease-fire in South-West Africa, diplomatic sources said today.

title: 16TH SEASON OF MET CONCERTS IN THE PARKS OPENS WITH GRACE BUMBRY SINGING IN 'IL TROVATORE'
description: ''I'm so nervous,'' Grace Bumbry was saying early yesterday afternoon in Central Park. ''I was driving around looking for this place'' - the place being an orchestra shell and two towering black speaker systems facing the Great Lawn.

title: 3 SCIENTISTS EACH WIN PRIZES OF $100,000 FOR CANCER WORK
description: Three scientists who have made major contributions to understanding the biology of cancer have each been awarded $100,000 and a gold medal by the General Motors Cancer Research Foundation.

title: A SUPERMARKET BOSS WITH A MOM-AND-POP PHILOSOPHY
description: ANYONE who doubts that the man at the top can establish the tone and personality of a giant corporation might well consider the Waldbaum supermarket chain. Having only limited confidence in such modern business instruments as formal market research, Ira Waldbaum, the 54-year-old president of the chain, is a consummate pragmatist. He and his 84-year-old mother, Julia, secretary of the corporation and its spiritual head, and about a dozen other relatives and executives conduct their own surveys by shopping regularly and reporting on their findings. When food products are being considered for private-label packaging, family members try them out at home.

title: 2 Food Chains List Earnings
description: Two supermarket chains yesterday reported net earnings for their most recent quarters. Pantry Pride Inc. said its third-quarter profits tumbled 36.5 percent from the same quarter last year, while Stop and Shop Companies said it rebounded from a first-quarter loss in 1981.

title: CONFEREES SEEK ACCORD ON 1983 BUDGET
description: In a process somewhat like patching up a family dispute, House and Senate budget conferees today began working out the differences between the conservative Republican budgets for the fiscal year 1983 adopted by each chamber.

title: U.S. JOB BIAS LAW HELD TO COVER JAPAN'S UNITS
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that subsidiaries of Japanese companies incorporated and doing business in the United States are bound by American laws not to discriminate in employment.

title: Explosion Kills 2 at School
description: An explosion and fire killed a student and a janitor and seriously burned an elementary school principal today as they used gasoline and an electric buffer to clean a school floor. Pisgah's Fire Chief, James Gorman, said the accident occurred about 7:30 A.M. at Pisgah Elementary School. The student was identified as Tim Brown, 18 years old, of Dutton; the custodian was Alex Jeffery, 65, of Pisgah.

title: Colombia Says Leftist Attack Killed 8 Soldiers and 6 Others
description: Leftist guerrillas ambushed an army patrol and killed eight soldiers and three peasants, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: KNICKS TO BUILD BY DRAFT
description: Dave DeBusschere says that the Knicks, hoping to obtain another high first-round draft choice, have talked with the five teams who will choose ahead of them in the National Basketball Association college draft June 29.

title: RECIPES ON MICROFICHE TO ASSIST CHEFS
description: COULD the croissant that comes on your breakfast tray in Athens be as good as the one you are served in Singapore or even Paris? That is not an unreasonable expectation at Hilton International hotels, which are in 86 locations around the world. Each has the same recipe developed by Hilton's food research center.

title: Judge Delays Execution Of Florida Killer
description: A Federal district judge today delayed indefinitely the execution of Ronald J. Straight, a convicted killer who had lost an appeal earlier in the day before the Florida Supreme Court.

title: MCI Rates to Rise
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said that it would file ''modest'' long-distance rate increases of 5 percent to 6 percent affecting its largest business customers, effective July 1, and that it would also increase some long-distance charges for residential customers on Aug. 1. Together, the moves should increase revenue by $10 million to $15 million, or about 3 percent, MCI said.

title: Pan Am Cuts Fares
description: Pan American World Airways today offered $99 one-way fares from several Northeast and Midwest points to Florida in response to fares announced last week by Air Florida.

title: Not the Real Bobby Knight
description: W hen Bobby Knight ran into trouble in the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico during the 1979 Pan American Games, some people wondered if he would ever again represent the United States. Three years later, Knight has been nominated to coach the men's basketball team in the 1984 Olympics.

title: June F. Esserman Dies at 55; Led Child Research Company
description: June Frier Esserman, chief executive officer of Child Research Service and its parent company, Hyatt Esserman Research Associates, died of a heart attack Monday at St. Clare's Hospital.

title: MAJOR RESHAPING AT HANOVER BANK
description: In a major restructuring, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has consolidated its consumer activities to focus more strongly on the national market, the bank announced yesterday.

title: Illinois Rights Backers See Prospects as Bleak
description: Supporters of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment acknowledged several hours into a meeting today that they did not have enough votes in the Illinois House to win approval of the proposal before the June 30 deadline.

title: GIBSON WINS A FOURTH TERM IN A CLOSE RUNOFF IN NEWARK
description: Kenneth A. Gibson won a fourth term today as Mayor of the state's largest city, beating back a strong challenge by Earl Harris, the City Council President.

title: Big Deficit At Wickes
description: In a report that underlined how quickly one of the nation's major retailers slipped toward insolvency, the Wickes Companies reported today that it lost $156.4 million in the 12 weeks prior to filing for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act on April 24.

title: Shuffle at McDonald's
description: Edward H. Schmitt, 56, has been elected to the newly created position of vice chairman of the McDonald's Corporation, the leading fast-food concern. The company's board elected Michael R. Quinlan, 37, president of the corporation, succeeding Mr. Schmitt, who will continue as chief administrative officer.

title: Armenians to Take Part In Tel Aviv Seminar
description: A group of international scholars will meet here next week to hear five Armenian colleagues describe the death of countless Armenians during World War I at the hands of Turks. Organizers said the Armenian speeches would take place despite reported Turkish threats of reprisals against Israel and Turkish Jews.

title: Accounts
description: * Home magazine to Foote, Cone & Belding.

title: BEGIN OFF TO U.S. WITH PLAN FOR NEW, PEACEFUL LEBANON
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin left for the United States today with a framework of broad goals for Lebanon that he hopes the Reagan Administration will help him achieve.

title: G.M. Unit Signs Japanese Accord
description: A General Motors Corporation subsidiary and a Japanese car importer signed an agreement that would allow the American auto maker to centralize the distribution of its vehicles in Japan, G.M. said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pinning Down Who's Who

title: Marketers and Women
description: Since women were the most sought-after consumers before the feminist revolution, they have become even more desirable as wage earners.

title: WHEN THE BIG APPLE PROVES THAT IT REALLY HAS A CORE OF GOLD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Nardi Reeder Campion is the author of ''Ann the Word: The Story of Mother Ann Lee, Founder of the Shakers.'' By NARDI REEDER CAMPION

title: News Analysis
description: In ruling Tuesday that the Constitution entitles illegal alien children to a free public education, the Supreme Court inevitably invited further tests of aliens' rights to other government services.

title: Gasoline Stocks Up
description: Gasoline inventories, which had been falling in recent months, rose 2.2 million barrels last week as refiners increased production, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday. In the week ended last Friday, stocks rose to 215.2 million barrels from 213.0 million barrels in the previous week, but were below the level a year ago of 252.8 million barrels and below the Department of Energy's recommended range for this time of year.

title: New York Fund Official Gets Rothschild Post
description: Madelon DeVoe Talley has been managing New York State's $16 billion common retirement fund since 1979. Yesterday, Rothschild Inc. announced that she would be joining the firm as president of its investment management unit July 6.

title: Petersen Is Readying Motorcycle Magazine
description: Petersen Publishing in the wonder world of Los Angeles is devoted to your leisure time through its monthly magazines, each of which is interested in a different time-off activity.

title: New Unit at Chemical
description: Chemical Bank announced yesterday that it had opened a special division that will cater to the wealthy, following the lead of Chase Manhattan and many other major banks that have recently established programs to lure affluent customers from brokerage firms and money market funds. Chemical's Worldwide Private Banking division will offer a combination of financial consulting services, international investment assistance and private banking for people with incomes of more than $50,000 a year.

title: CIGARETTE THAT SNUFFS ITSELF IS BACKED
description: The American Medical Association has called on the tobacco industry to produce self-extinguishing cigarettes to reduce the number of deaths and injuries and the amount of damage resulting from cigarette-caused fires.

title: INVASION AFFECTED 600,000, U.S. SAYS
description: Reports reaching the State Department's Agency for International Development have estimated that as many as 600,000 people have been affected by the Israeli attack against Palestinian strongholds in Lebanon.

title: Dr. Allan Barnes, 70, A Noted Gynecologist
description: Dr. Allan C. Barnes, an internationally known obstetrician and gynecologist and a retired vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation, died Sunday in University Hospital in Columbus, Ohio. Dr. Barnes, who had lived in Columbus since last year, was 70 years old.

title: OPERA: DONIZETTI IN ST. LOUIS
description: Internationally important opera does not dry up and blow away in the summertime, although an opera-parched New Yorker might be forgiven for thinking so. Here on the banks of the Mississippi it thrives in the form of the Opera Theater of St. Louis, an enterprising company that has made the musical world sit up and take notice by presenting an imaginative repertory with consistent excellence.

title: Bridge: The Simpler Conventions May Turn Out to Be Best
description: Whether a partnership should employ unusual conventions depends on a number of circumstances. Are both players happy using artificial devices? Have they good memories? And are they going to play together frequently? If not, they would be wiser to use simple methods.

title: Talks Start in Geneva On Afghan Settlement
description: The Foreign Ministers of Pakistan and the Soviet-backed Afghanistan regime met here separately today with Under Secretary General Diego Cordoves of the United Nations for the start of talks on settling the conflict in Afghanistan.

title: ISRAELIS FORTIFY THEIR POSITIONS AROUND BEIRUT
description: Israeli forces dug in on the hills of this resort town east of Beirut today as armored units continued to isolate Beirut from the rest of Lebanon.

title: THE HOME COMPUTER ARRIVES
description: When Michael Forrest first told his parents he wanted a computer for his 11th birthday, they did not take him seriously. ''We thought, 'He wants a computer - ha, ha,' '' said his mother, Esther Forrest of Great Neck, L.I. ''But then, when we really investigated prices, we found it's not so bad.'' So the Forrests bought Michael a $300 Commodore VIC-20 computer.

title: TORONTO MAYOR QUERIED ON ENTRY
description: The Mayor of Toronto said yesterday that before being admitted to the United States last Saturday for a conference on urban affairs in New York City he was questioned by a United States Immigration officer about what he planned to say at the conference.

title: Ford's Plant Plans
description: The Ford Motor Company will spend $563 million to retool an engine plant in this Cleveland suburb if union workers, the city and the state help, company officials said. In exchange for manufacturing its new V-6 engine in the economically depressed suburb, Ford is seeking work rule concessions from Local 1250 of the United Automobile Workers, tax abatements from the city and low-cost loans from the state.

title: A Little Mercy for the Haitians
description: When it comes to the Haitians, the quality of Attorney General Smith's mercy is strained, but it is mercy nonetheless and much to be welcomed. Almost 2,000 of them are still detained behind the high wire fences; many have been there for a year or more. Mr. Smith now would permit those with lawyers and sponsors to get out, pending hearings on whether they are admissible as refugees. Though grudging, this new policy may mean the beginning of the end of a sordid little chapter in American immigration history.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Acme Precision Products Inc., a cutting tool manufacturer, said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the automated machine division of Babcock & Wilcox Co. in a cash transaction for an undisclosed price.

title: 10 YEARS LATER: WATERGATE FIGURES RECALL TURNING POINT IN THEIR LIVES
description: Ten years after the political burglary that made Watergate a part of the American consciousness, the participants in the long unwinding of the scheme, felons and prosecutors alike, are scattered across the continent, from a hardscrabble farm in the Adirondacks to the airconditioned offices of a real estate developer in southern California.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ACF Industries has appointed Bruce A. Gustafsen corporate vice president, secretary and treasurer.

title: FRIEND OF THE FALKLANDERS
description: When Rex Masterman Hunt, the British Governor of the Falkland Islands, surrendered them to the invading Argentines last April, he made this defiant declaration, as he and his wife boarded the plane at the Stanley Airport: ''We'll be back.''

title: LOSER CONTESTS OUTCOME OF ATLANTIC CITY ELECTION
description: James L. Usry, who lost to Assemblyman Michael J. Matthews by 359 votes of 18,077 cast in the runoff election for Mayor of this resort community Tuesday, refused today to concede defeat and challenged the outcome.

title: RENT FRAUD SEEN IN HOTEL APARTMENTS
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams charged yesterday that many apartment houses were ''masquerading'' as residential hotels to obtain higher rents, more frequent rent increases and other benefits of the city's hotel stabilization law.

title: RIGHETTI WINS TO COMPLETE SWEEP
description: The wild man of Yankee Stadium controlled himself just enough last night to foil the Boston Red Sox again. Dave Righetti, who has walked as many batters this season as he has allowed hits, checked the Red Sox on three hits as the Yankees won a rain-shortened six-inning game, 4-1, at Yankee Stadium. The victory completed a sweep of the three-game series with the American League East leader, slicing the distance between the teams from 10 games to seven.

title: BOBBY CHACON CAN'T STOP FIGHTING
description: He could always read signs of weakness in an opponent. That is why Bobby Chacon has won most of the battles in his life.

title: Viola Records First Victory
description: Twins 5 Royals 2

title: MESA WINS IN COURT AND BID FOR CITIES SERVICE ADVANCES
description: The Mesa Petroleum Corporation got a green light yesterday for its $45-a-share takeover bid for the Cities Service Company when a Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., refused to grant Cities Service an 11th-hour injunction to halt the offer.

title: OUT OF THIS NETTLE
description: The events in Lebanon provide a historic opportunity for American leadership: so analysts on all sides agree, those who welcome Israel's military triumph and those who worry about its cost. The United States, it is said, should seize the moment to help restore a united Lebanon and to move for a wider Arab-Israeli settlement.

title: SESSION ON DISARMAMENT HAS DELEGATES IN A DITHER
description: The General Assembly's special session on disarmament is going in so many different directions it is difficult for even the delegates to get a sense of what is going on.

title: A NUCLEAR FREEZE IMPERILS PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: Spacesuits Loaded on Shuttle As Preflight Work Continues
description: Astronaut spacesuits were loaded aboard the space shuttle Columbia today as preparations continued to start the five-day countdown next Tuesday.

title: STAGE: 'KITTY HAWK,' FAR OUT COMEDY
description: THINGS are not what they seem in ''Kitty Hawk,'' Len Jenkin's new play at the Lion Theater, and obviously they're not supposed to be. Like the joke about trying to find Hollywood inside Los Angeles - there's no there there - so it is with this curious hour-and-a-half, one-act phantasmagoria. It's avant-garde, but there's no garde there.

title: States Back Phones Draft
description: State regulatory agencies and several consumer groups called on the House of Representatives today to pass a telecommunications bill scheduled for consideration Thursday by the Committee on Energy and Commerce. The committee is expected to approve the measure.

title: N.H.L. Negotiating For Soviet Amateurs
