description: S ports authorities in the Soviet Union are reacting coldly to the New York Rangers, Minnesota North Stars and Los Angeles Kings, each of whom selected a Soviet player in the seventh round of the National Hockey League amateur draft last week. In Moscow, a spokesman for the Soviet State Sports Committee, the country's governing body for sports, said the drafted players would not be permitted to play abroad, and certainly not for professional teams.

title: World Bank Studies Rates
description: Directors of the World Bank next month will consider offering poor countries loans with variable interest rates for the first time in the bank's 37-year history, Hans Hittmair, its deputy treasurer, said today.

title: 'MININUKES' HELP DETER THE RUSSIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITAIN IN THE FALKLANDS: MORALITY, LEGALITY AND THE U.N. CHARTER
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CHAD LEADER FACING HOSTILITY
description: Hissen Habre, the former Defense Minister who has emerged victorious from a civil war, has won, so far, the northern half of a country whose south is as hostile to him as it is economically vital.

title: Technology; Data Access In Your Pocket
description: AUTOMOBILE and portable radios have made it possible for people to listen to broadcasts wherever they are. Now a similar mobility is coming to business communications.

title: Why No Major Trades Have Been Made
description: W ith all of the major league club owners and many of their general managers gathered in Chicago for two days of meetings earlier this week, many baseball executives expected a torrent of trades just before the 8 P.M. Eastern daylight time deadline Tuesday.

title: NEW ORIENTAL RUGS: SHOPPING THE MARKET
description: A detailed drawing guides weavers of Oriental rugs through the intricacies of design. And faced with the complexities of today's market, many consumers might welcome a similar master plan to help them sort out the vast array of modern Oriental rugs, in terms of country of origin, type of weave, pattern and price. Not that Oriental rugs are novel. They have been woven for thousands of years and have been imported for American homes ever since the mid-19th century. But the political revolution in Iran and the commercial revolution in United States-Chinese relations have caused a merchandising revolution in Oriental rugs.

title: LEHRMAN IS PICKED AS G.O.P. DESIGNEE FOR GOVERNORSHIP
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, a multimillionaire who challenged the established leaders of the Republican Party, won the party's designation for Governor of New York yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: You Can't Tell the Party Without a Scorecard

title: Bowie Kuhn Lives
description: O ne of the most illustrious of all baseball cliches is about to be laid to rest. Can you imagine Ernie Banks no longer saying ''Let's play two''? Can you imagine Phil Rizzuto no longer saying ''holy cow''? Can you imagine a baseball commissioner no longer having the expression ''It's a league matter'' in his verbal arsenal?

title: A.O. Smith Cuts
description: The A.O. Smith Corporation, the Milwaukee-based diversified manufacturer with interests in automotive, agricultural and construction products, announced that it would reduce its corporate staff by 20 percent, saving the company $2 million. The company, which lost $6.8 million on sales of $176.8 million in the first quarter of 1982, will abolish 26 positions, including those of four officers. A.O. Smith's president, J.R. Parker, said in a statement that the action was being taken to reduce costs and decentralize the company, which has been hurt by downturns in the housing, auto and agricultural markets.

title: SHOWROOMS STEAL SHOW AT EXHIBITION IN CHICAGO
description: As Neocon 14, the National Exposition of Interior Contract Furnishings, got under way in the Merchandise Mart this week, the consensus among the office and residential furniture buyers, dealers, manufacturers and the dozens of designers and architects who congregated here was that this annual event was more an exhibition of new showrooms than one of new products. It was also an exhibition in which big names in modern architecture predominated and soft pastel colors flourished.

title: News Analysis
description: The lack of the usual political ''bosses'' and the diffusion of power in the New York State Republican Party was on public display yesterday in its efforts to reconcile competing power groups and put together a state ticket.

title: BRIEFING
description: V.A. Problem on Hold

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Edwin J. Beinecke Jr. on Monday incorrectly described his position with the Sperry & Hutch- inson Company. He had been chair- man of the executive committee.

title: Oil Imports Off in Europe
description: The 10 members of the European Economic Community imported 2.63 billion barrels of oil in 1981, substantially below the 3.47-billion-barrel target ceiling set in 1979, according to the annual energy survey by the community's executive commission.

title: Pontiac Sports Car
description: The General Motors Corporation's Pontiac car division plans to make 480 sports cars, or ''P'' cars, a day in the United States starting in the 1984 car model year, according to Wards Automotive Reports, a weekly newsletter. It said Pontiac had tentative plans to assemble the ''P'' cars, or plasticbodied automobiles with the engine directly behind the two seats, at 480 units a day, or 115,000 cars each year.

title: Advertising; Samsonite Is Pushing Soft Line
description: DESPITE a flat sales scene in the luggage business, David T. McGoldrick, president of the Luggage division of the Samsonite Corporation, Denver, made a brash move coming into 1982. He went to the parent company, Beatrice Foods, and recommended a doubling of the ad budget to something between $5 million and $6 million.

title: ISRAELI ASSURANCE OPENS BEGIN'S WAY TO SEEING REAGAN
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States had been reassured by Israel that its troops would not seize Beirut. This, they said, insured that President Reagan would meet with Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

title: Isle Off Africa Gets New Cabinet
description: The left-wing alliance that won elections in this Indian Ocean island state last week appointed a Cabinet today.

title: FACTORY USE OFF TO 70.8% IN MAY, A 7-YEAR LOW
description: The nation's manufacturers operated at just 70.8 percent of capacity in May, the Government reported today. Last month's rate was the lowest in seven years, although the monthly drop was smaller than those in the previous two months.

title: A Snag Develops In Sale of Nuggets
description: Only 24 hours after the transaction had been announced, B.J. (Red) McCombs said today that there was only ''a 50-50 chance'' that he would complete his purchase of the Denver Nuggets.

title: CONSERVATION REPORT FINDS LACK OF A FEDERAL ROLE
description: The Conservation Foundation, in a report on the ''State of the Environment 1982,'' said today that the Reagan Administration had failed to establish ''a positive Federal role in maintaining and enhancing the nation's environment.''

title: EXPERT PANEL ON CANCER ISSUES GUIDELINES ON DIET
description: For the first time, an expert panel of the National Academy of Sciences has fully explored the association between nutrition and cancer and today issued a list of dietary recommendations.

title: STATE PAYING PART OF MEDICAID FOR A YEAR
description: Governor Carey signed into law today a bill that provides for a one-year state takeover of a portion of local Medicaid costs.

title: Don't Milk the Consumer
description: Times are hard on America's farms, but no one told the cows: dairy production is at record levels. To maintain prices at the legislated minimum, the Federal Government must buy up $2 billion worth of butter, cheese and powdered milk for its already bulging warehouses. That's why President Reagan is right to ask Congress for permission to freeze the dairy support price for the rest of 1982, and if surpluses persist, to lower it in January.

title: ARGENTINE JUNTA 'AGONIZES' OVER ITS RESPONSE TO BRITISH
description: Argentina's military rulers met through much of today in an attempt to formulate an official Government response to British demands that they end all hostilities in the South Atlantic.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET PLEDGE ON NUCLEAR WAR IS EMPTY
description: The United States said today that a pledge by the Soviet Union not to use nuclear weapons first was ''unverifible and unenforceable'' and was an ineffective way to reduce the dangers of a nuclear war.

title: Panel Votes Revisions In Tobacco Allotments
description: The House Agriculture Committee today voted to force nonfarming institutions such as corporations and public utilities to give up their valuable Government-issued tobacco production rights.

title: THE UNDERGRADUATE MUST BE A TRUE PROFESSIONAL
description: To the Editor:

title: ROUTE TO THE MERGER OF CATALOGUE STORES
description: Modern Merchandising Inc., the catalogue showroom retailer based in Minnetonka, Minn., has been up for sale for at least three years. But it has taken two years of a squeeze on profit margins, expensive growth through acquisitions and a difficult economy to convince Harold Roitenberg, its chairman and chief executive, that the time was right for a merger.

title: POP: DIONNE WARWICK SINGS
description: producers Burt Bacharach and Hal David were synonymous with 1960's pop sophistication, has matured into a regal pop-soul diva in recent years. And on Tuesday in Carnegie Hall, where she sang with a 30-piece orchestra, Miss Warwick appeared in excellent voice.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gene Shue of the Washington Bullets was voted coach of the year in the N.B.A. by a news media panel for the second year in a row.

title: BOGUS SOCIAL SECURITY CARDS WERE TOO NEAT, SENATORS TOLD
description: Federal investigators told a Senate committee today that they had cracked a ring of swindlers trafficking in fraudulent Social Security cards because the applications for the documents were too neat to pass for Government work.

title: Construction Costs Up 5.3%
description: The cost of construction materials and labor around the nation rose 5.3 percent, down from 6.2 percent last year, according to an annual survey by the McGraw-Hill Information Services Company.

title: Western-Wien Link Endorsed
description: An administrative law judge recommended approval of the proposed merger of Western Air Lines Inc. and Wien Air Alaska, the Civil Aeronautics Board said.

title: Bio-Dynamics Sale
description: The Boehringer Mannheim Corporation, the domestic unit of the West German pharmaceutical company Boehringer Mannheim, said that the Andersen Group of Bloomfield, Conn., had agreed in principle to buy its Minneapolis-based Bio-Dynamics Medical Imaging division for $10 million. The division has annual sales of about $10 million, an Andersen spokesman said, which are expected to grow to about $50 million annually in three years. The division also introduced two new ultrasound diagnostic systems that can scan and provide highresolution images of veins and arteries.

title: Jump Up the Ladder
description: The Chicago Black Hawks were so impressed with the work of Orval Tessier in the junior leagues and with their Canadian farm club that they passed up more seasoned candidates to name him head coach of the National Hockey League club. The 49-year-old Tessier admitted that he was at ''somewhat of a disadvantage'' because he spent so much time in the junior leagues, but the Hawks' general manager, Bob Pulford, was confident enough to offer him a multiyear contract.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 17, 1982; The Economy
description: Housing starts rose 22.3 percent in May, to an annual rate of 1.09 million, the Commerce Department reported. It was the first time since last July that the figure had exceeded 1 million. Analysts attributed the May increase to a surge of housing construction in the South, to greatly increased construction of condominiums and to increased Federal construction activity. (Page D1.)

title: IN LEBANON, A MOURNFUL GHOST TOWN
description: From the heights of this Beirut suburb, the runways of the capital's airport can be seen through the morning haze. The lights reflected from the shimmering Mediterranean cast occasional flashes on the two large jetliners on the empty tarmac.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article June 3 about the history of United Press International incompletely described its policy on rates. Although the news agency says it offered some newspapers and radio stations cut-rate prices in the past, it adds that its rates have been uniform since 1979 and that 25 newspapers have become subscribers this year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AT THE KEYBOARD

title: CUBA'S DEPENDENCE ON WEST
description: Two decades after the Castro Government openly embraced socialism, the slump in world sugar prices has brought an uncomfortable reminder of Cuba's continuing economic dependence on the West.

title: Journal Says Qaddafi Weighs Sending Troops to Lebanon
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was reported today to have said that Libya was seriously considering military intervention in Lebanon to counter what he described as a brutal and barbarous invasion by Israeli forces.

title: FALKLAND DOCTOR IS CREDITED WITH HELPING SET UP TRUCE
description: A young doctor, braving shell fire, is said to have brought about the first contact between British and Argentine commanders on the Falklands for talks that led to the Argentine surrender.

title: GUIDED ARCHDIOCESAN SCHOOLS
description: Msgr. John J. Voight, pastor of St. Helena's Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx and former secretary of education for the Archdiocese of New York, died Tuesday at Calvary Hospital after a brief illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Total Eclipse of Moon To Occur Next Month
description: Americans will get a chance to view a full eclipse of the Moon early next month. The eclipse will occur early on the morning of July 6 and the Moon will be totally in shadow for 106 minutes, according to the United States Naval Obseratory, which said that a lunar eclipse of that length would not be matched in this century.

title: ALGERIA STUNS WEST GERMANY, 2-1, IN WORLD CUP
description: The World Cup tournament was startled today by one of soccer history's major upsets as Algeria defeated West Germany, a two-time champion, by 2-1 in Gijon. The match was the first ever in the World Cup for the North Africans.

title: MAY STARTS IN HOUSING UP 22.3%
description: Housing starts rose 22.3 percent in May, to an annual rate of 1.09 million, the Government reported today. It was the first time since the start of the recession last July that the figure exceeded 1 million.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: Stalled L.I.R.R. Train Holds Up Thousands
description: A disabled train that stalled in an East River tunnel yesterday afternoon caused extensive delays on all trains leaving and entering the city and created large crowds of frustrated rush-hour commuters in Pennsylvania Station, the Long Island Rail Road reported.

title: STUDY ASSERTS B-1 BOMBER'S COST MAY EXCEED WEINBERGER ESTIMATE
description: An internal Defense Department study asserts that the fleet of new B-1 long-range bombers that the Reagan Administration proposes to build would cost $26.7 billion, or 30 percent more than previously disclosed.

title: HINCKLEY REFUSES TO TESTIFY AND 2 SIDES REST CASES
description: Testimony came to a close this afternoon on the 37th day of John W. Hinckley Jr.'s trial as both sides rested their cases and the defendant said he had made a final decision not to take the stand. Closing arguments by the opposing lawyers are set for Thursday.

title: George Russell Concerts
description: Joseph Papp's New Jazz at the Public will present the George Russell Big Band Friday and Saturday evenings at 10 o'clock in the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. These programs will be the first New York concert appearance in three years for Mr. Russell, who is regarded as an influential composer of extended jazz works.

title: CHILEANS FEARFUL OF THE ARGENTINES
description: Bernardo Mora, a construction worker savoring oysters in the Mercado Central here, said Argentina would have attacked Chile had it not seized the Falkland Islands instead. ''It was either them or us,'' he said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Co. of America filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $250 million of debt securities and warrants to purchase debt securities, to be underwritten by First Boston Corp.

title: CHINA'S MINORITIES FIND A PLACE IN THE SUN AT LAST
description: The mountain men of the Wa ethnic group had a custom that upset their neighbors. They would grab some hapless victim and chop off his head to insure a plentiful harvest of the rice that they planted in fields slashed out of the rain forest.

title: EXHIBITS FEATURE PAPERMAKING ART
description: The American Craft Museum I and II are celebrating the medium of hand papermaking in three exhibitions. At Museum II, in the lobby of the International Paper Plaza at 77 West 45th Street, a lively mix of historical murals, technical charts and contemporary works of art are on display in ''Papermaking U.S.A.: History, Process, Art,'' which runs through Oct. 1. Artists whose works are represented include Kenneth Noland, Chuck Close and Robert Arneson.

title: Stocks Off in Active Trading; Dow Slides 4.37, to 796.90
description: The stock market ended moderately lower yesterday in accelerated trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average sinking below the 800 mark, its key support area.

title: News Analysis
description: The merger guidelines that the Justice Department issued this week provide little actual guidance on which mergers will pass legal muster, many antitrust experts say. Despite the adoption of the Herfindahl index, a mathematical standard to measure market concentration, they say the guidelines neither address the practical problems of merger law nor change the department's enforcement policy to any significant degree.

title: BEGIN TELLS CABINET TO IGNORE REPORTED U.S. THREAT
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin sent a message to the Cabinet from New York today urging the Government to make its decisions concerning military action in Lebanon without regard to reported hints that President Reagan might cancel his meeting with the Prime Minister if Israeli troops seized Beirut.

title: Clorox Chief Selected As Chairman in Shift
description: The Clorox Company announced yesterday that Calvin S. Hatch, president and chief executive officer, has been elected chairman of the board as part of a management transition he termed ''orderly and planned.''

title: S.E.C. Settles Fraud Charge
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that Kidder, Peabody & Company and one of its representatives had violated antifraud laws.

title: STAGE: MAMET EXPLORES THE FALL OF 'EDMOND'
description: CHICAGO IN David Mamet's new play, ''Edmond,'' the portrait of a man swept away by a wave of events beyond his control is as bleak and relentless as that in Buechner's ''Woyzeck,'' a play with which it shares common ground. The title character of Mr. Mamet's drama, in its premiere at the Goodman Theater, swirls from rejection to desperation to a homicide that seems almost involuntary. Woyzeck is the essential uneducated common man; Edmond is a middle-class contemporary suburbanite, but Mr. Mamet clearly sees him as a representative of an abused underclass.

title: U.S. Steel Sets Trading Mark
description: The largest block trade in the history of the New York Stock Exchange occurred yesterday when 5.25 million common shares of the United States Steel Corporation traded at a price of $18.25 a share.

title: BRITISH WARN ENEMY OF RISK FOR ILL P.O.W.'S IF WAR LASTS BUT TERMS STILL SPLIT JUNTA
description: Britain warned today that hundreds of Argentine prisoners of war in Stanley could die from hunger soon unless their country pledges to cease all hostilities over the Falkland Islands.

title: Thompson Executive Is Going to McCann
description: After 17 years with the J. Walter Thompson Company, William C. Thompson Jr., 43 years old and no relative, is moving to McCann-Erickson Worldwide, where he will be an executive vice president, as he was at Thompson. He will also be on the McCann board, as he was on J.W.T.'s.

title: General Instrument Net
description: The General Instrument Corporation yesterday reported an increase in profits in the first quarter, ended May 30, to a record $27.4 million, or 90 cents a share, from $18.8 million, or 65 cents, in the first quarter last year. Revenues rose to $265.3 million from $220.1 million.

title: Ormandy, Ill, Fails To Complete Concert
description: Eugene Ormandy, conductor laureate of the Philadelphia Orchestra, became ill during the opening concert of the orchestra's 53d summer season Monday night.

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO PRESS BRITAIN TO COMPROMISE WITH ARGENTINES
description: Administration officials said today that President Reagan had decided to press Britain through diplomatic channels to seek a compromise in the Falkland conflict. At the same time, they said, he will continue to support Britain publicly.

title: MUSTO ORDERED TO RELINQUISH HIS 2 POSITIONS
description: A Superior Court judge, upholding the constitutionality of a statute that requires a public official to forfeit his office if convicted of a felony, today ordered William V. Musto to vacate immediately his posts as Union City Mayor and State Senator.

title: STAGE: 'AFTER YOU'VE GONE'
description: ''AFTER YOU'VE GONE,'' the new play by Marjorie Kellogg at the Actors Repertory Theater, is and isn't. It is and isn't a well-made play; it is and isn't comic lunacy; it is and isn't any identifiable category that comes easily to mind. Think of it as a dream play, although it isn't exactly that, either.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''With all these human beings in a very sad and sorry state, we are getting absolutely no cooperation whatsoever from the Government of Argentina.

title: Toyota, Nissan Exports
description: The Toyota Motor Company said its vehicle exports in May fell 8.9 percent, to 149,900 units, from 164,500 in April and down 4.4 percent from 156,800 a year earlier.

title: A New President For Bankers Trust
description: Charles S. Sanford Jr. will become president of the Bankers Trust Company at the end of the year, Alfred Brittain 3d, chairman, announced yesterday. Mr. Sanford, 45 years old, now an executive vice president, will succeed John W. Hannon Jr., who will take early retirement. Mr. Hannon is 60.

title: RAVITCH SAYS FARE RISE MAY BE PUT OFF TILL 1983
description: Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday in discussing a variety of options that the authority might be able to delay an increase in the 75-cent bus and subway fares until early next year.

title: NEW HOME AND LIFE FOR STUDIO MUSEUM IN HARLEM
description: After 13 years in a rented loft above a luncheonette and liquor store at 2033 Fifth Avenue, the Studio Museum in Harlem will open its new facilities at 144 West 125th Street Sunday. With three times the exhibition space that it had before, and with facilities it no longer rents, but owns, the museum has taken a giant step toward becoming the first major black fine-arts museum in the country.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE TERRIBLE TWOS. By Ishmael Reed. 175 pages. St. Martin's/Marek. $11.95.

title: Texas Police Arrest Man With 34 Child Workers
description: A man the police said was making money from children selling candy has been charged with sexually molesting one of 34 children who were found crowded in two motel rooms here.

title: 'Fidelio' on S.I. Tonight
description: The Metropolitan Opera's free concert version of ''Fidelio,'' scheduled for last night at Clove Lakes Park on Staten Island and canceled because of rain, has been rescheduled for this evening at 8:30.

title: Three for One
description: With his proposed fight against Thomas Hearns called off, Marvelous Marvin Hagler has signed for three defenses of his world middleweight boxing championship before the end of the year. He will fight Fulgencio Obelmejias of Caracas, Venezuela, in San Remo, Italy, on July 15; Frank Fletcher of Philadelphia at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 3 and Tony Sibson of England at a date to be announced.

title: OHIO PAPER REPORTED IN PERIL
description: Television stations reported here tonight that The Cleveland Press, the city's afternoon newspaper, would close after its issue Thursday. If true, the reports would confirm rumors that have circulated for months.

title: ROUGH HEARING FOR REAGAN 'CRISIS RELOCATION' PLAN
description: As if the subject was not gloomy enough, a Congressional panel looking into this city's nuclear civil defense program has just made the disquieting discovery that the sketchy plans thus far composed make no provision for evacuating members of Congress, among others, in the event of a holocaust.

title: Ten Injured in Blast Aboard Carrier Saratoga
description: Ten persons were injured when a 1,200-pound steam valve ruptured today aboard the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Saratoga, which is undergoing a $526 million refurbishing here.

title: Rep. Richmond Loses Bid to Shield Records
description: Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn yesterday lost another attempt to shield some of his business and legal records from a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn. A judge ruled that 23 documents, including some the judge said were created ''in furtherance of fraud,'' had to be turned over to Justice Department prosecutors.

title: EL SALVADOR DENIES VOTE TOTALS WERE INFLATED
description: El Salvador's Central Elections Council has rejected charges that the officially announced vote total in the March elections was fraudulently inflated. It did so in a full-page statement dated Monday and published in the country's largest newspapers this morning.

title: A.T.&T. HAS 'NARROW' RISE OF 8.5%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, blaming the recession for a ''narrow margin of improvement,'' said yesterday that its net income for the three months ended May 31 increased 8.5 percent, to $1.66 billion, or $1.96 a share, from $1.53 billion, or $1.94 a share, in the comparable 1981 period.

title: PLANNING PANEL GIVES APPROVAL ON SATELLITE SITE
description: The City Planning Commission voted unanimously yesterday to clear the way for a private company to build a satellite communications center in a depressed section of Brooklyn.

title: Asian Bloc Bids Hanoi Pull Out of Cambodia
description: Non-Communist countries in Southeast Asia urged Vietnam again today to support a political solution to the Cambodian crisis and blamed Hanoi for endangering peace in the area.

title: Police in West Berlin Arrest 2 Soviet Jews
description: Riot policemen stormed an apartment today and arrested a Soviet Jewish emigre and his wife after he had threatened to throw their six-month-old baby from a window unless his demands were met, the police said.

title: Gloomier View Of '82 Spending
description: Robert J. Coen, senior vice president of McCann-Erickson and keeper and reader of the advertising industry's crystal ball, went on the record yesterday to say that the murky picture of last December is clearer but more gloomy this June.

title: TROUT ON THE HOUSATONIC
description: A n exciting brown trout fishery has been created on a special management stretch of the Housatonic River about 100 miles from New York City.

title: STREET TREES: HOW TO HELP THEM SURVIVE
description: IT'S one thing to plant a street tree. It's another to have it survive. Too many people assume that after they've paid for the planting, someone else will take care of it, which would be nice if it was true, but unfortunately it isn't.

title: Tragic Mideast Puzzle
description: It has been the sad, and repeated, experience of the Middle East that it takes war to break each impasse. The Israeli invasion of Lebanon has been particularly bloody and destructive, but it was foreseeable. The cease-fire of 1981 couldn't have been expected to last indefinitely since it left the Palestine Liberation Organization in limbo, unwilling to make a political breakthrough by recognizing Israel, unable to sustain its program of violence.

title: TEXT OF SURRENDER DOCUMENT
description: Following is the text of the Argentine surrender document, signed in Stanley on Monday by Gen. Mario Menendez, commander of the Argentine forces there, and issued today by the Ministry of Defense in London:

title: HEADHUNTER-IN-CHIEF GETS READY TO GO
description: For nearly two years, E. Pendleton James, the California personnel specialist, has been reading resumes for Ronald Reagan.

title: NIXON'S 'IT'
description: Richard Nixon had a lot of trouble answering Diane Sawyer's question the other morning on CBS. The dialogue: Diane Sawyer: ''You said ...you had made horrendous mistakes.... What was the worst one, the thing that you're most sorry about?'' Richard Nixon: Well, the - the -well, the - if - if - well, it ...perhaps ...on reflection, the thing that was the greatest mistake was in failing to concentrate on it the moment that I got the word on it.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For Starters, A Trip to the City

title: I.B.M. Plans U.S. Videotex
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced its entry into the videotex business in the United States.The company said that in December, it would begin selling software and hardware that would let companies set up private videotex systems, in which employees or customers could call up graphic and textual information on computer screens or terminals.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE AND YOUTHS CLASH OUTSIDE A CHURCH IN SOWETO
description: Hundreds of armed policemen in camouflage battle dress converged today on a church in this black township that was filled to capacity for a service marking the start of the Soweto student rising six years ago.

title: 2 West Bank Councils Are Dismissed by Israel
description: The elected city councils of two West Bank towns, Dura and Nablus, have been dissolved by Israel for refusing to work with the Israeli civil administration.

title: Rights Supporters Stop Illinois House Action
description: The Illinois House fell into chaos over the proposed Federal equal rights amendment today after 12 women who support the proposal invaded the chamber and demonstrated in front of the Speaker's rostrum.

title: SENATE PANEL CLEARS BILL THAT COULD ASSIST TRADE
description: The Senate Finance Committee today overwhelmingly approved an Administration-supported bill strengthening the powers of the President to negotiate lower foreign trade barriers.

title: WHERE IS THE JEWISH VOICE FOR MODERATION?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonn Legislators Criticized
description: Speaker Richard Stucklen of the West German Parliament today reprimanded two members, Karl-Heinz Hansen and Manfred Coppik, who heckled President Reagan when he addressed the chamber last week. The two, both former Social Democrats, strolled around during the speech and perched on bar stools in the aisles. When Mr. Reagan spoke of freedom, Mr. Hansen shouted: ''And in El Salvador?''

title: Market Place; Breakup Value Of Brunswick
description: AWHILE back, the Brunswick Corporation sold its Sherwood Medical I ndustries to American Home Products. The move was intended to d iscourage a takeover bid from the Whittaker Corporation, but the t actic vexed some Brunswick shareholders, who were eager for action. T he stock of the diversified leisure-products company sank from a t akeover high of 28 to the low teens.

title: An Appraisal
description: Fifty years after the opening of its first building - the 31-story tower at 1270 Avenue of the Americas - Rockefeller Center remains the nation's pre-eminent grouping of skyscrapers. Indeed, if anything, the complex is taken more seriously as a work of architecture and urban design today than it was a generation ago.

title: JUSTICE AIDES BACK LEGALITY OF TRAP FOR WILSON
description: Justice Department officials today defended the legality of the international trap that led to the arrest Tuesday of Edwin P. Wilson, the fugitive former intelligence official.

title: South Shore Wins City Title
description: George Tabone (7-0) limited Holy Cross to three hits yesterday in pitching South Shore High School, the public school champion, to a 5-0 victory over Holy Cross, the Catholic school champion, at John Adams Field in Ozone Park, Queens.

title: Bell Helicopter Layoffs
description: Bell Helicopter Textron said today that it was laying off 350 more employees this week, bringing to 700 the number of employees idled this month. Company spokesmen said the workers, whose last day of work will be Friday, will not be needed before next year.

title: Unesco Chief at Acropolis
description: Amadou Mahtar M'Bow, Director General of Unesco, said today that he was surprised at the amount of progress made in work on the Acropolis but he said it was still uncertain whether it could be saved.

title: A GERMAN VILLAGE AND ITS JEWISH SURVIVORS
description: THE title of ''Now ... After All These Years'' reflects the surprise, even annoyance, with which the makers of this forceful, outstandingly good hourlong documentary are greeted by some of their subjects. Their film is about Rhina, a very small Prussian village. A schoolgirl's essay from 1928, read several times in voice-over, explains that until 1923, Rhina was the only Prussian village with a predominantly Jewish population. By 1939 there were no Jews left in Rhina, and there are none there today.

title: M-G-M TRYING TO SELL UA MUSIC CO.
description: A combination of high interest rates, the stock market's slide and a number of expensive movies that did poorly at the box office, which left M-G-M/U.A. struggling under huge bank debts, has prompted the company to negotiate a sale of the UA Music Company and a package of 745 pre-1950 Warner Bros. movies and 327 cartoons.

title: CITY LISTS APPROVED BEACHES
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday released the list of public beaches approved for swimming for the 1982 summer season. Following is a listing of the approved beaches: Brooklyn: Coney Island from Manhattan Beach to West 37th Street.

title: THE TOLL OF LOSING DAY CARE IS STUDIED
description: What happens to working parents who rely on publicly funded daycare programs when they are eliminated from those programs? Do women continue to work? Who takes care of their children? What difference does the availability of good-quality, subsidized day care make in their lives?

title: Rehnquist Leaves Hospital
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court ended a brief hospitalization today but still refused to disclose the reason for his stay. A spokesman said that Justice Rehnquist ''checked out sometime this morning'' from his room at the George Washington University Medical Center.

title: Congress Coalition Opens Fight to Kill Clinch River Project
description: Ninety-one members of the House, joined by a long-time Senate opponent and an unusual coalition of environmental and conservative groups, mounted a campaign today to kill the decade-old Clinch River Breeder Reactor project.

title: Brewery Workers Strike After Rejecting Contract
description: Workers rejected a contract offer and went on strike today at the Jos.

title: U.N. LUMINARIES OF PAST AND PRESENT HONOR ROOSEVELT
description: With appeals to idealism and a considerable helping of nostalgia, officials and scholars at the United Nations today recalled the role of Franklin Delano Roosevelt in creating the organization more than 40 years ago.

title: CONCERT: CRAFT CONDUCTS PHILARMONIC IN 'EBONY'
description: FOR a musician so closely associated with Stravinsky, Robert Craft has been oddly out of sight during the various centenary Stravinsky celebrations. But recently he has conducted at the New York City Ballet, and Tuesday night he was given one program of the New York Philharmonic's Mozart-Stravinsky series at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: News Analysis
description: With the Israeli Army now 50 miles inside Lebanon, it cannot be denied that Israel has scored another stunning military success against an Arab foe. But the Israelis may still be a long way from achieving the political objectives they have set for themselves in Lebanon.

title: U.S. SAYS IT WILL INVESTIGATE CHICAGO COUNCIL REDISTRICTING
description: The Justice Department said today it would heed a request by Jesse Jackson, a civil rights leader, to investigate whether the redistricting of the Chicago city council reduces black representation in violation of the Voting Rights Act.

title: HOLDUP MAN IS SLAIN WITH HIS OWN GUN IN AN EAST SIDE STORE
description: A holdup man was shot with his own gun and fatally wounded last night after a counterman grabbed the pistol and opened fire as the man tried to escape after a bungled robbery of an ice cream store on the upper East Side.

title: Bid to Cut Israel Ties Rejected by Egyptian
description: Egypt's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Boutros Ghali, has rejected suggestions that Egypt sever diplomatic relations with Israel because of its invasion of Lebanon.

title: Blues and Flukes Are Running
description: A Margate, N.J.: Bluefish to 14 pounds offshore, smaller blues in inlets on the flood tide. Fluke fishing good in inlets and inland waters. Point Pleasant, N.J.: Party-boat bluefishing good day and night offshore; half-day party-boat fluke trips producing well. B Sea Bright, N.J.: Blues to 11 pounds being taken, mostly deep, by trolling and bait in Sandy Hook Bay; many small blues, three-quarters to one and one-half pounds, plentiful in lower portions of Navesink and Shrewsbury rivers. Fluke fishing good in inside waters. Captree State Park, L.I.: Half-day morning fluke trips by party boats producing well; some small bluefish inshores; party boats will start night chumming trips for blues near end of month; a few weakfish around. C Mastic Beach, L.I.: Both legal and sub-legal fluke plentiful in Moriches Bay, as are blowfish; winter flounder gone; weakfish scarce. Shinnecock, L.I.: Three-to six-pound bluefish along the beach; Larger blues offshore in 80 to 90 feet of water; a few large striped bass about. Montauk, L.I.: Big bluefish plentiful south of Montauk seven to 10 miles offshore and being taken on umbrella rigs and diamond jigs; cod from 12 to 15 pounds still south of Southwest Block Island; a few large stripers right off Montauk Light; porgies beginning to hit in inland waters. D Southold, L.I.: Porgies plentiful in

title: 3M Employee Plan
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said it would offer this summer a voluntary retirement program to 2,340 employees who reach age 55 and complete 20 years of service by Sept. 1. The company said the program is a ''responsible way to reduce operating costs during the current slack'' economy and to meet current business needs.

title: Workers Approve Pact At Northwest Airlines
description: Striking employees of Northwest Airlines overwhelmingly approved a proposed contract today, ending a 26-day walkout.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: SOLAR ENERGY, BUTTON DISPLAY
description: Sun Day, Cathedral of St. John the Di- vine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, 881-5888.

title: STRAVINSKY, DANCERS AND MEMORIES
description: IT was a half hour to performance time, backstage at the New York State Theater. But this was performance time with a difference, as dancers and musicians readied themselves for an evening in the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Centennial Celebration - the fourth in a series of festivals held over the last decade to pay homage to the great composers.

title: A Pickoff That Wasn't
description: T he busiest place in college sports these days is probably the office of Ron Fraser, the baseball coach at Miami. People are still besieging him with calls to congratulate his team on winning its first national championship, but more often to marvel at the fake pickoff play that trapped the fastest base-stealer in college baseball.

title: HERS
description: Joan Didion has called New York ''a city only for the very young,'' which may or may not be true. What is certain is that ''very young'' in New York is often older elsewhere. One is ''very young'' here, still, at 23 years old; elsewhere 23 is a man or a woman, maybe a spouse, maybe a parent.

title: STAINING OAK FOR MISSION LOOK
description: Early 20th-century oak furniture has survived well through the years for good reason. Sometimes called mission oak, it was designed in supposed imitation of the furnishings of Spanish missions in California and the Southwest. It was characterized by plain lines and dark color, and when sturdily built of heavy oak it was virtually indestructible.

title: FOR MOTHERS, THE RULES CHANGE, THE JOB DOESN'T
description: I was sitting on the front porch stoop, my clipboard on my lap, the warm evening breeze moving me into a twilight zone of reflections. I was watching my two small ballplayers on the park strip across the street, captured by the charming awkwardness of their summer bodies as they performed the street theater of their game.

title: 2 U.S. Airmen Die in Crash
description: Two United States Air Force pilots were killed today when their plane crashed at Papenburg, near the Dutch border. The Air Force said their Phantom plane had been taking part in a tactical air exercise near Jever Air Base, which is close to the North Sea northeast of Papenburg.

title: SOUTH KOREA CHIEF URGED TO QUIT
description: A Roman Catholic church group in South Korea has called on President Chun Doo Hwan and his Government to make the ''courageous decision to step down.''

title: Datapoint Has Loss of $23 Million
description: The Datapoint Corporation, suffering from a weak economy and irregular marketing practices, reported yesterday that it lost $23 million in its third fiscal quarter, ended April 30.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am building a house with an above-ground basement that I eventually plan to finish as an additional living area. For now I want to install insulation between the basement and the living area above in order to conserve heat. If I install the insulation with the vapor barrier on top (toward the upper area), should I later install another layer of insulation with the vapor barrier facing down since both sides will be heated? - E.W., Manhattan.

title: ISRAELIS SEEK A FRENCH ROLE IN LEBANON
description: Despite a cool reception, Israel has been pushing hard to win France's support for the creation of an international force to replace Israeli troops in southern Lebanon.

title: Indian Givers
description: India contends that Time magazine profits from the news it gathers in the world's largest democracy and wants to tax the gain. It figures the profit must be about 25 percent of expenses, so it would tax a fourth of whatever correspondents spend to gather news.

title: 4 LITTLE WORDS TURN A PLAY IN NEW DIRECTION
description: THE theater is a peculiar place, perhaps because all its lines are spoken aloud, perhaps because the people speaking them are actually present. In any case, there's an extra dimension about the stage that is capable of making the simplest of phrases blood-curdling. A line doesn't have to have ugly words in it in order to be ugly; it can chill the cockles of your heart by being altogether casual.

title: 1,250 FROM POLICE ACADEMY TO GO DIRECTLY TO FOOT PATROL
description: New York City will have more police officers on foot patrol this summer and fall than it has had in years, according to police officials, who said yesterday that 1,250 of 2,600 rookies would be walking a beat the day after their graduation June 25.

title: WHERE IS THE JEWISH VOICE FOR MODERATION?
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Campaign Official Says A TV Ad Had Run Its Course
description: The head of the Republican Party's Congressional campaign committee today denied a White House statement that television advertisements with actors portraying Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and Jimmy Carter had been withdrawn.

title: 10 Groups to Perform Sunday Art on Beach
description: Ten dance and music groups will perform Sunday afternoons on a picturesque sandlot in lower Manhattan from July 11 in the Art on the Beach arts festival, sponsored by Creative Time Inc.

title: 22 ACRES OF REAL ESTATE THAT GENERATE MILLIONS
description: Rockefeller Center is 50 years old this year. Begun in the Depression, it today constitutes one of the most successful real estate ventures in the world.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ferries in the Future?

title: Directors & Boards Plans to Accept Ads
description: Five-year-old Directors & Boards magazine, a quarterly with paid circulation of 2,500, 70 percent of which consists of chief executive officers, is going to accept advertising beginning with its fall issue, but only 24 pages an issue.

title: Wienerwald Chain Will Be Cut Back
description: Wienerwald, the worldwide restaurant chain, has announced a further step in its reorganization designed to meet the approval of the group's 24 Swiss and German creditor banks, which are owed the equivalent of $107 million.

title: ROUGH IS READY AT THE U.S. OPEN
description: The United States Open will begin Thursday morning on the Pebble Beach Golf Links, a gem of a course that for the moment is a more important subject of interest than the potential winners in the field of 153. This will be the second time the Open has been played on Pebble, the other being in 1972, when Jack Nicklaus won with 290, two over par.

title: RISE SEEN IN USE OF UNUSUAL CANCER THERAPY
description: Growing numbers of cancer patients are turning toward dubious ritualistic treatments and ''natural cures'' based on the notion that a purified body can cure itself, according to a researcher at the University of Pennsylvania Cancer Center.

title: Price Cases Settled
description: The Energy Department said it had reached separate proposed consent orders with the Getty Oil Company and the Williams Exploration Company.

title: AID ON MORTGAGES APPROVED IN HOUSE
description: The House brushed aside the threat of a Presidential veto today and approved an $8.9 billion supplemental spending bill that includes $3 billion for an emergency program to aid the housing industry.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 17, 1982
description: International Many Argentines could die from hunger soon unless their Government pledges to halt all hostilities over the Falklands, Britain warned. The commander of Britain's South Atlantic task force said that many of the 15,000 prisoners were seriously ill with malnutrition, dysentery and a parasitic skin disease. He said there was no shelter for most of the captives from the blizzards and subzero temperatures in the islands. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Argentine leaders tried to shape an official response to British demands that they halt all hostilities in the Falkland dispute. Informants said that the three-member junta was seeking to formulate a response that would not bar Argentina from resuming the war despite the surrender of its ground troops. (A16:1-2.)

title: WITH COURT HELP, A MASON WINS CETA CERTIFICATE
description: Two years after she enrolled in a 20-week federally financed bricklayer's training course, Dorothy Blitz, whose entry into the program created a dispute with the Government, finally has her mason's certificate.

title: Jury Still Considering Cunningham Verdict
description: The jury in the tax-evasion trial of Patrick J. Cunningham completed its second day of deliberations yesterday without reaching a verdict.

title: Clean Bill for Thompson
description: David Thompson's wife was so upset over his alleged use of cocaine that she reportedly sought help from the police six months ago, but pro basketball authorities who investigated the report agree that the problems of the Denver forward are all ''in the past.'' Cathy Thompson, his wife, asked the police to deter the supplier who allegedly was providing Thompson with cocaine, according to a copyright article in The Denver Post.

title: IN SIDON, 80 MORE BODIES FOR A VAST BULLDOZED PIT
description: The bodies of more than 80 Lebanese civilians were found today under two buildings destroyed during the Israeli invasion, Lebanese and Israeli relief officials reported.

title: BRIDGEPORT FIGHTS ORDER TO EDUCATE 2 EXPELLEES
description: The Board of Education here has been ordered to educate two students who were expelled after being charged with carrying or firing guns in their high schools.

title: ROBERT J. KIBBEE, CITY U. CHANCELLOR, IS DEAD AT 60
description: Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, the chancellor of the City University of New York, died at his Manhattan home last night at the age of 60. His death, after a long illness, came two weeks before he was to retire from the post he had held for more than a decade.

title: Polish Clergy Discuss Pope's Planned Visit
description: Archbishop Jozef Glemp summoned leading Polish bishops to Warsaw today to discuss last Sunday's street riots and their possible effect on the planned visit of Pope John Paul II.

title: THE PHONE THAT RINGS THURSDAYS ONLY
description: Congress is not totally overlooked in ''crisis relocation.'' Every Thursday morning at 10 o'clock sharp, a special beige telephone rings in the offices of the Congressional leadership, and the caller says hello and hangs up, then rings it again, confirming that this, the emergency warning line, is open and operating.

title: AT SCHOOL IN TYRE, GUNS AND ROCKETS
description: Like most schools in this part of the world, the Bab al-Wad Elementary School, near the center of the former Palestinian command center of Tyre, has an underground shelter for the children in case of attack. And like most schools throughout the world, it has a playground. But the shelter and the playground had another purpose until Israeli troops invaded Lebanon and captured Tyre last week.

title: Stock Indexes And S.E.C.
description: A House panel today passed a measure to increase the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission over stock index futures contracts.

title: SENATOR SEES LITTLE CHANCE FOR DONOVAN TO RETAIN JOB
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, expressed doubt today that Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan would be able to survive the mounting calls for his resignation.

title: Karen Rogers Rails At Injury Publicity
description: Rider Says Emphasis Is Sexist By STEVEN CRIST

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: REPLACING an old ceiling lighting fixture with a new one is a task that is both electrical and mechanical -electrical because there is obviously some wiring involved and mechanical because ceiling fixtures have to be very securely mounted on or suspended from a ceiling box or bracket. (In some areas, local building regulations stipulate that only a licensed electrician may do this kind of wiring, so if in doubt check with your local building department.)

title: Raybestos Plans Restructuring
description: Raybestos-Manhattan Inc., a manufacturer of energy absorption and transmission products for the automobile, construction and farm equipment industries, said today that its shareholders had approved the restructuring of the company into a new holding company, the Raymark Corporation, as of June 28.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Dark Ages in Astoria

title: NAVY IS BUILDING ANTI-CUBAN RADIO
description: The Navy was quoted today as saying that it had begun building four, 250-foot antennas for Radio Marti, even though Congress had not authorized funds for the station.

title: A DISCUS SPANS THE AGES
description: S cene: Olympic Stadium, Mexico City. Evening. October 15, l968. A thunderstorm. Action: Al Oerter, 6-foot-4-inch discus thrower, blue U.S.A. jacket soaking wet, hair matted, ascends the winner's stand. A soggy official slips the gold medal Oerter has just won around his size extra extra large neck. National anthem. American flag is raised to the highest pole on the rim of the flood-lighted stadium.

title: STEINBRENNER: I'M NOT ANGRY, HIDING OR SELLING
description: George Steinbrenner said yesterday that he was not angry at the losing record of the Yankees this season, denied that he had been hiding during a time of trouble and declared that he had not thought of selling the club.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: ONE of the joys of haunting the London streets in the 1920's and 1930's was the sight of something new by Virginia Woolf in a bookstore window.

title: Rain Cancels Mets, Pirates
description: The Mets' series finale against the Pittsburgh Pirates was postponed tonight because of rain. Randy Jones, scheduled to start, now goes in the second game of Friday night's doubleheader in St. Louis as the team doesn't play Thursday.

title: Dayan's Party Is Dissolved; Begin May Gain 2-Vote Edge
description: Telem, the party created by Moshe Dayan to contest the last Parliament elections, broke up tonight. The 18-member steering committee handpicked by Mr. Dayan, who died last year, decided to dissolve in view of the wide ideological differences and to permit the party's two representatives in Parliament to choose their own course.

title: U.S. AIDE DISCLOSES NEW POLICY ON RUSSIANS
description: A senior White House adviser, Thomas C. Reed, disclosed tonight that the principal new element in President Reagan's recently updated national security policy was the determination to prevail over the Soviet Union.

title: Amoco in Indonesia
description: The Amoco (Indonesia) Lombok Petroleum Company said today that it had signed a production-sharing contract with Pertamina, Indonesia's state oil company, for a 25,500-squarekilometer block off Lombok Island. Amoco paid a signature bonus of $1.2 million and committed itself to a $68.8 million work program over six years.

title: National Steel Sees 'Significant' Loss
description: The National Steel Corporation, the nation's No.4 steel company, said that it expected a ''significant'' loss in the second quarter of this year. As a result, the company said it had cut its dividend to 25 cents from 50 cents a share, payable June 30 to shareholders of record July 1.

title: 'S' NOVEL ON SALE IN U.S., AFTER CANADIAN DISPUTE
description: Ian Adams, author of ''S: Portrait of a Spy,'' made legal history in Canada two years ago when in a libel case he was ordered by the Ontario Supreme Court to disclose his sources. He declined. What made the $2.2 million case against him and his publisher remarkable is that ''S'' is a novel.

title: MORE THAN ONE WAY TO GO AROUND IN CIRCLES
description: To the Editor:

title: MORGENTHAU TESTIFIES IN TRIAL OF A LAWSUIT ON BADEN DISMISSAL
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan testified yesterday that Dr. Michael M. Baden had been ''extremely cavalier and uncooperative'' about evidence lost by the Medical Examiner's office.

title: NLT's Bid Raised In Takeover Battle
description: The NLT Corporation of Nashville, locked in a takeover battle with the larger American General Corporation of Houston, raised its bid to $55 from $50 a common share yesterday for the 11.2 million American General common shares it wants to acquire.

title: YIELDS RISE ON 2 YEAR U.S. NOTES
description: Rising interest rates resulted in an average yield of 14.43 percent for new two-year Treasury notes sold yesterday, up from 13.77 percent at last month's sale and far higher than the 14.05 percent yield that was expected as recently as a week ago.

title: HELPING FAMILIES AID SCHIZOPHRENICS
description: The average home life is too stressful for most schizophrenics, but if families learn to work out their problems calmly, the recovery of people suffering from the mental disease improves dramatically, researchers say.

title: JERSEY MAN INDICTED IN KILLING OF WOMAN AND CBS WORKERS
description: A New Jersey man was indicted yesterday on charges that he murdered three CBS employees on a rooftop parking lot in Manhattan and a woman who had been cooperating with a Federal investigation.

title: Pope Bids Israel Show Magnanimity in Beirut
description: Pope John Paul appealed to Israel today to show magnanimity in Lebanon, saying that he feared for those besieged in southern Beirut and now facing a decisive battle.

title: SAUDIS' SMOOTH CHANGE OF RULE IMPRESSES EXPERTS
description: Western specialists say that the smoothness of the leadership transition in Saudi Arabia since the death of King Khalid two days ago suggested that the change of rulers was likely to have only imperceptible effects on the country's domestic and foreign policies in coming months.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Monday on the United Steelworkers of America incorrectly reported the union's highest membership in recent years. It was 1.4 million.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN JUDGE BARS SOME EVIDENCE IN MERCENARIES' TRIAL
description: A judge trying 43 mercenaries accused of hijacking an airliner after a bungled coup in the Seychelles agreed today to a request by South Africa's Defense Minister that some evidence should not be heard.

title: CABLE TV FOR NEW LEAGUE
description: The United States Football League will announce today that cable television will broadcast two games a week, both in prime time, when the league's first season begins next March.

title: Nowak Gets to Handle Region for Pizza Hut
description: Unlike some of the super-sized fast-food chains, Pizza Hut does not have a national advertising program of network television run from headquarters, plus a regional program run by franchise-operator associations.

title: Costa Rican to Visit U.S.
description: Costa Rica's recently elected president, Luis Alberto Monge, will leave Sunday for a twoweek visit to the United States during which he will meet President Reagan, the Government announced today.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
FOR SPORTS EQUIPMENT
description: GETTING all your summer sports paraphernalia organized will keep the house tidy and the equipment in good condition and easy to find. The diverse shapes of bats, racquets, mitts and balls make finding one storage unit for all of them difficult.

title: KOCH AND CITY LEADERS STILL AT ODDS ON BUDGET
description: The Board of Estimate and the City Council tentatively agreed late last night to make changes worth about $50 million in Mayor Koch's proposed budget, with more than half the money earmarked for the public school system.

title: BRITAIN IN THE FALKLANDS: MORALITY, LEGALITY AND THE U.N. CHARTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Delaware Gunman Gives Up After Holding Lawyer 5 Hours
description: A gunman who held a lawyer hostage for five hours surrendered to the police today, the authorities said. The police had originally believed at least five hostages were being held in a downtown law office, but only the lawyer, John Grady, was released when the suspect surrendered.

title: Americans in Kenya Fired On
description: An unidentified gunman opened fire on a bus carrying seven Americans on safari today but ''everybody hit the floor'' and no one was hurt, one of the tourists said. William Ashley, 69 years old, of Bellport, L.I., said one bullet tore through the side of the bus as it drove through the Masai Mara game preserve, about a mile from the Tanzanian border.

title: Eager to Return
description: J.R. Richard, who was partly paralyzed by a stroke in 1980, has asked the Houston Astros to move him up from an instructional league to Tucson, their top minor league team. The 30-year-old pitcher rejects the suggestion that he should work his way up gradually through the minors. Although he has been throwing at the Astros' instructional school in Sarasota, Fla., Richard has not pitched in a regulation game.

title: WATERGATE: A DIKE THAT CAN LEAK
description: Watergate was a shocking reminder of the e ver-present need for vigilance against the corrupting influence of p ower. The aftermath, because of American idealism and the strengths o f constitutional government, brought a reaction and important r eforms that can be maintained and expanded only by the constant v igilance of informed and active citizens.

title: How to Promote Learning
description: What seemed not long ago to be a distant dream for New York's schools has evidently become a reality. Over half the pupils exceed the national norms in reading and mathematics. While reading progress this year was less spectacular than in the last two, the gain in math was seven points, to 56.5 percent. The city's educators and children deserve applause.

title: Harvester Orders
description: The International Harvester Company, the debtridden maker of farm machinery and construction equipment, announced that it had received dealer orders for about 2,500 medium- and heavyduty trucks with a retail value of about $100 million.

title: PHILADELPHIA RETRIEVING A HIDDEN HALL
description: For Hyman Myers, the experience at City Hall was like burrowing into an Egyptian tomb and uncovering a chamber of treasures. Hearing an excited shout from an assistant, he crawled through the dust and darkness of a space between a thirdstory ceiling and the fourth-story floor and looked into a black cavity.

title: Cuba Reports Getting 'Huge' Supply of Arms
description: Cuba has recently received ''huge quantities of modern and sophisticated weapons,'' the Cuban Vice President, Dr. Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, said today.

title: Atari Game Rights
description: Atari Inc., a division of Warner Communications, said that it had granted exclusive worldwide rights to manufacture and distribute the coin-operated video space game Tunnel Hunt to Centuri Inc., a maker of video games based in Hialeah, Fla. The value of the accord, Atari's first such licensing agreement, was not disclosed. Earlier this year, Centuri granted Atari a four-year license to develop home video games from Centuri's inventory of arcade games.

title: City and Western Party
description: Visitors to ''Jubilee 11,'' the 11th annual block party of the West 79th Street Block Association, will dance to a country and western beat Sunday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. on 79th Street, between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues. Three bluegrass and country bands will perform, and there will be games, rides, antiques and crafts and food. Information: 362-7011.

title: U.N. EXPECTED TO EXTEND PEACE FORCE IN LEBANON FOR 2 MONTHS
description: The Security Council plans to renew on Friday the mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon for a limited period even though their positions have been overrun by Israeli troops, delegates here said today.

title: STAGE: 'ALBERT NOBBS,' AN EARNEST MASQUERADE
description: A YOUNG woman calls herself Albert Nobbs and pretends to be a man in the male-dominated society of Ireland in the 1860's. Her reasons are largely economic, but the demands of her role are such that she believes she has to reject all possibility of sexuality. This is the subject of a George Moore story, supposedly based on an actual episode, which the French playwright-director Simone Benmussa has turned into a play, ''The Singular Life of Albert Nobbs.'' It is an oddly haunting piece of theatrical chamber music, at times so low-key as to be dim wattage, but one that holds our attention like a tale told at the fireside.

title: VERA ZORINA RETURNS TO DANCE STAGE
description: ''I NEVER saw her or heard her. Yet I continually bless the name of Ida Rubinstein for, because of her, I've had a whole second career,'' Vera Zorina said the other day during a break between rehearsals for her part in the Stravinsky Centennial Celebration at the New York State Theater.

title: Inco Shutdown
description: Inco Ltd. announced that its Inco Metals Company unit will not resume production before the end of August, even if the strike by its 10,750 workers ends earlier.

title: 2 Firms Acquired By Mills & Allen
description: Mills & Allen International, a British financial services and advertising company, said it had acquired the Garvin GuyButler Corporation, a New York money market and Eurodollar broker, and the Guy Butler International Group, based in London, for a total cost of $42 million.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * CP National Corp.'s debentures outstanding were raised by Standard & Poor's to a BBB rating from BB+ and its preferred stock to BBB from BB.

title: U.S. Payments Show a Surplus
description: The United States improved its balance of payments in the first quarter, with the broadest measure of international transactions showing a surplus of $1.2 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

title: THE A.C.L.U.'s ACTIVE WATERGATE ROLE
description: To the Editor:

title: SURRENDER EXPECTED TO BRING BETTER U.S.-LATIN TIES
description: Despite Latin America's dismay at American support for Britain in the Falkland conflict, Washington's relations with much of the continent may not have been permanently damaged by the crisis, according to diplomats, government officials and other experts in the region.

title: BAXTER ROLE UPHELD IN I.B.M. CASE
description: A Justice Department internal investigation has concluded there was no conflict of interest involved when William F. Baxter, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division, dismissed the Government's suit against the International Business Machines Corporation, a department official said yesterday.

title: HORN & HARDART EXPANDS ITS TEAM
description: Horn & Hardart used to mean Automats. Today, the company owns most of the Burger King and the Arby's roast beef restaurants in the New York area, 22 Arby's outlets in south Florida, 100 Bojangles chicken and biscuit restaurants with headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., a mail order division called Hanover House and, for old times' sake, one Automat, at 42d Street and Third Avenue.

title: CHIEF NAMED AT A.T.& T.'S NEW UNIT
description: With news conference flourishes, American Bell Inc. was born this week. The company, which will begin operations July 1 in Parsippany, N.J., is a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that will offer the first A.T.& T. products free of Government regulation. As such, its performance as a new profit center will be drawing attention, as will the man chosen to head it.

title: DEVLIN AND ROGERS SHARE THE LEAD
description: Nobody attacks the Pebble Beach Golf Links with impunity, and so on the first day of the 82d United States Open, subpar rounds were as scarce as low-interest loans.

title: MONEY FUND ASSETS FALL AFTER 6-WEEK RISE
description: After a six-week rise to a record high, the assets of the nation's 213 money market funds declined by $291 million during the week ended Wednesday, to $202.39 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: TEST RUN IN PHILADELPHIA FOR DEMOCRATIC HOPEFULS
description: The Democrats are warming up again for one of their intermittent national gatherings, packing their placards and buttons and position papers, snarling at the Republicans and worrying about which Democrat will upstage another.

title: A FEARFUL MOBUTU SEEKS SAFETY THROUGH ISOLATION
description: President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire went to South Korea on a state visit recently, but, from reading the officially controlled newspapers here, his departure from the capital was not apparent. The secrecy, the President's critics assert, reflects a nervousness about the security of his leadership of this vast, potentially rich and currently impoverished nation.

title: GULF OIL IS PLANNING $5.1 BILLION MERGER WITH CITIES SERVICE
description: In a $5.1 billion deal that would be one of the biggest corporate acquisitions on record, the Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy the Cities Service Company.

title: PLAYS
description: F or one fleeting moment at 6:54 A.M. yesterday, a 22-year-old waiter from Dayton, Ohio, stood in the center of the golfing world. Jack Nicklaus, Tom Watson and the big-money men were nowhere in sight when Brian Fogt, an amateur, stepped to the first tee at the Pebble Beach Golf Links. He peered through the mist of the Monterey Peninsula in California, selected a 3-wood from his bag and squared away to fire the first shot in the 82d tournament for the United States Open championship.

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 18, 1982; Companies
description: Gulf Oil has agreed to take over Cities Service in a $5.1 billion deal that would be one of the biggest acquisitions ever. The move was seen on Wall Street as an effort to frustrate an unwanted takeover of Cities Service being pressed by Mesa Petroleum. A Gulf-Cities Service merger would be exceeded in size only by the purchases of Conoco by Du Pont and Marathon Oil by U.S. Steel, and would create the nation's seventh-largest industrial corporation. (Page A1.)

title: Economic Scene; Pragmatism And Dowries
description: WITH so much excitement around the world - Israelis battling Syrians in Lebanon, the British rounding up Argentines in the Falklands, the biggest crowd in the history of the nation calling for a nuclear freeze -the economic story has been driven off page 1. President Reagan doubtless hopes it will stay off.

title: Salvador Rebels Report Downing Army Copter
description: Salvadoran guerrillas said today that they had shot down an American helicopter that was carrying the country's Deputy Defense Minister and a senior combat commander.

title: A SPOTLIGHT ON THE ASIAN AMERICAN FILM
description: The fifth annual Asian American International Film Festival opens today at New York University's Schimmel Auditorium with the premiere of a tragic love story made in China, Shui Hua's ''Regret for the Past.''

title: KOCH AGREES TO ADD $140 MILLION TO CAPITAL BUDGET
description: After last-minute negotiations with members of the City Council and Board of Estimate, the Koch administration agreed yesterday to add nearly $140 million to its capital budget for the coming fiscal year, bringing the total to $2 billion.

title: SERVICE INDUSTRIES MAKE BIG JOB RIPPLES, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: Israel is wrestling with its conscience. The pride in the army's military prowess, the hatred of the Palestine Liberation Organization, the determination to make the border with Lebanon secure - all these stand against a gnawing sorrow, a guilt being salved by vigorous efforts to provide humanitarian aid to the Lebanese civilians who had the bad fortune to live in the path of Israel's invasion.

title: OUSTED ARGENTINE LEADER IS A VICTIM OF SYSTEM THAT RAISED HIM TO POWER
description: Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri was the victim of Argentina's defeat on the Falkland Islands by British, a defeat he brought on by ordering the islands seized 11 weeks ago.

title: FOR CITY'S YOUNG, THE LIVING IS NOT EASY
description: Barbara Blair's first New York apartment was a railroad flat with one tiny bedroom that she shared with a roommate. ''There was no privacy,'' she said, ''but it was nothing like my second apartment, which was a horror.''

title: JUDGE AT HINCKLEY TRIAL BARS 2 REPORTERS FOR A DAY
description: Two reporters for United Press International were barred from attending final arguments today at the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr.

title: 2-DAY FOLK CELEBRATION SALUTES THE HUDSON
description: The fifth annual Great Hudson River Revival, a two-day festival of music, dance, displays and ethnic food, begins tomorrow at Croton Point Park in Westchester County on the banks of the river that its organizers are seeking to improve.

title: BEGIN TELLS LEADING U.S. JEWS OF INVASION'S GOALS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel told officials of American Jewish organizations yesterday that the Israeli Army would remain in Lebanon as long as the Palestine Liberation Organization posed a threat to the security of his country.

title: RESTAURANT RECORDS SEIZED BY I.R.S. IN BROAD INQUIRY
description: Teams of tax agents armed with search warrants seized financial records at three Manhattan restaurants yesterday in a Federal investigation designed to uncover ''the skimming of large amounts of cash'' in the restaurant industry.

title: SUBTLE PSYCHIATRIC DEBATE OVER HINCKLEY
description: To the Editor:

title: AT 11th HOUR CITY ADOPTS A BUDGET OF $1.54 BILLION
description: The City Council and the Board of Estimate, racing to beat a midnight deadline, formally adopted New York City's next budget last night.

title: Failures Post 50-Year High
description: More businesses failed last week than in any week since the Depression of the 1930's, snapping a four-week slowdown in the count, a private credit information service said yesterday.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S U.N. SPEECH ON THE NUCLEAR ARMS RACE
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address yesterday to the United Nations second special session on disarmament, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: POTENTIAL TROUBLE SPOTS FOR WEEKEND TRAFFIC
description: A. Henry Hudson Parkway: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street because of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation. B. Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive: Two lanes will be closed in either direction from the Brooklyn Bridge to the Battery. Also, the southbound ramp at Robert F. Wagner Sr. Place will be closed. Farther north, one northbound lane will be closed to traffic at 42nd Street as a project to strengthen the roadbed continues.

title: SCHOOL CROSS PURPOSES
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Works of Max Ernst Donated to Library

title: Israel Moves Managers Into Southern Lebanon
description: Israel has moved military administrators into the war-battered cities and towns of southern Lebanon, and there are indications they may remain for some time.

title: PRESIDENT OF BENNINGTON SELECTED FOR CITY U. POST
description: Dr. Joseph S. Murphy was selected last night by a search committee to be the next chancellor of the City University of New York. The nomination, which is considered virtually certain to be accepted, will be subject to approval early next week at a meeting of the university's board of trustees.

title: Poland's Bishops Hint Pope's Visit Is On
description: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops told Pope John Paul II today about their efforts to organize his August visit to Poland, hinting that they thought his journey would still take place.

title: Mean Joe Maradona
description: The commercial featuring Mean Joe Greene and the boy giving his bottle of Coca-Cola to Greene became an instant advertising classic and went on to win many awards.

title: Croquet, Anyone?
description: The metropolitan chapter of the Victorian Society in America will hold its third annual croquet tournament on the lawn of the Lyndhurst estate in Tarrytown on Sunday afternoon. Beginning at 1:30, visitors to the estate can watch the day's events unfold with a croquet demonstration for novices. Tournament play will begin soon after, with the finals scheduled for 5:30 P.M. For more information, call the Victorian Society, 783-0945, or Lyndhurst, (914) 631-0046.

title: Suit Is Dropped
description: The Artex Manufacturing Company of Merriam, Kan., has withdrawn its lawsuit filed against the Yankees and their principal owner, George Steinbrenner, a company spokesman announced Wednesday.

title: N.B.A. KINGS GET NEW YORK OWNERS
description: Three New York City businessmen, all friends, purchased 50 percent of the Kansas City Kings yesterday, making that team the third one this week in the National Basketball Association to receive an influx of new capital and ownership.

title: Stanford Dean to Leave
description: Rene C. McPherson, dean of the Stanford Business School since 1980, announced in Los Angeles today that he intends to resign the post no later than September 1983.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: CHRIS DIFFORD and Glenn Tilbrook of the English rock band Squeeze are polite, cheerful, even a little self-deprecating when you meet them. Mr. Difford can be a hearty conversationalist when he gets warmed up, while the slimmer, more boyishly handsome Mr. Tilbrook remains quiet.

title: 2 Plead Guilty In OPM Case
description: Two men pleaded guilty to tax evasion as part of a continuing Federal investigation involving more than $200 million in frauds carried out through OPM Leasing Services Inc.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 18, 1982
description: International A major shake-up in Argentina is under way. Leopoldo Galtieri resigned under pressure as President, Army commander in chief and junta member. Government sources said he would be replaced as President temporarily by Maj. Gen. Alfredo Oscar St. Jean, the Interior Minister, while the junta decides on a permanent successor. (Page A1, Column 6.) Argentina denied Britain's request to allow British ships to return prisoners taken in the Falklands directly to Argentine ports, the Foreign Office announced. However, later Argentina announced that it would send ships to the islands to pick up the prisoners in an operation aided by British ships and the Red Cross. (A1:4-5.)

title: 3 CARIBEAN PREMIERS DEFEND REAGAN'S DEVELOPMENT PLAN
description: Three Prime Ministers from Englishspeaking Caribbean nations defended the Reagan Administration's Caribbean development plan today, saying it would not contribute to unemployment in the United States.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ALASKA MAILING $1,000 CHECKS FROM OIL INCOME FUND TO RESIDENTS
description: The first $1,000 checks went into the mail in Juneau early today to begin a most unusual distribution of state funds.

title: F.C.C. REPEALS CURBS ON PAY TV STATIONS
description: The Federal Communications Commission today repealed regulations that have restricted the number of cities where pay television stations may operate.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SEKS CUBAN PULLOUT
description: West Africa, June 17 (Reuters) - Prime Minister P.W. Botha said tonight that agreement on Western independence proposals for South-West Africa was conditional on the withdrawal of Cuban troops from neighboring Angola.

title: JAZZ: BROWNIE'S REVENGE
description: FOR more than a decade, Don Pinto, a small, elfin trumpet player and arranger who usually works with Latin bands, has been holding together a 31-piece jazz orchestra called Brownie's Revenge. Because Maynard Ferguson and Stan Kenton have been primary influences on Mr. Pinto, it is not surprising that Brownie's Revenge is both large and loud.

title: Course Change At Woolworth
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company, which lost $16 million in the first quarter of the year, said it would expand its profitable specialty store operations in a departure from its traditional emphasis on variety and discount stores.

title: PACINO IN 'AUTHOR! AUTHOR!'
description: PACINO laughs. Furthermore, Pacino parents, if that's the word for it. In ''Author! Author!''
