Al Pacino plays a Broadway playwright with one wayward wife, one glamorous girlfriend and five loving, devoted, good-natured children, only one of whom is his own. Israel Horovitz's screenplay is about Ivan Travalian, who loves, struggles, suffers and still never loses his sense of humor.

title: THREE-STATE GUIDE TO THE SUMMER FLEA MARKET SEASON
description: MARKET visitors can be divided between those who go with a clear purpose - seeking a particular item that fills a need or adds to a collection - and those who go for the fun of it, to browse among other people's discards. Nostalgia, of course, plays a big part in the venture. Like Citizen Kane's Rosebud, items are often sought for the memories they may hold - a certain toy or an old cookie jar that conjures up the pleasures of another time.

title: FARM STRAWBERRIES FOR CITY PICKERS
description: Delayed by rainy days and cool nights, the region's strawberry crop is finally ripening on farms not too far from New York City, awaiting visits by pick-it-yourselfers.

title: STUDY SAYS BIRTH CONTROL PILL LESSENS OVARIAN CANCER RISK
description: A four-year study of women who use birth-control pills showed that such women were about half as likely as others to get cancer of the ovaries, according to a new report in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Seuffert Band Opener
description: The Seuffert Band Shell in the Music Grove at Forest Park in Queens will reverberate to the sounds of the Seuffert Band on Sunday at 3 P.M. in a concert marking the start of the 84th year of free public summer performances by the 50-member band.

title: Disaster Relief Chief Named
description: Peter McPherson, administrator of the Agency for International Development, was appointed by President Reagan today to coordinate American disaster relief efforts for Lebanon. Mr. Reagan has already authorized $5 million in relief and has asked Congress for an additional $20 million.

title: Tackled by the Law
description: A former running back who played for four N.F.L. teams has been found guilty of a jewelry store holdup in Reno. Jesse Phillips, whose employers included the Cincinnati Bengals, Oakland Raiders, New Orleans Saints and New England Patriots, faces a maximum prison sentence of 50 years on two counts of robbery and one count of burglary and escape. Phillips was shot by the police as he ran from the scene of the robbery.

title: SPIRITUAL AND SENSUOUS CHORUSES
description: SHOULD music stroke the senses or should it cut cleanly to the soul? From opposite ends of Manhattan this weekend, two singing groups will beg to differ.

title: Clemson Wins Suit
description: A Tennessee judge Thursday dismissed a $12 million suit charging Clemson University with football-recruiting violations. Special Chancery Court Judge William Inman threw out the suit filed last December against the university, head coach Danny Ford and Knoxville businessman and Clemson alumnus Thomas Breazeale.

title: Sony, Hitachi List Earnings
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that second-quarter earnings fell 21.7 percent while Hitachi Ltd. said earnings for the fiscal year ended March 31 rose 6 percent.

title: Collegian Granted Compensation Pay
description: Indiana State University will probably appeal a court ruling that would grant worker's compensation to a paralyzed football player, the school's president, Richard G. Landini, said today.

title: P.L.O. OFFICIAL IN ROME DIES IN A CAR-BOMB BLAST
description: A Rome-based official of the Palestine Liberation Organization was killed in a car-bomb explosion today, and an anonymous telephone caller claiming to represent the ''Jewish Armed Resistance'' later took responsibility.

title: FREE DEMOCRATS JOLT SCHMIDT'S COALITION
description: The troubled coalition Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt was jolted anew today when its Free Democratic coalition partners voted to form an alliance with the opposition Christian Democrats for key state elections in Hesse in September.

title: Mediation Chief Nominated
description: Kay McMurray will be nominated as director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to succeed Kenneth E. Moffett, the White House announced Wednesday. Mr. McMurray has been a consultant and arbitrator since 1977. From 1972 to 1977 he was a member of the National Mediation Board and served two terms as chairman in that time.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT may not have rained on anybody's parade this week, but it did r ain on a couple of garden parties. The 200 or so Italian-American w omen (and a few men) that Mayor Koch had invited to a cocktail r eception at Gracie Mansion on Wednesday watched the downpour from t he crowded salon, but their spirits were undampened.

title: N.F.L. Players Get Data on 'Rights'
description: The July newsletter from the National Football League Management Council to N.F.L. players explains the procedure by which they can resign from the players association without threat of disciplinary action when the collective bargaining agreement expires on July 15.

title: 32d Session of A-Talks Held
description: American and Soviet negotiators met for two hours and 20 minutes today in the 32d session of talks aimed at reducing nuclear arsenals in Europe. United States officials said the next session was scheduled for Tuesday. Details of the talks have not been disclosed.

title: Trade Panel's New Chairman
description: Alfred E. Eckes, a former Congressional staff member and history professor, was named chairman of the United States International Trade Commission today by President Reagan.

title: THE BALLET: 'FOUR CHAMBER WORKS'
description: THE best new choreography so far in the New York City Ballet's continuing Stravinsky Centennial Celebration turned up Wednesday night with the premiere of Jerome Robbins's ''Four Chamber Works'' at the State Theater. It is an instant crowd-pleaser.

title: People
description: * Walter G. Burek, Bertrand M. Lanchner and John B. Roedig have been elected senior vice presidents at N.W. Ayer Inc.

title: SENATE REJECTS WEAKENING CLAUSES
description: The Senate worked until about 1 A.M. today on the revised version of the Voting Rights Act after Senator Jesse Helms halted his filibuster against the landmark civil rights legislation.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY VOTES TO IMPOSE GASOLINE SURTAX
description: The State Assembly approved a 5 percent surtax on gasoline tonight, and Governor Kean signed a measure raising the state tax on a pack of cigarettes from 19 to 24 cents hours after the State Senate sent it to him.

title: 'DIRTY TRICKS'
description: -Do you remember Gemstone, Ruby I and II, Sedan Chair I and II, and Chapman's Friend? These were code names for covert operations managed and financed by the Nixon White House and the Committee to Re-elect the President. Their purpose was to gather political intelligence, sow dissension in the Democratic Party and, most important, defeat Edmund Muskie's efforts to win the Democratic nomination. They attracted less attention than the attempted burglary of the Democratic National Committee's office and the ensuing cover-up that led to Richard Nixon's resignation, but they probably represented a far graver threat to democratic institutions. The tragedy is that so little has been done to prevent them from happening again.

title: SINGLE PARENT HOMES ON RISE
description: WASHINGTON 17 (AP) - The Census Bureau reported today that the number of families headed by one parent had doubled since 1970, a change that officials said had been caused primarily by divorce.

title: CONFERENCE AGREES ON BUDGET FOR '83 ALONG G.O.P. LINES
description: Members of a House-Senate conference committee agreed late Thursday night on a budget for the fiscal year 1983 and early this morning adopted the entire budget resolution on a voice vote.

title: NEW LEADERS SAY THEY'D BRING P.O.W.'S HOME WITH BRITISH HELP
description: President Leopoldo Galtieri resigned under pressure today as President, Commander in Chief of the army and member of the ruling military junta.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ALL Australians, says the Australian-born director Bruce Beresford, think their country is the center of the world. ''And they imagine that when the bombs start dropping, they'll demolish Sydney and Melbourne, because that's where everything happens.''

title: Conoco Considers Sale of Reserves
description: Conoco Inc., a subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, announced that it was considering selling some oil and gas reserves of Continental Oil Ltd., an oil and gas partnership with interests in Oklahoma and Texas.

title: ART: KIESLER'S 'GALAXY,' SURREALIST OPERA SET
description: EVERY so often, there surfaces a marvelous work that serves to remind us of the big bang of Surrealism and its effect on New York artists during the 1940's. Such a work is the late Frederick Kiesler's ''Galaxy,'' an austerely brilliant stage set made for the 1948-49 production of the Darius Milhaud opera, ''Le Pauvre Matelot,'' at the Juilliard School of Music. That set and nine other Surrealist-influenced sculptures by David Hare done between 1944 and 1959 make up the cast of ''Two Installations,'' the current show at the Grey Art Gallery of New York University, 33 Washington Place (through Aug. 13).

title: PROTECTING CITIZENS
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alcan Aluminum Ltd. of Montreal said that its Aluminum Company of Canada unit would buy about 2,200 acres in the Laterriere area of Quebec for the possible construction of an aluminum smelter.

title: GENE SARAZEN AT 80
description: year-old-face. And soon dozens of strangers were surrounding the small, spry, sturdy ''Squire'' who won the Open 60 years ago and 50 years ago.

title: THE LATEST VERSION OF WHO'S TO BLAME FOR U.N. MIX-UP
description: The apportionment of blame in this town is an activity to be savored and discussed like a fine wine and planned with all the concentration of a chess match. Sometimes, when there is no success, there is nothing else to do.

title: ART: SHOW AT DRAWING CENTER OFFERS A DOZEN NEW NAMES
description: FAILING the sunshine, there are always group shows to mark the arrival of summer, and as usual, the lineup at the Drawing Center is among the more noteworthy. The 12 participants are all new names, the center's policy being to concentrate on artists who have not soloed in New York and who are not affiliated with galleries anywhere else.

title: Chancellor / Queen; Man for Hard Times
description: Robert Kibbee, the Chancellor of City University, who died this week, may not have won high marks for administration, but he had the political strength and skill his time required. He deserves much credit for CUNY's survival in a turbulent era.

title: BRIEFING
description: Assignment for Inman

title: Hagler Grows Younger After Underage Debut
description: I rving Rudd, the boxing press agent, has a trusty tape measure that recently took four inches off the reach of Sugar Ray Leonard and an inch off the height of Thomas Hearns. Now Rudd has knocked two years off the age of Marvelous Marvin Hagler.

title: BATTLE OF ARGENTINE ECONOMY
description: While the fight for the possession of the Falkland Islands appears over, a battle for control of Argentina's economy is just beginning.

title: RULING IS NEAR ON U.S. DETENTION OF HAITIANS
description: Perhaps Friday, no later than early next week, a Federal district judge here is to rule on whether the United States Government has discriminated against 1,910 Haitians and whether they should be released from detention facilities where most have been held for a year.

title: Is the Steel War Necessary?
description: ''This is especially welcome news,'' is how William DeLancy of Republic Steel described the Commerce Department decision to levy penalties on steel imported from nine countries. The deeply depressed American steel industry has indeed won a small battle in its war to protect its domestic market. But for the economy as a whole, the cost of victory will be high and the benefits modest. No legal or diplomatic manuevering can solve the industry's fundamental problems: excess capacity and low productivity.

title: HINCKLEY BREAKS DOWN, CAUSING RECESS OF TRIAL
description: Closing arguments in the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. were interrupted this afternoon when the defendant reddened visibly and broke down in tears while his senior defense lawyer was describing his hopes of a relationship with Jodie Foster as ''pathetic'' and ''delusional.''

title: A DECADE, DIES AT 60
description: Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, the chancellor of the City University of New York, died at his home in Manhattan Wednesday night at the age of 60. His death, after a long illness, came two weeks before he was to retire from the post he had held for more than a decade.

title: Georgia Loses Star
description: A leading high school football player has lost his scholarship at the University of Georgia over what Coach Vince Dooley described as ''technical violations.''

title: Express Mailman
description: Rayfield Dupree, a 1976 Olympic finalist, will compete in the triple jump today when the national outdoor track and field championships begin at Tom Black Track in Knoxville, Tenn. He says he is happy to be competing anywhere.

title: WATERGATE'S COSTS
description: -The question of what was learned, and lost, in Watergate is usually answered in moral terms (''Our trust in government, already shaky, was further eroded'') or personal terms (''Nixon broke his compact with the American people'') or constitutional terms (''In spite of it all, the system worked and the Republic endures'').

title: PUBLISHER CLOSES THE CLEVELAND PRESS
description: The Cleveland Press, unable to stem multimillion-dollar losses despite a change of owners and an infusion of new money, ceased publication yesterday afternoon.

title: Fujitsu Awarded MCI Cable Order
description: Fujitsu Ltd., a major Japanese computer manufacturer, said it had received an order for a fiber optic communications system from the MCI Telecommunications Corporation.

title: G.O.P. Chairman Cites; Lessons of Watergate
description: Richard Richards, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that a key lesson for Americans to draw on the 10th anniversary of the Watergate burglary was that it showed the need to make the nation's two major political parties strong.

title: U.S. ASKS ISRAEL FOR 2-DAY PERIOD TO LET GUERRILLAS LAY DOWN GUNS
description: The United States has asked Israel to agree to a strict 48-hour observance of the cease-fires in Lebanon to allow time for the Lebanese Government and army to assert control over the Palestine Liberation Organization forces in that country, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: KUWAIT TIES CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: Kuwait, whose players have plenty of incentive to reach the second phase of the World Cup finals, today made its debut in the tournament by surprising Czechoslovakia with a 1-1 tie in a Group 4 match in Valladolid.

title: BEAUTY QUEEN BATTLING TO REGAIN HER CROWN
description: One year ago, Virginia J. Reichardt was sewing thousands of sequins on her handmade gown. She was practicing the guitar after returning from work at 1 A.M. and reciting her speech about ''The Me Era'' after she rose in the morning. Miss Reichardt was soon to win the Miss Connecticut Pageant.

title: Bloodlust in the Donovan Case
description: Senate Democrats are getting unattractively bloodthirsty over the troubles of Secretary of Labor Raymond Donovan. They can't wait a few more days while the special prosecutor, Leon Silverman, completes his investigation into bribery charges and decides whether to prosecute. Instead, they urge that Mr. Donovan step aside until all suspicions are quieted.

title: EX-TRANSIT OFFICIAL GUILTY OF EXTORTION
description: A former official of the New York City Transit Authority was found guilty of extortion yesterday for having taken more than $30,000 in benefits from companies involved in producing the problem-plagued R-46 subway cars.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE REJECTS A 'FARM CRISIS' BILL
description: The House Agriculture Committee today rejected a bill that would have set up the machinery for a mandatory reduction of next year's wheat, feed grain and cotton crops. The legislation, sponsored by Democrats from grain-producing states, would also have provided emergency loans for hard-pressed farmers.

title: ACCESS TO TEACHING STILL HARD FOR MINORITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: SERVICE INDUSTRIES MAKE BIG JOB RIPPLES, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: Cruguet to Return
description: Jean Cruguet, who guided Seattle Slew to a sweep of the 1977 Triple Crown, will return to riding after a 23-month retirement when he is aboard Royal Leader in the sixth race at Belmont Park tomorrow. Cruguet, who turned 43 last March, retired after riding on July 19, 1980 to become a full-time trainer. He and his wife, Denise, have been training a small stable since. Mrs. Cruguet trains Royal Leader.

title: U.S. Inspector Suspended In Slaying of Mexican
description: A Federal tick inspector has been suspended after the shooting death of a Mexican national accused of trying to smuggle a horse across the Rio Grande into Mexico.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Allen Hughes NADIA BOULANGER. A Life in Music. By Leonie Rosenstiel. Illustrated. 427 pages. Norton. $24.95.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Wondering About the Sky, And Returning to Earth

title: ITEL SEEKS TO REORGANIZE AND CHAIRMAN RESIGNS
description: James H. Maloon, a turnaround specialist who joined the troubled Itel Corporation in 1980, resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive over what he said were ''philosophical differences'' with some of Itel's major creditors.

title: Nabisco Brands Assigns Former MCA Accounts
description: The brands that Nabisco Brands decided last month to remove from MCA Advertising after a one-year stay were reassigned yesterday to Benton & Bowles and McCann-Erickson, already on the company's agency roster.

title: BRITAIN SAYS IT WILL CONSIDER PLAN FOR REPATRIATING ENEMY'S TROOPS
description: Britain will consider a proposal by Buenos Aires that ships be sent to the Falkland Islands from Argentina to help in the repatriation of more than 10,000 Argentine prisoners, the Foreign Office said early today.

title: CBS AND FOX IN VIDEO VENTURE
description: CBS inc. and the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation announced that they will begin making, marketing and distributing home video products together, probably within 30 days.

title: OPERA: 'COSI FAN TUTTE'
description: ''Cosi fan tutte'' is often staged as a game in which a bored old cynic plays with the lives of two romantically attached couples with no better object but to prove that eternal fidelity is a provable fraud. For his American debut as an opera director, however, Jonathan Miller has taken a more sober approach to Mozart's work, treating it as a carefully controlled scientific experiment by an 18th-century philosophe, a skeptic and realist in the Diderot mold.

title: ELEANOR DULLES, ACTIVE AS EVER AT 87
description: If Eleanor Dulles had been a man, things might have been different. ''I would have been in the Cabinet,'' she said. ''I would have earned a lot of money.'' Miss Dulles, who is 87 years old now, raps her magnifying glass angrily against a coffee table in her apartment high above Washington. Her brother, John Foster Dulles, was Secretary of State. Another brother, Allen W. Dulles, was director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Miss Dulles, too, had an illustrious State Department career, but as a woman, she faced barriers.

title: Bridge: The Pre-emptive Response; Can Fool Your Opponents
description: When a partnership finds a fit in a competitive auction, or in an auction that may become competitive, it often pays to crowd the auction and let the opponents guess. A situation of this type occurs in responding to an overcall: Most expert partnerships now use a jump response as pre-emptive rather than invitational.

title: DOLLAR RISES SHARPLY; GOLD IN STEEP DECLINE
description: The dollar, buttressed by rising interest rates in the United States, continued its ascent yesterday, again establishing highs against the battered French franc, Italian lira and Canadian dollar. It advanced sharply against other major currencies, although European trading was curtailed because Frankfurt's market was closed for National Day.

title: Brout Co. Merger
description: Seidman & Seidman, an accounting firm with 38 offices nationwide, said that it had agreed in principle to acquire Brout & Company, a regional accounting firm based in New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday incorrectly identified the special prosecutor who is investigating allegations concern- ing Labor Secretary Raymond J. Don- ovan. The prosecutor is Leon Silver- man.

title: Canada's Prime Rate
description: Royal Bank of Canada raised its prime lending rate today to 18.25 percent from 17.50 percent.

title: RENTAL HOUSING GOING UP IN OYSTER BAY
description: So dismal is the climate for building new rental housing in the metropolitan area that the first reaction of an outsider to a place called Norwich Gate is one of disbelief.

title: PUBLISHING: PAUL GALLICO'S MINE STILL YIELDING GOLD
description: PAUL GALLICO has been dead for six years, but the output he left behind - 41 books and perhaps 200 short stories -continues to earn large amounts of money from motion picture and television production companies.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TELLS TRIBE OF TRANSFER
description: The leaders of one of the tribal ''homelands'' that South Africa has created were formally notified today that their Government would soon be dissolved so their territory could be handed over, with all its citizens, to the independent Kingdom of Swaziland.

title: CITY STREETS REFLECT BUSTLE OF U.N. PARLEY
description: One prime minister with a special interest in social conditions took an unannounced tour of Harlem. Busy security chiefs talked about ''hot issues and high risks.'' A receptionist at the United States Mission to the United Nations readied her jellybeans. And a Turkish Cypriot leader walked into a Fifth Avenue toy store and bought a small bowling ball with feet.

title: NEW ARMY STRONGMAN: CRISTINO NICOLAIDES
description: Maj. Gen. Cristino Nicolaides, who was appointed Commander in Chief of the army and newest member of Argentina's ruling junta today, is regarded as a direct, no-nonsense hardliner.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Back Seymour for Senate; Primary Fight is Set
description: The Republican Party's New York State Committee yesterday named Whitney North Seymour as its favored candidate for the United States Senate nomination. But two other candidates won enough committee support to put them on the ballot with Mr. Seymour in a primary election in September.

title: An Old-Timer Meets A New Timer
description: I n this city of impermanence, Louis J. Lefkowitz dropped in the other night at a party celebrating Edward V. Regan's designation once again as the Republican nominee for State Comptroller.

title: THE BRITISH WEIGH COST OF FALKLANDS
description: With fighting apparently at an end, Britain has begun counting the cost of recovering the Falkland Islands - over the last 10 weeks and in the years to come.

title: NOT GUILTY PLEA IN CBS MURDERS; A New Jersey man pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he murdered three CBS employees and a Federal witness last April 12 at a roof-top parking lot in Manhattan.
description: Acting Justice Felice K. Shea of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ordered that the man, Donald Nash, 47 years old, of Keansburg, N.J., be held without bail. He is in the mazimum security wing of the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men.

title: Famed India Outlaw Gives Up With Gang
description: A suspect sought in about 130 murder, kidnapping and robbery cases surrendered to local authorities in central India today, officials here reported.

title: BAPTIST MEETING BACKS SCHOOL PRAYER AMENDMENT
description: Reversing a long-held position, the Southern Baptist Convention has endorsed President Reagan's proposal for a constitutional amendment that would allow organized prayer in public school classrooms.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles. At Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Jim Palmer's lifetime record against the Yankees is 27-14. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Cardinals. (Television - SportsChannel; 6:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 6:30 P.M.) Boxing Henry (Hot Pepper) Brent vs. Mark Pacheco. Brent and Pacheco meet in a 12-rounder for the United States Boxing Association flyweight title. It is the first flyweight title bout in New York since 1931. Brent, of Staten Island, is 6-1-0; Pacheco is 11-7-1. In a 10-round welterweight match, Jose (The Threat) Baret, of the Dominican Republic, meets Gil Miranda, from Jonesboro, Ark. Baret is 10-0 with nine knockouts. Miranda is 9-3. (At Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M.) Larry Holmes vs.Gerry Cooney. (Television - HBO, 10 P.M., tape) Golf United States Open. Second round. (Television -ESPN, 4 P.M.; Channel 7, 11:30 P.M., tape.)

title: Holders Fight Sale Of Milwaukee Road
description: Major stockholders of the Chicago Milwaukee Corporation have asked the trustee of the bankrupt Milwaukee Railroad subsidiary to end talks on its planned sale to the Grand Trunk Corporation unless terms can be renegotiated.

title: 'FABIAN' IN PREWAR GERMANY
description: ''EMOTIONAL Inertia Grips Germany'' - that's a newspaper headline made up by the title character in ''Fabian,'' and it's as good a way as any to convey the film's mood. The action is set in Germany in the 1930's, and the atmosphere is one of studied decadence. People dance, sing and mate with absolute listlessness. All is artificial, all is hollow. Life is a cabaret.

title: 'PARADE OF SAIL' MARKS PHILADELPHIA BIRTHDAY
description: In slow and stately procession, the tall ships came to Philadelphia today, and Philadelphians crowded the shores of the Delaware River to bid them welcome and to glory in the honor of their visit.

title: FRANCES SCLAFANI CONTINUING A RECORD OF SUCCESS
description: There was one exception, a grinning President Reagan told a crowd of New York Republican leaders yesterday, to his pledge of neutrality until after the primary.

title: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES $20 MILLION TO LEBANON
description: A House panel voted today in favor of $20 million in emergency help for Lebanon as several members of Congress assailed Israel's attack against Palestine Liberation Organization strongholds there.

title: Takes Center Stage
description: O n the Lower East Side, tucked just south of the Con Edison smokestacks on 14th Street, the Ninth Precinct's spring theatrical season opened and closed yesterday. Forty-seven children of Public School 61, one of three children's theater units in the Police Athletic League program, performed a ''Firebird'' adaptation that went quite unnoticed in the dance world's Stravinksy centennial.

title: Parker Pen Acts To Improve Sales
description: The Parker Pen Company said it would soon introduce a lifetime guarantee on all its products, reduce its product line from 500 models to fewer han 100 and sign an advertising agency to increase foreign sales.

title: News Analysis
description: The British are a pragmatic people, and their postwar history has been a process of accommodation to the reality of reduced power and to the need to act in concert with allies.

title: FROM YANKEE MINOR LEAGUE TO CARDINAL SUCCESS
description: To wind up as the starting center fielder for the first-place Cardinals was more than Willie McGee dared hope when he was mired for four years in the Yankees minor-league system.

title: Adventures of a centerpiece.
description: AN elaborate silver centerpiece that once graced the table of Gov. De Witt Clinton, and that was subsequently on loan to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for more than a decade, set an auction record last Saturday and this week found its way back to the Met. The traylike centerpiece, which has a mirrored surface and is framed in a pierced gallery of winged lions, urns, garlands and leaves, was sold at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, for $240,000, the highest price ever paid at public sale for a work of American silver.

title: Machinists End Strike At Northwest Airlines
description: Machinists for Northwest Airlines returned to work today, ending a 26-day strike after voting to accept a contract that gives them a top wage of $39,000 a year and gives the airline what it called a ''substantial'' labor concession.

title: MUSIC: WASHINGTON SQUARE FESTIVAL
description: THE 1982 Washington Square Music Festival got under way Tuesday night, but not in Washington Square Park. A few years ago, the festival introduced the idea of presenting its first concert indoors in a Greenwich Village church, and this one was given at Grace Church, the imposing 19th-century Gothic structure on Broadway at 10th Street.

title: CLUE FOUND ON HOMOSEXUALS' PRECANCER SYNDROME
description: Federal epidemiologists investigating a serious disorder of the body's immune system that has mostly afflicted male homosexuals reported new evidence yesterday suggesting that the outbreak is linked to an infectious agent.

title: Question for Cowens
description: Dave Cowens says he would like to make a comeback in the National Basketball Association but in a city other than Boston, where he starred for the Celtics for 10 years until his retirement in 1980.

title: Woman Is Slain In Gramercy Park
description: A young woman was found stabbed to death in her Gramercy Park apartment early this morning, the police said. The woman, who was not immediately identified, was found dead in a fourth floor apartment at 246 East 23d Street at 1 A.M., according to Sgt. Ed Burns, a police spokesman.

title: WHITE HATS AND BLACK HATS
description: Leonid Brezhnev's pledge that the Soviet Union would not be the first to use nuclear weapons, says the State Department, is ''unverifiable and unenforceable'' and ''gives no assurance that an aggressor would not in fact resort to the first use of nuclear weapons during a conflict.''

title: Hidden Injuries
description: It is hardly a secret that National Football League clubs have used the injured-reserve list as a convenient cubbyhole to protect promising rookies and other young players they might otherwise have to cut during training camp. But the N.F.L. plans to expand the independent, random examinations of injured players, to keep coaches from trying to ''hide'' marginally injured players.

title: ANITA B.D. LITTRELL
description: Anita Blaine Damrosch Littrell, the last surviving daughter of Walter Damrosch, died yesterday at her summer home in Tyringham, Mass., after a long illness. She was 78 years old and lived in Boston, Mass.

title: 'SWEET WILLIAM'
description: ''SWEET WILLIAM,'' a 1979 English film opening today at the Thalia, seems less like an artifact of the 1970's than one of the late 50's or 60's. It's yet another example of the peculiarly English, literary subgenre - best represented in films by ''Room at the Top'' and ''Nothing but the Best'' -about the charming rake and his progress through life and dumbfoundingly pliant women.

title: Seychelles Defendant Unexpectedly Set Free
description: A South African-born woman charged with treason in connection with a bungled coup in the Seychelles last November was unexpectedly set free today in the courtroom where she and six white men were on trial for their lives.

title: TRANSPLANT SUCCESS REPORTED WITH PART OF A MOUSE'S BRAIN
description: A piece of brain has been successfully transplanted from one mouse into another, where it not only survived but also correctly hooked itself up and functioned almost normally, a New York scientist reported at a conference here.

title: A JERSEY BUILDER'S STRUGGLE
description: Marshall S. Klein is a home builder who tends to wear a suit more often than his work clothes these days. After all, he does not have much construction to oversee.

title: MINE VICTIM'S SERVICE SET
description: The family of a construction company worker who has been missing since he was buried in the collapse of an abandoned coal mine shaft has scheduled a funeral service Monday. Lucille White, whose husband, Gerald, was buried in the mine shaft May 21, said in a statement issued Wednesday that she had decided to go ahead with the service 'even with the absence of my husband's body.'

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Arum, the boxing promoter, denies that he kept a heavyweight, Tony Tucker, from fighting as a ploy to force renegotiation of their contract. Tucker has filed a suit in Grand Rapids, Mich., asserting that Arum's company, Top Rank, transferred his contract to the National Broadcasting Company without his approval, in violation of their contract. ... The Jets released two free-agent quarterbacks and signed another.

title: U.S. TO LIMIT CLAIM TO WATERS IN WEST
description: Attorney General William French Smith, in a reversal of policy, announced today that the Federal Goverment would no longer assert claims to unused water on Federal lands in the West.

title: Pipe Bomb Injures Yeshiva Pupil, 11
description: An 11-year-old boy playing with his classmates at a Brooklyn yeshiva was seriously injured yesterday when a pipe bomb exploded in the school's playground, the police said.

title: FROM MELLOPHONE TO FLUGABONE
description: ''THERE'S something about me that takes a long time to get boiling,'' said Don Elliott, the vibraphonist, mellophonist and singer who, in the 1950's, was a member of the George Shearing Quintet, the Terry Gibbs Quintet and small groups led by Benny Goodman and Buddy Rich. Singlehandedly, he brought so much recognition to the mellophone as a jazz instrument that he won the miscellaneous-instrument category in the Down Beat magazine jazz poll every year from 1953 to 1960.

title: P.L.O. REPORTEDLY WILLING TO LAY DOWN ITS WEAPONS
description: Kamal Hassan Ali, Egypt's Foreign Minister, said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization leadership in Beirut had voiced a willingness to lay down arms in Lebanon and a desire for talks with the Reagan Administration to move toward ''a mutual recognition with Israel.''

title: SHARED REVENUE A KEY ISSUE
description: George Steinbrenner passes out multimillion-dollar player contracts as freely as if they were handbills. On the other hand, the Yankees' revenue, bolstered by lucrative television contracts, also seems at times to be limitless.

title: BEIRUT QUESTION: PALESTINIANS' FATE
description: Leaders of Lebanon's disparate and often feuding factions, seeking a way to restore stability to their strife-torn country, have yet to tackle a fundamental issue: the fate of more than 600,000 Palestinians living in Lebanon.

title: NEW WARS SHOW POWER OF MILITARY BASICS
description: The fighting in Lebanon, in the South Atlantic and between Iran and Iraq has tended to focus public attention on advanced missiles and weapons, on glamorous military hardware. But the combat also seems to underline the importance of such basic military factors as training, tactics, motivation and the skillful use of standard weapons.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ARA Services Inc., Philadelphia, has appointed Robert J. Franco president of the newly created transportation sector and chief executive officer of Smith's Transfer Corporation.

title: STEALING 'FIREFOX'
description: THE Russians have developed a superweapon code-named ''Firefox.'' It's a fighter plane that flies six times the speed of sound and whose armament can be activated by the brain waves of the pilot, though the pilot must think in Russian. It isn't fair if he thinks in English and then transposes those thoughts into Russian. The possible effects of this estimated two- to three-second advantage over conventional weaponry boggles the minds of British and American intelligence officials. Says one grimly, ''It will change the shape of the world.''

title: Dethroned
description: Too bad Miss Connecticut, who was dethroned this week for dereliction of duty, never saw ''Nashville.'' At least we don't think she did.

title: NOW TRY FOR A JORDANIAN SOLUTION
description: Israel's stunning drive into Lebanon is not so much a response to terror and shelling from the north as an extreme effort to determine the fate of the West Bank and Gaza. But if Israeli forces have crushed the Palestine Liberation Organization's military, and will presently scatter its Al Fatah leaders, they have also advanced the prospects for a fully autonomous Palestinian homeland linked to Jordan. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. is wrong to concede that the Camp David autonomy negotiations should now be put aside. Rather, the Administration should move urgently to promote a Jordanian solution.

title: France and Austria Ask Pullout From Lebanon
description: France and Austria urged today that all foreign forces, not only Israel's, withdraw from Lebanon. In a joint declaration issued near the end of an official visit by President Francois Mitterrand, the two countries demanded that Israel respect United Nations resolutions calling for an immediate cease-fire and the withdrawal of invading Israeli troops.

title: NUGGETS SEND THOMPSON TO SUPERSONICS
description: David Thompson of the Denver Nuggets, once considered pro basketball's most spectacular player west of Julius Erving, was traded yesterday to the Seattle SuperSonics. For Thompson, the Nuggets received Wally Walker, a forward, and the Sonics' first-round choice, the 19th pick over all, in the college draft on June 29.

title: Advertising; 'Nonstop News Machine'
description: THE Satellite News Channel, a joint effort of Westinghouse's Group W and the American Broadcasting Companies, begins its 24-hour-a-day service on Monday, challenging the lock that Ted Turner's Cable News Network has on the cable TV news market. There will, of course, be advertising to help with the introduction.

title: DANES ARE DANCING A NEW KIND OF ORPHEUS STORY
description: It's hard enough for a dance company to go out on a choreographic limb when it is the medium of expression of a living dance maker. But the problems are even greater when the choreographer, dead for 103 years, lives on exuberantly through his highly personal and charming ballets.

title: Andrea Jaeger Quits Tourney
description: Andrea Jaeger, seeded fourth for the Wimbledon tournament that opens next week, had to withdraw from the BMW women's grass courts tennis tournament today with a recurrence of a groin injury.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Billboard, a trade publication. Singles and albums are determined by national sales and radio air-play reports. An asterisk indicates an especially fast-selling record. Albums ThisLast WeekWeek 12Asia* Asia 21Tug of War Paul McCartney 33Diver Down Van Halen 44Original Musiquarium I Stevie Wonder 56Dare* Human League 67Always on My Mind Willie Nelson 79Toto IV* Toto 88Aldo Nova Aldo Nova 95Success Hasn't Spoiled Rick Springfield 1010Chariots of Fire Vangelis Singles ThisLast WeekWeek 11Ebony & Ivory* McCartney & Wonder 23Don't You Want Me* Human League 37Rosanna* Toto 44The Other Woman Ray Parker Jr. 55Always on My Mind Willie Nelson 66Heat of the Moment* Asia 78Crimson and Clover Joan Jett & Blackhearts 816Let It Whip* Dazz Band 917Hurts So Good* John Cougar 1010It's Gonna Take A Miracle Deniece Williams Copyright c 1982 by Billboard Publications Inc.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on June 8 incorrectly characterized the average pay in the National Football League last season, as determined by the league's management council. The figure of $90,000 includes only salary and pro-rated signing bonuses, not fringe benefits.

title: STAB IN THE BACK
description: Prussian officers, after Germany's defeat in 1918, turned for an alibi to the Dolchstosslegende, a medieval tale in which the warrior Siegfried was stabbed in the back. Hitler later revived the same Dolchstoss in den Rucken, using the Jews as scapegoat for Germany's loss of World War I.

title: TORREZ, STAPLETON EXCEL
description: Mike Torrez stymied the Cleveland Indians on four singles for eight and two-thirds innings, and Dave Stapleton slugged his seventh home run to help the Boston Red Sox beat the Cleveland Indians, 6-3, tonight and snap a three-game losing streak.

title: Chile Air Routes Set
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today formally awarded routes between the United States and Chile to eight United States airlines. The eight carriers are American Airlines, Continental Air Lines, Northwest Airlines, United Airlines, Eastern Airlines, Air Florida, Pan American World Airways and TransAmerica Airlines. It is not known how many of the airlines plan to use their route authority.

title: Friday; TRIBUTE TO A TRUMPETER
description: In tribute to the jazz trumpeter Howard McGhee, who is ailing with heart disease, at least 30 musicians will offer ''A Brass Bouquet'' tonight from 11 to 3 A.M. at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets. Among those performing will be Jimmy Owens, Jamil Nasser, George Coleman, Al Grey, Harold Mabern, Woody Shaw and Slide Hampton. Proceeds will help pay for Mr. McGhee's recent hospital expenses. Donation: $10. Information: 924-5026. DAVID FRYE IN THE VILLAGE

title: 75-DAY BRITISH CAMPAIGN WAS WON BY INFANTRY, THE OLDEST WEAPON OF ALL
description: Britain's campaign to recover the Falklands, which ended in the victory at Stanley Monday, began in an afternoon of frenzied activity at the Admiralty on April 2.

title: News Analysis
description: As thousands of marchers inched past a platform in front of the United Nations at last Saturday's huge disarmament march, Elizabeth Holtzman, Brooklyn's District Attorney, told those in the crowd that they constituted a message to President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Transcript of speech, page A16.
description: President Reagan declared today that he was ''ready to take the next steps'' toward arms reduction. But he directly questioned the Soviet Union's sincerity by accusing it of practicing ''tyranny'' and ''oppression'' around the world.

title: Amid Grime of Greeley Sq.,; A New Touch of Green
description: H orace Greeley has never lacked for company amid the traffic roar of his square, 32d Street between Sixth Avenue and Broadway, across from Gimbels. If it wasn't pigeons on his sculptured head, it was a notably gritty set of bench warmers.

title: Elizabeth Taylor's 'Sweet Bird' is due in April.
description: THEY scoffed when Zev Bufman said he would produce plays with, and starring, Elizabeth Taylor; they said it would never happen. ''The Little Foxes'' was one thing, but ''Sweet Bird of Youth'' - a chimera and a dream, or, if you will, just another hype. But now there is the Elizabeth Theater Company, with Miss Taylor as co-producer and resident star, and a signed contract with Tennessee Williams for stage, cable television, tape cassette and probably T-shirt rights, too. ''Sweet Bird of Youth'' goes into rehearsal Jan. 24, plays Palm Beach and Fort Lauderdale in March, then moves on to New York, where it has it first preview April 8 and opens April 18. Then it goes to Washington and Los Angeles. Here is Miss Taylor, speaking from London, to confirm it:

title: 3 YOUNG JOURNALISTS RECEIVE NEW AWARD
description: The first annual Livingston Awards for Young Journalists were presented yesterday at the New York Public Library for the best 1981 local, national and international reporting by journalists under the age of 35.

title: TV WEEKEND FASHION SWEATSHOPS
description: WHAT with reruns and diminishing viewer levels, which are normal for this time of year, the weekend television schedule begins to look like a documentary festival. The range of styles is broad, from investigative reports to cinema verite portraits.

title: An Option Play
description: Joe Cribbs, who has threatened to sit out next season unless his contract with the Buffalo Bills is renegotiated, says he is thinking of playing for the new United States Football League if his salary dispute is not settled. Cribbs, who reportedly earns $100,000 a year, denied that he was holding out for a $1 million contract with the National Football League club. He said he would like parity with such backs as Walter Payton of Chicago, Earl Campbell of Houston and Tony Dorsett of Dallas.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES RISE SHARPLY
description: The credit markets were in turmoil yesterday, as heavy borrowing by large commercial banks helped to push short-term interest rates up sharply while investors and speculators shunned the note and bond market, where prices fell to their lowest levels in four months.

title: Foremost Spinoffs
description: Foremost-McKesson Inc. said that it would divest two of its three homebuilding operations through joint ventures with a new corporation formed by five of its current and former executives. Under the agreement, the new corporation has a four-year option to purchase, for an undisclosed price, $50 million of realty assets of Ditz-Crane of Arizona and Crocker Homes of Dublin, Ariz.

title: MERCE CUNNINGHAM WINS $25,000 PRIZE
description: The choreographer Merce Cunningham received the $25,000 Samuel H. Scripps-American Dance Festival Award Wednesday night, as Joan Mondale called him the ''philosopher-king of dance.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am going because the Army did not give me the political support to continue as commander and President of the nation.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: CHINESE food in Paris ranges for the most part from mildly pleasant to poor. So it was hardly exciting to learn that Tse Yang, the expensive new Chinese restaurant that opened on East 51st Street three months ago, is the spinoff of a Paris original. It is certainly the most lavish Chinese restaurant in New York, with intricately worked Chinese motifs hammered into copper wall panels, thick carpeting, large, widely spaced tables with starchy linens, graceful floral arrangements and a black-mirrored ceiling that dramatically reflects candlelit tabletops.

title: NATO Blames East For Arms Buildup
description: NATO said today that the West had been compelled to strengthen its forces because of a continued military buildup by the Warsaw Pact in Eastern Europe.

title: U.S. ENVOY MEETS LEBANESE LEADERS TO DISCUSS TRUCES
description: Philip C. Habib, the American special envoy, held a series of meetings with Lebanese officials today, reportedly aimed at heading off a collapse of Israeli-Palestinian and Israeli-Syrian cease-fires.

title: Market Place; Weak Quality Of Margin Debt
description: SIDELINED investors who are aware of the current weak condition of margin accounts may be looking for a stock market selling climax. A selling climax usually occurs over the course of a single day. Share prices drop suddenly and precipitously as a result of unanswered margin calls. But during that same trading session, the market recovers with a rush as well-financed investors snap up bargains. After a true selling climax, the market will enter a prolonged recovery phase.

title: Cosmos' Injuries Now at 8 Players
description: The Cosmos' list of injured players swelled to eight today when they announced that Steve Wegerle had a strained muscle in his left leg and would be out for at least 10 days.

title: Soviet Gas Storage
description: The Soviet Union is building an extensive network of underground gas storage sites in depleted wells to insure smooth delivery of Siberian natural gas to all customers, the Soviet minister for the gas industry, Vassily Dinkov, told a gas conference here. Natural gas now provides more than 25 percent of all the Soviet Union's energy, up from 7.9 percent in 1960, he said.

title: DANCE: COPLAND CONDUCTS FOR GRAHAM
description: AARON COPLAND conducted his own score for Martha Graham's ''Appalachian Spring'' at Wednesday night's performance by the Martha Graham Dance Company at the City Center. It was a joyous event. Mr. Copland led a nicely paced and rhythmically buoyant account of his music and, judging from their commitment on stage, the dancers obviously knew that a great composer was present in the pit.

title: THE SPREAD OF DRUGS, AND INDIFFERENCE
description: Drug abuse is spreading to all quarters of society, warns Joseph Califano, the former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, in a new study prepared at the behest of Governor Carey.

title: TONY CONIGLIARO FLASHES SIGNS OF HOPE
description: Tony Conigliaro's uncle spoke of the nightmare almost proudly, as if to illustrate his nephew's continuing ability to overcome adversity.

title: Judge Ends Immigration Rule
description: Judge Robert Aguilar of Federal District Court here today rejected immigration rules barring foreign homosexuals from entering the United States. Judge Aguilar said the rules violated the constitutional rights of free speech and association for homosexuals.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, some copies of the Late Edition yesterday omitted page D6 and carried page B6 twice. Readers wishing copies of the missing page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: HAIG ASSISTANT LEAVING
description: Robert D. Hormats, who has had a hand in the international economic decisions of the last four Administrations and is now Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs, will resign shortly to take a job in the private sector.

title: Standard Metals
description: The Oklahoma Publishing Company and the Standard Metals Corporation announced that they had agreed to drop all court actions brought against each other as the result of a proxy challenge filed by Oklahoma Publishing.

title: DOW DROPS TO A 26-MONTH LOW
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.42 points yesterday, to 791.48, its lowest level in 26 months, as rising interest rates continued to depress stock prices.

title: Woman Wins $19,000 In Toxic Shock Case
description: A Federal jury has awarded almost $19,000 to a woman who contracted toxic shock syndrome after using Playtex tampons. The verdict is believed to be the first time punitive damages have been ordered in a toxic shock case.

title: Saturday Sports
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore. At Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Cardinals. At St. Louis. (Television - Channel 9. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 8 P.M.) Pirates vs. Philadelphia. At Pittsburgh. Steve Carlton seeks 270th Victory. (Television - Channel 4, 1:15 P.M.) Reds vs. Los Angeles. At Cincinnati. (Television -Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Basketball Rucker Pro Summer League Tournament. At Holcombe Rucker Memorial Playground, 155th Street and Frederick Douglass Blvd., 2 and 4 P.M. Boxing Jamie Garza vs. Carmelo Negron. At Las Vegas. The undefeated Garza is ranked third by Ring magazine and Negron 11th going into this 10-rounder in the 122-pound class. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) World amateur championships. At Munich. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M., tape) Rugby England vs. Eagles, the United States national team. At Dillon Stadium, Hartford, 3 P.M. This is the sixth and final stop on the tour by the undefeated Britons.

title: Fassbinder Death Tied To Pills and Drug Use
description: The Munich prosecutor's office said today that Rainer Werner Fassbinder. the West German movie director, had probably died of an overdose of sleeping pills and cocaine.

title: RECOGNIZING THE SYMPTOMS OF REYE'S SYNDROME
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITAIN AND ARGENTINA AGREE ON RETURN OF MOST P.O.W.'S
description: Britain and Argentina have agreed on the return of most of the more than 10,000 Argentine prisoners being held on the Falkland Islands, the Foreign Office confirmed today.

title: Pro Bono Publico
description: I sympathize with readers who complain that newspapers always give you the full treatment when juicy stories first break but almost never tell you later how the plot ends. Our critics sneer that our mental faculties and attention span are stunted. In the interest of dispelling that widespread myth, I offer here updates on three suspense stories in Manhattan.

title: COURT BARS A HEARING ON BAXTER
description: A Federal appeals court ordered a district judge yesterday to ''cease any further inquiry'' into contentions that a conflict of interest was involved in the dismissal of the Government's antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: CONGRESS TAX BREAK ASSAILED
description: A subcommittee of the Senate Finance Committee today held the first Congressional hearing on the $75-aday tax deduction that lawmakers gave themselves last year, and nobody showed up to defend it. But there were plenty of critics.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS VOTE TO HOLD '84 PRESIDENTIAL CONVENTION IN DALLAS
description: The Republican National Committee, after being promised a ''warm welcome'' and nonunion labor in Dallas, voted unanimously today to hold its 1984 Presidential nominating convention there and then cheered predictions of gains in this year's elections.

title: ON THE INCIDENCE OF ALLIGATORS AND HARD TIMES
description: To the Editor:

title: GULF GOAL: DOMESTIC RESERVES
description: Few American oil companies have been more severely hurt by their reliance on foreign sources of supply than the Gulf Oil Corporation. And even fewer have matched Gulf's determination to buy another oil producer with large domestic reserves.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Nyela Mueller is a pianist, and Madelene Capelle a soprano, and together they gave a recital one night for an audience of about two dozen people on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: REBEKAH WEST HARKNESS, 67, PATRON OF DANCE AND MEDICINE
description: Rebekah West Harkness, a philanthropist who gave millions to the dance and to medicine, died of cancer Thursday in her Manhattan home. She was 67 years old.

title:
Patents;
Detecting Bacteria In Water
description: WASHINGTON AMETHOD of detecting the presence and number of harmful bacteria in water has been discovered in a laboratory of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: CITY BUDGET UNBALANCED, REGAN SAYS
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday that the $15.54 billion expense budget adopted by New York City late Thursday night was not balanced and that the city might have to reduce its work force.

title: U.S. HARDENS CURBS ON SOVIET GAS LINE
description: President Reagan, in a major rebuff to West European allies, refused today to ease his ban on the sale of United States oil and gas equipment to the Soviet Union and instead extended the sanctions to foreign companies producing such equipment under American licenses.

title: De Gustibus; SIT-DOWN COMEDY
description: Along with memories of meals that were wonderful, terrible and somewhere in between, a restaurant critic inevitably gathers recollections of dining experiences that, for a variety of reasons, were funny. Some of my favorites follow.

title: Norcen-Hanna
description: Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. said that an appeals court in Cincinnati had agreed to expedite its hearing on the Canadian company's request to lift a preliminary injunction blocking its offer to control the Hanna Mining Company. Earlier this month, Judge John M. Manos of Federal District Court enjoined Norcen's $45-a-share offer for 42.7 percent of Hanna. The judge cited evidence at the time that Norcen had misrepresented its intentions by telling regulators it only wanted an investment position when it planned to take control of Hanna.

title: Manhattan Democrats Reverse Koch Backing
description: After a day of court maneuvers and political acrimony, the Manhattan Democratic organization voted last night to rescind its week-old gubernatorial endorsement of Mayor Koch and support his chief rival, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: U.N. Extends Mandate Of Its Lebanon Troops
description: The Security Council, with the Soviet Union and Poland abstaining, voted 13-0 today to extend the life of the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon for 60 days, diplomats disclosed.

title: Sports of the Times; Six Birdies in a Row
description: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, meaning that the 32-year-old touring pro who grew up on Long Island had put together six consecutive birdies for a United States Open record. But out there on the Pebble Beach course at the time, he wasn't aware he was doing what nobody else had ever done.

title: Hunger Talks in Acapulco
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block will head the American delegation to a ministerial meeting of the World Food Council in Acapulco, Mexico, next week, it was announced today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bad Times, Fondly Recalled

title: Georges Bank Well Is Dry
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said yesterday that its first exploratory well on the Georges Bank off Massachusetts did ''not indicate the presence of hydrocarbons.'' Mobil said that the well would be plugged and abandoned.

title: Sports People; Fight Plans Closer
description: Boxing's back rooms are now active on two major fights - Thomas Hearns challenging Wilfred Benitez for the World Boxing Council junior middleweight title and Alexis Arguello challenging Aaron Pryor for the World Boxing Association junior welterweight championship. Jimmy Jacobs, Benitez's manager, said he was ''very, very positive, and that's one more 'very' than I usually use,'' that the 154-pound title bout will be arranged soon between the two former welterweight champions.

title: Around the Nation; 7 New Orleans Officers Again Face Charges
description: A Federal appeals court today restored indictments against seven New Orleans police officers accused of beating suspects in an investigation of a fellow officer's murder.

title: U.S. Available For Steel Talks
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that he was ''cautiously optimistic'' that an agreement could still be reached with the European governments accused of illegally subsidizing steel exports to the United States.

title: WEST WORRIED ABOUT A PAPAL VISIT TO POLAND
description: Western governments are becoming concerned that Pope John Paul II might agree to visit his native Poland this summer without obtaining what they consider an adequate relaxation in the country's martial law in return, according to diplomatic sources here and in Western Europe.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Weekend Forecast: Depression Moving In

title: Sports People; Criswell Gets 5 Years
description: Kirby Criswell, a former defensive end for the St. Louis Cardinals, was sentenced in St. Louis yesterday to five years in prison after having been found guilty on June 2 by a United States District Court jury of conspiring to make a drug, methamphetamine, and of possession of marijuana. After the sentencing, Criswell said he was shocked at its severity, adding that he felt the judge was making an example of him.

title: Pratt Appointment Approved
description: George C. Pratt, the Federal judge for the Eastern District of New York who conducted several Abscam trials, was confirmed by the Senate today for appointment to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. President Reagan nominated Judge Pratt for the court on the recommendation of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York. The 11-member Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit handles all Federal appeals in New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

title: DON'T BET ON CASINOS
description: It is becoming tempting for government officials who are hard pressed for revenue to legalize casino gambling. But, before they bet on it, they first should examine New Jersey's experience with casinos. They might not like what they find.

title: A.M.C. Price Rise
description: The American Motors Corporation said it would increase the prices of optional equipment on its cars and Jeep utility vehicles an average $35, or three-tenths of 1 percent, and destination charges by $26.

title: SAFETY DESIGN RULES ORDERED FOR CB ANTENNAS
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has voted, 3 to 1, to issue mandatory design standards for tall antennas for citizens' band base stations to prevent deaths from electric shock.

title: FLOOD VICTIMS LINE UP FOR AID IN CONNECTICUT
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency moved into the heart of the Connecticut flood zone this morning, opening a disaster assistance center in the Essex Elementary School gymnasium and providing multipage forms and the promise of succor to scores of victims of the flood that struck the state on June 5 and 6.

title: NOVELIST WON PULITZER PRIZE
description: John Cheever, whose poised, elegant prose established him as one of America's finest storytellers, died yesterday at his home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 70 years old and had been afflicted with cancer for several months.

title: Scouting; Junior Jumper
description: The cast at the national track and field championships in Knoxville, Tenn., includes the world's best long jumper of today and perhaps the best of tomorrow.

title: JUSTICES RULE RETARDED HAVE RIGHT TO TRAINING
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that mentally retarded people in state institutions are constitutionally entitled to safe conditions, freedom from unreasonable physical restraint and at least ''minimally adequate'' training in caring for themselves.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Call to the Chairman, An Answer From the Chief

title: Red Cross Reports Fighting Is Hindering Relief Operation
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that sporadic fighting in Lebanon was hampering relief operations for civilians.

title: Consumer Saturday; MEDICAL INFORMATION BY PHONE
description: ''N O cries were heard in the night,'' the woman says, her voice slow and succinct. ''The death is discovered only when the parents pick the baby up in the morning. Even children of doctors die this way.''

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 17.

title: FORD SET TO SHUT PLANT IN ALABAMA
description: The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that it had decided to shut down its Sheffield, Ala., aluminum casting plant, after a final effort to seek alternatives to keep the plant open. About 1,000 workers will lose their jobs over a gradual phase-out plan that will start this fall and end in late 1983, Thomas Foote, spokesman for the company, said.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.4 BILLION
description: The nation's basic money supply rose by $1.4 billion in the week ended June 9, the Federal Reserve announced late yesterday. That pushed the closely watched measure of money circulating in the economy higher than both the Fed's short- and long-run targets, and left market participants confused and apprehensive about what the Fed's intentions are.

title: American General Loses NLT Round
description: The American General Corporation's request for a preliminary injunction that would have barred a takeover attempt by the NLT Corporation was denied last night by a Federal Judge in Houston.

title: 'ALL THE SECTORS ARE QUIET,' ISRAELIS REPORT ON LEBANON
description: Israel said today that its guns were silent throughout Lebanon, contrary to reports from Beirut about continuing artillery duels.

title: CAR INSURANCE: BEYOND MINIMAL COVERAGE
description: Automobile insurance is different from other forms of coverage because it is virtually compulsory if you own a car. More than half the states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, have laws requiring minimum coverage; the others have ''financial responsibility'' laws that have a similar effect.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 16. 1. It may be the statue that the actress, in an interview, said she posed for in the nude over 50 years ago. The work, Anna Hyatt Huntington's ''Young Diana,'' is in the Boston Museum of Fine Arts.

title: Books of the Times; What Women Wanted
description: THE MAN WHO WAS VOGUE. By Caro- line Seebohm. Illustrated. 390 pages. Viking Press. $18.95.

title: A POLICY IS NEEDED TO HELP CONTROL CHILDREN'S EXPOSURE TO LEAD
description: To the Editor:

title: SPANISH MILITARY AT ODDS ON COUP TRIAL
description: Anger and divisions in the Spanish armed forces have spilled into public view with the house arrest of a general and an admiral, both members of the Supreme Council of Military Justice, because of their vehement views on the treatment of officers convicted in last year's failed coup.

title: Alcan Salary Cut
description: Alcan Aluminum Ltd. of Quebec, struggling with plunging earnings and depressed demand, said that 141 of its top managers would forfeit their salaries for two weeks in the second half of this year, the equivalent of a 7.6 percent salary cut.

title: Scouting; Larger Than Life
description: London's usual pre-Wimbledon fever has begun. And no tennis player seems to generate quite as much excitement there as John McEnroe, who caused a commotion at the world's most prestigious tennis tournament last year.

title: JACOBS RAISES HIS BID FOR PABST STOCK TO $24
description: The battle for the Pabst Brewing Company intensified yesterday when a group of financiers led by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor who is the company's largest stockholder, made a $76.8 million bid to acquire the troubled Milwaukee brewer and sell approximately half of its capacity to the G. Heileman Brewing Company.

title: Berlin Philharmonic Coming
description: The Berlin Philharmonic conducted by Herbert von Karajan will play four concerts in Carnegie Hall next Oct. 19, 20, 22 and 23. It will be the orchestra's first visit to the United States since 1976.

title: U.S. JURY ACQUITS REPUTED CRIME FIGURE IN UNION EMBEZZLING TRIAL
description: A reputed Chicago crime boss, Anthony Accardo, and the former secretary of the Laborers International Union were acquitted today of charges they embezzled about $2 million from the union's benefit fund.

title: CUNNINGHAM FOUND GUILTY ON TAX COUNT
description: Patrick J. Cunningham was found guilty yesterday of evading $14,000 in Federal taxes in 1974 and 1975 and of conspiring to cover up the crime.

title: Dome Petroleum In Talks on Debt
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the largest independent oil company in Canada, has been holding discussions with the federal Government, its bankers and private financial sources in an effort to renegotiate the scheduling of its major principal repayments.

title: PALESTINIAN VICTIMS OF OWN POLITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Syrians Are Rumored Holding Soviet Talks
description: Unconfirmed reports circulated in Arab diplomatic circles here today that the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad, was either in Moscow or was shortly to arrive here for talks with Soviet leaders on the fighting in the Middle East.

title: CONGRESS MOVES TO AID U.S. LENDING TO BUDGET
description: Congress took a first step early today toward extending the scope of the Congressional budget process to include Federal credit activities, a $200 billion function that is now largely outside the domain of overall budget constraints. As it now exists, the budget process is confined to appropriations, or budget authority, and spending, or outlays.

title: NEW PRESIDENT OF SOUTHERN BAPTISTS
description: As the Rev. Dr. James T. Draper takes over the presidency of the Southern Baptist Convention, he has reaffirmed his strict fundamentalism while refusing to denounce the growing number of moderates in the 13-million-member denomination.

title: Briefing
description: Kissinger Turns to Business

title: SOVIET CHIDES REAGAN ON TALK
description: The Soviet press agency Tass said today that President Reagan's speech to the United Nations disarmament session was a disappointment to a majority of the delegates, who, it said, had hoped Mr. Reagan would respond to a Soviet pledge not to be the first to use nuclear weapons.

title: Grand Trunk Continues Bid
description: The Grand Trunk Corporation, a unit of Canadian National Railway, said that it intended to proceed with its plan to buy Milwaukee Road, despite the railroad's objections.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JUNE 19, 1982
description: International ''Total cessation of hostilities'' with Britain would be reached only when Britain withdraws its forces from the Falklands, lifts its blockade of the Argentine coast and ends it economic sanctions, Argentina said in responding through the Security Council of the United Nations to British demands for a formal pledge to end all hostilities. (Page 1, Column 1.) Britain will repatriate most Argentine prisoners of war captured in the Falklands. Under an agreement with Argentina, two British ships will take 6,000 of the more than 10,000 Argentine troops to Puerto Madryn. Argentina is sending two hospital ships to the Falklands to bring home wounded and sick prisoners of war, a British spokesman said. (4:1-5.)

title: Rift Among Socialists Deepening in Portugal
description: A split among Portugal's Socialists deepened today after a setback in a campaign by the party leader, Mario Soares, against party members who support President Antonio Ramalho Eanes.

title: Alicia de Larrocha Cancels Summer Tour
description: Because of illness in her immediate family, Alicia de Larrocha has canceled her entire North American tour for the summer, according to her management company.

title: ALBANY LEADERS AGREE TO SET UP 98 JUDGES' POSTS
description: Governor Carey and state legislative leaders have reached agreement on 98 new judgeships to help deal with increasing case backlogs in New York State, aides to the Governor said today.

title: Letter: On Housing Help Building, Spur the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: In the wee hours this morning, bleary-eyed House-Senate conferees adopted a compromise budget resolution for the fiscal year 1983, and staff members will spend most of the weekend sorting out the numbers. The budget will be on the House and Senate floor for approval next week, and members of Congress are likely to focus on three major questions: Is it credible? Is it achievable? Will it make a difference?

title: News Analysis
description: The economic consequences of France's devaluation of the franc last weekend and the announcement of the first of what may or may not be a series of stringent anti-inflationary measures have yet to be seen.

title: U.N. Dismisses Liberian Aide; Says He Embezzled $200,000
description: A senior United Nations official has been dismissed after being accused of embezzling about $200,000 from a trust fund for African refugees, a spokesman confirmed today.

title: THIEF TAKES GOLD CHAIN OF TRANSIT SPOKESMAN
description: The chief spokesman for the Transit Authority, Jeanne Edelson, was robbed of a gold chain Thursday as she and two other transit officials walked out of a subway station at 42d Street and Avenue of the Americas at 6:30 P.M.

title: I.B.M.'S OTHER ANTITRUST BATTLE
description: As Washington's antitrust ardor has cooled, the Common Market has warmed to pursuing its own antitrust complaint, filed against the International Business Machines Corporation in 1980. It contends that the United States computer giant exploits its dominance of Europe's multibillion-dollar computer market to stifle competition.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from London Thursday incorrectly characterized a British statement about Argentine prisoners in the Falkland Islands. The British Government did not say how the prisoners might die if Argentina did not agree to a cease-fire; it reported only that they were suffering from malnutrition, dysentery and scabies.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Around the World; 3 Die in Santo Domingo In Election Board Blast
description: An explosion killed at least three people and wounded many others today at the Dominican Republic's election board, where officials were studying allegations of irregularities in last month's elections.

title: ROBERT BINGHAM, 57, EDITOR
description: Robert Kamerer Bingham, executive editor of The New Yorker for the last 10 years, died of a brain tumor yesterday morning at his home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 57 years old.

title: CITIES SERVICE BUYS BACK MESA STAKE
description: In a move intended to clear the way for the Gulf Oil Corporation to proceed with its $5.1 billion offer to buy the Cities Service Company, the Mesa Petroleum Company sold its 4.1 million shares of Cities Service stock back to Cities Service, Mesa and Cities Service announced last night.

title: CRIME AND A NEIGHBORHOOD COEXIST
description: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically. By M.A. FARBER

title: Sports People; Bills Worry Ferguson
description: Joe Ferguson, the quarterback for the Buffalo Bills, says he is satisfied with the long-term contract he signed last year, but he is critical of the team for its apparent lack of willingness to spend enough money on other players. He cited as examples the Bills' recent failure to retain Tom Cousineau, a linebacker, and their current contract problems with Joe Cribbs, a running back, and Jerry Butler, a wide receiver, both of whom want to renegotiate their contracts. ''It's just an indication they are not 100 percent willing to pay for a winning football team,'' said Ferguson.

title: 5-RUN RALLY STAGED IN RAIN-DELAYED 9TH
description: The evening's work took almost eight hours, involved 39 players, included two rains delays and spanned two days, but the Mets finally left Busch Memorial Stadium early this morning relatively satisfied after splitting a doubleheader with the first-place Cardinals.

title: Festival Orchestra Concert
description: The Festival Orchestra of New York directed by Clifford Gilmore will perform Mahler's Third Symphony June 28 at 8 P.M. at the Symphony Space.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INSTRUCTIONS
description: Following are excerpts from the instructions given today by Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker to the jury at the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr.:

title: PRESS IN LEBANON: FREEWHEELING MIX
description: Despite the anarchy here, or perhaps because of it, the press, radio and television stations are more free-wheeling than in any other Arab country.

title: CURT JURGENS, WAR FILMS' STAR
description: Curt Jurgens, the West German movie actor who was a star of countless World War II films, died in a hospital here today. He was 66 years old.

title: Gretchen Anne Phillips Wed to Myles Hannan
description: Gretchen Anne Phillips, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James F. Phillips Jr. of Buffalo, was married there yesterday to Myles Hannan, son of Rosemary Edwards Hannan of Springfield, Va., and the late Joseph A. Hannan Jr. The Very Rev. James M. Demske, president of Canisius College, performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Cathedral.

title: News Analysis
description: Stories of gloomy financial prospects are a familiar topic in corridors of public-television stations. With its noncommercial mandate, public television has long been more dependent on less reliable and remunerative sources of funds

title: House Panel Enacts Bill To Protect Wilderness
description: A House subcommittee, trying to head off Interior Secretary James G. Watt, voted today to put the national wilderness preservation system permanently off limits to oil-@ and gas-drilling except in cases approved by Congress.

title:
PATENTS;
Vocal Measurements Aid Speech Treatments
description: Faculty members at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville have invented apparatus for the measurement and display of vocal characteristics as an aid to treating speech disorders.

title: Around the Nation; Ford Company Recalls 2,300 '81 and '82 Trucks
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was recalling about 2,300 trucks because of the danger of a loss of steering because parts had been made of the wrong kind of steel.

title: Dow Drops by 2.86; Off 21.12 for Week; Cities Service Stock Soars
description: The stock market declined moderately yesterday to register a new 26-month low. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.86 points, to 788.62, bringing its loss for the week to 21.12 points. The continuing pressures of high interest rates, the recession and eroding corporate profits have brought the Dow to its lowest closing since 759.13 on April 21, 1980.

title: A CHEEVER SAMPLER
description: There are some Americans who, although their fathers emigrated from the Old World three centuries ago, never seem to have quite completed the voyage and I am one of these. I stand, figuratively, with one wet foot on Plymouth Rock, looking with some delicacy, not into a formidable and challenging wilderness but onto a halffinished civilization embracing glass towers, oil derricks, suburban continents, and abandoned movie houses and wondering why, in this most prosperous, equitable, and accomplished world - where even the cleaning women practice the Chopin preludes in their spare time - everyone should seem to be disappointed. - The Death of Justina.

title: TOP GENERAL QUESTIONS POLICY ON PROLONGED A-WAR
description: Gen. David C. Jones, retiring as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, expressed skepticism today about the Reagan Administration's policy of preparing for protracted nuclear war. He said financing the policy could lead to unending military expenditures.

title: 3-HITTER BY PALMER DEFEATS YANKS, 4-1
description: The Yankees would not mind at all if Earl Weaver, the retiring manager of the Baltimore Orioles, would send Jim Palmer to the bullpen permanently as a going-away present to them.

title: Around the World; Unidentified Submarine Is Chased by Finns
description: Finnish coastguardsmen fired warning shots after spotting an unidentified submarine in their country's territorial waters in the Sea of Aland today.

title: House Panel Opens Hearings On Measure to Limit Busing
description: A predominantly liberal subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee has started a protracted series of public hearings on a Senate-passed antibusing measure,and some lawmakers accused the panel Thursday of stalling to prevent a vote by the full House.

title: BALLET: DANES PRESENT TETLEY'S NEW 'FIREBIRD'
description: Surprise. The Royal Danish Ballet has scored a hit with, of all things, a premiere by an American choreographer. On Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the company from Copenhagen presented its first mixed bill, made up of Glen Tetley's new, unorthodox ''The Firebird''; its own fascinating and comic 1786 heirloom, ''The Whims of Cupid and the Balletmaster,'' and the company's New York debut in Alvin Ailey's modern-dance work ''Memoria.''

title: JAZZ: THREE WOMEN SING
