description: The opening of the fifth annual weeklong New York Women's Jazz Festival, scheduled for last Sunday afternoon at Damrosch Park, had to be postponed because of the heavy rain. It will be held instead tomorrow in Bryant Park from noon until 5 P.M.

title: 2d Boycott Set
description: Horse owners, angered over the Illinois Racing Board's decision to maintain its ban on race-day medication, decided today to boycott Arlington Park for the second time this month.

title: TWO-THIRDS OF THE U.N. DELEGATES SHUT BEGIN'S SPEECH
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel told the United Nations today that wars of self-defense ''were the noblest concept of mankind.''

title: 23 Die on Philippines Ship
description: At least 23 people were dead and about 70 others missing after a fire swept through a ferry carrying more than 300 people from this port to Jolo Island, the police said today.

title: Nuclear Blast in Nevada
description: The Department of Energy conducted an underground nuclear weapons test Wednesday at the Nevada Test Site, the eighth announced test there this year. A spokesman, Jack Campbell, said that the test was conducted 948 feet below Yucca Flat, 75 miles northwest of Las Vegas, and had an explosive force equivalent to less than that of 20 kilotons of TNT.

title: Chad Without Qaddafi
description: Some Africans might be tempted to view the defeat of Goukouni Oueddei, a warlord from Chad's Moslem north, as evidence of the need to stay on the good side of Libya. Hissen Habre, a rival warlord who chased Mr. Goukouni from Ndjamena, Chad's capital city, had himself been driven out 18 months ago by Mr. Goukouni, with the help of Libyan troops. Mr. Goukouni's downfall clearly began late last year when, uneasy over Colonel Qaddafi's designs on Chad, he sent the Libyans packing.

title: DEVLIN SHOOTS A 69 TO LEAD BY TWO
description: After what he called ''five holes of garbage,'' Bruce Devlin rallied today with three birdies on the back nine to score 69-139 and retain his lead in the second round of the United States Open. Four hours later a tour rookie named Larry Rinker finished second with a 67-141.

title: Pacheco Stopped 2d Time in 43 Days
description: Mark Pacheco, who was knocked out in the first round of a bout in Portland, Ore., 42 days ago, was knocked out again last night at the Felt Forum. Henry Brent of Brooklyn won the vacant United States Boxing Association flyweight title when the referee stopped the fight at 2:51 of the ninth round.

title: LOWER SHORT-TERM INTEREST RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: DISPUTE PUTS OFF FILMING OF 'DUKES'
description: The scheduled resumption of filming on CBS-TV's ''The Dukes of Hazzard'' was postponed yesterday when two of its stars, John Schneider and Tom Wopat, did not report for work.

title: PLEA OF NOT GUILTY IS SET FOR EX-SPY
description: A Federal district judge entered a plea of not guilty for Edwin P. Wilson today when the former American intelligence agent declined to plead guilty or not guilty on charges of illegally aiding Libyan terrorists.

title: JAZZ-PIANO: GUARNIERI IN HIS STRIDE
description: Johnny Guarnieri was one of the major swing-band pianists in the late 1930's and early 40's. He was with Benny Goodman for two years, with Artie Shaw for another two and, while he was with Mr. Shaw, he recorded the first jazz solos on harpsichord as a member of Mr. Shaw's small group, the Gramercy Five.

title: CORRECTION
description: The obituary yesterday of a former actress who was the last surviving daughter of the composer-conductor Walter Damrosch misspelled her name and the name of a concern in which she was once a partner. She was Anita Blaine Damrosch Littell. The concern was the Burden-Littell Enter- tainment Bureau.

title: Sports People; Denver Agreement
description: An agreement has been reached between B.J. McCombs, the Texas businessman, and the city of Denver on a lease for the McNichols Sports Arena there, paving the way for his purchase of the Denver Nuggets franchise in the National Basketball Association. The agreement was worked out by Bob Locke, Denver's manager of general services, and Gary Wood, president of McCombs Enterprises, and was approved by McCombs and Mayor Bill McNichols.

title: USE U.N. TRUSTEESHIP
description: The bloody conflict between Argentina and Britain is now mercifully over. But was it really necessary?

title: HINCKLEY JURY WEIGHS VERDICT IN SHOOTING OF REAGAN AND 3
description: A jury of seven women and five men today began deliberating whether John W. Hinckley Jr. was guilty of trying to kill President Reagan and three other men or whether he was not guilty by reason of insanity.

title: Billy Carter Declares Support for Wallace
description: Billy Carter said today that he planned to help former Gov. George Wallace return to the governorship of Alabama.

title: GRANVILLE HICKS, CRITIC AND LEADER IN PROLETARIAN MOVEMENT, IS DEAD
description: Granville Hicks, literary critic, novelist, columnist and a leading writer in the proletarian literature movement of the 1930's, died yesterday at the Franklin Convalescent Center in Franklin Park, N.J., after a long illness. He was 80 years old and had lived in Kendall Park, N.J., before entering the convalescent home.

title: UNION LEADERS APPROVE BID TO OPEN TALKS WITH STEEL INDUSTRY
description: Local union leaders today authorized bargainers for the United Steelworkers of America to begin discussions with eight major steel companies that could lead to a new labor contract and moderated labor costs in the steel industry.

title: ARTHRITIS DRUG WARNING ASKED
description: An advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration issued a report Thursday calling for warning labels on a number of drugs used to treat arthritis.

title: Rain Halts Yachts
description: The Bermuda race, which had been scheduled to start today, was postponed for 24 hours by the race committee because of a storm off Florida with the potential for hitting the yachts en route. A fleet of 181 boats in six divisions have entered the 635-mile race.

title: YOUR MONEY
description: ANEW wrinkle in automobile insurance has appeared recently with the o ffering by some companies of replacement insurance for the car. Resembling in many ways the replacement cost coverage for the c ontents of a home offered with homeowners' policies, the new auto i nsurance endorsements cover the partial or full expense of repairingo r replacing the owner's damaged vehicle after an accident. In c ontrast, the standard collision and comprehensive coverage is d esigned to reimburse owners for no more than the actual cash value o f their cars at the time of damage.

title: U.S. JUDGE VOIDS POLICY ON DETENTION OF HAITIANS
description: The United States made procedural errors when it adopted its detention policy for illegal aliens a year ago, a Federal district judge ruled today as he voided the procedures under which 1,910 Haitians are being held. But the judge said the policy was not discriminatory.

title: PARTIAL RISE IN PROPERTY TAX BRINGS PRAISE AND CRITICISM
description: A decision by the City Council to raise taxes for utilities and commercial properties was applauded yesterday by public-interest groups and criticized by people in real estate.

title: Scouting; Football Insider
description: Steve Hunt of the Cosmos was seated with Richard Todd of the Jets and Todd's bride, Lulu, at a recent luncheon.

title: MODEL IS FOUND FATALLY STABBED ON EAST 23D ST.
description: A 24-year-old fashion model affiliated with one of the leading agencies in New York City was found stabbed to death early yesterday morning in her apartment near Gramercy Park.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HARRAH'S 4 HITS PUT HIM AT .387
description: Miguel Dilone and Toby Harrah hit backto-back homers, and Von Hayes drove in three runs with a pair of doubles tonight to lead the Cleveland Indians to a 10-3 rout of the Boston Red Sox.

title: Around the World; Nicaragua Accuses Ex-Junta Member of Plot
description: The official radio has accused a former junta member of forging a pact with other Nicaraguan exiles to overthrow the Sandinist Government.

title: Computer Sciences
description: An appellate court has upheld the dismissal of racketeering, bribery and conspiracy charges against the Computer Sciences Corporation, but reversed a dismissal of false claims and mail and wire fraud charges against the company.

title: U.S. ENVOY SEES LEBANESE LEADERS AS ISRAEL-P.L.O. FIGHTING SUBSIDES
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy to the Middle East, held a fourth day of talks with Lebanese political leaders today in an effort to find a political solution to the situation created by the Israeli invasion.

title: Bridge: A Few Young Americans To Start International Play
description: When the world championships are played in Biarritz, France, next October, the American contingent will include a group of young experts who will be making their first foray in international competition.

title: HAIG AND GROMYKO MEET FOR 5 HOURS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. opened a new round of high-level Soviet-American talks with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko yesterday that was expected to include discussion of a possible meeting later in the year between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: F.D.A. BACKS NEW RULES ON USE OF ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: The United States Food and Drug Administration approved new guidelines today that will expand by thousands the number of people eligible to receive the artificial heart invented at the University of Utah, officials said.

title: Spacecraft May Detect Mystery Body in Space
description: A pair of American spacecraft may help scientists detect what could be a 10th planet or a giant object billions of miles away, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said Thursday.

title:
PATENTS;
License Availability Listed for Navy Patents
description: A list of 400 inventions made for the Navy, on which licenses can be granted for commercial use, was published this week in the patent section of the Official Gazette. Of the items, 242 are patent applications and 158 are issued patents.

title: Around the Nation; Fasting for Equal Rights, Woman Has Lung Injury
description: One of seven women in the 32d day of a fast for the proposed Federal equal rights amendment underwent minor surgery today to repair a collapsed lung, a hospital official said.

title:
PATENTS;
Intense Light Added To Dental Handpiece
description: An illuminator for a dental handpiece, patented this week, is described as giving a dentist pure daylight white light in the area where he is working. Patent 4,334,863, assigned to Kinetic Instruments Inc., Bethel, Conn., was granted William J. Becker, president of the company, and Kenneth S. Magid, executive vice president.

title: French Trade Improves
description: The Foreign Trade Ministry today reported a sharp narrowing in France's trade deficit in May, to $450 million, the smallest since last August. The deficit had widened to a record $1.5 billion in April.

title: IN FALKLAND FIGHTING, HARRIER JUMP-JETS AND EXOCET MISSILES WON NEW REGARD
description: The land-based Exocet missile that hit and damaged the British light cruiser Glamorgan was almost the last shot of the air-sea war around the Falkland Islands. This was perhaps fitting since the Exocet was the weapon used in the South Atlantic that has given military planners and ship designers the most to think about.

title: Scouting; The Mets Make Road Improvements
description: Although some baseball clubs discourage players' wives from traveling with their husbands, the Mets have been most hospitable, according to three wives who are on the current Pittsburgh-St. Louis trip.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Is Their Cup Half-Full, Or Doth It Run Over?

title: CORRECTION
description: The Real Estate column on May 28 incorrectly reported the sale prices of condominium units in the Hamlet project in Jericho, L.I. They range from $185,000 to $260,000.

title: Mitsubishi Plans Engines For Ford
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, 15 percent owned by the Chrysler Corporation, said that it would start supplying turbo-diesel engines to the Ford Motor Company beginning in the mid-1980's. A Mitsubishi spokesman said a three-year agreement had been signed by the representatives of the two companies this week in New York.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; DOCTORS' PACTS ON FEES BARRED AS PRICE FIXING
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that agreements among competing doctors to set maximum fee schedules constituted illegal price fixing, even when the agreements were part of an insurance plan that might result in lower costs for patients.

title: News Analysis
description: New York City's 75-cent subway and bus fare is going up on July 1, unless it doesn't. It is understandable if straphangers find this statement confusing. But it is, in summary, precisely what the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Richard Ravitch, is now saying about the future of the fare.

title: Around the World; Biafran Secessionist Returns to Nigeria
description: Odumegwu Ojukwu, the former Biafran secessionist leader, returned to Nigeria today, ending more than 12 years in exile after his defeat in the 1967-70 civil war.

title: Penney to Sell Insurance Unit
description: The J.C. Penney Company has agreed to sell its Great American Reserve Insurance Company to a subsidiary of Time Inc., the Lumbermen's Investment Corporation, the companies announced.

title: SALVADORAN COLONELS DIE IN CRASH
description: El Salvador's Deputy Minister of Defense and a senior combat commander were killed Thursday in a helicopter crash in a combat zone, according to an official military statement.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This recession has been a beneficial thing and a cleansing thing for this society.'' - Richard M. DeVos, national finance chairman of the Republican Party. (9:4.)

title: COSMOS' STREAK HALTED AT 7 GAMES
description: The Montreal Manic rallied from a two-goal deficit and snapped the seven-game winning streak of the Cosmos with a 3-2 victory tonight before a crowd of 32,654 at Olympic Stadium.

title: BELL'S FUTURE RESEARCH
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM JAPAN, DESIGNS FOR THE TAILORED WOMAN
description: Anyone who thinks that Japanese fashion is forever linked to the kimono and the obi had better think again. Japan's leading fashion designers recently presented their fall collections in Tokyo and proved that they neatly fit within the mainstream of contemporary fashion. One of these designers, Mitsuhiro Matsuda, arrived in New York on Wednesday with his collection and made that point very clear in a private showing of his work.

title: Yes, Trade on the Trade Center
description: The World Trade Center, which only a few years ago was regarded as the Port Authority's white elephant, has become a winner. Instead af wondering how to unload it, New York and New Jersey officials now wonder how to get their hands on its wealth. Peter Goldmark, the Authority's executive director, suggests a plausible way to put Trade Center profits to non-port uses.

title: Test Seeks to Preserve Books
description: The Library of Congress has announced plans to conduct a major test of a new process for preserving books that it is hoped will extend the life of treated volumes as much as 400 years.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 19, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan extended the ban on the export of oil and gas equipment to the Soviet Union to foreign companies producing such equipment under American licenses. The White House attributed the move, a major rebuff to European allies, to Mr. Reagan's desire ''to advance reconciliation in Poland.'' The sanctions were originally established - on American companies alone - in response to the imposition of martial law in Poland last December. (Page 1.)

title: Court Overturns Ruling On Intrauterine Device
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled today that individual claims filed by women who say they were injured by defective Dalkon Shield birth control devices do not have to be integrated into a class-action suit.

title: Up From The Feedbag
description: It is a curiosity unexplained by science that Americans nowadays are born understanding computers. You constantly read of tots who have plugged into giant institutional computing systems and transferred millions of dollars to Swiss bank accounts or wiped out entire electronic filing systems.

title: VOTING RIGHTS ACT RENEWED IN SENATE BY MARGIN OF 85-8
description: In a decisive show of support for the civil rights movement, the Senate today adopted a bill extending a critical section of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 for 25 years.

title: MAY INCOME AND SPENDING UP
description: A healthy gain in wages and salaries helped push total personal income seven-tenths of 1 percent higher in May than in April, the biggest increase since November, the Government reported today.

title: THEATER: GOOD-EVIL MESSAGE IN LONDON
description: The two most talked-about plays in the West End, Julian Mitchell's ''Another Country'' and the late C.P. Taylor's ''Good,'' both ask a question that one doesn't hear so often these days in the American theater: How does a ''good'' man turn evil? And, in both works, the question is given larger-than-life importance because it is posed against a tumultuous historical background. ''Another Country'' and ''Good'' each unfold during the crucial decade of the 1930's. The malevolent forces that swallow up the plays' respective protagonists are those twin 20th-century juggernauts of Stalinism and Nazism.

title: Baptists Attack Football TV Plan
description: Delegates to the Southern Baptist Convention have passed a resolution that attacks professional football's television schedule.

title: Ohio Bank Merger
description: The Banc One Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the Winters National Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, for $122.1 million in common and preferred stock.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Gulf and Western Industries' Associates Corp. of North America unit filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $300 million of senior debt securities and warrants to purchase such securities.

title: BALLET FESTIVAL ENDS IN STYLE
description: The New York City Ballet ended the Stravinsky Centennial Celebration last night very much the way it began - stylishly, expeditiously and en famile. George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein stood in front of the curtain of the New York State Theater and toasted Igor Stravinsky, the audience and each other. Stravinsky was not present, of course, but the audience loved it.

title: Sports People; Trade Questioned
description: The National Basketball Players Association is disputing the Seattle SuperSonics' right to trade Wally Walker to the Denver Nuggets as part of Thursday's deal in which they obtained David Thompson, a swingman. The association contends that Walker became a free agent on June 9, and was subject to the right of first refusal, which only the Sonics own.

title: Going Out Guide
description: JAZZ

title: Banks Is Thwarted In Bid for a Triple
description: Willie Banks cites many reasons why he should have problems in the triple jump. He is still slowed by a year-old hamstring injury. He often has trouble getting away from classes at U.C.L.A. Law School, where he has a year to go. He confesses to laziness. He says the public does not appreciate or even understand his event.

title: Nanci Martin Nelson Wed To Comdr. E.D. Smith Jr.
description: Nanci Martin Nelson of Greenfield Hill, Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Comdr. Esmond Douglas Smith Jr., U.S.N. Justice of the Peace Barbara Garrison of Fairfield performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Wilder, friends of the couple.

title: 8 PERSONS HURT IN AN EXPLOSION ON EAST 8TH ST.
description: A gas explosion and fire tore through the lower floors of an Upper East Side apartment building yesterday, injuring eight persons, five of them critically. The cause of the blast had not been determined last night.

title: THE SPRINGSTEENING OF DISARMAMENT
description: A vast number of supporters of disarmament ignore or willfully misunderstand the lessons of postwar Soviet-American diplomacy, perhaps because the lessons are so cheerless and the rallies, like the one in Central Park, often are so pleasant, offering camaraderie, sometimes music and always a good cause.

title: BALDRIGE DETECTS RECOVERY
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that recovery from the recession, among the most severe since World War II, had already begun and that figures for the second quarter would show that the economy had grown at an annual rate of between five-tenths of 1 percent and 1 percent.

title: Israel Advises Caltex to Start Repairs on Refinery at Sidon
description: The Israeli Government this week telexed Caltex, part owners of the war-damaged oil refineries in Sidon, to instruct their Lebanese staff to repair the damages and resume operations, a Ministry of Energy source said today.

title: ARGENTINES DEFEAT HUNGARIANS BY 4-1
description: Argentina, with some of its players crying in joy later, defeated Hungary, 4-1, today in a game that kept the defending champions in contention for the World Cup.

title: Players; BILL BUCKNER, CUBS' FIERCE COMPETITOR
description: CHICAGO W hat has it been like being a Cub? ''People would ask me that,'' said Bill Buckner, the first baseman for the Chicago Cubs, who over the last six seasons has been the best player on one of the worst teams in baseball. ''They'd be a little embarrassed, but they were dying of curiosity. It was embarrassing for me, too.

title: Grupo Alfa Snag
description: Negotiations have broken off between Grupo Industrial Alfa and the Mexican Government on the country's purchase of some of Alfa's subsidiaries.

title: Czechoslovakia Is Said to Try Four Human Rights Activists
description: Four Czechoslovak human rights activists went on trial today in Chomutov in northern Bohemia on charges of disturbing public order, according to emigre sources.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anschutz Corp., a privately held Denver concern, said it had purchased a Missouri copper scrap refining facility, formerly owned by a Penn Central Corp. unit, for undisclosed terms.

title: 'WE NEED THE CASH,' BEGIN SAYS AT BONDS LUNCH
description: Behind the speaker's stand where Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel sat yesterday, there were rows of long luncheon tables with white linen. At each seat in the tiers in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was a contributor who had pledged $100,000 or more to the State of Israel Bonds campaign.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA TRIUMPHS IN 3 SETS
description: Martina Navratilova reached her 17th successive final today with a 6-3, 3-6, 6-3 victory over Jo Durie of Britain in the semifinals of the $150,000 Eastbourne grasscourt championships.

title: CURRAN TRAILS LEHRMAN AT START OF G.O.P. RACE
description: Paul J. Curran, now the underdog in the race for the Republican Party's New York State gubernatorial nomination, began yesterday the tasks of planning campaign strategy and raising advertising funds.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Money Is to the Swift

title: Argentina Ungoverned Again
description: In Argentina, one kind of make-believe is following hard on another. A stunned country now learns that it has been deceived for weeks about how well the Falkland war was really going. Suddenly effacing the claims of victory are pictures of 10,000 forlorn prisoners, their repatriation delayed because the ruling junta could not bring itself to say the war's over. And instead of acknowledging collective blame, the junta has dumped its nominal leader, Leopoldo Galtieri, as if he were the sole culprit.

title: ISRAEL'S TOEHOLD IN AFRICA MAY FALL VICTIM TO WAR
description: Israel's newly reopened gateway to Africa takes the form here of a modest suite of offices on the second floor of a high-rise building that, on its upper reaches, affords a vista of the Congo River, a stream that is no stranger to the attempted penetration of this continent by outsiders.

title: Ballet Rambert to Open 'Dance as Theater'
description: ''Dance as Theater'' by the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College will begin Oct. 15 with an appearance by London's Ballet Rambert.

title: FOR ENERGY CHIEF, MIXED EMOTIONS
description: In a few months James B. Edwards, brand new to Washington when he became Secretary of Energy, will return to South Carolina to become a college president. He says he cherishes his experience here but that he is also appalled by much of what he has seen.

title: DIPLOMATS SEE U.S. ROLE IN FALKLAND SETTLEMENT
description: Latin American diplomats here say the end of the fighting in the Falklands gives the United States a major opportunity to help negotiate a settlement between Britain and Argentina and thereby salvage damaged relationships between the Reagan Administration and Latin countries.

title: C.K. KRIEGER, G.O.P. CANDIDATE
description: Charles K. Krieger, the Republican candidate for the House of Representatives from Hudson County, died in his sleep early Thursday at his home in Jersey City. He was 68 years old.

title: BUENOS AIRES SAYS FALKLANDS' TRUCE IS STILL UNCERTAIN
description: Argentina said today that a ''total cessation of hostilities'' with the British would be reached only when Britain withdrew its forces from the Falkland Islands, lifted its blockade of the Argentine coast and ended its economic sanctions.

title: FIGURE IN RICHMOND INQUIRY GETS 4 YEARS IN PRISON
description: A Brooklyn man who has charged entrapment by Federal agents investigating Representative Frederick W. Richmond was given a fouryear prison sentence yesterday for conspiracy to distribute cocaine.

title: Security Council Issues Call For Humanitarian Assistance
description: The Security Council issued a unanimous call tonight for humanitarian aid to Lebanon and urged all parties ''not to hamper the exercise'' of United Nations relief agencies in the Israeli-occupied area.

title: 'HOME' FOR FAMILIES OF ILL CHILDREN SET
description: THERE were times during the early stages of his 10-year-old daughter's fight with leukemia when W. Gary L'Hommedieu and his wife found only intermittant sleep on hospital waiting-room chairs and on an occasional cot. The pair took shifts keeping vigil at the hospital, he recalled.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART Their real profession is art. But they support themselves by baking, carpentering, locksmithing, hairdressing, teaching, landscape gardening, clothes designing, waiting on tables and even delivering striptease telegrams.

title: PART-TIME WORK: A WRITER'S REPORT
description: ''GOOD part-time jobs exist in any field in which there is great demand for qualified people,'' said JoAnne Alter of Great Neck. ''Where there are skilled or trained or experienced people, parttime opportunities exist simply because employers - even in a period of high unemployment - are desperate to find them.''

title: NEW YORK'S MINOR PARTIES SELECT STATEWIDE CANDIDATES
description: The Conservative Party gave Lewis E. Lehrman its nomination for Governor today, insuring that he will be on the November ballot no matter what happens in the Republican primary.

title: Dutch Harrison, Golfer, Dies; Member of the Hall of Fame
description: E.J. (Dutch) Harrison, who won 18 titles on the Professional Golfers' Association tour and was in the PGA Hall of Fame, died today of heart failure at the age of 72.

title: The World in Summary; FInally, France Gets in Step On the Franc
description: After bucking the tide of fiscal austerity for more than a year, France has changed course just in time to keep its currency afloat. Speculative pressures on the franc - caused by high inflation that in turn resulted from Francois Mitterrand's expansionary economic policies - had threatened to exhaust France's foreign currency reserves. The Government was obliged last weekend to devalue the franc by 5.75 percent against the currencies of the other seven members of the European Monetary System.

title: Wendy Rosenblum Is Wed To Edward M. Ordemann
description: Wendy Rosenblum, daughter of Mrs. Mortimer H. Hess Jr. of New York and the late William Rosenblum, was married yesterday to Edward Meriwether Ordemann, son of Marshall Frederick Ordemann of New Orleans and the late Mrs. Ordemann. Dr. Algernon D. Black, chairman emeritus of the Ethical Culture Society of New York, performed the ceremony at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Design; BARKING UP THE RIGHT TREE
description: Rustic furniture - pieces that are intentionally rough-hewn - has been fashionable in this country off and on for more than a century, but never more so than today. Though usually constructed of logs or twigs, with or without their bark, certain varieties also use milled lumber, particularly for chair seats and table tops.

title: LONG WHARF ACTRESS BUILDS CAREER ON VERSATALITIY
description: WE were seated at the kitchen table of the stage set of ''Ethan Frome'' having a most pleasant time in the midst of the starkness and gloom that is the setting for Edith Wharton's wintry melodrama, whose run has just finished. Joyce Ebert was wearing a tan pants suit and a ruffled blouse.

title:
Stamps;
NEW U.S. STATIONARY: ENVELOPE AND POTAL CARD
description: Two new postal stationery items have just been issued, one featuring the Great Seal of the United States and the other featuring the historic Academy of Music in Philadelphia.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: AS THEY WERE, by M.F.K. Fisher. (Alfred A. Knopf, $13.95.) A selection of Mrs. Fisher's writings on food, life and herself.

title: COSTA RICA DEPORTS 30 ALIENS
description: Forty Nicaraguans here have been ordered deported for ''compromising the neutrality of Costa Rica,'' according to an announcement by Manuel Carballo, Deputy Minister of the Presidency.

title: SHADOWY 'GHOSTS'
description: GARDEN CITY IF Ibsen's plays are all too often stereotyped as the stuff that stuffiness is made of, it's productions such as the Adelphi Festival Theater's ''Ghosts'' that tell us, all too tediously, just why.

title: Food
description: WHEN EGGS ARE HOT STUFF

title: R.H. Neihaus Weds Kate Southworth
description: The marriage of Kate Southworth and Robert Henry Neihaus, alumni of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, class of '82, took place at Christ Episcopal Church in Corning, N.Y., yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Scott Harvin, assisted by the Rev. Michael Hogan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: JUDY GEER CAPTURES SINGLE SCULLS TITLE
description: The Geer sisters from West Fairlee, Vt., Judy and Carlie, who are among the world's best in their sport, had a rewarding day in the finals of the Women's National Rowing Championships here today.

title: Business Conditions; LOWER BOND RATINGS
description: Although rising business failure rates and shrinking earnings figures are a grim testament to the immediate impact of the current recession on corporate America, they are not the whole story. They do not convey the longer-term effects of the sharp deterioration in corporate liquidity, particularly for larger companies.

title: NEW RELEASES ILLUMINATE BAROQUE OPERA
description: Opera in the age of the Baroque occupies - for our less patient ears at least - a suspiciously static and decorous world. We fidget at first over its ornate rhetoric, its coy conceits, its slower pace. And yet, passion, violence, intrigue and idealism are all here and with an intensity to match even an ''Otello'' or a ''Cavalleria Rusticana.''

title: TOURING THE CYCLADES BY FERRY
description: The closest approximation today to the excitement of New York Harbor 30 or 40 years ago may well take place at 8 A.M. in the port of Piraeus, when a dozen or so ferryboats load passengers and cars to set off for the Greek islands. The Greek ferries have little in common with either ocean liners or the Staten Island variety, but are more like short-haul, budget cruise ships, catering increasingly to do-it-yourself travelers.

title: Film View; FASSBINDER-THE MOVIES' FIRST GREAT SATIRIST
description: When you see the work of Jean Renoir or Luis Bunuel, you have the impression that they would be people you'd like to know. No matter how dark the films, you can detect within them the exceptional personalities of the men who made them. Renoir and Bunuel are nearly perfect father figures - wise, patient, understanding, amused, curious, puzzled, ever capable of astonishment, each possessed of an unsentimental wit that, though razor sharp, never threatens to cut off the branch on which we're all precariously huddled. They are artists as we idealize them.

title: ISRAELIS NOURISH HOPES - OR ILLUSIONS
description: JERUSALEM AS Israel's campaign in Lebanon began to assume a diplomatic form last week, officials in Jerusalem entertained hopes that their army's bold offensive had laid the groundwork for a more peaceful and stable Middle East.

title: Jacobsen Victor
description: Howard Jacobsen of the East Side Track Club won the New York City trials for the 50-kilometer race walk in the Empire State Games in 5 hours 30 minutes 15 seconds yesterday at Central Park.

title: CARRIER INTREPID BEING REFITTED FOR DUTY AS MUSEUM AT PIER 86
description: The conversion of the 43,000-ton aircraft carrier Intrepid into a floating naval, aeronautics and space museum has begun. Propelled by four tugboats, the carrier - freshly painted and refurbished at the Bethlehem Steel Plant in Bayonne, N.J. - arrived last Sunday at its permanent home on the Hudson River at Pier 86, at the foot of 46th Street. The museum is to open in mid-July.

title: Bill Spurs Efforts to Reduce Acid Rain
description: THE efforts of those who seek to reduce and eventually eliminate man-made sources of acid rain in this country have entered the critical phase.

title: Nancy R. LeSage, W.K. Hellmuth, Architect, Wed
description: The marriage of Nancy Russell LeSage, a project manager with Interphase Modular Systems Inc. in New York, to William Koerner Hellmuth, an associate partner with the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill in New York, took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church of Madison, Conn. The Rev. Winthrop Stone performed the ceremony.

title: NOW IT'S THE REPUBLICANS WHO SEEM OUT OF CONTROL
description: Within two hectic hours, two of four candidates for Governor dropped out. Frantic vote-switching began amid angry charges of duplicity, deal-making and bossism. In a binge of sentiment, one of the gubernatorial dropouts was unanimously supported for Lieutenant Governor.

title: HOW AN AMATEUR BECAME AN EXPERT IN A SEASIDE GARDEN
description: Interior-designer Lee Bailey's formal gardens shimmer with color against a backdrop of sea and sky on Long Island's East End. The geometrically shaped beds follow the contours of the land and balance the clean architectural lines of his house.

title: Free Lunch Limit Is Raised
description: Family income limits for children to receive free or reduced-price school lunches will be raised by 10 percent on July 1 in a cost-of-living adjustment, the Agriculture Department has announced. The maximum income a family of four can receive and still qualify for free lunches for its children will be raised to $12,090 from $10,990, the department said Thursday. Eligibility for reduced-price meals will be increased to $17,210 from $15,630 for a family of four.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Gene Upshaw, the Oakland Raider lineman who is president of the National Football League Players Association, received the A. Philip Randolph Achievement Award in Washington Friday night. The award is presented annually to the labor leader whose work for trade unionism and racial justice ''exemplifies in day-to-day work the values and principles of A. Philip Randolph.'' Mr. Randolph was the first black vice president of the A.F.L-C.I.O. ... The Boston Bruins next season will be without a familiar stalwart, the forward Don Marcotte.

title: Critics' Choices
description: OPERA Gregory Sandow looks for character and atmosphere in his operatic subjects, and his new three-act creation, ''Frankenstein,'' offers plenty of both. ''Frankenstein's'' first complete performances will be given Wednesday, Friday, next Sunday and June 29 at Long Island University's C.W. Post Center in Greenvale.

title: A GROUP SHOPPING SPREE STOCKS A MUSEUM WITH ART
description: Terry Dintenfass widened her eyes in astonishment. Twenty-one prospective buyers had just trooped into her normally quiet West 57th Street art gallery to see some paintings, and the ringleader of the group, a portly man with gray hair, was blowing a shrill whistle to bring everyone to attention. In her long career of selling art in New York - usually to one or two people at a time - Miss Dintenfass had never seen anything like this mob scene. She soon learned, though, that such an unorthodox way of doing business can pay off - and handsomely.

title: Emily C. Rushworth Is Married to Bynum G. Shaw
description: Emily Crandall Rushworth and Bynum Gillette Shaw were married yesterday in the Davis Chapel of Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Warren Carr, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony. The couple are graduates of Wake Forest, where the bridegroom is professor of journalism and creative writing.

title: Karen Schutt Is Married To Michael David Drazen
description: Karen Underhill Schutt and Michael David Drazen, who are with Scali, McCabe, Sloves Inc., a New York advertising agency, were married yesterday at the New York home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Chittenden Schutt. State Supreme Court Justice Arnold L. Fein of the Appellate Division performed the ceremony.

title: THEY'RE CREATING A WORLD OF DOLLS
description: THESE days most children put away dolls long before they reach the age of 10. Two Long Island women, however, have recently begun to dabble with dolls again, and for both Victoria Ward of Glen Cove and Sheila Kwartler of Great Neck, this has lead to new careers as serious doll makers.

title: LACK OF DATA DELAYS DECISION ON NEW RENTS
description: A tenant leader gave a crystal ball to the county's Rent Guidelines Board last week and even the landlords, who had been hissed and booed during a chaotic three-hour public meeting, laughed.

title: Susan Krasnoff Married
description: Susan Marsha Krasnoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Krasnoff of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Paul Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Davis of Newport, R.I. Rabbis Theodore Lewis and Eli Katz performed the ceremony at the Touro Synagogue in Newport. The bride is a systems analyst with Honeywell Information Systems in Wellesley, Mass. Her husband is a lecture agent with the American Program Bureau in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: DISSOLUTION, REVOLUTION AND MOSCOW'S INTENTIONS
description: YUGOSLAVIA'S Communists will hold their 12th party congress next weekend at a time of economic and political strains that have grown more severe since President Tito died two years ago. Milovan Djilas, who was once one of Tito's closest associates and subsequently one of his severest critics, candidly assessed his country's future in a recent interview with John B. Oakes of The New York Times.

title: Women as Rabbis
description: For many centuries, rabbis had always been men by tradition. Ten years ago the Jewish Reform movement in this country ordained its first woman to the rabbinate.

title: THE OTHER SIDE OF THE BERKSHIRES
description: LINDA CHARLTON is a reporter for The New York Times. BY LINDA CHARLTON

title: A SELECTMAN SPENDS HER SALARY ON HER TOWN
description: unit parade May 30 that was the biggest in the town's 280-year history.

title: WELSH MOUNTAIN HOLDING SECRET AND LAWSUIT
description: FFESTINIOG, Wales -Hidden inside a Welsh mountain is a secret that has pitted a soft-spoken Welshman against the British Government.

title: Sports of the Times; WATER, WATER, EVERYWHERE
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. ON eight of the 18 holes, the surf sometimes can be heard crashing against rocks or rumbling up the sand. And this is what separates Pebble Beach from the other famous golf courses where the United States Open is staged from year to year. This is the only Open course where the ocean lurks to drown a contender's chances, as it might today in what looms as a memorable Open finish.

title: Tough Victors, Stubborn Losers
description: Britain won the war last week, but what kind of peace was in store for the Falkland Islands remained unsettled. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher proclaimed victory for British sovereignty and ''the British way of life'' and ordered her colonial governor back to the islands. In that case, Argentine President Leopoldo Galtieri insisted, ''There will be no security or definite peace.'' But the President himself soon became a political casualty. Thousands of Argentines, humiliated by losing (and furious at being misled by military communiques), rioted below the presidential balcony, chanting ''Treason! Treason!'' The military forced out General Galtieri as army commander in chief and replaced him in the ruling junta with Gen. Cristino Nicolaides, a hard-liner. Gen. Alfredo Saint Jean, the Interior Minister, became interim President.

title: BLACK IN THE MIDDLE
description: A MAN'S LIFE An Autobiography. By Roger Wilkins. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: WATSON, ROGERS IN LEAD AT OPEN
description: The big names took control of the leader boards today in the third round of the United States Open. Tom Watson, who says he wants to win this championship more than anything else, and Bill Rogers, who tied for second last year and then went on to win the British Open and the World Series of Golf, tied for the lead after three rounds, setting up what should be a splendid confrontation in Sunday's finale.

title: ADOPTION: BILL DRAWS SUPPORT AND OPPOSITIION
description: WHEN they were infants, Barbara and Susan were adopted by the same family. They grew up as sisters in Upper Nyack, N.Y. Barbara, now Mrs. Richards, is 34 years old and lives in Valley Cottage, N.Y. She does not want to know her biological mother.

title: DAVID UNTERBERG YASPAN TO MARRY ANN ROTHENBERG
description: Dr. Carol Rothenberg of Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Ann Rothenberg, to David Unterberg Yaspan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Yaspan of Hewlett Park, L.I.

title: Start of Yacht Race Is Postponed Again
description: The start of the Newport-to-Bermuda race today was postponed for another 24 hours by the race committee because of an intensifying storm moving up the East Coast with winds gusting to hurricane strength.

title: Sports People; No 'Bites' for Johnson
description: Dennis Johnson, the Phoenix Suns' all-star guard, is still dangled as ''bid bait'' in the team's eagerness to obtain a first-round choice in the National Basketball Association's collegiate draft June 29. The Utah Jazz would not bite on three proposals for giving up its third selection on the opening round.

title: TV Mailbag; ABOUT RADIO TALK SHOWS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT THE MAGICIAN TAUGHT ME
description: WHEN I go to New York, I remember him. We lived together for most of my childhood, a time period that lasted longer than normal - only because he had such wonderous magical powers.

title: DEMOCRATS STARTING A PLATFORM TWO YEARS EARLY
description: The Democrats are about to gather in Philadelphia for a convention where briefing books and position papers, not funny hats and campaign buttons, are supposed to be the vital paraphernalia. The result may be something new in American politics - a midterm election effort in which the party out of power campaigns in a united way, with some approximation of a party platform.

title: JOYS OF SENDING CHILDREN OFF TO CAMP
description: AFTER spending countless summers sitting around 12-inch-deep wading pools, visiting nearby beaches chosen for their proximity to bathroom and snack-bar facilities and making endless trips to nature centers, local zoos and daycamps, many parents start seriously thinking about sleep-away camp for their children. No need to take a vacation this summer - the kids will be going out of town instead!

title: Swahili
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Space Program Losing Its Way
description: Caught between a tight budget and the Pentagon, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's soul is being searched for ways to survive into the next century. The latest diagnosis was released last week by the Office of Technology Assessment, a Congressional advisory arm.

title: Something for Dad in the Constitution
description: New fathers whose working wives don't get pregnancy leaves or maternity benefits are victims of discrimination against women. Divorced fathers in states where the mother automatically gets custody of ''a child of tender years'' are victims, too.

title: THEY ALSO SERVE
description: Alex Ward is the editor of The Living Section of The Times. By Alex Ward he Lawn Tennis Championships, better known simply as Wimbledon, are set to open officially tomorrow. But for one group of players - some of them up-and-coming, some of them trying for a comeback - the tournament has been going on for days now. These players are called qualifiers; their rankings are not high enough to gain them automatic entry into major tournaments, so they must compete among themselves to qualify for the handful of spots that have been set aside for them.

title: THE BUYING OF THE PRESIDENT
description: THE REAL CAMPAIGN How the Media Missed the Story of the 1980 Campaign. By Jeff Greenfield. 319 pp. New York: Summit Books. $15.95.

title: Around the World; Irish Report Arrest Of a New York Priest
description: An Irish Roman Catholic priest who has lived in New York for 25 years was arrested when antiterrorist police units broke up an Irish Republican Army gun-running operation, the police said today.

title: A LESSON LEARNED IN DAD'S WORKSHOP
description: AS a boy I never could understand why my father needed a special place to call his own. He already owned a whole house and ruled every aspect of the family's life. Yet the basement of our house was quite simply his workshop filled with his things.

title: DISHES THAT LINGER IN THE MEMORY
description: OLD GREENWICH WHEN we heard via the culinary grapevine that chef-owner Harvey Edwards was no longer doing the cooking at his small French restaurant, Cafe du Bec Fin, we decided it was time for a series of return visits. In 1979 Mr. Edwards's skillful handling of nouvelle cuisine merited an easy three stars. How in the interim has the restaurant fared?

title: Investing; SOME SOLID COMPANIES FOR A SAFETY NET
description: "BUSINESS balance sheets and corporate liquidity are more fragile than at any other time in the postwar period,'' warns Allen Sinai of Data Resources Inc., and who could argue?

title: POLITICAL SOLUTION FOR BEIRUT ELUSIVE
description: Lebanese political leaders continued their efforts today to convince the Palestine Liberation Organization to lay down its arms in return for Lebanese and American assurances that the Israeli Army will not move into the Palestinian-Moslem stronghold in West Beirut.

title: Garza Stops Negron In Bantamweight Fight
description: Jaime Garza of Los Angeles, ranked the No.2 bantamweight by the World Boxing Council, solidified his claim for a world title shot by stopping Carmello Negron of New York at 2 minutes 30 seconds of the fifth round of a scheduled 10-round bout at the Hacienda Hotel today.

title: The Nation in Summary; A Step Out Of Detention
description: In a decison that could significantly affect the Administration's immigration policy, a Federal judge ruled last week that procedures under which Haitian refugees have been detained violated the law. The judge, Eugene Spellman of Federal District Court in Miami, stopped short of declaring the detention itself illegal and discriminatory, but ordered a meeting for Wednesday, presumably to determine release procedures.

title: POET AND NOVELIST
description: Djuna Barnes, a recluse whose avant-garde literary work won wide acclaim in the 1920's and 30's, died at her home in Greenwich Village Friday night. She was 90 years old.

title: Bridge; TIME ON THEIR HANDS
description: Slow play used to be a serious problem on major bridge occasions. In 1962 one French player took almost half an hour to bid and play one deal, which proved a great trial to an opponent with a short attention span. That is far from the record, for in a New York match a single bid once took 25 minutes and the deal almost an hour.

title: Danica Kombol, D.C. Lewis Wed
description: Danica Suzanne Kombol and David Cartmell Lewis were married yesterday at the home of Linda and Anthony Lewis, parents of the bridegroom, in West Tisbury, Mass.

title: Lillian C. Doubleday Married
description: Lillian Clark Doubleday, daughter of Nelson Doubleday of Locust Valley, L.I., and Mrs. Paul J. Chase of Mill Neck, L.I., was married at her father's home yesterday to Newell Bertram Woodworth 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodworth Jr. of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Bruce A. Rodgers of St. John's of Lattington Episcopal Church performed the garden ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article May 23 incorrectly identi- fied the organization that exercised an option on two closed A.& P. supermar- kets in Philadelphia in the hope of re- opening them. It is the Philadelphia Association for Cooperative Enter- prises.

title: A YOUTH OF THE UNIVERSE
description: EMERSON IN HIS JOURNALS Selected and Edited by Joel Porte. Illustrated. 588 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $25. EMERSON'S FALL A New Interpretation of the Major Essays. By B. L. Packer. 244 pp. New York: Continuum. $14.95.

title: Seewagen Gains Final Of State Clay Tennis
description: Butch Seewagen, the defending champion, moved into the final of the New York State clay-court championships yesterday by defeating Ray Disco of Forest Hills, 6-2, 6-3.

title: HUMILIATION AND HOPE
description: There is much more at stake than the safety of Israel and the fate of Lebanon and the Palestinians in how their war ends. Urgent as it is to stop bloodshed and provide humane relief, it is essential when so many deadlocked questions have been blasted open to seize the chance to head off future disasters.

title: A METAPHORIC NOVEL OF THE SEA
description: SABBATICAL A Romance. By John Barth. 366 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Fathering

title: John English Jr., Mary White Wed
description: Mary Frances White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Skinner White Jr. of Durham, N.C., was married yesterday to John Earle English Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. English of Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Daniel Riggall performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Chapel of the Cross in Chapel Hill, N.C..

title: IS THERE AN ALTERNATIVE TO SHOREHAM?
description: THE increasing opposition to the Shoreham nuclear plant has brought to center stage the question, never seriously considered by the Long Island Lighting Company, nor by governmental decision-makers, whether there is an alternative to the Shoreham plant.

title: PAPER BOTTLENECK, MUSIC AND RAPIDS; Heavy Load Delays New Passports
description: When strong dollars, an anticipated tax cut, Government personnel economies and neurotic computers are mixed, the result -as many Americans have discovered this spring - is a delay in the issuance of passports. The strong dollar, apparently coupled with the expectation of an increase in disposable income resulting from the Federal income tax reduction scheduled to take effect July 1, has created an unexpected surge in the number of applications. In March, according to the Department of State, more passport applications were filed than in any month in history, and by April, 212,000 applications were awaiting processing, compared to 87,000 in 1981.

title: Polish Mine Blast Kills 9
description: Nine miners were killed and one was missing in the second major coalmining accident in Poland this month, the press agency P.A.P. said today.

title: The World in Summary; A Falling Out Among Generals
description: Top military leaders in Spain battled among themselves last week over the fate of the instigators of the February, 1981, coup attempt. The Supreme Council of Military Justice arrested two of its own members at a meeting called to discuss the possibility of granting conditional liberty to some of the convicted officers. The two judges came close to trading punches with other members of the council after the Government's hand-picked presiding judge, Gen. Federico Gomez de Salazar, cast the deciding vote against the plea for lenience.

title: AMERICA'S 'DREAM ADRIFT"
description: ACROSS the country, the housing market is struggling, with interest rates persisting in the 16 to 17 percent range. Sales activity has subsided and so has new construction.

title: Miss Porter, T. P. Ogden Are Married
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass., yesterday Cynthia McLaughlin Porter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip J. Porter of Brookline, Mass., was married to Thomas Penshorn Ogden, son of Mrs. Charles Clucas of Stockbridge, Mass., and Elliott M. Ogden Jr. of New York. The Rev. Donald Bitsberger performed the ceremony.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Five Towns College in Merrick had a birthday celebration last week on the occasion of its 10th anniversary and its move to larger headquarters in Seaford for the 1982-83 academic year.

title: 'Big' Rhode Island
description: Finding ''something of a complex'' among Rhode Island's 947,154 residents because of the smallness of their state, Gov. J. Joseph Garrahy counterattacked in July 1981 with a new song, ''The Biggest Little State in the Union,'' and ads lauding the state.

title: ACCORD COULD END FLORIDA SURGEONS' BOYCOTT
description: South Florida surgeons and state lawmakers have reached a tentative agreement that could end a five-day boycott of nonemergency surgery at about 20 hospitals in the region.

title: HOSPITAL IS INVESTIGATED ON LIFE-SUPPORT POLICY
description: A Queens hospital is under investigation by the New York Attorney General's Office for possible criminal violations stemming from the denial of certain life-support measures to some seriously ill patients.

title: NEW LOOK AROUND PRINCETON
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP THE offices of the Lawrence Township Planning Board sit right in the middle of the first floor of the Municipal Building. Its doors and windows bear no identifying logos or lettering, but there is no mistaking it or its work.

title: IDEAL ISLES, FROM ALPHA TO OMEGA
description: MARGOT GRANITSAS is a journalist and photographer who worked as a correspondent in Greece from 1977 to the end of 1981. By MARGOT GRANITSAS

title: Utilities' Employee Expressed Own Views
description: In your issue of May 2, you published an article on utility regulation in Connecticut by Thomas E. Conine Jr., associate professor of finance at Fairfield University. Then, in the May 30 issue, you published a letter from a Northeast Utilities employee which was critical of Professor Conine's article.

title: Karen K. Waltrip Becomes a Bride
description: Karen Kay Waltrip, daughter of William H. Waltrip, president and chief operating officer of Pan American World Airways, and Mrs. Waltrip of New York and Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Daniel Thomas Bennewitz, son of Beatrice Smoot Bennewitz of Westport and the late Don H. Bennewitz.

title: Music View; OPERA AND SERMONS STILL DON'T MIX WELL
description: The other night in Miami, while sitting through the world premiere of Robert Ward's ''Minutes Till Midnight,'' an antinuclear sermon cast in the form of an opera, I found myself thinking dismal, heretical thoughts. Would Verdi, I wondered, ever have become a cultural hero of the Risorgimento if he had been free of government censorship and able to write openly political and patriotic operas in behalf of Italian freedom? Possibly, if only because the talents of the man were so strong that they might have prevailed, no matter what. But opera seems to be an art form in which large social or political issues can best be treated successfully when they are approached by indirection, often through comedy. In any case, the path to success runs primarily through the ganglia of emotion rather than analytic rationality. Through poetry, in other words.

title: TAPPING THE GRASS ROOTS
description: HARTFORD IN these days of megabuck political campaigns, Representative Toby Moffett, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, is trying to tap a new revenue source - small contributions from the grass roots.

title: THEATER: HIRSCH ARRIVES IN STRATFORD
description: With the departure of Robin Phillips as artistic director, the Stratford Festival of Canada has been in a state of transition. Last year, John Hirsch assumed the critical position and this summer offers the first repertory fully designed under his aegis.

title: Maria Muro, Soprano, Offers Sephardic Songs
description: The New York debut of Maria Muro, a Spanish soprano, was presented Wednesday in Carnegie Recital Hall by the Spanish Institute in association with the the Consulate General of Spain, and the program was special. Accompanied throughout by guitar (Russel Brazzel), the last half was given over entirely to Sephardic songs from Turkey, Greece and Bulgaria sung in Ladino, Castillian Spanish of the late 15th century, and the first half contained offbeat items by Handel, Pradas, Rodrigo, Garcia Lorca and Garcia Leoz.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 14 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $ 15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes,M ichael Havelock saves the world from nuclear e xtinction. 2 2 6 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $ 14.50.) During a mission to Britain on the eve of W orld War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his own r omantic past. 3 6 3 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $ 15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in w hich two children of those antagonists marry one a nother. 4 3 8 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del R ey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series ''The S econd Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 5 8 20 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace J ovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy f amilies - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina -i s strained by the Civil War. 6 5 2 EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romancea nd political upheaval on a Caribbean island. 7 4 9 CELEBRITY, by Thomas Thompson. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A c rime committed in their boyhood comes back to haunt t hree young men.

title: RELEASE OF VIETNAMESE SOUGHT
description: The Reagan Administration is seeking the release of up to 100,000 Vietnamese prisoners for possible resettlement in the United States, the United States Deputy Secretary of State, Walter E. Stoessel Jr., said today.

title: Frank Gehry's Architecture
description: Thanks to Joseph Morgenstern for bringing a new kind of insight to articles on architects and architecture (''The Gehry Style,'' May 16). The article also brings to light an essential problem with many of today's prominent architects.

title: 'A TUMBLE OF TINY SPECKS'
description: JOHN RUSSELL is chief art critic of The New York Times. BY JOHN RUSSELL

title: The Week in Business; PERSONAL INCOME, HOUSING STARTS GAINED IN MAY
description: Personal income rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, the highest since November, and personal consumption was up 1.3 percent, the biggest rise since August, the Commerce Department said. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said the figures may indicate that the recession is ending. Earlier, a 22.3 percent rise in housing starts and an easing of the drop in factory and mine output prompted economists to say that a recovery may be near.

title: WHERE TO OBTAIN FLOOD AID
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S declaration last Monday of a major disaster in Connecticut following the severe flooding of June 5 to 7, has triggered a variety of assistance programs for flood victims in the state.

title: Other Business; MONOPOLY GOES ELECTRONIC
description: In the age of Pac-Man, it had to happen. Monopoly is going electronic. Parker Brothers, which has sold more than 80 million Monopoly games since 1934, has come out with an electronic accessory intended to speed up and jazz up the slow but stately real estate board game by adding blinking lights, music and new elements of strategy.

title: Asians in America
description: So often I've been disappointed with stereotypic portrayals of Asians or Asian Americans. But I was impressed with Robert Lindsey's piece (''The New Asian Immigrants,'' May 9) because he managed to embrace not only significant Asian contributions to American society, but even more critically, to point out the long-ignored fact that Asian immigrants have suffered severe discrimination since their arrival in this country.

title: CRIME-CASINO TIES SUBJECT OF HEARING
description: WASHINGTON A''VERY GRAPHIC'' picture of how organized crime functions in Atlantic City and Philadelphia is expected to emerge Tuesday at a Senate hearing on alleged corruption in the Hotel and Restaurant Employees International Union.

title: NOISE OF JET PLANES: DO ANIMALS SUFFER?
description: BASS RIVER STATE FOREST FOR three or four hours each day, the calm of the state forest and adjacent reserves here is broken by the thunderous boom of the Air National Guard's mock bombing and gunning missions over the nearby Warren Grove Target Area.

title: SCOUTING THRIVES IN PURSUIT OF VALUES
description: SCOUTING is on the rise on the Island, especially in Suffolk County, where Girl Scout registration is increasing despite national trends to the contrary. The reasons for renewed interest, according to Scout officials, include parental concern for a return to the wholesome values believed to be fostered by scouting programs as well as a growing acceptance, especially among teen-agers, of new programs.

title: THE PLAYWRIGHT VANISHES: REFLECTIONS ON TODAY'S THEATER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Margaret Croyden, the author of ''Lunatics, Lovers and Poets: The Contemporary Experimental Theater,'' writes frequently about the arts. By MARGARET CROYDEN

title: HASIDIM FLOURISH IN SUBURBAN SETTING
description: NEW CASTLE A remote corner of this community is decidedly suburban, but the language there is Yiddish. An 8-year-old boy politely but incredulously asks a visitor, ''You don't speak Yiddish?''

title: TAKE YOUR MARK, GET SET BUT DON'T YOU GO
description: WHEN a hockey player is guilty of slashing, he is banished to the penalty box for having violated the rules. Two minutes later, he may return to the ice and resume his mayhem, if he so chooses.

title:
ART;
IN HOBOKEN CAFE: CONFUSING ART AND ARTY
description: HOBOKEN AN INTERESTING and perhaps instructive exhibition opened recently at the Unicorn Gallery in downtown Hoboken. The artist to whom the gallery is giving the most play is Lynn Rosenthal, a photographer. She is skilled and accomplished and, although she knows exactly what she is doing in terms of photographs, she unfortunately does not in terms of art.

title: VALUED POSSESSIONS DEFINE OUR LIVES
description: DO I own my possessions, or do my possessions own me? It's a question I face every time my family goes away on vacation. Our pre-departure routine involves various tasks, some necessary from a practical viewpoint, some important from an emotional perspective. Mail must be held, newspaper deliveries halted, neighbors notified of our intended whereabouts. This last arrangement is necessary for its ''preventive paranoia'' value. If there have been no emergency phone calls while we are away, I can feel optimistic. I can return with only a slightly quavering sense of security, assuming with reasonable probability that our house will still be intact.

title: Dennis Piwowarski, Clark Suttle, Strings
description: Two promising young string players made their debuts at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday evening. Dennis Piwowarski, a violinist from Hawaii, played The Vieuxtemps Concerto No. 5 in A minor and Ravel's ''Tzigane.''

title: Sumos
description: To the Business Editor: The perfunctory diagnosis of ''Japan Struggling With Itself'' (June 13), cries out for some perspectives. It may be true that Japan's emphasis on hierarchy and conformity has discouraged creativity, but then it probably has also kept palpably low the violent crime statistics of this most densely populated nation.

title: Prospects
description: Chaotic Credit Markets

title: THE RETURN OF THE AMERICAN PORCH
description: THE return of the American porch can now be accurately documented. In 1975, ''Reader's Digest'' ran an article lamenting its demise and the life style it both symbolized and made possible. This was the faint, first sign of revival.

title: THE PALESTINIANS WILL AVENGE ISRAELI AGGRESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: ROMAN CATHOLIC PRIEST FOUND SHOT TO DEATH AT BRIDGEPORT INTERSECTION
description: A Roman Catholic priest was shot to death at an intersection in Bridgeport, Conn., early yesterday morning, and the police speculated that he might have been attacked and robbed after driving off the Connecticut Turnpike and becoming lost in an unfamiliar area of the city.

title: CARIBBEAN LEADERS SEE PERIL FOR U.S. AID PLAN
description: Political leaders in the Caribbean fear that the Reagan Administration is endangering its Caribbean development plan by not fighting for it in Congress, according to Prime Minister John G.M. Compton of St. Lucia.

title: DANCE: 'PERSEPHONE' STAGED BY BALANCHINE
description: In the end - and Friday night was its literal end - the New York City Ballet's nine-day Stravinsky Centennial Celebration served to re-emphasize the extraordinary stimulus Stravinsky's music has had for George Balanchine in his choreography since 1928.

title: Dance View; THE GOLD THAT IS GRAHAM
description: No matter the subject or the physical form - the movement - in her choreography, Martha Graham remains her amazing self. This may seem questionable to some in her latest work, ''Dances of the Golden Hall.'' It looks ornate, it glitters with the gold of Halston's tiaras and tigerskin half-robes, it specifically recalls India's temple sculpture rather than an abstraction of that imagery. It even sports a symmetry, possibly the biggest shock to those who see Martha Graham as the bearer of the 20th-century modernist principle in dance, the upholder of the jagged line and, in fact, of asymmetry.

title: MOTHERS AND SONS AND COMPASSION
description: Elizabeth Timmes is convinced that children do not love their mothers if they do not ''show their love on Mother's Day, at least once a year.'' I am the mother of three grown children whose love for me all year round is unquestionable.

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Many-Faceted Shop Excels in Engraving
description: Glass engraving and the repair or restoration of crystal is done on the premises at Martens in White Plains, an 18-year-old gift store specializing in glassware, china and crystal jewelry. The monogramming usually costs $6 for three letters, depending on the size of the item.

title: TECHNOLOGY ADDS JOBS IN STATE
description: New York State's economy is going through a profound transition away from the brawn of steel mills, locomotive works and shipyards into the brainy world of biomedical engineering, data processing and microelectronics.

title: Jewish Mideast Panel Elects New Chairman
description: Julius Berman, president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, has been elected chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, representing 34 groups.

title: SAILING SHIP TO JOIN SCOUT PROGRAM
description: ''AS your skin renews itself, so does a ship,'' Michael Platzer was saying. ''Your own skin is never the same skin you have when you're born; a ship renews itself, too.''

title: HEY! FATHER'S DAY
description: ''Can't Help Lovin' That Man of Mine,'' music from ''Lawrence of Arabia,'' ''Fiddler on the Roof'' and ''The Third Man,'' ''O Danny Boy'' and ''Won't You Come Home, Bill Bailey?'' are among the variations on the father theme to be played by the Yonkers Pops Band in its annual Salute to Father's Day concert at 2 P.M. today in Untermyer Park in Yonkers.

title: Venice
description: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed the articles by MacDonald Harris and Peter Lauritzen, ''All the Facts (Some True) About Gondolas'' (Travel, June 6). Having spent some time with my Venetian cousins, I, too, had the opportunity to learn about the remote sections of Venice and to meet and make friends with all sorts of people who live and work there.

title: Polarized Cliches
description: To the Editor:

title: Michelle Clay Fiancee Of Anthony M. Alexis
description: Michelle Catherine Clay and Anthony Michael Alexis, students at the Howard University School of Law, plan to be married July 17 in St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Correction
description: Two of the photographs accompanying Joe Klein's review of ''Dreams Die Hard'' by David Harris in the June 13 issue of the Book Review were incorrectly identified. On the left is David Harris in 1963. On the right is Dennis Sweeney in 1961.

title:
GARDENING;
NO EASY ANSWERS ON GYPSY MOTHS
description: IF we were to follow the ancient Chinese custom of naming each new year after a living thing, this could have been the Year of the Gypsy Moth. Never, since early childhood, have I seen an insect generate such concern and controversy.

title: The World in Summary; REbels Gain in El Salvador
description: A dispute over the size of El Salvador's voter turnout, for all its implications, was pushed into the background last week by the heaviest fighting so far in the civil war. Rebels said they took 43 prisoners and offered to turn them over to the International Red Cross.

title: THE BOLLINGEN ADVENTURE
description: AFTER four decades of producing a highly acclaimed series of studies in esthetics, cultural and art history, archeology, philosophy, poetry, criticism, psychology, mythology and religion, a unique publishing venture is coming to an end. The Bollingen Series, founded in 1940 by Paul and Mary Mellon, was turned over to Princeton University Press by the Bollingen Foundation 15 years ago, and at the time the intention was to complete the books that had already been commissioned and then to end the series. Earlier this year the trustees of Princeton distributed to the university library and the press $4 million that had been set aside for Bollingen books and reserved $1.8 million of the Bollingen fund to complete the 51 volumes now in the works. William McGuire, managing editor of the series, says he expects the last book to appear in 1988.

title: Washington Veterans; Out of Step
description: Robert Nimmo, director of the Veterans Administration, was supposedly hired to carry out retrenchments in the agency forced by budget cutbacks. In the process he has earned a reputation for astonishing insensitivity, if not hostility, to the people his agency is supposed to serve.

title: Maureen Howard
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: ABROAD, by Paul Fussell. (Oxford University Press, $5.95.) An American critic rediscovers and appraises the travel books that such British writers as Evelyn Waugh, Graham Greene, Norman Douglas, D.H. Lawrence and Robert Byron published during the 20's and 30's, a time he describes as the Indian summer of a great literary form. Our reviewer Jonathan Raban disputed Paul Fussell's argument that the form is dead but praised his study ''as exemplary criticism, immensely readable, bristling with ideas.''

title:
Economic Affairs;
WHY REAGAN CAN'T CAP GOVERNMENT
description: In the first quarter of 1982 we passed a statistical milestone. The F ederal Government ran a deficit of $126.4 billion on an annual b asis, as measured in the national income accounts, surpassing the e ntire amount of personal savings, which amounted to only $115.4 b illion. This is more a statistical curiosity than a traumatic e conomic event, because most gross saving in our society comes from b usiness and not from individuals. In the first quarter, business s aved $375.1 billion on an annual basis while state and local g overnments added a surplus of $36.4 billion.

title: STATE SPENDING ON MENTALLY ILL IN CENTERS IS TERMED INFLATED
description: New York State's payments to its 25 community mental health centers are twice as high as they should be, according to a report by a state commission.

title: CONCERT: FOR 19TH-CENTURY PARLORS
description: Conceptually, the ''Around the Square'' concert series is delightful and imaginative. Practically, the performances and circumstances have left something to be desired, and that pattern was maintained Wednesday night for a concert of 19th-century parlor music at the Salmagundi Club.

title: Empty Tomb?
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Federal Government cannot develop the flexible, broad range of policies and partnerships needed to rebuild and revitalize urban life.

title: The Region in Summary; Newark Mayor Weathers a Political Trial
description: Twelve years ago, Earl Harris helped Newark Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson win the office. Last week, he made a strong but unsuccessful effort to force him out.

title: MIX AND MATCH
description: Because the flood of conversions of factories into luxury residential apartments was threatening to wash away what remained of New York City's industrial space, zoning laws were recently revised to encourage mixed-use buildings in some areas that would give a little to everyone. Almost a prototype of what they had in mind is now filling up at 438-48 West 37th Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues, an area that developers now like to call the new "gateway to the Convention Center."

title: FRANK GEHRY'S ARCHITECTURE
description: As another ''standard architect,'' I appreciate Joseph Morgenstern's emphasis on Frank Gehry's adherence to budgets and his concern for ''light-filled spaces.'' But where are the other positive criteria by which to judge an architectural style? Mr. Morgenstern mentions ''human proportions.''

title: TV Mailbag; ABOUT RADIO TALK SHOWS
description: To the Editor:

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title:
ART;
HENRY MOORE: HOW THE WORK DEPICTS THE ARTIST
description: GREENWICH ABEAUTIFUL and very interesting exhibition called ''Henry Moore: Perspectives on Form'' will be on view at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn., through July 3.

title: THE HIGH SCHOOL DAYS OF CAROL BELLAMY
description: AT 6:15 the other morning, John A. Gambling welcomed Carol Bellamy, President of the New York City Council, to a WOR field tent near Borough Hall in Brooklyn. He was, he said, delighted to see this distinguished Brooklynite, to which Miss Bellamy replied that she was glad to be there -even though she was not from Brooklyn.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: foot-long protest vessel, has become something of a regular visitor to New Jersey's waters. Her owner, Greenpeace U.S.A. of Washington, says that it has now made a ''major commitment'' to antidumping activities in the New York Bight, the area of the Atlantic between the eastern tip of Long Island and Cape May.

title: Television Week
description: A Kabuki First According to Faubion Bowers, ''The Cruelty of Beauty'' is a documentary in which, for the first time, an actual Kabuki play has been filmed in its entirety. Mr. Bowers is the executive producer of the production, which will be broadcast on Channel 13 on Saturday at 10:30 P.M. He will also provide the English voice-over, translating the dialogue and explaining plot developments.

title: EFFORTS SET TO CURB SUMMER VANDALISM
description: AS the end of school approaches, vandalism is expected to rise to its usual summer levels, according to Nassau and Suffolk school and law-enforcement officials. The majority of vandalism incidents throughout the rest of the year occur during after-school hours, weekends and vacations.

title: Business Conditions; BENEFITS OF RISING INCOMES
description: Certain causes of the current recession - high interest rates and a strong dollar - have made the downturn deeper than it might otherwise have been. But other factors have helped prevent the drop from being even more severe.

title: NEGOTIATORS BETWEEN VOLUNTARY HOSPITALS AND UNION STALLED
description: Contract negotiations between voluntary hopitals in New York City and the union representing 46,000 of their employees are stalled with just 10 days left before the current agreement expires.

title: 103D STREET CELEBRATES GERSHWIN
description: Kay Swift remembered going on dates with ''Georgie,'' as she called him. Gerald Marks remembered his kindness to newcomers in Tin Pan Alley and his musical brillance. The West 102-103d Street Block Association remembered George Gershwin, too, by holding a block party to commemorate the house where he lived for a few years.

title: SEASONED ACTOR STARTS ANEW
description: DR. Stuart Framingham, a sexist psychiatrist, has problems aplenty. He goes into tantrums, smokes a pipe and a cigarette at the same time, berates a patient - he calls her ''Babe'' because she doesn't want to sleep with him anymore - and stalks her in a restaurant.

title: City Council Activities Scheduled This Week
description: The following City Council activities, scheduled for the week of June 20, are open to the public: MONDAY: Committee on Governmental Operations, 10 A.M., City Hall.

title: Television Week
description: Ain't Complainin' ''It was good working with them again, but it was scary as hell the first day,'' said Nell Carter. The star of the NBC situation-comedy ''Gimme a Break'' was referring to the fact that she had joined other members of the original cast of the Broadway musical ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' - Ken Page, Charlaine Woodard, Armelia McQueen, Andre De Shields and Luther Henderson - to tape the television version of the award-winning show, which will be broadcast Monday on NBC at 9 P.M. Miss Carter won the Tony, Drama Desk, Obie and Theater World awards for her performance in the tribute to Fats Waller's music, which closed last February after 1,500 performances.

title: CITY STUDENTS RAISE SCORES IN NATIONAL MATH TESTS
description: The improved achievement of students in the New York City public schools, which showed up last year in scores on reading tests, took on added significance this year when scores on mathematics tests rose, as well.

title: 12 Nurses Off to Falklands
description: Twelve army nurses left here today on the requisitioned cargo ship Rangatira to become the first British servicewomen assigned to the Falkland Islands.
