The Rangatira also is carrying 500 men of the Royal Engineers, field hospital equipment and huts to shelter the British troops on the islands.

title: Lowry Wins 800 Meters In Schoolboy Invitation
description: Ken Lowry, who won the mile run in the Golden West national high school meet last week in 4 minutes 5.2 seconds, dropped down to the 800 meters today in the 11th Annual International Prep Invitational Meet and won the event in 1 minute 50.8 seconds.

title: Twig C. George Becomes Bride of David Pittenger
description: The marriage of Twig C. George, educational coordinator for the Center for Environmental Education in Washington, to David M. Pittenger, curator of education for the National Aquarium in Baltimore, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's mother, Jean Craighead George, in Chappaqua, N.Y. Dr. Gene Mulcahy of the Church of Choice in Hartford performed the ceremony.

title: Nina Riggio Wed To John Troster
description: Nina Elizabeth Riggio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Riggio of West Islip, L.I., was married yesterday to John Gavin Troster, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gooch Troster of Atherton, Calif. The Rev. Jerome Nodelca of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Islip, L.I., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Vincent Riggio in Bay Shore, L.I.

title: WORLDS IN MINIATURE
description: AN UNSUITABLE ATTACHMENT By Barbara Pym. 256 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $12.50.BIRDS OF PASSAGE By Bernice Rubens. 223 pp. New York: Summit Books. $13.50.

title: THE TENNIS YEAR BEGINS NOW
description: LONDON AS in winemaking, tennis has its vintage years, and although it is still early in 1982, there are several places on the tournament schedule where we can sample the product and see how things are going.

title: WHEN PART-TIME WORK BEATS FULL-TIME SCHOOL
description: In football stadiums, school auditoriums and movie theaters across the nation this week, thousands of gowned seniors will shuffle down the aisles in the time-honored ritual of high school graduation. Increasingly, however, school officials are concerned about the thousands of young men and women who have dropped out and who will never receive their diplomas.

title: Critics' Choices
description: FILM This is going to be a good summer for the surreal, the extraterrestrial and the supernatural - not only in new films, but in old ones. ''Fantastic Films,'' the series launched last week at the Regency, contains a number of everyone's old occult and sci-fi favorites even as the new ones premiere elsewhere.

title: 50 YEARS FOR JACOB'S PILLOW
description: Liz Thompson, artistic director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, came to town recently to attend an auction. She wanted to buy some paintings for the Pillow, which this summer celebrates its 50th anniversary. More accurately, she wanted to buy back some paintings. These were two large portraits of Ted Shawn, the Pillow's founder, and Ruth St. Denis, his wife and partner, that were displayed at the Pillow at its opening in 1932 and which continued to hang there for four decades.

title: ITALIAN IN SCANDAL FOUND DEAD
description: The body of a missing Italian financier, Roberto Calvi, the central figure in a $790 million bank fraud scandal, was found hanging from a London bridge Friday, the police said today.

title: Brief Falklands Tour Planned for Reporters
description: Officials here are planning to let non-British reporters into the Falkland Islands for a quick tour, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: Mrs. Moxness Leads by 3
description: Barbara Moxness, a nonwinner in five years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, today carded birdies on five of her last 11 holes, shot a four-under-par 68 and took a three-stroke lead after two rounds of the $200,000 Lady Keystone Open at the Hershey Country Club.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SANTA BARBARA
description: ROBERT LINDSEY is chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The Times. BY ROBERT LINDSEY

title: SOME REUNIONS FAIL AND SOME SUCCEED
description: TERRY (she and her family have been given fictitious names), a 44-year-old woman from a northern New Jersey suburb, says that a nightmare began for her when she saw an advertisement in a local newspaper four years ago. As she recalled:

title:
MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
Houng-Yu Hsu, Pianist With Fantasy Theme
description: Fantasy played an important part in the program that Houng-Yu Hsu, pianist, offered Tuesday in the Merkin Concert Hall of the Abraham Goodman House in her New York recital debut. A number of the works she performed included that word in their titles, but even those that didn't were fantasylike statements, so that the whole evening became a study in how composers from Bach to Debussy had used the keyboard as a voice for this singularly unfettered form of thought.

title: WASHINGTON VETERANS; A Home Team
description: For decades, major league baseball religiously opened each season in Washington, D.C. When the Senators, perennial doormats of the American League, migrated to Texas in the early 1970's, the old ritual was replaced by a running debate over how long the national pastime could survive without fielding a team in the nation's capital.

title: THE PODIUM AND THE PIT
description: Wars are over in a hurry these days, and the flags don't fly for long at half-staff. Governments make war but soon forget the people who have to fight them. We must think of the living and not the dead, they say, which is a good idea, but a little late.

title: MANY FACES OF PASTA FOR SUMMER DINING
description: THE pasta salad, that darling of the carry-out shop, is here to stay. Especially in warm weather, the idea of tossing vegetables or seafood or poultry or meat or just herbs with a dressing, anchoring the mixture with cooked and cooled macaroni, tortellini or spaghetti to make it filling enough to be dinner is especially appealing.

title: Other Business; THE BATTLE OF THE BATS, PART 2
description: TOKYO The difficulties that American producers of aluminum baseball bats have encountered in trying to crack the Japanese market have taken on an outsized stature in Japanese-American trade relations.

title: QUESTIONS IN DONOVAN CASE RAISE A WIDER CONTROVERSY
description: Regardless of whether Raymond J. Donovan survives as Secretary of Labor, the investigation of accusations against him has soiled his reputation and raised questions about the judgment of top officials at the White House and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: U.N. WARNED P.L.O. OF ISRAELI RESPONSE
description: An incomplete report that became available here today shows that the commander of the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon warned leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization that various actions by the P.L.O. would lead to ''an unstoppable Israeli assault.'' .

title: AXIS SUPPORTERS ENLISTED BY U.S. IN POSTWAR ROLE
description: Albanian emigre leaders who collaborated with Axis forces in World War II were helped into the United States in the early postwar years in connection with efforts to undermine the Communist Government of Albania, according to State Department documents long classified as secret.

title: FRANKENSTEIN TALE BECOMES AN OPERA
description: BROOKVILLE TEN years ago, immediately after finally reading Mary Shelley's classic 19th-century novel ''Frankenstein,'' the composer Gregory Sandow ''mentally'' wrote the last scene of an opera that will have its world premiere on Wednesday at the C.W. Post Center here. Drawn to the humanity of the original work rather than to the fabled horrors of subsequent adaptations, Mr. Sandow had decided then and there that the Shelley creature was an operatic character.

title: Down at the Heels
description: Amid the heady affairs of state, a foot problem was reported at the White House and State Department in February 1981. Clement Conger, curator of the reception rooms, said that the spiked heels worn by some guests were snapping the expensive strands of Oriental and other rugs.

title: Mary Rhodes To Be Bride Of Sales Aide
description: Mrs. Donald S. Kennedy of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Philip H. Rhodes of Centre Island, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Jo Rhodes, to John Scoville Rounds Jr., son of Mrs. John McClenahan of St. Albans, England, and Mr. Rounds of Westerly, R.I.

title: LEWIS REPEATS DOUBLE
description: Carl Lewis, who made American track and field history a year ago, made more of the same tonight. Last June, in the USA/Mobil outdoor championships, Lewis won the 100-meter dash and the long jump, the first competitor to achieve that double since Jesse Owens in 1936, and tonight Lewis became the first to do it two years in a row since Malcolm Ford did it in 1884, 1885 and 1886. Tonight, the 20-year-old Houston sophomore from Willingboro, N.J., won both titles again. He ran the 100 meters in 10.11 seconds and long jumped 27 feet 10 inches.

title: 'Co-op Fever'
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLIDAY AT HOME
description: Many years ago a friend invited me to come along for a holiday in Mexico, and I answered that I'd rather stay home and read Wallace Stevens. Though this was a rather precious remark by a very young writer, there was an element of truth in it. For me at that time, Wallace Stevens was the greater adventure.

title: WALK ON WILD (AND WET)SIDE
description: SHELTER ISLAND NATURE lovers are an intrepid breed. Not rain, nor floods, nor the potential absence of fauna or obliteration of flora can keep some of them from the completion of their proposed rounds.

title: HIGH-TECH COMPANIES CASHING IN ON TODAY'S COMPUTER BATTLEFIELDS
description: The weaponry goes by such names as Shrike and Hawk and Wild Weasel a nd, as these names imply, they are instruments of destruction. F illed with sophisticated electronics, they brought a new dimension t o the battles that raged in Lebanon and the Falklands war. If there i s any lesson to be learned from these conflicts, it is that e lectronics have gone to war.

title: ADMINISTRATION SEEKS TO CUT AID TO CITIES, CHARGING IT IS HARMFUL
description: In a reversal of policy from past administrations, a draft of the first urban policy statement of the Reagan Administration asserts that Federal aid has contributed heavily to the decline of American cities and argues that many grants now being made ought to be eliminated.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Trans-Atlantic Commissions IRVING WALLACE, Erich Segal and Robert Elegant are all best-selling American novelists represented in the United States and abroad by Ed Victor, an American literary agent who lives in London.

title: Correction
description: An article in Travel on June 13 incorrectly listed the telephone number of the Wesley House in Oak Bluffs, Martha's Vineyard, Mass. The hotel's number is 617-693-0135.

title: U.S. AID DIRECTOR IN LEBANON: BY PETER KHISS
description: It was called El Monton, a mountain built of garbage on which squatters had built makeshift houses. The slum on the landfill outside Lima, Peru, was also home for a 24-year-old Peace Corps volunteer, Melville Peter McPherson.

title: Bomb Injures 2 in Paris
description: Two persons were injured, one seriously, when a bomb being carried in a package by an Iranian man exploded in a Paris street today, the police said. They said the bomb appeared to have gone off accidentally while the Iranian was carrying it in the Montmartre district. The Iranian, who has not been identified, was seriously hurt and a passer-by was also injured in the blast, the police said.

title: Through the Diet Fog
description: The relationship between diet and cancer is fraught with uncertainties, fads and fallacies. But certain rough shapes are beginning to emerge from the fog. They form the basis for a new set of recommendations on diet and cancer issued by a committee of the National Academy of Sciences. Unlike the previous diet sheet from the Academy, this one deserves to be taken seriously.

title: Fashion; HAS SUCCESS SPOILED MILAN?
description: The rise of Milan in the world of high fashion, a rise that has given true meaning to rags-to-riches achievement, is a story of modern design, quality workmanship and sophisticated marketing. Or at least it has been for the past five years. MISSING BH COMMAND But now, after a disappointing reaction to Milan's ready-to-wear collections for fall 1982, held three months ago, some Italian designers are concerned about the future of their fashion capital, a capital that certainly has challenged Paris (some thought it might overtake it) as the premier European fashion citadel. The complaints that followed the March showings ranged from disappointment with the clothes themselves - too ''costumey'' - to their prices - too high. And apprehensions continued about late deliveries.

title: Sound; UNORTHODOXY GIVES RISE TO A NEW BREED OF SPEAKERS
description: Unlike science in its higher reaches, engineering shies away from theory. Not that engineering is purely a matter of nuts and bolts. Far from it. The style of imagination that marks the creative engineer is actually quite similar to that of the creative artist. Yet the scope of engineering is inherently constrained by tangible - or at least measurable -fact.

title: What? Penalizing the Poor?
description: There he goes again. In Houston last week, President Reagan denounced ''the special pleaders'' who go about ''campaigning against our budget cuts as penalizing the poor.'' As he has insisted repeatedly, ''There have been no budget cuts'' - only slower spending growth.

title: IF YOUR THINKING OF LIVING IN MURRAY HILL
description: You can eat a fish-and-raw-egg Japanese breakfast in Murray Hill, read a Gutenberg Bible, buy a pornographic birthday card or swim on a rooftop. You can throw a private party at the Automat, protest marital law outside the Polish consulate or pump iron in a basement health club.

title: THE LUCRATIVE TRADE OF CRAFTING JUNK MAIL
description: BON APPETIT was a moribund gourmet magazine until the Knapp C ommunications Corporation purchased it a half-dozen years ago. Afterr estyling and upgrading its new product, Knapp commissioned a trim, u rbane San Francisco man named Bill Jayme to write a letter to p rospective readers. That letter ultimately coaxed several million f ood lovers to subscribe, and now Bon Appetit is a thriving p ublication.

title: Mariners 10, Royals 3
description: SEATTLE (AP) - Gary Gray and Al Cowens got three hits each for Seattle. Jim Beattie (4-4) struck out 10 Royals in seven innings for a career personal best and earned his fourth straight victory. Beattie scattered six hits before getting relief help from Ed VandeBerg and Larry Andersen.

title: ART SAMPLER
description: TODAY is a rather sad one for anyone who follows the New Jersey art scene. It is the end of the 1981-82 season for the Montclair Art Museum, which will close this afternoon and not reopen until after Labor Day.

title: Around the World; Soviet Accuses the U.S.  Of 'Political Blackmail'
description: The official Soviet press agency Tass said today that President Reagan's expanded embargo on United States supplies for the Siberian natural gas pipeline amounted to an attempt at ''political blackmail.''

title: Noble Damsel Wins on Belmont Grass
description: Three weeks ago, Michael Kay was walking down his shed row and talking optimistically about his hopes for two horses, Illuminate and Noble Damsel.

title: RUINS OF WAR LITTER HILLS AND VALLEYS OF LEBANON
description: Leaving the coastal highway after a trip north from the Israeli border this week, through the ruins of Tyre and Sidon into the hills and valleys of southern Lebanon, the war was never far behind.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I finally gave up waiting for a sunny weekend. Since I left college, 15 years ago, I had never had Saturdays and Sundays off. Newspapers are institutions with their own rules, and one of the rules is that you have to put in a lot of years before you can have your days off with the rest of the world. You also have to be lucky. Or so, at least, I thought before the lucky day came.

title: SOVIET PIANIST PERFORMS, BUT NOT IN NEW YORK
description: Vladimir Feltsman drew the shades, arranged the lights and sat down at his Bluthner grand piano for a concert of Mozart and Schumann - a concert he would have preferred to hold in New York this week.

title: BRAZILIAN FILMS FIND BIG BUCKS IN SOCIAL COMMENT
description: If Brazilian film makers were not convinced after a recent spate of international awards and box office successes here and abroad that their art was having an impact, the Government has confirmed it for them. Censors banned a new movie called ''Pra Frente Brasil'' (''Forward Brazil'') and ordered it withdrawn from a special showing last month in connection with the Cannes film festival.

title: A CORNUCOPIA OF CRAFTS IN INDIA
description: MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN is chief of the New Delhi bureau of The Times. BY MICHAEL T.KAUFMAN

title: JERSEY CITY SEEKS PRIVATE-SECTOR HELP
description: JERSEY CITY MAYOR GERALD McCANN wants to counter cuts in Federal and state aid by turning over 25 to 40 city services to United Way agencies, the Jersey City Medical Center and private groups.

title: Stage View; PASSAGES THAT REVEAL A PLAYWRIGHT'S POTENTIAL
description: One of a reviewer's most dismaying experiences, whether he is looking at a play on Broadway or Off, is the realization that nothing in the world is going to save the exhibit on view - and that as the play goes down in flames a possibly viable playwright is going down with it. Upon arrival in the playhouse you glance at the Playbill, make note of the author's name, and further make note that - because you've never heard the name before -this is probably a first play, or at least the first to get close to the bright lights. Then, gradually, you face up to the fact that it has probably got too close to the bright lights. All sorts of seams and smudges and jagged rips are showing, and you know in your bones that as of Saturday night it's going to belong to the Lost Cause department. Now, just as you've begun to surrender to this near-certainty, the author writes a good speech.

title: BY MID-JULY, CUT-RATE MORTGAGES
description: HOME buyers looking for alternatives to current high interest rates will be lining up in the next few weeks for state-assisted mortgages, but good timing will be critical in determining who gets them.

title: POST-LEBANON GOALS
description: War changes conditions. It does not often solve problems or make peace. War does not make opportunity. War destroys.When peace follows war, it is because leaders forge a strategy for building peace from the rubble and the hatred. Sadly, it is often because they will do after a war what they did not have the courage or concentration to do before.

title: Pink Slips
description: To the Business Editor: It was with great pleasure and professional pride that I read ''A Human Resource at Allied Corp.'' (June 6). I must, however, take strong exception to Charles Bischoff's indication that the choice time to separate an employee is Friday afternoon.

title: Recent Sales
description: Clifton $132,000 45 Godwin Place *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 21-year-old ranch; *2*central air-conditioning, 2-car garage; taxes $1,623. North Haledon $117,000 182 Highland Road *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; *2*fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $2,863. Pompton Plains $118,000 229 Sunset Road *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath, 3-year-old ranch; fireplace in *2*family room, partially finished basement; taxes $3,402 Wayne $180,000 1 Bullens Avenue *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old colonial; in-ground *2*swimming pool, cathedral ceiling; taxes $2,685. West Paterson $70,000 24 Highview Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old colonial; Cod; *2*fenced yard, finished basement, taxes $1,148. Pompton lakes $57,000 100 Pierson Miller Drive *2*1-bedroom, 1-bath, 3 1/2-year-old garden apartment condominium; *2*wall-to-wall carpeting, storm and screened windows; taxes $820. OTHER AREAS Bronxville, N.Y. $480,000 9 Rittenhouse Road *2*9-bedroom, 6 1/2-bath, 55-year-old stone Tudor-Norman; maid's *2*room, sewing room, breakfast room, 1acre; taxes $11,552 Litchfield, Conn. $145,000 South Street *2*7-bedroom, 4-bath, 1855 Victorian; swimming pool, 5 fireplaces, *2*exceptional landscaping, 1 acre; taxes $2,578. Plainview, L.L. $145,000 9 Princeton Drive *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; formal *2*dining room, eat-in kitchen, den with fireplace, *2*underground sprinkler system; taxes $4,278.

title: English Ruggers Romp
description: England's national rugby team completed its tour today with a 59-0 rout of the United States Eagles at Dillon Stadium.

title: THE WOES AND JOYS OF FATHERHOOD
description: STAMFORD AT 9 A.M. on Wednesday, John McDowell was late for a chat about the travails of fatherhood, and an hour later he was still missing. He had been delayed, it turned out, attending to one of the joys of his condition.

title: ASIANS IN AMERICA
description: Robert Lindsey's article was read with interest by those of us who are involved with refugee resettlement.

title: Valenzuela Conquers Reds, 2-1, For No. 9
description: Pedro Guerrero homered and drove in a pair of runs today, enabling Fernando Valenzuela to become the National League's first nine-game winner as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Cincinnati Reds, 2-1.

title: METS TOPPLE CARDS
description: The Yankees' relief corps gave the Yankees' hitters plenty of time to beat the Baltimore Orioles last night, and the hitters needed every bit of it.

title: PAVING THE WAY
description: ONE of the simplest ways of putting down an attractive paved entrance walk, or creating a paved path leading to a side door or back entrance of the house, is to set pieces of slate, stone or precast paving blocks into the ground. This not only eliminates the back-breaking job of mixing and pouring quantities of concrete, but also makes an esthetically pleasing walk that blends in more naturally with the grass and surrounding landscaping of most suburban homes.

title: HAVE HORROR FILMS GONE TOO FAR?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elliott Stein writes regularly for Film Comment. By ELLIOTT STEIN

title: Around the Nation; Atlantic Coast Storm Responsible for 9 Deaths
description: A storm that left nine people dead in three Eastern Seaboard states caused coastal flooding and chased vacationers from beaches before turning out to sea today.

title: BRITISH REPORTEDLY LAND ON SOUTH SANDWICH ISLANDS
description: Argentina said tonight that British forces attacked and surrounded an Argentine scientific survey station in the South Sandwich Islands. The islands are a British dependancy of the Falkland Islands.

title: Sailing, Sailing
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Michael Smith, Jocelyn Brown Wed
description: Jocelyn Michelle Brown, daughter of Robert Dyer Brown of Columbus, Ohio, and Dr. Donna Browder Evans of Bangor, Me., was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Douglas Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Reginald Smith of Washington. The Rev. Roger Bond Nichols performed the ceremony at the St. John's Episcopal Church in Bangor.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JUNE 20, 1982
description: International An ''unprecedented'' series of tests of strategic weapons by the Soviet Union in the past few days have cast doubt on Moscow's pledge not to be the first to use nuclear weapons, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., said at the conclusion of talks with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in New York. Mr. Haig said that ''only a few days after'' Mr. Gromyko's speech Tuesday at the United Nations in which the Soviet pledge was made, ''the Soviet Union has undertaken an unusually high level of strategic activity.'' He then specified the kind of weapons tests that he said had been carried out. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: JULES FEIFFER ON THE TYRANNY OF TRIVIA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Helen Dudar is a freelance writer who lives in New York City. BY HELEN DUDAR

title: CAMP IS GREAT. SHE HATES IT.
description: THE end of the school year is usually heralded by long, balmy days, long absentee lists and long lines at the camp outfitter's. With the final ring of dismissal, books are closed and kids are off to that memorable summer institution called camp.

title: HADDAD LOOKS TO SIDON AS A NEW HEADQUARTERS
description: MERJ 'UYUN, Lebanon, June 19 -Maj. Saad Haddad, the Lebanese Christian militia leader who controls an enclave on Israel's northern border, says he plans to move his headquarters to Sidon, the port city that was occupied by the Israelis in their invasion.

title: 5 STATES DELAY TAX REFUNDS IN BUDGET SQUEEZE
description: At least five states have delayed payment of state income tax refunds this year to help solve their budget problems, and a leading tax expert said it was the first time such a thing had ever happened.

title: MOTHERS AND SONS AND COMPASSION
description: After reading ''The Call That Didn't Come,'' one can only wonder how long it will be before the rest of the family flee for their sanity. Note the strange admission that the No. 2 son's ''bitterness caused his two brothers ...to agree to go with their father and me on a trip to the city''- i.e., if it hadn't been for her self-pity over their brother, they wouldn't have gone.

title: Catherine Barre Is Wed to Ralph Isham
description: Catherine Barre, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rene Barre of Paris, was married in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Etienne du Mont there yesterday to Ralph Heyward Isham, son of Heyward Isham, former Ambassador to Haiti, and Mrs. Isham of Washington and Sagaponack, L.I. The Rev. Alphonse de Menton and the Rev. William Sloane Coffin of the Riverside Church officiated.

title: ANIT-AMERICANISM SEEN IN SALVADOR
description: Anti-Americanism appears to be growing in this country's rightist establishment -among politicians, businessmen who back free enterprise and patriotic women's political organizations.

title: ELECTION IN MAURITIUS SHARPENS DIEGO GARCIA ISSUE
description: As far as the Defense Department in Washington is concerned, the elaborate and costly military staging area that it has built in the Indian Ocean on the tiny island of Diego Garcia, about 1,200 miles from here, is held under the terms of an ironclad lease that will not expire until 2025.

title:
Comment;
GHOST TOWN
description: Why are real interest rates so high, and what will it take bring t hem down? Real rates have never been this high for so long. E conomists are frantically rummaging around in their meager tool kitsl ooking for a way to make their old explanations fit this new p henomenon.

title: There Is a Need For Tutoring
description: About the article ''To Be Tutored or Not to Be Tutored - a Question of Needs'' (June 6), I should like to comment from my experiences in tutoring math for 25 years. Although I agree with some of your article, my tutoring has obtained excellent results with students of marginal ability in mathematics, where teaching on a one-to-one basis gives much needed clarity and reinforcement.

title: PRESS FOR RIGHTS AMENDMENT INTENSIFIES IN ILLINOIS
description: Shortly before noon, eight women, most of them weak from a month without food, moved feebly into the busy rotunda of the state Capitol and sat under a purple banner reading: ''Women Hunger For Justice.''

title: AGAINST THE JAPANESE GRAIN
description: Susan Chira, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times, recently returned from a year of study in Japan. By Susan Chira very Sunday, a little before noon, groups of junior- and senior-highschool students pour out of the Harajuku train station and head for the promenade at nearby Yoyogi Park in central Tokyo. Dressed in rainbow-colored vests and faddish pants, the girls wearing garish makeup, the youngsters clutch enormous radios and shopping bags. The leader of each group selects a space and sets the radio in the middle. Immediately, the teen-agers begin to dance, all performing the same stylized gestures to blaring rock music. Watching the milelong dancing festival has become a pleasant Sunday-afternoon pastime for hundreds of Japanese. Whole families thread their way through the crowds, munching on the fried seafood, noodles and crepes that vendors sell.

title: John S. Barada Marries Sandra Dawn Davies
description: Sandra Dawn Davies, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William de Ath Davies Jr., of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to John Sherman Barada, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Sylvester Barada 3d of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Mark Connolly performed the ceremony in St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: CARILLONS TO RING AT TRINITY
description: ''BELLS,'' wrote Charles Lamb, ''The music nighest bordering upon heaven.'' If you agree, Trinity College in Hartford is the place to be this week when some 100 bell-ringers convene for the annual congress of the Guild of Carillonneurs of North America.

title: Israel Turns Back Relief Ship, Citing a Mine Threat at Sidon
description: A ship carrying 750 tons of relief supplies for southern Lebanon has been turned back because the Israelis say there are mines off the coast, the International Committee of the Red Cross said today.

title: NATIONAL HIGH I.Q.'S TO MEET
description: give or take a few - whose brains are, in theory at least, better than most will be heading for Trenton State College here this week.

title: TREASURES IN THE HEART OF HUNGARY
description: PAUL LEWIS is a Paris-based economic correspondent for The Times. BY PAUL LEWIS

title: A LEGEND LINGERS
description: Fourty years ago, while being converted into a troopship, the Normandie burned and died at her Manhattan pier. Despite the loss, much of the Normandie magnificence has survived in bit and pieces because 2,400 truckloads of decoration were removed just before the fire.

title: YELLOW-RUMPED (MYRTLE) WARBLER; Dendroica coronata
description: Size: Five to six inches. Color: Upper parts bluish-gray with black streaks.

title: There Is No Fairness In Conversions
description: Regarding ''Case for Landlords on Conversions'' (May 23), a few facts were left out by Kenneth J. Gould. But first, I want to say this past Friday the Yankees won a ballgame 12-1. To Mr. Gould's way of thinking they really lost didn't they? He says it's O.K. if only 30 percent of a building give the O.K. for conversions.

title: NEW CAST AND GOAL FOR SHARON THEATER
description: SHARON ''ATTENTION, attention must be paid,'' declares Willy Loman's wife, Linda, in Arthur Miller's 1949 drama about the plight of the common man, ''Death of a Salesman,'' which will open the Sharon Playhouse summer season next week.

title: Miss Lindberg, William Steward, Will Be Married
description: Amanda Atwood Lindberg of Stonington, Conn., and Sam Claes Lindberg of North Haven, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Erica Sames Lindberg, to William Cree Steward, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Earl Steward of White Plains and Point Judith, R.I.

title: CONDO MALL
description: There wasn't a pizza parlor within miles when Oakridge, a 102-unit town-house condominium development, was begun two years ago in Vista, a rural hamlet in northern Westchester. There was a supermarket, a small pharmacy, a hairdresser and a luncheonette in a row of cinderblock buildings, but for anything else, residents had to drive five miles to Goldens Bridge or 10 miles to New Canaan, across the Connecticut line.

title: SUPER AIRCRAFT CARRIERS ARE NOT FOR THE FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
FAMILY ARTS DAY
description: It may be Father's Day today, but the Nassau County Office of Cultural Development has decreed it Family Arts Day at the Center for Fine Arts and has scheduled a little bit of something for everyone. From 1 to 5 P.M., the grounds of the Roslyn Harbor estate will host ''how to'' lectures and an exhibition by the Photography Club of Long Island and ''Lunch Lines, A Poemfest with the Poetry Society of America,'' to which all poets are invited to bring their works for open readings.

title: Music
description: To the Editor: We have been informed by the Drottningholm Court Theater in Stockholm that, contrary to the report given by Harold Schonberg in his article on Music Festivals (Travel, May 2), the ''Montezuma'' scheduled for performance in Stockholm this summer is not the opera by Roger Sessions, but another opera of the same name by an obscure 18th-century German composer named Karl Heinrich Grauna (1704-1759).

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Architecture View; STROLLING ALONG A POST-MODERN 'STREET' FROM VENICE
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Press Notes; MORE PAPERS ARE STUDYING MERGER GAINS
description: Before the decision last week by Attorney General William French Smith approving a merger of the business and production operations of Seattle's two daily newspapers, publishers in other cities were considering the benefits they might gain from similar mergers.

title: MIDEAST CRISIS PLUNGES REAGAN INTO NEW ROLE
description: The tumult in the Middle East provoked by Israel's invasion of Lebanon has cleared the way, many experts believe, for a rare opportunity for American diplomacy. On the eve of a crucial meeting between President Reagan and Prime Minister Menachem Begin, however, there seemed little assurancce that the Administration was ready to seize it.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA ROLLING ON
description: Martina Navratilova continued her winning ways on the eve of Wimbledon today, defeating Hana Mandlikova, 6-4, 6-3, for the $23,000 first-place prize in the BMW tennis tournament.

title: Around the World; Angolan Sees Hope In West's Namibia Plan
description: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola said today that the latest Western proposals for the independence of South-West Africa from South Africa could lead to rapid progress if South Africa showed good will.

title: Nancy Chang To Be Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Wei-Ping Loh of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of Mrs. Loh's daughter, Nancy Yung-Chung Chang, to Dr. James Burns Amberson 4th, son of Mrs. Peter J. Kuntz of Orleans, Mass., and Dr. Amberson 3d of Amherst, Mass.

title: DEMOCRATS SEIZE WEAPONS FREEZE AS ISSUE FOR FALL
description: The movement for a freeze on Soviet and American nuclear arsenals, which has attracted widespread bipartisan appeal, is increasingly being seized upon by Democratic politicians as a significant issue to sway votes in the November elections.

title:
Camera;
BOOKS DEVOTED TO THE BUSINESS OF PHOTOGRAPHY
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ONE of New Jersey's last great bargains will end in September, when Princeton University restricts access to Firestone Library, one of the few major research libraries open to the general public.

title: DESIGNING HOUSES RIGHT TO THE DISHES
description: WHEN Mel Tooker says that the houses he and his partner design and build in a wooded area of East Hampton are ''custom in every respect,'' he does not mean that they are fashioned to fit the individual requirements of their eventual owners, like a Savile Row suit. He means that when he, as a designer, and the architect John LaFerlita collaborate on a house, they tailor everything to their own tastes.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title:
DINING OUT;
ACROSS THE RIVER, INTO THE WOODS
description: TEN miles across the Hudson River, set among woods, gardens and ponds spurting shaped fountains and harboring ducks and geese, the Bully Boy Chop House has prospered and grown for almost a quarter of a century. The addition to the one-room original roadhouse by the owner, Thomas H. McQuade, has resulted in a charming hodgepodge of rooms, cul-de-sacs, alcoves, fireplaces and staircases. Each area carries a distinct mood, and, although some corners are more attractive than others, none lacks beauty -the flash of brass at the pubby bar; the tiny, correct Victorian lounge; cozy, low-ceilinged Colonial rooms with garden views and wallpaper reflecting the flowers that become swans and water lilies in the glass-walled, bileveled rooms that overlook the ponds.

title: WE MUST GIVE TALENTED YOUTH A PLACE TO GROW
description: WE JERSEYANS are a strange bunch. We are used to a wealth of resources, be they natural, garden, potholed or human. Human resources? We've got a ton. But, like I said, we Jerseyans are a strange bunch. We are just as used to squandering those resources. We tend to allow, even encourage, our human resources to migrate elsewhere, as if the rich and diverse experient soil of the Garden State will never be depleted.

title: Beverly Purcell Married
description: Beverly Kimtis Purcell, daughter of Joseph J. Kimtis of Boston, and the late Mrs. Kimtis, was married yesterday to Dr. Fernando A. Guerra, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fernando Guerra of San Antonio, Tex. The Rev. Kenyon Wildrick performed the ceremony at the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J. The bride is associate merchandising director of Vogue magazine in New York. Dr. Guerra is clinical associate professor of pediatrics at the University of Texas Health Science Center. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bridegroom's.

title: STRAWBERY BANKE: A LIVELY LEGACY
description: SHERRY MARKER is a writer who lives in Northampton, Mass. BY SHERRY MARKER

title: SundaySports
description: Auto Racing Michigan 400, at Brooklyn, Mich. This is the halfway point for the Nascar circuit and the leaders - Darrell Waltrip, Bobby Allison and Terry Labonte - are all fighting for Winston Cup championship points. (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.) Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M. Tommy John of the Yankees (4-6) and Mike Flanagan (5-5) start the finale of this three-game series, the Orioles' only visit here until September. (Television -Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. Remember Jim Bunning's 1964 Father's Day no-hitter against the Mets? Manager George Bamberger has Father's Day memories of his own from 1951. He pitched a nohitter for Ottawa against Toronto in the International League and won by drawing a walk with the bases full for the only run. (Television - SportsChannel 2:15 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570 and WGBB, 1240, 2:15 P.M.) Boxing Frank (The Animal) Fletcher vs. Clint Jackson, 12 rounds, United States Boxing Association middleweight title fight, at Atlantic City. Fletcher, 14-2-1 with 11 knockouts, ranked No.3 by the World Boxing Association and No.4 by the World Boxing Council, makes his third defense since capturing the U.S.B.A. title last June. Jackson is 18-1 with 14 knockouts. His only loss was to Tony Braxton, who was Fletcher's last victim. (Television - Channel - 4, 4 P.M.) Bicycling Harlem Bicycle Championships, at Marcus Garvey Park, 11 A.M. This is the 10th annual running of the popular event around the mile-square park that interrupts Fifth Avenue between 120th and 124th Streets.

title: PRUDENTI A WINNER AT G.O.P. PARLEY
description: ANTHONY J. PRUDENTI, the Suffolk Republican leader, scored a political victory at the Republican State Committee meeting last week while his not so friendly competitor and neighbor, Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican chairman, suffered a serious setback.

title: THE WALKER AND HIS WORLD
description: ADAM NICOLSON, a London writer, is the author of ''The National Trust Book of Long Walks in England, Scotland and Wales.'' By ADAM NICOLSON

title: CALIFORNIA SENATE RACE GETS OFF TO QUICK START
description: The Senate race between Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. and Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego has got quickly under way, with Mr. Brown emphasizing his opponent's support of policies of the Reagan Administration and Mr. Wilson assailing the Governor as ''a taxer and a spender.''

title: Headliners; Inman's Inside Gambit
description: Bobby R. Inman, former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, was considered one of the brighter lights in the intelligence community until policy differences with the Reagan Administration turned him off.

title: Around the Nation; Two Fights Break Out At San Quentin Prison
description: Violence broke out at San Quentin Prison today, resulting in injuries to 22 convicts and four correctional officers.

title: MILITARY LOSS NOW SHARPENS CHRONIC WOES
description: It had been a moment in the sun, when the country reveled in feelings of unity and of fighting for what all thought was a just cause. But the seizure of the Falkland Islands ended last week as a misbeggoten venture. Argentine troops surrendered, the President was forced to resign, and the nation was once again wallowing in a political abyss. Its frail sense of nationhood became a casualty of the war.

title: The Nation in Summary; BUdget Deal Made; Now to Live With It
description: ''This budget,'' snapped Senate Budget Committee chairman Pete V. Domenici snapped in a hot moment of public debate last week, ''has as much realism as any budget that's ever been produced.''

title: Values More Important Than Passing Fads
description: When parents and community leaders realize that video games (''Video Arcades Are Stirring Up Main Street, N.J.,'' May 23) are just another passing fad, maybe they will concentrate on moreimportant community-based projects, such as removing 42d Street atmosphere from their school systems and redirecting their children's materialistic attitudes of self-satisfaction back to a more-basic, down-to-earth value system.

title: STREET SCENE
description: FORSAKING ALL OTHERS By Jimmy Breslin. 431 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: New York Times Magazine June 20, 1982
description: William Safire 8 On Language Sherpa Run-Up Russell Baker 14 Sunday Observer Fathering Michael Wright 16 The Marine Corps Faces the Future World tensions and new weapons are helping the Marines overcome the severe image - and enlistment - problems they suffered after the Vietnam War. Alex Ward 20 They Also Serve Standing in the wings of big-time tennis are hundreds of players who brave the rigors and torments of qualifying matches in order to challenge the stars. John Russell 24 Lincoln Kirstein: A Life in Art Susan Chira 28 Against the Japanese Grain Prosperity has spawned a small but significant number of Japanese who want more out of life than a self-sacrificing work ethic provides them. June Weir 62 Fashion The Italian Missed Connection Marilyn Bethany 64 Design Barking Up the Right Tree Deborah Blumenthal 68 Beauty Taking a Pasting Craig Claiborne 71 Food with Pierre Franey When Eggs Are Hot Stuff 76 Puzzles Answers, Page 80 86 Letters Cover: Photograph by Herman J. Kokojan/Black Star Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: Nina S. Barclay Becomes a Bride
description: Nina Sturges Barclay and Jay Russell Versteeg were married yesterday in St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Charles Griswold performed the ceremony, assisted by the bridegroom's father, the Rev. Robert J. Versteeg of Toledo, Ohio, a Methodist minister.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: ''IWANT to be a dentist,'' 16-year-old Tim Brinkley was telling Dr. John E. Maupin, who at 72 is well established in that profession. ''I have great hands, I fix jewelry. I love using my hands.''

title: Killer Bees
description: Like a menacing thunderhead, the African ''killer'' bees appeared suddenly in news reports in the late 1970's. They were portrayed as savage creatures, prone to attack animals and humans in great swarms and with greater tenacity than European bees, common in North America.

title: RURAL BANKS UNITE TO MODERNIZE HOME LOANS
description: Bankers in the central Appalachian highlands announced a new effort today to bring a suburban style of financing with low down payments to one of the most poorly housed regions of the nation.

title: SHOPPING AT HOME WITH COMPUTERS
description: If we are what we buy, then how are we shaped by how and where we b uy it? What will things be like when Americans can stay home to s hop, and the television set becomes a kind of electronic department s tore? A new study by the Institute of the Future, Menlo Park, C alif., predicts that two new technologies known as videotex and t eletext could dramatically change the marketplace and society. An e xcerpt from the report, sponsored by the National Science F oundation, follows.

title: ON DIVERTING TRANSPORTATION USER FEES
description: IN A RECENT article, the columnist George Will wrote, ''Private life, including private enterprise, depends on publicly provided infrastructure.''

title: Frederick M. Rust to Wed Elizabeth Cancian in Fall
description: Mrs. John Cancian of Hyannisport, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Rose Cancian, to Frederick Michael Rust, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Rust of Sayville, L.I.

title: Robert Duncan Weds Julia Margaret Reade
description: Julia Margaret Reade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kemp Brownell Reade of Westport, Conn., was married in Portland, Conn., yesterday to Robert Atwater Duncan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Duncan of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Nathaniel P. Lauriat, pastor of the Unitarian Meeting House in West Hartford, performed the ceremony at the St. Clements Estate, property of Wesleyan University.

title: SAILING, SAILING
description: To the Editor: It is indeed possible to fall in love with a ship - especially one like the Sea Cloud. Our unforgettable adventure aboard the vessel was with the Smithsonian Institution earlier this year.

title: CAM FELLA HOLDS OFF MERGER AT THE WIRE TO WIN CANE PACE
description: ''We were going for it all,'' said Norm Faulkner, the Canadian-based co-owner of the 3-year-old colt Cam Fella. He and his partner had supplemented their colt for $25,000 and they weren't about to settle on just getting their investment back by finishing in the money.

title: A MAYOR IN SOUTH PHILIPPINES TAUNTS MARCOS
description: In this southern Philippine city, which is still under martial law, opposition to the 17-yearold presidency of Ferdinand E. Marcos appears to be growing under the flamboyant leadership of Mayor Cesar C. Climaco.

title: Index; International
description: U.S. arms negotiator in Paris is ''guardedly optimistic'' 3 Vietnam making its case on Cambodian invasion 3 A mayor in South Philippines challenges Marcos 4 Around the World 5 Soviet pianist, barred from emigrating, gives concert at home 6 Caribbean leaders fear for life of U.S. aid plan 7 Costa Rica orders 40 Nicaraguans to leave the country 8 Anti-Americanism appears to rise in El Salvador's right 9 Peking promises P.L.O. $1 million in emergency aid 11 Israeli ally in Lebanon is expanding his enclave 12 Welshman fights London for rights to a mountain 13 Italian banker tied to $790 million fraud is found dead in London 14 Diego Garcia's ex-residents keep issue alive in Mauritius 16 Government/Politics Congressional quarrel stalls buildup of military airlift 16 California Senate race gets off to quick start 19 Budget accord to have sharp impact on domestic programs 24 Carey signs bill on special property loans for the elderly 30 General Appalachia banks unite to modernize home financing 21 Around the Nation 22 California surfers clash over who gets the best waves 22 Parents may get a lower student-loan rate 28 Press Notes: Papers studying gains of merged operations 29 A Roman Catholic priest is found shot dead in Bridgeport, Conn. 32 The aircraft carrier Intrepid is being converted to a museum 34 Education/Welfare City students raise scores on national math tests 38 Arts/Entertainment John Hirsch's first productions at Canada's Stratford Fesitval 44 Mostly Mozart to open July 12 45 City Ballet ends Stravinsky Festival 48 10-day jazz festival begins Friday 49 Music debuts in review 50 ''The Postman Always Rings Twice,'' an opera in St. Louis 50 19th-century parlor music in Washington Square series 50 Style Fatherhood: expanding role and expanding joys 52 Obituaries Djuna Barnes, a poet, playwright and novelist 32 Features/Notes Man in the News: Melville Peter McPherson, A.I.D. director 10

title: JUDAICA AT YALE
description: Ezra Stiles, president of Yale, and Rabbi Haim Isaac Carigal met in Newport, R.I., in 1773, marking the beginning of a warm friendship based on scholarly dialogues between the two men. When Rabbi Carigal died in 1777, Mr. Stiles arranged for his portrait to be painted by Samuel King, an artist who had painted Mr. Stiles's own likeness some years earlier. Mr. Stiles's wish that the two portraits hang side by side in perpetuity was not honored and the portraits were eventually returned to the respective families.

title: Wits of the 80's
description: Not all of today's whiz kids are working in silicon valleys, contriving ways to revolutionize tomorrow's life through computers and other electronic devices. Some are concerned with life today, using the printed word to help Americans find relief from present-day pressures by poking fun at the latest fads and foibles. Last year, for example, a witty crew concocted the bestselling ''Official Preppy Handbook.'' Currently, a trio of new writers is making waves by offering satirical help to that embattled creature, the American male. Real Men

title: On Language
description: Sherpa Run-Up KIMBLE MEAD

title: Protesters in Guatemala Ask Inquiry Into Disappearances
description: About 150 people demonstrated outside the National Palace on Friday to demand a government investigation into how and why thousands of people disappeared in recent years.

title: The Region in Summary; Jersey's Way To Close the Gap
description: Governor Kean went out on a limb by proposing to increase taxes after promising to reduce them, and New Jersey legislators have been in no rush to join him there. Last week, as Mr. Kean prepared to impose some painful budget cuts, the Assembly reluctantly passed the Governor's 5 percent surtax on gasoline and the Senate gave final approval to his 5-cent-a-pack increase in the cigarette tax.

title: 5 Raccoons Believed Rabid; 16 Floridians Face Treatment
description: Five baby raccoons taken in as pets by different families three months ago are believed to be rabid, and at least 16 residents will undergo treatment for rabies, officials say.

title: The Region in Summary; City Schools Break a Barrier
description: Students may sweat through the standardized math and reading tests administered in New York City each year, but the bureaucracy sweats out the grades as a measure of its pedagogic talent. According to results announced last week, the system passed.

title: POP-SOUL: POINTER SISTERS
description: One of pop music's more proficient harmony groups, the Pointer Sisters have changed from a quartet who dispensed swing and jazz nostalgia into a mainstream pop-soul trio in recent years. And at the first show of a two-night stand at the Ritz Tuesday, they strutted their technique with a high-spirited exuberance that partially compensated for a lack of musical personality.

title: Diane Berson Married To Dr. Mark Lebowitz
description: Diane Stephanie Berson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Eugene Berson of Brooklyn and Key Biscayne, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Allan Lebowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Lebowitz of Roslyn Heights, L.I. Rabbi Joel Zion and Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: SYRIA CALLS FOR ATTACKS ON U.S. INTERESTS IN MIDEAST
description: The leaders of the political parties represented in the Syrian National Assembly tonight issued an appeal to ''Arab masses'' everywhere to show their solidarity with the Palestinians in Lebanon by ''attacking and destroying American interests'' in the Arab world.

title: Stephen Wolosonovich, In Violin Sonatas
description: Stephen Wolosonovich, a violinist in the area for many years, played his first New York solo recital in Carnegie Recital Hall last Saturday afternoon. His partner at the piano was Paul Kuetner.

title: Sports People; Umpire a Casualty
description: A deflection and a skid resulted in two casualties in Friday night's Toronto Blue Jays-A's game in Oakland, Calif. The injured were the home-plate umpire Mark Johnson, who suffered a broken right hand, and Mickey Klutts, the A's third baseman, who hurt his back and rib cage and will be out a week.

title: Television Week
description: Motherhood and Machismo

title: A PHILOSOPHIC NOVEL OF ACADEME
description: MICKELSSON'S GHOSTS By John Gardner. Illustrated by Joel Gardner. 590 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title:
GARDENING;
NO EASY ANSWERS ON GYPSY MOTHS
description: IF we were to follow the ancient Chinese custom of naming each new year after a living thing, this could have been the Year of the Gypsy Moth. Never, since early childhood, have I seen an insect generate such concern and controversy.

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ New York's annual jazz binge - the Kool Jazz Festival, known until last year as the Newport Jazz Festival - starts on Friday and goes on for 10 days with, according to the official count, 48 events and 1,000 musicians. During its first two days, the festival will stretch out from its regular Manhattan venues - Carnegie Hall, Avery Fisher Hall and the Forum Room of the New York Sheraton Hotel - to Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J., where the New Jersey Jazz Society will offer a plethora of pulsating pianists from 4 P.M. to 10 P.M. on Saturday, and to Purchase, N.Y., where a single admission, $15, opens the door to nine hours of music, from 2 P.M. to 11 P.M., played by 150 artists in six different sites all under the roof of the Center for the Arts at the State University, also on Saturday.

title: Personal Finance; HOW THE I.R.S. CAN SAVE YOU AN AUDIT
description: The taxpayer was a United States citizen who owned a vacation home a broad and wanted to sell it to a foreign charitable organization. B ut the charity was going to pay a bargain price for the house, and t he taxpayer wanted to know whether the difference between the fair m arket value of the vacation home and the amount he intended to c harge could be claimed as a charitable deduction.

title: Q&A
description: QUESTION: I live on the first floor of a three-story apartment building. Whenever the third-floor tenants take a shower, the water drips and leaks down through the walls in the baths of the tenants on the second and first floor. The landlord refuses to repair the damage, claiming that his efforts would be useless until he has evicted the third-floor tenants. What can I do to remedy this situation? D.F., Manhattan.

title: Around the Nation; Grain Storage Company Seeks Assets of Farmers
description: The trustee for a bankrupt grain storage company is seeking to attach the assets of Wayne Cryts and others who were found in contempt of court after a raid at a bankrupt grain elevator in Ristine, Mo.

title: LINCOLN KIRSTEIN: A LIFE IN ART
description: John Russell is chief art critic of The New York Times. By John Russell One of the most valuable of living Americans turned 75 several weeks ago. His name is Lincoln Kirstein. Among many other cultural accomplishments, he persuaded George Balanchine in 1933 to emigrate from the Soviet Union to this country. Not only did he get him here, but he beavered away until the dream of a specifically American ballet company of the highest order had come into being. Without Kirstein, there would be no New York City Ballet today. Nor would there be the School of American Ballet to keep alive the tradition of St. Petersburg's Imperial Ballet School in which Balanchine himself was raised.

title: Dr. Madonna Kelly Wed
description: Dr. Madonna Marie Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Kelly of West Seneca, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. David Jay Ettinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Ettinger of Woodside, Queens. The Rev. Matthew Gaskin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Newman Center of the State University of New York at Buffalo. The bride is resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the Children's Hospital in Buffalo, where her husband is a surgical resident at the Buffalo General Hospital.

title: SAUDIS WARNING ON ISRAELIS IN BEIRUT
description: Saudi Arabia said today that if Israeli troops entered Beirut, the Arabs would defend ''their territories'' with all their powers, according to the Saudi press agency.

title: Miss Parkinson And Brant Smith Married on L.I.
description: Elizabeth Terry Parkinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dexter Parkinson of Laurel Hollow, L.I., was married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., to Brant Richard Smith, son of Capt. Richard Carl Smith, U.S.N, retired, and Mrs. Smith of Springfield, Va. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: Maronite Leader Says He Started Israeli Link
description: Camile Chamoun, a Lebanese Christian leader and a former President of his country, said tonight that he was the initiator of the relationship that led to Israeli military aid for Christians in the Lebanese civil war.

title: GETTING BOOK IDEAS ON THE ROAD
description: VARIOUS sources inspire Francine Jacobs of Pleasantville to write. ''I find that when I'm on vacation my mind is totally relaxed, and I frequently come up with subjects for my books,'' she said the other day, recallinged a chance remark once by a resident of Hawaii about some magical creatures that supposedly caused mischief. His remarks - plus much research - resulted in two books of Hawaiian folk tales, ''The King's Ditch'' and ''The Legs of the Moon,'' both published by Coward McCann in 1971.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am going to Europe and expect to buy several bottles of cordials (not whisky or gin) in the tax-free shop in the airport there. I would expect to pay duty on the excess over the free allowance. However, I have been told that as a resident of New York I will not be allowed more than one quart; anything over that will be confiscated. Is this correct? -E.S.M., New York, N.Y. Answer:No, it is not; a spokesman for the New York State Liquor Authority said that a New York State resident out of the country for more than 48 hours can bring back an unrestricted amount of liquor for personal use; there is no question of confiscation. You are, however, liable for several taxes levied by the Federal Government and New York State.

title: REDISTRICTING AND SEGREGATION: REPEATING A PATTERN
description: SEVERAL years ago, Governor Carey referred to the Senatorial seat of Jacob Javits as the ''Jewish seat.'' Understandably and correctly, a storm of protest greeted this remark.

title: The Computer 'Cannot Harm Us'
description: ''Sufferin' Silicon!'' Are the neo-Luddites upon us already? Samuel Gulino is clearly sincere, if unduly alarmed, about the dangers posed by the computer bandwagon (''How the Computer Fails the Course,'' Opinion Page). I think we are all agreed that we must proceed with caution. But we all ought to understand that, since they are barely brighter than the average slug, computers cannot harm us.

title: Randy Lauren Smith Bride Of Peter C. Aberg, Student
description: Randy Lauren Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon H. Smith of New York, was married yesterday to Peter C. Aberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donlan V. Aberg Jr., of Sherman Oaks, Calif. The ceremony was performed by State Supreme Court Justice Richard A. Brown of the Appellate Division in the St. Regis Hotel.

title: THOMAS F. MORROW
description: Thomas F. Morrow, former head of the Chrysler Corporation's military contract operations, is dead at the age of 69.

title: CANOEISTS COMPETE IN ITALY
description: NORWALK HAVING not yet mastered the ''Eskimo roll,'' Charles and John Harris decided that the most prudent course was to swim to shore after their canoe flipped over in freezing water during a two-man white-water slalom race in Mascoma, N.H., in April of 1980.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Seeking Delay Of Lead Exposure Rule
description: The Government has proposed delaying the effective date of a safety standard that would have required smelters and battery manufacturing plants to find means of limiting workers' exposure to lead.

title: HOT RACE SIGNALS A CHANGE FOR DEMOCRATS
description: HARTFORD AT the Democratic State Convention four years ago, the delegates were so weary when time came to nominate candidates for Attorney General and two other offices that they brushed off the task with a quick shout of approval instead of bothering with a time-consuming roll call.

title: Headliners; Cunningham Convicted
description: Lawyers for Patrick J. Cunningham said during his trial on tax evasion charges that the mathematical ''errors'' and ''mistakes'' on his tax forms were not crimes. That explanation didn't add up to the jury, it seems. In Federal District Court last week, Mr. Cunningham, a former chairman of the New York State Democratic Party, was found guilty of evading taxes on $24,000 in 1974 and 1975 and of lying and conspiring to cover up the crime. Mr. Cunnningham, who rose to national power from a Bronx political clubhouse, contended that the prosecution was politically motivated and said he planned to appeal.

title: Irena Choi Wed To Bruce Stern
description: Irena Sangae Choi, assistant to the press attache at South Korea's Permanent Observer Mission to the United Nations, was married yesterday to Bruce Elliot Stern, an associate with the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: EARTHQUAKE KILLS 14 IN SALVADOR
description: A strong earthquake rocked El Salvador today, destroying villages and damaging buildings in the capital, including the United States Embassy. At least 14 persons were killed and several hundred were injured.

title: HENRY VIII'S CHURCH
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST HARLEM MOTHER STAYS WITH FRESH AIR FUND
description: Since she first sent her two daughters to spend two weeks with families in the country 22 years ago, Mary L. Ware has been working to insure that other New York City children get the same opportunity.

title: HOW YONKERS RACEWAY SUIT WAS SETTLED
description: WHITE PLAINS YONKERS Raceway, plagued by competition from offtrack betting and New Jersey's Meadowlands Racetrack, has settled one of the county's largest tax-appeal suits for $15.7 million.

title: BELL QUESTIONS COURT DECISION
description: The Supreme Court ruling requiring schools to educate the children of illegal aliens is a Federal intrusion into state affairs, Education Secretary T.H. Bell said today.

title:
Photography View;
A CONTRAST IN EARLY AMERICAN PORTRAITS
description: Strictly speaking, the photographs of Indian braves and chiefs on view at the Museum of the American Indian are not portraits but ethnographical studies, while Mike Disfarmer's photographs of Ozark Farm families at Staley-Wise Gallery are true portraits despite their strong ethnographical look. In portraiture, no matter how dramatized, prettified, superficial or inept, the aim is to catch a recognizable likeness of a particular individual. In ethnography, however, the aim is to show the peculiar characteristics of exotic strangers. There are faces, of course, each with its own characteristics, but the emphasis is on the national or racial type rather than the individual, and on the typical costume and mode of adornment.

title: A.I.A.W. Title to Tulsa
description: Tulsa won the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women Division I golf championship today, and Amy Benz of Southern Methodist took top individual honors. Tulsa became the first team to win both the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the A.I.A.W. championships in the same year.

title: Anne B. Thomas Becomes a Bride
description: Anne Benner Thomas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Banks Thomas Jr. of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Kenneth Emil Pariseau, son of Mrs. Alex Snitko of Gorham, N.H., and the late Paul R. Pariseau of Burlington, Vt.

title: Donna Davis Wed To G.W. Madison
description: Donna Jean Davis, daughter of Emalena Davis North of East Elmhurst, Queens, and Donald F. Davis of New York, was married yesterday to George Wheeler Madison, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Keith Madison of Jersey City. Canon Kenneth B. McDonald of the Episcopal Church of the Resurrection in East Elmhurst performed the ceremony at the Manor in West Orange, N.J.

title: Sports People; Too Poor to Compete
description: Although he won his third national foils championship two weeks ago and is ranked No.1 with that weapon, Michael Marx may not compete in the forthcoming world championships in Rome. His reasons are financial.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WHERE HAS PRIDE IN DADDY GONE?
description: IAM becoming more and more convinced that children are becoming less proud of their dads. If an earlier generation insisted that a mother was to be cherished and protected, it, at least, also demanded that a father was ''something to be proud of.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Food Guidelines To Fight Cancer
description: A panel at the National Academy of Sciences last week concluded that there is a strong enough link between diet and cancer to warrant issuing nutrition guidelines.

title: HOUSE IN A GREENHOUSE
description: A Manhattan archetect, William Kinsinger, has designed and is building a house in a greenhouse, like a ship in a bottle. Going up in the community of Mileses, near Monticello, N.Y., is Mr. Kinsinger's concept of an energy-effcient house that acts as a huge solar-energy collector.

title: WHAT'S LIFE WITHOUT SOFTBALL?
description: JUNE, almost. Softball season is in full swing. What I assured my friend Carole would be a one-night-a-week form of recreation has stretched to four nights a week plus all day Saturday and Sunday. In one of our two dates in the last month, she asked me, sobbingly, ''Why did this happen, when did it begin?''

title: HAIG SAYS SOVIET HOLDS BIG SERIES OF MISSILE TESTS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said yesterday that the Soviet Union had conducted an ''unprecedented'' series of strategic weapons tests in the last few days, casting doubt on Moscow's pledge that it would not be the first to use nuclear weapons.

title: LAST LICKS FOR A YOGURT SHOP
description: GREAT NECK CARMELLA the Yogurt Lady, who has been operating the Yogurt Stop on the ground floor of the Playhouse Theater on Middle Neck Road here since 1976, seems to have come to the end of the line in a battle against eviction.

title: Karen Triedman the Bride Of Earle Ullman Scharff 3d
description: Karen Jane Triedman, daughter of Dr. Ruth E. Triedman and Dr. M. Howard Triedman of Providence, R.I., was married there yesterday to Earle Ullman Scharff 3d, son of Dr. Scharff Jr. and Mrs. Robert Stien, both of Fort Worth. Rabbi Leslie Gutterman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El.

title: The Nation in Summary
description: Edwin P. Wilson last week was lured into a trap that a Robert Ludlum - or an Edwin P. Wilson - could have devised. Mr. Wilson, a former Central Intelligence Agency operative indicted in 1980 on charges of aiding Libya, was apparently tricked into leaving his sanctuary in Tripoli for a new life of exile in the Caribbean. Using a false Irish passport, he made his way across Europe and thence to the Dominican Republic. In Santo Domingo, where he had been led to believe he would find a safe change of scenery, authorites instead forced him to board a nonstop flight for New York. At Kennedy Airport, he was arrested by United States marshals. A Federal magistrate subsequently ordered him held in lieu of $20 million bail, and at an arraignment on Friday a U.S. District Judge entered a not guilty plea on his behalf.

title: The Region in Summary; Budget Finale, Scored for Trio
description: As Mayor Koch has noted, in final negotiations over the city budget, ''it takes three to tango'' - the Mayor, the Board of Estimate and the City Council. Last week they had to dance all night to beat the June 17 deadline for agreement on the New York's fiscal 1983 spending plan.

title: THE SPORTING LIFE, FROM SON TO FATHER
description: MY father was a good swimmer. Beyond that, I can't recall him participating in any kind of athletic activity when I was a kid. He never owned a pair of sneakers, let alone sports equipment of any kind.

title: Plains Wind Erosion Drops
description: Wind erosion damaged 5.1 million acres in 10 Great Plains states from November through May, less than half as much as in the comparable period a year earlier, the Agriculture Department reports.

title: BOB HOSKINS: 'I LIKE THE WAY I AM. I'M HAPPY WITH ME
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Benedict Nightingale frequently reports on cultural events in London. BY BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Freeing the Flow Of Western Water
description: To the delight of Western states and the disquiet of environmentalists, the Justice Department last week curbed Federal claims to water resources on Government lands.

title: TEACHER SLAIN AS WEST BANK ARABS CLASH
description: A 24-year-old Arab teacher was shot and killed near the West Bank town of Hebron today during a fight between about 100 Arab villagers and supporters of an Israeli-backed Village League, Palestinian sources reported. Eight other people were reportedly hospitalized with serious bullet wounds.

title: THE GUARDIAN OF NEW YORK'S LIVING HERITAGE
description: When Gerald and Beatrice Banu for refurbishing the handsome castiron balustrades that grace the front of their 114-year-old Greenwich Village brownstone, the City's Landmarks Preservation Commission was fast in granting an okay.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
ON-CAMPUS LIVING SPACE AT A PREMIUM
description: Like their predecessors, members of the class of 1986 will still be jockeying for living space this September as college enrollment remains high in New Jersey despite cutbacks in financial aid to students.

title: After Invasion, The Focus Shifts To Diplomacy
description: Lebanon has a new occupation army. Israeli forces last week pushed past the outskirts of Beirut, sealed off more than 6,000 Palestinian guerrillas and Syrians in western Beirut and announced their intention to remain in Lebanon until they could be sure it would never again serve as a base for attacks against Israel.

title: A DECORATIVE COLLABORATION
description: THE MAN WHO WAS VOGUE The Life and Times of Conde Nast. By Caroline Seebohm. Illustrated. 390 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $18.95. ELSIE DE WOLFE A Life in the High Style. By Jane S. Smith. Illustrated. 366 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: Miss Brown Has Nuptials
description: Andree deRapalyee Brown, daughter of Peter Megaree Brown and Mrs. Caroll B. Williams of New York, was married yesterday to Wayne Herkness, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lindsay C. Herkness Jr. of Philadelphia. The Rev. Alanson B. Houghton performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: ASIANS IN AMERICA
description: Although timely and informative, Robert Lindsey's article perpetuates some misconceptions in the American image of Asian immigrants living in this country.

title: China Backs Cambodians
description: China expressed support today for plans by three anti-Vietnamese groups in Cambodia to unite. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said, ''It is a good thing that after making efforts they have reached agreement on the joint declaration.'' The three groups are led by Pol Pot, who ruled Cambodia from 1975 to January 1979; Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former head of state, and Son Sann, a former Prime Minister.

title: Amelia Earhart's Sister Denies Spying Reports
description: The sister of Amelia Earhart says she believes the flier ran out of fuel and crashed in the Pacific in 1937 and was not on a spy mission.

title: WHEN WINNING (OR LOSING) BECOMES A HABIT
description: THE baseball season has been spiced by an unusual number of streaks, and nobody knows why: Not the Atlanta Braves, who won their first 13 games and then lost the next five, and not the Minnesota Twins, who recently lost 14 straight just after Kent Hrbek had hit in 23 straight.

title:
GARDENING;
NO EASY ANSWERS ON GYPSY MOTHS
description: IF we were to follow the ancient Chinese custom of naming each new year after a living thing, this could have been the Year of the Gypsy Moth. Never, since early childhood, have I seen an insect generate such concern and controversy.

title: FOR BRITAIN AND THE FALKLANDS, THE POSTWAR WORLD IS SHAKY
description: The political convulsion that swept Buenos Aires late last week, resulting in the ouster of President Leopoldo Galtieri, seemed to the British to open up the possibility of a fresh start in the South Atlantic. With General Galtieri still in office and worried about his personal honor, it had seemed that the British military triumph might be followed by months of pointless wrangling and indecision.

title: Chicago Fair in 1992 Urged
description: Chicago has been recommended as the site for a 1992 world's fair by the executive committee of the Bureau of International Expositions meeting in Paris.

title: MERRILL'S HONG KONG LINK
description: HONG KONG In Hong Kong, where making money is a national pastime, nothing is more applauded than a consummate deal, and no individual is more revered than the businessman who can make one. Most revered of all is Fung King Hey, an immigrant from China whose formal education stopped at about the eighth grade. Widely recognized as king of the deal makers, he has built a real estate, securities and banking empire larger than any other in Asia.

title: JAZZ: BRIAN TORFF, BASS
description: Brian Torff, the bassist who has played as part of a highly acclaimed duo with George Shearing, the pianist, for the last three years, has formed a trio that is making its debut, through this week, at Village West, 575 Hudson Street.

title: JUDGE RELEASES THE NAMES OF HINCKLEY JURORS
description: Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker today released the names and addresses of the jurors in the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr., saying he found ''compelling'' arguments that jurors should be interviewed by reporters as soon as possible after the verdict.

title: Beauty; TAKING A PASTING
description: Containing unfamiliar ingredients from distant corners of the globe -including Indian tree-bark extracts and a scarlet dye made from tropical insects - exotic toothpastes vary widely in color, flavor and composition. And despite their higher cost -from two to five times as much as popular supermarket brands - business is booming, retailers say. Caswell-Massey, the Manhattan pharmacy, sells between 5,000 and 10,000 packages a year of one product alone, ''Monkey Brand Black Toothpowder,'' from India.

title:
GARDENING;
NO EASY ANSWERS ON GYPSY MOTHS
description: IF we were to follow the ancient Chinese custom of naming each new year after a living thing, this could have been the Year of the Gypsy Moth. Never, since early childhood, have I seen an insect generate such concern and controversy.

title: Chess; THE HIDDEN OPENING
description: There is nothing as potent as an opening idea whose time has come, but who knows when that will be? There are untold ideas or plans asleep in just one column, or perhaps in a forgotten footnote of any tome on openings. Most are indeed unworkable and fully deserve to remain curiosities in a war museum. Yet there are others just waiting to be awakened by the implementation needed for them to display their true worth.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: FRANK GEHRY'S ARCHITECTURE
description: The interior of Frank Gehry's Santa Monica Place shopping mall is not a pleasant place to be.

title: Rinker Takes Open in Stride
description: Larry Rinker has an unusual approach to competing in the United States Open. Rinker, a 24-year-old from Orlando, Fla., says he is playing the Open as if it were ''just another golf tournament.''

title: HOUSE CALLS RETURN
description: MADISON THE doctor's house call has been resurrected in Morris County, and the organization that revived it hopes to expand into Bergen and Essex Counties and, eventually, the whole state.

title: VIETNAM PRESSING ITS CASE ON INVASION OF CAMBODIA
description: In the three and a half years since Vietnam invaded Cambodia, a stalemate has developed between Hanoi and most other governments around the world, which have adamantly refused to accept the invasion's legitimacy or results.

title: A MIXED FOLLOWING
description: WHO VOTED FOR HITLER? By Richard F. Hamilton. 664 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $50. Paper, $16.50.

title: MUSIC: SPRING SERIES ENDS
description: It was Stravinsky's 100th birthday Friday - with adjustments for the Julian calendar and Leap Year - and the New York Philharmonic under Erich Leinsdorf celebrated with four of his works. The concert ended the orchestra's Mozart-Stravinsky Spring Series.

title: Everybody Talks Of Arms Control
description: The superpowers last week gestured in the direction of arms control. Then they restated their rationale for enormous weapons spending.

title: EXPANSION OF MILITARY AIR TRANSPORT IS STALLED BY DISPUTE IN CONGRESS
description: The Reagan Administration has begun an ambitious and costly expansion of the military air transport crucial to the strategy of preparing for a prolonged worldwide war, but its plan has been stalled in a classic Congressional dispute over which aircraft to order.

title: THE YEAR THE BOTTOM FELL OUT FOR STEEL
description: IN an industry where triage has long been the norm and managements mete out their meager funds only to plants that clearly can survive, Baltimore's steel business is deemed blessed. At Sparrows Point, site of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's largest steel mill, the huge steel company is halfway through a modernization plan. Not far away, Armco Inc. and the Eastmet Corporation have fitted their stainless steel divisions with newer equipment.

title: POLITICIANS CONFRONT NEW CONSTITUENCIES
description: THE United States Constitution decrees that every 10 years, the population of the country shall be counted. It's a safe guess that some public figures in this county would have been happy to skip the latest count - or to have seen it carried out differently.

title: U.S. Beats Canada In World Lacrosse
description: The center of the lacrosse world today is Homewood Field at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. There the United States, Australia, Canada and England are competing to determine who will be the international champion for the next four years.

title: U.S. NEGOTIATOR ON ARMS CUT FEELS 'GUARDEDLY OPTIMISTIC'
