description: The chief United States negotiator in coming strategic disarmament talks with the Soviet Union said today that he was ''guardedly optimistic'' about the outcome.

title: Pamela A. Veith, T.R. Payton Wed
description: Pamela Anne Veith, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Ferdinand S. Veith of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Terry Richard Payton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Payton of Natick, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: Soviet Beats New Zealand, 3-0
description: The Soviet Union defeated New Zealand, 3-0, today in World Cup soccer, giving fellow Group 6 member Brazil passage into Phase 2 of the tournament and increasing its own chances to advance.

title:
ANTIQUES;
AN ECLETIC SHOW IN LITCHFIELD
description: LITCHFIELD EARLY next Saturday morning, while most of the town is still asleep, a caravan of station wagons, pickup trucks and vans will begin rolling slowly onto the grounds of White Memorial.

title: MUSTO SUCCESSOR TO BE ELECTED
description: UNION CITY VOTERS here and elsewhere in the 33d District will go to the polls Wednesday to elect someone to fill the State Senate seat that had been held by William V. Musto for the last 16 years.

title: UNDER SIEGE, IT'S NOW OR NEVER FOR LEBANON
description: BEIRUT The fate of Lebanon hangs as much in the balance today as in those anxious weeks before the republic was founded in 1943. The Israeli invasion has not only upset the fragile political consensus holding together the Government of President Elias Sarkis. At the same time it has remolded all the elements that make up that consensus - the Maronite Christian militias, the Lebanese Moslem parties, the Palestinian guerrillas and the Syrians.

title: Cosmos Find Reliable Scorer in Moyers
description: A large number of executives and experts in soccer believe that an important element for the success of the game in the United States is a native American who can score goals as consistently as Giorgio Chinaglia.

title: PARENTS MAY GET LOWER INTEREST RATE ON U.S. STUDENT LOANS
description: Parents who are patient can expect to get a break of 2 percentage points on loans they take out on behalf of sons or daughters in college next fall, according to Federal education officials. Starting Oct. 1, unless the nation's interest rates rise markedly, the 14 percent rate on Auxiliary Loans to Assist Students is expected to drop to 12 percent.

title: FATHERHOOD: EXPANDING ROLE AND EXPANDING JOYS
description: Children are at once a joy and a burden, and there is a certain kind of father who bears the burden with an easy grace. The child riding high on his shoulders, the child sprawled sleepy-eyed on his back, the child giggling on his knee seems less an encumbrance than an extension of his body. Man and child are bonded on this Father's Day as never before.

title: GALWAY TO CONDUCT OPENING OF MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL
description: Lincoln Center's 16th annual Mostly Mozart Festival will open at Avery Fisher Hall July 12, with a performance featuring the flutist James Galway as conductor and soloist. The concert will be repeated and televised nationally July 14 on the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series on public television.

title: PASSPORTS ARE BEING DELAYED BY A BACKLOG OF APPLICATIONS
description: Passport applications piling up at a record rate have created unusual delays in processing this spring. In some areas, would-be travelers have reported waiting more than two months for new passports. Lines at some regional branches of the United States Passport Office have been so long in recent weeks that some applicants have reported waits of up to eight hours.

title: FICTION: YES AND NO
description: Are university presses trying to horn in on the fiction market? The answer is, yes, a handful dream of those big, undiscovered novels that might make a mint for their subsidized, nonprofit presses; but, no, the overwhelming majority aren't planning to rush in where many trade-book houses fear to tread these days - publishing the contemporary novel.

title: KEMP'S GRAND SLAM DECISIVE
description: Steve Kemp hit a grand slam homer in the fifth inning and had five runs batted in as the Chicago White Sox scored a 7-6 victory today over the California Angels.

title: British Arms To Foe Reported
description: Britain sent military equipment to Argentina as late as March 25, just eight days before Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands, The Times of London reported today.

title: The Nation in Summary; SEnate Uncorks Voting Rights
description: Civil rights supporters moved closer to a key Congressional victory last week, as the Senate overwhelmingly voted to extend key provisions of the 1965 Voting Rights Act.

title: Hudson Benefit Cruise
description: A sunset cruise on the Hudson with dinner and dancing is planned for next Thursday to benefit the Floating Hospital, New York's Ship of Health established in 1866.

title: Cars Could Not Save Racers
description: The recent fatal accidents of Gilles Villeneuve and Riccardo Paletti have raised questions about Grand Prix race procedures and the safety of Formula One cars. Villeneuve was killed when his Ferrari ran into a slow-moving car during a qualifying session for the Dutch Grand Prix last month, and Paletti died from injuries when his Osella rammed a stalled car at the start of the Canadian Grand Prix last weekend.

title: DIAMONDS ARE NOT FOREVER
description: THE RISE AND FALL OF DIAMONDS The Shattering of a Brilliant Illusion. By Edward Jay Epstein. 301 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.50. By PAUL ERDMAN

title: CHINA OFFERS P.L.O. AID OF $1 MILLION
description: China promised the Palestine Liberation Organization today that it would give the organization $1 million in emergency aid to help offset damage and losses it suffered in Israel's invasion of Lebanon.

title: Mothers and Sons And Compassion
description: Concerning ''The Call That Didn't Come'' (Opinion Page): Elizabeth Timmes doesn't need to look much farther than her own essay to find one clue to her son's estrangement -from its lavish overlay of longsuffering self-pity to its barely concealed malice in contrasting the saintliness of the other sons (who brought such joy to poor Mom on her special day) with the ''bitterness'' and ''sickness'' of the truant son - whom, we are advised, the whole family urges her to ''forget about.''

title: Mailbox; A Falling Boxer Shouldn't Be Hit
description: To the Sports Editor: We are writing as a father-and-son team, both of us fortunate enough to have enjoyed injury-free competitive boxing careers, in the former case dating back to 1914. From our aggregate 102 years' experience as students of boxing, we believe it legitimately can be classed a ''sport,'' if sensible rules are written and enforced.

title: BLACK FILM FESTIVAL BEGINS WEDNESDAY
description: NEWARK ''THE Newark Black Film Festival is one of the few festivals where you can depend on having a responsive audience,'' said Dr. Clement A. Price, a member of the festival's Film Selection Committee. ''It's an audience that moans, cries, laughs and dances in the aisles.''

title: James Constantino Marries Alison Rand
description: Alison Valentine Rand, daughter of Mrs. George J. Meyerson of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late David L. Rand of New York, was married yesterday to James P. Constantino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominick P. Constantino of Hyde Park, N.Y. Family Court Judge Jack Turret performed the ceremony in the Carlyle Hotel.

title: OUR RECORD ON RACISM
description: HEARTS AND MINDS The Anatomy of Racism from Roosevelt to Reagan. By Harry S. Ashmore. 512 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Co. $15.95.

title: ARTIST UNDERGOES A TRANSFORMATION
description: JERSEY CITY AN EXHIBITION at the Jersey City Museum through June 30 could be titled ''The Transformation of Ben Jones.'' Mr. Jones, a 39-year-old artist who teaches at Jersey City State College, has been known until now as a champion of African culture struggling against impersonalizing influences of Western technology. Until he began what he calls his ''cloud series,'' he had built his reputation on figurative work in mixed media that reflect travel and research in Africa, Europe, South America and the Caribbean.

title: PROBLEMS LOOM FOR LANDFILL DESPITE ACCORD
description: WITH expanded garbage dumping expected to begin soon at the troubled Port Washington landfill, the controversy over the l0-yearold facility and whether it is hazardous to local residents' health is likely to continue in the coming weeks.

title: More Gospel
description: To the Business Editor: Your article, ''Management Gospel Gone Wrong'' (May 30), is certainly a timely admonition to pay more attention to development of new products and technologies while managing existing operations better at the grass roots. But this advice is helpful only if it can be applied in a reasonably constructive economic climate.

title: SAVORING CLASSIC FONDUE
description: KAY ELDREDGE writes on food and travel for national magazines. BY KAY ELDREDGE

title: Melita Joyce Wright Becomes Bride Of William Coburn Cox 3d in Roslyn
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday Melita Joyce Wright, daughter of Joyce Thomas Wright of Kingston, N.Y., and Alan Harriman Wright of Locust Valley, L.I., was married to William Coburn Cox 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cox Jr. of London. The Rev. Nils Blatz performed the ceremony.

title: Ideal Takes Honors In Jump At Ox Ridge
description: Ideal, ridden by Jay Land, won the Amateur-Owner Jumper Classic at the Ox Ridge charity horse show today.

title: COMPENSATION STUDY SOUGHT ON MEDICAL RESEARCH INJURIES
description: A Presidential commission has recommended that the Federal Government sponsor a project to gauge the need for a national program to compensate people injured in medical research as well as the feasibility of such a program.

title: David Melrose Marries Patricia J. Fitzgerald
description: Patricia Jean Fitzgerald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donal Francis Fitzgerald of Winsted, Conn., was married there yesterday to David William Melrose, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Melrose of Leatherhead, England. The Rev. Daniel T. Kenna performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Beth Ann Morley Wed To William G. Dean
description: Beth Ann Morley, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Morley of Dedham and Truro, Mass., was married yesterday to William Gardner Dean, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard B. Dean of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Richard J. Malone performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the Boston College Law School,

title: FACTS, ETHICS AND THE NUCLEAR ARMS DEBATE
description: To the Editor:

title: GLIMPSES OF WHAT'S CURRENT
description: HEMPSTEAD WHAT is of paramount importance about the exhibition at the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island is that it enables Long Islanders who have been unable to get to the Manhattan galleries to experience a number of major young artists of quality in a number of current noteworthy styles. The show more than eloquently justifies itself for the significance of the artists, the quality of the work and the insight into the contemporary art scene that the selections offer.

title: OPERA: 'POSTMAN ALWAYS RINS TWICE' IN ST. LOUIS
description: James M. Cain's ''The Postman Always Rings Twice'' would not seem to be inevitable material for an opera. The out-of-the-side-of-the-mouth prose, the grubby characters and the generally flat tone that persists no matter how violent the action becomes - could any text offer less promise in the lyric theater? It is hard to see how. Nevertheless, the Cain novel has been hammered into operatic form by Stephen Paulus and his librettist, Colin Graham, with modest success, considering the basic problems involved.

title:
DINING OUT;
A PLACE TO TAKE VISITING FIREMEN
description: THIS July marks the fifth anniversary of the stylish Aratusa Supper Club, which occupies a converted dayliner called the Chauncey M. Depew. The vessel, which is moored on the Hackensack River in Secaucus (almost in the shade of the Sports Complex), has quite a history, all of which is detailed on the menu.

title: FAST FOOD ON THE FAST TRACK
description: PATRICIA WELLS is a writer who lives in Paris. PATRICIA WELLS

title: Bambi Thorne Is Wed To Paul Elias Kuhl 3d
description: Helen Monroe Thorne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wellington Thorne Jr., of Trenton, was married there yesterday in the Trinity Episcopal Cathedral to Paul Elias Kuhl 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kuhl 2d of Titusville, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Lloyd G. Chattin, dean of the cathedral.

title:
Numismatics;
HOBBY'S NEWSPAPER CELEBRATES ITS 30TH BIRTHDAY
description: The surge of interest in coin collecting during the last few decades has been accompanied by an unprecedented outpouring of reference material - newspapers, magazines and books on numismatic subjects. And few individuals have played a more prominent role in publishing and producing these publications than Chester L. Krause, founder and current president of Krause Publications.

title: WHEN A BUSINESS IS BEHEADED
description: From where the chairman sat, in the cheerfully modern conference room, the view of the harbor was serene. Boats of assorted sizes gently rocked in the water. A balmy breeze blew across the scene, tossing up waves and stirring the leaves on the overhanging trees. Here at the corporate offices of Arrow Electronics up along Steamboat Road it's hard to image anything but an untroubled corporate existence.

title: Antiques; SHOWSTOPPERS: JAPANESE FOLK FURNITURE
description: Japanese folk art is virtually unknown in this country -especially the folk furniture crafted for 19th-century farmhouses, offices and shops. Far more familiar to most of us are the elaborately embellished formal wares used by aristocrats. Although not widely available, the simpler folk-art accessories - handcrafted clay pots, lacquered serving vessels, sculptured stone figures, twisted wood candles@tands, bamboo baskets, silk-screened robes, carved-wood mortars and hand-blocked textiles - are also occasionally seen in American shops. But Japanese folk furniture is definitely rare.

title: YALE OARSMEN FIRST IN CINCINNATI RACE
description: Yale's varsity crew captured the heavyweight race in the inaugural rowing of the Cincinnati Regatta on East Fork Lake today. The victory enabled the Eli to claim the national collegiate rowing championship in what Frank Ryan, the university's director of athletics, called, ''one of those rare moments of truth that occur in sport.''

title: ON COMMITMENTS AND FATHER'S DAY
description: IAM trying hard to be a liberated parent. But already I feel it has escaped me. After all, Kathy and I have had four children in eight years which in itself makes us throwbacks to a former era.

title: Television Week
description: Memory Piece Tennessee Williams's ''Summer and Smoke'' was a critical failure on Broadway in 1948, but a revival at the Circle in the Square Theater on Bleecker Street shortly afterwards boosted Geraldine Page to stardom and injected fresh life into the Off Broadway theater movement. The drama about a woman yearning for love was made into a film in 1961, starring Miss Page.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE search for a company to operate the Westchester County Airport under a new contract has started its final approach. The present operator, Pan American World Services, has been chosen from among three finalists by an evaluation task force composed of county officials and a representative of residents of the towns of Rye, Harrison and North Castle.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: WHEN President Reagan signed the letter last Monday designating Connecticut a major disaster area because of the recent torrential rains, it set off an election-year demonstration in political public relations.

title: Connie Carpenter Takes Bicycling Title Again
description: Connie Carpenter of Boulder, winning five of the nine stages, captured her second overall title at the Coors International Bicycle Classic today.

title: 14 Persons Selected to Serve Year as White House Fellows
description: Fourteen people have been selected as White House fellows in a one-year program of service as special assistants to the Vice President, Cabinet officers and members of the President's staff.

title: APPETIZERS ARE THE HIGHLIGHT
description: BEGINNING as a pleasantly informal spot for lunch or supper with salads and sandwiches as the mainstays of the menu, Cafe Harlequin in Sea Cliff has now evolved along more elaborate lines, serving dinners in the evening and maintaining a friendly atmosphere for night owls who cluster at the bar even later. Occasionally, tables are cleared and dancing begins around midnight.

title: Nancy A. Chandler Bride Of Peter Cauthorne Jaeger
description: Nancy Anne Chandler, a sales representative in New York for Brunschwig & Fils, the fabric company, was married yesterday to Peter Cauthorne Jaeger, president of P. J. Industries, an accessories-manufacturing company in New York. The Rev. Dr. Lloyd Frederick of the First Baptist Church of Westerly, R.I., performed the ceremony at the nondenominational Watch Hill Chapel in Watch Hill, R.I.

title: Around the Nation; Man With Gun Forces Evacuation of Monument
description: A man kept the police at bay inside the Washington Monument today by pointing an antique pistol at his head for more than two hours.

title: James Shea Jr. Weds Maureen Carroll Sager
description: Maureen Carroll Sager, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard A. Sager of Port Washington, L.I., and Stuart, Fla., was married yesterday to James Thomas Shea Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shea of Foxboro, Mass. The Rev. Francis J. Caldwell performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter of Alcantara in Port Washington.

title: PRESIDENTS: HIRED, MIRED, FIRED
description: So, President Reagan is already being shown the door. The sharp decline in his popularity that we see in the public opinion polls suggests that the people are ready to wash their hands of him in the usual length of time they give a President to satisfy them these days.

title: John Albert Bunyon, Evangeline Ames Wed
description: Evangeline Carroll Ames, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan P. Ames of Stamford, Conn., and Shelter Island, L.I., was married yesterday to John Albert Bunyan, son of Mrs. Ernst Watson Farley Jr. of Darien, Conn., and the late George Humphrey Bunyan. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Roger Watts in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford.

title: Business Conditions; WEAKNESS IN CHEMICALS
description: While sales figures for chemical processors showed a modest uptick in April, the industry remains seriously depressed, as weak demand, price discounting in key commodities and high interest rates continue to squeeze profit margins.

title: VALUES MORE IMPORTANT THAN PASSING FADS
description: I was appalled to read such kind remarks about Cliffside Park. I lived there for a number of years before moving to a really beautiful town.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: ROME The Sweet Tempestuous Life. By Paul Hofmann. 245 pp. New York: Congdon & Lattes. $14.95.

title: Eleanor Sailer Married
description: Eleanor Whitman Sailer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norris Hampton Sailer of Mountainville, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert John Kleinhans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul V. Kleinhans of Bedminster, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Lebanon, N.J., by the Rev. Hugh McGlashon, assisted by the Rev. Joseph McGroarty, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: THE MARINE CORPS FACES THE FUTURE
description: Michael Wright, an editor of The New York Times Week in Review, is a former naval officer. By Michael Wright fter years on the defensive, the Marine Corps, that all-American anachronism, has come charging back. Though the corps may not yet have made it all the way up there with mom, apple pie and Lite beer, it has been transformed into a place where even Lieut. Col. Bull Meechum, Captain Flagg and Sergeant Stryker, those renowned Hollywood leathernecks, would probably feel right at home.

title: A MUNICH HOSTELRY THAT PAMPERS YOU
description: JOHN VINOCUR is chief of The New York Times Bureau in Bonn. BY JOHN VINOCUR

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Court Extends Protections to Two Groups
description: Individual rights under the equal-protection provisions of the 14th Amendment got a double boost last week from the Supreme Court. A unanimous decision guaranteed the right of retarded patients in state institutions to ''minimally adequate'' training and freedom from unreasonable physical restraint, while a 5-4 vote affirmed the right of children who are illegal aliens to free public education.

title: Adele Edgerton Wed to Todd Rofuth
description: Adele Pleasance Edgerton, an associate with the Boston law firm of Fine & Ambrogne, was married yesterday to Todd Rofuth, a consultant on Federal and state employment incentives for Business Incentive Inc., in Boston. The Rev. Walter H. Taylor of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Noroton, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Stamford, Conn., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm J. Edgerton Jr.

title: THE COST OF JUSTICE
description: Anyone who has bought a cheap used car knows that paying less for repairs now may prove to be more expensive later. This basic truth is often forgotten by people who call for reduced Federal spending. The tendency to let tomorrow take care of itself is exemplified in America's approach to the administration and enhancement of justice.

title: A Correction
description: An article in The Week in Review of June 6 incorrectly identified the nationality of a Catholic martyr at Auschwitz, the Rev. Maximilian Kolbe. He was Polish.

title: POETS PUT THEIR STAMP ON ROCK LYRICS
description: Are rock lyrics poetry? Rock critics began asking this question in the mid-60's, when rock's burgeoning self-consciousness first made both intentionally poetic rock lyrics and literate rock criticism possible.

title: IRE AT VANDALISM SPURS AID FOR DISABLED
description: HALF HOLLOW HILLS THE students at High School East last year saved $2,000 of the annual allocation that pays for vandalism damage and decided to spend it on others.

title:
ANTIQUES;
RINGWOOD: TALE OF THREE FAMILIES
description: RINGWOOD IN THE oldest section of the 51-room Ringwood Manor House in the state park here stands a mahogany tall-case clock that Lucas Ryerson, a silversmith, made on the occasion of the marriage of a relative, Martin Ryerson, to Clarissa Van Winkle. The clock is dated March 24, 1806, a year before Martin Ryerson bought the property where the house stands.

title: LEBANON NEEDS CREATIVE DIPLOMACY
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC TV FACES ITS SEVEREST TEST
description: ''There are some who say that if the managers of public-television stations were asked to form a firing squad, they would automatically line up in a circle,'' says Anthony Tiano, president of KQED, San Francisco's public-television station.

title: THE HEALING VALUE OF A CLOWN
description: THE clown crouched to pluck a flower from the concrete floor of the hospital. He sniffed it with his big red nose, then gently offered it to the young patient. Although only the little girl and the clown could see the rose, she smelled it delicately and smiled.

title: New Program for Journalists
description: Stanford University has announced the establishment of the John S. Knight Professional Journalism Program to finance a year of advanced study for 12 midcareer journalists. The program, based on a $4 million grant by the Knight Foundation, is in honor of the late founder of Knight Newspapers.

title: Art View; RODIN'S 'GATES': HELL WAS HIS DISH
description: ''The Gates of Hell'' by Auguste Rodin (1840-1917) is to my mind the single most repulsive work of art ever produced by a major artist. I therefore dreaded its arrival in the Charles W. Engelhard Court of the Metropolitan Museum. The cast in question was made in France not long ago for Mr. and Mrs. G.B. Cantor, who have lent it to the museum, and I am bound to say that its appearance in New York amply justifies my apprehensions. ''The Gates of Hell'' is just as odious as ever it was - the more so, in fact, for being flanked, as Rodin himself wished, by the two standing figures that do so notable a disservice to our first father, Adam, and our first mother, Eve.

title: Giants 9, Braves 4
description: ATLANTA (UPI) - Johnnie LeMaster singled in the go-ahead run and Chili Davis capped a six-run ninth inning with a grand slam that won for San Francisco.

title: Lakers Owner Backs Clippers
description: The Los Angeles Coliseum Commission announced today that Jerry Buss, the owner of the Los Angeles Lakers, will not object to the proposed move of the San Diego Clippers to Los Angeles.

title: SUBURB'S LAW IS IN ORDER WITH 3 POLICE CHIEFS ON DUTY
description: One police chief in this St. Louis suburb was dismissed but continued to report to work, another was arrested with the Mayor who had him sworn in, and a third has said that the job is really his and that he has the badge to prove it.

title: CURTAIN'S UP ON THE SUMMER STAGE
description: THE Island's summer theater season has a mostly musical motif. There will be splashy musicals, ''Ain't Misbehavin' ,'' sedate musicals, ''Ain't Misbehavin' ,'' a brand-new musical and ''Ain't Misbehavin' .''

title: Heidi Stamas Becomes Bride of J. Thomas Beckett
description: Heidi Stamas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Stamas of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to J. Thomas Beckett, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Beckett of Durham, N.H. The Rev. Michael S. Kendall performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale.

title: THE PATTER OF TINY 'BARGAINS'
description: J udging from recent advertising, travel by children is getting extraordinary attention this year. Many suggestions are available on how to limit the inroads that travel can make on family budgets. Close examination often reveals, however, that it can be extremely difficult to determine which ''bargain'' is best. Some offers prove essentially to be gimmicks to generate business, more expensive than alternative choices for the same trips. The offerings involve travel by air, rail, bus and ship, as well as stays in hotels - virtually wherever competition is intense.

title: RAIL SHOP TERMED IMPROVING BY STANGL
description: A series of steps adding up to ''slow, steady progress'' have been taken by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and Conrail at the Harmon shop, where ''the heart of the maintenance and overhaul system'' on the Hudson and Harlem Division trains is located.

title: Porsche Team Leader In 24 Hours of Le Mans
description: The factory Porsche team continued to dominate the 24 Hours of Le Mans race early today after eight hours of racing.

title: Barbara Rothchild Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Rothchild of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Rothchild, to Michael H. Oshry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Oshry of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. The future bride is sales promotion manager for Federal Label Systems in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: TV View; AN EXHIBITIONISM EPIDEMIC
description: Yes, Susan concedes about her marriage to Douglas, ''that magic, that excitement has faded.'' No, insists Phyllis about her husband Alan, ''If I don't like someone, I just don't want to be around him.'' Maybe, says homosexual Scott about the possibility of an ''intimate relationship'' with his roommate Marilee - ''How do I know if I haven't tried it?''

title: The Region in Summary; No Throwaways, Carey Decides
description: If New York were littered with nickels it wouldn't stay dirty very long - or so the thinking went in Albany last week as Governor Carey signed a bill mandating a deposit of at least five cents on every beer, water and soft drink container sold in the state, beginning July 1983.

title: REGAN REVIEWING PLANS TO RESTRICT FEDERAL RESERVE
description: The Reagan Administration is conducting a major review of monetary policy, including consideration of proposals to restrict or remove the independence of the Federal Reserve Board, Treasury Department officials said today.

title: EAST END PONDERS A RARE SLAYING
description: EAST HAMPTON SIX weeks before graduation, a strapping, well-liked high school senior was slashed to death near this resort village's busiest intersection, within 50 yards of the police station. No weapon was found, and there were no eyewitnesses to the full sequence of events.

title: Nancy Gay Bashian Wed To Ronald A. McLean 3d
description: Nancy Gay Bashian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Bashian of Tenafly, N.J., was married there yesterday to Ronald Alexander McLean 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McLean Jr. of La Jolla, Calif., and Watch Hill, R.I. The Rev. Arnak Kasparian performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Armenian Church.

title: 40 PERCENT OF TOWNS FOUND HIT BY CUTBACK
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ASURVEY of New Jersey counties and municipalities several months after the Reagan Administration's budget cuts has disclosed a reduction in services, layoffs of government employees and tax increases in 40 percent of the affected towns.

title: BEYOND RECORDS: OPEN ADOPTIONS
description: THE scene looks like almost any one set in an American suburb: a slim, brown-haired woman in her 30's is smiling at a curly-haired child playing with blocks on the dining-room floor.

title: WHO RULES THE WAVES HAS SURFERS IN CONFLICT
description: The waves are not the only things that clash these days on California's beaches. So, sometimes, do the surfers.

title: DON'T BLAME MR. BEGIN FOR LEBANON'S TROUBLES
description: To the Editor:

title: TOWN REVERSING STAND ON CONDOS
description: BRANFORD FIFTEEN years ago, when condominiums were still unacceptable in most of the residential towns of Connecticut, this 27-square-mile shoreline community, with a sturdy history as a farming and boatbuilding center, prided itself on innovative thinking.

title: DEMOCRACY'S DIFFICULT FLOWERING
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Reese Must Look At Himself Again
description: ONE of the saddest and most frightening articles ever written by or about an athlete was published in the June 14 issue of Sports Illustrated.

title: Palmer Nearly Became a Yank
description: He had a feeling, Jim Palmer said, that if he had said one word - ''yes'' - he would have been a Yankee ''in a day.'' Or perhaps he would have been a Met, a Brewer, an Angel or a Phillie. The time apparently was right earlier this month for Palmer finally to leave Baltimore after 16 years.

title: Jogging
description: To the Editor:

title: RED CROSS SEES HUMAN SIDE OF DISASTER
description: THE flood waters have subsided around the state and in their destructive wake is a mountain of paper work, as families, individuals and businesses go about the task of seeking and giving charity, repairing and cleaning, filing insurance claims, suing to establish responsibility for man's role in one of nature's calamities and seeking to re-establish normal lives.

title: Padres 7, Astros 1
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Broderick Perkins, a pinch-hitter, hit a two-run single, and Alan Wiggins followed with a two-run triple during a five-run seventh inning.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Aleksei Takenouchi, Pianist, Plays Schubert
description: There were several contradictions in Aleksei Takenouchi's piano playing Wednesday night in the Merkin Concert Hall of Abraham Goodman House. The young pianist, who was born in Japan of Russian-Japanese parentage and who studied with his mother and with Renzo Silvestri and Angus Morrison, was attentive to minute shapings of musical lines in contemporary works, yet the lyrical gestures of Schubert's Sonata in G (Op. 78) splintered into dry pieces of sound. Mr. Takenouchi gave Richard Wilson's difficult ''Eclogue'' (1973) a sense of reflective impressionism, yet he was totally unprepared for the rhythmic exuberance and pianistic extravagance of Stravinsky's ''Petrouchka Suite.''

title: LONG AGO, WHEN MUSICAL LUNCHES WERE LEISURELY...
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Tim Page is host of an afternoon music program on WNYC-FM and writes frequently about music and musicians. By TIM PAGE

title: Brewers 10, Tigers 3
description: DETROIT (AP) - Robin Yount hit two homers, including one inside the park, and drove in four runs to lead Milwaukee. Moose Haas (4-4) went the distance for the Brewers and scattered nine hits. The Tigers lost their sixth consectutive game.

title: MICHIGAN IS WARY OF NEW OPTIMISM
description: For more than two years, Michiganders have seen a succession of cheerful economic forecasts crushed by the fact of a relentless recession, and now that a few glimmers of hope have appeared once again, even the experts cannot agree on what they may mean.

title: Grail Ann Walsh Wed To Thomas C. O'Neill
description: Grail Ann Walsh, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Walsh of White Plains, was married there yesterday to Thomas Charles O'Neill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. O'Neill of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. James McCarthy performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Good Counsel Chapel at Pace University.

title: Correction
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR POWER AND PEACE
description: Nuclear Power And Peace The irrefutable logic of Adm. Noel Gaylor's article on nuclear disarmament is the strongest argument for continuing the development of peaceful nuclear power (''How to Break the Momentum of the Nuclear Arms Race,'' April 25).

title: Donna Timmons Wed
description: Donna Frances Timmons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Timmons of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to Henry Joseph Carroll 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Jr., also of Garden City. The Rev. Daniel Pater, the bridegroom's cousin, performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The bride, a pianist, taught for three years at the Juilliard School as a teaching fellow. Mr. Carroll is with the internal auditing staff of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: The World in Summary; GErrymandering, Pretoria-Style
description: Some of South Africa's white-minority leaders have a scheme that would increase their proportionate strength - a land transfer that would revoke the citizenship of 900,000 blacks. A Government Minister said last week that the action would fulfill ''the long-cherished ideal'' of the blacks, who are ethnic Swazis and Zulus.

title: ARTICULATED BUS FROM RUMANIA TESTED ON L.I.
description: What is orange, white and blue, has six wheels, bends like a caterpillar and will soon be picking up passengers in Nassau County? It's a new Rumanian bus, the latest foreign-made bus making an appearance in the New York City area. The bus - actually a bus and a half that bends in the middle - has gone into service, and a second will join it on the roads in the coming weeks. Both vehicles are here for a 10-month trial period, at no cost to New York, to see if they are suited for local use.

title: WOMEN BUILDING ON-THE-JOB SKILLS
description: ON Tuesday 40 women from their early 20's to their late 60's will receive graduation certificates affirming their progress in career development. One night a week since September, they have attended the Career Development Women's Studies Program, developed by Cornell University's Institute for Women and Work to help women in clerical jobs improve their skills, gain confidence in their ability to perform on higher job levels and explore pursuing college courses.

title: THE MAGIC OF AN ISLAND HOME
description: Buying your own private vacation island within an hour or two's drive from Manhattan isn't a wildly improbable fantasy. Owning an island retreat has become a reality for a considerable number of families.

title: Other Business; A CHIPWICH BY ANY OTHER NAME...
description: For a person walking down a midtown Manhattan street, it can be a dizzying choice. Would you like a Chilly Chip? A Chips 'n' Chips? Something more Continental? How about a Nougat Suisse?

title: CAREY APPROVES SPECIAL PROPERTY TAX LOANS FOR THE ELDERLY
description: People 65 years and over who need money to pay property taxes or other special assessments on their property will be able to obtain special bank loans under legislation signed this week by Governor Carey. The law will become effective in August.

title: Headliners; Whistle-Blower Justice
description: The Pentagon didn't take it lightly when A. Ernest Fitzgerald, a civilian budget analyst for the Air Force, told Congress about multibillion-dollar cost overruns on the C-5A military transport plane in 1968.

title: STUDENTS PROVIDE SAFE RIDES
description: ''I was a witness. I saw the accident. We were so upset. We went in to the principal and said, 'What can we do? We can't just keep watching it happen.' '' - Kim Ryan, student Darien High School

title: NOTES: THE 'PEOPLES' SERIES THRIVING AFTER 82 YEARS
description: One of New York's oldest, worthiest, but least openly publicized musical institutions is in the news again these days, however evanescently, in order to announce that one of its series is returning to Town Hall (after four seasons at Hunter College) and that subscriptions are now being offered for it - however parsimoniously.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Equal Bonuses For Alaskans
description: Longtime Alaska residents may deserve something for sticking it out, but it's not extra money, the Supreme Court said last week. The Court invalidated Alaska's plan to distribute its oil revenue windfall among citizens on the basis of how long they have lived in the state - $50 for each year of residence retroactive to 1959, when Alaska became the 49th state.

title: Tenants Know Where Evil Lurks
description: As president of a tenants association in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, I represent 140 families. To answer Mr. Kenneth J. Gould, I would have to ask, ''Would I buy a used car from my landlord?'' To open, Mr. Gould says that the great majority of tenants literally jump at this chance to purchase their apartments. Stroll perhaps - jump no. As usual, the first item mentioned is the chance to buy and sell for profit. He fails to deal with two items, however: Where do the tenants get all this money to purchase and if they do sell, where do they go? Does Mr. Gould mention the cost to the tenant of paying maintenance and mortgage costs?

title: Blue Jays 3, A's 1
description: Damaso Garcia sparked a two-run 12th inning with his fifth straight single and Garth Iorg and Lloyd Moseby doubled in runs as Toronto dealt Oakland its fifth straight loss.

title: DOING IT UP GREEN
description: The wail of pipes and the rattle of drums will open the 12th annual Irish Festival next Sunday morning at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel.

title: PALESTINIAN DEFEAT MAY MAKE QUEST FOR PEACE EVEN HARDER
description: DAMASCUS, SYRIA ISRAELI forces in Lebanon have swept away the existing mnilitary balance and political order in the entire Middle East from Cairo to Teheran. While some in Washington and Israel saw an extraordinary opportunity to expand stability and peace, Western and neutral area specialists here are convinced that attaining peace in the region has become more difficult.

title: A WIMBLEDON OF MANY NEW FACES
description: Who will it be this year - Chip Hooper, Bill Scanlon, John Sadri, Marty Davis or perhaps even Victor Amaya?

title: LEE SCOTT PLANS AUGUST WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Hamilton Scott Jr. of Charlottesville, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Dallan Lee Scott, to John Gregory Odom, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Childs Odom of Hahira, Ga.

title: 10-DAY JAZZ FESTIVAL TO BEGIN FRIDAY
description: The Kool Jazz Festival will come to New York this week for the second year since its name was changed from the one that it carried for its first 27 years, the Newport Jazz Festival.

title: Call for a Policy On Waste Is Seconded
description: As a weekend student at the College of St. Elizabeth in Convent Station, where I am taking an environmental science course, and as a New Jersey taxpayer, I, too, am concerned over the our state's cavalier solid-waste policies.

title: Kathleen Evans the Bride of David Van Hecke Jr.
description: Kathleen Beaumont Evans, daughter of Kathleen A.H. Evans and the late Charles M. Evans, both of Washington, was married there yesterday to David Charles Van Hecke Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Van Hecke of Rock Island, Ill. The Rev. Sanford Garner performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. James L. Connor, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: New Dorp's Marsala Captures Youth Run
description: Charlie Marsala of New Dorp High School, the Public Schools Athletic League outdoor one-mile champion, won the Chase Youth Run five-kilometer road race in 15 minutes 31.4 seconds yesterday at Central Park.

title: Avowal, in 13 1/2 Lengths, Wins Canadian Oaks
description: Avowal won the $160,255 Canadian Oaks race at Woodbine today with a jockey, Brian Swatuk, who had been thrown by the two-year-old filly Truespirit in the third race.

title: Elizabeth P. Kent Is Married
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Patterson Kent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Kent of Greenwich, Conn., and Red Rock, Pa., to Peter Adam Nitze took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony.

title: '83 BUDGET TO CUT BENEFIT PROGRAMS
description: The 1983 budget plan that was approved early Friday by a Congressional conference committee makes substantial cuts in the projected growth of domestic spending and Federal benefit programs.

title: AS CRIMINALS TURN MOBILE, NASSAU MOBILIZES DEFENSES
description: In many of Nassau County's well-kept communities, double-locked doors and burglar alarms have become as common as twocar garages and recreation rooms. Robberies and break-ins have replaced high taxes and the quality of schools as major concerns. Big-city crime, it seems, doesn't just happen in the big city. And the question on the minds of residents is how much big-city criminals are to blame.

title: Sandra Bain Wed to Stephen Bigelow Cushman
description: The marriage of Sandra Sue Bain and Stephen Bigelow Cushman, graduates of Cornell University, took place yesterday at the Hamburg (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Edwin Sprague performed the ceremony.

title: TINY OXFORD SEEKS DEVELOPMENT IN A BIG WAY
description: OXFORD WHEN Exxon Enterprises Inc. and the Burroughs Corporation announced their plans last month to sell property they had originally purchased for development in this rural village, many Oxford residents chalked it up to another pinch in the current economic squeeze.

title: Smoking Aloft
description: To the Editor:

title: William Riseman, Architect Of Numerous Movie Theaters
description: William Riseman, an architect who specialized in designing motionpicture theaters, died of a heart attack Saturday in Boston City Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Inmate Killed in Georgia
description: One inmate was stabbed to death, another was wounded and a third escaped in separate incidents at the Georgia State Prison today, officials reported.

title: News Analysis
description: Two opposite, adamantly held views are being put forth in the labor movement in the wake of the Supreme Court decision last week that a labor union can prohibit candidates for union office from accepting campaign contributions from outside the union.

title: Commodities; The Price Distortion In Wheat
description: Rarely have wheat growers and traders seen as bizarre a distortion of prices as they have recently because of poor weather and high interest rates. While the weather improved over the weekend, interest rates did not, and many analysts expect a further warping of prices this week.

title: Barbara Feuerstein Bride of Dr. Howard M. Simon
description: The marriage of Barbara Lynn Feuerstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard A. Feuerstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Dr. Howard Marshall Simon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour B. Simon of Syracuse, took place yesterday. Rabbi Irwin Hyman performed the ceremony at Estherwood, a mansion on the grounds of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: THEODORE W. LIBBEY Jr.
description: Milton Cruz, a Juilliard-trained pianist from the Dominican Republic, offered works by Haydn, Rachmaninoff, Chopin, Ravel and Ginastera on Saturday evening in a recital at the Abraham Goodman House. Mr. Cruz was named his country's cultural attache at the United Nations in 1979, and this recital showed that he has already acquired a diplomat's skill at maneuvering through difficult situations while conveying fine shades of meaning. In fact, so successful was he at persuading listeners that he was in control of his program that he almost made one believe that breaks in continuity, errors in fingering and dropped notes all belonged there.

title: CONNECTICUT FARMERS REPORT FLOODS CAUSED LARGE LOSSES
description: Farmers in Connecticut are reporting widespread damage to crops and farmland from the floods that struck the southern half of the state two weeks ago.

title: News Analysis
description: The instructions of law that were given to the jury now deliberating John W. Hinckley Jr.'s defense of insanity at the time he shot President Reagan and three other men resolved substantial doubts on two potentially important legal issues in the defendant's favor.

title: G.C. Davis Weds Isabel J. Kaplan
description: The marriage of Isabel Jane Kaplan to Lieut. Gregory Cady Davis, U.S.A., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Allan S. Kaplan, parents of the bride, in Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz and the Rev. Jesse Vaughan 3d, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let's hope for a cool summer.'' -John D. Simpson, Transit Authority president, on bus and subway air-conditioning. (A1:1.)

title: Salvador Rebels Say They Captured a Colonel
description: El Salvador's Deputy Minister of Defense, Col. Francisco Adolfo Castillo, who had been reported killed in a helicopter crash, is alive, according to a rebel radio broadcast.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SEASONING

title: 2D ALL-NEWS SERVICE TO EMPHASIZE BREVITY
description: Satellite News Channel, a 24-hour cable service modeled on all-news radio, will begin broadcasting at 11 A.M. today. Its arrival poses the first challenge to the cable entrepreneur Ted Turner's round-theclock cable channel, Cable News Network, now seen in 13 million homes.

title: Index; International
description: Bustling British stores belie lag- ging life styles A2 Cambodian groups are expected to announce a coalition A3 Venezuela's claim to most of Guyana is alive again A3 Weinberger says U.S. isn't plan- ning protracted nuclear war A5 Britain reclaims Thule in South Sandwich Islands A6 Argentines still struggling to pick a leader A6 Around the World A7 Marshall Island landowners pro- test deal on arms tests A8 For some Lebanese Christians, a village is again home A10 Lebanese tells of being ''humili- ated'' by Israeli soldiers A10 Israelis trying to ease trade with southern Lebanon A12 Greeks give Palestinians a wave of popular support A13 Washington Talk Briefing A16 Calendar A16 Christian Right presses views in Government A16 General Around the Nation A14 Philadelphia ceremonies mark national Bald Eagle Day A14 The metropolitan area enjoys a sunny weekend day B1 West Hartford, Conn., finds itself to be an aging community B2 Miss America pageant to drop familiar song B3 News Analysis Thomas L. Friedman on Arab inaction in Lebanon war A1 Stuart Taylor Jr. on instructions to Hinckley jury A14 Gene I. Maeroff on problems new City U. chancellor will face B1 William Serrin on unionists' re- sponse to court decision B5 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Cale Yarborough wins Gabriel 400 in Michigan C10 Baseball: Bill Veeck from the bleachers C6

title: THE BEST SHOT OF MY LIFE'
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. IN sports, the burden of excellence for the best athletes is that they're expected to win the best championships. If they don't, their skill is suspect. So is their nerve. So is their place in history. And in golf, the United States Open is the best championship, the most difficult to win, the most prestigious.

title: Washington Watch; Seat on F.T.C.  Stirs Conflict
description: WASHINGTON A powerful senator and the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission are squaring off in a battle of wills over rival candidates for the commission's long-empty ''Democratic'' chair. It is the second time this year that the vacancy has touched off controversy.

title: Erica Lindenbaum Is Married to Steven Tishman
description: Erica Dale Lindenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Lindenbaum of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Howard Tishman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Tishman of Hollywood, Fla. Rabbi Benjamin Z. Kreitman performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: EUROPEANS TO LIFT EMBARGO ON TRADE WITH BUENOS AIRES
description: The foreign ministers of the European Common Market decided today to lift their trade embargo against Argentina, high-ranking European diplomats said.

title: The U.N. Today; June 21, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BRIEFING
description: Haig Splits Conservatives

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Souvenir of School Days

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cutting the Tracks

title: THE RUSSIAN THEATERGOERS TAKE TENNESSEE WILLIAMS TO THEIR HEARTS
description: MOSCOW The hottest American name on the Soviet stage today is Tennessee Williams. It may be more than three decades since Mr. Williams first thrilled and scandalized America with the drama of brutal conflicts played out under the veneer of Southern gentility, and it has been almost two decades since his last big Broadway success, ''The Night of the Iguana.'' But in Moscow and across the Soviet land, ''Koshka na Raskalyonnoy Kryshe'' (''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof''), ''Tatuirovannaya Roza'' (''Rose Tattoo'') and a host of other Williams classics are packing houses and drawing gasps, bravos and good press.

title: Postal Service Reports Operating Surplus Rises
description: The Postal Service reported a $634 million surplus today, an increase of almost $200 million since March.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK TO NARROW FIELD FOR COMPTROLLER
description: New York Democrats gathered here today, certain to pick Mayor Koch as their candidate for governor. His supporters, however, were less certain about who would run with him as a candidate for state comptroller.

title: SCHOOLS TRY TO ATTRACT WHITES BY EASING INTEGRATION EFFORTS
description: Angry white parents buried a school bus in protest 10 years ago when Memphis school officials began busing thousands of students to desegregated schools outside their racially segregated neighborhoods.

title: International
description: Trade ties with Europe will be further strained by the Reagan Administration's decision Friday to tighten its ban on exports of products and technology for the Soviet Union's natural gas pipeline to Western Europe, diplomats said in Luxembourg. (Page D1.)

title: New Cuisine Publisher
description: CBS Publications has named Anne Sutherland, 35, publisher of Cuisine magazine.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Break From Taxes

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: OLSON, RIPLEY SET U.S. VAULT MARK
description: Billy Olson and Dan Ripley broke the American record in the pole vault tonight by clearing 18 feet 9 1/4 inches. On the track, Steve Scott and Mary Decker Tabb won 1,500-meter titles in fast times.

title: 3 CAMBODIAN GROUPS FORMING COALITION
description: Three Cambodian groups are expected to announce the formation of a coalition government-in-exile this week, and a report here suggests that the Pol Pot faction may be given more power than the coalition's sponsors hoped it would get.

title: SUN POPS IN, OFFERING HALF A WEEKEND
description: Dawn came up not at all like thunder today, and as the wind carried wispy remnants of Saturday's storm out to sea, the metropolitan area began to enjoy its first weekend in five that was not completely waterlogged.

title: TV: 'AIN'T MISBEHAVIN,' 30's CABARET
description: After 1,500 performances on Broadway, ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' is coming to television, tonight at 9 on NBC, and it proves to be thoroughly winning.

title: News Analysis
description: With its fiscal footing unsteady, the confidence of its faculty weakened and its students often lacking proper preparation, the City University of New York will present its new chancellor with a very different set of problems from those that faced Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, who took over the position in 1971.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on June 7 about a reunion of the 1950 class of the Bronx High School of Science incorrectly identified the valedictorian. She was Cynthia Fox Dember.

title: TAX BENEFICIARIES MUST HELP THE POOR
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITAIN RETAKES ANOTHER ATLANTIC ISLAND FROM ARGENTINA
description: Britain said today that it had reclaimed the last of its South Atlantic possessions from Argentina without a fight. It said troops based on the Falkland Islands swooped onto Thule, the southernmost of the remote South Sandwich Islands, and captured a team of Argentine scientists. Britain said the scientists were there illegally, but Buenos Aires, which confirmed the takeover, said an agreement had been reached years ago authorizing their presence.

title: PITFALLS OF TRAVELING TOGETHER
description: "She wanted to stay up late and go to discos every night and do a lot of drinking. That's not for me.'' ''He started to bargain with the taxi driver. It was 11:30 at night. We were way out in the country. Why couldn't he just let the man take us to the hotel?''

title: ASIAN ISSUE SCHEDULED
description: Plans to sell new corporate bonds evaporated in the past week as yields rose sharply for intermediate and long-term issues. Two issues of convertible debt are scheduled, along with a zero coupon issue of the Asian Development Bank, which has not borrowed in the United States market since August 1976, when it sold 8 5/8 percent notes.

title: VENEZUELA'S CLAIM TO MOST OF GUYANA IS ALIVE AGAIN AS MORATORIUM ENDS
description: A long-standing territorial dispute between two neighbors on the northern edge of South America, Venezuela and Guyana, entered a new and potentially volatile phase two days ago with the expiration of a 12-year moratorium on Venezuela's claim to a piece of land that makes up five-eighths of Guyana's national territory.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 21, 1982
description: International Prime Minister Menachem Begin arrived in Washington for talks with President Reagan amid signs that the Reagan Administration was divided on how to react to the Israeli military moves in Lebanon. Administration officials said that Mr. Reagan was receiving conflicting advice from advisers. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., they said, advocates a soft public approach to Prime Minister Begin, while a public rebuke is reportedly favored by two other senior aides, William P. Clark, the national security adviser, and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. (Page A1, Column 6.) Withdrawal of Syrian forces from Beirut was sought by President Elias Sarkis of Lebanon but the request was turned down because it appeared to have been made under duress, with Israeli guns aimed at the presidential palace, a Syrian official said. Ahmed Iskander Ahmed, Syria's information minister, said its troops would not be withdrawn ''until after the last Israeli soldier has left the country.'' (A1:.5.)

title: NO I.R.S. SHELTER FOR HORSE-BREEDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil to Try 2 French Priests Accused of Inciting Violence
description: The military trial of two Roman Catholic priests from France, accused of inciting violence by peasants, opens Monday.

title: SOVIET GRAIN CROP: ONE MORE FAILURE
description: Summer has barely begun in the vast Russian grain belt that arcs eastward from the Ukraine to Kazakhstan, but the stands of winter wheat are already sere and stunted.

title: L.S.U. Tightens Academic Rules
description: Bob Brodhead, new athletic director at Louisiana State, has ordered that reports on classroom performance of athletes be made directly to his office and not through head coaches.

title: Iacocca Outlines Ellis Island Plans
description: Plans for the restoration and preservtion of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island were outlined Saturday by Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Statue of Liberty Ellis Island Centennial Commission.

title: Inquiry on Fixes In Meadowlands
description: Federal authorities have evidence that a group of gamblers fixed harness races at the Meadowlands last summer, according to a report in The Star-Ledger.

title: Diana Marie Kessler Wed
description: The marriage of Diana Marie Kessler, an account executive with Ted Bates Advertising/New York, to Douglas Edwin Singer, an associate with the New York law firm of Webster & Sheffield, took place in Morristown, N.J., yesterday. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Governor Morris Inn. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Kessler of Butler, N.J. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Singer of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: WIMBELDON TAKES HEED
description: page brochure includes a welcoming message from the chairman, a map of the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club, important telephone numbers, how and where to find a practice court and ticket information. To the astonishment of many players here for today's start of the Wimbledon championships, the brochure is specifically designed for them - not for debenture holders, news media representatives, tennis politicos, ticket touts or spectators.

title: Daniel C. Pinchas Marries Wendy Rosen in Maryland
description: Wendy Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Rosen of Hanover, Pa., was married yesterday to Daniel C. Pinchas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raphael Pinchas of New York. Cantor A. Lopes Cardozo performed the ceremony at Grey Rock Lodge in Reistertown, Md.

title: Sarah Jane Schlesinger Wed to Stanley Frankel
description: Sarah Jane Schlesinger, daughter of Renee C. Schlesinger of New York and Edward S. Schlesinger of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel yesterday to Stanley Raban Frankel, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Frankel of Evanston, Ill. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Robert Raab, assisted by Cantor Raymond Smolover.

title: HAPPY IN THE BLEACHERS
description: CHICAGO THERE was a collective moan in the center-field bleachers at Wrigley Field except from Bill Veeck, who smiled. A pop fly fell between three Chicago Cubs but Veeck grinned, just as he would several innings later when the Cub pitcher doubled in three runs. ''Baseball,'' muttered a man sitting behind him, and Veeck finished another hot dog.

title: Banks Ask Alfa to End Asset Shifts
description: Ten large foreign banks, all owed large sums by Mexico's hard-pressed Grupo Industrial Alfa, have demanded that the conglomerate stop diverting assets from its still-profitable Hylsa steel division to some of its weaker subsidiaries.

title: INDEPENDENT DISTRIBUTOR FINDS PROFIT IN LOW-GROSSING FILMS
description: Remember ''The Texas Chainsaw Massacre''? How about ''Reefer Madness''? Surely you haven't forgotten ''Polyester''? If none of those pop cult movies rings a bell, don't blame Robert Shaye. Mr. Shaye, 43 years old, is an independent film distributor, and sometime film producer. The company he founded, New Line Cinema, is one of a handful of small, mainly New York-based concerns that have carved out a niche in the distribution of low-budget, lowgrossing films that a United Artists or a Columbia won't touch.

title: Article 224549 -- No Title
description: The champagne may soon be flowing at two leading Wall Street firms, the First Boston Corporation and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. If, as seems almost certain, the Gulf Oil Corporation is successful in its $5.1 billion offer to buy the Cities Service Company, First Boston and Lehman Brothers would share equally in an advisory fee of about $20 million, to be paid by Cities Service.

title: Miss Neubert Sets Heptathlon Mark
description: Ramona Neubert of East Germany broke her world record today in the heptathlon - a seven-event track and field competition - in a meet at Halle, the East German press service ADN reported.

title: COSMOS TRIUMPH BY 3-2
description: Giorgio Chinaglia's first goal in four games, with 2 minutes 34 seconds left, gave the Cosmos a 3-2 victory over the Seattle Sounders today before a crowd of 27,357 at Giants Stadium.

title: Print Entries Do Poorly In Art Director Awards
description: Only 18 gold medals were given out last Friday at the 61st annual awards of the Art Directors Club at the Waldorf-Astoria, and only 10 of them were for media advertising. Last year, 29 golds were awarded.

title: BRITISH STORES BUSTLING, BUT LIFE IS OFTEN AUSTERE
description: To the casual visitor to this cosmopolitan city, signs of prosperity abound. Shoppers crowd fashionable Bond Street boutiques and make the aisles of Harrods department store virtually impassable on busy days. Prices in London remain high, and restaurants of even modest culinary pretensions seem extraordinarily expensive, even to New Yorkers.

title: WATSON WINS U.S. OPEN
description: Tom Watson being congratulated by Bruce Edwards, his caddie, after he birdied last two holes at Pebble Beach, Calif. Watson won first U.S. Open title by two strokes over Jack Nicklaus. Page C1.

title: California's Backfire on Crime
description: Four years ago, California's voters gave in to anti-tax hysteria and passed Proposition 13, which cut property taxes and gave the state fiscal migraines. Now they've succumbed to anti-crime hysteria and passed Proposition 8, which threatens to give the state's criminal justice system a bad case of the flu. A close look at the proposition should make clear to other states that criminal justice, for all its faults, still needs protection from the easy excesses of politics.

title: Tourneau Watch Shifts To Lois Pitts Gershon
description: Lois Pitts Gershon won the account of the Tourneau watch stores a month or so ago and never announced it.

title: Family Story Wins First Algren Award
description: The first annual Nelson Algren award, established by Chicago magazine in memory of the author who died on Long Island last year, has been won by Louise Erdrich for her short story, ''The World's Greatest Fishermen.'' More than 2,000 entries from all over the country were submitted in the contest, according to Christine Newman, the magazine's literary editor who coordinated the Algren award.

title: Canada Triumphs In Lacrosse, 26-8
description: Jim Weller scored six goals and assisted on two others today to lead Canada to a 26-8 rout of England in the World Lacrosse Games at Johns Hopkins University.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With a man on first and one out, the batter drives the ball into the bleachers for a home run, but the bat flies out of his hands and knocks the runner unconscious between first and second. What is the ruling, since the runner cannot make it to home plate?

title: OUTDOORS: NEW CASTING TECHNIQUE FROM ENGLAND
description: fishing devotees in this country.

title: Death Penalty Bill Near Vote in Jersey
description: New Jersey's Assembly is expected to pass legislation on Monday that would reinstate the death penalty, and for the first time in a decade, the state has a governor who plans to sign it.

title: The Talk of West Hartford
description: ''We're an aging community in both buildings and people,'' said Mayor Charles Matties. ''Somewhere along the line, the life cycles change.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Michiko Kakutani EDIE. An American Biography. By Jean Stein. Edited with George Plimpton. 455 pages. Illustrated. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Allen Gets 'Feeler' From New League
description: George Allen, the former head coach of the Los Angeles Rams and the Washington Redskins in the National Football League, yesterday said from his home in Palos Verdes, Calif., that he had received ''feelers'' from three teams in the newly formed United States Football League,

title: People
description: * David Keith, senior vice president, corporate communications, Houston Natural Gas, has been elected chairman of the American Advertising Federation, Washington.

title: WATSON WINS OPEN BY 2 SHOTS FROM NICKLAUS
description: Miracles are hard to come by in championship golf, but Tom Watson provided one today. He holed out from the rough beside the 17th green to win his first United States Open championship.

title: METS TOP CARDS IN 10th, 5-4
description: John Stearns galloped through the tunnel from the dugout to the clubhouse, delivering his exuberant message before he was through the door. ''Big win, men! Way to go, men!'' shouted the Mets' catcher-turned-third baseman whose 10th-inning triple had driven in the winning runs in a 5-4 victory over the first-place Cardinals.

title: HOW BOSTON REDUCED ITS MASS TRANSIT FARE
description: To the Editor:

title: SECURITIES HELD MORE RISKY
description: A less efficient market for Treasury securities has emerged recently as the newest explanation for higher interest rates. In normal times interest rates rise and fall as investors and speculators anticipate the economic developments - such as business and government credit demands and Federal Reserve monetary policy - that have influenced interest rates in the past.

title: FOR CHRISTIAN VILLIGERS, HAPPINESS AMID RUBBLE
description: Abdallah Shaya, a 54-year-old gardener with a round, tanned face, found his house amid the rubble of Damur today. Unlike most of the stone and concrete buildings in the hillside village, it was intact, somehow spared the flying shrapnel from the bombs and shells that had ravaged the town and filled the streets with dust and chunks of rock.

title: Family Circle to Trim 4th Quarter Rate Base
description: Family Circle, a 17-times-a-year publication owned by The New York Times Company, is cutting its rate base for the fourth quarter to 8 million, from 8.2 million.

title: Kansas City Evaluates Work in Hyatt Collapse
description: Emergency rescue and medical work at the Hyatt Regency Hotel skywalk collapse last year was performed as well as was possible in such a disaster, a investigatory team has concluded.

title: REAGAN AIDES ARE SAID TO SUGGEST LABOR SECRETARY SHOULD STEP DOWN
description: President Reagan's principal advisers have decided, at least among themselves, that Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan, who has been accused of having ties to organized crime figures, should step aside until a special prosecutor has completed his report, a White House official said today.

title: Egypt Offers to Give Asylum To P.L.O. Leaders in Lebanon
description: President Hosni Mubarak said today that Egypt was willing to provide asylum for Yasir Arafat and other Palestinian leaders under a plan proposed by Lebanese mediators to end the fighting in their country.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Agway Inc., Syracuse, has named Arthur J. Fogerty senior vice president, corporate relations.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday gave the wrong service affiliation of Gen. David C. Jones, retiring Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. General Jones was an Air Force officer.

title: GULF'S PURSUIT OF CITIES SERVICE
description: For weeks, the Gulf Oil Corporation had been flirting with the Cities Service Company. But the betrothal, which could lead to one of the biggest corporate acquisitions on record, was negotiated during 36 high-pressure hours that included marathon meetings at several Park Avenue addresses and last-minute telephone calls between the chairmen of the two companies.

title: JACKSON 4 FOR 4
description: Reggie Jackson had four hits in four times at bat, including his 13th homer, as the California Angels beat the Chicago White Sox, 3-1, today.

title: MARSHALL ISLAND LANDOWNERS PROTEST U.S. MISSLE BASE PACT
description: About 40 people who own land on the Marshall Islands have camped out on part of a $1 billion United States missile testing facility on Kwajalein, the largest of 34 atolls in the chain.

title: MARGRETTA D. CORT
description: Margretta D. Cort, a real estate agent and the widow of Harry L. Cort, the theatrical producer and playwright, died last Monday at her home in Manhattan.

title: HOW PSYCHIATRY CAN AID COURTS
description: The trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. for the attempted assassination of President Reagan has raised serious questions about the credibility of psychiatric testimony in the courtroom.

title: BALD EAGLE'S PROPONENT REJOICES ON BIRD'S 'DAY'
description: If Philadelphia's Benjamin Franklin had been as persistent as a New Yorker who loves eagles, this might well have been Turkey Day.

title: Out of the Bullpen
description: In all the confusion last week about whether or not the Yankees had been invited to participate in the Mobil Big Apple Games sports clinics for city youngsters, Jeff Torborg's name was neglected. Torborg, the Yankee bullpen coach, was among the first to accept an invitation to teach a baseball clinic as part of the program, which will offer clinics in eight sports and will culminate in the trials for selections of the city's Empire State Games teams.

title: NEW YORK TRANSIT FACES HOT SUMMER
description: When summer arrives at 1:23 P.M. today, half of New York City's buses and nearly two-thirds of its subway cars will be without airconditioning.

title: 'DON'T OVERREACH'
description: What will happen to the 6,000 P.L.O guerrillas trapped in West Beirut? That is the immediate question confronting Philip Habib as he tries to patch together some temporary arrangement in Lebanon. It is a question with deeper implications for the whole Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: LEBANON'S COUNCIL REPORTS NO PROGRESS IN FIRST MEETING
description: An emergency council representing Lebanon's major disparate factions met for the first time tonight to discuss ways of ending the Israeli siege around Beirut. The meeting made no progress.

title: OPERA: 'MADDALENA,' A FRAGMENT FROM PROKOFIEV
description: Music's history is like an archeological dig, littered with fragments waiting to be pieced together by the right specialist in shards and old bones. Prokofiev's fifth opera, ''Maddalena,'' is a fragmentary work, which he started when he was 20 and never finished orchestrating, although he did complete the piano score. Rescued from the boneyard, it had its first concert performance four years ago in England and now has been given its American premiere by the Opera Theater of St. Louis.

title: Decision File; Keeping Track Of Plane Bumping
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board recently announced that about 30 percent more travelers were being ''involuntarily denied confirmed seats'' than last year at the same time. In other words, more people are being bumped.

title: NICKLAUS PUTTING FAILS AT END
description: The putts Jack Nicklaus made today turned the final round of the United States Open into one of the most dramatic in its history. But his fine round also included three missed birdie putts on the last three holes and that meant second place instead of his fifth Open victory.

title: N.B.A. to Consider San Diego Move
description: National Basketball Association club owners will consider the San Diego Clippers' planned transfer to Los Angeles at their annual meeting that opens Monday.

title: Boy Electrocuted
description: A 14-year-old boy accidentally electrocuted himself while playing outside his home, the police said today.

title: Germans Extend Trade Pact
description: The Governments of West and East Germany have agreed to extend a controversial, interest-free credit arrangement used to finance their bilateral trade, according to a West German Cabinet official.

title: Anne Griffith Wed to George Freeman
description: Anne Griffith, daughter of Mrs. Everett C. Furman of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Leonard Griffith of Wantagh, L.I., was married yesterday to George Freeman, a New York lawyer. Justice Theodore Kupferman of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, performed the ceremony at the Excelsior Club in Manhattan.

title: Colombians Take Bicycling Honors
description: A Colombian team has raced to victory in the 11-day Coors International Bicycle Classic.

title: DATA GENERAL: TROUBLED 'SOUL'
description: In 12 years of uninterrupted growth, the Data General Corporation built a reputation as a feisty, hard-charging computer company where engineering was a passion and marketing an afterthought.

title: A BLACK-TIE DEBUTANTE PARTY ON THE NORTH SHORE
description: Cornelia Guest did not wear the shortest dress. But before she arrived many of the young women who wore modest floor-length taffeta had bet she would. Instead, the honor went to 21-year-old Princess Anita von Furstenberg of Vienna who raised a few eyebrows with a white Thierry Mugler pique miniskirt and black lace stockings.

title: BALLET: UNUSUAL 'LETTERS TO ORPHEUS'
description: THE Orpheus legend came in for the Scandinavian treatment Saturday night with the New York premiere and single performance of the Royal Danish Ballet's ''Letters to Orpheus'' at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Sharkey Is First
description: Francis Sharkey of the Belfast Track Club of New York captured the New York Road Runners Club Fathers Day four-mile run in 19 minutes 38 seconds yesterday morning at Central Park.

title: Yarborough Victor in Gabriel
description: Cale Yarborough beat Darrell Waltrip and the darkness in winning the rain-interrupted Gabriel 400 Grand National stock-car race today at Michigan International Speedway.

title: United Brands Purchase
description: The United Brands Company said that it had agreed to acquire from Salomon Brothers up to $23 million principal of its debt securities in exchange for up to 1.8 million United Brands shares. Salomon will offer the stock for sale for its own account.

title: Market Place; Flood's Impact On MITE
description: The MITE Corporation's stock eased after a flood inundated the company's New Haven plant during the first weekend in June. But the stock wasn't under water for long.

title: WORLD CUP HIT BY UNEXPECTED
description: Spanish sportswriters are calling the week-old World Cup championships ''the rebellion of the modest,'' delighting in the refusal of underdog third world soccer nations to be taken for granted by the mighty of the sport.

title: STEPPARENTS: ERASING THE 'WICKED' IMAGE
description: She is the wicked stepmother, and she has a powerful hold on cultural myth and children's imagination. In ''Hansel and Gretel,'' she persuades the woodchopper to banish his innocents into the sinister forest. In ''Snow White'' she is far from the fairest of them all. And in ''Cinderella'' she humiliates the hard-working heroine, as the first English version of ''Mother Goose Tales'' said in 1729, ''difplaying her ill humour by employing her in the meaneft work of the houfe.''

title: Passenger Protocol
description: To the Editor:

title: CHIEF SAYS DAYCO WILL WEATHER SUIT
description: The Dayco Corporation has been staggered by charges and countercharges involving millions of dollars in shipments to fill nonexistent orders from the Soviet Union. But to hear Richard J. Jacob, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, tell the story, Dayco not only will prevail but will come out stronger than ever.

title: Bermuda Race: Blaze of Color
description: Under cloudless skies and driven by brisk 15-to-17-knot northwesterly winds, a 178-boat fleet crossed the starting line today in the 635-mile race to Bermuda.

title: 7 British Soldiers Held
description: Argentina is holding seven members of the Special Air Service prisoner, and Britain may be hinging the return of 1,000 Argentine troops on their release, The Sunday Times of London reported. It said they were captured on the Argentine mainland more than a month ago.

title: Thousands March Peacefully In Disarmament Rally in Paris
description: Tens of thousands of people marched to the Place de la Bastille in Paris today calling for an end to the arms race.

title: Earl Weaver's 25th Son
description: EARL WEAVER says he is retiring as Baltimore manager after this season because he is tired of ''confrontations.'' Some of his best confrontations have been with Rick Dempsey, the gutsy catcher with the bright blue eyes.

title: Gretzky Becomes A Club Owner
description: Wayne Gretzky, the Edmonton Oiler star, became a club owner today by purchasing 45 percent of the Belleville Bulls of the junior Ontario League.

title: U.S. MOVE ON PIPELINE IS ASSAILED
description: European governments reacted with dismay and disappointment over the weekend to a Reagan Administration decision to uphold and extend an export ban on products and technology that the Soviet Union needs to complete a natural-gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: News Analysis
description: The absence of an effective response by Arab nations to the Israeli onslaught against the Palestinians in Lebanon is attributed by many Arabs to their overwhelming sense of helplessness.

title: Mrs. Walesa Requests Transfer of Husband
description: Lech Walesa's wife said today that she had asked Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish military chief, to transfer the interned Solidarity leader closer to their Gdansk home for personal and health reasons.

title: Dianne Durham Vaults From Obscurity
description: Dianne Durham, a muscular 15-year-old schoolgirl, vaulted her way out of obscurity over the weekend in the second United States Gymnastics Federation international invitation.

title: IRAQ WITHDRAWING IN WAR WITH IRAN
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said today that Iraqi troops had begun withdrawing from Iranian territory to the Iraqi border and would complete their pullback within 10 days, the official Iraqi press agency reported.

title: ADM. ROSCOE H. HILLENKOETTER, 85, FIRST DIRECTOR OF THE C.I.A., DIES
description: Vice Adm. Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, the first director of the Central Intelligence Agency, died Friday night at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 85 years old and had lived in Weehawken, N.@J., since his retirement from the Navy in 1958.

title: ENGLAND ADVANCES TO SECOND ROUND
description: England, re-establishing itself as a soccer power, defeated Czechoslovakia, 2-0, and West Germany, redeeming itself after an embarrassing defeat last week, beat Chile, 4-1, in their Phase 1 World Cup games today.

title: Second Generation
description: The 18th annual All-American Collegiate Golf Foundation dinner will be held Tuesday night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. For Chris Perry of Ohio State, Jay Delsing of U.C.L.A. and Billy Ray Brown of Houston, three of the eight first-team all-Americans, their honors are long tee shots from their fathers' major sports achievements.

title: Turkey Removes Prosecutors In Political Trials of Hundreds
