description: Turkey's ruling military council said today that it had dismissed the chief prosecutors in mass trials against an extreme-right-wing political party and a leftist labor union.

title: WEINBERGER DENIES U.S. PLANS FOR 'PROTRACTED' WAR
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Reagan Administration was not planning to fight a protracted nuclear war, but was preparing to prevail if the Soviet Union started such a conflict.

title: HELLO, MR. DEEDS
description: The National Security Council gathered in the Cabinet Room at 1:30 P.M. on Friday, June 18, to consider whether or not to offend our European allies by denying them access to U.S. technology in the construction of that great monument to detente, the Siberian gas pipeline.

title: State Senator Paid No Tax on Yacht
description: The chairman of the State Senate's Commerce Committee reportedly bought a $115,000 yacht but paid no state tax on the purchase.

title: REAGAN'S ADVISERS SAID TO BE DIVIDED ON LEBANESE CRISIS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel arrived here today for talks with President Reagan amid signs that the Reagan Administration was divided on how to react to Israel's military moves in Lebanon.

title: Susan Alison Gold Bride Of Robert M. Blumenfeld
description: Susan Alison Gold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor I. Gold of South Fallsburg, N.Y., was married at the Pierre Hotel yesterday to Robert M. Blumenfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Blumenfeld of New York.

title: AIDE SAYS URBAN REPORT IS STILL SUBJECT TO CHANGE
description: A White House aide told the nation's mayors today that President Reagan had rejected parts of a report from the Department of Housing and Urban Development that says cities would be better off without dependence on many Federal grants.

title: SYRIANS REFUSE LEBANON'S PLEA ON WITHDRAWAL
description: A Syrian official said today that President Elias Sarkis of Lebanon had asked for the withdrawal of Syrian forces from Beirut, but that the request had been turned down.

title: Attendance Off
description: Joao Havelange, head of world soccer's governing body, FIFA, predicted today that the World Cup tournament would be successful despite a drop in attendance.

title: PHILADELPHIA CREW TRIUMPHS
description: The College Boat Club crew from Philadelphia, a unit assembled and trained in just three weeks, won the elite eight-oared final today at the Women's National Rowing Championships.

title: Barbara Sablow, Brian Shore Wed
description: The marriage of Barbara Ellen Sablow, an art director with the Great Scott Advertising Company, to Brian Elliot Shore, a 1982 graduate of the Fordham University School of Law, took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Shore, in Sands Point, L.I. Rabbi Mark Somerstein officiated.

title: Jan Stephenson Rallies to Win by 1
description: Jan Stephenson, running off a string of five consecutive birdies in the middle of her final round, came from seven strokes off the pace today and won the Lady Keystone Open.

title: FROM GREECE, A WAVE OF SUPPORT FOR THE PALESTINIANS
description: The Greek Government's strong criticism of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon has been bolstered in recent days by a wave of popular support for the Palestinians.

title: CENTRONICS DATA LEADER IS MOVING ON, AGAIN
description: Robert Howard, chairman and chief executive of the Centronics Data Computer Corporation, is losing his 22d company this month to a heavyweight in the computer equipment industry - the Control Data Corporation. Mr. Howard will step down at the end of June when Control Data and two associated companies acquire 45 percent of Centronics, once the leader in computer printing.

title: Greek Bank Strike Extended
description: Greece's 32,000 bank employees today announced a two-day extension of a strike, already in its fourth week. The bank employees are demanding pay increases of as much as 40 percent.

title: Police Official Found Guilty
description: MIAMI (AP) - A suspended commander in the Metro-Dade Police Department was convicted Friday of possessing and trafficking in cocaine.

title: HUMILIATED BY ISRAELIS, A LEBANESE SAYS
description: When Safwat el-Khatib, an orderly at the Labib Medical Center, went with the other men of this coastal city to have his identification card stamped and validated by newly arrived Israeli military authorities, an Israeli soldier took a piece of charcoal and drew a big black X on the back of the red shirt he was wearing.

title: O'Neill Assails Budget In Graduation Address
description: Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. today accused the Reagan Administration of trading books for guns and said the Federal budget's cuts in aid to education were unforgivable.

title: MIZRAHI'S 'LA VIE CONTINUE'
description: ''LA VIE CONTINUE'' begins on a day that should be a supremely ordinary one in the life of the film's heroine, Jeanne (Annie Girardot). She is happy with her three children and very comfortably in love with her husband. Then, without warning, everything is changed forever. Her husband dies of a heart attack while Jeanne is out doing the marketing. ''La Vie Continue,'' as its title suggests, shows how Jeanne manages to weather this crisis and begin her life anew.

title: Bridge: For 25 Years, Cliff Russell Has Been Among the Best
description: Among the small band of experts who have been competing in national championships and winning titles for more than a quarter of a century, Cliff Russell of Miami Beach is a popular figure.

title: BROOKLYN MISHAP ENDS IN KILLING
description: An argument that erupted over a minor traffic accident in Brooklyn just before noon yesterday ended when one driver shot the other to death and then sped off, the police reported.

title: EFFORT TO HALT SPREAD OF A-ARMS SAID TO FALTER
description: United States officials and nuclear policy specialists fear that they may be losing a 35-year-old battle to curb the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Balbuco Scores At Horse Show
description: Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Butler's Balbuco, ridden by Conrad Holmfeld, won the $20,000 Almaden Vineyards Ox Ridge Grand Prix today.

title: Steps Involved In Tender Offer
description: Tender offers, such as the one Gulf is planning for Cities Service, involve a series of steps. Gulf is expected to make an official offer soon - probably by today - for 51 percent of the Cities Service stock at a price of $63 a share.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Driven From Manhattan?

title: Southern Pacific Titles
description: Denman K. McNear has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the Southern Pacific Transportation Company and its subsidiary, the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company.

title: Canada Prepares Study On Asian Chemical War
description: Canada is submitting to the United Nations a study on the reported use of chemical weapons in Southeast Asia, concluding that symptoms reported by victims cannot be explained by the natural occurrence of disease, according to Canada's Foreign Minister, Mark MacGuigan.

title: The Gridlocked Economy
description: Optimistic economists are scarcer these days than customers in a Chevy showroom, and no wonder. Thanks in large part to sky-high interest rates, the country is suffering the worst recession since 1937. But the Federal Reserve won't ease its squeeze on credit, lest it trigger a new round of inflation. So the best guess is that any spontaneous recovery will be choked off - by tight money.

title: Where Credit Is Due
description: What started four years ago merely as the 80th birthday party for Clinton Thomas, an outfielder who compiled a .350 career batting average in the Negro leagues, has grown into an annual festivity where many of the black stars of the 1920's, 1930's and 1940's, most of whom never received a chance to play in the major leagues, gather to celebrate their memories.

title: RICHARD LOCKRIDGE, WRITER OF NORTH MYSTERIES
description: Richard Lockridge, the mystery story writer who with his wife, Frances, created the fictional sleuths Mr. and Mrs. North, whose exploits appeared in novels and on the stage, screen, radio and television, died Saturday at his home in Tryon, N.C. He was 83 years old and had recently had a series of strokes.

title: PLANS TO LIFT TAXES DIVIDE BUSINESS
description: Robert E. Lighthizer, chief counsel of the Senate Finance Committee, says that the pattern of business tax lobbying this year is best portrayed by Senator Russell B. Long's ditty: ''Don't tax you, don't tax me, tax that fellow behind the tree.''

title: Balancing the Budget
description: The ax that has been slicing its way through the Federal budget nicked the National Football League Players Association a few weeks ago. For three years, the players association had been administering a program through a Job Corps grant, whereby athletes would visit Job Corps centers and encourage the youth who were learning trade skills.

title: Expos Beat Cubs in Gusts, 11-5
description: Chicago was the windy city yesterday. Gusts to 18 miles an hour swept through Wrigley Field as the Montreal Expos banged out 14 hits for an 11-5 victory over the Cubs.

title: CITY'S SUBWAY CARS NEED REPAIR, NOT REPLACEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Alan A. Platt Weds Kathleen O'Reilley
description: Kathleen O'Boyle O'Reilley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh O'Boyle of Silver Spring, Md., was married in Annapolis, Md., yesterday to Alan Arthur Platt, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Philip Platt of Oakland Gardens, Queens. Rabbi Jay Heyman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Stefan Rogers Skipp.

title: Switch-Hitting Golfer
description: One sportsman who will be taking part in the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Golf Classic this week at the Westchester Country Club has already accumulated $1,110,850 in prize money this year. He has won nine of the 13 tournaments he has entered and was runner-up in three others.

title: Seewagen Wins State Tennis Title
description: Butch Seewagen, the former touring pro and Columbia coach, won the New York State men's clay-court tennis championship for the eighth time yesterday.

title: Alan Epstein Marries Karen T. Isselbacher
description: At Temple Mishkan Tefila in Chestnut Hill, Mass., yesterday Karen Theo Isselbacher and Alan Epstein, Harvard graduates attending the Boston University School of Medicine, were married by Rabbi Richard M. Yellin.

title: MISS AMERICA PAGEANT PLANS TO CHANGE ITS TUNE
description: Like everything else, the price of music goes up, it seems - so Miss America will parade to a different tune this September. Having got along without Bert Parks as master of ceremonies for the past two years, the Miss America Pageant has now dropped the familiar strains of ''There She Is,'' which has accompanied the newly crowned winner on maiden strolls down the runway at Atlantic City for 27 years.

title: Flirting With Plutonium
description: The United States cannot stop dissemination of the ability to make plutonium, the deadly metal that both fuels nuclear reactors and arms nuclear weapons. It can only try to put off the day when every small country or terrorist group acquires access to it. Yet a policy recently approved by President Reagan will speed the arrival of a world plutonium economy, for no clear gain.

title: Convict Slain in Brawl At Prison in California
description: One convict was killed and six others were injured along with five guards today in the second day of racial violence between blacks and Mexican-American inmates at Folsom Prison.

title: MADRIGALS: WESTERN WIND
description: The Western Wind vocal ensemble warmed its audience with a catered meal Saturday night and then won it over with madrigal music from two centuries. The entertainment was at SoHo's Performing Garage and the music by William Bolcom and Adriano Banchieri.

title: HOW CONSERVATIVES VIEW U.S. POSTS
description: Bob Billings is a Christian evangelist who believes that rock music, sex education and homosexuality are bad and that we live in a ''corrupt, decadent society.''

title: JUDGE MANOS: MAN BEHIND DECISIONS
description: When the Mobil Corporation attempted to take over the Marathon Oil Company of Findlay, Ohio, last December, it ran up against a preliminary injunction issued by a Federal judge, John M. Manos.

title: Laura Daley Married To David B. Caravella
description: Laura Jeanne Daley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Daley of Greenwich, Conn., was married at Christ Episcopal Church there yesterday to David B. Caravella, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Caravella of Cos Cob, Conn. The Rev. James Kelloway and the Rev. Vincent O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: ORIOLES BEAT YANKS IN 11th, 5-3
description: When the Yankee bullpen bubble finally burst, it was the bullpen's best who had the pin stuck in him. After allowing no runs in 18 innings over a span of four games, the Yankees' relief corps faltered yesterday when Joe Nolan hit a pinch-hit two-run homer against Rich Gossage in the 11th inning that vaulted the Baltimore Orioles to a 5-3 victory.

title: ARGENTINES STRUGGLE TO PICK A LEADER
description: Argentina's military leaders continued their search for a new President for the country today amid signs they remained seriously split over the choice.

title: ISRAEL FORGING TRADE LINKS WITH SOUTH LEBANON
description: The Israeli Government, which wants to ease the passage of goods into southern Lebanon, plans to open three new banking and customs centers here along the Israeli-Lebanese border, and it is thinking of reviving an abandoned rail link with Lebanon.

title: A 17th-Century Monk Becomes a Saint
description: Pope John Paul II canonized his first saint Sunday: he is Crispin of Viterbo, a 17th-century Italian shoemaker who became a monk.

title: Advertising; Needham's Chief of USA Unit
description: KEITH Reinhard, the 47-year-old president of Needham, Harper & Steers in Chicago, has been named chairman and chief executive of Needham's newly established domestic company, Needham, Harper & Steers/USA. The unit is the principal component of the recently created NH&S Inc. holding company.

title: All-Female Crew Crosses Atlantic
description: Twelve French women have completed a trans-Atlantic sailboat race in what their captain said was the first such crossing by an all-female crew.

title: JAPAN'S PROGRAM FOR BALANCED GLOBAL DISARMAMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. C. Douglas Dillon Dead; Awarded the Legion of Honor
description: Phyllis Ellsworth Dillon, the wife of C. Douglas Dillon, former Secretary of the Treasury and Ambassador to France, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 71 years old.

title: Michigan and Union Fail in Concession Talks
description: Talks on concessions to avert a permanent or temporary layoff of 16,000 state employees broke down today. Negotiators for the state and its largest union of state employees said the union's call for increased job security remained unresolved.

title: Allen Hospitalized
description: Neil Allen, the Mets' relief pitcher, was admitted Sunday afternoon to New York's Roosevelt Hospital for tests to determine the cause of stomach problems that have bothered him for more than a week.

title: Cruguet Comes Back to Warm Greeting
description: ''The horse got tired,'' Jean Cruguet said after hopping off World Leader, who had finished sixth, 13 lengths behind the winner, in the seventh race at Belmont Park yesterday. ''I got tired at the same time.''

title: Bamberger, Swan Scuffle
description: Craig Swan's unhappiness with the Mets' travel arrangements - commercial rather than charter flights - led to a scuffle between the pitcher and Manager George Bamberger and his coaches in the Shea Stadium parking lot early today.

title: THE OASIS GOES DRY
description: The Israeli invasion of Lebanon has painfully highlighted the vulnerability of the Arab world. But others, too, have displayed something of themselves in all of this. The invasion told us something about the drift of things in the society that launched it, about the great confusion in the superpower that has become so much a part of that region's landscape, and about the delusions that military might gives rise to.

title: Purse Snatcher Chased and Slain
description: A 24-year-old purse snatcher was stabbed to death in the University Heights section of the Bronx last night when he was caught by a group of people who had been chasing him, the police said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review in Weekend on Friday of an art show at the Feldman Gallery misidentified the artist who made a mixed-media collage showing toxic waste dumps in New York State. The collage is by Alan Sonfist.

title: Baseball
description: Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens. The Mets will be facing Charlie Lea, the only French-born pitcher to hurl a no-hit game. (Radio - WMCA 570, WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee. Dave Righetti will face the Brewers for the first time since he won two games against them in the Eastern Division playoff series last October. (Radio - WABC, 770, 8:30 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Tigers, at Boston. Detroit has lost seven straight. (Television - Channel 7, 8:30 P.M.) Soccer World Cup tournament. First-round games in Spain: Algeria vs. Austria; Honduras vs. Northern Ireland; France vs. Kuwait. Television - Channel 41, 11 A.M., 2:45 P.M., 11 P.M.; 21 and 50, 6 P.M.; 13, midnight. Evenings programs, tape) Chase Soccer Cup. Finals of Long Island junior league, at Adelphi University, Garden City, L.I., 5:30 and 7 P.M. Tennis 105th All-England championships. First-round matches at Wimbledon. John McEnroe will attempt to win his second straight men's singles crown, and Martina Navratilova is top-seeded in the women's singles. McEnroe faces Van Winitsky at center court in the opening match. (Television - HBO, 5:30 and 11 P.M., taped highlights) Thoroughbred Racing Belmont Park, Elmont, L.I., 1 P.M. The $50,000 Twilight Tear at a mile has drawn a field of seven, including three of the nation's top older fillies, Love Sign, Andover Way and Prismatical. (Television - Sports-Channel, 7 P.M., tape) Monmouth Park, Oceanport, N.J., 1:30 P.M. Other Events Basketball: New York Pro Summer League, at Nat Holman Gymnasium, Convent Avenue and 138th Street, 6:30 and 8:30 P.M. Harness Racing: Meadowlands, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. (Television - Cablevision and MSG Cable, midnight, tape) Yonkers Raceway, Central and Yonkers Avenues, 8 P.M. Freehold (N.J.) Raceway, 1 P.M. Jai-Alai: Milford (Conn.)

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Ho Chi Minh City on June 7 about a visit there by Vietnam veterans gave an incorrect date for a meeting the veterans had with John H. Holdridge, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and the Pacific. It took place May 13.

title: The Baptist Switch
description: The Rev. Dr. Bailey Smith of Del City, Oklahoma, who left office last week as president of the Southern Baptist Convention, did not go gently into that good night. In the prepared text of his farewell address, he proclaimed it ''inexcusable'' for a Southern Baptist:

title: JOFFREY BALLET MAY MOVE TO COAST
description: The Joffrey Ballet, which has been based in New York City for 26 years, is negotiating a possible move to Los Angeles to become the resident dance company of the Los Angeles Music Center in July 1983.

title: IRVINE WARBURTON, FILM EDITOR
description: Irvine (Cotton) Warburton, an all-America football player in the 1930's and later a film editor who won an Academy Award, died today at Brotman Medical Center here. He was 70 years old.

title: FOR YOUNG MARINERS, A JOB QUEST IN TROUBLED SEAS
description: In 1978, when Bryan Fennell signed in as a plebe at the United States Merchant Marine Academy here, he felt that four years in a crisp white uniform at the nation's smallest military college was all he needed for a prestigious and profitable career in marine engineering.

title: Gain for Shamrock
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said it would receive $65 million in cash as part of a joint venture agreement with the Chemnor Corporation. Diamond Shamrock said that, under the previously announced deal, the companies would combine their electrochemical technology businesses into a new company named Eltech Systems.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article June 3 on the declining number of Roman Catholic priests in the United States incorrectly depicted the views of the Rev. Avery Dulles. Father Dulles has never advocated that priests be allowed to marry.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:30 P.M. Mets, sandwiched between Montreal and Philadelphia in the standing, have a total of 15 games with Expos and Phillies between now and Independence Day. They are hoping to break out of Eastern Division logjam and overtake St. Louis. Randy Jones (6-5) goes tonight against Dave Palmer (1-1). (Television - Channel 9 and SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.) Basketball New York Pro Summer League, at Nat Holman Gymnasium, Convent Avenue and 138th Street, 6:30 P.M. and 8:30 P.M. The league moved uptown this year with its past, present and future N.B.A. contingent. It was at Xavier High School on West 16th Street last year.

title: House Passes Changes For Tobacco Supports
description: The House approved legislation today requiring tobacco farmers to cover any future losses caused by Federal price supports and forcing nonfarm institutions to give up valuable tobacco production rights.

title: REGAN SOFTENS HIS CALL FOR REVIEW OF THE FED
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, while continuing to criticize the Federal Reserve Board's handling of the nation's money supply, said today that he sees little need now to bring the Fed under more direct control of the Administration.

title: Psychology Today Sets Cut in Circulation Base
description: Psychology Today, a Ziff-Davis publication, is cutting its circulation rate base to 850,000, from 1,175,000, with the October issue.

title: Novel of Rock World
description: The world of rock music - its machinations, gossip and compromises on the road to stardom - is the subject of a first novel, ''Walk on Glass,'' by Lisa Robinson, a reporter and radio interviewer.

title: GALLAGHER: RIGHT END OF THE LINE
description: It was not until breakfast time this morning that Raymond F. Gallagher won the promises he needed to run for comptroller on Mayor Koch's ticket.

title: Topics; Public Outreach; Pay-If-You-Will TV
description: Audiences that live outside big cities have a friend in the Federal Communications Commission. The regulatory agency voted last week to open the way for over-theair pay TV stations, like the Wometco Home Theatre, to serve less populous markets.

title: Hungary to Hold War Games
description: Soviet, Czechoslovak and Hungarian troops will stage military exercises in Hungary ''in the next few days,'' the official Hungarian press agency said today.

title: Cairo Offers to Provide A P.L.O. Political Base
description: President Hosni Mubarak said today that Egypt would be willing to allow the leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization to establish headquarters here provided that they conducted political work only.

title: Lockheed Agent
description: The Lockheed Corporation said it would pay an undisclosed amount to a former agent in Saudi Arabia as a result of arbitration.

title: Alfa Talks Said to Halt
description: The Mexican Government has withdrawn from talks on a possible Government purchase of about a dozen subsidiaries of the Alfa conglomerate, finance and banking sources said today. The sources said the Government preferred to await the disclosure late next month of the company's plans to foreign bankers, to whom it owes more than $2 billion.

title: Japan's Steel Output
description: Because of prolonged stagnation in domestic industry and sluggish exports, Japan's steel production will fall 5.2 percent, to about 24.6 million metric tons, in the July-September quarter from the previous three months, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. Exports are expected to go down 7.3 percent, to about 5.1 million tons.

title: 'DRUIDS' MARK SOLSTICE EUPHONIOUSLY
description: EVERY year, Charlie Morrow feels his Druidic oats and organizes a Summer Solstice Celebration under the auspices of his New Wilderness Foundation. This year's observance was the 10th, and it was dispatched with unaccustomed grandiosity. Mr. Morrow and his minions took over Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center from sunrise (5:23 A.M. yesterday) until 2 P.M., with a special blowout at 1:23 P.M., the actual moment at which the sun reached its northernmost point.

title: ARA Receives Iran Payment
description: ARA Services said that it had been awarded $416,085 from an account administered by the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal in The Hague.

title: Market Place; Buying Cheap, Holding Long
description: WITH few exceptions, most common stocks these days are trading at less than underlying values. But recession and a couple of wars have so affected the mood of the market that the low prices are drawing little enthusiasm from investors.

title: Sulu Sea Death Toll Mounts
description: Nine more bodies were recovered today from wreckage of the passenger ferry Queen Helen, which exploded and caught fire in shark-infested waters of the Sulu Sea Thursday, bringing the death toll to 36. Twelve people are still missing; 327 were saved. Officials are investigating whether the ferry was carrying arms to Moslem rebels in the Philippines.

title: DONOVAN SAYS HE WON'T QUIT, CRITICIZING 'VICIOUS ATTACKS'
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan, in his first extensive reponse to reports that he had ties to organized crime figures, said today that he had been the target of ''vicious attacks'' and declared that he did not intend to resign.

title: Chess: Arnold Cup Tourney Won By Norway's Leif Ogaard
description: The Arnold Cup Tournament in Gausdal, Norway, was won by the Norwegian international master Leif Ogaard with a 7-2 score. This gave Ogaard his second grandmaster norm. He needs one more to get the title.

title: SUPREME COURT EASES PATH OF THOSE FILING CIVIL RIGHTS ACTIONS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that an important civil rights law permitted individuals to sue state and local officials and agencies directly in Federal courts.

title: Baby Boy Windsor
description: ''The possibility of perfection,'' we said just a year ago, ''is, in the end, what a royal wedding is all about. It is inconceivable that the diamonds will be fake, the trumpets out of tune, or the horses spavined nags.''

title: Family Wins $5.5 Million; In Largest Lottery Payoff
description: A bank employee whose husband gave her $1 to bet in the Pennsylvania lottery has won $5.5 million. It was the largest single lottery payoff in the nation, the state Lottery Bureau announced today.

title: Kelley to Denver
description: Rich Kelley, who has played for New Orleans, New Jersey and Phoenix, will make his new home in Denver.

title: U.S. Move Due Today On New York Districts
description: The Justice Department told a special Federal court in Manhattan yesterday that the department would report by today on whether it approved a plan for reapportioning New York State's Assembly, Senate and Congressional district lines.

title: Bridge: Novices Occasionally Get A Deal Nobody Else Can
description: In all forms of duplicate and tournament play under its jurisdiction, the American Contract Bridge League rightly insists that every deal must be at random, whether it is generated by a computer, an official or the players at the table.

title: 'Last of the Blue Devils' To Start Forum Festival
description: The 10-day, six-feature Jazz Forum Film Festival will begin tomorrow with ''The Last of the Blue Devils'' and the New York premiere of ''Lambert & Co.''

title: Monica Brown Married To Robert Lamontagne
description: Monica G. Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Brown of Plandome, L.I., and Robert Albert Lamontagne, son of Mrs. David Lamontagne of Manchester, N.H., and the late Mr. Lamontagne, were married Saturday in the garden of the bridegroom's home in Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Jimmye Kinney, an Episcopal priest performed the ceremony.

title: SOVIET HUNGER STRIKER WILL GET VISA
description: The last of five people who had gone on hunger strikes in an effort to be allowed to join spouses in the West learned today that he would be allowed to join his wife in Baltimore.

title: Hinckley Will Be Sent To Hospital in Capital
description: St. Elizabeth's Hospital, where John W. Hinckley Jr. is expected to be sent, is a federally financed psychiatric facility providing care for the mentally ill. It is situated in one of the poorest neighborhoods in downtown Washington.

title: 0.6% RISE ESTIMATED FOR G.N.P.
description: The Government today reported the first official indication that the recession, which began last July, may be over.

title: PRINCESS OF WALES HAS BOY: CHARLES IS 'OVER THE MOON'
description: The Princess of Wales gave birth tonight to her first child, a boy, who comes second in line to the British throne after his father, Prince Charles.

title: BRIEFING
description: Ringing All the Changes

title: Rules Due On Satellite TV Service
description: The Federal Communications Commission is expected to approve this week the regulatory framework for the nation's first commercial television service delivered directly from satellites to homes.

title: Mother's Relief
description: Now that Elaine Zayak has a world figure-skating title and her driver's license, Jerri Zayak is wondering what's next. For as long as she can remember, Mrs. Zayak has been driving her daughter from their home in Paramus, N.J., to different ice rinks for workouts, shows and promotional appearances.

title: A Robot's Ramble
description: R eports filtering in from Madison Avenue over the weekend smacked of unreliable informants, possibly spaced out on the plethora of sci-fi and fantasy movies. There was this robot, the story went, being taken for a walk Friday near 75th Street.

title: ROSE GETS 3,771st HIT, TYING AARON FOR 2d
description: Pete Rose tied Hank Aaron for second place on baseball's career hitting list when he singled off Dave LaPoint of the St. Louis Cardinals in the sixth inning tonight.

title: New Sinatra Generation
description: J udging by their blue jeans, T-shirts and long hair, it was a safe bet that the many teen-agers at the head of the Carnegie Hall line yesterday were not die-hard Frank Sinatra fans. A very safe bet.

title: Ex-Student Said to Admit Role in Korean Arson
description: Moon Bu Shik, a 23-yearold former student of a Pusan theological seminary, admitted in court today that he was the leader of an arson attack in March on a United States Cultural Center in a protest against the South Korean Government, court sources said.

title: New Theater Company At Boston University
description: A resident theater company is being formed by Boston University, acccording to Gerald J. Gross, vice president and acting dean of the university's arts school.

title: U.S. STEEL TO CUT PAY OF 20,000 AIDES
description: The United States Steel Corporation, asserting that the steel industry ''is in its worst market crisis since the Great Depression,'' said yesterday that it would reduce salaries for its 20,000 management-level employees by at least 5 percent, effective July 1.

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE SEEKS $878 MILLION RATE INCREASE
description: The New York Telephone Company asked yesterday for $878 million in annual rate increases, including an average rise of 9.9 percent in the cost of home telephone service throughout the state.

title: 52 JOIN 6 FOREBEARS FOR GOLDEN WEDDING
description: Three Karnik sisters and three Suda brothers, who were married in a triple ceremony on June 21, 1932, celebrated their golden wedding anniversaries here Sunday.

title: Laurels for Bird
description: There was only one unanimous choice to the N.B.A.'s all-league team by a group of 69 sports reporters and broadcasters: Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics. The other players on the all-league team, announced at the N.B.A. meetings in Coronado, Calif., were Julius Erving of Philadelphia, Moses Malone of Houston, George Gervin of San Antonio and Gus Williams of Seattle.

title: Cash Discount Plan at Amoco
description: The Amoco Oil Company, noting that the gasoline prices of its dealers have been undercut by competitors such as Hess and Arco that do not take credit cards, said that it would cut its price to its dealers in the New York City area by 1.7 cents a gallon, allowing them to offer discounts for cash purchases.

title: ISRAEL LOOKS TO REBUILDING OF SHATTERED SOUTH
description: It will take six months to one year for the economy of southern Lebanon to return to normal, Israeli officials said today.

title: Administration Backs Altered Pesticide Rules
description: The Reagan Administration joined industry spokesmen today in supporting amendments to the Federal pesticide law that would change the rules on public access to information about the safety and health of pesticides.

title: MANAGING MONEY
description: We are in the worst recession since the 1930's. Nearly 10 percent of our workforce and 30 percent of our industrial capacity are idle. Real interest rates and Federal deficits have reached their highest levels in history. Dun & Bradstreet reports the highest number of business failures in a single week since 1932.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Which planet is the smallest in our solar system. Some reference books say it is Pluto and others say it is Mercury?

title: The U.N. Today; June 22, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Adoption in Ohio Upheld in Jersey
description: The State Supreme Court ruled today that a couple who had moved to New Jersey from Ohio could retain custody of their adopted daughter, even though an Ohio court had ordered her returned to her natural mother.

title: Italy Holds Terror Suspect
description: A part-time teacher believed sympathetic to West German terrorist causes was arrested carrying a bomb in a suitcase with a false bottom at Rome's Leonardo da Vinci Airport, authorities said today. Police sources said the woman, who flew in from Bucharest Friday, declared herself a ''political prisoner'' and refused to answer questions. She was identified as Christa Margot Frohlich, 40 years old, a resident of Hanover, West Germany.

title: FLORIDA REBUFFS EQUAL RIGHTS BID
description: The state Senate took a little more than two hours today to serve notice that Florida would not ratify the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

title: INTRUDER KILLS 2 WORKERS IN THE FINANCIAL DISTRICT
description: An office manager and an underwriter employed by separate insurance companies were shot and slashed to death in a fierce struggle with an assailant in a washroom near their offices on the 20th floor of a tower in Manhattan's financial district yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: LOW-TAR RIVALRY HEATS UP
description: The bitter competition in selling low-tar cigarettes has broken out into a dispute among the big tobacco companies, with charges and countercharges of unfair marketing practices.

title: 322 Refugees Arrive In Paris From Lebanon
description: An Air France jetliner carrying 322 European and American refugees from Lebanon arrived in Paris today. On board were 44 Americans, 22 Britons and a number of West Germans, Canadians, Spaniards, Italians and French nationals. The 322, who were evacuated from Lebanon by French military personnel, were taken by a French warship to Cyprus before boarding a special Air France flight for Paris.

title: U.S. MILITARY OPERATIONS IN SPACE TO BE EXPANDED UNDER AIR FORCE
description: The Air Force announced today that it had formed a Space Command to expand United States military operations in space, including future shuttle flights with national security missions.

title: ARGENTINE JUNTA APPEARS AT ODDS
description: Leaders of the Argentine Air Force today strenuously opposed efforts by the army to install a retired general as President and joined with the navy in calling for a for a civilian to fill the post.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED ON 'HIT MAN'
description: The sheriff of Broward County says his detectives may have been mistaken when they described a 37-year-old suspect as one of the top professional killers in the United States.

title: Consumer Backed in Mental Health Case
description: The Supreme Court today expanded the ability of consumers to bring damage suits in cases charging violations of Federal antitrust law, even when higher prices have not resulted.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY VOTES DEATH-PENALTY BILL, 54-19
description: After more than four hours of emotional debate, the New Jersey Assembly late today approved a bill restoring the death penalty in the state for some types of murder.

title: WHO GETS THE FOOD STAMPS IN NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DEFENSE GUIDANCE PLAN IS NO SABER-RATTLER
description: T o the Editor: No one could argue that the question of peace is one of the most important in this land. But the public discussion necessary to decide prudently how best to maintain and preserve peace is not advanced - indeed it is positively retarded - by Op-Ed articles such as those by Professors Bethe and Gottfried and by Cecil Currey (June 10).

title: Cambodian Exiles Plan To Sign Accord Today
description: Leaders of the three main Cambodian factions opposing Vietnam assembled here today to sign an agreement establishing a government in exile. The signing was expected to take place Tuesday.

title: A FLOWER SHOP FOR BROWSING
description: It began in the mid-1970's, when two graduate students of landscaping and horticulture sat around a cafeteria table at Temple University in Philadelphia and talked about what they'd like to do with their lives. After six years of various endeavors, Sheila Okun and Mary Fritz are doing exactly what they had wanted at school.

title: BRIEFING
description: Sticky Questions Disowned

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WHAT PRICE A WAITER'S LIFE?
description: We have more lawyers per acre than any other country in the world -one for every 450 people - so maybe it's only natural, in our ultralitigious society, that they get blamed for a lot of things. On the other hand, maybe -by the reluctance of the majority to discipline the seamy minority -they've brought their tattered image upon themselves.

title: The Winner on Film
description: Five months after he lost a decision to Eusebio Pedroza in a title fight at Atlantic City, Juan LaPorte has been ruled the winner - but not necessarily the new featherweight champion of the World Boxing Association. Joe Walcott, New Jersey's boxing commissioner, reversed the outcome of the bout because, having reviewed the films, he felt that Pedroza should have been disqualified for flagrant fouls. Walcott, who once held the world heavyweight championship, has written a letter to the W.B.A. recommending a rematch, inasmuch as his ruling does not summarily affect the association's position on the fight.

title: Allen-Bradley Deal
description: The Allen-Bradley Company, the Milwaukee-based manufacturer and marketer of industrial automation control products, announced today that it had reached an agreement with Oy Stromberg of Helsinki, Finland, to market and service the Finnish company's line of high-horsepower, alternating-current drives in North America. Allen-Bradley, a privately held concern with 1981 sales of $700 million, did not disclose the terms of the transaction, which is to take effect July 1.

title: DEFENDANT SMILES, JURY IS IMPASSIVE
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., as he heard the judge intone the verdict, count by count, seemed stunned at first at what he heard.

title: 18 Are Reported Killed In Guatemalan Violence
description: At least 18 people, including two mayors, were killed over the weekend in political violence in Guatemala, the police said today.

title: China Denounces U.S.  For Presence in Korea
description: Defense Minister Geng Biao of China demanded today that the United States pull out of South Korea and said China and North Korea would share ''life and death in the same boat'' no matter what the future holds, the official North Korean press agency reported today.

title: D.D.B. Gets Reese's
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation, which gave its first assignments to Doyle Dane Bernbach four years ago, has given it some additional business. It is for Reese's Pieces, formerly at Ogilvy & Mather. Leading National Advertising puts the budget at about $3 million.

title: Suspect Surrenders in Killing That Followed Auto Mishap
description: A man wanted in the fatal shooting of a motorist over a minor traffic accident in Brooklyn Sunday surrendered to the police yesterday and was charged with second-degree murder, the police said.

title: ON WOMEN IN LEGISLATURES
description: Ten years ago Norma Paulus, then a Republican member of the Oregon House of Representatives, told a national conference of women who were legislators that when women began running against each other for public office, ''we'll have made great strides.''

title: BONN SEEKS SHIFT ON GAS CURB
description: West Germany said today that it had begun talks with the United States in an effort to get it to reverse its decision to widen restrictions on the use of American-developed equipment in a projected natural gas pipeline between Western Europe and the Soviet Union.

title: BARRIER TO NUCLEAR PLANTS IN A STATE SET FOR REVIEW
description: The Supreme Court, accepting a case with important implications for development of nuclear power as a source of electricity, agreed today to decide whether a state may impose a ''moratorium'' on the construction of nuclear power plants.

title: F.B.I. IN CITY ARRESTS 4 IN PLOTS TO EXPORT ARMS TO I.R.A. UNITS
description: Two men were arrested in New York City yesterday on charges of conspiring to purchase and export weapons and munitions, including surface-to-air missiles, for use by the Provisional Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland, Federal authorities said.

title: Beclouded
description: S ummer stumbled into town at 1:23 P.M. yesterday. Under skies of intermittent gray, no one noticed.

title: Sibling Rivalry At Wimbledon
description: W hen the scoreboard at Wimbledon features the names ''Evert-Lloyd'' and ''Goolagong-Cawley'' this week, it won't be listing a women's singles match.

title: Allied Stores Plan
description: Allied Stores Corporation said that it would combine the management and merchandising staffs of Stern's and Gertz, its two store divisions in the metropolitan area, but would retain their individual identities. Stern's operates seven stores in New Jersey and Gertz has eight stores in Queens and on Long Island. An Allied spokesman said no decision had been reached yet on how many employees might be displaced by the move.

title: Palestinians in Beirut Detain 5 U.S. Reporters
description: Five American reporters were detained for questioning here today by leftist Palestinian militiamen. They were released two and a half hours later after the Palestinians had apparently satisfied themselves that the Americans were not Israeli intruders.

title: Cheever's Funeral Is Today
description: John Cheever will be buried Tuesday near his parents in the First Parish Cemetery at Norwell, Mass. The Pulitzer-winning author died Friday at his home here. A ceremony, conducted by the Rt. Rev. John Gallop of St. John the Evangelist Church in Bingham, Mass., will be held at the cemetery at 1 P.M.

title: Banc One Sets Ohio Takeover
description: The Banc One Corporation, a bank holding company in Columbus, Ohio, yesterday announced an agreement to acquire the Dayton-based Winters National Corporation for $122.1 million in stock. The merger would raise Banc One's assets to $6.2 billion, from $4.6 billion, and make it Ohio's largest banking organization.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've spoken with Charles, and he's absolutely over the moon.'' - Earl Spencer, grandfather of the royal baby. (A1:2.)

title: 6 Oil States in Pact
description: Finance and economy ministers from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates have agreed to abolish customs tariffs on national products and apply new and freer transit and travel regulations from Dec. 1, the official Saudi press agency said today.

title: Law Permits a Gift For Jersey Police
description: Governor Kean signed legislation today that allowed the state to accept a gift of $180,000 for the purchase of 800 bulletproof vests for the state police.

title: GOAL DISPUTE MARS VICTORY BY FRANCE
description: In a game that produced the first major controversy of the World Cup soccer tournament, France defeated Kuwait, 4-1, today and improved its chances of advancing to the second round.

title: Japanese Film Series Opens at Public Today
description: As if their industrial conquests were not enough, the Japanese have taken over Joseph Papp's summer film program. From today to Sept. 23, the Public Theater festival will be all Japanese.

title: EUROPEANS WEIGH SANCTIONS FOR ISRAELIS
description: The foreign ministers of the Common Market worked today on what is expected to be a major Middle East declaration that might include a call for economic sanctions against Israel because of its invasion of Lebanon.

title: Georgia Prisoners End Day of Disturbances
description: Hundreds of prisoners set fires, seized five buildings and destroyed ''everything that wasn't nailed down'' at the Coastal Correctional Institute today in a protest of grievances ranging from the treatment of visitors to a shortage of soap.

title: 4 Annual Andy Awards Go to Needham, Harper
description: The Advertising Club of New York sponsored the Annual Andy Awards last night at the Sheraton Centre. Needham, Harper & Steers, with four awards, was the top winner.

title: RESEARCH BATTLE STIRS TURMOIL
description: WASHINGTON LIKE many of his colleagues at the Heritage Foundation, the conservative research organization, Dr. George C. Roche 3d favors abolishing the Department of Education, the National Institute of Education and the policy-making National Council on Educational Research - of which Dr. Roche himself was recently named chairman by President Reagan.

title: GENIAL WAR FOR ISRAELIS NEAR BEIRUT
description: Despite the artillery and rocket exchanges that break out from time to time around Beirut, most of the Israeli troops who have besieged the Lebanese capital exist in a strange environment of remoteness from the war.

title: Required Reading; Plumber's Lesson
description: Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, in an address before the Tennessee Bar Association, Memphis:

title: MUSIC: A GOOD PREMIERE
description: ONLY some music being played outdoors this summer is legitimate outdoor music -music that is scored and written with incisive attacks, unison emphases, broad gestures and buoyant clear rhythms that can project across large open spaces.

title: DOW EDGES UP 1.33, TO 789.95
description: The stock market, which has been declining almost steadily for the last six weeks, made a small technical advance yesterday in active trading.

title: G.T.E.'S CELLULAR PACT WITH A.T.&T.
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation today disclosed details of its agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to provide cellular radio telephone service to 29 of the nation's 30 largest cities.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Agripost Inc. announced that the effective date for its $18.5 million offering of 15.5 percent, 15-year debentures was June 18.

title: FRENCH GENERATOR PACT
description: Alsthom-Atlantique S.A. said today that Electricite de France had placed two firm orders and four options on eight sets of 1,300-megawatt turbo generators. The company did not state the value of the order but said that the generators used French technology only.

title: ANDERSON TESTS A SPRINGBOARD FOR '84
description: The office is just upstairs, past the living room, up the wide staircase, beside his daughter's bedroom. John B. Anderson, the renegade Republican who ran for President as an independent in 1980, is there most mornings these days.

title: Gold in New York Rally After Decline Abroad
description: A spate of heavy selling by Hong Kong bullion dealers early yesterday caused gold futures to tumble later in Europe and then in this country before a late rally on New York's Commodity Exchange wiped out most of the losses. Comex silver futures, which have recently been influencing the gold market, followed bullion down yesterday.

title: 'GOOSE MENACE' LEADS TO RAID IN JERSEY
description: A combined force of Federal, state and local agents swooped down on Loantaka Pond today, startling early-morning joggers and dog walkers and scaring the honk and quack out of the geese and ducks.

title: Changing Times
description: The Knicks have decided to change the starting time of their games on Saturday nights from 8:05 to 7:35, the same as on week nights.

title: ADOLFO COTEREIE TURNS UP TO SEE AND BE SEEN
description: Adolfo fans convened yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel as much to pay homage to their favorite designer and to see what other women had bought as to see his latest fashion collection. A lot of them have already made their fall selections since they like to get their shopping for the next season out of the way before they go on summer vacation. (His best-known client, Nancy Reagan, usually shops in September, ''but we make her choices quickly,'' Adolfo said.)

title: REAGAN DISCLAIMS DRAFT OF REPORT ON URBAN POLICY
description: A draft report asserting that Federal aid had harmed the cities is not Administration policy, President Reagan said today. ''I pledge that the Federal Government will not abandon its partnership with the nation's cities,'' he said.

title: 1,300 ARRESTED IN CALIFORNIA ANTINUCLEAR PROTEST
description: More than 1,300 antinuclear protesters were arrested today in a nonviolent demonstration at the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, one of two facilities in the nation where nuclear weapons are designed.

title: Mrs. Thatcher to Visit Reagan To Discuss Falkland Islands
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain will visit Washington on Wednesday afternoon to discuss the Falkland Islands situation with President Reagan, the White House said today.

title: In Lieu Of
description: Some call it the powder room. Others call it the down-the-hallfirst door-to-your-right.

title: President of Ogden Stresses Flexibility
description: The Ogden Corporation supplies food for the Concorde. It owns an ocean shipping fleet. It builds ships and rail freight cars. It owns Progresso soups and spaghetti. It owns scrap yards and machine shops and many more disparate businesses. In short, it is a highly diversified conglomerate.

title: Nuclear Plant Denied Operating License
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today refused to issue an operating license for the $1.5 billion Zimmer Nuclear Power Station near Cincinnati.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY ISN'T JUST MIDDLE-CLASS
description: To the Editor:

title: WATSON'S NEXT GOAL IS P.G.A.
description: Shortly after he won his first United States Open golf tournament Sunday, Tom Watson was asked: ''Why have you never won the P.G.A. championship?''

title: Pat Nixon In Hospital
description: Pat Nixon, the wife of former President Richard M. Nixon, was admitted Sunday night to Valley Hospital here with a pulmonary infection and was resting comfortably today, hospital officials said.

title: Chile to Sell State Concerns
description: Chile will accept bids for eight state-owned companies in an effort to halt its recession, the finance and economy ministries said today.

title: Insurer to Acquire William Penn Life
description: The Continental Corporation, a large insurance company based in New York, announced that one of its units would acquire the William Penn Life Insurance Company of New York for more than $20 million. William Penn is a subsidiary of the Massachusetts Indemnity and Life Insurance Company, which in turn is a unit of Penncorp Financial Inc.

title: Publisher of The Dial To Leave the Magazine
description: Richard B. Barthelmes, 43, publisher of The Dial magazine since March 1981, is leaving the magazine because of ''philosophical differences,'' he said.

title: Italy Acts In Bank Case
description: The Italian Government tried to head off financial panic today following the apparent suicide of Roberto Calvi, former president of Italy's largest private bank, Banco Ambrosiano.

title: HIGH COURT TO REVIEW DISPUTED JERSEY PLAN FOR ELECTION DISTRICTS
description: New Jersey's disputed new Congressional districts, from which the state's voters will elect 14 members of Congress this year, will receive a definitive review in the United States Supreme Court next year.

title: Indiana Standard Pact
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) will invest a minimum of $22 million in oil exploration off the Mediterranean coast of Morocco under an accord signed here, officials said today. Exploration will be carried out under two permits totaling about 10,000 square kilometers.

title: SUICIDE ATTEMPTS REPORTED RISING AMONG HAITIANS IN U.S. DETENTION
description: Federal officials say they have observed a sharp increase in psychiatric problems, especially depression and suicidal behavior, among Haitians detained at camps in Florida and Puerto Rico.

title: American General Sues NLT
description: The American General Corporation said yesterday that it had filed suits in four states asking for preliminary injunctions against the ''early pay'' provisions of the NLT Corporation's takeover bid for American General.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page Satur- day incorrectly described New York regulation of automobile insurance rates. All insurance rates for private passenger autos are subject to prior approval by the State Insurance De- partment. In Connecticut, present law requires prior approval of auto liabil- ity and no-fault coverage; on July 1, 1983, the requirement will end.

title: A Bus Too Small; For Carey and Koch
description: P oliticians have a way of elbowing each other, even when they insist they are doing no such thing. Word went out the other day that Mayor Koch would appear outside City Hall tomorrow, accompanied by a prototype of a new bus built to Transit Authority specifications by Hino, the Japanese manufacturer.

title: MATH LESSON FROM JAPAN
description: AMERICANS like to ascribe the superiority of Japanese children in mathematics to rigid discipline and concentration on the ''Three R's.'' But Dr. Jack Easley, an expert in mathematics and science education at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, has exploded that myth.

title: A Mighty Barrier: 6 Inches of Grass
description: I t is only 209 yards from the tee to the hole, but the 17th green at the Pebble Beach Golf Links is protected like a fortress, by land and by sea: bunkers, rough grass and the Pacific Ocean. And, when Tom Watson hit his 2-iron from the tee, with the United States Open championship at stake, everybody followed the ball as it carried to the right of the green.

title: Famous Parents
description: The first offspring of Seattle Slew are 2-year-olds and have begun racing in New York, and Spectacular Bid's first batch of foals were born this spring. But the most eagerly awited progeny of the superhorses of the 1970's are from the crop in between: They are now yearlings, the first sons and daughters of Affirmed and Alydar.

title: The Buck Pass War
description: With Yankee ingenuity, Connecticut's General Assembly has found a new stratagem to wage the New Federalism war against the Reagan Administration.

title: FOR SHUTTLE THE LAST TEST LOOMS, CLOAKED IN MILITARY SECRECY
description: THE space shuttle Columbia is standing on its launching pad once again, ready for its fourth and final test flight, and packed inside its cargo bay is a payload with a symbolic message. It is a military payload and classified secret. It marks an end of innocence for United States manned space flight and the beginning of a union between the civilian and military space programs.

title: PRESS CLUB RENOVATION
description: T he National Press Building, two blocks from the White House, is undergoing a $40 million facelift that indicates how booming the news business is in the capital. The big news, beyond the reassuring bulletin that the press club bar will remain open through three years of construction dust, is that the renovated building will no longer have room for public relations and advertising specialists.

title: THERE IS STILL TIME TO MAKE SAFETY A 'MUST' IN THE WORKPLACE
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL PREOCCUPIED WITH MEN AT WAR
description: Few people in Israel speak of the astronomical cost of the invasion of Lebanon or of such inconveniences as being called up to active military duty and less-frequent bus service.

title: A FREEZE BASED ON LIFE WISH, NOT TRUST
description: To the Editor:

title: Chesebrough
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. said that it had agreed in principle to acquire Prince Manufacturing Inc., a closely owned maker of tennis rackets, for $62 million in Chesebrough common stock. Sales of Prince rackets are expected to reach $60 million this year, up from $34.9 million last year, Chesebrough said.

title: CAREY TELLS STATE DEMOCRATS TO CAMPAIGN ON HIS RECORD
description: Governor Carey, in a speech today to the party that twice nominated him for New York State's highest office, urged Democrats to run on his record.

title: CANCELED SUBSIDY STIRS CLASH ON PRESS FREEDOM IN MEXICO
description: The Mexican Government's decision to withdraw all official advertising from two leftist magazines has been protested by journalists here as an attack on freedom of the press.

title: G.N.P. Falls 2% in Canada
description: Canada's gross national product - the value of all goods and services produced and sold in the country -fell by 2 percent in the first quarter of the year after inflation is taken into account, the Government's statistics agency reported today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alberta Energy Corp. said it had begun its offer to purchase 7 million shares of Chieftain Development Co. for $24 (Canadian) each.

title: NEW STUDY SUPPORTS THE SOCIAL SCIENCES
description: MUCH conventional management wisdom (often meaning whatever the boss thinks) has it that an outfit that is tightly controlled from the top works best. Take up the slack, cut out the fat, get everyone in step, streamline the goals and the result is success, vitality, profits, winning, or whatever else allows the boss to sleep well at night.

title: POP: SPRINGFIELD, PIED PIPER
description: AFTER toiling in the outback of rock-and-roll for more than a decade, Rick Springfield, the Australian-born singer and soap-opera star, has emerged as the most popular rock performer among teenyboppers since the heyday of the Cassidy brothers. Roughly two-thirds of the audience at his Saturday show, the second of three sold-out concerts at Carnegie Hall over the weekend, were pubescent girls less than half Mr. Springfield's age, and their hysterically rapturous response brought back memories of Beatlemania.

title: Insider Trade Charges Filed
description: Kenneth and Aaron Rubinstein, both New York lawyers, have been charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with profiting from inside information that Kenneth Rubinstein obtained while working on corporate mergers.

title: TOP OFFICIAL AT TREASURY RESIGNING
description: Norman B. Ture, the architect of last year's tax cut and the leading advocate of supply-side economics in the Reagan Administration, today announced his resignation, effective June 30.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 22, 1982
description: International American and Israeli positions on long-range objectives in Lebanon appeared close after three hours of talks by President Reagan and Prime Minister Menachem Begin. The two leaders agreed that all foreign troops, including Israeli and Syrian forces, should be withdrawn from Lebanon as part of a long-term solution guaranteeing Israel from attack from Lebanese soil. The Administration voiced no public criticism of Israel's invasion of Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israeli forces bombarded Palestinian camps and civilian neighborhoods in the western part of Beirut while Israeli and Syrian troops traded fire along the Beirut-Damascus highway. Police sources said that seven persons had been killed and 55 injured in the shelling, which damaged the Soviet Embassy compound. (A1:5.)

title: Senate Confirms Jersey School Chief
description: The New Jersey Senate today confirmed the nomination of the Madison Schools Superintendent, Saul Cooperman, as the state's Education Commissioner.

title: NEW LAW ON INSANITY PLEA STIRS DISPUTE IN ALASKA
description: In a Criminal Court matter of unusual significance in Alaska, Charles Meach 3d, charged with killing four teenagers in a park, entered a plea June 15 of ''not guilty because of mental disease or defect.''

title: REGAN AND BEGIN APPEAR IN ACCORD ON LEBANON STEPS
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel agreed today that all foreign troops - including Israeli and Syrian forces - should be withdrawn from Lebanon as part of a long-term solution to protect Israel from attack from Lebanese territory.

title: The Economy
description: The first official indication that the recession may be over was reported by the Commerce Department. It said that the preliminary ''flash'' estimate for the gross national product rose at an annual rate of 0.6 percent in the second quarter, after adjustment for inflation. The increase, based on incomplete data, would be the first for the G.N.P. since the July-September quarter of last year. (Page D1.)

title: TV SPORTSNeil Amdur
description: WIMBLEDON, England M ore than ever, American television viewers will be able to savor the grandeur and greatness of the Wimbledon tennis championships, which began yesterday at the historic All England Club.

title: HAIG-CLARK FEUD EMERGING OVER FOREIGN POLICY
description: Three weeks ago in Paris, in the course of President Reagan's trip to Europe, William P. Clark, his national security adviser, and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. confronted each other several times in several days in what aides described as ''shouting matches'' on several issues.

title: Doctor Hails Hinckley Verdict
description: The verdict of not guilty in the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. is a victory for modern psychiatry, according to an assistant professor of psychiatry at Harvard University who was one of the leading defense witnesses in the trial.

title: STAGE: LONDON'S 'CATS,' A NEW WEBBER MUSICAL
description: Over the last decade, the young composer Andrew Lloyd Webber conducted a tireless campaign to prove that, yes, the British can create contemporary musicals as sleek and snazzy as Broadway's. Certainly it can be argued that he has made his case. With two successful shows in New York right now, ''Evita'' and ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat,'' and a third, ''Cats,'' arriving at the Winter Garden next October, Mr. Webber is almost as dominant a force in the American musical theater as he is in England's.

title: HINKLEY IS CLEARED BUT IS HELD INSANE IN REAGAN ATTACK
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. tonight was found not guilty by reason of insanity on all 13 charges of shooting President Reagan and three other men on March 30, 1981.

title: DILEMMA FOR UNION TRUCKERS
description: Last week in Carteret, N.J., 12 teamsters were manning a picket line in front of the main trucking terminal that houses, among others, the local operations of Hemingway Transport Inc., one of the nation's oldest regional trucking companies.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: THE scene: A medical school professor is lecturing to a virtually empty classroom and a spinning tape recorder. As the talk ends, one of the few students present retrieves the recorder and prepares to transcribe the lecture and to distribute copies to classmates who stayed away.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The World Food Council, a United Nations body, says that imbalances in international food supplies are leading to increased hunger and severe malnutrition, now affecting 400 million people around the world.

title: Mark Aguirre's Reformation
description: CHICAGO T he summer league basketball game was already into the first few minutes on a recent night when Mark Aguirre, the star forward of the Dallas Mavericks, came up from the locker room.

title: SHRINKING U.A.W. TRIES TO STEER A STEADY COURSE THROUGH TROUBLED TIMES
description: Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers, was sitting in his office at Solidarity House here. He had with him, in the manner of an accountant, several large white sheets listing the union's membership figures.

title: Accounts
description: * House of Seagram to Mingo-Jones Advertising for minority advertising on Lord Calvert Canadian, Burnett's Gin, Calvert Extra and Kijafa Danish Wine.

title: Allow Drug Tests
description: S adly, reports of cocaine use in the National Football League continue. But even more sadly, Ed Garvey, the executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association, continues to resist drug-testing methods that may preserve the futures, if not the lives, of many players.

title: JOYFUL CHEERS ATTEND THE ROYAL BIRTH
description: A long day of waiting for a royal birth ended tonight. A crowd of about 500 people waving Union Jacks and holding bottles of champagne cheered the arrival of the second-in-line to the throne shortly after 9 P.M., when the word flashed through the crowd that it was a boy.

title: CLASS OF '82 MULLS BENEFITS OF WEALTH AT SUBURBAN HIGH
description: The real estate advertisements simply say, ''Mam Pub Schs.'' For house-hunting parents, that promises the Mamaroneck public school system, with its own television station, its advanced placement courses, its graduates in the Ivy League and its per-pupil financing that is nearly twice the national average.

title: TOPICS FROM WASTE TO WESTWAY FILL OUT LEGISLATURE'S AGENDA
description: While leaders of the political parties have been busy selecting their statewide tickets, top legislative officials have been busy preparing for what they hope will be the final weeks of the legislative session.

title: FOR THE SECOND TIME SPAIN DELAYS OPENING OF THE GATES TO GIBRALTAR
description: The Government of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo decided today for the second time in two months to put off the opening of the gates to Gibraltar, closed by the Franco regime in 1969, as well as negotiations on the future of the British colony.

title: New Ranger Farm
description: The Rangers announced yesterday that they had signed a one-year working agreement with the Tulsa Oilers of the Central Hockey League.

title: Soft Bifocal Lens By Ciba Approved
description: Ciba Vision Care, a division of Ciba Geigy of Switzerland, said that the Food and Drug Administration had approved its bifocal soft contact lens for marketing.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: SUMMER is finally here, which is usually the signal for stores to g et in their fall stocks. But this year there is a slight difference.O h, fall clothes are in the windows, all right, but only a smatteringo f corduroys, gabardines and dark silks are in most departments. T here is very little room for them because there is so much summer m erchandise left.

title: BALLET: A RADIANT GALA CHARITY EVENT
description: THERE were three memorable moments at ''A Diamond Night at the Ballet,'' a charity gala that assembled an international array of dancers Sunday night in the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Sophia Loren to Start Wertmuller's 'Tieta'
description: Sophia Loren recently returned to Italy and to a brief term in jail for tax evasion. The reason for her return, more specifically, was to make ''Tieta,'' according to a spokesman for her.

title: S.E.C. Investigates Northwest Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating February trading in the shares of Northwest Industries, looking for possible manipulation or trading irregularities in Northwest's $375 million tender offer for its own shares, some targets of the investigation said today.

title: THE DEMOCRATS DESIGNATE KOCH FOR STATEHOUSE
description: The Democratic State Committee selected Mayor Koch today as its favored candidate for governor of New York, but qualified Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to challenge him in the September primary.

title: RIGHETTI FOILED BY 2 HOME RUNS
description: The most expensive collection of singles hitters in baseball history encountered this year's most prodigious home-run hitting team tonight. The home-run hitters won.

title: TREASURY BILL RATES ADVANCE
description: Three- and six-month Treasury bills were auctioned yesterday at their highest rates since early spring. In secondary trading, however, Government securities prices rose slightly as yields declined. Dealers said the improved market tone was essentially a technical response to the sharp price drops of last week.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt FAMOUS LAST WORDS. By Timothy Findley. 396 pages. Delacorte/Law- rence. $14.95.

title: DAY BY DAY
description: Whose Dime Was It?

title: Heinz Net Off 5.4% in Period
description: The H.J. Heinz Company said today that net income in its fiscal fourth quarter fell 5.4 percent from a year earlier, but earnings for the full year rose 19.9 percent.

title: Occidental Life Picks Chief Operating Officer
description: The Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that David R. Carpenter had been elected president and chief operating officer, in a promotion that underscored the company's commitment to marketing, analysts said. Mr. Carpenter, 43, had served since December as executive vice president and chief marketing officer of the Los Angeles-based company.

title: Semiconductor Loss in Quarter
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation reported a fiscal fourthquarter loss of $3.1 million, reversing a profit of $12.6 million, or 55 cents a share, in the comparable 1981 period.

title: News Analysis
description: Two and a half years after she was enthusiastically voted back to power from the brink of political banishment and the threat of imprisonment, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi remains the single national political figure with large popular appeal in virtually all parts of India.

title: FINALLY, THE SMALL BITS OF ANCIENT EGYPT ARE UNPACKED
description: FOR 10 years, a largely unnoticed archeological expedition has been searching for Egyptian antiquities at a site seen only by a few. The expedition has been conducted far from the fertile mud of the Nile Basin and the sun-bright sand of the desert. There are no sunburned archeologists carefully sifting small bits of stone and earth for clues about the persisting enigma of ancient Egypt.

title: Substituting Stealth for 'Stealth'
description: The oldest military game in Washington is pushing the cheap weapons system that proves expensive later - too late to save much by abandoning it. It's rarely admitted, but budget ''overruns'' often stem from initial understatements. Something that looks, smells and sounds like an admission of such stealth has just been extracted from the Pentagon on the B-1 strategic bomber.

title: ISRAEL BOMBARDS REFUGEE CAMPS IN WEST BEIRUT
description: Israeli warships and armored units bombarded Palestinian camps and civilian neighborhoods in the western half of Beirut today, while Israeli and Syrian ground troops traded fire along the Beirut-Damascus highway.

title: People
description: * J. William Grimes has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network, a subsidiary of the Getty Oil Company.

title: Alexander Chancellor
description: -The British are so grateful that the Falkland Islands war is over that the question of whether it was worth fighting now seems almost irrelevant. But before I go into that issue, it must be said that victory came as a huge relief for everybody.

title: SATELLITE TO SURVEY NATURAL RESOURCES
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - A sophisticated new satellite to survey the Earth's natural resources has been scheduled for launch from California July 9.

title: The Sour Politics of Sugar
description: Congress has long been sweet on the sugar lobby, protecting domestic growers at the expense of consumers and foreign producers. In recent months, however, this incredibly wasteful program has become an embarrassment to all but the most diehard. Senators Quayle and Tsongas hope to take advantage of this change in mood, by cutting back on price supports and reducing the damage to United States trade partners in the Caribbean.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Wasp Virus Defense

title: BALLET: ELISA MONTE'S JUDITH
description: CAN a dancer transform a dance? Elisa Monte came close to making something transcendent of ''Judith'' in a performance by the Martha Graham Dance Company at the City Center Sunday afternoon.

title: IRAN SAYS IRAQIS' WITHDRAWAL WON'T END WAR
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, said in a radio broadcast today that the war with Iraq would not end even if the Iraqis left Iranian territory. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq announced the beginning of the withdrawal on Sunday and said it would be completed within 10 days.

title: Swift to Purchase Slaughtering Plant
description: The Swift Independent Packing Company, the processor of fresh meat that was spun off by Esmark Inc., announced that it had tentatively agreed to acquire an idle boxed-beef plant at Hereford, Tex., from Armour & Company. The price was not disclosed.

title: Exxon Cutback
description: The Exxon Corporation wants to cut its staff because of poor economic conditions, company officials said.

title: U.S. Oil Imports to Rise
description: The Energy Department forecast United States net oil imports would increase from 3.7 million barrels a day in the first half of 1982 to 5.4 million barrels a day in the second half. It forecast a 3 percent drop in petroleum consumption in 1982 compared with 1981.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board opened a hearing yesterday into the trainer P.G. Johnson's appeal of his 60-day suspension because of positive findings of a drug in one of his horses at Saratoga last August. ... Burt Hooton, Los Angeles Dodger pitcher, underwent surgery to remove a bone spur from his right knee and was placed on the 21-day disabled list.

title: The Graveyard Shift
description: S o menacing is Times Square late at night that the neighborhood's most prominent employer has begun busing its workers out of the immediate area after midnight.

title: Allen in U.S.F.L.
description: George Allen, whose odyssey in pro football has already taken him across the continent and then north to Canada, was named head coach and part-owner of the Chicago franchise in the new United States Football League yesterday. The 60-year-old Allen, who as a head coach made winners of the Los Angeles Rams and the Washington Redskins before his brief tenure as chief executive of the ill-fated Montreal Alouettes earlier this year, is the third big-name coach to join the fledgling league, following Chuck Fairbanks at New York and Red Miller at Denver.

title: Peugeot May Get Japan Tie
description: Peugeot S.A., France's second-largest automaker after Renault, has asked the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation to jointly produce small Mitsubishi-style cars in France, the economic newspaper Nihon Keizai reported yesterday.

title: U.S. SETS NEW RULES FOR WARNING LABELS ON TAMPON BOXES
description: The Government announced new rules today requiring tampon manufacturers to warn women that tampon use is associated with toxic shock syndrome, a serious and sometimes deadly disease.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Smoking and Heart Risk

title: CARTER CLOUTS 2, DRIVING IN 3
description: The way the game turned out, it was not that important that Pete Falcone started for the Mets last night with just one day of rest and had problems for the second straight start.

title: Ellis Island Commission
description: C an Lee Iacocca do for Ellis Island what he is doing for Chrysler? The question arises with the formation of a 21-member Presidential commission of private citizens, headed by the Chrysler Corporation's chairman, to help the Administration restore Ellis Island and maintain the Statue of Liberty on nearby Liberty Island. Mr. Iacocca's own parents emigrated from Europe by way of Ellis Island.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Volkswagen Sales Off
description: The Volkswagen Company's worldwide group sales fell to 948,883 vehicles in the first five months of this year, 8.1 percent below the figure for the same period last year, a company spokesman said today. He said the company faces its biggest problems in North America.

title: Talking Business; with Loughran of C.F.T.C.; Regulating Index Futures
description: WASHINGTON A decade ago, most futures contracts on the nation's commodity exchanges were for agricultural products, primarily corn, soybeans and wheat. Since then, such new financial products as futures on Government bonds and mortgages have fueled extraordinary growth.

title: Key Schlitz Executive Stays After Takeover
description: With the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company of Milwaukee being tucked under the wing of the Stroh Brewing Company of Detroit in a $500 million transaction, Stroh is moving its top people into key Schlitz posts.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Asian International Bank has elected Wilfrido C. Tecson chairman.

title: KENNEDY DENOUCES REGAN FOR 'VOODOO ARMS CONTROL'
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that President Reagan's nuclear arms reduction proposals were an example of ''voodoo arms control'' that would lead to more financing for a long list of Defense Department projects.

title: LEBANON'S ARMY MAY GET PEACEKEEPING ROLE IN BEIRUT
description: While leaders of Lebanon's political factions try to find a way to insure an Israeli withdrawal and to extricate the country from its internal strife, the Lebanese army is being talked about more and more as a mechanism for assuring the restoration of calm to Beirut.

title: Personal Computers; HOW MUCH MEMORY TO BUY
description: ACOMPLEX memory sets man apart from the other species of animals. Memory is also what sets a computer apart from other machines. The peculiar memory pertinent here is not the individual recall of one man or one computer, but the permanent memory of records that man and computer are able to keep and interchange.

title: AFTER PET TAKEOVER, IC INDUSTRIES IS SET FOR NEW CONQUESTS
