description: Having recovered from its unsuccessful attempt last year to acquire the Sunbeam Corporation, a leading appliance maker, IC Industries is pursuing other companies these days to add to its consumer products operations.

title: NIGERIA WAS FIRST
description: To the Editor:

title: PIPELINE BAN OF U.S. IRKS JAPAN
description: Japan, like some Western European nations, is upset by the Reagan Administration's decision last Friday to strengthen the ban on the sale of American oil and gas equipment to the Soviet Union.

title: Transfer Of Raiders Is in Doubt
description: The California Supreme Court ruled today that the City of Oakland has the right to acquire the Oakland Raiders under the city's power of eminent domain.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GREAT HALL

title: Advertising; President Of L.& G.  Honored
description: PHILADELPHIA, the home of the Liberty Bell and the City of Friends, is also the cradle of the advertising agency business. As such, it was the locale yesterday for awarding to Robert G. Wilder the title of Man of the Year by the Television, Radio and Advertising Club of Philadelphia.

title: GENOCIDE SEMINAR, OPPOSED BY ISRAEL, OPENS
description: An international academic conference on Nazi death camps and other genocidal horrors opened today despite efforts by the Israeli Government to have it called off.

title: Ogden to Acquire Allied Maintenance
description: The Ogden Corporation and the Allied Maintenance Corporation announced a definitive agreement for Ogden to acquire Allied in a transaction valued at about $116 million. Under the agreement, Allied stockholders would receive 1.75 shares of Odgen common stock for each Allied share.

title: MS: A MEDICAL DETECTIVE STORY
description: EAST ORANGE. N.J. FIVE years ago, Dr. Stuart D. Cook, a neurologist at the Veterans Administration hospital here, stumbled upon a provocative cluster of patients -three sisters, all of whom had developed multiple sclerosis in 1974. A fourth sister, a nonidentical twin of one of the victims, who had moved away from the parental home three years earlier, remained healthy.

title: A CALM OPENING FOR WIMBELDON
description: In the words of Stan Smith, who emerged as a first-day hero with a four-set victory over ninth-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador, it was a ''dull, not exciting'' opening to the Wimbledon tennis championships today.

title: SENATE PANEL INCREASES LEBANESE AID PROPOSAL
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today increased the size of the Reagan Administration's proposal of emergency aid to Lebanon to $50 million, from $20 million, amid expressions of anger toward Israel by traditional Senate supporters of that nation.

title: LINGUISTICS SPECIALIST ON CORNELL'S FACULTY
description: John M. Echols, professor emeritus of linguistics and Asian studies at Cornell University and an authority on Indonesian languages and literature, died in his sleep last Wednesday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: Optimism for DeLorean
description: Sir Kenneth Cork, receiver at the failed Belfast sports car company of the American businessman John DeLorean, told reporters today that he was ''very optimistic'' the company can be saved. ''The plant could be back in production by the autumn and employing upwards of 1,000 men,'' he said. Mr. DeLorean will have a near essential role to play in selling the car in the United States market if the company is reorganized, he added. Two London financial insitutions are studing a takeover bid for DeLorean from an unidentified British consortium.

title: Musto Fails in Bid To Regain Offices
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court unanimously rejected today William V. Musto's latest attempt to regain his posts as a State Senator from Hudson County and Mayor of Union City.

title: Marjorie Bennett Dead at 87; Acted in Chaplin's 'Limelight'
description: Marjorie Bennett, the cheerful, whitehaired actress best remembered as Charlie Chaplin's gruff landlady in the 1952 movie classic ''Limelight,'' has died after a long illness.

title: TO MRS. HARRIS, LOCAL RACE IS DIFFERENT DIMENSION
description: Patricia Roberts Harris, who held two Cabinet positions in the Carter Administration, who was the first black woman to hold an ambassadorship and whose resume lists 39 honorary degrees, looks slightly uncomfortable just now.

title: HOOPER SHOWS BIG SERVE IN UPSETTING McNAMARA
description: For Chip Hooper, playing at Wimbledon for the first time today was a totally different aura, ''like playing on some sort of different planet.''

title: POLES TO PURGE PROFESSORS UNFIT IN SCHOOL OR POLITICS
description: Poland's Minister of Higher Education said today that the Government was preparing to weed out political malcontents and the academically unfit from among university teachers.

title: HOUSTON'S COUNCIL TRIES TO CONTROL CITY GROWTH
description: Yielding to pressure to control unbridled growth, the City Council today imposed stringent controls on developers to stop them from hemming in highways with skyscrapers and cutting off streets with shopping centers.

title: Happy Fish Story
description: Former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalyn, enjoy fishing. Until this week, though, Mrs. Carter had never gone after salmon.

title: ROOSTER SPUR PEPPER: SCARCER THAN HEN'S TEETH?
description: Book publication parties are a staple amusement in the nation's capital, especially when former Administration officials use the occasion to reveal low doings in high places. But a reception scheduled for Wednesday night in the Hay Adams hotel to celebrate the publication of a new book by former Attorney General Griffin Bell promises to be noteworthy not because of its disclosures about the Administration of Jimmy Carter, but because of an item on the menu.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, testified yesterday before an administrative law judge of the National Labor Relations Board on the players association's effort to acquire financial data from the league's Management Council. Little new ground was covered in the testimony, and the judge said a decision might take as long as two months. ... The Arrows sold the defender Renato Cila to Baltimore. He's married to the daughter of the Blast's owner, Bernie Rodin.

title: NEW YORK STATE'S PLANS TO REVISE VOTE DISTRICTS REJECTED AS BIASED
description: The Justice Department today rejected the New York State Legislature's plans to reapportion Congressional, State Senate and Assembly districts on the ground that they discriminated against minority groups in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan.

title: PENTAGON REJECTS AIRBORNE MX PLAN
description: The Defense Department disclosed today that airborne basing of the MX missile, the basing method preferred by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, had been scratched from the list of options.

title: JEWISH GROUPS IN U.S. SUPPORTING THE INVASION
description: Israel's military campaign against Palestine Liberation Organization forces in Lebanon has received solid support from American Jewish officials, though there is also regret over the casualties incurred in the fighting.

title: Dent's Vote Says He's No All-Star
description: B ucky Dent is grateful for the enthusiasm Yankee fans have shown for him in the All-Star voting, but he says if elected he'll refuse to serve.

title: FOR THE LONG, HOT SUMMER, A PARK OASIS
description: The Loula D. Lasker Pool is at the northernmost end of Central Park, where the big shade trees of the park meet the streets of Harlem. It contains 33,000 gallons of water, is three and a half feet deep and, on a hot summer night, long after closing time, has been known to hold as many as 3,000 people gaining illegal entry through a rectangle made in the cyclone fence with wire cutters.

title: LEBANON'S FATE: LIBERATION OR INCINERATION?
description: To the Editor:

title: Killers Can Be Crazy
description: To many people who did not hear the evidence, and even to some who did, the verdict is an outrage. John Hinckley not guilty? Inconceivable. Intolerable. Some politicians already are demanding satisfaction. Abolish the insanity defense, they insist, or at least drastically change it.

title: 39 Artists To Cook For Benefit
description: A group of visual artists will briefly quit the studio for the kitchen Sunday, focusing their creativity on the stove for the benefit of the Cinque Gallery.

title: Morning Sickness Drug To Include an Advisory
description: Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, a subsidiary of the Dow Chemical Company, says that it will start placing advisory leaflets into packages of Bendectin, a drug prescribed for morning sickness in pregnant women.

title: Afghan Rebel Success In Vital Valley Reported
description: Afghan insurgents ambushed a convoy of trucks carrying about 1,000 young Afghan Communist activists to the strategic Panjsher valley, inflicting heavy casualties, a Western diplomat reported here today.

title: 2 JURORS ASSERT THAT PRESSURE FORCED THEM TO ALTER VOTES
description: Two jurors in the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. said today that they believed he was sane when he shot and wounded President Reagan and three other men. They said they had been placed under pressure to find Mr. Hinckley not guilty by reason of insanity.

title: STATE JUDGE IN BRONX IS REBUKED BY PANEL OVER CUT-RATE TRIPS
description: A State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx was publicly rebuked yesterday by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct for accepting vacation trips at reduced prices from a man he had appointed as a receiver in 26 real-estate foreclosures between 1975 and 1978.

title: OVERHAUL:1. TAXES 2. BUDGET
description: Even if the recession were to vanish tomorrow, bold initiatives will be required to achieve sustained economic growth in an era of technological change and increasing competition in world markets.

title: National news is on pages A12-17, B5-7 and D19; San Francisco Board Moves to Ban Pistols
description: San Francisco's Board of Supervisors has taken a major step toward banning ownership or possession of pistols by almost all people in this city of 700,000 residents.

title: 19 Die in Air Crash At Bombay Airport
description: An Air India jet carrying 111 people crash-landed in a blinding rainstorm at Bombay International Airport today, killing 19 people and injuring dozens, airline officials said.

title: QUARANTINE PROTESTS GET IN THE LAST WORD ON 'TALKING CHIMPS'
description: Sprung from quarantine cages after a deluge of protest by animal rights advocates, two chimpanzees that ''speak'' sign language left a New York University research laboratory by truck yesterday to return to their previous home in Norman, Okla.

title: Ogden Merger
description: The Ogden Corporation and the Allied Maintenance Corporation announced that their directors had approved a previously announced agreement to merge in a transaction valued at about $116 million. Stockholder meetings are scheduled for Sept. 15, and the merger is expected to be completed immediately afterward. The merger would add Allied's maintenance service to Ogden's service group.

title: WHO REALLY REPORTS NEWS ON TELEVISION?
description: When Mike Wallace appeared in January as the correspondent on a hard-hitting CBS documentary about Vietnam - the reporting methods for which have been called into question by TV Guide - the average viewer might have logically assumed that Mr. Wallace was the person responsible for digging up the story.

title: 2 Are Jailed in the Strangling Of a Girl, 18, in Old Westbury
description: Two Westbury, L.I., men were ordered held without bail today on charges of strangling 18-year-old Patricia Puerto in a wooded area of Old Westbury last week.

title: A MEETING OF THE MINDS
description: T his was on the 50th floor of the McGraw-Hill Building, at high noon. One grown man said to another, ''Pumpsie Green?'' The other grown man replied, ''Elston Howard.'' We both wore ties, as if we needed an extra tongue or our heads were on a leash.

title: SUSPECT SEIZED IN TWO MURDERS IN WALL ST. AREA
description: A man who was given a conditional discharge from prison last December was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder on Monday of two insurance executives in an office tower in Manhattan's financial district.

title: Harvester Sells Holding in Mine
description: The International Harvester Company, the troubled manufacturer of farm machinery and construction equipment, said it had sold its 15 percent interest in the Empire iron ore mining partnership in Michigan's Upper Peninsula to one of its partners, the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Ore Company of Cleveland.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FACING LITTLE CHOICE, 7 LEBANESE LEADERS TRY TO SORT OUT THEIR DIFFERENCES
description: The political and military chaos in Lebanon, greatly accentuated since the Israeli invasion more than two weeks ago, forced the creation last week of something called the Council of National Salvation.

title: TV: 'SUMMER AND SMOKE,' AN OPERA
description: PUBLIC television's opera scene moves tonight from the ornate three-part ''Monteverdi Cycle'' that was concluded on Monday to the modern chamberlike setting of ''Summer and Smoke.'' Based on Tennessee Williams's play, the Lee Hoiby opera, with a libretto by Lanford Wilson, can be seen on WNET-TV, Channel 13, this evening at 8:30.

title: BRIEFING
description: Reagan's Use of Prompter

title: A CASE OF CALIFORNIA WINE BRINGS $5,400 AT AUCTION
description: An Atlanta restaurateur who is trying to create the best wine list in the South paid $5,400 at the second annual Napa Valley wine auction here Sunday for a case of wine that he had never tasted.

title: JAMES BOND SETS SCENE AS HOG FIGURES EMERGE
description: A policeman, girdled with weapons, hovers by a door marked ''Lockup in Progress.'' Barricaded behind the metal door is a warren of offices, many marked ''Restricted Area.'' The light and air are bad because all the windows are darkened with special blackout shades and sealed with metal strips. A technician wanders though the maze of corridors, electronically sweeping the rooms for unfriendly bugs.

title: N.B.A.  Files Suit
description: The National Basketball Association asked a Federal court today to clarify the league's rights with respect to a proposed move by the San Diego Clippers to Los Angeles.

title: QUEBEC PLEDGES MORE ELECTRICITY FOR NEW ENGLAND
description: Quebec is prepared to accelerate the delivery of low-cost electricity to New England from its huge new hydroelectric complex at St. James Bay, the tenth annual conference of New England Governors and Eastern Canadian Premiers was told today.

title: ISRAEL BARS TRANSMISSIONS BY ABC
description: Israel suspended ABC News satellite transmissions from here today after the network used an Israeli ground station to send an interview with Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, that had been filmed in Beirut.

title: Ex-Leader of Chad in Algeria
description: Former President Goukouni Oueddei of Chad has been granted asylum in Algeria, authorized sources said today. Mr. Goukouni was forced into exile earlier this month when rebel forces captured Ndjamena, the capital of Chad.

title: Market Place; Sound Stocks At Under $10
description: SHARES of sound companies that slide to especially low levels in bear markets often do exceptionally well in recoveries. Early momentum is often supplied by individuals, because stocks priced below $10 a share are regarded as suspect by institutional investors. But when these stocks reach the $10 level, institutions can provide the added stimulus for still higher prices.

title: The U.N. Today; June 23, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Session on Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WILLIE AND THE GOOSE
description: N o hitter in the major leagues intimidates Goose Gossage when the Yankees' big relief pitcher is rested and throwing his best smoke. But there is one man in another league who fills him with awe.

title: HEARING ON INDIAN POINT SAFETY OPENS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission opened a hearing today on whether the Indian Point nuclear power plants should be shut for safety reasons.

title: Florida Surgeons to End Nonemergency Boycott
description: Gov. Bob Graham today signed compromise legislation on doctors' malpractice insurance rates, and surgeons who have been refusing to perform all but emergency surgery in a boycott to protest the rising costs of such coverage said they planned to return to full work schedules.

title: TWO SOUTHERN SPECIALTIES THAT THE NORTH MIGHT SAVOR
description: ESPITE the fact that America is supposed to be in the midst of a regional cooking renaissance, we are still a nation of strangers where many native dishes are concerned. Most Northerners, for instance, have not developed a passionate hunger for crawfish bisque and crawfish etouffee, any more than Southerners have for pastrami on rye or lox and bagels. And Northerners can no more understand the Southern craving for biscuits and country ham with ''red eye gravy'' than a Southerner like myself can comprehend the New Englander's enthusiasm for redflannel hash.

title: Global Fights a Takeover Attempt
description: Frank G. Beatty, president of Global Natural Resources P.L.C., a British oil and gas exploration company, thinks that 50 percent of his company's shareholders may be in the United States.

title: BUDGET IS ADOPTED BY HOUSE, 210-208
description: The Democratic-controlled House today grudgingly approved a Republican-sponsored budget compromise, which one supporter acknowledged ''may be nobody's cup of tea, but the only cup of tea we have.'' The vote was 210 to 208.

title: U.S. ACTS OVER HEATER DEATHS
description: The Consumer Products Safety Commission has filed a complaint seeking a $500,000 fine against a water heater manufacturer on the ground that it failed to report deaths and injuries associated with the product.

title: BALLET: A DANISH 'COPPELIA' LED BY LIS JEPPESEN
description: ''COPPELIA'' is such a well-known ballet in the United States that American audiences might be in for a surprise with the Royal Danish Ballet's somewhat different but very merry and colorful version.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: HUGO FLESCH has pulled off something of a coup for Metropolitan Diary. He has managed to get hold of the program listings for Channel Z, the all-new French-language cable-television network that will make its debut in New York City. You say you've never heard of the channel before? Few have; in fact, it is impossible to find anyone who has heard anything about it at all, aside from Mr. Flesch.

title: HOSPITAL ONCE 'HOME' FOR EZRA POUND
description: In the District of Columbia, the nation's largest Federal mental hospital for civilians is known familiarly as ''St. E's.'' Elsewhere, St. Elizabeths Hospital is thought of, if at all, as the place where Ezra Pound, the poet accused of treason, was committed for 12 postwar years.

title: HOLIDAY INNS FOUNDER TRIES DATA FRANCHISING
description: Kemmons Wilson knows how to sell a franchise. Thirty-one years ago on a trip to Washington he was outraged at the $16 he had to pay for a room for his family.

title: DEMOCRATS BACK DELBELLOFOR NO. 2 SPOT
description: The Democratic State Committee today designated Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, as its favored candidate for lieutenant governor and qualified two others to run for the same post in the September primary.

title: An Evening Of Oriental Strings
description: According to Ton Kin-woon's introduction to his performances Saturday night at the Alternative Museum, the seven silk strings stretched across a four-foot-long resonant wood body that lay before him were more than just zither strings. The Chinese chin, he explained, is an instrument that since the second century has been linked to Taoist scholars; it is an instrument for meditation, for a ''return to simple things.''

title: INDUSTRIALIST FORMED PISTONS OF THE N.B.A.
description: Fred Zollner, the founder of the Detroit Pistons basketball team, died Monday in North Miami, Fla. He was 81 years old.

title: Reagan and Begin
description: There has been a bit of a tussle within the Reagan Administration about how to handle the Middle East tangle in general and Prime Minister Begin of Israel in particular, but President Reagan has handled it so far very carefully and probably wisely.

title: FLAWS FOUND AT ATOM PLANTS
description: Up to half the nuclear plants in the country are ''generally deficient'' in one or more areas in their ability to respond to accidents, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was told today.

title: Cardinal Is Hospitalized
description: Cardinal Humberto S. Medeiros, head of the Archdiocese of Boston, was in a critical care unit of St. Cloud Hospital today with high blood pressure and ''extreme fatigue,'' but his condition was reported ''stabilized,'' a spokesman said.

title: ISRAEL, DISPUTING RED CROSS, LISTS CASUALTIES
description: Israel's Foreign Ministry announced today that a total of 460 to 470 civilians had been killed and 1,600 wounded in fighting in southern Lebanon, excluding Beirut, for which the Israelis have no casualty figures.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bass Enterprises told the Securities and Exchange Commission that its two subsidiaries had reduced their stake in Trans World Corp. to 8.8 percent of preferred stock.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: One Path to Progress: Hanging on to the Past

title: Bridge: A Calculator Has Its Place When the Scores Are Close
description: If a declarer concerned about the percentage chances of two lines of play whipped out a pocket calculator his opponents might well object. The laws do not cover the matter, but the tournament director would probably uphold the objection.

title: Squeeze, Rock Quintet In Garden Debut
description: Squeeze, the British rock quintet thought by many critics to be one of the finest pop ensembles in the world, put themselves to a crucial pop-music test Friday when they performed for the first time in Madison Square Garden. Considering that the Garden, with its booming acoustics, is hardly the ideal venue for a group whose songs combine light, cheerful surfaces with subtle literary whimsy, they acquitted themselves handily.

title: VOTE IN THE HOUSE ON THE '83 BUDGET
description: Here is how area members of Congress voted today as the House approved, 210 to 208, a compromise budget for the fiscal year 1983. A ''yes'' vote is a vote in favor.

title: SOVIET STILL THE MAIN THREAT, BRITON SAYS
description: Defense Secretary John Nott said today that the Falkland war might lead to some changes in Britain's military structure, including ''a different mix of forces,'' but that the Soviet Union remained the nation's main threat.

title: BRIEFING
description: 35 Years of U.F.O.'s

title: Oklahoma Catholic Aide Calls Refugees 'Parasites'
description: The head of the United States Catholic Conference in Oklahoma, which has sponsored more than 5,000 refugees in the state since 1975, says many of them have become ''parasites'' who ''sponge off the American people.''

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE first time I went snorkeling I got so excited by the wealth of creatures swimming around me that I stuck my head up and called to no one in particular: ''C-c-c-ome quick! L-l-l-look at this!'' I don't usually stutter, but now and again certain circumstances, among them times of extreme excitement, fear, urgency or anger, cause me to trip over my own words.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There must be an end to the doctrine that allows so many persons to commit crimes of violence, to use confusing procedures to their own advantage, and then to have the door opened for them to return to the society they victimized.'' - Attorney General William French Smith, on Hinckley acquittal. (B6:1.)

title: Rose Passes Aaron in Hits
description: Pete Rose of the Philadelphia Phillies moved into second place on the career hit list tonight. Rose doubled on a 3-0 pitch from John Stuper of St. Louis in the third inning.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard THE CORRESPONDENCE OF BORIS PASTERNAK AND OLGA FREIDEN- BERG 1910-54. Compiled and edited, with an introduction, by Elliott Moss- man. Translated by Elliott Mossman and Margaret Wettlin. Illustrated. 365 pages. Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: In the last six or eight years, there has been a kind of freefloating Isadora Duncan revival - a play, a movie, re-creations of Duncan dances and any number of seminars, often featuring Maria Teresa Duncan, one of the ''Isadorables.'' All this interest is not directly attributable to the dancer Annabelle Gamson, but certainly much of it is, and July 7 at Carnegie Hall the reason should be apparent.

title: Tournament of Roses Sponsorship to Nabisco
description: If you are a traditional watcher of Tournament of Roses parades from Pasadena, Calif., on television on New Year's Day, you are going to have a hard time missing commercials for Nabisco products come Jan.1.

title: Public Radio Salutes Female Songwriters
description: Any number of literate lyricists, male and female, insist that Sylvia Syms sings their songs better than anyone else. For this and other reasons, National Public Radio will offer a three-hour program July 3 live from Avery Fisher Hall that will feature Miss Syms and be called ''This Time the Ladies.''

title: ALBERT G. MAIORANO
description: Albert G. Maiorano, a former news assistant for the The New York Times, died Tuesday at Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Amid Bad News, A Glint of Good
To the Editor:$

title: BIRTH-CLINIC VISITS ROSE DURING '80
description: Nearly five million American women and girls went to family-planning clinics in 1980, almost 15 percent more than the year before, and the pill was the most popular form of birth control, a survey reports.

title: Economic Scene; The Limits of Social Science
description: ECONOMISTS and other social scientists have been swept by a wave of pessimism over their failure to solve an array of problems ranging from economic stability and growth to the persistent poverty and political turbulence of large areas of the world.

title: MESQUITE: BAD PRESS BUT GREAT FLAVOR
description: COWBOYS damn its thorns and impenetrable thickets. Ranchers uproot it, burn it, poison it. Cursed as a ''scavenger tree,'' it's often described as noxious and malignant. Yet the aroma of its burning wood and the distinctive flavor it imparts to grilled meat and fish have captured the palates, if not the hearts, of even its die-hard enemies.

title: Fawn Pug Dies
description: Ch. Dhandy's Favorite Woodchuck is dead. His name may not be commonly known, but it means a lot to dog fanciers, as does the mystery surrounding his death.

title: Ex-Reporter Says Paper Libeled Her
description: A former reporter for The Advocate of Stamford says she knew the true identity of her roommate, Katherine Boudin, for a year before Miss Boudin was arrested in the Brink's robbery in which two policemen and a guard were slain in Nanuet, N.Y.

title: SANCTIONS HURT POLISH TRADE FAIR
description: A sharp reduction in the number of Western businesses exhibiting their wares at this year's Poznan Trade Fair, which closes today, appears to be at least partly a result of the economic sanctions the United States and its allies imposed on Poland after martial law was declared in December.

title: COGENERATION MEANS CHEAPER ENERGY FOR NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. GHANDI PICKS SIKH ALLY TO BE CEREMONIAL PRESIDENT
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today nominated Zail Singh, a loyal aide and Home Affairs Minister, for the largely ceremonial post of President.

title: GETTING A BIG BOARD LISTING
description: Minutes before 10 A.M. yesterday, officials from National Utilities and Industries entered the crowded trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange, where N.U.I. was getting ready to be listed on the Big Board for the first time in the company's 127-year history.

title: 13 Are Appointed To Theater Council
description: Mayor Koch's office yesterday announced the appointment of 13 persons to the Theatre Advisory Council, which was established last month to advise the Planning Commission on questions of preservation and demolition of Broadway theaters.

title: RIGHTS PLAN IS DEFEATED IN ILLINOIS
description: The proposed Federal equal rights amendment was defeated today in the Illinois House. The vote, culminating one of the final efforts in a 10-year struggle to ratify the constitutional ban on sex discrimination, was 103 to 72, or 4 short of the 107 needed under the Illinois General Assembly's rule requiring three-fifths approval for proposed constitutional amendments.

title: HIGH RATES PUSH GOLD BELOW $300
description: Gold closed yesterday in New York below $300 an ounce for the first time in nearly three years as high interest rates continued to depress bullion prices.

title: CHRONOLOGY OF THE EVENTS BEFORE REJECTION OF PLANS
description: Every 10 years, states are required to redraw their political boundaries to take into account population shifts recorded in the census.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Toward Less Salt

title: X-RAYS APPEAR TO BOLSTER BLACK HOLE THEORY
description: Analysis of pulsing X-ray emissions from an object in the constellation Scorpius has provided new evidence for the existence of the astrophysical phenomena known as black holes, scientists at the Naval Research Laboratory reported yesterday.

title: 3 CAMBODIANS SIGN ACCORD ON EXILE REGIME
description: A new Cambodian government in exile was signed into existence today by three men, once bitter enemies, who now see Vietnam as their common foe.

title: 4 WALKS BY JONES AT START
description: At the start of last evening, the Mets watched Randy Jones walk the four batters he faced and walk off the mound, embarrassed. Near the end of the evening, they watched Bob Bailor fling his bat in frustration after striking out to end the eighth inning with what could have been the tying run at second base.

title: Saxon Inventories
description: Saxon Industries, a paper-products and photocopier maker operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act, said its auditor had uncovered an ''apparent overstatement'' in the inventory of its business products group of ''at least $24 million.'' The auditor, Fox & Company of New York, is still investigating, but Saxon expects that inventories will be reduced and prior operating performance hurt, said Saxon's chief executive officer, William J. Scharffenberger.

title: Irvin W. Underhill, 86, Ex-Missionary, Is Dead
description: The Rev. Irvin W. Underhill, a former Presbyterian missionary in West Africa and former pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Nunda in Livingston County, N.Y., died of cancer Monday at his home in Geneseo, N.Y. He was 86 years old.

title: People
description: * Norton B. Leo has joined Greenstone & Rabasca as executive vice president and management supervisor.

title: Humanities Head Seeks The 'Tough Projects'
description: For the most part, William J. Bennett, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, has kept a low profile, neither seeking nor desiring much exposure. However, in a recent issue of The Claremont Review of Books, a publication of the Claremont colleges in California, Mr. Bennett offers this vision of the role of the agency:

title: Wickes Auditor
description: The Wickes Companies, now operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act, named Arthur Andersen & Company as its independent auditor for the fiscal year 1983, succeeding Coopers & Lybrand. Wickes said the change had been made so it could ''take a fresh look at the company and its problems.''

title: Careers; Training: A Growth Industry
description: AT W.R. Grace & Company, there is a belief that a recession should not get in the way of preparation for the future.Grace has begun an extensive training program for its retail managers and eventually for their staffs - a total of 5,000 people. In its retail sector, the highly diversified company operates chains like Herman's (sporting goods), Channel (home equipment), Sheplers (western clothing) and J.B. Robinson (jewelry).

title: NLT Acquires 7.7% Of Insurer
description: The NLT Corporation of Nashville paid $102.5 million for about 7.7 percent of the American General Corporation of Houston - 1.53 million common shares at $55 each and 458,000 preferred at $40 - as a first step toward acquiring the larger insurance company, NLT said.

title: Garvey and Baker Power the Dodgers
description: Steve Garvey and Dusty Baker hit home runs and three pitchers combined on a three-hitter tonight to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 4-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves. The victory moved the third-place Dodgers 5 1/2 games behind the Braves in the National League West.

title: SHARP CLIMB LED BY GASOLINE
description: Consumer prices rose 1 percent in May, the Labor Department reported today, pushing the Consumer Price Index back to a double-digit annual rate and halting, at least temporarily, this year's surprisingly good news on inflation. The sharp increase in the index, which translates to a compound annual rate of 12 percent, follows small rises and one decline in the last four months. It was the largest monthly increase since last September.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CASTRO OFFERS TO GIVE HIS ALL
description: Over the last two decades, Fidel Castro has conceived myriad ways of keeping alive Cuba's revolutionaty spirit. Last year, he caught Cubans by surprise with his campaign against obesity. Now he has asked them to donate their - presumably slimmed down - bodies for medical use after death.

title: CORONA'S LAWYER SAYS HE'LL SHOW BROTHER IS GUILTY
description: Defense attorneys representing Juan Corona at his retrial on charges of killing 25 farmworkers in 1971 fought hard today for the right to try to prove that a half-brother of Mr. Corona committed the murders.

title: New Zealand Freeze
description: Prime Minister Robert D. Muldoon of New Zealand today announced a 12-month wage and price freeze effective at midnight tonight in what he described as a major attack on inflation. He said all interest rates and housing rents would also be frozen for a year. Mr. Muldoon promised to offset the measures with substantial but unspecified income tax cuts in the annual budget, scheduled to be announced toward the end of next month. New Zealand's annual inflation rate is 15.7 percent.

title: Advertising
description: IF all goes well - and why shouldn't it? - there will be a Harvard Lampoon parody of Newsweek in November. And, according to Lisa Henson, the president, the reason the reading public will be so blessed is that 13 members of The Lampoon's staff want summer jobs that will help them hone their writing skills. That is why we went for seven years without a parody until last year's People spoof: not enough Lampoon members with enough interest to do it.

title: Gulf Starts Offer For Cities Service
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation formally began its $5 billion takeover bid for the Cities Service Company by starting a tender offer of $63 a share for 51 percent of Cities Service's common stock.

title: FROM CAT-COLLAR BRACELETS TO MOUSE PUZZLES; 1. For a Summer Table
description: If you're looking for some well-designed suggestions for setting a summer table, you might drop in at Wolfman-Gold, at the corner of Broome and Wooster Streets. Hand-carved and cheerfully painted roosters and hens from Indonesia are meant to be napkin rings, but a clutch of them could be a centerpiece. They're $5.50 each. The shop has handsome white napkins edged in heavy lace ($4.25 each) and cotton damask restaurant napkins ($1.50 each). Unusual and practical for picnic napkins are diapers from China - large (28 inches square), made of soft cotton and $2.50 each.

title: NORMAN THOMAS'S FOLLOWERS SUPPORT A FREEZE
description: To the Editor:

title: BELGIUM AND SOVIET ADVANCE
description: Belgium and the Soviet Union, each gaining ties, joined Poland today in advancing to the second round in World Cup soccer.

title: TRUTH IN PACKAGING; Encore Presentations
description: A South Dakota artist who owns the original of a 1963 ''Blondie'' comic strip recently discovered that, except for the last frame, it's identical to one published last month. No harm done, says cartoonist Dean Young, whose father created the comic strip, and who has carried on since 1973.

title: Miss Connecticut Regains Crown
description: Virginia Jill Reichardt became the reigning Miss Connecticut again after an out-of-court settlement today in her battle to keep her crown.

title: BLUE-VEINED CHEESES: THE EXPANDING CHOICES
description: ''THIS business is like fashion, with everyone following the latest idea,'' said Jean-Paul Grasmuck, director of sales and marketing for a major cheese importer. And right now in cheeses, blue is big. Imports to the United States of blue cheeses totaled about 5 million pounds last year, an increase of 633,000 pounds over 1980.

title: PEPPER GRINDERS
description: AFEW years ago I was amused to learn of a letter in a newspaper from a woman who complained about recipes calling for freshly ground pepper. ''I am a very busy housewife,'' she wrote. ''I don't have time to grind pepper fresh every time I make a dish.'' I could not imagine what her cooking must have been like if she found even a simple activity like grinding pepper such a chore. And by using previously ground pepper she was contributing absolutely nothing to the flavor of the food.

title: What Might Justify Lebanon
description: Israel's path out of Lebanon can be more treacherous than the march in. That is why Prime Minister Begin has asked President Reagan to help extricate him. And that is why Mr. Reagan holds a powerful hand in the diplomacy now begun.

title: CITY OFFERS SEMINAR ON BUYING ITS PROPERTY HOLDINGS
description: For some time now, New York City has been the largest landowner in the city. But it is a title municipal leaders are not particularly pleased about, and in fact they seem to be doing everything they can to relinquish it.

title: TRUTH IN PACKAGING; Condemned
description: It's commonplace for sports fans to condemn local teams for lackluster performance. City officials in Oakland are carrying condemnation to a startling extreme.

title: ABC DELAYS ENTRY INTO SATELLITE RADIO
description: The American Broadcasting Companies said yesterday that it would ''delay indefinitely'' the start of its much-publicized Superadio, a national radio music program beamed by satellite. .

title: July 4 Concert at Caramoor
description: Concerts at the Caramoor Festival will include a special Fourth of July ''All-American Independence Day Concert'' at 5:30 P.M. in the Venetian Theater. The program will include Aaron Copland's ''Appalachian Spring,'' Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' and Ives's ''Symphony No. 3.''

title: PRUDENT DIET AND CANCER RISK
description: LAST week the National Academy of Sciences issued a report entitled ''Diet, Nutrition and Cancer,'' which informs adults, in effect, that if they want to live longer they ought to pay attention to what their mothers told them to eat when they were children.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Arrives in U.S.
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain arrived in New York tonight amid tight security to address the United Nations conference on disarmament and to hold talks with President Reagan on the Falkland crisis. The Prime Minister, who will address the United Nations and see Mr. Reagan in Washington Wednesday, left Kennedy International Airport without making a statement.

title: Compatibility Data Sought by Japanese
description: The trade secrets being sought by the Japanese businessmen arrested yesterday would have helped their companies build computers that would have been interchangeable, or compatible, with devices made by the International Business Machines Corporation, the Justice Department said.

title: HINCKLEY ORDERED TO A U.S. HOSPITAL FOR MENTAL TESTS
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. was committed today to a Federal mental hospital for psychiatric examination to determine whether he should go free, amid a chorus of outrage from Reagan Administration officials and others at his acquittal Monday evening.

title: EUROPEANS PROTEST U.S. CURBS ON STEEL IMPORTS AND GAS LINE
description: Europe's foreign ministers, at the close of a three-day meeting here, issued a strongly worded protest today on American decisions to levy duties on European steel products and to restrict the use of American-developed equipment in a planned natural gas pipeline to connect Siberia and Western Europe.

title: Capitals in Trouble
description: Among several National Hockey League teams that are awash in red ink, the Washington Capitals appear to be in the worst shape. And now from Toronto, where the league's board of governors is meeting, comes confirmation that the club may have to be sold unless the owner, Abe Pollin, can attract a partner willing to share the burden.

title: Goodbye, Bonds
description: No other major leaguer ever hit more than 30 home runs and stole more than 30 bases in a single season five times. He played as a star outfielder for seven big-league teams and took part in three All-Star games, twice for the National League and once for the American.

title: 59 TOP U.S. COMPANIES PLAN GENETIC SCREENING
description: Fifty-nine corporations, most of them among the nation's 500 top industrial companies, have informed the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment in anonymous questionnaires that they plan to begin some genetic screening of their workers in the next five years.

title: France
description: Roquefort: Although a few other sheep's milk blue cheeses are made, Roquefort is the only one whose reputation has become international. The first of several limitations on the use of the Roquefort name was issued in 1666 by the Council of Toulouse. Today the cheese must be made in the Roquefort caves (but the milk can come from other regions such as Corsica, where another sheep's milk blue cheese, Bleu de Corse, is made).

title: Semiconductor In Arizona Move
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., said it had expanded its successful systems division by opening an additional development center in Mesa, Ariz., and increasing research and development spending by 67 percent, to $10 million a year from $6 million spent in the year ended May 31, 1982.

title: LANDLORD'S CONCESSIONS END A SUIT OVER CO-OPS
description: An agreement barring until July 1, 1983, any further sales activity to convert to cooperatives the 113-unit apartment building at 375 Riverside Drive was made known yesterday by State Attorney General Robert Abrams' office.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: I was distressed to see the letter (June 14) from Franklin H. Williams, a Con Edison director, claiming that cogeneration will hurt small-business people in our city. This is absolutely false.

title: WINE TALK
description: Through the oval windows cut into the winery's 21-inch masonry walls, the vines of the Red Rock Terrace Vineyard are visible. Beyond them flows Diamond Creek, tumbling down Diamond Mountain toward the Napa River far below. The soil of the seven-acre vineyard is a dusty red, and it produces some of the best cabernet sauvignon in America.

title: Aussie Team Wins
description: Paul Lynch and Jeff Kennedy scored six goals each, leading Australia to a 24-18 upset victory over Canada in the World Lacrosse Games tonight at Johns Hopkins. The Australians (2-1) will meet the United States in the championship game Friday night.

title: New I.L.O. Rule Would Tighten Layoffs
description: The International Labor Organization's assembly of member states adopted a convention today that places on the employer the burden of proof that layoffs are justified.

title: VIETNAMESE BOATS REPORTEDLY FIRE ON U.S. SHIP IN SOUTH CHINA SEA
description: The United States Navy destroyer Turner Joy, which figured in an incident critical to American involvement in the Vietnam War 18 years ago, was fired on again Sunday night by Vietnamese ships, the Defense Department disclosed tonight.

title: HIGH U.S. OFFICIALS EXPRESS OUTRAGE, ASKING FOR NEW LAS ON INSANITY PLEA
description: The acquittal of John W. Hinckley Jr. provoked outbursts of anger on Capitol Hill today, accompanied by demands for revision of the law that permits criminal defendants to plead not guilty by reason of insanity.

title: Quaker Oats To Sell Units
description: The Quaker Oats Company announced today that it had entered into a definitive agreement to sell its chain of 89 Magic Pan resturants to private investors. Though the terms and price were not disclosed, the resturant chain will continue to carry the Magic Pan name, and retain its San Francisco headquarters.

title: MOB KILLER SAYS HOFFA TOLD HIM TO SLAY SUCCESSOR
description: A self-described mob murderer said today that James R. Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, ordered him seven years ago to kill Mr. Hoffa's successor, Frank E. Fitzsimmons.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 23, 1982; The Economy
description: Consumer prices rose a steep 1 percent in May, the Labor Department reported. The increase, pushing inflation back up to a double-digit annual rate, was the largest since September. The surge was led by gasoline prices, which had been declining lately, as well as by housing and food prices. It was expected by economists, who are also predicting increases for June and July. But most look for inflation of no more than 7 percent for the year. (Page A1.) Last month, consumer prices jumped 1.1 percent in the New York area. (D7.)

title: No Kick About Time
description: Eddie Robinson, whose Grambling State teams have produced more than 100 professional players, isn't sure whether this year's Whitney M. Young Jr.

title: LIVING COST UP BY 1.1% IN THE CITY
description: The cost of living in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area rose sharply last month, departing from the pattern of the last seven months, in which there had been little change.

title: REPORT TELLS PLIGHT OF ELDERLY WOMEN
description: The elderly population in New York City is largely female and largely poor, and it is neglected by government, the medical profession, social agencies and news organizations, according to a report issued yesterday by the City Council's Subcommittee on the Status of Women.

title: NEW ALBUM SHOWS X HAS GROWN
description: ''WILD GIFT,'' the second album by X, a Los Angeles rock band, was last year's best rock lp. At least this critic thought so, and so did a number of others, from coast to coast. ''Wild Gift'' combined the pile-driving force of pioneering punk-rock bands such as the Ramones with a more complex lyrical sensibility, ragged-but-right harmony singing that sounded at times like Appalachian mountain music, witty quotes and borrowings from first-generation rock-and-roll stylists like Carl Perkins and Chuck Berry and a wonderfully infectious swing that suggested at least one of X's four musicians - the drummer D.J. Bonebrake, it turns out - had some experience playing jazz.

title: SHRINKING FROM JUSTICE
description: For an exercise in legal absurdity it would be hard to improve on the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. Having shot the President, been taken into custody, advised of his constitutional rights and afforded legal counsel, Hinckley was examined by squadrons of psychiatrists to determine his state of mind at the time of the shooting.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SESQUICENTENNIAL

title: Updike Hails Cheever For His Tales of Purity
description: John Cheever was buried today in a picturesque New England town similar to the suburbs about which he wrote so vividly.

title: DOES SHE PHONE THE MAN IN 82?
description: HE'S just the kind of man she's been waiting for -intelligent, assured, amusing. But the cocktail party ends and there's no dinner invitation. So what? She's a young professional, successful and liberated. If the man doesn't make the first move, she'll pick up the telephone the next day and ask him for a date. These are the days of liberation, and sex role playing is old-fashioned.

title: Coast Protesters Charge Police With 'Slugging'
description: Antinuclear activists accused the police today of ''slugging'' and ''punching'' as 85 more people were taken away to jail in the second day of protests at the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory.

title: REAGAN PROMISES AID FOR COSTA RICA
description: President Reagan gave a pledge of economic support to the President of Costa Rica today and warned that Latin American countries were threatened ''by forces of the extreme right and the extreme left.''

title: Albany Mayor Ill
description: Mayor Erastus Corning 2d of Albany was transferred to the intensive-care unit of Albany Medical Center following breathing problems early today, hospital officials said.

title: DIFFICULT DAYS AHEAD FOR DATAPOINT'S CHIEF
description: The dreams were unlimited at the Datapoint Corporation. Harold E. O'Kelley, highly respected on Wall Street as a man firmly in control of the company's destiny, wrote in the 1981 annual report: ''We now have in place the management and organization to take us to the $1 billion level and beyond.''

title: STUDY OF SEX EDUCATION AND PROMISCUITY
description: Sex education in schools does not promote promiscuity among teenagers and may even discourage teen-age pregnancy, a study reported yesterday.

title: Steelmet Plant
description: Steelmet Inc. of Pittsburgh, a leading processor of scrap metal, said it was negotiating the sale of its Ostend Street plant in Baltimore to two officers, Arnold I. Plant, senior vice president, and Morton B. Plant, a director, who resigned effective immediately. Alan Amper, chairman and chief executive officer, said he hoped the sale would be closed in 30 days but he would not disclose any details until then. Steelmet has two other processing plants in Baltimore and facilities in other states and in Europe.

title: JAPANESE EXECUTIVES CHARGED IN I.B.M. THEFT CASE
description: Eighteen Japanese businessmen, many of them senior officials at two major Japanese computer companies, were charged today with conspiring to steal confidential computer information from the International Business Machines Corporation and transport it to Japan.

title: Marschalk Gets More Of Thompson Billings
description: The Marschalk Company, which became an agency of the Thompson Medical Company in a small way last November, has become a big one now with the addition of about $6.5 million in billings.

title: MILWAUKEE WINS SEVENTH IN ROW
description: Roger Erickson created a problem for his manager tonight. Making what could have been his last start before heading for permanent bullpen duty, Erickson registered his most impressive performance as a Yankee.

title: GENERAL IS CHOSEN TO RULE ARGENTINA
description: The Argentine Army appointed a retired general today as President of Argentina over the objections of the navy and air force and announced that it was ''assuming the responsibility for the political leadership'' of the Government.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Grandeur in the Park

title: U.S. Urged to Leave the U.N.
description: The John Birch Society announced plans today to send the White House and Congress petitions with 2,953,500 signatures as part of a campaign to get the United States out of the United Nations. A letter accompanying the petitions calls on the Administration to ''help separate our nation from the petty tyrants, Communists and assorted America-haters who dominate the U.N.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Royal Heir

title: * To the Editor:$
description: One hopes, after reliable figures are compiled on civilian casualties, the number of innocent bystanders uprooted from their homes and the amount of property destroyed in the in-vasion of Lebanon, Norman Podhoretz (''Our Aims and Israel's,'' Op-Ed June 15) will reconsider his position that the Israeli incursion is ''in the interests of the Lebanese people themselves.'' v. ould he also argue that the Holocaust was good for Jews because it led to the creation of Israel? This sort of callous thinking, that great human suffering is insignificant in the forward march of history, has created a common bond between Israel, the P.L.O. and all other ravagers of humanity.

title: PANEL HEARS PLEAS TO SAVE U.S. PARKS
description: Former Interior Department officials, conservationists and other witnesses told a House Interior subcommittee today that legislation was urgently needed to rescue what they described as a rapidly deteriorating national park system.

title: CORRECTION
description: A quotation in the ''Evening Hours'' column on the Style page Feb. 26 was incorrectly attributed. The person at a party to raise funds for the homeless who said she lived in the ''H'' line of the building was not Shelley Zacharia but a woman sitting nearby.

title: Tin Producers Form Group
description: Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia, which together produce more than two-thirds of the world's tin, today formally announced creation of a producers association.

title: PANEL STARTS WORK ON TELEPHONE BILL
description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce today began consideration of a controversial telecommunications bill that would be the first overhaul in 50 years of the regulations governing the phone industry.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE alliance of certain Russian and French dishes has always interested me - dishes like chicken Kiev (in which the boned chicken breasts are wrapped around butter and chives, breaded and deepfried) and stroganoffs (most or all of which contain sour cream) and coulibiacs (such as brioche dough filled with a salmon-and-rice mixture before baking).

title: LOUIS E. GOLDSTEIN
description: Louis E. Goldstein, a former president and chairman of the National Bank of America, died Sunday at South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. He was 86 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: ISRAEL, AT REQUEST OF U.S., ANNOUNCES CEASE-FIRE
description: Israel agreed tonight to an American request to announce a cease-fire at the end of a day of serious clashes between Syrian and Israeli forces, an authoritative Government official said.

title: No Headline
description: Briefs on the Arts Williamstown to Hail Tennessee Williams

title: Only Cobb Stands In Rose's Way
description: P ete Rose has been having a pretty good week, even for Pete Rose. On Saturday, he became the fourth-highest scorer of runs in baseball history. On Sunday, he became fifth in games played. And on Monday, he tied Henry Aaron for second in total hits.

title: STEMKOWSKI IS SENTENCED TO PROBATION
description: Pete Stemkowski, the former playoff hero for the Rangers, was sentenced to three years' probation today for attempting to hire another man to break a wrist and an ankle of a San Diego businessman who, Stemkowski says, owes him $70,000.

title: THE PRINCESS OF WALES TAKES HER BABY HOME
description: The Princess of Wales and her still-unnamed son went home tonight, less than 24 hours after his birth. Wearing a lime green polka-dot smock and smiling radiantly, the 20-year-old Princess walked out of St. Mary's Hosiptal, Paddington, shortly before dinnertime. She was carrying the new Prince, who was so tightly swaddled in white that only part of his face was visible. Prince Charles accompanied them on the ride back to Kensington Palace.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL CHARLESTON (IL) - Signed Brian Doyle, second baseman, as a free agent.  DETROIT (AL) - Traded Steve Lueb- ber, pitcher, to Texas for Rick Matula, pitcher.METS (NL) - Recalled Terry Leach.  right-handed pitcher, from Tidewater of International League. Sent Rusty Till- man, outfielder, to Tidewater.  PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Named Tony Taylor manager of its top farm club, Okla- homa City of the American Association.  PITTSBURGH (NL) - Acquired Dick Davis, outfielder, o
description: ST. LOUIS (NL) - Activated Steve B raun, infielder-outfielder. Optioned Or- l ando Sanchez, catcher, to Louisville of the A merican Association.

title: ISRAELI JETS POUND SYRIANS AND P.L.O. IN BIG OFFENSIVE
description: Israeli tanks and fighter planes began a large-scale offensive today, apparently aimed at driving Syrian and Palestinian forces off the Beirut-Damascus highway.

title: Xerox Computer
description: The Xerox Corporation introduced a new personal computer, the 820-II, designed for business and professional use.

title: Unique Homes Taking Ads to Go With Its Ads
description: In the Ziff-Davis stable of magazines has a publication that should be dear to any publisher's heart, it is a little number called Unique Homes that is all advertising, all real estate display advertising for very costly homes and estates.

title: DOW JUMPS 9.71 POINTS, TO 799.66
description: Monday's slight gain in stock prices blossomed into a rally yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 9.71 points, to 799.66, buoyed by favorable news about the budget deficit and the economy.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on June 10 about the writer William L. Shirer incorrectly indicated the publisher of his book ''The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich.'' It was Simon & Schuster.
To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Q. It will soon be canning time for various preserves and jellies and I am curious to know whether jellies that are sealed with paraffin also need a screw top as a second lid. I'd also like to know if I can use the empty jars from commercially purchased products, such as mayonnaise and peanut butter, for canning.

title: DURABLES ORDERS UP 1.4% IN MAY
description: New orders for factories' durable goods increased 1.4 percent in May, partly recovering from April's steep decline, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.N. Warning on Food
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, warned a conference here today that the world food situation was at its most critical point since the early 1970's.

title: BILL SIGNED TO LEGALIZE STATUS OF LOFTS' TENANTS
description: Governor Carey signed a bill today legalizing the status of thousands of tenants living in converted industrial lofts in New York City.

title: WESTCHESTER IS GILBERT'S LUCKY GAME
description: Gibby Gilbert, a 41-year-old professional golfer from Chattanooga, Tenn., plays in about 30 tournaments a year, with moderate success. But at the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, which begins here Thursday, Gilbert has been something of a tiger over the years and he is not sure why.

title: SCREEN ACTORS DECIDE NOT TO BACK POLITICIANS
description: The board of the Screen Actors Guild voted 60 to 9 Monday night to continue the guild's traditional policy of not endorsing political candidates.

title: Joseph Buell Jr., 66, Headed Million Market Newspapers
description: Joseph R. Buell Jr., the retired chairman and chief executive officer of Million Market Newspapers, a company that solicits advertising for newspapers around the country, died Monday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: 60-CONCERT SERIES PLANNED
description: The Great Performers Series at Lincoln Center will present 60 concerts during its 1982-83 season. There will be four recital and orchestral series at Avery Fisher Hall, seven series of recitals and chamber concerts at Alice Tully Hall and single events.

title: Boys Choir of Harlem Presents Bach Cantatas
description: The Boys Choir of Harlem sang cantatas by J.S. Bach and George Walker in Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon. From Bach came ''Lobe den Herren'' and ''Ein Feste Burg.'' Mr. Walker's piece, commissioned by the Harlem choir, was a setting of Psalms 23 and 24.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Filling a Request By Rebekah Harkness

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * ACF Industries has elected Irma L. Beckley vice president-human resources.

title: COUNTDOWN BEGINS FOR SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The countdown began today for the space shuttle Columbia's final test flight and first military assignment.

title: A DEATH PENALTY BACKER WHO HAS A FEW DOUBTS
description: He has always been an unsettled man, pushing his cause and pestered by doubts along the way. This morning, after a major legislative victory and with the prospect that his measure would finally become state law, little had changed for State Senator John Russo, New Jersey's most public advocate of the death penalty.

title: Truth in Packaging; Puff Huff
description: Oscar Wilde said that the man must have a heart of stone who can read of the death of Little Nell and not burst out laughing. It is hard not to feel the same way about the tempest among cigarettemakers accusing one another of deceptive advertising.

title: Genentech Accord
description: Genentech Inc. said it had agreed with two Japanese companies, the Kyowa Hakko Company and Mitsubishi Chemical Industries, to use its genetic engineering methods to develop a thrombolytic agent, tissue plasminogen activator, for degrading blood clots.

title: HAD SERVED AS HEAD OF ESSO STANDARD CO.
description: Stanley C. Hope, retired president of the Esso Standard Oil Company, died last Friday at Methodist Hospital in Houston following a stroke. He was 88 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Madison, Conn.

title: 14 AMERICANS ADVANCE IN TCHAIKOVSKY COMPETITION
description: Fourteen Americans - five cellists, five violinists and four pianists - have advanced into the semifinal round of the seventh International Tchaikovsky Competition, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

title: Index; International
description: Reporter's notebook: Castro offers to give his all A2 Reagan pledges to help Costa Rica's ailing economy A3 Mrs. Gandhi nominates Home Minister to be President A4 Around the World A5 Three ex-enemies sign pact forming Cambodian exile regime A6 Poles to purge academically and ideologically unfit professors A7 Lebanese leaders are trying to sort out their differences A8 Israel lists its own casualty figures A8 U.S. destroyer is reportedly fired on by Vietnamese vessels A10 Government/Politics House plan hears pleas to save national park system A17 Death-penalty sponsor in Jersey Senate isn't without doubts B2 Washington Talk Briefing B5 Patricia Roberts Harris seeks local office B5 At release of hog figures, atmosphere of conspiracy B5 Georgia pepper stars at book party B5 60-Second Debate: Political action fund contributions B5 General Around the Nation A12 Mental hospital where Hinckley is to be evaluated B6 Landlord agrees to halt further sales in a co-op conversion B12 Health/Science X-ray bursts appear to bolster black hole theory D19 Countdown begins for flight of fourth space shuttle D19 Obituaries Stanley C. Hope, ex-president of Esso Standard Oil Co. B11 The Living Section Food Blue-veined cheeses: the ex- panding choices C1

title: M-G-M/U.A. to Sell Some of Its Assets
description: The debt-burdened M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment Company said today that it had agreed to sell its music publishing business and a portion of its celebrated film library to Warner Communications Inc. for $95 million.

title: LIBERATION OR INCINERATION?; *
description: To the Editor:

title: A MILD NEW PRESIDENT FOR ARGENTINA
description: Reynaldo Benito Antonio Bignone, who was thrust into Argentina's presidency today, is a curious complement to the man who put him there, Lieut. Gen. Cristino Nicolaides.

title: Volcker Cites Latin Risks
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the recent pace of Western lending to Latin America would have to be cut back.

title: NO ARMS AGREEMENT WITHOUT 'GENEROSITY'
description: To the Editor:

title: Oilers Obtain Mulvey
description: Paul Mulvey, who was sent to the minors for refusing to jump over the boards and join a brawl last Jan. 24, was traded by the Los Angeles Kings to the Edmonton Oilers for a minor league wing, Blair Barnes. Mulvey wound up the season in New Haven. After investigating the incident, the National Hockey League fined the Kings $5,000 and suspended Coach Don Perry for 15 days in February.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Ho Chi Minh City on June 5 about children of American-Vietnamese background incorrectly gave the number of such cases documented by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the American Embassy in Bangkok. It is 2,000, although the High Commissioner believes the children number about 4,000.

title: ON THE FALKLAND CRISIS, MOSCOW AND HAVANA
description: The crisis over the Falkland Islands provides some important lessons about Soviet and Cuban policies in Latin America that should not be ignored by the Reagan Administration as it attempts to repair the damage caused by Britain's victory.

title: Tackling a Piano
description: Barry Switzer's instructions from his wife were stern and precise: ''Greg is to get in his two hours of practice every day.'' So while Switzer, the University of Oklahoma football coach, was attending a Big Eight news conference at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in New York yesterday, his 13-year-old son was hitting the keyboard in a suite with piano arranged for him by the hotel.

title: FILM: 'BOB LE FLAMBEUR,' ABOUT A GENTLE CRIMINAL
description: ''Bob le Flambeur'' was shown as part of the 1981 New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of Sept. 26, 1981. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio 2, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: IN SKIS OR RACQUETS, HE'S MADE A NAME
description: Howard Head has done it again. He developed the metal ski and in 1969 the AMF Corporation acquired his Head Ski Company for $16 million. He developed the oversize tennis racquet and now is selling the company that makes them, Prince Manufacturing Inc., to Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., for $62 million in Chesebrough common stock.

title: Libby Klaperman, 60, Is Dead; Writer and Jewish Union Aide
description: Libby Klaperman, a writer and former national vice president and education chairman of the Women's Branch of the Union of the Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, died last Friday at her home in Lawrence, L.I. She was 60 years old.

title: Taiwan Acts to Widen Its Nuclear Technology
description: Taiwan has announced plans to reduce its almost complete reliance on the United States for nuclear expertise by seeking French technology to reprocess its weapons-grade nuclear wastes.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens. 7:30 P.M. Craig Swan (5-1), who saw extensive bullpen duty early in the season as he came back from a shoulder injury, continues in the starting rotation, facing the Expos' Steve Rogers (8-3). Swan has apologized to Manager George Bamberger for the fuss he created in complaining over the Mets' travel arrangements. (Television - SportsChannel. Radio - WMCA, 570, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Brewers at Milwaukee. Mike Morgan (3-4) pitches for the Yankees against Mike Caldwell (4-5). (Television - WPIX, Channel 11. Radio -WABC, 770, 8:30 P.M.) Golf Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, at the Westchester Country Club, North and Purchase Streets, Harrison, N.Y. The pro-am portion of this $400,000 tournament begins at 7:45 A.M. Tom Watson, winner of the United States Open, is expected to be there and so are Bob Hope, Dinah Shore and Ivan Lendl.

title: Ex-Police Officer Held In Perth Amboy Killing
description: A former Perth Amboy police sergeant was arrested today and charged with murdering a Perth Amboy man while robbing his apartment and setting it on fire, officials said.

title: Kean Picks Public Defender
description: Public Advocate Joseph H. Rodriguez will be nominated to replace Stanley C. Van Ness as the State Public Defender, Governor Kean announced today. Mr. Kean said he had informed the State Senate of his intention to nominate Mr. Rodriguez during its session on Monday.

title: BRIEFING
description: Helms Aide Joins Law Firm

title: Coke Completes Columbia Merger
description: The Coca-Cola Company announced completion of its acquisition of Columbia Pictures Industries, which the softdrink concern valued at about $750 million.

title: Heileman Pabst Talks
description: Russell Cleary, chairman of the G. Heileman Brewing Company, said today that the company had discussed acquiring the Pabst Brewing Company with a New Orleans company, but he denied that Heileman and the Coy International Corporation had reached any agreement. He added that he was not pursuing a deal with Coy but that Heileman was awaiting results from a proposal by Irwin Jacobs, a Minneapolis businessmen, under which Mr. Jacobs's group would acquire Pabst and then sell some Pabst operations to Heileman.

title: THE WHITE-COLLAR PAY FREEZE
description: As interest rates remain stubbornly high and order books thin, more companies are freezing, or even cutting, the salaries of their white-collar workers.

title: 60-Second Debate; Should a limit be placed on the amount of money a Congressional candidate can get from political action committees?
description: Dan Glickman Democratic Representative from Kansas

title: Reagan Fills Intelligence Job
description: President Reagan announced today that he intended to nominate Charles Jarvis Meyers, a Denver lawyer and former dean at Stanford University, to be a member of the President's Intelligence Oversight Board. In addition, Mr. Reagan named Edward Sulzberger, a New York realtor, to be a member of the Board of Directors of the National Corporation for Housing Partnerships.

title: NABOKOV 'QUIXOTE' TALKS SLATED IN '83
description: Vladimir Nabokov's lectures in two books - ''Lectures on Literature'' and ''Lectures on Russian Literature'' - will be joined by a third volume early next year titled ''Lectures on Don Quixote,'' published by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich/Bruccoli Clark.

title: 113 Arrested In Drug Raids
description: The police arrested 113 persons yesterday and confiscated drugs and cash in an eight-hour sweep of the Lower East Side, authorities said.

title: LEVI STRAUSS DATA GENERAL TUMBLE
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the San Francisco-based apparel maker, reported yesterday that net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1982 fell 46.5 percent, to $18.6 million, or 45 cents a share, from $34.6 million, or 83 cents a share last year. Sales for the period declined by a smaller margin, 10.7 percent, to $612.5 million, from $686.1 million in the second quarter of 1981.

title: MOOD IS 'ANGRY' AS BEGIN MEETS PANEL OF SENATE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin left the United States today after what was described as a highly emotional confrontation on Capitol Hill with senators critical of Israel's policies in Lebanon and in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan.

title: BLACK MAN IS KILLED BY MOB IN BROOKLYN: ATTACK CALLED RACIAL
description: Three men were attacked and one of them was beaten to death when their car stalled on a street in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning. The victims, who were on their way home from work, were black, and the police said the attack was unprovoked and ''racially motivated.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Perils of Technology

title: U.S. CHARGES CANADA ON M.T.A. PACT
description: The United States is bringing formal charges that the Canadian Government illegally subsidized export credits to help a Canadian manufacturer win a contract to supply New York City with subway cars, the United States trade representative, Bill Brock, announced today.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 23, 1982
description: International A major Israeli offensive led by planes and tanks began in Lebanon in an apparent effort to drive Syrian and Palestinian forces from the Beirut-Damascus highway. Israeli jets and artillery also bombarded Palestinian camps and residential areas in Beirut. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Israel announced a new cease-fire after several hours of fighting at the request of Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy. (A8:1-2.)

title: Soviet Hunger Striker Reported in Hospital
description: A Soviet hunger striker named Yuri Balovlenkov, who ended a 42-day fast after receiving Government permission to join his wife in the United States, has been taken to a hospital, his mother said today.

title: No Headline
description: TFollowing is the roll-call vote by which the Senate, 51 to 45, tentatively accepted the compromise budget for the fiscal year 1983. Those not listed did not vote.; FOR THE BUDGET - 51; Republicans - 48

title: Bozell & Jacobs Is Set To Acquire Healthmark
description: Bozell & Jacobs is on the verge of acquiring Healthmark, a health care ad agency, Charles D. Peebler, B.& J.'s chairman, confirmed yesterday.

title: Treasury Issues Move Lower; 6-Month Bill's Rate 13.18%
description: Negative economic statistics combined with the credit market's entrenched worries over monetary and fiscal policy to force prices of Government securities moderately lower yesterday. This offset Monday's gains and sent yields back up to the levels prevailing on Friday.

title: Hagler Injures Rib
description: Another injury may have added to the string of title fights that have been canceled or postponed in recent months. Marvelous Marvin Hagler's defense of the middleweight championship against Fulgencio Obelmejias, scheduled for July 15 in Italy, has been threatened by a rib injury that Hagler suffered in a sparring session Tuesday night.

title: JOSEPH A. MARGOLIES, A FORMER EXECUTIVE FOR BRENTANO'S, DIES
description: Joseph A. Margolies, vice president and merchandising manager of the Brentano's bookstores from 1944 to 1951, died Tuesday at a nursing home in West Hartford, Conn. He was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S.-CITY TASK FORCE ARRESTS 303 CRIMINALS IN 10-WEEK EFFORT
description: Working quietly out of an abandoned Brooklyn warehouse, a special task force of Federal marshals and New York City detectives arrested 303 fugitives and career criminals in a 10-week roundup that ended yesterday, officials said.

title: Ruth Muskrat Bronson, 84; A Specialist in Indian Affairs
description: Ruth Muskrat Bronson, a specialist in American Indian affairs and a former executive secretary of the National Congress of American Indians, died June 12 at a nursing home in Tucson, Ariz. She was 84 years old and lived in Tucson.

title: West Side Man Slain in Apartment
description: A man was found fatally beaten last night in his apartment at 215 West 98th Street. The man, whose identity had not yet been confirmed by the police last night, was apparently bludgeoned to death with a hammer, according to Sgt. Leroy Barr.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: IN 1896, a young Swiss landscape architect named Theodore Wirth became superintendent of public parks in Hartford. Within a year, he began work on what became the first municipal rose garden in the United States, a decidedly Continental touch within a park system fashioned mostly in the English style. Today, after a five-year period of restoration, the Rose Garden, on the corner of Asylum and Prospect Avenues, is still the elaborate centerpiece of Elizabeth Park, and for the next few weeks will be at its peak of bloom.

title: JUDGE HEARS ARGUMENTS ON THE RELEASE OF HAITIANS
description: A Federal district judge who last Friday declared the Government's year-old detention policy for Haitian refugees to be illegal heard proposals today on how best to go about paroling the refugees.

title: SOTHEBY'S WOES ARE SHARED IN ART WORLD
description: If Sotheby's, the world's oldest and largest auction house, were itself put on the block today, the bidding would be less than electric.

title: RHINEBECK, N.Y.  The biggest craft fair in the world is bigger than ever. Now in its 17th year, the Fair at Rhinebeck, which used to be called the Northeast Craft Fair, has 580 exhibitors whose wares are spread through four hangarlike buildings, three huge tents and assorted open-air stands at the Dutchess County Fairgrounds here.
description: Store buyers and gallery owners scurry from booth to booth seeking the handmade wares their customers have developed a craving for in recent years. The demand grows: Crafts are now a $2 billion industry in America. Sales at Rhinebeck last summer were $5 million, up $500,000 from the year before.

title: Tobacco Plant to Close
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, a subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries, said today that it would stop production at its cigarette manufacturing plant here on July 30. The company, which said it would keep its corporate headquarters here, plans to shift its operations to a modern plant in Macon, Ga. The shutdown will eliminate more than 800 salaried and hourly jobs at the plant.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE ACTS REVEALED
description: The commander of the Johannesburg security police was closely questioned today in an inquest into the death in detention of a white unionist.

title: REPORTS OF INSIDER TRADING
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follows: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: CONCERT: JOHANNA MEIER SINGS 'FIDELIO' IN CENTRAL PARK
description: It is only about a 20-block walk from the marble and glass facing of the Metropolitan Opera House to the Great Lawn of Central Park, but a great deal can happen to an opera when it is transported those few short blocks. If the amplification fails, as it did during the first part of Tuesday night's unstaged performance of Beethoven's ''Fidelio,'' any similarity between what is seen and heard over the night air and a real, live opera is strictly coincidental.

title: Tests on Reactor's Core Start at Three Mile Island
description: Tests that could give the first hard evidence of the extent of damage inside Three Mile Island's crippled nuclear reactor began tonight but had to be stopped after a few minutes, officials said.

title: Snipers Kill 3 People On River in Tennessee
description: Three people were killed and another was seriously wounded today when snipers opened fire on them while they were fishing on the Duck River in Maury County, the police said.

title: News Analysis
description: The reversal of lower-court decisions in the Levittown case yesterday represents a significant blow to forces seeking to eliminate unevenness in spending by rich and poor school districts across the state.

title: Nirvana Betters Bermuda Record
description: The 81-foot dark-blue sloop Nirvana drove across the finish line first in the Bermuda Race today, breaking the record for the 635-mile course by more than five hours.

title: WHY STEEL USERS NEED A REALISTIC TRADE POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: LENDL FINDS GRASS IS ONLY FOR GOLFERS
description: Ivan Lendl, who is ranked No. 4 in the world tennis standing, had said that he is not playing at Wimbledon this year because he does not play well on grass.

title: 20 NATIONS ADOPT TIN PRICE PACT
