description: Twenty countries accounting for most of the world's production and consumption of tin adopted a five-year agreement today that is meant to stabilize the metal's price on international markets.

title: Briefs on the Arts; Lincoln Center Granted $1.25 Million by Hearsts
description: Lincoln Center and three of its constituents received $1.25 million from the William Randolph Hearst Foundation Tuesday night. ''We are responding to the Reagan Administration's challenge to the private sector to increase its support to the vitally important area of the performing arts,'' Frank A. Bennack Jr., the president of the Hearst Corporation, said.

title: BOSSA NOVA: PAUL WINTER
description: TWENTY years ago, Paul Winter, a saxophonist fresh out of Northwestern University, wangled a State Department tour of Asia and Latin America for his college be-bop band. In Rio de Janiero, he heard bossa nova for the first time, and was one of the first American jazz musicians to bring that music to the United States.

title: NEW INVESTMENT IN FOTOMAT
description: The Konishiroku Photo Industry Company, a leading Japanese manufacturer of photographic products and the makers of Konica cameras, said yesterday that it would invest $13.5 million in the Fotomat Corporation in exchange for an increase in its stake in the large photofinishing retail chain to 20 percent from 8 percent.

title: Norcen Energy
description: The Ontario Securities Commission said it was investigating a takeover bid that Norcen Energy Resources Ltd., a Toronto-based oil company, is making for the Hanna Mining Company. Norcen is currently appealing a Federal court ruling in Cleveland earlier this month that blocked its offer to buy 42.7 percent, or about 3.8 million shares, of Hanna common stock for $45 a share. The company currently owns 8.8 percent of Hanna, a Cleveland-based mineral producer that has substantial iron ore and other mining interests in Canada.

title: Fletcher/Mayo Given All Harvester Ads
description: The International Harvester Company, the Chicago-based heavy equipment manufacturer with major financial troubles, has consolidated the responsibility for all advertising for its equipment group, previously at three agencies, in one - Fletcher/Mayo Associates, a subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: BALLET: DANISH ATTENTION TO NONDANCING ROLES
description: THE special aspect about the Royal Danish Ballet that never ceases to amaze is the attention paid to the most minor of nondancing roles in its productions.

title: FRIENDS AND COLLEAGUES RECALL CHEEVER AT A MEMORIAL SERVICE
description: In this Hudson River town where he spent much of his later life, friends and colleagues remembered John Cheever this afternoon as a writer of radiance and a man of charm.

title: Charter Unit Sued By Securities Firms
description: Two securities firms, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Inc., said that they had filed a class action complaint against the Flight Transportion Corporation and others in United States District Court in Minneapolis.

title: 2 YOUTHS SEIZED AS ARRESTS START IN RACIAL KILLING
description: Two teen-agers were arrested yesterday in the fatal beating of a transit worker in Brooklyn on Tuesday by a taunting group of young men.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA CLASH ON HIGHWAY EAST OF BEIRUT
description: Israeli planes, tanks and artillery attacked Syrian positions just south of the Beirut-Damascus highway today as a cease-fire announced by Israel Tuesday night collapsed.

title: Restaurants in Japan
description: General Mills Inc. said today that its restaurant group and the Jusco Company had formed a 50-50 joint venture in Japan to open four Red Lobster restaurants by the end of 1983.

title: Bell Canada Sets Restructuring
description: The Bell Canada telephone company said it plans to reorganize itself and establish a new parent company, to be called Bell Canada Enterprises, through a share-for-share exchange of its stock.

title: STENCILED DESIGNS FOR FLOOR CLOTHS
description: Stenciled floor cloths have become popular today among people in rented houses or apartments who don't want to invest the time or money in permanent decoration. Like wall stenciling, stenciled floor cloths also appeared in the 1700's and were originally used in place of costly Oriental rugs.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE THATCHER ADDRESS
description: Following are excerpts from a speech delivered yesterday to the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, as provided by the British Mission to the United Nations:

title: Newmont Layoffs
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation said yesterday that it was curtailing mine development work at the San Manuel division of its Magma Copper Company subsidiary and that it had begun layoffs of 650 employees. The company said the moves would not affect production immediately as the division had been operating at reduced levels because of weakness in the copper market.

title: Allen's 'Tramps'
description: Was George Allen kidding when he said he could field a competitive franchise in the new United States Football League with players cut from National Football League camps?

title: ISRAEL SAYS SYRIA BROKE CEASE-FIRE
description: Israel said today that Syrian and Palestinian forces attacked Israeli troops in Lebanon south of the Beirut-Damascus highway this morning, resulting in heavy fighting.

title: FRENCH-SOVIET CREW BEGINS SPACE MISSION TODAY
description: If all goes well, a 43-year-old French Air Force colonel, Jean-Loup Chretien, will ride a Soviet rocket into earth orbit Thursday with two Russians, thus becoming the first astronaut to fly in space who is neither an American nor a citizen of a Communist nation.

title: BIG 3 CAR SALES OFF 21.9% AS G.M. SLIDES 25.4%
description: The Big Three auto makers reported today that new car sales fell 21.9 percent in the June 11-20 selling period, the first drop in auto sales in more than a month.

title: A 'LITTLE ARCHITECTURAL TOUR'
description: IT used to be a shoulder-pad factory. Now it is Knoll International's new SoHo space, which also houses its showroom for residential furniture - a place to look at pieces that must be purchased through architect or designer.

title: Aerojet-General
description: The Aerojet-General Corporation said that it would sell, close or merge 10 of its profitable subsidiary companies and that it would concentrate on United States space exploration and munitions. As a result, its work force of 8,000 would be reduced to 5,000. The maker of rocket engines, a subsidiary of the General Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, Ohio, said that it would retain five companies, all in the Sacramento or Los Angeles areas.

title: G.M. and Fujitsu Start Robot Unit
description: The General Motors Corporation and Fujitsu Fanuc Ltd. of Japan have established a joint venture to build industrial robots in the United States, G.M. sources said.

title: F.C.C. Clears MCI Merger
description: The MCI Communications Corporation was authorized by the Federal Communictions Commission to proceed with its first major diversification move by purchasing Western Union International Inc. from the Xerox Corporation.

title: Japan Opens New Rail Line
description: Japan National Railways put a new fleet of high-speed trains into operation today on a line linking Tokyo and northern Japan, cutting train travel time in half. The new green-andwhite bullet trains cover the 291 miles between Tokyo and Morioka in three hours and 17 minutes, traveling at a maximum speed of 130 miles an hour and stopping at seven stations on the way.

title: RODGERS DEFEATS METS, 5-0
description: In the clubhouse of the Montreal Expos, where grown men are known as Kid, Cro and Hawk and where there was once a Spaceman, the leading pitcher is known as Cy, as in Cy Young, as in the Cy Young Award, the award he has never earned. Perhaps this will be the year Steve Rogers changes that situation.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt UNDER THE APPLE TREE. By Dan Wakefield. 342 pages. Delacorte/Lawrence. $13.95.

title: FINANCING METHOD FOR SCHOOLS RULED VALID IN NEW YORK
description: The New York State Court of Appeals, overturning two lower courts, found today that the state's system of financing its public schools was constitutional and that there was no constitutional requirement that school spending be equal among districts.

title: Small Business Bill Advances
description: A bill to give small businesses a bigger share of the $40 billion that the Federal Government spends on research and development each year won House approval today.

title: SHOW TO SALUTE N.C. WYETH
description: In observance of the 100th anniversary of the birth of the renowned illustrator N.C. (Newell Convers) Wyeth, the Brandywine River Museum in Chadds Ford, Pa., is honoring him with a major exhibition. The show, which runs through Sept. 6, consists of 48 paintings, including landscapes, still lifes and portraits.

title: U.S. Business Failures Up
description: Business failures rose for the second consecutive week, bringing the total so far in 1982 to 10,978, the highest level since the 1930's, Dun & Bradstreet reported yesterday.

title: MRS. THATCHER AND REAGAN TALK FOR AN HOUR
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher met with President Reagan for an hour today and later declared that there was ''no difference'' between her and Mr. Reagan on the issue of sovereignty in the Falkland Islands.

title: AIDE TO MUSTO WINS THE SPECIAL ELECTION FOR HIS SENATE SEAT
description: Nicholas J. LaRocca, a 69-year-old lawyer and legislative aide to former State Senator William V. Musto, easily won a special election today to replace Mr. Musto, who forfeited his seat upon his conviction and sentencing on racketeering and conspiracy charges.

title: Hot Feet Limited Holmes's Dancing
description: Larry Holmes could not ''get up on my toes like I wanted'' for his heavyweight title fight against Gerry Cooney because of a bad case of hot feet, the World Boxing Council champion said yesterday. The canvas in the outdoor ring in Las Vegas, Nev., which had been exposed to a 99-degree sunny day, was so hot that the champion's feet became badly blistered.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Electric Power Co. said it would seek regulatory approval for a public offering of up to seven million shares.

title: RENEWAL OF CENTRAL PARK STIRRING BROADER DEBATE
description: Twenty-four pin oaks planted in 1947 in memory of 24 servicemen who died during World War II are slated for removal by the Parks Department as part of a comprehensive plan to renovate the park.

title: ALVIN WILLIAMS STOKES
description: Alvin Williams Stokes, a former New Jersey investigator on the staff of the House Un-American Activities Committee, died Sunday at his home in Westwood following a long illness.

title: LATE RALLY SPURS 13.51 DOW GAIN
description: A late rally spurred by news of Senate passage of the compromise Federal budget plan sent the Dow Jones industrial average up 13.51 points yesterday, its biggest daily gain in three months, in very heavy trading.

title: SCHWEIKER PROPOSES TO SPEED DRUG APPROVAL
description: Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services, today proposed several procedural changes intended to allow new drugs to be marketed up to six months earlier than under current rules.

title: Thrift Unit Tie Is Set on Coast
description: The California Federal Savings and Loan Association reached an agreement today to acquire the Brentwood Savings and Loan Association in a $44 million transaction that will make California Federal the nation's third-largest savings and loan institution.

title: LABORITE LEADERS MOVE TO OUST LEFT-WING FACTION
description: The Labor Party leadership, seeking to reverse a long political slide, moved today to rid itself of a ''conspiratorial'' left-wing faction that was partly responsible for defections to the new Social Democratic Party.

title: Voting Rights Measure Approved by Congress
description: The House gave final legislative approval today to a 25-year extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. The measure went to President Reagan for his signature.

title: Northern Tier Pipeline Gets Getty Executives
description: The Northern Tier pipeline project, a plan to pump Alaskan crude oil across 1,500 miles from Puget Sound to Clearbrook, Minn., appeared dead in April after Gov. John Spellman of Washington rejected a critical permit application.

title: Settlement in Sierra Deaths
description: A tentative $4.9 million settlement has been reached in suits filed by the families of seven men who plunged to their death when a platform collapsed at a hydroelectric construction site in the Sierra Nevada. The men were killed Jan. 23, 1981, when a steel work platform collapsed inside a 971-foot shaft at the Pacific Gas and Electric Company's Helms hydroelectric project in the mountains east of Fresno.

title: POLISH LOAN OF 1946
description: To the Editor:

title:
CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
SYMPHONY ORCHESTRAS: THE TONE IS STILL UPBEAT
description: IT is strange how the possibility of the death knell for an American orchestra is greeted within the family. There is no hysteria, no wringing of hands. Indictments are not leveled at the Federal Government for failing to come to the rescue. Instead, there is a realization that the amount of money an orchestra can spend is limited, and a shared opinion that any orchestra that cannot live within its means is doomed.

title: FROM RKO'S FILES, A GIFT FOR U.C.L.A.
description: Nearly 1,000 filing-cabinet drawers full of scripts, musical scores, contracts, private letters and documents from RKO General were donated today to the University of California at Los Angeles's film archives.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy's Chicago Move Pays
description: NO matter how big a reputation an advertising agency may have, establishing a new office in another United States city with a large indigenous agency population is extremely difficult. New York and Chicago, the two largest advertising towns, are probably the most difficult.

title: Woman, 34, Slain While Sunbathing
description: A 34-year-old woman was shot to death yesterday afternoon while sunbathing on the roof of her Brooklyn apartment building, according to the police, who had no immediate explanation for the shooting.

title: 2 High Aides' Wives In Africa for 2 Weeks
description: The wives of Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to President Reagan, and of Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis are on a two-week, five-nation trip to Africa that is being paid for by the Government.

title: WNET'S BOARD PASSES A 'BAREBONES' BUDGET
description: ''I am personally confident that we are not about to go down the tubes -we are on a very sound course,'' said John S. Crowley, a trustee of WNET-TV, urging his fellow board members to adopt a ''barebones'' budget of $47.4 million for the station next year. The board approved the budget. If all goes according to plan, the station projects a $542,000 surplus.

title: 10 New Options
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange, the nation's largest options marketplace, will open trading on 10 new options starting Monday.

title: More on Drug Use
description: Kevin McLain, the linebacker who was the No.1 draft choice of the Los Angeles Rams in 1976, acknowledges that he often used illegal drugs when he was a pro player. ''I enjoyed socializing and partying,'' McLain, who retired two years ago, said in an interview with The Los Angeles Herald Examiner.

title: TV TRANSMISSIONS, SATELLITE TO HOMES, APPROVES BY F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission opened a broad new avenue of television broadcasting today by approving final rules for direct satellite-to-home transmission.

title: Pittsburgh Brewer Ends Pabst Talks
description: Robert Seymour, chairman and president of the Pittsburgh Brewing Company, said that a proposed merger with the Pabst Brewing Company had been terminated.

title: RACCOON KILLS A RARE CRANE
description: Tex, a whooping crane that attracted national attention when she gave birth after going through intricate mating rituals with a human, was mauled and killed by a raccoon today.

title: Tokens vs. Taxes
description: The State Legislature and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority view the future from different angles. The legislators, their eyes on public opinion, believe the transit taxes they passed in 1981 should hold the fare at 75 cents. The M.T.A., straining to impress bond-rating agencies, worries that bankers will notice that last year's taxes haven't produced the expected subsidies.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Sine Die Adjournment Of Part M
description: Maruffi's, an old-time saloon, had been a hangout for cops and correction officers since 1938, when the Tombs and the Criminal Courts Building opened across Baxter Street. There was a lot of waiting-around time for them while suspects went through arraignment procedures.

title: JAPAN'S HITACHI ADMITS PAYMENT FOR I.B.M. DATA
description: Hitachi Ltd., a leading Japanese computer manufacturer, said today that it had authorized the payment of $540,000 for confidential computer information belonging to the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Jackson Sees Chrysler Aides
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met with officials of the Chrysler Corporation today to discuss how the auto maker could increase its dealings with black businessmen and promote more blackowned dealerships, officials said.

title: YUGOSLAVIA - STRAINS, RIVALRIES, DISPARITIES
description: Two years to the minute after Marshal Tito died, the sirens sounded throughout Yugoslavia. An eerie quiet descended over all the land. For one brief moment, the disparate peoples of the six republics joined in silent tribute to the man whom most revere, some revile and all acknowledge as father of their fiercely independent country.

title: JUSTICES AGAIN BAR EVIDENCE IN ILLEGAL ARREST
description: The Supreme Court today reaffirmed a longstanding doctrine barring the police from using the ''poisonous fruits'' of an illegal arrest.

title: TYPES OF CAR SAFETY SEATS FOR CHILDREN
description: One type of furniture for children is highly recommended by highway safety experts and required by law in a growing number of states: the automobile child safety seat.

title: Decision File; Court Reinstates Intelligence Aide
description: When the smoke cleared, the Army's case against one of its civilian intelligence specialists turned out to be hush-hush hocus-pocus, a court held. In the dictum of the Court of Appeals here, the evidence was hearsay and, at times, ''bald and misleading.''

title: STENCILERS, TEACHERS, BOOKS AND SOURCES
description: Professional Stencilers The Clayton Store, Star Route, Southfield, Mass. 02159, 413-229- 2621.

title: BIG RING SMUGGLING ALIENS REPORTED BROKEN
description: Undercover immigration agents have smashed a smuggling ring that was responsible for bringing 24,000 aliens a year into the United States from Mexico and seven other countries, Federal officials said today.

title: ROCKIES SELECT A COACH
description: The new hockey team in the Meadowlands may not have a new name, or a lease, but it does have a coach. He is Billy MacMillan, who left a job as Al Arbour's assistant with the Islanders two years ago to coach the Colorado Rockies and then moved up to general manager after the 1980-81 season.

title: COURT APPOINTEES TO MODIFY REDISTRICTING PLAN FOR STATE
description: A three-judge Federal court ruled yesterday that a court-appointed lawyer should modify and complete a reapportionment plan for New York State while the state's legislative leaders try to overcome Justice Department objections to their own reapportionment plan.

title: U.S. AGENTS SEIZE TANKER OFF COAST
description: An armed Federal task force went out on the high seas and boarded a Liberian-flag tanker late Tuesday, removing 22 crew members who had kept the ship immobilized at anchor for more than five weeks in a labor dispute.

title: CLOSE ENCOUNTERS OF THE NUCLEAR KIND
description: To the Editor:

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens, 7:30 P.M. A rare instance of playing in town the same night as the Yankees. Charlie Puleo pitches the getaway game before a weekend series in Philadelphia. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WBNX, 1380, in Spanish, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. The Yankees return after a difficult series in Milwaukee, with Ron Guidry (8-1) on the mound against the Indians (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770, 8 P.M.) Golf Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, at the Westchester Country Club, North and Purchase Streets, Harrison, N.Y. The opening round begins at 7:45 A.M. Ray Floyd is the defending champion, but Tom Watson is on hand after his victory over Jack Nicklaus in the United States Open.

title: 24-Hour Strike Jolts British Hospitals
description: Hundreds of hospitals offered only emergency treatment today as Britain's state-run National Health Service was hit with a 24-hour strike by ambulancemen, porters, cleaners, clerks and cooks demanding higher pay.

title: SUPREME COURT REAFFIRMS PUBLIC'S RIGHT OF ACCESS TO CRIMINAL TRIALS
description: The Supreme Court, reaffirming a 1980 ruling that the press and the public have a ''constitutional right of access to criminal trials,'' today declared unconstitutional a state law that required courtrooms to be closed during the testimony of young rape victims.

title: REAGAN SIGNS AGENTS MEASURE
description: President Reagan, calling agents of the Central Intelligence Agency the ''heroes of a grim twilight struggle,'' signed into law today a bill that would make it a crime to disclose the names of covert American intelligence agents.

title: Red Sox 10, Tigers 4
description: BOSTON (AP) - Glenn Hoffman drove in four runs with a tie-breaking two-run homer and a single as Boston dealt Detroit its 10th consecutive loss.

title: Blue Note Signs Chet Baker, Trumpeter
description: Chet Baker, one of the West Coast's cool-school jazz musicians of the 1950's, will perform in New York at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, from next Tuesday through July 4.

title: G.E. Information
description: The General Electric Company announced a national toll-free information service to give consumers information on where to buy G.E. products and how to repair them. The service, on telephone number 800-626-2000, uses 70 operators and a computer and will cost $3.5 million in its first year, company officials said. It is the result of a G.E. survey in which consumers indicated they needed more information about the company's products.

title: Harvester Cuts Freight Costs
description: The International Harvester Company announced today that it had chartered a freighter to export $15 million worth of its agricultural equipment to Australia.

title: REAGAN'S TRAVELING SPY STORY
description: President Reagan in remarks at a bill-signing ceremony at the Central Intelligence Agency, Langley, Va. White House transcript. June 23, 1982.

title: LINK TO TRADE TALKS IS DENIED BY U.S.
description: A Justice Department official denied today that its charges accusing employees of two Japanese computer companies of trying to steal trade secrets from I.B.M. were intended to exert pressure on Japan in trade negotiations.

title: EXCERPTS FROM RULING ON FINANCING SCHOOLS
description: Following are excerpts from the majority decision and the dissenting opinion of the New York State Court of Appeals in the Levittown, L.I., school case. The majority decision was written by Judge Hugh R. Jones and the dissent by Judge Jacob D. Fuchsberg. Majority Decision

title: BECKER EXPECTS A LOSS, BUT SAYS IT IS 'SOUND'
description: Warburg Paribas Becker-A.G. Becker Inc. expects to incur a loss of $2 million for the eight months ending June 30, but nevertheless is in ''very sound'' condition, Ira Wender, its president and chief executive officer, said yesterday.

title: Princess Anne Silent On Birth of a Nephew
description: Princess Anne, asked how she felt being an aunt with the birth of a son to her brother, Prince Charles, and the Princess of Wales, told reporters, ''That's my business!''

title: Inco Shutdown
description: The Inco Metals Company, a unit of Inco Ltd., said it will extend its Ontario division's shutdown to Oct. 3 and close its Manitoba mine for two months in an attempt to reduce production and costs. The company is also considering other cost-saving measures because of the continuing deterioration in company revenues as a result of lower metal prices and deliveries.

title: Royal to Buy U.S. Insurer
description: Royal Group of London, one of the largest British insurance companies, said yesterday that its American subsidiary, Royal Insurance, planned to acquire the Milbank Mutual Insurance Company of Milbank, S.D. This will give it an entry into a nine-state area ''where we would like to grow,'' a Royal Group spokesman said.

title: House of Fraser Vote
description: The House of Fraser P.L.C. has secured more proxy votes than Lonrho P.L.C. in the disputed resolutions due before the House of Fraser's annual meeting tomorrow in Glasgow, market sources said today. Proxies in favor of resolutions offered by the House of Fraser's management total 65 million shares of 151 million issued, they said, while Lonrho is supported by 57 million shares. Lonrho, however, is in a position to block the House of Fraser's two special resolutions, requiring 75 percent approval.

title: News Analysis
description: For several months the United States Conference of Mayors has been trying to put together a ''road show.'' A group of leading mayors would travel throughout the country to appeal for public support of their opposition to the Reagan Administration's domestic policies.

title: CITY SCHOOLS BAR 3 TEXTBOOKS SAID TO ENDORSE CREATIONISM
description: Three high school biology textbooks have been rejected for use in the New York City public schools because of what Board of Education officials say is an inadequate treatment of the Darwinian theory of evolution.

title: U.S. MILITARY ADVISERS ARE FOUND IN A COMBAT ZONE IN EL SALVADOR
description: In an apparent violation of restrictions governing their activities in El Salvador, American military advisers were encountered in a combat area on the Lempa River here today.

title: U.S. Opposes Grain Plan
description: The United States, Canada and Australia, the world's largest grain exporters, have expressed reservations about a grain reserve plan supported by the third world.

title: Chief Executive of SFN To Quit Book Publisher
description: Gordon R. Hjalmarson said yesterday that he planned to resign as chairman and chief executive officer of the SFN Companies, one of the nation's largest book publishers.

title: COSMOS WIN, 3-2 ON GOAL BY MOYERS
description: The Cosmos had another narrow escape tonight. They needed a late goal to defeat the Vancouver Whitecaps, 3-2, before a crowd of 22,914 at Giants Stadium.

title: Market Place; A Slow Start For Cigna
description: ON March 31, amid considerable fanfare, the Connecticut General Corporation and the INA Corporation officially formed the nation's second-largest investor-owned insurance enterprise. Known as the Cigna Corporation, it ranks behind the Aetna Life and Casualty Company among publicly traded insurance giants.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: SALVAGE AND HERBS
description: Savers of the Lost Arch Exhibition and Architects Awards Show, Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street), 935-3960.

title: HERS
description: ISAW another bad play last evening: a cute series of sketches that left me feeling cheated and soured me on the rest of the night. Once, sometimes twice a week, I go to the theater. I'm lucky - I have a friend who gets me a lot of free tickets so I don't have to spend huge sums for what is usually a disappointment. But I'd probably go anyway, even if I had to pay, even if the plays got worse, which is often hard to imagine. With a few rare exceptions the theater has been dormant for more than a decade. I know it, but I go because I believe, all evidence to the contrary, that the theater is still worthwhile. I choose to be credulous about it. I go as an act of faith.

title: Orr Sues Black Hawks
description: Bobby Orr has filed suit against the Chicago Black Hawks for $120,830 in back pay, plus interest and court costs.

title: WOMEN SAY THEY'LL END FAST BUT NOT RIGHTS FIGHT
description: Vowing that the fight for equal rights was far from over, seven women nevertheless said they would end their 37-day ''Hunger for Justice'' fast here Thursday.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Dramatists Take a Walk From Tony TV Show

title: 2 Killed and 62 Injured In Fire on Amtrak Train
description: A sleeping car on Amtrak's Coast Starlight burst into flame early today in the northern California mountains, killing two people and injuring 62.

title: Might Makes Wrong
description: ''This is not an invasion of Cambodia.'' - Richard Nixon, April 30, 1970. ''Israel did not invade any country.'' - Menachem Begin, June 21, 1982. WASHINGTON, June 23 - From the moment Israeli forces entered Lebanon, on June 6, we have been told that it was a limited operation - one that, with American leadership, could provide the opportunity for peace in the Middle East. It is time now to recognize that the facts are otherwise.

title: No Headline
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Living Section yesterday about wood for cooking included incorrect information on buying mesquite. A minimum wholesale order from Ranchmen's Manufacturing of Dallas is 300 cases at $12.50 a case.

title: Exemption Idea
description: Officials of the ''big three'' championships in tennis - Wimbledon, the United States Open and the French Open - will meet today at the All England Club, and a chief topic will be the creation of a qualifying exemption for champions at those events next year.

title: ARGENTINE CHIEF COURTS POLITICAL LEADERS
description: The retired general who is Argentina's newly designated President said today that he wanted to meet Thursday with civilian politicians to discuss the policies of his coming transition Government.

title: PRESENTING THE 'NATIONAL OPEN' CHAMPION
description: HARRISON, N.Y. E very so often during the last few days, with the inner smile of supreme satisfaction, Tom Watson has thought to himself, ''I'm the National Open champion.'' His phrasing is significant. The official name of the golf tournament he won Sunday is the United States Open, or simply the U.S. Open, sometimes just the Open. But when Tom Watson was growing up, and for decades before that, it was mostly known as the National Open.

title: HOUSING DESIGNED FOR THE DISABLED
description: Gary Sodergren, who has been disabled since his neck was broken in a car accident two years ago, pulled his van into the parking lot of the John C. Nutting Apartments here, got out and rolled up the walk in his wheelchair. There were no steps to climb, no problems with the doors and no barriers.

title: G.M. RETAINS DOMESTIC STEEL SUPPLIERS
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that the nine domestic companies that currently supply it with steel will continue to do so for the 1983 model year, which runs well into 1984.

title: SMALLEY HOMER DECIDES
description: After admitting he had ''absolutely stunk'' against left-handed pitchers this season, the switch-hitting Roy Smalley went out tonight and hit a three-run homer against a lefthanded pitcher, Mike Caldwell.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amadac Industries of Cincinnati announced that it had agreed to purchase Warren Refrigerator Co. from Chemold Corp. for $6.6 million.

title: Coe-Ovett in Jeopardy
description: The long-awaited confrontation between the world's two fastest middle-distance runners, in a three-race series this summer, appears to be in jeopardy. A shin injury suffered by Sebastian Coe has forced him to withdraw from one tune-up in Oslo Saturday and two others in Sweden, and has made it doubtful that he will be ready to face Steve Ovett in their first scheduled meeting, at London's Crystal Palace in a 3,000-meter race in mid-July. That Ovett has been out of action for eight months, trying to recuperate from the rupture of a thigh muscle, has added to the uncertainty.

title: Bridge: When a System Is Altered, Results Can Be Surprising
description: Switching systems is rather like switching autos. Reading the manual and knowing where the controls are is not enough: If you want to avoid skids and other misfortunes you must be able to react appropriately in a wide variety of situations.

title: BRIEFING
description: Monitoring Weapons Costs

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report May 21 on the Stadt Huys excavation in lower Manhattan where artifacts and building foundations from the early Dutch occupation of New York have been found incorrectly reported the date of the original discovery. The foundations were unearthed in 1970.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Eases Ruling on Texas Prisons
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit today modified the impact of a Federal court order aimed at reforming the Texas penal system by ruling that the state did not have to provide a cell for each inmate.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BLASTOFF

title: Blazers Get Carr
description: The Portland Trail Blazers thought the forward Kenny Carr would be a suitable replacement for Kermit Washington, who has retired. And the Detroit Pistons wanted another first-round selection in next week's draft. Both clubs thus expressed satisfaction in yesterday's trade involving the 6-foot-7-inch Carr. ... The Phoenix Suns said they had discussed with Red Auerbach, the Celtics' general manager, the possibility of getting rights to the contract of Dave Cowens, who is considering a comeback.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
FOR THE DO-IT-YOURSELFER, THINGS TO SUBSCRIBE TO
description: IF you are a hardware buff who likes to keep up to date, there are several publications that are useful sources of information. A monthly newsletter named Gadget calls itself ''The newsletter for grown-up kids.'' It is a 12-page publication that does not take advertising. The first several pages are devoted to critiques of three or four new appliances or electronic products. The rest of the publication consists of short essays on many products, from gadgets to sophisticated electronics. This section does not report on how products perform.

title: M.A.C. ENDORSES THE CITY BUDGET, BUT WARNS OF POTENTIAL PROBLEMS
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday endorsed New York City's new budget as balanced, but warned that because of uncertainties the city ''now faces the most difficult budgetary test since 1975.''

title: TV: SHIRLEY MACLAINE IN SPOTLIGHT
description: IN ''Illusions,'' a one-hour entertainment special on CBS-TV tonight at 9 o'clock, Shirley MacLaine has devised the perfect format for a star reluctant to share the spotlight with anybody else. She does have one guest - Gregory Hines, who joins Miss MacLaine for a brief novelty song-and-dance number. But for the rest of the show, through the courtesy of trick photography and assorted new technologies, Miss MacLaine, when not doing a solo, sings, dances and chats with herself.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've got a political document here that won't stand the light of implementation: You won't have the troops, you won't have the votes.'' -Senator Ernest F. Hollings, on the Federal budget. (D22:5)

title: HOUSE FOREIGN AFFAIRS PANEL SEEKS NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee, in a rebuff to President Reagan, approved a resolution today that called for a freeze in American and Soviet nuclear arsenals.

title: THE HIGHER COURAGE
description: Philip Habib, the selfless U.S. envoy in the Middle East, is still trying desperately to prevent a huge bloodbath. But the battle of Beirut seems inexorable.

title: 'Dancin' ' Will Close After Sunday Matinee
description: Bob Fosse's musical entertainment ''Dancin' '' will end its long Broadway run Sunday after the matinee performance at the Ambassador Theater.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;
description: The Reagan Administration asked Congress today for $5.1 million to give ''political and moral support'' to Nicaragua's Roman Catholic Church and other elements of the private sector opposed to the leftist Sandinist Government.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 24, 1982
description: International Israeli forces attacked Syrians just south of the Beirut-Damascus road as a cease-fire announced by Israel collapsed. The Israelis used planes, tanks and artillery in intense, daylong exchanges of fire, and fighting was reported in at least nine places along the highway. The American Embassy is closing today, and all Americans in Lebanon have been urged to leave. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel said heavy fighting was continuing at Beirut as well as along the Beirut-Damascus highway. An Israeli military spokesman said that Syrian and Palestinian forces had first broken the cease-fire. (A15:1.)

title: WHITE HOUSE REVISES 'NEW FEDERALISM' PROPOSALS
description: The Reagan Administration, in a revision of its ''new federalism'' proposals, has offered the states more control over Medicaid in return for the states' taking over the main welfare program, the White House said today.

title: HOUSE APPROVES $50 MILLION AID FOR LEBANON
description: The House of Representatives authorized a $50 million package of emergency humanitarian aid to Lebanon today, and some members took the opportunity to criticize Israel's invasion of that country and the policies of Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

title: 54-45 SENATE VOTE PASSES THE BUDGET
description: The Senate gave final approval today to a Republican-sponsored compromise budget for the fiscal year 1983, ending a tumultuous five-month Congressional debate on national priorities. The action set the stage for a new struggle over whether Congress is willing to enforce its budget plan.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Enemies Switch Candidates
description: Political opponents of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi selected Hans Raj Khanna, a former Supreme Court judge, as their presidential candidate after their first choice, a Communist leader, was disqualified.

title: News Analysis
description: The cascade of public outrage after John W. Hinckley Jr.'s acquittal Monday on the ground of insanity reflects a widespread suspicion that law and psychiatry have combined in a way that confuses juries and almost presumes that people cannot be held responsible for even the most bizarre and heinous crimes.

title: STATES CURBED ON TAKEOVERS
description: The Supreme Court, in a decision that apparently dooms efforts by 36 states to regulate corporate takeovers, declared today that the Illinois Business Takeover Act placed an ''excessive'' burden on interstate commerce and was unconstitutional.

title: Guilford Mills Set To Sell Its Assets
description: Guilford Mills Inc., a fabric company based in Greensboro, N.C., said that it had agreed in principle to sell its assets to some of its senior executives and two other investors, including Harold S. Geneen, a former chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, for $23 a share in cash.

title: PARTY MARKS THE 10TH ANNIVERSARY OF MS. MAGAZINE
description: GLORIA STEINEM exhorted the 1,200 or so guests gathered in the cavernous Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 66th Street to get out on the dance floor. ''Emma Goldman used to say,'' she told them, '' 'If there's no dancing, why go to the revolution?' ''

title: Bonn Says Sun Myung Moon Will Not Be Allowed to Enter
description: The West German border police are under orders to turn back the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, leader of the Unification Church, if he should seek to enter this country, a Government official said today.

title: BLUES AND WEAKFISH PLENTIFUL
description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Medium to large bluefish plentiful six to eight miles offshore; weakfish to eight pounds in same area; flounder fishing good in interior waters and Great Egg Inlet. Barnegat, N.J.: Mako sharks to 300 pounds taken offshore in recent days; blue sharks plentiful in the same area; bluefish from six to 12 pounds responding to chumming and bait offshore; commercial longliners taking swordfish 90 to 100 miles offshore. Point Pleasant, N.J.: Large bluefish plentiful in Mud Hole area, caught by bait and chumming day and night; good in Shinnecock Bay. Blackfishing good near Shinnecock Inlet. Montauk, L.I.: Large bluefish plentiful five to seven miles south of Montauk. Striped bass scarce. Medium-to-large porgies taken about a mile east of the lighthouse; two giant white sharks were spotted about 35 miles south of Montauk in midweek. One, estimated at 2,000 pounds, was harpooned by the Mistress Too out of Montauk, but it was lost. 2 Sea Bright, N.J.: Good fluking in

title: Baked Offerings
description: If there is one thing we've learned for sure from this century's series of medical communiques it's that living is bad for health.

title: MINORITIES MUST BE REPRESENTED
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE TAKING TWO AIRPORTS FROM M.T.A.
description: Governor Carey signed legislation yesterday transferring control of Stewart Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., and Republic Airport in Babylon, L.I., from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to the state. The action opens the way for more than $60 million in Federal spending in the areas and hundreds of job opportunities.

title: HOFFMAN, JUDGE FOR TRIAL OF CHICAGO 7, INCHES UNGENTLY TOWARD RETIREMENT
description: New amid the signed photographs and letters of praise that line the walls of Judge Julius Jennings Hoffman's chambers is a tribute from his colleagues on the United States Court for the Northern District of Illinois.

title: The Trouble With Isabelle
description: ''Isabelle will make us famous,'' the physicists at the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island said to themselves. ''Why, if her superconducting magnets soup up her counter-rotating proton beams to 400 giga electron volts apiece, and if the beams zap into one another head on, then by George, we may shake loose an intermediate vector boson! That will stick it to the Europeans for beating us to the gluon, and we'll win a Nobel Prize for sure.''

title: Co-op Board Says No To Klemperer
description: Celebrities, on occasion, have been turned down by co-op boards when they have sought to buy apartments in New York, and the actor Werner Klemperer joined the list a few days ago when he was rejected by the board of 5 Riverside Drive, at 73d Street. He was not thrilled about losing the two-bedroom apartment, Mr. Klemperer said.

title: TREASURY ISSUES UP SLIGHTLY
description: Government securities prices posted slight gains yesterday as the investment community prepared for $17 billion of new notes and bills that the Treasury will sell by July 1.

title: Jerseyan Is Held in Murders Of His Wife and Her Mother
description: A 27-year-old man has been arrested in the shooting deaths of his wife and her mother, the police said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: At the Lunch Hour: A Taste of Theater

title: 'SECOND CAREER' PRIESTS CAN VITALIZE THE CHURCH
description: To the Editor:

title: Poland's Food Rationing Will Be Phased Down
description: The Government plans a gradual reduction in the unpopular food rationing program started during last year's crisis, the official press agency P.A.P. reported today.

title: IMM Energy Services
description: IMM Energy Services and Technology said today that it had tentatively agreed to sell and lease back 19 offshore oil-service vessels. The move would increase its working capital by about $4 million, it said. In addition, the company said, it had agreed to acquire the Coates Marine Company of Houston for an undisclosed amount of common stock.

title: A 'CLOUD OF DOUBT' ENGULFS DONOVAN
description: To the Editor:

title: POTPOURRI: PRESERVING SCENTS OF SUMMER
description: SUMMER'S garden is filled with fragrance. There is the sweet smell of mock orange or the heavy odor of lavender. The rose garden offers a mixed perfume, while flower borders are individual with pinks, verbenas, sweet alyssum and petunias adding their scents. As evening comes there will be nicotiana and moonflower.

title: East Hampton Planning Poet-and-Artist Show
description: An art exhibition featuring collaborations between 42 pairs of poets and artists will open at the Guild Hall Museum in East Hampton on July 4 and close Aug. 1.

title: B.N.A. Rejects Thomson Offer
description: The International Thomson Organization Ltd., a publishing conglomerate based in Toronto, has made an $80 million bid, or $45 a share, to acquire the Bureau of National Affairs, a major publisher of newsletters on Government regulations, a B.N.A. official said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Black, White and Death

title: Q & A
description: Q. A concrete birdbath in my yard was accidentally knocked over and it cracked. I coated the inside with cement I had left over from another job, but after two coats, the bath still leaks water through the bottom, though the leak is slower since the second coat of cement was applied. Can you tell me how to fix this so the birdbath will hold water again? - D.N., Thiells, N.Y.

title: COUNTDOWN CLOCK TICKS FOR SHUTTLE
description: The countdown for the fourth and final test mission of the space shuttle Columbia proceeded smoothly and on schedule today, with technicians ready to begin servicing the secret Defense Department payload.

title: The U.N. Today; June 24, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee of the Special Session on Disarmament - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Penchina Agency On Next Plateau
description: Stephen Penchina opened his own agency under his own name a year ago with a bunch of lawyers as clients. Having survived that experience he has stepped up to the next plateau and now he is chairman and creative director of Penchina, Selkowitz, at a new location, 575 Madison Avenue, instead of 870 Fifth Avenue, and has a couple of new clients.

title: Italy and Argentina Advance
description: Argentina, the defending champion, and Italy, a two-time champion, advanced to the second round of the World Cup today. But their achievements were tempered by the prospect that both teams would next have to contend with Brazil, a three-time champion and the most impressive team so far this year.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL SEATTLE (AL) - Optioned Mike Moore, rookie right-hander, to Salt Lake City of Pacific Coast League.; BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Traded Ken Carr, forward, to Portland for first-round selec- tion in next week's draft.; FOOTBALL CINCINNATI (AFC) - Signed Dan Feraday, quarterback, after he was cut by Toronto of Canadian League.  DALLAS (NFC) - Signed Bill Purifoy, defensive end, and Joe Gary, defensive tackle. Hired Dick Bestwick as a scout.  NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Cut Barry
description: Announced r esignation of Tim Dennison, assistant f ootball coach.

title: PAIN FAILS TO STILL CAREW'S BAT
description: Observing Rod Carew, Ted Williams once said, ''When I first saw him in the late 1960's, he was a little too lackadaisical to suit me. He still looks lackadaisical. It's his style. He's so smooth he seems to be doing it without trying. Some guys - Pete Rose is one, and I put myself in this category - have to snort and fume to get everything going. Carew doesn't.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Anheuser-Busch Inc., St. Louis, has appointed Walter A. Suhre vice president and general counsel.

title: S.E.C. Nomination
description: President Reagan announced today that he intended to nominate Bevis Longstreth to continue as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Longstreth, a Wall Street lawyer who earlier this month completed a one-year appointment as an S.E.C. commissioner, will complete the remaining two years of the term of Philip A. Loomis Jr., who recently retired.

title: THE BITTER WAR IN COMPUTERS
description: The arrest of Japanese businessmen for trying to steal computer secrets from the International Business Machines Corporation represents the latest twist in what has become an increasingly tense and bitter Japanese-American battle for world supremacy in electronics.

title: A RENAISSANCE IN THE FINE ART OF STENCILING
description: In America, in the late 18th century, itinerant craftsmen traveled from town to town decorating the walls and floors of houses with colorful stencils. Carrying brushes, a supply of patterns and dry colors, which they mixed with skim milk, their decorative work was used as an inexpensive substitute for European wallpapers and Oriental rugs.

title: CRIME AN INCREASINGLY COMPELLING POLITICAL ISSUE
description: Politicians consult opinion polls for guidance the way preachers consult the Bible. And as lawmakers ponder the gospel according to Gallup and Harris these days, they find violent crime rising toward the top of every list of public concern.

title: Speedy Prospect
description: There is supposed to be a wealth of talent in this year's crop for the National Basketball Association's draft, which takes place Tuesday. Yet, when more than 200 players, including such stars as James Worthy, Dominique Wilkins and Terry Cummings, were evaluated by the N.B.A.'s scouting service, only one player got a top rating in any single talent category.

title: EXPERTS FEAR THAT UNPREDICTABLE CHAIN OF EVENTS COULD BRING NUCLEAR WAR
description: Time and again, the people who are engaged in the grim exercise of speculating how nuclear war might begin allude to the summer of 1914, when the nations of Europe slipped into a world war after a relatively minor incident.

title: FIGHT THE CRUISE MISSLE CHALLENGE BY MAINTAINING NAVAL STRENGTH
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. TO PENALIZE THOSE VIOLATING CURBS ON SOVIET
description: The Reagan Administration, heading toward a trade confrontation with Western Europe, said today that any foreign company violating an embargo on sales of American pipeline technology to the Soviet Union could be barred from obtaining merchandise or data from the United States.

title: CITY'S UNIFORMED FORCES REJECT 3% A YEAR RAISE
description: New York City offered its uniformed forces 3 percent pay increases in each year of a four-year contract yesterday, but negotiators for the coalition immediately rejected the proposal, calling it ''woefully inadequate.''

title: AVANT-GARDE: CONNIE BECKLEY IN 'PRINCIPLES IN PERSPECTIVE'
description: CONNIE BECKLEY is a composer and performance artist of a distinct individuality; her work is suffused with a cool methodology that can either clarify emotion or confound it. Her ambitious new installation and performance series in the august Great Hall of the Chamber of Commerce at 65 Liberty Street is more austere than even her own past work; at times her determination lapses into the dogged. But it is still worthy of attention, especially for those who have valued her past work and wish to trace her progress. The first of the performances, entitled ''Principles in Perspective,'' took place Tuesday night, with two more yesterday and repeats next Tuesday evening at 8 o'clock, Wednesday noon and evening and July 4 at 3 P.M.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL ALTERS BID FOR NLT
description: The American General Corporation said yesterday that it would bid $690 million, or $46 a share in cash, for 43.3 percent of the NLT Corporation as a first step in its planned $1.44 billion bid for the entire company. Analysts said that the new bid would ''force the issue'' of two insurance companies' takeover battle.

title: MUSIC: GAY MEN'S CHORUS
description: THE New York City Gay Men's Chorus, which made an impressive debut at Alice Tully Hall a year ago and won further praise in subsequent concerts elsewhere, returned to Tully Hall Tuesday night for the first of three concerts there this week (the second tonight, the third Saturday night).

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HOME handymen and do-it-yourselfers are always on the lookout for new tools and other products that can make repair and maintenance simpler and quicker. Here are some recently introduced items: Electronic Stud Finder

title: News Analysis
description: Administration officials said today that the coming days would tell if President Reagan's decision not to rebuke Prime Minister Menachem Begin publicly would lead to flexibility by Israel in helping produce a solution to the Lebanon crisis.

title: AT SOCCER CUP TIME, BRAZIL GETS THE BIGGEST KICK
description: At least 24 nations, world powers among them, have entered an enchantment these June days that will extend until the middle of next month.

title: JAZZMAN, 54, GERTS HIS B.A.
description: For 38 years Bob Wilber has been working as a clarinetist and soprano saxophonist, playing traditional jazz. This last year he was artist-in-residence at Oberlin College and he taught at the New School for Social Research. Today, he will be graduated from college.

title: U.S. FLEET REACHES EAST MEDITERRANEAN FOR NAVAL EXERCISES
description: The United States Navy has assembled a task force of 50 warships led by four aircraft carriers in the eastern Mediterranean for NATO maneuvers, but has ordered them to be ready for possible rescue operations in Lebanon, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Technology; Cryogenic Refrigerator
description: CRYOGENICS, the study of extremely low temperatures and their effect on matter, is a field of bustling scientific research. Scientists have shown that they can make electrical circuits faster, instruments more sensitive and some kinds of surgery safer in a molecular deep freeze where temperatures range from 320 degrees to 452 degrees below zero Fahrenheit.

title: DR. LEONARD SMALL
description: Dr. Leonard Small, a clinical psychologist and chief consultant psychologist for Altro Health and Rehabilitation Services of New York City, died Tuesday at New York University Medical Center.

title: Letter: On Prisons; More Cells Will Not Mean Less Crime
description: To the Editor: In a recent editorial (May 21), The Times endorsed New Jersey Governor Thomas Kean's proposal to expand the state's prison system through a $160 million construction bond.

title: MRS. THATCHER, AT U.N., DECLARES AGGRESSORS, NOT ARMS, MAKE WARS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, fresh from Britain's triumph over Argentina in the Falkland Islands, told the special session on disarmament today that aggressive nations, not weapons, make wars.

title: A WAY TO ARBITRATE CONSUMER PROBLEMS
description: A$400 suit comes back from the dry cleaner ruined. The cleaner says he is not responsible. A baby grand piano arrives at a new home with a shattered leg. The movers say it is not their fault. The owner of a new sports car says it is a lemon and demands a replacement. The dealer refuses.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 24, 1982; International
description: Any foreign company violating an embargo on sales of American pipeline technology to the Soviet Union may be barred from buying U.S. goods or data, the Reagan Administration said. The tough new sanctions, meant to hinder a natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe, will cost American companies $1.2 billion worth of business, officials said. (Page A1.)

title: DEMOCRATS FACING TEST ON UNITY GOAL
description: The Democratic Party's goal of presenting itself as a unified, mainstream force may face its most difficult test soon in the area of military affairs and arms control, Charles T. Manatt, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today.

title: McENROE FUMES BUT IS A WINNER
description: Legend has it that when you cannot see the metal rooster atop the steeple of St. Mary's Church from the players' tea room at the All England Club, the weather is bound to be bad for the Wimbledon tennis championships.

title: WHERE TO SHOP FOR NURSERY FURNITURE
description: The cost of a newborn's nursery can be negligible or more than $1,000. For the lucky, whose friends' tastes are compatible with theirs, a nursery can be furnished by donation. For those who do not have friends with outgrown furniture or who balk at haunting thrift shops, furnishing the nursery can be costly.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: International Theater Fare

title: TELLS OF PLANS FOR HERE AND ABROAD
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov will return to the stage on July 8 at the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy, performing with dancers from the American Ballet Theater. Mr. Baryshnikov, artistic director of the company, has been off the stage for four months because of a knee injury that forced him to cancel appearances with Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan this summer.

title: No Headline
description: An article yesterday about the Caramoor Festival gave an incorrect date for the all-Baroque concert. It will take place Saturday, July 3, at 8:30 P.M. in the Venetian Theater.

title: IRONING OUT SEASONAL STATISTICS
description: It is summer once again, so supermarket prices for tomatoes and other fresh vegetables should be falling sharply.

title: General Portland
description: General Portland Inc. said it had temporarily suspended cement production at its Signal Mountain plant after laying off about 100 hourly employees last week. The production halt, which is expected to last from three to six weeks, was caused by a slowdown in new construction, Bill Abercrombie, the plant manager, said. The cutback is one of several temporary plant closings that General Portland, which is based in Dallas, has carried out in recent weeks to limit inventories of cement and gravel.

title: AN ECONOMIC AGENDA
description: A steadily increasing flow of products, people and money across borders has created complex interdependence among national economies. The implications for our economy are enormous. International trade accounts for twice as much of our gross national product as in the 1960's. Exports generate one in six manufacturing jobs and keep one of every three acres of farmland productive. Foreigners' savings in America help finance our capital stock.

title: A BRIDGE BUILDER FOR CITY UNIVERSITY
description: Not long after becoming head of Queens College in 1971, Joseph S. Murphy was invited to a Sholom Aleichem festival being held on campus. Those attending the gathering in memory of the Yiddish writer quickly learned how adept the young college president could be in charming an audience. He spoke in Yiddish.

title: Purolator Deal Off
description: Tiger International Inc., the Los Angeles-based transportation company, said that it had sold all of its 955,000 shares of Purolator Inc. stock, a 14.6 percent stake, resulting in a pretax gain of $2.3, because it could not reach an ''amiable agreement'' to acquire Purolator's Courier division. A block of 955,000 Purolator shares traded yesterday at $32.75, down $1.75. For its first quarter, Tiger reported a loss of $24 million, or $1.42 a share, compared with a 1981 first-quarter profit of $10.8 million, or 63 cents a share.

title: Lord Grade Joins Norman Lear Team
description: Lord Grade at age 75 is starting over. The British entertainment executive stepped down in January as head of Britain's Associated Communications Corporation after it got into financial straits. Yesterday, he was named chairman and chief executive officer of the newly created Embassy Communications International.

title: NO ARAB COMPASSION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Tests Nuclear Device
description: (UPI) - United States scientists staged an underground nuclear test today after a delay of an hour and 45 minutes for what the scientists said were technical reasons. Residents in Las Vegas, 110 miles away, had been warned that some ground movement might be felt from the blast. The device was buried in a vertical shaft 2,100 feet below the desert floor.

title: DEMOCATS CHEER CALL FOR FREEZE ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Averell Harriman, the elder statesman of his party, brought the Democratic National Committee to its feet for ovations today as he called for support for the nuclear freeze concept.

title: SUNDAY NIGHT: SPECIAL SETTINGS
description: Either you've come back early from the country to beat the traffic, or you're frazzled from being in that traffic. Perhaps you've spent the day, following a late brunch, picking lazily through the newspaper or walking the avenues looking at your reflection in the windows of unopened stores. The private comforts of the Colony and Cosmopolitan Clubs are closed and unavailable, and so are just about all of the French restaurants in town.

title: TRADE ETHICS IN SILICON VALLEY
description: Although the arrest of Japanese businessmen by the Federal Bureau of Investigation this week set off a furor, the acquisition of trade secrets by legal and illegal means has always been part of doing business in Silicon Valley, the center of the American electronics industry.

title: Panel's Phone Legislation
description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce recessed today without bringing to a vote a controversial bill to revamp regulations covering the telecommunications industry.

title: OFFICER KILLS A GUNMAN ON BUS
description: A New York City police officer who was on his way to work shot and killed a gunman on a Brooklyn bus yesterday morning after the man tried to rob a passenger, the police reported.

title: MITTERRAND ENDS TENSE VISIT TO SPAIN
description: President Francois Mitterrand ended a three-day visit to Madrid today after failing to assuage Spanish suspicions that France is delaying this country's entry into the European Economic Community and allowing Basque terrorists to operate with impunity north of the Pyrenees.

title: But the Constitution Can't Teach Math
description: New York's highest court has derailed a progressive campaign to narrow the gap in educational spending between wealthier and poorer public school districts. The Court of Appeals rejected the view of lower courts, and some courts in other states, that such disparities violate the Constitution's equal protection clause. Without denying the social problem, it said the remedy had to be political, not judicial.

title: Big week for Americana.
description: AMERICAN autographs, manuscripts, prints, paintings and furnishings will be the focus of three sales at Sotheby Parke Bernet next Tuesday through Thursday.

title: 3 SEEDED WOMEN LOSE AT WIMBLEDON
description: Wimbledon finally caught fire today, and Hana Mandlikova, Mima Jausovec and Evonne Goolagong Cawley were the seeded casualties.

title: Gilder Leads Westchester by One on a 64
description: Favored by the second June date of its 16-year history, the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic got off to a gloriously sunny start today. It was a welcome difference from the chilly mists of last week's United States Open.

title: LEADERS CONCEDE LOSS ON EQUAL RIGHTS
description: Leaders of the fight for an equal rights amendment officially conceded defeat today. But they vowed to continue the struggle for equality of women by electing their backers to state legislatures and by suing corporations that practice sexual discrimination.

title: FUTURISTIC 'BLADE RUNNER'
description: THE view of the future offered by Ridley Scott's muddled yet mesmerizing ''Blade Runner'' is as intricately detailed as anything a science-fiction film has yet envisioned. The year is 2019, the place Los Angeles, the landscape garish but bleak. The city is a canyon bounded by industrial towers, some of which belch fire. Advertising billboards, which are everywhere, now feature lifelike electronic people who are the size of giants. The police cruise both horizontally and vertically on their patrol routes, but there is seldom anyone to arrest, because the place is much emptier than it used to be. In an age of space travel, anyone with the wherewithal has presumably gone away. Only the dregs remain.

title: Vietnam Denies Navy Attack
description: Vietnam denied today that fishing boats fired on three American warships on Sunday about 70 miles off the southern tip of Vietnam. The Vietnam News Agency, in a broadcast monitored in Tokyo, said the American charges were a ''fabrication.'' The United States Navy said Tuesday that the destroyers Turner Joy and Lynde and the cruiser Sterett had been fired on ''by a vessel believed to belong to the Socialist Republic of Vietnam.''

title: Illegal Role by Advisers In Salvador Is Denied
description: The United States Embassy in San Salvador Wednesday night denied that American military advisers here were carrying combat weapons or participating in any combat operations.

title: MOLIERE IN PARK OPENS TONIGHT WITH 'DON JUAN'
description: THE New York Shakespeare Festival gets under way tonight at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, not with Shakespeare but with his French counterpart, Moliere. And not with one of Moliere's familiar comedies either, but with ''Don Juan.'' To this day, it remains one of the least known and least performed of his major works.

title: G.I.'S IN WEST GERMANY MEET RISING WALL OF BIAS
description: The United States Armed Forces Television Network is broadcasting a series of reports this week called ''Off Limits.'' The title is stark, but the programs deal only in passing with discrimination against American soldiers in West Germany, a problem that has become increasingly sensitive in the last few months.

title: Chrysler 'E' Cars
description: The Chrysler Corporation will begin production of 1983 model six-passenger ''E'' cars - Plymouth Grand LeBaron and Dodge 600 - this summer for an autumn debut at Chrysler and Dodge division dealer showrooms, a company spokesman said. Company sources said the new Chrysler and Dodge cars would have more leg room and better fuel economy than previous models.

title: CONNECTICUT SHOWS ACTOR'S FLAIR AND MYSTERY
description: Some 10 miles up the Connecticut River in the town of Hadlyme stands one of the more notably eccentric buildings in the country, a castle built by an actor who made a fortune playing Sherlock Holmes in the early part of the century.

title: YOUTH HELD IN SLAYING OF SUSPECT
description: A teen-ager who was to graduate from DeWitt Clinton High School last night surrendered to the police earlier in the day and was charged with stabbing to death a suspected mugger in the Bronx last Sunday, the police said.

title: L.I. Rabbi to Be Head Of Rabbinical Council
description: Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman of Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., today was elected president of the Rabbinical Council of America, the largest Orthodox rabbinic group in the world.

title: ART: AN UNNATURAL 'NATURAL HISTORY'
description: ''NATURAL HISTORY'' is the title of a group show at the Borgenicht Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue at 57th Street, but that is not really its subject. The show's organizer, Scott Cook, proposes in his catalogue introduction that nature scarcely exists anymore except where it has been consciously preserved - as a national park, for example, and therefore as a ''product'' of our culture and one of its ''most potent fictions.''

title: Yonkers Meets Budget Deadline
description: The City Council adopted a balanced $220 million budget for Yonkers today. It was the first time in seven years of fiscal uncertainty that the Council had met the Chartermandated deadline of July 1.

title: MRS. CARNER'S 67 LEADS BY A STROKE
description: JoAnne Carner, who needs one more tour victory to become a member of the Ladies' Professional Golf Association Hall of Fame, used a strong putting game to shoot a five-under-par 67 today and take the first-round lead in the $200,000 Rochester International.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL SWINGS INTO NEW YORK AREA FOR 10-DAY GIG
description: AFICIONADOS of the Kool Jazz Festival have come to expect star performers, and this year's edition is no exception. Benny Goodman, Stan Getz, Dizzy Gillespie, Max Roach, Buddy Rich, Joe Williams and Mel Torme are just some of the major artists who will appear in the first weekend of the festival, which begins a 10-day run in New York this evening. But along with these regulars, the first three days of the festival will highlight performers for whom a jazz festival appearance is unusual - Eileen Farrell, the opera singer, Mabel Mercer, the peerless cabaret singer, Mitch Miller, the conductor and arranger, and Harvey Phillips, the classical tuba player. There will even be musicians from Senegal, India and Turkey.

title: France, in the U.N., Will Push A Cease-Fire Plan for Beirut
description: The Security Council is due to meet Friday on a French proposal for a cease-fire and a disengagement around Beirut.

title: Rothko Estate Awarded Ex-Executor's House
description: Judge Millard L. Midonick has ruled in Surrogate's Court that the New York residence of Theodoros Stamos is now the property of the Rothko estate.

title: ELDERLY AT CENTER CONFRONT ANXIETY
description: For many elderly, a major fear is a loss of control over their lives. Among residents of nursing homes, who must depend on others for even some of the most basic daily necessities, this worry can be particularly acute.

title: BRIGADOON TAKES BERMUDA RACE HONORS
description: Brigadoon, a 57-foot sloop owned by Robert W. Morton of Newport, R.I., captured top honors on corrected time today in the 635-mile Bermuda Race.

title: Fertile Fruit Fly Found In San Joaquin Valley
description: Trappers discovered a fertile Mediterranean fruit fly today, the first discovered in seven months, in the agriculturally rich San Joaquin Valley.

title: PIPELINE SANCTIONS UPSET BONN
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt expressed concern today about the repercussions of the Reagan Administration's attempts to hinder development of the Soviet-West European pipeline deal in a speech before Parliament.

title: DANCE: MARTHA GRAHAM'S 'ANDROMACHE'S LAMENT'
description: MAGNIFICENT theater, emotional power, superb art. How else can one describe Martha Graham's ''Andromache's Lament,'' which had its world premiere Wednesday night at the City Center?

title: Workers Load Fuel and Prepare Cargo for Shuttle's Flight
description: Workers pumped fuel aboard the space shuttle Columbia and opened the cargo bay late today to prepare the Defense Department's secret payload for its flight into space Sunday morning.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Right Spot At the Right Time

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL DEFENDS ABSCAM INQUIRY TACTICS
description: Attorney General William French Smith, in his first comprehensive statement on the use of undercover agents in the Abscam bribery investigation, defended such techniques and said they were essential tools in the battle against corruption.

title: HELPING TO BUILD HOPE IN SCARRED BEDFORD-STUYVESANT
description: Through the large windows of his spacious sixth-floor office in north-central Brooklyn, Curtis A. Wood can see New York Bay and the office and residential towers of Manhattan.

title: P.L.O. VIOLENCE AGAINST THE U.N. PEACEKEEPERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Lee Pitching Again
description: Bill Lee, the veteran left-handed pitcher who was dropped by the Montreal Expos last month after a series of disputes with Jim Fanning, the manager, says he has called every team in the National League asking for a tryout but that none responded. No matter.

title: Soviet Blames Egypt in Part For Israel's Lebanon Invasion
description: Tass, the official Soviet press agency, accused Egypt today of bearing large responsibility for Israel's invasion of Lebanon and implicitly criticized other Arab countries for lacking unity.

title: House Panel's Bill Would Ban Drilling in Wilderness Areas
description: The House Interior Committee today approved legislation barring Interior Secretary James G. Watt from approving oil and gas drilling in the nation's wilderness areas.

title: YUGOSLAVIA(S)
description: ''When I was 11 years old during World War II,'' said the professor, ''I was forced to watch my father, my uncle and all the other adult males of our Serbian Orthodox village in Croatia rounded up and slowly knifed to death by Croatian nationalists. That's not an easy thing to forget, but if we're going to have a country, we must forget it -and that's what I've brought my children up to do.''

title: Reuschel to Get Second Opinion
description: Rick Reuschel, the Yankee pitcher who has spent the season on the disabled list, returned to New York yesterday and confirmed that he has a partial tear of the rotator cuff. The shoulder ailment, which has ended the careers of a number of pitchers, is the first serious injury Reuschel has suffered in his 10 years in the major leagues

title: ONE FROM COLUMN A
description: Those who have difficulty grasping the direction of Reagan foreign policy should think of options arrayed on a Chinese menu.

title: DOUBTFUL FOR OAKS
description: The same unusually competitive spirit that brought Cupecoy's Joy to the brink of sweeping the filly triple crown tomorrow in the Coaching Club American Oaks may have deprived her of a chance to run in the race.

title: Anti-Israel Throng Sacks U.S. Office in Calcutta
description: About 300 people protesting Israel's invasion of Lebanon ransacked the American Center Library in Calcutta today and replaced its flag with a Palestine Liberation Organization banner.

title: SCRAMBLE TO GIVE TICKETS TAKING A TOLL ON MORALE
description: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically. By M.A. FARBER

title: 5 HINCKLEY JURORS TESTIFY IN SENATE
description: Three of the jurors who found John W. Hinckley Jr. not guilty by reason of insanity last Monday said in Senate subcommittee testimony today that they would have found him both guilty and mentally ill if they had been given that option.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, JUNE 25, 1982; Companies
description: Standard Oil (Ohio) raised the price of oil from Alaska's North Slope. Sohio, which produces 53 percent of Prudhoe Bay oil, would not disclose the size of the increase, but industry sources said it was $2 a barrel to refiners on the West Coast and $3 a barrel on the Gulf Coast. Analysts said the move indicated domestic crude prices are firming. Another North Slope producer, Atlantic Richfield, said it was reviewing its prices but hasn't yet taken any action. (Page D1.)

title: World Airways Debt Extension
description: Troubled World Airways received more time from its creditors to work out a debt restructuring plan. The carrier, which is battling to avoid the fate of the bankrupt Braniff Corporation, obtained from its 16 creditors a two-week extension, to July 9, to restructure $17 million in debt and lease payments coming due through June 30, 1983, Brian Cooke, a World senior vice president, said.

title: Deficit of $104 Billion May Be Underestimate
description: The record deficit of $104 billion Congress is forecasting for the 1983 fiscal year may seem small compared with the deficit the Government actually runs up.

title: MITSUBISHI QUALIFIES ITS DENIAL IN I.B.M. STOLEN DATA CASE
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation pulled back today from its flat denial that it had conspired to steal confidential information from the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Volvo to Acquire White Motor Unit
description: The White Motor Corporation said that A.B. Volvo of Sweden plans to acquire the American assets of White's finance subsidiary, the White Motor Credit Corporation.

title: P.L.O.-DOMINATED WEST BEIRUT: ARMED CAMP IN CROWDED CAPITAL
description: Much of west Beirut, particularly the coastline from the American Embassy to the airport and the Palestinian-controlled inland areas south of the Corniche Mazraa road, has been turned into an armed camp. Huge mounds of dirt have been heaped on the roads to deter tanks, and the streets have been dug up so mines can be planted.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard THE LAST LORDS OF PALENQUE. The Lacandon Mayas of the Mexican Rain Forest. By Victor Perera and Robert D. Bruce. Illustrated. 311 Pages. Little, Brown. $17.95.

title: Just a normal youth named O'Neal.
description: ''I'M a normal guy from Malibu who surfs every day,'' says 17-yearold Griffin O'Neal. But some of what seems normal to Griffin O'Neal would appear fairly exotic to the rest of us.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Note of Inspiration

title: HONDURAS OUSTED BY LATE GOAL
description: Four teams squandered opportunities today to qualify for the second phase of the World Cup, and the last five placed will now be decided Friday.

title: Drug Ads to Doctors May Boom
description: THERE are continuing signals coming out of the nation's capital that the move toward relaxed regulations will certainly include those at the Food and Drug Administration concerning the introduction of pharmaceuticals.

title: RULES ON F.B.I.'S SURVEILLANCE OF POLITICAL GROUPS TO CHANGE
description: Guidelines restricting spying on domestic political organizations by the Federal Bureau of Investigation are about to be eased to let it keep an eye on ''terrorist'' groups, the director, William H. Webster, told Congress today.

title: P.L.O.'S ALLY SAYS GUERRILLA GROUP APPEARS 'FINISHED'
description: The principal Lebanese ally of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Beirut said today, ''The P.L.O. as it used to be in Lebanon is finished.''

title: NEEDED: AN INTERIM ARMS PACT
description: President Reagan's decision to proceed with strategic nuclear talks on Tuesday and his pledge not to ''undercut'' existing arms agreements are both sensible and a measure of the impact of public opinion at home and abroad. But the first need is for a prompt interim arms-control pact.

title: Apology Accepted
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and Ted Turner have apparently patched up their differences. Their dispute had led Mr. Jackson to storm out of Mr. Turner's box at an Atlanta Braves game last month.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Associated Dry Goods Corp. has appointed Donald E. Ray president and chief executive officer of Stix, Baer & Fuller, St. Louis; John L. Hoerner president and chief executive officer of L.S. Ayres & Co., Indianapolis; Donald R. Midkiff president and chief executive officer of the H.& S. Pogue Co., Cincinnati; Lewis G. French president and chief executive officer of Stewart & Co., Baltimore, and James A. Rodefeld president and chief executive officer of the Sycamore Specialty Stores in the Middle West.

title: House Democrats File a Bill; To Provide Temporary Jobs
description: House Democrats have introduced a $1 billion bill that they said would give summer jobs to 203,000 people in areas with above-average unemployment.

title: SYNTEX ENDS TALKS
description: The Syntex Corporation said it had ended talks to acquire a 6.5 percent equity interest in Key Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Miami for $30 million. It gave no reason for the action, but said the companies were continuing talks on potential product licensing agreements. Syntex said the proposed licensing deal would involve development by Key of some Syntex products, and certain sales rights to each other's products.

title: Friday; FAIR AT RHINEBECK
