description: The Fair at Rhinebeck, billed as the largest craft market anywhere, will be held today through Sunday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., at the Dutchess County Fairgrounds. This is the 17th year of the event, formerly called the Northeast Craft Fair. Glass, ceramics, jewelry, leather, handmade paper and other work by more than 580 artisans will be offered. There will be refreshment stands and picnic tables; parking is free. The grounds are on Route 9 just south of Red Hook, N.Y., two hours from Manhattan. A courtesy car goes to and from the fair from the nearby Rhinebeck train station. Admission is $4 (free for under-12's). Information: (914) 255-0039. EAST VILLAGE BECKETT

title: Dr. Shelley Roth Married To Dr. Jed I. Weissberg
description: Dr. Shelley Roth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Roth of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Jed I. Weissberg, son of Dr. and Mrs. William W. Weissberg of Elizabeth, N.J. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El.

title: Economic Scene; A Fading Ideology
description: NOTHING is more dreadful for a cook than to have the sauce separate. And the sauce that was Reaganomics - a mixture of supplyside tax cuts and monetarism - appears to have separated. Norman Ture, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for fiscal policy, who was the most ardent spokesman of supply-side economics within the Administration, has announced he is resigning to make more money. That may be a reasonable thing for a supply-sider, sensitive to pecuniary incentives, to do. But, following the earlier resignation of the other top Treasury supply-sider, Paul Craig Roberts, it does dramatize the fading of the supply-side ideology that had suffused the Reagan revolution.

title: U.S. EFFORTS TO HELP AMERASIAN CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: OFF THE BEATEN TRACK
description: A barge anchored at Pier 40 on the Hudson River, the jazz club Fat Tuesday's and the Citicorp Center are the sites of some of the Kool Jazz Festival's most adventurous concert programs - and biggest bargains.

title: Oil Find By Texaco
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it was operator for a group of companies that had made a ''significant'' oil discovery off Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: 75th St. Paper Fair
description: Paper collectibles and memorabilia from movies, sports and politics will be on sale tomorrow in the parish house of St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church, 173 East 75th Street.

title: Mugabe's Residence; Is Attacked by Gunmen
description: Gunmen attacked the official residence of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe today and battled with guards outside the home of a senior minister, Government spokesmen said.

title: Beck Earns His Confidence
description: In the four years since he qualified for the professional golf tour, Chip Beck has learned his lessons well. His game has shown constant improvement, as have his earnings, and a good score in the first round of a tournament is a comfort but not a celebration.

title: MUSIC: FOUR AFTER-DINNER OPERAS
description: ''I'VE heard it whispered privately that Menotti is your cup of tea,'' is the way one character insults another's taste in Normand Lockwood's short opera ''Requiem for a Rich Young Man.''

title: For a Toyota Deal, G.M. Favors Coast
description: The General Motors Corporation prefers to use one of its two idle California assembly plants in any joint venture with the Toyota Motor Company to produce small cars in the United States, G.M.'s chairman, Roger Smith, said.

title: Erie Savings Plans Merger
description: The Erie Savings Bank of Buffalo and the Statewide Savings and Loan Association of Kingston announced plans today for Erie to acquire Statewide.

title: Market Place; Analyst Likes Dome Outlook
description: SHARES of Dome Petroleum are getting about as much favorable response these days as salt water in a drilling prospect. This is an amazing switch. A year ago, this leading Canadian oil and gas producer was hailed as one of the most promising companies anywhere.

title: Downtown Walk
description: Pace University is sponsoring a three-hour walking tour through Lower Manhattan beginning at 11 A.M. on Sunday on the civic center campus, across from City Hall Park.

title: PRESBYTERIAN UNIT ELECTS HEAD
description: The dean of a theological seminary in Atlanta has been elected moderator of the United Presbyerian Church, which has 2.5 million members, at the denomination's general assembly in Hartford.

title: FLEEING BEIRUT CHAOS TO SAFETY AT SEA
description: Hundreds of Americans, Western Europeans and Lebanese with American immigration papers were evacuated by a transport ship of the Sixth Fleet today, just hours after the American Embassy in western Beirut closed down.

title: BEIRUT-DAMASCUS HIGHWAY
description: The Syrian high command said tonight that its forces in Lebanon destroyed 17 Israeli tanks and other armored vehicles and killed about 80 Israeli soldiers in heavy fighting during the day in mountain areas southeast of Beirut.

title: Delmed Bid Approved
description: Delmed Inc. said that its stockholders today approved the acquisition of the American Medical Products Corproation of Howell Township, N.J., which manufactures a proprietary line of dialysis systems that it markets to home patients, and related products.

title: NUTRITION WATCH COMMITTEE FINDS HUNGER IN STATE RISING
description: Evangeline Gouletas-Carey and other members of a State Nutrition Watch Committee toured a hospital as well as food programs in Harlem and the South Bronx yesterday. After the tour, the committee, created by Governor Carey six months ago, released its final report.

title: Driscoll Race Won By Genghis Kahn
description: Genghis Kahn coasted to a 1 1/2-length triumph today to win his 10th pace of the year. It came in the Gov. Driscoll Pacing Series at the Meadowlands, which ends with a $164,000 final next Thursday.

title: Open Justice, Case by Case
description: In striking down a Massachusetts law that automatically closed off rape trials when a complaining witness under 18 takes the stand, the Supreme Court has given timely reinforcement to the principle of open justice. It left trial judges free to exclude the public when necessary for a witness's welfare, but not without hearing from journalists and others with an interest in attending.

title: Two Campers Charged In Slaying of 3 on River
description: Two young campers were charged today with what the first officer to arrive at the scene called the ''mindless slaughter'' of three members of a family who were killed by sniper bullets while fishing along a peaceful river.

title: EMIL PATTBERG JR., 72, HEADED THE FIRST BOSTON CORPORATION
description: Emil J. Pattberg Jr., retired chairman of the First Boston Corporation, the investment banking company, died Wednesday at his home in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 72 years old and had lived in Ridgewood, N.J., and Manhattan before his retirement in 1975.

title: ISRAEL IS WEIGHING ACTION ON WEST BEIRUT
description: A senior Israeli official reported today that the Government had decided to stand by its decision against sending forces into west Beirut. But that decision will be reviewed again Friday.

title: Paris Lakers?
description: The National Basketball Association bills its champions as the world champions, but Pat Riley, the coach whose Los Angeles Lakers won that championship this year, knows differently.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * A-S Exportfinans, a Norwegian agency, filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the issuance in U.S. markets of $300 million of securities to be offered through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title: BACH FESTIVAL IS BACK AT STONY BROOK CAMPUS
description: Bach lovers can indulge themselves immoderately in the next two and a half weeks at the Stony Brook campus of the State University of New York on Long Island. The Bach Aria Group is holding its second Bach Festival and Institute at the Fine Arts Center there - a series of concerts, master classes, rehearsals and lectures, many open free to the public.

title: SOUTHERN BAPTISTS ASSAILED ON SCHOOL PRAYER VOTE
description: The organization of Reform Jewish synagogues has assailed the recent vote by the Southern Baptist Convention to support President Reagan's proposed amendment to allow organized voluntary prayer in public schools.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jerry Buss, already the owner of basketball's Lakers and hockey's Kings, now has a third team: the Los Angeles Lazers, who were brought into the Major Indoor Soccer League yesterday as the league's 13th team. The Lazers will play in the Forum, which Buss also owns. ... Jerry West, the general manager of the Lakers, says he is still trying to trade the No.1 choice over all in Tuesday's draft, in exchange for a high pick next season.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dial H for History

title: MIXED SIGNALS FRAY NERVES AS DOG DAYS SET IN
description: It's not even July, but Dog Days seem to have arrived at the White House. Aides to President Reagan have only now begun to recover, physically and emotionally, from his grueling nine-day European trip earlier this month. And the disappointing economic news at home has dampened the staff's ability to savor the President's budget victories in Congress.

title: WARNER SUES 'HAZARD' STARS
description: Warner Bros. announced yesterday that it had filed a $90 million countersuit against John Schneider and Tom Wopat, two stars of the top-rated CBS-TV series ''The Dukes of Hazzard,'' charging them with libel, conspiracy to libel and breach of contract.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies. Doubleheader. Making up a game postponed by the April 6 blizzard, the Mets will play five games in three days in Philadelphia.

title: NEWARK TRUANCY PLAN TEACHES A BAD LESSON
description: To the Editor:

title: From Tex-Mex to China and SoHo.
description: THREE things that are hard to find in New York are inexpensive restaurants, decent Mexican food and good places to eat in the theater district. All three of these needs are fairly well met by El Tenampa, a small, casual cafe on Restaurant Row - 46th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Well-spiced Mexican food at low prices is offered for lunch and dinner, and both menus include not only the standard Tex-Mex panoply of such dishes as tamales, tostados, tacos, burritos, flautas, enchiladas and taquitos, but also a full array of chicken, beef and pork specialties, complemented by subtle and heady sauces.

title: MINORITY GROUPS IN STATE CTITICIZE DISTRICTS RULING
description: Leaders of black and Puerto Rican groups said today that parts of a Federal ruling designed to insure fairness in political representation to racial minorities in New York might actually reduce it.

title: 5 Exhumations Ordered in Essex
description: At least five bodies will be exhumed in connection with separate homicide investigations because medical examiners failed to perform autopsies, Essex County Prosecutor George Schneider said today.

title: CITY INTENDS TO REMOVE UNSAFE SUBWAY TUBING
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy announced yesterday that the city would provide $2 million in the 1983 budget to replace some of the polyvinyl chloride tubing in the subway system.

title: Lehrman G.O.P. Bid Endorsed by Ex-Rival
description: Lewis E. Lehrman was endosed today by Richard M. Rosenbaum, a former rival for the Republican nomination for Governor. Mr. Lehrman is opposed by Paul J. Curran in the Republican primary.

title: Art lights up Times Sq.
description: IT is not every day that artists can get their work up in lights on Times Square. But this year, no fewer than 12 will have their ideas transformed into animated dots and colors on the huge Spectacolor computerized light board at No. 1 Times Square.

title: Bridge: Like Any Real Champion, Eddie Wold Always Tries
description: Among the qualities that make up a true champion are concentration and intensity: a willingness to put forth maximum effort at all times. A case in point is the diagramed deal, which came almost at the end of the Vanderbilt knockout final in March.

title: Potential Trouble Spots For Weekend Traffic
description: A. Henry Hudson Parkway: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street because of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation. B.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Monday incorrectly cited a Soviet grain har- vest estimate. The estimate of 158 mil- lion tons was for last year's Soviet harvest.

title: Frank Hook, 89, Dies; Former Representative
description: Frank E. Hook, who was an active supporter of labor as a Democratic Congressman from Michigan from the mid-1930's to the 1940's, died Monday in Edina, Minn. He was 89 years old.

title: N.B.A. Is Sued Over Clippers' Move
description: The Los Angeles Coliseum Commission filed a $120 million antitrust lawsuit today against the National Basketball Association, 12 of its clubs and 11 club owners.

title: ...AND NOW A DISARMAMENT INDUSTRY
description: There are buttons, bumper stickers, books, movies, T-shirts, posters, newsletters, ''peace'' quilts, polltakers, public relations firms and political action committees - all part of the veritable cottage industry spawned by the nationwide campaign to freeze Soviet and American nuclear arsenals at current levels.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In view of the special nature of the President's constitutional office and functions, we think it appropriate to recognize absolute Presidential immunity from damages liability for acts within the 'outer perimeter' of his official responsibility.'' - Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. (A12:4.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: U.N. Security Efforts Beget Frustration

title: Man, 25, Accused Of Slaying Priest
description: A 25-year-old man was arraigned today on a charge of felony murder in the shooting death of a Roman Catholic priest who investigators believe gave the suspect a ride into Bridgeport's West End.

title: U.S. AIDE SAYS SOVIET WANTS ARMS PACT
description: The chief United States negotiator to the coming talks on reducing strategic arms said today that he was convinced Soviet leaders wanted an arms agreement and an overall reduction in tensions with the West.

title: ARGENTINE CHIEF TO DECIDE ON THE WAR
description: Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez said today that it would be up to the next Government to decide whether Argentina should formally end the war with Britain in the South Atlantic.

title: People
description: * Robert F. Foth has been named senior vice president for operations at Atwood Richards Inc.

title: JOVIAL BRITON FOR U.S. POST: JOHN OLIVER WRIGHT
description: When he goes to Washington to replace Sir Nicholas Henderson as British Ambassador this fall, Sir Oliver Wright will finally be assuming a job that people have been suggesting him for since the early 1970's.

title: The Message of Gravesend
description: ''It was a bunch of kids hanging on a corner getting drunk,'' one neighbor speculates. ''These guys were probably passing by and maybe somebody shouted 'nigger,' and the words went back and forth.

title: JOSEPH BOGDAN
description: Former State Representative Joseph Bogdan died Tuesday at St. Rafael's Hospital in New Haven after a brief illness.

title: HIGH COURT RULING ALLOWS POLITICAL WORK STOPPAGES
description: The Supreme Court, in a victory for organized labor, ruled today that Federal courts may not enjoin work stoppages that are politically motivated.

title: LONG-TERM U.S. RATES EASE
description: The Government securities market went through a cautious session yesterday that saw some long-term rates easing slightly as prices improved, while short-term rates rose.

title: Arkansas Bank Closed
description: Beverly J. Lambert, the state's banking commissioner, today ordered Citizens Bank, the only bank in this community of 300 residents, closed because of ''large and unusual'' losses. Allan Whitney, a public information officer with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said in a statement Wednesday from Washington, D.C., that Commissioner Lambert had named the F.D.I.C. receiver for the bank.

title: Index; International
description: Argentine war ruling to await new regime A3 Mitterrand ends Spain visit with strains unallayed A3 South Korean Cabinet is shuffled A4 Around the World A5 Israel is said to launch a major drive against the Syrians A6 West Beirut: portrait of an armed camp A6 U.S. urging nations put pressure on P.L.O. A8 Government/Politics Attorney General Smith defends Abscam investigation tactics A16 Democratic Presidential rivals set up trailer encampment A17 Major repairs on three city swimming pools to begin Monday B3 Guidelines on F.B.I. surveillance being relaxes B14 Washington Talk Briefing A14 White House: Summer Dog Days A14 And Now a Disarmament Industry A14 General Around the Nation A10 Student charged with stabbing death of mugging suspect B3 Health/Science Workers prepare space shuttle for its flight Sunday A9 Religion Group assails Southern Baptist support of school prayer A10 United Presbyterians elect dean as moderator A13 Features/Notes Man in the News: Sir Oliver Wright, new British envoy A5 Sports People A26 Issue and Debate: Ocean dumping of sewage sludge B2 New York Day by Day B3 Weekend Weekender Guide C1

title: YANKS' LOSS IRKS STEINBRENNER
description: The Yankees finally played the Cleveland Indians last night for the first time this season, and they found another team that can beat them.

title: JAPAN BEATS U.S.
description: Japan beat the United States , 6-5, after defeating Australia, 14-0, Wednesday in the opening play of the World's Fair International baseball tournament. The United States team, which beat Mexico 11-0 in the first round, held a 5-4 lead going into the final inning. The tournament is for leading highschool seniors and college freshmen from each nation.

title: Optimism Expressed Over Namibia Talks
description: Officials of Western countries seeking independence for South-West Africa, or Namibia, are holding a new round of meetings here amid what a United States official today called controlled optimism over the territory's future.

title: Chief of Allen-Bradley Adds Title of Chairman
description: Claude R. Whitney, 58, has been named chairman of the privately held Allen-Bradley Company, a Milwaukee-based manufacturer and marketer of industrial automation control products. Mr. Whitney, who currently serves as vice chairman and chief executive officer, will succeed I. Andrew Rader, 67, who will retire Nov. 30.

title: NLT Offer Begins; New Bid on Table
description: The American General Corporation of Houston said that its tender offer of $38 a share in cash for 15 million common shares, or 43 percent, of the NLT Corporation of Nashville began yesterday. However, American General noted that it had proposed a second, higher bid of $46 a share, conditioned on the approval and recommendation by NLT's directors.

title: DOW LOSES 2.76 AS RALLY STALLS
description: The stock market's rally stalled yesterday afternoon on indications of a softening bond market. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 810.41, down 2.76 from the opening. It had gained more than 5 points during the morning.

title: MUTUAL OIL LEASE
description: Mutual Oil of America said it had acquired a lease from the Publishers Paper Company, a subsidiary of the Times Mirror Company, covering 100,000 acres in Oregon.

title: Heads-Up Tactics Lead To a Goal
description: TO soccer players, nobody ranks higher than ''the Maestro.'' He is the man who orchestrates the skills for the entire team, the field leader. Quite simply, the master.

title: Stolen-Base Controversy
description: Jody Davis, a catcher with the Chicago Cubs, has accused a former teammate, Ivan DeJesus, the shortstop, of helping fellow Latin players on other teams to steal bases. Davis made his remarks after twice throwing out Omar Moreno, the National League's leading base stealer, during Wednesday night's victory at Pittsburgh.

title: NU-WEST SALE
description: Nu-West Inc. said it intended to sell all its Arizona residential land and a 2,000-acre parcel in San Clemente, Calif., to Western Savings and Loan Association. Nu-West said the proposed purchase price included a combination of notes secured by a portfolio of mortgages and preferred shares of Western savings with a combined face value ranging from $86 million to $116 million. The company said that it would continued to manage and act as sales representative for the residential land assets for a transition period after completion of the deal.

title: No Headline
description: The Editorial Notebook; 'We Would Take Canada'

title: IS COLLECTIVE SECURITY A DEEP STATE SECRET?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BIG PRICE CUTS IN CLOTHING
description: The recession, now rounding out one year, has forced price reductions in many fields. In the clothing industry, however, discounting has become epidemic.

title: Toyo Kogyo
description: The Toyo Kogyo Company, the Tokyo-based maker of Mazda cars, said that earnings for the six months ended April 30 rose 13.5 percent.

title: 'PYTHON' IN HOLLYWOOD
description: ''MONTY PYTHON LIVE at the Hollywood Bowl'' should not be confused with another current concert film, ''The Secret Policeman's Other Ball,'' a filmed recording of two benefit shows staged by John Cleese with only some of the other Python stars.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds grew by $515 million, to a record $202.9 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 25, 1982
description: International The P.L.O. is finished in Lebanon, according to a faction leader who has been the main leftist ally of the Palestinian guerrillas in Beirut. Walid Jumblat, a leader of the Druse, told reporters that the guerrilla group ''is outdated - it is over.'' In the fighting, Israeli jets continued attacking the positions of the Palestinian guerrillas trapped in Beirut. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The evacuation of hundreds of Americans and Lebanese with American immigration papers was carried out by a transport ship of the Sixth Fleet hours after the American Embassy in Beirut closed. At the 11th hour, scores of other Americans, Lebanese and Western Europeans arrived at the docks in the Mediterranean port of Junieh and were also taken aboard. (A1:3-5.)

title: Mayors Call For Talks; To Stop Nuclear Race
description: Big-city mayors adopted a resolution on Wednesday urging President Reagan to negotiate with the Soviet Union to stop the nuclear arms race and freeze the deployment of nuclear weapons.

title: TWO STRIKES AGAINST A'S PITCHERS
description: Murray Chass on Baseball

title: Mobil British Plant
description: The Mobil Oil Company Ltd. will complete a fluid catalytic cracking complex at its Coryton, Essex, refinery late this year, a Mobil statement said. The complex, consisting of a cracker and six other processing units, will enable the refinery to increase production of higher grade products such as gasoline and diesel fuel.

title: Golf P. Bronisch Dies at 81; Shipping and Marketing Aide
description: Golf P. Bronisch, a shipping and marketing expert and an aide to the Mayor of Berlin in the 1930's, died June 19 at Cabrini Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived of Manhattan.

title: Coffee Talks Are Extended
description: With talks deadlocked, the 73-nation council of the International Coffee Organization voted today to postpone Friday's deadline in negotiations for an extension of the world coffee pact until next Wednesday.

title: Brighton Beach in 1938 is setting for Simon play.
description: ABOUT nine years ago, when he was working on ''The Sunshine Boys,'' Neil Simon began to think about a play that would deal with people coping with the Depression and facing World War II. Five years later, he got around to starting such a play, but he put it aside after he found himself unable to write more than 35 pages. Last year the play suddenly ''started to blossom,'' as Mr. Simon describes it, and he was able to finish it. He calls the new play ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' and he will bring it to Broadway next season.

title: The U.N. Today; June 25, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee of Special Ses- sion on Disarmament - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MUSIC: MCNEIL ROBINSON
description: AT the end of his organ recital at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin Wednesday night, McNeil Robinson played two themes. The first was submitted by Vincent Persichetti; it was intricate, asymmetrical, replete with chordal and melodic dissonance.

title: ROGERS OF SAINTS SAID TO ADMIT USE OF COCAINE
description: George Rogers, the National Football League's leading rusher, and Dave Wilson, one of his teammates on the Saints, have told a Federal grand jury in New Orleans that as rookies last season they purchased and used cocaine, according to Justice Department officials here.

title: SOUTH KOREA PREMIER NAMED IN NEW SHUFFLE OF THE CABINET
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea replaced his Prime Minister and three other ministers today. The new Prime Minister, Kim Sang Hyup, 62 years old, is a Japanese-educated law professor and head of Korea University in Seoul. He served once before in the Cabinet, as Education Minister for eight months in 1962.

title: 'THE THING,' HORROR AND SCIENCE FICTION
description: JOHN CARPENTER'S ''The Thing'' is a foolish, depressing, overproduced movie that mixes horror with science fiction to make something that is fun as neither one thing or the other. Sometimes it looks as if it aspired to be the quintessential moron movie of the 80's - a virtually storyless feature composed of lots of laboratoryconcocted special effects, with the actors used merely as props to be hacked, slashed, disemboweled and decapitated, finally to be eaten and then regurgitated as - guess what? - more laboratory-concocted special effects.

title: SOHIO ALASKA OIL PRICE $2-$3
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) yesterday raised the price of oil it produces on Alaska's North Slope by $2 a barrel to refiners on the West Coast of the United States and by $3 a barrel on the Gulf Coast, in what analysts said was a significant indication that domestic crude prices are firming.

title: POPULARITY OF SHARK FISHING GROWING
description: D uring the last decade, shark fishing has become astonishingly popular along the East Coast. Shark tournaments are held from the west coast of Florida to New England, and in New York and New Jersey in late spring and summer, hardly a weekend goes by without one or several such events.

title: DEMAND FOR WATER IN ARIZONA CAUSING DEEP GROUND CRACKS
description: Until recently, they were found mostly in sparsely populated, rural areas of the state: great, jagged fissures that would seem to appear overnight across the surface of the desert, as if the earth had been rent by some silent earthquake. Often these scars are several miles long and so deep that when you drop a rock into them, you never hear it hit bottom.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was an evening full of surprises Monday at the benefit for Children's International Summer Villages.T he first surprise for some guests was to find themselves wandering a round Central Park in the dark looking for the Dairy, the site of t he billed '' Midsummer Night's Dream.'' Once found, and with thirst a lleviated, there was a fashion show that could, with some accuracy, b e described as unique.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Reverse Speeds
description: Lou McCullough, the athletic director at Iowa State, was asked about one of his football stars from last season, Dwayne Crutchfield, the 245-pound fullback who was the third-round draft choice of the Jets.

title: JERSEY SENATE REJECTS 5-CENT RISE IN GASOLINE TAX THAT KEAN SOUGHT
description: The State Senate today rejected Governor Kean's proposed five-cent surtax on gasoline. The Governor warned that the Senate action would mean layoffs of state employees, elimination of needed road and transportation improvements and increases in transit fares.

title: 'DECEITFUL NEW GAMBIT' IN HAITIAN REFUGEE POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Price Communications
description: The Price Communications Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the WOWO-AM radio station in Fort Wayne, Ind., for $6 million cash from the Westinghouse Broadcasting Corporation.

title: BILLIE JEAN KING REACHES 100
description: and winning for the 87th time - she looked back on her first retirement as ancient and regrettable history. She had gotten the idea in her head that all the great ones retire on top, so that's what she did - won the Wimbledon title in 1975 and retired.

title: Addenda
description: * Needham & Grohmann Inc. has opened a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., office called Needham & Grohmann/Southern division.

title: Cairo Asks Nonaligned Talks
description: Egypt called today for a meeting of the selfprofessed nonaligned nations to discuss the crisis in Lebanon and urged Washington to persuade Israel to end its siege of western Beirut. The Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Boutros Ghali, said he had taken up the issue of a nonaligned conference with Yugoslavia's Ambassador, Aleksandr Bozovic. He also said President Hosni Mubarak had asked President Reagan for decisive measures to lift the siege of Beirut.

title: SALLY RUSH DOWNING
description: Sally Rush Downing, a patron of the arts who was the widow of Russell V. Downing, former president of Radio City Music Hall, died Wednesday in a nursing home in Memphis. She was 80 years old and had moved to Memphis two years ago after more than 50 years in New York City.

title: METS DEFEAT EXPOS
description: In a 162-game season, the salvation of inconsistent baseball teams is this rule: Sooner or later, everything evens out. The Mets, a team that is being rebuilt partly with high-priced power hitters, beat Montreal, 3-1, last night with two soft line drives to the opposite field, a misplayed pop fly, two hard-hit infield singles and a clever bunt.

title: RODERICK CRAIG
description: Roderick Craig, professor emeritus of entomology at the University of California at Berkeley, died last weekend at the age of 79.

title:
ISSUE AND DEBATE;
DISPUTED DUMPING OF SEWAGE SLUDGE IN OCEAN
description: For 40 years, New York City has been shipping its sewage sludge - the blackish liquid left after treatment by 12 water pollution control plants - to a dumping site in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: AGENTS GET COCAINE WORTH $200 MILLION FLOWN TO L.I. AIRPORT
description: More than 100 Federal, state and local law enforcement officers staked out near a runway at Brookhaven Airport before dawn today watched as 610 pounds of pure cocaine in duffel bags were shoved out of a plane. They later arrested four men on charges of drug trafficking.

title: 'AGING,' KABUKI AND 'PREMATURE'
description: TONIGHT at 7:30, WCBS-TV is presenting the final installment of the local station's ''Project Aging,'' a three-week effort that has focused on concerns of the elderly in the metropolitan area. ''We Don't Act Our Age'' looks at old people through the eyes of young people, specifically the students of Carol Karasik at Public School 75 on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: FRENCHMAN BECOMES A SPACE PIONEER AT LAUNCHING OF SOVIET ROCKET
description: Invoking the words ''liberte, egalite, fraternite'' as the countdown clock neared zero, a 43-year-old French Air Force colonel, Jean-Loup Chretien, blasted into orbit aboard a Soviet rocket today and became the first astronaut who is neither an American nor a citizen of a Communist nation to fly in space.

title: Bell Canada's Restructuring
description: Bell Canada's proposed reorganization will not require approval of the Canadian Radio-Television and Telecommunications Commission, A.J. de Grandpre, the company's chairman, said today.

title: PUBLISHING: JEFFERSON VOL. 20, 45 TO GO
description: LATE this summer or early in the fall, the 20th volume of the Thomas Jefferson papers will be published by Princeton University Press, continuing a project that began during the Jefferson Bicentennial Celebration of 1943. This latest book in the 65-volume project, will bring Jefferson's correspondence up to August 1791. Volume 21, a cumulative index, is scheduled for publication before the end of this year.

title: WHO'S DOING WHAT, WHEN AND WHERE
description: A schedule of events follows for the Kool Jazz Festival, which runs today through the Fourth of July. Included are days, times, places, performers and ticket prices. To charge tickets, call Chargit (944-9300) or Teletron (947-5850). For further information, call 787-2020.

title: Harvester to Sell 5 Parts Centers
description: The International Harvester Company said that it was putting its five parts remanufacturing centers on the block. The decision to divest itself of the operations, which generate combined annual sales of more than $40 million, is the latest in a series of actions designed to concentrate the company's efforts on its core trucks and tractors businesses.

title: DANCER RECALLS THE THRILL OF WORK IN 1931
description: THE revival of Martha Graham's ''Primitive Mysteries,'' an early signature work, has been one of the major successes this season for the Martha Graham Dance Company at City Center. A new generation of audiences has responded to ''Primitive Mysteries,'' with its stark formal patterns and its summoning of a vivid moment of apotheosis when one woman emerges from the ranks as an elect.

title: BRIEFING
description: Priorities on Survival

title: Bear, Stearns Official Keeps Global Shares
description: Some years ago, Alan C. Greenberg's now-deceased boss at Bear, Stearns & Company, Salim L. Lewis, observed that Mr. Greenberg was a successful trader because he never grew attached to a particular security. He was known for buying a stock in the morning and selling it in the afternoon.

title: GOOD MEDICINE AT HOME
description: The look on the patients' faces mixes delight and disbelief - as if a dodo bird, endearing but extinct, had landed on their doorstep. The visitors are doctors who make house calls day and night, weekends and holidays, all over New York. Most sick people in this city and in other traffic-choked areas across the nation have not seen physicians at their bedsides for at least 30 years. But almost always, these patients and their families express gratitude for the Brooklyn-based Doctors on Call.

title: TANKER OWNERS PLAN TO SEND HOME 22 IN 'MUTINY'
description: Crew members who held a Liberian-flag tanker at anchor for five weeks were engaged in a ''mutiny'' rather than a labor dispute, the owners of the vessel said yesterday. But they said they would send home the 22 crewmen, who were removed from the tanker by an armed United States force on Tuesday.

title: E.E.C. Sets Steel Cuts
description: The European Economic Community today announced the toughest mandatory production cuts ever imposed on the community's steel industry.

title: DR PEPPER DRAWS BIG NAMES TO PIER 84
description: What would summer in the city be without the Dr Pepper Music Festival? With the help of various sponsors, and under a succession of names, this venerable concert series has been presenting some of pop music's biggest names in outdoor settings for 17 years.

title: President Resigning From Commodore
description: James Finke is leaving the executive suite for a life closer to that of an entrepreneur. Commodore International Ltd., the computer company based in Valley Forge, Pa., announced yesterday that Mr. Finke was leaving the president's post upon the expiration of his contract on June 30.

title: Ovett Running for Coe
description: Steve Ovett says he ''pitied'' the promoters of tomorrow's big international track meet at Oslo because of the shin injury that has caused them to lose Sebastian Coe, their top draw, from the 800-meter field. So Ovett, whose slowly healing leg has forced him to pass up all competition since late last year, will return to the track sooner than expected, having told the promoters when they called him Wednesday that he would enter Olso's 3,000-meter event.

title: SCULPTURE: ON THE BEACH
description: SCULPTORS have once again invaded the sandy acreage of the Battery Park City Landfill, a site, as they say, for sore eyes. Opening tomorrow is the fourth annual edition of the summer sculpture garden known as ''Art on the Beach,'' an environmental exhibition that offers as backdrop the World Trade Center, the Statue of Liberty, the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and a peerless view of Hoboken. This year's show, again sponsored by Creative Time Inc., the not-for-profit organization that matches artists with city space, boasts the work of 10 contributors who have by and large, managed to enrich the dazzling local landscape.

title: POLISH DEBT NEGOTIATOR RELIEVED OF HIS POSITION
description: Poland's top debt negotiator, Marian Minkiewicz, was relieved tonight of his position as the chairman of Bank Handlowy, the Polish foreign trade bank.

title: SHEARSON SETS ENRTY INTO REALTY
description: The Balcor Corporation, one of the nation's largest real estate syndicators, will be purchased by Shearson/American Express Inc. in a two-step transaction worth up to $103 million, the two companies announced today.

title: Dissident Professor Gets 2 Years in Polish Trial
description: A military court here sentenced Prof. Ryszard Herczynski, a dissident, to two years in jail today for passing information termed harmful to the state to two United States diplomats who were expelled last month.

title: STAGE: DEBUT BY SPANIARDS
description: ELS JOGLARS of Barcelona is a Spanish experimental theater group with good young actors and ingenious technological stagecraft going for them. But the group, appearing in its New York debut through Sunday at La Mama E.T.C., suffers from the shortcomings of its material, a two-hour '' 'vaccination' against Fascism'' called ''Olympic Man Movement.''

title: UV Trust Reports Exxon Settlement
description: The trust set up to liquidate UV Industries said yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to pay damages of $39 million to the Reliance Electric Company, a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, to settle a two-year legal battle over a subsidiary that the trust sold to Reliance.

title: Guatemalans Die in Crash
description: Guatemala's Agriculture Minister, Otto Martinez Recinos, an assistant, a bodyguard and the pilot were killed Wednesday night when their small plane crashed in a rainstorm. The police said the wreckage was found today in a gulley 100 miles west of the capital.

title: U.S. BIDS OTHERS PUT PRESSURE ON P.L.O.
description: The United States has urged Arab and Western European governments to try to persuade the Palestine Liberation Organization to end its military presence in west Beirut.

title: Required Reading; Duties of an Ambassador
description: Allan E. Gotlieb, Canada's Ambassador to the United States, in an address to the Harvard Law School Association, June 16, 1982:

title: Judge to Decide on Haitians
description: After lawyers failed to agree. a Federal judge said today that he would decide how and when nearly 2,000 Haitian refugees should be released from detention centers across the country. Judge Eugene Spellman of the Federal district court said his ruling would be made public Tuesday. He said conferences between lawyers for the Immigration and Naturalization Service and those representing the Haitian refugees had deadlocked.

title: AMERICAN POSTS BAIL AS DETAILS OF OPERATION BY F.B.I. UNFOLD
description: The lone American arrested on charges of participating in a conspiracy to steal computer secrets from the International Business Machines Corporation was released on bail today in San Jose, Calif.

title: BEN J. GRANT
description: Ben J. Grant, retired managing editor and director of the magazine U.S. News & World Report, died early today at Hilton Head Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Judge to End Role In Boston School Case
description: After virtually running Boston's troubled school system for a decade, Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity has announced that he will end his court's role in the city's school desegregation.

title: AT GARDEN, 2,500 POLICE GRADUATES HAIL A COMRADE
description: With Madison Square Garden filled by their families and friends, nearly 2,500 men and women graduated from the Police Academy in an emotional ceremony yesterday. But much of the feeling was directed toward a man who did not graduate.

title: RIVALS LINE UP TRAILERS FOR 1984 SPOT
description: Like the tents of rival champions at the royal joust, the private office trailers of the Presidential aspirants sit backstage on wheels, ready for the first signs of Democratic battle in the morning.

title: HOPE STEVENS, 77, HARLEM LEADER, LAWYER AND BUSINESSMAN, IS DEAD
description: Hope Stevens, a lawyer, businessman and civic leader who helped found a mutual insurance company and savings bank in Harlem, fought job discrimination against blacks and became the first black president of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce, died of a heart attack yesterday at Booth Memorial Hospital in Queens. He was 77 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Former Judge, Terminally Ill, Freed From Prison Hospital
description: A former Florida judge, convicted two decades ago of plotting the deaths of another judge and his wife, received an early release from a Federal prison hospital today because he is dying of cancer.

title: Hagler to Miss 3 Months With Injury
description: Marvin Hagler, the world middleweight champion, will be out of action for at least three months, it was learned today. A bone scan showed that Hagler has a fractured rib, which will prevent him from defending his title July 15 against Fulgencio Obelmejias of Venezuela.

title: CHARLES L. SYLVESTER, COUNSEL FOR DEFENSE IN PROMINENT CASES
description: Charles L. Sylvester, who was the defense counsel in a number of highly publicized cases, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BID FOR LIONEL UNIT
description: William Electronics Inc. said it had offered to acquire Dale Electronics from the Lionel Corporation for $26 million and the assumption of several million dollars in debt. Lionel, which has 82 percent of Dale's outstanding stock, said negotiations were contingent upon getting an independent appraisal of the terms.

title: Cranston Can Divert Funds
description: The Federal Election Commission ruled today that supporters of Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, could legally divert funds from his 1986 re-election campaign chest and spend them on his potential Presidential candidacy. Mr. Cranston, the assistant minority leader in the Senate, had $236,000 left over from his 1980 campaign that was transferred to a new committee formed to support him for re-election in 1986. The commission unanimously adopted an advisory opinion saying that ''testing the waters'' for a potential Presidential campaign was a ''lawful purpose'' for using excess campaign funds.

title: 'SERIE NOIRE,' FRENCH VERSION OF AMERICAN YARN
description: ''SERIE NOIRE,'' Alain Corneau's semiserious parody of hard-boiled American fiction transplanted to alien French soil, is about a handsome door-to-door salesman named Frank Pupart (Patrick Dewaere), a fellow doomed to failure, possibly because he has a mind the size of a parakeet's.

title: Garment Field Jobless at 18.1%
description: The jobless rate in the American apparel industry rose to 18.1 percent in April, its highest level since April 1975, because many domestic producers either reduced their output or shut down, the research department of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union reported yesterday.

title: HOUSING AID BILL IS VETOED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan vetoed an $8.9 billion supplemental appropriation bill today, saying that the $3 billion it provided to help the housing industry would put the country ''even deeper in debt.''

title: AFTER THE HINCKLEY CASE
description: Despite all the shock and outrage occasioned by the Hinckley acquittal, the biggest loser is not ''society'' or ''the state''; it's probably the practice of psychiatry.

title: 3 NETWORKS IN DISPUTE WITH ISRAEL
description: The three major United States commercial television networks have come into conflict with the Israeli Government over what network news executives charge is ''political censorship'' of their reports on the war in Lebanon. The networks charged that this week the Israelis began to censor certain film segments - primarily depicting Lebanese casualties - because such sequences are politically embarrassing.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Gambling on Support

title: BEATRICE OFF
description: The Beatrice Foods Company reported yesterday that net income in its first fiscal quarter ended May 31 declined 34.5 percent, to $71.3 million, or 68 cents a share, from $108.9 million, or $1.06 a share, in the first quarter of 1981.

title: U.S. TO TIGHTEN ATOMIC EXPORT RULES
description: An Energy Department official said today that the Administration would soon tighten controls on exports of some kinds of nuclear technology and materials to several countries to help curb the spread of atomic weapons.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DECISION ON PRESIDENTIAL IMMUNITY
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today giving the President absolute immunity from civil suits for damages. Associate Justice Lewis F Powell wrote the majority opinion, and Associate Justice Byron R. White filed a dissenting opinion. By Justice Powell

title: IN FOOTSTEPS OF 'THIN MAN'
description: AMERICA is dreams, and sometimes those dreams go walking. Perhaps the most durable are movie dreams based on memorable lines, the most famous being, ''Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn.'' There is also Dashiell Hammett's description in ''The Maltese Falcon'' of that priceless, ephemeral bird, ''It's the stuff that dreams are made of.''

title: 5-4 RULING ON NIXON CASE; Companion Decision Upholds 'Qualified' Protection for White House Advisers
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that no President may be sued for damages for any official action he takes while in office.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Stewart Granger Cast For Prince Philip Role

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Darci Kistler Promoted By New York City Ballet

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $2.3 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the nation's basic money supply fell by $2.3 billion in the week ended June 16, to $452.5 billion.

title: Going Out Guide
description: TRADITION

title: EXCERPTS FROM JUSTICES' OPINIONS ON ISLAND TREES, L.I., SCHOOL LIBRARY SUIT
description: Following are excerpts from today's Supreme Court ruling on the limits of a school board's discretion to remove books from a school library. There was no majority opinion. Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote the plurality opinion, joined in full by Associate Justices Thurgood Marshall and John Paul Stevens and in part by Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun. Associate Justice Byron R. White wrote a separate concurring opinion. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Associate Justices Lewis F. Powell, William H. Rehnquist, and Sandra Day O'Connor all filed dissenting opinions.

title: U.N.'S 3 MAIN BODIES MOVE TO HEAD OFF ISRAELI SEIZURE OF BEIRUT
description: The three principal bodies of the United Nations acted today to head off an Israeli invasion of Beirut and achieve a cease-fire that might last.

title: HEUBLEIN LOBBYING IN HARTFORD
description: Prompted by concerns of possible takeover attempts involving Heublein Inc. and other major companies, Connecticut is moving to give its state-chartered corporations more flexibility to fight off hostile suitors.

title: MILLIONS IN ITALY STRIKE FOR A DAY
description: Millions of Italian workers paralyzed traffic and services today in a general strike protesting Government austerity and the scrapping of an agreement that protected their wages from inflation.

title: Sports People; Dailey Gets Probation
description: Quintin Dailey, an all-America guard coveted by the Knicks in next week's draft, was placed on three years' probation by a judge in San Francisco yesterday for an assault on a student nurse last December.

title: LAWS REQUIRING OFFICIALS TO QUIT BEFORE SEEKING NEW POSTS UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of state laws that require public officials to resign before running for a different office.

title: No Headline
description: Briefs on the Arts Sale of Old Vic Approved

title: AT 46, GOODMAN QUARTET STILL SWINGS
description: Forty-six years after Benny Goodman, Lionel Hampton and Teddy Wilson first played together with the late Gene Krupa as the Benny Goodman Quartet, Messrs. Goodman, Hampton and Wilson were playing together again last night at Carnegie Hall on the opening evening of the Kool Jazz Festival.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In recent months it has become clear to me that the foreign policy on which we embarked together was shifting from that careful course which we laid out. Under these circumstances, I feel it necessary to request that you accept my resignation.'' - Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., in letter to President Reagan. (4:4.)

title: U.S. JEWS AND LEBANON
description: Among the problems created by the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, one in particular addresses the American Jewish community: Is open, vigorous dissent from the Begin Government's policies appropriate and vital for Middle East peace and Israel's welfare? This question assumes - correctly, we believe - that Israel's military victory will prove self-defeating.

title: A Major Loss
description: In losing Alexander Haig, the Reagan Administration has lost its only top-ranking official with significant experience abroad. Alone in the President's circle, he understood how other governments behave and how their conflicting ambitions can be made to serve American purposes. Intense and hard-driving, General Haig did not always practice the tact of a diplomat. But his policy goals and tactics were moderate. He should have been eagerly handed the power and status for which he was forced to grasp.

title: Briefing
description: Bottom Note on Organs

title: Arson Is Ruled Out in Blaze That Killed 12 in Texas Hotel
description: Investigators have ruled that the Westchase Hilton hotel fire, in which 12 people died in March, was accidentally started by a cigarette left smoldering in an overstuffed chair.

title: Nucorp Energy Is Sued 4 Times
description: Nucorp Energy Inc. confirmed it had been sued four times by vendors for canceling orders for tubular oilfield goods in an attempt to deal with excess inventory.

title: SOVIET SCHIZOPHRENIA TOWARD STRAVINSKY: RAZING HIS HOUSE AT CENTENNIAL TIME
description: Musical Life, a Moscow magazine, recently published a letter by one of its readers that describes the fate that has befallen the composer Igor Stravinsky's house, which was built in 1907 according to his design in the village of Ustilug (now a city) in the Ukraine. ''It's been a year that no one has lived in the Stravinsky house, and at present it is being used as a warehouse. The state organization that owns the warehouse intends to raze the building.''

title: Israelis Assail Greek Leader For Likening Them to Nazis
description: Israel issued a ''strong verbal protest'' today over Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's equation of Israel's current action against the Palestinians in Lebanon with Nazi crimes against the Jews, a spokesman for the Israeli diplomatic mission in Athens said.

title: Shultz to See Reagan At Camp David Today
description: George P. Shultz, President Reagan's choice to replace Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State, is scheduled to arrive at Dulles Airport outside Washington at 11 A.M. Saturday via Concorde jet, the White House said tonight.

title: IMPORT SURGE WIDENED U.S. TRADE GAP IN MAY
description: Despite another sharp drop in imported oil, total American imports of foreign goods surged in May at the fastest rate in at least eight years, swelling the nation's merchandise trade deficit to $3.29 billion for the month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 'STUNNED' POLICY ANALYSTS DIFFER ON EFFECT OF DEPARTURE
description: The departure of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. surprised most of the American foreign policy establishment, dismaying those who saw him as a force for moderation in the Administration and pleasing those who regarded him as too moderate.

title: Cluster Bomb Remains Found by Israeli Troops
description: The Israeli military Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Raphael Eytan, has disclosed that remains of cluster bombs were found in southern Lebanon.

title: Israeli Troops Rescue Aunt of U.S. Senator
description: Israeli troops have rescued the 88-year-old aunt of Senator James Abdnor from the combat zone in Lebanon and taken her to Israel, the senator's office said today.

title: REGENTS GIVE A BREAK TO EX-YANKEE
description: In his 16-year career as a major league baseball player, Paul L.D. Blair played on at least two World Series teams, including the 1978 New York Yankees. He won eight Gold Glove awards and was named to two All-Star teams.

title: Dr. Pierre Mertz, 85, Is Dead; Ex-Bell Laboratories Scientist
description: Dr. Pierre Mertz, a scientist formerly with Bell Laboratories and a specialist in telephotography and television transmission, died Wednesday at the Meadow Lakes Presbyterian Home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 85 years old and had lived in Lido Beach, L.I., until moving to Hightstown eight years ago.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REMARKS BY REAGAN AND HAIG ON RESIGNATION
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's statement today in Washington on the resignation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., followed by Mr. Haig's subsequent statement, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News.

title: MAN, 50, IS MANACLED AND SLAIN
description: A 50-year-old man was found shot to death yesterday, his face covered with a ski mask and his hands manacled behind him, in his 39th-floor, $2,000-a-month apartment at 66th Street and Second Avenue.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 26, 1982; Markets
description: The nation's basic money supply fell $2.3 billion in the week ended June 16, the Federal Reserve Board reported. Analysts said that the larger-than-expected decline may ease interest rates at a time when the Treasury is planning to raise $18.6 billion in the credit markets. The Fed also revised upward the money supply figure that it reported for the previous week. (Page 31.)

title: NO TAR TEST ON BARCLAY
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it could not rule on the low-tar claims made by the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation for its Barclay cigarettes because its testing methods could not accurately assess the effectiveness of the Barclay filter.

title: Around the Nation; Relief Agencies Prepare For Haitians' Release
description: Relief agencies adopted a plan today to resettle 1,910 Haitian refugees, expressing confidence that a Federal district judge would order their release from United States detention centers on Tuesday.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 17. 1. A combined force of Federal, state and local agents rounded up the geese, which had refused to budge from their resting places in the New York metropolitan area, and is transporting them to southern states.

title: ARAFAT IS KEEPING BUSY TO BOOST P.L.O. MORALE
description: Yasir Arafat and other leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization have been trying to keep busy while hoping for some way out of their impasse.

title: THE RALLY-GOERS CAME FOR PEACE, NOT FOR ROCK MUSIC
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH'S CONTRADICTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Scouting; Share Alike
description: Most professional teams have a ''fine fund,'' money that accumulates during the season from player fines paid for such things as being late for practice or missing a team flight or bus. And most teams use that money for themselves at the end of the season, either dividing it up, throwing a team party or perhaps buying something for the locker room.

title: Cupecoy's Joy Is Improved
description: Cupecoy's Joy, whose chance to sweep the filly triple crown in the Coaching Club American Oaks today was imperiled by a freakish collision with another horse Thursday morning, is recovering ''beautifully'' and ''will almost definitely'' race, according to Robert Perez, her co-owner.

title: Reagan 'Concerned' Over Losses
description: President Reagan is ''deeply concerned'' about the growing casualties in Lebanon, a White House spokesman said today.

title: ANGOLAN FIRMNESS ON CUBA CLOUDS NAMIBIA TALKS
description: Before negotiations on ending the guerrilla war in South-West Africa begin, Angola today renewed its objection to Western suggestions that a settlement in the territory on its southern border be conditoned on the withdrawal of Cuban forces from Angola.

title: Drivers of Buses To Airports Strike
description: Drivers for a private bus line between the city's two major airports and Manhattan went on strike yesterday, leaving tourists, airline personnel and business travelers scrambling for alternate rides.

title: Around the World; Jet's Engines Restarted After It Plunges 5 Miles
description: A British jetliner, its engines choked off by ash from an erupting volcano, plunged five miles before the pilots restarted the engines, aviation and airline officials here reported today. No injuries were reported among the 224 passengers and crew of 16.

title: Offer by Coke Is Oversubscribed
description: The Coca-Cola Company announced that its cash offer to shareholders of Columbia Pictures Industries was oversubscribed, and as a result a previously announced proration procedure would go into effect. Under it, the former Columbia stockholders who asked for cash would receive a reduced percentage of cash but also some Coca-Cola stock, Carlton Curtis, Coke spokesman, said.

title: HITACHI APPROACH REPORTED
description: The president of a small firm of computer designers said today that executives of Hitachi Ltd. had asked him last August to obtain several volumes of confidential workbooks for computers being introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Saturday Sports
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia. Doubleheader. (Television - Channel 9, 5:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 5:30 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Boston (Television - Channel 4, 1:45 P.M.) Boxing Saoul Mamby vs. LeRoy Haley. Mamby of the Bronx defends World Boxing Council lightweight title in l5-rounder. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Cornelius Boza-Edwards vs. Roberto Elizondo. Lightweight 10-round bout. (Television - Channel 7, 5 P.M.) Track Bislet Games, Oslo. (Television - Channel 7, 5 P.M.) Other Events Basketball: Rucker Pro Summer League, at Holcombe Rucker Memorial playground, 155th Street and Frederick Douglass Blvd. 2 and 4 P.M. Michelob Halfcourt tournament, championship, at Central Park and 84th Street, 10 A.M. Holcombe Rucker Memorial-I.T.T. Summer League. Opening-day ceremonies for 800 scholastic, collegiate and amateur players in the 32d annual tournament, at Col. Charles Young Park, West 145th Street and Lenox Avenue. Bowling: Showboat Doubles Classic, at Las Vegas, Nev. (Television - Channel 7; 3:30 P.M.) Golf: Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, third round, at Westchester Country Club, Harrison, N.Y. (Television - Channel 2; 3:30 P.M.). Gymnastics: United States Gymnastics Federation Junior Olympics finals, at Jadwin Gymnasium, Princeton, N.J. 7:30 P.M. Harness Racing: Yonkers, 8 P.M. $177,362 7-Up Pace. (Television - Channel 9; 11:30 P.M., tape.) The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - Cablevision and MSG Cable, midnight, tape.)

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 26, 1982
description: Haig's Resignation Alexander M. Haig Jr. resigned as Secretary of State because, he said in a letter to President Reagan, foreign policy had departed from ''the careful course'' that he and the President had initially set. Mr. Reagan made the announcement without giving any reasons for Mr. Haig's departure. George P. Schultz, a former Treasury Secretary, was named to succeed Mr. Haig. It was unclear, even to some of Mr. Haig's closest advisers, whether his resignation was at his own initiative or had been forced upon him. (Page 1, Column 6.) Mr. Haig's abrupt resignation followed long-standing animosity between him and the White House staff that recently boiled over into questions of style and substance on Middle East and Soviet policies, White House aides said. The officials said that disputes over the crisis in Lebanon and President Reagan's decision to tighten economic sanctions against the Soviet Union were exacerbated by a multitude of petty disputes that infuriated the Presidential staff. (1:5.)

title: HIGH COURT LIMITS BANNING OF BOOKS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the First Amendment's guarantee of freedom of speech limits the discretion of public school officials to remove books they consider offensive from school libraries.

title: Yonkers Receives County Aid
description: Westchester County presented Yonkers with $1.1 million today and took title to a 26-acre city tract on Austin Avenue that will be developed into an industrial or office park.

title: JERSEYAN IS KILLED IN 'WRONG-WAY' CRASH AT TUNNEL
description: A 55-year-old man was killed yesterday when his automobile sped through a wrong lane on a New Jersey ramp of the Lincoln Tunnel and collided with a bus. Seventeen of the 53 passengers on the bus were injured.

title: Around the Nation; Third Rare Crane Killed by Raccoons
description: Marauding raccoons eluded patrols, traps and an electrified fence to kill a third rare crane today, setting off an intensive raccoon hunt.

title: L.I. SCHOOL BOARD UNSURE OF NEXT STEP
description: It has been nearly seven years since the board of the Island Trees Union Free School District removed nine books from the shelves of school libraries here, saying that the books contained ''material which is offensive to Christians, Jews, blacks and Americans'' and ''just plain filthy.''

title: WORKSHOPS AT DEMOCRATIC MINI-CONVENTION MIX PARTY HOOPLA AND CYNICISM
description: Once they can find that rare hotel elevator not reserved for privileged party ''VIPs,'' and once they get past the Civic Center metal detectors that weed out armed Americans, the Democrats traditionally offer fanfares for the common man as their poltical motif.

title: ME-TOO'ING CITIES
description: Americans have always looked longingly at European cities. For much of our history, our attitude could be characterized as abject inferiority. In fact, the protection of our natural ''crown jewels'' in a unique national park system was successfully advocated as the American response to Europe's inimitable cathedrals, grand squares and other architectural treasures.

title: Around the World; West German Kills 3, Including 2 U.S. Blacks
description: A West German political extremist shot and killed a black American soldier, a black American civilian and an Egyptian Thursday night, then took his own life after shouting a Nazi slogan, the police said today.

title: WET DAY, BEE BITE IN TENNIS
description: Pam Shriver had fallen asleep for almost 30 minutes in the women's locker room at the All England Club today. She awoke to the sound of Rosie Casals doing a rain dance and the sight of Martina Navratilova holding Virginia Wade's 5 British note.

title: A BREAK IN POLICY
description: George P. Shultz, who will succeed Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State, reportedly agrees with the policies of President Reagan, particularly his toughness toward the Soviet Union and what is seen as a tougher approach toward Israel over Lebanon. These are the issues that were said to have caused Mr. Haig's departure. This is bound to produce consternation abroad, particularly in Western Europe, China, the Soviet Union and Israel. Leaders in these countries have come to look at Mr. Haig as their principal defender in the Reagan Administration. Concern will be particularly acute in Israel because Mr. Shultz is known to be less sympathetic to Israeli policy than Mr. Haig is.

title: Scouting; Garland Fails
description: Wayne Garland, the right-handed pitcher who as a free agent in 1976 was signed to a 10-year contract by the Cleveland Indians, has been released by the Nashville Sounds of the Southern League, the Yankees' Class AA farm club. Garland, who is 31 years old, had been released by Cleveland in January with five years remaining on his contract, which was reportedly for $230,000 a season.

title: SOUTHEAST'S SHAKY DOMINION
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation, for years the commanding presence in Florida's lucrative banking market, appears to be losing its once-formidable dominion to a host of threatening challengers.

title: SYRIANS CONCEDE LOSSES TO ISRAEL
description: The Syrian high command conceded today that its troops had been forced to give up ground to the advancing Israeli forces along the strategic Beirut-Damascus highway.

title: Firestone Canada
description: Firestone Canada Inc. said its Hamilton, Ontario, plant would be closed for four weeks from July 19.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Facelift For Gracie Mansion

title: The U.N. Today; June 26, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Emergency Special Session on the Question of Palestine - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

63-127, leads by 3 strokes at Westchester 21 Players: Pepitone taking Yankee tension in stride 21 Pam Shriver wins after easing sting of opponent's bee bite 21 Yankees beat Indians, 11-3, as Gamble gets 3 hits 21 Mets lose doubleheader to Phillies and drop to .500 21 Quotation of the Day

title: BECHTEL LOSES ANOTHER OFFICER TO REAGAN'S CABINET
description: The Bechtel Corporation, a huge international construction and engineering company that ranks among the country's largest privately held concerns, is not at all unaccustomed to hiring senior Government officials for key management jobs.

title:
PATENTS;
Way of Fusing Genes To Produce Proteins
description: A method of fusing genes was patented this week for Harvard University. The research was financed by the National Science Foundation and other organizations.

title: THE HOBOKEN BONGOS WITTY AT BOTTOM LINE
description: The Bongos, a Hoboken-based pop group that appeared Wednesday at the Bottom Line, are one of the most promising young local bands.

title: THE RALLY-GOERS CAME FOR PEACE, NOT FOR ROCK MUSIC
description: To the Editor:

title: It's a Time for Silence, Shultz Says in London
description: George P. Shultz, named to be Secretary of State, declined to comment tonight on his return to Government service. ''I think this is my time for some silence,'' he told a reporter as he returned to the Stafford Hotel with his wife from a private dinner.

title: A FIFTH SUSPECT HELD FOR AIDING COCAINE AIRDROP
description: A fifth person was arrested yesterday in connection with the seizure on Thursday of 610 pounds of pure cocaine in an airdrop smuggling operation on Long Island.

title: Around the Nation; Illinois Senate Vote Backs House in Rights Defeat
description: The Illinois Senate, drawing the dying breath out of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, rejected the proposal today and backers sprayed what they said was the blood of women across the Capitol in protest.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American General Corp. and NLT Corp. have both been added to Standard & Poor's Corp.'s creditwatch list.

title: Sports People; Hough's New Post
description: The other boot dropped at Belmont Park yesterday when Stanley Hough, who resigned earlier this week as the trainer for Harbor View Farm, was named head trainer for the powerful stable of Bert and Diana Firestone, effective July 15. Hough resigned from Harbor View because of a clash over stable policy with Dr. Manuel Gilman, the former chief veterinarian at New York thoroughbred tracks, who was named Harbor View general manager last week. The Firestones have one of racing's most powerful breeding operations.

title: IN CONGRESS, DISMAY BUT PRAISE FOR HAIG AND SHULTZ
description: Congressional leaders expressed surprise and dismay today at the announcement of the resignation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., whom they praised as a moderate and a professional. But they also voiced confidence in George P. Shultz, who was nominated to be his successor.

title: Sports People; Bulls Like Westhead
description: The Chicago Bulls hope to name a new coach by the end of the weekend and it appears that Paul Westhead, former coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, is the team's top choice. General Manager Rod Thorn has completed interviews for the post, and according to a report in The Arlington Heights Daily Herald, Westhead will be selected barring any unforeseen contract problems. ... Jody Davis, the Chicago Cub catcher who earlier this week accused Ivan DeJesus of helping fellow Latin players on other teams steal bases when DeJesus was with the Cubs, apologized for the remark yesterday, and he added, ''It was all blown out of proportion.''

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 18.

title: 2 Suspended By Ketchum
description: Harold M. Altshul, chairman and chief executive officer of Ketchum & Company, said yesterday that he had suspended the president of the Ketchum Laboratories subsidiary and the president's secretary after an internal audit had found evidence of possible embezzlement and accounting irregularities.

title: BALLET: 'A FOLK TALE' BY THE DANES
description: The crucial scene in ''A Folk Tale'' - the 1854 ballet by August Bournonville, which had its New York premiere Thursday night with the Royal Danish Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House - occurs in the middle of the performance.

title: A MAN OF MANY WORLDS
description: George Pratt Shultz, President Reagan's choice to succeed Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State, is a labor economist whose service in government during the Nixon Administration led him into the international business world, including significant involvement in the Middle East.

title: Chicago and Seville Awarded Provisional World Fair Dates
description: The general assembly of the 35-nation Bureau of International Expositions has voted to award provisional date reservations to Chicago and Seville, Spain, for a World's Fair in 1992 to mark the 500th anniversary of Columbus's landing in America.

title: REDESIGNING SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Wisps of white hair curl down his neck and stick out behind his ears. His high forehead gives him a scholarly look. His voice is soft.

title: SHAREHOLDER SUIT NAMES CLAROSTAT
description: The Clarostat Manufacturing Company, a New Hampshire producer of electrical supplies that recently resolved a proxy fight by buying out its dissident shareholders, declined to respond yesterday to a suit filed by some of its shareholders.

title: THE HUSTLING EMIGRE WAITING IN THE WINGS
description: Jack D. Burstein, the Miami accountant who is widely believed to be considering a takeover bid for the Southeast Banking Corporation, Florida's biggest banking organization, is no novice at dealing in the state's volatile financial markets.

title: 2 ASTRONAUTS FLY TO LAUNCHING BASE
description: The astronauts for the final test mission of the space shuttle Columbia had a stormy arrival at their launching base here this afternoon. They had to fly above and around thunderstorms for an hour before bringing their T-38 jets to a safe landing on an alternate landing strip.

title: I.R.A. Explodes a Car Bomb Outside a Nurses' Residence
description: A 200-pound car bomb exploded on a busy street outside a nurses' residence at lunchtime today, wounding 25 people with flying glass and brick, the police said.

title: KEEPING THE POOL SANITARY
description: FOR many people who own swimming pools, the arrival of summer this w eek meant it was time to buy chemicals, test the water, and, in g eneral, prepare the pools for family use.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Pomp and Circumstance' In Riverside Church

title: WABC-TV FACES PUNITIVE ACTION BY F.C.C. FOR IMPROPER CONDUCT
description: WABC-TV, the rich and powerful network-owned television station in New York City, is threatened with disciplinary action by the Federal Communications Commission for improper conduct as a broadcaster, according to sources at the commission.

title:
Patents;
Television Channel Identifier
description: WASHINGTON THE millions of users of video games, home computers and other facilities linked to television are promised a way to connect them quickly. A channel identifier patented this week for the RCA Corporation will signal the proper receiver channel to be plugged in.

title: EX-SOLDIER ENDS BATTLE TO GUIDE FOREIGN POLICY
description: The announcement today of the resignation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. ends, for the time being at least, the stormy Washington career of a West Point soldier who guided one President's exit from office and who battled for the right to guide another President's foreign policy.

title: No OPEC's for Doctors
description: Organized medicine may not welcome the Supreme Court's finding that a fee schedule followed by Arizona physicians amounts to illegal price fixing. But the nation's patients should welcome this recognition that price competition can help to contain medical costs.

title: Scouting; Name Search Is Bedeviled
description: New Jersey hockey fans have been sending suggestions for a name for their new team - the former Colorado franchise that will play at Byrne Meadowlands Arena beginning next season - to area newspapers, which have been forwarding them to John McMullen, the team's principal owner. According to McMullen, one of the most popular choices is ''Devils,'' for historical reasons.

title: AMERICAN PIPE SUPPLIES UNNEEDED, SOVIET SAYS
description: If President Reagan's decision to extend the ban on American technology for the Siberian gas pipeline has hurt or frightened the Russians, they have been characteristically careful not to show it.

title: WHY SUBSTITUTING GENERIC DRUGS COULD BE A HEALTH HAZARD
description: To the Editor:

title: OPEC Unit Meets July 7
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced today that its four-member market monitoring committee would meet in Vienna on July 7, but it said nothing about reports that a full session of all 13 members would immediately follow.

title: Playboy Assets
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said the value of its assets declined 22.8 percent, to $192.6 million in the 1982 third quarter ended March 31, from $249.4 million a year earlier.

title: DR. JULIAN B. KAYE
description: Dr. Julian B. Kaye, professor of English at Brooklyn College, died last Saturday at his home in Manhattan.

title: TWO COLONIALISMS BATTLE IN THE FALKLANDS
description: To the Editor:
To the Editor:

title: LIBERTY SHIP RETIRES FROM TEACHING
description: Like other Liberty ships, the John W. Brown was slapped together in a few weeks of frantic welding in the early days of World War II. Many young merchant seamen got their first taste of life at sea aboard the Brown in the Mediterranean theater.

title: Clyde T. Holliday, 70; Filmed Earth Features
description: Clyde T. Holliday, who designed and built a camera system that produced the first pictures of the Earth from space, died Wednesday in Arlington, Va. He was 70 years old.

title: Around the World; Editor of Managua Paper Reports Being Beaten
description: An editor of the independent newspaper La Prensa said today that he had been beaten and his life threatened by four masked men, one of them carrying a machine gun.

title: IRVING N. TOLKIN
description: Irving N. Tolkin, retired president of Jennifer Dale Inc. of Manhattan, died Monday at the age of 79 at his home in Hewlett, L.I. He had founded his first garment-manufacturing company in 1937, with $11,000 that he won in the Irish Sweepstakes.

title: ARGENTINE POLITICIANS HAIL NEW PRESIDENT AFTER TALKS
description: Civilian political leaders here said today that they were heartened by a promise made by the President-designate that he would immediately lift the military's ban on politics when he takes office next Thursday.

title: THE LIFE AND REGRETS OF A SENATOR EMERITUS
description: The Senator has many visitors. They come to the sunny little back room in his duplex apartment and swap stories and seek counsel. The Senator does not want to name names, but his wife comes in and ticks them off - some of the most distinguished men in the Congress, in foreign affairs, in public life.

title: LONDON'S SUBWAY SERVICE IS SHUT DOWN BY STRIKE
description: All of London's subway service was halted by a strike today that resulted in mass congestion on roads and raised the prospect of still greater disruption Monday when trainmen plan to add a nationwide shutdown of British Rail.

title: ACTOR IN SEX MOVIES IS FOUND NOT GUILTY OF 4 COAST MURDERS
description: John Holmes, a star of pornographic films, was acquitted today of charges that he bludgeoned five of his friends in a Laurel Canyon home, leaving four of them dead and one severely injured.

title: Republicans' Spending Outstrips Democrats'
description: National Republican Party committees raised nine times more money than the Democrats in the first 15 months of the 1982 election cycle and spent seven times as much as the Democrats spent, the Federal Election Commission said today.

title: Newspaper Guild Delegates Back a Merger With Printers
description: Delagates to the convention of the 31,500-member Newspaper Guild have voted overwhelmingly to approve a merger with the 40,000-member International Typographical Union.

title: SALVADORANS' STATUS AT ISSUE ON COAST
description: Along Pico Boulevard, blasting out of tiny cantinas that sell ''cerveza'' and the thick Salvadoran tortillas stuffed with cheese called pupusas, the pounding, brassy popular music of El Salvador seems omnipresent.

title: ENROLLMENT IN PRIVATE SCHOOLS IS GROWING RAPIDLY IN ALASKA
description: Private elementary and secondary education has increased rapidly here in the last five years in parallel with the emergence of fundamentalist religious leaders as a political force.

title: GAMBLE'S 3 HITS ANSWER A CRITIC
description: Drawing once again on his experience as an assistant college football coach, George Steinbrenner delivered a 40-minute pre-game clubhouse address to the Yankees last night that was followed by an 11-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: BENNY GOODMAN GROUP KICKS OFF JAZZ FESTIVAL
