description: Benny Goodman clowned and twirled his clarinet like a baton. Lionel Hampton sustained long solos while grinning impishly at Mr. Goodman. Teddy Wilson observed their antics impassively from his piano stool, moving just enough to reveal the scarlet lining of his dinner jacket.

title: Presidents Above the Law
description: Richard Nixon is the first President ever to pay money damages for violating a citizen's individual rights, and this week the Supreme Court made him the last. It ruled, 5 to 4, that Presidents are absolutely immune from civil liability - even for clearly illegal activity - when acting within the ''outer perimeter'' of their office.

title:
PATENTS;
Radiation Detector Operated by Battery
description: A battery-operated nuclear radiation detector and monitor, trademarked Radiation Sentry, was patented this week.

title: REFUGEES FLEEING BEIRUT FOR ISRAELI-HELD SOUTH
description: Thousands of refugees are pouring out of Beirut and heading south along the coastal road into Israeli-held territory.

title: Brewers Rout Red Sox, 9-3
description: Cecil Cooper drove in three runs with a single and a two-run homer and Gorman Thomas also hit a two-run homer tonight as they powered the Milwaukee Brewers to a 9-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Westway Deceit (1)
description: The second stage of the Westway cover-up trial, just ended, produced testimony showing that the concealment and distortion of crucial evidence was far more pervasive and serious than anyone had earlier imagined.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: 'Blade Runner' Illustrates Perils of Technology

title: ISRAEL SAYS SYRIAN BUILDUP NEAR BEIRUT HAS COLLAPSED
description: The Israeli military spokesman declared tonight that ''the entire Syrian military buildup'' in the Lebanese mountains east of Beirut had collapsed at the end of the fourth day of heavy fighting along the Beirut-Damascus highway.

title: PROVISIONS OF THE LAW
description: The Endangered Species Act, which Congress is expected to extend soon for three years more, seeks to protect animals and plants whose extinction is feared as a result of human activity. It makes it illegal to capture, kill, transport, buy, sell or possess any species or part of any species deemed endangered. A second category, threatened species, which Alan Levitt, a spokesman for the Fish and Wildlife Service, described as a ''slightly less dire'' category, is almost as fully protected.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Summer Camp, Chinese Style

title: METS AT .500 MARK AFTER LOSING A PAIR
description: The Mets began a grueling series of five games in 44 hours by losing both ends of a doubleheader to the Phillies here tonight and falling to .500 for the first time since May 10.

title: Arab League Plans Parley
description: Arab foreign ministers will hold a special meeting here next Tuesday night to examine the situation in Lebanon and prepare a conference on the question, the Arab League said today. The Palestine Liberation Organization had agreed to take part but Lebanon had not yet said it would, sources in the organization said.

title: CHERVIL: UNSUNG AMONG THE BASILS AND THE THYME
description: Encouraging as it is to have so much emphasis placed on fresh herbs in cooking these days, it is disappointing to note the relatively short shrift given to my own favorite, chervil, surely one of the most refreshing flavors with which to enliven summer cooking. Dill, tarragon, basil, chives, thyme, parsley, rosemary and even the exotic corriander are well represented in markets and in restaurants, but the feathery chervil is rarely in evidence, probably because it wilts as soon as picked.

title: Northrop Sets Delay on F-5G
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it would cut back production plans for its F-5G Tigershark tactical fighter aircraft. It attributed the move to ''delays'' in United States Government commitments.

title: Antidraft Groups Vow Rallies If U.S. Begins Prosecutions
description: Several antidraft organizations have announced that they will sponsor more than 100 demonstrations around the country if the Justice Department begins prosecution of young men who failed to register for a military draft.

title: Sports People; Weaver-Cobb Reset
description: CBS has agreed to purchase the television rights to the second Mike Weaver-Randall (Tex) Cobb World Boxing Association heavyweight title bout, which has been rescheduled for July 25.

title: REAGAN VETOES 2D SPENDING BILL, CALLING IT EXCESSIVE BY $1 BILLION
description: President Reagan, calling for ''deeds, not just promises'' to reduce the Federal deficit, today cast his second veto of an emergency spending bill in two days.

title: A Russian Cleric Joins New York Unity Service
description: Patriarch Pimen of Moscow, head of the Russian Orthodox Church, took part in an ecumenical prayer service in New York yesterday. He is the first Russian Patriarch of Moscow to visit the United States.

title: Teletext Services
description: Plans to introduce national teletext services, in which ''pages'' or screenfuls of information and graphics can be called up on a television screen by viewers equipped with special TV attachments, were announced by CBS Inc. and NBC Inc. CBS said that a 100-page ''magazine'' offering news, sports, finance and other information would be made available to its affiliates as early as this fall, once an inquiry is completed into teletext standards by the Federal Communications Commission. Since April 1981, CBS has been testing a regional teletext service called Extravision in Los Angeles. NBC has been testing a format called Tempo L.A. in Los Angeles and said it planned to start its service early next year.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: ABC Radio Cancels Plan For 24-Hour Music Service

title: Kean and Democrats Agree on Budget Cuts
description: The Democrat-controlled Joint Appropriations Committee and the Republican administration of Governor Kean reached agreement today on $186.5 million in cuts needed to balance the $6.4 billion fiscal 1983 budget.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Campbell Soup Co. of Camden, N.J., announced it had agreed in principle to purchase Juice Bowl Products Inc. of Lakeland, Fla., for undisclosed terms.

title: CAREY'S CLEANUP
description: To the Editor:

title: Otis in Yonkers
description: The Otis Elevator Company, which started here 130 years ago as a family-owned business and at one time employed 1,300 workers, may close its flagship plant, company and city officials said. Speculation about a shutdown of the plant, which has been one of the hard-pressed city's largest manufacturers, came from Mayor Angelo Martinelli after 40 layoffs were announced Thursday.

title: 6-WEEK CLOSING SET AT BETHLEHEM PLANT
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would close its basic steel-making operations at its Lackawanna, N.Y., plant for six weeks, putting 1,650 workers on temporary furlough.

title: FOREIGN CAPITALS HAVE MIXED VIEWS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., whose departure came as a surprise Friday night to government officials, had won considerable respect here for his efforts to seek a peaceful solution to the crisis over the Falkland Islands.

title: RENT RISES OF UP TO 10% SET IN 400,000 STABILIZED UNITS
description: The Rent Guidelines Board yesterday approved basic rent increases for 400,000 rent-stabilized apartments in New York City on new leases in the year beginning Oct. 1. The increases were 4 percent for oneyear leases, 7 percent for two years and 10 percent for three years.

title: FLANAGAN SPOTLIGHTS HIS PIANO
description: Tommy Flanagan, who has spent most of his career out of the spotlight as piano accompanist for Ella Fitzgerald and Tony Bennett, playing in groups in the shadow of such prominent leaders as Miles Davis, Coleman Hawkins, Sonny Rollins and John Coltrane or performing quietly in piano rooms, gave his first major concert Thursday evening at the Merkin Concert Hall. It was a model of what a talented and thoughtful jazz pianist can do.

title: CALIFORNIA RESUMES AERIAL SPRAYING FOR FRUIT FLIES
description: State agricultural officials, responding quickly to the first discovery of a fertile Mediterranean fruit fly in California since November, resumed aerial spraying of pesticide today to prevent the pest from spreading through the San Joaquin Valley.

title: NORTHERN IRELAND WINS WITH 10 MEN
description: Horst Hrubesch scored on a header today to give West Germany a 1-0 victory over Austria in Gijon, and both teams earned berths in the second round of the World Cup.

title:
PATENTS;
Device Promotes Relaxing Brain Waves
description: A device to promote brain wave patterns associated with relaxed and meditative states of mind has been patented for the Omnitronics Research Corporation, Akron, Ohio. John D. Williamson, an electronics engineer, is the inventor named in this week's patent 4,335,710.

title: Players; PEPITONE CALM IN TURMOIL
description: ''W hat do you think, Joe?'' asked John Mayberry, the big first baseman, sitting in the Yankee clubhouse yesterday afternoon. ''We're all going,'' said Joe Pepitone, the batting coach, possibly kidding. ''Not you,'' said Mayberry. ''You're a fixture here.'' ''Sure,'' said Pepitone. They were talking about the latest uproar created by George Steinbrenner, in which the Yankee owner criticized the poor play of the team, and said that everyone's job was in jeopardy. That is, presumably everyone's except the principal owner's.

title: Around the World; Afghan Talks in Geneva Reported to Make Gains
description: Pakistan and Afghanistan have made important political concessions in seven days of talks aimed at bringing peace to Afghanistan, a United Nations special envoy said today.

title: MAYOR TESTIFIES BADEN'S OUSTER WAS NECESSARY
description: Mayor Koch made an unusual court appearance yesterday to defend his dismissal of Dr. Michael M. Baden as the city's Chief Medical Examiner. The Mayor took the stand to assert that the dismissal was based on Dr. Baden's ''inability to work within the system.''

title: Heat Wave Sweeps Italy
description: Hundreds of minor forest fires broke out today as a severe heat wave swept the southern half of Italy, the police said. There were no reports of injuries and no immediate estimates of damages. In Palermo, the Sicilian capital, the temperature soared to a record 109 degrees, setting off an exodus to the seashore, traffic authorities reported.

title: REAGAN NAMES SHULTZ; Reagan and Haig transcripts, page 4.
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. resigned today as Secretary of State. In a letter to President Reagan, he said the Administration's foreign policy had moved away in recent months from the ''careful course'' he and the President had laid out.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Putting the Bite on Crime

title: POLICE ARREST A THIRD SUSPECT IN ATTACK ON TRANSIT WORKERS
description: The police arrested a third suspect yesterday in the assault on three black transit workers - one of whom was beaten to death - by a group of white youths in Brooklyn on Tuesday.

title: A Little Lift, at Least, for Housing
description: Federal housing subsidies have been cut to the bone and beyond. But a genuine need for low-rent housing in New York continues. The state and city years ago established three agencies that could help meet that need - but only if state laws are changed to accommodate the agencies to what's left of Federal housing assistance.

title: Bridge: It Might Be a Bit Difficult To Follow These Results
description: If there were a national team championship in which each squad had to be composed of players with the same last name, the result would be a foregone conclusion.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON TESTS FOR FUTURE SCHOOL PRINCIPALS
description: A settlement that requires new licensing examinations for applicants for jobs as school principals was reached yesterday in a 10-month-old lawsuit brought by Frank J. Macchiarola, the New York City Schools Chancellor. His suit charged that the present examination was biased against black and Hispanic applicants.

title: Bedtime For Midas
description: When I was poor I used to sit on tenement steps on steamy summer nights and envy the rich who went to the mountains or the seashore. How little I knew.

title: GILDER LEADS BY 3 WITH 63-127
description: Bob Gilder complacently thought he had the field ''intimidated'' and ready to ''crumble'' today, but Peter Jacobsen was not cowed, nor was Tom Kite.

title: Your Money; Sidestepping Estate Taxes
description: THE concept of the marital deduction in estate taxation, whereby one spouse may make a tax-free bequest to the other, was introduced in the United States through the Revenue Act of 1948. But, with the passage of the Economic Recovery Tax Act last year, a radical change in this concept was authorized in the form of an unlimited marital deduction that began at the beginning of 1982.

title: Braniff Avoids Eviction
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today denied a request by the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport to evict the Braniff International Corporation, which is in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Suspect Is Seized In Officer's Holdup
description: A 25-year-old Manhattan man has been arrested and charged in the shooting and attempted robbery of an unarmed probationary police officer on June 1 after he left a check-cashing agency in East Harlem.

title: ISRAEL PLANS HALT TO TV BROADCASTS
description: A senior Israeli official said tonight that Israel intended to bar the transmission over its broadcasting facilities of television material for American networks gathered by their correspondents based in Beirut.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's efforts to prevent foreign companies from helping to construct a natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe - a policy decision that apparently played a role in the decision of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to resign - may rest on shaky legal ground.

title: Scouting; Unpassable You
description: The woman walked off the grass court at the All England Club redfaced and grumbling.

title: SHOCK, SADNESS AND PUZZLEMENT GREET HAIG MOVE
description: By 3:30 this afternoon, they had gathered, whispering in small groups in the hallways and in front of television sets in offices. Almost all had a theory about their former chief, Alexander M. Haig Jr., as well as their new one, George P. Shultz.

title: IN CAIRO, ANGUISH AMONG PALESTINIANS
description: ''It will be like a disease,'' said Haj Massoud Abdelmagid, a Palestinian merchant. He said the guerrillas ''will become more violent, and they will go all around the world.''

title: Data General Plans a Shutdown
description: The Data General Corporation announced that it would close all seven of its United States plants for nine days in July to trim increased inventories caused by falling sales.

title: Ellen L. Clark Married To Fowler McC. Brown
description: Ellen Lianne Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Bruce Clark of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., was married yesterday to Fowler McCormick Stillman Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Brown of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Tally H. Jarrett, rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Del Mar, Calif., performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Chapel of the Bishop's Schools in La Jolla, Calif.

title: OUST MEDICAL EXAMINER, ESSEX PROSECUTOR URGES
description: The Essex County Prosecutor urged today that the County Medical Examiner, Dr. Thomas A. Santoro, be ousted because ineptness in determining the cause of death of victims in criminal cases was jeopardizing the prosecution of the cases.

title: SOVIET-EUROPE GAS PACT SPLIT U.S. AIDES
description: A proposed 3,700-mile natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe has been the subject of fierce arguments between factions in the Reagan Administration for the past year and might have figured in the resignation today of Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECHES BY POTENTIAL CANDIDATES AT DEMOCRATIC CONFERENCE
description: Following are excerpts from the texts of speeches by five possible Democratic aspirants for the Presidency in 1984, given today at the opening session of the Democratic National Party conference: Senator Alan Cranston

title: SAMUELS IS NAMED TO HEAD N.A.S.L.
description: Howard J. Samuels, a New Yorker who has been successful in business and as a public official, has taken on a new challenge - as president and chief executive officer of the North American Soccer League.

title: U.S. TREASURY DIDN'T LOSE IN THE DRYSDALE CASE
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELIS HIT BEIRUT AND DRIVE SYRIANS FROM KEY HIGHWAY
description: Israeli fighter-bombers, warships and artillery unleashed a nonstop barrage today against Palestinian camps and residential areas of western Beirut, the heaviest since the invasion of Lebanon began on June 6.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Avoiding the Obvious

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Sports People; Suns Talk to Cowens
description: The Phoenix Suns have begun talks with Dave Cowens, who is considering an end to his two-year retirement from basketball but who by all accounts wants to play in the West instead of returning to the Boston Celtics. Coach John MacLeod and General Manager Jerry Colangelo met with Cowens Thursday night in Salt Lake City, where the 33-year-old former star center had arrived for a river-rafting trip.

title: Sports of the Times; THE DREAM JOB
description: O f all the dreams of youth, there is no sweeter one than this: a job as bat boy for the New York Yankees - even at less than the minimum wage.

title: News Analysis
description: The Texas prison system has got such abysmal reviews in Federal courts for the last decade that this week state officials hailed a decidedly mixed ruling as a victory.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Excerpts from the speeches, page 11.
description: Democrats, all but tasting victory in November, denounced the Reagan Administration today as unfair to the poor, insensitive to the risk of nuclear war and unconcerned about women's rights.

title: Bolivian Convicted In Drug Smuggling
description: A civil engineer from Bolivia was found guilty last night of cocaine-smuggling charges by a Federal Court jury in Brooklyn that deliberated 20 minutes.

title: A PLAYGROUND MOB, A KILLING AND A NEIGHBORHOOD ASKS WHY
description: It was just after midnight on May 3 of last year. Roscoe Fountain had finished his 4 P.M.-to-midnight tour as a Housing Authority policeman at the Coney Island projects in Brooklyn.

title: Sports People; Ralston Eyes U.S.F.L.
description: John Ralston, who coached the Denver Broncos in the National Football League for five seasons ending in 1976, will coach in the new United States Football League league next year, most likely at San Francisco. ''Chances are I'll wind up in San Francisco,'' Ralston told The Denver Post on Thursday. ''The man who originally had the San Francisco team is now working with Los Angeles.''

title: EX-SAINT IS INDICTED AGAIN IN DRUG CASE
description: Mike Strachan, a former running back for the Saints, was indicted a second time yesterday by a Federal grand jury in New Orleans that is investigating cocaine trafficking.

title: ENDANGERED BREEDS CURBING THE MARKET
description: The shipment of women's shoes had arrived at Kennedy International Airport on a flight from Italy and was bound for a store in the Forest Hills section of Queens. Customs Service inspectors, noting that the shoes were made partly of a scale-patterned skin, referred them for further examination to agents of the Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service. The agents found that the scaled skin was from a species of sea turtle listed as endangered under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 and that importation of the shoes - like the importation of any product made from animals on the endangered list - was prohibited.
To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS STRIVE FOR ACCORD AT CONVENTION IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Suppressing their instinctive urge to fight among themselves, the Democrats are trying hard to present a united front on the issues at their national party conference.

title: EXPANSION OF MORNING NEWS FORCES 'KANGAROO' TO WEEKENDS
description: Beginning Oct. 4, CBS-TV will move up its early morning newscast one hour earlier, to 6 A.M. The program will link up with the ''Nightwatch'' newscast from 2 A.M. to 6, creating the longest continuous network television news service - seven hours.

title: Georgia Civil Rights Activist Sent to Jail in a Traffic Case
description: A Superior Court judge today ordered State Representative Hosea Williams, the civil rights activist, to begin serving a one-year prison sentence on a year-old driving conviction.

title: Savin Planning Operations Shift
description: The Savin Corporation, a developer and marketer of office copying machines, announced plans to phase out its word processing and data processing operations, and to focus ''aggressively'' on the copier and copier duplicator field instead. No details of the withdrawal from the word processing market were disclosed, but Savin reported that it was testing prototypes of a new line of ''60 copy per minute machines.''

title: Around the Nation; Reagan Acts to Save Meharry Medical College
description: President Reagan approved $55.6 million in aid today for Meharry Medical College in an effort to prevent the historic black institution in Nashville, Tenn., from losing its accreditation.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Frankfurter Explored By DAVID MARGOLICK FELIX FRANKFURTER AND HIS TIMES. The Reform Years. By Michael E. Parrish. Illustrated (with photo- graphs). 330 Pages. Free Press. $17.95.

title: Dow Declines 7.33 As Trading Slows; Haig Move Speeds Drop
description: The stock market declined moderately yesterday, with about half of the losses occurring following the unexpected news of the resignation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: GREEK COMMUNISTS ASSAIL SOCIALISTS
description: Greece's governing Socialist Party and the pro-Moscow Greek Communist Party, which once followed similar anti-Western foreign policies, have split as a result of the Government's adoption of a more cooperative attitude toward the West and of moderate domestic policies.

title: Tammis A. McMillan Wed
description: Tammis Archambo McMillan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard I. McMillan Jr. of Wayzata, Minn., was married yesterday to Gary Richard Vibbard, son of Earl Richard Vibbard of Endwell, N.Y., and Virginia Monroe Vibbard of Syracuse. The Rev. Edwin Eilertsen performed the ceremony at St. Martin's by-the-Lake Episcopal Church in Minnetonka Beach, Minn. The bride is a merchandiser with the Garnac Grain Company Inc., in New York, where Mr. Vibbard is a vice president of Heafitz, Widmann, McMahon & Gardner Ltd., an investment banking firm.

title: FOSTERING NEW AMERICAN COMPOSITIONS
description: Though most audiences seem satisfied with the activities of major American orchestras, critics and composers perennially raise a series of complaints: American orchestras perform too little new music, American orchestras perform too little American music, and American orchestras have become purely curatorial organizations.

title: COMMANDED FORCE IN EUROPE
description: Maj. Gen. Frank O'Driscoll Hunter, a World War I flying ace and commanding general of the unit that provided crucial air protection for Allied troops in World War II, died Friday at St. Joseph Hospital in his hometown, Savannah, Ga.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 15 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 2 7 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) During a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past. 3 3 4 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 4 4 9 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 5 6 3 EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romance and political upheaval on a Caribbean island. 6 5 21 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 7 10 6 FOR SPECIAL SERVICES, by John Gardner. (Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, $9.95.)

title: A 'QUICK TRIP HOME' BY CAR
description: I read with interest and understanding Richard F. Shepard's ''About Long Island'' on his wife's reluctance to drive into Manhattan. As the director of a program for aviaphobics, and a Long Island lecturer, I have met many, many Long Island men and women who don't drive on the Long Island Expressway or the Northern State Parkway, and countless others who take the Long Island Rail Road into Manhattan, rather than drive.

title: Elusive Formula In Redistricting
description: In deciding how to protect minority voting rights without unfairly enhancing them, the Justice Department has sometimes created problems as it solved others. Last week, in rejecting the New York State Legislature's plan to reapportion Congressional, State Senate and Assembly districts, the department again found itself in such a fix.

title: WOUNDED BOY, 12, TELLS HOW P.L.O. DRAFTED HIM
description: About six weeks ago, men from the Palestine Liberation Organization entered a school's classroom in a Palestinian refugee camp near Damascus and selected five of the brightest, ablest 12- and 13-year-old boys for a ''trip'' to Lebanon. One of them was a thin, smooth-faced lad named Burhan Ahmed el-Tayef, 12.

title: ISRAELI JETS STRIKE AT SYRIAN MISSILES
description: Israeli warplanes destroyed Syrian SAM-6 missiles today as they were being installed in east Lebanon's Bekaa Valley, the Israeli military command said.

title: Other Business; THE LAGGING SCHOOL SPIRIT BUSINESS
description: Her 10-karat gold school ring may not be ''a perfect ring with a diamond,'' says Nancy Cawley of Rochester, Minn., ''but it says I went to John Marshall High School and I'm proud of it.''

title: 'LAUGHING ON THE OUTSIDE' IN CHAPPAQUA
description: CHAPPAQUA CAN Alec, a 42-year-old architect, find happiness with a 22-yearold punkette? Will his wife, who has thrown him out after 17 years of ''being stuck in a suburban sitcom,'' find fulfillment and have him back? Should he get rid of Gorman, his Charley McCarthy-like dummy - the intermediary between Alec and his life ever since he was 9? Will Alec ever grow up?

title: RECENT ALBUMS CHAMPION THE OPERAS OF BERLIOZ
description: As far as modern opera houses are concerned, Hector Berlioz is almost a forgotten man. ''Les Troyens'' receives an occasional grand revival - it will open the Metropolitan's centenary season -but it is really too grand for everyday usage. The others are dramatically unwieldy, and the dramatic-symphonic frescoes are more often heard from symphony orchestras; indeed, Berlioz originally wanted to call ''La Damnation de Faust'' an ''opera de concert.''

title: Further Views On Evacuation Plan
description: In response to the recent article ''Evacuation Plan Stirs Old Doubts'': Lilco's recent action in asking state officials to accept an evacuation plan for Shoreham that Suffolk County officials now call seriously flawed stirs more than the old doubts as to whether such a plan will actually work. What angers many people is the way in which the company went about it.

title: Zurich and Burton Take Bowling Doubles Event
description: Sam Zurich and Nelson Burton Jr., defeated Jim Winklepleck and Dave Husted, 227-200, today and captured the final game of the $110,000 Professional Bowlers Association Doubles Classic.

title: AFRICAN WINS AND LOSSES
description: THE CONGO CABLES The Cold War in Africa - From Eisenhower to Kennedy. By Madeleine G. Kalb. 466 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $19.95. FROM THE CONGO TO SOWETO U.S. Foreign Policy Toward Africa Since 1960. By Henry F. Jackson. 324 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $13.95.

title: POLICE UNIONIST ACCUSES A DENTIST OF BRIBERY
description: The head of the city police union has accused a dentist who manages a health services company of trying to bribe him to obtain a lucrative contract.

title: Reagan News Session Planned for Midweek
description: President Reagan will hold his first news conference in more than a month in midweek, aides said today. Mr. Reagan announced the news conference late Friday in his surprise statement on the resignation of Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Covering Wimbledon Just as there are various approaches to playing the game of tennis, so too there are different ways in which championship games can be covered for the home screen. For instance, Ted Nathanson points out noticeable stylistic differences in the way the American networks cover the century-old All-England Tennis Championships at Wimbledon and the way the British Broadcasting Corporation and foreign networks in general do it. Mr. Nathanson will be directing NBC's $1-million coverage of this year's matches, 15 3/4 hours of which will be seen both recorded and live throughout this week.

title: THe Pyrenees Loom Large
description: The Falkland war and fragile domestic politics have further complicated post-Franco Spain's slow integration into the rest of Europe. Last week in Madrid, it was hard to tell that Spain had just become NATO's 16th member and was scheduled to join the European Common Market in 1984.

title: DELIGHTS OF JAPANESE CUISINE
description: THE delight of dining Japanese style on the Island continues to increase with the latest addition, Umai in Merrick. This attractive restaurant is built on three levels, with the areas divided by the same light wood as the booths, tables and chairs. Construction was recently completed on the open sushi bar, which is presided over by an experienced chef who was previously sequestered in the kitchen.

title: Fashion; THE RISING PRESTIGE OF TOKYO
description: First it was the camera. Then there were calculators and cars. Now Japan is focusing its design talent and expansionist attitude on clothes, and as a result Tokyo is fast becoming a new international fashion center. ''We find Japan very exciting, the way Europe was eight years ago,'' says Gene Pressman, a vice president of Barney's, which is promoting Japanese clothes for both men and women.

title: Cape Cod
description: To the Editor: Susan Daar, in her article ''What's Doing on Cape Cod'' (Travel, June 13) quotes a round-trip air fare of $142 minimum from New York City to Hyannis. However, by routing our clients via Boston, using Delta's round-trip fare of $54, and then utilizing Provincetown-Boston Airline's round-trip excursion fare of $61, the only restriction being a seven-day advance purchase, we can ticket the entire trip for $115. v. ho says travel agents are out to ''get'' the public? THOMAS C. RIZZO JR. Travel Associates, Inc. New York

title: A STUBBORN CHAMBER OF COMMERCE ROILS THE WATERS
description: WASHINGTON IT is the largest business lobbying group in business-minded America. Secure in its stately headquarters on Lafayette Park, directly opposite the White House, the United States Chamber of Commerce seems impregnable in its new-found power and influence. At a hint from the Chamber, its membership of 250,000 companies, up from 100,000 only a year and a half ago, can deluge Capitol Hill with thousands of letters and tie up the phones in legislators' offices for hours. A word from 1615 H Street on a Congressional race, and a candidate can reportedly wake up with $100,000 in his or her campaign chest.

title: SECRETARY'S SPLIT WITH PRESIDENT LONG IN MAKING
description: A working lunch of the National Security Council had just adjourned in the Cabinet Room of the White House early Friday afternoon when President Reagan said to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., ''Al, may I see you for a moment?''

title: Melinda M. Moore Is Bride of Steven A. Wellvang
description: Melinda Marie Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Moore of Shawnee Mission, Kan., was married yesterday to Steven Allan Wellvang, son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Wellvang of Rochester, Minn. The Rev. Dr. George Cory performed the ceremony at the Country Club Congregational Church in Kansas City, Mo.

title: THE MAKING OF A DOCTOR
description: I am a 1964 graduate of the New York University School of Medicine, and David Black's article brought back memories to me of my own medical-school days.

title: Miss Haynie Leads By a Shot on 69-209
description: Sandra Haynie shot a three-underpar 69 today to overtake JoAnne Carner and move into the lead after three rounds of the $200,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association Rochester International.

title: SENSIBLE POLICY TOWARD MOSCOW
description: After President Reagan's speeches before the United Nations and the British Parliament, in which he attacked the legitimacy of the Soviet regime and called for a global campaign to undermine it, a prominent television commentator observed that the President's rhetoric toward the Soviet Union was harsher than his actions. This indulgent judgment obscures the fact that the rhetoric is not cost-free to America and that the Administration's conflicting actions toward the Soviet Union reflect a confusion of purposes.

title: RISING TRADE BARRIERS STIR MEMORIES OF US DEPRESSSION
description: A surge of aggressive economic nationalism, as strong as any in the last half century, threatens to overwhelm the freetrade policies that have underwritten the postwar prosperity of industrialized nations.

title: Ill Wind; For Urban Aid
description: When it comes to urban policy, Cabinet-level drafts don't necessarily indicate which way the wind is blowing in the White House, President Reagan said last week. The explanation was offered to big-city mayors concerned that the Administration would officially adopt the view that Federal aid to cities contributed more to local problems than to their solutions.

title: AMERICAN AND RUSSIAN SHARE PRIZE IN MATHEMATICS
description: An American scientist and a Russian have been named the first winners of an international prize in mathematics that is administered, like the Nobel Prizes in physics and chemistry, by Sweden's Royal Academy.

title: CHANGING VIEWS OF FATHERHOOD
description: WHEN Vinnie Parisi took a six-month unpaid paternity leave from New Jersey Bell last year, he became one of America's most famous fathers.

title: Rome Group Admits Murder
description: Members of an Italian right-wing group claimed responsibility today for the fatal shooting Thursday of a Rome policeman who was guarding the home of Nimer Hammad, a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The group, the Armed Revolutionary Nuclei, told the Italian news agency that the attack was not aimed at Mr. Hammad, but was in retaliation for the death of a rightist killed in Rome in a police shootout two months ago.

title: VERSAILLES JOURNAL
description: LEONARD SILK is the economics columnist of The New York Times. BY LEONARD SILK

title:
DINING OUT;
FROM TANK AND ICE, SWIMMINGLY
description: SINCE its opening almost three years ago, The Fisherman's Catch in Elmsford's Town Hall Shopping Center has made commendable changes. Last January, it added a fish shop through which one passes - lobster tank on the left, bins of shaved ice on the right - to enter the homey dining room in back. Fish shop paired with fish restaurant affords advantages for both shopper and diner: fish is either cooked or sold while it is still fresh. But when it comes to eating fish, freshness, it seems, is not enough. Equally vital for the success of any seafood dish is perfect juiciness, and we were pleased to find on recent visits to Fisherman's Catch not one piece of overcooked fish.

title: Liza Wick Wed to C. H. Rice
description: Carlotta Elizabeth Wick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Robert Wick of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Hawkinson Rice, son of Margery Hawkinson Rice of New York and Edward Rice Jr. of Sagaponack, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Charles Edward Berger performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: THE MAKING OF A DOCTOR
description: The extreme difficulty in gaining entrance to medical school and the subsequent rigor of learning to adapt to the training contribute to a natural-selection process which, unfortunately, favors the more conservative college graduates today. The training process, which imposes immense social and financial hardships, certainly does not help to broaden one's humanistic perspective. In fact, working in large municipal hospitals such as Bellevue more often than not breeds contempt on the part of the student physician for the very people these hospitals are designed to treat. RUSSELL H. REIFF, M.D.

title: SOUTH AFRICA CURBS THE PRESS OVER DETAINEES
description: The police made public the names today of three journalists detained for interrogation under the security laws. The action came after newspapers had been prevented for two days from identifying the imprisoned men.

title: THE MAKING OF A DOCTOR
description: With three years of experience on the Bellevue Hospital wards, I can state without reservation that a more dedicated group of young physicians and nurses cannot be found anywhere. The observed antagonism between the nursing staff and medical students, and occasionally house staff, is much less a function of some inherent power struggle than it is a result of chronic understaffing, low salaries and poorly supplied wards. The nurses at Bellevue do an excellent job given these relentless, daily obstacles. JONATHAN M. KOLODNY, M.D. Senior Resident in Medicine Bellevue Hospital

title: Residential Downsizing
description: His corporate namesake learned a while back that big cars don't sell.

title: AMERICAN UNIVERSITY OF BEIRUT IS REPORTED SHELLED
description: A trustee of the American University of Beirut said he had been told that five Israeli naval artillery shells scored ''direct hits'' on the campuses of the university and two constituent schools on Friday.

title: DRUMMERS LEAD WELL-ROUNDED BILLS
description: Jazz groups led or dominated by famous drummers used to tend to get by on percussive flash and muscle. But at the Jazz Festival on Friday, bands led by three drummers - Max Roach, Andrew Cyrille and Sunny Murray -and an all-star group that featured the drummer Elvin Jones confounded any expectations that were based on this particular jazz cliche. All these groups played well-rounded programs. There were drum solos, but for the most part they were concise as well as inventive.

title: LEADERS PLAN SPEEDY SESSION
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly will begin another special session tomorrow in a rare bipartisan mood to deal quickly with flood relief and a few other matters and adjourn before election-year politics can intrude.

title: Diane E. Silien Is Wed To Larry D. Fordyce
description: Diane Ellen Silien, director of product development, fragance, with Revlon Products Inc., in New York, was married yesterday to Larry David Fordyce, founder and president of the L.D. Fordyce Company, general contractors in New York. The Rev. James Gardner, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the Rooke Chapel at Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pa.

title: N.A.A.C.P. CONVENTION TO FOCUS ON POLITICAL ISSUES
description: Increasing political action among blacks will be a major concern at the 73d annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which begins here Sunday.

title: IN THE HEART OF NEWARK, THE SKIRLS CUT THROUGH TIME
description: NEWARK CONTRARY to popular belief, there is life after dark in downtown Newark, and it is punctuated by a sound that seems to be a wailing out of the infancy of mankind.

title: TEACHER TURNOVER IS GREAT
description: ''AGE,'' says Ann Marie Winters of East Brunswick, who has been a teacher for 20 years, ''is not a handicap. It is a tool. Some teachers without experience can use that as a means of relating better to pupils.''

title: Reclusive Wealth
description: Simon Goldstein, a postal worker, lived frugally and reclusively in a municipal project in Brooklyn. When he died Dec. 29, 1980, at the age of 79, the police found bundles of cash, unopened pay envelopes dating to 1940 and 22 bankbooks.

title: TWO LIVES CAUGHT IN HISTORY
description: THE CORRESPONDENCE OF BORIS PASTERNAK AND OLGA FREIDENBERG 1910-1954. Compiled and Edited, With an Introduction, by Elliott Mossman. Translated by Elliott Mossman and Margaret Wettlin. Illustrated. 365 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: CITY BALLET, STRAVINSKY, SIN AND REDEMPTON
description: Love and death were the overriding themes of the New York City Ballet's Tchaikovsky Festival last year. For this month's Stravinsky Centennial Celebration, George Balanchine conceived a thematic framework of sin and redemption. This was by no means the ''subject'' of all the ballets on view. And most of the ballets on view were, in fact, a reprise from the jollier 1972 Stravinsky Festival Mr. Balanchine organized in tribute to the composer, who had died the year before. This time, to mark the anniversary of Igor Stravinsky's birth, the company also presented 12 works of various types it had not done before. Some were world premieres, albeit three to five minutes long; some were longer ballets; one was the New York premiere of an earlier pas de deux by Lew Christensen created for his own San Francisco Ballet. A few were choral works, presented as cantatas or theater pieces.

title: AN EX-TEAMMATE AND A WORLD OF SPECULATION
description: NOW, 14 years later, it is a different season and a different city, but again Junior Kennedy and I are drawn together and the circle of history is complete.

title: PUTTING EYES TO AN EARLY TEST
description: MANHASSET ALTHOUGH 2 1/2-year-old Joel Shapiro is too young to read an eye chart, doctors already know that the vision in his right eye is much worse than in his left. However, because the problem was detected so early, there is a good chance that by school age his sight will improve and become similar in both eyes.

title: TONOPAH-SURVIVOR OF MINING DAYS
description: HERBERT GOLD, a San Franciscan, is the author most recently of the novel ''Family.'' By HERBERT GOLD

title: ON THE BEACH: A ROUNDUP
description: ANNA QUINDLEN writes the About New York column for The Times. BY ANNA QUINDLEN

title: Hollace Brown, Film Aide, Is Wed to Lewis Wallensky
description: Hollace Ann Brown, a vice president of Paramount Pictures, was married yesterday to Lewis Wallensky, who heads his own financial planning company in Los Angeles. Rabbi Bernard Cohen performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Hollywood Hills, Calif.

title: SCHOOL SYSTEMS ARE EVERYBODY'S RESPONSIBILITY
description: ''IS THIS the name I saw in the newspaper last night?'' The bank teller had a reassuring smile as she tapped her pencil alongside my name on the deposit slip.

title: Q and A; Mobile Homeowner Rights
description: Question: I own a mobile home and live in a trailer park, where I pay rent for the space that my home occupies. Where can I go to learn of the rules I have to abide by and my rights as a mobile homeowner? ... R.D., Danbury, Conn. Answer: For a copy of the state laws governing mobile homes, contact the Connecticut State Real Estate Commission (165 Capitol Avenue, Hartford, Conn. 06115; telephone (203) 566-5132).

title: MRS. KING GAINS THE ROUND OF 16
description: For Billie Jean King, every match at Wimbledon is an adventure these days. Last Thursday, the 38-year-old Mrs. King played her 100th singles match at the All England Club. No other tennis player is close to equaling that record.

title:
Economic Affairs;
A VICIOUS CYCLE OF HIGH RATES
description: term interest rates to have c ontinued so high for so long. Interest rates have tended to fall in p revious recessions, as business demand for working capital eased. W hat is different about this recession? One important but l ittlediscussed explanation is that the demand for short-term loans m ay be unusually high this time around because of the extraordinarilyh igh interest rates that preceded the recession.

title: RETURNING RELUCTANTLY, ARRIVING TRIUMPHANTLY
description: PLANES whining overhead, trucks growling on either side of my traffic lane, night lights glaring as far as the horizon, polluted air stenching my nasal passages all told me that I was back on Long Island.

title: Other Business; A BEVY OF DEELY BOBBERS
description: They've been dubbed ''Deely Bobbers'' although most people don't know what to call them. But one thing is clear: They seem to be the most popular headgear since the Sony Walkman.

title: YANKS WIN IN 17TH
description: The Yankees, who complained last month when a practice was called on a day off, were forced to work overtime last night for the second straight Saturday night.

title: 'Decision of Principle,'' Ex-Reagan Aide Says
description: Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's former national security adviser, said here today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s resignation was a ''decision motivated by conscience and principle and I think he has to be respected for that.''

title: COMING OUT OF COMA
description: On the afternoon of Dec. 13, 1979, Sgt. David Mack and eight other members of the Minneapolis Police Department smashed through the door of a rented house in search of stolen property. When the man inside started shooting, Mack was struck in the abdomen and the neck; he stopped breathing, lapsing into a coma. ''Sergeant Mack will never regain cognitive, sapient functioning,'' said Dr. Ronald E. Cranford, an associate professor of neurology at the University of Minnesota Medical School, six months later. ''He will never be aware of his condition nor resume any degree of meaningful voluntary conscious interaction with his family or friends.''

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A Return South ''This,'' said Dick Fontaine, one of the producers of ''I Heard It Through the Grapevine,'' ''is not an attempt to survey the results or the lack of results of the civil rights movement; it's James Baldwin's personal journey, a personal essay on film.'' The film essay, which had a brief commercial release here in March at the Film Forum, will be broadcast on Channel 13 Wednesday, from 9 to 10:30 P.M. Baldwin, the writer, left Paris in 1957 and in the late 50's and early 60's traveled through parts of the South, meeting and talking to participants in the freedom movement.

title: A SAMPLING OF SEASHORES
description: Although the sun may shine on the just and the unjust alike, it seems to shine to better effect on some places, like Hawaii, unjust as that may be. California has more than 1,000 miles of coastline, much of it gone to beach. Florida has 1,800 miles, more shoreline than any state except Alaska, which is not anybody's first choice for sunbathing. (Neither is Canada, but it's not as outlandish a choice as it might seem.) Mexico's beaches lie on three coasts and Delmarva's take in three states. The beaches of France and Germany are as different as - well, France and Germany. Italy has more beaches than pasta. Following is a sampling of beaches, based on reports from bureaus of The New York Times. Hawaii Not very far from the madding crowd

title: RUTGERS TO CELEBRATE ITS DUTCH HERITAGE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE arrival tomorrow morning of Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands will set off a day-long series of ceremonies and festivities proclaiming her country's long and flourishing ties to Rutgers University and the New Brunswick Theological Seminary.

title: Rabbi Shneur Kotler, 64, Head Of Rabbinical School in Jersey
description: Rabbi Shneur Kotler, dean of Beth Medrash Govoha, a postgraduate rabbinical school in Lakewood, N.J., died Thursday at Massachusetts General Hospital, in Boston.

title: SUBJECTIVE ANTHROPOLOGY
description: SHABONO By Florinda Donner. 301 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $14.95. By COLIN TURNBULL

title: THE FRIDAY CLUB, A CHEEVER SALON
description: winning author who died at his home in Ossining on June 18, organized a club 16 years ago that he once described as "about as private as a telephone booth." His fellow members recalled it last week as a modest but scintillating salon.

title: DANCE: INTERPRETATIONS
description: Good dances lend themselves to a variety of interpretations. On Thursday at the City Center, two members of the Martha Graham Dance Company brought new illumination to Miss Graham's ''Cave of the Heart.''

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JUNE 27, 1982
description: Haig's Resignation George P. Shultz, Secretary of State-designate, and President Reagan met at Camp David. After the meeting Mr. Shultz said that he saw his new role as an opportunity ''to advance the causes of peace, freedom and justice in a world so troubled and so anxious to hope for a good future.'' He told reporters that he was ''truly surprised'' by the sudden resignation of Alexander M. Haig Jr. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: News Analysis
description: George P. Shultz, President Reagan's nominee for Secretary of State, will face an unusually large number of international crises as well as continuing institutional tensions between the White House and the State Department.

title: Miss Geisler Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Lauren Geisler, an associate with the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, to Mark Vicars Donovan, a senior editor with People magazine, took place in Sands Point, L.I., yesterday. The Rev. Allen Wells, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's father, Hedley Donovan of New York and Sands Point.
To the Editor:

title: N.B.A. DRAFT: AFTER SCRUTINY AND SPECULATION, TIME TO PICK
description: THE scrutiny of college basketball talent for this year's draft began last Nov. 21 at the Tip-Off game at Springfield, Mass., the first college game of the season. Dick McGuire, the Knicks' chief scout, and scouts from many other National Basketball Association teams were there to watch Ralph Sampson as his Virginia team defeated Brigham Young, 63-61.

title: EXCERPTS OF RESOLUTION ON THE STRIFE IN LEBANON
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a draft Security Council resolution on the Lebanese situation that was vetoed early today by the United States, and from the text of a resolution that was approved by the General Assembly by a vote of 127 to 2:

title: Arms Negotiator Sees No Change in Position
description: Edward L. Rowny, head of the United States delegation to the strategic arms talks that are to open here on Tuesday, said today that the resignation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. should have no impact on the negotiations.

title: ON BOSPORUS, OLD AND NEW ARE MINGLING
description: ''Too short are our lives to love this enchanting spot,'' Yahia Kemal, the Turkish poet, wrote of the Bosporus early in this century.

title: A Student's Opinion Of School Computers
description: I am 13 years old and a school computer user. I read the recent article ''How the Computer Fails the Course'' by Samuel J. Gulino (Opinion Page).

title: Donovan Leaps to His Own Defense
description: While the President is ostensibly standing by his Secretary of Labor, it was reported last week that Mr. Reagan's closest advisers had concluded that Mr. Donovan - accused of, among other things, having witnessed the payment of a bribe to a union official in 1977 - should either resign or step aside until the special prosecutor looking into his affairs, Leon Silverman, has completed his report. Though the precariousness of Mr. Donovan's position was such that officials were reportedly considering the names of several potential replacements, his fate is not likely to be decided until Mr. Silverman's inquiry is completed.

title: LIFE ALONG THE WATERFRONT
description: OWNING waterfront property can be a delight, a headache or a matter o f some dispute. Unless it leaks or floods or is ransacked by b urglars in a boat, waterfront property can be a good investment -onet hat appreciates faster, brokers say, than inland acreage.

title: Business Conditions; DEFENSE BUDGET WOES
description: As Congress contemplates large reductions in military spending as one way to trim future budget deficits, it may already be too late to make anything but minor cuts in military expenditures. The momentum begun last year, when the initial Reagan budget was passed, may already preclude anything of great magnitude.

title: The Toy, Coy Convention
description: The Democrats' mid-term conference in Philadelphia looks like a toy convention, a coy trade show. The hall is a third the standard size. The boisterous demonstrations that, in election years, run 30 minutes are held punctiliously to 60 seconds. The declarations of party policy are bland expressions of consensual virtue.

title: Inmates Fight Over Boxing
description: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuter). June 26 - Two hundred prisoners fought at Pleasanton prison in northern California in a dispute over the world heavyweight championship fight between Larry Holmes and Gerry Cooney, prison officials said today. The prisoners were watching a television rerun of the fight, won by Mr. Holmes, the World Boxing Council champion, when the fighting broke out Friday night.

title: GETTING SUMMERFARE FESTIVAL UNDER WAY
description: GETTING one's international act together can be a problem, even for as smooth an operation as the monthlong Pepsico Summerfare Festival, which opens July 10 at the Performing Arts Center of the State University of New York. For the first time in its three-year history, there will be several important foreign companies involved.

title: FROM BROOKS BROTHERS TO BROADWAY?
description: Bought two shirts on Thursday night One was blue and one was white They arrived at home today One was pink the other gray. Oh the service, The customer service The service isn't what it used to be.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Every year for the past 18, the Associated American Artists Gallery (663 Fifth Avenue at 52d Street) has sponsored a ''New Talent in Printmaking'' exhibition, flushing out artists not overly exposed in New York on the basis of technical proficiency, originality of expression, and future promise. Fair enough grounds on which to base a show, and this year six artists have risen to the challenge.

title: THE MAKING OF A DOCTOR
description: I was moved by David Black's articles. Having just completed the first year of a medical residency, I would like to add my thoughts.

title: NEW GOALS ON AGING OFFERED
description: EWING TOWNSHIP THE recently released official report on the White House Conference on Aging says that America's elderly are ''the wealthiest, best-fed, best-housed, healthiest (and) most self-reliant older population in our history.''

title: THE BEAUTEOUS, ELONGATED GLOSSY PURPLE 'EGG'
description: EGGPLANT is one of our most beautiful foods, with its shiny purple skin and dark-green leaves clustered at the husk. It is a favorite Mediterranean and Middle Eastern dish - Arabs say they know a thousand ways to prepare it. There are many shapes and colors, although the most common in our markets is the egg-shaped, deep purple variety measuring around six to eight inches long. But the small ones are even better, especially those slender eggplants with paler thinner skins usually sold in Oriental or Indian markets. I have even come across an ivory-skinned kind that was the sweetest I have ever tasted.

title: CORPORATIONS STEP INTO ROAD RUNNING
description: ELMSFORD SOMETHING new is being added to the county's road-running scene - this time on a corporate level. On Tuesday night the first of four, three-mile corporate run-offs will be held in this community's industrial Executive Park. The other three runs are scheduled for later in the summer.

title: Paris Cafes
description: To the Editor: It was with deep consternation, sadness and pain that I read over Patricia Wells's list of favorite Parisian sidewalk cafes ''Where to Sit, To See and to Be Seen'' (Travel, June 6). How could she leave out the Danton on the carrefour de l'Odeon and the neighboring Monaco on rue Monsieur le Prince, where so much of my youth was so happily misspent?

title: IMMIGRANT SLAPSTICK
description: PANNA MARIA By Jerome Charyn. 447 pp. New York: Arbor House. Cloth, $17.50. Priam Books. Paper, $9.50. By RICHARD P.BRICKNER

title: DEMAND HIGH FOR COURSES ON PERSONAL SAFETY
description: SOUTH NORWALK SHORTLY after 9 P.M. one recent moonlit night, Detective Richard T. Rilling of the Norwalk Police Department, in full uniform complete with officer's cap, a gleaming medallion on his chest and a handgun protruding from a holster at the hip, pulled his car into the parking lot at Ischoda Yacht Club on Water Street.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Indians, at Yankee Stadium, 161st Street and River Avenue, the Bronx. Roger Erickson (4-6) will pitch for the Yankees against Lary Sorensen (5-6). (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia. This will be the fifth Mets-Phillies game in 44 hours. Craig Swan (5-2), who lost to Montreal last Wednesday, starts for the Mets against Mike Krukow (6-5), who beat St. Louis last Wednesday. (Television - Channel 9, 1:35 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570, and WGBB, 1240, 1:35 P.M.) Boxing Carlos (Sugar) DeLeon vs. S.T. Gordon. DeLeon is the World Boxing Council cruiserweight champion and is 31-1-1 with 23 knockouts. Gordon is the North American Boxing Federation champ and is 21-5-0 with 19 knockouts. One of Gordon's defeats was a March 1978 disqualification against Gerry Cooney. (Television -Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Soccer Cosmos vs. Edmonton Drillers, at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., 2:30 P.M. (Radio - WVNJ, 620, 2:30 P.M.) Other Events Basketball: Rucker Professional Summer League Tournament, at Holcombe Rucker Memorial Playground, West 155th Street and Frederick Douglass Blvd., 2 and 4 P.M. Holcombe Rucker Memorial-I.T.T. Summer Basketball League for scholastic, collegiate and amateur players, at Col. Charles Young Park, West 145th Street and Lenox Avenue; Marcus Garvey Park, 121st Street and Madison Avenue; Msgr. Kett Playground; Dyckman Houses, 203d Street between Nagle and 10th Avenues, 10 A.M. until dusk. Golf: Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, final round, at Westchester Country Club, North and Purchase Streets, Harrison, N.Y. (Television -Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.) Rochester International, final round, at Locust Hill Country Club, Pittsford, N.Y. Harness Racing: Monticello (N.Y.) Raceway, 2 P.M. Horse Shows: Essex Horse Trials, at United States Equestrian Team Headquarters, Route 206 and Pottersville Road, Gladstone, N.J. Stadium jumping is featured in this final day of three-day event. 10 A.M. Lacrosse: World championships, at Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore.

title: One of Bill Veeck's Former Pen Pals
description: To the Sports Editor: A couple of years ago, I decided to write a series of letters to the owner of my favorite baseball team, making all kinds of suggestions as only a fan has the chutzpah to make. It was really more a desire to vent my spleen rhetorically than an impractical expectation that an actual dialogue would be established.

title: NOt a Bad Week To Be a Democrat
description: The Democrats and their Presidential hopefuls are gathered in Philadelphia, determined to advance their cause primarily by agreeing on one. Going into the closing session of their National Party Conference today, it appeared they might get through three days of potshotting the Republicans without catching each other in the crossfire.

title: CORRECTION
description: Last week's article on the steel industry incorrectly described the expense of the Inland Steel Company's mill expansion.

title: MEDIATION, A NEW WAY TO DIVORCE
description: AFTER 15 years of marriage and two children, Grace and Stanley Miller are getting a divorce. Mr. Miller earns $50,000 a year and can well afford a lawyer, but the Millers are obtaining their divorce through a mediator for a fraction of the cost of two lawyers in an adversarial proceeding.

title: The Week in Business; FEDERAL BUDGET FINALLY CLEARS THE SENATE
description: The Senate approved a $769.8 billion budget for next year, providing record-high peacetime military outlays, sharp cuts in domestic spending and a victory for President Reagan. The President vetoed an $8.9 billion supplemental appropriation bill that included $3 billion to subsidize mortgages and a $1 billion emergency-spending bill.

title: HE STARS AS A SALESMAN OF SHOW TO THE NETWORKS
description: In a few weeks, next fall's television series will be going into production. July and August are frantically busy months for television producers, but the hard work has no tinge of despair.

title: POORER SCHOOLS TO PRESS CASE IN LEGISLATURE
description: ALBANY FOR the last year, whenever anyone proposed drastically revising the state's education-aid formula, the leader of the Senate Republican majority, Warren M. Anderson, said that any change would have to await a ruling by the state's highest court.

title: Ads in Fake Law Journal Sold
description: An Essex County man has pleaded guilty to a charge of soliticing money for advertisements in a bogus law enforcement journal, The New Jersey Narcotics and Law Enforcement Journal, and taking the funds he collected for his own use. Edwin H. Stier, director of the state's Division of Criminal Justice, said Friday that the man, Andrew Tulli of West Orange, N.J., had entered the plea to a charge of conspiracy to commit theft by deception before Judge Edward F. Neagle Jr. of Superior Court.

title: Reading and Writing; IN PRAISE OF CONTACT
description: In his first novel, ''The Frog Who Dared To Croak,'' which is reviewed in this issue, sociologist Richard Sennett shows how rigid social planning in Communist countries frustrates the development of personality. In ''The Uses of Disorder,'' a nonfiction book published in 1970, he examines the opposite effect: how the development of personality in our country often frustrates the kind of housing, school or zoning planning that would enable heterogeneous groups to live comfortably together in New York City.

title: LEBANESE AND P.L.O. MEET TO DISCUSS NEW U.S. PLAN
description: Lebanese Government officials and Palestine Liberation Organization leaders met today to consider a new set of United States proposals for settling the Lebanon crisis. The meetings came as a new cease-fire between Israel and Palestinian and Syrian forces in Lebanon held firm today, nearly 24 hours after it went into effect.

title: IT'S TIME FOR MANAGEMENT CONCESSIONS
description: MANAGEMENT requests for union concessions in contract bargaining a re reaching epidemic proportions. We are told by chief executives, a cademicians and government officials that if granted, such requests w ill stimulate economic growth, slow inflation, raise profits, reduceu nemployment and rejuvenate vital industries. Nothing could be f urther from the truth.

title: GILDER'S 192 TIES A TOUR RECORD
description: Bob Gilder scored the rarest of golf shots today, a double eagle, to take a six-stroke lead in the third round of the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic.

title: N.F.L. SAYS PLAYERS' COCAINE USE COULD THREATEN INTEGRITY OF GAME
description: Officials of the National Football League warned yesterday that the use of cocaine had become so widespread among its players that it now posed a threat to the continued integrity of the game.

title: Keith Plapinger Weds Miss Heath
description: Ellen Louise Heath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Heath of Buffalo, was married there yesterday to Keith David Plapinger, son of Wallace R. Plapinger of New York and Adele W. Plapinger of Yardley, Pa. The Rev. Donald Rydel performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Universalist Church.

title: Look Backward at Sport Fishing
description: IAM troubled by the proliferation of fishing tournaments in this c ountry. Such affairs, it seems to me, tear asunder the centuries-old c oncept that sport fishing is a relaxing, contemplative endeavor, a w ay to escape the abrasions and competitiveness of the work-a-day w orld.

title: Talking Appraisals; HOW TO SET RIGHT PRICE ON A HOME
description: A house near the railroad tracks is worth less than one near a c ountry club. A house on a busy main road is worth less than one witha swimming pool and a wooded lot. Finishing a basement will make a h ouse more valuable by giving it a family room. Right?

title: Miss Finney To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Graham S. Finney of Mount Airy, Philadelphia, and Prout's Neck, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Roswell Finney, to Mark Haynes Johnston, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Johnston of Wellesley Hills and Cataumet, Mass.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The Check Is In the Mail

title: Jan Karen Hall and John Crawley Burruss Married
description: Jan Karen Hall, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Anthony Hall of Sherborn and Annisquam, Mass., was married yesterday to John Crawley Burruss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Ross Burruss of Tucker, Ga. The Rev. John P. Cobb of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Dayton, Ohio, performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Universalist Area Church in Sherborn.

title: Priscilla Porter Bride Of Harold Brenner
description: Priscilla Cunningham Porter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Stanley Porter of Virginia Beach, Va., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Harold Brenner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erving Brenner of Suffern, N.Y. Walter Lawton, a leader in the New York Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the Stanhope Hotel.

title: REDEFINING A DOCTOR'S ROLE
description: AS students leave medical school and assume wider responsibilities as physicians, there are greater resources available to them and greater challenges ahead than ever before. The amazing technologic achievements in diagnostic and therapeutic medicine during the last few decades improve dramatically the life expectancy and the quality of life for many patients who in the past would have died in the early phase of their illness.

title: GIRDING THE KING
description: When Wilhelm Steinitz outrageously decreed that ''the king is a fighting piece,'' he did not mean just in the end game. The crotchety, provocative ruler of the chess world from 1866 to 1894 would at times contemptuously send his king to roam a hazardous battlefield in the early stages of a game.

title: THEATER: 'A DRIFTER, ' A MUSICAL FABLE
description: ''A Drifter, the Grifter & Heather McBride,'' at the 47th Street Theater, is a difficult title to remember, but don't bother trying - it probably won't be around long. This wantonly inane musical set in a mythical ''Hoosier village'' wants to be a folksy fable about the corruption of the American dream. Bernie Bernardo is an energetic good-for-nothing - the ''grifter'' of the title - whose whimsical business schemes haven't earned enough to pay the rent, yet he is suddenly elected the local businessman of the year. Heather McBride is his secretary and sweetheart, a simple girl; as she announces seconds after her entrance, she dreams of ''a man of my own/ Some kids and a home.''

title: Coach Gets Tough
description: Bill McCartney, the new football coach at the University of Colorado, is making good on his promised ''get-tough'' attitude.

title: VISITORS VIEW CITY FROM A FRESH ANGLE
description: For some New Yorkers yesterday was a day for the parks or the beaches, but for a few people it was a day for climbing out onto a small steel grid hanging 300 feet above 41st Street.

title: HONORING A GIFTED ECCENTRIC
description: The piece is named ''The Warriors,'' it was composed in 1913, and is in one movement, lasting about 20 minutes. It is scored for three or more pianos, is very heavy on percussion, has an offstage brass choir, and has so many rhythmic complexities that two or more conductors are needed. It is basically tonal, but has spiky bursts of dissonance.

title: GULF'S RESIDENT MERGER MASTER
description: MORE than 30 years ago, when he was a young management consultant in New York City, Harold H. Hammer helped a friend sell a small electrical business as a favor. Much to his astonishment, he found a check in the mail for $15,000 -more than his entire income that year - and promptly went into business buying and selling companies.

title: Kean Comes Up Short on Taxes
description: Death and taxes were inevitably on the agenda when the New Jersey Legislature met last week. For the third time in nine years, lawmakers voted to restore capital punishment.

title: AMERICAN ADVENTURES
description: UNDER THE APPLE TREE By Dan Wakefield. 342 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $13.95. CHANCE By Sara McAulay. 195 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.50.

title: Miss Campbell Will Be Bride Of Eric Peters
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh D. Campbell of Waitsfield, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Mary Campbell, to Eric Landon Peters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Landon Peters of Princeton, N.J., and Edgartown, Mass.

title: IMMIGRANTS OF THE PLANT WORLD CAME AND ALMOST CONQUERED
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Judy Glattstein teaches and writes about gardening topics. BY JUDY GLATTSTEIN

title: Pamela Ruth Carney Bride Of Rowland Barstow Bates
description: Pamela Ruth Carney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin W. Carney of Melrose, Mass., was married there yesterday to Rowland Barstow Bates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barstow Bates of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. John C. Corbiere, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: THE MAKING OF A DOCTOR
description: During the summer of 1980, Aaron Kenigsberg and three other firstyear medical students were assigned to the Village Nursing Home as the practicum for a geriatrics class which they were taking. Their mornings consisted of making rounds with our doctors and attending interdisciplinary team meetings with the administrative staff.

title: BREWERS, UP BY 6, TOP RED SOX, 11-10
description: Ben Oglivie hit a home run and broke an eighth-inning tie with a two-run single, as the Milwaukee Brewers defeated the Boston Red Sox today, 11-10, after losing a six-run lead.

title: PLEASURE AND PAIN
description: SPANKING THE MAID By Robert Coover. 102 pp. New York: Grove Press. Cloth, $10.95. Paper, $4.95.VIRGINIE Her Two Lives. By John Hawkes. 215 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: BEAMON, NOT THE ALTITUDE, SET LONG-JUMP RECORD
description: IAM among the many who have been following Carl Lewis's remarkable e xploits with great interest, particularly in the long jump. Frank L itsky certainly was right in his article (''Carl Lewis, the Man Who W ould Be King,'' The New York Times, June 6) about Lewis in stating t hat Bob Beamon's record has appeared impregnable.

title: Venice
description: To the Editor: Concerning MacDonald Harris's question in ''All the Facts (Some True) About Gondolas'' (Travel, June 6) as to why all gondolas are painted black, I refer him to the following statement, Page 72, Volume 19 of the Encyclopaedia Britannica (15th edition - 1980): ''Since 1562, in obedience to sumptuary laws seeking to suppress ostentation in civil dress and decoration all gondolas have been painted black.'' I also read some time ago in some forgotten text that during one of the great plagues that swept Venice (possibly the Black Death plague of 1347-52) all gondolas were painted black in mourning and remained so afterwards in remembrance of those who had died. Apparently, in either case, the gondolas of Venice had previously been painted in various colors. PHILLIP A. WILEY v. atertown, N.Y.

title: LILLIAN MOORE
description: Lillian Moore, who had been president of Moore's Trucking Company in Piscataway, N.J., and former president of the State Bank of Plainfield, died yesterday at Paul Kimball Hospital in Lakewood, N.J. She was 93 years old and moved to Lakewood after having lived in Plainfield for 65 years.

title: Palenque
description: To the Editor: I would like to add a footnote to Katherine Bouton's wonderfully evocative and informative article ''The Mayan Ruins of Palenque'' (Travel, June 6).

title: WITH HAIG, A LOT OF CRISIS MANAGEMENT WAS INTERNAL
description: WASHINGTON GEORGE P. Shultz's first task upon confirmation as Secretary of State seems obvious: to give direction and cohesiveness to the Reagan Administration's management of foreign policy. For the past 17 months, the Administration has frequently lack a concerted approach, not only in formulating actual policy but in deciding who should be directing it.

title:
CAMERA;
TIMING IS KEY TO TAKING GOOD ACTION PICTURES
Sandra von Salis Bride of Walo Schoch
description: Sandra Evelyn Frances von Salis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Franz von Salis of Malans, Switzerland, and West Caldwell, N.J., was married yesterday to Walo A. Schoch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Schoch of Basel, Switzerland. The Rev. Dr. David St. George performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Essex Fells, N.J.

title: HOW ART AND TRADITION CAST THE SPELL OF KABUKI
description: A muffled sound of wooden clappers begins and the theater grows quiet. Faster and faster they beat. The curtain moves, its vertical green, rust and black stripes twitching as some unseen presence pulls it open to reveal a painted landscape and an array of solemn-faced musicians and their drums, flutes and plucked samisens. In front of them stand the actors, dressed in elaborate wigs and many-layered costumes covered by brocades of vivid hues. They are all men, although their faces are painted to represent both male and female characters. There is a stir on stage and then among the audience, as a warrior or maiden, perhaps, or a priest or a messenger comes into view at the back of the orchestra, advancing along the hanamichi or ''flower way'' ramp in measured steps onto the stage.

title: Nova Scotia
description: To the Editor:

title: Collaboration
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
A DIFFERENT PLACE AT THE SHORE
description: ASURE BET after an afternoon at the track or a day at the beach is to dine at the Continental in Long Branch. Open only when Monmouth Race Track is, this popular establishment is one of the best restaurants at the shore.

title: 'BIG APPLE PERSON' IN EXECUTIVE SUITE
description: WHEN Eugene J. Sullivan left the United States Navy at the end of World War II, he was a 25-year-old lieutenant, a husband and a father, and he wanted a job.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: ZUCKERMAN UNBOUND, by Philip Roth. (Fawcett/Crest, $3.50.) Nathan Zuckerman strives to free himself from the consequences of the fame and fortune his four novels have brought him by coming to terms with his third wife whom he had walked out on, with the heritage of his deceased father and the Jewish community, and with the literary critics in their role of custodians of high culture. In his latest novel, Philip Roth is masterful, sure in every touch, clear and economical; his usual heartbreak and hilarity are present, but more muted than in his early work.

title: ONCE UPON A TIME, IN THE SAFETY OF THE SUBURBS...
description: LIFE in the suburbs has become a mass of contradictions. Many parents who chose a suburban life style in order to guarantee a comfortable and safe environment for children have been painfully disillusioned. We followed the promise of security, and one by one our plans were thwarted; our dreams were shattered. And we have sadly been forced to compromise on our ideals, as slowly we began to contradict our original plans.

title: TOWN RALLIES FOR CANCER PATIENT
description: EAST HADDAM SEVEN tame white rabbits and three fat ducks tumble around on the lawn of the neat ranch house in the Millington Green section of East Haddam, where Leonard and Carol Dean live with their three children. Inside, in the living room, a pair of parakeets chirp in counterpoint to the quack of a fluffy, down-covered gosling. Carol Dean picks up the yellow gosling; he pecks at the buttons of her shirt with his orange beak.

title:
GARDENING;
TWO SELECTED AS ALL AMERICA ROSES
description: IT is the time of year again when the All America Rose selections committee makes its announcement of award-winning roses for 1983. Two roses made it to the winner's circle; Sun Flare, a bright yellow floribunda and Sweet Surrender, a pink hybrid tea.

title: Paul Batchelder Cosentino Marries Anne Hays Talley
description: Anne Hays Talley, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Doak Talley 3d of Richmond, was married there yesterday to Paul Batchelder Cosentino, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Cosentino of New York. The Rev. Eric Sutliffe Greenwood Jr., performed the ceremony at the Grace and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: ARCHEOLOGICAL CONSERVANCY GUARDING NATION'S BURIED HERITAGE
description: In the early 19th century, when American pioneers pushed westward, there were probably more than 20,000 significant archeological sites in the Ohio and Mississippi valleys alone, places that were inhabited or somehow used by peoples that, even then, were long gone and forgotten.

title: June 27, 1982
description: NONFICTION THE CONGO CABLES: The Cold War in Africa - From Eisenhower to Kennedy. By Madeleine G. Kalb. 7 THE CORRESPONDENCE OF BORIS PASTERNAK AND OLGA FREIDENBERG 1910-1954.

title: FIREWORKS DIM A BIT
description: INFLATION and crowd-control problems are determining how Long Islanders will celebrate the Fourth of July this year. With municipalities facing tight budgets and the police worried about keeping tabs on merrymakers, fireworks displays have declined in number.

title: MENU MATCHES DOWN -HOME LOOK
description: WESTPORT THE THREE BEARS is no longer a stagecoach stop. Nor is it a country inn, as it was during much of the 19th century. But as a restaurant, this 1821 establishment, situated at the edge of Norwalk, Wilton and Westport, has been turning out lunches and dinners for as long as we can remember.

title: AFRIKANERS' SENTIMENT IS CAPTURED BY 2 SINGERS
description: The two biggest names these days in the popularmusic world of the Afrikaners, the dominant white group of South Africa, are probably Blokkies Joubert and David Kramer. Blokkies Joubert is indisputably an Afrikaner, but although some of his fans do not realize it, he does not exist.

title: SPeaking to the Point
description: Margaret Thatcher certainly has a way of slicing through rhetoric. Fresh from conducting Britain's successful rout of Argentine invaders in the Falklands, she told the United Nations session on disarmament last week that ''wars are caused not by armaments but by the ambitions of aggressors.''

title: JAPAN'S STRUGGLE
