description: To the Business Editor: You do an excellent job of pointing out the shortcomings of an economic and cultural system that many American managers have come to view with uncritical awe. However, you failed to present an effective argument for the point persistently implied: that the Japanese economy cannot continue to prosper if it maintains its present course of development.

title: STAGE: 'ABERCROMBIE APOCALYPSE'
description: ''Abercrombie Apocalypse'' is a portentous title for a play, although its subtitle, ''An American Tragedy,'' says it better. Paul Carter Harrison has written a considerable heap of mystification into the work that the Negro Ensemble Company opened at the Westside Arts Theater, but dismiss the mystification, ignore the portentousness, and the message, a traditional one, is clear: The folks who live on the hill are miserable, not to mention kinky.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Sunday is the last day to catch two different but individual dance troupes. Among the younger generation exploring new modes of tap dancing is Brenda Bufalino.

title: THEATER: ACCORDION PLAYER THE STAR
description: ''Jane Avril'' is a kind of first for Off Broadway - an accordion player who never says a word has all the action. If you love the squeeze box, you'll love ''Jane Avril.'' If you don't, stay away from the Provincetown Playhouse, where the play opened this week.

title: PORT CHESTER PARADE
description: ''The Great American Fourth of July Parade,'' stepping off from the steps of the Port Chester Library at 11 A.M. Saturday, was named for a poem of the same title written by Archibald MacLeish and chosen as the 1976 Bicentennial selection of the International Poetry Forum. The parade will proceed down Westchester Avenue to the village marina, where the Second Annual Byram River Arts Festival will be under way from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Saturday through July 5.

title: Closest Pursuers Still Hopeful
description: Bob Gilder's two playing partners, Peter Jacobsen and Tom Kite, had different responses to Gilder's double eagle in the third round today at the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic.

title: SOME OBSERVATIONS ON THE BEHAVIOR OF THE RETARDED
description: RECENTLY, I had a chance to observe closely the behavior of several retarded citizens at a Town Council meeting in a neighboring community.

title: EUCLIDIAN FETE IN NORWALK
description: NORWALK IN 1936, when he was 38 years old, Bern Dibner read a book entitled, ''Men and Machines.'' To his surprise, he came upon a list of inventions attributed to Leonardo da Vinci. Dr. Dibner knew of Leonardo as an artist, but never, not even in his college studies of engineering, had encountered him in the guise of scientist.

title:
GARDENING;
TWO SELECTED AS ALL AMERICA ROSES
description: IT is the time of year again when the All America Rose selections committee makes its announcement of award-winning roses for 1983. Two roses made it to the winner's circle; Sun Flare, a bright yellow floribunda and Sweet Surrender, a pink hybrid tea.

title: MICHAEL KORDA: SUCCESS IS IMPORTANT
description: MICHAEL KORDA, the exuberant editor in chief of Simon and Schuster, is sitting in his bloodlessly modern 14th-floor corner office, flanked on two sides by pictures of himself, his wife and their horses. He is telling stories. This he does with great gusto and considerable charm, for he is a natural raconteur, a skilled mimic and an unabashed performer, quite willing to stand up and act out all the parts if it enhances the drama.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE KENNEDY HALF DOLLAR IS NOT DEAD YET
description: Reports of the death of the Kennedy half dollar appear to have been premature. Although the coin has not been struck this year for circulation, the United States Mint did include it in the 1982 U.S. proof set and Mint Director Donna K. Pope says that in all likelihood it also will appear in next year's set.

title: Dr. Mary M. Holford, Fought For Improved Race Relations
description: Dr. Mary Michael Holford, the founder and president of the Creative Resources Institute, a Manhattan concern that provides classroom programs to aid race relations, died of cancer Wednesday at the Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. She was 42 years old and lived in Denville, N.J.

title: Richard Taney to Wed Dr. Frances Halpern
description: Judge and Mrs. Joseph Halpern of East Meadow, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Frances Amy Halpern, to Richard Lawrence Taney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Feigenbaum-Taney of Caracas, Venezuela.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: NELSON LEDGES, Ohio THE worst thing, hanging upside down there in my safety harness, was the knowledge that I'd let everybody down. The Peugeot's roof was on the ground, the wheels were spinning in the air, and this was still practice. We hadn't even started the race.

title: AUTO-RACE WEEKEND
description: The Kendall Cup Nationals, at Lime Rock Park in Salisbury every Fourth of July weekend, will feature 23 classes of cars from singleseat open ''hotdogs'' to showroom stock sedans, Corvettes and Camaros.

title: Q and A
description: Question:My husband and I enjoy traveling to other countries and try to learn as much as we can about each country we visit: its people, their daily life, culture, history, geography and nature. In some countries, however, we feel we would prefer touring in a group. Are there any national or international organizations that provide tours catering to more education-oriented tourists? We are interested in a more detailed group visit and a less ''touristy'' approach. - J.E.B., Lakeland, Fla. Answer:The organizations to which you should first turn are academic and cultural institutions such as universities and museums; frequently these institutions are the sponsors of the kinds of group travel that you describe. You might also try religious groups as well as unions and professional organizations of which you may be a member.

title: CHEERS FOR U.S. HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT SOTHEBY'S MEANT TO A NEIGHBORHOOD
description: It is bad news all round that as of the end of this season Sotheby's will no longer have sales on Madison Avenue. It is bad news for Sotheby's itself, in that Madison Avenue at 77th Street is as good a location as anyone could wish. It is bad news for those who are laid off. It is bad news for the neighborhood, and it is bad news for all of us, whether or not we ever went to an auction, let alone bid at one.

title: THE COMING FLOOD OF TREASURY DEBT
description: THESE past weeks have rattled the nation's credit markets, where theU nited States Government and American industry turn for money. Bond p rices have skidded to yearly lows, and interest rates remain s tubbornly high. The number of bids at the most recent Treasury a uction shrank by a fourth, a disquieting sign of things out of j oint. High interest rates have long since driven corporate borrowersf rom the long-term bond market, and the highly publicized collapse ofD rysdale Government Securities, a small, over-ambitious player in G overnment bonds, has caused nervous investors to become even more s kittish.

title: Mary E. Barrett Becomes Bride Of Richard Bruns
description: The marriage of Mary Ellin Barrett, assistant editor of Family Weekly, to Richard S. Bruns, a reporter for Time magazine, took place yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. Henry Hobson Sturtevant, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Recent Sales

title: A STROLLER'S HONG KONG
description: LAILAN YOUNG is a London-based freelance whose book on the Chinese will be published in the spring. By LAILAN YOUNG

title: Miss Koopman Becomes Bride Of Mark Eaton
description: Dorothy Brooks Koopman, a vice president of E.S.G. Associates Inc., an energy consulting company in Washington, was married yesterday to Mark Robertsen Eaton, son of Carroll K. Robertsen and Dr. Leonard K. Eaton, both of Ann Arbor, Mich. Rabbi Neil Kominsky, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Koopman in West Hartford, Conn.

title: Strike Grounds Greek Airline
description: Flight attendants on Olympic Airways, Greece's national airline, started a 48-hour strike today, grounding all international and domestic flights.

title: World Cup Soccer Enters Second Phase
description: After two weeks and 36 games, the World Cup soccer tournament enters the second round Monday with the field reduced to 12 teams.

title: Jennifer Stevens Will Be Married
description: Dr. and Mrs. Walter B. Stevens of Salt Lake City have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Aline Stevens, to Eric C. Smith of Midway, Utah, and Orangeburg, N.Y.

title: REVUE: WAITING TO BECOME 'STARS'
description: Mickey and Judy are back with us again. This time they're putting on a show in an empty garage and, instead of just two of them, they are a trio of particularly flea-brained idiots.

title: HINCKLEY'S INSANITY PLEA AND 'CONVOLUTED' JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
NEWARK MUSEUM OFERS AN E.L. HENRY EXHIBITION
description: NEWARK FOR THE last 15 years or so, exhibitions of American 19th-century art have featured revivals of vanished reputations. ''E.L. Henry's Country Life,'' a show at the Newark Museum through July 5, is another exhibition in this seemingly endless series.

title: Ian Smith Out of Hospital
description: Former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith was discharged from a hospital here today after treatment following his collapse in Parliament three days ago, a hospital spokesman said.
To the Editor:

title: HINKLEY VERDICT TESTED MORE THAN THE JURY
description: WHEN John W. Hinckley Jr., who fired explosive bullets into the bodies of President Reagan and three other men nearly 15 months ago, was found ''not guilty by reason of insanity'' last week, the public reaction was outrage. Mr. Hinckley, who was committed to a Washington mental hospital, theoretically could be released within months; his lawyers, who maintained during the eight-week trial that the attack stemmed from his desire to win the love of actress Jodie Foster, said they wouldn't attempt to free him until they no longer considered him dangerous. The Week in Review asked Senator Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican, and Alan Dershowitz, a professor at the Harvard Law School, to talk about the insanity defense. Excerpts of their discussion with Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, and Stuart Taylor Jr., a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, follow.

title: THE ISLAND TREES CASE TURNS ANOTHER LEGAL CORNER
description: IN 1976, nine books were removed from the shelves of junior and senior high schools in the Island Trees Union Free School District, a middle-class community on Long Island. A seven-member school board found the books - which included ''The Fixer'' by Bernard Malamud, ''Down These Mean Streets'' by Piri Thomas and ''Soul on Ice'' by Eldridge Cleaver - ''anti-American, anti-Christian, anti-Semitic and just plain filthy.'' The banning prompted a lawsuit by five former students, who contended it violated the First Amendment. A Federal District Court dismissed the suit without a trial in 1979, but the next year a Federal appeals court decided that the students were entitled to try to prove their case in court. Last week, the United States Supreme Court ruled that the First Amendment does limit the discretion of school officials in such cases. The court made no attempt to define what those limits were but, in sending the matter back to the lower court, kept alive the students' challenge.

title: SPEAKER O'NEILL FINDS A GAIN FOR WEINBERGER IN SHAKE-UP
description: Thomas P. O'Neill, Speaker of the House of Representatives, praised Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today and expressed concern about his designated successor, George P. Shultz.

title: U.N. LEBANON PLAN IS VETOED BY U.S.
description: The United States today vetoed a Security Council resolution demanding a limited withdrawal from Beirut by Israeli and Palestine Liberation Organization forces.

title: CALLERS CAN LISTEN TO SHUTTLE
description: For the first time, the American public will be able to eavesdrop on conversations between the space shuttle Columbia and the Johnson Space Center in Houston.

title: Laura Ingraham Is a Bride
description: Laura Jane Ingraham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Foster Ingraham 3d of Mill Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to William Barbour Clemmens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clemmens of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Richard W. Reifsnyder performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Oyster Bay, L.I. The bride is a geologist with the United States Environmental Agency in Denver. Mr. Clemmens is assistant regional counsel for the Denver region of the United States Highway Administration.

title: Sarah Jean Van Buren Is Bride of Robert Schramm
description: Sarah Jean Van Buren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin E. Van Buren of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Bruce Schramm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Schramm of Excelsior, Minn., and Tucson, Ariz. The Rev. Walter Wagoner, minister of the Round Hill Community Church, performed the ceremony at the North Greenwich Congregational Church.

title:
Design;
THE PAST IS ALSO PRESENT
description: Before Japan was opened to the West in the middle of the 19th century, it had been sealed off from outside design influences for almost two centuries. Most houses were built of wood and looked alike, and furniture was generally limited to storage chests and tables. Today, however, Japanese architecture and furniture design have moved very much into the international mainstream.

title: JOINT FUND WEIGHED FOR DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY SLATE
description: Democratic leaders supporting Mayor Koch for governor say they are exploring the possibility of financing the Mayor's campaign jointly with that of his preferred candidates for lieutenant governor and state comptroller. In the past, primary contests have been handled separately.

title: IN MILAN, LA SCALA IS JUST AN OVERTURE
description: WILLIAM WEAVER is the author of several books on Italian opera, including ''The Golden Century of Italian Opera'' (Thames and Hudson). He lives in Tuscany. By WILLIAM WEAVER

title: Typography
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BOSTON, CULINARY ARTS
description: JANICE HARAYDA, former editorial director of Boston Magazine, is a writer who lives in Cambridge, Mass. By JANICE HARAYDA

title: Roberta Rubin Married
description: At the Harrison (N.Y.) Jewish Center yesterday Roberta R. Rubin, who is with the New York Subways Advertising Company, was married to Dr. Jeffrey H. Graf, a senior resident in internal medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital. Rabbi Bernard N. Cohen and Cantor Lawrence Avery officiated. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Rubin of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Mr. and Mrs. Rudolf F. Graf of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: STATE EXPECTED TO ACT ON MEDICAL-DATA ACCESS BILLS
description: The fate of proposals to guarantee patients access to their medical and mental-health records is expected to be decided in the Legislature next week, key legislators and lobbyists said today.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS ASSURE THE ALLIES ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: Leading American officials, including a deputy of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., sought today to assure allies of the United States that there would be no change in common goals as a result of Mr. Haig's resignation.

title: HAIG IS NOT PRESENT
description: Secretary of State-designate George P. Shultz conferred with President Reagan today and then said he saw his role as an opportunity ''to advance the causes of peace, freedom and justice in a world so troubled and so anxious to hope for a good future.''

title: In the Defense Of Tutoring
description: A broadside against tutoring for school-aged children was leveled by Lewis Lyman (''To Be Tutored or Not to Be Tutored - a Question of Needs,'' Opinion Page) in the June 6 edition of Westchester Weekly. While the cases described are not atypical, there are many other reasons why families seek extra instructional help for their youngsters.

title: Perspectives: The Office Market; FOR BRITISH, NOTHING'S QUITE LIKE 'PRIME'
description: THE word ''prime'' has a magic ring in real-estate circles, and B ritish investors in Manhattan office properties seem to be p articularly bewitched.

title: CONSUMER CO-OP BANK'S SHAKY FIRST STEPS
description: WASHINGTON SPEAKING of contradictions, there is the National Consumer Cooperative Bank. It is a private institution, but also a public one. With $225 million in assets, it is no bigger than many neighborhood savings and loan associations, yet it is the flagship of the sputtering consumer co-op movement. And it is supposed to be a capitalistic bank with a socialistic heart, making solid loans to cooperatives that are generally ineligible for credit elsewhere.

title: 'Untrue' Claim
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOTT'S 3:48.53 IN MILE IS 3RD FASTEST
description: OSLO June 26 (AP) - Steve Scott of the United States equaled the third fastest one-mile time ever run and won in 3 minutes 48.53 seconds at the Bislett Games today.

title: Fare of the Country; SHE-CRAB SOUP: SOUTHERN TRADITION
description: GLORIA LEVITAS, who teaches anthropology at Queens College, has a special interest in food. By GLORIA LEVITAS

title: EVERYBODY OUT OF THE (VAN) POOL!
description: EACH day it becomes increasingly clearer that sheiks and desert nomads are not very sympathetic to the needs of automobile lovers. In their desert logic they feel that since they practice polygamy, we Americans can at least double up in our cars. These people who have never sneaked into a drive-in movie for an ''all-nighter'' are now dictating our life style by forcing us to commute to work in car pools and van pools.

title: Administration Issues Rules On Operation of Incinerators
description: The Reagan Administration has issued rules governing the operation of more than 300 incinerators that burn hazardous wastes.

title:
CONNECTICUT GUIDE;
CROSS-CULTURAL ART
description: In the early days of the 20th century, working concurrently, yet independently, two groups of American and Canadian painters broke away from the stylized art then in vogue to do their own, then revolutionary thing. In the United States they were the ''paint slingers'' of the ''Ashcan'' school; in Canada, the ''secessionists'' belonging to the ''Hot Mush'' school. After two years of planning, the Heckscher museum in Hungtington has opened ''The Canadian Group of Seven/'The Eight' Americans: Rebels and Renegades,'' the first exhibition ever mounted that documents the bond between the two schools.

title: 3 Decades of Best TV
description: The Museum of Broadcasting, at 1 East 53d Street, will present a retrospective of 30 years of popular television programs from July 13 to Sept. 18. ''Television's Top-Rated Shows: A Look Back at Popular Programming by Decades'' will be made up of programs from the 50's, 60's and 70's.

title: W.D. Brighton Weds Andrea Wolfman
description: Andrea C. Wolfman and William David Brighton, 1978 graduates of the University of Michigan Law School, were married at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington yesterday by Judge Myron H. Bright of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.

title: BANNERS/BIRDS/BUSES; Saunas on Wheels
description: The only thing worse than coping with a technology that doesn't work is pretending that it does.

title: TAX ABATEMENT AND LID ON RENTS
description: THE owner of a Manhattan apartment building that will lose its t enyear tax abatement next Wednesday is locked in a court battle withh is tenants over whether the building may be removed from rent s tabilization when the abatement lapses.

title: MAMBY LOSES TITLE TO HALEY
description: Leroy Haley upset Saoul Mamby, the defending champion from the Bronx, with a 15-round majority decision to take the World Boxing Council junior welterweight title today at the Front Row Theater.

title: Times of London Strike Ends
description: A strike by electricians that stopped publication of The Times of London for two days ended today when four men who had been dismissed for refusing to do maintenance work were reinstated, the paper's management said.

title: AN AMERICAN IN PARIS
description: LAST year Jonathan Boyer was allowed to wear a red, white and blue jersey for the 23 days of the Tour de France, in honor of being the first American ever to ride in the world's most important bicycle race.

title: DIRECTOR'S MEDIUM
description: Faces are to Federico Fellini what legs were to Busby Berkeley. ''For my films,'' Fellini says, ''I seek faces that are expressive, full of character, faces that with their appearance on screen tell us all there is to know about them.'' How does he find them? ''I'm sitting in my office, the door opens, and in comes a little old man, a hooker, one who wishes to sell me a watch, a duchess, a fatso. I may see a hundred people, yet use no more than two of them in the movie. However, I do take in their clothes, dialects, mustaches, tics, or postures. Somebody may enter and be delighted because I insist on having pictures taken, while all that's of interest to me is the photo of his glasses.''

title: HUNGARIAN RHAPSODY
description: Those who feel that bridge has a social value and can contribute to international detente have long regretted that the game did not have official sanction in Eastern Europe. Chess was in favor and bridge was not, and one cannot put the blame on the kings and queens, since they appear in both games.

title: Emily Swartzentruber Is the Bride of Robert Shull
description: Emily Alice Swartzentruber, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. A. Orley Swartzentruber of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert M. Shull, son of Dr. Gilbert M. Shull of Bernardsville, N.J., and the late Karen Lunde Shull. The Rev. George C. Alexander performed the ceremony at All Saints' Episcopal Church, where the bride's father is rector.

title: THIRD SUSPECT ARRAIGNED IN ATTACK ON THREE TRANSIT WORKERS
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man yesterday became the third suspect to be arraigned in connection with the attack on three black transit workers last Tuesday in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. One of the workers was killed.

title: About Books and Authors
description: Graduation Day

title: BLACK POLICE PICKETS DEFY A MAYOR
description: Despite efforts to maintain an air of unity at the Democratic national party conference here, a long-simmering intraparty dispute over racial questions in Philadelphia has spilled out for all to see.

title: Padres 7, Giants 6
description: SAN FRANCISCO (UPI) - Broderick Perkins drove in Garry Templeton in the 15th inning to lift San Diego over San Francisco. The victory went to Eric Show (6-3), who entered the game in the 14th.

title: THE MAKING OF A DOCTOR
description: I am a proud graduate of Bellevue (class of 1944). Our rigors and the intensity of our work paralleled those of Aaron Kenigsberg.

title: CAMERAS USED TO HUNT WHALES
description: ''THAR she blows,'' that spine-tingling call to adventure, has summoned the Ishmael in each of us. The decks we tread are not those of the Pequod but the Dolphin III, a party fishing boat berthed at Provincetown, on Cape Cod.

title: Editors' Choice
description: AS THEY WERE, by M.F.K. Fisher. (Alfred A. Knopf, $13.95.) A selection of Mrs. Fisher's writings on food, life and herself.

title: NUCLEAR BARGAINING
description: Leslie H. Gelb, The Times's national-security correspondent, headed the State Department's Bureau of Political and Military Affairs from January 1977 to July 1979. By Leslie H. Gelb MEMORANDUM FOR THE PRESIDENT. SUBJECT: STRATEGIC ARMS REDUCTION TALKS.

title: Muddy Treasure
description: Millions of dollars in silver bullion. Right in the mud of New York Harbor. That hope sent four Jersey scuba divers into Federal Court in July 1981, seeking the right to chase the prize in fetid Arthur Kill.

title: 61 NIGHTS OF FUN FOR FREE
description: A TOTAL of 61 free nights of entertainment, and one benefit concert to help pay for it all: that's the package at the Levitt Pavilion for the Performing Arts, and it remains one of the best deals in Connecticut.

title: SERVING THE ENVIRONMENT
description: That buzz phrase, ''public sculpture,'' has meant different things at different times. These days, it puts most of us in mind of outdoor art works, studio-oriented in design, and often just plunked down on urban plazas. In fact, some call these works ''plunk art,'' and they have also been referred to as ''private art for public spaces.'' Thousands of such pieces dot the land, many made by well-known artists, and commissioned by governments, corporations and private citizens. Some are beautiful, competing successfully with nature and the built environment; some, on the other hand, fight a losing battle with the great outdoors. What most of them have in common, however, is that, except for their size, they could just as well function in museums.

title: EXAMINING THE MEDICAL EXAMINERS HAUPPAUTE
description: IT seemed that it would be a rather smooth transition, replacing a retiring medical examiner with a younger physician who had held the most prestigious medical examiner's job in the nation. But the succession of Dr. Michael M. Baden, the former Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, to the position of Suffolk County Medical Examiner, which is being vacated by the the retirement of Dr. Sidney Weinberg this Thursday, has hit a snag.

title: Around the World; Peking Frees the Last Of Nationalist Captives
description: All remaining Nationalist prisoners held for more than 30 years as spies and traitors have been released as part of an amnesty announced in March, the New China News Agency said today.

title: AIR GUARD, A 30-YEAR TRADITION, TAKES FLIGHT
description: AFTER more than 30 years here, the New York State Air National Guard is leaving Westchester, and both the Guard and county officials say they are happy about it. The Guard is getting a new base at Stewart Airport near Newburgh, N.Y., and the county government is getting the approximately 30 acres of prime airport property the Guard is leaving behind.

title: IN NEW INCOME-TAX DEBATE, FLAT RATE IS LOOKING FAIRER
description: An issue that has always been troublesome for politicians - the matter of fairness - lies at the heart of an increasingly lively debate centering on proposals to replace the current income tax with a ''flat'' tax.

title:
ANTIQUES;
WOODWORKING--THE OLD WAY
description: PISCATAWAY AGAINST the background of East Jersey Olde Towne, a reconstructed early American village here, members of CRAFTS of New Jersey will demonstrate next Sunday the way of woodworking of the past.

title: AID SOUGHT FOR LEBANON
description: PEARLS normally are formed through friction, but the recently formed Perle of Westchester is an attempt to overcome friction. The acronym, which stands for ''People for Relief in Lebanon,'' is an interdenominational countywide effort to provide assistance to that war-ravaged nation.

title: DISPUTE OVER BROADCASTS TO CUBA INTENSIFIES
description: A dispute over a Reagan Administration proposal to broadcast to Cuba on ''what is really happening'' in that country has intensified since the recent disclosure that the Navy had begun building four 250-foot antennas in the Florida Keys.

title: HOMES FOR RETARDED: STATE SHIFTS POLICY
description: STARTING Thursday, the element of surprise will be eliminated from the process by which the state's Division of Mental Retardation acquires group homes for the mentally retarded.

title: Sally Wister Married To Robert Dial Parrott
description: Sally Wister, manager of Graphics 1 and Graphics 2, an art gallery in Boston, was married yesterday to Robert Dial Parrott, an associate with the Boston law firm of Palmer & Dodge. The Rev. Arthur Bello performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Woodstock, Vt.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Clothing Bargains For Young People

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: United States Captures World Baseball Event
description: The United States won the World's Fair international baseball tournament by beating Japan, 10-4, today in the final game.

title: City Council Meetings Scheduled This Week
description: The following City Council meetings are open to the public this week: TUESDAY: Committee on State Legislation, City Hall, 10 A.M. Committee on General Welfare, City Hall, 12:45 P.M. Meeting of the full Council, City Hall, 1:30 P.M.

title: BOTTLE BILL: WHY GOVERNOR SIGNED IT
description: Up to the day Governor Carey signed a law requiring a 5-cent deposit on soda and beer containers in New York State, neither supporters nor opponents knew what he was going to do.

title: Around the World; 14 Nations in Accord On Antarctic Minerals
description: The 14 Antarctic Treaty nations, including the United States, announced today that they had agreed on a preliminary framework for a pact allowing oildrilling and mining in the region.

title: ANTI-SEMITIC VANDALISM ON L.I.: WHAT ARE THE CAUSES?
description: MORE than 100,000 Jews live on Long Island, and if ever there was a prototypical modern Jewish community, suburban division, Long Island is it. The Jews of Long Island are predominantly middle class or upper middle class. About half are clustered in quasi-enclaves nearest to New York City where the first Jews to migrate from the city settled, forever unofficially marking them as Jewish neighborhoods. (That is beginning to change as the newest generation of Jews tends not to want to live in areas known as primarily Jewish.)

title: Around the World; Salvador Says Its Troops Destroy Guerrilla Camp
description: About 400 Government troops backed by artillery leveled a guerrilla camp north of the capital, killing 10 insurgents, a military spokesman said today.

title: HERE'S HOW TO INSULATE ROOMS TO REDUCE NOISE IN THE HOUSE
description: ONE frequent complaint received in the mail by this department concerns the problem of what to do about noise inside the home - especially noise that comes through from rooms above when children are playing or when a stereo or television set upstairs is on loud and the people below find this annoying.

title: Investing; QUALITY OVER HIGH YIELD IN MONEY FUNDS
description: CALL it a reaction to a recession that has made the debt issues of m any companies suspect, or simply the growing sophistication of o rdinary investors. Whatever the reason, more and more investors are w illing to sacrifice a point or two of interest for the security t hey gain by investing in money market funds that only buy Governments ecurities.

title: COUNTRY FAIR TO FOCUS ON ARTISANS
description: NEW ROCHELLE HANDMADE crafts will once again dominate the New Rochelle Country Fair, which opens Friday and runs through next Monday, July 5, at Ward Acres Park in the northern end of the city. The park's 67 acres will also be filled with artisan exhibitions, musical performances, a farmer's market, horse-drawn trolley and a number of other events and activities.

title: SCHOOL-AID DECISION BACK TO LEGISLATURE
description: ALBANY IN the Lakeland School District, Dr. Leon Bock, the Superintendant, had already prepared taxpayers for the good news: the stiff tax rate paid in the relatively poor school district would very likely go down when the state's Court of Appeals ruled on a challenge to the system of school financing.

title:
ART;
PRINTS THAT SHOW INTAGLIO'S VARIETY AND UNPREDICTABILITY
description: MAKING workshops, both professional and educational, enjoy a considerable reputation on the Island, where artists benefit from the expert instruction and guidance of master printers whose technical skill, experimental attitudes and personal commitment are stimulating a growing interest in the graphic arts.

title: Ticket Prices for Productions
description: Ticket prices for theater productions during Summerfare are $7 to $11; for dance events, $8 to $12; for opera, $7 to $12, and for concerts, $7 to $11. Admission to family programs, such as Theatre Sans Fils, is $7.

title: COST ON PLANT IS SOUGHT
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH the state's Public Advocate continues to press for abandonment of the Public Service Electric & Gas Company's Hope Creek I nuclear power plant, and a legislative committee hopes to compel an overall review of whether it is needed, advisers to Governor Kean are proposing that the facility be completed and a lid be placed on its final cost.

title: A SAMPLING OF REMARKS BY GEORGE SHULTZ
description: ''It is a lesson you learn in mediation. People have to regard you as shooting straight or you lose your entree.

title: Japan's Struggle
description: To the Business Editor: One seldom finds as good a summary of the flaws within Japan's business structure as in Steve Lohr's article ''Japan Struggling With Itself'' (June 13).

title: State Relieved Of Equalizing School Spending
description: All school districts are not created equal, New York's highest court ruled last week, but the state is under no constitutional obligation to make them so.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: DESPITE medical success in combatting tuberculosis, there was a 2 percent increase in the number of New Jerseyans with the disease in 1981, according to a report by Dr. Shirley Mayer, Commissioner of the state's Department of Health. At the end of the year, she said, 1,525 persons were being treated for TB.

title: A 'Quick Trip Home' By Car
description: Richard F. Shepard, in his recent ''About Long Island'' column, bewails the fact that his wife is afraid to drive on parkways and ''through Manhattan's traffic-choked streets.'' Because of this, he has to go home to the suburbs by means of public transportation when he meets his wife downtown ''of an evening after work.''

title: FACTORY-BUILT HOUSES: TICKY-TACKY NO MORE
description: NEARLY 40 years ago, pre-fabricated shanty towns were thrown up a round the weapons factories of World War II, and their ticky-tacky q uality gave prefabs a lingering bad image. Quietly, however, what a re now called ''factory-made'' houses have grown in number around t he country, indistinguishable in their many incarnations from other h ousing on the landscape.

title: Postings; Rx for Conversion; Hospital Becomes A Condo
description: Until it was closed in 1980, the 15-story Art Deco building at 40 East 6lst Street housed the LeRoy Hospital. The 80-bed institution initially was a private hospital that cared for the affluent, and such celebrities as Judy Garland and Nat King Cole were treated there. Later, it became a center for osteopathic medicine.

title: Hearts and Minds In Earth Orbit
description: Like aviation in its early days, space travel used to seem a matter of magnificent men and their flying machines. But last week, the military and political realities overshadowed almost everything else.

title: THE P.L.O. IN LEBANON MAY BE FINISHED, BUT ITS GOALS SURVIVE
description: BEIRUT, LEBANON THREE weeks after the Israeli invasion, events in Lebanon were focused on a single simple question: How would the Palestine Liberation Organization lose? With the Palestinians trapped by the Israelis in 10 square miles of western Beirut and with Israeli air strikes and artillery bombardment tightening the noose, it seemed likely that the P.L.O. was finished, at least for now, as an independent Palestinian guerrilla organization with its own semisovereign base of operations in Lebanon. Its isolation was heightened late last week as Israeli armor cut the Palestinians' links to Damascus and, in fighting at Sofar, Aleih, Mansuriye and Shtaura, pushed Syrian forces back toward their frontier.

title: HOW ONE COUPLE SWITCHED THEIR ROLES
description: SCOTCH PLAINS ATTACHED to the refrigerator door in Mark and Linda Pastir's home is a cartoon showing a woman drinking coffee at a messy table. As smoke billows from the kitchen behind him, the husband, who is serving his wife from overflowing pots, asks:

title: Letters
description: Omission Noted To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
AT 82, HE ADDS POETRY TO HIS ART
description: EAST HAMPTON AT the age of 82, after 50 years as an artist with works in permanent collections of institutions such as the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art, Nahum Tschacbasov has started a new career. On Thursday when the Southampton College Press formally unveils ''Machinery of Fright,'' Mr. Tschacbasov becomes a poet.

title: REDRAWING OF HOUSE DISTRICT ENLIVENS NORTH CAROLINA RACE
description: The Legislature's redrawing of the Second Congressional District, which has already led Representative L.H. Fountain to decide to retire after 15 terms in the House, is now creating a two-party scramble to elect his successor.

title: TOUCHING ALL BASES
description: The Waterloo Music Festival is mixing piano concertos with fireworks next month, as well as featuring a chamber-music ensemble that plays ragtime and Sousa.

title:
GARDENING;
TWO SELECTED AS ALL AMERICA ROSES
description: IT is the time of year again when the All America Rose selections committee makes its announcement of award-winning roses for 1983. Two roses made it to the winner's circle; Sun Flare, a bright yellow floribunda and Sweet Surrender, a pink hybrid tea.

title: LEAVE IT TO CALIFORNIA
description: President Reagan should be comfortable now. He has turned the foreign and defense policies of the United States over to his old California buddies, Judge Clark at the National Security Council, George Shultz at the State Department, and Cappy Weinberger at the Pentagon.

title: WOMEN'S ORGANIZATION ASSAILS 101 AS EQUAL RIGHTS DEFECTORS
description: The National Organization for Women today identified 101 Democratic state legislators as ''anti-women's rights candidates'' and promised to work against their re-election.

title: Paperback Talk; A Summer of Horror
description: Bridgeport was such a lovely place to live, a quiet place where nothing ever happened .. Until little Emma Winthrop invented a playmate named Abigail .. Until Abigail taught Emma how to make strange things happen with her mind .. Until Emma learned how to move objects, arrest heartbeats and create grisly fires .. Until blood flowed like water and people began to die .. Horror had come to Bridgeport to stay .. A masterpiece of modern horror in the tradition of Stephen King's ''Carrie.''

title: Pittsburgh's Symphony In Public Radio Series
description: The ''American Orchestras'' series on National Public Radio will begin in October with concerts by the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra.

title: BREAKING WITH TRADITION
description: Marlyn McCusker successfully fought a two-year-long lawsuite to get the right to work in a coal mine. After working in one for two years in Oceola Mills, Pa., the roof fell in on her and she became the first American woman to be killed in a deep mining accident.

title: BALLET: ROMANTIC 'MIDNIGHT'
description: Eliot Feld's ''At Midnight,'' which the Feld Ballet revived Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, is a ballet about the sheer unfairness of life. The desires of its characters are seldom satisfied and its protagonists are doomed to pine and sigh. Set to songs by Mahler, one of which is used twice, ''At Midnight'' is Romantic in its melancholy and demands an unabashed Romanticism of its performers.

title: Not So Easy To Disengage
description: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said his forces would end their 21-month occupation of Iran this week ''to remove an important pretext being used by the notorious regime in Teheran to continue the war.'' But Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini had other pretexts.

title: SOME ISRAELIS FEAR THEIR VIETNAM IS LEBANON
description: - The main question being debated within the Israeli Government last week was whether to move militarily against the Palestine Liberation Organization in Beirut and suffer the wrath of the United States, or to maintain the siege, continue the political effort with Lebanese leaders and hope for Palestinian surrender.

title: ANDREW ASCH
description: Brevity was the dominant quality Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. There was only one work, Andrew Asch's ''Five by Seven'' for string quartet and piano.

title: A LESSON ON THE ELDERLY FROM NOMADS
description: IN in his television series and book, ''The Ascent of Man,'' Jacob Bronowski describes a nomadic society, the Bakhtiari of Iran. These nomads have been migrating over the mountains and valleys of Persia for centuries. They have a hard life.

title: U.S. WIVES COPING IN NEW GUINEA JUNGLE
description: In ''Goodbye Darkness'' William Manchester describes New Guinea as a most unpleasant place, the kind of country that ''would give the bravest man pause.''

title: FROM TRADITION TO TRAVESTY
description: IN his baseball orations, George Steinbrenner invariably mentions ''Yankee tradition,'' presumably referring to the glory that was Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, the grandeur that was Joe DiMaggio and Mickey Mantle, and the grit that was Reggie Jackson and Thurman Munson on the last Yankee teams to win the World Series way back there in 1978 and 1977.

title: 94 FACTORY-BUILT HOUSES PLANNED FOR SOUTH BRONX
description: Charlotte Street in the Bronx, for years a symbol of urban blight, looks much as it did in 1977 when President Jimmy Carter picked his way across the rubble-strewn site and then promised Federal financial assistance for revitalization. The rehabilitation plans collapsed two years later in dissension on the Board of Estimate.

title: Martin Sues Sabres
description: Rick Martin, the left wing who is the second-leading scorer in the history of the Buffalo Sabres, has begun legal proceedings against his former National Hockey League team, contending that medical treatment by team doctors shortened his playing career. Martin's action includes what he calls a ''multimillion-dollar'' suit against Scotty Bowman, the general manager and coach, and Dr. Peter A. Casagrande, a team physician.

title: Mohawk Trail
description: To the Editor: There are many interesting side trips off the legendary Mohawk Trail, but Ellen Perley Frank, the author of ''Touring the Mohawk Trail'' (Travel, June 13) neglected to mention the most spectacular of them all - the journey to the top of Massachusetts's highest peak, Mount Greylock. The winding drive up Notch Road off State Route 2 in North Adams leads to the lofty summit (3,491 feet) and expansive views of the Berkshire Valley, the Taconic Range, and several neighboring states.

title: KOCH PICKS FAVORITES AND CURRIES FAVOR
description: Ed Koch began his political career as a boss battler. But at the Democratic state designating meeting last week, the Mayor proved to be a bit of a boss himself, albeit with largely benevolent results.

title: New Road for a Petty
description: Richard Petty, whose 195 victories are the most in Grand National stock car racing, has decided to break up a family tradition. He said yesterday in Joliet, Ill., that his 21-year-old son, Kyle Petty, would complete this season's schedule in a Buick Regal owned and prepared by Ross Ellington.

title: INTERFAITH ALLIANCE IN YORKVILLE INITIATES GRANTS TO AID NEEDY
description: The Yorkville Emergency Alliance, an interfaith coalition, has awarded $50,000 in grants to seven social service agencies to help them meet needs in the Upper East Side area.

title: Rent Increases Are Kept Down
description: In a move that won general approval from tenant advocates, the Rent Guidelines Board last week approved basic rent increases beginning Oct. 1 for 400,000 rent-stabilized apartments in New York City. The increases, 4 percent for one-year leases, 7 percent for two years and 10 percent for three years, were significantly lower than those sought by landlords - 12 percent, 22 percent and 30 percent respectively.

title: Kristine Summerill Married
description: Kristine Starr Summerill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Summerill 3d of Toms River, N.J., was married yesterday to Stuart Laurens Craig Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Craig of Danville, Va. The Rev. Lawrence E. Moore performed the ceremony at the First Methodist Church in Island Heights, N.J. The bride is an alumna of Sweet Briar College. Her husband, a graduate of Washington and Lee University, is with Bruce Coleman Inc., a photography agency with offices in New York and London.

title:
STAMPS;
NATIONS MARK PRINCESS DIANA'S 21ST BIRTHDAY
description: The Princess of Wales is celebrating her 21st birthday this Thursday so an array of countries with ties to Britain and the British Commonwealth are joining the celebration by issuing stamps to mark the occasion in what is the first big omnibus issue of this year.

title: POLITICs; ABATE'S UPHILL BATTLE GETS MIXED RESULTS
description: HARTFORD LAST Monday officials of the State Federation of Teachers were at the State Capitol office of Ernest N. Abate, to announce their endorsement of Mr. Abate's candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: 'MEGAFORCE' IS A MIX OF JOVIALITY AND STUNTS
description: Ya-hoo! Those fellas wielding the high-tech weapons in Hal Needham's ''Megaforce'' may look like space patrollers, but they're really good old boys at heart.

title: INNOVATION IN THE SAFE DEPOSIT BOX
description: For two weeks New Yorkers have been taking advantage of the newest wrinkle in personal security, the city's only private safe deposit box facility, one not within a bank.

title: GETTING UP DANDER OVER GOOSE, GANDER
description: THE Bronx River Parkway has become a sort of tourist attraction where the river flows into a small lake before it curls around and becomes a broad stream once again, for it is here that Canada geese have gathered for the last several years. What was once a rarity - a few birds at most - is now commonplace.

title: N.F.L. Players Angry At Drug-Abuse Stigma
description: Reports of drug use in the National Football League are beginning to cause a backlash among players who are angry about being perceived as addicts.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: GOODMAN REUNION EVOKES NOSTALGIA
description: Forty-six years after Benny Goodman, Lionel Hampton and Teddy Wilson first played together with the late Gene Krupa as the Benny Goodman Quartet, Messrs. Goodman, Hampton and Wilson were playing together again Friday night at Carnegie Hall on the opening evening of the Kool Jazz Festival.

title: SALVADORAN TACTICS ARE CALLED INTO QUESTION
description: Last August, rebel forces held Perquin, a village in Morazan province, for nine days. This month, they held it for two weeks and also took nearby San Fernando, reportedly overcoming 250 Government troops. It took three American-trained battalions to dislodge the rebels, and there is still fierce fighting in the mountains.

title: Seminar on Minorities In Films and Television
description: A seminar on Minorities in the Motion Picture and Television Industries will be given at the New Federal Theater tomorrow with actors, film makers, producers and others.

title: HOME FROM THE TOUR
description: Barely back in the saddle after castle-hopping through Europe, President Reagan has revived frictions with allies that his trip was so carefully planned to ease.

title: Miss Johnson, John Putz Wed
description: Katherine Arnold Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Frederick Johnson of Basking Ridge, N.J., was married there yesterday to John Rodney Putz, son of Eloise Anderson Putz and Robert R. Putz, both of San Diego. The ceremony was performed in the Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. J. Calvin K. Jackson, the pastor, and the Rev. Dr. William H. Felmeth, vice president of the Princeton Theological Seminary.

title: Around the Nation; Six Convicted Racketeers Receive Prison Terms
description: Six men convicted of Federal racketeering charges were sentenced Friday to as long as 10 years in prison and were fined up to $15,000 by Federal District Judge James Giles.

title: Around the Nation; Police Chief Reinstated After Fight With Mayor
description: The police chief in the St. Louis suburb of Pagedale was reinstated Friday by court order after a dispute with a Mayor who heads an all-woman city government.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My name is George Shultz; I'm from California.'' - The Secretary of State-designate after arriving in Washington. (20:5.)

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSICElaine Comparone is a much-praised harpsichordist with a big sound who has said, ''The harpsichord seems to have attracted a certain type of performer -which I am not.'' One thing Miss Comparone is not is a specialist who draws a line at some hypothetical date in the repertory - 1785 suffices for some - beyond which she will not play.

title: SUMMER JOBS FOR YOUTHS IN SHORT SUPPLY
description: FEDERAL cutbacks and the recession have teamed to make the summer job picture a bleak one for young people in New Jersey. About 4,000 federally financed summer job slots have been wiped out in the state since last year, and many teen-agers - particularly among the working poor, who in other years might have found employment -have been frozen out.

title: Mary Bresette Bride Of Robert A. Buccino
description: The marriage of Mary Patricia Bresette and Robert Alan Buccino took place yesterday at the United Methodist Church in Lakeville, Conn. The Rev. Gerard Pollock performed the ceremony.

title: More Relief For Connecticut
description: Too little water can cause big problems, Connecticut residents learned last year, but too much water can cause bigger ones. So last week, Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed a plan to help the state bail out from one of the worst storms in a century.

title: Alice Risa Van Dyne Wed To Robert Steven Hoffman
description: Alice Risa Van Dyne and Robert Steven Hoffman were married yesterday at Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I. by Rabbi Norman Kahan. The bride, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Roger Van Dyne of Old Westbury, L.I., was graduated from Brandeis University and received an M.A. degree from Teachers College, Columbia University.

title: Index; Haig's Resignation
description: U.S. officials assure allies on for- eign policy 18 Schultz, as Treasury chief, was known as ''free market'' man 18 Arms negotiator sees no change in U.S. position 18 Speaker O'Neill sees gain for Weinberger 18 Transcript of Shultz's remarks after meeting with Reagan 20 International Three Americans on Soviet TV panel discuss nuclear war 3 A group of retired generals presses for disarmament 3 Greece's Socialists and Commu- nists split 4 Around the World 5 British governor is welcomed back to Falklands 6 South Africa withholds names of detained journalists 8 American University of Beirut reported hit by shells 11 Excerpts from U.N. resolutions on Lebanese situation 12 12-year-old boy tells of being drafted by P.L.O. 12 Israeli jets strike at Syrian mis- sile positions in Bekaa Valley 12 Israel's invasion of Lebanon hurt- ing its trade with Egypt 12 Despite fighting, Damascus does not have look of city at war 13 Government/Politics Redrawing of North Carolina dis- trict spices up primary 24 What made Carey decide to sign the bottle bill 28 Democratic meeting also has an anti-convention 30 Presidential hopefuls attempt to shine at Democratic parley 30 Koch, at Democratic conference, assails Reagan over loss of aid 30 General Philadelphia health official ac- cused of bribery 21 Around the Nation 22 N.A.A.C.P.'s 73d annual conven- tion opens Monday in Boston 23 Psychiatrists say predicting fu- ture crimes is difficult 25 ''Boomerang'' opens new city vistas to visitors 28 Health/Science Countdown moves into final hours for space shuttle liftoff 26 Russians unveil sophisticated new space control center 26 Education/Welfare An American and a Russian share prize in mathematics 15 Arts/Entertainment Benny Goodman Quartet has a reunion 42 Opening night's presentations at Jazz Festival 42 ''Megaforce'' arrives on screen 43 Afrikaners find an idol in a singer 46 ''Life Is Not a Doris Day Movie,'' revue at Village Gate 46 Obituaries Maj. Gen. Frank O'Driscoll Hunter 32 Style An innovation in the safe deposit box 47 United States wives cope in New Guinea jungle 47 News Analysis Leslie Gelb assesses problems facing Shultz 1

title: Molly McDonald Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward McDonald of Milton and North Scituate, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Molly Blair McDonald, to David Preston Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Jackson of Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: WHAT CECIL COOPER CAN DO
description: ABEER might have made Milwaukee famous, but Milwaukee hasn't made Cecil Cooper famous. ''My last six years or so are almost identical to Steve Garvey,'' C ooper said the other day. ''But most people don't realize I'm in t hat class.''

title: Coach Alters Cosmos Lineup
description: The Cosmos have 13 victories in 16 games, their best record halfway through the regular season since 1978. They lead the North American Soccer League in victories and in points. They have won nine of their last 10 games. But they have not convinced their coach how strong they are.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF SHULTZ'S REMARKS AFTER MEETING WITH REAGAN
description: Following is a transcript of a statement that Secretary of State-designate George P. Shultz made today at the Pentagon, as recorded by The New York Times with the assistance of Cable News Network.

title: DESPITE WAR, DAMASCUS SEEMS RELAXED
description: Damascus does not have the look of a capital at war. The streets are clogged with honking cars, truck and buses. Construction continues on a large new suburb west of the city. In the souk, the covered old market, fine gold ringlets and chains glitter in the jewelers' shops, and the scent of oriental spice hangs over the narrow passages.

title: 2D AUTOPSY ON HANGED ATHLETE IS INCONCLUSIVE
description: Four forensic pathologists who performed a second autopsy on the body of Ron Settles, a California college football star who was found hanged in a jail cell a year ago, said today that they were unable to agree on the cause of his death.

title: HINCKLEY'S INSANITY PLEA AND 'CONVOLUTED' JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT IS A POLITICAL CONVENTION WITHOUT AN ANTI-CONVENTION
description: The convention came alive early this morning with hugs and euphoric shouts and finger-popping litanies. ''Are we scared?'' ''No!'' hundreds of delegates shouted. ''Are we Republicans?'' ''No!'' ''This is the Democratic Party. Am I right?'' In truth, it was the convening of the Acorn Party, the nationwide movement of the poor and working poor gathered three blocks from the Democratic conference to complain that the Democrats give only lip service to the neediest.

title: INDIVIDUAL TAXPAYERS BEAR RISING BURDEN OF RECESSION
description: Along with all the other miseries of the recession, people who live in the states hit worst by it are also paying for the economic slump in another way: through higher personal taxes.

title: TED HOOD, THE COMPLETE SAILOR
description: Ted Hood peered down the beam of a flashlight into the open aft end of the new boom he had just fit on Nirvana, the 81-foot maxiyacht that earlier in the week had sliced more than five hours off the Newport-to-Bermuda race record. Now, the fleet, with colorful signal-code flags flying from the rigging, had filled the docks at the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club for a couple of days of festivities before returning home.

title: On Protection From Eviction
description: The article by Kenneth J. Gould entitled ''Case for Landlords on Conversions'' (Opinion Page, May 23) contains an inaccurate statement that might tend to mislead your readers. That is that the elderly and handicapped may not be evicted in Westchester under an evictionconversion plan.

title: MOVIES AND POEMS
description: PASOLINI A Biography. By Enzo Siciliano. Translated by John Shepley. Illustrated. 435 pp. New York: Random House. $20. POEMS By Pier Paolo Pasolini. Selected and Translated by Norman MacAfee with Luciano Martinengo. Foreword by Enzo Siciliano. 231 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $10.50. Vintage. Paper, $5.95.

title: Parachuting Dogs
description: Fitted with a harness that hitched them to a parachutist, police dogs were hitting the silk at Fort Bragg, N.C. ''The Army is considering the feasibility of parachuting dogs with the 82d Airborne Division,'' the news report said in September 1981.

title: Lorraine M. Pirog Bride Of Christopher D. Starr
description: Lorraine Marie Pirog, a fashion model, was married yesterday to Christopher Daniel Starr, an account executive at Lally, McFarland & Pantello, a health-care advertising agency in New York. The Rev. John Catoir, director of the Christophers, performed the nondenominational ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L. I.

title:
Food;
PIES FOR THE FOURTH
description: Lee Thompson is a food columnist.

title: ALBANY HOUSES SPLIT ON MEASURES TO TIGHTEN P.S.C.
description: Steadily rising utility rates have led Democrats and Republicans in the Assembly and the Senate to try to either reshape the Public Service Commission or change the rules it operates under.

title: RUSSIANS UNVEIL MODERNIZED SPACE CONTROL CENTER
description: When a former French fighter pilot accompanied two Soviet astronauts into earth orbit this week and became the first Western European to fly in space, the Kremlin notched a small propaganda victory for a manned space program that has been lagging badly behind the spectacular missions mounted by the United States.

title: Child Hurt by Bomb in Spain
description: A 10-year-old boy was badly injured today when a bomb that was believed to have been planted by separatist guerrillas went off in the center of this Basque town, police sources said.

title: Mary McLean Lummis Wed
description: Mary McLean Lummis, daughter of Mrs. Sheila W. Lummis of Greenwich, Conn., and John M. Lummis of New York, was married yesterday to James Sedgwick Kernan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kernan Jr. of Whitesboro, N.Y. The Rev. Frederick Prevost performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in Whitesboro.

title: ELVIS COSTELLO--IS HE POP'S TOP?
description: Is Elvis Costello, the original angry young man of rock's new wave, going to turn out to be the Cole Porter of the 1980's? His most devoted admirers are convinced that he is exactly that - and Mr. Costello himself says that's just what he is aiming for. ''That kind of songwriting - Porter, Kern, Rodgers and Hart - is something I'm very fond of and aspire to,'' he admitted recently. ''When people ask me to name a great song, I mention something like 'Love for Sale' or 'Someone to Watch Over Me.' In the last 20 years or so, very few people have been up to that standard of lyric writing.''

title: Business Conditions; WINE SALES STAY STRONG
description: Recessions come and recessions go, but the sales of wine keep on flowing. Statistics from Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, the investment banking house, show that more than 541 million gallons of foreign and domestic vintages were sold in the United States last year, up 5.8 percent from a year earlier.

title: No Headline
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. FOOTNOTES The one new hard-cover fiction best seller, Robert A. Heinlein's ''Friday,'' moved to its present position in 12th place from its position as distant runner-up last week by increasing its sales 170 percent.

title: 'GENERALS FOR PEACE' PUSH CASE AT U.N.
description: In Cyprus, on his last post, Brig. Michael Harbottle first discovered that swords are best beaten into ploughshares.

title: FORMER COLLEAGUE AIDED U.S. IN TRAPPING EX-C.I.A. AGENT
description: Last July, Ernest R. Keiser, an urbane New York businessman with mysterious intelligence connections, approached the Justice Department with an unusual offer. He said he could help the Government capture Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent accused of illegally aiding Libyan terrorists.

title: A FRESH AIR CAMP STRESSES THE 'GREAT' IN OUTDOORS
description: Once across the George Washington Bridege, the sense of country is immediate. The vast panorama of lush foliage on the Palisades Parkway is a heartening sight, but for children of the Fresh Air Fund - many of them lacking much experience with grass or trees - the change takes some adjustment.

title: Kathleen Graber Married
description: Kathleen Graber, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Graber of Oshkosh, Wis., was married yesterday to Leo Gasienica, son of Mrs. Bertha Gasienica of Garfield, N.J., and the late Leon Gasienica. The Rev. Julien Mueller performed the ceremony in Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Saltaire, Fire Island, L.I.

title: VENICE
description: To the Editor:

title: LOOK FOR ME IN MY FILMS
description: SOMETHING LIKE AN AUTOBIOGRAPHY By Akira Kurosawa. Translated by Audie E. Bock. Illustrated. 205 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.

title: Teresa Taafe Elms Becomes the Bride On Coast of Robert Demarest Lindsay
description: Teresa Taafe Elms, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Alden Elms of Fullerton, Calif., was married in the First Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Robert Demarest Lindsay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Van Cleef Lindsay of New York and Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Michael D. Landreth performed the ceremony.

title: EGYPTIAN COMPANIES ARE REPORTEDLY CANELING DEALS WITH ISRAELIS
description: Egyptian companies have been canceling orders for Israeli goods in protest over Israel's invasion of Lebanon, according to Egyptian and foreign businessmen here.

title: CABLE TV TURNS HUNGRILY TO THE THEATRE
description: Given cable television's voracious appetite for fresh programming, it should come as no surprise that the new medium is turning to the theater for sustenance. Indeed, as feature films - cable's standard fare - become less exclusive and more costly, spirited bidding is currently underway for almost every theatrical production that ever saw a footlight. Recent Broadway plays and musicals, classics by authors such as Eugene O'Neill and Clifford Odets, regional theater productions, even works by unknown playwrights are now being eagerly sought by cable programmers.

title: Anne Schwartz Becomes a Bride
description: Anne Margaret Schwartz, associate editor of Garden, a magazine of the New York Botanical Garden, and Daniel Levitan, a composer and percussionist, were married yesterday. Judge Judith A. Hillery of the Dutchess County Family Court performed the ceremony in the Cary Arboretum in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: TYRANNY AND LOVE
description: THE FROG WHO DARED TO CROAK By Richard Sennett. 182 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95.

title: MILLICENT FENWICK: MARCHING TO HER OWN DRUM
description: William E. Geist is a reporter on The Times's metropolitan staff.

title: '83 Wimbledon Open to Borg
description: The Men's International Professional Tennis Council has adopted a new format for the 1983 Volvo Grand Prix that will allow Bjorn Borg to compete at Wimbledon, no matter how many tournaments he plays during the year.

title: Headliners; Britain's Heir
description: Britons expected much from Lady Diana Spencer when she wed Prince Charles to become The Princess of Wales 11 months ago.

title: A Nameless Crime
description: An ancient crime has crept to a new prominence in the United States. Its victims are only the best or most eminent, those whose fall can jar the edifice of the state.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: IN RESPONSE to what it called ''repeated attacks'' on New Jersey's efforts to raise money to protect wildlife, an animal-welfare group in Fair Lawn has criticized the Friends of Animals of Neptune, another such organization.

title: Susan Foster Is Wed to David Swensen
description: Susan Candler Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H.W. Foster of Needham, Mass., and Palo Alto, Calif., was married yesterday to David Frederick Swensen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard David Swensen of River Falls, Wis. The Rev. Dr. William B. Heuss performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Wellesley, Mass.

title: DOCTOROW BAND WEAVES A TEXTURAL SPELL
description: LISTEN as summer breezes whisper through rippling leaves. Raindrops patter softly against uneven surfaces. Tires hiss along the road. The breeze quickens, the sky darkens; deep, rumbling thunder shatters the calm. An oncoming train whines shrilly its faint clackety-clack, building to a deafening throb as it whooshes by, and slowly fades from view.

title: Miss Markoe, C.W. Simone Are Married
description: Andree Sutherland Markoe, daughter of Frank Markoe Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., and Margaret McCormack Anderson of Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Charles Winston Simone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Simone of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Lyford Cay, Nassau. The Rev. Dr. Hays Rockwell officiated at the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in New York.

title: RACE TRACK TAKES COURT TURN
description: THE prospective purchasers of the 520-acre Bridgehampton Race Circuit are seeking a trial in New York State Supreme Court this summer to resolve the problems surrounding the property's sale.

title: Death-Penalty Foe Is Taken to Task Unlike Albert G. Besser (Opinion Page, June 6).
description: I, like many others, am all for Governor Kean's making good his campaign promise to reinstate capital punishment.

title: CUPECOY'S JOY RUNS SECOND
description: The important part of the race was over. Cupecoy's Joy and the improbable dream of her winning the filly triple crown had faltered at the top of the stretch, and the big gray filly named Christmas Past was drawing off to a devastating six-length victory in the Coaching Club American Oaks. It was then that Cupecoy's Joy showed the class and heart of a champion.

title: LIFE IN LOS ANGELES: IT GOES ON GLOOMILY FOR THOSE DISILLUSIONED BY JUNE
description: The first wave of summer tourists has arrived in Los Angeles, and so has the June Gloom. As they do every year about this time, tourists are strolling along Hollywood Boulevard, exploring Disneyland down in the Orange County hinterlands and wondering what happened to southern California's vaunted sun. The natives know: It's gone into hiding, probably until July.

title: BRITISH REPORTERS ASSAIL FALKLAND CENSORSHIP
description: Three British correspondents who covered the Falkland Islands war said today that British censorship had been frustrating, and one called it ''stupid.''

title: The Making of A Doctor
description: As a medical student, I was fascinated by David Black's account of Aaron Kenigsberg's third-year rotations (''The Making of a Doctor,'' May 23 and May 30). I was especially pleased to see the caring and the kindness of clinical faculty members noticed and spoken of.

title: FURTHER VIEWS ON EVACUATION PLAN
description: Like medieval theologians disputing how many angels could dance on the head of a pin, the politicians, corporate bigwigs and engineers discuss Shoreham evacuation plans. The simple truth that overhangs all this solemn nonsense is that if any of them really believed in the eventualities they are discussing, there would be no Shoreham plant.

title: Postings; Museum Adrift; Goodbye to the Boathouse
description: For six years, the National Maritime Historical Society has made its home in the Fulton Fireboat House on the Brooklyn shore. The fireboat house is a small, white clapboarded building with a lighthouse-like tower that stands in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, not far from the River Cafe.

title: Stephen Wohlgemuth Marries Holly S. Puritz
description: Holly Suzanne Puritz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Puritz of Lakewood, N.J., was married there yesterday to Stephen David Wohlgemuth, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul R. Wohlgemuth of Waterbury, Conn., Rabbi Stanley Yedwab performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Ann in Lakewood.

title: NASA IS HOPEFUL ON LIFTOFF
description: A dark thunderstorm, punctuated by lightning and hail, struck the Kennedy Space Center late today and caused some damage to the space shuttle Columbia. Repairs were being made overnight, and space officials still expected the mission to be launched on schedule Sunday morning.

title: Prospects
description: Dampers on Tax Cuts

title: QUESTIONING CONVENTIONAL WISDOM
description: New York Republicans had an unusually tumultuous state committee meeting to designate candidates for statewide office. The Democratic meeting was unusually peaceful.

title: CHINESE STUDY CAPITALIST LESSONS
description: DALIAN, China AGIANT statue of Chairman Mao Zedong dominates the entrance of the Dalian Institute of Technology, and his quotations, along with those of Marx and Lenin, adorn the great stairwell inside like elegant graffiti.

title: Around the Nation; Bank in Arkansas Town Ordered Closed by State
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today began paying the depositors of the Citizens Bank, which was closed because it had insufficient capital.

title: Postings; In Mamaroneck; A 'Pet Rock'
description: For years, developers had found themselves between a rock and a hard place when it came to one of Mamaroneck's choice locations. The site directly opposite the railroad station had been considered ''undevelopable'' because of an eight-foot-high rock outcrop there.

title: Jennifer Lynn Knapp Married to Mark C. Beudert
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Manhattan yesterday Jennifer Lynn Knapp, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Charles L. Knapp of New York, was married to Mark Christopher Beudert, son of Hubert Beudert of Birmingham, Mich., and the late Margery Lozier Beudert. The Rev. John Macnab performed the ceremony.

title: All Else Failing, Argentina Turns To Politicians
description: The Argentine military used to defend its hold on power by recalling civilian politicians' bickering and legacy of instability. In the aftermath of the Falkland debacle, the tables have turned.

title: FINDING THE WAY TO THE HEART OF CHILDHOOD
description: Television isn't all bad. Among its other public services is the manufacture of a lot of regular comedy shows featuring the sort of wisecracking monster-children who, otherwise, might be turning up in theatrical films. There's no need to mention the shows. You know which ones they are, and I don't want to be in the position of knocking some worried, highly-strung, prematurely aged 10-year-old who is his family's sole means of support.

title: POLITICS AND MUSIC
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNTY G.O.P. SALLIES IN WAKE OF DEBELLO
description: WHITE PLAINS SOON after Alfred B. DelBello awoke last Wednesday morning in his northern Westchester home, he told a caller, ''I feel a little worn out. I'm trying to sort things out, but I feel good.''

description: William Safire 9 On Language Miss Word of 1982 Russell Baker 12 Sunday Observer The Check Is in the Mail Leslie H. Gelb 17 Nuclear Bargaining: The President's Options William E. Geist 20 Millicent Fenwick: Marching to Her Own Drum In her campaign to become a Senator from New Jersey, the 72-year-old, pipe-smoking millionaire speaks with a startling candor that her supporters find charming. Critics question how much substance there is behind her political style. As for her, she thinks the Senate ''would be a bully pulpit, wouldn't it, my dear?'' title: DECISION NEARS ON L.I.R.R. FARE INCREASE
description: IT began last month with the normal rumblings all too familiar to Long Island residents: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority was faced with huge deficits, and it looked as though another rise in subway, bus and railroad fares was in the cards.

title: BACKLOG OF CASES SPURS CHANGE FOR STATE COURTS
description: MORE criminals have been brought to trial in recent years, more individuals are suing the Government and each other and more lawyers have set up shop to help them. But the number of courts in Connecticut is not keeping up. The result is longer waits for trial, and several proposals for changing the legal system to accommodate the crush.

title: Sally W. Harrison Is Bride Of Harry Allan Jacobs 3d

The Rev. Owen Speaker, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Harrison home.

description: Medical schools will better guarantee the preparation of ethical physicians if they expect a strong liberal-arts, rather than emphatically scientific, undergraduate education of their students.

description: Barbara Ann Larsen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Aubrey A. Larsen of Evansville, Ind., was married yesterday to Bryan R. Dunn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Dunn of Wayne, N.J. The Rev. John Rollins performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Pompton Lakes, N.J.

description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freeelance writer based in Los Angeles. BY STEPHEN FARBER LOS ANGELES

title: The Better to Battle Hanoi
description: It was all hugs and smiles last week as three unlikely allies formed a Cambodian government-in-exile to fight a common foe, Vietnam.

title: A Future for Gene Screening
description: A medical examination called genetic screening, used to help determine susceptibility to some diseases, appears to be rapidly gaining ground in the workplace.

title: Opinion Writer Replies To 2 Critical Letters
description: Lee Marotta's ad hominem attack on me and my family (letter of June 6 in reply to Alan Jay Weiss's Opinion Page article of May 30) is to be expected in Union City.
