description: Prompted by the verdict in the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr., five members of the Illinois House introduced a resolution today calling on Congress to enact a law, similar to one used in Illinois, that permits a verdict of ''guilty but mentally ill.''

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: school nights, the P.T.A., the 5 A.M. weather reports on January mornings - all because he wants to retire in three days.

title: Gail Ruth Gremse Is Married to David Semel Rose
description: Gail Ruth Gremse, daughter of Mrs. Edward Lance Gremse of New York and the late Mr. Gremse, was married yesterday to David Semel Rose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Rose of New York and East Hampton, L.I. Rabbi Martin J. Zion performed the ceremony at Fraunces Tavern.

title: Michelle C. Sutter Becomes a Bride
description: Michelle Cynthia Sutter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford S. Sutter of Osterville, Mass., formerly of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Stephen Bogardus, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Bogardus Jr. of Greenwich. The Rev. W. Raymond Webster 2d performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville.

title: ON THE BUTTON
description: Scenes of the French Revolution under glass. A painted portrait of Julius Caesar. Tick-tack-toe on a blackboard. An Art Deco plastic coffee service. And an adorable, if obese ivory walrus.

title: STATE LAGS ON FOOD GIVEAWAY
description: TRENTON THE Federal Government's giveaway of millions of pounds of processed American cheese - and now butter, too - has been stalled in New Jersey for nearly four months because the Kean administration has not figured out how to distribute the free food.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: WHEN the Main Street Theater closed its doors last March after the first of the season's four scheduled performances, the board of directors decided not to dissolve the financially strapped theater but to make an attempt to rescue it.

title: Elizabeth Alexander Harrison Is Wed To Nicholas Hadley, Ph.D. Candidate
description: Elizabeth Alexander Harrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Harold Harrison of Andover, Mass., was married yesterday to Nicholas John Hadley, son of Arthur Twining Hadley 2d of New York and West Tisbury, Mass., and Mrs. Francis Fitz Randolph of New York and Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Philip Zaeder performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Cochran Chapel at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.

title: Jolinda Menendez Becomes a Bride
description: Jolinda Menendez, a principal ballerina with the Pennsylvania Ballet, was married yesterday to Patrick Bissell, a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: HARD CHOICES LOOM FOR L.I. DISTRICTS
description: LEVITTOWN IF they want to spend more money on education, school officials here and in nearly a dozen other school districts on the Island are faced with the prospect of seeking higher property taxes or making further budget cuts in the wake of last week's ruling by the state's highest court upholding the state's current system of financing public education.

title: CHARLES PRATT'S VIEW OF NATURE; WASHINGTON, D.C.
description: Fate is just as fickle, and fashion just as fleeting, in photography as in everything else. Lately a great deal of effort has been spent dusting off forgotten or overlooked photographers from earlier eras and burnishing them with fresh appreciation; at the same time, however, certain more recent reputations have lapsed into obscurity. Since memory is selective, the reasons for these lapses tell us as much about the state of the medium as do the current fashions.

title: Janet Garlough, 60, Director Of Sales to Women for T.W.A.
description: Janet Garlough, an executive with Trans World Airlines for almost 40 years, died Thursday of cancer.

title: YUGOSLAVS URGED TO END DIVISIONS
description: Yugoslavia's Communist Party opened its 12th congress here today with the focus on the country's serious economic difficulties and the factionalism that has undermined the unity of Yugoslavia's six republics.

title: ANOTHER MUSTO MAY RUN
description: UNION CITY ''WE WANT Rhyta! We want Rhyta!'' the crowd at the Italian Community Center shouted during victory celebrations last week for Nicholas J. LaRocca, the 69-year-old lawyer who has replaced William V. Musto as State Senator from the 33d Legislative District.

title: DIGITAL DISKS BURNISH CHAMBER MUSIC
description: During the past few years, the advantages of digital recording have been exploited by a number of firms. In many cases, they have been passed along to the consumer in audiophile albums devoted to splashy orchestral showpieces. A few enterprising labels, Telarc and Delos are two, have also made imposing recordings of solo literature, particularly that for the piano. The piano is one of the most difficult instruments to record faithfully by conventional means because of its frequency range, dynamic range and the strength of its transients: For the same reasons it is an ideal challenge for the digital method.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: History Lesson Corridos are Mexican-American ballads. One is about Gregorio Cortez, a ranch hand and tenant farmer who became a folk hero.

title: Unmitigated Disbarment
description: Last year, Nassau County Republican leader Joseph Margiotta was found to have broken the law.

title: 'COSI' AS FLAWLESS THEATER
description: ST. LOUIS It remains to be proved whether Jonathan Miller is, or can become, the best opera director in the world. It is already apparent, however, that nobody is thinking more clearly or talking more intelligently about the formidable problems facing anyone who sets out to stage a familiar operatic masterpiece for a modern audience. Moreover, his American debut the other day as director of ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' in St. Louis proved that the intellectually restless Englishman knows how to put his theories to work. This ''Cosi'' turned out to be a remarkably logical and thoughtful version of Mozart's most misunderstood comedy. In fact, a more intellectually provocative and internally consistent ''Cosi'' you are not likely to come across in a lifetime of opera-going.

title: CLASS AND WELFARE IN THE UNITED STATES
description: THE UNDERCLASS By Ken Auletta. 348 pp. New York: Random House. $17.50.

title: ART NOT ONLY FOR 'CAR NUTS'
description: LAKEVILLE THERE won't be the whine of turbo-charged engines, the smell of burning rubber or the feel of hot asphalt under the foot. But scores of auto racing fans are expected to gather indoors next weekend for the fourth annual Auto Art Exhibition and Sale, to be held at the Interlaken Inn in Lakeville from Friday through July 6.

title: VIOLENCE TERMED HARD TO FORETELL
description: Many prominent members of the mental health professions do not believe that reliable predictions can be made about whether John W. Hinckley Jr. might commit further acts of violence in years to come.

title: Travel Advisory:; TAHITIAN CANOES, ORIENT EXPRESSES; Keeping Track Of Two Trains In Europe
description: Once upon a time, there was a romantic train called the Orient Express. Then, to great lamentation, the Orient Express was no more. But later the Orient Express returned as a nostalgia trip. And now nostalgia has spawned another Orient Express.

title: THE HINCKLEY TRAVESTY
description: On March 30, 1981, hundreds of millions of television viewers throughout the world saw John W. Hinckley Jr. crouch in front of the Washington Hilton Hotel, take deliberate aim at the President of the United States, lodge a bullet within inches of his heart, and shoot down three innocent bystanders.

title: PATERNITY LEAVE GAINING GROUND
description: NEW personnel policies in New Jersey's private and public sectors are letting men take unpaid paternity leaves, trading briefcases for diaper bags without the fear of losing their jobs. Such leaves range from a few weeks to two years.

title: Other Business; GOSPEL MUSIC ON THE ASCENT
description: The marquee four doors away offers a live nude revue for a quarter. A man on the street outside peddles ''loose joints.'' But in the sanctity of the Christian Publications Book Store near Times Square, gospel records are the hot items. About 1,000 are sold each month, the store manager, Gary Gin, says.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH ONE-TERM PRESIDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA FRUIT FLIES SPRAYED
description: The discovery of a single Mediterranean fruit fly in the San Joaquin Valley brought airplanes spraying malathion today over nine square miles to stop a potential threat to California's $14 billion agriculture industry.

title: Israeli Food
description: To the Editor: In the article ''Stuffed Vegetables, Israeli Style'' (Travel, May 30), Jane Friedman writes, ''Visitors expect to find gefilte fish, kishkes and other European Jewish favorites ...'' I don't believe that visitors are looking for ''kishkes,'' which means internal organs or intestines. They are looking for ''kishke,'' which is a thoroughly cleaned intestine or in more recent times a plastic casing stuffed with a mixture of cooked grain, fat, onions and various spices. Kishke could be put in a class of food related to haggis. DONALD M. KIRSCHENBAUM Brooklyn

title: BARANELLO'S TURN
description: election as Democratic state chairman - if Mayor Koch is the Democratic gubernatorial nominee.

title: Catherine T. Matthews, J.J. Pietrafesa 2d Wed
description: Catherine Therese Matthews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Vincent Matthews of Swarthmore, Pa., was married yesterday to Joseph John Pietrafesa 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Pietrafesa of Syracuse and North Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. William J. O'Halloran, director of corporate affairs at Holy Cross College and former president of LeMoyne College in Syracuse, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Cathedral Basilica of SS.

title: THE MAKING OF A DOCTOR
description: The clinical clerk's concern should not be gallivanting around the hospital in search of ''action.''

title: Around the Nation; Hunters Kill 7 Raccoons After Attacks on Cranes
description: Hunters with dogs and shotguns who patroled the grounds of the International Crane Foundation overnight killed seven raccoons.

title: JOB PROGRAM CUTTING COSTS OF WELFARE
description: Street life, with its empty hours and lure of drugs, had been Thomas Standke's world for years. What he needed, he says now, was an opportunity to turn his ''negative energy into positive energy.''

title: Cathleen Bacich, Charles Stewart Wed
description: Cathleen Anne Bacich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Bacich of Brookfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles Evan Stewart, son of Jenifer B. Stewart of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Charles T. Stewart of New York. The Rev. Ronald Lafferty performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: LUNDHURST OFFERING AMBITIOUS PROGRAM
description: LYNDHURST, the former Jay Gould estate in Tarrytown and now a property of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, has been having serious financial problems. The building was closed altogether for a time and now is open for public visits only on Sundays. The Lyndhurst concerts, however, are gearing up for their 12th anniversary season with high hopes and splendid programs.

title: JAZZ EVENTS
description: Following is a schedule of today's Jazz Festival events: 1-9. Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J. Picnic with John's Other Bunch, Cayenne Jazz Band, Doc Cheatham's All-Stars, Lew Green's Jazz Band, Harlem Blues and Jazz Band, Benny Venturas's New York Jazz, Bob Wilber's Bechet Legacy with Butch Miles and the Tri-State McDonald's High School Jazz Ensemble. Featuring Eddie Davis, Kenny Davern, Eddie Durham, Chuck Folds, Jack Gale, Herb Gardner, Al Hall, Scott Hamilton, Connie Day, George Kelly, George Masso, Linc Millman, Michael Moore, Marty Napoleon, Ronnie Traxler, Warren Vache, Dick Wellstood, Jackie Williams, Glen Zottola, Peter Dean, Adam Makowicz, Bucky Pizzarelli, John Pizzarelli, Dick Sudhalter and Buddy Weed. $10 ($5 for those younger than 12). 2-11. Center for the Arts, State University College at Purchase. ''Jazzfare II,'' with the Gerry Mulligan Quartet; Sonny Stitt Group; Nat Adderley Quintet,Jimmy Cobb, Walter Booker, Sonny Fortune and Larry Willis; Roy Haynes Ensemble; Tania Maria Trio; Janet Lawson Quintet; Dave Burrell Sextet; Dewey Redman and Lou Donaldson Quartets; Dick Hyman-Roger Kellaway Duo; Ted Curson; Ernie Royal; Joe Newman; Hugh Lawson; Jukkis Uotila and Harvie Swartz; Teddy Charles-Teo Macero Group; World Bass Violin Ensemble; the Vibration Society; Clark College Jazz Orchestra; Paul Motian Band; Carrie Smith with Andre Franklin and Al Hall; Earl Coleman with Harris Simon, Brooks Kerr, Bill Kirchner, Barbara Lea and Larry Carr; J.R. title: Around the World; Mauritius to Seek Return of Archipelago
description: The newly elected leftist Government of Mauritius announced plans Friday to wage a diplomatic campaign for the return of the Chagos Archipelago, which includes the American military base at Diego Garcia.

title: A CLOSER LOOK AT SOVIET SOLDIERS AND THEIR ARMY
description: To the Editor:

title: FANNING THE SPARK OF CREATIVITY
description: ART, a universal language, has no specific form, line or color. It stimulates the mind and nourishes the soul. And it is not just the appreciation of art that is universal, for a spark of creativity lies within everyone.

title: PITY NEAR-HINCKLEY'S
description: Let's put aside legal consideration of insanity for a moment and look at the irrational side of life upon which many of us sometimes walk.

title: EARPHONES VS. SPEAKERS
description: Just to ease my conscience about being unable to answer all the letters addressed to this column, let me pick a few questions for public reply. Q. Why is it that when I listen through earphones the music always sounds brighter than when I listen through speakers?

title: BATTERED BEIRUT BURYING ITS DEAD AS LATEST TRUCE APPEARS TO HOLD
description: As the latest cease-fire appeared to be holding, this bloodied and battered city today began burying the victims of Friday's fierce Israeli strikes.

title: RATIFICATION DEFEAT LEAVES RIGHTS LAW ON UNEVEN PATH
description: Faced with this Wednesday's deadline for ratification, the proposed equal rights amendment went down to certain defeat last week as it was rejected by the Illinois House and the Florida Senate, the two states in which supporters felt it had the best last chance. Thirty-five states have ratified; three more are needed.

title: IT'S A LONG WAY TO STAR WARS
description: The cargo bay of the space shuttle Columbia was loaded with secret Pentagon test equipment last week for the shuttle's fourth flight scheduled for today. This did not mean that an era of military exploitation of space had just dawned, however. It is already mid-morning.

title: Postings; After 55 Years; R.I.P. Abbey
description: It was the Abbey Victoria Hotel, then the Abbey and Victoria Hotels and, later, back again. In recent years it was simply the ''Shabby Abbey.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Steve Scott, the world's third-ranked miler behind Sebastian Coe and Steve Ovett of Britain, has been chosen to assist in coaching distance runners at Arizona State University. ... Eusebio Pedroza of Panama, the World Boxing Association featherweight champion, will defend his title against Bernard Taylor of Charlotte, N.C., at the Charlotte Coliseum Aug. 14. ... Larry Brown, the former running back for the Washington Redskins who was the National Football League's most valuable player in 1972, has been was ordered to pay $2 to a man he struck outside a bar three years ago. At a trial in Rockville, Md., the jury deliberated five hours before deciding that Brown was to award H. Selby Scaggs nothing. But the judge told the jury that there must be at least nominal damages, so Scaggs was awarded $1 in compensatory damages and $1 in punitive damages.

title: Miss Makepeace Wed to Minister
description: Mary Zelinda Makepeace and the Rev. Dr. John Douhan Jr. were married yesterday in the chapel of St. Gabriel's Episcopal Church in Marion, Mass. The Rev. Charles P. Scott, chaplain of Middlebury College and summer pastor of St. Gabriel's, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Dr. Roscoe Robison, executive minister of the American Baptist Churches of Massachusetts.

title: AT Last There's A Budget, but Who's Cheering?
description: ''The alternative,'' Slade Gorton, a Republican Senator from Washington, said last week, ''is chaos and disorganization that would have an extremely adverse impact on the economy.'' Clearly, enough of Congress agreed. With a marked lack of enthusiasm, both House and Senate approved the broad outlines of a plan for Government spending and taxing for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1.

title: ANOTHER FARE RISE SEEN IN JERSEY
description: Officials of New Jersey's masstransportation agency said today that they planned to hold public hearings to discuss fare increases of as much as 25 percent for trains and buses. Those increases, if approved, would be in addition to rises of 10 to 50 percent that become effective next week.

title: Geoffrey Nicholson Weds Miss Lutley
description: At All Saints Episcopal Church in Wynnewood, Pa., Elizabeth Theresa Lutley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Lutley of Newtown Square, Pa., was married yesterday to Geoffrey William Greer Nicholson, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Greer Nicholson of Ottawa. The Rev. John J. Albert performed the ceremony.

title: Assert Beats 9 Rivals In Irish Sweeps Derby
description: Assert, winner of the French Derby, outclassed nine other horses to win the 21st running of the Irish Sweeps Derby over 1 1/2 miles at the Curragh today.

title: GYPSY MOTHS RETREAT IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The gypsy moth population has dropped sharply this year in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, according to state and Federal forestry officials.

title: Both Parties Are Held Culpable on the Budget Assemblyman
description: Chuck Hardwick's Opinion Page article, ''What's Behind the Public Fight on the Budget?'' (June 13), implies that only the Democrats are guilty of posturing on the state budget. That is selfserving drivel.

title: DOUBLE-STANDARD FOR SELF-DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter of the Law
description: For 15 years, the private New Canaan Country School in Connecticut had run a summer program of cultural and athletic enrichment for inner-city children. In June 1980 the program, Horizons, ran afoul of the law after it had applied to the state for a food subsidy of $6,000.

title: Business Conditions; ASSETS TAKE A BEATING
description: With the rate of inflation declining and interest rates stuck at record levels, the past 12 months have been sorry ones for many traditional investments.

title: FANFARE IN LONDON'S PARKS
description: WILLLIAM BORDERS, deputy foreign editor of The Times, recently completed an assignment in the London bureau. By WILLIAM BORDERS

title: MEMORIES AND EXPECTATIONS OF GENEVA
description: THE process that used to be called the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks began in 1969 and will resume Tuesday under the acronym Start, for strategic arms reduction talks. The chief American negotiator in Geneva will be retired Lieut. Gen. Edward L. Rowny, who represented the Joint Chiefs of Staff at the SALT talks from 1973 to 1979 but resigned because he believed the SALT II treaty would leave the United States strategically inferior to the Soviet Union.

title: KOCH, AT DEMOCRATIC CONFERENCE, ASSAILS LOSS OF FEDERAL AID TO CITY
description: Mayor Koch joined the critics of the Reagan Administration at the Democratic national party conference today, charging that New York City had lost $2 billion in Federal aid in the last two years.

title: What's Doing in Ottawa
description: In its role as the capital of Canada and a city whose major activity is government, Ottawa tries, and largely succeeds, in being a national showplace, presenting as attractive a face as possible to the considerable number of visitors who come each year -once the harsh winter is past.

title: Steel's Plight
description: To the Business Editor: Your article ''The Year the Bottom Fell Out of Steel'' (June 20), accurately describes the current troubles of the steel industry. However, there was no mention of a major cause of today's troubles for steel: the strong dollar.

title: Lesley E. Barth Is Bride
description: Lesley Elizabeth Barth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Barth of Mount Kisco, N.Y., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Hugh McKay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh McKay of Maplewood, N.J. The Rev. Stephen Bolle performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Charlene Curson, Teacher, Wed to Michael Trotman
description: Charlene Curson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Curson of Jersey City, was married yesterday to Michael J. Trotman, son of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Trotman of New Brunswick, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Leonard Bethel, a Baptist minister and professor of African studies at Rutgers University, performed the ceremony in the Voorhees Chapel on the campus of Douglass College in New Brunswick.

title: BANNERS/BIRDS/BUSES; The Late Tex
description: ''When I talk about Tex, I hope I don't sound like a screwball,'' George Archibald, the director of the International Crane Foundation, said of his extraordinary efforts to induce the whooping crane, who mistook him for her mate, to breed.

title: Hogan Wins Title
description: Marty Hogan of San Diego won his fifth consecutive national professional racquetball title today, defeating Dave Peck of El Paso, Tex., for the $25,000 top prize. The scores were 11-9, 6-11, 11-5, 11-4.

title: Miss Morton, John Barton Are Married
description: Pamela Mary Morton, daughter of the Very Rev. and Mrs. James Park Morton of New York, was married yesterday to John Whipple Barton, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Maxwell Barton of Espanola, N.M. Canon Edward N. West performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where the bride's father is dean; he gave a blessing.

title: CAROLYN KIMBALL DEBUT
description: Carolyn Kimball, a soprano from New Jersey now living in Mexico City, sang her first New York solo recital in Alice Tully Hall Monday night. Jan Holmquist, her husband, accompanied at the piano.

title: WHEN PUBLIC TV EXCELS
description: The premiere season of public television's ''American Playhouse,'' broadcast Tuesdays at 9 P.M. on WNET/Channel 13, began Jan. 12 with the late John Cheever's ''The Shady Hill Kidnapping,'' a survey of the foibles of modern suburbia. It concludes this week with Victor Villasenor's ''The Ballad of Gregorio Cortez,'' a true turn-of-thecentury story of a young Mexican-American cowhand pursued, captured and tried for the shooting of an ''Anglo'' sheriff. The series has been uneven, but during a year in which the public-television picture has seemingly been monopolized by old movies and still another British blockbuster, ''Brideshead Revisited,'' the ''American Playhouse'' project has provided the system with at least one badly needed source of pride and, equally important, hope.

title: Civil Suits Stop at the Oval Office
description: You can fight city hall and a host of state and local officials on civil rights matters in Federal court, the Supreme Court held last week in a 7-to-2 decision. But in a separate, closely fought case, the Court drew the line at civil suits involving the President of the United States. Voting 5 to 4, the Court said no President can be sued for damages for official actions he takes while in office.

title: 'TORCH SONG TRILOGY'--SELF-MOCKERY AS A SHIELD
description: One way or another I happened to miss Harvey Fierstein's ''Torch Song Trilogy'' when it made its formal debut Off Broadway, but its downtown reception was warm enough to encourage its move to 44th Street's Little Theater. Seeing it now at the Little, watching author Fierstein play his own garish and garrulous drag queen, listening to an audience response that is both ardent and indiscriminate, I wonder if two things may have happened to the four-hour piece between its first and its second openings. One has to do with the special nature, both preening and self-mocking, of Mr. Fierstein's performance. The other has to do with the trigger-quick quality of that laughter.

title: FROM THE OPERA TO RISOTTO
description: Tourist Offices Milan is the gateway to Northern Italy, with direct air service from New York and major European cities. The city's byword is efficiency, and this truly applies to the Ente Provinciale per il Turismo. The Tourist Office headquarters is at Via Marconi 1 (at the corner of Piazza del Duomo), where a large, ground-floor counter is staffed by informed employees. The E.P.T. has other offices at the Central Railroad Station and, during the tourist season (April-September), on the main highway approaches to the city. At any of these offices, you should ask for the free booklet ''Tutta Milano'' (available in English), which contains telephone numbers (consulates, banks, shops, restaurants), a schematic history of the city and information about the main sights. The E.P.T. also publishes a schedule of museum opening and closing times, a list of hotels with prices and amenities, and other free publications. The Comune di Milano, the city government, also has an office for the public in the Galleria, at the Scala end (around the corner from Algani's newsstand, which has the best selection of foreign newspapers). This office is chiefly for the Milanese, who have to grapple with the city's bureaucracy; but for the foreign visitor it provides information about what's going on in the theaters.

title: TEACHERS TRIP THE COLOR LINE
description: To most people, school desegregation means shifting around black and white children. Another, less publicized aspect of school desegregation has also been at issue, however - the racial balance of teaching staffs. To have students exposed almost entirely to teachers of only one color is seen by many critics as another form of racial isolation.

title: New Report on Dailey
description: Quintin Dailey, the University of San Francisco basketball player who was sentenced to three years probation on Friday on charges of assaulting a nursing student last December, may have more problems. The San Francisco Chronicle reported yesterday that Dailey had received $1,000 per month from the Electrical Supply Company in Salinas, Calif., for a summer job, but that it was not necessary for him to report to work.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC Marshall Crenshaw, who will be at the Bottom Line on Wednesday, has been compared to Buddy Holly so many times he must cringe at the merest mention of Mr. Holly's name. It's true that Mr. Crenshaw looks a little like Buddy Holly, with his black-rimmed glasses and open, freshly scrubbed face.

title: Personal Finance; HOW TO CUT LONG-DISTANCE PHONE BILLS
description: IN most American households, long-distance telephone calls have b ecome much more than an incidental expense. For those with relativesl iving in other states, friends scattered across the country or jobs t hat obligate them to an occasional interstate business call from t he home, monthly long-distance bills can range from $25 to more than$ 100.

title: HAIG MOVE CAUSES ANXIETY IN EUROPE
description: Many officials and commentators in Western Europe reacted with trepidation yesterday to the resignation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., whom they saw as their chief supporter and the leading moderate in the Reagan Administration.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: F.B.I. Programs a Computer Caper
description: A Federal undercover operation last week netted 19 businessmen on charges of high technology piracy, most of them officials at Hitachi Ltd. and Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, major Japanese computer companies. Eight were arrested in California.

title:
GARDENING;
TWO SELECTED AS ALL AMERICA ROSES
description: IT is the time of year again when the All America Rose selections committee makes its announcement of award-winning roses for 1983. Two roses made it to the winner's circle; Sun Flare, a bright yellow floribunda and Sweet Surrender, a pink hybrid tea.

title: Correction
description: An article in Travel on the Greek islands June 20 omitted the country and city codes from the telephone numbers for two chartering organizations. The Greek Yacht Brokers' and Consultants' Association can be reached in Athens at (301) 981-6582 or (301) 982-7107, the Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners' Association at (301) 452-6335.

title:
THEATER IN REVIEW;
THRILLING 'DIVINERS' IN ROCKLAND AND SCI-FI IN NEWARK
description: STONY POINT, N.Y. THE Penguin Repertory Company here is offering more than a touch of the poet in Joe Brancato's thrilling direction of ''The Diviners.'' There is the touch of genius, and nowhere is this clearer than in the play's penultimate scene.

title: Alison L. Smith Becomes a Bride
description: Alison Leigh Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Procter Smith Jr. of Montclair, N.J., and West Chop, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., was married yesterday to Jonathon Parker Hitesman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wood Hitesman of Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard. The ceremony was performed at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown by the Rev. John A. Greely, the rector, and the Rev. Arthur Hargate, rector emeritus of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford.

title: DEMOCRATIC PARLEY LETS HOPEFULS SHOW CHARMS
description: The serious business of the Democrats' national party conference here, as measured by money and energy expended, has turned out to be a beauty pageant of potential Presidential candidates.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THE people were marching down to the sea, to watch the animals crawling out of it. Clutching flashlights they had been instructed not to use, exclaiming as sneakers squished into salty muck, they made their way through the marsh on this humid, moonless night.

title:
Comment;
SUBWAY DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON has now jumped into the battle to block a deal between N ew York City and Canada for the sale of much needed subway cars. L ast week, the United States Government formally accused Canada of i llegally subsidizing the subway car sale, thereby promising a s lugging match with our most important trading partner. If New York i s not to be the victim, the traditional American approach to trade p olicy will have to be changed. It will no longer suffice to stop a g ood deal just because someone is hurt or put out of a job; the b enefits to others will have to be measured and weighed against the c osts.

title: Practical Traveler:; THE BOTTOM LINE ON CAR RENTALS
description: So many new policies, promotional offers and restrictions keep arising in the car-rental business that extra-careful attention is needed to sort the worthwhile from the chaff.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE American Cancer Society is seeking 1,400 volunteer researchers on the Island who will each enlist 10 more volunteers to complete questionnaires asking for approximately 500 bits of information concerning their life styles for its Cancer Prevention Study II.

title: Older Old-Timers At Fenway Park
description: To the Sports Editor: The old-timers game at Fenway Park this year was not the ''first ever.'' In George Vecsey's excellent columns on Ted Williams and Carl Yastrzemski, he said there had never been an old-timers game at Fenway (The New York Times, May 2 and May 3).

title: IT'S BERRY-PICKING TIME
description: THE recent floods reduced the supply of corn for dairy cows and the second winter of freezing temperatures killed off a substantial number of peach buds in the state, but the pick-it-yourself crops of small fruits appear to have suffered only marginally from the heavy rains.

title: VENICE
description: To the Editor: In doing research for an adaptation of the Johann Strauss operetta, ''A Night in Venice,'' I came across an amusing article by Mark Twain written in 1867, in which he displays the same awe and curiosity about the gondolier's art of maneuvering his craft as does MacDonald Harris in his recent article. At the risk of adding just one more ''fact'' to those which may already have besieged you about why gondolas are painted black, I quote Mr. Twain:$''The gondola is painted black because in the zenith of Venetian magnificence the gondolas became too gorgeous altogether, and the Senate decreed that all such display must cease, and a solemn unembellished black be substituted.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A RENOWNED COLLECTION TO BE SOLD
description: OLD LYME THE estate of one of New York's and New England's best-known gentleman-collectors and dealers will be sold at auction July 13 when the contents of Duck Creek, the home of the late J.A. Lloyd Hyde are offered by Christie's.

title: Haitian Detainee Dies
description: Solange Eliodor, a 26-year-old Haitian at the Krome Avenue Detention Facility for refugees, died today after she had had a long battle with tuberculosis, the Immigration and Naturalization Service reported today.

title: BOLD MAN OUT
description: AT 3 P.M. on Friday, President Reagan walked into the White House press room and announced, without further explanation, that he was changing Secretaries of State.

title: LOBBYING INTENSE ON STATE PENSION
description: UNIONS representing New York State employees are busy lobbying Albany lawmakers in an effort to allow certain legislation affecting their pension contributions to lapse on July 1.

title: MOODY SCENES FROM TONALISTS
description: NEW BRITAIN WHEN American Impressionism was enjoying a statewide reappraisal two years ago, there was no talk of Tonalism, a not unrelated style from roughly the same period, 1880 to 1915. Now, several of the artists represented in those shows as well as in the current display of Barbizon painting at the Lyme Historical Society in Old Lyme are being billed as Tonalists in a large lineup at the New Britain Museum of American Art.

title: DANCE: RETELLING MEDEA IN 'CAVE OF THE HEART'
description: Although Martha Graham's choreographic versions of Greek myths are often considered examples of psychological dance-drama, ''Cave of the Heart,'' her retelling of the story of Medea, contains virtually no psychological development whatsoever. At the curtain's rise, the characters have already become virtually everything they will ever be, and they are all monsters.

title:
In New Jersey;
BANKS TASTE THE BROKERAGE BUSINESS
description: A little over a year ago, Revere Savings & Loan in Bernardsville b ecame the first banking institution in the state to establish a r eal-estate brokerage subsidiary. Operating out of a second-floor o ffice in the bank's building, the subsidiary, Revere Services, has p osted approximately $2 million worth of home sales in Morris and S omerset Counties.

title: EXPOS DROP FOURTH IN A ROW
description: Tom Seaver allowed three hits over eight innings and an unusual two-error play that allowed Dan Driessen to score from first base gave the Cincinnati Reds a 2-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves tonight.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WHEN HALLEY'S COMET LAST SAILED INTO VIEW
description: SKY AND TELESCOPE, a magazine devoted to astronomy, carried a letter in its December 1981 issue from an observatory in Cologne, West Germany, asking for eyewitness reports from anyone alive today who saw Halley's comet in 1910.

title: Knight: Epitome Of a Good Coach
description: To the Sports Editor: I take great exception to George Vecsey's column (The New York Times, June 16) about Bobby Knight. I have know Coach Knight since I was 16 years old.

title: DEMOCRATS OFFER JOB PLAN FINANCED BY CAP ON TAX CUT
description: A $7.5 billion jobs program to rebuild the nation's public works won strong support today at a national conference of the Democratic Party. The plan would be financed by limiting the tax cuts scheduled for 1983.

title: ENERGY OBSCURES CHARM IN 'CARNIVAL'
description: PORT JEFFERSON ''CARNIVAL'' is a musical of considerable built-in charms. In Theater Three's misguided production, they're all locked in. The show is deceptive. It cries out for splashy showmanship and all-out production values. At the same time, it hugs you and wraps you up in warmth and intimacy.

title: Topics; Banners / Birds / Buses; New Glory
description: The President has a flag, Cabinet departments have flags and states have flags. So, asks Representative Austin Murphy of Pennsylvania, why not Congress?

title: Harald B. Findlay Marries Pamela Sherman Sperry
description: Pamela Sherman Sperry, daughter of Mrs. Mark Leavenworth Sperry 2d of Woodbury, Conn., was married there yesterday in St. George's Episcopal Church to Harald Beals Findlay, son of Mrs. E. Andrew Deeds of Charlotte, Vt., and David Findlay Jr. of New Canaan, Conn.

title: New York Medicine Academy Picks Chicagoan for Director
description: Dr. David R. McNutt, deputy commissioner of health of Chicago, has been appointed director of the New York Academy of Medicine. Dr. McNutt, who is 45 years old, will assume his duties on Sept. 1, Dr. Norbert S. Roberts, president of the academy, announced Friday. He replaces Dr. Marvin Lieberman, who has been acting director since the death last September of Dr. James E. McCormack.

title: U.S. DOCTORS DEBATE A-WAR ON SOVIET TV
description: The Soviet Union took the unusual step today of allowing three American doctors to join high-ranking Soviet physicians in a television panel discussion on nuclear war.

title: THE MAKING OF A DOCTOR
description: The assertions ''Today, doctors can cure people ... and what they can or will soon be able to do seems nearly unlimited ...'' are romantic and dangerous oversimplifications. Clearly, medical progress has been enormous and, as a doctor, I'm grateful for its marvels daily.

title: THE MAN WHO PUT JAZZ IN THE MONEY
description: GEORGE WEIN is a peripatetic deal maker, an old-fashioned e ntrepreneur who does not deal with venture capitalists or resort to a pocket calculator to drive a hard bargain. He is widely respected f or keeping his word in an industry known for shifting u nderstandings, and by most accounts, he plays the negotiating table a t least as skillfully as his piano.

title: If you're thinking of living in:; NEW MILFORD
description: IN 1882, as he was chronicling the first 170 years of New Milford's history, Samuel Orcutt could not resist adding a bit of chest-puffing to hiss cholarship. Having seen New Milford become ''in some mercantile r espects the center for the whole county,'' he wrote, ''it merits p articular consideration as to the causes of its growth and p rosperity.''

title: THE MAKING OF A DOCTOR
description: As a classmate of Aaron Kenigsberg's, I was distressed with what I felt to be its overly positive presentation of medical education. Dr. David Livingston's statement that ''a third year student is like a 2-year-old ... (he) knows nothing'' bespeaks a problem that the medical establishment continues to ignore. During the first two ''basic science'' years of medical school, medical students are completely divorced from the clinical setting.

title: The Spoiled Broth of Foreign Policy
description: There has not been a moment's peace in 18 months in the Reagan foreign-policy kitchen. The public heard all along about the tantrums of the chef, Alexander Haig, the rival concoctions of the crew at the Pentagon, the sabotage of the soup by the White House stewards. Personalities aside, the reckless feuding was said to be normal; the modern world simply looks different to diplomats than to soldiers, and still more different to their political bosses. Sooner or later, the President would set his course and, like Kennedy or Nixon, assert it from the top, or like Truman, Eisenhower and Ford, yield enormous power to his Secretary of State.

title: Shopper's World; 'FINDS' IN CAIRO, WITH NO HAGGLING
description: WILLIAM E. FARRELL is chief of the Cairo bureau of The New York Times. By WILLIAM E.FARRELL

title: Victoria Bijur, Editor, Becomes Bride Of Edward Levine, Record Producer
description: Victoria Bijur, a daughter of Mrs. William Bijur of New York, and the late Mr. Bijur, was married yesterday to Edward Philip Levine, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morris Levine of Cedarhurst, L.I. West Tisbury Justice of the Peace John Alley performed the ceremony at the West Tisbury, Mass., home of the bride's mother.

title: Index; International
description: Reporter's notebook: Two faces of Argentina A2 Forty-three people die in wind storms in Brazil A3 Bitter cost of Falkland war comes home to Argentines A3 Salvador audit faults land redistribution program A3 3,000 Poles mark anniversary of 1956 Poznan rioting A4 Yugoslav's first priority is the economy A5 A coup attempt in Iran is reportedly thwarted A6 Arab foreign ministers fail to reach agreement A6 Around the World A7 Pravda says Haig was made a scapegoat A11 Government/Politics Study finds all-volunteer armed services racially imbalanced A12 Special prosecutor plans to issue Donovan findings A12 City says it will replenish dwindling Staten Island lake B1 Excerpts from Kennedy speech at Democratic Party parley B6 Women's issues are in forefront at Democratic conference B7 Washington Talk Staff of House Armed Services panel has unusual power A13 Calendar A13 Briefing A13 Required Reading A13 General Around the Nation A12 Butte's love-hate relationship with copper pit is almost over A12 At least 2 killed as small plane crashes in L.I. Sound B2 Mensa holds its annual international gathering B2 Jocularity and resolve mark homosexual-pride march B3 Doctors are divided in opinion of cause of athlete's death B9 SportsMonday Baseball: Yanks send Righetti to Columbus for special coaching C1

title: ANTIQUE DEALER 63, FOUND SLAIN IN BEDROOM OF GREAT NECK HOME
description: A 63-year-old Long Island antique dealer was found shot to death yesterday morning in his Great Neck home, the Nassau County police reported.

title: Dutch Queen Stops at Albany
description: Queen Beatrix and Prince Claus of the Netherlands arrived here today to conclude their tour of the United States commemorating 200 years of uninterrupted diplomatic and trade relations between the two countries. Albany, a Dutch West Indies Company fur-trading settlement founded nearly 373 years ago, was once known as Fort Orange,

title: Goalby Winner
description: Bob Goalby survived tentative putting and a late rally by Gene Littler today to capture the $200,000 P.G.A. senior tournament at the St. Charles Country Club by a stroke.

title: GILDER WINS BY 5 SHOTS AT 261
description: Bob Gilder walked away with the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic today by a five-stroke margin.

title: INDEPENDENT FED IS SUPPORTED
description: Credit market participants are bracing themselves for what Donald E. Maude, chief financial economist of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, describes as ''potentially one of the most tumultuous periods in recent memory.''

title: TEXT OF ISRAELI PEACE PROPOSAL
description: Following is the text of Israel's peace plan for Lebanon, as issued here by the Cabinet today: The Cabinet resolved that: 1. Israel will maintain the cease-fire in Lebanon.

title: MAY ORDERS FOR TOOLS FELL 56.7%
description: Orders for new machine tools fell 56.7 percent in May from their level a year earlier, the National Machine Tool Builders Association said yesterday.

title: Ice-Conditioning
description: ''It beats putting in air-conditioning units,'' said Lou Vairo, the new coach of the United States ice hockey team that will defend its 1980 Olympic gold medal in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, in 1984. Vairo, who is 37 years old, grew up in Brooklyn and credits two of his neighborhood friends with introducing him to hockey.

title: SPRITUALS: MISS WALKER
description: WHEN singing a selection of spirituals Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, Vivian Huey Walker used her contralto voice to create not just strings of notes, but a lyrical atmosphere, suited to the character of each song. The spirituals' earnestness, melancholy or languid yearning were communicated even though Miss Walker's voice was not in itself remarkable.

title: Washington Watch; Private View Of Recession
description: WASHINGTON MURRAY L. WEIDENBAUM may wish that the cat had gotten his tongue earlier this month when he volunteered that the Administration had been privately forecasting a recession while selling its economic program to Congress in February 1981.

title: CAROL SIMON HAS NUPTIALS
description: The marriage of Carol A. Simon, an associate with the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, to Gary W. Kubek, an associate with the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, took place yesterday at the Green Brook Country Club in North Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated.

title: ALLIES' VIEW OF U.S. PIPELINE POLICY: A STUNNING ACT THAT IS SELF DEFEATING
description: The damage done to allied relations by the Reagan Administration's extention of sanctions involving the Soviet-West European natural gas pipeline project is apparently real.

title: Linda Dukess Is Married
description: Linda Dukess, administrative director of educational programs at the Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies, was married in New York yesterday to Lawson Fredrick Bernstein Jr., a premedical student in the Thomas Hunter honors program at Hunter College. Rabbi Joy Levitt performed the ceremony at the Regency Hotel. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Carleton Dukess of Larchmont, N.Y. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. Bernstein and Charlotte Nowick, both of New York.

title: ISRAEL PROCLAIMS TOUGH PROPOSALS FOR ENDING WAR
description: The Israeli Cabinet issued a peace plan for Lebanon today, calling for the Lebanese Army to enter west Beirut and for the Palestine Liberation Organization to lay down its arms and leave the country along the Beirut-Damascus highway. Israel guaranteed safe passage for the P.L.O.'s members and leaders.

title: BRIEFING
description: Saving by Paying Late

title: MUDDLED THINKING ON THE MIDDLE EAST
description: Many commentators are pointing out that while Israel's invasion of Lebanon may have temporarily destroyed the Palestine Liberation Organization, it has brought no closer a solution of the fundamental problem: the plight of the two million or so Palestinian refugees. Moreover, it is asserted, or simply taken for granted, that any such solution is to be found in the West Bank and therefore hinges on the question of autonomy (leading to eventual statehood) for that territory.

title: Two New Films Shown With the Festival
description: Two films that are being seen for the first time as part of the annual jazz-film festival that parallels the Kool Jazz Festival, held this year at Jazz Forum, 648 Broadway at Bleecker Street, are strongly focused on recording.

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: JOSEPH KLINKOV was apprehensive when he thought about the impending a rrival of his daughter, Ariana, from New Mexico, where she lives w ith her mother. Ariana, who is almost 12 years old, is spending the s ummer with him in his Upper West Side apartment, as she has for the n ine years since the divorce of her parents.

title: WEAPONS OF FEAR HOLD THE WORLD HOSTAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY SAYS ALL-VOLUNTEER MILITARY HAS BECOME RACIALLY UNBALANCED
description: A Brookings Institution study said today that America's all-volunteer armed services had become racially unbalanced, as critics had predicted, raising both social and military questions.

title: DIE CASTERS ARE STRUGGLING TO ADAPT
description: A 400-pound, five-foot-long yellow arm carries a bucket of molten aluminum from a furnace and pours it into a casting machine. It swings around, refills the bucket and begins again, repeating the movements every 30 seconds.

title: Brewers, Oglivie Keep Up Barrage
description: Paced by Ben Oglivie, the Milwaukee Brewers are staging an offensive barrage that is making American League pitchers cringe. Yesterday, they slammed out a 7-5 victory over the Red Sox in Boston for their 10th triumph in 11 games and their third straight at Fenway Park. They climbed to two games behind the Red Sox, the Eastern Division leaders, whom they play again tonight in the finale of a four-game series.

title: Iraq Says Outpost Was Shelled by Iranians
description: Iraq reported that Iranian forces shelled an Iraqi border outpost for three hours today.

title: Bridge:; When 'Forcing Stayman' Is Really '2-Way Stayman'
description: Terminological confusion is quite common in bridge, and in one case the majority belongs in the ranks of the bewildered. If you took a cross section of players at a tournament and asked them to define ''forcing Stayman,'' there would be a high percentage of inaccurate answers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Enough, enough.'' - Nadia Haddad of Beirut. (A1:6.)

title: Train Derailed in Alberta
description: A runaway freight train of sulfur and propane gas tank cars crashed and burst into flames near this tiny Alberta community, forcing about 200 people to evacuate the area. The police said there were no reports of casualties after 27 of the rail cars hurtled off the track last night and exploded.

title: JWT Makes O'Brien Manager in New York
description: The latest management change within the JWT Group has Walter J. O'Brien, 47 years old and since February the domestic president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, taking on the additional job of general manager of the big New York office. That marks the consolidation of the managements of the domestic and local operations.

title: MUSIC: BEETHOVEN OFFERED BY HOUSING ORCHESTRA
description: SOMETHING unusual usually happens to Beethoven when his music is played outdoors. The grand extrovert of the concert hall begins to seem very small-scale, even a bit quaint, as brusque orchestral chords and repetitions are projected into the evening air.

title: Leida Snow, ABC Aide, Wed to Louis Sepersky
description: Leida Snow, a correspondent for the American Broadcasting Company and theater critic for WINS Radio, an ABC affiliate, was married yesterday to Louis Sepersky, a 1982 Democratic candidate for the New York State Senate from Manhattan's East Side. Rabbi Irving Block performed the ceremony at the Brotherhood Synagogue.

title: RIGHETTI'S DEMOTION SUDDEN AND TEARFUL
description: If there were anything for Dave Righetti to say as he packed his belongings early yesterday morning, he could not find the words. Less than six hours before, he had been the starting pitcher for the Yankees, struggling to show management the type of performances that had made him the American League rookie of the year last season.

title: PENSION BILL HURTS 'RANK-AND-FILE' EMPLOYEES
description: To the Editor:

title: Bausch Selling Lens Abroad
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. has announced that it had begun marketing abroad its soft contact lenses for cosmetic extended-wear use.

title: N.F.L. AND COCAINE: CARL ELLER'S DECLINE
description: Dr. Walter Riker, the medical consultant to the National Football League on drug abuse and a leading expert on the effects of cocaine on athletes, says he can spot the strung-out players on his television screen any Sunday afternoon in the fall. One looks much too tired, as he is barely able to walk off the field when the ball changes hands.

title: Trade Surplus Dips in Britain
description: Britain's trade surplus slipped slightly, to the equivalent of $339 million in April from $384 million in March, the Trade Department said Friday.

title: Charles J. Russhon, 71, Dies; Basis of Comic Strip Figure
description: Charles J. Russhon, who served as a photographer in World War II and was the first American to photograph Hiroshima after the atomic bomb attack, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Lebanon's Plight

title: Ellen Danzig, an Art Aide, Is Wed to Mark H. Grisar
description: The marriage of Ellen Kay Danzig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Danzig of Eastchester, N.Y., to Mark H. Grisar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Grisar of Mill Basin, N.Y., took place yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Benjamin W. Helfgott performed the ceremony at the Tappan Hill, a restaurant.

title: Dr. Linda Ellen Hillman is Bridge of Michael Chayes
description: Dr. Linda Ellen Hillman, daughter of Harriet Arnold of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Murray Hillman of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Chayes, son of Mathy Pottok of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Leo Chayes. Cantor Daniel Rous performed the ceremony at the Terrace Restaurant at Butler Hall.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: MUSIC: CARAMOOR FESTIVAL BEGINS 37th SEASON, WETLY
description: CARAMOOR'S Annual Music Festival opened Saturday night in Katonah, N.Y., celebrating for the 37th consecutive summer the graces and greenery of this 117-acre estate. The players were the Caramoor Festival Orchestra under Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, and though the program followed a narrow, well-traveled path, Mozart's E flat Symphony, No. 39, the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto and Beethoven's Second Symphony all seemed to blend peacefully and comfortably into the softness of the night.

title: SALVADORAN AUDIT FAULTS THE LAND REDISTRIBUTION PLAN
description: The Salvadoran agency administering the land redistribution program is so poorly run as to raise questions of impropriety and corruption, according to a Salvadoran Government audit. The audit also concluded that it was not yet possible to determine how the agency has spent funds provided by the United States.

title: Increase of 9 a Gallon In Gas Prices Reported
description: Retail gasoline prices have risen by 9.2 cents a gallon for regular and 9 cents for unleaded grades in the last month, according to a survey of 45 stations in New York City and on Long Island. Over a two-month period, the prices have increased 15.5 and 16.1 cents respectively.

title: No Headline
description: SATURDAY afternoon Mike Souchak, once one of the longest hitters on the golf tour, was watching the Westchester Classic on the television set in his Belleair Beach, Fla., home when the phone rang. Minutes later he was talking to his caller when he heard his son Christopher shouting.

title: TREASURY OFFERINGS SET
description: Dominating the new-issue calendar once again, the Treasury this week will sell $17 billion in bills and notes. Moreover, investor reception of these issues promises to set the tone - and yield levels - for the credit market over the next several sessions.

title: IN THE WILD, HANDICAPPED GAIN CONFIDENCE
description: ''All right, there it is,'' said Anthony DiSalvo, eyeing the green and gold tent he had just raised with the help of two campers. ''Take a look at how your house looks inside.''

title: 10 YEARS AFTER VICTORY ON BUSING, N.A.A.C.P. IS BACK IN COURTROOM
description: Ten years after one of the country's biggest courtroom struggles over school desegregation, blacks in Prince Georges County, Md., are back in Federal court here demanding that the victory they won in 1972 be fully carried out.

title: 200 BLACKS JOIN MARCH TO PROTEST A FATAL BEATING
description: More than 200 shouting, chanting black demonstrators marched yesterday in front of the Avenue X Bagels shop in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn to protest the beating death of a black man last Tuesday in that predominantly white area.

title: Maria Switz Wed To Hugh Halman
description: Maria Hartford Switz, daughter of Olivia Wrightson Switz of Red Bank, N.J., and Paul F. Switz of New York, was married yesterday at her mother's home to Hugh Talat Halman. The Rev. Harold Turner of the Lincroft (N.J.) United Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony.

title: PROVENZANO BARS UNION ROLE
description: Anthony Provenzano, former president of a New Jersey teamsters local and convicted of racketeering and murder, has signed a consent agreement barring him from any future role in the local, the Justice Department said yesterday.

title: Hyman Plays Waller And Handy on Organ
description: Dick Hyman, who has been playing the music of Fats Waller and other jazz composers on church and theater organs for several years, combined the works of Mr. Waller and W.C. Handy in an organ recital at All Saints Church, Madison Avenue and 129th Street, yesterday afternoon as part of the Kool Jazz Festival.

title: More Use for Prizm In Target Marketing
description: In a business community more and more taken with the concept of target marketing, the Potential Rating Index by ZIP Market is finding a wide universe of users. The service, known by the acronym Prizm, was created by the Claritas Corporation, Rosslyn, Va., and first offered two years ago.

title: WOMEN TURN VIEW TO PUBLIC OFFICE
description: Despite its failure to win ratification of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, the women's movement has emerged from the 10-year struggle with a strong political organization that, its leaders say, will now work to elect more women to public office.

title: NEW RESPONSIBILITIES FOR CONTINENTAL OFFICER
description: The Continental Corporation, a big insurer, has realigned its operating divisions, with major responsibility falling to John H. Bretherick Jr., who has been in charge of the company's domestic property and casualty business.

title: MILITARY PANEL STAFF: ROOTS OF POWER
description: The staff of the House Armed Services Committee is considered by its admirers to be among the strongest and most powerful committee staffs on Capitol Hill and by its critics to be among the most arbitrary and autocratic.

title: News Analysis
description: The Democrats went home today feeling good about themselves, surer than they were when they came that they are a party with a future.

title: AKZONA APPOINTS PRESIDENT AND CHIEF
description: Akzona Inc. says it will name G. John Coli, now president of its American Enka division, as its new president and chief executive officer.

title: A Course Full of Hot Air
description: N ew Yorkers, it seems, have a zest for almost anything called ''extended education.'' And nowhere more than at the New School, which offers a one-class course called ''Up, Up and Away'' that is even more extended than most.

title: Vengeance Will Not Rule the Waves
description: Guess who now thinks the ownership of the Falklands is settled, beyond all negotiation? With the Union Jack triumphantly restored, Prime Minister Thatcher sounds just as implacable as the Argentine junta a few weeks ago. Argentina is hardly in a position to instruct her in international legality. But if Britain fought for a principle rather than for land, it would be well advised to stop implanting stakes.

title: British Railroads All Shut by Strike
description: Britain's rail network ground to a halt tonight as a nationwide strike began. Officials indicated that they saw little hope of a quick settlement.

title: POPE BACKS PALISTINIAN RIGHTS
description: Pope John Paul II, describing reports from Lebanon as ''terrifying,'' reiterated a call today for the recognition of Palestinian rights and said he would dedicate a mass to prayers for peace in ''tormented'' Lebanon.

title: U.S. 1 by Sneakers
description: Jay Birmingham passed through town over the weekend. On Saturday, he ran down from Norwalk, Conn., and yesterday he hopped off toward New Brunswick, N.J. The 36-year-old high school biology teacher from Jacksonville, Fla., has been running south on U.S. 1 since June 13 when he began his prospective 2,225-mile grind at Fort Kent, Me., near the Canadian border. He hopes to reach the end of Route 1 near Key West, Fla., in 47 days, near the end of August.

title: PRIDE AND JOY AT HOMOSEXUAL PARADE
description: The annual Gay and Lesbian Pride March coursed through Manhattan yesterday in a buoyant celebration by tens of thousands of participants.

title: THE TIDES NURTURE HOPES (AND ARMS)
description: NORFOLK, Va. IF the future success of the Mets depends on their young pitching arms, then that success must develop slowly and carefully. Fifteen years ago, the names were Seaver, Koosman, Ryan, Gentry and McAndrew. Today, the names include Darling, Holman, Ownbey, Gaff and Terrell.

title: 3,000 POLES PEACEFULLY MARK ANNIVERSARY OF POZNAN RIOTS
description: About 3,000 people, some of them shouting ''Long Live Solidarity!'' and ''Free Lech Walesa!'' attended officially approved ceremonies today marking the 26th anniversary of rioting in Poznan in which officials say 53 died.

title: NO DOUBTS ABOUT BRITAIN'S FALKLAND ACTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Loss in Trenton
description: New Jersey's Governor Thomas Kean argued strenuously for a tax on gasoline. But a lot of people remembered that as a candidate he had promised that there would be no new taxes, and legislators not surprisingly yielded to strong antitax sentiment.

title: The U.N. Today; June 28 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Subcommittee on Petitions Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: 2 BROTHERS DIE IN PLANE CRASH
description: Two brothers from Stamford, Conn., were killed yesterday afternoon when a light private airplane in which they were traveling suddenly plunged into Long Island Sound near Larchmont Harbor, authorities said.

title: WORLD CUP'S BITTER TASTE
description: up in the air, the world's most popular sports event moved into its second stage today with single games here and in Madrid.

title: HAIG'S LAST LUNCH
description: Last Tuesday, I called Al Haig, told him he seemed to be on the ropes, and suggested we finally have our one-onone talk; he invited me to lunch in the Secretary's eighth-floor dining room at noon on Thursday.

title: 600 'COUSINS' MEET TO CELEBRATE ROOTS
description: For Roland J. Hill the scene seems like a memory or a slightly faded picture of the day his great-great-great-grandfather arrived in America. ''I can see his hands and legs shackled.'' he said. ''The sun's hot. The plantation owners, in panama hats, stand around the auction block appraising him - like they are bidding for a horse.''

title: News Analysis
description: George P. Shultz, the Secretary of Statedesignate, will bring to the State Department a broad range of experience in economic affairs that is likely to spread his influence far beyond the normal reach of the office. His experience as Secretary of the Treasury and as director of the Office of Management and Budget in the Nixon Administration and his rapport with President Reagan point to a broad role for Mr. Shultz.

title: Shirley Field-Ridley, 45, Held Posts in the Guyana Cabinet
description: Shirley Field-Ridley, a former Cabinet minister and a leading activist in local and Caribbean women's organizations, died Saturday, family members said today. She was 45 years old.

title: A STUDY OF FOLK-JAZZ FUSION
description: ''Jazz and World Music,'' presented by the Kool Jazz Festival at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night, was a four-hour argument for a provocative thesis. Joachim Berendt, the German jazz writer and producer of records and concerts, put the program together to support his contention that the fusion of jazz with ethnic, folk and tribal music from around the world has been one of the most significant developments in the last two decades of jazz history - a development as potentially revolutionary as the coming of free jazz in the early 1960's.

title: RECESSION IN JERSEY: 'DIRE' OR 'MILD'?
description: Is New Jersey in economic trouble these days or is it riding out the recession quite nicely, thank you? The answer depends on whom you talk to - and perhaps where you look.

title: Runaway Train Sets 6 Fires
description: O'NEILL, Neb., June 27 (UPI) - The brakes on a Burlington Northern train idling in a rail yard were apparently released, sending it rolling on a 13-mile trip without lights and without its crew, a spokesman for the Nebraska State Patrol said Saturday. Ron Wilson, a patrol dispatcher, said there were indications that the train was deliberately set loose late Friday. A burning engine brake that remained operational caused about six grass fires as the train rolled along the tracks, he added.

title: LECTURE BY PHIL DONAHUE IS CANCELED
description: Phil Donahue is not a rock star. Rock stars don't sell 250 tickets in a 2,700-seat hall when they play New York, which is what happened to Mr. Donahue last week.

title: Bulls to Name Westhead
description: Paul Westhead, the former Los Angeles Laker coach, will be named head coach of the Chicago Bulls at a Monday morning news conference, team officials confirmed today.

title: MARINERS 6, WHITE SOX 5
description: SEATTLE (AP) - A two-run triple by Al Cowens sparked a five-run fifthe inning for Seattle. With one out, Steve Trout (5-6) walked Bobby Brown and Julio Cruz and the runners completed a double steal.

title: Petro-Lewis Offer
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation said subscriptions to the public partnership formed in June in its oil income program were a record $86.9 million, up sharply from $15 million in the June 1981 partnership. The company said the June partnerships brought the total for the fourth fiscal quarter ending June 30 to $155.4 million, surpassing the previous quarterly high of $128.7 million raised in the three months ended Sept. 30, 1980.

title: 44 Kurdish Suspects Seized in Turkey
description: Turkish security forces arrested 44 suspected Kurdish insurgents in recent raids into villages and mountain hideouts, military authorities said today.

title: U.S. WARNS ISRAEL AGAINST NEW ATTCKS ON BEIRUT
description: The United States has told Israel that it supports an end to the Palestine Liberation Organization's military presence in west Beirut but that barring major provocations, Washington will not countenance further military activity against the city, Administration officials said today.

title: IRAN SAYS AN ATTEMPTED COUP BY ARMY GROUP WAS FOILED
description: Reports from Teheran said tonight that the Iranian Government had put down an attempted military coup. The Bahrain-based Gulf News Agency quoted the Iranian afternoon newspaper Ettelaat as saying ''a first batch'' of conspirators would be tried shortly by a military tribunal.

title: A Woonerful Idea
description: T he woonerfs are coming to Chelsea! But no need for panic. West 22d Street, in the planning stage for reconstruction, has become a candidate for a woonerf - a technique used in Europe to make traffic slow down on a residential block or avoid it entirely.

title: SHUTTLE, CARRYING MILITARY CARGO, BLASTS OFF IN SMOOTHEST START YET
description: The space shuttle Columbia rocketed back into space today carrying its first military and commercial payloads and seeking to establish the re-usable spaceship's credentials for regular orbital operations.

title: Cut in Food Stamp Benefits
description: Food stamp benefits for about two-thirds of Connecticut's 60,000 recipients will be reduced slightly beginning Thursday, and 195 recipients will be cut off entirely, state officials said. They said the reductions were the result of higher eligibility levels in the program.

title: Sarah N. Warburg Wed to Y.J. Bliumis
description: Sarah Neff Warburg, daughter of Mrs. James Paul Warburg of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Warburg, was married yesterday to Yefim Jacob Bliumis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Bliumis of Brooklyn. Rabbi David E. Greenberg performed the ceremony in the garden at Mrs. Warburg's home.

title: WAR'S BITTER COST COMES HOME TO THE ARGENTINES
description: When the first hospital ship arrived from the Falkland Islands nine day ago at a port in the south, Marta Oviedo was there looking for her 19-year-old nephew. She did not find him.

title: METS GO 0 FOR 5 IN LOSING WEEKEND
description: George Bamberger said that his ''spirits could be better,'' but there was no mood of panic or anger in his office today after the Mets lost their fifth game in three days to the Philadelphia Phillies, this one by 8-3.

title: Man, 37, Found Shot to Death Near a Brooklyn Discotheque
description: A 37-year-old man was shot to death outside a Brooklyn discotheque in an apparent gangland slaying early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: BLISS AND BIT OF BLRANEY AT IRISH FAIR
description: Amid aging brick warehouses and factories, along streets that are still in some places made of cobblestones, hundreds of New Yorkers spent the weekend listening to Irish folksingers, trying on hand-knit sweaters and eating corned beef and cabbage at the second Great Irish Fair on Brooklyn's waterfront.

title: People
description: * Stephen R. Patchen has joined Fulcher/Brownfeld Inc., Phoenix, as president and head of account services.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN A SUIT BY CITY ON TRANSIT CARS
description: The manufacturers of wiring and cables in 754 subway cars have tentatively agreed to pay New York City and the Transit Authority more than $4 million in settlement of a lawsuit charging that the products were defective.

title: Marion Blake Dead at 86
description: Marion Blake, the wife of Eubie Blake, the 99-year-old jazz and ragtime pianist and composer, died of a heart attack Saturday at their home in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. She was 86 years old and had been married to the pianist since 1945. Mrs. Blake had been a singer and dancer.

title: WOMEN'S ISSUES GIVEN STRONG SUPPORT BY DEMOCRATS IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Despite the demise of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment last week, women's rights emerged as one of the dominant issues at the Democratic Party's national conference that ended here today.

title: JAMES WORTHY AWAITS NO. 1 CALL FROM PROS
description: called ''gym rats'' wandered into and around the place, as they always seemed to do. But the sounds of the fast-paced pick-up game in progress on the court echoed off the rows of sky blue metal bleachers that surrounded it.

title: Market Place; Oil Merger Rumors Flying
description: ALGUR MEADOWS, founder of the General American Oil Company, used to call himself ''a man of three centuries.'' Born as the 19th century drew to a close, he was still healthy enough in 1978 to predict he would live until the year 2000. People who knew this tireless executive were almost convinced he would make it. But after playing golf one June day in 1978, Mr. Meadows was killed in an automobile accident.

title: WESTCHESTER COURSE DEFENDED DESPITE LOW-SCORING ROUNDS
description: At the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Golf Classic the score of the winner, Bob Gilder, was 19 strokes beneath par. His total, 261, was the lowest by two strokes on the professional golf tour this year and the lowest on the tour in seven years.

title: Soviet Arms Negotiator Arrives in Geneva
description: Viktor P. Karpov, head of the Soviet delegation to the negotiations with the United States on limiting long-range nuclear missiles, said today that Moscow wanted an accord providing for ''substantial quantitative reductions in strategic arms.''

title: Barbara L. Kotlikoff Wed To Laurence M. Harman
description: Barbara L. Kotlikoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Wolfe Kotlikoff of Pennsauken, N.J., was married in Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, yesterday to Laurence M. Harman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Harman of New York.

title: TALK OF WIMBLEDON: MANY CHANGES AMID THE RAIN
description: Judge Robert Kelleher watched the spectators hurriedly moving through the main walkway adjacent to the center court at the All England Club on Saturday.

title: KEY EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY KENNEDY
description: Following are excerpts from the address given here today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts at the national conference of the Democratic Party:

title: SAVINGS UNIT HELP EXPECTED
description: A special group of Federal regulators is expected to approve on Tuesday a new short-term savings certificate intended to help thrift institutions and commercial banks in competing with money market mutual funds. But some of the intended beneficiaries of the savings certificate doubt that it will help them much.

title: Updates:; SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: * Lee Mazzilli, the Brooklyn-born outfielder who played five seasons with the Mets before being traded to the Texas Rangers last spring, has missed five weeks of play with torn ligaments in his wrist. He is expected to return to active duty this week. He was batting .260 with two home runs and 12 runs batted in at the time of his injury. ''It's been strange,'' he said. ''I never missed more than three games with an injury before this. It's been very boring. Playing in Texas has been a tough adjustment for me. It's very hot down here, like Coney Island. But there are good people here and the game of baseball, between the white lines, is the same as it is anyplace.''

title: COSTA MENDEZ IS OUSTED IN ARGENTINA
description: Argentina's President-designate, Maj. Gen. Reynaldo Bignone, was reported to have dismissed Nicanor Costa Mendez as Foreign Minister today.

title: THREAT BY TEAMSTERS LEADER CASTS PALL ON BUILDING BOOM
description: This article is based on reporting by Michael Oreskes and Selwyn Raab and was written by Mr. Raab. This is one of the great boom times for New York City's multibillion-dollar construction business, but industry leaders are nervously watching the calendar for two events in July - both involving the same man - that could seriously affect the industry in the midst of the busy summer building period.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Lehigh Instruments Ltd. of Ottawa said its engineering and aerospace division had been awarded a $37 million contract for the manufacture of two electronic pilot systems for Canada's new fighter aircraft.

title: BEGIN, OFFER A BRANCH
description: Many Israelis ask themselves how the operation ''Peace for Galilee'' has led their army to Beirut. They criticize the extension of the war beyond its original objectives. They feel manipulated by their own Government - as it seems to have been manipulated by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon. They deplore the suffering of innocent civilians, both Lebanese and Palestinians, who have been caught between two hatreds, victims of the cynical strategy of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which made them its hostages, and of the massive and morally questionable use of our own military machine. Even more fundamentally, they were victims of the disintegration of Lebanon - an fact that bred many others.

title: PENSION BILL HURTS 'RANK-AND-FILE' EMPLOYEES
description: To the Editor:

title: Expansion Sought For Hiring Rules
description: New regulations to force the hiring of poor people by private developers who receive city tax abatements have been proposed by the city's Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board.

title: Statistician's Heaven
description: Sports fans who dote on statistics should get ready for a new lode. Officials of the Volvo Grand Prix professional tennis circuit have announced that since the beginning of the year they have compiled statistics on certain service categories.

title: HOLDERS GET BANKRUPTCY VOICE
description: The bankruptcy court here, its docket crammed with the financial carnage of the automobile supply business, is setting some precedents, giving stockholders a voice in the battle for corporate assets.

title: Advertising; Minority Marketing
description: JONES ADVERTISING is celebrating its fifth anniversary with two pieces of new business and, as usual, they are from major corporations.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE'S ASTRONAUTS HAVE HAD A SHARE OF EARTHBOUND FRUSTRATIONS
description: Henry Warren Hartsfield Jr. is known as a patient man, but his patience has been tried by the length of time he has had to wait to travel beyond the earth's atmosphere.

title: Labor and Management Debate Meaning of Rally
description: Union officials said today that fear of reprisals by the General Motors Corporation was respondible for low attendance at a white-collar unionization rally this weekend.

title: BAIT FISHING FOR STRIPED BASS TAKES WORK
description: SOONER or later, anglers learn that bait, dead or alive, is sometimes all that striped bass will hit. What fishermen do with that knowledge is a matter of temperament or a highly developed notion of what is the proper way to go after such a splendid fish.

title: FLEE WEST BEIRUT, ISRAELI LEAFLETS WARN RESIDENTS
description: With Israeli armored units building up in the hills around the capital today, Israeli warplanes showered west Beirut with multicolored leaflets warning people to flee if they wanted to save their lives.

title: HOW F.B.I. SET UP IN SILICON VALLEY
description: Much of the F.B.I.'s success in charging Japanese electronics companies with trying to buy computer trade secrets can be attributed to the highly developed business structure in the electronics industry.

title: MISS HAYNIE'S 67 BRINGS 6-SHOT VICTORY
description: Sandra Haynie birdied two late holes and won the Rochester International golf tournament by six strokes today with a closing five-under-par 67. It was her 41st victory on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: Military Analysis
description: Israel's campaign in Lebanon has redrawn the military map of the Middle East. The Israeli forces are now at the doorstep of Beirut, the Palestine Liberation Organization's military power is probably broken, and Syria has been unable or unwilling to risk major action in support of the guerrillas.

title: Sony Gives More Work To Backer & Spielvogel
description: Backer & Spielvogel, which was assigned the portable Sony Betamax account in March, has now been given the rest of the Betamax assignment, which could bill in the $5 million area.

title: Hallie Cohen and Francis Levy Wed
description: The marriage of Hallie D. Cohen, a painter and an assistant professor of art at Marymount Manhattan College, to Francis N. Levy, a freelance journalist and critic, took place yesterday. State Supreme Court Justice Hortense W. Gabel performed the ceremony at the Manhattan home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Norman F. Levy.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: PENSION BILL HURTS 'RANK-AND-FILE' EMPLOYEES
description: To the Editor:

title: APPETIZERS FOR PARTY HUNGRY FOR VICTORY
description: Out on the convention floor, as the Democrats wound up their safe and pallid dress rehearsal for 1984, the party's haunting question of the heart was taken up once more.

title: Someone Else's Poorhouse
description: The firemen are rushing around with verbal hoses to douse an inflammatory new Reagan urban policy report. It advocates sharply reducing Federal help for cities but it is ''only a draft,'' says a spokesman. ''The Federal Government will not abandon its partnership with the nation's cities,'' the President pledges.

title: Landry Cites Drug Factors
description: Instant fame, big-money contracts and intense pressure make new players susceptible to drugs, according to Tom Landry, coach of the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Miss Malkin Is Married
description: Cynthia A. Malkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Malkin of Greenwich, Conn., was married at her parents' home there yesterday to Richard Blumenthal, son of Martin Blumenthal of New York and the late Jane Rosenstock Blumenthal. The ceremony was performed by Judge Jon O. Newman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, for whom the bridegroom had served as law clerk.

title: Massey Shutdown
