description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. has said that it will extend by two weeks its normal August inventory and vacation shutdown at its plants in Toronto and Brantford, Ontario. About 2,650 workers will be affected by the closing, which will last from July 19 to Sept. 7. The company attributed the extension to deteriorating sales of combine harvesters.

title: FROM JAPAN, ANOTHER USE FOR TATAMI
description: Something different in summer bags is being shown at Carven, at 191 East 79th Street.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NEW TEAM

title: A Fundamental Confusion
description: Censorship is shameful but bowdlerization is ridiculous. Textbook publishers commit both when, in surrender to certain fundamentalists, they put out texts on biology that soft-pedal its unifying explanatory system, the theory of evolution.

title: FEWER STUDENTS APPLYING FOR U.S. LOANS
description: Applications for federally guaranteed student loans in New York State have fallen sharply since the Government tightened its eligibility requirements last October, according to state education officials.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: TWO FACES OF ARGENTINA
description: To a visitor, Buenos Aires can seem a place where reality is on permanent holiday. With its soaring modern skyscrapers squeezed in among gracefully aging European-style mansions, it does not look like many other Latin cities.

title: DOMINICAN POSITION ON SUGAR QUOTAS
description: To the Editor:

title: PCB's Discovered At PATH Fire
description: Traces of PCB's, or polychlorinated biphenyls, a toxic substance, were found at the scene of the fire in a PATH tunnel near the Exchange Place Station June 2, a Port Authority investigation has found.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt WHAT THE TROUT SAID. About the De- sign of Trout Flies, and Other Mys- teries. By Datus C. Proper. Drawings by Bill Elliott. 273 pages. Knopf. $16.50. FISHING DRY FLIES FOR TROUT ON RIVERS AND STREAMS. By Art Lee. 284 pages. Illustrated. Atheneum. $19.95. THE STREAMSIDE FLYFISHER'S GUIDE. By Max Hale and Brian Kahn. 87 pages. Illustrated. Baetis Press, Sonoma, Calif. $6.95 (paper).

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With a runner on first and less than two out, the batter, with two strikes, attempts to bunt. He pops up in foul territory and the catcher grabs the ball for the out. Is it a strikeout or a putout?

title: 3 From White Plains Drown in Connecticut
description: Three White Plains residents drowned in the Housatonic River in New Milford, Conn., yesterday. One was lost when she slipped from a rock, and the two others drowned when they tried to save her, the police said.

title: Nancy Louise Messner Wed to Joel Franklin
description: At Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday Nancy Louise Messner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold E. Messner of Great Neck, became the bride of Joel Richard Franklin, son of Helene Franklin Farmer of Fort Lee, N.J., and Henry Franklin of Yonkers. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: Commodities; The Debate On Options Systems
description: ONE of the most emotional issues confronting the commodity industry today is a pilot project involving exchange-traded options on futures contracts, which is expected to receive final approval by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission within a few weeks. Several exchanges plan to start trading options soon after Labor Day.

title: A LEAKY LAKE AND STATEN ISLAND IRE
description: For the people living near Staten Island's Silver Lake, a mysterious leak somewhere below the former reservoir's surface has become a symbol of the distance between their quiet community and City Hall.

title: EXPOS' PALMER CHECKS PIRATES
description: The Montreal Expos, who lost the National League championship series to the Los Angeles Dodgers in five games last year, are hoping to get strong pitching from David Palmer and Charlie Lea to hold off their strongest rivals, the St. Louis Cardinals and the Philadelphia Phillies, in the Eastern Division race.

title: BUTTE, MONT. FACES FUTURE WITHOUT COPPER MINE
description: The business district of Butte, a city that was once scheduled to be devoured by the world's largest open-pit copper mine, now sits on the edge of that pit, granted a reprieve for which it must pay dearly in lost jobs.

title: Joe Williams Stars In 'Nancy' Concert
description: A Kool Jazz Festival concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening called ''Three Faces of Nancy,'' theoretically ''dedicated to jazz and blues singers past and present,'' was a strange mixture of performers and material that failed to develop a sense of direction.

title: Pittsburgh's Symphony In Public Radio Series
description: The ''American Orchestras'' series on National Public Radio will begin in October with concerts by the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra. The orchestra will be heard in recorded concerts from its ''Junefest '82'' series celebrating the birthdays of Haydn and Stravinsky.

title: Holiday Inns Refuses to Pay for Ad
description: Holiday Inns Inc. has refused to pay for an advertisement that ran on a controversial CBS television program. The motel chain said Friday that the program gave a onesided argument against President Reagan's economic policies.

title: ANGELS 9, ROYALS 1
description: Juan Beniquez hit a two-run homer, and Doug DeCinces, Don Baylor and Brian Downing added solo homers for California.

title: PRIVATE EXPERIMENTS GET A 'BARGAIN' RIDE IN SPACE
description: Riding on the space shuttle Columbia, bolted inside the cargo bay, is a canister the size and shape of a large garbage can, with contents about as eclectic. There are duckweed and green algae, fruit flies and brine shrimp eggs, a little powdered bismuth-tin and some oil and water for mixing.

title: Miss Fisher, Jonathan Rosenthal Wed
description: Margaret Fisher and Jonathan Rosenthal, fourth-year medical students at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, were married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony at the Haddonfield (N.J.) Friends Meeting.

title: BALLET: A STRIPP DEBUT
description: THE Royal Danish Ballet ended its brightly successful season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday night with bouquets thrown at the dancers from some well-organized fans who made this last night as festive as the company, with its dancing, had made the entire two weeks.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1982; The Economy
description: Orders for machine tools fell 56.7 percent in May from a year earlier. In another report, the Conference Board says capital appropriation projections among manufacturers are being revised downward. The business research group expects capital spending to rise only 5 percent this year, half the rate predicted earlier. Analysts cite continuing pessimism about a third-quarter recovery. (Page D1.)

title: SPECIAL PROSECUTOR MAY ISSUE FINDINGS ON DONOVAN TODAY
description: The results of a six-month investigation into allegations that Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan had ties to organized crime figures are expected to be released Monday by Leon Silverman, the special prosecutor in the inquiry.

title: Reagan News Session Likely
description: President Reagan dropped a strong hint today that he would hold a news conference Wednesday. Earlier, his aides had said he might meet reporters before leaving Thursday for a visit to California. Today, returning from Camp David, Md., Mr. Reagan was asked questions about foreign policy. ''Wednesday,'' was his only reply.

title: Perette Genoese Wed
description: Perette Andrea Genoese, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Genoese of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday to Bernard David Ross, son of John Ross, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mrs. Ross. The Rev. Eugene Pryor performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents. The bride's father is an international representative for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Musyoki Wins Road Race
description: Michael Musyoki burst ahead of Jon Sinclair over the final 50 meters today to capture the 15-kilometer Cascade Run Off road race.

title: RUDY MAY ANNOYED IN RETURN
description: Early yesterday morning, Dave Righetti, having nearly lost a game, left the Yankees amid a new controversy. Late yesterday afternoon, Rudy May, having returned to the Yankees amid a newer controversy, helped lose a game. The names changed; the sense of controversy remained the same.

title: Alaska Studies Shift In Gas Line's Route
description: For almost five years, advocates of a pipeline to carry Prudhoe Bay natural gas into the lower 48 states have been frustrated in their attempts to put together a package of financing for the multibillion-dollar project.

title: YUGOSLAV PUTS THE ECONOMY ATOP HER LIST
description: Milka Planinc, the first female Prime Minister of Yugoslavia, is a businesslike politician whose overriding concern is the ailing state of the nation's economy.

title: WHEN DEMOCRATS TURNED DOWN A FREEZE
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ EVENTS
description: Following is a schedule of today's Jazz Festival events: 5. Forum Room, New York Sheraton.

title: CARLO RENZULLI
description: Carlo Renzulli, a violinist with the New York Philharmonic since 1957, died of lung cancer last Thursday in Abilene, Tex.

title: Use of Cluster Bombs Is Confirmed by Israel
description: Israel confirmed today that its forces had used antipersonnel cluster bombs and shells in civilian areas of Lebanon.

title: Mindy Lookstein Is Bride Of Jay Cinnamon, Student
description: Mindy Lookstein, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Haskel Lookstein of New York, was married yesterday to Jay Cinnamon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore S. Cinnamon of West Hempstead, L.I. The bride's father performed the ceremony in the main synagogue of Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, of which he is the spirtual leader. Dr. Israel Miller, senior vice president of Yeshiva University, and Rabbi Sholom Gold of West Hempstead, assisted.

title: ARAB AIDES FAIL TO REACH ACCORD
description: Arab foreign ministers failed to agree today on how their countries should react to Israel's invasion of Lebanon during a stormy meeting in which the Palestinian representative threatened to walk out.

title: Baseball Phillies vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Philadelphia
description: The Phillies will carry a seven-game winning streak, including five victories over the Mets this weekend, as they open a series against the Cardinals for the top spot in the National League East. Steve Carlton (9-7), goes against the Cards' Steve Mura (5-6).

title: ON-TIME LIFTOFF A DEPARTURE FROM PAST TRIPS
description: When the space shuttle Columbia hurtled toward space on time today, that flawless start stood in counterpoint to delays in all previous test missions. Although each of the three previous flights were considered successful, each had troublesome moments.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 28, 1982
description: International Israeli leaflets fell on west Beirut, warning people to flee if they wanted to save their lives. In the meantime, Israel moved more armored units into the hills surrounding Lebanon's capital. A series of meetings to find a formula that would provide the Palestinian guerrillas with an ''honorable'' exit were held by President Elias Sarkis of Lebanon, his Prime Minister, Shafik al-Wazzan, Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, and Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy to the Middle East. (Page A1, Column 6.) An Israeli peace plan for Lebanon calls for the Lebanese Army to enter west Beirut and for the Palestine Liberation Organization's leaders and members to surrender their arms and leave the country by way of the Beirut-Damascus highway under guaranteed safe passage. It had the tone of an ultimatum. (A1:5.)

title: 2 UNIONS AND G.E. AGREE ON CONTRACT
description: The General Electric Company and its two major electrical unions reached a tentative agreement in New York City yesterday on new national contracts.

title: Lotto Winner Sets Up Fund
description: M ario Montuoro threw a party in the Bronx Saturday night to celebrate his good fortune. Not many people win $2.5 million in the state lottery, even if it means taking home a somewhat less prepossessing figure of $117,000 a year for the next 20 years.

title: PREMATURELY BURYING OUR INDUSTRIAL SOCIETY
description: It is intellectually chic to say that the United States is changing from an industrial society to a high-technology society. This statement vastly exaggerates trends that are slowly taking place, and it disregards some significant counter-trends resulting from the need to adapt to the new energy environment and to reindustrialize, and from national security considerations.

title: Nijinsky's Secret Is Winner
description: Mrs. John A. McDougall got a quick return yesterday on a recent investment when Nijinsky's Secret, a promising 4-year-old colt she purchased last week, won his first stakes race in the $58,900 Tidal Handicap on the grass at Belmont Park.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Briefs on the Arts Alliance Proposed For Public Broadcasting

title: THE SMART PUT HEADS TOGETHER IN JERSEY
description: The professor of preventive medicine leaned back in his chair, surveying the crowd rapidly filling the student lounge of Trenton State College. Everybody around him seemed to be talking at once, on subjects from lasers to Sherlock Holmes; there were few listeners.

title: ALCHOLISM STUDY UNDER NEW ATTACK
description: The findings and the honesty of influential studies suggesting that some alcoholics can be treated successfully in a program of moderate drinking have been challenged by researchers who have been investigating the approach for close to a decade.

title: Seminar on Minorities In Films and Television
description: A seminar on Minorities in the Motion Picture and Television Industries will be given at the New Federal Theater today with actors, film makers, producers and others.

title: DEMOCRATS CLOSE SESSION UNIFIED IN VEHEMENT CRITICISM OF REAGAN
description: The Democrats ended their three-day national conference today, attacking President Reagan with renewed vehemence and cheering Senator Edward M. Kennedy, with their carefully engineered political unity still intact.

title: Television Reporter Dies In Fall From Hang Glider
description: A television reporter who was being filmed while flying a hang glider fell 1,000 feet to his death today when one of the aircraft's wings buckled, said Lieut.

title: THEATER: 'PLAY ME A COUNTRY SONG'
description: ''THIS place really used to jump in the old days,'' claims one of the denizens of Woody's, the Rocky Mountain truck-stop saloon that serves as the setting for Broadway's newest musical, ''Play Me a Country Song.'' Maybe so, but when exactly were those old days? The 1920's? The 1890's? The late Renaissance? Certainly they were a long, long time ago, for the present-day Woody's we encounter at the Virginia Theater (formerly the ANTA) is so dead it might convert even a confirmed alcoholic to Perrier.

title: DEMOCRATS' POSITION STATEMENTS ON ECONOMIC, MILITARY AND RIGHTS ISSUES
description: Following are excerpts from the statements on issues adopted today by the Democratic National Party Conference. Foreign Policy and Arms Control

title: U.S. to Expand Duties Of Safety Investigators
description: The Reagan Administration has announced that it is telling job safety inspectors to help employers correct workplace hazards instead of merely issuing citations for safety violations.

title: RANGERS 10, A's 4
description: Dave Hostetler of Texas knocked in four runs and had four hits, including a club-record 11th homer for a month.

title: PRAVDA CALLS HAIG 'SCAPEGOAT' FOR CRISIS IN FOREIGN POLICY
description: Pravda said today that Alexander M. Haig Jr. had been made a scapegoat for an unraveling foreign policy and expressed little grief at his leaving the post of Secretary of State.

title: LEADER OF NEW TV UNIT NAMED AT M-G-M U.A.
description: The M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment Company has streamlined its television operations by combining its United Artists and MGM units. Richard S. Reisberg, 41, has been named president of the merged operations, which will be known as the M-G-M/ United Artists Television division.

title: HAIG STEP TRACED TO 3 REAGAN AIDES
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s desire to offer his resignation to President Reagan was discussed by Mr. Reagan and his staff in the middle of last week, before Mr. Haig expressed his feelings to Mr. Reagan personally, according to White House officials.

title: AT THE EDGE OF DISASTER
description: The Haig affair has displaced Lebanon from the center of attention. But the crisis in Lebanon has not gone away, and it will not wait for the transition at the State Department. The next week - the next few days - may be crucial. What happens will have a lasting impact on the Middle East, not least on American interests there.

title: Anne Marie Moss Sings Some Pensive Ballads
description: It is unlikely that Anne Marie Moss, who performs with a trio at the New York Sheraton Hotel under the auspices of the Kool Jazz Festival, will reach the pinnacle of prestige enjoyed by Ella Fitzgerald and other singers who are obvious influences on her. But Miss Moss, who sang an engaging recital of 11 songs, is one of those valuable middleweight talents without whom the jazz vocal tradition would probably have a much harder time surviving.

title: This Firehouse Dog Is as Cute as a Doll
description: R usty has eyes as bright as buttons. He also has a new rhinestone dog collar and a new doghouse, built for him only yesterday by Fireman Tom O'Neil.

title: COSMOS CONQUER DRILLERS, 3-1
description: The Cosmos won for the 14th time in 17 games today, posting a 3-1 victory over the Edmonton Drillers at Giants Stadium. But they once again failed to perform convincingly in the eyes of Coach Julio Mazzei.

title: JOHN BARTH, IN SEARCH OF SIMPLICITY
description: During the last two decades, John Barth has been writing increasingly complex novels concerned with the intricacies of language and form. Having brought these self-conscious preoccupations to a culmination in his last book, ''Letters'' - a 772-page opus composed almost entirely of correspondence written to or by characters from his previous novels - he says he decided to start working on something simple and straightfoward. The result is the recently published novel ''Sabbatical,'' which recounts the story of a sailing trip taken by a former Central Intelligence Agency operative and his wife.

title: Men of Steel
description: The title of ''Strongest Man in Pro Football'' now belongs to a man who has yet to play a game in the National Football League. Rick Donnalley, a 265-pound guard and center who sat out his rookie year with the Pittsburgh Steelers in 1981 because of a broken hand, lifted a total of 42,000 pounds last Friday night to defeat six other lineman in the third annual weight-lifting competition for N.F.L. players in Brownsville, Tex.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American International Group has elected Stephen Y.N. Tse senior vice president-foreign investments.

title: Hooks Calls for Votes To Retire Reagan
description: Benjamin L. Hooks, the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, called 1982 ''the year of the ballot box,'' and said today he wanted to make it politically possible for President Reagan to return to ''the purple hills of California.''

title: A.T.& T. Product
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company introduced a terminal for use in creating screenfuls of information for videotex systems. The terminal, which will sell for $34,000 and be available starting in August, will create graphics using the proposed North American standard developed by A.T.& T. last year. The first customer for the terminals will be Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc., which is developing a home electronic information service in Florida.

title: METS' SHALLOW PITCHING IS EXPOSED
description: The pitching rotation changes virtually every week, the fielders shuffle positions and the heavy hitters cannot seem to get on track at the same time. But one thing remains constant with the Mets: the even disposition of a manager who said from the start that he would be contented with a .500 team.

title: FANS' ANGER RAGES IN WEST GERMANY
description: In 1954, West Germany won the World Cup in soccer, and in the intervening years more than a few talk-show sociologists and op-ed page instant historians cited the event as an important one in rebuilding German self-respect and self-confidence after World War II.

title: N.B.A. CLUBS SCRAMBLE FOR DEALS ON EVE OF THE DRAFT
description: The Los Angeles Lakers' victory in the National Basketball Association finals two weeks ago is history now because the collegiate draft, which begins today at noon, marks the unofficial beginning of the 1982-83 season.

title: LEGISLATORS IN ALBANY, HARTFORD AND TRENTON FOCUS ON MONEY
description: With Democrats providing the votes needed for passage, the New Jersey Legislature tonight passed a scaled-down $6.2 billion state budget that forecasts increased transportation costs for commuters, a reduction in school aid, a cut in funds to relieve prison overcrowding and a loss of money needed to repair bridges and local roads.

title: BUDDY RICH FLASHBACK: FRIENDS REPLAY CAREER
description: THE career of Buddy Rich, from his early days as Traps, a boy wonder who danced and played drums in vaudeville, through his service with the swing-era bands of Artie Shaw and Tommy Dorsey, his years of playing with a variety of jazz stars and his present position as leader of a long-established big band, was reviewed with humor and joy and a lot of music at Carnegie Hall Sunday evening in a Kool Jazz Festival program produced by Burt Korall.

title: Matsushita's Profit Up 9.1%
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company today reported a 9.1 percent rise in earnings for its fiscal first half, ended May 20, reflecting brisk sales of video and communications equipment.

title: Study Says Paraguay Regresses on Rights
description: A new report by the International League for Human Rights asserts that there has been a deterioration of human rights in Paraguay over the last two years.

title: Sudden Stalls Reported In Recent G.M. Models
description: The engines of as many as 735,000 1981 and 1982 model automobiles manufactured by the General Motors Corporation can suddenly lose power or stop altogether because of faulty catalytic converters, an industry publication reported today.

title: Cooney Awaits Pinklon Thomas
description: The next opponent for Gerry Cooney may be fighting on the undercard Saturday night at Ice World in Totowa, N.J. His name is Pinklon Thomas and, according to Dan Duva, the promoter, he is ''acceptable'' to the Cooney management, provided Thomas moves up in the rankings by the time Cooney is ready to fight again.

title: Market Place; Diamond As Oil Target
description: THE Diamond Shamrock Corporation is like dozens of other well-run companies. The management, pleased with a job well done, views the idea of being taken over with distaste, even alarm. At Diamond's annual meeting in April, William H. Bricker, the chairman, responded to published reports of takeover rumors by saying the company was not for sale.

title: MYRON SULZBERGER JR.
description: Myron Sulzberger Jr., a New York lawyer who had been active in Democratic Party politics and veterans affairs, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: American Repertory To Tour Europe, Israel

title: TALKS IN LEBANON ON P.L.O. PROPOSAL SAID TO MAKE GAINS
description: Palestinian, Lebanese and American officials tried to reach agreement today on a Palestine Liberation Organization proposal that would neutralize the group's military presence in Lebanon and allow for the eventual departure of the P.L.O. leadership from Beirut, Government sources said.

title: TIME FOR GIRLS OF SUMMER
description: From small towns in the Middle West and West they come, from Beaver Dam and Pelican Rapids, East Grand Forks and American Fork, from Bountiful, Paw Paw, Mabelvale and Winner, Oakley, Libby, Fridley and Firth; ''the girls of summer,'' as they are known in some New York area communities. In others, they are ''summer girls,'' ''mother's helpers'' and ''au pair'' girls.

title: Manila Sets Loan Request
description: The Philippines will seek a $1.2 billion World Bank development loan, of which about $900 million would be on a long-term basis, Prime Minister Cesar Virata's office said today.

title: LEGISLATORS IN ALBANY, HARTFORD AND TRENTON FOCUS ON MONEY
description: The Assembly tonight overrode Governor Carey's vetoes of $320 million in new spending on school aid, aid to local governments and other programs.

title: GAUGING AIRLINES' TRAFFIC RISE
description: Aided by an increase in travel for pleasure, the nation's major airlines have been experiencing increased traffic this year and are expected to show further gains this month.

title: MILLIONS IN 'FICTITIOUS' ORDERS ENMESH DAYCO IN COURT FIGHT
description: The company was big and so was the opportunity. In 1979, the Dayco Corporation had record sales of $740 million, stood among the largest 400 industrial companies and was offered a chance to break into a vast new market: the Soviet Union.

title: THE FINGERTIPS' VIEWPOINT
description: IN 1868, when Johannes Brahms was incorporating calls from the Alpine horns of Zurich into his First Symphony, a less-remembered Christopher Latham Sholes was composing Qwerty. The fingering required of musicians to perform his symphony probably concerned Brahms little; to Sholes, fingering was crucial. In his primitive typewriter, the consecutive striking of adjacent keys would often snare their wobbly linkages. Therefore, letters frequently combined in English had to be separated on the keyboard by others less often used.

title: ISRAELIS AND THE CHRISTIANS: ALLIES AT ARMS LENGTH
description: A Lebanese policeman started to upbraid an unarmed Lebanese Christian militiaman today who had driven his car into a crowded intersection, snarling traffic.

title: Blue Cross Refund
description: Maryland's insurance division announced today that Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Maryland had 90 days to refund nearly $11 million to group policyholders as part of a twoyear-old state order. The nonprofit companies made an excess profit of $10.9 million in 1979 and were ordered by the state insurance commissioner to return the money to subscribers in 1980.

title: MISS TAYLOR WINS PUBLIC LINKS TITLE
description: Nancy Taylor of Pheonix, Ariz., sank an 18-foot putt on the 17th hole Sunday to defeat Kerri Clark of North Las Vegas, Nev., 2 and 1, and win the sixth annual United States Women's Amateur Public Links championship.

title: SAN FRANCISCO BANS POSSESSING MOST PISTOLS
description: The San Francisco Board of Supervisors passed a law today banning most residents from owning pistols. The vote was 6 to 4.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bethesda Research Laboratories Inc., Gaithersburg, Md., has named M. James Barrett chief operating officer.

title: TV: A MEXICAN LEGEND
description: PUBLIC television's worthy ''American Playhouse'' series concludes its first season on WNET-TV, Channel 13, tonight at 9 o'clock with ''The Ballad of Gregorio Cortez,'' written by Victor Villasenor and directed by Robert M. Young for the National Council of La Raza, a federation of Hispanic organizations.

title: COSTA RICA TIGHTENS ITS BELT
description: Less than two months after inheriting a virtually bankrupt economy, Costa Rica's new Government has begun introducing a series of belt-tightening measures, including across-the-board price increases, in an attempt to lift the country out of its worst economic crisis in 30 years.

title: DURHAM SHOWS HUSTLE IN OUTFIELD
description: B aseball managers talk so much about ''fundamentals'' that people sometimes wonder if they are simply groping for an alibi when things go wrong. But last spring when Lee Elia took over as manager of the Chicago Cubs, a last-place team, he not only talked about fundamentals but crusaded about them.

title: Vietnam Announces Shift In Its Top Leadership
description: Vietnam announced a shuffle today of its Council of State, including the dismissal of Xuan Thuy from the posts of deputy chairman and general secretary.

title: U.S. PREPARATION FOR A DRAFT URGED
description: A panel of 55 prominent citizens urged President Reagan and Congress today to prepare for a resumption of the military draft in the near future.

title: ALBERT G. MILLER, 76, WROTE RADIO SCRIPTS AND STAGE COMEDIES
description: Albert G. Miller, playwright, radio scriptwriter and author of children's books, died Friday in Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HOPE DIMS FOR ROCKETS THAT SANK
description: The space agency said Monday that the sinking of the space shuttle's rocket boosters apparently was caused by the failure of their parachutes to slow their velocity after they were jettisoned from the orbiter.

title: 'Dunk Diplomacy'
description: Lou Carnesecca, who has been taking American basketball players on tours of Europe and South America for 16 years, will lead a team of collegians, all from Big East conference schools, to Angola next month in an effort at ''dunk diplomacy.'' The St. John's coach says he hopes the trip will help improve relations with the African nation the way ''Ping Pong diplomacy'' did with China 10 years ago.

title: ALEC WILDER JAZZ REPERTORY
description: THE relationship between Alec Wilder, the composer who died in 1980, and his circle of friends resulted in an unusually mixed repertory of compositions. Mr. Wilder wrote primarily for his friends. And, because his friends included the late John Barrows, the French horn player, Harvey Phillips, the tuba virtuoso, Mitch Miller in his oboe-playing days, singers such as Eileen Farrell, Mabel Mercer and the team of Jackie Cain and Roy Kral, and such jazz musicians as Marian McPartland, Gerry Mulligan, Bob Brookmeyer and Stan Getz, Mr. Wilder's writing covered such a wide spectrum that he slips through any attempt at categorization.

title: Lord, Geller Observance
description: The sentimental folks at Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein will celebrate the 15th anniversary of the agency July 10 by running small-space ads in the July 15 issue of their favorite magazine (and client), The New Yorker, for 21 of their clients.

title: HAIG SAID TO HAVE FELT JEALOUS OF MIDEAST ROLE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s disagreements with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and Vice President Bush over how much to criticize Israel for its actions in southern Lebanon do not seem to have played as big a role in his resignation last Friday as his concern that others were interfering in his ability to manage foreign affairs.

title: POLISH POLICE AND PROTESTERS CLASH AT RALLY MARKING RIOTS
description: Polish policemen clashed briefly today with a crowd of young demonstrators who taunted them with cries of ''Long live Solidarity!'' and ''Gestapo!'' in Poznan, according to reports from the industrial city.

title: STAGE: JULES FEIFFER'S 'A THINK PIECE'
description: JULES FEIFFER has something corrosive to say in ''A Think Piece,'' his new comedy at the Circle Repertory Company, and, as always, he has an unusual, at times daring, way to say it. Whether he has a play is another matter. In its current state, ''A Think Piece'' falls flat, yet one keeps feeling the nagging sensation that this work may be more vigorous than the Circle Rep's production lets on. Though Mr. Feiffer is by no means blameless for the failures, it can't be easy for a writer to hone a tricky script when it is inadequately cast and raggedly staged in its initial airing.

title: Waste Plan Vote Declared Invalid
description: A State Supreme Court justice today declared invalid a referendum that empowered Westchester County to establish a taxing district to help pay for a plan to convert garbage into energy.

title: KNICKS' HOPES BRIGHTEN IN DRAFT
description: A big chart with the order of selection in today's National Basketball Association college draft was on Dave DeBusschere's desk in the Knicks' office yesterday. Penciled in next to each team were the names of the players the Knicks' staff thought each team would draft on the first round.

title: BONIEK IS THE WHOLE SHOW FOR POLAND
description: Zbigniew Boniek of Poland put on a show tonight that deserved better than a stadium that seemed nearly twothirds empty. He scored three goals in three different ways as Poland defeated Belgium, 3-0, in the opening game of the second round of the World Cup competition.

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 29, 1982; International
description: Canada's ruling Liberal Government announced a program to encourage foreign investment and to curb wages and prices in a bid to end the nation's worst economic crisis in 50 years. Finance Minister Allan J. MacEachen said that, to help cut inflation, wage rises for 500,000 federal employees would be limited to 6 percent in the next 12 months and 5 percent the following year. (Page A1.)

title: Dillingham Corp., Ala Moana Sued
description: Ala Moana Hawaii Properties said that a class action suit had been filed against it, its general partners and the Dillingham Corporation in Federal District Court here, accusing them of violations of Federal securities laws.

title: Old Stone Acquisition
description: The Old Stone Corporation said today that it had received a favorable ruling from the Internal Revenue Service, which judged as tax-free its previously announced acquisition of the Pacific-Southern Mortgage Trust. It said the deal is expected to be closed within the next few days.

title: NO EVIDENCE FOUND TO BACK CHARGES AGAINST DONOVAN
description: A special prosecutor announced yesterday that he had found no evidence to justify charging Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan with any crime for activities when Mr. Donovan was an executive of a New Jersey construction company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In sum, there was insufficient credible evidence to warrant a prosecution of Secretary Donovan on any charge.'' - Special Prosecutor Leon Silverman. (A1:6.)

title: Bechtel Chief President, Too
description: S.D. Bechtel Jr. has assumed the presidency of the Bechtel Group of San Francisco, the company said yesterday.

title: Hoax Suspected In Distress Call
description: Coast Guard officials said today that a distress call telling them that a cabin cruiser with five persons aboard was foundering off Manasquan Inlet might have been another in a long line of hoaxes.

title: BRIEFING
description: Policing Consultants

title: Prenatal Factors In Crib Death
description: Prenatal factors, including smoking, could be ''another piece of the puzzle'' that explains why some babies are susceptible to crib death, scientists said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: END OF THE LINE

title: Waste Management In Acquisition Offer
description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest solid-waste disposal company, said yesterday that it would offer to buy 4.2 million shares, or 53 percent, of Chem-Nuclear Systems Inc. for $15 each, or a total of $63 million.

title: Man Shot Dead, Woman Wounded
description: A man was shot to death and a woman with him was wounded early yesterday by a gang of four men while the couple were sitting in a parked car in Springfield Gardens, Queens, the police said.

title: Saint Denies Drugs Link
description: Dave Wilson, the New Orleans Saints quarterback, denies reports linking him with the accused cocaine dealer Mike Strachan, a former Saints running back.

title: G.M. Reviews Loan Denials
description: The General Motors Corporation is reviewing complaints from consumers who say they were unable to qualify for the special 12.8 percent interest rate on car loans because their vehicles were delivered late, the auto maker said today.

title: SUMMARY OF PROSECUTOR'S REPORT AND A TRANSCRIPT OF REMARKS BY DONOVAN
description: Following are the text of the general summary of the report of the special prosecutor, Leon Silverman, regarding allegations against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, and a transcript of the remarks made by Mr. Donovan at the Labor Department. General Summary

title: RHINOS TRAPPED IN A STRANGE WEB OF RITUAL AND ECONOMICS
description: MASAI MARA GAME RESERVE, Kenya ''BE very quiet,'' warned John, the guide, as he switched off the ignition of the Land Rover. He pointed to a wooded knoll about 300 yards away. ''Rhino,'' he whispered. There, just below the crest, was the dark, massive form of a black rhinoceros. Behind it, barely visible in the tall grass, was a baby rhino, born perhaps eight days before.

title: A Bronx Hospital Plans to Expand
description: Bronx-Lebanon Hospital in the South Bronx announced plans yesterday for an $89.4 million modernization and construction project.

title: DESPITE FAVORABLE DONOVAN REPORT, REAGAN AIDES TALKING OF RESIGNATION
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan said today that he felt vindicated by the special prosecutor's report that there was not evidence to warrant criminal charges against him.

title: THE ARMS RACE: A NUCLEAR BALANCE SHEET
description: History of Arms Talks July 25, 1963. An agreement is reached in Moscow to ban testing in space, above ground and under water of nuclear weapons. The agreement, which includes a pledge for talks on the reduction of arms and other controls on nuclear weapons, is signed on Aug. 4 and approved by the Senate on Sept. 24.

title: Righetti Late for a Date
description: The Columbus Clippers had expected Dave Righetti to arrive for a workout with their pitching coach, Sammy Ellis, this afternoon. But the Yankee left-hander found that tying up loose ends and arranging a flight from New York were not simple matters.

title: Bridge: Discoverers May Not Find Just What They Expected
description: The voyages of Christopher Columbus and Henry Hudson were significant and useful, even if they did not discover quite what they had expected.

title: Dr. Hannibal Hamlin, Former Neurosurgeon
description: Dr. Hannibal Hamlin, a retired neurosurgeon at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, died yesterday at the hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Providence, R.@I.

title: 4 Die in Crash Of Car Into Tree
description: Four persons were killed yesterday morning after their speeding car crashed into a tree in upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: WORD OF MOUTH SOUND: RICHLY PAN-AMERICAN
description: WITH his 20-piece Word of Mouth Big Band, Jaco Pastorius, the bass player and leader, has assembled an imposing jazz ensemble with a strong Pan-American outlook and a grandly overripe sound. At Avery Fisher Hall Sunday, where they were joined by the harmonica virtuoso Toots Thielemans, who was billed as a special guest, Word of Mouth offered set pieces that practically burst at the seams in rich, chunky horn-based climaxes augmented by the steel drum of Othello Molineaux.

title: The U.N. Today; June 29, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special session on disarmament - 10.30 A.M.

title: Let the Fed Make Its Own Mistakes
description: As a bank economist rudely puts it, ''The Administration and Congress between them have screwed up fiscal policy; why should we (also) give them monetary policy?'' He's a bit unfair to those who argue that the powers of the Federal Reserve Board should be subject to political veto. The debate is as much about the substance as the procedures of monetary policy. But the economist is right to suggest that changing the system could do more harm than good.

title: Dow Up 8.85 in Slow Trading
description: Stock prices posted brisk gains yesterday with energy, technology and selected blue chips leading the advance. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.85 points, to 811.93.

title: TREASURY BILL YIELDS JUMP AT AUCTION
description: The Treasury auctioned three- and six-month bills yesterday at sharply higher yields compared with last week's auction. The average rate on the three-month bills jumped to 13.269 percent from 12.588 a week earlier, while the companion six-month bill rose to 13.419 percent from 13.031.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET VIEWS FAR APART AT OPENING OF ARMS TALKS TODAY
description: The Soviet Union and the United States will begin strategic arms reduction talks in Geneva on Tuesday with positions that are far apart despite ritualistic expressions of ''cautious optimism'' and publicly shared hopes for ''substantial reductions.''

title: Changing Signs
description: Not that long ago, most stock-car tracks in the South had these warning signs posted in the garage and paddock areas: ''No Dogs or Women.''

title: Preacher Terry Cummings
description: HE'S all skill and substance, now - the Rev. Terry Cummings, P.F., as in power forward. At a muscularly tapered 6 feet 9 inches, the 21-year-old all-American from De Paul is expected to be the second choice in today's National Basketball Association draft of college talent. He's also an ordained Pentecostal minister in the fundamentalist Church of God in Christ.

title: Justices Term Powers of New Bankruptcy Courts Too Broad
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the new Federal Bankruptcy Courts, created as part of the sweeping revision of Federal bankruptcy law in 1978, cannot constitutionally exercise all the power that Congress gave them.

title: Coast Thrift Units
description: Benjamin Franklin Federal Savings and Loan Association announced that it would acquire the Equitable Savings and Loan Association for $10 million, subject to shareholder and regulatory approval. The institutions are based in Portland, Ore.

title: Rio Tinto Copper Find
description: The Rio Tinto Zinc Corporation said today that its Riocanex Inc. subsidiary had discovered copper on a property in the Chibougamau area of Quebec in conjunction with Corner Bay Explorations Ltd. Six initial drillings indicate about 2 million tons of ore containing 4 percent copper with minor gold and silver values, it said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: JAPAN IS SAID TO PLAN FOR MORE WARPLANES IN BIG ARMS BUILDUP
description: After more than six months of debate, the Japanese Government is reportedly close to a decision on the largest arms program since the war.

title: Dreco's Canadian Operations Are Placed in Receivership
description: The Canadian operations of Dreco Energy Services Ltd., a leading oil drilling equipment company based in Alberta, went into receivership yesterday after most of its United States subsidiaries filed for protection in this country under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act late last week.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DREAMS DIE HARD. By David Harris. 341 pages. St. Martin's/Marek. $14.95.

title: Gasoline Cost Up 2 a Gallon
description: The retail price of gasoline has jumped almost 2 cents a gallon in the last two weeks, according to the latest survey of gasoline stations by Dan Lundberg, an oil industry analyst. But he predicted that the price should remain steady through the summer.

title: NEW RULES FOR CLEAN WATER: ATTACKS ON 2 FRONTS
description: Compared with the stormy legislative debate over the future of the Clean Air Act, current Reagan Administration proposals to revise the Clean Water Act are creating few visible disagreements.

title: WESTWAY DEFICIT (2)
description: We still do not know the full extent of the Westway cover-up by the Federal and state officials and by their consultants and lawyers, but what has emerged so far in a Federal courtroom here makes it plain that a special, independent prosecutor is needed to get at the truth.

title: RAIL STRIKES BRING LONDON'S WORST JAMS
description: A combined subway and national rail strike brought 80 miles of bumper-to-bumper traffic this morning to London's approach roads, the worst snarled mass of cars, Scotland Yard said, that the city had ever experienced.

title: SOME FURTHER THOUGHTS ABOUT REVOLUTIONS AND MATHEMATICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Radioactive Rain
description: The raindrops that keep falling on our heads may not cause our hair to fall out but they are, nevertheless, radioactive. By collecting rain from thunderstorms that originated over land and sea and measuring it with a scintillation counter, a kind of sophisticated Geiger counter, two physicists at the University of Minnesota have discovered that raindrops are more earthly than previously thought.

title: 30 ISRAELI SOLDIERS PROTEST ASPECTS OF INVASION
description: Thirty Israeli soldiers on leave from duty in Lebanon demonstrated here today against aspects of the invasion. In Tel Aviv, meanwhile, five Israelis who had suffered as a result of guerrilla attacks into Israel condemned criticism of the Government and appealed for unity.

title: Pope States His Willingness To Visit Lebanon at Any Time
description: Pope John Paul II, calling it his Christian duty to risk anything in the pursuit of peace, said today that he was willing to visit Lebanon.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Raquel Welch in 'Woman'

title: CATCHING THE EARLY BIRDS, LIVE
description: For the American soccer fan, the Football Association Cup final from England was a breakfast treat. Tennis followers on ESPN also watched the live telecast of the Italian Open men's singles final from Rome. In coming days, the Wimbledon tennis finals; World Cup soccer games, including the final, and the British Open golf tournament will be shown on live morning telecasts in the United States.

title: THE COST OF PLAYING BY TRADE GAME RULES
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Delays Steel Reaction
description: European steel companies will put off deciding how to respond to the Reagan Administration's curbs on their exports to the United States, industry sources said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM JUSTICES' OPINION IN CASE OF A DEAF GIRL AND SCHOOL DISTRICT
description: Following are excerpts from today's Supreme Court ruling that Federal law does not require schools to provide sign-language interpreters for deaf children. The majority opinion was written by Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist, and the dissenting opinion by Associate Justice Byron R. White. For the Majority Justice Rehnquist

title: Realtors Call Ruling Blow to Financing
description: Spokesmen for the real estate industry said yesterday's Supreme Court action overruling state laws that prevent enforcement of ''dueon-sale'' mortgages will make home financing more costly in some states, at least in the short run.

title: HARRY MILLS, 68, A MEMBER OF THE SINGING MILLS BROTHERS
description: Harry Mills, a member of the Mills Brothers, who in more than half a century recorded hits ranging from ''Tiger Rag'' to ''Paper Doll'' and ''Lazy River'' and who are regarded as founders of modern-day black-harmony singing, died yesterday at his home. He was 68 years old.

title: Forum Group
description: The Forum Group Inc. said it had agreed to acquire American Medical Centers Inc. of Nashville for $88 million in common stock, cash and assumption of debt. The move is subject to approval by Forum's board and shareholders of American Medical Centers, which operates 10 psychiatric and medical-surgical hospitals in Virginia, Florida, Texas, Georgia and Alabama.

title: MEDICAL RESEARCH BEGUN ON SHUTTLE
description: The Columbia's astronauts, in their first full day of orbiting the earth, today began an experiment that could lead to the manufacture of medical products in space. This marked the first use of the space shuttle by American business.

title: CBS NEWS POLL FINDS AMERICANS ARE SPLIT OVER ISRAELI INVASION
description: About as many Americans think Israel was wrong to send troops into Lebanon as believe that the military action was justified, but only a quarter of the respondents to a CBS News Poll released last night felt that the United States should respond by reducing military aid, as some members of Congress have suggested.

title: A Long Lines Account To McCann-Erickson
description: Ma Bell has picked McCann-Erickson, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to be its agency for the business segment of the Long Lines service, which has just been split off for special attention. Billings could be more than $20 million.

title: Kennecott Divestiture
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it had approved the Kennecott Corporation's proposal to divest itself of its Filter Media division to Midwesco Inc. of Niles, Ill., which designs and builds commercial cooling and ventilation systems. A 1981 F.T.C. order required that Kennecott divest itself of the assets to a commission-approved acquirer, as a result of Kennecott's acquisition of Dorr-Oliver Inc., which is also in the air filter bag market.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. The Brewers, 2-1 against the Yankees this year, were 18-9 against the American League East going into last night's finale in Boston and they are climbing toward first place. Mike Caldwell (4-7) has a 9-3 carrer record against the Yankees. (Television -Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal. The Mets, who lost five games last weekend in Philadelphia, face Andre Dawson, who is on an 11-game hitting streak, and Steve Rogers (9-3), who has four shutouts, seven complete games and a 1.74 earned run average (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 7:30 P.M.) Basketball National Basketball Association draft, at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, is open to the public, free of charge. James Worthy of North Carolina is expected to be the first player chosen (Television - USA Network, noon) New York Pro Summer League, at Nat Holman gymnasium, City College, West 138th Street and Convent Avenue. 6:30 and 8:30 P.M. Boxing Steve Zouski vs. Vic Valentino, heavyweights, 10 rounds, at Tropicana Hotel, Atlantic City. Zouski (23-2, 14 knockouts) is 25 years old and from Rocky Marciano's hometown of Brockton, Mass. He is a last-minute substitute for Jimmy Young, who suffered a case of food poisoning over the weekend. His opponent, 27, is 18-5, with 13 knockouts, and comes from Niagara Falls, N.Y. Valentino is using his real name after fighting previously as Pat Cuillo.

title: A LION TELLS OF ELEVATORS AND 'HIGHS'
description: W hen asked his thoughts on the possibility that National Football League players would be given urinalyses to check for drug usage after games, Doug English, the Detroit Lion defensive tackle, said, ''Sure it's dehumanizing, but when you think about it, almost all of football is dehumanizing.''

title: Shell Lifts Oil Price
description: The Shell Oil Company said it had raised the price it will pay for most United States crude oil by $1 a barrel, effective today.

title: HAIG AND ISRAEL
description: In the last days before President Reagan accepted his resignation, Secretary of State Haig was out of step on at least two critical issues:

title: ALEXANDER MITSCHERLICH, 73, GERMAN PSYCHOANALYST, DIES
description: Alexander Mitscherlich, a German psychoanalyst credited with pioneering the study of aggression by large groups and with starting the resurgence of psychoanalysis in Germany and Central Europe after World War II, died Saturday in Frankfurt after a long illness, the German Information Office in New York reported yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: Computers, Spies and Scapegoats
description: It will take years to settle the legal issues, but the court of public opinion has already reached its verdict in the Japanese computer espionage case.

title: HARVEST OF WHEAT WORRIES FARMERS
description: This is the time of year when Kansas usually becomes the state of the golden fleece. The fleece is here again, in the form of another record winter wheat crop. But this time the gold is largely missing. Huge supplies already in the bins from last year's crop have deflated farmers' prices. And the rainiest summer in Harper County memories was delaying the harvest, making it more difficult and costly to move combines through the soggy fields.

title: WHEN THE BAPTISTS ARGUED FOR SEPARATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Mariah Acquires Rights To Resume Magazine
description: Bits and pieces from magazine land: Mariah Publications, publishers of Outside magazine, has announced that it has acquired the publishing rights to Rocky Mountain magazine, which ceased publication in April because of ''recessionary pressures.''

title: EFFECT OF HANDICAPPED RULING UNCLEAR
description: The Supreme Court's decision yesterday that a Peekskill, N.Y., school district does not have to provide a sign-language interpreter to a deaf fourth grader was greeted yesterday with expressions of relief from school boards across the country and with disappointment by groups representing the deaf and other handicapped youngsters.

title: EGYPT WARNS U.S. ON PALESTINIAN DESPAIR
description: The Palestinian movement will become more radical as a result of the Lebanon crisis, a key adviser to President Hosni Mubarak said today.

title: PUT THE FED UNDER POLITICAL CONTROL. NO, DON'T
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ EVENTS
description: Following is a schedule of today's Jazz Festival events: 5 P.M. Forum Room, New York Sheraton Hotel.

title: Spoils of Victory
description: Mats Wilander, the Swedish teen-age tennis star, won more than just the $66,000 first prize at the recent French Open.

title: Ex-Miners Union Head Declares His Candidacy
description: Arnold Miller, a former president of the United Mine Workers who retired in 1979 because of ill health, announced today that he is a candidate for the union presidency.

title: Soviet Says U.S. Moves Threaten Arms Accord
description: The official press agency Tass said today that the Soviet Union ''sincerely wishes'' a strategic arms accord but warned that the talks could be jeopardized by plans to modernize the American nuclear arsenal.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Maize Products Co. of Stamford, Conn., said it had tentatively agreed to sell its S.A. Schonbrunn coffee subsidiary to Tetley Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Springs Industries
description: Springs Industries said it plans to invest $175 million in new textile technology by 1984. Springs said it would be able to complete the program without borrowing and that the first phase would involve the purchase of $80 million of machinery for its sheeting and apparel fabrics plants.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Godiva Chocolatier Inc. sells chocolates for $16 a pound, and one might imagine the head of such a company to be a renowned chocolate expert.

title: Rose Stopped, Phils Go
description: Pete Rose of the Phillies had his consecutive-game hitting streak stopped at 21 last night while a teammate, Steve Carlton, stopped St. Louis on a six-hitter, 1-0, in Philadelphia.

title: LEGISLATORS IN ALBANY, HARTFORD AND TRENTON FOCUS ON MONEY
description: The General Assembly failed today in an attempt to override a veto by Gov. William A. O'Neill of a bill passed in its spring session that would have levied an income tax on New Yorkers who work in Connecticut.

title: Schroder Energy Fills Executive Post
description: The time may not be opportune, but Schroders Inc., the New Yorkbased holding company of the British Schroder Group of Companies, has decided to move into investment and financial services for the oil and gas industry in a big way.

title: CAN 3 YEARS OF 7TH GRADE BE USEFUL?
description: AS the school year closes in New York City, several thousand students face the unpleasant prospect of spending their third straight year in the seventh grade. Boys and girls almost old enough to drive to work and to vote will be compelled to remain in the seventh grade because their achievement scores have not risen high enough to be promoted.

title: Dole Expects Tax Action
description: Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that he expected it to approve a tax bill by Friday that would provide the additional revenues contemplated by Congressional budget planners, almost all of it from taxing business. The budget for the fiscal year 1983, as approved by both houses, calls for $21 billion of extra revenues next year and $100 billion over three years.

title: Dart-Wickes Pact
description: Dart and Kraft Inc. said it agreed in principle to acquire the Wickes Companies' vehicle fleet and general equipment leasing operations for an undisclosed sum. It said that all new and renewal vehicle fleet leasing will be for Dart & Kraft's leasing subsidiary. The deal is ''not directly involved'' in Wickes' filing under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, according to Dart & Kraft.

title: Samuels Stresses Improving N.A.S.L.
description: Howard Samuels made his debut as president and chief executive officer of the North American Soccer League yesterday at a news conference in which he faced much skepticism.

title: BEHAVIOR AND HEREDITY: LINKS FOR SPECIFIC TRAITS ARE GROWING STRONGER
description: IN Denver, two psychologists working, in a manner of speaking, as professional strangers, made a practice of visiting the homes of twin children who had never seen them before. Some of these 1- and 2-year-old twins were identical, some were fraternal. Whether they were one or the other turned out to matter considerably in a study that would ultimately demonstrate that shyness appears to be largely an inherited trait.

title: G.E. Union Negotiators Approve Tentative Pact
description: By The Associated Press The coordinating body for 12 labor unions bargaining for more than 100,000 employees of the General Electric Company gave its approval yesterday to a pattern-setting tentative agreement.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 3 U.S. Cellists Reach Final Tchaikovsky Round

title: LOS ANGELES APPOINTS JOFFREY RESIDENT TROUPE
description: The Joffrey Ballet will become the resident dance company of the Music Center of Los Angeles County. The announcement was made late yesterday after a meeting of the center's Performing Arts Council Board of Governors. The Joffrey will continue to maintain a base in New York as part of its agreement with the music center, performing yearly New York seasons of at least five weeks and maintaining offices and its school and second company, the Joffrey II, in New York.

title: U.S. RELAXES RULES ON MEAT LABELING
description: The Agriculture Department refueled a long-standing controversy today by announcing new, relaxed rules on the labeling of meat products that contain finely ground bone.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 29, 1982
description: International Negotiations continued in Beirut among Palestinian, Lebanese and United States officials. Government sources said that the conferees were seeking to reach agreement on a proposal by the Palestine Liberation Organization that would neutralize the guerrilla group's military presence in Lebanon and permit the eventual departure of its leadership from Beirut. (Page A1, Column 1.) The P.L.O. has only a few days to accept Israel's offer of safe passage out of Beirut, according to officials in Jerusalem. (A8:1.)

title: Q & A
description: Q. Which uses more energy to maintain the same temperature, an empty refrigerator or a full one? I have heard both assertions.

title: Another Fight Off
description: In a boxing year notable for fights that never happened, Jimmy Young has canceled his heavyweight bout scheduled for tonight at Atlantic City against Vic Valentino.

title: Barnett Banks In Acquisition
description: Barnett Banks of Florida said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy a controlling interest in Great American Banks Inc. from Combanks Corporation of Winter Park, Fla. Barnett said it would offer to buy the rest of the company.

title: Eroded Cups of Lemon Tea
description: In 1979, a doctor at the University of Connecticut reported his discovery that lemon tea erodes polystyrene cups. Though no polystyrene could actually be detected in the lemon tea, it was alarming to see it being eroded from the cups, because of an earlier report that cancer had resulted when polystyrene was injected under the skins of mice (polystyrene is completely insoluble in water or in tea without lemon).

title: Comings and Goings
description: Charles S. Feeney, president of the National League, said that Jody Davis of the Cubs had apologized to him about remarks Davis made of Ivan DeJesus, a former teammate. Davis, a catcher, had asserted that DeJesus, while a Cub shortstop, helped Latin players on other teams to steal bases. ''The case is closed,'' said Feeney. ... The Oakland A's have released Jim Spencer, a first baseman who came to the A's from the Yankees last season.

title: QUESTIONS AND RUMORS RUN RAMPANT IN BEIRUT
description: Under intense Israeli pressure and threats against predominantly Moslem west Beirut, this besieged city was a muddle of unanswered questions today as politicians and militia leaders met to try to avert another Israeli attack.

title: KUROSAWA'S 'ONE WONDERFUL SUNDAY'
description: AKIRA KUROSAWA'S ''One Wonderful Sunday,'' which opens at the Public today to begin that theater's ''Summer in Japan'' series, is something of an archeological find. Here is an alternately sweet and desperate romantic drama made early in 1947, less than two years after Japan was A-bombed into unconditional surrender and before Kurosawa made his internationally recognized classics, including ''Rashomon,'' ''Ikiru,'' ''Seven Samurai'' and ''Throne of Blood.''

title: EX-NOMINEE IN NEW JERSEY KEEPS DEGREE
description: Trustees of Fairleigh Dickinson University voted today not to revoke the doctoral degree of Ronald H. Lewis, who had been nominated New Jersey Education Commissioner but withdrew because of allegations that he had plagiarized large parts of his dissertation.

title: WHY: MICHAEL MAY BE IN TROUBLE
description: George Steinbrenner may surpass even himself before long. He may, for the first time in his turbulent reign as principal owner of the Yankees, change managers for a second time in the same season.

title: Dome to Sell Unit's Tankers
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said today that it had agreed to sell the branch lines division fleet of tankers of its subsidiary, Davie Shipbuilding Ltd., for $44 million to private business interests in Quebec.

title: WOMEN TURN TO COURTS TO GAIN RIGHTS
description: Feminist lawyers, disheartened but not discouraged by the certain failure of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, say they will use existing laws to extend the frontiers of sexual equality, although the battle will be more diffused, costly and time-consuming than it would have been if the measure had been ratified.

title: PRESERVING U.S. COMMAND AFTER A NUCLEAR ATTACK
description: A few years ago when President Carter instructed his national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski, to draw up a list of people to be evacuated from the White House in case of imminent nuclear attack, Mr. Carter ordered that his own name be omitted from the list.

title: THIS PANEL WAS NO SURROGATE FOR A PARTY BOSS
description: To the Editor:

title: Reheating SALT
description: The world's oldest established permanent floating disarmament conference reopens in Geneva today. It has been a long time since the United States refused to ratify the SALT treaty, but now it and the Soviet Union will sit down again to work to contain strategic nuclear weapons - and the heat's on.

title: Brooks Is Out for 15 Days
description: The Mets yesterday placed their third baseman, Hubie Brooks, on the 15-day disabled list to rest a pulled left hamstring that he originally injured June 1 and re-injured Sunday.

title: A Bloodless Cup
description: Dr. Johanna Pindyck, the director of the Greater New York Blood Program, leaves today for Europe in an attempt to locate additional sources for a blood bank that has been apparently hit hard by the World Cup soccer tournament in Spain.

title: 'E.T.' MAY SET SALES RECORD
description: Hollywood's spectacular summer got at least temporarily derailed last weekend. Ticket sales dropped between 10 percent and 15 percent, lending credibility to the theory of an industry analyst, Art Murphy, that the big box-office boom early in June was borrowing audiences from July and August.
To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Cukor on Barrymore Panel

title: EINSTEIN'S PAPERS NEAR PUBLICATION
description: AFTER more than a decade of preparation, controversy and costly litigation, the project to publish all of Albert Einstein's papers in 20 volumes is moving ahead, thanks in part to a $1 million donation from Harold W. McGraw Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of McGraw-Hill Inc., the publishers.

title: Armored Truck Robbed of $420,000
description: Two gunmen held up an armored truck in Brooklyn at about 6:30 P.M. yesterday and escaped with $420,000, the police said. The truck, which belonged to IBI Security of Long Island City, Queens, was taken over while stopped for a light at the intersection of Humboldt Street and McGuiness Boulevard, in the Greenpoint section, according a police spokesman.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Benguet Corp., a Philippine gold producer, said it was seeking a $25.6 million letter of credit to cover a 210-million-peso loan from Philippine-American Life Insurance Co.

title: 2 MORE SUSPECTS SEIZED BY POLICE IN MOB ASSAULT
description: Two more young men were taken into police custody yesterday in last week's mob attack on three transit workers in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. The arrests brought to five the number of suspects in custody. One of the workers, William Turks, was beaten to death.

title: DANA ATCHLEY, 89, A TEACHING DOCTOR
description: Dr. Dana W. Atchley, who blended research, teaching and medical practice and achieved prominence in all three areas, died Sunday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: NEW LOOK IN REAGAN HAIR STYLE?
description: Has President Reagan traded in his 1940's style pompadour for a more contemporary ''dry look''? The question came up recently when careful observers noticed that Mr. Reagan's normally slicked-back hair style had given way occasionally to a wavy forehead droop. Among other things, the new, puffier style seemed to do more to show off his traces of gray.

title: HANDLING ALL THE COMPLAINTS TRAFFIC WILL BEAR
description: Picture a giant funnel, with Samuel Azadian at the end. From all over the city, the complaints are funneled to him, problems with traffic tie-ups and construction projects, missing street signs and unfilled potholes, mismatched ferry and bus schedules, sewer repairs and road cave-ins.

title: Sohio Sells Part Of Alaska Field
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said it had sold small parts of its interest in the Prudhoe Bay oilfield in Alaska to its major partners in the project, the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Exxon Corporation.

title: Richard Returns
description: In his first start since he suffered a near fatal stroke two years ago, J.R. Richard pitched four innings last night in a Class A Florida State League game at Daytona Beach, Fla. The 6-foot-8-inch right-hander threw 64 pitches - 37 strikes and 27 balls -for the Houston Astros' Daytona Beach farm club. He yielded three runs on three hits in the first inning to St. Petersburgh, a St. Louis Cardinals minor league club, but he completed the rest of his stint without allowing another run. Richard, who spent the last month in a special extended training program in Sarasota, yielded one more hit, struck out one and walked two before a crowd of 4,500 at City Island Park. At the end of his outing, Richard leaped and thrust his right arm into the air in a display of emotion. Team officials and doctors following Richard's comeback effort had said that uncertainty about how the pitcher would respond to batted balls was their chief concern in his rehabilitative effort. During the four-inning outing last night, Richard was involved in only three fielding plays. He was slow covering first base on two slow rollers to the right side of the infield. On the third play, a weak line drive back to the mound, the ball glanced off Richard's glove, and the pitcher picked it up and threw out the batter. ... Meanwhile, as the Astros headed to Atlanta to begin a series against the Braves another ailing pitcher, the reliever Joe Sambito, went in the opposite direction.

title: Con Ed Sets Refund
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York said yesterday that it would refund its customers $12.3 million as a result of a Federal regulatory decision that reduces the cost of natural gas supplied by an interstate pipeline company. The utility's natural gas, electric and steam customers will begin to get lower fuel adjustments on their bills next month.

title: Polaroid to Skip Wage Increase
description: The Polaroid Corporation, which earlier this year dismissed 1,000 employees in a move to cut costs, said that it would not pay a midyear cost-of-living increase to most of the remaining employees.

title: People
description: * Gordon M. Patrizio named chairman; David Jordan vice chairman, and John Goodchild executive vice president, at Weightman Inc., Philadelphia.

title: JUDGE REJECTS LINK TO CORONA'S BROTHER IN RETRIAL ON COAST
description: The judge in the retrial of Juan Corona, accused of slaying 25 farm laborers, ruled today that evidence suggesting that the defendant's brother may have been linked to the killings will not be allowed in court.

title: CANADIAN CRISIS BUDGET STRESSES WAGE RISE LIMITS
description: Canada's governing Liberal Government, its popularity brought to a two-year low by rising inflation, unemployment and interest rates, tonight proposed a program of federal wage freezes and investment incentives to help ease the country out of its worst economic crisis since the Great Depression,

title: Iraqi Leader Dismisses Entire Ruling Council
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq dismissed all members of his ruling Revolutionary Command Council and eight Cabinet ministers, the Bahrain-based Gulf News Agency reported today from Baghdad.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pleasure and Peril

title: Itel and Lloyd's Settle Claims
description: The Itel Corporation said that it and Lloyd's of London have settled their claims relating to Itel's former computer lease financing business.

title: 6 JOURNALISTS ARE LISTED AS MISSING IN SALVADOR
description: The abandoned vehicles of six journalists were found today along a road north of the capital and the Government is investigating, a National Guard spokesman said.

title: Use of Oil Is Called High
description: Despite substantial improvements in energy efficiency and in substituting other fuels, reliance on oil remains uncomfortably high among the 21 member countries of the International Energy Agency, the group said today in an annual review of energy policies.

title: DNA AND BIOLOGICAL WARFAE
description: The Federal Government's chief advisory committee on gene-splicing policy went on record indirectly today as opposing any use of the research field's powerful techniques for the purposes of biological warfare.

title: Kate Greenaway
description: Kate Greenaway Industries, a New York manufacturer of girls' dresses, said it had filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 7 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Advertising; G.E. Ads To Stress Information
description: THE people of General Electric, who since the fall of 1979 have been telling us that they ''bring good things to life,'' will next be using their advertising to supply information on how to buy and maintain their products.

title: Diamond Salt Chairman Has a Family Interest
description: The Moore family once let the Diamond Crystal Salt Company get out of its hands. But it does not expect to do so again. Frederick S. Moore, 44, a descendant of the company's founder and a member of the board, has just been named chairman of the St. Clair, Mich., company. The family now holds more than half of the company's stock.

title: MEXICAN REGIME LETS THE OPPOSITION HAVE ITS SAY
description: For over two hours, the columns of peasants, workers and students marched into the huge plaza in front of Mexico's National Palace until it was alive with red flags decorated in gold with the hammer and sickle. ''We are here,'' said one speaker from a specially built podium, ''because we aspire to govern from the palace.''

title: ALBANY SUBMITS A NEW PLAN TO U.S. FOR VOTING DISTRICTS
description: The legislative leaders today released a new set of boundaries for Congressional and legislative districts that were designed to win the approval of the United States Justice Department.

title: N.A.A.C.P. CHEERS KENNEDY'S ATTACK ON REAGAN
description: To frequent applause from delegates to the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for vigilance to strengthen civil rights despite the Reagan Administration's policies.

title: JUSTICES GIVE EMPLOYERS NEW TOOL FOR MINIMIZING JOB BIAS LIABILITY
description: The Supreme Court today gave employers who are sued for job discrimination a potentially important new tool for minimizing their eventual financial liability if they lose the suit.

title: TOWARD ARMS CONTROL
description: One can only hope that the formal opening of arms limitation talks between the two superpowers in Geneva today will bring to an end the public posturing and the global propaganda that has marred the debate over nuclear weapons. I do not entirely endorse President Reagan's proposals, which may destabilize the arms race, but it may not be too late to turn what has been a largely polemical exercise into real negotiations.

title: DISCO IN SLAYING IS SUBJECT OF INQUIRY
description: A Brooklyn discotheque whose intended purchaser was shot to death early Sunday is being investigated by the State Liquor Authority for possible hidden ownership, Alan Cohen, the authority's senior investigator, disclosed yesterday.

title: Goodbye to Toxic Shock?
description: A surgeon who has studied the ebb and flow of staphylococcal bacteria for 35 years predicts that toxic shock syndrome will begin to recede in the United States after three to five years. The syndrome, which has been linked to a toxin-producing strain of Staphylococcus aureus, seemed to appear out of nowhere last year, causing a sudden life-threatening illness especially in women who used tampons.

title: 4 Healthmark Officers In a New Enterprise
description: Glenn DeSimone, 35-year-old former executive at Healthmark Communications, which is expected to be sold to Bozell & Jacobs, is now founding president of Sutton Communications, which is also in the health care field.

title: SHAD ENDS HIS ROLE IN 'SHELF' RULE
description: John S.R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced today that he would remove himself from further participation in a new underwriting rule now before the agency. He cited the question of a potential conflict of interest that was raised because of his financial dealings with Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banking firm.

title: ISRAELIS SAY SIEGE WILL NOT DRAG ON
description: Israeli officials said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization would be given only a few days to accept Israel's offer of safe passage out of Beirut. The Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin, the officials said, does not intend to let the siege of the Lebanese capital drag on for weeks or months.

title: Pettibone Accepts A Merger Offer
description: The Pettibone Corporation, a material handling concern, said it had entered into a letter of understanding with a group of investors headed by Harold S. Geneen to be merged into a corporation being formed by the group.

title: Court in Stuttgart Sentences Neo-Nazis
description: A self-styled successor to Adolf Hitler and three neo-Nazi followers were sentenced to prison terms ranging from six years to life today for bomb attacks on foreigners that killed two Vietnamese.

title: READING PRIMERS: DULL, DULL, DULL
description: ''COME, Mark, come. Come here, Mark, come and jump. Come and jump, jump,'' says Janet. And Mark replies: ''Here I come, Janet. Here I come. Jump, jump, jump.''

title: CONNORS SURVIVES IN 4-SET STRUGGLE
description: Jimmy Connors fought through four sets and darkness to defeat a determined Drew Gitlin and join John McEnroe in the last 16 of the men's singles at Wimbledon today.

title: ASSUMED MORTGAGES ARE CURBED
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that federally chartered savings and loan associations may refuse to allow home buyers to assume existing mortgages.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: COMMON MARKET LEADERS, AT BRUSSELS TALKS, DIVIDED OVER LEBANON MOVE
description: European leaders wrestled here today with the problems of how to deal with the Israeli invasion of Lebanon and the trade and monetary policies of the United States.

title: Murder Conviction Upset in Jersey
description: A 26-year-old man convicted of murder in 1978 after a tavern brawl is entitled to a new trial because he was questioned without a lawyer present, the State Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Chess: Sometimes Strong Knight Works Better Than Bishop
description: From at least the early 19th century, there have been partisans of the knight and partisans of the bishop, but their quarrel cannot be resolved without consideration of the pawn position and the comparative placement of these pieces.

title: MARIO RIVERA, 'REFUFEE' FRON LATIN JAZZ BANDS
description: MARIO RIVERA, a saxophonist from the Dominican Republic, calls the jazz bands that he periodically assembles the Salsa Refugees. That's a clever name for a band, but it doesn't really do Mr. Rivera's music justice.

title: Pilots and 3 Passengers Attacked in Miami Flight
description: A man went berserk today aboard a commuter plane, attacking the pilot, co-pilot and three passengers before he surrendered, officials said.

title: Accounts
description: * Guest Quarters, a hotel chain with headquarters in Washington, to McCaffrey & McCall.

title: Censorship by Israel: How It's Carried Out
description: Israeli military censorship applies to foreign newspaper and wire service dispatches transmitted from Israel during both war and peacetime on military and security issues.

title: No Headline
description: Briefs on the Arts Natural History Museum To Raise Adult Fee to $3

title: Federal Judge Dismisses 'Creation Science' Suit
description: A Federal district judge today threw out a lawsuit aimed at forcing the teaching of ''creation science'' in Louisiana's public schools.

title: Business and the Law; Photocopying Vs. Copyrights
description: THE Sony Betamax case awaiting Supreme Court action may be getting a lot of attention, but an obscure case in a Manhattan Federal court is likely to decide another copyright question that could be just as important.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: SUMMER hardly seems the time for women to get done up in men's d inner suits, but fashion has very little to do with logic, or the c alendar. Remember the hot pants fad of a decade ago that peaked in m idwinter and faded away by spring?
