Well, at just about every chic p arty these nights, you'll see not only men in black tie but also oneo r two women.

title: Ad Pages Up in May
description: The 113 magazines that are members of the Publishers Information Bureau showed a 2 percent gain in advertising pages in May over the same month last year with the total being 11,847, an increase of more than 287 pages. Advertising revenues were up 13 percent to $338.9 million, a gain of $39.5 million.

title: FED MOVES TO REDUCE MONEY SUPPLY VOLATILITY
description: In a victory for the Reagan Administration, the Federal Reserve Board today approved in principle a key change in its monetary operations that is intended to make movements in the money supply less erratic.
To the Editor:

title: SOME FURTHER THOUGHTS ABOUT REVOLUTIONS AND MATHEMATICS
description: To the Editor:

title: HINCKLEY 'SHOCKED' BY NOT GUILTY VERDICT
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. says he was shocked last week when a jury found him not guilty by reason of insanity in the shooting of President Reagan and three other men.

title: A NEW CONQUEROR IS NAMED WILLIAM
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales ended a week of national speculation today by disclosing that they have chosen William as the name for their son, who is second in line to the British throne.

title: NONCONFORMISTS WHO CREATE FOR INDIVIDUALISTS
description: Fashion is not simply a matter of sweeping trends and mass movements that periodically change the way women present themselves to the world. It is also a question of individual touches that express the personality of the wearer and, not incidentally, that of the designer.

title: CORNING OFF 52.3% AS SALES DROP
description: Corning Glass Works reported yesterday that continued economic weakness in the consumer goods sector caused profits in the second fiscal quarter ended June 20 to plunge 52.3 percent while revenue dropped 10.2 percent.

title: Aide Says Reagan Will Run
description: Larry M. Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, told reporters today that he expected President Reagan to seek re-election in 1984.

title: SCHOOLS BACKED ON LIMITING AID TO HANDICAPPED
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal law entitles handicapped children to a public education from which they can derive ''some educational benefit.'' But the Court said that local school districts are not obliged to provide services that such children need to reach their full academic potential.

title: 3 More Face Charges In Fatal Racial Attack
description: Three Brooklyn men were indicted yesterday on charges of assault, rioting and violation of the state civil rights law in an attack on three black transit workers, one of whom was beaten to death,

title: FESTIVAL ORCHESTRA PERFORMS MAHLER
description: CLIFFORD GILMORE, a violist in the New York area, has assembled a large number of his freelance colleagues into the Festival Orchestra of New York. The group's first public venture was Monday night at Symphony Space playing Mahler's ''Third Symphony.''

title: Blocker Properties
description: The Blocker Energy Corporation said its directors had authorized management to pursue the sale of substantially all its oil and gas properties, now carried on the books at $50 million but with a fair market value of $29 million. Thus it expects a charge of about $21 million in the second quarter.

title: U.S. Asks Fink to Halt Work on New Districts
description: The Federal Justice Department today asked Stanley Fink, the New York State Assembly Speaker, to halt legislative action on a new set of election district boundaries, until it is discussed with the department.

title: Holder Sues Holly
description: A Holly Sugar Corporation shareholder filed a class action lawsuit against the company and its directors in an attempt to enjoin it from going private. Holly said the suit, filed in New York State Supreme Court by a ''purported'' shareholder, Morris Epstein, seeks to stop the move on the ground that it is unfair to shareholders, and seeks damages in the event that it is completed. Holly, which said that its attorneys were reviewing the suit, added that it ''will not deter'' Michael S. Buchsbaum, chairman, who said in March said that he was considering forming a group to buy out shareholders at about $65 a share.

title: NEW STRIFE IN AFGHAN PARTY REPORTED
description: President Babrak Karmal of Afghanistan, who returned home last week after a two-month visit to East Germany and the Soviet Union, is facing opposition from members of the ruling Communist party who are angered by the reported slaying of hundreds of young party activists in a valley north of Kabul, the capital, Western diplomats said today.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PRESSES CUBAN TROOP ISSUE
description: A South African Government delegation has told State Department officials that the withdrawal of Cuban soldiers from Angola is the key issue in working out an independence agreement for South-West Africa.

title: Market Place; Zenith Radio's Diversification
description: THERE is more to Zenith Radio than meets the eye and ear. Though mired in the unprofitable color television market, Zenith is diversifying rapidly. The company is convincing fans that it will be important in some growing high-technology areas by the mid-1980's.

title: Books Of The Times
description: Books of The Times By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt DR. ROCKSINGER AND THE AGE OF LONGING. By Jill Robinson. 337 pages. Knopf. $13.95.

title: UNION PANELS BACK G.E. ACCORDS FOR 7% RAISE
description: New tentative agreements between the General Electric Company and two big electrical unions representing 73,000 employees would provide an initial wage increase of 7 percent this year and raises of 3 percent in each of the succeeding years of a three-year contract.

title: 'Jersey Devils' Wins Name Poll
description: The owners of the New Jersey hockey franchise will announce the team's name this morning, and sources close to the talks say it is likely to be ''Jersey Devils,'' despite potential religious objections.

title: YANKS AND GUIDRY ROUTED BY BREWERS
description: Harvey's Wallbangers, also known as the Milwaukee Brewers, staged an explosive show at Yankee Stadium last night, demolishing Ron Guidry and the rest of the Yankess, 11-4.

title: RICHARD SULLIVAN, SPECIALIST IN EDUCATION
description: Richard H. Sullivan, vice president and treasurer of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, died June 22 at the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 64 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Continental Plans To Acquire CIC
description: The Continental Corporation has signed an agreement to acquire the CIC Financial Corporation for $40.7 million in cash, the companies said.

title: Lockheed Order
description: The Lockheed-California Company, a unit of the Lockheed Corporation, announced the signing of a $269 million agreement to deliver 10 P-3C Orion antisubmarine aircraft plus spare parts to the Royal Australian Air Force. The planes are scheduled for delivery between November 1984 and March 1986. Lockheed also agreed to buy back 10 P-3B Orions from the Australian Air Force, which also owns 10 P-3C's from an earlier purchase, for an undisclosed price.

title: APPROPRIATE BEHAVIOR; Firsthand Testimony
description: I'm afraid that John Hinckley will be able to show himself to be sane and get off scot-free. Just look at this interview in The Washington Post.

title: BRIEFING
description: Ban on Devil's Advocacy

title: Widow of Congressman To Complete His Term
description: By The Associated Press Jean Ashbrook, the widow of former Representative John M. Ashbrook of Ohio, won a special election yesterday to serve out the rest of her husband's term. She pledged to continue Mr. Ashbrook's conservative policies.

title: THEATER: GRAND KABUKI OPENS 2-WEEK SEASON
description: The Grand Kabuki, which opened last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for a two-week run, is likely to seem an alien world to Western eyes. It is, first of all, theater that combines music, dance and drama in remarkably even proportion. It is theater that is full of contradiction. Time and impersonations shift with dizzying rapidity. Symbols and symbolic action prevail, conventions refined in four centuries of evolution.

title: Australia-U.S.  Antitrust Pact
description: The United States and Australia signed an agreement today that pledged cooperation in settling antitrust disputes.

title: THE BAPTISTS SENT A MESSAGE, NOT AN ORDER
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Putting On the Dog

title: Topics; Appropriate Behavior Prince William
description: No one understands the Royalty business better than the Windsors; they can add the necessary pomp to the homeliest circumstance - like naming a baby boy.

title: CRITICS ASSAIL SUPPLY-SIDE RESULTS ON EVE OF SECOND REAGAN TAX CUT
description: First of several articles appearing this week on the second phase of President Reagan's tax cut. By KAREN W. ARENSON

title: Carey Signs Bank Tie Law
description: Governor Carey today signed a bill to allow outof-state banks to open or acquire banks in New York, but only if other states extend the same right to New York-based banks.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Tues- day incorrectly described the Polar- oid Corporation's reduction of its workforce earlier this year. The severance program was voluntary.

title: POLITICAL ACTION UNITS INCREASE FUND RAISING
description: Political action committees collected more than $109 million in the 15 months ended in March, a 52 percent increase over the same period in the 1980 election cycle, the Federal Election Commission said today.

title: Mother Regains Child In Ruling Tied to Race
description: The Georgia Supreme Court today gave back to Kathleen Blackburn the 3-year-old son a lower court had taken from her after she had an illegitimate daughter by a black policeman.

title: BILL LEE FINDS SERENITY IN THE 'GOOD LIFE'
description: On a soft summer evening in Prefontaine Park, Bill Lee supervised his children's romp in the grass, cheered his softball team's unsuccessful rally and mused about the unstructured pleasures of his new life.

title: AIDES, CITING REPORT, SAY REAGAN WON'T ASK DONOVAN TO QUIT POST
description: President Reagan has come to feel that Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan's continuation in the Cabinet may be politically damaging to his Administration but that Mr. Donovan should be allowed to remain in office, White House officials said today.

title: MIDEAST NEWS FAILS TO LIFT OIL PRICES
description: World oil prices have been consistently soft over the last month, despite Israel's invasion of Lebanon, Iran's successes in its war against Iraq and the death of King Khalid of Saudi Arabia - all factors that might have sent prices soaring a few years ago, when oil was perceived as less plentiful.

title: HAIG. VANCE. WHY?
description: Only 26 months elapsed between the resignations of Cyrus R. Vance and Alexander M. Haig Jr. from the post of Secretary of State. Each chose to leave in his own style: Mr. Vance, selfeffacing; Mr. Haig, combative. Yet while there were stylistic differences in the two dramas, there were also instructive similarities: Both episodes said some very fundamental things about the difficulties of conducting foreign policy under Presidents who refuse to exercise strong leadership.

title: York-Hannover
description: The York-Hannover Ltd. Group, Toronto, said it had established a new subsidiary, York-Hannover Seamless Tube Inc., Pittsburgh, to build and operate a $400 million integrated steel mill in the Southeast. It said the mill, to open by 1985, will produce 220,000 tons of high-quality seamless tubular goods annually for the petroleum industry.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: EVERY so often a health matter discussed in this column or an issue raised by new health-related developments or products prompts a flood of mail from readers. Some letters offer additional information based on experience; some ask about the safety of a new product or technique; some write to clarify what they believe to be a misunderstanding or oversight on my part. Starch Blockers

title: The Great Caribbean Fizzle
description: The air is running out of the Caribbean Basin Initiative, for three reasons: (1) President Reagan and his main aides show little sign of caring; (2) as the November election nears, the power of protectionist lobbies grows; (3) liberals and moderates suspect the plan is just a cover for new military aid to El Salvador.

title: POLICE CHASE IN QUEENS LEADS TO A FATAL CRASH
description: A motorist waiting at a stoplight at Northern Boulevard and 38th Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, was killed last night when his automobile was struck by a car that was being pursued by the police, according to a Police Department spokesman.

title: Victim of Nazis Faces Mail Fraud Charges
description: A Polish survivor of German concentration camps, Lucian Kozminski, has been accused of defrauding other victims of $75,000 in restitution payments.

title: DESIGNER OF WOMEN'S CLOTHES
description: Pierre Balmain, the French couturier who helped revive the custommade dress business after World War II, died of liver cancer yesterday at the American Hospital in Paris. He was 68 years old and had just completed the sketches for his fall collection.

title: EILEEN FARRELL OF OPERA JOINS MABEL MERCER IN ACT
description: THE singing team of Eileen Farrell, from the world of opera, and Mabel Mercer, from the world of supper clubs, made its debut Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall in a Kool Jazz Festival program produced by Loonis McGlohan and titled, ''Listen to the Words.''

title: HENDRICK BATS IN 7 AS CARDS ROUT PHILS
description: George Hendrick drove in seven runs with a bases-loaded home run and a double tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals routed the Philadelphia Phillies, 15-3, to regain first place - by two percentage points - in the National League East.

title: Boxing on Track
description: Problem: A clubful of boxers with no place to box. Solution: The rail at Yonkers Raceway. That's what Mike Cohen, vice president of the Momentum Enterprises boxing promotional group in Westchester and a former publicity director for Yonkers Raceway, is hoping.

title: LET NURSING HOMES ACHIEVE OPTIMAL STANDARDS
description: To the Editor:

title: IRRADIATED FOOD: PROMISE AND CONTROVERSY
description: WHEN Mona Doyle, a marketing pollster, asks people if they want alternatives to the chemical preservatives in their food, most of them say yes. When she asks if they want fruits, vegetables and meat that stay fresher longer, they say yes.

title: Real Estate; Research Venture at Polytechnic
description: IN Philadelphia, the city and a group of colleges and universities have built the University City Science Center, a 16-acre complex bound by the University of Pennsylvania and Drexel University. The center consists of nine buildings designed to house scientific research activity.

title: CLEAR THAT DESK
description: Memo to the new Secretary of State: Dear George, will you please tend to the following matters right away? (1) Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe - Stop it from being built. We don't want our NATO pals dependent on Commie gas, do we? Explain why it's better for Europeans to continue paying extortionate prices to Arabs for oil. They'll whine about it. ''Well, you dropped the grain embargo against the Russkies and made American farmers dependent on Soviet imports, didn't you?'' they'll say. ''If Americans can accept grain dependence, why can't Europe accept a little gas dependence?'' Think of something to tell them, will you, George?

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT ON THE MIDEAST ISSUED BY LEADERS OF THE COMMON MARKET
description: Following is the text of the statement on the Middle East issued today by leaders of the European Economic Community (1)

title: CURRAN GIVES HIS TAX DATA FOR 10 YEARS
description: Paul J. Curran yesterday released his tax returns for the last 10 years and called on Lewis E. Lehrman, his opponent for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York, to do the same.

title: U.S. Assailed Over Exports
description: The Common Market, under fire from Washington for subsidizing its steelmakers and farmers, asserted today that United States tax laws unfairly bolster American exports.

title: N.A.A.C.P. OUTLINES NEW PROGRAM TO MARSHAL BLACK VOTERS
description: A strategy to increase political action among blacks throughout the nation was outlined today for members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: Adams Resources' Debt
description: Adams Resources and Energy Inc. said today that it had reduced its bank debt outstanding to $30.5 million, as required by its bank loan agreement, and that it was in compliance with all provisions of the agreement.

title: Ford Europe Account Chief
description: Mention the name Ford at J. Walter Thompson and you immediately win everyone's attention.

title: A TOUGH-MINDED WEST POINTER
description: Nearly 20 years ago, Edward Leon Rowny poured after-dinner cognac for some guests in his cramped rooms in a Saigon bachelor officers' quarters, put a recording of his own harmonica music on a tape deck and settled back to ask several reporters their impressions of how the Vietnam War was going in the Mekong Delta. Startled by the reporters' pessimistic views, a newly arrived colonel who was also present objected that they must be mistaken. Mr. Rowny, then a major general, interrupted in a gruff voice, ''Shut up dummy, you might learn something.''

title: CABLE NEWS, AILING FINANCIALLY, CUTS COVERAGE
description: Less than a month into its second year of life, the Cable News Network has run into financial problems that have imposed constraints on the operation of the 24-hour service. Although Cable News officials say that the quality of coverage has not diminished, some producers and correspondents contend that the cutbacks have impaired their ability to pursue stories.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New Winter Digs For Aquarium's Dolphins

title: ISRAELI ENVOY SAYS GOAL IS TO DEMOLISH P.L.O.
description: A senior Israeli representative said today that his Government's goal in Lebanon was to ''demolish the infrastructure'' of the Palestine Liberation Organization and ''to do our best to see it was not re-established again.''

title: President Leaves Towner
description: Wendell W. Robinson, 41 years old, resigned today as president and chief administrative officer of the Towner Petroleum Company, based in Lorain, Ohio. David S. Towner, 49, the chairman and chief executive officer, will take over Mr. Robinson's duties.

title: McLouth to Meet With Creditors
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation is scheduled to meet Wednesday in New York with its lenders, and the nation's 11th-largest steelmaker is expected to request another 90 days to operate and to find a buyer or a merger partner.

title: Dole Backs Simpler Taxation, Lower Rates and Wider Base
description: Senator Bob Dole, speaking as chairman of the tax-writing Finance Committee, declared his support today for a ''step-by-step'' evolution of the Federal income tax in the direction of lower rates, simpler rules and a broader taxable-income base.

title: Sybron Purchase
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation, an international distributor and maker of health-care products, and the Sybron Corporation, the Rochester-based maker of medical instruments and products, signed a definitive agreement for Sybron to acquire American's worldwide dental-supply manufacturing and distribution operations, the companies said today. Sybron said it intended to acquire American's United States-based operations in exchange for either $66 million of American's common stock or $69 million in cash, and the foreign-based operations for $21 million in cash.

title: DOCTOR SAYS IMPROVED DEVICE DETECTS MIND-ALTERING DRUGS
description: A modified version of a machine used to measure electrical impulses associated with eye movements has been used to detect mindaltering drugs in the bodies of humans and animals, a New Jersey ear, nose and throat specialist reported yesterday.

title: ISRAEL TO PROTEST P.L.O.'S USE OF U.N. REFUGEE INSTALLATIONS
description: Israel intends to protest to the United Nations over the use of United Nations refugee installations in Lebanon for Palestinian military purposes, a senior Israeli official said today.

title: Construction In May Up 7%
description: Construction contracts in May rose a seasonally adjusted 7 percent, recovering from April's sharp drop, according to the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company, which reports on construction activity. Despite the improvement, the total of $11.8 billion in new construction starts in May is 11 percent less than the value of contracts in May 1981.

title: WOMEN'S POLITICAL HABITS SHOW SHARP CHANGE
description: The political habits of women appear to be undergoing deep changes that worry the Republicans and raise the long-range hopes of the Democrats.

title: UNIFORMED SERVICES AND CITY STEP UP NEGOTIATIONS
description: With contracts scheduled to expire at midnight tonight, negotiators for New York City's uniformed services pressed their efforts yesterday to narrow differences with the city and open the way for critical bargaining on money issues.

title: RELIEF AND DOUBT VOICED ON DONOVAN'S CLEARANCE
description: Susan Summerall, personal secretary to Raymond J. Donovan, was in the Labor Department's sixth-floor cafeteria ordering a salad and soda for lunch today, quietly celebrating the special prosecutor's report Monday that concluded there was ''insufficient credible evidence'' to indict her boss.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: BY the early 1960's, most of the stars and musical innovators of rock-and-roll's first generation - Elvis Presley, Chuck Berry, Jerry Lee Lewis, Buddy Holly, Eddie Cochran, Carl Perkins - were either in the Army, in trouble with the law, victims of cold-war morality and de facto censorship, or simply victims of life on the road. The English Invasion that would bring the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and other British mimics of black American styles to our doorstep had not yet arrived. What was worth listening to? Not much, according to most rock histories. But according to Alan Betrock's ''Girl Groups: The Story of a Sound'' (Delilah Books, $8.95), the early 1960's produced at least as many great records and musical innovations as any other period since rock's beginnings. Who made most of these great records and used their alluring voices and come-hither posturing to sell these musical innovations to the masses? Girl groups.

title: Norwich Eaton Adds To Lally Account
description: The Professional Products Group of Norwich Eaton Pharmaceuticals, a division of Morton Norwich, has consolidated the responsibility for the advertising of its prescription drugs into Lally, McFarland & Pantello, an agency that started in business two years ago with Norwich Eaton as its first client.

title: MIDWAY AIR FINDS FARE WAR CAN HURT
description: Midway Airlines first made a name for itself in 1979 by offering fares as much as 50 percent cheaper than those of the major airlines. Initially, the larger carriers ignored Midway, saying it and other low-fare airlines did not have enough capacity to be a threat.

title: 2 FRENCH CABINET AIDES REPLACED
description: Two Cabinet ministers were replaced today in France's first Government changes since President Francois Mitterrand's Socialists swept to power a year ago.

title: HINCKLEY FINDS LIFE IN A MENTAL HOSPITAL IS PLEASANT ENOUGH
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. says he expected to be convicted for shooting President Reagan and finds his new life in a mental hospital pleasant enough. ''Nobody bothers me,'' he said.''

title: COMRADE AT THE ARMS TABLE
description: Negotiating disarmament pacts is a long and tedious process, as Viktor Pavlovich Karpov must be among the first to know.

title: U.S.-Japan Charters
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it would establish a system to allocate charter flights by United States airlines between the United States and Japan. American and Japanese airlines are each allowed 300 one-way charter flights a year between the United States and Japan under a new bilateral agreement expected to be signed soon.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: NEW YORKERS who are eagerly anticipating the lunar eclipse next week have a lot to look forward to. ''It should be gloriously beautiful, assuming the weather is clear, which is never a very good assumption when you're talking about an eclipse,'' said Christoper Cerf, Metropolitan Diary's official urban astronomer.

title: Shiite Group to Aid Israelis
description: Al Amal, the military wing of the Shiite Moslems in Lebanon, announced Monday that its members would carry arms by arrangement with the Israelis to keep the Syrians and Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas out of areas already cleared by Israeli forces. A commander of the militia force said his men would use their weapons to catch terrorists and turn them over to the Israelis.

title: Clippers Revise Plans
description: The San Diego Clippers have apparently decided to abandon plans to move to Los Angeles for the next basketball season, General Manager Ted Podleski said today. ''My reaction is that we'll be playing in San Diego next year,'' Podleski said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brock Hotel Corporation, Topeka, Kan., has named Rick D. Kasch executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: URBAN STARGAZERS SEE BEYOND SMOG
description: WHEN a friend invited Gladys Monsky to walk to Central Park West ''to look at stars up close,'' her first thoughts, she said later that evening, were of ''Paul Newman or Al Pacino or maybe even Sir Laurence Olivier - they're always making movies around here.''

title: Reagan News Session To Be on TV Tonight
description: President Reagan will hold a news conference tonight at 8 o'clock Eastern time. It will be covered live on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on the Cable News Network and on the Satellite News Channel.

title: KNICKS' TOP CHOICE IS 6-5 TRENT TUCKER
description: The Knicks had five minutes yesterday to make their first selection, the sixth over all, in the National Basketball Association college draft. While Knick officials discussed their choice on the fourth floor of the Madison Square Garden complex, the crowd of about 2,000 at the Felt Forum urged them with a series of chants to take Clark Kellogg, the Ohio State forward.

title: ISRAEL ISN'T THREATENED. THE WAR'S ILL-ADVISED.
description: ''In the Mideast what is at stake, on Israel's side, is survival. If Israel loses, just once, it is gone.'' So writes Conor Cruise O'Brien, in The Observer of London, of the Israeli war in Lebanon. He was right - until this war.

title: Wheeling to Trim Managers' Wages
description: In a forced trade, the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation is cutting management and executive salaries 10 percent effective July 1 in exchange for preferred stock.

title: Maxon Files Plan
description: Maxon Industries, a maker of refuse-collection vehicles, said it had filed a formal plan of reorganization under bankruptcy proceedings. It said the plan, involving issuance of redeemable preferred stock in exchange for creditor claims, had been unanimously approved by a creditors' committee.

title: Careers; Business Reassesses The M.B.A.
description: There is little disagreement in the business world that holders of master's degrees in business administration are in oversupply these days and that many are ill equipped to deal with the current challenges facing corporate management.

title: American General Shares to NLT
description: The NLT Corporation said that 10.7 million shares of the American General Corporation had been submitted to it by Monday, the second proration date in its $676 million bid to buy 48 percent of the Houston company. The submissions, which include 544,778 of the larger insurance company's 1980 junior cumulative preferred shares, leave NLT just short of its 48 percent goal.

title: Air Canada Delays Boeing Jet Orders
description: Air Canada said it would delay until fall a decision on whether to exercise options it holds to purchase six more Boeing Company 767 aircraft.

title: APPROPRIATE BEHAVIOR; Federal Medicine
description: In the nick of time, President Reagan has rescued Meharry Medical College, one of only two predominantly black medical schools in the country (Howard is the other). Founded over a century ago by two Civil War veterans, one black and one white, the medical school has since trained more than 40 percent of the nation's black physicians and dentists.

title: Phillies Are Sued
description: The Philadelphia Phillies and a shirt manufacturer are being sued for $10,000 in damages by the parents of boy who was severely burned when his Phillies T-shirt caught fire. Manufactured by the Union Underwear Company of New York, the shirt was distributed by the team at a promotion in 1980.

title: LEBANON: ESTABLISHING VICTIMS AND AGGRESSORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q. Somewhere, somehow, I have acquired a bottle of something called fenugreek. I have no earthly idea how to use it. Can you tell me?

title: Nets' Aim: Bolster Backcourt
description: The Nets utilized the draft and then the trading market today in moves that changed the character of the team, especially its backcourt.

title: Italian Jetliner Hijacked On a Flight to Bangkok
description: An Italian jetliner with 261 people on board was hijacked today on a flight from New Delhi to Bangkok.

title: NO NEED TO RUSH CAPITAL PUNISHMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Ithaca Gun Co.  Has Thai Order
description: The gun manufacturer that made the shotguns used by the sharpshooter Annie Oakley said it had landed a $1.75 million contract to make firearms to be used to protect Thailand's borders from Communist infiltrators.

title: Johannesburg Inquest Off Until September
description: An inquest into the death in detention of a white trade unionist, Dr. Neil Aggett, was adjourned for nearly three months today after the security police withheld statements made by the unionist.

title: 64 Are Reported Killed in Iran When Kurds Attack Garrison
description: An attack by Kurdish guerrillas on the Saleh barracks in the northwest Iran city of Mahabad set off gunbattles in which 64 people were killed, the Teheran evening newspaper Ettelaat reported today.

title: IRAQ REPORTS LAST OF ITS TROOPS HAVE LEFT IRAN
description: Iraq, in the hope of getting peace negotiations started, announced today that the last of its soldiers had left Iran, ending a 21-month occupation of Iranian border areas.

title: 2% G.M. Price Rise Seen
description: In what may signal a moderate price increase in new cars this fall, the General Motors Corporation confirmed today that it was offering fleet operators no more than 2 percent price increases on most 1983 cars.

title: MANILA SQUATTERS ARE AN EYESORE FOR MRS. MARCOS
description: Vincente Centeno sat with his head in his hands. ''He did not go to work today,'' said Antonio Centeno, Mr. Centeno's 12-year-old son. ''My father is afraid they will come and arrest us. My father would come home. No family.''

title: 'BOOK' OF SCENTS TO TRAIN NOSE FOR WINE
description: PARIS FRESHLY roasted coffee, new-mown hay, mushrooms pushing through the earth after rain are all familiar smells. Yet few people can identify these or any of the 300 other aromas that make up a wine's bouquet, according to Jean Lenoir, a French oenologist.

title: Elia Kazan and Frances Rudge Wed in Manhattan
description: Elia Kazan, the director and author, married Frances Rudge, the former wife of Peter Rudge, the manager of the Rolling Stones, on Monday.

title: Delmed-Tufts Accord
description: Delmed Inc. said today that it had signed an agreement with Tufts University under which certain faculty members of Tufts medical and nutrition schools would cooperate with the company in developing commercial applications of Delmed's Del-Pak intravenous solution system.

title: FLIGHT OF SHUTTLE CALLED 'CLEANEST' OF TEST PROGRAM
description: Flight controllers today described the space shuttle Columbia's performance on this mission, its fourth, as the ''cleanest'' of the test program, with all systems of the complex winged vehicle operating virtually trouble-free.

title: An Israeli Navy Vessel Is Barred by Greek Isle
description: Residents of Kalymnos forced the departure of an Israeli military training vessel visiting the Aegean island over the weekend, the port police on the island said today.

title: IS THE VIOLENCE IN 'BLADE RUNNER' A SOCIALLY DESTRUCTIVE ELEMENT?
description: The film is called ''Blade Runner,'' a detective story set in the year 2019, and it has won praise for its lavish and detailed depiction of the Los Angeles of the future. The movie also contains scenes of grisly sadism that are perhaps unequalled in recent popular entertainment:

title: CITY TO DELAY HIRING SOME EMPLOYEES
description: The Koch administration, faced with continuing budget uncertainties, has decided to delay indefinitely the hiring of some new employees, including 500 civilians in the Police Department who were scheduled to free officers for patrol duty.

title: PLAYS
description: C ity Island Park in Daytona Beach, Fla., seats 4,500 people, but there were 4,719 in the little minor league field Monday night. They stood and clapped when J.R. Richard walked to the mound, far from the major league stadiums where he had struck out 1,493 batters in 1,606 innings, and far from the Astrodome, where he suffered a stroke two years ago next month.

title: NETS DRAFT FLOYD AND TRADE RAY WILLIAMS TO KINGS
description: Within hours of the completion of the National Basketball Association college draft yesterday, the Nets overshadowed the selections they made by acquiring Phil Ford from the Kansas City Kings in return for Ray Williams and an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: General Motors Disclaims Recall of 700,000 Cars
description: A spokesman for the General Motors Corporation said today the company had made no plans to recall the more than 700,000 1981 and 1982 models that may lose acceleration and fail to start because of faulty catalytic converters.

title: LEBANON: ESTABLISHING VICTIMS AND AGGRESSORS
description: To the Editor:

title: MENU IMPROVISATIONS FOR SUMMER NIGHTS
description: red ripe tomatoes and that consummately delicious seasonal delight, corn on the cob. All are welcome and familiar tastes, of course, and mere anticipation of them helps extend the pleasures of eating at this time of year.

title: Dolo Coker, Pianist
description: Dolo Coker is a first-rate modern-jazz pianist who has failed to build a reputation commensurate with his talent, largely, one suspects, because he lives on the West Coast. His personality could have something to do with it, too.

title: Drug Use Denied
description: David Thompson, who was recently traded from the Denver Nuggets to the Seattle SuperSonics, has denied that he ever had a problem with drug use and said the best way to silence his critics was with his performance on the basketball court next season. At a news conference at the Sonics' offices, Thompson said: ''I'm denying that I ever had a problem with cocaine.''

title: On Who Asks Whom
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Your article (''Who Phones the Man in '82?,'' June 23) struck a responsive chord. From the male standpoint, I suspect that there's a tremendous amount of hidden anger about the social asymmetry of phoning for a date.

title: U.S. NOTES HIT 14.96% AT AUCTION
description: The Treasury sold $4 billion of four-year notes yesterday at a price that produced the highest interest cost in more than three months. The average rate at the auction was 14.96 percent, the highest since the 14.05 percent at the auction of last March 24.

title: U.S. Study Backs Baxter
description: William F. Baxter, an Assistant Attorney General, was not involved in a conflict of interest when he dismissed the Justice Department's antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation, though he gave the ''appearance of a conflict,'' according to a Justice Department study released today.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 30, 1982; Markets
description: The Treasury sold $4 billion of four-year notes at a price that produced the highest interest cost in more than three months. The average rate at the auction was 14.96 percent, the highest since the 14.05 percent recorded last March 24. The record average rate on such notes was 15.91 percent, set on Sept. 23, 1981. (Page D1.)

title: CBS-A.T.& T. Videotex To Study Ad Potential
description: The 200 homes in Ridgewood, N.J., that will take part this fall in an experiment of videotex service by CBS and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will also be getting advertising from 13 of the country's better-known advertising agencies.

title: Rematch at Spectrum
description: Dwight Braxton, who was once employed as a member of the crew that moved equipment around the Spectrum in Philadelphia, is going to revisit the arena in a new role. Braxton, the light-heavyweight champion of the World Boxing Council, will defend his title there Aug. 7 against Matthew Saad Muhammad, the former champion, who lives in Philadelphia.

title: FASHION BECOMES STREET THEATER IN SOHO
description: What began as a small, somewhat exclusive Broome Street show of fashions from young English designers the other afternoon became, as things occasionally do down in SoHo, a rush-hour street happening.

title:
Economic Scene;
The Dollar And Gold
description: FOR 18 months we've all waited for President Reagan to do something about interest rates. The suspense is killing - especially for housing, autos and the hope of ever achieving balance in the Federal budget.

title: COMSAT BOARD NOMINEE SEEMS EAGER TO LEARN
description: ''I have zero confidence in the direction of satellites,'' said Justin W. Dart, President Reagan's choice for the board of directors of the Communications Satellite Corporation. ''I've never had any experience with them.

title: LIVING A CORPORATE NIGHTMARE
description: When he was 18 years old, Bernard Korn was a G.I. stationed in the South Pacific and he used to worry that he would never return to the United States alive. Mr. Korn survived the war, and now, almost 40 years later, he is fighting to keep his company alive.

title: England In 0-0 Tie; Italy Wins
description: England and West Germany played cautiously today and wound up in a scoreless tie in their second-round World Cup soccer match Tuesday.

title: FENCE IS TAKEN DOWN AT GRACE PLAZA
description: A spiked iron fence erected to enclose Grace Plaza, at 43d Street and the Avenue of the Americas, and discourage undesirables has been dismantled by order of city officials.

title: HOUSE IN QUANDARY AS SENATE PASSES NEW VERSION OF SPENDING BILL
description: Just when the House thought that it had averted the threat of having some Federal agencies run out of funds and had left town for a two-week vacation, the Senate ignored the House-passed interim spending bill and came up with one of its own.

title: The Chain Snags Argentina
description: a great big chain. The Italians created it 30 years ago. Purists hate this defense of four men aligned near the goal mouth, because it spoils the beauty of fast little men dribbling for goals. It has been maligned in World Cups and European tournaments. Yesterday evening it tripped and cut and ultimately beat the defending world champions.

title: Bridge:; Some Ideas Are Expressed On the Worst Axiom of All
description: Among the rules of thumb that have descended by word of mouth - never by written authority - from the earliest days of bridge, the worst is no doubt this: ''Lead through strength and up to weakness.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Shopping the Food Show

title: Lesson for School Censors
description: Local governments have wide discretion in running public schools, but they may not deny students access to ideas only because they are offensive to the community. That is the important teaching from the Supreme Court's decision in the Island Trees book-ban case. Too bad the lesson had to come from Washington; schools should teach it by example.

title: Good Old Waldie's
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Having served as a newspaper reporter, librarian, schoolteacher and public relations person during a checkered career, I am delighted that Ira Waldbaum regards those of us who pursue such professions as intellectuals (''A Supermarket Boss With a Mom-and-Pop Philosophy,'' June 16). My friends probably think otherwise, so I must rush straight to the market and buy generics to cement my image.

title: News Analysis
description: Monday's ruling by the United States Supreme Court that a Westchester County school district need not provide a deaf fourth grader with a sign-language interpreter in the classroom was a psychological blow to forces seeking to improve the education of handicapped youngsters. And it opens the possibility that some public schools may reduce their services to some handicapped children.

title: Japan Concerns Drop Print Ads
description: Two Japanese corporations implicated in a scheme to purchase computer secrets stolen from the International Business Machines Corporation said today that they had stopped print advertising because of their damaged reputations.

title: A Day to Recall
description: Yesterday was the 32d anniversary of the greatest triumph by the United States in international soccer, considered one of the biggest upsets in World Cup history. On June 29, 1950, the United States team, composed of men who played together only once before going to Argentina for the cup, upset England, 1-0.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. The Brewers came into this series with the American League's top two home-run hitters, Ben Oglivie, with 19 homers, and Gorman Thomas, who is tied with Cleveland's Andre Thornton at 18. Along With Cecil Cooper (14), the three Brewers had as many home runs as the Yankee team (51). (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal. The Mets had a chance last year to get Al Oliver from Texas, but the Rangers wanted some of their young pitchers. Oliver instead went to Montreal, where he is playing first base and hitting .314, his seventh straight season above .300. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M., tape. Radio - WMCA, 570; 7:05 P.M.) Boxing Petty Officer Third Class Mark Mahone and Private First Class Lucious Kirkley, top heavyweights in the Navy and Army, will meet in a threeround exhibition at City Hall, Park Row and Broadway at Chambers Street, 12:30 P.M. The event will include presentation of the first Joe Louis Memorial Scholarship Award to an athletically gifted city public school student by Martha Louis, widow of the late heavyweight champion.

title: A FAN AT THE GAME/John Leonard
description: W ouldn't it be grand if the old lady won the big one once again? If you don't agree, go someplace else. I have been a Billie Jean King fanatic since she first showed up, Little Miss Moffitt, at Wimbledon in 1961, all 5 feet 4 of her, and immediately attacked the net. Any such passionate identification is, of course, irrational. A map of a fan's emotions would have to be at least as complicated as a diagram of a synthetic carbon derivative. But consider these points:

title: TALKS ON FATE OF THE P.L.O. ARE SAID TO BE DEADLOCKED
description: Official Lebanese sources said today that the American special envoy, Philip C. Habib, told a European Ambassador that, although the Palestine Liberation Organization had accepted the principle of neutralizing its military presence in Lebanon and transferring its leadership elsewhere, ''there is a total block on how and when this should be done.''

title: DAZED REFUGEES DELUGE A GRACEFUL PARK IN BEIRUT
description: Think of Gramercy Park, that intimate enclave of green in Manhattan. Sanaye Park in the center of Beirut used to be very similar to it.

title: Canada Offers to Cut M.T.A. Credit Subsidy
description: Canada's Minister for International Trade, Edward Lumley, said today that his Government was willing to reduce the credit subsidy and raise the interest rate on a $662 million contract between New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority and a Montreal company to build 825 subway cars, provided the M.T.A. agreed.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Hoechst Corp. said its petrochemicals division had announced new price increases for styrene monomer, effective Aug. 1.

title: IGOR GOUZENKO, UNMASKED SPIES
description: Igor Gouzenko, a Soviet cipher clerk whose defection in 1945 helped to unmask Soviet efforts to crack Western atomic bomb secrets, has died, the police and his associates said today. He was 65 years old.

title: JUSTICES OVERTURN 'CHECK KITING' CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the writing of bad checks as part of a ''check kiting'' scheme does not violate Federal law.

title: 36 CHURCHES IN BROOKLYN PLAN TO BUILD 5,000 HOMES
description: A coalition of 36 Brooklyn churches announced plans yesterday to build 5,000 single-family town houses in blighted sections of Ocean Hill, Brownsville and East New York. The three areas are among several in Brooklyn that have experienced severe housing abandonment and devastation in the last decade.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * California Life Corp. said it had again extended its offer to purchase $16 million of its 11 percent sinking fund debentures at $45 for each $100 principal amount.

title: PRESBYTERIAN MERGER WITH SOUTHERN UNIT GAINS AT CONVENTION
description: The general assembly of the United Presbyterian Church voted overwhelmingly today in favor of plans for merging with the Presbyterian Church in the United States and healing a breach that goes back to the Civil War.

title: TV: A CLOSE LOOK AT PAROLE SYSTEM
description: JAY L. MCMULLEN is one of those longtime television correspondents who like to find out, in exhaustive detail, how things work. About once a year, the CBS News reporter-producer takes off with a camera crew and returns with a thorough, and usually thoroughly engrossing, documentary essay. He has covered everything from corporate executive corridors to drug trafficking. Tonight at 10 o'clock on CBS-TV, he looks at ''The Parole Game.''

title: U.S. AND SOVIET BEGIN TO DISCUSS STRATEGIC ARMS
description: Talks between the United States and the Soviet Union on reducing strategic nuclear weapons began today with the American delegation presenting a letter from President Reagan that appealed for a reversal of the trend toward increasingly unstable strategic relations between the two countries.

title: IN HARTFORD, CRIME ROBS A CATHEDRAL OF PEACE
description: It all began, the Rev. Denis Ferrigno recalls, on a Saturday near Christmas. Walking outside the Cathedral of St. Joseph, the seat of the Archdiocese of Hartford, on his way to celebrate 6:45 A.M. mass, Father Ferrigno noticed a door to the cathedral's school ajar. He remembers thinking, ''What dummy left that open?'' He walked closer and found that the door had been ripped off its hinges and left leaning against the portal.

title: 39 Hurt in Hong Kong Crash
description: Thirty-nine people were injured today when three streetcars traveling in the same direction collided, the police said. The cause of the collision was not immediately known.

title: 4 Receive Life Terms In Death of Mail Carrier
description: Four people, including two sisters, have been sentenced to life imprisonment in the slaying of a mail carrier who was kidnapped while on his route on the Salt River Indian Reservation.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: A group of aspiring young cooks visited my kitchen recently, and they asked about the basic techniques of naming dishes. I explained that if a dish contains olive oil, tomatoes, garlic, bay leaf and thyme, it might very well be named after regions such as Provence or the Riviera or towns and cities such as Antibes or Monte Carlo and so on, because those basic five ingredients are characteristic of Mediterranean locales. The addition of basil might indicate Italy, because basil is more often found in Italian cooking than French.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Long and Short Of the Donovan Report

title: Getty Wins Oil Permit
description: A petroleum exploration permit covering the Duntroon Basic west of Kangaroo Island of South Australia has been awarded to a group led by the Getty Oil Company, Energy Minister John Carrick said today. In addition to Getty, the group comprises Ampol Exploration Ltd., Natomas Petroleum International Inc. and Sovereign Oil Australia Ltd. Mr. Carrick said the group's rights to the area would last for six years and that it would spend the equivalent of $40.7 million drilling at least four wells.

title: EUROPEAN LEADERS URGE A BEIRUT PULLOUT
description: Leaders of the 10 Common Market countries called today for a simultaneous withdrawal of Israeli and Palestinian military forces from Beirut.

title: Advertising; Magazines Aid Office Equipment
description: THE nation's magazines may be troubled by a few soft advertising categories, but office equipment is not one of them. Business is booming in that field as white-collar work space leaps into the future.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Charles Atlas, born Angelo Siciliano of Brooklyn, the Horatio Alger of the human body, has been dead for a decade now. Charles P. Roman keeps alive his legend. It has always been so.

title: CANADA'S NEW BUDGET ASSAILED
description: An attempt by Canada's Liberal Government to halt both high inflation and a deep recession through budget measures was met with hostility today in the stock market, in foreign exchange markets and among labor leaders.

title: Beckenbauer Back?
description: Franz Beckenbauer, the former captain of the West German national team who retired this spring, said in Madrid that he was negotiating to return to the Cosmos of the North American Soccer League, the team for which he played for almost four seasons.

title: How to Clear a Cabinet Officer
description: A special prosecutor has lifted the vapor of criminal charges from Secretary of Labor Raymond Donovan and in the process handsomely vindicated the Ethics in Government Act. Prosecutor Leon Silverman's finding that there is no credible evidence of criminality will not end the Secretary's political problems, nor add to his qualifications for office, but it goes surprisingly beyond merely sparing him an indictment.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Significant Events,' M.T.A. Style

title: C-E Lummus Contract
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. said today that its C-E Lummus unit had been awarded a contract by the Saudi Yanbu Petrochemical Company to provide a process simulator for a new petrochemical complex at Yanbu, Saudi Arabia.

title: Inquiry in Belushi Death Is Reopened on Coast
description: The Los Angeles police today reopened their investigation into the drug death of the entertainer John Belushi.

title: U.S. URGES ISRAELIS TO MAINTAIN TRUCE
description: The United States appealed to Israel today to allow time for Philip C. Habib, the special Middle East envoy, to work out a political arrangement in Beirut that would lead to the end of the Palestinian military presence there.

title: Help on the Way
description: With drug abuse by some football players now accepted as harsh reality, professional clubs know that a defense to the problem will not be found in their playbooks. In Houston, the Oilers are about to hire a physician or psychiatrist to counsel players who have drug problems.

title: The U.N. Today; June 30, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Subcommittee on Petitions - 10:30 A.M.

title: Alice Riley Misho Is Bride
description: Alice Riley Misho, a realtor associate with Village Realty in Winter Park, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to Henry Tunny, vice president in charge of operations, engineering and marketing for the Florida Group of the United Telephone System in Altamonte Springs. The Rev. Dr. David Randolph performed the ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist. Previous marriages for the bride, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank Riley of Boston, and the bridegroom, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Joseph Tunny of New York, ended in divorce.

title: 1,000 ARRESTED IN A SWEEP OF MANHATTAN SUBWAYS
description: More than 1,000 people were arrested yesterday in the second oneday sweep in a month by New York City's transit police to combat crime in the subway system. The arrests were for offenses ranging from turnstile jumping to weapons possession.

title: SONG: FRANK PATTERSON, TENOR
description: IT'S rare these days to encounter top-flight classical vocalism in a nightclub, but that is precisely what is being offered through Saturday at Tommy Makem's Irish Pavilion, 130 East 57th Street, where Frank Patterson is holding forth for two sets a night. Mr. Patterson bills himself not without justification as ''Ireland's greatest tenor,'' the heir to the John McCormack legacy. He has made numerous records of concert repertory (no opera, for some reason), and his recordings of the McCormack light-classical and sentimental-ballad repertory sell handsomely in Ireland.

title: Fly a Kite
description: Of course flags will fly on July 4. But more fun than hanging a flag is sending a patriotic-looking kite skyward. A wonderful kite to take to Central Park or the beach on the Fourth is an enormous one, with a wing spread of 13 feet (See page C1.) It's made of nylon that's not easily torn, and it is striped and starred in red, white and blue. You'll find it at Go Fly A Kite, 1201 Lexington Avenue (81st Street) for $72. 1. Shielding Candlelight It's pleasant to dine on a terrace or in a garden by the flicker of candlelight - that is, until a stiff breeze blows out the candle. Solution: a lantern to protect the flame and add a subtle light. The Pine Ridge Pottery of Canaan, N.Y., has made some good-looking handthrown lanterns in beige speckled glaze with blue-green bands. The tops are beehive shaped and pierced so the light is attractively diffused. The Candle Shop at 118 Christopher Street has the lanterns, priced at $18 for a five-inch model and $30 for the seven-inch.

title: Chapin Heads Board Of Symphony League
description: The American Symphony Orchestra League has elected Schuyler G. Chapin chairman and Peter R. Kermani president of its board of directors.

title: Israeli Envoy Remains In a Coma in London
description: The condition of Shlomo Argov, the Israeli Ambassador to Britain, has improved slightly but he remains in a coma 26 days after he was shot in the head during an attempted assassination, the Israeli Embassy reported today.

title: OUT-OF-STATE HOLDINGS BY BANKS CONCERN FED
description: The Federal Reserve Board indicated strong opposition yesterday to the acquisition by a banking company of nonvoting shares in an outof-state bank.

title: Transactions
description: MONDAY BASEBALL

title: WHO'S NOW IN CHARGE?
description: You don't have to be a great admirer of Al Haig to recognize that he was virtually insulted out of the State Department. In some ways he asked for it, and maybe he should have been fired or never hired, but the way they got rid of him was a shabby performance.

title: VOTING RIGHTS ACT SIGNED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan today signed into law an extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 in an East Room ceremony witnessed by many critics of Mr. Reagan's record in race relations and civil rights.

title: LEGISLATORS AGREE TO EXTEND A CONTROVERSIAL PENSION PLAN
description: Over the objections of municipal unions, legislative leaders agreed today to extend for a year without change a pension plan covering 300,000 state and muncipal employees.

title: Group Fights Bell Breakup
description: The National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners told United States District Judge Harold H. Greene today that the proposed breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company would lead to higher telephone rates and thwart the goal of providing telephone service for everyone.

title: A 'PRAGMATIC' BANKER FOR AMRO IN NEW YORK
description: The Amsterdam-Rotterdam Bank formally opened a New York branch yesterday at 500 Park Avenue. Its general manager is Johann H. Brinckmann, 50.

title: METS DEFEAT EXPOS
description: After designing a left-handed hitting lineup to combat the right-handed pitching of Steve Rogers, Manager George Bamberger watched his Mets break a five-game losing streak with a 5-4 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: WITNESS IDENTIFIES TWO DEFENDANTS AS GUNMEN IN SHOOTING OF OFFICERS
description: A cook in a social club took the stand in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday and pointed to two reputed members of the Black Liberation Army -Anthony N. LaBorde and James Dixon York - saying they were the gunmen he saw attack two police officers last year. ''I had a clear view,'' the witness said.

title: Swiss Banks Tighten Rules
description: Switzerland's banks today tightened rules intended to prevent abuses of the country's banking secrecy law, such as the illegal flight of capital, tax evasion and the ''laundering'' of criminal funds.

title: LEBANON: ESTABLISHING VICTIMS AND AGGRESSORS
description: To the Editor:

title: STORM IN JERSEY LASHES RETIREMENT COMMUNITY
description: A sudden storm with fierce winds, possibly including a tornado, lashed a retirement community on the central New Jersey coast last night, wrecking some homes, damaging others, uprooting trees and overturning cars. Authorities said no serious injuries were reported.

title: NEW-HOME SALES UP, BUT LOW
description: Sales of new single-family homes rose 13.3 percent in May, reversing the plunge of the previous month, the Government said today.

title: '78 PACT SAID TO LIMIT ISRAELI USE OF CLUSTER BOMBS
description: Some United States officials said today that Israel had agreed in 1978 not to use American-made cluster bomb units except in combat with two or more ''Arab states'' and that Israel's admitted use of the weapons in recent fighting with Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization might constitute a violation of the agreement.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GARDENING

title: CAREY AND LEGISLATORS CLASH OVER PRISON CONVERSION PLAN
description: Governor Carey and the Legislature clashed sharply today over Mr. Carey's plan to convert mental health facilities into prisons.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 30, 1982
description: International A face-saving offer to the P.L.O. was announced by Prime Minister Menachem Begin in an address to the Israeli Parliament. Declaring that Israel had no desire to humiliate the Palestinian guerrillas, he said they could leave Beirut with their personal weapons. Just two days earlier, Israel's Cabinet insisted that the arms be surrendered to the Lebanese Army. (Page A1, Column 6.) A deadlock was reported in the talks for neutralizing the military presence of the Palestinians in Lebanon. The special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, was quoted as saying, ''there is a total block on how and when this should be done.'' (A10:1-2.)

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A.I.A.W. DISCONTINUED
description: The Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women, which competed with the National Collegiate Athletic Association for control of women's athletics, will discontinue operations Wednesday.

title: ISRAELIS SAY P.L.O. CAN LEAVE BEIRUT CARRYING WEAPONS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin offered today to let Palestinian guerrillas leave Beirut with their personal weapons. He said Israel had no desire to humiliate them, but merely to see them out of the Lebanese capital.

title: Picking Up Speed
description: Mark Fidyrch moved a little closer to the form that made him a pitching sensation for the Detroit Tigers six years ago.

title: WINE TALK
description: Dowell Cellars, California's first solar-powered winery.

title: 6 Journalists Reported Safe After a Battle in El Salvador
description: A military spokesman said six journalists were found ''safe and sound'' today, a day after they disappeared near the scene of a clash north of the capital between guerrillas and troops.

title: LEGISLATIVE LEADERS VOW TO CLOSE ANY GAP IN M.T.A. TAX PACKAGE
description: Legislative leaders pledged today to make up any shortfall in revenue from a package of taxes it passed last year to assist the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: PORTABLE FOOD SMOKER
description: A couple of years ago I built an extremely efficient plywood smoker from scratch. It has been used successfully for all kinds of meat, game and fish, from the quick smoking of eel to the prolonged smoking of a ham.

title: DYSON BELIVED QUITTING RACE
description: John S. Dyson, the chairman of the State Power Authority, will drop out of the race for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor, the Manhattan Democratic County chairman and persons close to Mr. Dyson said today.

title: YUGOSLAV PARTY VOWS TO FOLLOW TITO'S COURSE
description: Yugoslavia's ruling Communists closed their 12th party congress today with a pledge to follow the basic independent policies of Marshal Tito but with a call for more action and greater responsibility at all levels.

title: 3 BRITISH REPORTERS RELEASED FROM JAIL BY ARGENTINE JUNTA
description: Three British journalists who were arrested April 13 in southern Argentina on espionage charges during the war with Britain over the Falkland Islands were set free on bail Monday and allowed to leave the country today.

title: WOOLWORTH AND ASARCO WIN CASES
description: The Supreme Court today expanded on its recent decisions on the right of states to tax multinational corporations. In two opinions likely to generate more lawsuits in state courts, the Court indicated that it would take a case-by-case approach to the question of taxing multinational corporations, giving attention to assertions of those companies that certain subsidiaries are not part of their ''unitary businesses.''

title: London Subway Strike Set to End Today
description: Striking workers on London's subway system decided today to return to work Wednesday, but a second rail union voted to begin another indefinite nationwide strike against British Rail on Sunday.

title: GOOD OLD WALDIE'S
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: It is refreshing to read about a modern supermarket chain that is as humble and ''hamishe'' as Brooklyn institutions tend to be. I've been a fan of Waldie's, as it is affectionately called in my household, for about 15 years.

title: Dart in Pact for Wickes Units
description: The Wickes Companies and Dart & Kraft Inc. have reached an agreement in principle for the acquisition by Dart of two Wickes leasing units. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CHIEF HEADS CHROMALLOY
description: A few men are chief executives of more than one major company. Now Norman E. Alexander is one of them. He is chairman and chief executive officer of the Sun Chemical Corporation of New York. He is also chairman of the Chromalloy American Corporation of St. Louis. Sun owns 37 percent of Chromalloy's common stock. Mr. Alexander, 67 years old, was named yesterday to the additional post of chief executive officer at Chromalloy.

title: NEW SAVINGS CERTIFICATE APPROVED BY REGULATORS
description: In an effort to help savings institutions and banks better compete with money market mutual funds, Federal regulators approved the issue of a short-term certificate on which the interest rate would be tied to the yield on three-month Treasury bills.

title: NUNS' KIN SUING IN SALVADOR SLAYINGS
description: In the 18 months since three American nuns and a missionary worker were murdered in El Salvador, their families say they have implored the Reagan Administration through every avenue of bureaucratic paperwork and personal plea to obtain concrete information on what the Government knows about the crime.

title: 257 POLES ARE ARRESTED AT A SOLIDARITY CEREMONY
description: The Polish police said today that they arrested 257 people in the southwestern town of Wroclaw on Monday after a crowd of several thousand workers tried to lay a wreath at a plaque commemorating the founding of the local chapter of the banned Solidarity union.

title: Thrift Units Plan Merger
description: Two black-owned savings institutions in New York City, the Carver Federal Savings and Loan and the Allied Federal Savings and Loan, said yesterday that they had agreed to a merger that would create the nation's second-largest black-owned savings institution, with combined assets of $103.4 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A NOW Contender

title: Dow Manages Fractional Gain
description: Stock prices finished yesterday on an even keel with the key averages showing only minimal changes. The Dow Jones industrial average, down by nearly 3 points at 3:30 P.M., closed at 812.21, up 0.28. Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the New York Stock Exchange's composite index each registered slight declines.

title: TOP COURT RULES PROOF OF JOB BIAS INTENT IS NEEDED
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that proof of intentional discrimination is needed to establish a violation of an important Federal civil rights law. The 7-to-2 decision also held that an employer cannot ordinarily be found liable for the discriminatory practices of a labor union with which the employer cooperates in a hiring hall system and apprenticeship program.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies of Metropolitan Report Monday about a private airplane that plunged into Long Island Sound incorrectly identified the two victims. They were the pilot, Temple Cann, 31 years old, and Geoffrey Davis, 24, of Yonkers. They were the only occupants.

title: 7 of Dozier's Rescuers Accused of Brutality
description: Seven policemen who were part of the team that rescued Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier from Red Brigades kidnappers have been arrested on charges of mistreating their prisoners, the police said today.

title: Soviet Hunger Striker Is Told He Will Be Given an Exit Visa
description: A Soviet artist who fasted for 37 days for the right to go to West Germany to be with his wife and son was told today that he would be given an exit visa.

title: HEY! THAT CLOCK IS WRONG
description: Wait a second! Because the earth seems to be getting tired. Because the International Committee of Weights and Measures, in October 1956, defined the ephemeris second, an astronomy unit reckoned independently of the earth's rotation, as one-31,556,925.9747th of the time it took for the earth to complete its path around the sun beginning at noon on January 1, 1900.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As the two leading nuclear powers in the world, the United States and the Soviet Union are trustees for humanity in the great task of ending the menace of nuclear arsenals and transforming them into instruments underwriting peace.'' - President Reagan in a letter to Edward L. Rowny, the chief American negotiator in talks on reducing strategic nuclear weapons. (A1:2.)

title: MRS. KING, MRS LLOYD GAIN QUARTERFINAL
description: For a while today, Martina Navratilova, Chris Evert Lloyd, Andrea Jaeger, Pam Shriver, Sylvia Hanika and Wendy Turnbull seemed headed for a collective fall in the fourth round of the Wimbledon tennis championships.

title: GENTLE JABS MARK HAIG'S FAREWELL
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. said he wanted to dispel gossip that the Reagan Administration was becoming pro-Arab. ''I only today had to quell the rumor,'' he deadpanned, ''that Cap Weinberger had closed the Pentagon cafeteria for Ramadan.'' And that's the way it went, a bit of humor mixed with nostalgia, at a State Department party given Monday night by the departing Secretary of State for about 200 senior aides and their spouses.

title: Patricia Blake Is Married In Texas to Ronni Dugger
description: Patricia Blake, an associate editor of Time magazine, was married yes-terday in San Antonio to Ronni Dugger, editor and publisher of The Texas Observer. United States District Court Judge Woodrow Seals of Houston performed the ceremony at the Los Patios restaurant.

title: RECIPES FROM HOME TO MARKET
description: Most good home cooks have been told at one time or another that their pepper jelly or zucchini pickles or raspberry tarts are as good as anything on the market. Why not try to sell them? friends and family suggest. Others have done it; some, like Wally Amos of Famous Amos, who started baking cookies for friends, are making millions. But there's more to it than buying more ingredients or a larger pot before the product is on the shelves of fancy-food shops.

title: FAULTY INSTRUMENT BLAMED FOR '78 AIR INDIA CRASH
description: Design defects in a key cockpit instrument helped cause a Boeing 747 crash in India in 1978, a lawyer for more than 160 of the 213 persons killed in the crash said today.

title: U.S. BALKS AND SETS APPEAL
description: A Federal district judge ordered the United States today to parole most detained Haitian refugees, but the Justice Department said it would appeal the decision and seek a stay of the order.

title: D.& H.'s Sale Is Opposed
description: The proposed sale of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad to Guilford Transportation Industries would destroy rail competition in the Northeast, competing railroads told the Interstate Commerce Commission today.
